On the West Coast of the South Island, taipo', or what is supposed to be the English translation of that word,bush devil', is the name generally given to the common tree weta, Hemideina megacephala. Weta' is the real Maori name for this and related species of large, long-horned wingless grasshoppers;taipo' is a word of unknown origin and obscure meaning. (Nov 8, 1957,Christchurch Star-Sun) [NOTES: (I.W.T. Munro) could be Nov. 8 or 9]

On the West Coast of the South Island, taipo', or what is supposed to be the English translation of that word,bush devil', is the name generally given to the common tree weta, Hemideina megacephala. Weta' is the real Maori name for this and related species of large, long-horned wingless grasshoppers;taipo' is a word of unknown origin and obscure meaning. (Nov 8, 1957,Christchurch Star-Sun) [NOTES: (I.W.T. Munro) could be p. 8 or 9]

PASCOE Charlie always admitted that he hated, almost to the point of fear, two things: taipos (wetas) which he spells `typos', and those dark brown bush creeks the bottom of which is hard to see. (1957,Mr Explorer Douglas,xii) [NOTES: [reference West Coast] 1957 A.P. Harper in Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas xii]

McLINTOCK The former [family Henicidae] includes the tree or ground wetas and the taipos' of the West Coast of the South Island, the name of which to the Maori meansthe devil who comes by night'. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/636)

4 n. a train

COWAN Now the white man was coming and presently his iron rail and his steam `taepo' would lay the trail that was to conquer ... the mana of the Maori. (1916,Bush Explorers,2)

5 n. esp. (?West Coast) a name for a (?dangerous) river (see also 1957 citation in 3. below: and get Haast etc. citations)

At Taipo, at Tata, at Takaka, at Aurere, at all points, in fact, of this extensive district, coal is known to abound, and by cropping out, as it does in several seams, at West Wanganui, or on the other western side of the coast, there can be scarcely a doubt but that the whole of that part of the island is a vast coal-field. (May 25, 1850,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,50)

The extent of flat land is considerable, chiefly wooded, and these districts are opened up for a short distance by their respective rivers; limestone is to be obtained in any quantity; coal at the Taipo, and Tata, at the Motupipi, and the Takaka. (Sep 27, 1842,New Zealand Colonist & Port Nicholson Advertiser,2)

A grass grown hill immediately behind Jackson's, not far west of the Otira mouth is Rangi Taepo (goblin sky), generally wrongly spelt Taipo. (Jun 17, 1908,Grey River Argus,1)

The following tenders have been received for the Taipo Bridge contract, Hokitika Christchurch road ... (May 13, 1885,West Coast Times,2)

MONEY (West Coast) We afterwards learnt that the Maories had named this river [flowing into the Teremakau, Westland] `Typoo', which means the devil, and there certainly was a spice of devilry about its raging waters that suggested bad spirits in a perpetual state of frenzied agony (1871,Knocking About in NZ,49)

HAAST ... though the Taipo was still high, we were enabled to ascend along its banks ... (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,116)

MORRIS (1898,Austral English)

ROBERTS Mr Wyatt was shepherd on the Taipo run, and lived with his wife ... in the Taipo whare, near to where Teschemaker's railway siding is now. (1914,History of North Otago,26,1978 ed.) [NOTES: 1906 W.H.S.Roberts in 1914 History of North Otago (1978) 26]

GUTHRIE-SMITH This crossing [of the Papakiri] has always been known in my time as the `Taipo' - goblin-crossing, a name probably given because of a totara block which used to lie there hewn roughly to the similitude of a man's head. (1926,Tutira,91)

BEATTIE One of the shepherds ... lived in a hut at Taipo [Central Otago]. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,152)

VON HAAST [On the Midland Railway to West Coast] ... numerous bridges were erected, the most remarkable of which was the bridge over the legendary Taipo [a branch of the Taramakau], in which many a tall fellow found his doom. (1948,Julius Von Haast,437)

5 n. in exasperation, or humorous endearment, applied as an epithet, nickname, term of address, etc. (possibly shift 1 above here) [ca1935 J. Morison (Havelock)e.g. You little taipo, come here!]

DEVANNY Oh Mary, don't be a taipo. (1930,Bushman Burke,300) [NOTES: [West Coast reference]]

5 n. a children's nickname, or abusive epithet, for an unattractive Maori [ca1935 Havelock Mungamunga taipo (or `tarpot'), probably from mangamanga. black. [Note that [wi:rou] also used in a similar context at that time and place: ?Maori whiro 1. evil, bad 2. the proper name of a malevolent atua, personification of evil, and of darkness and of death.]]

BAKER We ... use the doggerel Maori mungimungitaipo! as a ferocious expression. Taipo, it may be added, was noted by Morris as applied to `a surveyor's theodolite because it is a land-stealing devil,' ... (1941,NZ Slang,56)

PARK ...shaking showers of white quince blossom down upon herself, she yelled, `Maunga manga taipo!' at Mauri in an unreasoning, provocative impudence, but he did not mind being called a black devil and cuffed good-naturedly at her head with a big brown paw. (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,127)

... the happiest days of our lives. Young white gods yelling mangumangu taipo! without knowing what it meant, only that it was something to be yelled at the Maori kids in the swamps on Sunday afternoon. Mangumangu taipo, nigger-man devils! And it didn't much matter that you yourself weren't a Maori, ... (Jul 1954,Numbers,1/4) [NOTES: (Mincher)]

5 n. ?from a rough temper, or ? a rough frightening exterior; or merely as a bushman, humorously from taipo, the tree weta. Possibly, however, whero (i) or (ii), but not likely)

DEVANNY [West Coast reference] ... nicknamed Taipo Burke. (1930,Bushman Burke,12)

5 n. usually from the primary Maori sense devil; ghost' figuratively used, or transferred toa fearsome person or thing' (e.g., a weta); thence in various weakened uses, as a nickname (possibly an `Old Nick' name) mainly for animals, in familiar address to (usually naughty) children pron [|taipou] spg occasionally typo

MORRIS Taipo, for instance, of course on knows its meaning, though it has been adopted chiefly as a name as common a Dash' orNero' for New Zealand dogs. ... Often applied by settlers to a vicious horse. (1898,Austral English)

taipo n. the devil; a vicious dog or horse; sl. the theodolite of the surveyor, because it is thought to rob the natives of their land. [Maori tae, come, and po, night=a spectre of the darkness] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,11)

FINLAYSON `Now for the old girls,' he says, and Taipo yaps with joy. Uncle Ted heads for the cow paddock ... (1948,Tidal Creek,28,1979 ed.)

McGILL Don't mind Taipo', she said as she ushered me in. I froze. ...What the devil is it?' She chuckled. A Beardie'.Does it bite?' ... [123] I had said it before. Taipo meant devil, or goblin. He was some kind of distant cousin of an Old English Sheepdog. (1985,G'day Country,122)

McGILL taipo dark dog; kiwi colloquialism from mid-C19 and extant (Ref. guard dog at Fyffe House, Kaikoura); or a vicious horse. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,111)

6 n. [ca1956 W.J. Orsman popular New Zealand name for the game of Bagatelle. ; a NZ made table game (1930s-40s)using ball bearings and enclosures marked out with steel pins (DEH]

taipo-master¶

n.

An old Maori chief... approached Mr Crawford [sc. an engineer] with great reverence, saying "You taipo-master?" meaning thereby to ascertain whether Mr. Crawford could work and control the machinery. (Oct 28, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

Tairoa trousers¶

n. [Probably misspelling of Tairua on the Coromandel. More likely than Taiaroa on the Otago heads or a non-existent Tairoa, especially since it was apparently a prime gold-mining site.]

2 pairs Drill or Tairoa Trousers (state size). (Nov 11, 1893,Northern Advocate,4)

Tairoas.. are a sort of white drill trousers affected by outdoor workers in summer time. (Oct 10, 1917,Te Aroha Times,2)

OWEN & PERKINS The customary dress was the old Blucher boots... and Tairoa trousers, which were made of a kind of heavy white duck; these were tied with bowyangs below the knees. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,155)

Taitai¶

n. (pron) early pron. of Taita

SCANLAN Now they were passing the little cemetery at Taitai ... (1934,Winds of Heaven,43)

taiwharu¶

n. kokopu

PHILLIPPS Galaxias brevipinnis Guenther. GUDGEON; TAIWHARU or KOKOPU. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,13,1971 ed.)

Galaxias brevipinnis: [European Name] `Gudgeon' [Maori Name] Taiwharu or kokopu. (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,73) [NOTES: 1936 Handbook for NZ (ANZAAS Conf. Jan. 1937) 73]

PHILLIPPS GUDGEON Galaxias brevipinnis Gunther ... This is the taiwharu of North Auckland and the kokopu of the Arawa tribe who also call the young (together with the young of Retropinna retropinna) inanga in Lakes Rotorua, Rotoiti and Taupo. (1940,Fishes NZ,21)

taiwhenua¶

n. [ORIGIN: Maori, = land, district (P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 233)]

As you'll know, due to the collapse of the Wairarapa Taiwhenua - we haven't had an umbrella organisation representing Ngati Kahungunu. (Jul 26, 2005,Wairarapa Midweek,32)

Taj Mahal¶

n. a men's convenience in Courtenay Place, Wellington, later converted to restaurant and later again to a bar, often abbrev. to TAJ, pron [ta:d3] [ca1941 at least [LOST IDENTITY] ?66-67 Never mind that ... it earned the title of the Taj Mahal of Amnesty Cove only from those people who had really [67] been caught short there.]

A recent example of such a demonstration was the attempt by a number of students to drink the Taj Mahal dry. (1966,Cappicade,9)

the Taj Mahal: Wellington public toilet (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

LAY And when she rode past the propositions and obscenities would have covered the walls of the Taj Mahal. (1988,Fools on the Hill, The,85)

The bar sits on an island between Kent and Cambridge Terraces, in a building still affectionately known to many Wellingtonians as "Taj Mahal". (Nov 2, 2000,City Voice,16)

takahe¶

n.

n. (Environment) also called notornis a rare, flightless, native bird. [Maori takahe[e-macron]] [[Ma. takahē (Notornis Mantelli), flightless gallinule] cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 233.]

Maud the mauled takahe is on the way back .. Takahe are territorial and trouble for Maude started when her partner Albert died. (Apr 3, 2000,Evening Post,14)

The skull of a notornis, or takahe, a native bird which has not been seen since the end of last century, has been found at Whakaputu, by the director of the Southland Museum, Mr. J. H. Sorenson. (Nov 16, 1938,Evening Post,20)

The takahe .. is a true grassland bird, plucking tussock tillers and seeds for food and laying eggs in a raised bowl of grasses under the shelter of tussock leaves. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/47)

'A very large step for the takahe,' (for they have very big feet), "a giant leap for conservation." (1991,NZ Geographic,10)

This bird was called Takahe, and was of a black colour, destitute of wings, and had a long bill, which, as well as the legs, was of a bright red colour. (Jul 23, 1851,New Zealander, The,4)

A nearly complete skeleton of the famous takahe was found a few years ago not far from here [sc. Lake Te Anau). (Mar 6, 1890,Otago Witness,35)

A nearly complete skeleton of the famous takahe was found a few years ago not far from here [sc. Lake Te Anau). (Mar 6, 1890,Otago Witness,35)

THOMSON The Takahe (Notornis Mantelli), a bird about the size of a turkey, with imperfect wings, was discovered in Dusky Bay, in the Middle Island, in 1850, by sealers. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/27)

BULLER NOTORNIS MANTELLI. (MANTELL'S NOTORNIS.) .. Native names. Moho, Takahe, and Tokohea. [191] Mr. Walter Mantell states that .. It was known to the North-Islanders by the name of Moho', and to the South-Islanders by that ofTakahe'. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,189, 191,{1888 2nd edn 2/85} ed.)

HAAST However, nothing was known of the exact habitat of the Takahe, (Notornis) till .. Grey .. obtained the information. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,449)

I was informed .. that the skeleton of a Takahe had been found .. near lake Te Anau .. As is well known, the only recent remains of Notornis hitherto obtained are the two stuffed specimens in the British Museum ... (1886,TrNZI,18/78)

Notornis mantelli. - Takahe; Moho. Resolution and Secretary Islands; and at Barepatch, between Maruia and Upokororo Rivers, east of Lake Te Anau. (1886,TrNZI,18/113) [NOTES: (Martin)]

By a strange ... coincidence, the first two specimens of the Notornis, or takahe as it was called in the South island, were secured ... (1889,TrNZI,21/226)

PARKER The Takahe is the rarest of existing native birds, if indeed it is not already extinct. (1889,Catalogue NZ Exhibition,116) [NOTES: (Morris)]

MORRIS Takahe, n. Maori name for an extinct New Zealand Rail, Notoris mantelli, Owen. See Notornis. (1898,Austral English,455)

Notornis hochstetteri Meyer. Takahe. One of these birds was reported to have been seen in full view on a track near Lake Te Anau so recently as 1914. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/81) [NOTES: Myers Endemic Birds]

takahe, a bird (Notornis hochstetteri), first found as a fossil (N. mantelli) by W. B. D. Mantell: found alive only six times in over 100 years, and confined to the rugged south-west corner of the South Island. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/150) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

POWELL The Takahe (Notornis hochstetteri), long believed extinct ... (1947,Native Animals of NZ,82)

takahe: extinct bird (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

The Maori name for a large kind of bird of the rail family (notornis) were found again in 1948 by a party led by Dr Orbell in the Lake Te Anau district. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),404)

SINCLAIR takahe Small flightless bird (Notornis hochstetteri) (1959,History of New Zealand,302)

MASTERS On being informed the prisoner had been killed, Tai Kawa said the Ngatimomoe would be banished into [293] the haunts of the Takahe and would only be safe in the depths of the forest. (1960,Back-Country Tales,291)

takahe n -s [Maori] : NOTORNIS 2 (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2329)

DURRELL (1966,Two in the Bush,103)

FALLA et al. TAKAHE Notornis mantelli Other name: Moho. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,109)

McLINTOCK takahe (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

takahe n. see notornis (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

168 (1966,English as it is spoken in NZ)

NATUSCH The takahe, as every New Zealand schoolboy knows, was thought to be extinct, until Notornis mantelli, rediscovered in 1948 to the west of Te Anau .. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,268)

takahe .. n. See notornis. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

138. Notornis mantelli Owen, 1848 Notornis (Takahe) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,43,1980 ed.)

takahe n. a rare flightless New Zealand rail. Also called: notornis. [< Maori] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,119) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 782; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 490]]

Takahe Notornis mantelli OWEN, 1848 .. OTHER NAMES: Moho, pass bird. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,170)

My first note refers to the Notornis mantelli, the rara avis called by the Maoris the takahea'.</i> The name of this bird is spelled <i>takahe' in Buller's `Birds' ... The Maoris inform me that this is wrong; there should be a final a, as I have spelt it here. (1906,TrNZI,38/337)

first appears in 1917 5th edn 428 (MOHO 1. a bird. appears in 3rd 1871, 85, and 4th 1892, 99) Takahee (ii), takahea|, n. Notornis hochstetteri; a large and rare species of rail. = moho. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,428) [NOTES: 1954Williams[1957/434 ... a large and rare flightless bird closely related to the pukeko.]]

There are just 260 surviving takahe left in the world. (Jun 15, 2006,NZ Herald,A8)

We watched nectar-eating stitchbirds visiting wayside feeders, a tui taking a bath and a shy takahe fossicking in long grass. (Sep 26, 2004,Sunday Magazine (Auckland),38)

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] a New Zealand-bred cultivar of wheat.

Tiritea grains are compared with takahe. In trials in Southland, the new wheat cultivar yielded 6.25 tonnes per hectare, which was more than 7 percent more than what Takahe yielded. (May 1982,NZ Journal of Agriculture,23)

takahe man¶

n. ?an old-timer, one who prefers the old ways

MARSHALL Beneath the new order the takahe men still lived on, diminishing in quiet, unfettered contempt, unaware that they were no longer typical. Ibid. 20 Passion and prejudice were strong among the takahe men: reticence an unconscious disguise. (1984,Day Hemingway Died, The,16)

takahea¶

n. variant rather than a spg of takahe

COWAN These men in their young days made periodical [122] expeditions up into the lakes region, hunting for the weka ..., the kakapo or ground parrot, kiwi, and the rare and elusive takahea, the blue-plumaged notornis which is now believed to be extinct. 133 [caption] The takahea or Notornis Hochstetteri ... (1926,Travel in NZ,(Vol II South Island) 121)

takahi¶

v.

COWAN No doubt they would have been discovered had the Arawa from Rotorua takahi'd, or trodden down, the fern, as was the practice in cases of the kind, but [they] carefully refrained from doing so, knowing doubtless that some of their unfortunate kinsmen lay trembling there. (1922,Travel in NZ,2/170,1983 ed.)

takahikahi¶

n.

LEE & KENDALL Tak|ahi k|ahi; A bird so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,206)

YATE The Takahikahi is nearly of the same size as the Tuturiwatu ... It differs ... in its plumage, and in its general habits. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),66)

DIFFENBACH 47. Charadrius xanthocheilus. Wagl. ... Tuturiwhatu of the natives. Miss Stone.Takahikaki[check?] of the natives. Yate. Tuturuata of the natives of Cook's Straits. Dieffenbach. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/`195)

takahikaremoana¶

n. storm petrel

FALLA et al. WHITE-FACED STORM PETREL Pelagodroma marina Other names: Takahikare-moana, Skipjack, Jesus Christ Bird (shortened to `J.C. Bird'). (1966,Birds of New Zealand,55)

SALE ... [The storm petrel] has many other names - skipjack, Dancing Dolly, frigate petrel - from the Pakeha; and takahikaremoana from the Maori. (1982,Four Seasons,38)

Takaka marble¶

n.

The turn-of-the-century Edwardian villa.. and Parliament Buildings have something in common - the same Takaka marble graces both. This link comes from one of the house's previous owners, Leonard Mills, who was a partner in.. the contracting firm that built Parliament Buildings using kairuru marble from its Tasman Bay quarry. (Apr 10, 1999,Dominion,28)

takakau¶

n. flat unleavened bread

He used to help his parents, who were staunch Ratana followers, to gather kumara, bake fried bread and takakau (a flat, unleavened bread) to sell and raise funds for Labour. (Jun 1996,Mana,No.13: 25)

HILLIARD SOME MAORI WORDS ... takakau hard bread (`wagon-wheels') (1963,Piece of Land, A,192)

HILLIARD Knives and forks were passed around [by the Maori family], and a plate of buttered takakau. (1969,Green River,29)

HILLIARD ... the remains of a meal: mussel shells, bones of fish-heads sucked clean, pork bones, stalks of watercress, and a few crusts of takakau. (1976,Send Somebody Nice,154)

HILLIARD Takakau, also called WAGON WHEELS a flour-and-water dough, no leaven, rolled out flat and baked in the oven; a sort of oven-damper. A good maori dish to feed a crowd. (Sep 1988,Personal Communication)

takapu¶

n. gannet Morus serrator

DYSPORUS SERRATOR. - Gannet (Takapu). (1886,TrNZI,18/99) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

LEE & KENDALL T|akapu, s. A bird so called; (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,206)

COLENSO ... several fine Gannets (Sula, sp.) ... [the natives] call it Takupu. (1844,Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ) [NOTES: 1844 Colenso Excursion Northern Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 54]

Sula serrator. Takapu. Breeds on Mahuke Island. (1869,TrNZI,1/161) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

HUTTON 146. DYSPORUS SERRATOR. Banks. Gannet. Takapu. Sula capensis. LICHT. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,49)

BULLER SULA {DYSPORUS} SERRATOR. (AUSTRALIAN GANNET.) ... Native names.- Takapu, Takupu, and Toroa-haoika. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/177)

MORRIS Maori name for the bird Dysporus serrator, Banks, a Gannet (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,455)

BAUGHAN Takapu (tah-kah-poo): The gannet. (1908,Shingle-Short,186)

Takapu n. the common gannet. [Maori] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,11)

takapu, a bird (Moris serrator), gannet. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

POWELL GANNET (Morus serrator), Takapu of the Maoris, is common around the coasts of the North Island. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,79)

FALLA et al. AUSTRALIAN GANNET Sula serrator Local name: Takapu. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,60)

takapu ... n. in N.Z., a gannet [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

76. Sula bassana serrator Gray, 1843 Austral[as]ian Gannet (Takapu) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,31,1980 ed.)

Australasian Gannet Sula bassana serrator GRAY, 1843 ... OTHER NAMES: Takapu, Australian gannet, solan goose. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,110)

takapu n. NZ name for an Australian variety of gannet. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,782) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

Takapuna oyster soup¶

n.

TAKAPUNA OYSTER SOUP ... milk ... onion ... pepper ... fry ... flour ... Allow the whole to boil ... Put in the oysters and simmer ... (1913,Australasian Cookery Book, The,213)

Takapuna Russet¶

n. a variety of apple

I was quite aware of the origin of the Takapuna Russet, having some years ago seen the tree (Reinette du Canada) that threw out the sport from one of its branches. (Sep 17, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,28)

Takapuna surprise¶

n. a steak stuffed with oysters

TAKAPUNA SURPRISE top-side steak ... Prepare a forcemeat ... oysters ... sweet herbs ... cayenne pepper ... breadcrumbs ... fill the steak with the mixture ... Sew up ... slices of bacon over the top, and bake ... (1913,Australasian Cookery Book, The,213)

McGILL Takapuna surprise steak stuffed with oysters. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,111)

Takapuna/Takapuna class¶

n. a former (class of) small sailboat, designed in Takapuna; aka Z class, Zeddie

All the clubs have added a race for the new Takapuna one-design class... The first boat is now ready for launching... Some difficulty is being experienced in getting the sails, owing to a shortage of the necessary silk cloth. (Oct 29, 1921,Auckland Star,18)

The latest class, the Takapuna, 12 ft 6 in flatties, are very handy little craft, and ideal for racing or knocking about the sheltered bays and beaches of Takapuna. (Nov 26, 1921,Auckland Star,18)

AVERY ﻿I'm going to.. Drink a handle or a schooner as I tack my Takapuna. (1974,Ken Avery Songbook, The,Unpaged)

CARTER Next to the X class. is the Z class, or what are often referred to as the Cornwall Cup boats. They owe their existence to a small band of Takapuna yachtsmen who planned the first boat, with much the same idea in their minds as did George Honour when he built the first of the 14-foot square bilge boats, namely, low first cost, ease of construction, and an ever-watchful eye on speed and performance under Auckland harbour weather conditions. The yachts were originally designed for the Takapuna Boating Club but owing to their popularity from the outset the type was quickly adopted by many other yacht clubs throughout New Zealand... From small beginnings the Takapuna one-design class rapidly expanded. (1944,Little Ships: NZ's Yachting Fleet,127)

TITCHENER A good example.. was the design of the famous but ill-fated Z-class, which became known as the Takapuna class throughout New Zealand. (1978,Little Ships of NZ,64) [NOTES: [Specifications - 3.8 m yacht, designed by R B Brown of Northcote. 1.5m beam,m square chine vee-bottom principle. The whole of the sailing area carried on a gunter mainsail, on a short mast forward, no bowsprit or headsail]]

DAVIS The Z class, or "Zeddie" as it was affectionately known, was another class which was designed as a low cost sailing boat to get the boys into something safer than the tin canoes or derelict dinghies in which they cruised Shoal Bay. Ibid. 114 The Takapuna Boating Club which was then situated at Bayswater, was the sponsoring club and the yachts were often referred to as the "Takapuna Class". (1989,Kohimarama,113)

MANDER & O'NEILL On the other hand to be in a fleet of Takapunas and come about the weather mark, in a cloud of blossoming spinnakers and fly away before the breeze in a surge of foam was a roundabout which made up for the swing. (1964,Give a Man a Boat,35)

takaraka¶

n. hoiho

Yellow-eyed Penguin Megadyptes antipodes (HOMBRON & JACQUINOT, 1841) ... OTHER NAME: Takaraka. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,42)

takarama¶

adj. [may yet prove to be other than NZ lexeme, one further citation found at Australaian web site: ... ash. Joined: Thursday 17 July 2003 Posts: 444 From: Sydney, Posted: 2004-03-07 17:54 call me crazy but i think its takarama to the max...? .ash. ... www.vogue.com.au/forum/viewtopic. php?topic=53633&forum=8&9]

The glitzy set .. the lounge orchestra - it's takarama, right down to the glitterball microphone waved by the implausibly named Candy Lane. (May 8, 2005,Sunday Star Times,A6)

takaruwha¶

n. a fresh-water fish

TAYLOR Takaruwha, a fresh-water fish a foot long, and thick in proportion, found in the Waingongoro; this is called the eel trout, and rises at the fly. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,414)

takata pora¶

n. a ship person, a Pakeha [takata = tangata]

SHORTLAND PORA, a ship. Takata pora,' a man of a ship, or whiteman, equivalent to the termpakeha,' used commonly in the North Island. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,312)

takatapui¶

n. a homosexual [ORIGIN: Maori, http://www.learningmedia.co.nz/nz/online/ngata/m2edictionary]

Yes there are deep seeded [sic] issues about Takatapui/tootika/taerarua in every society/community/religon [sic] and all of these issues need to be addressed in a forum such as this ... (Dec 11, 2007,Internet - see Notes)

Every four days one gay, takataapui or bisexual man in New Zealand is being diagnosed with HIV. (2006,Jack,issue 4 Dec 2005 / Jan 2006, p31)

In the first half of this year, one gay, takataapui or bisexual man in New Zealand was diagnosed with HIV every four days. (Nov 2005,Express (Gay & Lesbian Express),16)

The inclusion of the world takataapui in William's nineteenth century dictionary, and the story that accompanies its presence there, alerts us to the fact there is indeed another reading. (Aug 24, 2005,Express (Gay & Lesbian Express),4)

.. But still I would like to see more takatapui online and in life ... (Jan 24, 2008,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.maori.org.nz/papa_panui/forum_topic.asp?]

takatapuitanga¶

n. matters to do with homosexuality [ORIGIN: Maori]

Twas only a matter of time before someone dedicated a whole thread to takatapuitanga. (Dec 9, 2007,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.maori.org.nz/papa_panui/forum_topic.asp?]

takawaru¶

n. a fish

LEE & KENDALL T|aka w|adu, ss. A fish so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,206)

take¶

n. [(muttonbirding)]

... but this presumption has been rebutted by the admission that he had no `take', therefore he has no right to this island. (Aug 1911,Gazette) [NOTES: 1911 Aug Gazette in 1979 Wilson Titi Heritage 41]

WILSON `Take', and all references thereto, include taking, catching, killing, or pursuing, by any means or device, ... (1979,Titi Heritage,171) [NOTES: 1912 Regulations under Land Act in 1979 Wilson Titi Heritage 171]

WILSON Down the generations it had been observed that this happened about the same time each year, so the wise old chiefs set the season for the take' for that certain time of the year which became known to the pakeha as half of March, all of April and May, allowing no trespassing on the island at any other time of the year lest the birds, refusing to nest on an islandtouched' by human presence, should fly away and never return. Ibid. 27 Especially when the pakeha took a Maori wife; he could then share her journey to her island, and help her to take' enough birds for their family needs. <i>Ibid.</i> 39 Some of these descendants actually visited the disputed islands and attempted totake'. <.i>Ibid. 55-56 Ever since the beginning, to take' meant journeying to the islands and living there for the season and using hands or any device to catch the birds. ... totake' also includes an attempt to take'. During the torching season the birds run down the paths to the sea at night. Paths are used as boundaries by the [56] supervisors and in some cases the dividing line is the middle of the path. If one pursues a bird and grabs it over the other edge of the path one can be prosecuted, even although the bird came from the pursuer's manu. <i>Ibid.,</i> 66 In the season 1921 the Colac Bay and Riverton Maoris caught 24,000 birds, In 1922 thetake' was 14,000. (1979,Titi Heritage,25)

(two syllables) n. purpose, cause [ORIGIN: Maori]

The academy's take (purpose) is about changing kids' attitudes in order to make them more employable... Rangihuna.. is passionate about the academy's real take and frustrated by the fixation on its sporting success. (Oct 1997,North & South,77)

SINCLAIR Now he arranged with General Cameron to reoccupy the European land at Tataraimaka despite the repeated Maori warnings that they would regard this action as a take, a just cause for war. Ibid. take Root, cause (1959,History of New Zealand,134)

1 n. (Rural) [land-breaking] the germination and growth of a plant crop.

GUTHRIE-SMITH Between the isolated plants of the miserable 'take' of seed there was ample space left for the germination of undesirables. (1921,Tutira,165)

TAIT The grass seed being sown in the ashes as soon as possible after the burn to ensure an early take of grass with the first rains. (1955,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,131)

GASCOIGNE Either from this factor or an indifferent grass "take" much of this large paddock had always been disappointing and now quite obviously was in poor shape. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,129)

take (up) the burnt chops¶

phr. (Rural) to go mustering.

BAKER Here a few [farming terms] that appear to have originated this century: to take the burnt chops (said of a person) to take on work as a musterer. (1941,NZ Slang,54)

In the old days, they used to say that a man who had gone mustering had 'taken up the burnt chops.' (Nov 15, 1983,NZ Journal of Agriculture,20)

GORDON These [mustering] gangs were made up of men who'd taken up the burnt chops, ate 'hockey sticks', wore 'Bill Masseys' slept in a 'scratcher' and rode pigskin ... (1983,Other Side of Farming, The,1)

.. while mustering they are doing a dog job, taking up the burnt chops or bringing in the wool. (Nov 22, 2002,Dominion Post,C6)

PARTRIDGE Take the burnt chops.. To work as a musterer of sheep:. New Zealand rural: C. 20. B., 1941. (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1194)

burnt chops, to take the (Phr.). take on work as a muster. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),5)

take a beat¶

1 phr. (Rural) to have a position in a mustering gang.

MACNICOL Whether working in the shed, 'taking a 'beat'on the hill, or simply washing dishes, Jim was enjoying himself. (1965,Beyond the Skippers Road,146)

NEWTON Jack Wilson first mustered at Mesopotamia in the early years of the First World War and he was still taking a beat during World War II. (1975,Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,19)

NEWTON Ian at nearer seventy than sixty is still taking a beat on walking country .. that autumn muster he took the outside beat right over the top. (1975,Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,112)

take a cut¶

1 phr. (Rural) [stock management] to move into a mob of stock and take out particular animals.

LOUGHNAN to take a cut: to take out this portion. It needs a good man on a good horse to cut cows from their calves at foot, and, an even more delicate operation, to take a cut of ewes without mismothering them from their lambs. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,23)

take a fit¶

phr.

THATCHER Tell him to take a fit and `bust,' / Ask him if he gets his boots on trust, / And you'll be a leary boy. (1875,NZ Songster,No.5/63) [NOTES: The Leary Boy]

take a jerry¶

phr.

Halfway through the piece he [sc. the Premier] "took a jerry", and in his hasty endeavour to remove the offending bowler, he dropped it. (Aug 2, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,V/49 : 5)

take a powder¶

phr. to escape

MacKENZIE powder to take a powder, to escape (1980,While We Have Prisons,98)

take a pull¶

phr. to pull oneself together: often in imper. stop! [cf. P: `desist, discontinue': Aust: 20c: In imper. occasionally: Take a pull on oneself!]

On again, then through Napier, the Patea country, in and out till I came to Maraekakaho station: when I took a pull I was by this time heartily sick of the game, and made up my mind to give it best, and came into Hastings. (Jan 7, 1911,NZ Truth,289/4/5)

HAUGHEY Look here -, it's about time you took a pull. Just shake yourself up a bit quick. (1946,Railway Reminiscences,21)

take a pull (slang phrase) to reform (oneself). (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

take a pull (Sl. phr.) to reform (oneself). (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

His face was clear, his eyes were bright, and he had evidently been taking a pull at himself, as the horsey men say. (Feb 10, 1875,Thames Star,3)

When you feel anyhow and life seems just one blessed thing after another, don't get dispirited. Take a pull on yourself. (Sep 20, 1924,Evening Post,21)

"We have got to take a pull on these street collections; the public is getting sick of them," remarked Councillor W. Appleton. (Aug 16, 1935,Evening Post,8)

It is time the sprinter took a pull and kept away from the store. (Jan 23, 1897,Observer (Auckland),22)

'Come, now, take a pull! You're coming too strong! ...' (Nov 21, 1901,West Coast Times,4)

IT is about time that Lord Charles Beresofrd [sic] should either take a pull on his unbridled tongue or be made to prove some of the wild assertions that he has been making of late in order to show that the Navy is and has been neglected. (Jan 29, 1910,Grey River Argus,2)

It is time New Zealand took a pull at herself in the matter of football. [i.e., people are mad over football and should calm down] (Sep 15, 1906,NZ Truth,65/4/2)

take a shingle off¶

phr. to become angry or offended; to hit the roof, to blow one's top

He takes his offers too in such a manner as he would make you believe he really don't want a drink, but he "doesn't like to take a shingle off." (Apr 26, 1873,Taranaki Herald,5)

There had been a raffle for a horse, and as the winner was going out to lead him away the landlord of the bush hotel, always keen for business, said, "Shure'n you'll shout for all hands after that lump o' luck; you're not the wan to take a shingle off a poor man's roof, I'll be bound." (Oct 26, 1894,Wanganui Herald,2)

BATHGATE Gilbert, thinking it best to be civil, thanked the [digger], but declined his offer [of a shout]. You must not take a shingle off,' said the landlord addressing him,that won't do.' (1881,Waitaruna,132)

take a tumble to¶

phr. to understand something suddenly [ca1945 Wellington, Victoria University students]

(Slang phrase). to realise suddenly, to become aware of. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

PARTRIDGE Although, he said, he was the white-haired boy with the trump he was due for a shake-up and he had to take a tumble to himself as to how he gave the company-rations away. Ibid. 288 Hey, turn it up and stop all those gloomy forecasts or you will find that I can go very hostile, and it's time we all took a tumble to ourselves and discussed something pleasant, say a little party. (1935,Slang Today,287) [NOTES: A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287]

(1979,Heinemann NZ Dictionary)

tumble ... 3 take a tumble to NZ & Austral. sl. understand suddenly. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,829) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 1261; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 516]]

".. There have been too many ducks kissing and slobbering over me for the last five years, and I think it's time to take a tumble and get a sure grip on one." (Oct 16, 1886,Evening Post,2)

And then "I took a tumble" - the Opera House is to be in the same street, and on the same section of ground, so the adjoining buildings - even if some little distance away - must be in keeping, outwardly at any rate, with our up-to-date Opera House. (May 17, 1899,Wanganui Chronicle,2)

Taking a line through Saturday's performances at Miramar, a few of our senior players ought to take a tumble to themselves and give the game best. (Jun 6, 1908,NZ Truth,3)

By-and-by they take a tumble. They begin to see that there is nothing humanitarian about the methods of these humbugs. (Feb 8, 1913,NZ Truth,8)

"Cambist" hopes that this review will enable shareholders to "take a tumble" to the need for a complete overhaul of affairs. (Jun 20, 1925,NZ Truth,17)

take down¶

v. to beat (not necessarily by cheating) ; in various uses deriving from an original sense swindle

take down v.tr. cheat, deceive. take down n. a deception, fraud. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

take down v.t. cheat, deceive. take down n. a deception, fraud. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

2 v. to cost [ca1952 H.S. Gajadhar, Wellington My holiday took me down for twenty pounds.]

COOZE A doughy concoction labelled cake `took us down' for seven and six. (1944,Kiwis in the Pacific,20)

3 v. ?take down from where they are hanging

BOWEN As there are several different types of handpieces there is not space to set out how each of them should be taken down and experted. (1955,Wool Away!,79)

take it away¶

phr. to begin

MASON GUEST 1: ... Give us a haka, Johnny. JOHNNY: Aw, now. Don't feel like it, eh. GUEST 2: Yes! Ka mate, ka mate! Take it away, boy! (1963,Pohutukawa Tree,45)

take it on the toe¶

phr.

I recognise this bloke as a dumper, so I take it on the toe out the gate and up the frog and toad. to take it on the toe....to run (May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19)

take on¶

v. to engage in a fight; to challenge to a fight [ca 1935]

take on the tongs¶

1 phr. (Rural) to work as a shearer.

NEWTON Lennie had a brother Ted who also took on the tongs ... (1964,Straggle Muster,46)

take one's coat off¶

phr. get serious, get down to hard work

Sherwin expressed an opinion as to what kind of novel it was. It's pretty solid,' he said,you'll have to take your coat off to read it.'... Counsel acknowledged that he didn't think that the expression take your coat off' referred to immorality. Crown Prosecutor Russell:It is a very hearty expression.' (Oct 3, 1908,NZ Truth,172/5/4)

take one's hook¶

phr. to leave, get away (from) (cf. sling one's hook)

PARTRIDGE Take one's hook. To decamp; run away: New Zealanders': C. 20. Ex sling one's hook. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,862)

PARTRIDGE Fritz landed a daisy-cutter and the transport driver done his block and took his hook. (1935,Slang Today,287)

(Apr 4, 1938,Press, The) [NOTES: 1938 McNab NZ slang [Slang of the N.Z.E.F.]]

BALLANTYNE `I certainly wish I could take my hook from everybody in Gladstone' she said. (1948,Cunninghams, The,132)

... not staying on here if you all take your hook. (1948,Voices I,7) [NOTES: 1948 Voices I (ed Martin) (D Ballantyne)]

take one's horse for a gallop¶

phr. to urinate

take your horse for a gallop: urinate (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

take out the back teeth¶

phr. to neuter (a cat)

McGILL take out the back teeth neutering the domestic tomcat. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,111)

take over¶

v. (Rural) to inherit, occupy or buy land from a former owner or occupier.

When the farm was taken over ten years ago, the 200 acres in grass supported browntop and rough feed. (May 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,14)

Because this man had recently taken over the farm and lacked the finance to purchase feed, the herd was faced with virtual starvation over the winter-spring period. (Feb 2, 1953,NZ Dairy Exporter,39)

TAIT The youngest son took over the property. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,36)

TAIT The present owner took over the farm when his father died. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,40)

They took over the farm from their father, Mr John Searle. (Jun 10, 1958,NZ Dairy Exporter,28)

Before Tom took over, the farm's top production season was 50,200 lb of fat from about 150 cows. (Nov 11, 1963,NZ Dairy Exporter,4)

take the back track/back trail¶

phr. to retrace one's steps; occas. to retire (from a difficult situation).

WHITWORTH There was nothing for it but to turn back ... so I determined to take the back track as soon as possible. (1870,Martin's Bay Settlement,34)

ANZAC Our little party now came to the conclusion that it was time to take the back trail. (1916,On Anzac Trail,105)

(Apr 19, 1971,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56) [NOTES: see bushed]

take the blanket¶

phr. of a Pakeha, to live as a Maori

Then came the agony between a young European wearing the tartan name of Stuart Mclvor and his erring half-caste Maori missus called by the festive name of Pehipa, who has, to use a current term, returned `to the blanket' in preference to Stuart's manly buzzim. (Aug 17, 1912,NZ Truth,373/5/7)

COWAN Sometimes renegade white men joined with the Maoris in the ceremonies around the niu. One of these runaways from civilization who had `taken the blanket' ... (1922,NZ Wars, The,2/14)

take the day off to carry bricks¶

phr.

McGILL take the day off to carry bricks a working holiday. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,111)

take the dog collar¶

phr. (obsolete) take the prize, the cake

... we find in proportion to population ... New Zealand takes the dog collar [for incidence of lunacy]. (May 19, 1906,NZ Truth,48/6/6)

take the gate¶

1 phr. (Rural) [stock-drafting] to operate the drafting-gates in a race.

LOUGHNAN Oddly enough, though he [the drafter/buyer] may handle them expertly he rarely bothers to take the gate. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,28)

LOUGHNAN gate: to take the gate: to operate the gates of a drafting race. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,34)

LOUGHNAN take the gate: to do the actual handling of the drafting gates. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,83)

ACLAND (1933,Press, The)

take the iced biscuit¶

phr.

For right down, cool, blasted cheek the announcement of the New Zealand selectors that they could not decide between Stubberfield and Mckay for a place in the team for Hobart, takes the iced biscuit. (Feb 8, 1908,NZ Truth,138/3/3)

take the knock¶

phr. accept the loss?

The bookie' will simply, to use their own vulgar parlance,take the knock' and go on as before. [This quote is the next sentence to SUGAR and must imply not paying out, doing a bunk or something like that] (Sep 23, 1911,NZ Truth,326/2/4)

take to¶

v. to attack (esp. with the fists)

Take to him, Bill. (1911,Kiwi on the Swag,9)

take to burnt spurs¶

phr. (Rural) to go mustering.

burnt spurs, to take to: to go mustering (1981,Loughnan Glossary,14)

take to one's scrapers¶

phr. to take to one's heels

CRUMP Tonker took to his scrapers and hid in a hedge. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,63)

take to the boards¶

1 phr. (Rural) to begin a shearing run.

At a woolshed party a few days after John Lennon died, they took to the boards and played air microphones with the handpieces. (May 12, 2001,NZ Farmer,64)

take to the burnt spur¶

phr. (Rural) to go mustering.

ACLAND burnt chops: an expression somewhat akin to the expression 'burnt spur' which denoted the business of a high country mustering: 'So-and-so has taken to the b.s.', meaning he has taken on mustering. (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,366)

take to the road¶

phr. (Rural) [itinerant workers] to depart on foot or to shoulder one's swag.

CHINN The shearing was in full swing and those who had not been fortunate enough to obtain employment shouldered their swags and took to the road again. (1963,Packtrack to Highway,62)

take to the track¶

phr.

OWEN & PERKINS I took to the track, I came up north and swagged with a character that was well known on the track at that time. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,68)

take up¶

v. occupy (land, for farming or mining)

Further concessions to soldiers who take up land were urged at the meeting of the Advisory Board of the War Relief Societies yesterday. (Nov 17, 1916,Evening Post,5)

... this had been forest ... long before the run had been `taken up' or stocked. (1908,TrNZI,40/518)

ACLAND It was the first station ... to be taken up in South Cantebury ... (1946,Early Canterbury Runs,160)

BUTLER My companion and myself have found a small piece of country, which we have just taken up. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,v/66)

WALKER (Central Otago) Prospected about 10 miles up river, every place worth having seems to have been taken up. ... [Jan 12-13] ... we went up the gully to see if there was room to put in anywhere, but found it was all taken up, so we went up to the top of the hill ... (Jan 10, 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker))

BUTLER Taking up the Run - ... I had waited to see how the land was allotted before I took it up. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,viii/114)

WILSON The land up here 110 miles from the sea coast (Oamaru) was taken up in 1858, and all the habitable parts in of New Zealand have now been taken up ... These men are perhaps safer than these men down here [near the coast] as no one can take their land up for a long time. (Feb 2, 1873,Diary) [NOTES: 1873 Feb 2 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 164]

HOCKEN (country) freehold or lease Thus [168] fresh country was continually taken up and active explorers went further and further afield, ... (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,167)

I shall never forget the small dark man who took up a run at the back of beyond, carted a piano up there on a bullock dray, and passed his solitary evenings playing Bach's fugues; ... (Aug 19, 1912,Lesson Outlines for Christian Education) [NOTES: 1912 Aug 19 Sir Joshua Strange Williams letter in 1919 Jones Samuel Butler 1/85]

ANTHONY I took the section up in the first place through ignorance. (1927,Follow the Call,111,1975 ed.)

The original occupier of country in the early days was said to have taken it up. Who took up this station?' meansWho was the first occupier?' Nowadays people tell you that Mr Jones had just `taken up' 1000 acres of Brown's run. (C.) The old sense of the world was understood everywhere on stations up to about 1900. (Dec 23, 1933,Press, The) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

ANDERSON When these stations were first taken up the access was poor, or the soil was infertile, and so they were not suitable for subdivision. 1868. (1981,Both Sides of the River,8)

take up ... 2. N.Z. to occupy and break in (uncultivated land): he took up some hundreds of acres in the back country. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1192) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 490]]

sc a claim BRICKMAKERS', near Punga Flat. Five men's ground, taken up in March (1868,Thames Miner's Guide, The,83)

SCOTTER (sc. country: cf mining use) In April, 1853, six months after his arrival in New Zealand, he bought 820 sheep in Nelson and drove them to Canterbury in search of land and it was only after he saw that all the open country was taken up ... that he ... decided to cross the Waitaki River. (1948,Run, Estate and Farm,1)

v. (Rural) to occupy, lease or purchase land for the purpose of farming, usually as the first occupant.

HOBHOUSE Every bit of the valley to the highest mountain-top has been greedily taken up for runs ... (Nov 10, 1860,Hobhouse Letters and Papers)

My companion and myself have found a small piece of country, which we have just taken up ... (1860,BLANK ENTRY,66) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

.. was munificently rewarded for his bravery and sacrifice by being allowed to take up this section of virgin bush ... (Oct 1918,NZ Farmer,1339)

The original occupier of country in the early days was said to have 'taken it up.' (Dec 23, 1933,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

STUDHOLME When some of the North Island runs were first taken up, dogs were so destructive that it was hard to stock up with sheep. (1940,Te Waimate,42)

CRESSWELL When the MacKenzie Country was discovered and all available land taken up ... (1951,Canterbury Tales,143)

TAIT The property had changed hands three times and had reverted to bracken, manuka and blackberry since it was first taken up in standing bush in 1910. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,74)

FEARON Ashton had also taken up his block in April 1919, and built a house close to the road. (1980,Te Wharau,182)

I have a nine acre section, and finding I could do with another small one, I applied for it, and was informed that I could only hold one deferred section at a time. Now sir, on applying I understood by the declaration I could apply for more, as long as I did not exceed the 320 acres. On this condition, I took up the small section I now occupy. (Oct 3, 1884,Taranaki Herald,2)

take-out¶

n. (Sport) [cf. put-in]

Toward the end these paddlers did decide to walk a rapid or two, but we finally got to the take-out (bridge) soon after... (2005,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.huttkayakers.org.nz/tripIndex.php *Accessed 17/04/06. No date for site construction or posting.]

take/be put down the track¶

phr. be fired, sent down the road

18/14/2 ... and a drummer' is the man with the lowest tally - perhaps because he is likeliest to take and keep the track with hisload.' The general applications of these fresh significations may be doubted. (Jul 7, 1911,Maoriland Worker)

RICHARDS The lamb would have to be killed. I felt embarrassed and upset because I was sure I would be put down the track' <i>Ibid.</i>115 I was certain I would be putdown the track', and I was terrified by the thought. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,98)

takeke¶

n. garfish, Reporhamphus ihi or (? earlier) Hemirhamphus intermedius, H.australis half-beak, ihe, piper, taheke [check that Colenso spg not mistranslit.: misprint or typo]1970 Pictured and named on the definitive issue, of the NZ 7d atamp]

WILLIAMS The whole of the long range of the New Zealand Coast is abundantly supplied with beautiful fish. Of this variety of 78 species I will name a part, viz. ... takeke, Guardfish; ... [Glossary 120 takeke Guardfish, garfish, or piper (Hemirhamphus intermedius)]. (1843,NZ Journal,40,1956 ed.)

COLENSO A small but graceful species of garfish ... [55] flow, or rather sprung into my boat. ... Here [near Bay of Islands, the natives] call them Taheke; but among the southern tribes, Ihe. (1844,Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ) [NOTES: 1844 Colenso Excursion Northern Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 54-55]

English Name Native Name ... ... Guardfish Takehe [sic, but check] (1849,NZ Journal,9/125) [NOTES: quoting Anglo Maori Warder Oct]

HEMIRAMPHUS INTERMEDIUS Cantor. Garfish, or Piper; Takeke. Occurs in abundance around all the northern coasts. Common, Otago, in spring and early summer. ... Distribution: New Zealand coasts. (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/120) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

PHILLIPPS Hemirhamphus intermedeus Cantor. GARFISH or PIPER; TAKEKE. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,21,1971 ed.)

GRAHAM GARFISH or PIPER (TAKEKE) Reporhamphus ihi Phillipps. This fish is known in Auckland as Piper, although in Otago it is called Garfish or Guard Fish. ... It is on account of this peculiarity [a long bottom jaw] that they are sometimes called Halfbeaks. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,157)

PARROTT THE GARFISH Reporhampus ihi (Phillipps) ... Maori name: TAKEKE or IHI. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,33)

DOOGUE & MORELAND GARFISH ... Other names: Reporhamphus ihi; piper, half-beak; ihe, takeke (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,206)

McLINTOCK3/705-712 Garfish (piper) - ihe, takeke, Reporhamphus ihi (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An)

MORELAND GARFISH [Reporhamphus ihi] ... Also called piper, halfbeak, ihi, and takeke. (1967,Marine Fishes,16)

2 n. smelt

TAYLOR My boys were disappointed of their eels ... the only fish they caught were a few takekes which is remarkable for the large roe it has though only about 4 inches long. (Apr 10, 1847,Journal,5/20)

TAYLOR Awa, is a small tidal river fish, resembling the roach; the settlers call it the herring, which it only resembles in shape. It is synonymous with takeke. Ibid. 414 Takeke, a small fresh-water fish, syn. Tikihemi. It is an oily fish. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,411)

takeketonga¶

n.

PHILLIPPS Makaira mazara (Jordan and Snyder). BLACK MARLIN or SWORDFISH; TAKETONGA. [check] (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,47,1971 ed.)

DOOGUE & MORELAND STRIPED MARLIN ... Other names: Makaira audax; takeketonga (Maori). Universally called striped marlin in English-speaking countries. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,273)

MORELAND STRIPED MARLIN [Makaira audax] ... The Maori name takeketonga is not often heard. (1967,Marine Fishes,54)

takeovers panel¶

n.

... I repeatedly called for an increase in the commission's power in this respect, but the government of the day, the stock exchange and professional bodies resisted conferring that role on the commission along with the other areas of needy regulation, such as appointment of a Takeovers Panel. (Nov 13, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

taker-up¶

1 n. (Rural) one who takes up, purchases or leases land for farming purposes.

WOODHOUSE Mount Cook Station is now managed by Catherine Burnett's grandson, Donald Mount Cook Burnett, and is one of four stations in South Canterbury that have been held continuously by the 'taker-up' and his descendants. (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,257)

takeyahways¶

n.

McGILL takey-ah-ways take-away food, pronounced as if a Maori word. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,111)

taki¶

n. a ritual challenge [ORIGIN: Maori]

For the young Tai Tokerau men dressed as warriors for the taki, or ritual challenge, it's been a long wait. (Feb 28, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10)

Takitimu¶

adj. Geol. classification

Recently completed theses and projects include: Bruce Houghton (PhD) Geology of the Takitimu Group and related intrusive rocks, Central Takitimu Mountains, western Southland, New Zealand. (Nov 1978,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,46/18)

Takitimu gecko¶

n. (Environment) a rare gecko found from southern Fiordland to the Richardson Mountains; well camouflaged by bright herringbone patterning. [Hoplodactylus cryptozoicus]

[Hdg] Takitimu gecko. In 1966, A Department of Conservation field worker, Tony Jewell, found a very unusual gecko on a scree in the Takitimu Mountains in western Southland... Tony Jewell captured three more Takitimu gecko in 2000, and another in 2001, all from the same scree. (May 2002,Forest & Bird,No. 304/17)

DOC Biodiversity ranger Ros Cole confirmed that this was the first Takitimu gecko to be found in the southern Fiordland area. "The find follows a 2005 discovery, which was the first indication that Takitimu geckos are capable of living in both alpine and forest environments." (Jun 2007,Conservation Action,6)

takiwa¶

n. territory [ORIGIN: Maori] (See see also taurahere)

In 1997, the tribe won all the island's pounamu in their Treaty settlement - every bit within their takiwa, or territory, effectively all the greenstone in New Zealand. (May 29, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

takiwai¶

n. teardrop greenstone (See tangiwai)

[Milford Sound's] waters were familiar to [Maori] from their travels to mine the takiwai, or teardrop greenstone, found at the entrance to Milford Sound. (Nov 5, 2002,Dominion Post,C8)

takoha¶

n. tax, contribution

Purchases by gratuities, more regularly called 'takoha', were introduced to extinguish such Maori possessory rights as had been assumed or were claimed in the Waimate Plains or in the south. (1996,Waitangi Tribunal Report,143 : 193)

taku tama¶

phr. my son [ORIGIN: Maori]

A quiet breeze reveals to him a pause in animosity of storm upon the forest in the war of ancestors, where brother battles brother for the land beneath his feet, whose mauri even now rises within him and calls him taku tama. (2007,Best New Zealand Fiction, Vol 4, The,36) [NOTES: 'The Good and the Gentle', Ben Brown, 2007]

takuta¶

n. doctor [ORIGIN: Maori]

When he left the battalion in 1945, Bill Ngata son of Sir Apirana, said of Moore: "You were not the most academic of our takuta (doctors). You were not (quite) the bravest, but you were the most Maori". (Feb 2005,North & South,107)

talamea¶

n. (See taramea)

talc¶

n. greenstone, usu. green talk (1770) [also jasper talc(obs: early use)]

At the conclusion of the lecture, Mr. Lyon put us in possession of a curious fact connected with the development of the mineral wealth of the southern island, namely that the greenstone, or poonamor, of the natives, a species of talc slate, is in such demand in the Chinese market for the manufacture of their idols, ornaments, &c., that as much as GBP1500 per ton can be had for it. (Sep 9, 1842,New Zealand Colonist & Port Nicholson Advertiser,2)

As we have in New Zealand many of the conditions under which gold is found in other countries, as well as most of the gold-bearing rocks; such as crystalline rocks composed of quartz and felspar [sic], with a grey base, sometimes approaching to the character of porphyry; together with dykes of quartz in talc and mica-slate schist, &c. ... (Jul 13, 1852,Daily Southern Cross,3)

On the latter part of this journey Dr Shortland gained from an intelligent Native named Huruhura the first specific and reliable information regarding the interior of the island, and of the lakes which had always vaguely figured in the earliest maps under the title of Water of Green Talc, Greenstone Lake, Te Wai Pounamu. (Oct 7, 1887,Otago Witness,14)

An important discovery of mica ore and talc was made near the mouth of the Paringa River, in South Westland. (May 8, 1891,North Otago Times,2)

The tools ... are adzes or axes some made of a hard black stone, and others of green Talk. ... The green talk axes that are whole and good they set much value upon. [ed. fn] i.e. talc; pounamu, greenstone or nephrite, ... (Mar 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/284,1955 ed.)

...this man had a human tooth hanging at his ear- and a piece of green talk about two and half inches long, and an inch and half broad, flat, and carved into the figure of a most uncooth [sic] animal of fancy (Oct 18, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/581) [NOTES: 1769 Oct 18 W.B. Monkhouse in 1955 Cook Journal 1/581]

... one seizd his weapon of Green talk ... (Oct 9, 1769,Banks Journal,1/402,1962 ed.)

[see Te Wai Pounamu] (Jan 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/243,1955 ed.)

COLLINS (1798,Account of the English Colony in NSW, An)

SAVAGE There is a green semi-transparent talc, brought from the interior, of considerable hardness, with which they make their tools, and a number of ornaments. [transfer to TALC ?] (1807,Some Account of NZ,9)

CRUISE They also wear, fastened round the neck by a cord, and hanging on the breast, a piece of green talc, carved to represent what cannot be deemed human. (1823,Journal,183,1957 ed.)

MATHEW [Patamouri] presented the Governor with one of their splendid Green Talc Hatchets or Mares' expressly for QueenWikitoria'. nephrite, ...] (Feb 6, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Feb 6 F.Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 41 See also Mathew (?Matthew)1842]

POLACK The Meri is ... formed of the green talc, jade, serpent-stone, and jasper (for it has been called by all these names). (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,2/30)

SAVAGE There is a green semi-transparent talc, brought from the interior, of considerable hardness, with which they make their tools, and a number of ornaments. (1807,New Zealand (various authors/titles),9)

POLACK Singular to relate, the central island has existed hitherto unnamed; as a distinguishing mark it has been called Te Wai Poenenamu[a-acute], or the Waters of Green Talc (rather an anomalous same for terra firma), from the time of Cook's survey; ... Ibid.1/194 ... a dark-gray and black-coloured granite, termed onewoa by the natives was made use of in its stead, or the green talc, poeanamu[a2-acute] and pieces of red jasper chipped off adroitly, resembling in shape our common gun-flints. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/1/5fn)

2 n. greenstone

CRAIK [They] make certain of their weapons, and carving tools, of a green talc, or jasper stone, which is found only in the southern island ... (1830,New Zealanders, The,184)

CRAIK [They] make certain of their weapons, and carving tools, of a green talc, or jasper stone, which is found only in the southern island ... (1830,New Zealanders, The,184)

It is called pounamu or poenamu by the Maoris, and jade,'jadeite,' or nephrite,' by various writers, while old books refer to thegreen talc' of the Maoris. (1892,TrNZI,24/481)

2 n. greenstone

MONKHOUSE He had a narrow slip of Jasper talk formed somewhat like a french bean, hanging to his ear- ... (Oct 18, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/581,1955 ed.) [NOTES: 1769 Oct 18 W.B. Monkhouse in 1955 Cook Journal]

talc-stone¶

n.

COLLINS They ... carry on a traffic for flax and green talc-stone, of which they make axes and ornaments. (1804,English Colony in NSW,344)

talent quest¶

n. a public entertainment/competition with the object of discovering talented amateur singers, musicians, etc. [Jim Cameron writes: In use for many years. Neither this compound nor song quest (as in Mobil Song Quest) is recorded in OED or other dictionaries. OED has an entry for talent show.]

talk¶

v. (of a tree) to make sounds indicating it is about to fall [ca1951 R. Gilberd Okaihau That means that a tree is about to fall and the weight of the top is breaking the fibres of wood. They crackle and squeak and groan - `talking'.]

Don't you hear her talkin'?' as a gentle ticking would indicate the act of partition had commenced. Then the wedges werebacked up,' and a few solid blows from the heavy mauls would complete the operation. (Dec 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,178)

McGILL talk the leg off an iron pot you talk too much. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,112)

talk a glass eye to sleep¶

phr. to talk boringly

McGILL talk a glass eye to sleep boring; ref. Stevan Eldred-Grigg, Oracles and Miracles. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,111)

talk and puha¶

phr. (a heading) punning on pork and puha q.v.

talk boots¶

phr. (Rural) to argue.

LOUGHNAN talking boots: a musterers' term for arguing the point. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,83)

talk bullock¶

phr. to use colourful language (See bullock language,bullocky)

In modern Australia ... we hear of men on up-country stations who can do nothing but talk bullock;' and so all men did to a great extent in days when both word and idiom had origin in cattle-speech. [fn] For ancient use of expressiontalking bullock' see Bible (Apocrypha), Ecclesiasticus, xxxix, 25. [HWO: Jerusalem and Vulgate references don't seem to be quite apt.] (1889,TrNZI,21/450)

BAKER .. as long ago as 1864 ... Thatcher ... used the expression to talk bullock. (1941,NZ Slang,47)

McGILL talk bullock bad language bullock drivers were noted for; ref. Sam under `bullocky'. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,111)

PARTRIDGE Talk bullock. To use much-and picturesque-bad language: New Zealand coll.: 1846, Charles R. Thatcher (cited by B., 1941). Both bullock-drivers and their beasts have much to put up with. (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1194)

talk oneself around¶

v. to deny (something)

Here is a man who took advantage of a school situation to flog off a narcotic. Talk yourself around that one. (Apr 3, 1979,Evening Post,5)

talk the leg off an iron pot¶

phr. to talk excessively [ca1910 W.H.B. Orsman]

(Loud cheers, and "Oh, don't ask, he'd talk the leg off an iron pot.") (Jan 28, 1870,Colonist (Nelson),3)

My word, Dot, she would talk the leg off an iron pot! (Dec 18, 1907,Otago Witness,83)

Among all the pots and dishes among the motley assortment of goods strewn round the place there can surely be none with legs still adhering for if anyone could "talk the leg off an iron pot" it is this auctioneer. (Sep 15, 1923,NZ Truth,6)

talk to one's saddle¶

phr. (Rural) [boundary shepherds and outstation shepherds] to become disturbed from isolation.

MACFARLANE Men became so strange and quiet in the back, so much alone, begin 'talking to their saddle' as the old saying goes. (1946,Amuri,97)

talkback¶

n. shortened form of "talkback radio"

Talkback can get a bit hairy sometimes. (Sep 2, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

talkback n. NZ & Austral. broadcast programme in which listeners participate by telephoning the studio (an incensed caller on Radio Avon's Sunday night talkback). (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,783) [NOTES: HNZD1 [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 490]]

talkback radio¶

n.

It could be argued that talkback radio is democracy at work - even in action. (Aug 15, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

talkbacker¶

n. someone who phones in to a talkback show

The cricketers have gone on to win the acclaim of the radio talklbackers. (Dec 27, 1999,Dominion,37)

Talking Shop¶

n.

HYDE `Vox populi, vox dei.' You won't hear it at the Talking Shop, ... (1934,Journalese,40)

Talky-Talky¶

n.

Mr Jerningham Wakefield was christened "Talky-talky" because of his ability to talk any one of them to a standstill in half an hour. (Dec 23, 1890,Otago Witness,18)

Tall Blacks¶

n. the NZ men's basketball team

By sheer luck, I spotted him in the crowd at the Tall Blacks versus Canada basketball test in Auckland. (Jan 2000,North & South,78)

Basketball's Tall Blacks emphasised the folly of making such lists when they won their first two matches in the world championships in Indianapolis, performaces regarded as among New Zealand's finest sporting achievements. (Apr 4, 2002,Dominion Post,D9)

The apt Tall Blacks is recorded from 1995 for the men's basketball team. a men's ice hockey team played in 1998 under the name of Ice Blacks, and the Wheel Blacks travelled to Canada for the second wheelchair rugby World Cup in June 1998. (Jan 1999,NZWords,5)

The international series sees the Tall Ferns and the Tall Blacks take on India in three matches. (Mar 10, 2006,NZ Herald,Super Sport, D21)

[Winston's] so on the margins of the action these days, that even in Parliament - his natural habitat - it's like watching Ronnie Corbett playing Piggy in the Middle with a couple of Tall Blacks. (Apr 3, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

tall country¶

1 n. (Rural) high altitude mustering land.

MCMILLAN .. the legendary musterer, gone from the tall country. (1975,More From the High Country,44)

MCMILLAN I went to Glenorchy at the start of the week to muster tall country. (1981,Tales of the High Country,45)

Tall Ferns¶

n. the NZ women's basketball team (cf. Tall Blacks)

Meanwhile at least one more example established itself in 1999; the women's basketball team predictably blended the existing Tall Blacks and Silver Ferns to be known as Tall Ferns. (Aug 2000,NZWords,4 : 1)

She and Colling both made the Tall Ferns (the New Zealand Women's basketball team) before they made the Silver Ferns together in 1996. (Sep 1999,North & South,74)

The international series sees the Tall Ferns and the Tall Blacks take on India in three matches. (Mar 10, 2006,NZ Herald,Super Sport, D21)

tall poppy¶

v.

What this conference shows is you have a lot of interest in entrepreneurship. Don't tall poppy it, let them go, let them do their own thing. (Feb 20, 2000,Sunday Star Times,E1)

n. someone who stands out above others [aka taller poppy; OED online: b. Allusively, spec. as tall poppy: in Australia, an especially well-paid, privileged, or distinguished person; also transf.]

He was asked how he governed his people, and he went into his garden, taking a stick; he found there a tall poppy, and struck off its head, and said that was how he ruled his people. (Mar 27, 1886,Wanganui Herald,2)

The usually objective and witty Rosemary McLeod indulged in some tall poppy pruning recently in her criticism of Sandra Coney in North and South (July 1988). (Jan 7, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

The so-called tally [sic] poppy syndrome is a condition invented by celebrities to deflect the criticism they usually deserve. (Jan 21, 2001,Sunday Star Times,A8)

New Zealand is famous for cutting down tall poppies by means of the great clobbering machine. (Feb 28, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

When Team New Zealand won the America's Cup, not only did they get the keys to Auckland City, and for one or two entry to the rich list, they were also granted free life membership of the order of the tall poppy. (Jun 1999,Metro,39)

The present social system (he says) must go; the principal of authority must be pulled up by the roots; the tall poppies must be lopped. (Apr 12, 1900,NZ Tablet,17)

We most of us know, from reading or hearsay, the old story of the cutting off of the heads of the taller poppies, and, of course, understand the gist of the moral conveyed in the action. (Aug 22, 1874,Otago Witness,8)

The defendants include several "tall poppies," such as the millionaire J. Ogden Armour, Louis F. Swift, Edward F. Swift, and Edward Tilden. (Dec 23, 1911,Evening Post,8)

Undue exposure of their bodies to the enemy's fire, the more striking colours or adornments of their uniform, the nature of their work, and the well-known policy of lopping off the taller poppies in battle, has usually led to a higher relative mortality among officers than among men in almost every war. (Oct 26, 1899,NZ Tablet,1)

Shortish and sharp, Macdonald sees himself as one of the tall poppies of Otaki. (Mar 13, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),41)

Mary Cull, consultant with Tall Poppies, says people should now be encouraged even within organisations to see themselves as "Me Inc." (Feb 22, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

Some say she is a martyr to the feminist cause, a tall and brilliant poppy cut down by grey males. It's nonsense, but the nonsense will endure. (Aug 5, 2001,Sunday Star Times,A8)

One of the things that drives me nuts about this place, and I love it to bits, is the tall poppy. (Apr 8, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),71)

There's no such thing as a tall poppy playing rugby. (Aug 23, 1992,Dominion Sunday Times,11)

As a result, even the most devoted tall poppy potshotters could not quite get him clearly in their sights. (Jan 9, 2004,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,2)

They're so low-key about how good they are. It would be impossible for them to be tall poppies. (Nov 10, 2002,Sunday Star Times,F2)

Some people just can't stand you being better'n them. Tall rose syndrome or something. (Apr 11, 2002,Evening Post,8)

At some stage in this affair, I'll warrant, the terms "tall poppy syndrome" and "politics of envy" will get an airing. (Mar 6, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

This tall poppy business is tedious. If Martin is a poppy, he's no taller than John Kirwan.. Grant Fox and John Walker have been over the past few years. (Jun 25, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),61)

The tall poppy sydrome is a cliche used by many self-congratulating achievers in New Zealand. It seems to have become part of the ladder to the top to complain about how tall poppies are being chopped down. (Feb 11, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

(From the "SATURDAY REVIEW," September 10) .. It [The Order of the Garter] is a kind of public proclamation that you are a tall poppy; and that, as in these days your head cannot be struck off, it is worth while to buy you. (Dec 27, 1864,Daily Southern Cross,5)

n. [attrib]

You name it, New Zealand has an award for it. There's the incongruously named Tall Poppy Business Excellence Award to start with. (Aug 23, 2004,Dominion Post,C4)

Political correctness, tall poppy culling and - my favourite - the belief that being entitled to an opinion is an excuse for ignorance. (Sep 5, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C10)

tall poppy syndromer¶

n. person who attempts to bring down the cleverest, most powerful, or most successful person in a group

anyone who earns above the poverty line here is always a target of the tall poppy syndromers for being overpaid (Nov 14, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C13)

tall poppydom¶

n.

Maybe it's time for a kinder, gentler variety of tall poppydom. (Nov 7, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

tall poppyitis¶

n.

[Hdg] Paul's CD and tall poppyitis (Jan 14, 2001,Sunday Star Times,A8)

tall tussock¶

n. = snow tussock

Most tall tussocks mast synchronously throughout their range, from red tussock on the valley flats to the slim snow tussock (C. macra) in the alpine zone. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/35)

The genus Chioonochloa (chion = snow;chloa = grass) includes the snow tussocks, or tall tussocks - up to 2 metres high - that make up the grand, golden army that dominates our subalpine grasslands, furring the hills a tawny gold and forming a magnificent backdrop for beer and car commercials. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/28)

...the larvae of tussock butterflies (Argyrophenga spp.) feed on silver and tall tussocks, whereas Butler's ringlets (Erebiola butleri) sticks to low alpine Chionochloa species in the wetter western South Island mountains. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/43)

tall-poppy¶

adj.

It's a powerful study of two long-parted brothers reunited and conflicting as they journey to their father's tangi. But the tall-poppy knives are going to be out, Strang acknowledges. (Apr 22, 2001,Sunday Star Times,F1)

tall-poppy cutter¶

n.

The sooner we get rid of the poppy-cutting machine and the gun we hold to shoot ourselves in the foot, the better. (Jan 23, 2002,Dominion,13)

[Hadlee] is our greatest wicket taker and arguably the best middle order batsman we have produced. As such he should be cannon fodder for the Tall Poppy Cutter, right? (Jan 24, 2001,Capital Times,4)

These carping, tall poppy cutters will doubtless dismiss any likening of the passing persecution of newsreaders with the decades-long detention of the living symbol of the antiapartheid movement. (Jun 27, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C10)

tall-poppy lopper¶

n.

In typical New Zealand fashion the tall poppy loppers have started whinging about being bored seeing the confident, professional, remorseless way the Black Magic boat crew goes about its business. (Apr 2000,North & South,8)

tall-poppy puller¶

n.

He says his humble background helps lessen the attacks from tall-poppy pullers. (Aug 10, 2004,Dominion Post,A2)

tall-poppy topper¶

n.

Your correspondent.. appears to be one of these tall poppy-toppers with loppers in hand. (Feb 12, 2001,Evening Post,4)

tall-poppy-bashing¶

n.

There's a part of me, that cynical, tall-poppy bashing bit so characteristic of New Zealanders that assumed I'd take a few swipes at the clothes, at the exhibition, at some little discordant thing. But I can't. (Apr 9, 2001,Evening Post,4)

It's joined our alltime favourite [art form] of tall-poppy-bashing, which has given many a lot of pleasure for years - chopping down those who dare to rise above the grey clouds of normality only to draw attention and criticism upon themselves from the unadoring crowd below. (Feb 12, 2002,Evening Post,17)

tall-poppy-chopping/-scything¶

adj.

I'll take negative things that happen around me in this tall-poppy-chopping country and thrive on them. (Aug 13, 2000,Sunday Star Times,F3)

And that, I think, is why I'm pleased that Mr Fossett failed in his mission. Plus, of course, a deep-seated, tall-poppy-scything, thwarted, splenetic, mean-spirited pleasure in someone else's disappointment. (Aug 22, 2001,Evening Post,10)

tall-poppy-lopping¶

n.

My friends say there has not been such a frenzy of tall-poppy-lopping in living memory; they are utterly bewildered by its ferocity. (Aug 20, 2000,Sunday Times (UK)) [NOTES: Robert Hughes talking about Australia]

n.

The flip-side of tall-poppyism is a gracious good-sportiness that sees both winner and loser applauded as they depart and return. (Mar 4, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

adj.
