talleyman¶

n.

MUNRO, D.J. & P.J. The railway wagon, of course, has long since gone, and the fish is landed at the fish "centre": and transported rapidly to the markets in Dunedin, or elsewhere, or to cool or frozen stores , by motor transport. For many years., the "talleyman", whom the Society engaged to do just that, was an important figure. But sometime he, apparently, might have "slipped a bit", according to the minutes! (1984,History of Port Chalmers Fishermen's Co-operative,35)

tallie¶

n. a tall bottle of beer (?750ml)

At half time a couple of crates of tallies would be trotted out for each team and they never came back with any full bottles. (2001,Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success,235)

tallow-wood¶

n. eucalyptus 1884

(Nov 1958,NZ Timber Journal,62)

tallowy¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of sale stock] esp. fat.

Heavy and tallowy types were in the discard at prices 3/- to 6/- easier. (Dec 20, 1951,NZ Farmer,46)

tally¶

n. (Rural) a hundred sheep.

.. in the happy camaderie of shed life, where toil is plenty and the little rest doubly appreciated, the general remarks revealed ambitions for 'tallies' in the afternoon. (Mar 1, 1946,Ex-Pupils Budget,11)

LOUGHNAN a hundred sheep. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,83 (i))

(1) A hundred sheep. When large mobs are counted the man counting calls out T[ally].!' every time he gets to 100, and then starts again. Another man answersT.' and cuts a notch in a stick. When the whole mob is counted the number of notches gives the hundreds and the odd number completes the total, which is also (2) called the t. 3. The total number of sheep shorn by each shearer in a day. 4. Hence t.book, in which the man who counts out, writes them down. 5. The ts. for the day before are written up each morning on a tally board kept in the shed. (C.) (Dec 23, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

n.

FERNANDEZ He had left the tally to Guy while he ransacked in the store for a spark plug .. (1973,Tussock Fever,33)

n.

n. [meat works; cf TALLY-SPEED] (See cut tally)

COLIN GORDON Tally: You cut tally if you get 100 per man, and you drop so many off the tally for stags (one-ball sheep) and rams (the penises and balls of both these are cut out, and this is how one counts them; pizzles (undeveloped penises) are cut off wethers. (May 17, 1951,Personal Communication) [NOTES: Feilding Freezing Works terms p.c.]

WILSON It is a mechanical business ..., slaughtering [62] by thousands, ... tinning the tongues, freezing the carcases, and tying them up in their little, white muslin shrouds, to be `tallied' and shipped to England, ... (1894,In the Land of the Tui,61) [NOTES: 1890 Feb 8 in 1894 Wilson Land of the Tui 61-62]

n. the amount of work done in a given time

The demand is even more urgent than usual as the threshing season has been fine and short straw has enabled mills to make quick work. Record tallies for a day's work have been made. (Mar 22, 1911,Grey River Argus,1)

BATHGATE ... any good tallies, boys. (1913,Sodger Sandy's Bairn,71)

LEE They would work with a will for an hour or two at the outside [at gorse-cutting]. And their tally was good. (1944,Shining with the Shiner,136)

THOMSON He will help our tally along if we have a bad spell; ... (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,21)

SUTHERLAND Some of the high tallies taken in the early days of the so-called `culling' operations in the great snow-grass basins of the southern Alps and elsewhere show that the shooters learned the wisdom of concentrating their fire on the leader hinds .. (1953,Golden Bush, The,69,1963 ed.)

CRUMP Stan said that a dog that chases deer on your block can cost you half your tally because it makes them more wary and difficult to catch. ...[25] I had a tally of 185 deer. (1961,Good Keen Man, A,21)

v. (Rural) [shearing] to reach a total.

RICHARDS By the end of the day Bluey had shorn 285 and I tallied 303. (1991,Off the Sheep's Back,83)

WILSON The silly creatures run and jump through [the gate], being counted or `tallied' whilst they are skipping into another enclosure. (1894,In the Land of the Tui,243)

Packs and loads of skins tallying over 100lbs. are far from easy to carry over vestigial tracks. (Apr 8, 1953,Freedom,5)

n. [nf AND] spec. uses of OED vb ? (in the general sense of `counting a number of objects individually and entering the numbers up, or marking them off': e.g. tally cargo, etc) esp. by shearers, freezing workers, storemen; cf also EDD 7. A specified number or weight; in hop-picking, the number of bushels for which the picker receives a shilling. Glo Lon Sur Also vb. [(cf TALLY n1)]

(1953,Short Stories (various authors),215) [NOTES: a1927 1938 Antony Me and Gus in 1953 Short Stories 215]

BOWEN (1956,Wool Away!)

NEWTON Tally: To tally is to count sheep. When counting big mobs, one man does the counting, and at each hundred he calls `Tally'. Another man keeps the tallies - at each call he may cut a notch in a stick or pick out a small pebble. The tally book contains a record of sheep counted during the year. (1966,Boss's Story, The,190)

n. [count of prisoners]

HYDE .. hot contests ranging between gangs of soldiers as they scored up their tallies. (Aug 1936,Passport to Hell,94)

MacKENZIE tally count of prisoners (1980,While We Have Prisons,98)

v. (Rural) to count sheep.

NEWTON Carefully the mob was 'tallied' through the gateway. (1949,High Country Days,114)

RICHARDS With the sheep tallied and safely paddocked for the night, dogs, horses and riders faced a tiring ride home. (1991,Off the Sheep's Back,53)

n. (Rural) a total number of sheep shorn by a shearer in one day

A shearer's tally is not just the basis on which he is paid, it affects his ranking in the gang. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,84)

FERNANDEZ The pumice in the wool played up with the gear, blunted the cutters and combs, ruined a man's tally .. Better beat the gong if he wanted a good tally. (1973,Tussock Fever,17)

LOUGHNAN all a shearer's sheep shorn in a day. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,83 (iii))

RICHARDS Bluey and I were determined to try and equal his tally if we got some good cutting sheep. (1991,Off the Sheep's Back,82)

"That will do," said Brice, quite quiet; "close your shears and leave the shed." / Dick stopped swearing, took to sneering - "You don't mean it now," he said! / "I came here to get a tally, not to knuckle down to you; / You may take it how you fancy, but I mean to see them through " (Sep 3, 1896,Otago Witness,41)

Under the heading of "Large Shearing Tallies" one of your correspondents, signing himself "Manager," makes such a gross misstatement re the tallies on this station that I cannot allow it to pass unchallenged. (Feb 9, 1884,Otago Witness,14)

And they'll be talking up at Laghmor of the tallies that were shore,/ (Oct 15, 1896,Otago Witness) [NOTES: 1896 Oct 15 Otago Witness in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 131]

WOODHOUSE For Barcoo Ben will run him and half a dozen more/ Of the lank Australian crush upon the board,/ And it ain't no use to tell us of tallies that he shore,/ There'll be records broke this year, you take my word./ (1950,Farm & Station Verse,33) [NOTES: 1897 McKee Wright Station Ballads `Shearing' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 33]

BAUGHAN I've scored my last tally, I've done my last dip / ... there's no crutching aboard of a ship. (1903,Reuben & Other Poems,85)

BOWEN Climatic conditions, the treatment sheep have had in the months before shearing, and the breeds of the sheep all play a big part in a shearer's tally. For this reason a shearer's tally can fluctuate considerably, depending on the type of sheep he is shearing. It is a mistake for young shearers to make `tally' paramount in their ambition to progress in shearing when quality of work would have to be the first point taken into account. Ibid. 157 TALLY. The number of sheep a shearer does in a day. (1955,Wool Away!,2)

Tally: The number of sheep shorn during a run or other specified period. However, the general term is also used to describe a shearer's capacity to shear in a day. E.g. `He has a tally of 120.' (Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing)]

TALLY: The number of sheep shorn during a run or other specified period. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20)

CHARLES When the shearing season is over you will hear the ringers boast/ About their shearing tallies and the big cheques they have made/ (1981,Black Billy Tea,28)

HENDERSON He knocked up excellent tallies on neighbouring shearingboards, . (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,15)

tally ... 6. Austral. & N.Z. the number of sheep shorn in a specified period. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1193) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 784]]

OGONOWSKA-COATES Tally. The total number of sheep shorn by a shearer in a day. (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,98)

WOODHOUSE ... Close your shears and leave the shed.'/ Dick stopped swearing, took to sneering -You don't mean it now!' he said./ I came here to get a tally, not to knuckle down to you;/ <i>(1950,Farm & Station Verse,31</i>) [NOTES: 1897 McKee Wright Station Ballads 34 (?35)The Bloke That Ran across a Snag' (also in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 31]

RICHARDS I expected immediately to ... shear big tallies as my first step towards becoming a top shearer... I had plenty of time to stroll down the board to watch Fred's movements and still cut my tally (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,75)

MIDDLETON Reg was our fastest shearer. For a few days George ... put up some high tallies, but ... he dropped back to 200. (1959,Stone, The,43)

tally: The term for the number of sheep shorn. Each shearer has his personal tally for the `run', the day, and his final tally for the shed. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/28) [NOTES: Wallace Shearing Glossary]

PEACHE ... 100 sheep a day is quite an ordinary shearer's tally ... But the machine does far better work and neither cuts the sheep nor the fleece (i.e. second cut, or cutting the fleece, or staple of the wool). (Apr 20, 1890,Journal) [NOTES: 1890 Apr 20 letter Peache Jnl in 1970 Gray Quiet with the Hills 82]

n. count

1 n. (Rural) a number of stock in a count

BATHGATE ... he had only to make a mark on a rail each time 'tally' was called. (1881,Waitaruna,70)

SWANTON .. the shed boss who looks after everything, takes the tally ... (1892,Notes on NZ,97)

LOUGHNAN The total, i.e. all the hundreds and part-hundreds counted. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,83 (ii))

ASPINALL Short tallies entailed another trip loooking for stragglers. (1993,Farming Under Aspiring,183)

Cut and tailed 130 Ewe ... lambs drafted off Hoggits - tally of whole flock ... 1813. (Aug 30, 1860,Puketoi Station Diary)

NEWTON Tally: To tally is to count sheep. When counting big mobs, one man does the counting, and at each hundred he calls `Tally.' Another man keeps the tallies - at each call he may cut cut a notch in a stick or pick out a small pebble. The tally book contains a record of sheep counted during the year. (1949,High Country Days,197)

2 n. during a run, or for a specified period (often a day), or for the whole of a woolshed job [1965 see cit. a. above]

2 n. [number of sheep]

CASEY I had a tally of eight hundred when I crutched them June last year, ... (1963,As Short a Spring,161)

FERNANDEZ He pushed his completed, naked sheep through his legs and out the porthole then paused to change his cutter. The pumice in the wool played up with the gear, blunted the cutter and combs, ruined a man's tally; ... (1973,Tussock Fever,3)

Number of sheep shorn by a shearer or a gang in a day, or the number of sheep in a group. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,60)

2 n. [the record of number of sheep, usually but not exclusively shearing context]

MEREDITH As I was finishing the counting-out, the boss came towards the shed with a couple of towels in his hand and invited me to come for a swim. I said I would join him as soon as I had all the tallies. The two ringer contestants then called to him, `We're going.'. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,144) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 144]

RICHARDS ... Bob Hadfield was asked to make up the tallies. When these were completed and each shearer's account had been made up, John produced his chequebook ... (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,68)

2 v. [to number]

2 n.

3 n. to shear (and get paid for) a number of sheep [to sort incompatible word class and defn]

4 n. . [(playing) truant; ?or n1 f. teachers taking a `tally' of attenders]

She said she had great difficulty in getting the eldest boy, Thomas, to school, and he frequently played "tally" when she had sent him there. (Sep 14, 1891,Star, The,3)

He couldn't run about and play with other boys, or bowl a hoop through the window of the grocer's shop at the corner, or fight Billy Ah Sin for "shaking" his alley tawr, or land home from an orchard expedition with the rear guard of his pants cut to ribbons, or play tally or anything else worth while. (Mar 16, 1912,Evening Post,3)

"I were fishin' yesterday," he said slowly, "and I met Mr Crayley, and he sez, sez he, 'If I catch you playing tally again I'll inform yer parents!' sez he." (Apr 1, 1903,NZ Illustrated Magazine,36)

SUTTON-SMITH Playing the wag was very common. We made for the bush, but it was difficult to time one's arrival at home correctly (1875; Dunedin) We called it `playing tally.' (1875; Wakefield) (1981,History of Children's Play,41)

7 n.

8 n. number of animals trapped

A Tawa Flat settler has so far got a tally of over 200 fish for the season, most of which were caught in the Porirua stream. (Nov 21, 1908,Marlborough Express,14)

Some very good slaughtering tallies have been put up at the Longburn works this season. (Feb 21, 1914,Evening Post,6)

HELMER No enormous tallies of deer shot; no fantastic shots pulled off a fantastic ranges; no shrieking blizzards or raging floods to battle for survival in; no life-risking bravery... (1964,Stag Party,6)

CURRIE And the fork tines flash as the sheaves are turned on the frame of the one-horse dray; .. the long trap-line; / The tallies are big on the rock-strewn spur ... (1949,Centennial Treasury of Otago Verse,58)

tally board¶

n. [(cf TALLY n 1.) 1933 Acland]

1 n. (Rural) a woolshed blackboard on which all shearing tallies or totals to date in a season are recorded.

MEEK With age for age there's few could top that on the tally board ... (1952,Station Days in Maoriland,71)

LOUGHNAN tally board: each morning the shearers arrive and see, hanging up in the shed, the tally board. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,83)

Seventeen clauses will be referred to the Arbitration Court for settlement. Summarised, they are as follows .. 34. Supply of tally board ... (Dec 1, 1910,Poverty Bay Herald,5)

BOWEN A very good practice is to have the tally board hanging up on the wall where all the shearers on that particular board can see it, allowing them at any time of the day to know how their tally is progressing. (1955,Wool Away!,97)

tally book¶

n.

tally book: The official record of what every man has shorn in each run of the day. It is made after the run by checking each shearer's counting out oen before clearing for the next session. Each shearer's tally for the day is then transferred to the tally book. In earlier times a `tally board' was used with the previous day's tallies chalked up. No matter whether the book or the board is used, the tallies must be displayed in the shed. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/28) [NOTES: Wallace Shearing Glossary]

MEREDITH I said nothing, put my tally-book in my pocket, and followed the boss. ... I told him I had docked a few sheep [from the tallies] for bad shearing and cutting. (station) (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,144) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 144]

(also Newton) (1933,Press, The) [NOTES: ACLAND]

FERNANDEZ The shearers untied the greasy, sacking slippers they wore on the board, ... then gathered around for a look at the tally book. (1973,Tussock Fever,13)

RICHARDS When Fred looked at the tally book at lunch time, I was only eight behind Thornton. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,76)

1 n. (Rural) a small notebook used by farmers or shearing-gang contractors to record stock numbers.

MEREDITH As I was finishing the counting-out the boss came towards the sheep. I said nothing, put my tally-book in my pocket and followed the boss. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,144) [NOTES: (1935)]

BARNS-GRAHAM Dad goes out with the 'tally' book for the final count of the day. (1950,Sheep Station New Zealand,62)

NEWTON In 1885, which is as far as this particular tally book goes ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,30)

NEWTON There were the tally books, covering over 100 years of shearing ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,33)

LOUGHNAN tally book: the sheep are counted out after each shearing run, and each man's tally is written down. At the end of the day these are added up to make his day's tally .. copied out of the tally book, everybody's total for the previous day. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,83)

SALISBURY soon as the last sheep of the run was shorn, Mr Williams would count the sheep from the counting-pens, recording each man's tally in the shearers' tally book. (1994,I Was So Lucky,26)

The next question as to the number shorn and wages earned, was soon ascertained by reference to the tally books, which Mr Fox produced. (Jan 7, 1892,Otago Witness,6)

tally clerk¶

n.

He finished his working life as a tally clerk at the Westfield freezing works. (Jun 1998,Cuisine,No. 22: 6)

The special holiday provisions under existing legislation for waterside workers and tally clerks are extended to apply to shipwrights and ships' carpenters engaged in the preparation of ships for cargo or in the loading or unloading of cargo. (Aug 8, 1945,Evening Post,6)

The employers had once again complained about an increase in wharf thefts and the Court wanted tally clerks, whose duty it was to detect and prevent pilfering, to be free of any union control or interference. (1993,Wharfie,p26)

Some of the tally clerks employed on the wharves declined to start work this morning under the present pay of 1s 3d an hour, considering it worth as much as the waterside workers, who under the new award, will receive 1s 5d per hour from Thursday. (Feb 6, 1912,Grey River Argus,5)

Tally clerks are steadily increasing in numbers on the Queen's Wharf, and the latest step has been the formation of a union under the title of the Wellington Tally Clerks' Association. (Jan 29, 1907,Evening Post,4)

A tally clerk named Pollock working on the breakwater received severe injuries by a heavy sling. (Jun 22, 1885,Grey River Argus,2)

A well attended meeting of tally clerks connected with shipping in the port, was held last night, when it was decided to form a New Zealand Federated Marine Tally Clerks' Union, and to apply to the Maritime Council for affiliation. (Jul 16, 1890,Timaru Herald,3)

BOWEN When `runs' are finished the tally clerk should be ready to tally sheep out, for when the run is finished, a shearer likes to know how he has been going. (1955,Wool Away!,97)

tally clerk n. N.Z. & Austral. a person, esp. on a wharf, who checks the count of goods being loaded or unloaded. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1193)

The use of waterside workers as tally clerks should be discontinued. (Sep 4, 1952,North & South,8)

He was working.. as a tally clerk on the wharf. (Oct 21, 1924,Otago Witness,54)

tally clerking¶

v.

He found himself at a loose end and so did some part-time tally clerking on the wharf. (Jan 2000,North & South,53)

tally counter¶

1 n. (Rural) a mechanical counter attached to the outside of a shearer's catching-pen.

WILLIAMS As the shearer passes through the gate [of the catching pen] he presses his tally counter. (1999,Tales from the Shearing Shed,16)

tally out¶

v.

Taking into account the number of sheep shorn, the clip may be regarded as a fair one, though as in former seasons, taking the district through, a considerable number are missing compared with those tallied out last fall. (Feb 28, 1885,Otago Witness,12)

Witness said he could shear if he liked: he shore a few sheep but they were tallied out to the other shearers. (May 14, 1897,Clutha Leader,5)

Docking is now well over, and the percentage of lambs is fairly good, considering the rough nature of the country on which many of the flocks of this district run. I heard of two lots tallying out at 100 per cent., but generally the figures range from 80 to 94 per cent., this in most cases slightly exceeding the percentages of last year. (Nov 4, 1909,Hawera & Normanby Star,6)

Members cannot be yarded like cattle, and tallied out just at the pleasure of the "whips" at the critical moment of a division. (Oct 12, 1878,Tuapeka Times,2)

BOWEN When `runs' are finished the tally clerk should be ready to tally sheep out, for when the run is finished, a shearer likes to know how he has been going. (1955,Wool Away!,97)

tally pen¶

1 n. (Rural) a counting-out pen used in drafting or shearing.

BOWEN This is why a lot of tally pens and yards holding freshly-crutched sheep present the appearance of a fall of snow ... (1955,Wool Away!,65)

.. pushed the shorn sheep from between my legs and down the short, steep race leading to the tally pen. (Jan 2, 1963,Weekly News,32)

It is an internal chute shed with tally pens under the floor. (Dec 31, 1964,NZ Farmer,6)

The building is conventional in floor layout, with the woolroom and catching pens elevated to give full headroom to tally-pens and night-pens underneath. (May 8, 1969,NZ Farmer,2)

It is also so arranged that it may be easily filled with machines by the addition of a beam over the tally pen doors. (Nov 5, 1897,Hawke's Bay Herald,4)

The Commissioner of Crown Lands notifies that the Starborough woolshed, men's hut and tally pens will be sold by auction in the township on the 1st May. (Apr 21, 1900,Marlborough Express,2)

BOWEN Tally pens should be large enough, where possible to hold one run of sheep. (1955,Wool Away!,97)

FERNANDEZ In his tally pen ... [the roughly-shorn sheep] looked a speckled mess, their injuries daubed with tar to keep the flies off. (1973,Tussock Fever,13)

tally stick¶

n.

HARPER The sheep came out with a run through a narrow gate in the yard, and, after the manner of sheep, hesitating, rushing, jumping over each other, whilst on one side I stood, with a smooth stick and a knife, ready to make one notch for every ten, and two for every hundred, as they passed me. Opposite me the purchaser's shepherd did the same. Both our tally sticks were found to correspond, to my no small satisfaction. (Sep 1, 1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,23,1914 ed.)

tally up¶

v.

THOMSON On tallying up our kill we found we had shot seventeen beasts ... (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,185)

1 n. (Rural) a count of stock.

ANDERSON Bill and I will go over on Monday and have a good tally up. (1962,Life's Roundabout, A,68)

tally-speed¶

n. the working-speed of a chain

COLIN GORDON Tally-speed for a 34-man chain say 8 a minute is the speed of the chain which all would be expected to keep up with. (May 17, 1951,Personal Communication) [NOTES: Feilding Freezing Works]

tallyplate¶

n.

A leather ticket or a tin tallyplate is considered too commonplace for these aesthetic travellers. (May 21, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,21)

talofa lava¶

exclam. greetings [ORIGIN: Samoan]

Kia Ora, Talofa Lava and Warm Pacific Greetings. (Oct 5, 2005,Northern Courier,7)

Ihimaera 'Talofa lava,' she calls cheerily. 'Welcome home. Did you had a nice trips?' Sofia has a problem with tenses and also the singular and plural. (2007,Ask the Posts,45)

tama¶

n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of ryegrass (Lolium multiflorum). [ORIGIN: Maori]

NEWTON The present practice is to grow about 250 acres of Tama and this is supplemented with lucerne hay. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,242)

When the maize has been taken off he has sown an area of turnips and another of tama for winter feed. (Jan 1977,NZ Dairy Exporter,21)

Ken Brown (of the DSIR Grasslands Division) propounded the philosophy that the heavier the weight in a bushel of tama, the better the establishment of the resultant crop. (Mar 22, 1979,NZ Farmer,25)

Northland dairy farmer Doug Taylor includes tama with nui ryegrass when oversowing paddocks. (Jul 1983,NZ Dairy Exporter,5)

Bought a 19001 portable trough to use on the tama over the winter. (Jun 20, 2000,Waikato Times,5)

Tama is mown for silage. (Oct 2000,Waikato Times,24)

One variation is the sowing of chicory in spring which is then undersown with tama ryegrass to provide pasture. (Oct 26, 2001,Dominion,17)

Annual grasses, such as Tama and Moata, with high metabolisable energy values, are grazed throughout the winter. (Apr 12, 2001,NZ Farmer,31)

n. son

MASON PERA. ... There's two or three little tamas round here can call him Dad if they want to. (1969,Awatea,22,1978 ed.)

BUCK3/340 (1949,Coming of the Maori, The)

tamaiti¶

n.

McCRAE Pomarre[acute] .. .. Rungatyeeda no te Kaaingha. E Wharre[acute] .. .. Whaheene[acute] no Pomarre[acute]. Poaka .. .. Tamyte[acute] no Pomarre[acute]. ... E Po .. .. Koeteedo no Pomarre Whaheene no Tenana. (1820,Journal,27,1928 ed.)

child - tama|i|t [tamaiti] (1835,Boultbee Journal,109,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 109]

MOSER ... the journey itself would at least cost him three days travelling, on acount of the tamaitis (children), who were not strong enough to walk ... (1863,Mahoe Leaves,30)

I started for New Plymouth, got medecine for Roka and a small tomite and sent it back from Waitara. (Aug 8, 1878,Chudleigh Diary,271,1950 ed.)

I called out to the man. Have you seen my Tomaiti. Yes we have she is in the house. (Dec 10, 1889,Chudleigh Diary,398,1950 ed.) [NOTES: check date]

child; root tama, son. (Jun 1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157) [NOTES: J.C.Andersen]

HULME 178 Tamaiti = child (1983,Bone People, The,467)

ROSIER-JONES She is enveloped by Aunty's flesh. Warm, sweet-smelling. `You are my darling tamaiti, my darling child.' (1985,Cast Two Shadows,52)

n. a child, a boy [ORIGIN: Maori, cf. tama]

AS A TAMAITI, 25-YEAR-OLD MANU BURKHARDT MACRAE WAS ALWAYS INTERESTED IN BUILDING THINGS AND FINDING OUT HOW THEY WORKED. (2005,Te Mana Taiohi,issue 18 summer 2005 / 2006, p12)

Ihimaera ed. 'Oh my boy,' she sighed forlornly, rocking him. 'What are you doing to yourself, eh? What are you doing, tamaiti?' (2007,Get on the Waka,120) [NOTES: (Kingi McKinnon)]

tamaiti, child; root tama, son. (1956,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/157) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

tamariki¶

n. children [ORIGIN: Maori]

Due to recent expansions we now have vacancies for Tamariki aged 0 - 2 years & Tamariki aged 2 - 5 years (Jan 17, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,10)

ELDER I told you when you were at Parramatta I would send you a gentleman to teach your tameheekes (tamarikis) and koctecdos (kotiros) to read. (1934,Marsden's Lieutenants,58)

A dense crowd of rangatahi, kuia, kaumatua, tamariki, people in cheelchairs, and supporters of many ethnicities backed up the advances of a barefoot warrior / kaitiaki... Parents responded by wrapping their tamariki up warm, and keeping them moving as the sky cried above. (May 3, 2004,Salient,8/52)

His Worship the Mayor Sir Barry Curtis, Deputy Mayor Anne Candy, Manukau City Coucillors, City Manager Colin Dale, Director of City Services Wayne Goodley and council staff, extend all their aroha and awhinatia to John's whanau, especially his hoa wahine Raiha, tamariki and mokopuna. (Dec 6, 2005,NZ Herald,C8)

The chief.. claimed us part and parcel of his tribe, said we were his '' tamariki: (children) and bosom friends. (Aug 28, 1890,Otago Witness,36)

'You may not realise it,' says Ronald, 'but falls are the main reason why our tamariki aged 1-14 years and our kaumatua end up in hospital.' (2008,Mana,85/56)

Loving father to all his tamariki and his Australian and New Zealand mokopuna. (Feb 24, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,46)

The successful applicant will have the following skills and attributes: Have a passion to work with tamariki... (Aug 10, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,12)

The chief and members of the tribe intend in true Maori fashion to give a hearty harema [haere mai] to their Rangatira, who left them as a tamariki and now returns in the full bloom of early manhood. (Oct 17, 1904,West Coast Times,4)

We hear the Bishop was badly treated by his tamariki. (Sep 5, 1855,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

KEENE tamariki: children. (1963,O Te Raki,194)

n. a child (See tama,tamaiti)

COLLINS E-Ta-ma-ree-kee[acute], A young man. (1804,English Colony in NSW,562)

ELDER I told you when you were at Parramatta I would send you a gentleman to teach your tameheekes (tamarikis) and koctecdos (kotiros) to read. (Mar 9, 1814,Marsden's Lieutenants,58,1934 ed.)

boy - tama|rique [tamariki] (1835,Boultbee Journal,109,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 109]

ANGAS The tamarikis (children) set to work endeavouring to delineate each other, and one boy drew my likeness ... with a piece of charcoal. (1847,Savage Life,2/102)

[The Maori elders] declined the discussion, & told us to wait for the morrow, when the young men would be ready to explain &c. Having quoted Rehoboam's case on the danger of making tamarikis counsellors, I left .. (1860,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/562) [NOTES: (Rev. R. Maunsell)]

TINNE Fancy these tamariki, piccaninnies or brats of one or two years old, indulging ... in the herb nicotiana. (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,9)

Warriors, Wahines, Kuri, Poaka, Tamariki, Kumeras, Karos, Interpreters (1st, 2nd and 3rd grade), Poets Laureate, Poi Dancers, Guides, &c. on application to the Registrar. ...WAIPIRO - - An acursed drink ... TAIHOA - - The Police have the matter in hand POAKA - -a pig PUKEKO A bokakker out of season KORERO A long talk UTU - - The spike HAPU - - A Tribe KUMERA - - A sweet Spud (1913,Auckland University Carnival Book,27)

LANCASTER Seeing a plug of the Major's best tobacco on the table, Nene suddenly descended from his dignity. `A chew, now, Mahore, and I will take the tamariki home.' (1938,Promenade,58)

GVRIEVE `I think the tamariki burn him.' [fn] Tamariki - children. (1939,Sketches from Maoriland,110,1961 ed.)

HOWE Tamariki, Tamarikitanga - children were traditionally openly cared for, and shared particularly by both parents and grandparents; they had the advantage of being able to expect similar care and protection from not just close kin, but other parents within the hapu (larger kinship group). They were encouraged to become independent and responsible as quickly as possible. One detrimental effect of urbanisation on the economic realities of today is the breakdown evident in such caring. (1985,Towards Taha Maori,22)

tamarikitanga¶

n. (See tamariki)

tamarillo¶

n. (formerly in New Zealand called tree tomato) a bright red, subtropical fruit grown on a small tree. [pl. -os]

The tamarillo, it seems, is still a fruit New Zealand has largely to itself, for though it is grown in private gardens around the world in warm frost-free places like California, South Africa, Asia and Africa, only here is it cultivated systematically on a commercial scale... In the 1880s, Mr D Morris, director of the Botanbical Gardens in Jamaica, sent seeds to the hill districts of India and Sri Lanka, and it was from northern India that the first seeds were sent to New Zealand, to Hay and Sons, nurserymen of Parnell in Auckland. The Hay's 1891-1892 catalogue states that the nursery then had "plants of strong and healthy appearance" for sale... The name "tamarillo" officially came into being on January 31, 1967, after New Zealand exporters decided a more romantic, exotic name was needed than "tree tomato". The strategy worked, and today tamarillo seems to have become the accepted name internationally. (Jun 12, 2004,Dominion Post,E8)

He cites the economic potential of the pepino on a par with the tamarillo. (Jun 1982,Orchardist NZ,143)

On February 1, 1967, the name tamarillo officially replaced tree tomato. (Feb 1967,Orchardist NZ,23)

The tamarillo or tree tomato, Cyphomandra betacea Sendt.. is a native of Brazil and Peru. (Jun 1970,Orchardist NZ,149)

YEREX Tamarillos have been around for a long time and do quite well on the local market. (1988,Best of Both Worlds,109)

We're [sc. the Rural Bank] also financing orchids, carnations and roses for export.. even sub-tropical fruits such as tamarillos, persimmons, avocados and kiwifruit. (Apr 6, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),72)

BURTON A native of the Andean region of Peru and of southern Brazil, the tamarillo is the only one of the 30 species of its genus, Cyphomandra, to be widely known...It was from northern India that the first seeds were sent to New Zealand, in 1891, to D. Hay & Sons, nurserymen of Parnell, Auckland. (1985,Delectable Fruits Cookery,145)

Gently peel the tamarillos then carefully slide them into the simmering syrup. (Sep 1999,Cuisine,No. 76 : 86)

The Sex Kitten uses perfectly ripe tamarillos, blended with homemade vanilla sugar syrup and extra vanilla scraped from the pod, strained and frozen into ice cubes. (Sep 11, 2003,Dominion Post,D1)

Although it sounds Spanish, the name 'tamarillo' is another New Zealand invention. The former name 'tree tomato', was considered inappropriate for use overseas where people buying the fruits for the first time might expect them to taste like tomatoes. In 1967, orchardist Bill Thomson took the Maori word 'tama' added 'tillo' (taken from tomatillo, a complete unrelated Mexican fruit) and then (just to make the sound more mellifluous) he replaced 't' with an 'r'. Thus, 'tamarillo' was born. (Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,58)

So if you are a true New Zealander who enjoys cutting a tamarillo in half and scooping out the juicy flesh straight into your mouth, there is still plenty of time for this refreshing tonic. (Aug 20, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

(Oct 12, 1966,NZ News,6/2)

(Oct 9, 1968,NZ News)

The currency of tree tomato (p. 263) might also owe something to New Zealand, where the tree is well known and has always been called tree tomato (until in 1967 the growers decided to change the name to tamarillo, thought to be a better name for publicity). (1968,Anglia,86/359) [NOTES: G.W.Turner review Pitcairnese Language]

(Jul 23, 1969,NZ News,4/5)

MITCHELL So the N.Z.B.C. was treated like the tamarillo (nee tree tomato): the name was changed and the creature kept the same. (1972,Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The,124)

... other subtropical fruits such as passionfruit, Chinese gooseberries, feijoas, and tamarillos (formerly called `tree tomatoes'). (1974,NZ Agriculture,126)

Supplies of tropical fruits were curtailed because of the Japanese threats to the sea lanes, and tamarillo (or tree tomato as they were then known) growing began in earnest. [WWII] Ibid. 141 An uncultivated native of the Andes region of Peru, the tamarillo is also found wild in India, Sri Lanka and parts of South East Asia. It was from the hilly regions of northern India that New Zealand's first seeds came, introduced by the Auckland nursery of D. Hay and Sons in 1891. At first only the yellow and purple varieties were grown and it was not until the end of World War I that the now almost universal red variety was bred at Mangere, Auckland. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,31)

Two well-known New Zealand exports, neither of them native, are tree-tomatoes and Chinese gooseberries, but neither is called that by the exporters. The tomatoes are a South American fruit, a rich source of vitamin C and long popular in New Zealand. About twenty years ago, the name tamarillo was deliberately contrived, much as a brand name is. On the basis of tomato, a diminutive -ill- was added; then tomatillo was altered, in honor of a legendary Maori tribal hero, Tama-te-kapua, to tamatillo; and then a change to tamarillo was considered more euphonious. And so a new word was born. (1985,Verbatim,2/11) [NOTES: (G.W.Turner)]

tamarillo n. (pl. tamarillos) subtropical tree with bright red fruit; this fruit. [invented word] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,784) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 490]]

Too late in the day for kiwifruit of course but there was still a European market out there for tamarillos. (1987,Metro Fiction,13) [NOTES: (O'Sullivan Wonderland)]

n.

How she must have shuddered when newspapers referred to the Crusaders' red of her suit as trendy tamarillo, when obviously the imagery she wanted was sav in tomato sauce. (Sep 2, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

LAW Spiced Tamarillo Mould. The strong colour and flavour of tamarillos make an exciting jelly to serve on its own or with plain mousse or ice-cream. (1988,Dessert Cookbook, A,31)

Nowadays, having sold his engineering business, Mr Brown runs his property company largely from the office in his home on a tamarillo orchard. (Jul 15, 2000,Dominion,20)

[Hdg] Regrets over tamarillo trial. A Northland anti-genetic engineering group leader says she never wanted to sign a deal silencing protesters over a tamarillo trial. (Jul 11, 2002,Dominion Post,A2)

There was a tamarillo tree - it never used to be there, but I do remember our dad taking an axe to a row of peach trees just before he left home. (Oct 6, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

tamate¶

n. (See tamaiti)

Tame Nikau¶

phr. generic term used by NZ Observer for either Maori in general or Maori soldiers

[Hdg] Tame Nikau. New Zealand has welcomed back with generous warmth a body of splendid young Maori warriors... In some cases Tame returns to a home desolated by the dire "flumonia". (Apr 12, 1919,NZ Observer,4)

Tamiherism¶

n.

First, a retraction: only two out of the last six Young Labour presidents were gay - the last one, in fact, was married. My bad, and I apologise unreservedly for my Tamiherism. (Apr 12, 2005,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://publicaddress.net/default,2010.sm#post Accesssed 12/04/06 (Yes, 1 year later)]

tamingi¶

n.

HOOKER Tamingi, Geolog. Surv. Epacris pauciflora. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

tamping¶

n.

MONEY [There being] no good fuses to be obtained for blasting, he made vesta matches answer equally well, using a needle' andtamping' instead of the regular fuse. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,79)

tamure¶

n. snapper

LEE & KENDALL `Tamure s. Bream fish.' (1820,Grammar and Vocabulary of Language of NZ,206)

DIEFFENBACH Tamuri - the snapper fish (1843,Travels in NZ,2/385)

DIEFFENBACH Tamuri - the snapper fish (1843,Travels in NZ,2/385)

WAKEFIELD There are many other sorts of fish, including the tamure, [check spg ?tamore] or snapper, the manga, or barracouta, the mango, or dog-fish, of which the native [?sic, check] catch large quantities. (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/93)

English Name Native Name Rock Cod Whapuka Snapper Tamuri ... ... (1849,NZ Journal,9/125) [NOTES: (quoting Anglo Maori Warder Oct 5)]

LUSH (Nov 19, 1850,Auckland Journals,38,1971 ed.)

DRURY FISH [MET WITH IN PELORUS]. Rock Cod - Pakiri of the natives, red and brown, or black, very numerous. Snapper - Tamuri, not abundant. ... (1855,Sailing Directions,67)

HECTOR ... the Snapper (Pagrus unicolor). This name, by which it is best known, is adopted from Australia, its Maori name Tamure being seldom used by Europeans. ... The Snapper is not reputed to occur south of the Kaikoura Peninsula, the fish which usually goes by that name in the Dunedin market being the Tarakihi. (1872,Edible Fishes,106)

BAINES ... but big Tamuri or Schnapper, by which name it is `best known' to Europeans, is not very good eating ... (1874,Edward Crewe,163)

[Native or Common Name] Tamure, Snapper .. [Scientific Name] Pagrus unicolor (1877,TrNZI,9/485) [NOTES: (P. Thomson, Otago)]

[Native or Settlers' Name] Tamure, Snapper .. [Scientific Name] Pagrus unicolor (1879,TrNZI,11/382) [NOTES: (P. Thomson, Otago)]

HAY In the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga). (1882,Brighter Britain,2/151)

MORRIS Ta[acute]mure, n. the Maori name for the New Zealand Schnapper fish (q.v.). [1820, 1845 Wakefield, 1855, 1879] (1898,Austral English,456)

Ta-mui.re (ta.-mui.ra.), n. [Maori.] The Australian schnapper. See SCHNAPPER. [Local, N. Z.] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

PAGROSOMUS AURATUS (Forster). Snapper; Tamure. ... Distribution: Known as far south as Jackson's Bay and Port Molyneux. (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/116) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

Other fish such as kahawai(Arripis trutta (Forster)), tamure (Pagrosomus auratus (Forster)), snapper and moki (Latridopsis ciliaris (Forster)), are also caught. (1926,TrNZI,58/615) [NOTES: (Buck)]

PHILLIPPS Pagrosomus aratus (Forster). SNAPPER; TAMURE. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,35,1971 ed.)

BEST The following fish were caught with hook and line: araara, maomao, moki, mango, ngoiro, pakirikiri, kahawai, tamure, tarakihi, and warehou. The kanae, kehe, kopipiro, moho, nanu and other species were taken by net. (1929,Fishing Methods,43)

tamure, a sea-fish (Pagrus unicolor), a brightly-coloured vigorous fish, a favourite in the market: often called snapper, and as often and wrongly as schnapper (as in Supplement). (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/150) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

LYON The class of fish [available] varied with the locality - in the north the tamure or snapper, and the patiki or flounder, were the most common. (1952,Faring South,131)

PARROTT SNAPPER Chrysophrys auratus (Bloch & Schneider) ... Maori name: TAMURE The Snapper, one of the most valuable food fishes both in New Zealand and Australia, was described in 1801 from a specimen caught in Queen Charlotte Sound. (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,98)

DOOGUE & MORELAND SNAPPER ... Other names: Chrysophrys auratus; schnapper'; bream (brim'); tamure (Maori). Term bream is applied to small specimens in Australia and North Auckland. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,239)

~ n. Maori name for the snapper. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

MORELAND SNAPPER [Chrysophrys auratus] ... The name bream is applied to small examples, and the Maori name tamure is still in use about northern coasts. (1967,Marine Fishes,42)

NATUSCH Family SPARIDAE. ... the coppery, turquoise-dotted snapper or tamure, Chrysophrys auratus ... , commonest north of Cook Strait. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,221)

tamure ... n. Maori name for the snapper [Maori] (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

SORENSON SNAPPER (a) Scientific name: Chrysophrys auratus. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Golden Snapper (c) Other common names: Schnapper; Brim (small snapper at Nelson); Tamure. (d) Principal localities where taken: From Nelson northwards to both coasts of the North Island. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,45)

BURTON Snapper, or tamure in Maori, is our most popular food fish and also one of the most plentiful, particularly in the waters around the top half of the North Island. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,79)

[species name] snapper .. [scientific name] Chrysophrys auratus .. [other name(s)] schnapper, tamure. See also premium snapper (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

There were several kinds of shellfish, including kutai, kokote, and huangi; of fish, tamure (snapper), takeke (guardfish), arara (travalli). (Jun 4, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,16)

"Smoke Tamuri is the Staff of Life." (May 12, 1906,Observer (Auckland),4)

COTTLE He sent the [horse] up and down the tan ... so that bidding became brisk. (1891,Frank Melton's Luck,87)

tana¶

n. (See tawa)

n. (Rural) a NZ-bred cultivar of clover. [ORIGIN: Maori]

Highest seasonal yields were produced by 'Tana' birdsfoot trefoil growing in the shelter of the trees. (Mar 1986,Proceedings 1985 Hill & High Country Seminar,34) [NOTES: Proceedings 1985 Hill & High Country Seminar]

tanakaa¶

n. (See tanekaha)

tanalised¶

adj. (of timber) having been put through a process for preserving wood [1971 (Griffiths Collection)]

He favours materials such as tanalised pine for their "rawness. (Nov 25, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),61)

Because the advantages of using tanalised sawdust sawdust appear to be substantial and its risks so negligible, I would have no hesitation in digging it into my garden... Apart from tanalising, New Zealand timber may also be preserved with boron, or with pentachlorophenol - chemicals with quite different effects. Don't confuse these sawdusts with tanalised sawdust (stained green) or you will have a gardening disaster on your hands. (Feb 13, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

Loe's Canterbury coach Vance Stewart reckons that Loe, his legs like tanalised posts and a chest like the Millard stand, still holds a record for all-round strength set at Lincoln years ago when the young prop was a New Zealand colts trialist. (Jul 2, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

For sale - Five tantalised [sic] fencing posts. (Jun 25, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9) [NOTES: Originally from Upper Clutha Messenger, 21/4/94]

MACLEAN Most of the pit-sawn timber, cut from the surrounding bush, has been replaced with tanalised pine. (1994,Tararua : the Story of a Mountain Range,250)

HILL ... the starter held the gun in his right hand and pressed it against a piece of tanalised 4 x 2 held in his left hand. (1988,More from Moaville,23)

tandem cowshed¶

n. a shed in which cows stand in a straight line for milking at the side, so that they can enter and leave each unit individually.

Tandem cowshed. Cows stand in a straight line for milking at the side. They can enter and leave each unit individually. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,39)

tandem shed¶

n. (See also herringbone,rotary,walk-through)

McMEEKAN The tandem shed consists of a set of bails which the cows stand in line, head to tail... on a platform 30 inches above the milker's level. (1960,Grass to Milk,149)

McMEEKAN There are three commonly used types of milking shed in New Zealand - the walk-through, the tandem and the herringbone. ... [149] The walk-through shed is strictly a New Zealand invention. ... It was born of the ingenuity of farmers faced with the task of milking large herds on their own, or with little help. ... [150] The herringbone is a New Zealand development of the tandem type. ... In this type of shed the cows are angle-parked in two rows separated by the milking `well' which is thirty inches below the cow platforms. (1961,Grass to Milk,148,149,150)

1 n. (Rural) a model of cowshed where cows stand in line, head to tail, to be milked.

It was Mr Stan Slater's tandem-bail shed at Carterton that impressed them most. This tandem shed at Kaitoke provides milking comfort. (Jun 10, 1958,NZ Dairy Exporter,37)

.. the Christies say that the tandem shed allows them to treat their cows as individuals. (Jun 10, 1958,NZ Dairy Exporter,39)

MCMEEKAN Some tandems have a special washing bail attached .. If a farmer decides to build a tandem shed, it is much better to scrap the washing bail idea and to wash and stimulate in the bail. (1960,Grass to Milk,153)

MAF Tandem : Cows stand in a straight line for milking at the side. They can enter and leave each unit individually. [tandem bail] (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,39)

'Handsome young tane like him should have a beautiful Maori gal by his side - or a stunning Maori queen.' (2001,Huia 4: Contemp. Maori Fiction,105)

But that's not all to this tane who plays a wicked game of rugby too. (2005,Te Mana Taiohi,issue 18 summer 2005/2006; p1)

Tane¶

BAUCKE Ibid.128 Ibid. 245 No chips might be gathered and burnt; an insult to the god of forests, Tane, he will resent with merciless afflictions. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,34)

taneewha¶

n. (See taniwha)

taneka¶

n. (See tanekaha)

tanekaha¶

n. an indigenous pine characterised by lacy leaf appearance. [ORIGIN: Maori, Phyllocladus trichomanoides aka parsley leafed pine, parsley-leafed pine, parsley-leaved pine, parsley pine, celery pine, found in upper tip of South Island and in the North Island north of a line from Mokau to Mahia Peninsula - latitude 39 degrees.]

Not so many know the curious philocladus, the tanekaha, or celery-pine, so odd in details of growth, so shapely in whole, brilliantly clothed in yellow and red,with a bark that brings in a high price for the tanning of ladies' gloves. (Oct 12, 1935,Christchurch Star-Sun,14)

WILLIAMS Mr Fairburn tried the Tanakaha to split for shingles ... Phyllocladus trichomanoides, =CELERY PINE Maori taanekaha (Jul 23, 1828,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,139,1961 ed.)

WILLIAMS Went with the Sawyers up to Waikino; felled one Kauri and one Tanakaha; ... (Jan 28, 1834,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,359,1961 ed.)

McDONNELL A great variety of hard-wood grows at New Zealand, admirably adapted for the timbering of any sized ships; among them is the boride[e-acute], rattar[as-acute], taraide[ase-acute], mai[a-acute], totara[a1-acute], koi katoa[a2-acute], toa[a-acute] toa[a-acute], tani raha[as-acute], to wai[a-acute], reiva[a-acute] reiva[a-acute], tana[as-acute], and many others. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,19,1979 ed.)

MARKHAM Tarnicar [tanekaha] resembles Coudie in size but is more perishable wood and more yellow. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),33,1963 ed.)

YATE Tanekaha (Podocarpus asplenifolius, or Phyllocladus trichomanoides) - This regular, beautiful, and highly-ornamental tree, is found on hilly lands, or in dry shaded woods. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),38)

POLACK Many other trees abounded in Pamaki [a's-acute], such as the kaikatea [a2-acute], towai, rewa-rewa, totara [a's-acute], puriri, rata [a's-acute], kahika [a2-acute], tipow, tanikaha [a2-acute], rimu, and various kinds of akkas, all of which will be found described in the Appendix (Note 7). Ibid. 2/391 Tanikaha [a2,a3-acute] (pinus asplenifolius) g. coniferae, is a very valuable species of pine, very serviceable to the shipwright and general builder. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/109)

MATTHEWS Tane-Kaha (a pine) (1840,Reports and Essays,15)

... tanakaa[a-acute] (1841,NZ Journal,2/31/81) [NOTES: (G. Bennet)]

HODSKIN Tanekaha is a valuable species of pine ... (1841,Narrative of Eight Months Sojourn in NZ, A,27)

BIDWILL The Tanekaha [fn Phyllocladus trichomanoides] is also occasionally to be met with, but only on the steep sides of gullies; ... (1841,Rambles in NZ,37 and fn,1952 ed.)

DIEFFENBACH ... I must especially mention [from the Middle island] a new species of the parsley-leaved pine (Phyllocladus trichomanoides), which the natives call E Hutu, to distinguish it from the tanekaha, another species of the same genus. Ibid 1/427 ... Tanekaha ... Phyllocladus trichomanoides ... one [pine] is called hutu by the natives, and is a Phyllocladus; ... Ibid. 2/385 Tanekaha - a pine-tree (Phyllocladus trichomanoides) (1843,Travels in NZ,1/188)

COLENSO [Maoris] used the tough, forked branches if the Tanekaha (Phyllocladus trichomanoides) and Kahikatoa (Leptospermum scoparium) for the hooks for the fish. (1844,Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ) [NOTES: 1844 Colenso Excursion in the Northern Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 6]

WAKEFIELD 15. Tanekaha, (Phyllocladus trichomanoides.) This tree is not very common in the central and southern parts of New Zealand; ... (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,143)

McKILLOP The tanekaha tree yields a black or brown dye, and the tuhuhi a blue-black dye from the wood and bark, as does the mako; the whakou also yields a handsome blue. (1849,Reminiscences,162)

HOOKER Phyllocladus trichomanoides, Don. ... Nat. names, Tanekaha' north of the Thames, andToa Toa' south of that river, Col. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 235)

HURSTHOUSE 5. Taneka .... (say Pitch Pine.) (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/141)

ANGAS By another process they draw from the plant long slender fibres, shining like silk, and white as snow, and of these they manufacture their finest articles of dress, called kaitaka,' dyeing their borders black and red in various angular patterns, with the juices of thetanehaka' and the `hinau' tree.[check spg tree name???] (1866,Polynesia,46)

HOOKER Tanekaha, Col[enso]. Phyllocladus trichomanoides. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

TAYLOR The Tanekaha, a pine much prized for masts of small vessels, is almost, if not entirely, peculiar to the [Auckland] province. (1868,Past and Present of NZ,205)

... the graceful fern-plumaged Kawaka, ([Libocedrus Doniana, Hook: f.]), the handsome celery-leaved Tanekaha, (Phyllocladus trichomanoides,) ... the ornate Tawhai, (Fagus Menziesii,) and ... the ... Tawhai-rau-nui, (Fagus fusca,). Ibid.. 34 The channelled stems of the Neinei (Dracophyllum latifolium), and the ... saplings of Toatoa, or Tanekaha (Phyllocladus trichomanoides), made valued walking-sticks. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/4) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

LASLETT (1875,Timber and Trees,306) [NOTES: (Morris)]

KIRK TANEKAHA.- (Phyllocladus trichomanoides.) ... more abundant in the Province of Auckland. (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,12)

HAY The Tanekaha ... is a larger tree again. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/191)

HECTOR Phyllocladus trichomanoides, Don. Tanekaha, Celery-leaved Pine.--A slender handsome tree 60 feet high; trunk rarely exceeds 3 feet in diameter: (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,125)

(1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,120) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 120]

Tanekaha .. Phyllocladus trichomanoides .. Timber white, heavy, tough, strong, and straight grained; ... Ibid..33 Lithograph of tanekaha foliage. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,14)

MORRIS Maori name of a New Zealand tree; also called Celery-topped Pine, Phyllocladus trichomanoides, Don., N.O. Conifera. (1898,Austral English,456)

CHEESEMAN P[hyllocladus] trichomanoides, D.Don. ... Tanekaha; Toatoa; Celery-leaved Pine. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,658)

LAING & BLACKWELL Phyllocladus trichomanoides (The Celery-leaved Pine [The Celery Pine). The native name of this tree - Tanekaha - is said to signify virile, or strong in growth. (1907,Plants of NZ,76,1940 [79] ed.)

tanekaha n, -s [Maori] : CELERY-TOPPED PINE (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2336)

tanekaha n. New Zealand tree, with straight-grained wood, variety of pine. [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

tanekaha ... n. N.Z. tree, with straight-grained wood [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

tanekaha n. NZ celery-topped pine. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,784) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

tanekaha, a tree (Phyllocladus Trichomanoides), celery-leaved pine. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Notes Andersen Maori Words in English]

The other and unspecified timbers include poplar, miro, rata, tanekaha, taraire, mangeao, blue-gum, pukatea, rewarewa, silver-pine, hinau, puriri, kamahi, kawaka, maire, macrocarpa, yellow-pine, and willow. (Jan 11, 1929,Evening Post,9)

It has been found that kowhai, puriri, kauri, houhere, and rimu thrive in these unusual surroundings, but tanekaha, birch, and a few other trees cannot get sufficient water or are affected by the dust and smoke. (Aug 17, 1935,Evening Post,8)

The trade of the place is confined to the export of timber.. and sometimes small quantities of tanekaha bark and gum. (Oct 11, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,7)

Crowe In its slender, mature form, kaikomako makes a good specimen tree, well suited to small gardens. (2009,Which Native Tree?,31)

The association decided on a most comprehensive display, which will take the form of two large easels containing eight to ten pieces each of the various timbers produced in the districts, such as rimu, totara, kahikatea, maire, miro, tanekaha, rewa rewa, black birch, rata, manuka[,] puriri, etc. (Aug 11, 1906,Grey River Argus,1)

The land to the water's edge abounds with Pohutukawa, Tanekaha, Kauri timber, while the facilities for building and launching are not to be surpassed. (Feb 4, 1874,Daily Southern Cross,2)

KEENE tanekaha: moderate-sized tree 50 ft. to 70 ft. high. (1963,O Te Raki,194)

The price of tanekaha bark in Auckland is usually about forty dollars per ton. * (Dec 15, 1883,Auckland Weekly News,21)

The plant is correctly named.. the tanekaha, but is far better known as the celery-leaved pine. (Nov 4, 1924,Otago Witness,17)

tanewa¶

n. (See taniwha)

tanga¶

n.

Called Te Atakura, the programme was designed to provide people strong in Maori language and tanga, who could act as role models for Maori pupils. (Dec 2, 1987,Auckland Star) [NOTES: (Race Conciliator puts onus on teachers) (p.c. Ross Clark)]

We must abandon such jargon as Maoritanga, which was coined by a non-Maori, and in its place establish Aupouritanga, Ngapuhitanga or whatever tribal tanga that is involved in any issue. (Jul 27, 1997,Sunday Star Times,A5) [NOTES: From a 1979 statement]

tangahangaha¶

n. Pseudolabrus celidotus, spotty, pakirikiri

The tangahangaha (Pseudolabrus pittensis, banded parrot-fish) is one of the smaller fish found about the rocks and reefs. Ibid. 646 The hiwihiwi (Chironemus fergussoni), tupuku, ngutere, tangahangaha, and koeaea (Corridodax pullus Forster) (butterfish), are amongst those caught (1926,TrNZI,58/630) [NOTES: (Buck)]

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,2/215)

tangaloa¶

n. [ORIGIN: Samoan]

The Samoan community bestowed on David Lange the chiefly matai title of tangaloa in recognition of his service to the Pacific communities of New Zealand. (Aug 16, 2005,NZ Herald,A10)

tangao¶

n. (See tangeao)

tangaroa¶

n. ?? [ORIGIN: Maori, citation unclear; Tangaroa guardian of the sea; waning moon (Ryan) ???]

Maori never ever owned the only one tangaroa. (Sep 6, 2005,NZ Herald,A13)

Tangaroa¶

n. god of the sea, guardian of the sea, Neptune

COLLINS He is a native of the district of Ho-do-doe, (which is in Doubtles bay,) of which district Too-gee's father is the Etang-a-roa[macron]h, or high priest; and to that office the son succeeds on his father's death. (1804,English Colony in NSW,342)

BAUGHAN Tangaroa (Tah-nga-ro-ah): God of the Sea. (1908,Shingle-Short,50)

FINLAYSON (1938,Brown Man's Burden,21)

Place them on the stone. In that way Tangaroa is placated and the offering still lives for when the tide comes in. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/31)

Tangaroa Accord¶

n. a group of 16 iwi, including most tribes north of Taupo

The tribes of the Tangaroa Accord support the [Waitangi Fisheries] commission's Ahu Whakamua proposal, based on the best of tribal traditions, which is to suppress differences for the good of all... The 16 iwi of the Tangaroa Accord, which includes most tribes north of Taupo, represent more than 54 per cent of the Maori population, but these tribes will get just 32 per cent of the Ahu Whakamua allocation. (Nov 13, 2002,Dominion Post,B9)

tangata¶

n. a human being [ORIGIN: Maori, Maori tangata person (either sex), pl. tangata humankind, people (Ryan 239)]

English New Zeland South-sea Islands A Chief Eareete Earee A Man Taata Taata A Woman Ivahino Ivahine (Mar 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/286,1955 ed.)

FORSTER A Comparative Table of the Various Languages in the Isles of the South-Sea ... [English] A Man ... [New-Zeeland] Tangata [a1-macron, a2-macron grave, a3-macron] (1778,Observations Made During a Voyage,284)

LEE & KENDALL T|angata; man; male or female. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,207)

man - ton'gata [tangata] (1835,Boultbee Journal,109,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 109]

What was this country to him now, with its spirits of old tangata haunting the tree-tops ... (1966,NZ Short Stories,93,1976 ed.) [NOTES: (Wilson `End of the River')]

tangata n. NZ a human being, a person of either sex. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,784) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 491]]

tangata, man; human being. In Hawaii dialect t' becomesk' and n'"n'" whence tangata becomes kanaka, the vulg. Pakeha for man' in the Pacific, heavily accented on the second "a": ta'ata in Tahiti: all threea's' are equally light in accent. (In OED under kanaka.) (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/158) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

n. foreigner

LEE & KENDALL T|angata ke,s. A foreigner, another person. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,207)

tangata kaitiaki¶

n. [ORIGIN: Maori, lit. 'people caretaker']

The following have been nominated as the Tangata Kaitiaki for managing customary food-gathering from Mahurangi to Bream Tail extending 130km in an easterly direction: ... (Nov 21, 2006,NZ Herald,C7)

The taking of fish, aquatic life or seaweed (ie, customary food-gathering) may not take place in the area/rohe moana without an authorisation from a Tangata Kaitiaki. (May 4, 2007,Whakatane Beacon,26)

tangata Maori¶

n. a Maori person [(Orsman)(Maori)... very frequently used to distinguish objects from others having special characteristics; thus, ... tangata maaori, man, human being, as opposed to a supernatural being: ... later, man of the Polynesian race, not a foreigner, the distinction not being confined to colour]

CAMPBELL One of Cook's peculiarities was to run down the Maoris. ... Waipeha, on the other hand, always stood up manfully for Tongata Maori. Ibid. 2/6/103 Fish in plenty, fowl but scanty, flesh none, save a rat, so poor Tongata Maori had to fall back upon himself when the craving for animal food seized him, . (1881,Poenamo,2/3/70)

CAMPBELL Waipeha was equal to any amount of taihoaism, and tangata Maori loved him accordingly. (1881,Poenamo,88)

MARSHALL A considerable number of natives including about thirty of the Tangata Mauri, or heads of tribes, ... (1834,Narrative of Two Visits,108)

HYDE `Plurry pakeha, eh? You got the skin like the Maori, but you're not tangata Maori. There isn't any Maori who doesn't eat the hou-hou.' (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,148)

HOCHSTETTER Tangata maori is the native in contradistinction to Tangata pakeha, the stranger. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),00)

I. Maori, a. 1. native. 2. He wai maori; fresh water. -->A. The original Maori adjectival use is recorded in early English texts(as is the substantival), translated as native' COPPER MAORI (q.v.) would fall within this use (contrast MAORI COPPER), as would PAKEHA MAORI. -->[J.C. Andersen Maori Names p.30 notes "<i>Korari Maori</i>: Here McCrae uses the word Maori in its usual sense signifyingnormal, usual, ordinary. Not until long after this time did the word come to mean what Euopeans assume it actually means, and in which the natives themselves now aquiesce - that is the name of the people, the New Zealanders. It had no such meaning in the mind of the natives until a comparatively recent date, nor was it apparently so used by them to any extent until about 1850, though Wakefield [? which one ?] and some English writers had begun the use some years before. In earliest times tangata maoridid not mean man of the Maori race but human being as opposed to supernatural being; wai maori was fresh water'; <i>Whetu maori</i>inferior stars' Cook spoke of the inhabitants of NZ as Indians, early Europeam writers as natives or New Zealanders. [Andersen is paraphrasing Williams Dictionary here.] (1871,Dictionary of the Maori Language,75)

New Zealander - ton|g|ata ma|u|ree [tangata maori] (1826,Boultbee Journal,109,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 109; ALSO 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 282]

MARKHAM [contrast tangata ma] Mr Hamlyn is so good a Linguist that ... the people got up ... to look at him closer as the[y] said he was a Tangata Mar', or white Man but that he had the Tongue of aTangata Mouri', native; ...[`native' is a marginal note] (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),71,1963 ed.)

POLACK They [sc. Maoris] were all exceedingly pleased with `Ko te pakeha [a1-acute] pai, kaore [a/e-acute] ano redi e na [a-acute] tangata [a2,a3-acute] maori,' (the excellent white man, who permitted the natives to do what they pleased, without being angry in return). (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/75)

POLACK ... kainga maori or native village Ibid. 123 ... the national nomenclature is that of na tangnata [sic] maori or native people .... the word maori representing the term of native or indigenous. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,2/47)

DIEFFENBACH They call themselves Maori which means indigenous, aboriginal; or Tangata Maori indigenous men; in opposition to Pakea which means stranger, or Pakea mango mango, a very black stranger, a negro. Ibid. 2/370 Maori - indigenous, native, natural; haere maori - walking, as a native [sic: not `maori'] has no other chance[?check]; wai maori - fresh water (1843,Travels in NZ,2/7,1963 ed.)

The pas, villages, and houses of the people are not visible, not actually to be seen by mortal (Tangata Maori) eyes. (1909,Journal of the Polynesian Society,III/3)

MARKHAM When the Bar was crossed Canoes or in the Native Mourie [Maori] Tongue, Walker [waka] Mouries, or Native Boats, boarded us, ... Ibid. 30 [here TANGATA MOURI felt as a noun with Mouries pl cp. NATIVE] Crow made all hands of the Natives (or Tangata Mouries) give us some of their Dances, ... Ibid. 53 The Sawyers tell the Natives when in Anger, They will exterminate the Tangata Mouries' as theRah Parkieah' has the `Rah Mourie'. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),29,1963 ed.)

...he will find that originally "maori tangata" meant an "ordinary man" or a man native to the place where he was living. (Jan 18, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

Before that can be done, we must try to remove the tap or tappers which lawless chiefs for the most part put on the principal points of rivers; they are traps in fact to catch the unwary and extort payment from them; they are, as some of the Maories said to me, only the mau mingering of the tangata Maori, the lying for the purpose of which is to have pretexts for roads and forays, and keep the rest in subjection and slavery: it keeps the land locked up, however, and you may travel fifty to a hundred miles on the banks of some of our rivers without seeing a native. (Jul 12, 1853,Daily Southern Cross,2)

tangata Pakeha¶

n. a European person (contrastive with tangata Maori) [ORIGIN: Maori]

HOCHSTETTER Tangata maori is the native in contradistinction to Tangata pakeha, the stranger. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),00)

tangata teddy¶

n. (humorous)

Manu is currently leading the occupation of a playcentre outside Whangarei and claims tangata teddy have failed to meet their obligations under the Treaty. (May 7, 1995,Sunday Star Times,C5)

tangata tiriti¶

n. Pakeha (literally 'people of the Treaty')

But the same treaty gave Pakeha people the right to be here ("Tangata Tiriti" as Judge Eddie Durie calls them). (2000,2000AD Millennium: The Anthology,46) [NOTES: Michael King]

Does he agree that by that definition, while Pakeha cannot call ourselves 'indigenous' or 'tangata whenua', we do belong here by right of Te Tiriti o Waitangi, and could justly call ourselves 'tangata tiriti'. (Aug 4, 2004,Dominion Post,A2)

Pakeha sometimes feel they miss out. Who are we? Are we second-rate? No, we're not, and the reason we're not is because, as Mason Durie so beautifully put it, we're tangata tiriti. We're legitimately here by virtue of the Treaty. (Jul 16, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

Paradoxes swam out of the creation: culture as art, the exotic as workaday and, miraculously, exiles creating connections with and between tangata whenua and tangata tiriti. (Dec 14, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),41)

Two cultures signed the Treaty of Waitangi - one the tangata whenua represented by many iwi chiefs, the other the tangata tiriti represented by the British Crown. (Feb 21, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

Debate on GM issues ... is made unique by the partnership between tangata whenua and tangata tiriti created by the Treaty of Waitangi. (Aug 11, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

.. the first indigenous people had made a treaty with the Crown that permitted colonisation and gave us two streams of people with rights to be here, tangata whenua and tangata tiriti, to use Eddie Durie's characterisation of them. (Sep 2007,English in Aotearoa,73)

tangata whaiora¶

phr. a mentally ill person [ORIGIN: Maori]

The Like Minds, Like Mine movement to promote respect and equity for people with experience of mental illness/tangata whaiora has taken off and there is great community support. ... Tangata whaiora in the Eastern Bay report a greater feeling of acceptance and less discrimination than when we started five years ago, but there is still some way to go. (Oct 5, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,2)

I have experience of mental illness. Twenty-eight years ago as a teenage university student, I began the long haul as a tangata whaiora (patient). (Jan 10, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,4)

tangata whenua¶

n. . [ORIGIN: Maori, earliest people in NZ, as distinct from later boat-people; apparently Maori, but not exclusive of Moriori]

HENDERSON Peace and prosperity marked the time when there was cooperation between the newcomer and the tangata whenua. (1963,Ratana,2,1972 ed.)

In addition, the concept of tangata whenua (people of the land) remains intact despite the alienation of the land. (1984,Te Maori,31)

McGILL Somes Island was Matiu and Ward Island was Makaro ... in the days when the Ngai Tara, the tangata whenua, first lived there. (1985,G'day Country,114)

Statement on the Status of Maori people as Tangata Whenua of Aotearoa New Zealand ... The Commission recognises the importance of Maori culture ... to all people of Aotearoa New Zealand. (Mar 1988,Human Rights Commission Focus,1)

Tangata Whenua as a concept requires some explanation. It is often translated as people of the land, but such a translation doesn't correctly convey the deeper meaning. I prefer to translate the phrase as `people who are the land'. (Mar 1988,Human Rights Commission Focus,1) [NOTES: (H. Kaa)]

"I have cited a long list of great authorities, all agreeing that the continent of Asia was the land from which the Maoris came .. They are one people - Tangata Maori in India, in Indonesia, and in the Pacific ..." (May 2, 1913,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

Data concerning the previous arrivals on these shores had gradually accumulated until we were in a position to state that the ancestors of the so-called tangata whenua (aboriginal people) landed on these shores about thirty generations ago. (Jul 15, 1930,Evening Post,3)

NGATI POROU IN AUCKLAND Your Taura Here seeks a Kaitiaki A Rohe .. *To foster relationships with Te haukaenga, tangata whenua, matawaka ... (Jul 17, 2006,Dominion Post,D12)

There were many different tribes of these tangata whenua ... (May 14, 1896,Otago Witness,42)

n. [ORIGIN: Maori, people of the land, not necessarily Maori or NZ]

McGILL Despite that, readers were assured, folk were friendly and you could find Maori and Islander values here parallel to the strong clan-like traditions of the Presbyterians; it sounded like the Presbyterians were to be seen as the tangata whenua, the Maori and Islanders as late arrivals. (1985,G'day Country,174)

In recent months I have drawn two arrows, as it were from my own Maori lexicon. I used the word tangata whenua to describe locals. I used the word putiputi to describe freeloaders. This last word is not to be found in any standard Maori dictionary but was in common usage a good while ago. (Nov 28, 1986,Contact (Wgtn),2)

The paradox that still besets Australia is that it has learnt to live and prosper with its many racial migrant communities while remaining brutally ignorant ... about its tangata whenua. (Dec 12, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

n. a Maori person or persons [ORIGIN: Maori]

Not a tangata whenua in sight, either, which is one of the rich ironies of this whole business. (Aug 30, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

They go down into the east in great numbers - a vast horde of stalwart warriors, prepared to force their way through the tangata whenua who may oppose them. (Jul 30, 1896,Otago Witness,48)

1 n. . [Moriori, Chatham Island Moriori]

SIMPSON Meanwhile at Chatham Island the tangata whenua - or Morioris as we now call them - found that their new home boasted no timber.... (1950,Chatham Exiles,26)

A story runs that the first armed clash between the emigrants and the tangata whenua or people of the soil, arose from Muaupoko treachery, as a result of when, two of the children of Te Rauparaha were slain and he himself barely escaped with his life. (Apr 12, 1932,Evening Post,14)

Unfortunately, New Zealand's earliest people, whoever they were, have left no permanent relics, being ignorant of of metals; but further research in the North may, even with this drawback, still throw some light on the traditional "tangata whenua" - "The People of the Land." (May 14, 1910,Evening Post,4)

2 n. "people of the land", the indigenous people; the local people, the local residents of a particular place [ORIGIN: Maori, NZ context; usually Maori; general and also with specific reference to a particular place within NZ]

MACRAE `That Lillian bird better watch which of the tangata whenua she mouths off like that in front of,' ... (1988,Awful Childhoods,89)

"The land wars are over, so the consent of the tangata whenua is required before customary title can be extinguished." (Jul 5, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14.)

The grey mists wreathe through the ivory towers as benighted geologists scutte around searching for goals on which to impact, for end-users with whom to be relevant, and for an ecological niche in which to embed cyclotherms amongst the legitimate aspirations of the tangata whenua. (Mar 1997,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,112/73)

If some councillor made a racist statement I don't think we would put them on a committee that dealt with the tangata whenua. (Dec 20, 1992,Sunday Times (NZ),3)

We.. have reached a point where the Union Flag appearing in the canton has little significance for non-Britons, and even less for the tangata whenua. (Aug 16, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9)

At large Maori gatherings when... there are visitors from other tribes whom the "tangata whenua," the sons of the soil, delight to honour, songs are chanted.. that date back centuries. (Dec 1, 1928,NZ Free Lance,6)

Up at Waitangi the tangata whenua of Aotearoa discuss their colonisation and whether to celebrate it. (Mar 2, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

I took care, however, to arrive some time earlier than the Premier that I might be regarded as distinct from his party, "He tangata whenua," not "He Manuhiri," i.e., a resident and not a guest. (Aug 3, 1895,Wanganui Chronicle,3)

Later, climb previously uncharted peaks with the gorgeously craggy Mark Whetu - the first tangata whenua to climb Mt Everest under the terms of the Treaty of Waitangi. (Oct 14, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),69)

Labour MP Dover Samuels stood up to respond to the greetings of the tangata whenua. (Jun 6, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),35)

Baucke ...for the `tangata whenua' (resident) took precedence on his own soil; ... (1905,Where the White Man Treads,54)

Howe Tangata whenua - whenua' (q.v.) is the placenta which was usually buried in a special place which would not be walked over and thus defiled by anyone. Thus a person's spiritual well being was linked with the land belonged to.Tangata whenua' thus refers to the `people belonging to the land', who have therefore the right to live there according to their own traditions and values. (1985,Towards Taha Maori,22)

Ihimaera We are the tangata whenua, the people of the land. Ibid. 28 I want us to be in full view of the pa, so that the tangata whenua can see that we are here. (1986,Matriarch, The,4)

Paul Temm feels essentially unchanged by his experience on the tribunal, sitting at marae around the country, listening to the elders vent their frustrations in Maori, hongi-ing with both tangata whenua and manuhiri (visitors), chatting over tea and kai. (Jun 21, 1986,Evening Post)

[Hdg] Capitalism v tangata whenua... Clearly the ideologies of capitalism and tangata whenua are in conflict, so accommodations have to be made between Maori and Pakeha if they are to inhabit the same social space. (Jul 24, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

And yet the tangata whenua of this country have to scrape, have to make do, have to put up with second-best in health, education, jobs and housing. (May 12, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

There were about fifty canoes containing the visitors, and about fifty had already arrived conveying the "tangata whenua." (Jun 5, 1857,Daily Southern Cross,3)

About 11 a.m. Nga ti Haua and the Tangata Whenua (tribes who called the meeting and provided the food) mustered their fighting men, in war costume, i.e., armed with muskets or guns, and naked except a bandage or other covering round the middle of the body: in all about 300 or 400 marched on to the ground, where they formed in column. (Jun 5, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,2)

Again, from their behaviour they were a nuisance, not only to the Europeans, but also to the natives, the "tangata whenua" themselves. (Mar 29, 1883,Waikato Times,2)

Zimmerman And here again the club gave expression to a fundamental idea of Maori life, that of the obligation of hospitality of the tangata whenua, the man of the country, to whoever might chance to be his guest. (1946,Where the People Sing,37)

Henderson The taua muru party ... crouched with their weapons ready. The tangata whenua ... now sprang to their feet and danced a furious war dance. (1948,Taina,43)

tangata whenua the local people (e.g. as opp. to nga manuhiri) the visitors) (knowing the invaders were approaching, the tangata whenua had hidden their heirlooms). [M, = people of the land] (1896,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,784) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

The Maori Land Court will then be asked to vest the reservation in a body corporate, which will include representation from the tangata whenua (local people), appointed by the court in trust for the community. (Jun 29, 1988,Dominion,2)

How a project ... with the blessing ... of all the tribes, including some but not all the tangata whenua Ngai Tahu, plus Pakeha-dom ... could have become so unstuck ... is a complex tale of human foibles. (Mar 5, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

He has enormous trouble with certain words; for instance, he can't pronounce "tangata whenua" or "socialism" witrhout breaking out in hives and experiencing a gagging and choking sensation. (Mar 13, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9)

tangata whenua-ness¶

n. [[Ma. /"taNata"fenua/: Williams 494 Tangata whenua, people belonging to any particular place, natives.]]

"So what of Toi Kairakau, of Rauru, my history, my tangata whenua-ness, my 1000 missing years?" (Nov 17, 2005,NZ Herald,A1) [NOTES: Pita Sharples' maiden speech in parliament.]

tangata whenuan¶

adj. of the tangata whenua; Maori

As "Enid Barker, children's librarian, beautiful, witty, Tangata Whenuan" [she] looked beautiful in her sweeping crinoline skirt. (Jun 8, 1993,Salient,22)

tangatiaki¶
