n. food guardian [ORIGIN: Maori]

.. a Kaikoura man was caught with 90kg of paua and the tangatiaki (food guardian) who issued the permit was charged with altering it to make the catch appear legal. (Jul 12, 2005,NZ Herald,A7)

tangeao¶

n.

LEE & KENDALL T|ange |o; A tree used for fire-wood. Litsaea calicaris, a tree (Williams 379) (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,207)

POLACK There are many other woods of much service to Europeans, differing in quality, among others: the 30 Warangai - 31 Pata -32 - Niho - 33 Tangio, - 34 Maihoi - 35 Nene [e's-acute] - 36 Taraiti - 37 Kohihihu - 38 Waihupuku - 39 Kaikamoko - 40 Pukapuka - - 41 Karanghu - 42 Utuhutu - 43 Angiani - 44 Akkas of various kinds. 45 Parekireki, &c. Of all these woods there are abundant quantities. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/400)

HOOKER Tetranthera calicaris, Hook. fil. ... Nat. name, `Tangao'. [check spg] (1853,Flora NZ,216)

HOOKER Tangeao, Col[enso]. Tetranthera calicaris. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Of our shrubs and smaller timber trees, several are of strikingly beautiful growth ... (e.g.) the Houhere, Hoheria populnea ...; the Horopito Drimys axillaris; the Manuka-rau-riki, Leptospermum ericoides; the Kohuhu.. , the Tangeao, Tetranthera calicaris.... Ibid. 46 The Tangeao or Mangeao, (Tetranthera calicaris,) is a small tree, also confined to the Northernmost parts of the Island ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/5) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

CHEESEMAN L[itsaea] calicaris, Benth and Hook.f. ... A perfectly glabrous closely branched leafy tree 30-40 ft. high ... NORTH ISLAND: ... to Rotorua and East Cape. ... Mangeao; Tangeao. ... wood strong, tough, and elastic ... (1906,Manual NZ Flora,603)

The mangeao (or tangeao) is seldom used. It is useful for boat-building purposes, as it possesses the property attributed to the oak, of closing up instantly should the wood be pierced by a bullet. (Nov 5, 1861,Daily Southern Cross,2)

n.

57 Lithograph of tangiao foliage. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,17)

tangelo¶

n.

Tangelos are citrus hybrids obtained by crossing the tangerine and the grapefruit. (1964,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue,231)

New Zealand-grown mandarins and tangelos are gaining steadily in popularity with the public. (May 1968,Orchardist NZ,102)

Two kinds of citrus which have adapted well to New Zealand's relatively cold growing conditions.. are the so-called New Zealand grapefruit and, more recently, the seminole tangelo. (Jan 1972,Orchardist NZ,25)

Tangelos are a group of citrus fruits derived as hybrids of mandarins and grapefruits which are more or less intermediate in character between the parent species. (1974,Orchardist NZ,239) [NOTES: Check month of issue]

MALCOLM Today there are still orange trees similar to the modern Tangelo. (1982,Where it all Began,41)

With the large number of Seminole Tangelo trees in New Zealand a considerable number of bud mutations should be expected to occur. (Aug 1986,Orchardist NZ,252)

MATTHEWS Tangelos are the result of hybridising tangerines and grapefruit. (1986,NZ Garden Book,244)

With the large number of Seminole Tangelo trees in New Zealand a considerable number of bud mutations should be expected to occur. (Aug 1986,Orchardist NZ,252)

tangi¶

n.

Tangihanga leave [headline] The CSU is to lodge a claim for the recognition of tangihanga leave. The claim is based on the belief that tangihanga is a grieving process, and that as a consequence, extended bereavement leave should be granted those attending a tangi. (Jun 18, 1986,PSA Journal,6)

n. [ORIGIN: Maori, lament; one cit: tangitary]

MACKIE Standing by our inn I heard a noise like the howling of dogs and asking a man who was passing what it was, he told us that it was the Maories at their pa .. howling or crying on acount of the death of one of their number, they call it `tangitary', wailing for the dead. (Apr 8, 1853,Traveller under Concern,99,19I73 ed.)

n. weakened or trivialised in European perceptions to the feeding of the guests at the TANGIHANA; then = feast (thence ? below confused with HUI or weakened to a drunken party) cf 19 cit.

n. a crying or weeping as a ceremony of welcome, or meeting

MUNDY .. a friend who had been for some time in the colony pointed out this scene to me, as `a good case of tangi' (1852,Our Antipodes,121)

(1840,Journal of Ensign Best) [NOTES: [see cit. 1a. above]]

ANGAS On entering one of the enclosures .. these visitors commenced their salutations by pressing noses with each in succession, and then sat down in silence; the women setting up a tangi, or `crying of welcome'. (1847,Savage Life,1/237)

POWER Muskets were laid aside, hands shaken, noses rubbed, news talked over; and, while the feast was preparing, a considerable majority sat [32] down to indulge in a `tangi', as an expression of their pleasure at meeting. (1849,Sketches in NZ,31)

SMITH We .. were enlivened by a good hour's tangi between our guide and the woman .. at the end of which our guide .. knocked off, and fell upon a kite of potatoes ... (Jan 13, 1858,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1858 Jan 13 Smith Notes of a Journey in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 360]

MANING .. our chief advanced towards him, fell upon his neck embracing him in the most affectionate manner, commenced a tangi, or melancholy sort of ditty, ... and ... shed floods of tears. (1863,Old New Zealand,3/56)

MOSER As the reader may not know what a tangi' is, I may briefly say, that when Maories meet after a long absence, they invariably have a good cry ..., and that the sametangi' is likewise held over their dead ... (1863,Mahoe Leaves,32)

GORST All the old women turned out to tangi' over him, according to the Maori fashion of saluting an old friend, ... [fn] The old native women always show affection by a sort of whimper, which is often prolonged for hours. This is called atangi'. (1864,Maori King, The,322)

ANGAS When friends meet, who have been separated for some time, a `tangi,' or crying, takes place, the parties sitting in silence opposite to each other for perhaps half an hour, exchanging no words, but uttering melancholy wailings; then, all of a sudden, they approach, press noses, and commence laughing and chatting in the most lively manner possible. (1866,Polynesia,150)

BAUCKE Our college graduate arrives; the home-coming tangi and nose-greeting is over; .. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,278)

n. a funeral, a farewell [metaphorical, anglicised egs]

There have been merry Irish wakes, and tangis running beer, / (1893,College Rhymes,36)

HYDE Starkie thought he would like a bonfire, .. or one of those great native tangis, kumaras and shark and eel and sucking-pig cooked under the wet sacks on hot stones, ... (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,41)

HYDE [Masses of grub and long orations] were inevitable at their tangis and huis. The tangi was a funeral, the hui a feast; but there wasn't much difference. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,121)

POTTS These birds [sc gulls] .. when they meet together, after a few deep-toned barks or growls hold a regular `tangi', and utter most dismal wails and yells. (1874,On Recent Changes in the Fauna,9)

As to his gratuitous advice of burying it and holding a tangi at Kennedy's, I firmly believe the settlers will nurse it to maturity, and hold a meeting of rejoicing over its vigorous manhood, for getting rid of the baneful influence Rutland Chambers seems to exercise in road matters. (Jul 13, 1883,Wanganui Herald,2)

If a night is missed, that is the night [the slugs] seem to hold a "tangi"and devour all the choice seedlings in sight. (Feb 10, 1916,Feilding Star,2)

Man-o'-war officers and men.. held a "tangi" on board last Saturday night over the ashes of the British team. (Aug 27, 1904,NZ Observer,7)

So in that sense, was the recent Labour leadership struggle the real death of Rogernomics - a convulsion the party had postponed, but needed to endure? "Yes," says Helen Clark, "we'd never held the tangi." (Dec 18, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

n. [no citations; ca1935 R. Mason The day after Parliament opens there is a short recess in memory of members who have died in the previous session. This is [still c1953] popularly known among M.P.s as a tangi, a time of mourning.]

n.

n.

n. espec. a booze-party

MILLER A barrel of beer arrrived at the cookhouse after tea time, so the section settled down to a large evening. I missed most of the tangi. (1939,Camps, Tramps and Trenches,131) [NOTES: 1917 Sep 5 in 1939 Miller Camps Tracks and Trenches 131]

DEVANNY They'll be having a tangi [after the wedding] in the evening I understand. (1926,Butcher Shop, The,60)

DEVANNY Duke had a drink and went off, but the remainder set to for the usual tangi (1928,Dawn Beloved,227)

PARTRIDGE Tangi. n. and v. Tangi, a maori word for a tribal gathering at a funeral: a dirge':Now very commonly adopted here [New Zealand] by the upper classes, especially as an equivalent of the outmoded `beano'. E.g., Harold and I were on the tangi (or were tangi-ing) last night; or there is a big tangi on to-night,' Niall Alexander, letter of Oct. 22, 1939. (1949,Dictionary of Slang,1194)

NEWTON I spent Christmas at the Bealey [hotel] for five consecutive years, and they were `tangis' that are worth remembering. (1952,High Country Journey,132)

ROGERS Hal's teeth flashed ... `Hislops are holding a tangi tonight. Tiare invited all of us. ... I'm taking Concertina Charlie over with me. Special invitation to bushwhackers.' (1960,Long White Cloud, The,13)

MIDDLETON .. I had often fooled around with girls .. at a local hui or tangi. (1964,Walk on the Beach,160) [NOTES: (Not for a Seagull) [check if correct category???]]

NEWTON But I was mighty curious all the same - that must have been a real bottler of a tangi. (1966,Boss's Story, The,100)

tangi ... n. Maori for a lamentation, cry, dirge [Maori]; European New Zealanders use the word tangi to mean a celebration. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

DAVIN Michael came back. They'd had a terrific tangi [sc a student party], he said. He drank a cup of black coffee .. and went to bed. (1972,Brides of Price,170)

Our occasional carousals were tolerated .. What's that appalling racket?' Alexander had asked.Oh, that's just Des having one of his tangis.' (Jun 1973,Meanjin Quarterly,32/3/134) [NOTES: (Dan Davin) [This or foll. cit. to be retained - correct date???]]

DAVIN What's that appalling racket?' Alexander asked.Oh, that's just Des having one of his tangi's.' (1975,Breathing Spaces,131)

LAMBERT Now, there are races, shows, ...football, ... dances, cinemas, tangis, huis and boxing ... (1936,Pioneering Reminiscences of Old Wairoa,186)

n. wailing

GUTHRIE Their two boys upon hearing of the projected departure had set up such a howling tangi (shedding tears into all his possessions, so Toby declared) that to silence them the Twins promised they should also go. (1930,NZ Memories,88)

During the whole night the poor wretch kept up a horrible "tangi." (Feb 1, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,21)

n. a mourning ceremony; lament. [also tangie, taki]

SOLJAK New Zealand colloquialisms which are of Maori origin include: .. hold a tangi: to hold a feast, party or meeting (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),116)

NICHOLAS This [91] had caused, he said, nuee nuee tanghee tanghee (a good deal of crying) among them ... (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/90)

tangi n. Maori for a lamentation, cry, dirge [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

POWER All day long there had been a considerable howl over the dead and wounded, and to-[28]morrow the bodies will be carried to Waikanahi to have a tangi there ... (1849,Sketches in NZ) [NOTES: 1849 Power Sketches in NZ 27-28 Aug. 21st [1846].]

The Taiaroa Tangi / The Last Tribute to the Remains of a Great Chief [headlines] (Apr 19, 1905,NZ Truth,9/5/6)

BAUGHAN When a messenger comes to your gate and cries, `Tama died last night,' the men unyoke their teams .. Ailing children are made into bundles, and away you rush to the tangi. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,130) [NOTES: also 1905 Baucke White Man Treads 34, 128]

BAUGHAN Tangi (Tang-ee): The Maori wake. Literally, `a crying.' (1908,Shingle-Short,44)

Gone are the days when the Maori was summoned to many momentous meetings to discuss real or fancied wrongs, or to attend a tangi to the departed. (Apr 20, 1912,NZ Truth,356/4/1)

BEAGLEHOLE tangi funeral celebrations and rites (1946,Some Modern Maoris,xxii)

ASHTON-WARNER I'll wash my grief away as the Maoris do after a tangi. [fn] Maori funeral. (1958,Spinster,152)

HILLIARD Then Mrs Te Weu died .. and was buried with Grace absent from the tangi. [fn] tangi - Maori funeral rites; lamentation. (1960,Maori Girl,28)

BAXTER Tangi [title] Ibid. 448 Matui Jackson fell from the face of the dam, / .. / They buried him without a tangi. (1979,Collected Poems,400) [NOTES: [check name spg???] (1967) 1979 Baxter Collected Poems 400]

FINLAYSON tangi: a wake, a ceremonial of mourning and farewell before burial. For an important person it may last two or three days. As a verb, the word means to cry or mourn. (1973,Brown Man's Burden,142)

NATUSCH The coffin, covered with a beautiful kaitaka, was carried to a whaleboat and rowed across to a Maori [143] burial ground [at Stewart Island] .. then the women sat by the stream and began the low chanting .. of the Southern taki. (1978,Acheron Journal,142)

tangi n. N.Z. 1. a Maori funeral ceremony. 2. Inf. a lamentation. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1194) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 785; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 491]]

FINLAYSON The time was opportune for another feast-day. .. there had not been a marriage .. for months now; and among the long-lived little community, neither had the occasion for a tangi arisen, altough it was evident that poor old Honi Tawa was not far now from the road to the Reinga. (1938,Brown Man's Burden,3,1973 ed.) [NOTES: (Wedding Gift)]

HULME I have never seen someone die. What do you do? Pray? Tangi? Listen. Ibid. 449 Tangi = weep, mourn. (1983,Bone People, The,365)

The intelligence brought back by this messenger, who visited Rangihaeata's pah, is to the effect that that savage will be able to collect from Otaki, Wanganui, and other places, two hundred men, who will arrive at Porirua under pretence of holding a tangi over a chief lately dead, and will, afterwards, proceed to the Hutt and establish themselves at the Taita. (May 16, 1846,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,2)

In December of the same year, a large concourse of natives, from different parts of the Nelson Province, were assembled, on one of their periodical visits, at Porirua to hold a tangi or lamentation over some of their relatives recently deceased. (Jul 17, 1860,Colonist (Nelson),3)

He said he was obliged to hold a tangi; it was native custom. (Nov 16, 1895,Hawke's Bay Herald,4)

BAUGHAN As a widow, a mother, they wail, at a death, at a tangi. (1908,Shingle-Short,4) [NOTES: Check whether page is 4 or 41]

Lahood feels Numero Bruno is like a continuing tangi for Lawrence. (Jul 17, 2000,Dominion,14)

To hold the doeful tangi or, / shed for him a tear (Nov 21, 1860,Taranaki Punch,5)

The drunken debauchery at Maori tangis is much to be deplored. (Aug 13, 1904,NZ Observer,3)

Some 200 came down the Waipa in their canoes, and were of course received with the usual "haeremais" and "tangis". (Mar 8, 1873,Auckland Weekly News,14)

PAYTON Then they collected all the bones into a heap, got up a tangi over them, and departed to look out for their next debauch, among some tribe that was not related to them. (1888,Round about NZ,93)

PAYTON Tangi literally means "a weeping", and is a ceremony of joy, or sorrow.Ibid. 332 Most of them got out of doing any real tangi business, that being generally left to several old women. (1888,Round about NZ,328)

OWEN & PERKINS At a tangi, of course, the body would be lying in state on the porch of the meetinghouse, and as we advanced there would be the karanga, calling to us to come and weep for the dead. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,109)

I always felt sorry for the widows at those early tangi. (Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,109)

PARK Nobody had seen a tangi as big as Uncle Pihopa's. He was a great chief, that old man who ate bishops. (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,80)

BEAGLEHOLE On the first day of the tangi kinsmen and tribal members, together with tribes related to that of the dead person, are notified of the death.Ibid. 258 The climax of the tangi is reached on the fourth day, the day of the burial. Ibid. 259 The abiding impression that one receives as one follows the course of a full-scale Maori tangi is that death is a very matter-of-fact event for the people. (1946,Some Modern Maoris,257)

PARK In the old days tangis had gone on for so long that sometimes the deceased had tricked away through the cracks in the coffin. (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,80)

LEE & KENDALL T|angi, s. A cry, lamentation; (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,207)

cry - takki [tangi] (1835,Boultbee Journal,112,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 112; ALSO 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 285]

WILLIAMS .. an old lady put forth her miserable strains in a tangi ... (Feb 19, 1835,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,413,1961 ed.)

At daylight we were awakened by the howlings of some Mauries .. who were making the Tangie' .. The high note of theTangie' is like a dog Baying at the moon .. there is the Tangie for the dead or sick - the Tangie' of welcome or after a long absence and [sic] theTangie' at separation. (Aug 1840,Journal of Ensign Best,233,1966 ed.)

POLACK1 When the dance ceased, the lamentation (tangi ) commenced, in which this singular assemblage dissolved into [89] tears ... (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/88)

WAKEFIELD A tangi by all hands lasted nearly an hour. (Feb 20, 1841,Journal) [NOTES: 1841 Feb 20 E.J. Wakefield Journal in 1842 Heaphy Residence in NZ 57]

McKILLOP THE `TANGI', OR WAIL. [heading] (1849,Reminiscences,253)

[The Maoris] were going to have a tangi over the grave. (Aug 7, 1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/153) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

HARPER His wife had lately died, and a number of Maori women, from their settlement close by, were holding a `Tangi', or lamentation, to bewail her death, ... (Nov 4, 1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,43,1914 ed.)

MANING He mocks the war-song, but I see your fall, at least one Pakeha Maori shall raise the tangi; and with flint and shell as of old shall the women lament you. (1863,Old New Zealand,1/3)

MONEY This was the first occasion upon which I had ever heard the `tangi,' or melancholy wailing, which is performed by [58] the women of the tribe on the departure or return, as well as on the death, of one of its members. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,57)

MARRYAT Why do they weep and lament in that distressing way?'.. it is what they call tangi in their language.' During the time that the women tangied, the men stood silent. (1874,Among the Maoris,113) [NOTES: 1874 Emilia Norris (Marryat) Amongst the Maoris 113]

CAMPBELL Perhaps some old woman did a quiet tangi over his grave. (1881,Poenamo,191)

RENWICK 'Tis the tangi floats on the sea-borne breeze,/ In its echoing notes of wild despair. (1883,Betrayed,41) [NOTES: [Morris]]

PAYTON It is always the custom in New Zealand, especially in the North Island, to use Maori words frequently in referring to the natives and their doings; a colonist would no more dream of calling a Maori wharehouse,' or a tangi `a ceremony of weeping' than he would of saluting Tawhias [sic check -o?] as King of New Zealand. (1888,Round about NZ,viii)

MARTIN The old Bible words, `He lifted up his voice and wept,' become a reality to any who have heard the shrill Maori ta-ngi. (1884,Our Maoris,18)

MORRIS Tangi, n. (pronounced Tang-y) Maori word for a lamentation, a cry, or dirge. (1898,Austral English,457)

tangi n. lamentation; mourning. [Polynesian] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,11)

Tokotoko says she is not going to Kawa. She can't be bothered going to the `backblocks' she says, and in any case .. there will be plenty more tangis to go to before her own. (1945,Journal of the Polynesian Society,54/97) [NOTES: (Beaglehole)]

tangi, sound; cry; lament, as in a wake; sound of birds: in place-name Waitangi, it means "sounding water." (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

dirge or lamentation (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

The Maori word for weeping, wailing, lamentation, a ceremony on the death of a distinguished Maori. (1958,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,405)

tangi n -s [Maori, lit., to mourn, cry] : a Maori funeral rite; also : a lamentation or dirge that accompanies it (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2337)

PEARSON I'm a full Maori and proud, too. .. Old Mum she meant I'm still a savage, that's what she meant. Just quietly, eh? Haka and tangi. (1963,Coal Flat,43)

v. to mourn or weep [as in Maori funeral]

BAKER Everybody tangi'd over the grave, so many people dead, seven in one hole. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,89)

M. WILLIAMS I .. decided to send Joseph to Turanga. I could not think how I had consented and tangied over his preparations. (Oct 17, 1844,Journal) [NOTES: 1844 Oct 17 M. Williams Journal in 1960 Drummond Married and Gone to NZ 39]

ANGAS .. she [a Maori woman] begged .. that she might be permitted to tangi over it [a sketch] .. saying, `it was her brother and she must tangi till the tears came ... (1847,Savage Life,2/47)

[The Maori] was Komene's wife. .. She sat down, began tangi-ing, waving her arm occasionally; so they remained for some minutes. (Apr 19, 1864,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/107) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

MARRYAT Why do they weep and lament in that distressing way?'.. it is what they call tangi in their language.' During the time that the women tangied, the men stood silent. (1874,Among the Maoris,113)

MANING He was .. consoled by hundreds of friends who came .. to condole and tangi with him ... (1863,Old New Zealand,(iv) 74)

The great-nephew of the chieftainess, Mr Joe Karaka, her namesake, Mrs Tuaiwa (Eva) Rickard and relatives followed Mrs Rongo into the tomb to tangi over the remains. (Sep 25, 1972,Marlborough Express,6)

FINLAYSON (1973,Brown Man's Burden,142) [NOTES: [see noun 1.above]]

WEBSTER Pemia went first, pulling the black shawl over her head and adjusting it before she began to cry out, tangi-ing towards the corpse for a few minutes and then getting closer, and crying out again. (1979,Rua,24)

HULME 375. Tangi = weep, mourn (1983,Bone People, The,468)

'K' Here we stop for a few minutes to enable our native companion to be tangi'd over. (1885,Visit to Lake Rotoaira, A,4)

To establish and maintain all forms of amusement and entertainment, and in particular schools and colleges and whare taperes of poi-dancing, and hakas and tongue stretching, and dismal tangi-ing, living pictures, and abdominal contortions. (Dec 6, 1912,Wanganui Chronicle,2)

Tito Kowaru has emerged from his retreat .. and, at the last accounts, was visiting and tangi-ing over the scenes of his former exploits. (Oct 4, 1870,North Otago Times,3)

Who was the young lady who 'tangied' when she heard of the boat capsizing and dear Ralph was nearly drowned? (May 20, 1899,Observer (Auckland),21)

The poor wounded woman was there tangi-ing for her lost child. (Jul 13, 1912,Evening Post,13)

"I don't want to tangi and all that crap," he says. (Apr 27, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

A chief died in Te Karaka once, and they tangied for over a year on end. (Jul 22, 1924,Otago Witness,71)

adj.

MEREDITH The tangi band knelt on the ground, ... leant forward, and placed their hands on the ground. (1876,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,111,1935 ed.)

BAUCKE Since the introduction of measles this district has been a continual travelling route of tangi parties. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,128)

BUCK The tangi custom was also a source for the spread of infection. (1949,Coming of the Maori, The)

n. [weeping, not necessarily over death]

As the march began, Eva Rickard, organising Kotahitanga (unity council) president, admitted: `I had a big tangi (cry), didn't I? (Jan 29, 1984,NZ Times,1)

KEENE tangi: dirge, lamentation; to mourn (1963,O Te Raki,194)

n. a post-mortem meeting or discussion [fig]

BAKER When we refer to holding a tangi about a setback or problem we are putting another Maori term into colloquial use,... (1941,NZ Slang,56)

PARTRIDGE Tangi, holding a. Faced with a problem or a set-back: New Zealand: C. 20. B., 1941. Ex Maori tangi, `a wake'. Cf. prec. entry. (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1194)

I hear that Miss Lelia Williams, who was pronounced by the verdict of those present as being the belle, in view of the feeling displayed by some of the disappointed ones, does not intend to accept the kind offer of Mr Foy, of having her photo enlarged, but intends instead to hold a tangi at Kopu over the remains of 'blighted hopes' of those who thought they were entitled to the coverted [sic] honour, and for the occasion she purposes [sic] wearing the same costume, so that even the Maoris will not think she is anything but a princess of their own blood, as the majority of those present at the ball did. (Oct 28, 1893,Observer (Auckland),22)

One Councillor said that they had better make the final payment first and hold a tangi over the work afterwards. (Jul 26, 1909,Feilding Star,3)

n. a squabble, a fight

DAVIN And if she was angry enough she'd go in and give him a tongue-lashing ... Now it had never struck me that I might get involved in one of these tangis. (1959,No Remittance,170)

n. [recitation]

BUDDLE Here he recited a native tangi, see p. 17, of Sir George Grey's collection. [`Tera in tai o Ngamotu'] (1860,Maori King Movement,56)

7 n.

9 v. lament [one cit, to be tangi'd over]

tangi leave¶

n. leave from work for the purpose of arranging or attending a tangi; funeral leave

We hear also that one should not hire a Maori employee because they are able to take unlimited tangi leave. The law is absolutely clear that all Kiwis have the opportunity for bereavement leave, whatever their colour, race or creed. (Feb 24, 2004,Dominion Post,B4)

The Council of Trade Unions has explained that he's got it wrong about tangi leave. (Feb 18, 2004,Northern Courier,5)

Statements by the National Party in recent weeks.. about a fictitious concept called "tangi leave", need to be addressed. Every employee has the same entitlement under the law to bereavement leave. (Feb 28, 2004,Dominion Post,B4)

The controversial bereavement provisions allowed for a day's bereavement leave if employers accepted an employee had cultural responsibilities towards the deceased, a clause interpreted by National as amounting to "unlimited tangi leave". (Oct 10, 2004,Sunday Times (NZ),D1)

Margaret Wilson (Feb 28) seems determined to misrepresent the effects of Government employment law change as it applies to the so-called tangi leave. (Mar 5, 2004,Dominion Post,B4)

tangi-er¶

n. someone attending a tangi

A coterie of mourners was selected to tangi for the deceased, a master of ceremonies was appointed whose principal duty was to see that the `tangi-ers' kept up to concert pitch. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,111) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 111]

tangiao¶

n. (See tangeao)

Tangier pea¶

n. (See contrast everlasting pea)

pea, Tangier [s] Lathyrus tingitanus L. Ibid. 77 Tangier pea [s] Lathyrus tingitanus L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,57)

TAYLOR TANGIER PEA (Lathyrus tingitanus) Beautiful biennial ... often mistaken for everlasting pea but flowers are red-purple and fewer in bunch. (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,47)

tangihanga¶

n. mourning; mourning party [ORIGIN: Maori, aka tangihana]

TAYLOR The natives were busy preparing food for the expected Tangihana ... [July 3] About ten the fleet of canoes containing the tangihana or crying party appeared in sight .. (Jul 2, 1846,Journal,4/70)

FITTON .. a great meeting of natives at Te Wairoa on the occasion of a grand `tangihana' for Apatri, an old chief drowned last year. (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),106)

COWAN Taraia died in November 1871 ... and the Governor ... went up ... to Ohinemuri to attend the tangihana. (1940,Sir Donald Maclean,112)

HENDERSON ... all those taking part in the tangihana who were psychic or receptive hoped to catch this gift from the departing spirit. (1948,Taina,181)

HULME 238 Tangihanga = funeral, and the ceremonies connected with it (1983,Bone People, The,467)

HOWE Tangihanga - this word refers specifically to the ceremony which takes place when a person dies. It is closely linked with the idea of `whanaungatanga' (q.v.). People go to the tangi to share their grief with the bereaved family, to reaffirm family ties, to recall the living past. (1985,Towards Taha Maori,22)

Tangihanga leave [headline] The CSU is to lodge a claim for the recognition of tangihanga leave. The claim is based on the belief that tangihanga is a grieving process, and that as a consequence, extended bereavement leave should be granted those attending a tangi. (Jun 18, 1986,PSA Journal,6)

Tangihanga aren't exempt either. It's not uncommon to farewell the tupapaku the night before burial with songs and jokes - and booze. (Jun 1996,Mana,No.13: 56)

A very large number of Natives have gone to the Tangihanga. (Dec 9, 1874,Star, The,3)

Tangihanga leave [headline] The CSU is to lodge a claim for the recognition of tangihanga leave. The claim is based on the belief that tangihanga is a grieving process, and that as a consequence, extended bereavement leave should be granted those attending a tangi. (Jun 18, 1986,PSA Journal,6)

From the Anglican cup of tea to the wailing of the tangihanga, where the deceased are never left alone, we find out why funerals are changing. (Sep 28, 2004,Dominion Post TV Week,3)

Tangihanga to be held at Poutu Pa Shannon-Foxton Highway Friday 10 February 2006 at 11am. (Feb 8, 2006,Dominion Post,D9)

By means of a long stick and noose they succeeded in raising the body, which was then quite black, from the fatal cave, and the messenger arrived here as above to invite the Ngatipikiaos to attend the "tangihanga." (Sep 9, 1880,Bay of Plenty Times,3)

TANGIHANGA AT SOUTH WAITAKI. (Aug 6, 1897,North Otago Times,3)

When that chief lost his life by the great land-slip which totally destroyed Te Rapa, Iwikau assumed the patronymic Te Heu Heu, and fearing lest another ta niwha should destroy his abode at Te Hihi he removed to Pukawa, and there he received the grand tangihanga, which came to do honour to his brother's memory. (Dec 3, 1862,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

A large tangihanga will be held at Papawai.. in memory of the Hon. Mr. Wi Pere. M.L.C. (Mar 2, 1916,Wairarapa Daily Times,5)

Marae spokeswoman Moko Tini Templeton said the tangihanga was a huge logistical exercise. (Aug 17, 2006,NZ Herald - The College Herald,A1)

Tangihanga at Otawhare Marae, Omaio. (Aug 30, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,10)

n. funeral [ORIGIN: Maori, [Ma. tangihanga mourning] cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 239.]

tangiing¶

n.

HUNT Here we stopped, and the canoes were drawn up in front of the pa, amidst much tangi-ing, and shouts of `Haeremai, haeremai, haeremai!' - the usual amount of shaking hands and rubbing noses being over, a long korero, or talk, ensued. (1866,Chatham Islands,17)

The night ... was spent in speechifying, tangeying, going through the war dance ... (1879,Waikato War,15) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

CAMPBELL After each new arrival had performed the proper [179] amount of tangi-ing wailing at the semi-circle they retired to feast, and to gossip - ... (1881,Poenamo,Bk3/5/178)

There has been great feasting and tangiing going on for the past two or three weeks. (May 14, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,22)

Tangiwai¶

n. rail tragedy at Tangiwai on Christmas Eve, 1953, during Queen's visit, when a lahar from Mt Ruapehu destroyed a rail bridge with loss of 151 lives.

At this precise time National Radio will air a two-hour documentary, Tangiwai ... A River of Tears, detailing what happened that night in 1953 and exploring the ongoing significance of what became known as the Tangiwai - translates as "river of tears" - disaster. (Dec 20, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),66)

Yes, the memories flow throughout the reunion, not least of that terrible Christmas Day as the news of Tangiwai spread. (Mar 27, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

There are many reasons why, half a century on, the name Tangiwai has an emotional resonance for more than one generation of New Zealanders. Most obviously, it was the country's fifth worst disaster and, at the timne, the eighth biggest railway disaster the world had ever known. Then there was the timing, Christmas Eve. (Dec 20, 2003,Dominion Post,B2)

"We've heard about you and your bloody Tangiwai. You didn't even get your feet wet." (Apr 20, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),72)

At the end of the day word filtered through to the New Zealand team of the Tangiwai rail catastrophe back home. (Jan 11, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

tangiwai¶

n. a translucent variety of greenstone.(bowenite

MONRO There are two kinds of greenstone, that which is commonly seen, and which is named the ponamoo, and another sort more glassy and transparent named tuggewai. The ponamoo is exceedingly hard, and has an irregular fracture. The tuggewai is much softer, of a more transparent green, and divides easily into plates. (1844,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 261]

MANING 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 261 (1863,Old New Zealand,321) [NOTES: [that is, the notes check date]]

Serpentine occurs in two forms - as common Serpentine ..., and as noble Serpentine (Tangiwai) in thin veins associated with Jade. ... Jade - ordinarily known as Maori Greenstone (Poenamu) occurs in situ on several parts of the West Coast ... (1868,Province of Otago in NZ, The,39)

With the exception of the tangi-wai, the various kinds of greenstone are all found in a restricted locality on the west coast of the South Island. (1892,TrNZI,24/481)

COWAN Taking the dead warrior's gun and whakakai pendant of tangiwai greenstone as trophies, Mair hurried back to the scene of the fight. (1922,NZ Wars, The,2/158,1983 ed.)

Amongst the most valued objects in the Cook relics ... is a bowenite (tangiwai) ear-drop. (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,7/181) [NOTES: (Thorpe)]

COWAN High above on the slopes of the Mitre Peak range there are deposits of the famous tangiwai or bowenite, the greenstone sought after so much by Maori and pakeha alike. ... The discovery of this tangiwai reef is described in ... the legend of Tama-ki-te-Rangi. (1926,Travel in NZ,(Vol II South Island) 148)

FIRTH Among the Maori, considerations of aesthetic interest helped quite materially ... to decide the relative worth of objects made of the pounamu, the nephrite so much prized for pendants, mere, and adzes. Most prized was the kahurangi stone, bright green, translucent, hard and clear; the inanga variety perhaps comes next, with its white milky-veined appearance, [389] followed by the kawakawa, dark olive-green, dull and opaque. ... Tangiwai (`tear drop'), bowenite, a softer stone of a clear pale green, with the appearance of drops of water in the texture, was less esteemed, though more beautiful in the European eyes, whilst kahotea, green, spotted or streaked with black, was an inferior type, and was used for small chisels, and for objects of subordinate interest. (1929,Primitive Economics of NZ Maori,388)

ELDER Bowenite was used, but genuine specimens in this material are excessively rare. (1932,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,432)

ZIMMERMAN Each variety has its own Maori name, but the two most prized are inanga, which is heavily flecked with white, and tangiwai, the deep, clear kind. (1946,Where the People Sing,149)

New Zealand greenstone is either the mineral nephrite (Maori: pounamu) or bowenite (Maori: tangiwai). (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/875)

PHILLIPPS A material similar in appearance to greenstone, but known to the geologists as bowenite and to the Maori as tangiwai, is widely used in the same manner as greenstone. Some pieces are quite translucent while others show the characteristic yellow-brown colouration. Bowenite is a softer material than greenstone. (1966,Maori Life and Custom,98)

HALL-JONES McKenzie picked up many Maori artefacts at this source of the translucent tangiwai type of greenstone (bowenite) which the Maoris used for ornaments. (1968,Early Fiordland,32)

DUFF Closely resembling nephrite to the inexpert eye, and closely associated with it in Maori tradition, the greenish translucent bowenite (tangiwai) is again recorded only from the remote south-western coast of the South Island, namely Anita Bay in Milford Sound. (1977,Moa-Hunters of NZ,231)

NATUSCH Greenstone was picked up at Anita bay - takiwai, not the esteemed pounamu. (1978,Acheron Journal,159)

HULME (1983,Bone People, The)

One of the party, who in past years had seen a great deal of work by the Maoris in greenstone, and had a good knowledge of the stone, disputed somewhat hotly Captain Hutton's ruling. The Maoris call this kind tangiwai, an allusion to the water contained in it. (Mar 21, 1874,Wellington Independent,2)

There are two kinds of greenstone, that which is commonly seen, and which is named the ponamoo, and another sort more glassy and transparent named tuggewai ... the tuggewai is much softer, of a more transparent green, and divides easily into plates. (Oct 5, 1844,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

One of the chiefs who spoke - a tatooed, grey-haired warrior - wore a very beautiful pendant ear-drop, made from the tangiwai, or tear-water greenstone. (May 25, 1904,Otago Witness,49)

Tangiwai is clear like glass, and ranges from olive-gree to bluish green. Most tangiwai is sourced from two isolated areas at Piopiotahi (Milford Sound). Koko-tangiwai, the longer name for this stone, referes to a deep sorrow that is never completely healed. (Oct 23, 2009,Press, The,4)

tangle fern¶

n. Gleichenia dicarpa (formerly alpina, circinata), having thin, spidery pinnae. [(often preceded by a descriptive epithet)]

Umbrella ferns are quite unlike any other fern. Rather than producing a typically divided frond, the midrib divides repeatedly into two, producing a bud at the end of each branch, with two new branches arising immediately below it. Lateral branching of this sort can be finite, producing a distinctive shape, as in the umbrella fern (Sticherus cunninghamii), or it can continue almost indefinitely, with the frond forming extensive thickets, as in the tangle fern (Gleichenia dicarpa). (2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/72)

WILSON Gleichenia dicarpa TANGLE FERN ... Spider fern ... Swamp umbrella fern ... Fronds wiry, forked ... often forming tangled thickets or cushion-like springy masses ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,432)

POTTS (And) Gleichenia dicarpa (formerly alpina) alpine tangle-fern (1882,Out in the Open)

COCKAYNE (And) Gleichenia dicarpa (formerly alpina) alpine tangle-fern (1909,AJHR,C-12)

H.B.DOBBIE (And) Gleichenia dicarpa (Nov 21, 1921,Letters)

MARK & ADAMS Several species are virtually confined to peat-bogs - the wire rush (Calorophus minor) and the tangle fern (Gleichenia dicarpa ). Ibid. 3 Gleichenia circinata Swartz TANGLE FERN (1973,NZ Alpine Plants,22,1979 ed.)

WILSON Gleichenia dicarpa TANGLE FERN ... Spider fern ... Swamp umbrella fern ... Fronds wiry, forked ... often forming tangled thickets or cushion-like springy masses ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,432)

Lateral branching of this sort can be finite, producing a distinctive shape, as in the umbrella fern (Sticherus cunninghamii), or it can continue almost indefinitely, with the frond forming extensive thickets, as in the tangle fern (Gleichenia dicarpa). (2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/72)

tanglefoot¶

n. liquor

In prohibition districts 8 bottles of tanglefoot are known a `kit'. 2. beer, bad liquor: (Aug 19, 1905,NZ Truth,1)

n. obstructive vegetation

THOMSON After an hour of this the going improved considerably, the river bank being more level with less `tanglefoot' and a more defined track appearing, as if wapiti had frequented it at some earlier date. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,129)

tanglefoot paper¶

n. (sticky) flypaper

... to catch the bugs ... They tried tanglefoot paper at first... plastered gummy paper. (Apr 7, 1906,NZ Truth,1)

tani raha¶

n. (See tanekaha)

taniko¶

n. an ornamental border or band [ORIGIN: Maori, sometimes refers to the mat, not just its border]

The girls try to keep up some of the Maori arts, such as weaving and doing Taniko. (Sep 21, 1927,NZ Tablet,39)

TREGEAR If men ever wove they confined their attention to the weaving of the ornamental borders (taniko) of mats. (1904,Maori Race, The,228)

BUCK The taniko in the embroidered borders of cloaks, is from the point of technique the latest development in Maori weaving. (1929,Coming of the Maori, The,28)

The garment was a parawai or kaitaka cloak with a taniko border. (Jul 30, 1933,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/103) [NOTES: (Ngata) 1933 July 30 in 1988 Na To Hoa Aroha (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 3/103]

The arts and crafts section comprised tukutuku, ... plaiting (rourou [fn A small basket used for cooked food.], rough kits and floor mats), taniko work and making poi balls. (Mar 28, 1936,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/212) [NOTES: 1936 Mar 28 in 1988 Na To Hoa Aroha (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 3/212 (Ngata)]

BEAGLEHOLE Some of the women ... are skilled at taniko plaiting, but such work is hardly common enough to be called a folk art. (1946,Some Modern Maoris,108)

ZIMMERMAN She would have been a beauty, dressed in the old fashion, in the piu-piu skirt, with her hair flowing free under a narrow taniko head band. (1946,Where the People Sing,116)

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,2/172, 173)

MALING A warrior's cloak, or cape, woven from the finest flax fibre, bleached white, with a decorative taniko border. (1958,Torlesse Papers,126 fn,1958 ed.)

MASON ... the children almost all in traditional Maori costume, the elders with a few concessions to it - some of the women wear pare round their heads, or piu-pius over their dresses, a few older men with taniko bordered cloaks. (1969,Awatea,48,1978 ed.)

BAXTER And Your Mother wears on her head the taniko band. (1979,Collected Poems,449,1969 ed.)

ADCOCK taniko woven band or belt (1982,Contemporary NZ Poetry,143)

BAXTER taniko woven band or belt (1982,Selected Poems,189)

The following contributions were received at the Museum during the quarter ending March 31 .. Rev. James W. Stack, Kaiapoi - Taniko (flax mat), Maori chief's cloak. (Apr 22, 1872,Star, The,2)

The mat on the left is called taniko, and the other, on the right, korawai. (Dec 10, 1889,Otago Daily Times,6)

FOR SALE, Handsome MAORI MAT with Taniko Border. (Mar 9, 1892,Otago Daily Times,3)

Among the ceremonial garments are some feather cloaks and capes, while one of the garments shows really exquisite "Taniko" bordering. (Jan 10, 1918,Evening Post,8)

The mana of meeting houses and the cult symbols of the Maori millennial prophets.. combined with the triangles and diamond shapes of taaniko weaving provide the atmospherics for one of Cotton's best-known paintings. (Dec 12, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),37)

One of the kuia observed that one section had the precise colour and form of taniko weaving. (Dec 14, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),41)

During those younger years she learnt taniko weaving from a Pakeha teacher and later became a master weaver. (2008,Mana,84/9)

Maori material culture, the patterns and forms of tekoteko, taniko and tukutuku, is a tempting source of raw material for artists. (Dec 14, 2005,NZ Herald,B4)

These 100-hour courses help you learn new techniques in kowhaiwhai, raranga, whakairo, taniko and kakahu. (Nov 17, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,13)

taniwha¶

n. a legendary water monster; a river guardian [ORIGIN: Maori]

LEE & KENDALL T|aniwa, s. A sea monster so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,207)

ELDER `The taneewha (taniwha) whom the natives say upsets their canoes and drowns them, at other times takes them out of the canoe bodily, drowns, and eats them; ... they ascribe to their taking some old thatch from a house which was tapu or sacred into their canoe to sit upon. The taneewha or one of the sea-gods was angry, upset the canoe, etc. (1934,Marsden's Lieutenants,255) [NOTES: 1822 Aug 15 John King in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 255]

Taniwha: fabulous monster; prodigy; incubus of the imagination: might take any shape, saurian, rock, log: might be stationary, or move from place to place in air, water or land, even through the land as a fish through the water or a bird through the air. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/`158) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words [check spg saurian and commas???]]

BAXTER Growing cold in amber water, riding the logs/ Upstream, and waiting for the taniwha. (1979,Collected Poems,45,1979 ed.)

fabulous monster (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

SAR GESON No. No thanks. They had a big parcel of fish and chips. ...There. In the dragon [a merry-go-round car so shaped] (like the taniwha, eh!). Poppy was minding it. Ibid. 273 (gloss.) taniwha: water-spirit or monster in Maori mythology. (1949,I Saw in My Dream,252,1974 ed.) [NOTES: 1949 Sargeson I Saw in My Dream (1974 ed. Rhodes) 252]

Aorangi dominated the view for miles as we drove back to Taihape ; a fit abode for the taniwha, Tarakumukumu, who lives in a lake on the summit - a taniwha, it is said, with a head like a cattle beast, a semi-human body and amiable disposition. (Sep 1958,Tararua,15)

KEENE taniwha: fabulous monster supposed to live in deep water. (1963,O Te Raki,194)

HINTZ The Horomatangi reefs are named after a fierce taniwha - a mythical marine monster - which, the Maoris say, used to lurk in the rocks. (1964,Trout at Taupo,38)

Taniwha n. a mythical Maori monster [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

taniwha ... n. mythical Maori monster [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

BAXTER ... the place at the river-bend is named/ After her tears - I accept that - I wait for/ The taniwha in the heart to rise - (1979,Collected Poems,467,1969 ed.)

HULME 174 Taniwha = a mythical (?) water terror/monster (1983,Bone People, The,466)

taniwha n. mythical monster inhabiting pools of water. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,785) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 491]]

IHIMAERA & LONG Something deep inside him was let loose like a raging taniwha out of the deep cave and before his party mates on the beach realised it, Hemi had pushed Tare off the crate and was on top of him punching wildly. (1982,Into the World of Light,217)

KNOX A book... About taniwhas - disinherited taniwhas. They're at a loose end about what to do and feel they don't belong anymore. It's rather sad, on a sort of conservationist theme. (1987,After Z-Hour,3)

Taniwha block highway builders in Waikato. (Dec 3, 2002,Dominion Post,B5)

The Taniwha, fearful and fierce, / Who is clad from head to tail / In a coat of scaly mail. (Feb 1, 1890,NZ Observer,6)

Such "taniwhas" as this [sc. a 34 lb eel] account for many lf the fry liberated in the stream they inhabit. (Dec 26, 1928,NZ Free Lance,42)

BAKER The taniwha gave you part of the story and I'm giving you a bit more... It was Cally's taniwha, carved in white bone, inlaid with chips of coloured stone, with a plaited flax thing attached. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,67)

[The government]announces thgat the SAS will be issued with secret medals. What do they tell the other ex-servicemen on Anzac Day? That they were issued by a taniwha. (Dec 8, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A12)

Suddenly it's a place of spiritual cleansing along the greenstone trail or birthing canal of the great taniwha or something. (May 15, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

'There's a sign down there,' said Marion. 'It says the harbour is guarded by taniwha.' (2001,Huia 4: Contemp. Maori Fiction,16)

I would not wonder if we had failed to record many old New Zealanders, including the Hoihois and Taniwhas. (Nov 20, 1890,Otago Witness,42)

A blue taniwha painted on a window loooks out over a small field of mud. (Jul 22, 2001,Sunday Star Times,C1)

Cool off in the firece Waikato River where jet boats patrolled to save the unwary from the clutches of the taniwha. (Jan 7, 2003,Dominion Post,C1)

An angry hoarse murmur was heard.. as though the dreaded Taniwha were coming to avenge the insult. (Apr 26, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,18)

They are seized by a large eel - a regular taniwha to ducks. (Nov 5, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7)

Most historical accounts of taniwha have them resembling a water-borne serpent, and over the years there have been claims of sightings... "I don't subscribe to the idea these taniwha come out and cause problems because a road's going through. Taniwha are actually guardians, they have always been more helpful than non-helpful." Ibid. C1 In a week when a taniwha created headlines for holding up a motorway development.. business people have every right to be sceptical of the Government's latest bureaucracy-busting move. (Nov 9, 2002,Dominion Post,A7)

There lived, not far from these parts, a dreaded taniwha, a dragon who came at time from his deep mountain cavern to devour all with whom he came into contact. (Oct 12, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,94)

His answer, when it finally comes, might give those who appointed him a hint that they may have a taniwha by the tail. (Nov 23, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C1)

[Hdg] Urban Taniwha roaming... From conception to completion, the making of Urban Taniwha has been a musical journey filled with passion, rage, despair and ecstasy. (Oct 12, 2000,City Voice,4)

And this is certainly the only country in the world that has ever stopped rebuilding a lethal stretch of highway because a local hapu complained that it ran over the home of a one-eyed taniwha. (Sep 13, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

Hochstetter They sent it [sc. fire] to him through the two Taniwhas (mountain and water-spirits living underground), Pupu and Te Haeata, by a subterranean passage to the top of Tongariro. (1867,New Zealand (Heaphy),391)

[Miria Simpson's] contribution was such that she was heralded simply as "Te Reo" by the hundreds who gathered to farewell her at Victoria University's Te Reo Waka Marae on Tuesday and yesterday. Others have fondly taken the description further, calling her "te reo o te taniwha" (the taniwha of the language). (Jun 13, 2002,Evening Post,9)

WILLIAMS A son of old Tarea who had died long ago, and turned into a Tanewa, God of the Sea, had appeared to him ... (Jan 28, 1832,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,223,1961 ed.) [NOTES: [check title and page number???]]

YATE If a ship is lost ... [at Hokianga], it is attributed to the anger of the Taniwa, sea monster, or god, who has raised himself under the vessel, and overturned it. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),94)

POLACK (Wairoa[a2-acute]) another person I knew, for the same cause, was within a few moons after drowned while bathing, the river god (Taniwoa) took hold of him. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/125)

... a lovely little bay shaded by Pohutekawa trees formerly the abode of the Tuniwa, or Sea God who upsets the Canoes and then devours the people. (Apr 4, 1842,Journal of Ensign Best,338,1966 ed.)

WADE Hearing us use the word <i>tapu</i>, as we looked towards it, one of our boatmen quickly repeated that the place was tapued for the tanewa (a water demon).And I wonder,' was his irreverent addition, `what this same tanewa may be! An old pot leg, perhaps!'' (Sep 9, 1842,Journey in NZ,34)

TAYLOR The natives affirm this river is filled with Taniwas, which they say are spirits which assume the form of fishes and eat men. (Jun 13, 1845,Journal,3/127)

SHORTLAND The creature spoken of in the traditions of the New Zealanders is frequently called Tuatara, a name also common to the iguana of the country, derived from the circumstance of its back being armed with a row of spines. It is also sometimes called Taniwha, a word of indefinite signification, equivalent to the English monster: ... (1856,Traditions & Superstitions,75)

SMITH At the southern end, the lake for some distance round is tapu, on account of the many canoes that have been swallowed up by a great taniwa called Horomatangi, which the natives say lives there. (Jan 21, 1858,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1858 Jan 21 Smith Notes of a Journey in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 370]

MANING `Take care, the pakeha is taniwha! the pakeha is a tino tangata!' (1863,Old New Zealand,2/32)

ANGAS ... the New Zealanders have their legends and songs about the terrible `taniwha,' ... (1866,Polynesia,76)

MEREDITH Subsequent conversation elicited that the Maoris were frightened to go to this particular waterhole, because they alleged that a taniwha (a fabulous reptile) lived in it. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,42,1935 ed.)

NESFIELD Whether the Taniwha was offended I do not know ... (1881,Chequered Career,109)

The ridge-boards are carved to represent a number of ngarara, or lizards, running along the roof, and the maihi, or gable-boards, have carvings of the mythological animal known as the manaia - probably a kind of taniwha. (1895,TrNZI,27/674)

Ten years ago a taniwha was captured in a lagoon near hamilton ..., and exhibited in a butcher's shop, and it proved to be a Stenorhynchus. (1895,TrNZI,28/88)

`The river at one time is reported as having been infested with taniwhas - gigantic fish that used to swallow the natives - and a Maori pointed out a deep pool under some willows, and told me his grandfather had been sezied by one of these monsters at that spot, dragged to the bottom and eaten. ... (Jan 23, 1896,Otago Witness,51/2)

MORRIS Maori name for a mythical monster (1898,Austral English,457)

Tai.ni-wha (ta.-ne.-hw&adot.), n. [Maori.] A fabulous monster, resembling a dragon, famous in Maori legend. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

TREGEAR The Maoris had belief in the existence of huge monsters (taniwha ) generally of saurian character and mostly water-dwellers. (1904,Maori Race, The,428)

BAUCKE [The Maori's] existence was burdened with the knowledge of huge reptilian monsters, ngarara on land, and taniwha in the water, who could speak, and roar, ... [39] and decoy with satanic duplicity! (1905,Where the White Man Treads,38)

BAUGHAN Taniwha (Tah-nee-whah): A sea-monster. (1908,Shingle-Short,51)

Taniwha n. a legendary sea-monster credited with destroying human begins. [Maori] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,11)

Perhaps the taniwha, god-devil of the ocean, would be merciful ... (1930,NZ Short Stories,262) [NOTES: 1930 Iris Wilkinson (Robin Hyde) in NZ Short Stories 262]

FINLAYSON (1938,Brown Man's Burden,66)

HYDE There's a little old woman taniwha , who comes up behind the souls of the dead. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,136)

n.

CARR Going back a few years, I recall my first ever pig hunt. My brother-in-law had condescended to take a rather timid townie to tackle the taniwha. In my mind at least, the furtive inhabitants of the bush resembled monsters, leviathans, behemoths and the such like, in their inherent savagery and ferocity. (1986,Diary of a Pig Hunter,35)

taniwha clause¶

n.

If he had a niggle, it was around presentation and "MPs' use of emotive language such as the taniwha clause", which he believed many Maori would dislike. (Jan 25, 2003,Dominion Post,A1)

The perfect symbol for all this is the Meremere taniwha. This one-eyed spirit stopped work on a new highway.. and gave National leader Bill English a new slogan. A reference to the Treaty in new legislation became the "taniwha clause" - a phrase coated in political poison... Historian Michael King says the issue "has nothing to do with the literal existence of non-existence of taniwha. Taniwha are a metaphorical way of saying that place is either dangerous or has special spiritual or historical significance. The way Maori signified that was by talking about taniwha or guardian to make poeople respect it and to explain the fact that sometimes people disppeared or drown or whatever, in those places". (Feb 2, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C5)

A requirement [in the 2002 Local Government Act] labelled the "taniwha clause" by opponents also drew fire. The clause demands that council decisions have regard to the Treaty of Waitangi and allows separate council seats for Maori. (Dec 28, 2002,Dominion Post,C5)

Taniwha soap¶

n. a brand of soap

An early contender, with more than a dash of local character, was certainly Taniwha soap. A by-product of one of the country's defining features, the meatworks, its very name conjured up mythical monsters, while the label displayed a bevy of topless mermaids lathering up against a backdrop of smoking volcanoes. (Jan 2000,NZ Geographic,No. 45/20)

Taniwhasaurus oweni¶

n. particular mosasaur

Hector's two species of mosasaur, taniwhasaurus oweni and Tylosaurus haumuriensis, are regarded as valid. (Dec 1970,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,29/15)

tank¶

v. to booze

He was a terror to tank (1903,NZ Illustrated Magazine,8/365)

n. a corrugated iron water tank for house supply [Jim writes: (In DNZE with 1902 citation... There are references to the use of house tanks before 1870 (though not the words tank stand or tank water) in Maclean.. The earliest recorded use might thus be pushed much further back.]

Drays arrived with tank boards &c. (Apr 9, 1861,Puketoi Station Diary)

Some time ago the Board of Education sent up a large tank and stand for the use of the schoolmaster's residence; it now lies on the public road, some chains from the house. (Dec 30, 1879,Timaru Herald,2)

In the open space allotted to implements is erected a tank stand of considerable altitude, containing four tanks, from which the fountains will be supplied by water pumped up by force pumps worked by motive power. (Apr 1, 1882,Timaru Herald,3)

The picture is a presentment of Messrs Hungerford and M'Kay's tank stand, from which great icicles are seen hanging, while the gorse bushes close by are beaten down with the weight of ice, the whole of which was the work of one nights [sic] frost. (Aug 5, 1895,Grey River Argus,2)

The application for the renewal of this license was also held over for a month to allow repairs to be effected to the fire escape and tank stand. (Jun 2, 1910,Hawera & Normanby Star,8)

Maclean The majority of the townspeople [sc. of Wellington] were dependent on shallow wells, rainwater tanks, and some on water from running streams. (1964,Challenge for Health,68)

SALMOND In the 1880s big corrugated iron tanks came on the market which were cheap enough for most households, and large enough to store water for the biggest of families. The round, corrugated tank became a characteristic of villa houses, sitting out the back on its high wooden stand hard up under the eaves, so that water would flow naturally through the outlet pipe in the bottom to the house. (1986,Old New Zealand,143)

n. a safe, a burglary involving a safe [(cf blow a tank, tank-artist)]

MACKENZIE tank a safe (1980,While We Have Prisons,99)

PARTRIDGE (1937,Dictionary of Slang)

PARTRIDGE A safe: New Zealand: since ca. 1920: 1932, Nelson Baylis (private letter); by 1935, also Australian; 1945, Baker, `To blow a tank, to break open a safe with gelignite'. Ex its shape-resemblance to a small watertank. (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,713,1961 ed.)

Now, I'd been in the cooler for a tank job and my presence is not wanted on racetracks. a tank....a safe (May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19)

Coulter: [A prison escaper. `I intended to] knock off a couple of tanks and shoot through.' (Jul 4, 1963,Dominion,5)

NEWBOLD TANK (n) A safe. Derives from British rhyming slang `septic tank' (bank). (1982,Big Huey, The,255)

Words for crimes include.. tank for a burglary involving a safe (presumably from the usage of tank, which refers simply to a safe). (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

tank folk¶

n. people dependent on tank water supply [Jim writes: I remember a light-hearted editorial in the Evening Post in the late 40s or 50s which referred to tank folk, ie people living in the Paremata-Kapiti area who were dependent on tank water.]

tank loaf¶

n. a concertina loaf

BYCROFT LTD Tank loaf (1934,Bread Baking in NZ,?124)

tank stand¶

n. the wooden platform on which stood a household water supply tank [common usage in Taranaki in the 1930s and subsequently]

When it's this early, I creep back past the wash house, the tank stand, the scullery ... (1986,Day and Night,5)

TANK STANDS. - Build tank stands with 6in. x 4in. uprights ... (1902,Brett's Colonists Guide,1146)

McCAULEY And a handyperson is wanted to do tankstand repairs. (1986,Then Again,116)

Just as the train was nearing the station at Gore, a dog was run over, Mr. Conyers leaned over from the side of the engine and was looking down the line, when his head struck against the tank stand, which had been placed too near the rails. (Feb 14, 1879,Otago Daily Times,3)

It was lying on the ground near the house tanks, having apparently been placed on the tank stand by Mr. Westlake on his return from Foxton. (Sep 23, 1929,Evening Post,10)

An injury to the groin was sustained by J. Urwin, a carpenter, of Raumati South, as a result of jumping from the top of a tank stand on which he was working on to a stick. (Apr 1, 1936,Evening Post,13)

Fatal injuries were received by John Harold Gibson, a middle-aged farmer, of Kaimiro, when a tank stand on which he was working yesterday, collapsed and he was pinned beneath a 400-gallon tank full of water. (Mar 28, 1944,Evening Post,4)

ANTHONY Peter had just finished his out-door work, on my arrival, and was busy at the tank stand, having a wash. (1936,Follow the Call,63)

tank water¶

n. household water supply collected originally from the roof by guttering and later pumped in from streams, wells etc.; usu. rainwater collected from a roof and fed into a holding tank for domestic use [ca1960 Wellington (Pukerua Bay)]

This [distilled] water was found greatly preferred to the tank water embarked ashore. (May 31, 1851,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,59)

They consider that some want of proper care in the selection of the casks must have occasioned this, as the tank water was not tainted. (Apr 12, 1862,Lyttelton Times,5)

This very ingenious and effective improvement in filters will be gladly welcomed by all householders, but it must commend itself at once more especially to those who reside in the country and who are necessarily more dependent upon tank water than wells. (Mar 7, 1896,Feilding Star,2)

In various parts of the town and district the tank water has a heavy, clayey appearance, caused, it is surmised, by dust from the eruption in Samoa brought down by the rain. (Nov 15, 1902,Grey River Argus,3)

BIRDS AND TANK WATER. (Jun 14, 1912,Poverty Bay Herald,5)

CARNARVON STREET - 4 Goood [sic] Rooms; new shed for motor-car, sewerage, city water, tank water; built of kauri. (Nov 26, 1920,Poverty Bay Herald,4)

".. The greater portion of water at present used in the town was either tank water or surface water taken from the well, into which drained, in many cases, stagnant pools, and all sorts of rubbish " (Sep 3, 1870,Timaru Herald,2)

No fresh tank water had been opened shortly after leaving there, nor had the passengers been eating tinned meat. (Dec 23, 1885,Star, The,4)

"Beachcomber" talks about the health value of tank water. (Jun 20, 1931,Evening Post,12)

TO LET, Farm Cottage, 3 rooms and kit., Normandale Rd., 2 miles from Lower Hutt Station, no e.l., tank water. (Oct 17, 1945,Evening Post,4)

tank-artist¶

n. a safe-blower

SARGESON 'Actually by profession he's a tank-artist... That's what they used to call a cracksman. (1967,Hangover,87) [NOTES: 1984 edition]

tank-trap¶

n.

STEAD Around the countryside, on roads coming up from likely landing places, 'tank-traps' appeared - the trunk of a large tree, one end pulled up on a steel cable, ready to be dropped down in the path of invaders. (1999,Talking about O'Dwyer,22)

tank-up¶

v. a booze-up

SLATTER `Anyway, let's get crackin on our own tank-up. Over to the bar at the high port. I'm dry as a wooden god.' (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,181)

tankblower¶

n.

HAMILTON I'd back some of the tankblowers to get a smoke through a two foot wall. They're the best, the tankblowers, and the more boob they've done the better usually. (1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,73)

tanked¶

adj. drunk; in the sense `drunk, boozed' as common in NZ as elsewhere, possibly reinforced by soldiers in WW1 (cf TANK)

He seldom committed that vulgar error of becoming `tanked'. (1916,Anzac Book, The,45)

All mad - or tanked. (1916,On the Anzac Trail,69)

FOSTON Many got `tanked' (full up with drink). Ibid. 187 Tim went on the bust and got tanked. (1921,At The Front,128)

MC: I'm drunk. ...Drunk. Tanked. Cut. Sloshed. Out of my tree. Shickered to beat the band. (Nov 22, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

So if you're tanked as a goldfish and hurt yourself, who's to blame? (Dec 21, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),7)

tanker¶

1 v. (Rural) to convey milk by tanker from farm to factory.

When milk tankers first came in, they closed down the little branches and tankered the milk to Midhurst. (Jul 20, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,22)

tanker driver¶

1 n. (Rural) [sp. use] a driver of a milk tanker that collects milk from dairy farms.

HARRISON 'You silly bugger!' said Sid, aghast when Harry proudly showed him his little green seedlings. Anyone could spot them a mile off, tanker drivers, whoever. (1986,She's a Fair Cow,66)

tanker loop¶

n. driveway around which tanker can turn when collecting milk

Winter is a good time for essential maintenance in and around the farm dairy, tanker loop and effluent ponds and systems. (Jun 2005,Farmlink,25) [NOTES: -]

. . . the woman sitting in the back of the Government issue Ford Falcon as it swooped along the tanker loop. (Dec 2003,Dairy Exporter (NZ),56) [NOTES: -]

Dairy companies are also recommending the middle of the tanker loop should be planted. (Apr 2002,Rural News) [NOTES: -]

tanker track¶

n. a farm road by which a milk tanker travels to collect milk from a cowshed.

..Mr Cox says the council was worried about effluent getting into water courses, which is why he confined the spreading to the tanker track. (Jun 2004,Dairyman, The,15)

1 n. (Rural) a road on a dairy farm on which a milk collection tanker can traverse paddocks to collect milk.

It [illusion of excellence] goes as far as keeping the milking shed painted, the tanker track clear of junk, and making your property attractive from the road. (May 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,111)

Roy grades the tanker track. (Sep 12, 2000,Waikato Times,9)

Tanker track troubles. Some North Taranaki dairy farmers say the Kiwi Dairy Company is taking a bullying approach over the state of tanker tracks on their farms. The farmers - who decline to be named because they say they fear retribution from Kiwi - believe the company's grading system for tanker tracks is overly rigorous. Acccording to the farmers, the company conducted surveys of tanker tracks and entrances, which included measuring track widths, turning conditions and entrances. (Nov 2, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,15)

In the hands of its dedicated and creative family, the tanker track has become lawn, the paddock, flowing and flowering borders. (Dec 22, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,14)

tankie¶

n. member of the Tank Corps

FULLARTON Most of [the tanks] conked out so the tankies used them as pill-boxes. (1944,Troop Target,30)

DAVIN `Where else? The show's a wash-out. You tankies have let him run all over you.' The sergeant flushed. (1975,Breathing Spaces,111)

HUGHES The walls of the APC bulged like a wobble board and out of the turrets popped the heads of a couple of stunned tankies, rather like startled prairie dogs. (1999,Shooting from the Lip,95)

tanking¶

n.

Tanking- A continuous waterproof membrane applied to a surface to precent the ingress or egress of water. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,113)

tankman¶

n. a safe-blower (cf TANK n2)

The old-style criminal activity such as breakmen' andtankmen' blowing safes and so on is starting to go. (Jul 17, 1978,Dominion,4)

NEWBOLD TANKMAN (n)C Safe-blowing expert. (1982,Big Huey, The,255)

tanky¶

1 n. (Rural) a water joey, or threshing mill crewman in charge of the water tank.

I joined the crew of Tozer's chaff-cutter in June 1926 .. I secure a job on the crew as 'tanky.' My mate. Gil McBride, was engaged as 'sewer' Jim Hamilton (my cousin) was to be ringer, Matt O'Driscoll the 'steerer' and 'feeder', then two stackmen. (Jan 9, 1963,Weekly News,33)

EVANS He later returned to the district as the 'tanky' or tank water driver (1975,Silver Tussock, The,134)

tannergram¶

n. [cf mod. gorillagram, stripogram]

Tannergrams is the somewhat apt designation which the new sixpenny telegrams have been christened in commercial vernacular. (Jun 13, 1863,Oamaru Mail)

MORRIS Tannergram, n. very recent New Zealand slang. On 1st of June, 1896, the New Zealand Government reduced the price of telegrams to sixpence (slang, a `tanner') for twelve words. (1898,Austral English,457)

BAKER (1941,NZ Slang,46)

The most simple and expressive is "Tannergram," and will doubtless come into equal popularity with "cablegram," which has for many years held its own. (Dec 9, 1885,Tuapeka Times,3)

Tanpap¶

abbr. There are no proposals at present to.. [ORIGIN: acronym]

This is a slightly more elegant version of the previous government's Tanpap scheme. "There Are No Proposals At Present to ... confiscate solo mothers' children / send all school leavers to boot camp / sell the Symphony Orchestra to Fay Richwhite." (Jun 24, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

tansy¶

n.

tansy [s] Tanacetum vulgare L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,71)

TAYLOR TANSY (Tanacetum vulgare) ... A European plant, formerly used for ornament and for tansy tea, now locally common throughout New Zealand,... (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,145)

tansy ragwort¶

n.

tansy ragwort n : a common ragwort (Senecio jacobaea) with pinnatifid leaves and compact clusters of yellow flower heads that is native to Europe, No. Africa, and western Asia but has been introduced in No. America, New Zealand, and Australia and in some areas is a dangerous and aggressive weed and toxic to cattle when consumed in quantity (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2338)

tantie¶

n. (informal) a tantrum [noun. Also tanty.]

There's even a special road rage concoction imaginatively titled Calm blending bergamot, mandarin and frankincense and myrrh (yes, really) to ease those traffic light tanties. (Jan 20, 2002,Sunday Star Times,D2)

After a brief attempt to find a street leading back to the city, the driver threw a tanty and pulled over. (Nov 16, 2005,Capital Times,3)

Had it been presaged even two years ago, there would have been major tanties. (Dec 18, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

And if they're not first, then it's tanty fits at 50 paces. (Oct 28, 2001,Sunday Star Times,A7)

What is so pathetic is that he has to get the media along to film him throwing his tantie. (May 20, 2001,Sunday Star Times,C5)

Plus I wanted to hear about the tantrums and get to laugh at their artistic pretensions. As it turned out, no tanties were witnessed. (Jul 16, 2001,Salient,No. 13 : 22)

We also got an authentic Laws tanty with oathing and blinding and a lot of girly foot-stamping, after his luggage got soaked during the eight-hour journey on top of the train. (Apr 2, 2003,Dominion Post,B7)

After a brief attempt to find a clear street leading back to the city, the driver threw a tanty and pulled over. (Nov 22, 2005,Capital Times,3)

[Hdg] A tour with plenty of laughs and tanties... Tracey throws an impressive tantrum when her boyfriend Stuey turns out to have cancelled a luxury coach booking for a cheaper trip in Tronk's Vee Dub Kombi. (Nov 7, 2000,Dominion,27)

tantrumatics¶

n. [Term used by Jenny Shipley on National Radio speaking to Kim Hill on 13/08/98 in reference to Winston Peters' action in walking out. Probably an accidental coinage - tantrum + dramatics]

tao cooking¶

n.

BURTON There are countless ways of preparing food Maori style, but basically there were only three ways of cooking it. The first, which involves steaming in a subterranean oven called an umu or hangi, is known as tao cooking. It was the preferred method of cooking for groups of people, from family size up, in a village setting. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,1)

taoka¶

n. treasure [ORIGIN: Maori, SI Maori = taonga]

Taoka, however precious to us, become forlorn junk, leftovers, on our deaths (1989,Homeplaces,119)

taoka tuku iho¶

phr. treasured asset of the past [ORIGIN: Maori, SI Maori taoka = taonga] (See taonga tuku iho)

It's an opportunity for Ngai Tahu to restore a taoka tuku iho (treasured asset of the past) ... (Jul 2005,Conservation Action,21)

taokete¶

n. brother-in-law; sister-in-law [ORIGIN: Maori, Definition from: http://www.learningmedia.co.nz/nz/online/ngata/m2edictionary]

Loved Taokete of Irene Mokai. Will be sadly missed. (Feb 24, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,46)

taonga¶

n. (collective) goods, valuables; (in singular) a highly-prized (Maori) object or person etc.; a treasure. [ORIGIN: Maori]

Are 'taonga' (valuables) buried there, too? (Dec 4, 1912,Otago Witness,89)

The second article of the Treaty guarantees to iwi Maori the control and enjoyment of those resources and taonga which it is their wish to retain. The preservation of a resource base, restoration of iwi self management, and the active protection of taonga, both material and cultural, are necessary elements of the Crown's policy of recognising rangatiratanga. (1989,Principles for Crown Action,10)

Ta|onga, s. Property procured by the spear, &c. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,207)

DIEEFENBACH Taonga - treasure, property, goods, rich ... (1843,Travels in NZ,2/384)

MANING The chief also, having made some enquiries .. such as, whether I was a rangatira, if I had plenty of taonga (goods) on board .. gave me a most sincere welcome. Ibid. (ii) 22 Has he not half a shipfull of taonga? Ibid. 236 Taonga - Goods; property. (1863,Old New Zealand,(i) 6)

BULLER The beautiful snow-white plumes from the back of this bird [Kotuku] have always been greatly prized by the Maoris, for the personal adornment of both the living and the dead, and their ancient poetry abounds in references to this valued taonga. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/127)

BAUCKE [The Maori] understood that by signing [the Treaty of Waitangi] he incorporated himself into a community whose stores of taonga (goods), of guns, blankets, axes, rum, and others were illimitable ... (1905,Where the White Man Treads,113)

.. the Maori is reacting on himself & his native culture, equipped with the `taonga' [ed fn: Property, treasures] the pakeha has laboriously gathered for himself. (Jan 4, 1929,Na To Hoa Aroha,1/166) [NOTES: 1929 Jan 4 Na To Hoa Aroha (1986) (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 1/166 (Ngata)]

Before last election Tumate, Te Rata's brother had announced his candidature. He was persuaded after some difficulty and the use of diplomacy to retire but not before Pom had been made to declare he would only run the life of this Parliament and then hand back the `taonga' to Waikato. (Jul 16, 1930,Na To Hoa Aroha,2/40) [NOTES: 1930 July 16 Na To Hoa Aroha (1987) (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 2/40 (Ngata)]

MYERS She was to be married tomorrow .. and the [Maori] children were laden with gifts. Each brought a little taonga; and into her apron, there fell the oddest assortment of things! (1941,Valiant Love,21)

A lump of wood of little or no great significance is thus transformed through the art process, by building words (korero) into it and by contact with people, into ting Maoris class as a taonga, or in full, he taonga tuku iho. The dictionary describes taonga as 'property', or as 'anything highly prized' (Williams 1971: 381). Thus a taonga tuku iho is a highly prized object that has been handed down from the ancestors. Ibid. 22 In the popular sense a taonga is a highly prized possession to which is attached korero (text or story). An example is a whakapapa (genealogy) staff. (1984,Te Maori,21)

The key element to the power of Te Maori [exhibition] has always been the presence of the elders, the supporters and the performers, that is, the people. We are moved by our taonga, by the ancestors represented in Te Maori. (Jun 13, 1986,NewsVUW (Wellington),13) [NOTES: S.Mead]

Wellington Maori, backed by Maori throughout the country, say that the Treaty of Waitangi requires the State to uphold the greatest taonga (treasure) of all, the Maori language, which, they say, has been prejudiced by several Acts of Parliament. (Jun 21, 1986,Evening Post,27)

Emotion spilled over as the Governor-General, Sir Paul Reeves, yesterday handed the taonga (treasure) back to the Tahitahi family and Te Aupouri tribe at Waimirirangi meeting house. (Jul 19, 1986,Dominion,1)

Old Hapuku .. presented him with a great taonga .. It is the skin of a very peculiar Huia ... (1879,TrNZI,11/337)

The head salesman .. had supplied Marama with so much taonga and "truck". (Dec 1912,NZ Free Lance,Xmas Annual 30)

A knowledge of Maori art and history and a commitment to the care of taonga is necessary. (Dec 19, 1992,Evening Post,28)

Of course the national psyche must suffer somewhat a the sight of one of our national taonga being so publicly and ritually disgraced. (Feb 2006,Express (Gay & Lesbian Express),11)

In Jon Gadsby's novel The Trough, the museum elevates an old Kelvinator found at the Petone tip to taonga status, after its provenance is traced back to the kai for the investiture of Dame Te Atairangikaahu. (Apr 8, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

It followed the Ngati Kahu claim that they need not pay dog registration fees because those four-foots, which are elsewhere called flea taxis in that other language, were suddenly elevated to "taonga" or treasures and, by definition, gave the tribe a guaranteed right of undisturbed possession under the Treaty of Waitangi. (Mar 29, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

"Ngawha to many Maori is a taonga from God... " In addition, most land in the north was of historical value to Maori and could be described as "taonga". (May 19, 2002,NZ Catholic,8)

Sarah admits she was going to chuck it all in after missing out on a taonga at the Sydney Olympics in 2000. But with the tautoko and awhi of her partner .. she decided to push on ... (2005,Te Mana Taiohi,8,Autumn ed.)

In New Zealand, a school cannot stop their students from wearing religious symbols, taonga or faith crucial clothing. (May 2005,Tearaway,13)

The site - the Observatory Reserve at Kelburn - is highly significant: it is a taonga, a turangawaewae, to be treasured and preserved - none but a fool or a knave would willingly surrender it! (Nov 1993,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,102/66)

Taonga such as Topeora's cloak and huia feathers provide the starting point for each episode. (Jun 8, 2006,Dominion Post,EG.8-14 June, p5)
