Hone Kouka We are now in a position to reclaim land and other taonga that had been confiscated illegally in the past. (1999,Ta Matou Mangai (Our Own Voice),10)

taonga industry¶

n.

What I now call the taonga industry indeed has the best of backing... The courts, and in particular the Privy Council, may have accepted the Waitangi Tribunal's findings, but the fact is that the taonga industry was founded on myth. (Jun 2, 2004,MediaSearch) [NOTES: The Press, City Edition]

taonga puoro¶

n. Maori musical instruments / music

Canadian composer Teresa Connors, in partnership with respected taonga puoro musicians Rangiira Hedley ... (Mar 1, 2006,Porirua City News,1)

Exhibitions of Ta Moko (body art), Hauora (health in massage), Taonga Puoro, (Maori music), Raranga (weaving), Korero Purakau (storytelling). (Sep 27, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,10)

The festival will focus on taonga puoro or Maori musical instruments, and there'll be a free concert from Anika Moa and a kapa haka performance. (May 27, 2004,Wellington Contact,1)

Traditional Maori instrument player Richard Nunns says New Zealanders are more familiar with the sounds of the instruments, or taonga puro, than they know. (Sep 24, 2004,Dominion Post,B10)

taonga species¶

n. treasured species (See species taonga)

Taonga species are native birds, plants and animals of special cultural significance and importance to Ngai Tahu that are found within the Ngai Tahu takiwa, defined by the Te Runanga o Ngai Tahu Act 1996 as being most of the South Island (excluding a northern segment) and the islands to the south including Stewart Island/Rakiura and others. There are 49 bird, 58 plant and 6 marine mammal taonga species - see full list below. (2010,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.doc.govt.nz/about-doc/role/maori/settlements/ngai-tahu/species/]

They [Westland petrels] are classified as vulnerable by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and considered a taonga species by Ngai Tahu. (Jan 8, 2006,Sunday Star Times,A6)

taonga tuku iho¶

phr. treasures passed down [ORIGIN: Maori]

"The Maori Party is based totally on taonga tuku iho, [treasures passed down] that's come down for 1000 years in these islands and survived colonisation, just. ..." (Dec 2004,North & South,64)

taonga tuturu¶

n. valuable artifacts, especially those newly discovered. [ORIGIN: Maori]

NOTICE OF TAONGA TUTURU FOUND .. Pursuant to section 11 of the Protected Objects Act 1975, the Acting Chief Executive of the Ministry for Culture and Heritage has been notified of the finding of the following taonga tuturu .. Claims for ownership of one or more of the taonga tuturu are to be lodged with the Acting Chief Executuve within 60 working days ... (Feb 11, 2009,Dominion Post,C13)

Taonga tuturu are a special category of protected objects. They have to be 50 years or older, but are also things that relate to Maori culture, history or society, or are believed to have been made, or used, by Maori. (Jun 3, 2012,Sunday Star Times,C4)

taonui¶

n.

By far the most plentiful amongst the bird community at Karewa is the flesh-footed shearwater (Hemipuffinus carneipes), or taonui of the Maoris. (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,7/183) [NOTES: (Sladden)]

FLESH-FOOTED SHEARWATER, or TAONUI (Puffinus carneipes). (1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/208)

tap¶

v. to ask (a person) for a favour, esp. a loan; =(cold-)bite is as common in NZ as elsewhere

PATTERSON On arrival on a new field the nearest storekeeper is tapped' as to his willingness or otherwise to give the newcomer astart' - that is, to provide him with a few weeks' provisions while he digs the necessary gum. (1904,Kauri-Gum,5)

Rumor [sic] has it that before leaving Wellington this youthful nobleman tapped' a Minister of the Crown for a pony, and soon after his arrival in the northern city he suddenly became short of theneedful'. (Feb 11, 1911,NZ Truth,294/7/1)

Some tap the boss before they join,/And their record clearly shows/ By this they make their marble good/ (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,31)

SYDER & HODGETTS To ask for a loan. .in 4;`Perhaps you could get some help from your brother. Why don't you tap him for a loan - I think he'd very likely let you have the money.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],1009) [NOTES: (1962-63)1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust. and NZ English [TS] 1009]

tap ... NZ & Austral. colloq. minimum amount of work (in neg. contexts, e.g. he hadn't done a tap). (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,785) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

v. to obtain bush-bled kauri gum from the live tree

REED [Climbing for fresh-bled tree gum] he makes a cut in the bark [of the kauri] like the horizontal barb of an arrow. The cut (he calls it the `tap') is deepest at the apex. (1948,Gumdigger, The,78)

tap-a-tap¶

n. [[e.g. under tattoo - 1842 Bremner???]] (See tapu)

tap-room¶

n.

... the great number of runaway sailors that are to found generally spending every shilling in the tap-room ... (Sep 13, 1849,Letters from Otago,36,1878 ed.)

tapa¶

n.

MANING There was a kind of variation on the tapu, called tapa, of this nature. For instance, if a chief said, That axe is my head', the axe became his to all intents and purposes, except, indeed, the owner of the axe was able to break hishead', in which case, I have reason to believe, the tapa would fall to the ground. It was, however, in a certain degree necessary to have some legal reason, or excuse, for making the tapa; but to give some idea of what constituted the circumstances under which a man could fairly tapa anything, I must needs quote a case in point. (1863,Old New Zealand,(xii) 174)

tapa cloth¶

n. cloth made from paper-mulberry bark

For years, he boldly plugged on with his belief that tapa cloth can rightly sit beside quilt-making in exhibitions he has curated - a welding of the indigenous and the colonial. (Sep 2003,NZ Heritage,No. 90/25)

tapairu¶

n. first-born female

tapairu, first-born female in female of high rank, who was invested with special mana and special tapu: noblesse oblige strictly observed. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/158) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

Tapanui flu¶

n. a common name for a group of symptoms otherwise called the myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME) syndrome. [from Tapanui, a town in Southland]

[Hdg] Tapanui flu remains a mystery. Right now no one really knows what ME (myalgic emphysema or Tapanui flu) is all about, despite the fervent beliefs of some doctors and many patients who have been pigeon-holed in the appropriate diagnostic box. (Feb 17, 1993,Evening Post,18)

His first real break.. was followed by three long years of a perplexing, Tapanui-flu-like condition which saw him sidelined by exhaustion three games out of five. (Sep 2000,North & South,32)

Dr Pajak also blames the explosion for the Tapanui 'flu which he believes is caused by exposure to the high levels of radioactivity that can still be found in some pockets in the Crater. (Aug 1988,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,81/52) [NOTES: Reproduced from NZ Truth.]

I first became aware of the debilitating nature of this in the early 80s when a workmate's daughter went down with what they then called Tapanbui flu just before whe was due to leave for the UK on her OE... Unfortunately no one knows what causes this chronic fatigue. It has been called many names: Tapanui flu, myalgic encephalomyelitis and immune dysfunction syndrome but it now seems that the medics in this country and Australia have settled on the term Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS). (Apr 2000,North & South,103)

In 1983 the 'Tapanui Flu' was for people in Tapanui; terms like ME - myalgic encephalitis - or Chronic Fatigue Syndrome were largely unknown (Mar 1991,More Magazine,108)

For a while though it was McGregor who looked after Fergus, when he was badly debilitated by chronic fatigue which dates from a bout of Tapanui flu in 1984. (Jul 1, 2005,Dominion Post,B11)

There is a belief - though this has yet to be backed by strong scientific evidence - that a bout of glandular fever can lead to ME (myalgic encephalomyelitus), chronic fatigue syndrome or Tapanui flu. (Mar 19, 2002,Dominion,12)

Even its name depends on the direction you come from: benign myalgic encephalomyelitis, Tapanui flu, postviral syndrome, epidemic neurasthenia - or any of 30 longwinded titles. (Nov 29, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

tapatapa¶

n. a curse, especially one involving a notable person [ORIGIN: Maori]

TREGEAR The third curse (tapatapa) was to call anything by a person's name ... For instance, if a chief taptapa'd a spear by saying that it was one of his legs, it became his property ... (1904,Maori Race, The,204)

Taylor Another way of obtaining revenge was by cursing. To call any object by the name of a chief, and then strike or insult it, was regarded as a curse; this was tapatapa or tukutuku. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,94)

.. and it is not uncommon to hear a chief complain that he has been shot at, when on explanation it appears that he has only been shot in effigy. This form of insult is called a "tapatapa" or "tukutuku". (Mar 31, 1852,New Zealander, The,2)

.. were a chief to become aware that a chief of a neighbouring district had used some insulting expression towards him, he might tapu the track leading to that district, which would cause much inconvenience until it was reopened. That particular kind of insult known as a tapatapa might cause such an action. (1907,Proceedings RSNZ,40/198)

taper off¶

v.

Stop drinking too much (without misery). In old days station hands and others used to get `on the spree' when they visited town. when they returned to the station they drank a little less each day for a few days till they felt normal. Then they got back to tea, bread, and mutton without much suffering. (C.) (Dec 23, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

tapeur¶

n. a frequent borrower (of money) (cf TAP v, and French

Oscar was a notorous `tapeur' borowing money from a friend and forgetting to pay it back. (1913,Triad, The,20/9/19)

tapitap¶

n.

A letter might be written about the tapitap so useful for hammer handles, the hakihaki for the handles of axes, and the ramiram for ramming in the posts in fencing. (Jun 15, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/97,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (H.R. Richmond)]

Tappy¶

n. (informal) Mount Tapuaenuku (Marlborough) [ca1930 R. Mason Very general among trampers ca1940 common in Marlborough.]

tappy-tap¶

n. (See tapu)

tapu¶

n. [ORIGIN: Maori]

FINLAYSON He remembered well how he himself had once tomahawked a Pakeha who broke the tapu of a burial ground. (1938,Brown Man's Burden,36) [NOTES: 1973 edition]

The body of Te Heuheu, who was killed by a land slip, was lying in a native tapu. (May 7, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,14)

adj.

FINLAYSON A pretty state of affairs, he said, if a tapu tree could be desecrated by mere busybodies. (1938,Brown Man's Burden,36) [NOTES: 1973 edition]

CHEVASSE Well, we talked about everything except our bush walk; that was tapu. [fn] Sacred, impermissible. (1990,Integrity,14)

"Achieving a great gig occurs when you treat the stage like it's sacred, like a treasure, sort of tapu." (May 8, 2003,Dominion Post,D3)

The rock is represented by a stylised pyramidal shape with no sense of mass, power or beauty, and its central placement upstage inhibits the action horribly (being tapu, it cannot be played in front of, so the actors are confined almost entirely to the sides of the stage). (Sep 21, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

If the present death rate continues most of the "fine old Maoris" of Whangaroa will be consigned to the local tapu ground. (Dec 6, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,8)

[The Brothers] was a tapu place where dwelt an atua or deity, who controlled the winds and seas. (May 2, 1910,Dominion,6)

Now the sons of those men told me that, and they believed in the end that the treaty itself ought to be left alone as a tapu document. (Aug 11, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

v. [to render tapu, cf taboo]

In the parish of Omanaia, in this district, a block of land, containing several thousand acres, has been tapued on the forty-acre system; and not a single settler is residing there. (May 29, 1867,Daily Southern Cross,6)

When the Maori war broke out Wells was captured by the Maoris, but was saved from torture and death by the wife of a maori chief, who "tapued" him. (Sep 24, 1889,West Coast Times,4)

tapu rakau¶

phr.

The warrior places before them a tapu rakau (leaf or similar object.) (Dec 19, 1999,NZ Catholic,7)

tapu'd/tapued¶

1 adj. (Rural) [Ma.] [of land and other features] sacred.

HUNT And so they kept going until the whole of the tapued property, potatoes, pumpkins and barley, were neatly piled up in the yard. (1866,Twenty-Five Years in NZ,51)

JACOBSON .. if they had reserved nothing more than the 'tapued' lands that we indicate as being those between Periga (Peraki) and the Bay of Oihoa. (1940,Akaroa Mail and Banks Peninsula Advertiser,184)

WOODHOUSE In 1923 the Waikopiro Maori block was opened up for returned soldiers and the five sections were balloted for. This land was tapu-ed by the maoris on account of the massacre that had taken place there so many years before. (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,73)

STACEY His [harvesting] fork was his own and tapu'd an inch thick. Lord help any new chum who had the impudence to touch it. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,41)

tapu-lifting/tapu-removal¶

n. [attrib.]

MIKAERE Tapu-lifting ceremonies were also carried out to [42] remove restrictions which had been imposed for specific purposes. (1998,Te Maiharoa,41)

MIKAERE Perhaps because St Paul had said that the old covenant was fulfilled in Christ, the tapu-removal ceremony was to be performed once only. (1988,Te Maiharoa,43)

tapued¶

adj.

adj. [also tapu'd] (See tabooed)

WILLIAMS In the afternoon we were told that a large party was on their way to this place, for the purpose of stripping us ... Tikoki had stripped an Englishman on the opposite side yesterday ... out of revenge for some property of his, which had been stolen out of a tapued house ... (Jan 29, 1827,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The) [NOTES: 1827 Jan 29 H. Williams Early Journals (1961) 41]

WILLIAMS The canoe was Tapu'd, having conveyed the body of Hengi ... to his former place. (Jan 18, 1832,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,1961 ed.) [NOTES: 1832 Jan 18 H. Williams Early Journals (1961) 220]

YATE A man who has touched a very young child, or has approached a corpse, or has rendered the last sad offices of friendship for a friend, is strictly tapued for several days; and is not allowed to touch food with his hands, nor in any way to feed himself, but by picking up his sustenance from the ground with his lips and teeth. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),85)

POLACK ... such would have been Caddell's fate, had he not ran up to a chief ... who happened accidentally to be tapued at the time, and, catching hold of his garment, was saved in consequence; ... Ibid.1/67 She politely welcomed us, as we marched through her plantation of Indian corn and kumeras [a-acute], which were nearly ripe and in fine condition : unfortunately for us, the place was strictly tapued, or prohibited from being touched by any person, until the following harvest; ..Ibid.1/141 The whole of the prepared flax was tapued [a-acute], and of course safe from depredation. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/52)

POLACK When a place is to be tapued, the intimation is announced to all whom it may concern (or not) by a raoui or grotesque carving in wood, painted with the usual red earth, which is found in certain districts, and is baked after the native method. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,2/276)

MAJORIBANKS The tapu' or tabboo is a ceremony common to New Zealand, along with all the other South Sea Islands. The power oftapuing' seems to be vested in the principal chief alone, and may be considered the most important bulwark of his authority. This ceremony [90] renders every object, either animate or inanimate, sacred, or not to be approached, so that no person can enter tapued ground, nor touch a tapued person. Every girl promised in marriage is tapued, and married women also, until chastised by their husbands, when the `tapu' ceases, and they are then free to any one who can catch them, a remarkably good plan for securing the affections of the husband, and relieving the sex from some of those periodical chastisements in which some of the husbands in this country are so apt to indulge. Favourite pigs, canoes, and muskets are sometimes tabooed; burial ground is always tabbooed, and so is also a chief's head. (1844,Travels in NZ,89)

... a principal chief, who it seems was tapued, or rendered sacred for the time, was knocked down and beaten by one of the Maori police, ... (May 17, 1851,Lyttelton Times,6)

MUNDY The tapued resting place of departed chieftains. (1852,Our Antipodes,284,1855 ed.) [NOTES: [check pagination with 1852 edn]]

THOMSON ... at certain seasons places where shell-fish abounded were tapued. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/153)

MANING In some cases he would be fed by another person, who ... would manage to do it without touching the tapu'd individual; ... Ibid. (viii) 136 ... I myself once got tapu'd with this same horrible ... style of tapu? (1863,Old New Zealand,(viii) 134)

SHORTLAND About two hours after she retired to a house, in which had been hung up a tapued gun; this she loaded, and ... discharged it. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,63)

GUTHRIE Some of the settlers had unwittingly caused trouble by cutting down `tapued' trees to build boats. (1930,NZ Memories,80)

CURR [see introd. cits] No wonder the subject is tabooed (or tapued) here [in Wellington]. (1856,Waste Lands of Wellington, The,5)

He walked a short distance to a tapu'd place and with the utmost unconcern brought me the head wrapped in a dirty bloody native mat. (1999,James Preece Missionary Papers,23) [NOTES: From The Missionary Register 1838]

The carrying of a road for the Company through a piece of tapued ground is still under consideration, and only requires the exercise of a little patience and pertinacity to secure it. (Feb 16, 1870,Taranaki Herald,8)

Ragwort, tutu, docks, fern, etc., outgrow those of any "tapued" native land, while fences are delapidated [sic], gates and rails require painting, and to aggravate (or is it to hide?) the offence, a belt of half-dead and unattended trees, planted by past trustees, adjacent to the fence, are a blot on the landscape and are left to shut out the sun and air from graves and road ... (Jan 5, 1910,Bay of Plenty Times,4)

Twenty men (among whom was our cook, Pirougia), headed by Hohaia te Rarau, formed the tapued party. (Apr 30, 1897,Evening Post,2)

adj. [(see also 1827 cit. a. above)]

2 adj. [tapu'd - move to tapued + Note]

tapuing¶

n. [aka tabooing]

Tiroa [205] returned the knife to me, after he had taken the taboo off, by rubbing it over with the gills of a fish. This strange custom of tabooing I do not understand, further than that it is a law strictly observed, & any wilful breach of it is considered a serious offense, & in severe instances punishable by death. (1827,Boultbee Journal,204) [NOTES: 1827 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 204-205]

[This or prev. cit???] This strange custom of tabooing I do not understand, further than it is a law strictly observed, and any wilful breach of it is considered a serious offence, and in several instances punishable by death. (1835,Boultbee Journal,88) [NOTES: c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 88]

MAJORIBANKS The tapu' or tabboo is a ceremony common to New Zealand, along with all the other South Sea Islands. The power oftapuing' seems to be vested in the principal chief alone, and may be considered the most important bulwark of his authority. This ceremony [90] renders every object, either animate or inanimate, sacred, or not to be approached, so that no person can enter tapued ground, nor touch a tapued person. Every girl promised in marriage is tapued, and married women also, until chastised by their husbands, when the `tapu' ceases, and they are then free to any one who can catch them, a remarkably good plan for securing the affections of the husband, and relieving the sex from some of those periodical chastisements in which some of the husbands in this country are so apt to indulge. Favourite pigs, canoes, and muskets are sometimes tabooed; burial ground is always tabbooed, and so is also a chief's head. (1844,Travels in NZ,89)

Campbell When any article was fancied, the intending purchaser took a thrumb from the fringe of his or her mat, and fastened it on to the chosen article. If the selector happened to be wearing a blanket or shirt or mat without a fringe, or wearing nothing at all, as was sometimes the case, from which any tapu-ing mark could be detached, then a neighbouring flax bush, or piece of flax from a potato kit, supplied the wherewithal to affix the tapu. (1881,Poenamo,4/6/293)

The committtee of runanga have (I hear) agreed to allow the sale of wheat, provided it never rules at a lower rate here than 5s. cash; but as they say we have been making a profitable spec. by sending timber to your market, they have stopped that branch of trade by tapuing the sale of all timber, firewood, &c., either for sale or home consumption. (Jan 29, 1859,Otago Witness,6) [NOTES: Reprinted from the Hawke's Bay Herald]

There was a meeting convened for the purpose of taking into consideration the propriety of tapuing an aukati at Aotea, for the object of preventing any white traders visiting Kawhia; and it was agreed by runanga that no persons should be allowed to pass he boundary line without signing their names in a kind of pass-book, kept for the purpose by Maaka, the King's toll-keeper. (Jun 13, 1867,Daily Southern Cross,3)

The Otago Mining Stock Exchange almost unanimously carried a resolution to ask other exchanges to join them in tabooing any further flotation of dredging companies. (May 24, 1900,Timaru Herald,3)

The question of the status of counsel before the Committee was also discussed, and the general feeling appeared to be in favor of tabooing the legal gentlemen. (Jul 15, 1896,Tuapeka Times,3)

tapuism¶

n.

To institutionalise the religion of "tapuism" is an outright breach of the Bill of Rights, and the Minister responsible should be called to account. (May 6, 2000,Evening Post,4)

taputini¶

n. a variety of kumara [ORIGIN: Maori]

Dell Wihongi, a leading figure in the claim, said the hutuhuti, rekamaroa and taputini were the last remaining varieties of the indigenous crop, and it was important Maori were recognised as guardians. (Feb 1, 2007,NZ Herald,1)

TAR¶

abbr. Traffic Accident Report

This figure comes from Traffic Accident Reports (TAR) filled out by the police after every accident involving injury they attend... Kippenburger says there are many corners on rural roads that drivers don't manage to negotiate even at 80km/h, and these will probably be recorded as excessive speed on a TAR sheet. (Jan 15, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

tar¶

n.

tar: Stockholm tar was once used as an antiseptic sealer on cuts, and although this has been generally replaced by improved antiseptics and special powders against flies, these new substances are still referred to as tar'. At one time in the big sheds when any shearer calledtar' there was a tarboy to dab the cut, but now this is usually by the nearest shedhand. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/28) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

v.

In case a shearer turns out a sheep badly cut or insufficiently tarred, he shall at once sew and tar such wounds in his pen. (1906,Awards etc.,VII/625)

In some sheds the managers insist on the cuts made in shearing being tarred, to prevent them being fly-blown; others use kerosene. (Sep 28, 1878,Otago Witness,3)

1 v. (Rural) to apply tar to a sheep afflicted with shearing wounds or fly-strike.

T.J.S rode round again to Kahikanui and tarred a ram with the fly. (Dec 14, 1889,Tutira Station Diary)

2 n.

Tar.- In the old days t. was always put on sheep cut by the shears. Nowadays some carbolic dip, kerosene, or Condy's is used; but it is always called t. When he cuts a sheep the shearer calls out T., boy, t. on the leg', and a fleecepicker or broomie dabs the disinfectant on with a <i>t.stick</i> and puts it back in the <i>t. pot.</i> Patterson writes ofThe tar boy, the cook, and the slushy, The sweeper that swept the board', but I do not think a tarboy was ever employed specially in New Zealand sheds. (C.) (Dec 25, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

NEWTON TAR: In earlier days a pot of Stockholm tar was kept in shearing sheds. If sheep were cut during shearing, the cut was dabbed with tar. Today this has been mainly replaced by other antiseptics, but these are still referred to as tar.' If a shearer cuts a sheep he calls:Tar.' (1949,High Country Days,197,1950 ed.)

SCRYMGEOUR exclam. (shearers') Proceeding just fair, but with their regularity that follows a shearer getting his back used to the arduous job, the advancement went on but with a different and a rougher cut than was usual. More frequently application of the loppies galloping down the board, to the ever increasing cry of `Tar'. The cut was becoming rougher and numbers spoilt good work, and slowly the gore of the classer, the shepherds, and certainly that of William Steuart, rose. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,49)

PINNEY A tarboy would disinfect cuts made by the shearers. He came at the cry of Tar'. For a bad cut the cry would be:Tar, and a bag for the guts'. (1981,Early Northern Otago Runs,12)

ANDERSON "Tar" one yelled (when a sheep is cut a shearer calls for tar or sulphur to dab on the cut) . (1975,Mary-Lou,57)

WHOLESALE PRICES CURRENT .. TAR: Coal GBP1 15s 0d .. GBP0 0s 0d[,] Stockholm GBP2 0s 0d .. GBP5 0d. (Oct 31, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,4)

3 n. shortened form of tar-seal [ca?1939 A Havelock rhyme about a child who persisted in riding his tricycle on the newly-sealed main road Robin rode on the Havelock road,/ A motorist came from afar;/ Jim Lovell took his shovel and broom/ And scraped him off the tar.]

RHODES `Follow the tar-sealed road as far as Darfield,' Mike Foster's instructions read ... Off the tar now and on to shingle - and into clouds of dust. (1952,Fly Away Peter,99)

tar pot¶

1 n. (Rural) a tin containing Stockholm tar, used to apply to shearing cuts on sheep.

MCMILLAN Water pots, tar pots, rosellas, bare bellies - words gone from sheds that will never come back. (1975,More From the High Country,42)

RICHARDS Each stand had a tar-pot nailed to the wall. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,44)

ASPINALL It was always my job to turn the grindstone for them (shearers); to shed up, pick up, pen up, press up and be there pronto with the tar pot. [tar-pot] (1993,Farming Under Aspiring,93)

When the boss is cursing loudly, and the tar-pot's flying round, / When the pieces and the bellies is a coverin' the ground, / When the shears is clicking quickly, and the fleeces coming thickly, / When the rouseabouts are grumblin' - well, ye'll know it's shearin' then. (Feb 17, 1904,Otago Witness,59)

Tar White¶

n. an Anglicisation of Te Awa-iti

The spot was known by the mellifluous name of Te Awa-iti, "the little river"... How were they to know that.. the whalers and scalliwags.. would corrupt the musical name into the awful crudity of "Tar White?" (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,165) [NOTES: Written of 1940]

The rusting try-pots are the only relics of "Old Tar White". (1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),2(1) : 3)

tar-baby¶

1 n. Maori

SHADBOLT `Those tar-babies and that fellow in the sweater - if you ask me ...' (1959,New Zealanders, The,140,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (Play the Fife Lowly)]

2 n. road cyclist

[heading] The Onslow Tar-babies. ... The name derives from a mountain-bikers' name for road cyclists. ... The Tar-babies have a "president for life", a "hunt master" to control each ride, and a self-appointed committee that meets by Internet or over a beer in the "Postie's Whistle" once or twice a year. ... The Onslow tar-babies are assembled at the old BP station in Khandallah. (Oct 22, 2005,Evening Post,E18)

tar-boy¶

n. a person who walks the board where sheep are prone to fly strike and puts a smear of tar on the shearing cuts made in response to the shearers' call `tar!' (Tar is now replaced by modern antiseptics and fly repellants.)

1 n. (Rural) a shed-hand who applies tar to a cut on a sheep being shorn. [shearing; aka tarboy, tar boy]

MCLEOD ... there would come a shout from the other end of the board, and if he didn't come at once - 'Tar! boy, tar!' to hurry him up. (1954,On the Hill,12)

Tar-boy: the first-aid hand who in earlier days administered Stockholm tar to the wounds on badly shorn sheep. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20)

MACNICOL & TROTTER I used to pick up the fleeces and sweep the floor and be tar boy. (1987,I, Duncan from Skippers,61)

RICHARDS The tar-boy was kept busy applying Stockholm tar to the minor cuts but more severe cuts had to be stitched. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,44)

Tar.- In the old days t. was always put on sheep cut by the shears. Nowadays some carbolic dip, kerosene, or Condy's is used; but it is always called t. When he cuts a sheep the shearer calls out <i>T</i>., boy,<i>t</i>. on the leg', and a fleecepicker or broomie dabs the disinfectant on with a <i>t.stick</i> and puts it back in the <i>t. pot.</i> Patterson writes ofThe tar boy, the cook, and the slushy, The sweeper that swept the board', but I do not think a tarboy was ever employed specially in New Zealand sheds. (C.) (Dec 23, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

BOWEN TAR-BOY. The hand who walks the board where sheep are subject to the fly and who puts a smear of tar of the cuts made on sheep. (1956,Wool Away!,157)

The first-aid hand who in earlier days administered Stockholm tar to wounds of sheep cut in shearing. (Feb 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing)]

tarboy n. woolshed hand who applies tar to cuts made on sheep by shearers. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

TAR-BOY: The first-aid hand who in earlier days administered Stockholm tar to the wounds on badly shorn sheep. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20) [NOTES: Shearer's language]

tarboy ... n. woolshed hand who applies tar to cuts made on sheep by shearers. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

PINNEY [Notes] 12. A tarboy would disinfect cuts made by the shearers. He came at the cry of Tar'. For a bad cut the cry would be:Tar, and a bag for the guts'. (1981,Early Northern Otago Runs,229)

Person who walks the board where sheep are prone to fly strike and puts a smear of tar on the shearing cuts made in response to the shearers' call `tar'. Tar is now replaced by modern antiseptics and fly repellants. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,60)

RICHARDS ... I was allowed to miss school to help in the shed by picking up the bellywool and removing the pizzle stains from the wether bellywool. I was also `tar-boy', which meant putting dabs of Stockholm tar on any cuts inflicted by the shearers. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,55)

tar: Stockholm tar was once used as an antiseptic sealer on cuts, and although this has been generally replaced by improved antiseptics and special powders against flies, these new substances are still referred to as tar'. At one time in the big sheds when any shearer calledtar' there was a tarboy to dab the cut, but now this is usually by the nearest shedhand. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/28) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

But the shearer is up and busy two or three minutes before the time, has taken his shears from the tar-boy, or "picker up," who has been practicing a little through the leisure, has given the blades a final touch with the stone, thrown the coat off his shoulders, and stripped and eager as a wrestler at the call of "time," stands at the door of his pen. (Oct 20, 1887,Timaru Herald,4)

One recently returned, per registered parcel post, addressed to a Hawke's Bay station-owner, a pair of greasy bluchers, found in a bale of New Zealand wool. Probably, a "tar-boy's" joke. (Sep 19, 1903,New Zealand Free Lance,26)

RICHARDS I was also "tar-boy", which meant putting dabs of Stockholm tar on any cuts inflicted by the shearers. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,55)

tar-brand¶

v. tar-mark, sc. of sheep, or occas. cattle

ELWELL It took a good month to muster and tar-brand all the sheep. (1878,Boy Colonists,202)

Mr Heslop said he had had cattle in his possession which had been tar-branded for weeks, and the brand was quite plain; and, more than that, he used to tar-brand all the cattle he sent to the Witaraa works, and there would be no difficulty about it at all. (Jun 20, 1893,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

No doubt, the sheepfarmers of the South were compelled to tar-brand immediately after shearing, and in the case of merinos this would be generally sufficient for a twelvemonths, but long-wool sheep would have to be branded at frequent intervals to keep the brand legible. (Jun 21, 1889,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

No doubt, the sheepfarmers of the South were compelled to tar-brand immediately after shearing, and in the case of merinos this would be generally sufficient for a twelvemonths, but long-wool sheep would have to be branded at frequent intervals to keep the brand legible. (Jun 21, 1889,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

Mr Heslop said he had had cattle in his possession which had been tar-branded for weeks, and the brand was quite plain; and, more than that, he used to tar-brand all the cattle he sent to the Waitara works, and there would be no difficulty about it at all. (Jun 20, 1893,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

Some parties who had previously paid Messrs. Chalmers for twelve months, and whose term was not expired, claimed to be exempted till the end of such period producing their receipt, were informed they should have to pay just as others would have to do; that he should tarbrand all cattle on the run to prevent evasion; that all calves when six months old should be so branded and paid for ... (Oct 24, 1868,Tuapeka Times,3)

Mr Budge interjected that if you tar-branded cattle, and the cattle rubbed, together in the yard, the brands would simply be a smudge in the course of half an hour, and that certainly the brands would not last. (Jun 20, 1893,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

n. [tar mark on farm animal, as label; incl attrib] (See tar-mark)

At first sight I thought I was in this way going to escape the tar-brand business; but no turning to clause 19, I find that though I may ear-mark if I like, I am in some mysterious way to do so "without removing any part of the whole ear," under a penalty of GBP20. (Jun 8, 1880,Evening Post,2)

I could not swear to his sheep but by the tar-brand; they were not counted to me. (Jul 4, 1857,Otago Witness,2)

LOST from Messrs. Hunter and Co.'s saleyards, on the night of Saturday last, a Yellow HEIFER, springing in calf, with white stripe down the back, white tail, short horns, and a tar-brand "33". (Jun 18, 1866,Daily Southern Cross,1)

LOST from the farm of JOHN CROZIER. - One WHITE HEIFER, branded 30 (fire-brand) and 13 (tar-brand). (Sep 19, 1881,Taranaki Herald,3)

It is too late for any suggestions as to wool-branding sheep to be made use of for the benefit of this season's clip, but the complaints respecting tar-brands in wool are so strong that we repeat the buyers' remarks on the subject, so that when branding sheep after shearing some of teh many non-injurious branding materials may be used. (Oct 4, 1892,Ashburton Guardian,2)

STRAYED, from the Scotch Church, Otahuhu, a Strawberry COW, close to her calving; tar-brand 24. (Apr 2, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,2)

tar-mark¶

n. [tar mark or brand as label on farm animal] (See see tar-brand)

LOST, last week, four fat COWS; and the week previous, one fat STEER with tar-mark on shoulder. (Apr 20, 1883,Otago Daily Times,1)

v. to mark a farm animal (espec. sheep) with tar [cf.tar-brand v]

PHARAZYN Tar marked B's and M's sheep. (1847,Journal,81)

... tar-marking and branding cattle (Aug 30, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,61)

STRAYED from Kaikorai Yards on Wednesday last, 16th inst., THREE COWS, tar-marked near shouder and loin. (Apr 23, 1873,Otago Daily Times,1)

STRAYED from Kaikorai Yards on Wednesday last, 16th inst., THREE COWS, tar-marked on near shoulder and loin. (Apr 23, 1873,Otago Daily Times,1)

The following morning Ching and I went to draft the cattle; he .. called my attention to a calf that was not tar-marked. (Dec 15, 1884,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

tar-marked¶

adj. [stock farming: marked with tar as farmer's label]

A large quantity of wool is used in the manufacture of carpets and similar productions, and although employes [sic] are cautioned to exercise due care and vigilance to take out any tar-marked wool, they may discover, it frequently happens that tar marks in small quantities pass through the various stages into the finished goods and cause considerable damage and loss. (Jun 4, 1896,Star, The,2)

tar-pot¶

n.

SMITH Prior to the commencement of shearing the board is fitted with `tar-pots', so called because in the early days tar was used to put on the cuts accidentally made by the shearers; but as tar [74] would not scour out ..., it is now usual to use an antiseptic liquid. (1927,Sheep & Wool Industry,73)

When he cuts a sheep the shearer calls out `T., boy, t. on the leg', and a fleecepicker or broomie dabs the disinfectant on with a t.stick and puts it back in the t. pot. (Dec 23, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

WOODHOUSE Get ready with tar-pot and brooms for the job,/ While the shearers stroll over to size up the mob/ (1950,Farm & Station Verse,185) [NOTES: 1949 Stronach `Shearing' in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 185]

tar-seal¶

n. a tar-sealed road, bitumenised roadway [aka tarseal]

FRAME (1957,Owls Do Cry,48)

SHADBOLT Tar-seal gave way to a road of clay and pumice ... (1959,New Zealanders, The,88,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (Love Story)]

SLATTER Harry ... got out saying he wanted to live and walked ahead of us along the tar-seal, a defiant figure marching along in the headlights, ... (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,15)

BACON As we came nearer to Estuarine, the roads improved, and once we were on the tarseal, my spirits rose. (1963,In the Sticks,172)

HILLIARD (1963,Piece of Land, A,91)

[tar]-sealed (New Zealand), surfaced with [tar] macadam, so [tar]-seal n.; (1964,Concise Oxford Dictionary,1325)

DAVIS At the shops the tar-seal ended as though it had never been and the going became rough, two wheel tracks through loose metal, ... (1964,Watersiders,129)

SEVERINSEN Wilby and I were pounding up the tarseal toward Te Anau Downs with Terry. (1970,Hunt the Far Mountain,123)

TAYLOR There are a few no-exit offshoots near the town but once the ten miles of tarseal give on to the rough, metalled surface, one is bereft even of the comforting sighting of a friendly crossroads and a few direction signs. (1971,Plekhov Place, The,9)

ARMFELT So they took the tar-seal to Waitapa. (1971,Catching Up,62)

BAXTER I want to go up the river road/... Past Atene where the tarseal ends, (1979,Collected Poems,589,1972 ed.)

By the time they hit the tarseal she was well out of sight. The road [271] was perfect for speed (1973,Islands,5/270) [NOTES: Gifkins (Winter Riders)]

STEAD He turned towards the lake. Just below the motel the tarseal came to an end and the road was of clay ... . (1973,Smith's Dream,80,1971 ed.)

STEAD He turned towards the lake. Just below the motel the tarseal came to an end and the road was of clay ... . (1973,Smith's Dream,80,1971 ed.)

WILSON We were awfully quiet in the car, as Gil ripped her along the tar-seal at about fifty-five. (1973,NZ Jack,97)

CURNOW and a rubbery squeal / tells the tarseal / that a man goes home / [Check 1937 edn Enemies] (1974,Collected Poems,31)

SARGESON bitumen road On the suburban side of the Belt all to the eye was uniform and conforming, the latest tar-seal serving the affluent middle-class and their housing : new cars breaking the speed limit ... (1974,Islands,7/92)

SARGESON On the suburban side of the Belt all to the eye was uniform and conforming, the latest tar-seal serving the prosperous middle-class and their housing; ... (1976,Sunset Village,31)

FRY Two oppossums/ ... / on the tarseal/ hammered flat/ by singing tyres/ (1978,Brushed Words,7)

WILLIAMS Sandra presses her horn ... and the youngish man ... starts to head back to his appropriate side of the tarseal. (1979,Skin Deep,39)

HOOPER ... he watched cars flashing past on the wet tar-seal ... (1981,Goat Paddock,159)

She said she felt the bus go off the tarseal and shouted. The driver then whipped the bus to the right. (Mar 2, 1982,Dominion,1/6)

WEDDE Look out for the shellfish family licking its way/ across the fourth lane of tarseal/ (1984,Georgicon,42) [NOTES: (`Off/Of')]

[caption to a photo of a land-yacht] Taking to the tarseal (Sep 1, 1986,Dominion,3)

tar-seal v.t. NZ & Austral. surface (a road etc.) with tar macadam; tar-seal n. NZ & Austral. a tar-sealed road or area; tar-sealed a. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,786) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

King of the Tarseal [title] (Jun 1987,Landfall,162/125) [NOTES: (Murphy)]

HILL ... 30-odd wethers, all pattering ... along the tarseal on their way from Wally's paddock six sections down the road to Wally's other paddock eight sections up the road. (1988,More from Moaville,28)

Everything has been tried, starting with the old macadam rolled in water-bond to tar-concrete, tar-macadam, tar-sealed macadam, Bituco, Tarvia, Kortfelt, and a dozen other patent and other methods, and, lastly, plain cement concrete. (Jun 17, 1914,Evening Post,14)

adj. [aka tarseal]

KNOX There's a long, pot-holed tarseal road between the towns ... (1987,After Z-Hour,110)

Macadam, the famed roading engineer after whom tarseal roads are named, was one of the first to use broken rock in the early 1880s. (Oct 16, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

Many times during the past few years we have referred in these columns to "non-permanent" macadam roads, to "permanent" concrete roads (cushioned with suitable material), and to the various grades of "semi-permanent" tarseal or tar-macadem roads that fill the space between the "non-permanent" and "permanent" types. (Jul 18, 1921,Evening Post,6)

v. [aka tarseal]

HALL-JONES With the tarsealing of the road from Invercargill, Te Anau township surged ahead ... (1968,Early Fiordland,180)

BOYD When more money became available, a start was made by forming and metalling Heretaunga Street and levelling and tar-sealing a footpath past the town hall. (1984,City of the Plains,84)

Mossburn - Te Anau road.. has had its corners straightened, its dips filled and its surface tarsealed. (Sep 7, 1956,NZ Herald,5)

(Aug 2002,NZ Memories,37/16) [NOTES: There was little traffic about and many of the roads in Taranaki were tar-sealed, thanks to the revenue from toll-gates which were placed strategically around the province.]

In view of the number of new houses which are being erected the City Council is to be requested to have the footpath in Nicholson Road between Clutha Avenue and Cockayne Road tar-sealed. (Nov 18, 1937,Evening Post,5)

LAMBERT The Waimate West County achieved a New Zealand first in roading, by tar-sealing roads in their area in 1914. (1983,Illustrated History of Taranaki,106)

Of the 293 miles 39 chains of roads in the Taranaki County, 54 miles 77 chains or 18.6 per cent, are tar-sealed. (May 25, 1939,Taranaki Herald,4)

tar-sealed¶

adj. [aka tarsealed]

DARE When we'd gone twenty-five miles on a pretty good tar-sealed main road, we switched off into a secondary road ... (1956,Rouseabout Jane,2)

Goodbye - To the quickening kiss, and the long-drawn sigh, / And the tar-sealed roads and the open sky. (Jul 25, 1928,NZ Free Lance,42)

The anual [sic] cost of 75 miles tar-sealed ("Restar") roads and concrete bridges is estimated as follows (Mar 7, 1914,Wanganui Chronicle,6)

Everything has been tried, starting with the old macadam rolled in water-bond to tar-concrete, tar-macadam, tar-sealed macadam, Bituco, Tarvia, Kortfelt, and a dozen other patent and other methods, and, lastly, plain cement concrete. (Jun 17, 1914,Evening Post,14)

In truth it's nothing more than a booze up in a tar-sealed car park. Everyone's in shorts and jandals and they're drinking beer straight from the can or bottle. The beer is in cartons piled up on the back of a ute. (Mar 1992,Metro,32)

Mossburn - Te Anau road.. has had its corners straightened, its dips filled and its surface tarsealed. (Sep 7, 1956,NZ Herald,5)

There was little traffic about and many of the roads in Taranaki were tar-sealed, thanks to the revenue from toll-gates which were placed strategically around the province. (Aug 2002,NZ Memories,37/16)

tar-sealing¶

v.

GUTHRIE ... Councillor Whortle was hoping that the Mayor would support a motion ... for tar-sealing the street in which he lived. (1935,Little Country, The,140,1937 ed.)

n. [See also sealing; [dateline missing???] The tar was coming out of the tar-sealing. Tar-sealing is a dirty job]

Shingle for tar-sealing has been started out for the road fronting Powdrell's property. (Oct 9, 1917,Wanganui Herald,8)

MIDDLETON Catching butcher-boys was good fun ... You chose a piece of footpath where there was no tar-sealing and looked for little round holes in the earth. When you found a hole, you pushed the soft end of a grass stalk into it ... As soon as it moved you pulled it out and caught a small white grub clinging to the end with its nippers. (1959,Stone, The,29) [NOTES: (The Stone)]

Who among the pupils of the time will ever forget the tar-sealing of the road. (1957,Hurleyville School 65th Anniv.,15)

adj. [aka tarsealing]

The big tar-sealing programme is now nearly completed. (Jan 10, 1941,Evening Post,8)

The acquisition of the water synchronised with the tar-sealing of the first stretch of the main road in Pahiatua County a mile and a half past the hospital. (Feb 11, 1935,Evening Post,10)

An announcement of interest to local bodies having control of roads was made to-night, when it was stated that a company had been formed to manufacture a tar-sealing compound which promises to go a long way towards solving the roading problem. (Apr 21, 1914,Poverty Bay Herald,8)

He favoured an extension of footpaths and tar-sealing work. (Apr 26, 1929,Evening Post,15)

n.

SLATTER ... I saw the England of working with a tamper ... and wheeling barrows of chips for the tar-sealing gang I was on, ... (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,37)

tar-stick¶

n.

In the old days tar was always used to put on sheep cut by the shears. Nowadays some carbolic dip, kerosene, or Condy's is used; but it is always called tar. When he cuts a sheep the shearer calls out `Tar, boy, tar on the leg,' and a fleecepicker or broomie dabs the disinfectant on with a tar-stick and puts it back in the tar-pot. . (1933,Press, The) [NOTES: Acland]

I got out, and looked for the tarstick. (Mar 27, 1909,Marlborough Express,2)

tar-water¶

1 n. (Rural) an infusion of tar and water, used as a stock and pasture remedy.

I am sorry to say that tar water has proved a failure against root fungus. (Oct 1890,NZ Farmer,402)

Mr Kirk gives the following recipoe for making the tar-water: Boil 1/2 lb of coal tar in 1 gallon of water; after boiling for sometime, dilute with 50 gallons of fresh cold water. (1898,NZ Farmer,186)

Tar-white¶

n. Te-awa-iti

WAKEFIELD The native name of this place is Te-awa-iti, or The little Stream'; but it is more generally calledTar-white' by the whalers. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,230)

EASTERN ENTRANCE, OR TORY CHANNEL. Te Awaiti of the natives. Tarwhite of the whalers. (1854,Canterbury Almanac, The,70)

tar-wood¶

n. monoao (D. sublatum, a shrub

This species is the yellow pine or tar-wood of the Otago settlers. (1877,TrNZI,390)

MORRIS Tar-wood, n. name given by the Otago bushmen to the tree, Da[c]rydium colensoi, Hook.; Maori name, Manoao (q.v.). (Kirk, `Forest Flora,' p. 189.) (1898,Austral English,460)

LAING & BLACKWELL D. Colensoi, the silver-pine of Westland. (1940,Plants of NZ,77)

n. [1889 KFF (Andersen) Dacrydium Bidwillii ]

n. [1875 LFN 1909 CSI (Andersen, 4 entries)]

KIRK (And) (1889,Forest Flora)

Pine, mountain (tarwood) .. Dacrydium Bidwillii .. Timber hard, and used for firewood (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,13)

CHEESEMAN D[acrydium] biforme, Pilger ... Mountain districts ... Yellow-pine; Tar-wood. This is for the most part the D. Colensoi of the [Hooker] Flora ... Dacrydium biforme (1906,Manual NZ Flora,653)

COCKAYNE (And) Dacrydium biforme tar-wood (1908,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of the Tongariro National Park]

COCKAYNE (And) Dacrydium biforme tar-wood (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island]

Of the so-called pines there were many varieties, perhaps the most common being the bog pine, or tarwood (Dacrydium Colensoi) a tree remarkable on account of its exhibiting leaves of the most opposite appearance, as even on the same branch the young leaves will be found spreading in shape and half-an-inch in length, while the older ones are so closely placed that the branchlets seem to resemble strings of whipcord. (Feb 6, 1907,Otago Witness,25)

tara¶

n. (See taro)

n. a fern

The former extent of native cultivations is attested by the common occurrence of the Tara [is this the correct location???] (1870,TrNZI,2/91) [NOTES: (Kirk)]

MORRIS Tara, n. ...(2) A Tasmanian aboriginal name for the fern Pteris aqulina ... 1834 Ross, Van Diemen's Land Annual,' p.129:The most extensively diffused eatable roots of Van Diemen's Land are those of the tara fern [etc.] ...' (1898,Austral English,458)

Tara [marked foreign word] ... sb. [? Native name in Tasmania.] The edible fern of Tasmania and New Zealand, a variety of the common brake, Pteris aquilina var. esculenta. Also tara fern. (1933,Oxford English Dictionary,11/89)

tar'a(-fern), n. Edible fern of New Zealand etc. [Tasmanian] (1964,Concise Oxford Dictionary,1325) [NOTES: [omitted 1982 7th ed.]]

n. in New Zealand, the sea swallow or tern; variety of fern [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

tara ... n. in N.Z., sea swallow or tern; variety of fern [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

ta[a-dieresis]ra, n. a variety of bracken with edible rhizome. - also tara-fern. . (1977,Chambers Twentieth-Century Dictionary,1380)

n. female genitals [is this from an Island word: used only by females: is it a have on from Williams Tara (i) .. 6. Membrum virile.: or from Tara (vi). Pudenda muliebra.: or possibly Tara (iii) ... 3. ... Gosip, scandal.: or from a modern Maori word (HWO);I knew this use from South Taranaki in the 1940s (DEH) 1984 16 F E37 Pakuranga Coll. 11 TARA [addressin an equal] -->1984 16 F E40 Pakuranga Coll. 11 TARA -->1984 16 F E42 Pakuranga Coll. 25 TARAS]

n. usually the white-fronted tern; but also the black-fronted tern and other varieties. [Maori] often with suffixed epithets, applied to various sea-birds:

LEE & KENDALL T|ara, s. A gannet; (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,208)

DIEFFENBACH 77. Sula australis, Gould, ... Tara of the natives of Queen Charlotte's Sound. - Dieffenbach. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/200) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/200]

2 n. tern (white-fronted tern, etc.), sea-swallow, [cf hydro + progne]

POLACK1/112 Puhi ... arranged the hair of the gentlemen, placing ... the various feathers of the uia and tara, sea-fowl, that assisted the decoration. (1838,New Zealand (Polack))

POLACK The gentlemen arranged the hair of each other, and being all sons of chiefs, placed with the gout[u-circumflex] of connoisseurs the plucked feathers of the albatross (Uianui), gannet (tara[a1-acute]), and other sea-fowl in various parts. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/80)

TAYLOR [Word list] Tara a sea bird Toro do a large bird (Aug 1843,Journal,52)

TAYLOR ... we remarked a great number of sea swallows (Tara) flying about in every direction ... (Nov 10, 1845,Journal,3/166)

PRESHAW eggs of a small bird called tara, or sea swallow (1888,Banking Under Difficulties,105) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

Sterna frontalis. Tara. Abundant. (1869,TrNZI,1/161) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

HUTTON 113. STERNA FRONTALIS. Gray. Sea Swallow. Tara. S. LONGIPENNIS. FINSCH. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,42)

BULLER STERNA FRONTALIS. (WHITE-FRONTED TERN.) ... Native name.- Tara; `Sea-swallow' of the Colonists. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,281,{1888 2nd edn 2/68} ed.)

BULLER STERNA ANTARCTICA. (GREY {BLACK-FRONTED} TERN.) ... Native name.- Tara. ... This ... Tern is very common in every part of the South Island, but is only occasionally met with {is not so plentiful} on the north side of Cook's Strait. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,282,{1888 2nd edn 2/71} ed.)

STERNA - Sea swallows (Tara). Five species in New Zealand ...; but Sterna antarctica (Common Tern) I found as far as forty miles inland ... (1886,TrNZI,18/99) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

MORRIS Tara, n. (1) Maori name for the birds Sterna caspia, Pallas, and S. frontalis, Gray, the Sea-Swallow, or Tern (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,458)

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,2/96)

tara, a sea-bird (Sterna stricta), white-fronted tern: several other birds are known as tara with suffix, as S. nereis, fairy tern, tara-iti; Hydroprogne caspia Caspian tern, tara-nui; Larus novae hollandiae, red-billed gull, and L. bulleri, black-billed gull, tara-punga; but these are not so definitely used in general as to be adopted. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/158) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

POWELL WHITE FRONTED TERN (Sterna striata), Tara of the Maoris, is abundant all around the New Zealand coasts and occurs in Tasmania and Eastern Australia as well. This is the graceful little Kahawai-bird' orSea-swallow,' which pursues schools of small surface fish, wheeling, darting and dipping to the water, in its energetic quest of food. Since the Kahawai fish is predaceous on the small school fish also, the tern is an excellent indicator of the presence of Kahawai. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,80)

(1952,Chambers Shorter English Dictionary Supp.,805/2) [NOTES: [OEDS]]

RICHARDS Sterna ... frontalis [? striata] ... It pursues schools of small fish close to the coasts of New Zealand, Tasmania and Australia, and as the kahawai fish also feed on the same class of food, the tern is a useful indicator to fishermen of their presence. Hence its name of kahawai bird. Kahawai Bird. Sea Swallow, Tom Noddy. TARA. (1952,Chatham Islands,82)

FALLA et al. BLACK-FRONTED TERN Chlidonias albostriatus Other names: Tara, Sea Martin, Ploughboy, Inland Tern, Riverbed Tern. Ibid. 164 WHITE-FRONTED TERN Sterna striata Other names: Sea-swallow, Kahawai Bird, Tara, Blackcap, Grenadier, Swallowtail, Noddy (Chathams), Tikkitak (Stewart Is.) (1966,Birds of New Zealand,157)

n. in New Zealand, the sea swallow or tern; variety of fern [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

tara ... n. in N.Z., sea swallow or tern; variety of fern [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

205. Sterna striata (Gmelin, 1789) White-fronted Tern (Tara) New Zealand (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,55,1980 ed.)

Black-fronted Tern Sterna albostriata (GRAY, 1845) ... OTHER NAME: Tara. Ibid. 232 White-fronted Tern Sterna striata (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAMES: Tara, sea-swallow, kahawai bird, black cap, grenadier, swallowtail, noddy. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,227)

hey funny! think of all the taras in there! Tara tara tara! (1986,Te Kaihau,10)

tara n. black and grey NZ variety of tern. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,786) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

"Tara" is a greenstone skewer. It's also a seabird... The writer of these words is lying on a hillside "near the top" ("tara" can mean the top of a hill)... "Tara" can also mean the side wall of a house. (May 31, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

3 n.

DIEFFENBACH 75. Larus scopulinus. Forst, ... He-Talle of the natives of New Zealand. Forst. M. Lesson speaks of a species under the native name of Akiaki. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/200) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/200]

tara-iti¶

n.

BULLER STERNA NEREIS. (LITTLE WHITE TERN.) ... Native name.- Tara-iti. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,285,{1888 2nd edn 2/75} ed.)

Fairy Tern Sterna nereis (GOULD, 1843) At the turn of the century the fairy tern was a common bird along the coasts of both main islands. ... Today it is rare. ... OTHER NAME: Tara-iti. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,230)

One, the little tern, known to the Maoris as tara-iti, and to scientists as Sterna nereis, is clad in much the same attire as the familiar white-fronted species, but the bill and feet are yellow. (Nov 5, 1927,Evening Post,17)

Taradise¶

n. Taranaki

"You don't get depressed in Taradise," he says. (Jan 25, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

[Hdg] "Taradise" comes at a high price... Not long ago, the film star [sc. Tom Cruise] told the world he loved what locals call Taradise. (Apr 20, 2003,Sunday Star Times,D1)

Affectionately known by some as "Taradise"; the Taranaki region is really natural New Zealand at its best. Whether you are from across town, across the country, or across the world, Taranaki has many treasures awaiting your discovery. We make it easy.. (Apr 23, 2001,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.withers.co.nz/withers.php?content=taranaki&rhs=rhs_mountain]

From mountain to surf in just 30 minutes Too good to be true? Not in "Taradise", a stunning region on the west coast of New Zealand's North Island. (Apr 23, 2003,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.workingin-newzealand.com/info/taranaki.php]

n. Taradale

What a bloody lovely boss she was. Now employed by a glue factory back in Taradise [Taradale to the uninitiated] for my Dr Doolittle-like ability to keep the horses quiet. (Feb 1, 2003,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://neon.otago.ac.nz/chemistry/alumni/conj01.htm; from Otago Chemistry Alumni Newsletter]

taragehe¶

n. (See tarakihi)

tarahine¶

n.

[?Chathams] Huia was bare-footed and could not go on the hard bare points of Tarahine so [429] she got on my back and I carried her with ease. (Aug 20, 1905,Chudleigh Diary,428,1950 ed.)

HOLMES The most prolific trees were formerly Dracophyllum arboreum (Tarahina), broad-leaved Olearia and Corokias which grew in large areas. (1984,Chatham Islands,92)

taraire¶

n. variant spellings of taraire [taraire taraide/tarairi]

n. a native tree, Beilschmiedia tarairi, used in fencing and in some farm buildings (common north of Auckland). [ORIGIN: Maori, aka tarairi, taraide]

Taraire (Tryday) splits very easily indeed and for that reason would not hold staples as well as some other timbers. (Sep 13, 1951,NZ Farmer,28)

A mellow finishing touch inside has resulted from using varnished taraire on the wall and gates facing the board. (Nov 27, 1975,NZ Farmer,14)

LEE & KENDALL T|araide, s. A tree so called. (1920,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,208)

McDONNELL A great variety of hard-wood grows at New Zealand, admirably adapted for the timbering of any sized ships; among them is the boride[e-acute], rattar[as-acute], taraide[ase-acute], mai[a-acute], totara[a1-acute], koi katoa[a2-acute], toa[a-acute] toa[a-acute], tani raha[as-acute], to wai[a-acute], reiva[a-acute] reiva[a-acute], tana[as-acute], and many others... Ibid. ?...taraide [acutes on a,a,e] (1834,Extracts From a Journal,19,1979 ed.)

YATE Torairi [sic] (Laurus macrophylla) - This tree grows to ... fifty to seventy feet ... Its berries are black, exactly resembling the damson in size and appearance; ... Its leaves are like those of the finest, largest and most brilliant English laurel; ... (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),42)

POLACK Tarairi, (laurus tarairi,) is among the least valuable of timber trees. It is bacciferous, bearing a dark purple berry, on which the wild pigeon feeds heartily. The taste is particularly acrid. Ibid. 2/400 There are many other woods of much service to Europeans, differing in quality, among others: the 30 Warangai.. 36 Tarairi .. 45 Parekireki, &c. Of all these woods there are abundant quantities. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/396)

WILLIAMS The Taraire is a very comon tree sometimes used for fencing, splits fairly , but soon decays, it bears a large blue plum, apparently wholesome, ... (1844,NZ Journal,105,1956 ed.)

HOOKER Neso daphne Tarairi, Hook. fil. ... Nat. name, `Taraire', Cunn. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 217)

HOOKER Taraire, Col[enso]. Nesodaphne taraire. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

TAYLOR Also the Tarairi, an ornamental but not valuable tree, only fit for firewood and charcoal. (1868,Past and Present of NZ,205)

The general character of the [Great Barrier Island] bush greatly resembles that of the main land north of Auckland, its ... difference being the variety of the Tarairi, Neodaphne Tarairi ... (1869,TrNZI,1/144) [NOTES: (T. Kirk)]

Tarairi. Used for most of the purposes for which sycamore is applied in Europe. (1873,Catalogue of Vienna Exhibition) [NOTES: (from Morris)]

HAY The Taraire (Nesodaphne Taraire) is a huge and handsome tree ... (1882,Brighter Britain,2/196)

DOMETT Laurel-tree (Tarairi) ..... O. Lauriniae; G. Neodaphne; S. N. Tarairi. `A forest tree; sixty to eighty feet high; berry one and a half inches long; deep purple.' (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,2/336)

HECTOR Beilschmiedia tarairi, Hook. Tarairi.--A lofty forest tree, 60-80 high, with stout branches. Grows in northern parts of North Island. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,129)

KIRK [Native name] Taraire .. [Settlers' name] Taraire .. [Family] Lauriniae (1886,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121)

The general bush consists of Manuka ... Rata ... Taridi Tawa ... (1887,TrNZI,19/182) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

Taraire .. Beilschmiedia tarairi .. Wood close, straight in the grain, and easily split; used for firewood (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,14)

MORRIS Taraire[dieresis], n. Maori name for a New Zealand tree; formerly Nesodaphne tarairi, Hook., now Beilschmiedia tarairi, Benth. and Hook., N.O. Laurineae. (1898,Austral English,459)

Ta-rai.i-re (ta.-ra.i.&emacr.-r&amacr.; colloq. t&adot.-r&imacr.i.re.), n. [Maori.] A New Zealand lauraceous tree, Beilschmiedia (Nesodaphne) tarairii. It is a lofty evergreen, confined to the Auckland district. [Local, N. Z.] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

CHEESEMAN B[eilschmiedia] Tarairi, Benth and Hook.f. ... Tarairi. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,602)

L;AING & BLACKWELL Beilschmiedia Tarairi (The Tarairi). A handsome tree, 60 ft.- 80 ft. in height, ... . (1907,Plants of NZ,175,1940 p. 183 ed.)

taraire, a tree (Beilschmiedia taraire), no common name, and even the science name has here adopted the Maori name as the specific one. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

The Maori name of a small tree which bears blue-black berries. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),405)

CRUMP (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,126)

taraire also tarairi n -s [Maori] 1 : a New Zealand timber tree (Beilschmiedia tarairi) of the family Lauraceae 2 : the light easily worked wood of the tarairi (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2340)

McLINTOCK Taraire .. taraire .. Beilschmiedia taraire (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

taraire n. New Zealand tree with white wood [Maori]. applied in Europe.' (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

TURNER taraire ... n. N.Z. tree with white wood [Maori]. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,169)

taraire ... n. N.Z. tree with white wood [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

taraire n. large NZ forest tree with white wood. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,786) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

McKENZIE Taraire ran second in one heat. (1978,Roydon Heritage, The,25)

MALCOLM He was felling a taraire tree when it split up the middle, fell back the wrong way and killed him. (1982,Where it all Began,31)

The actual output of sawn timber of all descriptions from the mills during the year ended 31st March, 1920, was as follows .. taraire, 174,650 ft ... (Oct 1, 1920,Evening Post,8)

Examples of totara, hinau, kowhai, pohutukawa, nikau, puriri, pukanui, toru, kauri, miro, houhere, rewarewa, tarairi, ramarama, ruakawa, and porokaiwhiri are now growing in the concourse. (Aug 17, 1935,Evening Post,8)

Increasing numbers of tomtits and tui, plus reports of improved kohekohe and taraire fruiting, are all positive signs that Marunui Forest is beginning to respond to an intensive pest control operation that began in early 2004 (Nov 2005,Open Space,8)

Crowe An easy timber to saw, machine and turn, taking a good finish, taraire is well-suited to its 19th century uses of furniture-making, picture frames, the manufacture of ships' blocks and light carts. (2009,Which Native Tree?,53)

Taraire Rails [per hundred] .. [GBP]1 10s 0. (Oct 3, 1876,Waikato Times,4)

tarakihi¶

n. a fine-eating fish common in New Zealand waters, the jackass fish of southern Australia. Dactylopagrus macropterus (formerly Chilodactylus), a fine food fish [ORIGIN: Maori, incl terakihi, common spelling error]

LEE & KENDALL T|ara k|ii; A fish so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,208)

LEE & KENDALL T|ara k|ii; A fish so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,208)

At the Portobello Marine Fish - hatchery the swimming form has been taken from the stomachs of the following fishes: Smooth-hound (Mustelus antarcticus), Spined dogfish .(Polyprion prognathus), Tarakihi .. (and Leather jacket (Pseudomonacanthus scaber). (1929,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/111) [NOTES: (Thomson and Thomson)]

SPEIGHT The Terakihi Dactylopagrus macropterus) is said to be the commonest New Zealand food fish,... (1927,Natural History of Canterbury,199) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 199]

PHILLIPPS Dactylopagrus macropterus (Forster). TARAKIHI. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,38,1971 ed.)

BEST The following fish were caught with hook and line: araara, maomao, moki, mango, ngoiro, pakirikiri, kahawai, tamure, tarakihi, and warehou. The kanae, kehe, kopipiro, moho, nanu and other species were taken by net. (1929,Fishing Methods,43)

  1. Dactylopagrus macropterus Forster. Tarakahi. Maori: Tarakahi (1929,TrNZI,61/144) [NOTES: (Young)]

(1944,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn))

BEATTIE The above list of fish to be caught along the Canterbury coast has some notable omissions, as hoka (red cod) ... though I am not so sure about the rawaru (blue cod). Others omitted are the tarakihi, or terakihi, the moki, the komutumutu (trevalli), the puhaiwhakarua (red-jacket), koiro (conger eel), tuere (blind eel), whai (skate), and the koekohe [sic] (trumpeter). (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,62)

tarakihi, a sea-fish (Cheilodactylus macropterus), a popular fish, often mis-spelt terakihi on menu-cards. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/158) [NOTES: 1946 Andersen Maori Words in English JPS 55/158]

McLINTOCK The vocabulary of New Zealand English has been influenced by ... the adoption of Maori words and phrases. ... Examples of the native words now in general use are the names of birds, fish, plants, and trees: kea, tui, hapuku, tarakihi, koromiko, raupo, and kauri. (Cheilodactylus douglasii) (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/679) [NOTES: Wall NZ Speech]

CRUMP They.. swung their lines into the surf to catch the snapper, kahawai, cod and tarakihi that.. boiled in the surf in shoals the size of quarter-acre sections. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,126)

MORELAND TARAKIHI [Cheilodactylus macropterus] ... Only the Maori name is in common use. (1967,Marine Fishes,34)

NATUSCH Family CHEILODACTYLIDAE. The tarakihi,Dactylopagrus macropterus ... is commonest south of East Cape;the porae, Cheilodactylus douglasii ... is greenish-grey above and commonest north of Cook Strait; (1967,Animals of NZ, The,222)

tarakihi ... n. N.Z. fish, the morwong. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

SORENSON TARAKIHI (a) Scientific name: Cheilodactylus macropterus. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Tarakihi. (c) Other common names: Tiki (Kaikoura); Porae (Cheilodactylus douglasi) is normally lumped with Tarakihi and is known as Morwong in Australia and also as Sea Bream. (d) Principal localities where taken: [all except far south] (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,47)

DRYLAND When I asked about the menu they recommended something called "terakee".' ...It happens to be terakihi.' Elsa's pronunciation was only approximately Maori, but she managed to avoid undue accent. (1973,Multiple Texture, A,34)

AYLING TARAKIHI (Jackass fish) Nemadactylus macropterus (Cheilodactylus macropterus) ... in far northern waters, on rock pinnacles rising from deepwater on the continental slope, fishermen often catch fish they call king tarakihi that are old large tarakihi that may be over 60cm long and weigh ... 6kg. (1982,Collins Guide,242,1984 ed.)

BURTON Similar in appearance to the snapper, and almost as popular as a food fish, is the tarakihi, which is abundant in cooler waters from East Cape southwards. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,80)

tarakihi or terakihi n. a common edible sea fish of New Zealand waters. [< Maori] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1196)

HULME Tarakihi, hapuku = delicious fishes (1983,Bone People, The,467) [NOTES: 1983 Hulme Bone People (Gloss) 467 [p] 222]

PAUL Tarakihi Nemadactylus macropterus ... Known almost exclusively by this name (or a misspelling of it) in New Zealand, but as morwong or jackass fish in southern Australia ... (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,102)

BASHAM CURRIED SMOKED TERAKIHI ... cover with milk. Simmer until tender. Melt ... butter with ... currie [sic] powder, and cook ... Add ... flour ... tomato soup powder ... break down with milk from fish adding ... hard boiled egg and the pieces of fish. Serve with loose rice. (1939,Aunt Daisy's Cookery Book,16)

Tarakihi fillets, which were retailed at 2s 3d a pound in the week ending May 11, cannot now be sold for more than 1s 3d. (Jun 6, 1945,Evening Post,6)

Forest & Bird is delighted that Burger Wisconsin has chosen to follow the advice of its Best Fish Guide and switch from deepwater oreo/dory to tarakihi in its burgers in its 24 outlets around New Zealand... (Aug 2009,Forest & Bird,333/10)

There are restrictions on taking the tasty blue cod here but we bring up a terakihi that is perfect for the pot. (Dec 17, 2010,Waikato Times,14)

In another tank are terakahi [sic], green-blue with a dark shoulder bar, and with eyes like black velvet tinged with opal. (Jun 15, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,14)

It is now illegal to have fish in possession below the following weights or measurements .. gurnard, horse mackerel, trevalli, mullet, butterfish, warehou, and tarakihi, each 4oz .. measure taken from tip of nose to end of tail. (May 9, 1895,Otago Witness,34)

By these persons are prohibited from taking, buying, selling, or having in their possession, fish of the following description under the weight or length annexed .. tarakihi, four ounces ... (Apr 28, 1885,Bay of Plenty Times,3)

I.. landed two fine teraki. (Dec 28, 1920,Otago Witness,55)

The Canoes ... ran away ... to the banks most frequented by the Taragehe. (Jan 24, 1843,Journal of Ensign Best,397,1966 ed.)

WILLIAMS The whole of the long range of the New Zealand Coast is abundantly supplied with beautiful fish. Of this variety of 78 species I will name a part, viz. ... Tarahika [Tarakihi] marked with a peculiar round spot on each side; ... [.us;Glossary 120 tarahika tarakihi? The description suggests kupara, the John Dory (Zeus faber)]. (1843,NZ Journal,40)

COLENSO They preferred the flesh of the Tarakihi (a fish which migrates towards these coasts in great shoals in the summer). (1844,Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ) [NOTES: 1844 Colenso Excursion North. Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 6]

TAYLOR Tarekihi [sic], a beautifully flat silvery fish, with a black spot on the back. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,415)

DRURY FISH [MET WITH IN PELORUS]. Terakehi - not abundant. Hapuka - plentiful near the entrance in deep water. (1855,Sailing Directions,67)

HUNT ... at her feet would be laid the treasures of the deep, the finest pawa, or the fattest tarakia; ... (1986,Chatham Islands,32)

HECTOR TARAKIHI. ... (Chilodactylus macropteros). This is a very common fish in the market. (1872,Edible Fishes,107)

BAINES Truly ... presently in the bottom of the boat lay Hapuku, Tamuri, Tarakiki [sic], Rock-cod, Yellow tail, young shark, crayfish ... (1874,Edward Crewe,163)

About the end of January, a few Tarakihi, Chilodactylus macropterus, were brought to market,... (1879,TrNZI,11/381) [NOTES: (P. Thomson, Otago)]

The fish for eating are hapuka, Oligorus gigas; rock cods, Percis colias; tarakihi, Chilodactylus macropterus; moki, Latris ciliaris, etc.,etc. (1885,TrNZI,17/198) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

The fishing off the island is very good, there being abundance of hapuku, kohikohi, maumau, schnapper, kahawai, tarakihi, in addition to plenty of shell-fish such as koura or cray-fish, crabs, paua,etc. (1885,TrNZI,17/419) [NOTES: (Goldsmith)]

SHERRIN TARAKIHI (Chilodactylus macropterus). ... The tarakihi is found in the Tasmanian waters, where it is known as the black perch. ... In Sydney it is called the carp, or morwong, where its length varies from 12in. to 18in. (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,98)

Of the sea-fishes that are used as food in New Zealand, we have among the constant residents on all parts of our coast the hapuku, tarakihi, trevally, moki, aua, rock-cod, wrasse, and patiki; and while the snapper, mullet, and gurnet are only met with in the north, the trumpeter, butterfish, and red-cod are donfined to the south. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,167)

Of the sea-fishes that are used as food in New Zealand, we have among the constant residents on all parts of our coast the hapuku, tarakihi, trevally, moki, aua, rock-cod, wrasse, and patiki; and while the snapper, mullet, and gurnet are only met with in the north, the trumpeter, butterfish, and red-cod are donfined to the south. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,167)

  1. Portland Island. - Tarakihi, moki, frost-fish, barracouta, king-fish, john-dory, warehou, maomao, parrot-fish, flying-fish, smooth-hound, soldier fish. (1892,TrNZI,24/403) [NOTES: (Thomson)]

MORRIS Tarakihi, n. the Maori name for the fish Chilodactylus macropterus, Richards.; called in Sydney the Morwong (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,459)

Tá.ra-kí.hi (ta.́.ra.-k&emacr.́.he.), n. [Maori.] The fish called morwong in Australia. See MORWONG. [Local, N. Z.] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

DRUMMOND & HUTTON The warehou, tarakihi, and gurnet are common in the north, and the moki, butterfish, and frost fish in the south, while the kahawai, hapuku (the groper of Dunedin), blue cod, barracouta, the little sea mullet, sometimes called the herring, and the flat fish are found all round the coast. (1982,Nature in NZ,71)

WAITE Cheilodactylus Macropterus ... Tarakihi (1911,Records of the Canterbury Museum,1/220)

Its nearest allies amongst New Zealand fish are Cheilodactylus macropterus (the tarakihi) and Douglasi (the porae) (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/6) [NOTES: (Thomson)]

Tarakihi. Dactylosparus macropterus ... In the winter, spring and early summer months an abundance of tarakihi is constantly seen exposed for sale. (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/271) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]
