tarakupenga¶

n. Lycopodium sp.

TAYLOR These [bunks] were covered with dried flag leaves and a wirey plant which is very elastic (tara kupenga) ... (Aug 4, 1851,Journal,7/222)

TAYLOR The building was carpeted with branches of the fragrant manuka a species of myrtle wh. were laid with great regularity and the portion laid off for the minister was strewed with the tarakupenga, a beautiful creeping lycopodium. (Sep 7, 1851,Journal,7/229)

2 n. Coprosma spp.

BROOKER et al. Coprosma australis (A. Rich.) Rob. Maori names: Manono, papauma Coprosma robusta Raoul maori name; Karamu (name applied to any large-leaved Coprosma Coprosma acerosa A. Cunn. Maori names: Tarakupenga, tataraheke, tatarahake (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,86)

taramahoe¶

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] a variety of kumara.

Since the variety known as the "Waina" came into possession of the Natives they have gradually discarded most of the others with the exception of a few varieties, such as the Uti-uti, Taromahoe and Rekamaroa, the other kinds being mostly small, rough, and irregularly shaped, and light croppers. (Oct 20, 1914,NZ Journal of Agriculture,280)

taramea¶

n. speargrass (espec. Aciphylla squarrosa); also called spaniard, spear-grass, bayonet-grass the larger of two related varieties of spear-grass. [Maori]

gum - tallama'er [taramea] (1835,Boultbee Journal,109,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 109 See also 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 282 (|= macron precedes) gum, ta|lla maer [taramea]]

TAYLOR ...taramea, a prickly plant, abounds here [Auckland]. (1840,Journal,2/II/302) [NOTES: 1840 R. Taylor Journals (1833-) 2]

SUTHERLAND We also found the `taramea', a small plant with fleshy sharp-pointed leaves, not unlike the American aloe in its mode of growth. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,217) [NOTES: 1844 Jan 15 in 1851 Shortland Southern Districts of NZ 217 [check re initial caps for taramea and aloe???]]

TAYLOR ... we came into an open grass country with the taramea growing in it as sign of our having reached the Taupo region. (Mar 12, 1845,Journal,3/88)

BRUNNER In the Rotoiti Valley is found a species of spear-plant, called by the natives taramea. (1846,Great Journey,21,1952 ed.)

BRUNNER In the Rouiti [Rotoiti] Valley is found a species of spear-plant, called by the natives taramea, which is much valued by them. (Dec 24, 1846,Journal of an Expedition) [NOTES: 1846 Dec 24 Brunner Expedition Middle Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 262]

Thick growth of kalo and talamea near the bush which was ... a black birch forest with an occasional red pine. (Apr 14, 1849,Torlesse Papers,74,1958 ed.) [NOTES: [see KARO quot]]

SHORTLAND TARAMEA, a small stemless plant, having fleshy triangular leaves, terminating in a sharp point, all growing in a tuft from the level of the ground. From them the natives procure a scent (vide p. 217). (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,313)

SHORTLAND TARAMEA, a small stemless plant, having fleshy triangular leaves, terminating in a sharp point, all growing in a tuft from the level of the ground. From them the natives procure a scent (vide p. 217). (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,313)

There are two plants, the karo (prickly thorn) and taramea (spear grass), whch are well worthy of their names, but are almost exclusively confined to the hilly regions. There generally grows near these a plant called the timuka, from the leaf of which the natives make mats and leggings, which are impervious to the sharp points of the former. (Jun 28, 1851,Lyttelton Times,7)

HOOKER Taramea, Col[enso]. Aciphylla Colensoi. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

LINDSAY A.Colensoi Hook f. ... the `Taramea' of the Maoris, (Colenso.) (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,49)

LINDSAY A.Colensoi Hook f. ... the `Taramea' of the Maoris, (Colenso.) (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,49)

Taramea. Aciphylla Colensoi, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI,1/3/42) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Several of the smaller species have become comparatively rare from the repeated burnings of the taramea ... (1895,TrNZI,28/7)

CHEESEMAN [Aciphylla Colensoi, Hook.f.] Taramea; Spaniard. ... By far the finest species of the genus ... A[ciphylla] squarrosa, Forst. ... Taramea; Kurikuri; Spear-grass. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,209)

LAING & BLACKWELL Aciphylla Colensoi (Colenso's Spaniard) ... Both islands. Maori name Taramea. (1907,Plants of NZ,321,1940, p. 339 ed.)

BEATTIE The hill was covered with taramea or speargrass ... (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,127)

taramea, a plant (Aciphylla squarrosa and other sp.), spear-grass, bayonet-grass, spaniard: a hill and mountain plant from whose spiny blades the Maori by heat and torsion extracted a valued scent. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/158) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

MEAD ... crossing first a grassy plain filled with tumatikuru ..., taramea, ... and a pretty cream-coloured star flower, .. (1966,Richard Taylor,69)

taramea [s] Aciphylla colensoi Hook.f. Aciphylla ferox Oliver (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,77)

HAYES ... a land [at Hakataramea] of rolling downs with mile upon mile of golden tussock and yellow-green sharp thickets of speargrass or `taramea' . (1978,From the Toss of a Coin,23)

MIKAERE ... there was the little thing ... playing about quite happily amongst the matagouri and the taramea. (1988,Te Maiharoa,78)

He noted that there were more scented flowers in New Zealand than in any other country he had visited; and those who remember the mahoe, the euosmia, the golden akeake, the autumn earina, the taramea, will agree that it is a land of fragrances. (Feb 15, 1932,Evening Post,3)

The "Kohuhu" and the "Tarata" .. and the "Taramea" (Aciphylla Colensoi) [sic] were highly prized for their perfume by the natives. (Aug 8, 1889,Otago Witness,20)

Certainly something mystic would seem to have been connected with this taramea, or prickly high-growing plant; the germ of it was gathered only by young maidens, who sought its lovely haunts after certain ceremonial songs. (Nov 29, 1905,Otago Witness,82)

Backcountry farmers, trampers and others who frequent the hills know them variously as speargrass or Spaniard, while Maori refer to them as kuri kuri or taramea, which means "rough, spiky thing". (Nov 27, 2004,Dominion Post,E13)

The peculiar plants which I have noticed growing in the Mania are the taramea, a prickly plant with a root like a carrot, two kinds of fennel also with tuberous roots, a real carrot, two kinds of asters, a gentian, with several other plants, with a beautiful scarlet flowering burr, and several shrubs bearing berries in lieu of the cranberry, and a curious shrub, an aralia; the chief rocks are whiustone. (Apr 7, 1847,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,3)

taramoa¶

n. (See tataramoa)

KEENE tataramoa or taramoa: climbing bramble of the bush known as 'bush lawyer'. (1963,O Te Raki,194)

The Maori name for the prickly "bush lawyer," taramoa, or tataramoa, he learns from Tahiti is "the-cock's-spur plant." (Aug 1, 1893,Timaru Herald,4)

Taranaki¶

adj. of Taranaki

taranaki adj, usu cap [fr. Taranaki, New Zealand] : of or from the provincial district of Taranaki, New Zealand : of the kind or style prevalent in Taranaki provincial district (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2340)

SUTTON-SMITH Occasionally unusual types of hiding games were played, for example All In or Taranaki. In this game there were two teams and a home base. One team, the outs,' went and hid, while the home team, looked for theouts.' As soon as an in' player saw anout,' he cried, All in for Tommy Jones' (theout' player who had been spotted). At that cry all the in' players raced for home, and all theout' players emerged from their hiding places and attempted to tag them. If all the in' players could get home without being tagged, then the person seen (Tommy Jones), was considered captured, and he had to come and sit in the home base, And so thein' team went on trying to sight players and [53] then get home without being tagged. (1981,History of Children's Play,52)

[Hdg] Preparing pillars and Maori mats The entrance to Government House, Wellington, will soon have a Taranaki flavour - carved pillars and woven mats made in the Te Atiawa (Taranaki) style Petone Technical Institute students carved pou out of a 100-year-old totara pile ... Te Atiawa women are still plaiting the mat to be laid at the main door. (Oct 31, 1986,Evening Post,6)

Alley bought a Taranaki farm ... He walked off the land in November 1926 .. (Dec 28, 1987,Dominion,2)

[In article Feats of Clay, caption to a picture of clay model of a rough wood-block with a crude `gantry' bolted to it from which is hanging a light bulb - a real Heath-Robinson outfit - entitled:] Taranaki Bedside Lamp by Peter Lange. A humorous approach to the manipulation of clay. (1988,Pacific Way,41)

McGILL Taranaki drive a technique used in bush felling whereby one tree is felled on to another, in order to lay a group of trees down. Unlike many Taranaki references, this one is a skilled operation, a dangerous practice that is not encouraged, except when there is the need to knock down `hang ups'. [G. Johnston] (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,99)

1 n. (Rural) [of objects or processes] makeshift, but showing ingenuity. (See Taranaki gate; Taranaki huntaway; Taranaki drive)

Referring to the use of the word 'Taranaki', Mr Loughnan says that it always seems to have suffered at the hands of South Islanders, who have used it as an adjective to refer to something makeshift, but which implies a definite degree of usefulness and ingenuity. The most common use of Taranaki is, of course, for the makeshift gate of wires and battens, which is a nightmare for the novice to open and shut. (Feb 11, 1977,Press, The,19)

LOUGHNAN Taranaki seems to have suffered at the expense of South Islanders, who have used it as an adjective to mean something makeshift. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,83)

2 n.

WILLIAMS ... they again formed into a double line, ... the forty Taranaki's [sic] who had arrived with Patara continually running round them shouting ... (1932,East Coast Historical Records,92) [NOTES: 1865 Mar 25 S.A.Levy in Williams East Coast Historical Records (19??) 92]

The Ngatiawas had arranged to [?] the N.Z. Government, and the Taranakis objecting, marched up the slopes of the mountain, 2,500 strong, [?] sell their beloved mountain. (Jan 18, 1905,Otago Witness,42)

2 n.

RICHARDS (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,103)

2 adj. often connotes `makeshift; rough-rural; country-bumpkinish; uncouth' (cf. the way Irish is used in general English: ?many Irish-pedigreed farmers in Taranaki)

Taranaki bullshit¶

n. boasting

SARGE (1950,Excuse my Feet!,8) [NOTES: [see BULLSHITTER: see notes]]

SLATTER At Maadi he had trained hard ... had read all the good news about Hitler getting the shits, no Taranaki bullshit. (1968,Pagan Game, The,69)

Taranaki cow¶

1 n. (Rural) a run cow or one in poor condition.

BAKER Taranaki cow, a nondescript beast of poor type. (1941,NZ Slang,59)

BAKER Taranaki cow, a nondescript beast of poor type. (1941,NZ Slang,59)

McGILL Taranaki cow any nondescript or poorly conditioned cow. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,112)

He commenced with the Taranaki cow, and by judicious selection he has suceeded in establishing a good dairy, producing first-class butter. (Apr 17, 1886,Taranaki Herald,2)

To do justice to the Taranaki cow requires an abler pen than mine. Nothing less than a modern Homer would do her merits justice. Born as she is to "blush unseen and waste her sweetness on the desert air," but not desert fields, of fair Taranaki, she fills our pails, she fills our pockets, and by-and-bye she will fill our ships with the butter and cheese she produces ... (Dec 14, 1891,Taranaki Herald,2)

Just a week or two ago one read that the Taranaki cow business was thriving with a forty horse-power thrive. It was a record season for butter, and farmers were getting huge milk cheques. (Dec 29, 1906,NZ Free Lance,12)

Taranaki drive¶

1 n. (Rural) a bush drive, in which several trees are felled at once.

MCGILL Taranaki drive: a technique used in bush-felling whereby one tree is felled on to another, in order to lay a group of trees down. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,99)

West Coast bushmen call this a Taranaki drive - driving this tree onto that other one which is hung up there. I don't know where the word comes from. (Sep 6, 1987,TV1) [NOTES: Country Calendar]

Taranaki exquisite¶

n.

THOMSON .. it is worthy of notice, that the colonists, soon after the formation of all the settlements, acquired distinguishing epithets; thus there was an Auckland cove, a Wellington swell, a Nelson snob, a Taranaki exquisite, an Otago cockney, and a Canterbury pilgrim. These epithets, almost already forgotten, are too characteristic to be buried in oblivion, as each originated in some peculiarity of the leading colonists. The Otago settlers derived theirs from their ignorance of the country in which they lived; the Auckland people from their extensive Sydney connexions; and the origin of the other names are sufficiently obvious without explanation. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,2/188)

BAKER `There was an Auckland cove, .. a Taranaki exquisite... (1941,NZ Slang,24)

McGILL Taranaki exquisite nickname for person from Taranaki in provincial government times. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,112)

Taranaki fern¶

n. ?bracken, ?paesia

HAAST The banks of the Mawhera-iti ... were covered with small grass patches ... beyond which ... large terraces appear, partly covered with splendid grass, partly with toitoi, Taranaki fern, and stunted manuka. (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,39)

Taranaki gate¶

n.

1 n. (Rural) a makeshift gate of wire and battens, difficult to open and shut. [Irishman's gate; ten-minute gate aka taranaki, Taranaki as abbreviations] (See Irishman's gate; ten-minute gate)

SMITH [New Plymouth] also introduced the Taranaki gate - it is a pity it didn't stop at black sand. (1947,From N to Z,57) [NOTES: 1959 edition]

"Taranaki" gates are usually a curse on any dairy-farm. They are damnable to open and damnable to shut. (Dec 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,9)

The 'Taranaki' gate is excusable only when it has not to be opened more than half a dozen times in the year. (Mar 1931,NZ Farmer,217)

To reduce the cost of fencing many farmers skimp on the material to be used for gates or erect "Taranaki" gates built out of fencing materials. A good solid gate .. will give service years after the "Taranaki" gate has become a wire entanglement and a menace to stock in the vicinity. (Aug 15, 1939,NZ Journal of Agriculture,145)

Although it is quite possible and very cheap to use an electrified 'Taranaki' gate, we go in for proper timber gates ... (Jul 15, 1940,NZ Journal of Agriculture,23)

NEWTON In the saddle the track cut through a 'Taranaki' gate, on to the Glen Lyon country again. (1952,High Country Journey,15)

J of Ag June Then it was a matter of setting to to make the necessary Taranaki gates as we discussed. (1986)

HALL It was a Taranaki gate (ie made of wire and fence battens) and the top had come loose and collapsed. The sheep just walked over it. (1987,Shepherd's Year, A,25)

FISK This is the secret of a good Taranaki. If the loops at this end are too short you will find it hard to close. If it is too sloppy, the gate will be too slack ... (1996,Practical Smallfarming,20)

Still got the odd Taranaki gate? (Nov 2001,Dairying Today,15)

NZ Historic Places 84 Feb 34 There is great potential for studying and interpreting how these entities worked and interrelated from .. all the way down to the Taranaki gate and the knots used to join No 8 wire. [Taranaki] (2002)

HARSANT There were only bridle tracks in lieu of road, but throughout the farm were several "Taranaki" gates to be opened and shut, if one wanted to go further afield. (1979,They Called Me Te Maari,17)

HENDERSON All of these were out to do you harm; but they were harmless compared with the Taranaki gate, a fascinating invention fit to rank with the discovery of penicillin, the breaking of the atom, or the invention of the steam engine. (1971,Our Open Country,79)

CARR Up near the trig station was a Taranaki gate. (1986,Diary of a Pig Hunter,66)

You could say it's a bit of a Taranaki gate arrangement, but it worked very well. (Oct 5, 1992,Dominion,3)

KELLY The nosedive that followed the turn stopped short at a Taranaki gate. (1986,Gun in the Hills,119)

None of them seemed to know what a scrum was or understand the technicalities of a Taranaki gate. Some American students thought it was the particular way Fr Michael walked. (Aug 1999,Wel-com (Wellington),20)

JACKSON A Taranaki gate - barbed wire and batons [sic] - lying in long grass. (1988,Rainshadow,6)

FINLAYSON He's satisfied that the taranaki is properly up. (1948,Tidal Creek,205)

He [sc.. Murray Ball] decided that Aloudek was only going to get it right by seeing the fine detail, right down to the way wire coils around a Taranaki gate- post, for himself. (Nov 26, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),68)

But the townies' image of wealth creation was the hardworking cockie and his make-do inventions such as the Taranaki gate. (May 7, 2005,Dominion Post,C2)

He knew which end of a Taranaki gate to smash with his front foot so that it would drop from the loop. (Feb 23, 1966,Weekly News,37)

These 22 yarns are wildly improbable, very funny, and as New Zealand as a Taranaki gate. (Sep 1991,Metro,159)

In 1910 wooden gates were being made to replace some of the Taranaki gates, those notorious barways made out of wire and battens. (Apr 1961,NZ Geographer,10)

Taranaki Gothic¶

n.

Peter Simpson's study of Morrieson concludes with a plea to recognise this inventor of "Taranaki Gothic" as breaking through to a kind of writing that is different in kind and quality to what is usually written in New Zealand. (Jun 12, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),100)

Taranaki huntaway¶

1 n. (Rural) a rock driven down a hill to scatter sheep, rather than sending out a dog. (See German doggie; Maori huntaway; Nelson huntaway)

LOUGHNAN Taranaki huntaway: a rock rolled down the hillside to disturb sheep, thus saving running a dog. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,84)

There is also the delightful "Taranaki huntaway," for a rock rolled down a hillside to disturb sheep and save a dog running out. In some quarters Mr Loughnan adds this has been adapted to "Nelson huntaway" - presumably in Taranaki. (Feb 11, 1977,Press, The,19)

Taranaki ironsand¶

adj.

The plant for the Taranaki Ironsand Company will be on the ground in three months. (Jul 2, 1904,NZ Observer,7)

Mr. E. Metcalfe Smith, of Taranaki ironsand fame.. is "dead agin" the early closing of public houses on occasions. (Mar 5, 1904,Free Lance,12)

n.

In the early 'seventies, Mr. Smith had a small arsenal in Wellington, and here from Taranaki ironsand he used to manufacture breech blocks for the rifles then in use by the Colonial Government. (Mar 30, 1912,Dominion,22)

There were.. samples of the product of Taranaki Ironsand which Mr Smith laboured so long and untiringly to develop. (Jul 28, 1926,NZ Observer,6)

Taranaki ironsand consists principally of magnetite (magnetic oxide of iron), ilmenite (titanate of iron), ferro- magnesian minerals such as augite and hornblende, some olivine and quartz. (1923,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/140)

Mr. Smith, who has identified himself so conspicuously in the manufacture of steel from Taranaki iron sand, gave a sample of the metal in the rough , and also a razor to a gentleman on his way home to England. (Mar 29, 1873,Auckland Weekly News,4)

Mr. Smith, who has identified himself so conspicuously in the manufacture of steel from Taranaki iron sand, gave a sample of the metal in the rough , and also a razor to a gentleman on his way home to England. (Mar 29, 1873,Auckland Weekly News,4)

[Caption] Taranaki Iron-Sand. (Aug 16, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,5)

I have just witnessed copious stream of the Taranaki iron sand pouring like water from a temporary furnace, in execution of a Government order for railway plant castings. (Nov 1, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,6)

He intended to decide whether the "sponge" which could be produced from Taranaki ironsand, could be treated electrically or otherwise. (Feb 9, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,20)

STEWART The beach was of the famous Taranaki iron-sand, grey in the heat where we sunbaked, gleaming black where it stretched out far and flat to meet the water. (1991,Springtime in Taranaki,84)

We have on numerous occasions alluded to the iron sand of Taranaki; and pointed out what a vast amount of undeveloped wealth is lying on the shores of that province. (May 22, 1871,Evening Post,2)

Taranaki lily¶

n.

The section has one other representative in New Zealand, the very much larger, but otherwise similar, 'Taranaki lily,' Arthropodium cirrhatum. (Mar 2, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

Taranaki mat¶

n.

BUDDLE The Governor accepted the offer, ... and Teira laid at His Excellency's feet a Parawai (a Taranaki Mat) as a symbol that the offer was accepted. (1860,Maori King Movement,29)

Taranaki Maunga¶

n. Mount Taranaki [ORIGIN: Maori, why glossed 'barren' mountain in citation?]

Acccording to legend, Taranaki Maunga (barren mountain) once lived in the centre of the North Island with Tongariro - with whom he fought over Mount Pihanga, one of Tongariro's wives. (Jul 2002,North & South,32)

Taranaki method¶

1 n. (Rural) a basic method of making silage where a hole is dug and the silage buried.

The 'Taranaki method' of ensilage stacking - stacking grass, green oats or anything handy, and weighing it by earth excavated from the side of the stack, the earth being afterwards replaced when the silage was being used. The Taranaki method should become popular among New Zealand dairymen. (Oct 17, 1903,Farmers' Advocate,5)

Taranaki salute¶

n. Taranaki salute: a smart turn with an extra stamp to shake the shit off the heels [ca1987 p.c.]

With the exception of Taranaki, where legend has it that cow cockies shake dung off their boots with a stamping movement called the Taranaki salute ... (May 2007,NZ Geographic,61)

Taranaki spanner¶

n. a bottle opener [ca1960 John Kelly A regional (and not universal) West Coast usage]

Taranaki steel¶

n. (See also New Zealand steel)

GORST The landing [at Onehunga] used to be effected through heavy surf upon the black sand of the seashore....This sand is composed of a very fine haematite iron ore, which many projectors have made vain efforts to utilise commercially, and out of which a small quantity of what is known as `Taranaki Steel' is made, used chiefly for surgical instruments. (1908,New Zealand Revisited,46)

Taranaki Street tuatara¶

phr.

He had met a Taranaki St. Tuatara who could hit a fly at forty paces with a squirt of tobacco juice. (Mar 16, 1942,NZEF Times,I/38)

Taranaki Street virago¶

phr. a female supporter of the 1913 strikers

(Nov 29, 1913,Hutt Valley Independent,3/152/1) [NOTES: [This may be a journalistic nonce-use only: ?omit]]

Taranaki sunshine¶

n. (Rural) rain, thick mist or drizzle.

.. a "Bedourie shower" is a duststorm and "Taranaki sunshine" is rain or drizzle. (Aug 26, 2001,Sunday Star Times,A4)

CRYER .. rain and drizzle is referred to as Taranaki sunshine ... (2002,Curious Kiwi Words,214)

.. the Dictionary of New Zealand English provides ten such collocations, including Taranaki bedside light, Taranaki salute, Taranaki sunshine, Taranaki topdressing, Taranaki violin ... (2002,NZWords,VI 4)

McLauchlan ed. Although, they say, when the mountain's clear like that...this usually means there's rain on the way. Taranaki sunshine. (2000,Morrieson's Motel,219)

Taranaki topdressing¶

n. cow dung [ca1935 Havelock]

PARTRIDGE (1937,Dictionary of Slang,1311)

BAKER Taranaki top dressing, a facetious euphemism for cattle-dung. (1941,NZ Slang,59)

PARTRIDGE Taranaki top-dressing. Cattle dung: New Zealand (mostly the South Island): C. 20. Niall Alexander, letter of Oct. 22, 1939; B., 1941. Taranaki Province is famous for its dairy cattle. `Among the sheep-farming communities, Taranaki is usually referred to as a land of cows and cow cockies up to their knees in mud and cow dung' (N. Alexander, l.c.). (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1195)

TURNER (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The)

McGILL Taranaki topdressing cow dung. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,112)

1 n. (Rural) cow dung.

BAKER Taranaki topdressing, a facetious euphemism for cattle-dung. (1941,NZ Slang,59)

TURNER .. in New Zealand cowdung is referred to as Taranaki topdressing ... (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,31)

... The Dictionary of New Zealand English provides ten such collocations, including Taranaki bedside light, Taranaki salute, Taranaki sunshine, Taranaki topdressing, Taranaki violin and Taranaki wool. (2002,NZWords,VI 4)

Taranaki twist¶

n. [ca1940 Lyttelton, Bill Martin colloquial for any cheap tobacco (specifically, Riverhead Gold)]

Taranaki violin¶

n. a set of cowbells used as a crude musical instrument

... to a performance on the `Taranaki Violin', a set of cowbells manipulated by Mat Salmon. (Jul 15, 1953,Evening Post,?15) [NOTES: or EP July 13?]

First appearance of a very rare musical novelty act, MR. MAT SALMON and his Taranaki Violin - wtih [sic] band accompaniment. (May 15, 1943,Evening Post,2)

1 n. (Rural) the sound of cowbells.

CRYER .. the sound of cowbells is sometimes called Taranaki violins. (2002,Curious Kiwi Words,214)

.. The Dictionary of New Zealand English provides ten such collocations .. Taranaki violin and Taranaki wool. (2002,NZWords,VI 4)

Taranaki War¶

n.

The Taranaki War was caused by some surveyors pegging out. (Dec 23, 1935,Christchurch Star-Sun,8)

BUDDLE Thus commenced the Native War at Taranaki, which has continued from that day [c1854] to this, ... [He] appears to have ben one of the speakers who attended [check ben???] the meeting of chiefs at Wellington in April last - a meeting convened ... for the purpose of hearing the views of the native chiefs in reference to the Taranaki War ... (1860,Maori King Movement,6)

... ornamental scars/ Of blue, with red ones added in/ The Taranaki wars./ (1866,Canterbury Rhymes,97)

BOOTH In 1860 commenced the disastrous Taranaki war, which lasted some years. (1912,Five Years in NZ,[intro])

PINFOLD During the Taranaki War ... the prayer was still offered up ... (1930,Fifty Years In Maoriland,81)

Cause of Taranaki War. (Jan 7, 1943,Evening Post,4)

That was just after the Taranaki war, and the colony was soon to enter upon the Waikato war. (Aug 30, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,Suppl. 1)

He was obliged to leave Kawhia, with other Europeans, during the first Taranaki war. (Aug 2, 1880,Evening Post,2)

Our readers are reminded that Mr C.O. Montrose, the veteran campaigner, litterateur, and war correspondent, will give a narrative, in the Alexandra Hall on Monday evening next, commencing at 9 o'clock, of his personal experiences in the Taranaki war, and the Waikato. (Jul 9, 1892,Taranaki Herald,2)

Let us suppose that the Governor, disenabled from consulting the Representatives, - with a sufficient excuse for acting mero motu, upon his own authority, had expended large sums of colonial money in preparation for a Taranaki war: who would then have had a right to complain? (Sep 18, 1855,Daily Southern Cross,3)

There was a large attendance (though not so large as was expected), including numerous pioneer settlers and Taranaki war veterans. (Apr 12, 1909,Grey River Argus,2)

There is not much known of her early life, except that she was known as a Queen's Maori during the Taranaki Wars. (Dec 2003,NZ Memories,No. 45/25)

There is not much known of her early life, except that she was known as a Queen's Maori during the Taranaki Wars. (Dec 2003,NZ Memories,No. 45/25)

It's a familiar roll-call: Northern War 1845-6, the Wellington and Wanganui skirmishings of 1846 and 1847, the First and Second Taranaki Wars, the main campaigns in the Waikato and Bay of Plenty, ending with the campaigns of Titikowaru and Te Kooti. (Sep 28, 2002,Dominion Post,F9)

Taranaki wool¶

n. the tree fungus Auricularia polytricha Hakeka; an old word for the edible jew's ear fungus collected for sale. [from its one-time commercial importance in a mainly dairy-farming area] (See ear fungus)

CROWE Ear fungus Auricularia polytricha Hakeka This fungus has also been known as 'Taranaki wool' from the days when its collection provided a livelihood in Taranaki. (1997,Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ,126)

Often when household funds were low, a few shillings were obtained by selling fungus, otherwise known as "Taranaki Wool," which was exported to China for culinary purposes. (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,91) [NOTES: Writing of 1940]

"Chew Chong, based in Taranaki, exported Wood Ear fungus to China. In the mid-1800s there was a huge trade in fungus. It was at one stage larger than butter exports." The fungus attracted the popular name of "Taranaki wool", Yee says. (Aug 13, 2003,Capital Times,19)

LOCKE In a single year, 1885, seventy-two thousand pounds worth of this "Taranaki wool" was sent away. (1984,Kauri & The Willow, The,91)

The box on fungi tells us that Chinese trader Chew Chong, one of New Zealand's early dairy exporting entrepreneurs, first made his name as an exporter of the edible wood ear fungus, then known locally as "Taranaki wool". In the 1880s the trade was worth thousands of pounds. (Jul 1998,NZ Geographic,No. 39/18)

SINCLAIR & HARREX Settlers breaking in new land [sc. in Taranaki] had to rely on contract work on the roads and such trades as that in fungus (or 'Taranaki wool' as it was called) for an income during their initial years on the land. (1978,Looking Back,79)

The district has been invaded by a party of Parihaka Maoris, some 80 strong, in pursuit of that commercially mysterious product known as fungus, and once styled in derision "Taranaki wool." (Mar 23, 1899,Taranaki Herald,3)

1 n. (Rural) a fungus grown in Taranaki for export to China.

In these days of honest endeavour to maintain Taranaki's reputation as a primary products province, it is well to remember the part played by its early settlers in establishing it. Those advance agents for long enjoyed little recompense for their labours beyond the proceeds of the abounding 'Taranaki wool' crop. (Jan 5, 1929,Hawera Star,14)

BARRER The children also had to work hard, picking fungus, which was facetiously known as 'Taranaki wool'. (1939,Brave Days: Pioneer Women of New Zealand,141)

It is difficult to realise what fungus - commonly known as 'Taranaki wool'- meant to the pioneer dairyman in that province. (Apr 1958,NZ Journal of Agriculture,377)

MCGILL Taranaki wool: a fungus the Chinese regarded as medicinal and a delicacy, exported to Hong Kong in the early 1880s by Taranaki entrepreneur Chew Chong ... (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,99)

Taranaki-bred¶

adj.

COWAN This Taranaki-bred pioneer has packed into his fifty years many a touch-and-go adventure. (1916,Bush Explorers,13)

Taranakian¶

n. a person born in, residing in, or loyal to Taranaki

I like to think we Taranakians at least will not try to erase from memory the name of the buoyant 1870s Premier... (Oct 2, 2002,Capital Times,p3)

The last attack, and the most fatal one to the Taranakians, was made about seven years since, ... (1841,Establishment of New Plymouth Settlement,66,1940 ed.)

The last attack, and the most fatal one to the Taranakians, was made about seven years since, ... (1841,Establishment of New Plymouth Settlement,66,1940 ed.)

.. there were many miles of flax growing . . ., more particularly about the Sugar-Loaves, which had once been in a state of cultivation by the Taranakians ... (Sep 16, 1842,Letters from New Plymouth,52,1958 ed.)

Taranakians (1850,McLean Papers,8/272)

Taranakians (1857,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/39)

.. a Taranakian in the Ministry ... (1865,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/616)

The best thing that Taranakians can do. (Aug 12, 1905,NZ Truth,8/1/8)

The Taranakians are satisfied with the present route and protest against her being omitted from the regular ports of call, in any arrangement hereafter to be made; the speech of Mr. Richmond, at the Nelson dinner, having first supplied the hint that Ministers contemplated recommending a route in which Taranaki would be passed by. (Jan 26, 1859,Lyttelton Times,4)

The Taranakian became a knight automatically after serving in the Speaker's chair for the term of one Parliament's life. (Apr 19, 1924,NZ Truth,1)

In the second spell, J. Sullivan, the one Taranakian with first-class All Black prospects, moved in from centre, and Babrow thereafter failed to shine as affectively [sic]. (Aug 2, 1937,Evening Post,15)

Taranakians, who for decades have dejectedly left their depopulating mountain kingdom to seek their fortunes outside, are scurrying back . . . (Jul 2002,North & South,32)

Our news telegrams yesterday morning notified the opening of the refinery in connection with the Taranaki oil fields. The plant is said to be one of the most up-to-date. It cost GBP36,000, and is a monument to the faith and enterprise of the Taranakians, who in this matter have shown the same doggedness of their race as when they were called upon to defend their homes during Maori troubles. (Jul 30, 1913,Grey River Argus,4)

Water has obtained an unusual prominence in the surroundings of this earthly pilgrimage - a prominence that, however congenial to the taste of the amphibious Taranakian, does not seem to meet with the approval of recent arrivals from drier climes. (Apr 29, 1892,Taranaki Herald,2)

Yesterday, on parade, we had a very pleasing affair; lots were drawn in order that the comforts in clothing, sent us by the ladies if Lyttleton [sic] and Wellington, might meet with an equal distribution amongst us. They were sent only to the volunteers, but we agreed to translate the word to civilian, so that every Taranakian had something of use and value. (Oct 16, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,3)

2 n. a person born in, residing in, or loyal to Taranaki

Taranakis¶

n. a Taranaki (rugby) team

In the second spell the Northerners fairly romped over the Taranakis, who were beaten in every department of the game. (Aug 19, 1897,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

taranakite¶

n. a mineral

A New Zealand mineralogist seeing the book is naturally interested in the minerals first described from this country, namely akatoreite, (Read and Reay), awaruite (Skey), huttonite (Palst), hydrogrossular (Hutton), motukoreaite (Rodgers, Chisholm, Davis and Nelson), taranakite (Hector and Skey), tuhualite (Marshall), wairakite (Steiner and Coombs),and wairauite (Challis and Long). (Oct 1982,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,58.71)

This mineral, which is double hydrous phosphate of alumina and potash, part of the alumina being replaced by ferrous oxide, was first discovered by H. Richmond, Esq., at the Sugar Loaves, Taranaki, where it occurs as thin seams which occupy fissures in trachytic rocks. It is described by Dr. Hector (Juror's Rep. N. Z. Ex., 1865, p. 423) as of a yellowish-white colour; amorphous and soft; readily fusible before the blowpipe and in other respects resembling wavellite. (1883,TrNZI,15/385) [NOTES: (Cox)]

taranakite n -s [Taranaki, provincial district in New Zealand, its locality + E -ite] : a mineral ... ? consisting of a basic hydrous phosphate of aluminium and potassium in compact clayey masses (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2340) [NOTES: [In OEDS in this quotation]]

This included the first description of the new mineral taranakite, discovered near New Plymouth. (Nov 1990,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,90/44)

I have much pleasure in acknowledging the receipt from E.B. Dickson, Esq., of New Plymouth of three interesting geological specimens:- No.1, a specimen of granite from the Sugar Loaves, showing the formation of the newly described mineral, "Taranakite;" No.2, a larger one from an outlying reef; and No.3, a smaller specimen of the Taranikte by itself. It is probable that this substance will prove to be of some commercial value, as it evidently contains much phosphate of lime, which, for agricultural purposes, is highly esteemed. (Sep 19, 1866,Daily Southern Cross,4)

taranga¶

n. also called native or Maori daphne a long-leaved pimelea

CHEESEMAN P[imelea] longifolia, Banks and Sol. ... A small erect much-branched shrub 2-5 ft. high ... Taranga. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,609)

LAING & BLACKWELL Pimelea longifolia (The Long-leaved Pimelea) ... Maori name Taranga; an attractive plant, worth cultivation. (1940,Plants of NZ,283)

MARTIN Another very floriferous shrub to be seen on the [204] drier hillsides of Nelson and Marlborough and of North Island hills is that known as the NATIVE DAPHNE or TARANGA (Pimelea longifolia). Ibid. 235 Pimelea longifolia Maori Daphne or TARANGA. (1929,Flora NZ,200,1961, p. 204 ed.)

taranui¶

n. Caspian tern

BULLER STERNA CASPIA. (CASPIAN TERN.) ... Native name.- Tara-nui. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,279,{1888 2nd edn 2/73} ed.)

POWELL CASPIAN TERN (Hydroprogne caspia), Tara-nui of the Maoris, is a larger and more solidly built bird than the white fronted Terns. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,80)

FALLA et al. CASPIAN TERN Hydroprogne caspia Maori name: Taranui. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,158)

There are birds all round. Scolding taranui, and dotterels tiptoeing nimbly away over the wet grass of the air-strip. (Apr 3, 1984,Dominion,6) [NOTES: [Keri Hulme]]

Caspian Tern Hydroprogne caspia (PALLAS, 1770) OTHER NAME: Taranui. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,226)

HULME & MORRISON The first sign is taranui plummeting into the surf (utterly abandoned to the strike the Caspian tern falls). (1989,Homeplaces,108)

tarao¶

n.

TAYLOR Of such is the Tarau, a ganoid fish, two-and-a-half feet long, found among the rocks at Taranaki, where it lays concealed; (1855,Te Ika a Maui,627)

PHILLIPPS Odax vittatus Richardson. KELP-FISH; TARAO. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,40,1971 ed.)

Odax vittatus Richardson. Kelp-fish. Tarao. (1938,TrRSNZ,68/412) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

PARROTT THE KELPFISHOdax vittatus (Richardson) ... Maori name: TARAO (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,126)

TAYLOR At Waiapu I learned there is a bird which abounds on the mount Ikorangi - The Tarapo - ... which is the size of a turkey it is red has a beak like a parrot and is much prized as an article of food ... the kiwi also abounds on this mountain (Apr 26, 1839,Journal,2/117)

TAYLOR At Waiapu I learned there is a bird which abounds on the mount Ikorangi - The Tarapo - ... which is the size of a turkey it is red has a beak like a parrot and is much prized as an article of food ... the kiwi also abounds on this mountain (Apr 26, 1839,Journal,2/117)

tarapunga¶

n. also called red-billed gull, mackerel gull, makora a small New Zealand gull with scarlet bill, feet and eyelids. [Maori]

LARUS SCOPULINUS, Forst. Tara-punga. Little Gull. (1870,TrNZI,2/76) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

HUTTON 109. LARUS SCOPULINUS. Forst. Mackerel Gull. Tarapunga. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,40) [NOTES: nf 1873 edition; named there mackerel-gull]

BULLER LARUS SCOPULINUS. (MACKEREL- {RED-BILLED} GULL.) ... Native name{s}. Tarapunga, {Makora, and Akiaki}. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,273,{1888 2nd edn 2/55} ed.)

BULLER LARUS BULLERI. (BLACK-BILLED GULL.) ... Native name.- Tarapunga. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/58)

GULL. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,175)

POWELL RED-BILLED GULL (Larus novaehollandiae), Tarapunga or Akiaki of the Maoris, is abundant throughout New Zealand, Australia, New Caledonia and South Africa. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,80)

FALLA et al. RED-BILLED GULL Larus scopulinus Other names: Tarapunga, Mackerel Gull, Jackie (Chathams). (1966,Birds of New Zealand,154)

194. Larus novaehollandiae scopulinus Forster, 1844 Red-billed Gull (Tarapunga) New Zealand ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,53,1980 ed.)

Red-billed Gull Larus novaehollandiae scopulinus FORSTER, 1844 ... The red-billed gull is one of the commonest gulls on the New Zealand coast; it rarely lives inland. ... OTHER NAMES: Silver gull, tarapunga, akiaki, mackerel gull, jackie. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,222)

The pretty little gulls called Tarapunga by the Maoris are very plentiful on Rotorua, and have been protected for some years, but recently a number of dead and wounded birds have been seen floating on the lake. (May 10, 1902,Evening Post,6)

On a little point on the north side of the lake, some years back, the red-billed seagulls (tarapunga), from Lake Taupo, used to build their nests amongst the stones close to the waters edge. (Jun 26, 1912,Evening Post,17)

The red-billed or mackerell gull - .. the Maoris' tarapunga - is a smaller and prettier bird. (Aug 13, 1908,Auckland Weekly News,38)

Tarara¶

n. a Dalmatian

Even the Maoris learnt Nashki as they were accpeted as being ours and we were theirs. They even honoured us by giving us our special name of Tarara. (Aug 2004,NZ Memories,No. 49/49)

Thousands of people are expected to visit Waitakere City's Te Rangi Hiroa Park on March 3 for Tarara Day 2002. A celebration of the joining of Maori and Croatian cultures on the gumfields more than 100 years ago, Tarara Day provides an opportunity for people of Croatian-Maori descent to celebrate their cultures and learn more about their heritage. 'Tarara' was the name given to Croatians by Northland Maori to distinguish them from the English. (Jan 29, 2002,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: Waitakere City Council Media Release www.waitakere.govt.nz]

In business we can't be islands unto ourselves. We've got to work with the Tararas [Yugoslavs], Hindus, the Pakehas - anyone. (Sep 8, 2004,Dominion Post,C3)

BATISTICH We Dalmatians got on well with the Maoris from the start. It was almost as if we were related, maybe somewhere back in time. The Maoris had a name of their own for us: tarara, from the sound of our speech, not unlike their own; the same broad vowels and rolled 'r's, the musical inflexion that belongs naturally to song. (1987,Sing Vila in the Mountain,35)

In the 1860's the first Dalmatian gum diggers arrived fleeing hard times back in their Adriatic homeland. As the diggers were exclusively men, they found wives among the Maori community who called the newcomers Tarara, a reference to the sound of their speech. (Jul 2004,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: Planetfm 104.6 Newsletter of the Access Community Radio Ak Inc. July.Aug./ 2004. www/.104.6.planetfm.org.nz /Media. July - Aug 2004]

She also has English ancestry from her father and Tarara connections through her grandfather Mate Vuletich (on her Mum's side). (May 2002,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.terarawa.co.nz/kukupa/may2002.htm]

tarariri¶

n.

Puriri Posts, house blocks and firewood (puriri, tea-tree, matai and tarariri). (Sep 1907,Wairoa Bell & Northern Advertiser,[13])

Tararua¶

n. [R. Mason notes: also other examples: of a view a thick mist'; of weatherwith mist and/or drizzle, bad, sometimes windy and wet [?d] Tramper 12(5):6 ... the weather remained typically Tararua ... [d?] ibid 16(8):9 ... the view typically Tararua ...]

... Often the weather or the view is typically Tararua' or merelytypical'. No one is under the illusion that the conditions are then good; ... (Sep 1958,Tararua,28) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail']

Tararua biscuit¶

n.

BURTON [Title] Tararua Biscuits. A New Zealand mountaineers' staple, one of these biscuits lies buried in the Himalayas, on the summit or Yerupaja Norte. The gesture was the brainchild of Graeme Dingle, who was the first to conquer the mountain in 1968. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,152)

Among the authentic local baking-terms the one I find most evocative is the Tararua biscuit. It comes in high-fibre high- calorie slabs... Two generations of Wellington dentists must have made a tidy income from its inroads. I must be one of the few of my old Mt Holdsworth gang with my own teeth, since I only once tackled a Tararua biscuit and I must confess I did not take it straight. (Jun 4, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),55) [NOTES: [I.A. Gordon]]

Among the authentic local baking-terms the one I find most evocative is the Tararua biscuit. It comes in high-fibre high- calorie slabs... Two generations of Wellington dentists must have made a tidy income from its inroads. I must be one of the few of my old Mt Holdsworth gang with my own teeth, since I only once tackled a Tararua biscuit and I must confess I did not take it straight. (Jun 4, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),55) [NOTES: [I.A. Gordon]]

Tararua biscuit inf. tramper's home-made biscuit (1985,Collins Compact Dictionary,492) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD]]

PICKERING A classic lunch food is the Tararua biscuit. This is any sort of home-baked biscuit baked out of a mixture of rolled oats, flour, golden syrup and other ingredients, and formed into a hard flat biscuit that acts as a base for butter and spreads. The principle of Tararua biscuits is that they serve as a replacement for bread on long trips. ... The taste is not a crucial matter, but they must be firm and filling - and all of the same size, otherwise bickering will develop over who's got the biggest. (1988,Hills, The,71)

BURTON Tararua biscuits must be baked hard to withstand jostling about in a pack. (1982,200 Years of NZ Food & Cookery,152)

While on a hunting trip in the Grebe Valley the other weekend, we bumped into some members of the Peninsula Tramping Club and (I think) the Over 40s Tramping Club at Clark Hut. I peered over their shoulders and noted that their lunches included good old Tararua biscuits and one person had boiled eggs ... (Nov 2011,FMC - (Federated Mountain Clubs of NZ) Bulletin,52)

Among the authentic local baking-terms the one I find most evocative is the Tararua biscuit. It comes in high-fibre, high-calorie slabs generally baked by young males in secret when Mum is watching TV. Two generations of trampers swear by its life-sustaining qualities and two generations of Wellington dentists must have made a tidy income from its inroads. (Jun 4, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),55)

After his appearance in Trog 80, presiding over recipes for 'Aunt Hazel's Neutron Pudding', an improved 'Tararua Biscuit' and 'Tasty Kea Stew a la RF&B', Uncle Jacko was consigned not so much to history as oblivion. (Aug 2010,FMC - (Federated Mountain Clubs of NZ) Bulletin,31)

Tararua dishmop¶

n. Raoulia tenuicaulis creeping mat plant, one of the scabweeds [ca1952 May R. Mason fide N. Elder May 1952 From its being used by trampers as a dishcloth. Originating among Wellington trampers, but long obs in Wellington. Survives in Hawkes Bay.]

It is unnecessary to write at length in general of New Zealand plant names, but mention may be made of the Tararua dishmop and the mountain mop. Apparently the first is given to Raoulia tenuicaulis, one of the scabweeds, by Heretaunga Tramping Club. No doubt plenty of Tararuas have used it with sand or ashes to clean out a billy, little thinking that their actions might inspire a new plant name, given to it by Canterbury mountaineers apparently, from the tufts of leaves at the ends of the branches. (Sep 1958,Tararua,30) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail]

McGILL Tararua dishmop Raouli tenuicaulis plant, used by trampers to clean out pots and billies. (Cf mountain mop.) (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,112)

Tararua pack¶

n. a special frame-pack built on a bergan frame

tarata¶

n.

Close to our garden fence ... the officers of the 65th have their tents and right forninst the schoolroom windows are the soldiers [sic] warres. Remember too that we are now on the road, all our lovely geranium and tarata fences are gone. (Nov 17, 1855,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/183,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (Miss M.J. King)]

50 Tarata (turpentine) slab. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,16)

n. a New Zealand tree (Pittosporum eugenoides). also called the lemonwood, mapau a small native tree with aromatic leaves and gum. [Maori] (See lemonwood)

Ta-rá.ta (ta.-ra.́.t&adot.; colloq. t&adot.-ra.́.t&adot.), n. [Maori.] (Bot.) A New Zealand tree (Pittosporum eugenoides). (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

(1849,Torlesse Papers) [NOTES: karo: this possibly refers to taramea]

HOOKER Pittosporum crassifolium, Banks et Sol. ... Nat. name, `Tarata', R.Cunningham. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 23)

HOOKER Tarata, Col[enso]. Pittosporum eugenioides... Tarata, R.Cunn. Pittosporum crassifolium. ...Tarata, Lindsay. Pittosporum tenuifolium. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

MAPAU FAMILY. White Mapau; Tarata (Pittosporum eugenioides). Ibid. Tarata. Pittosporum eugenioides, A. Cunn. Ibid. (1869,TrNZI,1/3/33) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Pittosporum eugenioides Tarata (1870,TrNZI,2/121) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

(1876,TrNZI,9/143) [NOTES: W. N. Blair [alWo 1879]]

BULLER Tarata ... Pikiarero (1878,Forty Years in NZ,502)

HAY The Tarata (Pittosporum eujenioides) is a small tree noted for its purple blossom. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/197)

[Native name] Tarata .. [Settlers' name] Tarata .. [Family] Pittosporeae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

FEATON PITTOSPORUM EUGENIOIDES (A.Cunn.) ... The TARATA'.- ... It is known to the settlers in some parts asLemon Wood'. Ibid. 178 Tarata [Maori name] .. Lemon wood [Settlers' name] .. Pittosporum Eugenioides .. Tree (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,35)

Turpentine (tarata) .. Pittosporum eugenioides .. Timber white and elastic; ... (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,15)

Turpentine (tarata) .. Pittosporum eugenioides .. Timber white and elastic; ... (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,15)

MORRIS Tarata, n. Maori name for the New Zealand tree Pittosporum eugenioides, A. Cunn., N.O. Pittosporeae; called also Mapau, Maple, etc. See Mapau. (1898,Austral English,459)

CHEESEMAN [Pittosporum eugenioides, A.Cunn.] Tarata. ... The largest of the New Zealand species, ... (1906,Manual NZ Flora,61)

LAING & BLACKWELL Pittosporum eugenioides (The Lemonwood) ... Maori name Tarata. (Name from Eugenia, a genus of myrtles)... [Pittosporum eugenioides] it is often cultivated for its beauty, and is sometimes - though not so often as P. [195] tenuifolium - used to form an ornamental hedge. It is known by a variety of names amongst the colonists, such as Mapau, White Mapau, and even Maple, and Lemon-tree. The Maori name seems to have been Tarata, but it is also called the Mapau. (1907,Plants of NZ,194,1940 p. 202 ed.)

tarata, a tree (Pittosporun Eugenioides), lemonwood; gum used by the Maori for scenting oil. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146)

tarata, a tree (Pittosporun Eugenioides), lemonwood; gum used by the Maori for scenting oil. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146)

LEVY ... such species as lancewood, karamu, toro, ramarama, koromiko, kanono, kohuhu, kawakawa, hangehange, rangiora, five finger, patete, toru, tree daisies, broadleaf, kamahi, mahoe, tarata, karo, ... Some have been merged: but merge all of these regardless. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,87,1970 ed.)

LEVY ... such species as lancewood, karamu, toro, ramarama, koromiko, kanono, kohuhu, kawakawa, hangehange, rangiora, five finger, patete, toru, tree daisies, broadleaf, kamahi, mahoe, tarata, karo, ... Some have been merged: but merge all of these regardless. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,87,1970 ed.)

tarata also taratah n -s [Maori tarata] : a small evergreen tree (Pittosporum eugenioides) of New Zealand having white bark and fragrant corymbs of pale yellow flowers - called also white mapau (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2340)

tarata also taratah n -s [Maori tarata] : a small evergreen tree (Pittosporum eugenioides) of New Zealand having white bark and fragrant corymbs of pale yellow flowers - called also white mapau (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2340)

tarata n. small New Zealand tree, called also lemon-wood. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

tarata ... n. small N.Z. tree, called also lemon-wood. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),19)

tarata n. small NZ evergreen tree of pittosporum family with aromatic leaves. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,786) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

Tarata, the larger leafed Pittosporum eugenioides), does well in deeper and good soils... Tarata has sweet fragrant flowers and the crushed leaves give off a lemon-carrot scent. Both tarata and kohuhu were used by Maori, mixed with kereru fat to make a body lotion or, using gum bled form vertical slits in the trunk, mixed with oil from crushed titoki berries to make a scented body oil. (Oct 2000,Growing Today,69)

FEATON The "Tarata"... It is known to the settlers in some parts as "Lemon Wood". [Pittosporum eugenioides]. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,35)

2 n.

Pittosporum crassifolium, sea-side tarata, or kihihi. - A fine shrub or small tree, sometimes attaining the height of twenty-five feet; common on sandy or rocky coasts, from the North Cape to Poverty Bay; produces seed freely; a most valuable plant. (1873,TrNZI,6/48) [NOTES: (Kirk)]

2 n. Pittosporum tenuifolium

(1875,Durability NZ Timbers) [NOTES: (And)]

taratimoho¶

n.

BULLER PODICEPS RUFIPECTUS. (NEW-ZEALAND DABCHICK.) . Native names.- Weweia, Totokipio, Taihoropi (Hokianga), and Taratimoho (Waikato). (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/280)

tarau¶

n. (See tarao)

His tarau's in a real mess... He's tutaed himself. (Oct 1, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),109)

LEE & KENDALL T|ara w|era; A shell-fish. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,208)

RICHARDS PELLAEA ... rotundifolia ... TARAWERA. (1952,Chatham Islands,13)

Tarawera Ash¶

n. Geol. definition

He estimates 30,000 pitswere dug in the Rangitaiki Valley (Bay of Plenty) in the period between the Kaharoa and Tarawera Ashes (c. 1300 - 1886). (Oct 1982,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,58/52)

tarawhatu¶

n. brown duck

BULLER ANAS CHLOROTIS. (BROWN DUCK.) ... Native names.- Tarawhatu, Patete, {Tete,} and Tete-whero. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,248,{1888 2nd edn 2/257} ed.)

[Our prisoners] asked if it was Taro [circumflex a], a Species of Arum, the root of which we now learnt constituted a part of the food of these people - they spoke also of their using the Yams and Sweet Potatoes. (Oct 6, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/569) [NOTES: 1769 Oct 6 W.B. Monkhouse Journal in Cook Journals (1955) 1/569]

[Our prisoners] asked if it was Taro [circumflex a], a Species of Arum, the root of which we now learnt constituted a part of the food of these people - they spoke also of their using the Yams and Sweet Potatoes. (Oct 6, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/569) [NOTES: 1769 Oct 6 W.B. Monkhouse Journal in Cook Journals (1955) 1/569]

tare¶

n. wild tare, wild vetch

I set about and organised a gang and set out for Little River to the grass rush. ... The grass crop is very fair this year, though in some places crushed by a noxious weed called tare, and it is a bit late on account of the wet season. (Feb 16, 1912,Maoriland Worker,49/12/2)

HILGENDORF TARES (Vicia sativa), also called wild tares and wild vetch, abundant in waste places and cropped fields throughout. ... Tares climb by means of tendrils and grow 3 to 4 feet high. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,11,1967 ed.)

wild tare [=] narrow-leaved vetch [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,87)

tarehinu¶

n. shrub with tough, wiry, hard wood

KEENE tarehinu: shrub with tough, wiry, hard wood. (1963,O Te Raki,194)

tarenga¶

n.

FORSTER A Comparative Table of the Various Languages in the Isles of the South-Sea ... [English] The Ears ... [New-Zeeland] Tarenga [as-macron e-grave] (1778,Observations Made During a Voyage,284)

tarepo¶

n. [aka tarapo]

Cnemiornis calcitrans. - Tarepo. (Kaimanawa Range?) A large bird is mentioned in the Transactions of the N.Z. Institute by, I believe, Mr. T. Cockburn Hood, as having been killed by a settler's dogs; which bird, if I remember rightly, was supposed by the writer to be a Tarepo. (1886,TrNZI,18/113) [NOTES: (Martin)]

TAYLOR I find the tarapo is well known here [in Waiapu Valley] and much prized as an article of food (Apr 29, 1839,Journal,2/121)

TAYLOR [Word list] Taropo ) land birds Mohukura) Tikke ) A kokoko) (Aug 1843,Journal,52)

BULLER STRINGOPS HABROPTILUS. (OWL PARROT.) ... Native names. Kakapo {,Tarapo} and Tarepo; `Ground-Parrot' of the colonists. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,26,{1888 2nd edn 1/177} ed.)

Kakapo Strigops habroptilus GRAY, 1845 ... OTHER NAMES: Tarapo, tarepo, owl parrot, ground parrot, night parrot. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,242)

'.. When the Natives came they said that it was the bone of a tarepo, a very large bird which lived on the top of Hikurangi Mountain, and that they made their largest fishing-hooks from its bones.' (Jun 27, 1931,Evening Post,19)

The name given to the moa on the East Coast was tarepo, and not moa, but this word is not used elsewhere. (Nov 7, 1872,Evening Post,2)

This discovery (I mean of the bone, for the living bird never materialised, although explorers found plenty of caves) was made on the east coast, where the natives called the bird the "tarepo." Four years later, on the west coast, he found a perfect cemetery of these bones and heard the bird called for the first time the "moa" - the natives, very singularly, never having heard the name used by their brethren on the other side of the island. (Oct 20, 1894,Tuapeka Times,1)

tariere¶

n.

LEVY [Table 2] Tariere (1951,Grasslands of NZ,89)

taringa hoi¶

n. glue ear [ORIGIN: Maori, taringa = ear, hoi = earwax (and deaf)]

If so, they could be suffering from glue ear, taringa hoi. (Nov 2005,Pu Kaea,9) [NOTES: -]

tarmac over¶

v. (figurative) bury (in a rut)

Mike, 45, who says he was in such a deep rut he felt he had been "tarmacked over", was keen to take a break to plan his next career move, after 18 years in the travel business. (Jun 24, 2006,Dominion Post Indulgence,4)

tarn¶

n.

SUTHERLAND There must be a lake in there,' he said,though there's nothing on the map to say so, not even a tarn is showing.' (1953,Golden Bush, The,168,1963 ed.)

tarnicar¶

n. (See tanekaha)

taro¶

n. OED : a. A food-plant, Colocasia antiquorum, N.O. Araceae, cultivated in many varieties (C. esculenta, macrorhiza, etc.) in most tropical countries for its starchy root-stocks, or its succulent leaves or stems, which in a raw state are acrid, but lose their acridity by boiling. 1769 S. PARKINSON Jrnl. 1 Oct. in Jrnl. Voy. South Seas (1773) II. 97 Adjoining to their houses are plantations of Koomarra and Taro.

PARKINSON They [the natives] informed us, that there was Taro, Eape, Oomara, Yams, and also a peculiar kind of Deer, to be found upon the island. (Oct 11, 1769,Journal)

MONKHOUSE [Our prisoners] asked if it was Taro [circumflex a], a Species of Arum, the root of which we now learnt constituted a part of the food of these people - they spoke also of their using the Yams and Sweet Potatoes. (Oct 6, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/569,1955 ed.)

English New Zeland South-sea Islands ... ... ... Coccos Tara Taro Sweet Potatoes Cumala Cumala Yamms Tuphwhe Tuphwhe (Mar 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/287,1955 ed.)

FORSTER A Comparative Table of the Various Languages in the Isles of the South-Sea ... [English] Arum esculentum or eddoes ... [New-Zeeland] Tallo [a-macron grave] (1778,Observations Made During a Voyage,284)

NCIHOLAS In the plantations adjoining this village, I observed a plant very common in our West India settlements, where it is called tacca, and named by the natives of this island tarro. It does not appear to me that this plant is indigenous to New Zealand, but must, in my opinion, have been brought hither, either by Captain Cook or some other European navigator who has visited the country. (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/351)

MARSDEN They were clothed with their best mats, their heads ornamented with feathers, and had prepared an immense quantity of common and sweet potatoes and some tarra (taro), a root which they are very fond of, about the size of a small turnip. (Aug 1820,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,283,1932 ed.)

LEE & KENDALL T|aro, s. A root so called; bread. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,209)

McRAE Next day went to Wy Whero a fine tract of cultivated land - Peaches - Taroo Flax, Meero - return to house, - (1820,Journal,26,1928 ed.)

McNAB Q. Of what does their agriculture consist? A. The cultivation of yams, the potatoes (sweet and English), a native plant or root called tarra (? taro) [sic], and the calabash. (1908,Historical Records,1/543) [NOTES: 1821 May Evidence of Ensign McCrae before Commissioner Bigge in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/543]

MARKHAM We had to go through Cultivation mostly all the way. Indian Corn, potatoes and Cumeras [kumara] or Sweet potatoes, Tarraw [taro] a kind of Yam. The Tarras comes I believe from the South sea Islands. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),42,1963 ed.)

POLACK ... between those [small] hills the large broad lotus leaf of the tarro appeared; ... Ibid. 1/288 The taro (Arum esculentum) is a well-known legume; various species are planted in the islands, especially southward; it is very farinaceous. The taro oia, or soldier taro, has a blue cast, within a thin, atramentous skin; ... (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/181)

TAYLOR Here [East Cape] we are sitting in our tent ... we have a large fire in front and a smaller one in which a cake I have been making of taro is baking; Williams is kneading a damper in a tin pot; (Apr 30, 1839,Diary,17)

POLACK A long lane was formed on an extensive level plain, fifty feet in width, by two high walls, formed by perhaps upwards of ten thousand baskets of potatoes, kumeras, Indian corn (Holcus indicus), tarro (arum), water melons, turnips preserved, (kou) steamed kernels of the native fruit, (karaka[as-acute]) baked roots of the ti palm tree, (korou) a quantity of dried cod, eels and other fish, also of shell-fish, bundles of fern-root, onions, peaches, grapes, &c. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/91)

Natives ....regaled us with Taro (a kind of luscious slimy root more like the Jerusalem artichoke than any other vegetable). (1840,Journal of Ensign Best) [NOTES: 1840 Best Journal 1837-1843 ed 1966 Taylor 256]

HEAPHY Turnips have for a length of time been grown in the native plantations, ... and the indigenous Polynesian vegetable, `Taro'. (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),30)

COLENSO Leaving Te Kawakawa ... I passed by several of the Taro (Caladium esculentum, Vent.) plantations of those natives ... [7] Of the Taro plant the natives possess two kinds (species?) Taro maori and Taro Hoia; ... the former is supposed to have been introduced with the present race of natives, whilst the latter, as they themselves state, is quite of modern introduction. [check this citation] (1844,Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ) [NOTES: 1844 Colenso Excursion Northern Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 6, 7]

LINDLEY `Whole fields of Colocasia macrorhyza are cultivated in the South Sea Islands under the name tara or kopeh roots.' (1846,Vegetable Kingdom,128) [NOTES: [Stanford]:]

ANGAS Tradition further tells us that they [sc. New Zealanders] came from the island of Hawaiki (which lies eastward), bringing with them [306] taro and dogs. The kumera, or sweet potato (convolvulus battata) ... also came from the eastward. (1847,Savage Life,1/305)

BRUNNER ... each [Maori] having a kit of potatoes and taro, a large quantity of the kotiro, or preserved potato, ... Ibid. 56 ... and tara [fn Taro, edible lily of Polynesian origin] plantations of former days [West Coast]. (1847,Great Journey,54,1952 ed.)

MacLEAN There are 1,200 kits of kumara, large baskets of taro, papa or bark cases of birds cooked ..., including tui ... (Jul 6, 1849,Diary) [NOTES: 1849 July 16 Maclean Diary in 1940 Cowan Sir Donald Maclean 48]

THOMSON Next in importance [in Maori diet] to the original sweet potato was the taro (Caladium esculentum). The edible part is a bulbons root, ... (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/156)

[check this and following cit???] Ibid. 55 The ground-work of this feast appeared to be sweet potatoes and taro, but on top ... was placed either dried shark, eels, mullet, or pork, all `piping hot'. (1863,Old New Zealand,49)

HOOKER Taro, Col[enso]. Caladium esculentum. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

These were - two roots, and one gourd-like fruit; the Kumara, or sweet potato, (Convolvulus batatas), the Taro (Caladium esculentum), and the Hue, a large kind of gourd ... (1869,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),1/3/29)

These were - two roots, and one gourd-like fruit; the Kumara, or sweet potato, (Convolvulus batatas), the Taro (Caladium esculentum), and the Hue, a large kind of gourd ... (1869,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),1/3/29) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

These were - two roots, and one gourd-like fruit; the Kumara, or sweet potato, (Convolvulus batatas), the Taro (Caladium esculentum), and the Hue, a large kind of gourd ... (1869,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),1/3/29) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

DOMETT `May a bed, That late in such luxurious neatness spread, Of melon, maize and taro - now a wreck.' (1872,Ranolf and Amohia,374)

DOMETT `May a bed, That late in such luxurious neatness spread, Of melon, maize and taro - now a wreck.' (1872,Ranolf and Amohia,374)

Fascines of a tolerable thickness are ... disposed chess-board fashion (like Maori taro beds), and the sowing is made. (1873,TrNZI,5/109)

CAMPBELL We all had a turn at the soup-making; some put kumeras into the pot, some put tarro, a vegetable which is like a lump of flour, and if left long over the fire boils away by slow [118] degrees and thickens the soup. (1873,Poenamo,2/7/117)

DOMETT The small cray-fish in myriads bred,/ With sunk fern-bundles lifted from the Lake:/ Next pounded fern-root pounded to a cake,/ ...; and the choicer roots,/ .../ The kumara [u-acute] and taro. [a-acute] Ibid. 1/303 Taro ..... O. Pandaneae (Aroideae); G. Caladum; S Caladum esculentum. `A staple article of food in many parts of the Old World' A root something like the kumara - but whiter, firmer, and less sweet. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/184)
