[a-acute] Ibid. 1/303 Taro ..... O. Pandaneae (Aroideae); G. Caladum; S Caladum esculentum. `A staple article of food in many parts of the Old World' A root something like the kumara - but whiter, firmer, and less sweet. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/184)

MORRIS a familiar food plant, Colocasia species, widely cultivated in tropical regions, especally in Polynesia. The Word is Polynesian, and much used by the Maoris. (1898,Austral English,459)

MORRIS a familiar food plant, Colocasia species, widely cultivated in tropical regions, especally in Polynesia. The Word is Polynesian, and much used by the Maoris. (1898,Austral English,459)

TREGEAR Upon the stages were piled baskets of [rest of cit???] (1904,Maori Race, The,113)

BAUCKE The staple cultivated foods of the ancient Maori ... were: Kumara, kumara, taro, hue, dried fish ... etc. ... taro, and hue. Ibid. 15 [rest of cit???] (1905,Where the White Man Treads,12)

taro n. a plant, a species of colocassia, cultivated in many Pacific islands for its edible roots and tubers. [polynesian] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,11)

HUNT Potatoes, kumeras, taros, and water melons were the chief crops grown in the ... humid bush-surrounded plots ... (1951,Confessions,24)

A food plant which the Maoris cultivated, having brought it with them from Hawaiki. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),406)

SINCLAIR The Maoris thrived and multiplied largely because they introduced certain food plants to New Zealand, especially the kumara (the sweet potato), the taro, and the yam. iBID. 302 [Maori glossary] taro Food plant (Colocasia antiquorum) (1959,History of New Zealand,19)

KEENE taro: food plant (1963,O Te Raki,194)

BURTON There is now little doubt that the primary migration to New Zealand ... brought the Maori food plants from an eastern Polynesian homeland, ... These plants were the island yam (Dioscorea esculenta), the bottle gourd, the taro, a dwarf type of cabbage tree and the kumara. Ibid. 4 Taro grows wild in a few places in the north, having escaped from old Maori gardens, and is not difficult to grow. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,3)

taro n. pl. -ros. 1. an Asian plant, cultivated in the tropics for its large edible rootstock. 2. the rootstock of this plant. [C18: < Tahitian & Maori] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1197) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 786; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 492]]

Filipo trims taro at an Otara supermarket. (Oct 27, 2004,Capital Times,11)

Plant scientists believe they are close to defeating a disease which a decade ago nearly crippled Samoa and still threatens the Pacific's vital taro plantations. (Jul 16, 2002,Dominion Post,B1)

"It doesn't matter how well you cook the taro... That doesn't pay the bills." (Oct 26, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),89)

Totally unversed in the mysteries of subsoil ploughing, and ignorant of the virtues of guano, all their field work is performed by the hoe, by use of which, however, and by not sparing their own labour, they contrive to raise abundant crops of yams, taro, potatoes, and kumeras [sic]. (Oct 16, 1850,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,3)

The land here is very fertile and productive - maize, kumeras [sic], potatoes, taro, and tobacco growing in great luxuriance, peaches also very plentiful. (May 9, 1862,Daily Southern Cross,5)

My Dad walked home with taro and Twisties / in his work-bag and he recalls his past with / a bottle of 'Vailima' in his hand. (Aug 25, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),93)

2 n.

BAKER ...Hemi was waiting on the grassy bank with a taro sack he'd found in the storeroom. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,43)

taro Maori¶

n. (Rural) a cultivar of taro, Colocasia esculenta. [ORIGIN: Maori]

BEST The great labour of growing taro maori (the old pre-European variety) caused it to be abandoned when the taro Merekena was introduced. The latter is hardy, prolific, runs wild in fact, and easily cultivated, but it is very inferior in flavour and flouriness to taro maori. I don't think I have seen taro maori for thirty years. (1925,Maori Agriculture,127)

taropo¶

n. (See tarapo)

tarp¶

v. to cover with a tarpaulin

REDMOND This was really hard yakker because I had to tarp the loads. (2000,Truckers: NZ Truckers on the Road,103)

n. (informal) short for tarpaulin [Jim writes : In NZPOD but not DNZE. NSOD tags it as NAmer & Austral.; Collins as US Austral and NZ.]

Geary Haden lifted the tarp on his transport tray. - I brought a rope and tyre, see. (2003,Man of the People, A,151)

tarpaulin muster¶

n.

BAUCKE (1905,Where the White Man Treads,243)

WAITE The crews had a `tarpaulin muster,' the result of which was a present for every man in the division of half a pound of tobacco, at a time when it was specially acceptable. (1919,New Zealanders at Gallipoli,263)

If the good old fashion of a `tarpaulin muster' among friends constitutes charity, well, what next? (Sep 18, 1963,People's Voice,5)

BAUCKE "I am too poor, let us make a tarpaulin muster and call in a surveyor, that this distraction be ended." (1905,Where the White Man Treads,243)

Tarpaulin Muster, Miramar Progressive Association meeting 17s 0d. (Feb 9, 1928,Evening Post,10)

The ceremony of dedicating at the War Veterans' Home in Narrabeen two rooms, together with furnishings, provided out of a "tarpaulin muster" by the New Zealand returned soldiers who visited Sydney for the 1938 Anzac Day celebrations [which] took place today. (Apr 15, 1940,Evening Post,13)

Tommy says there is not a sufficient number of the old Mosquito Fleet left now to raise a tarpaulin muster. (Aug 13, 1881,Observer (Auckland),546)

The Government, I think, are trying to strengthen their hands by sending over the Wellington portion of the tribe, who arrived at Te Waotu last week, bring in their pockets subscription lists for native parsons, good moral tracts, and such like remedies for the present state of darkness (mental) in which their Waotu brethren are living; but I am afraid a " tarpaulin muster" for a bottle of grog would find more favour amongst them than dubbing up for the purpose of keeping another native preacher. (Aug 23, 1873,Daily Southern Cross,2)

The great Conference of the representatives of the goldfield counties at Wellington, came to a conclusion on Monday last, just before dinner time, and so satisfied were the deputants that their deliberations would meet with the approval of the Premier, and that the Government Sugar Basin would be placed within reach of their spoons, that they got up a tarpaulin muster of a tanner a head, and indulged in a half hour's anti-teetotal recreation in anticipation of the success of their plans. (Jun 24, 1891,West Coast Times,2)

RICHARDS Rather than cancel the trip and return, the females of the party decided to take up a "tarpaulin muster" and by shedding the odd garment here and there they soon had Pud warm and dry and dressed in a new set of finery. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,47)

The camp was kept going by a tarpaulin muster. (Sep 18, 1919,Maoriland Worker,8)

The Waitomo County Council yesterday had a "tarpaulin muster" for a staff presentation. (Dec 10, 1937,King Country Chronicle,4)

Any organisation to which he belongs forms the ideal means for the procuring of liquor by a tarpaulin muster. (Dec 20, 1937,King Country Chronicle,5)

tarpot¶

n. [ca1935 Havelock schoolchildren Mungimungi tarpot' (orMungimungi taipo') as an abusive catcall to a Maori]

ADSETT Isabel did not say how, when at school, she had taken a leading part in the teasing of Maori kids by chanting `Tar pot! Tar pot! Who fell in the tar pot!' (1963,Magpie Sings, A,88)

n.

SARGESON (1949,I Saw in My Dream,112,1974 ed. Rhodes ed.)

MORRIESON As if the crafty bitch would have it in her bag', Miriam scoffed.All these tarpots are too cunning to turn their back on themselves. And half-castes are the worst of the lot ...' (1976,Pallet on the Floor,49)

tarra¶

n. (See taro)

tarring¶

n.

WILSON The last and hardest task (I thought) was the `tarring', as it was called. Each bag was placed in a basket, the totara bark stripped and placed around the bag for protection. Each bag was then tied securely with flax and twine, branded with our private brand and stacked in the storehouse to await the half time boat. (1979,Titi Heritage,88) [NOTES: ?f. TO-TARR(A)ing]

tarro¶

n. (See taro)

tarry soil¶

1 n. (Rural) a dark sticky loam soil [ esp. S I.]

WALLACE The best soil on the [Totara] estate [near Oamaru] is a black sticky loam, locally termed `tarry soil'. ... (1891,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,258)

tarseal¶

n. [surface of roadway, as opposed to road itself; aka tar-seal]

The tar-seal of "Restar" costs about GBP150 per mile. (Mar 7, 1914,Wanganui Chronicle,6)

HILL In the 1930s, the Wharetapu and Pukerangi Roads were narrow strips of metal with shallow ditches on each side. In the1980s they're narrow strips of tarseal with deep ditches on either side. (1985,Moaville Magic,68)

It leads, after 45km of skinny metal, then skinny tarseal, then wide tarseal, to Taupo, via Kinloch and Acacia Bay. (Apr 4, 1993,Evening Post,20)

Basil and Trudy Meyer live on a narrow road where the tarseal runs out back of Ikamatua. (Jun 23, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

tarsealer¶

n. one who tarseals roads

TARSEALER HOT ON SPEEDING DRIVERS ...Tarsealing gang foreman...had some harsh words for inconsiderate motorists... (May 6, 1983,Dominion,10)

tart¶

v.

BALLANTYNE Where you been all this time?' his mother asked.Down the library,' he said. ... `I bet he's been tarting,' Joy said. (1948,Cunninghams, The,32,1976 ed.)

n. a female, espec. a girl; a girl-friend, sweetheart -->(children's often jam-tart) [1951 14-17 M 14 St Bede's, Chch 28 TART [24] girl friend -->1960 16C F B5 Wellington Girls C. 28 TART -->1960 17C M B6 St Bede's, Chch 28 TART -->1960 17C M B8 Wanganui Girls C.I 28 TART]

A tart from Hataitai / Skips around and pokes her flamin' / Umbrella in me eye. (Dec 1, 1920,NZ Free Lance,Xmas Annual 43)

Tarts don't climb trees. Tarts don't play with footballs. Tarts don't ride bicycles. (1988,Back Then..,I : 90) [NOTES: Refers to around 1930]

he cavorted around the [ball-]room in a rather undignified manner, a number of the tarts turned their broad backs in his direction .. and snubbed him vigorously. (Aug 17, 1905,NZ Truth,9/7/8)

No matter how sweet a tart' may be she always wantssugar'. (Jan 6, 1906,NZ Truth,29/1/4)

(Feb 8, 1913,NZ Bulletin,16) [NOTES: [= girlfriend: see quot cobber]]

(Sep 2, 1916,Hutt Valley Independent,6/294/4) [NOTES: [= woman]]

(1916,Anzac Book, The,22) [NOTES: [= woman]]

Becos, yo' see, th' muse this side,/Is such a bonzer tart. (Aug 1917,Princes Street,12)

Bosker tart [equivalent to American `Jane'] (Aug 16, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,33)

He's only ninepence, and would like to treat/ His Sunday tart to sparkling `fizz' and oysters./ (Nov 1, 1918,Quick March,23)

When I draw'd me wind, and wus walkin' aht/ In me slommicky 'orspital blue,/ I sights a tart, who gets me cart'/ Wiv aglad' wot bites me through./ ... We wus photograrfed, jest me an' 'er,/ 'Ere 'ave a cook at the proof.'/ Bill `cooked' and saw RED. (Jul 19, 1919,Quick March,17) [NOTES: (by Harcus Plimmer)]

ANTHONY Gus was busy flying all over Taranaki on his motor-bike, taking some red-headed tart to football matches and such like, ... . (1927,Me and Gus,82,(1977 Gus Tomlins ed. Sturm) ed.)

I was standing in a public hall in Wellington one evening, when I heard one young fellow ask another to `give him a knockdown to that tart in the green skirt'. I gathered he was asking for an introduction to a young lady. (May 1930,National Education,197) [NOTES: (C.J. Hickson)]

CAMPBELL (also jam-tart) Check that have cit. from Campbell Island to Island Classrooms were smelly places in the thirties, especially on wet mornings when small boys and girls (tarts' orjam tarts', we used to call them), ... began to steam in their damp clothes. (1984,Island to Island,89) [NOTES: [c1936]]

HYDE `Christ. Well, young or old, my old women or the next, it's all the same in the finish. A tart's a tart.' (1938,Godwits Fly, The,129,1970 ed.)

HYDE `He can see a tall, dark woman going to cross my path, and I'm to look out, 'cos she's not the kind of tart my mother would have liked.' (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,61)

MARSH I don't see that silly little tart fixing counterweights. (1937,Vintage Murder,156)

LAWLOR [children speaking] Ever been out with a tart. (1938,House of Templemore, The,199)

BENNETT The slang word for girl is tart, used, for instance, by schoolboys; it has only lately begun to assume the derogatory sense it now has elsewhere. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,85)

(in Cockney) A tart' is a common name for a girl, just like ourdame,' and does not mean a loose woman. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,38)

FINLAYSON `I know why you're off to Moss's - that young tart of his. Ha-ha!' (1948,Tidal Creek,102,1979 ed.)

MUIR `There was a tart used to be mad keen on me, see? ... But I notice this picture in the Weekly and I says to me cobber, I reckon I know that [251] bint.' (1960,Word for Word,250)

I had a schottische with the tart from the Butcher's,/ Got stuck for a waltz with the constable's wife;/ I had a beer from the keg on the cream-truck,/ And the cop had one, too, you can bet your life. (1964,Book of New Zealand, A (J.C. Reid),259) [NOTES: (Cape `Down the Hall on Saturday Night)]

SLATTER [see poppy show] Ibid. 230 Tank Tarrant once led his gang across the paddocks ..., kicking the puffballs and the sheep turds, throwing the dry cow pats at any tarts he met. Chanting the gang haka. (1968,Pagan Game, The,52)

MANTELL `That's my wife. Now, d'you think I'd let that silly tart [sc another woman] loll over me like that ...' (1980,Murder or Three, A,65)

BARLTROP A prostitute is not called a tart by Cockneys, because tart' has always meant a girl. It is a street word, not used indoors, but it is not coarse or unpleasant. It conveys a well made up, attractive girl. One might sayWho's that ginger-haired tart,' or Harry was talking to a tart', or evenyour tart' - though the last shows a poor vocabulary and would be said only by children. The term has been going strong for at least seventy [83] years, and probably derives from something like `jam tart'; given that, why should a reference to colourfulness and sweetness be offensive? (1980,Muvver Tongue, The,82)

BEARDSLEY tarts girls (1984,Blackball 08,245)

He wasn't interested in girls at that stage. But there were always the tart chasers. All the girls weretarts' regardless of their morals I suppose. But most of the fellows weren't interested.' (May 31, 1985,Evening Post,15) [NOTES: [Mr Peter Rasmussen reminiscing about St Patrick's College, Wellington in 1909]]

tart 2 1 n. sl. girl, sweetheart (NZ & Austral.). (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,786) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

Your correspondent, in Tuesday's issue, tries to explain the meaning of the words, "Jam Tart." I fancy that his brain must have been in the same haze that your own dear brain was, respecting the sense of the term. I real meaning of the name, both from a confectionary [sic] and social point of view, is a thing with a great deal of puff, but with very little in it. (May 10, 1879,Waikato Times,2)

Thus "The Sporting Times" was sued in relation to a paragraph, in its dramatic column, in which the young ladies of the chorus of the Avenue Theatre were described as "tarts." (May 21, 1887,Te Aroha News,6)

What about the old tarts on the New Zealand bench? (Mar 23, 1912,NZ Truth,6)

At a case in the Te Awamutu Police Court recently a witness was making a statement. "Me and my wife," he said, "went ." Then he stopped. "Pardon," he said. "I and the missus went ." Still feeling that something was wrong somewhere he stopped again, and reddened. Then his face lit us. "Yes," he said, "The old tart and myself ___." (Sep 8, 1920,Ohinemuri Gazette,2)

[Caption] I was late for dinner, late for the tart, and she chucked me! (Sep 20, 1913,NZ Observer,16)

CAPE I had a schottische with the tart from the butcher's. (1967,Shanties by the Way,148)

The fact is, the Herald, like a number of the Remuera 'jamtarts' was disgusted at finding Lennox was a thorough Liberal, and not a sham one who would profess advanced views to humbug the working class and go to Parliament to act in the opposite interest. (Jan 1, 1891,Observer (Auckland),6)

I blushes like a 14-year-old tart. (Jul 5, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/47 : 251)

The attendance was very meager, only about twenty couple [sic] putting in an appearance. This was principally owing to the fact that invitations were limited to lady friends of the members only. However, a few of the opposite sex - on whom the "jam-tarts" occasionally bestow a passing notice - managed to gain admittance. (Jan 14, 1882,Observer (Auckland),282)

Jam-tarts were a-bun-dant at the Institute ball,and were found in both supper and dancing rooms. (Nov 23, 1901,Observer (Auckland),26)

BEARDSLEY The tarts getting plenty too [sc. lollies] and filling their aprons, so quick they were, little hens darting on the lollies. (1984,Blackball 08,62)

2 n.

She was an old tart with a high-bridged smelling apparatus. (Aug 26, 1905,NZ Truth,10/7/8)

BALLANTYNE That tart gets my goat ... that skinny old biddy. Ibid. 28 OLD TART, old woman He felt crook again, remembered the old tart hitting him with a broom, the kids watching. (1948,Cunninghams, The)

SARGESON No, I don't know, but there's a yarn his father was a whaler that stayed out here and got in tow with some maori tart. He's part maori for sure though, because once he got me to witness a paper and it was about maori land.Ibid. 116 166 But do you know what that tart did? he said. She ran up the trunk of one of the willow trees and sat up there in the branches. (1949,I Saw in My Dream,117) [NOTES: (1974 ed. Rhodes)]

CRUMP Y'see, we got a job working for an old tart who had a bit of a sheep -and cattle-run in the Hawke's Bay. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,190)

SLATTER The old tart on the sideline who tripped up Fartstick Taylor with her umbrella when he was clean away for a try. (1968,Pagan Game, The,174)

McINNES Hurry up you kids. It's three tarts on bikes. The three tarts were aghast. (1969,Castle on the Run,52)

MASON HINGAWARU ... When Rangi chooses his wahine, someone else pays, ne? RANGI: When I choose, Dad, I'll choose a girl, not a wahine! Hate that word! Makes me see fat slobbery old tarts waddling along the beach. (1974,Hand on the Rail, The,20)

tartan mafia¶

n. the established Dunedin business community

tartape¶

n. black, tarred-cotton insulation tape (as distinct from the plastic)

He bound what remained [of the pocket-knife handle] with tartape so it fitted edgeless and easy in the hand. (Mar 8, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26) [NOTES: Hulme (The Knife)]

taru¶

n. grass

The camp shelters were made of patiti (tussock) and taru (grass) woven on sticks and were of a temporary nature merely designed to keep off the rain and wind. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/40)

tarua¶

n.

DIEFFENBACH 47. Tripterygion fenestratum. - ... (Blennius fenestratus, G. Forster ...) ... Inhabits the fresh-water rivulets of Dusky Bay, and is named by the natives `Hetarooa'. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/212) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna (Richardson's Fish) In 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/212]

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] a New Zealand-bred cultivar of red clover.

His Matua [prairie grass] Tarua red clover mixture is good for extending the lactation period in the autumn. (Sep 1985,NZ Journal of Agriculture,17)

taruke¶

n.

MEREDITH They [East Coast Maoris] also used a taruki (crayfish pot) and had an ingenious way of lifting it. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,114,1935 ed.)

tarweed¶

n.

HILGENDORF TAR WEED ([Odontites] viscosa) is abundant in all moist pastures. It is an annual growing about a foot high, stiffly erect, unbranched. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,159,1967 ed.)

HILGENDORF TAR WEED ([Odontites] viscosa) is abundant in all moist pastures. It is an annual growing about a foot high, stiffly erect, unbranched. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,159,1967 ed.)

Tarweed (Bartsia viscosa) is a common annual weed of the gum lands of the north. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,364)

Tarweed (Bartsia viscosa) is a common annual weed of the gum lands of the north. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,364)

tarweed [=] Chilean tarweed: red tarweed: spurrey [s] ...tarweed [s] Parentucellia viscosa (L.) Car. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,77)

TAYLOR TARWEED (Parentucellia viscosa). ... This plant is native to southern Europe and occurs throughout New Zealand in ditches and in pasture. (1981,Weeds of Lawns,113)

WILSON Parentucellia viscosa TARWEED ... Yellow bartsia ... Erect, stickily hairy annual herb. ... Native to: Europe. (=Bartsia viscosa). on damp ground. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,224)

2 n.

TAYLOR CHILEAN TARWEED (Madia sativa) Annual forming stiff erect stems in summer ... the whole plant becomes propressively more sticky as it matures ... it is very common in its native Chile, but common ... only in parts of Marlborough and North Canterbury. (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,39)

Chilean Tarweed [s] Madia sativa Mol. Ibid.77 tarweed, Chilean [s] Madia sativa Mol. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,13)

2 n.

red tarweed [s] Parentucellia latifolia (L.) Car. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,63)

tarwhine¶

n. (See tauhinu)

Taskforce Green¶

n. a scheme to use unemployed for landscape improvement

Maharey says these won't be sheltered workshop-type schemes or even Taskforce Green-like. (Aug 5, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

Tasman¶

adj. Australian and New Zealand [DEH : alternative to "Australasian"]

[Hdg] Tasman bourses at 16-month low (Dec 10, 1994,Dominion,15) [NOTES: cf "Trans-Tasman"]

Tasmanian blackwood¶

n.

Tasmanian blackwood [s] Acacia melanoxylon R.Br. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,77)

They have planted a commercial Douglas fir plantation, joining existing woodlots of high quality timber such as Tasmanian blackwood and cedars. (Jul 3, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

The Government may have to poison up to 2000 hectares.. exotic Tasmanian blackwood trees planted in Westland using taxpayer funds... The "special purpose" trees were planted after the West Coast Accord. Most were Acacia melanoxylon, better known as Tasmanian blackwood. (May 31, 2001,Dominion,7)

Tasmanian grass grub¶

n.

They are Tasmanian grass grubs, an unwelcome immigrant from Australia, and they are eating their way across Hawke's Bay and down into Wairarapa. (Jul 24, 2003,Dominion Post,C4)

Tasmanian kingfish¶

n.

WILSON [The Southern Kingfish is] Called Hake in southern fish shops but bears no resemblance to the traditional English Hake which is far less oily. Tasmanian kingfish, barraconda and `tikati' (Maori) are other names. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,201)

Tasmanian muttonbird¶

n.

62. Puffinus tenuirostris (Temminck, 1835) Short-tailed Shearwater (Tasmanian Muttonbird) Breeding on islands off south east Australia and Tasmania ... occurring regularly in New Zealand coastal (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,27,1980 ed.)

Tasmanian pudding¶

n.

TASMANIAN PUDDING ... bread (buttered); place together like sandwich, with raspberry jam between, and soak with milk ...pin in cloth, and boil ... serve with boiled custard or maizena sauce. (1932,St Andrew's Cookery Book,126) [NOTES: maizena is a brand of cornflour]

Tasmanian swamp quail¶

n.

The third species seem to be the Tasmanian swamp quail. (Jun 1, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

tassel¶

n. the greasy locks of wool left on legs or brisket

BOWEN For the tassels right under the front leg, especially for young shearers, the fingers of the left hand stretch the skin bringing the tassels around so they are easier to cut off. Ibid. 157 TASSEL. Greasy locks of wool left under the legs and brisket. (1955,Wool Away!,40)

Tassels: Greasy locks of wool left on the legs or brisket. (Dec 26, 1965,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing)]

TASSELS: Greasy locks of wool left on legs or brisket. (Feb 21, 1968,Straight Furrow,20) [NOTES: [Shearer's language]]

1 n. (Rural) a remnant of wool left on sheep's legs or briskets after shearing.

MCGILL tassels: 'greasy locks of wool left on legs or briskets' says Straight Furrow, 21 February 1968. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,99)

Tassie¶

n. Tasmania; a Tasmanian [aka Tassy; also attrib]

The Salvarmy in Tassy. (Sep 2, 1905,NZ Truth,11/1/5)

PFAFF I remained in Tassy about four years, came back to Auckland .. and then went back to Tassy (1914,Diggers' Story, The,112)

Tassie, -y a. & n. NZ & Austral. colloq. Tasmania(n). [abbr.] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,787) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

OWEN & PERKINS A Tassie bushman once said to me, `I don't like that new bloke the Old Man started.' .. The Tassie was dead serious ... (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,63) [NOTES: (Bob Edwards, bushman)]

I was disappointed at the state of things that existed throughout, but as the rate of progress is about an iota every 20 years, I must allow the Tassies that period to perfect matters horsey. (Feb 24, 1888,Otago Witness,25)

The streets are wide and well kept, and good footpaths are a prominent feature of the city, but the business people are a long way behind the age in spite of their opinion that the "Tassies," as they fondly call themselves, have the collective wisdom of centuries. (Jun 4, 1891,Inangahua Times,4)

On the return journey a special train ran from Perth to Melbourne, taking home the Victorians, the "Tassies," some South Australians, and a number of Mother Staters. (Nov 29, 1924,Evening Post,18) [NOTES: NZ writer on bowling trip to Aust.]

n. the Tasman Sea [the ditch] (See the ditch)

This advice is particularly accurate when pushing wet weather gear and other apparel for a trip over the 'tasie'. (Jun 2000,Sailing NZ,59)

Ballantyne Saw him [a trans-Tasman yachtsman] a few days before he took on the Tassy. (1980,Penfriend,69)

tassle fern¶

n. [JD queries ?invented?]

WILSON Lycopodium varium HANGING CLUBMOSS ... Tassel fern ... Dark green tufts of variable form: (A) growing upright on the ground, with drooping tips[? HWO =`tassels']; ... (C) long, pendent from tree trunks and branches ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,474)

taste¶

n. drug users': a portion of heroin, the amount of one `hit' or injection, a portion of heroin, the amount of one hit; one injection of a drug

BAXTER This is the core of junkie ethics. To protect your friends from the fuzz. To share a last taste of shit with them as men in a lifeboat share out the last drops of water. (1972,Islands,130) [NOTES: Elegy for Boyle Crescent]

NEWBOLD .. five or ten dollars for a taste of adulterated heroin. Smack wasn't economical [rest of cit???] Ibid.17 At the price [heroin] worked out at about $2 to $3 a taste. (1982,Big Huey, The,14)

BEATON SANDY: Fuck stockin's an' shit! Just give me a fucken taste an' I'd be happy. Ibid. taste the amount of one `hit' or injection of a drug. (1984,Outside In,89)

tasty¶

adj. describing a well-matured cheddar cheese

Cheese is bung. By long tradition this has been our tradition. Bung comes in two varieties - mild or tasty. Or soap and putty. Something to fill up on ... or to toss on the bar as counter-lunch. Come to think of it, counter-lunch is le mot juste, stifling as it does all desire for other food. (Dec 1952,Here & Now,5)

tat/tatt¶

n. a tattoo (esp. prison, and often self-applied, or amateurly applied) (also as verb)

As we've seen in the South Auckland postie crisis, local authborities lack the will to persuade dangerous dogs in dangerous neighbourhoods, where someone with tats might swear at them. (May 3, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

BAKER Puru, tats and gang colours, talked about organising a dogwatch. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,36)

HARRISON You know what a boob tat is?'...A tattoo done in jail. Or borstal. Or D.C. ... Detention Centre. Or remand home' (1981,Quiet Earth, The,153)

BEATON DI: I can see it now. Ginny in a pretty pink dress, hair set, face set. Tatts hidden under long sleeves. Ibid. tatt tattoo, especially one applied in prison. (1982,Outside In,101) [NOTES: [itals OK???]]

The big mean tatts we see on his biceps on TV are wash-off transfers. (Sep 1986,Metro)

HALEY Her white arms were covered in scrawled tats. (1989,Transfer Station,46)

...there was a tremendous conglomeration of people; a lot of Pakeha in there, activists, radicals, church people - and the gangs, the boys with the tats. And you could see these boys with the tats saying, 'We was robbed.' (Jul 23, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),59)

Te Manahau is a sort of Don Corleone type, but with better enunciation and excellent tats. (Jun 26, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),70)

BAKER 'Those shop ones are just toys anyway,' said Mangu, dreads, tats and a checkled swanny... (2000,Kokopu Dreams,126)

Imagine, you get the tatts, and then you follow through with a genuine wahine. (Jul 27, 2000,Dominion,8)

David Geary He talked about how good the sea had been for his skin, how he was going to get a dermatologist to remove all his scars and tatts. (2008,Six Pack 3, The,118)

tata¶

n. the brown duck

BEATTIE Tata (usually spelt tataa to show emphasis is on second vowel). This is the brown duck, now very rare. (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,64) [NOTES: c1880 South Island Maori Lists `Wahi Mahika Kai' in 1945 Beattie Maori Place-names of Canterbury 64]

MIKAERE There were putakitaki (paradise ducks), parera (grey ducks), tataa (brown ducks) and whio (blue ducks). ... The pukeko (swamphen) were caught only as a last resort, because their flesh was stringy and tough. (1988,Te Maiharoa,75)

tatahi¶

n.

SANSOM Herekopare and Woman's Island are the only two beneficiary muttonbird islands. All the rest are Crown lands. ... I know ... that the fierce nettle also grows on Herekopare. Other lovely ... plants are there too - the Stewart Island yellow senecio, teteaweka of course, ... Cook's health-giving scurvy grass, soft native tatahi grass and punui, the giant-leafed umbrella-like araliad. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,69)

tataiato¶

n. the whitehead

YATE Tataito - A small bird about the size of the wren; ... of a dusky brown colour; the head and breast inclining to white. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),55)

POLACK The tataiato [a1,a3-acute] is a small bird, with a forked tail, very long; its plumage is of a dusky brown. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/299)

TAYLOR I also noticed a curious kind of rasp the Tataramoa [fn This is the only thorn in New Zealand.] which has a singular looking leaf ... (Apr 13, 1839,Journal,2/100)

tataka¶

n. a shrub

HOOKER Tataka, Mantell. Melicope ternata. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

FEATON MELICOPE TERNATA (Forst.) ... The WHARANGI' orTATAKA'.- This small tree is indigenous to the Northern Island, and the Nelson District, in the Middle Island. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,81)

tataki thrush¶

n. fernbird

FALLA et al. FERNBIRD Bowdleria punctata Other names: Matata, Tataki Thrush (Foveaux St.). (1966,Birds of New Zealand,205)

tatarahake¶

n.

HOOKER Coprosma acerosa, A.Cunn. ... Nat. name, `Tatara hake', Colenso. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 109)

HOOKER Tatara-hake, Col[enso]. Coprosma acerosa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

... the bark and stems of the Pikiarero (Clematis hexasepala), and the root of the Tatarahake (Coprosma acerosa.) (1869,TrNZI,1/III/39) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

Tataraheke. Coprosma acerosa, A. Cunn. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/43) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

acerosa ... the curious red fruit of the Titoki, or Titongi, (Alectryon excelsum); ..and of the two littoral species, Taupata (C. retusa), and Tataraheke (C. )... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/31) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

RICHARDS C[oprosma] acerosa ... Sand Coprosma. TA TARA-HEKE (bristling). (1952,Chatham Islands,61)

BROOKER et al. Coprosma australis (A. Rich.) Rob. Maori names: Manono, papauma Coprosma robusta Raoul Maori name; Karamu (name applied to any large-leaved Coprosma Coprosma acerosa A. Cunn. Maori names: Tarakupenga, tataraheke, tatarahake (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,86)

[Maoris used] as slightly alterative, a decoction of the bark and stems of the pikiarero (Clematis hexasepala), and the root of the tataraheke (Coprosma acerosa) (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,16) [NOTES: 1869 Colenso TrNZI 1/1/58 (On the Botany of the North Island) in 1981 Brooker et al. NZ Medicinal Plants 16]

tataramoa¶

n. (bush-) lawyer, taramoa, New Zealand bramble

KEENE tataramoa or taramoa: climbing bramble of the bush known as 'bush lawyer'. (1963,O Te Raki,194)

The kohia (Passiflora tetrandra) is very abundant, ... while karioi [supplejack], mangemange, clematis, and tataramoa twine and intertwine as they unite tree to tree. (1889,TrNZI,21/37)

DIEFFENBACH ... the primeval forest was often almost impenetrable, on account of the thick creepers, and the thorns, tataramoa (rubus), of which several species are to be found, and which tore our hands and faces severely. Ibid. ) 2/386 Tataramoa - thorns, blackberry (1843,Travels in NZ,1/143)

TAYLOR I also noticed a curious kind of rasp the Tataramoa [fn This is the only thorn in New Zealand.] which has a singular looking leaf ... (Apr 13, 1839,Journal,2/100)

HOOKER Rubus australis, Forst. ... Nat. name, `Tataramoa', Cunn. (1853,Flora NZ,II Flora Novae-Zelandiae I Flowering Plants 53)

HOOKER Rubus australis, Forst. ... Nat. name, `Tataramoa', Cunn. (1853,Flora NZ,II Flora Novae-Zelandiae I Flowering Plants 53)

ANGAS Dr. Bennett says, I accompanied a native to a place where I could see the tree-ferns growing. After passing through a dense forest, annoyed by thetataramoa,' or New Zealand bramble, and stumbling over the lianas, or supple-jacks, which trailed upon the ground, we descended a hill covered with exuberant vegetation, and shaded by enormous trees; ... (1866,Polynesia,47)

HOOKER Tataramoa, Col[enso]. Rubus australis. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

LINDSAY In this condition [Rubus australis, Forst.] forms one of the most ... troublesome Lawyers,' orSupple-Jacks,' of the forest. It is known to the settler also as the Wild Irishman,' and to the North Island Maori asTataramoa'. [fn] A term defined by Dieffenbach as `Thorns, Blackberry,' - a description at least partly applicable, and with greater propriety, to Discaria Toumatou. (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,54)

... the fruit of the Tutu-papa (Coriaria thymifolia); of the New Zealand Bramble, Tataramoa, (Rubus australis);... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/31) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

Tataramoa. Rubus australis, Forst. varieties (1869,TrNZI,1/III/41) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Rubus australis Tataramoa (1870,TrNZI,2/123) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

BULLER I have sometimes found its crop distended with the ripe pulpy seed of the tataramoa (Rubus australis), or with the berries of the kaiwiria (Parsonia albiflora) [?Parsonsia] [and kareao (Rhipogonum scandens); and it is said to feed also on the leaves of the thistle and wild cabbage. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,154,{1888 2nd edn 1/3} ed.)

PYKE NOTE. - As I have no desire to mystify readers unacquainted with New Zealand flora, I append a brief description of the shrubs mentioned:- Kowhai - A papilonaceous flowering tree, of the acacia tribe. [17] Bush-lawyer - Native name, Tataramoa - A disagreeable bramble, very tenacious of grasp. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,1/iii/16,1974 ed.)

HAY The Tataramoa ... is equally well-known under the designation of `bush-lawyer'. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/201)

FEATON RUBUS AUSTRALIS (Forst.) ... The NATIVE BRAMBLE'.- ... [120] The Maori name of the plant isTataramoa', whilst the settlers designate it as the Native bramble', orBush lawyer'. Ibid. 178 Tataramoa [Maori name] .. Bramble [Settlers' name] .. Rubus Australis .. Shrub (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,119)

I found his crop gorged with the berries of the tataramoa bramble (Rubus australis), ... (1897,TrNZI,29/194) [NOTES: (Buller)]

SATCHELL Supplejack vines, and the saws / And spines of tatara-moa. (1900,Patriotic Rhymes,37)

CHEESEMAN R[ubus] australis, Forst. ... Tataramoa; Bush-lawyer. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,125)

LAING & BLACKWELL The native name, Tataramoa, signifies a heap of prickles. The Maoris have also bestowed this name upon the English furze, and upon brambles generally. (1907,Plants of NZ,196,1940 p. 205 ed.)

BAUGHAN Over the noble lumber, the Bramble, the envious Tataramoa / Springing up, ... [fn] Bramble: Better known to New Zealanders as `Bush Lawyer'. (1908,Shingle-Short,190)

tatara[a]moa, tara[a]moa, a scrambling bramble (Rubus australis) bush-lawyer, wait-a-bit, both names inspired by the recurved prickles. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/158) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

MARTIN The TATARAMOA or COMMON BUSH LAWYER (Rubus cissoides) is one of several Rubus species ... (1929,Flora NZ,143,1961 ed.)

WILSON Rubus cissoides BUSH LAWYER ... Taataraamoa The commonest and most savagely prickly of the native brambles ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,40)

Rubus Australis (Tataramoa, bush lawyer). (Mar 2, 1917,Ohinemuri Gazette,4)

Its Maori name, tataramoa, is given in Tregear's Maori dictionary as simply "the bramble." (Oct 16, 1922,Evening Post,6)

Amongst the berry-bearing trees were tataramoa, rama-rama, porokaiwhiria, mahoe, titoki, taupata, kohekohe, puriri, karaeo, and miro. (Apr 19, 1934,Evening Post,10)

The leaves of the tataramoa, or bush lawyer vine, can be boiled up to make a pleasant tasting concoction, safe and mild enough even for teething babies. (Feb 2001,Growing Today,26)

I ventured into the bramble, or tataramoa (tatter you more, rather). (Dec 17, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

The Maori name for the prickly "bush lawyer," taramoa, or tataramoa, he learns from Tahiti is "the-cock's-spur plant." (Aug 1, 1893,Timaru Herald,4)

tatare¶

n. (See totara)

tatariki¶

n.

YATE Tatariki - A small brown bird, with a white head, short black beak, black legs, and brown feet with four claws. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),161)

tatata¶

n. a garment

POLACK The smallest garment woven is called the patai[a1-acute], principally worn by females for an inner garment; the korowai differs but little from the former, except in having a deep fringe of knotted flax strings. The tatata[as-acute] is similar in size to the former, having pending from every part, an infinity of small cords six inches long, of no use or ornament; its origin must be ascribed to the arbitrary taste of fashion, (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/177)

tatatarra¶

n. (See totara)

tatau¶

n. a door slab [Williams [omit or include because of Satchell's Greenstone Door]

tatau, sliding slab for closing a door or window in a Maori house: tatau-pounamu (greenstone door), a term for an enduring peace between two tribes. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/158) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

n. a Samoan tattoo [ORIGIN: Samoan]

"We are all aware as Samoans that if a malu or tatau is tattooed without the agreement of the family, its results are fatal," Stanley told the Samoa Observer newspaper. (Dec 6, 2007,NZ Herald,A7)

His legs are as distinctive as any in the game, courtesy of full-length tattoos - Samoan "tatau". "These were formerly done in high chiefs, but restrictions have been loosened and just about anyone can get them. They're to do with manhood, if you're brave enough to get them"... (May 7, 2004,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,5)

The first feature outing by Peter Burger and co-written by Black Sheep's Jonathan King .. a supernatural thriller about an American tattoo artist (Jason Behr) who unwittingly unleashes an evil spirit when he dabbles in the Samoan art of tatau. (Jul 12, 2007,Time Out,5)

tatere¶

n.

TAYLOR I went to see the fish which is called the Tatera its skin is rough like the shark ... 8 feet long ... 6 gills [sketch with caption] The Tatera or ururoa or Tuatini. 8 ft. long. (Nov 28, 1844,Journal,3/41)

tats¶

n. teeth

  • when swift as a flash, she swished a stinging left hook on to his chin and - presto - his whole set of upper front `tats' fell into his long beer! (Jul 28, 1906,NZ Truth,58/1/5)

Tattersall's¶

n. an Australian lottery, popular in NZ because it offered better prizes than the local lottery

HUNT When I did she told me ... that she didn't think she would invest in any of my tickets', as her brother had frequently taken tickets inTattersall's' and had never got anything for his money. (1951,Confessions,67)

Still, I could see they wanted someone outside themselves to believe in rainbows and trout and pots of gold and that Southland would win the Ranfurly Shield ... and Dad would win on his ticket to Tattersalls and take us all home to Galway where he'd come from. (Aug 29, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46) [NOTES: Davin]

He died at the age of 58, universally lamented by a large circle of sporting men, who frequented his "Minor Tattersall's." (Oct 14, 1843,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

It was settling day at Tattersall's, and Palmer could not show. (Sep 5, 1856,Daily Southern Cross,3)

Most of our readers will remember the well known Tattersall's Corner, where so much betting is, in the season, transacted. (Feb 18, 1864,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

n.

Here is the famous "marble bar" built out of the unclaimed funds of Tattersall's. (Sep 1, 1904,NZ Observer,5)

Formerly, the method used was for Tattersall's to post tickets direct to the customer from Hobart. (Jan 21, 1953,NZ Truth,5)

adj.

4 In Tattersall's Horse Bazaar at the annual Grand National sale in Christchurch of trotting and thoroughbred stock, a black mare changed hands twice within the hour. (Aug 23, 1940,Taranaki Herald)

Tattersall's sweep¶

n.

Two Christchurch residents, Parish, a milkman, and Pierce, barman at the Oxford Hotel drew Glenloth in Tattersalls sweep, the monster cash prize consultation on the Melbourne Cup and they divide about GBP9000. (Nov 2, 1892,Bay of Plenty Times,2)

At the Police court to-day, Joseph Isaacs, tobacconist, was charged on four informations with breaches of the Gaming Act by disposing of tickets in Tattersall's sweeps. (Nov 26, 1913,Evening Post,8)

tattoo¶

v. [also tatu]

"It is generally supposed Te Kooti has Ririrangi tattooed up in his breast; but this is quite wrong, as cer[t]ified by those who have known him from childhood up to the fall of ngatapa, and whose information is of the most reliable kind. (Oct 14, 1869,West Coast Times,3)

n. . [aka tatu, tatto; derived from Polynesian dialects, was introduced to general English after the publication of Cook's Voyages (so Morris), and used by English speakers in New Zealand as the usual word for (applying) the Maori moko n `tattooing (on face or body)'] (See moko)

Both sexes paint their bodys. Tattow as it is called in their language. [check context and reference: ??Maori] (Jul 1769,Cook's Journals,1/125,1955 ed.)

... in each of the Canoes were two or three Cheifs [sic] and the habits of these were superior to any we had yet seen, the Cloth they were made on was of the best sort and cover'd on the out side with Dog skins put on in such a manner as to look agreeable to the Eye. Few of these people were tattow'd or mark'd in the face like those we have seen farther to the south, but several had their Backsides tattou'd much in the same manner as the Inhabitants of the Islands within the Tropics. (Nov 1769,Cook's Journals,1/213)

They have a custom of staining their bodies ... which they call <i>Tattowing</i>. They prick the skin, so as just not to fetch blood, with a small instrument, something in the form of a hoe. ... <i>(1773,Hawkesworth's Voyages,2/191</i>) [NOTES: >1773.Hawkesworth's Voyages' (Cook's First Voyage; at Tahiti, 1769), vol. ii. p. 191:]

LEDYARD They are very curiuosly tatowed or punctuated in different parts of the body, particularly in the face. The food of the New-Zealanders is chiefly fish, ... (Feb 1777,Journal) [NOTES: 1777 Feb in 1783 Ledyard Journal (1963) 14]

FORSTER ... the custom of tattowing the faces in spirals and Various scrolls, which prevails in New-Zeeland .... (1778,Observations Made During a Voyage,271)

MARSDEN The chisel was constantly dipped in a [172] liquid made of soot from a particular tree, and afterwards mixed with water, which communicates the blackness or, as they call it, the amoko (moko). I observed proud flesh rising in some part of the breech which had been cut almost one month before. The operation is too painful to bear the whole tattooing at one time. They appear to be several years before they are perfectly tattooed. (1819,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,171,1932 ed.)

McCRAE ... as a gratifying memorial of his victory, [he] had got his nose tattooed afresh. (1820,Journal,19,1928 ed.)

tattoo - em|ook [e moko] (1835,Boultbee Journal,111,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 111 also in Begg 1979/283]

CRAIK The term tattoo is not known in New Zealand. (1830,New Zealanders, The,47) [NOTES: [Rutherford's account:]]

McNAB In Witness whereof I have this day set my hand and Seal in my Tatto likeness Opposite. Middle Island or Tavai Poenammoo. (1913,Old Whaling Days,90) [NOTES: 1832 Nov 9 Deed in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 90]

HODGSKIN They were much tattooed about the face; ... (1841,Narrative of Eight Months Sojourn in NZ, A,8)

All [women] are tattooed that are tap-a-tap or married. (1843,Letters from Settlers,74) [NOTES: 1842 Thomas Bremner in 1843 Letters from Settlers 74]

WAKEFIELD A very famous artist in tatu came with the party. (1845,Adventure in NZ,2/109)

MORRIS ... and to mark the human body with indelible pigments. The word is Polynesian; its first occurrence in English is in Cook's account of Tahiti. The Tahitian word is Tatau which means tattoo marks on the human skin, from Ta, which means a mark or design. (Littre.) The Maori verb, ta, means to cut, to tattoo, to strike. See Moko. (1898,Austral English,461)

TATTOO BETRAYED HIM. A native named Mohi Te Kati was arrested at daylight at Petane Pah in August 1884 ... The prisoner was discovered through his having his name tattooed [sic] on his breast. (Feb 18, 1886,Grey River Argus,2)

1 v. (Rural) to brand or ear-mark cattle or dairy cows.

I've got 180 samples in this shed waiting to be tested and 16 meters to scrub and pack as well as 30 calves to tattoo. (Jun 1977,NZ Dairy Exporter,38)

tattooed¶

adj. [aka tatued]

WILLIAMS I well remember many a hard fought battle with these same tatued countenances (Nov 2, 1834,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,399,1961 ed.)

tattooing¶

n.

ELDER The face had been oiled in order to make the marks of the tattooing clear. (Jul 23, 1815,Marsden's Lieutenants,87,1934 ed.)

MARSDEN The chisel was constantly dipped in a [172] liquid made of soot from a particular tree, and afterwards mixed with water, which communicates the blackness or, as they call it, the amoko (moko). I observed proud flesh rising in some part of the breech which had been cut almost one month before. The operation is too painful to bear the whole tattooing at one time. They appear to be several years before they are perfectly tattooed. (1819,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,171,1932 ed.)

Another interesting specimen of Maori art is an elaborately-carved feeding tube. This article was once used to convey liquid nourishment to persons undergoing the tattooing process, who were therefore in a very tapu condition, and debarred from handling food. (May 4, 1910,Wanganui Chronicle,4)

That the art of tattooing was a comparatively recent development among the Maoris was pointed out by Mr. R. F. Way, who gave an address on "Maori Moko, or Tattooing," to the Auckland Society of Arts, states the "Auckland Star." (Sep 22, 1931,Evening Post,6)

"Moko or Maori Tattooing." By Major-General Robley. 1896. 95s. (Mar 10, 1928,Evening Post,21)

"I love," followed by a name, is so common a form of tattooing that the record of it fills several pages. (Dec 26, 1895,Otago Witness,51)

Moko is the art of latter-day tattooing amongst the Maori. The older style was called Mokokuri, and was practised by the demigod Mani, who used to tattoo the muzzle of a dog - whence dogs went with black muzzles as we see them now. (Nov 26, 1896,Otago Witness,3)

tattooing adze¶

n.

... they fell to pieces on being touched, as did most of the bone articles - ... excepting the uhis or tattooing adzes ... (1903,TrNZI,32/240)

Tatts¶

n. Tattersall's lottery [aka Tatt's; incl attrib]

It did not require a tram ticket of an obsolete 31,456 in a Tatt's sweep to win admission. (Jul 12, 1911,Evening Post,3)

A man who was working on the new Strand Arcade in.. Auckland, won GBP5000 on "Tatts" the other day. (Nov 12, 1910,NZ Free Lance,13)

The Government says it is wrong to send a little bit over to Tatt's. (Feb 11, 1920,NZ Free Lance,7)

[Hdg] A Ticket in Tatt.'s... This Government clerk was acting in Government time as agent for Tattersall's (Jun 3, 1916,Dominion,14)

[Caption] Thou shalt not, on the pain of death, buy a ticket in 'Tatts'. (Jun 9, 1912,NZ Free Lance,1)

JACKSON When he failed ... to win Tatts or the Art Union, he took it as a personal slight ... (1988,Rainshadow,105)

Every member ... will have the option of keeping a pub.' or running aTatts' agency. (Jul 1, 1918,Quick March,10)

... I can't afford to ... shut up the little tabaccory and barbery because this is the flush season for my little `Tatts' business (on the side). (Nov 1, 1918,Quick March,19)

... I was a tobacconist ... with a side-line in `Tatt's'. (Jan 10, 1922,Quick March,17)

HYDE We struck a ticket in Tatt's, and we won't be needing it sc money]. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,339)

HYDE We struck a ticket in Tatt's, and we won't be needing it sc money]. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,339)

HISLOP We were soon on the way again [after a lucky escape from accident], and on arrival at Queenstown the few locals ... came round advising me to take a ticket in `Tatts'. (1943,Pure Gold,54)

PARK You're so lucky you ought to buy a ticket in Tatts. (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,160)

Heights of `pretty good' are reached only ... rarely by the backers of 16-16 outsiders and Tatts winners. (Sep 1952,Here & Now,15)

Heights of `pretty good' are reached only ... rarely by the backers of 16-16 outsiders and Tatts winners. (Sep 1952,Here & Now,15)

SLATTER ... see you in Tatts after the war the blokes used to say and I'll shout you a beer ... (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,26)

HILLIARD Was there any show of his busting out of it? None that he could see - unless he struck Tatts or a good double at the races, enough to get a stake to start himself. (1960,Maori Girl,238)

McLAGLAN I gave them enough money to buy a ticket in Tatts which seemed to please them. (1965,Stethoscope & Saddlebags,165)

SARGESON ... perhaps his share in some winning Tatts ticket, ... (1965,Memoirs of a Peon,197)

I. DAVEY (Whangarei) The Turner index refers to TATTS. Why not UNCLE T? That is - or was - common when Uncle T was illegal in NZ. (Jul 29, 1966,Letter)

Tatts n. shortened form of Tattersall's formerly Tasmanian, now a Victorian lottery. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

TURNER The Golden Kiwi established partly to prevent sent money being sent out of New Zealand for tickets in Tatt's, a Tasmanian lottery with a name abbreviated from Tattersall's and quite unconnected with the English cant word tatts dice'. It was illegal to sell tickets in Tatts' in New Zealand but many barbers' shops displayed a notice,We communicate with Hobart', which was universally understood. . . .It was clear that in the context of a barber's shop window the notice meant we sell tickets in Tatt's', but legally a man can announce that he writes to Tasmania. Newspapers might report the good fortune of winners but the illegal source of the winnings would not be specified. The money came froman overseas consultation'. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,175)

Tatt's ... n. shortened form of Tattersall's, formerly Tasmanian, now a Victorian lottery. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

RICHARDS Before leaving Raglan my mother had purchased a Tatt's lottery ticket. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,25)

Porridge in New Zealand is horribly legal and Tatts delightfully illegal. (Jun 14, 1923,Aussie (NZ Section),XVI)

[Hdg] Tickets in "Tatts"... This clerk was acting in Government time as agent for "Tatts." (Jun 3, 1916,Press, The,8)

My plans would require the winning of the Irish Sweepstake as well as "Tatts". (Apr 2, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,99)

He whispers low to me at Tatt's, / All among the noisy Babel, / Jack won't speel, but Envious will, / Is the straight tip from the stable. (Dec 22, 1883,Observer (Auckland),6)

It is quite true that Tatt's. prize of GBP1800 in the Sydney Cup came to Dunedin. (May 6, 1897,Otago Witness,33)

Tatt's was known throughout the length and breadth of the land, and many are the stories told of persons unexpectedly lifted from penury to affluence by a lucky ticket in one of the big consultations. (Jan 22, 1908,Tuapeka Times,3)

If you can call the risking of 5s once or twice a year in a sweep gambling, then such moderate gambling gives us a distinct pleasure in life, and makes us more cheerfully bear the burdens which fate has fitted to our backs, for a ticket in 'Tatt's' gives us a scent of that one Flower of Eden over which the trail of the serpent is not - Hope! (Jul 24, 1901,Otago Witness,51)

At Ashburton they arrested a man for drunkenness and finding three tickets in "Tatts" in his pocket, charged him with purchasing the tickets, and he was fined 20/-. (Dec 24, 1924,Christchurch Star,6)

Sandy's expression could not have been more pleasing if he had won a Tatt's prize. (Jul 25, 1925,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,60)

n.

Tatts ticket¶

n. [aka Tatt's ticket]

SMITH Between [Australia and NZ] there is one of the roughest seas in the world but that has never stopped us importing Cabinet Ministers and Tatt's tickets. (1947,From N to Z,17)

A great deal of fuss is made over a Tatts ticket and the sale of such gambling chances, but when it comes to joint stock company swindles, nothing is done to protect the public. (Oct 22, 1921,NZ Truth,4)

Should Poneke win this competition, the members ought to buy a "Tatt's" ticket apiece. (Aug 5, 1911,NZ Truth,3)

Weekly investment in a Tatt's ticket is a recognised practice among thousands of New Zealanders, denied the right to speculate in a similar lottery with such substantial prizes in this country. (Jan 21, 1953,NZ Truth,5)

Better than a "Tatts" ticket. (Jan 18, 1918,Grey River Argus,2)

tatua¶

n.

Last year all the senior girls made ketes and tatuas. (Sep 21, 1927,NZ Tablet,39)

These will make the tatua or belt for the loin cloth worn by the men. (Feb 1998,Mana,No. 20: 21)

It's a look he seldom varies, except when he looses his hair, puts on tipare (headband), piupiu (flax skirt) and tatua (ceremonial sash) to lead Manutake in haka. (Dec 2004,North & South,64)

tau inu¶

n. (See tauhinu)

tau tau¶

n.

JOSEPH The jade, the pounamu ... It's a beautiful stone ... Look,' he said, holding up a long hooked ear-drop of pearly translucence,that's tau tau and the stone is called inanga. And this, the pekapeka - they say the shape comes from the bat. This is for the ear, too - the mako, like a shark's tooth ... And these,' - he ran his fingers along a row of ... nephrite adzes - toki. See this one' - he held the heavy red-mottled adze in his palm -that's the red kind, totoweka, woodhen's blood. The deep green, that's kawakawa.' (1962,Pound of Saffron, A,113)

taua¶

n. war party [(Frequent in early North Island missionary journals and letters, and among those living among or dealing with Maoris. It is perhaps part of early missionary English (?jargon).) [check discards]]

ELDER The tear (taua) departed from hence on the 25th. The whole consisted of about thirty canoes and eight hundred men. (Feb 20, 1817,Marsden's Lieutenants,135,1934 ed.) [NOTES: 1817 Feb 20 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 135]

ELDER The tear (taua) departed from hence on the 25th. The whole consisted of about thirty canoes and eight hundred men. (Feb 20, 1817,Marsden's Lieutenants,135,1934 ed.) [NOTES: 1817 Feb 20 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 135]

CAMPBELL Then he called in as ally the wily Waikato chief ... with a taua of two hundred warriors, promising them all the kuki (slaves) taken and all the booty they could carry away. (1955,By Reef and Range,15)

H WILLIAMS ... and war parties immediately assembled for revenge. Henry Williams ... went with the taua, and by his intervention peace was made. (1961,Journal,20) [NOTES: 1961 Rogers (editor's introduction) Journ. H. Williams 20]

KEENE taua: war party (1963,O Te Raki,194)

McLINTOCK3/52 In September 1819 a Ngapuki taua (war party) who had recently acquired muskets ... passed through Kauhia ... . (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An)

McLINTOCK3/52 In September 1819 a Ngapuki taua (war party) who had recently acquired muskets ... passed through Kauhia ... . (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An)

BRAITHWAITE TAUA War party. (1967,Evil Day,381)

BELICH taua war party (1986,NZ Wars, The,337)

I heard afterwards that they had just returned from a taua, or a rubbing excursion, into the country of the Waikato; with whom the tribe of Roto-rua is in constant hostility. (Mar 30, 1844,Daily Southern Cross,4)

Just before dawn one morning, the sleeping kainga was aroused by the yells of a band of armed men, a small roving taua of the Ngati-Tuwharetoa tribe from the distant Taupo country. (Jul 2, 1910,Evening Post,10)

With a taua (war party) bristling on the edge of the town, it was a moment of bloody racial tension that spilled briefly into war. (Dec 14, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),41)

Yet she refers to some of these taua (war expeditions) as "Hika's army". (Oct 18, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),60)

The greater portion of his taua was retained here as a reserve, and he madly set out to attack the thickly populated district of Waikato, with about three hundred men. (Jul 27, 1855,Daily Southern Cross,1)

At this juncture, the AFC took up the pursuit, as did a Tuhoe taua, both parties separately skirmishing with the Ringatu in October. (Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

The Omuturangi taua rode up shortly after, had a friendly meeting, camped for the night, and rode off next morning, having received a present of two horses and a calf, which quite satisfied the Omuturangi relatives of the parties concerned. (Sep 5, 1872,Daily Southern Cross,3)

LEE & KENDALL Taua, s. A meeting, an army, a battle, ... (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,209)

WILLIAMS At 9 o'clock Tohiapu with the Taua came round the point. (Apr 21, 1829,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,153,1961 ed.)

MARKHAM ... some Chiefs were going to get payment for the Coco again ... or they would bring a Tower [taua] `for[c]ible seizure' ... [fn] Tower a foray for an Insult or Injury. E.M. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),53,1963 ed.)

POLACK [An envoy arrived] ... to advise the old chief to hasten with the building of his fortification, as the tribe of whom both parties were apprehensive had given Terarau ... intimation they would make a tawa [a's-acute], or war, against Kaka [a1-acute], while his pa [a-acute] was defenceless. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/129)

TAYLOR (1839,Te Ika a Maui,2/129)

BIDWIL;L They so strongly dissuaded me from going that I waited for several days, but as there was no further sign of the `Tower' I began to get impatient, and at last made up my mind to set off and run the risk of meeting them. (1841,Rambles in NZ,98,1952 ed.)

TAYLOR This morning George King came running to me saying that the Taua had come over this side and was digging up Mawai's potatoes. (Jan 13, 1845,Journal,3/59)

SELWYN At Whanganui I found a `taua' or fighting party of 170 natives headed by Te Heu Heu ... (1845,Letter) [NOTES: 1845 Selwyn Letter in 1847 NZ Part IV (The Church in the Colonies XII) 7]

McKILLOP ... a sufficient excuse for making what the natives call a tower on their property (which means, coming in such numbers as to defy resistance), and seizing everything on the premises, ... [65] He once made a tower or rush at me with his tomahawk, ... (1849,Reminiscences,41)

POWER The Governor ... commenced the operations ... which ended in the capture of Te Rauperaha, in baffling the taua from Wanganui, ... and thus laying the foundation of the present prosperity. (1849,Sketches in NZ,xvlvii)

SHORTLAND Speaking of their `taua' or military force, which went out to fight in olden times, they will tell you that it was ... a great many. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,52)

Thompson, unable to carry his point with the taua, it is believed will return to Waikato (Apr 13, 1861,Otago Witness,6)

MANING Altogether this taua is better armed and equipped than ordinary; ... (1863,Old New Zealand,47) [NOTES: see also p. 42]

2/117 Got a little consolation from Matiu te Huia, who declares that the supposed taua (or war party) is really a heke (or migration) of women & children ... (1864,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1960) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

HUNT Then put them under the mat or the taua will take them: ... I really felt for the poor fellow, and promised to taua with the best in his behalf. (1866,Chatham Islands,48)

TAYLOR The tauas, or war parties, rapidly decreased [with the advent of Christianity] in number, and those chiefs who could before muster a force of five or six hundred men, were afterwards satisfied with two hundred, and thus from the want of followers their contests gradually ceased, and with them their horrid feasts. Ibid. 272 A few weeks only elapsed before a taua arrived to revenge their deaths. (1868,Past and Present of NZ,11)

DOMETT Give up our wars - war-dances - tauas - taboo,/ Whence all our wealth, and power, and fame accrue,/ (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/140)

MARTIN Only a few months, however, before our visit to the Waimate, a taua,' i.e., a fighting-party, had come to the Bishop's house to demandutu' (payment) for a trespass. (1884,Our Maoris,37)

BAUGHAN The host of your taua, address'd as to fight! [fn3] Taua (tah[a acute]-wah): A warrior band. (1908,Shingle-Short,54)

GUTHRIE-SMITH To rehabilitate the mana of Popoia two tauas or war-parties were sent forth from Mohaka. (1926,Tutira,69)

LAMBERT ... a strong taua (war-party) was being organized ... (1936,Pioneering Reminiscences of Old Wairoa,149)

COWAN In December, 1844, a taua or war-party of the Taupo tribe ... descended the Wanganui River ... (1940,Sir Donald Maclean,12)

taua, war-party: ta[a]ua and taua[a] have quite different meanings. The three words look much the same, but th different. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/158) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

WAR PARTY. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

taua muru¶

n.

BELICH taua muru customary plundering expedition, exacting compensation for an offence, in which blood is seldom shed (1986,NZ Wars, The,337)

tauhau¶

n. (See tauhou)

tauhino¶

n. (See tauhinu)

The Maori name for a shrub, cassinia, which spreads rapidly as a weed in parts of New Zealand. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),406)

tauhinu¶

n. [tawini, tawhina]

n. a small shrub, the New Zealand cottonwood. [Maori] [Tawini, tawhine, tawhina, et al; the main application in NZ English is to the Cassinia sp., a troublesome weed of central New Zealand. Its eradication generates word-combinations: tauhinu-contract, tauhinu-pulling, tauhinu-rash, to pull tauhinu. =yellow scrub (?Golden tauhinu)]

LEE & KENDALL Tau |inu; A shrub so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,210)

DILLON There are no trees except for the banks of the river which has little woods which the settlers call bushes but which I think you will understand better by the name of Tawhitti as they have no trees but large and high shrub. (1844,Papers,61) [NOTES: [?Marlborough]]

... tauwhinau ... (1874,Ena, or the Ancient Maori,WILSON,286 ed.)

Tauhinu (Cassinia retorta) seeds very freely and is apt to spread. (1876,TrNZI,205)

CRAWFORD [In the Marlborough Sounds] after ... trees have been felled, fire will go through the forest and a scanty pasture be produced ... until the shrub called tauwhinu take possession and smother the pasture. (1880,Travels in NZ,263)

CRAWFORD [In the Marlborough Sounds] after ... trees have been felled, fire will go through the forest and a scanty pasture be produced ... until the shrub called tauwhinu take possession and smother the pasture. (1880,Travels in NZ,263)

BULLER This bird [Pukeko] often leaves its home ... to travel ... amongst the tauhinu bushes in quest of grasshoppers. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/82)

... resinous Tawhina (1900,NZ Illustrated Magazine,354)

In the portion of Marlborough north of the Wairau River care is necessary to prevent the land ... being overrun with brambles, briars, St. John's wort, manuka, tawhinau ... (1901,TrNZI,33/327)

BAUGHAN Clear'd I have, and I've clear'd an' clear'd. / Yet everywhere, slap in your face, / Briar, tauhinu and ruin .... (1903,Reuben & Other Poems,88)

ALEXANDER & CURRIE Tauhinu: an aromatic shrub infesting poor soil. (1906,Treasury of NZ Verse,289)

DEVANNY [?Nelson, ?West Coast] ... tarwinie (1926,Old Savage,47)

HILGENDORF Tauhinu (Cassinia leptophylla, C. vauvilliersii, etc.), commonly pronounced Tawhini, and also called yellow scrub; grows as a woody shrub, 3 to 4 ft. high with yellow leaves and white flowers. It is a native, and commonest on poor clay soils ... (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,212)

STUDHOLME ... dense thickets of manuka and other scrub, including [247] tawhini, ... (1940,Te Waimate,246) [NOTES: [spg tawhini]]

(1944,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),406)

[The Nelson farmer] called it tawhine, not tauhinu, and I've never heard a farmer call it anything else. (Dec 26, 1947,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12) [NOTES: (Sundowner)]

LEVY Gorse, blackberry, bracken fern, hard fern, manuka, cottonwood, mauhinu, and other scrub growths are neglected on the hills, ... (1951,Grasslands of NZ,293,1950 ed.)

MACFARLANE There is bidi bidi, a native messing up the wool, ... ; tarweni, a shrub covering light land that is inclined to be sour. This plant is supposed to have arrived from South America eighty or ninety years ago; ... (1954,Te Raka,41) [NOTES: [spg tarweni]]

DUFF (1955,New Zealand Now,92)

tauhinau The river forced us to do much sidling through the tauhinau and matagouri and across a limestone face ... (Sep 1958,Tararua,76)

HILGENDORF & CAL;DER TAUHINU (Cassinia leptophylla, C. vauvilliersii and also Senecio cassinioides) The cassinias have yellowish leaves and are therefore often called yellow scrub. ... All grow as rounded woody shrubs 3 or 4 feet high. (1967,Weeds of New Zealand,225)

tauhinu [=] golden tauhinu mountain tauhinu: whatitiri [s] ... tauhinu [s] Cassinia leptophylla (Forst.f.) R.Br. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,77)

McLEOD ...the sweet-scented Cassinia or tauhinau, generally known as `Tawini'; (1970,Glorious Morning,108)

McLEOD ...the sweet-scented Cassinia or tauhinau, generally known as `Tawini'; (1970,Glorious Morning,108)

McCARTHY There were only four of us ... to cut 100 acres of scrub, tauhine and ti-tree (manuka). (1973,Listen...!,35)

NEWTON . . . once the early fertility went the [D'urville Island] country was invaded with tauhine _ Ibid 44 This was of course before the tawhine (or tauhinu) became such a problem. (1873,Big Country,36,1977 ed.)

MOORE & IRWIN CASSINIA LEPTOPHYLLA. Cassinia is a genus of Australasian and South African shrubs. The five New Zealand species, known as cottonwoods'ortauhinu'... The grey-leaved C. leptophylla so invaded neglected hill pastures (as about Wellington) that it, along with the golden tauhinu C. fulvida, was designated a`scheduled noxious weed'. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,138)

TAYLOR TAUHINU (Cassinia spp.) ... A native plant locally common east of the main ranges from Wairoa to Central Otago, and perhaps most abundant about Wellington and Marlborough Sounds. (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,145)

HUNT Gather round you chaps and I'll tell you a yarn/ When we pulled tawhina, down on Harris's farm. (1985,I'm Ninety-five,36) [NOTES: (Bill Henderson)]

RICHARDS [spg tawhine] The farm was poor and only partially improved, the majority being in its original state of scrubby tea tree and tawhine. Ibid.145 [spg tawhini] We dug fox-holes along the ridges ... at the edge of the windswept manuka and tawhini ... (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,64)

tauhinu n. densely-growing NZ shrub with white daisy-like flowers. Pop. called tawhine. Ibid. 788tawhine see TAUHINU. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,787) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

She ... helped him stalk ...a stray wild pig through the manuka and tawhina scrub. (1987,Happy Endings,110) [NOTES: 1902 Lancaster Our Lady of the Plains in 1987 Happy Endings 110]

WILSON Thistles and rushes, docks and tawini scrub, grew in the empty paddocks. (1984,South Pacific Street,8)

HOOKER Tauhinu, Col[enso]. Pomaderris ericifolia. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

FEATON POMADERRIS PHYLICIFOLIA (TODD.) ... The `Tauhinu'.- This small heath-like shrub is peculiar to the Northern Island, and grows abundantly in certain localities on dry fern hills. Ibid. 178 Tauhinu [Maori name] .. Tauhinu [Settlers' name] .. Pomaderris phylicifolia .. Shrub (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,91)

CHEESEMAN [Pomaderris phylicaefolia, Lodd.] North Cape to Otaki and Cape Palliser. Tauhinu. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,101)

CHEESEMAN [Pomaderris phylicaefolia, Lodd.] North Cape to Otaki and Cape Palliser. Tauhinu. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,101)

LAING & BLACKWELL Pomaderris phylicaefolia (The Phylica-leaved Pomaderris). A strongly scented, health-like shrub, which grows profusely amongst the small tea-tree, upon gum-lands. ... Maori name Tauhinu. [fn] This name is also applied to Cassinia leptophylla. (1907,Plants of NZ,238,1940, p. 251 ed.)

LAING & BLACKWELL Pomaderris phylicaefolia (The Phylica-leaved Pomaderris). A strongly scented, health-like shrub, which grows profusely amongst the small tea-tree, upon gum-lands. ... Maori name Tauhinu. [fn] This name is also applied to Cassinia leptophylla. (1907,Plants of NZ,238,1940, p. 251 ed.)

tauhinu, a troublesome scrub (Pomaderris Phylicaefolia), densely growing and persistently regenerating. C. leptophylla is tauhinu-korokia or tauhinu-koromiko, but these names are not in general use as is tauhinu, or tawhini as some miscall it. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/158) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

HOOKER Tauhinu, Geolog. Surv. Podocarpus nivalis. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768) [NOTES: Podocarpus nivalis]

Australian tauhinu [s] Cassinia arctuata R. Br. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,3)

LEVY Golden tauhinu - Cassinia fulvida. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,Appendix II 355,1970 ed.)

MOORE & IRWIN CASSINIA LEPTOPHYLLA. Cassinia is a genus of Australasian and South African shrubs. The five New Zealand species, known as cottonwoods'ortauhinu', ... The grey-leaved C. leptophylla so invaded neglected hill pastures (as about Wellington) that it, along with the golden tauhinu C. fulvida, was designated a`scheduled noxious weed'. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,138)

mountain tauhinu [s] Cassinia vauvilliersii (Homb. & Jacq.) Hook.f. Ibid. 77 tauhinu, mountain [s] Cassinia vauvilliersii (Homb. & Jacq.) Hook.f. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,50)

silvery tauhinu [=] tauhinu [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,70)

C HEESEMAN C[assinia] leptophylla, R.Br. ... Tauhinu-korokio; Cottonwood. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,345)

On the Spread of Cassinia leptophylla. By W.T.L. Travers... Most persons ... visiting the Miramar Peninsula ... will have noticed the increase ... of an indigenous shrub commonly known by its native name as the Taiwhenu, or sea mat-cord, but known to botanists as Cassinia leptophylla. (1874,TrNZI,6/248)

Rhamnaceae Pomaderris phylicifolia var.ericifolia tauhinu (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: (Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri)]

DAVIES Well, we'd better get a bite to eat now, and then pull some tawhini; that's what the Boss said to do. (1975,Outback,59) [NOTES: spg tawhini]

STUDHOLME ... dense thickets of manuka and other scrub, including [247] tawhini, . (1940,Te Waimate,246)

KEENE tauhinu: shrub. (1963,O Te Raki,194)

Pomaderris phylicaefolia (Tauhinu): Abundant in open undulating country. (Feb 28, 1917,Ohinemuri Gazette,4)

The Committee of the House to consider questions pertaining to noxious weeds, gorse, briars, &c., was set up yesterday, and, at the instance of Dr. Newman, ti-tree and tauhinu (cotton bush) were added to the pests to come under the committee's review. (Jul 22, 1891,Evening Post,2)

The following interesting list of the native and botatical names of a number of indigenous trees and shrubs has been prepared by Mr H. Graham, of the Brunner railway service, and placed at our disposal for publication .. Tauhinu .. Pomaderris phylicifolia ... (Oct 1, 1896,Otago Witness,8)

n. [Podocarpus nivalis]

4 n.
