golden tauhinu [s] Cassinia fulvida Hook.f. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,29)

4 n.

4 n.

tauhou¶

n. [Maori, stranger: the bird arrived from Australia in the mid-19th century] Zosterops lateralis, silvereye, white-eye, wax-eye, blight bird (See silvereye)

ZOSTEROPS LATERALIS, Lath. Tauhou. Blight-bird. We first noticed this bird ... in the Rockwood Valley, Malvern Hills, July 28th, 1856. ... It very soon obtained the name of Blight-bird ... from its habit of feeding on the American blight, with which apple trees in this colony are so generally infested ... (1870,TrNZI,2/61) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

HUTTON 14. ZOSTEROPS LATERALIS. Lath. White-eye. Wax-eye. Blight-bird. Tauhou. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,6)

BULLER ZOSTEROPS LATERALIS {CAERULESCENS}. (THE SILVER-EYE.) ... Native names. Tau-hou, {Whiorangi, Hiraka, Motingitingi,} Kanohi-mowhiti, Karu-patene, {Karu-ringi,} Karu-hiriwha, Poporohe, and Iringatau. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,{1888 2nd edn 1/77} ed.)

BULLER ZOSTEROPS LATERALIS {CAERULESCENS}. (THE SILVER-EYE.) ... Native names. Tau-hou, {Whiorangi, Hiraka, Motingitingi,} Kanohi-mowhiti, Karu-patene, {Karu-ringi,} Karu-hiriwha, Poporohe, and Iringatau. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,{1888 2nd edn 1/77} ed.)

HAY The Tauhau (Zosterops lateralis) is a beautiful little green bird, much like a wren. ... It is much seen about gardens and clearings, and settlers know it as the `blight-bird'. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/226)

The natives distinguish the bird as Tau-hou (which means stranger), or Kanohi-mowhiti (which may be interpreted as spectacle-eye or ring-eye). It is also called Poporoke and Iringatu, names suggested by its accidental or periodical occurrence. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/81)

LIST OF NAPIER BIRDS. ... Zosterops lateralis. (Blight-bird; tauhou.) ... Himantopus leucocephalus. (Red Stilt.) (1901,TrNZI,33/215)

Coming to our little white-eye, or tauhou, `the stranger', who came from Australia in 1856 ... is now as rare as he was common. (1908,TrNZI,40/489)

tauhou, a wandering bird (Zosterops halmaturina), blight-bird; twinkie; button-eye; wax-eye; ring-eye. Tauhou means stranger and this name was given by the Maori when the bird appeared, in 1856, in the central part of Newzealand, gradually spreading north and south till the islands were occupied. It is an Australian bird, and was blown across the Tasman sea in the year mentioned. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

SILVEREYE, FOREST BIRD. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

FALLA et al. SILVEREYE Zosterops lateralis Other names: Tauhou, Waxeye, White-eye, Blightbird, Blightie. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,223)

263. Zosterops lateralis lateralis (Latham, 1801) Silvereye (Tauhou) Originally Tasmania and Bass Strait islands; the species colonised the South Island ... (before 1856), North Island (1856) ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,69,1980 ed.)

Silvereye Zosterops lateralis lateralis (LATHAM, 1801) ... OTHER NAMES: <White-eye, waxeye, blightbird, tauhou. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,288)

Grub's up: A waxeye, or tautou, feeds on a loquat tree in Greenhithe. (Oct 13, 2005,NZ Herald,A16)

We have a flock of lively tauhou, the white-eye or silver-eye..... pegging away at the scraps in tins hung on a tree for them. (Jul 1937,NZ Railways Magazine,25)

n. [Maori: stranger. This the person, cf bird]

Accordingly, one of my boys being a tauhou (stranger), climbed up and tied an old soldier's coat on it. (Apr 25, 1852,Wellington Independent,3)

tauihi¶

n. prow of a waka

The tauihu, or prow, of a waka was discovered on a farm 15 km northeast of Tauranga 10 days ago. (Feb 27, 1999,Evening Post,2)

tauira¶

n. a student

Students, or tauira, interviewed "were consistently dissatisfied with the lack of learning resources information and reponses by Te Wananaga a Aotearoa to tauira complaints," said the report. (Aug 17, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C5)

tauiwi¶

adj. not Maori, foreign [ORIGIN: Maori]

She asked if she could move to the "tauiwi" group, where she would have a better chance of improving her Maori language skills. (Aug 29, 1998,Dominion,8)

Maori still had to ask Government for financial support for initiatives - but were forced to make them fit tauiwi [foreign] criteria. (Oct 22, 1999,Evening Post,13)

n. outsider, foreigner, non-Maori

Here, after all, was the woman who habitually refers to non-Maori New Zealanders as tau iwi, which, depending on the inflection of translation, means foreigner. (Sep 16, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

Pakeha' is a word that seems to be bugging many New Zealanders. Perhaps this is the reason why the Royal Commission on Social Policy in its booklet dealing with the Treaty of Waitangi uses the wordTauiwi' instead of Pakeha'. For example a section of the booklet is headedPartnership between Maori and Tauiwi'. Tauiwi, according to the booklet's glossary, means later settlers from another country'. A Dictionary of the Maori Language ... givesstrange tribe, foreign race' as the meaning of Tauiwi. As a New Zealander born and bred in this country I was disturbed at the unceremonious use of a word which seems to make me some sort of foreigner in my own land. ... On phoning the commission's office I was informed that despite considerable unease over the use of Tauiwi in the treaty booklet staff were told that it had to be used. I was also informed that the use of Tauiwi instead of Pakeha had been discontinued. (Jun 6, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,11)

Here he was overwhelmed by a distinctly unappreciative din from his fellow indigenes and tau iwi alike. (Aug 4, 2004,Dominion Post,A2)

Just a couple of years back, one of the Prime Minister's colleagues.. insultingly classified non-Maori New Zealanders are [sic] foreigners in their own land by referring to them as "tauiwi". (Jun 4, 2000,Sunday Star Times,A8)

taumaihi¶

n. a small tower

BELICH taumaihi tower, part of pa (1986,NZ Wars, The,337)

taumaka¶

n. rockfish

PHILLIPPS Acanthoclinus quadridactylus TAUMAKA. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,49,1971 ed.)

POWELL ROCKFISH (Acanthoclinus quadridactylus ), Taumaka of the Maoris, is tha small brownish-olive fish, about 7 inches in length, which is found lurking under boulders at low tide. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,72)

GRAHAM ROCKFISH (TAUMAKA) Acanthoclinus quadridactylus (Bloch and Schneider) ... [ibid. 322] Those who do know this fish call it Rockfish, but I prefer the Maori name, Taumaka. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,320)

DOOGUE & MORELAND ROCKFISH ... Other names: Acanthoclinus quadridactylus; rock cod, butterfish; taumaka. (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,283)

MORELAND ROCKFISH [Acanthoclinus quadridactylus ] ... Taumaka, a Maori name, is not widely used. (1967,Marine Fishes,20)

Taumarunui¶

n.

In fact, just one song would be enough to confer immortality on him [sc. Peter Cape]: "Taumarunui (on the main trunk line)", which has passed so soccessfully into the national vernacular that I'd be willing to bet that few know who actually wrote it. (Apr 13, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

taumingi¶

n.

BROOKER et al. Cyathodes juniperina (J.R. & G. Forst.) Druce Maori names: Taumingi, tumingi, mingimingi ... This small-leaved shrub, formerly known as C. acerosa R.Br., is common and variable. (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,51)

taunoka¶

n.

TAYLOR I noticed 2 new varieties of the Taunuka, the New Zealand broom, one was a beautiful leafy bush, the other was leafless and its branches round it was very diminutive ... (Mar 1, 1845,Journal,3/79)

taunuka¶

n. (See taunoka)

taupare¶

n. a figure-head

POLACK1 Over the door-ways and window-sills, handsomely carved boards are fixed, painted in flaming red, these are placed horizontally or in a gable form called maihi, surmounted by a wooden image termed the taupare warre ; some of these figures are exceedingly droll.... [caption] The Maihi, a carved board for the front of a house, surmounted by the Toupare, or figure-head. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/206)

taupata¶

n.

She [sc. Alison Gray] proved the point in a 1981 study, co-authored with Rosemary Barrington, called The Smith Women. This identified our tidy suburban homes, clipped taupata hedges, flower beds in well-cut lawns. (Sep 7, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

JACKSON An arthritic taupata hedge sheltered it from the sea, though from the sunporch - which became my room - you could see the ocean ... (1988,Rainshadow,98)

This summer, as last year, rain was so plentiful in parts of Wellington that taupata berries have swollen up like juicy blueberries. (Mar 8, 2003,Dominion Post,F15)

n. (Environment) a shrub of the coprosma family often used as a hedge plant; Coprosma repens [ORIGIN: Maori, also called plumber's curse. [Ma. taupata coastal shrub (coprosma repens) cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 251.]

HOOKER Taupata, Col[enso]. Coprosma retusa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

TAYLOR The Putiritiri, of the same order [as Karamu, coprosma sp.], is a beautiful tree with a small leaf, and also the Taupata, which having a fine bright leaf is a very ornamental tree ... (1868,Past and Present of NZ,225)

.. the curious red fruit of the Titoki, or Titongi, (Alectryon excelsum); the fruit .. of several species of Coprosma, - particlularly the Karamu (C. lucida), and (C. robusta), of the Papaauma (C. grandifolia), and of the two littoral species, Taupata (C. retusa), and Tataraheke (C. acerosa) ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/31) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

LAING & BLACKWELL C[oprosma retusa] is much used for hedges in Wellington and Melbourne. In the former place it is generally known as taupata (sometimes naupata); in the latter it is called the looking-glass plant. Ibid. 395 Coprosma [retusa] (The Taupata) .. Maori names, Taupata and Naupata. (Coprosma Baueri). [The true C. Baueri is a native of Norfolk Island]. (1907,Plants of NZ,392,1940 p. 420 (p. 423) ed.)

The plant which is dominant and chiefly gives character to these island shrubberies is Coprosma Baueri, commonly known as the taupata. (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,7/185) [NOTES: (Sladden)]

taupata, a tree (Coprosma retusa), with dark green leaves shining as if varnished; much used for hedges, cutting well till in the course of years it grows too woody. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

SINCLAIR [Maori glossary] taupata Tree (Coprosma retusa) (1959,History of New Zealand,302)

HILLIARD And there's the lights on the leaves of the taupata, and on the tutu trees over the creek where the cows can't get at them. (1960,Maori Girl,215)

DURRELL (1966,Two in the Bush,68)

MANTELL There were trees growing thick there - ngaio, taupata, native fuchsia. (1980,Murder and Chips,34)

Between it and the front hedge (taupata) there were eight large trees. (1985,Women's Work,114) [NOTES: (Roche Structurally Sound)]

taupata n. NZ shrub of the coprosma family, widely used for shelter-fences. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,787) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

DAWSON In the North Island particularly, prostrate shrubs of the shiny-leaved taupata (Coprosma repens), known as the `looking glass plant' in California where it is cultivated) are often prominent. (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,155)

LEE & KENDALL T|ao r|eka r|eka, s. A slave. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,207)

Taupata has thick oval-shaped leaves with an almost plastic feel to them .. In the garden, where conditions are less harsh than the beach, the leaves grow broader and flatter, and taupata can be easily grown and pruned to a hedge eight metres tall. (Feb 11, 2006,Dominion Post,20,Indulgence ed.)

We spread our rugs in a spot where a wind-sculpted taupata and clumps of spinifex sheltered our backs from the gusty northerly. (Jan 31, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

The vicar had observed that the taupata needed trimming to clear the harbour view. (Apr 19, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

Taupata (Coprosma repens) is one of the commonest native shrubs in this part of the country, and it seems to evoke a love or hate reaction. (Mar 8, 2003,Dominion Post,F15)

The planting programme has wound down now that the pioneer plants such as ngaio, taupata and korimiko are established. (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 1)

BOXTHORN - Extra fine plants in any quantity, and other hedge plants suitable for Hawera and district, such as Taupata, Olearia of sorts, Escallonia, Euonymus, etc. (May 21, 1903,Hawera & Normanby Star,4)

The City Council generously donated 300 taupata trees for the purpose of planting the school ground. (May 1, 1914,Evening Post,2)

CROWE Like other coprosmas, taupata belongs to the coffee family, a fact that inspired experiments in the late nineteenth century by a Mr J.C. Crawford, who presented a sample of ground coffee made from these seeds to the Wellington Philosophical Society in 1877. 'The beans .. 'he wrote,' when roasted and ground have a splendid coffee aroma and when made into coffee the results seem to be thoroughly satisfactory.' (1995,Which Coastal Plant?,9)

Taupo Pumice¶

n. . [geol. classification]

Similar large Taupo pumice is also found about Rotorua, beyond the range of the Taupo Ignimbrite. (Jul 1998,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,116/42)

Radiometric Ages of Taupo Pumice and Waimihia Lapilli at Gisborne. WA Pullar. NZ Soil Bureau, Whakatane - title of paper (Feb 1964,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,15/16)

The upper part of the section comprises Taupo Pumice, Kaharoa Ash and Rotomahana Mud intercalated with beds of peat. (May 1975,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,39/36)

Paul Froggatt, on the final morning, led us into the Taupo Forest to examine the 50 m thick Oruanui Breccia and the Taupo Pumice Formation. (Feb 1982,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,55/32)

The first day commenced near Matawai where a 6 m thick sequence (from Rotoehu Ash 50 kyr to Taupo Pumice 1800 yrs B.P.) is preserved in a road cutting on SH2 a few kilometers east of Matawai. ... At the top of Panikau Hill a thin but relative [sic] complete distal section is preserved and contains Rotoehu Ash through to Taupo Pumice. (Jul 1984,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,65/17)

They could easily sold as together as a set, possibly as part of a resource, with a photo set (currently available from the Taupo Observatory) and perhaps even a piece of Taupo pumice! (Nov 1993,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,102/66)

taupulega¶

n. traditional councils [plural? Etymology: Tokelau]

Tokelau is governed by taupulega, traditional councils of old men made up of the heads of each atoll family, but remains a New Zealand territory. (Dec 18, 2005,Conservation Action,A4)

taura here¶

n. urban grouping within an iwi [ORIGIN: Maori, (from tpk.govt.nz) Due to the large population and land area, TRAION has implemented Takiwa (natural geographical groupings) to assist with the management of issues relating to the population and the marae that fall into the Ngapuhi catchment area. There are also two Taurahere (urban groupings) since 80% of the tribe live outside the traditional Ngapuhi boundaries (40% in Auckland alone). The TRAION structure is grassroots focussed with the marae and all who whakapapa to these marae being the main drivers for the vision, and for the tribal immortality of Ngapuhi.]

The report said the onus to build a positive relationship with taurahere organisations was on council. ... He wanted the term tuarahere better defined. (Nov 3, 2005,Horowhenua Mail,5) [NOTES: -]

NGATI POROU IN AUCKLAND Your Taura Here seeks a Kaitiaki A Rohe .. *To foster relationships with Te haukaenga, tangata whenua, matawaka ... (Jul 17, 2006,NZ Herald,D12)

Tauranga disease¶

n. bush sickness

tauranga n -s [Maori] NewZeal : BUSH SICKNESS (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2344)

1 n. (Rural) a potentially fatal disease of sheep, caused by cobalt deficiency. [aka Tauranga sickness]

At the time of my visit the deaths had ceased for this year, and I was unable to obtain lambs for post-mortem examination that had died of the 'Tauranga disease.' (Nov 1891,NZ Farmer,447)

DEPT OFLANDS & SURVEY This wasting disease or condition in ruminant stock was known locally by several names: 'Tauranga disease' (because it was first reported from there in 1893 and again in 1897) ... (1975,Prosperity from Pumice Land,7)

During the 1890s, stock inspectors and veterinary reports described a condition known as 'bush disease' in cattle and 'Tauranga disease' in sheep. (Mar 1979,NZ Journal of Agriculture,60)

Take for instance the `Tauranga sheep-disease,' as it is called: professors of different colleges are sent for, to investigate it ... (1892,TrNZI,24/626)

The study of the deficiency disease for many years known as bush sickness',bush disease', Tauranga disease', orthe skinnies', and now definitely and officially known as iron starvation' was commenced by the writer in 1910. <i>Ibid.</i> 538 ) Gilruth (3) 1899 recorded his examination of a few cases ofTauranga or Bush Sickness' [in 1899, Annual Report, Dept of Agriculture, 87]. (1928,TrNZI,58/537) [NOTES: Aston]

".. Some experiments in contagious mammitis have yet to be done, and the 'Bush['] or 'Tauranga' disease, which affects a considerable area of country near Rotorua, still remains to be coped with." (Jan 11, 1909,Evening Post,3)

[Hdg] "Tauranga" or "Bush Disease". This peculiar wasting disease, which is confined to the tract of land lying in the vicinity of Tauranga, and extending from there to Rotorua and Lichfield, was made the subject of an investigation by Mr. Park three years ago... It appears that both sheep and cattle will do well and put on condition for the first few months after being placed on this diseased country, but as time goes on a gradual wasting sets in, which ends in death if they are not removed to another district. (1899,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,VII/87)

It would seem that to deal thoroughly with the matter much more time and research will have to be given to it, than the examination of a few sheep or lambs can accomplish, though done by as able an expert as Professor Thomas; whose instructions, as to parasitical disease, seem to have been carried out as well as opportunity allowed, and yet disclosed nothing specially distinct in the Tauranga disease. (Apr 15, 1891,Bay of Plenty Times,2)

Tauranga/Tauranga class¶

n. alternative name of P class q.v.

Mr Highet designed his prototype of the P-class yacht about 70 years ago. It had its first outing at Onerahi Bay,Whangarei, on New Year's Day, 1920... In 1924 the boat was officially recognised in the Tauranga seven-foot one-design class. (Feb 6, 1989,NZ Herald,I/1)

CARTER What is often referred to as the "Baby Class" of New Zealand, the 7-foot Tauranga boats, also owe their existence to the efforts of a Wellington yachtsman, Mr. M.H.A. Highet, who was the originator of the class. These tiny yachts, which are built on the chine principle, have a beam of 3.6 feet, and carry a single sail of the gunter type. (1944,Little Ships: NZ's Yachting Fleet,132)

TITCHENER The P-class is also known as the Tauranga class, because Mr Highet moved from Wellington soon after designing the yacht. The first yachts from this design sailed on the Tauranga Harbour (1978,Little Ships of NZ,73)

Taurangian¶

n. a person born or resident in Tauranga

GIFKIN All Pakeha Taurangians were superior to all Maori; even an educated 'Pakeha-fied' Maori would end by going 'back to the mat'. (1988,Through the Looking Glass,128) [NOTES: Meikle]

taurekareka¶

n. (historical) a slave or war captive [ORIGIN: Maori, also taureka]

KEENE taurekareka:slave, low person (a term of supreme contempt). (1963,O Te Raki,194)

CRUISE ... they expressed their astonishment that we could so far forget ourselves as to sit down and eat with a towra caracca, or prisoner of war; and this degrading appellation was universally applied to the American gentleman as long as he remained amongst us. (1823,Journal,198,1957 ed.)

[spg touwrikka] Price ... told the natives, Capt. K. was a towrikka, or cookie, and that he was of no note etc (1835,Boultbee Journal,793,1986 ed.) [NOTES: also 1827 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 196]

POLACK He has often been reproached as a slave, (taurekareka), a term that applied to a chief of spirit, would engender in his breast a determination to seek revenge ... (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/25)

DIEFFENBACH The rest of the men are either rangatira, free men, or tau-reka-reka, slaves. ... The slaves, tau-reka-reka, are the prisoners of war, male or female, and such of their children as are born in slavery. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/113)

ANGAS These [Maori] boys were very inquisitive, ... they wanted to know if the [Queen Victoria's] palace was any larger than their house at Te Awa iti, and what number of taua reka rekas, or slaves, the Queen had belonging to her. (1847,Savage Life,1/281)

POWER ... a man who has been found guilty of the crime [of theft] is considered a tau reka-reka',a slave'. (1849,Sketches in NZ,145)

MARSH (1937,Vintage Murder,268)

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,3/338)

HENDERSON ... the tohunga made it ... tapu, so that the kukis, taurekarekas, tutuas, and other varieties of slaves ... would be afraid to meddle. (1948,Taina,26)

HULME Aue, I know you recall. You lost your good temper and yelled at me all kinds of rude names and swearing, taureka and sloven, 'pokokohua and bitch. (1986,Te Kaihau,115) [NOTES: [spg taureka]]

Europeans who embraced Maori culture were sometimes called taurekareka Maori or slaves. (Apr 2002,AA Directions,No. 51 (Autumn) : 61)

GRACE You are a low-bred set of men, taurekareka, all of you. (1901,Tales of a Dying Race,88)

MARSH "I should have forgotten that an ariki does not lay hands on a taurekareka." [Note. Taurekareka-slave, low-class person]. (1937,Vintage Murder,232)

'They are going to kill me, and make a taureka (slave) of you but that will never happen,' and picking her up, he knocked her brains out against the hatch-combing. (Jul 18, 1896,Hawke's Bay Herald,5)

If a tribe was.. nearly annihilated. and the small remnant was captured, they became the slaves (tuarekareka) and the land the absolute property of the conquerors. (May 21, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,34)

He answered, "I am a Ngapuhi chief, and a rangatira;" "but I found out," says Mrs. Moran bitterly, "on getting to the Bay that he was only a taurekareka." (Jul 5, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,15)

'But,' the waitress protested, 'he's a big chief' Heni shook her head as an assertation of independence.'He may be big rangatira on his own marae, he just a taurekareka in my kitchen.' (Mar 1963,Te Ao Hou,42: 16)

They are naturally proud, and haughty; they have keen sense of honour; pride would not allow them to brook an insult; their honour trampled on, a degrading epithet applied, a chief called a taurekareka, or familiarities with his wives, were insults not to be passed over. (May 17, 1851,New Zealander, The,2)

The Provincial Government, which has been famliarly known, sometimes as the uneducated Government, and sometimes as the Taurekareka Government, has obtained for itself a new title. It is now known as - the I.O.U. Government. (Jun 28, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,1)

With a well-assumed air of surprise and innocence the scoundrel confronted the indignant chief, and said, "I paid this man here, your taurekareka, for the pigs. Ask him if I did not count out 70 sovereigns and give them to him in a bag sealed up." (Sep 10, 1881,Observer (Auckland),614)

Moreover, he resuscitates a forty-century old mummy, which he compels to go forth invisably on nefarious errands, to the unspeakable disgust of the spirit of the ancient Pharaoh, who has an excusable objection to being made the lackey of a mere taurekareka of these degenerate days, and in the sequel takes ample revenge. (Feb 11, 1911,Evening Post,13)

taurepo¶

n. a small shrub, Rhabdothamnus solandri (in DNZE as matata hom.2)(also called NZ gloxinia, waiu-atua)

LAING & BLACKWELL Rhabdothamnus Solandri (Solander's Rhabdothamnus) ... Maori name, Taurepo. (1940,Plants of NZ,415)

... the TAUREPO or FOREST ABUTILON (Rhabdothamnus solandri). (1961,Flora NZ,196,1929 ed.)

Taurepo is .. an undershrub and shade lover. .. taurepo is the only New Zealand representative of the large and diverse tropical Gesneriaceae family. (Apr 1, 2006,Dominion Post Indulgence,21)

taurikarike¶

n. [Possibly variant of "taureka"]

They all jabbered and cut capers when they knew the taurikarike pakeha had mated up with the daughter of such a rangatira. (1900,Auckland Weekly News,Xmas No. / 17)

tautoko¶

v. to support [ORIGIN: Maori, cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 253 (noun use in second citation below)]

.. heaps of famous cats from all over getting together to tautoko the next wave of Polynesian Superstars ... (Aug 14, 2000,Salient,No. 17 : 35)

Sarah admits she was going to chuck it all in after missing out on a taonga at the Sydney Olympics in 2000. But with the tautoko and awhi of her partner .. she decided to push on ... (2005,Te Mana Taiohi,8,Autumn ed.)

I and my friends tautoko what you are trying to do to keep [sic] and help us knowing that there is a big world out there. (Sep 2005,Tearaway,4)

tautua¶

n. service and hard work

Pacific culture has some wonderful qualities: alofa (generosity and love), tautua (service and hard work) and fa'aaloalo (respect), which can be intertwined into the world in which we live and work. (Mar 30, 2005,Dominion Post,B7)

tauwhinau¶

n. (See tauhinu)

tavern¶

n.

tavern ... 2. U.S. & N.Z. a place licensed for the sale and consumption of alcoholic drink. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1199) [NOTES: [cf. 1986 NZPOD 788; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 493]]

Jim Tangira, a bushman, said he had been a neighbour of Tauriki for nearly 15 years. ... He accompanied Tauriki ... to two taverns ...They consumed beer and talked. (May 13, 1989,Press, The,14)

taw¶

n. a large or choice marble; a big marble; a bonser (cf broncs, grandads) ca1918-20 Auckland (man 66 yrs) a big marble called bonser' ortaw' -

Marbles, it seems, are 'in'.. and entered interest in the fortunes of the elusive "taw" surpasses all the blandishments of which I am master. (Dec 17, 1935,Christchurch Star-Sun,12)

SCANLAN `Reverend Mother talks of when she used to give you marbles for being a good little boy - pee-wees and agates, and stonies and glassies and a big tor. And once she tried to play with you, and you said she funked because her knuckle was inside the ring.' (1933,Tides of Youth,153)

HYDE (1936,Passport to Hell,25)

PARK ... a mob of little boys had their tails up over a marble game. ... they fired their taws, green and blue and brilliant yellow, at the squares richly lined with the weatherbeaten old clay soldiers which sold at twelve a penny and were known as dakes. thought to be spelled tor [common G. Kennedy] (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,176)

SUTTON-SMITH Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as taw' orshooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; dubs',dates', stakes',dukes', or changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at.<i>Ibid.</i> 176 [Waitara, Taranaki, 1899] Ataw' was usually an alley' orblood alley' made of agate. We used to take them home and burn them in a fire to convert them into `blood alleys'. (1972,Folkgames of Children,174)

PARK Some of them spat in the pathway of an opposing taw and cried 'Mississippi!' while others chanted, with deadly unselfconsciousness: 'Shut up, button yer lip, cork yer eye with a juniper pip! If you listen to this, you are bound to miss, miss, miss!' (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,176)

PARK With red faces and eyes bulging with an afternoon of stooping, they fired their taws, green and blue and brilliant yellow, at the squares richly lined with the weatherbeaten old clay soldiers which sold at twelve a penny and were known as dakes. (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,176)

tawa¶

n. [2x timber, 1x waikurupopo]

HEAPHY The Towa spars are considered the best for this purpose. (1842,Narrative of a Residence in Various Parts of NZ,42)

The properties of Tawa timber are as follows ... (Jan 1884,NZ Journal of Science,110)

21 Tawa slab. tall timber tree with edible blue-black berries. [Maori] (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,16)

We camped again, having been fortunate to find a decayed tawa tree, from which the natives squeezed a kettle of bitter and not over clear water, known, I believe, as the waikurupopo. (Jan 11, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,14)

n. a general name for various species [Maori] Beilschmiedia tawa, a forest tree, its timber, and its fruit (tawa-berry) [aka tower. [?d] Ed. Fairburn Maharatanga 47f. ... his bunch of towers.]

McDONNELL [spg tana] A great variety of hard-wood grows at New Zealand, admirably adapted for the timbering of any sized ships; among them is the boride[e-acute], rattar[as-acute], taraide[ase-acute], mai[a-acute], totara[a1-acute], koi katoa[a2-acute], toa[a-acute] toa[a-acute], tani raha[as-acute], to wai[a-acute], reiva[a-acute] reiva[a-acute], tana[as-acute][check ?sic or = taua] and many others. towa, a mis-spelling for tawa : cf tarairi below (laurus tarairi) : next entry towai (1834,Extracts From a Journal,19,1979 ed.)

YATE Tawa (Laurus Tawa) is a frequenter of damp and deeply - shaded woods, with leaf and branches similar to those of the Mairi-tree; ... (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),42)

Tawa ... [check title and date, and expand citation] (Apr 17, 1837,Sydney Herald) [NOTES: 1837 Apr 17 Sydney Herald E.G. Wakefield and J. Ward British Colonies 324]

POLACK Towa [a-acute] (laurus Australis,) is a useful timber for boarding the interior of houses; ... (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/396)

BIDWILL The trees were chiefly the Towa, [fn Leiospermum racemosum] a tree strongly resembling the beech in leaf and general appearance, and bearing a fruit about the size and colour of a damson, but with a very large seed. (1841,Rambles in NZ,35 and fn,1952 ed.)

HEAPHY The Kahikatea white pine, and the Mahi, Totara, Rata, and Tawa red pines, all grow to a great size; ... (1842,New Zealand (various authors/titles),102) [NOTES: (cf Towa earlier)]

There is also rata, tawa, honeysuckle &c., which, though of harder nature, may hereafter be applied to many useful purposes. (Nov 27, 1842,Letters from New Plymouth,58,1968 ed.) [NOTES: (1842 Nov 27) 1843 (1968) Letters from New Plymouth 58]

JOLLY [spg towa] ... about 8 miles from Nelson in a hut situated close to a small clump of White pine (Kahikatia) and Towa trees, ... (1873,Reminiscences,4) [NOTES: [c1844] 1873 Ed Jollie Reminiscences [MS] 4]

CHAPMAN Tower, Koi Koi, and Remo are the prevailing woods in this locality. [check date and title] (1847,Journals and Correspondence)

WAKEFIELD 6. Tawa, (Laurus tawa.) This tree abounds all over the district, and especially in the same situations as the totara. (1848,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),141)

EARP The fruit of the tawa resembles a prune damson ... (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),129) [NOTES: 1853 Allom letter in 1853 Earp NZ 129]

HOOKER Neodaphne tawa, Hook. fil. ... Nat. name, `Tawa', Cunn. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 217)

HOOKER Tawa, Col[enso]. Nesodaphne Tawa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

HAYNES Tower trees (so called from their towering above all the other trees of the bush) ... (1865,Ramble in the NZ Bush, A,18)

HECTOR Beilschmiedia tarairi, Hook. Tawa.--A lofty forest tree, 60-70 feet high, (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,129)

[Native name] Tawa .. [Settlers' name] Tawa .. [Family] Lauriniae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

Tawa .. Beilschmiedia tawa .. The wood is white, straight grained, and easily split; ... (1891,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,14)

MORRIS Tawa, n. Maori name for a New Zealand tree, Nesodaphne tawa, Hook., N.O. Laurinea. The newer name is Beilschmiedia tawa, Benth. and Hook.f. Allied to Taraire (q.v.). A handsome forest tree with damson-like fruit. (1898,Austral English,462)

Tá.wa (ta.́.w&adot.; colloq. toú.&adot.), n. [Maori.] (Bot.) A lauraceous tree of New Zealand, (Beilschmiedia (Nesodaphne) tawa. [Local, N. Z.] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

tawa, a tree (Beilschmiedia tawa); from its straight-grained and light wood the Maori made his long bird-spears, from twenty to thirty feet in length: its large purple berries much sought by the pigeon. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

tawa tree (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

A handsome New Zealand forest tree yielding a light, soft timber useful for making casks, buckets, etc. The plum-like fruit was used as food by the Maoris. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),406?)

tawa n -s [Maori] : a New Zealand evergreen tree (Beilschmiedia tawa) of the family Lauraceae with slender branches and graceful foliage resembling that of the willow and white straight-grained wood used chiefly for rough work (as clothespins) (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2344)

McLINTOCK Tawa .. tawa .. Beilschmiedia tawa (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

tawa n. lofty New Zealand tree, with soft light wood used for box-making [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

tawa ... n. lofty N.Z. tree with soft, light wood used for box-making [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

BURTON Unlike the berries of the karaka, tawa (Beilschmiedia tawa) berries have a non-poisonous kernel. If eaten raw, however, the kernels have a distinctive, turpentine-like flavour which is unpleasant to most palates. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,6)

tawa n./i a New Zealand timber tree with edible berries. [< Maori] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1199) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 788; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 493]]

tawa berry¶

3 n. the fruit of the tawa [usually plural; aka tawa-berry; also towa berry]

HEAPHY The Towa and the Kraka berries also yield an useful oil. (1842,Narrative of a Residence in Various Parts of NZ,43)

SELWYN Among these ... pools ... the natives are sitting up to their breasts in hot water, shelling Tawa berries, or peeling potatoes, or ... enjoying their never failing resource of smoking. (Oct 30, 1843,Journal) [NOTES: 1843 Oct 30 Selwyn Journal in 1845 NZ Part II (Church in the Colonies VII) 31]

SMITH Scattered about [at Rotomahana] ... are ... large square slabs of white stone, laid in a horizontal position over hot springs, and are used ... for drying tawa berries; ... (Jan 25, 1858,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1858 Jan 25 Smith Notes of a Journey in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 374]

"Tawa berry halves," said Rangi, as he put one in his mouth. (Sep 13, 1924,Evening Post,15)

The pigeon in those days enjoyed a bounteous food supply, commencing in April with tawa berries, and following with those of the matai, kahikatea, miro, hinau, and maire, with the berries of the cabbage tree between times. (Aug 2, 1930,Evening Post,17)

The rebels are known to be living on the tawa berries, and the root of the tara [sic], which is cooked in various ways, by being boiled, roasted, or steamed in a hangi or kopura-maori. (Apr 13, 1864,Daily Southern Cross,3)

For seven days they saw no sun in the dense trackless forest, and subsisted only by eating such wretched fare as turpentine-impregnated tawa berries. (Apr 14, 1871,Grey River Argus,2)

As a token of the hospitable reception we had at the hands of this patriarch of the Children of the Mist, I may remark that within four hours of our arrival we were compelled to sit down to no less than three meals, at which we were regaled upon pork, potatoes, biscuit, coffee, preserved pigeons, honey, and tawa berries. (Aug 12, 1897,Otago Witness,46)

The tawa berries just now are falling, and the pigeons abound, while high overhead the paroquet chatters. (Jun 15, 1903,Evening Post,6)

Town children must now go further afield if they seek to commune with bird and flower in the woods, and take toll of the pigeon's tawa berries. (Jan 21, 1911,Evening Post,13)

tawaapou¶

n. variant of tawapou

Milk tree, or Tawaapou (Epocarpurus microphyllus). The Milk tree of the Settlers, from the bark exuding a vegetable milk when wounded. Ibid. 48 Tawaapou. Epicarpus microphyllus, Raoul. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/37) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

tawai¶

n. occas. erron. variant of towai; variant of taewa

n. Weinmannia spp.

DIEFFENBACH Intermixed with these are the tawai [fn Leiospermum racemosum.] and hinau [fn Elaeocarpus hinau.]. Ibid. 1/55 This bird lives on the fleshy ... fruits of the hinau (Etacocarpus [sic =?Elaeo-] hinau), of the tawai (Leiospermum racemosum), [= Weinmannia racemosa, towhai, tawhero]of the miro (Podocarpus ferruginea), and of the mai (Dacrydium mai). Ibid. 1/399 The forest [near Rotorua] was mostly tawai (Leiospermum racemosum), miro, and hinau; the Dracophyllum, which often grows to the size of a small tree, and the reddish leaves of which render it a very remarkable and beautiful shrub, was ... to be met with. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/27)

TAYLOR [Near Hikurangi] we passed through a noble forest of beech trees (Tawai) some were 8 feet in diameter and of great height (Nov 10, 1845,Journal,3/166)

WAKEFIELD 9. Tawai, (Leiospermum racemosum.) This tree has a rough, dark-brown bark, and a small round leaf, in shape like that of an elm. The wood is particularly well adapted for ship-building, and for the staves of barrels, and is commonly called `black birch' by the sailors and other Europeans acquainted with it. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,142)

HOOKER Weinmannia racemosa, Forst. ... Nat. names, Tawai', <i>Cunn</i>.;Tawhere', Southern Island, Lyall. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 80)

DRURY TREES [MET WITH IN PELORUS]. Kawa-Kawa ... Flax - Korari of natives ... Tawai - a large tree, commonest of all trees in the Pelorus forests. (1855,Sailing Directions,67)

HOOKER Tawai, Cunn. Weinmannia racemosa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

ROBERT TOD HAS on hand a large stock of RATA and TAWAI (sound and dry), the best that Taranaki can produce. (Aug 21, 1896,Taranaki Herald,3)

We were obliged to stop a day here; and on the 6th we followed the left stream, on a flat covered with an open forest of tawai, for about ? of a mile, and as we observed that the flat did not extend any further, and that the hills descended in steep declivity towards the water, I ascended the hills with Mr. Deans and Eckford to have a look around us. (Sep 12, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

n. beech, birch, black birch, red birch

The tawai, or black birch as it is called ... . (1841,NZ Journal,2/29/51) [NOTES: (Dieffenbach)]

HOOKER Fagus fusca, Hook. fil. ... HAB. Mountains of the Northern Island ... Common in the Middle Island ... Nat. name, Tawai', <i>Bidwill.</i>Black Birch' of the colonists. ... [230] A lofty, handsome forest tree, 80-100 feet high ... Fagus Menziesii, Hook. fil. ... HAB. Mountains of the Northern and Middle Islands. ... Nat. name, Tawai', [?tavai check] <i>Col</i>.Red Birch' of the colonists. ... A very handsome tree, 80-100 feet high, ... Bark silvery, outer layers peeling off and exposing a red surface. (1853,Flora NZ,II Flora Novae-Zelandiae I Flowering Plants 229)

HAAST I had not then been accustomed to pass weeks in the dark tawai forest. Ibid. 11 I had noticed ... that the vegetation began to change; totara, kahi-katea, ... were intermixed with the tawai (black birch), which had till then been the reigning forest tree. (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,10)

HOOKER Tawai, Col[enso]. Fagus Menziesii. ... Tawai, Bidwill. Fagus fusca. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

HAY There is the cabbage-tree palm, with bare shank and top-knot; the nikau palm, with weird and wondrous frondage; the lancewood, ...; the fern-tree, .... There is the twisting, squirming rata; the gaunt ... kahikatea; the golden kowhai; the dark velvet-covered rimu; the feathery red tawai; the perfumy mangiao; ... Ibid. 2/190 The Tawai (Fagus Menziesii), called `red birch' by settlers, is a favourite for fencing when young. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/187)

tawai (as tawhai), a tree (Nothofagus spp.), beech; wrongly called birch; Tawai-raunui and tawai rauriki recognized as species by Maori and Pakeha alike: there are also hybrids: Also called tawhai. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

The Maori name for one or two kinds of New Zealand beech. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),406)

Description of land: All forest, composed of rimu, rata, tawai, &c.; generally flat; soil light, being a thin deposit upon volcanic ash and stone; well watered and more fit for pastoral than agricultural purposes. (Jan 4, 1894,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

The forest is again formed of one sort of trees, the tawai, or black birch as it is called. (Sep 12, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

Tawai contains 5 per cent. of potash and about an equal quantity of lime. The ash of tawai must make a capital manure. (May 5, 1908,Taranaki Herald,3)

A.R., HAVING completed arrangements for a constant supply of FIRST-CLASS FIREWOOD, consisting of Tetoki, Tawai, and Manuka, is prepared to supply the same at the following prices ... (Sep 1, 1886,Poverty Bay Herald,3)

tawai berry¶

n.

The native storehouses for tawai berries were completely destroyed by the volcanic mud eruption. (Mar 19, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

tawaiwai¶

n.

HOOKER Tawaiwai, Lindsay. Phyllocladus trichomanoides. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

tawaka¶

n. a fish

LEE & KENDALL T|a w|aka; [A fish so called;] (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,211)

n. a bush hawk

HIERACIDEA {HARPA} NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (QUAIL HAWK.) .. Native names. Karearea, Kaiaia, Kaeaea, Kakarapiti, Karewarewa, and Tawaka. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,1,1888 2nd edn 1/213 ed.)

BULLER HIERACIDEA BRUNNEA {HARPA FEROX}. (BUSH-HAWK.) ...Native names. Karearea, Kaiaia, Kaeaea, Kakarapiti, Karewarewa, and Tawaka; but sometimes distinguished as Karewarewa-tara. `Sparrow-Hawk' of the colonists. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,6,1888 2nd edn 1/220 ed.)

n. a mushroom

BURTON Many types of fungus were eaten by the Maori. These were known by various names such as hawai, wairuru, tiki-tehetehe, maiheru, tawaka (a species of Agaricus) and hakeka (Himeola). (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,8)

tawake¶

n. the red-tailed tropic bird [1952 Mitchell]

tawake, a bird, the red-tailed tropic bird, see amokura (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

tawaki¶

n. Crested Penguin

HUTTON 158. EUDYPTES PACHYRHYNCHUS. Gray. Crested Penguin. Tawaki.[?tawhaki (1871,Birds of New Zealand,53)

HUTTON EUDYPTES PACHYRHYNCHUS. Gray. Crested Penguin. Tawaki.[?tawhaki (1873,Birds of New Zealand,53)

BULLER EUDYPTES CHRYSOCOMUS {PACHYRHYNCHUS}. (YELLOW-CRESTED PENGUIN. {CRESTED PENGUIN.} Native name{s}.- Tawaki {and Pokotiwha}. (1879,Birds of New Zealand,344,{1888 2nd edn 2/287} ed.)

RICHARDS Eudyptes ... Sclateri ... Big Crested Penguin. TAWAKI. (1952,Chatham Islands,92)

tawaki n. [check spg ?misprint h]a New Zealand penguin [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

tawaki [check]... n. a N.Z. penguin [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

Fiordland Crested Penguin Eudyptes pachyrhynchus GRAY, 1845 ... OTHER NAMES:Tawaki, thick-billed penguin, crested penguin, Fiordland penguin. Ibid. 52 Erect-crested Penguin Eudyptes sclateri BULLER, 1888 ... OTHER NAMES: Tawaki, big-crested penguin. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,50)

tawapou¶

n. Sideroxylon costatum

Among the ... plants on or near sea cliffs ... may be mentioned ... the tawapou (Sideroxylon costatum), sometimes called the New Zealand olive, from the resemblance of its fruit to that of the olive (the true New Zealand olive is the maire - Olea) (1911,TrNZI,43/200)

tawara¶

n. (See tawhara)

tawari¶

n. a tree with showy white flowers, found in the northern North Island. [Maori tawari[a1-macron]]

Escalloniaceae Ixerba brexioides tawari (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: (Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri)]

HOOKER Tawari, Col[enso]. Ixerba brexioides. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Of our shrubs and smaller timber trees, several are of strikingly beautiful growth ... (e.g.) the Houhere, Hoheria populnea ...; ..the Tawari, Ixerba brexioides; .. the Horoeka, MPanax crassifolia: and, on the sea-coast, ... the Karo, Pittosporum crassifolium; and the truly evergreen Ngaio, Myoporum laetum ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/5) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

[Native name] Tawari .. [Settlers' name] Tawari .. [Family] Saxifrageae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

FEATON IXERBA BREXIOIDES (A.Cunn.) ... The `TAWARI'. This elegant tree, is confined to the Northern Island. Ibid. 178 Tawari [Maori name] .. Tawari [Settlers' name] .. Ixerba brexioides .. Small tree (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,132)

353 Lithograph of tawari foliage. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,22)

C HEESEMAN I[xerba] brexioides, A.Cunn.. ... Tawari. ... A remarkably handsome tree. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,196)

LAING & BLACKWELL Ixerba brexioides [(The Tawari)]. A beautiful tree, sometimes 70 ft. in height. ... [188] Maori name Tawari. (1907,Plants of NZ,186,1940, p. 188 ed.)

COCKAYNE The tawiri [check spg: should be tawari] (Ixerbia brexioides) of the Auckland upland forest is so showy that the Maoris had a special name, `whakou,' for its blooms. (1910,NZ Plants,37)

COCKAYNE The tawiri [check spg: should be tawari] (Ixerbia brexioides) of the Auckland upland forest is so showy that the Maoris had a special name, `whakou,' for its blooms. (1910,NZ Plants,37)

(1958,NZ Timber Journal,62/2)

MARTIN (1961,Flora NZ,165)

MOORE & IRWIN IXERBA BREXIOIDES. Tawari is a northern tree found in some upland forests of the Auckland and Gisborne districts. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,78)

LOCKE Botanical discoveries were spice to the dish. I shan't forget the first time I saw the tawari (Ixerba brexioides) in flowers all along the sunlit verges of the brick-red clay road along the ridge [near Auckland.] (1981,Student At The Gates,73)

Above 900 m hard beech is replaced by red beech which begins to dominate the canopy up to the summits of the Ikawhenua Range. Also at these altitudes are Hall's totara and tawari. (1983,Land of the Mist,60)

On the branches of the rata [a's-acute] and other trees, where the soil had been raised by heavy gusts of wind, ... flourished the wild indigenous para-[110]sitical plant called tawara [a2,a3-acute] (Astilia angustifolia). (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/109)

HEAPHY The pulpy part of the middle of the stem of the Tawara or Astilia is an excellent substitute in pastry for the apple. (1842,Narrative of a Residence in Various Parts of NZ,45)

Honey from the waxy white blossom of the native tawari tree, which grows in the warmer parts of the country, has a wonderful light, flowery flavour with a lingering butterscotch finish. (Mar 18, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),52)

The following woods, from New Zealand have been tested as to their capability of bearing pressure applied to the centre while supported at the two extremities .. 13. Tawiri. (Jan 6, 1857,Daily Southern Cross,4)

The following is a list of the Auckland contributions towards the Vienna Exhibition .. special collection of wood sections in the round; tawari, iserba bresioides ... (Jan 23, 1873,Daily Southern Cross,2)

The tree Ixerba brexioides is "tawari," [b]ut its flowers are "whakou." (May 29, 1909,Evening Post,13)

tawatawa¶

n.

LEE & KENDALL Taua taua; A fish so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,210)

English Name Native Name ... ... Herring Tawa tawa ... ... (1849,NZ Journal,9/125) [NOTES: quoting Anglo Maori Warder Oct 5]

TAYLOR Tawatawa, is about the same size as the kahawai, or mackerel, which it closely resembles in color and general form. Ibid623 The Tawa tawa is the same size as the Kahawai, or mackerel, which it resembles in color [sic] and general form. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,413)

SHERRIN MACKEREL ... This valuable fish (Scomber australasicus) is only known to me from ... Wellington Harbour about the 15th December, 1870, but it appears to be the fish that is called by the natives Tawa-tawa. In colour, size, and form it closely approaches the common Mackerel of England, and is very superior in delicacy to the Scad or Horse Mackerel, which is commonly called the Mackerel in New Zealand. (1872,Edible Fishes,112)

SHERRIN MACKEREL (Scomber Australasicus). ... This valuable fish is well known as an occasional visitant in Wellington Harbour, being called by the Natives tawatawa. In colour, size, and form it closely approaches the common mackerel of England, and is very superior in delicacy to the scad or horse-mackerel, which is commonly called the mackerel in New Zealand. (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,61)

SCOMBER AUSTRALASICUS Cuvier and Valenciennes. Southern Mackerel; Tawatawa. ... Distribution: North Island and northern coasts of South Island. (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/118) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

PHILLIPPS Pneumatophorus australasicies (Cuvier & Val.). SOUTHERN MACKEREL; TAWATAWA. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,45,1971 ed.)

tawatawa, a sea-fish (Scomber australasicus), mackerel. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

BUCK2/212 (1949,Coming of the Maori, The)

RICHARDS ADIANTUM ... affine ... Maiden-hair. TAWA TAWA. (1952,Chatham Islands,13)

DOOGUE & MORELAND COMMON MACKEREL ... Other names: Scomber japonicus; southern mackerel, English mackerel, frigate mackerel; tawatawa (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,267)

BAUGHAN Te Ika a Maui (Tny Eeka ah Mow-ee): The fish of Maui - the Maori name properly for the North Island only of New Zealand, but often for the whole country. (1908,Shingle-Short,56)

Another of our food fishes.. is the true mackerel (Scomber astralasicus) . . . The Maoris call the fish tawatawa. (Jan 30, 1890,Otago Boys' High School,18)

taweke¶

n. sowthistle

CHEESEMAN [Sonchus asper, Hill,] Sow-thistle; Rauroroa; Tawheke; Puwha. ... As this was collected by Banks and Solander it must be regarded as indigenous. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,388) [NOTES: Williams does not give tawheke the spg above]

tawera¶

n. [also tawhara, kie kie, NZ screw pine; Freycinetia banksiitawera]

... the tawera, or New Zealand screw pine, Freycinetia banksii, ... often climbing to the tops of the loftiest trees, and might be procured by thousands of tons. (1874,TrNZI,6/56)

tawha¶

n. (See tawhara)

tawhai¶

n. = tawai

Fagus cliffortioides Hook. f. .. Mountain beech or birch. [Fagus] fusca Hook. f. .. Tawhai, black-birch. [Fagus] Menziesii Hook. f. .. Silver or red birch. [Fagus] Solandri Hook. f. .. White-birch. (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/144)

HOOKER Tawhai, Col[enso]. Fagus Menziesii and Solandri. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Tawhai. Fagus Menziesii, Hook. f. ... Tawhai. Fagus fusca, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/48) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

... the graceful fern-plumaged Kawaka, ([Libocedrus Doniana, Hook: f.]), the handsome celery-leaved Tanekaha, (Phyllocladus trichomanoides,) ... the ornate Tawhai, (Fagus Menziesii,) and ... the ... Tawhai-rau-nui, (Fagus fusca,). Ibid. 1/III/44 (Colenso Botany North Isd) The Tawhai, and Tawhai-rau-nui, or Black and Red Birches, (Fagus Solandri and F. Fusca,) often form large ... trees. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/4) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

[Morris] Tawhai. Large and durable timber ... (1873,Catalogue of Vienna Exhibition)

HECTOR Nothofagus fusca, Hook. Tawhai Tawhairaunui, Black-birch of Auckland and Otago (from colour of bark), Red-birch of Wellington and Nelson (from colour of timber). --This is a noble tree 60-90 feet high the trunk 5-8 feet in diameter. The timber is excessively tough and hard to cut. It is highly valued in Nelson and Wellington. ... Nothofagus menziesii, Hook. Tawhai, Red-birch (from the colour of the bark). --A handsome tree, 80-100 feet high; trunk 2-3 feet in diameter. The timber is chiefly used in the lake district of the South Island. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,125)

[Native name] Tawhai .. [Settlers' name] Entire-leaved birch .. [Family] Cupuliferae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

MORRIS Maori name for several species of New Zealand Beech-trees, N.O. Cupuliferae. The settlers call them Birches (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,462)

The formation is chiefly Upper Palaeozoic and Upper Mesozoic rocks. 244,000 acres, mainly in the back country, are covered with bush, chiefly tawhai, tawhai rauriki, and tawhai raunui, the last being found along the shores of Lake Sumner and the banks of the Hurunui River, and, with the exception of the tawhai raunui, is of little value for timber purposes. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,262)

CHEESEMAN F. Menziesii, Hook.f. ... A tall forest-tree 60-80 ft. ... high; ... bark white or silvery, expecially in young trees; ... [641] Tawhai; Tawai; Silver-birch; Red-birch. ... The wood is dark-red ... but is not durable when exposed to the weather. Ibid. 643 F. Solandri, Hook.f. ... A lofty forest-tree 40-60 ft. high; ... bark black ... in old trees ... pale and smooth on young ones; ... Leaves ... clothed with an appressed greyish-white pubescence beneath ... usually in hilly or mountain districts. ... Tawhai; Tawhai-rauriki; Black-birch; White-birch. ... Wood pale-red, often streaked with black, not durable ... (1906,Manual NZ Flora,640)

ANDERSEN ... In my introductory essay ... T.W. Kirk was quoted on the singular exception in the case of the beeches, which the Maori seemed to class together as tawhai adding, perhaps, in our own manner, a descriptive modifying word or words, as tawhairaunui for the large-leaved beech. The recent studies of Dr. L. Cockayne (NZ State Forest Service, Bulletin No4, 1926), show that in this, too, the Maori was right ; the rigid specific distinction did not exist: As in Hebe (Veronica) there is much hybridization. ... and as the Veronicas were all Koromiko to the Maori, so the varieties of Nothofagus were all tawhai. (1926,Popular Names,57/905)

tawai (as tawhai), a tree (Nothofagus spp.), beech; wrongly called birch; Tawai-raunui and tawai rauriki recognized as species by Maori and Pakeha alike: there are also hybrids: Also called tawhai. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in]

tawhai, tawai n. any one of several species of New Zealand beech-trees [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

tawhai, tawai n. any one of several species of New Zealand beech-trees [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

tawhai, tawai ... n. any one of several species of N.Z. beech-tree [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

tawhai n. NZ = NOTHOFAGUS. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,788) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 493, TAWAI]]

The crowns of the ranges are covered with tawhai, commonly known among bushmen as silver birch. (Feb 5, 1924,Otago Witness,15)

tawhai-raunui¶

n. red beech

HOOKER Tawhai-rau-nui, Col[enso]. Fagus fusca. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

... the graceful fern-plumaged Kawaka, ([Libocedrus Doniana, Hook: f.]), the handsome celery-leaved Tanekaha, (Phyllocladus trichomanoides,) ... the ornate Tawhai, (Fagus Menziesii,) and ... the ... Tawhai-rau-nui, (Fagus fusca,). Ibid. 1/III/44 The Tawhai, and Tawhai-rau-nui, or Black and Red Birches,( Fagus Solandri F. Fusca,) often form large ... trees. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/4) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

HAY The Tawairaunui (Fagus fusca) is a species of the former, known as `black birch'. ... [It] is not so plentiful in the North. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/190)

[Native name] Tawhai-raunui .. [Settlers' name] Tooth-leaved birch .. [Family] Cupuliferae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

CHEESEMAN N. fusca F. fusca, Hook.f. ... A noble forest-tree 60-100 ft. high; ... bark dark-brown or black in old plants, deeply furrowed, smooth and greyish-white on young trees; ... rare in Canterbury and eastern Otago. ... Tawhai; Tawhai-rau-nui; Black-birch; Red-birch. ... [642] Wood bark-red, ... more durable than that of other species, ... (1906,Manual NZ Flora,641)

tawai (as tawhai), a tree (Nothofagus spp.), beech; wrongly called birch; Tawai-raunui and tawai rauriki recognized as species by Maori and Pakeha alike: there are also hybrids: Also called tawhai. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

tawhai-rauriki¶

n. black beech

HOOKER Tawairauriki, Geolog. Surv. Fagus Solandri. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Tawairauriki. Fagus Solandri, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/48) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

The Tawai-rauriki (Fagus Solandri) is the `White Birch' of the settlers. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/197)

The formation is chiefly Upper Palaeozoic and Upper Mesozoic rocks. 244,000 acres, mainly in the back country, are covered with bush, chiefly tawhai, tawhai rauriki, and tawhai raunui, the last being found along the shores of Lake Sumner and the banks of the Hurunui River, and, with the exception of the tawhai raunui, is of little value for timber purposes. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,262)

CHEESEMAN F. Solandri, Hook.f. ... A lofty forest-tree 40-60 ft. high; ... bark black ... in old trees ... pale and smooth on young ones; ... Leaves ... clothed with an appressed greyish-white pubescence beneath ... usually in hilly or mountain districts. ... Tawhai; Tawhai-rauriki; Black-birch; White-birch. ... Wood pale-red, often streaked with black, not durable ... N. cliffortioides ...F. Cliffortioides, Hook.f. ... A small tree, usually from 20 ft. to 40 ft. high ... Mountain districts ... Tawhai-rauriki; Mountain Beech or Birch. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,643)

tawhara¶

n. . [aka tawera, tawara; also New Zealand screw pine. Freycinetia banksii. 1848 Brunner [see quot patiki]]

MARKHAM ... a kind of Lily a sort of Parasitical Plant ... [Blank space left for drawing with caption Tawara Astilia Angustifolia'] <i>IbidD.</i> 91 [1963 fn 39 p 35] The drawing shows a large tree ... bearing, on the branches clumps of Astelia which Markham, following Yate, has erroneously labelledTawara Astilia Angustifolia'. Tawara' is a rendering of <i>tawhara', the Maori name for the fruit of ... Freycinetia banksii (kiekie) .. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),61,1963 ed.) [NOTES: [recheck p. no. and spg]]

YATE [The food of the New Zealanders] was formerly confined to the sweet-potato, the fern-root, and fish, with the sweet stalk of the Tawara (Astilia angustifolia), a parasitical plant, growing between the branches of the Kahikatoa and Puriri trees. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),107)

POLACK On the branches of the rata [a's-acute] and other trees, where the soil had been raised by heavy gusts of wind, ... flourished the wild indigenous para-[110]sitical plant called tawara [a2,a3-acute] (Astilia angustifolia). (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/109)

HEAPHY The pulpy part of the middle of the stem of the Tawara or Astilia is an excellent substitute in pastry for the apple. (1842,Narrative of a Residence in Various Parts of NZ,45)

ANGAS The food is served in baskets made of flax, or the long narrow leaves of the tawara (Freycinetia Banksii), plaited so as to resemble coarse matting. (1847,Savage Life,1/319)

HOOKER Freycinetai Banksii, Cunn. ... Nat. name, `Tawhara', Col. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 237)

HURSTHOUSE ... vine and mulberry show fruit; tawara ripe; ... (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/115)

HOOKER Tawhara, Col[enso]. Freycinetia Banksii. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Tawhara. Freycinetia Banksii, A. Cunn. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/49) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

... the Kahikatea ..., - the fruit of which was called Koroi ... and also the fruit (Ureure) and sugary bract-like spadices (Tawhara) of the climbing plant (Kiekie). (1869,TrNZI,1/III/31) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

... the tawera, or New Zealand screw pine, Freycinetia banksii, ... often climbing to the tops of the loftiest trees, and might be procured by thousands of tons. (1874,TrNZI,6/56)

MEREDITH We went out into the bush after tawharas this week. This is the fruit of the kia kia, a parasite which climbs and adheres to the dead trees. The Maoris make excellent hats resembling the celebrated `cabbage-tree' hats, from the fibre of the leaves. (1935,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,135) [NOTES: c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 135]

SUTTON-SMITH The soft stamens of one of these are cream-coloured and covered with creamy-yellow pollen. This we called the lady' or sometimes what the Maoris called it, <i>tawhera</i>. [check spg ?tawhara]The other, thegentleman' giggy (tiore) had harder brownish-green stamens. (1981,History of Children's Play,116,1981 ed.)

HAY The Tawhera or Kie-kie (Greycinetia Banksii) appears to be sometimes a parasite, sometimes a shrub, and sometimes a small tree. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/193)

MORRIS Tawara, n. Maori name for the flower of the Kie-kie (q.v.), Freycinetia Banksii. (1898,Austral English,462)

BAUCKE Aye, and kie kie also, with its two kinds of sweetmeats, both on the same vine - the first at, and before Christmas, when the plant distills its nectar juices, and collects them in that bunch of tender succulence of fleshly leaflets the Maori called tawhara - the very name is maddening to think of! - and later, in winter, when its fruits, shaped like a corncob studded with the heads of translucent amber! Ah me! (1905,Where the White Man Treads,16)

C HEESEMAN [Freycinetia Banksii, A.Cunn.] ...Kiekie; Tawhara (the edible bracts); Ureure (the fruit). ... ripe fruit in May. ... The white fleshy bracts surrounding the spadices are often eaten; the fruit less commonly so. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,742)

LAING & BLACKWELL [Freycinetia Banksii] Maori name Kie-kie. The flower is usually called Tawhara. ... [Freycinetia is called after the French navigator, Freycinet]. (1907,Plants of NZ,80,1940, p. 83 ed.)

FIRTH The fleshy bracts of the root-climbing tawhara, the perei orchid,the young fronds of the mauku ... also furnished vegetable food. (Colocasia esculenta, Scholl.) ... (1929,Primitive Economics of NZ Maori,51)

HYDE` You can eat the tawhara in the woods around. This is the fleshy cream flower of a great green palm - sweet as honey and water-melon in one. (1934,Journalese,171)

tawhara, flower-bracts of Freycinitia eaten as a sweetmeat, see kiekie. [spg Freycinetia???] (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

LYON The fruit [of the kiekie] was called tawha, and was a favourite Maori delicacy. (1952,Faring South,104)

BOSWELL ... each carrying ... a great bunch of tawharas or, in autumn, patungatungas (flower and fruit of the kiekie vine) ... Ibid. 150 There was in spring the delicious tawhara, the fleshy edible flower of the kiekie vine, or later the still more delectable patungatunga, the ripened seed-pod of the tawhara. (1956,Dim Horizons,55)

KEENE tawhara: edible flower of kiekie (1963,O Te Raki,195)

Not only was there edible fruit, ureure, in summer; but, in spring the sweeet white inner leaves of the flower, tawhara, were also consumed. (Nov 12, 2005,Dominion Post,Indulgence 23)

n.

HAY Where there is a great deal of supple-jack, or tawhera scrub, the work [of clearing] may get on as slowly as if the trees were comparatively large. (1882,Brighter Britain,1/187)

tawharu¶

n.

HYDE You can eat the tawhara in the woods around. This is the fleshy cream flower of a great green palm - sweet as honey and water-melon in one. (1934,Journalese,171)

HARSANT I drunk with eating some tawhara I find in the bush. You know, you eat it and it not very ripe, you get silly. Get drunk! (1979,They Called Me Te Maari,84)

tawheke¶

n. (See taweke)

tawheowheo¶

n. occasionally called New Zealand lilac a small North Island tree. [Maori tawheowheo[a-macron]]

Quintinia serrata A. Cunn. .. Tawheowheo. (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/144)

Escalloniaceae Quintinia serrata tawheowheo (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: (Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri)]

CHEESEMAN Q[uintinia] serrata, A.Cunn.. ... Tawheowheo. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,135)

LAING & BLACKWELL Quintinia serrata (The Serrated Quintinia) ... Called by settlers [Sometimes called] New Zealand lilac. Maori name [Tawheowheo]. North Island only: Auckland, Hawke's Bay, and Taranaki. (1907,Plants of NZ,186,1940 p. 193 ed.)

MOORE & IRWIN >i>QUINTINIA SERRATA, tawheowheo. Quintinia is another small genus shared with New Guinea, ... (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,78)

2 n. Quintinia acutifolia

COCKAYNE Quintinia acutifolia mountain tawheowheo (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

tawhera¶

n. (See tawhara)

Racemes of small white flowers of the red birch - kamahi in part of the South Island, tawhera in the North Island, Weinmannia racemosa to botanists.. are reflected in magic mirrors while they drink the waters of the lake. (Nov 23, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17)

They are called "tawhera" by the Maoris, and were very popular with them, prior to the coming of the pakeha with his sugar sweet, as a sweetmeat. (Aug 21, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,31)

tawhero¶

n.

The largest trees on the range are tawhero (Weinmannia sylvicola) and pukatea (Laurelia novae-zelandiae.) (1889,TrNZI,21/38)

HOOKER Weinmannia racemosa, Forst. ... Nat. names, Tawai', <i>Cunn</i>.;Tawhere', Southern Island, Lyall. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 80)

HOOKER Tawhero, Col[enso]. Weinmannia sylvicola. ..Tawhero (Southern Island), Lyall. Weinmannia racemosa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

The Towai, and Tawhero, (Weinmannia sylvicola, and W. racemosa,) are small trees ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/46) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

KIRK TAWHERO.- (Weinmannia racemosa.) ... Often called black birch, and substituted for that timber, to which it is greatly inferior in strength and durability. (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,19)

BULLER The spot fixed upon was ... under the shadow of a three-stemmed tawhero (Weinmannia racemosa), sheltered all round by close-growing porokaiwiria, torotoro, and other shrubby trees ... (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/12)

FEATON Its [Quintinnia serrata, native lilac] durability is probably about equal to the wood of the Tawhero - Weinmannia racemosa - or Black Birch of Otago, to which it is indeed closely allied. Ibid. 136 WEINMANNIA RACEMOSA. (Forst.) ... The TAWHERO' OR ``KAMAI'. This handsome and useful tree is found in both Islands; ... In Otago the tree is popularly known as theBlack Birch'. Ibid. 178 Tawhero [Maori name] .. Birch [Settlers' name] .. Weinmannia racemosa .. Tree (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,131)

  1. Tawhero .. All purposes to which mahogany is applied ... (Mar 7, 1846,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,4)

n.

450 Lithograph of tawhero foliage. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,25)

2 n.

FEATON in error for the TOWAI (W silvicola) WEINMANNIA SILVICOLA (Banks & Sol.) ... The `TOWAI'.- ... The wood is similar in quality to its ally W. racemosa, but is denser, and of finer grain; ... [136] This tree is sometimes called Tawhero, or Kamai, and is not unusually confounded with W. racemosa, the Tawhero or Kamai proper. In the same manner the tawhero is confused with this species by the uninitiated. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,135)

CHEESEMAN [Weinmannia sylvicola, Sol.] NORTH ISLAND: ... Tawhero. (1906,NZ Flora,139)

LAING & BLACKWELL Weinmannia [sylvicola (The Tawhero)]. Maori names Tawhero, Kamahi. (1907,Plants of NZ,180,1940 p. 197 ed.)

COCKAYNE Confined to the north are ... the mangaeo (Litsea calicaris), the makamaka (Ackama rosaefolia), the tawhero (Weinmannia sylvicola), the toatoa (Phyllocladus glaucus), and some other trees and shrubs. (1910,NZ Plants,46)

LEVY Mangroves characterise the tidal mud flats, while certain poor clay soils, popularly known as gum-lands, were dominated by the kauri and its associate the tawhero. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,3,1970 ed.)

tawherowhero¶

n. a tree

[Caption] Clouds often shroud Hautaru's 700 m-high peaks, which are covered with a stunted moisture-loving cloud forest rich in southern rata, tawa, tawhero, Westland quintinia and tawari. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/15)

...by throwing a rope by aid of a stone over a tawhero tree we gained a wide ledge which let us travel down the stream bed. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/28) [NOTES: W M Hamilton's 1932 field journal in NZ Geographic]

The canopy tree tawherowhero, a prominent feature along the shores of the Bay of Islands and in montane forests, bears a mixture of red and green leaves in unpredictable proportions; both leaf types are apparently healthy, and the trees thrive. (Nov 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 60/61)

tawhina¶

n. (See tauhinu)

tawhiri¶

n. . [aka tawiri; these both variants of tawari according to Harry.]

BENNETT The Tafiri, the lemon-tree of the settlers [tenuifolium (1860,Gatherings of a Naturalist,416)

DOMETT `Its floor ... with faint tawhiri-leaves besprent.' (1872,Ranolf and Amohia,108)

DOMETT Tawhiri ..... O. Pittosporum; S. P. cornifolium. A large shrub; many varieties; leaves of some highly scented. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/303)

BRACKEN [Morris] The early breeze that ... stole/ The rich Tawhiri's sweet perfume. (1884,Lays of the Maori,21)

MORRIS Taawhiri, or Tawiri, n. Maori name for the Black Mapau. A name applied to the tree Pittosporum tenuifolium, N.O. Pittosporeae. It is profusely covered with a fragrant white blossom. See Mapau. [1872 Domett]; 1884 Bracken (1898,Austral English,462)

LAING & BLACKWELL The gum of the taramea [was mixed by the Maori with] ... the fragrant resin of the tawhiri (Pittosporum tenuifolium), ... (1907,Plants of NZ,322,1940 p. 341 ed.)

tawhiri, a tree (Pittosporum tenuifolium); so called because small branches were broken off to wave welcome while calling out haeremai to approaching visitors: tawhiri means to beckon. The tree has smallish chocolate-coloured flowers very fragrant in summer evenings and nights, when the bowers of the trees too are a-flutter with the visiting lady-moths: also called ko[o]hu[u]hu[u] and tawhiwhi. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

tawhiri, tawiri n. New Zealand pittosporum, with fragrant white blossoms. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

tawhiri, tawiri ... n. N.Z. pittosporum, with fragrant white blossoms. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

tawhiri n. NZ tree of pittosporum family with fragrant white blossoms. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,788) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

HECTOR Carpodetus serratus, Forst. Tawiri, White Mapau, White-birch (of Auckland). --A small tree, 10-30 feet high, trunk unusually slender. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,132)

Tawiri-kohu-kohu, or white-mapau (Carpodetus serratus) (1892,NZ Official Handbook,150)

FIREWOOD. MIXED Rata, Birch, Tawiri, and Miro, sound and dry. (Jun 10, 1927,Evening Post,14)

The food of the whitehead, according to his observations, consists of the smaller insects and their larvae, varied occasionally with the seeds of certain trees, such as those of the tawari, tawhiwhi, and karo. (Mar 6, 1937,Evening Post,17)

n.

DOMETT This cheerful cot .../ Its floor, for fragrant orange-scent/ With faint tawhiri-leaves [i1-acute] besprent;/ (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/157)

tawse¶

n.

TURNBULL "Had a tawse hung up; that talked if I wanted discipline." "I'll neither tawse nor talk," said Angus. (1935,Happy Voyage,240)

AYSON The Teacher deemed it wise next day to try the effect of his tawse upon the palms that had tied the flaxen knots. (1937,Thomas,16)

tax-cart¶

n.

The pack-saddle over the hill and the tax-cart from the foot of it to Christchurch are wretched makeshifts . (Aug 22, 1857,Lyttelton Times,4)

taxing¶

n. gangs' recovery of losses from drug-dealings

[Hdg] Nomads jailed for drug 'taxing'.... Justice Goddard said it was the type of organised criminal activity, known as taxing, that happened when people tried to retrieve perceived losses when drug deals went wrong. (Apr 24, 2004,Dominion Post,A4)

TB shelter¶

n. treatment centre for tuberculosis patients

Many other venues were visited, including the Oakley Mental Hospital (as it was then known), the TB shelters in Epsom, the Veterans' Home, children's homes, and Mt Eden Prison. (Apr 2003,NZ Memories,No. 41/43)

TBC¶

abbr. Television Broadcasters' Council

"The Television Broadcasters' Council says that the public should be given a switch-off date to prepare them for the inevitable."... Ostensibly a lobby for all free-to-air networks including TV3 and Prime, the TBC is run by former TVNZ journalist and PR man Bruce Wallace. (Apr 28, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

TC¶

abbr. unfaithful woman; harlot [slang]

NEWBOLD TC (n) Unfaithful woman, harlot. (1982,Big Huey, The,255)

TCF¶

abbr. Telecommunication Carriers' Forum [ORIGIN: acronym]

The Telecommunications Carriers' Forum (TCF) plays a vital role in the New Zealand telecommunications industry by working collaboratively on the development of key industry standards and codes of practice that underpin the digital economy. The TCF works with a wide variety of industry participants and government agencies to promote competition and investment in the sector, accelerate the introduction of new generation services, and encourage excellence in customer service. (2010,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: tcf.org.nz]

tchaik¶

n. the Chatham Island taiko Pterodroma magentae [ORIGIN: Moriori]

Chatham Island Taiko Pterodroma magentae (GIGLIOLI & SALVADORI, 1868) ... However, this extremely rare bird is hardly ever seen. ... OTHER NAMES: Magenta petrel, tchaik of the Moriori. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,78)

... the most important [Chatham Island] edible sea-birds: AS WRITTEN AS PRONOUNCED ENGLISH hopo ho[macron]p' albatross hakoakoa ha[macron]ko[macron]k' mutton bird taiko tchai[macron]k' pied shear water tupoupou tchu[macron]poup' pied blue billie reoreo ro[macron]ro[macron] Mother Carys chicken turiwati tchu[macron]riwat' dottrel [sic] kuaka ku[macron]k' snipe Notes 1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs 358 (1928,Bishop's Guide to Wellington,Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 358)

tchakat henu¶

n. people of the land, tangata whenua [ORIGIN: Moriori]

[The Moriori Trust] grew out of the unification of Te Iwi Moriori Trust Board and Tchakat Henu Association of Rekohu Trust (tchakat henu means tangata whenua in Moriori). (Jul 10, 2004,Dominion Post,E6)

tchakat Mai-hor-r¶

phr. the form used frequently by Baucke for Moriori

SKINNER & BAUCKE Unlike the Maori, the Moriori had no name for his race. When questioned, he answered: tchakat Mai-hor-r.' This not having the assonance of Maori speech, this purist changed it totangata Moriori' (Moriori man); by which name the race became known to common use. (1928,BP Bishop Memoirs,9(5):357) [NOTES: 1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 357]

TCR¶

abbr. Territorial Customary Right

But there was concern at how a finding in the High Court of a Territorial Customary Right (TCR) would be given effect, and Government MPs were looking at ways to give the courts some guidelines. A TCR is a collection of customary rights that would have amounted to full customary and fee simple title if the new law had not asserted Crown ownership. (Nov 5, 2004,Dominion Post,A2)

TCS¶

abbr. The Correspondence School (See Correspondence School)

The bags - which have been in use since The Correspondence School (TCS) started in 1922 - are a quaint reminder of a pastoral, low-tech New Zealand that has faded quickly in the past two decades... Eight in 10 of TCS's secondary students are dual-enrolled, and 98 per cent of New Zealand's secondary schools use the service. (May 8, 2004,Dominion Post,A12)

Te Aho Matua¶

phr. a philosophy developed for 'kura' schools [ORIGIN: Maori, (from glossary at educationcounts.edcentre.govt.nz) Te Aho Matua is a philosophy specifically developed for 'kura' schools. Te Aho Matua describes the principles for operation and for teaching in kura. (literally 'the main line'?)]

Te reo Maori and an understanding of the philosophy of Te Aho Matua are required. (Nov 16, 2005,Dominion Post,E14)

te ano o te raiona¶

phr. the den of the lion (parliament) [ORIGIN: Maori]

We know that Parliament is perceived as a place of conflict and struggle as it is evident in how our people refer to the institution with terms such as * Te ana o te raiona - the den of the lion. * Te mura o te ahi - a reference to the flash of fire on a battlefield. * Te waha o te taniwha - the mouth of the taniwha. (Dec 2, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,6)

te ao hurihuri¶

phr. [ORIGIN: Maori, hurihuri = unstable, volatile (P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 62)]

Maori Liaison - Palliative Services .. and feel confident in moving between 'te ao Maori' and 'te ao hurihuri', then you may be exactly what we are looking for. (Oct 25, 2006,Wairarapa News,E10)

te ao Maori¶

phr. the Maori world [ORIGIN: Maori, cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 30.]

Grace 'You, you're stuck there in among all the home politics where you can't even fart without everyone knowing and having an opinion. You, getting the people their fish but not knowing what else is going on in Te Ao Maori.' (2001,Dogside Story,179)

.. and feel confident in moving between 'te ao Maori' and 'te ao hurihuri', then you may be exactly what we are looking for. (Oct 25, 2006,Dominion Post,E10)

te ao Pakeha¶

phr. the Pakeha world [ORIGIN: Maori]

"Every story I have heard of them is that they were honourable gentlemen, steeped in tikanga and matauranga Maori and well equipped in te ao Pakeha. ..." (Nov 25, 2005,Dominion Post,A2)

Te Araroa¶

n. [ORIGIN: Maori]

The [walkway] in Belmont Regional Park is part of the national Long Pathway, or Te Araroa, the length of New Zealand. (Jan 19, 2006,Wellingtonian,14)

Te Arawa¶

n. (iwi)

They are one of the senior tribes of Te Arawa.. because they descend directly from the tohunga, Ngatoroirangi, who performed super-hero feats such as saving the Arawa canoe from being lost in a whirlpool on the trip from Hawaiiki. (Feb 1998,Mana,No. 20: 21)

DUFF [Sir Charles Bennett] grew up in Maketu, where the Te Arawa canoe landed in the Great Migration, home of the Te Arawa tribe, place of bountiful seafood. (2000,Maori Heroes,19)

Te Ariki¶

n. in Christian contexts, The Lord (cf. Te Atua)

BAXTER Te Ariki the Lord (1982,Selected Poems,188)

Te Atua¶

n. God (cf. Te Ariki) [ORIGIN: Maori]

BAXTER Te Atua God (1982,Selected Poems,188) [NOTES: Glossary]

Te Horo spuds¶

n. (informal) (See local turnips)

Enjoy your new patch of dirt/sand/Te Horo spuds! (Nov 9, 2006,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.nzairgunners.com/nzairgunforum/archive/index.php/t-871.html]
