The question of what to do with all these stones, known affectionately as Te Horo spuds or local turnips, has been around a long time. (Feb 4, 2006,Dominion Post,E9)

Te Ika a Maui¶

n. the traditional Maori name for the North Island (occasionally in former use for New Zealand as a whole), literally 'the fish of Maui. [ORIGIN: Maori]

In present-day use Aotearoa is the accepted Maori name of the whole country and the North Island is Te Ika a Maui (Maui's fish). However, just as Aotearoa was used in the past of the North Island, so Te Ika a Maui has occasionally referred to the whole country. When Maori activist Titewhai Harawira went to the Netherlands in 1990.. she was reportedly advocating Te Ika a Maui and not Aotearoa as an indigenous replacement. (Oct 2000,NZWords,4 : 2)

There are some small difference [sic] in the Language spoke by the Aehei-no mouweans and those of Tovy poe nammu but this difference seem'd to me to be only in the pronunciation and is no more than what we find between one part of England and other: ... (Mar 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/288,1955 ed.) [NOTES: (Te Ika a Maui-an);North Island(er) 1773 Cook Journal 2/68 -->[see kumara]]

BAKER (1941,NZ Slang,59)

Te Ika a Maui n. the Fish of Maui, the N. Is. of N.Z. [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

Chants that emphasized the points of a weighty speech in the runanga-house, short ditties that maidens carolled forth about the pa, war songs that fired the hearts of warriors on the march-these were heard through the length and breadth of Te Ika-a-Maui, Maori poets vieing one with another to compose songs suitable for the occasion. (1953,Te Ao Hou,6: 18) [NOTES: Royal Tour number]

Te Kakahu skink¶

n. (Environment) a very smooth chestnut-coloured skink known only from specimens found on the Te Kakahu, or Chalky, Island in Fiordland in 2002. [Oligosoma "Te Kakahu"]

Te Kakahu skink: Discovered in 2002 on an island in Fiordland. Found only in one small area of low, open vegetation at the top of a cliff. Has distinct colour pattern differences to other species and different scale counts. (Aug 2, 2004,Dominion Post,A4)

Te Kawana¶

n.

Over the doorway hung a banner inscribed "Te Kawana" (the Governor). (May 29, 1912,Otago Witness,33)

The bewildered old Maori stood there watching the retreating cloud of dust that contained the "Kawana". (Aug 10, 1912,NZ Free Lance,4)

The women all wore green wreaths of willow, expressive of their regret at the departure of the "Kawana." (Mar 29, 1873,Auckland Weekly News)

Te Keke Tini¶

n. [The stadium in Wellington, ie the Cake Tin.]

Nevertheless, the games I saw on TV were excellent, especially the upsets, and the costumes worn by the good-natured crowd at Te Keke Tini were wonderful. (Feb 13, 2012,Dominion Post)

Sporting Basil best game at the stadium (Te Keke Tini): First equal: South Africa v Wales and France v Tonga, Rugby World Cup. (Dec 26, 2011,Dominion Post)

Te Kuiti Group¶

n. Geol. defn.

The northern three quarters of the peninsular is underlain by undeformed, northeast-dipping, massive to crudely bedded glauconitic sandstone (Ruatangata Sandstone, Te Kuiti Group, Runangan-early Whaingaroan) known from drillholes to be over 129 m and possibly up to 300 m thick (Fig. 2; Ferrar 1925 p. 43). (Aug 1989,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,85/19)

Te Mangai¶

n. Ratana

CHAPPLE Ratana became Te Mangai, the mouthpiece of God, and he divided his farmland and gifted it to his followers the morehu, the tribal fragments. (2002,Te Araroa: the New Zealand Trail,119)

Te Mangai Paho¶

phr. the Maori broadcasting funding body

This is Iti in his element: 15 hours a week on the Te Mangai Paho-funded Auckland radio station to rark up listeners, spread his word, and blast techno music through the traditional waiata for the hell of it. (Oct 21, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),64)

Take the example of Te Mangai Paho, the agency that funds Maori broadcasting and shapes its development. (Feb 22, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

Te Mangai Paho, the Maori broadcasting funding authority, is committed to promoting te reo Maori and does not allocate any funds to programmes in English. (May 20, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

Te Maori¶

n. international exhibition of Maori art

The exhibition Te Maori showed New Yorkers a vision of life that was totally foreign to them, yet strangely exciting... Te Maori is an example of a culture reaching out internationally through the medium of art. (Aug 16, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),75)

te mura o te ahi¶

phr. the flash of the fire (parliament) [ORIGIN: Maori]

We know that Parliament is perceived as a place of conflict and struggle as it is evident in how our people refer to the institution with terms such as * Te ana o te raiona - the den of the lion. * Te mura o te ahi - a reference to the flash of fire on a battlefield. * Te waha o te taniwha - the mouth of the taniwha. (Dec 2, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,6)

Te Papa¶

n. The Museum of NZ; previously the Dominion Museum, then National Museum of New Zealand

The heads will be brought direct to Te Papa, where they will be stored in a wahi tapu (sacred vault). (Jul 2, 1998,Dominion,1)

It was gimmicky, nostalgic, significant in a Te Papa kind of way. (Jan 22, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),63)

The Te Papa white elephant and the proposed new ministerial palace are prime examples of their [sc. the government's] largesse. (May 30, 1997,Independent (Auckland),22)

It was well-known trhat Clark, responding partly to a snotty review by Theodore Dalrymple in the.. New Statesman (he called Te Papa "the MTV of museums ... a temple to the short attention span"), helped to generate Te Papa's reinvention. (Dec 1, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),51)

When Defence Minister Max Bradford visited the [East Timor] base, he was greeted with a sign proclaiming "Kiwi Compound"' the words illustrated with a kiwi and a taiaha (long club). Below was scribbled "Te Papa" - apparently to drum into the Aussies that it wasn't their place. (Oct 1, 1999,Dominion,8)

The purpose of the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa is to provide a forum for the nation to present, explore and preserve the heritage of its cultures and knowledge of the natural environment in order better to understand and treasure the past, enrich the present and meet the challenges of the future. (Jul 1990,Architecture NZ,31) [NOTES: There is an earlier report in NZ Museums Journal 22(2) : 191-20]

"Strategic plan" covers everything from Te Papa to tap-dancing. (Aug 5, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),37)

Te Papa-ised¶

adj.

Because even the Te Papa-ised type inspires dread in the hearts of the uninitiated in a way that theatres or opera houses don't seem to anymore. (Apr 28, 1999,Capital Times,5)

Thomson is best known for work like his now Te Papa-ised corrugated iron-covered stationwagon, and stampeding herds of elephants and broods of chickens. (Dec 17, 2000,Sunday Star Times,D13)

Te Papa-ite¶

n. an admirer of the Te Papa museum

If bright lights, computers, push buttons, taped narratives and startling juxtapositions.. are your scene, then you're probably a Te Papa-ite. (Apr 2000,North & South,48)

Te Papaism¶

n.

True to currently fashionable Te Papaism, he mistakes crowd attendance for a measure of intellectual and artistic quality. (Aug 2000,NZ Books,2)

Te Puku o Te Whenua¶

phr. The Maori electorate for the Central North Island

There's a toss-up in Te Puku o Te Whenua between Rino and Rana. And Peter may make it too. (Jun 1996,Mana,No.13: 22)

Te Puni Kokiri¶

phr. the Ministry of Maori Development

I came across this ad in a magazine while waiting for my order at the Chinese takeaway on the corner of the road that leads to our local Maori bacon factory, Te Kuni Porkery. (Jan 2002,Cuisine,No. 90 : 266) [NOTES: Tom Frewen]

Legislation is being drafted to allow Te Puni Kokiri, Ministry of Maori Development, to conduct audits of Government agencies on meeting their commitment to close the gaps between Maori and non-Maori... TPK wanted wider monitoring functions. (Oct 5, 2000,Evening Post,2)

Thse new bodies will function alongside Te Puni Kokiri (TPK), the bureaucracy already supposed to monitor whether government is responsive to Maori needs... "The responsibility for these commissions is going to be directly to me, not to TPK." (Feb 8, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

Te Rauparaha¶

n.

MILLER In the Ngati Toa pa there was great indignation, and Te Rauparaha, their fighting chief, gathering together a war party, surprised and killed Te Uira and anothee Waikato chief, Te Aomarama. Ibid. 18 The acquisition of firearms from the whalers and flax-traders at Kapiti encouraged Te Rauparaha to embark on the conquest of the South Island. The story of these raids constitutes a perfect Iliad. (1958,Early Victorian NZ,16)

Te Reinga¶

n. the place (Cape Reinga at the far northern tip of the North Island) in Maori tradition from where the spirits of the dead are believed to enter the next world. [ORIGIN: Maori] (See Reinga)

Ihimaera This was the time when Maori believed that the spirits of the dead began their long voyage to Te Reinga. There, at the northernmost tip of Aotearoa, they waited for the sun to go down. (2000,Uncle's Story, The,109)

te reo¶

phr. the Maori language [ORIGIN: Maori, [Ma. te the (indicates singular)] [Ma. reo voice. language, speech, audio] cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 217.]

Text came to play a greater role during this period, too - Maori text that left Pakeha viewers like me groping for their te reo dictionaries. (Sep 23, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

And not only does Hapeta deliver hits such as "E Tu" with increased power and confidence, but also his te reo rhymes roll far more readily off his tongue. (Nov 23, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

We have to keep [Maori TV] bilingual or else the te reo nazis will capture it. (Mar 27, 2004,Dominion Post,E3)

Te Ropu Maori¶

phr. the Maori group or party [ORIGIN: Maori, see Ryan 224] (See roopu,ropu)

The students were taught a haka powhiri (or greeting) which is a traditional Maori performance by six of the members of Te Ropu Maori group. (2005,Internet - see Notes,0) [NOTES: http://www.bbc.co.uk/cambridgeshire/out_about/2003/07/whale_rider.shtml Accessed on 09/01/2006. true date of writing unknown.]

Translated as, say, "Te Ropu Maori", the party name would be a less effective marketing tool than the English version. (Aug 31, 2005,Dominion Post,B5)

Te Ropu Maori, the new Maori channel on the Alcohol Advisory Council's website, has been designed to support Maori communities working on health and substance abuse issues. (2005,Internet - see Notes,ADA Newsletter Volume 2, Number 2) [NOTES: http://www.adanz.org.nz/content/documents/14/news2.pdf Accessed 09/01/2006. Date of writing unknown, 2005 a substitute.]

Te Tai Hauauru¶

phr. The Maori electorate for Auckland and south to Taranaki

Another interesting tussle will be for Tai Hauauru which stretches from Mokau to the Manukau Harbour. (Jun 1996,Mana,No.13: 22)

Te Tai Rawhiti¶

phr. The East Coast Maori electoral district

Te Tai Tokerau¶

phr. a grouping of NI iwi; a Maori electorate covering Northland

I suppose Tai Tokerau want to be here - it's [sc. Waitangi] their marae after all. (Feb 28, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10)

Tau Henare should win Tai Tokerau. (Jun 1996,Mana,No.13: 22)

Te Tai Tonga¶

phr. The Maori electorate for Wellington Province and the South Island

Te Teko-ite¶

n. a resident of Te Teko

What about Te Teko-ites lives? (Nov 15, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,2)

te tuhi whakaniko¶

phr. painting [ORIGIN: Maori, whakaniko: decorative curves (Ryan)]

A three-year degree programme covering five different aspects of Maori art including: Weaving (raranga), Carving (whakairo), Painting (te tuhi whakaniko), Architecture (whaihanga), and Body Art (ta moko). (Dec 2, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,10)

te waha o te taniwha¶

phr. the mouth of the taniwha (parliament) [ORIGIN: Maori]

We know that Parliament is perceived as a place of conflict and struggle as it is evident in how our people refer to the institution with terms such as * Te ana o te raiona - the den of the lion. * Te mura o te ahi - a reference to the flash of fire on a battlefield. * Te waha o te taniwha - the mouth of the taniwha. (Dec 2, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,6)

Te Wahi Pounamu¶

n.

The name Te Wahi Pounamu'</i>, orlocality of greenstone', which they gave to the South Island, points in this direction. (1898,TrNZI,30/554)

Te Wai Pounamu¶

n. the South Island [also Te Waipounamu]

For the five weeks it took to feel their way around Te Wai Pounamu, Banks only had wistful glances of the landscape he so dearly wanted to explore and botanise. (Jul 18, 2004,Sunday Star Times: Escape,11)

BAUCKE Pounamu' (greenstone) was only to be found in the creeks of the inland ranges of [40] the Middle Island, and hence calledTe wai pounamu.' (1905,Where the White Man Treads,39) [NOTES: [kept in 1928 edn p.39]]

COWAN This volume ... is descriptive of the varied landscapes of the South Island, more particularly the alpine, lake and fiord scenery for which the Wai-Pounamu is famous. (1926,Travel in NZ,(Vol II South Island) i(Preface))

HINGSTON So you land on the shores of the Te Wai Pounuma (the water of green-stone), the middle island of New Zealand ... (1879,Australian Abroad, The,292)

Inspired by his favourite pepeha - "Do not die a rotting death like mine, but instead pass from this world via the fragrant ovens of a battlefield" - Te Radar set out to find and tell stories about some of Te Wai Pounamu's unsung, often unhinged, heroes. (Aug 20, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

Te Waipounamu¶

n. the South Island [aka Te Wai Pounamu; cf. Te Ika a Maui]

The old Maori-myth names of the islands Eaheinomawe and Tavai Poinammoo, as Cook calls them, or Ika-na-mawe and Tavai-Pounamu as D'Urville more correctly calls them, still disfigure many maps, but are utterly obsolete for all practical purposes. (Oct 21, 1874,Timaru Herald,8)

This man spoke of three lands the two above mentioned which he called Tovy-poenammu which signifies green/Talk or stone such as the[y] Make [sic] their tools on, oramints [sic] etc. ... (Jan 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/243)

There are some small difference [sic] in the Language spoke by the Aehei-no mouweans and those of Tovy poe nammu but this difference seem'd to me to be only in the pronunciation and is no more than what we find between one part of England and other: ... (Mar 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/288,1955 ed.)

FORSTER The whole southern extremity of Tavai-poe-namoo, or the southern island of New Zeeland, ... [145] consists entirely of steep rocky mountains ... (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/144)

On leaving Tavia [?typological error] Poenammoo, or the Middle Island, I was forcibly struck with the bleak and savage appearance of its chain of mountains ... Ibid. 112 DECLARATION of Sovereignty over Tavai Poenammoo. This island, called Tavai Poenammoo or Middle Island of New Zealand ... was accordingly taken possession of ... and Her Majesty's colours hoisted at the paa of Hoiakaka, Cloudy Bay ... (1841,GBPP,(No.311) 109) [NOTES: 1840 June 28 Thomas Bunbury's Report in GBPP House of Commons 1841]

WAKEFIELD The natives procure ... quantities of a green jade, or serpentine, much prized by them for [314] the purpose of making war-clubs ... It is called by them Ponamu', whence the name once assigned to the Middle Island - <i>Te Wahi Ponamu' or, `The Place of Green Stone'. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,313)

SHORTLAND The name Tovy Poenammoo, or, as it would [155] now be written, Te Wai-pounamu, meaning the Pounamu-water, by many still imagined to be that of the Middle Island, is, as Captain Cook suspected, `only the name of a particular place, where the natives got the green talc, or stone, of which they made their ornaments and tools, and not a general name of the whole southern district.' (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,154)

Dissatisfied younger sons, ambitious women or slighted elders sought redress by force of arms or went into [72] the open spaces of Aotearoa or Tewaipounamu. Our Courts recognised the arikiship in the award of shares in land ... (Mar 22, 1933,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/71) [NOTES: Ngata]

`Te Waipounamu' as the name for the South Island [Maori context] (Mar 1985,TV1) [NOTES: Maori News]

".. He killed all the tribes of Kapiti, and he also crossed over to Te Waipounamu (the Southern Island), destroying all the people " (Apr 24, 1875,Colonist (Nelson),3)

When Captain Cook asked what was the name of the Middle Island, he was told "Te Wahi Pounamu," or "The Place of the Greenstone," which was got most plentifully there, and on the old maps the Middle Island is named "Tarai Pounamu." (Jun 13, 1866,Daily Southern Cross,3)

"We have received .. a copy of Tepuki o Matariki (the Pleiades) 'the official gazette of the independent Royal Maori power of Aotearoa,' dated Maungakawa, Waikato, 12th April 1894, giving notice to the hapus and tribes of New Zealand from the tail to the head of Maui's fish, crossing the Sea of Raukawa (Cook Strait) to Te Waipounamu, that the following laws have been adopted by the Maori Kauhanganui (convention) and assented to by King Potatau Tawhiao under his royal seal and sign manual." (Jun 7, 1894,Otago Witness,22)

Te Whiti¶

n. [(attrib. uses)]

Mabel and I called on Wi Te Tahuhu ... and saw some 2000 tuna drying. ... I think there will be quite 20,000 eels in all for Te Whiti. Piripiri and Pene took a large contract from me[word missing???] fencing. They gave their word as Te Whiti men but would not sign an agreement. (Feb 12, 1885,Chudleigh Diary,332,1950 ed.)

In Wellington. It is settled that Major Gudgeon, a sargeant and six A.C. [Richards's note: Artillery Corps] go to the Chathams .. to run in the Te Whiti Maoris. (Sep 3, 1889,Chudleigh Diary,367,1950 ed.)

I do not know whether you heard the story about a Nelson woman beseeching Mr. Mackay to give up the pakehas and go and live at Parihaka, for Te Whiti had told his people that all the Europeans would be destroyed, and she begged her old friend to embrace Te Whiti-ism while there was yet time. (May 10, 1879,Taranaki Herald,2)

Te Ua is now never mentioned, Te Whiti and Te Tou, of Taranaki, formerly slaves of the Waikatos, being the fancied prophets of God. (Jun 20, 1867,Daily Southern Cross,3)

It is as well to mention here that Te Whiti (who was one of the few who embraced Hauhauism) has recently been studying the scriptures, consequently he scarcely uttered a sentence at the meeting without quoting from the bible. (Mar 26, 1870,Taranaki Herald,2)

At the district Court to-day, John Stitt of Opunake, filed a petition asking that Te Whiti, the Parihaka Chief, should be declared a bankrupt. (Jul 14, 1891,Marlborough Express,2)

Te Whiti, the Parihaka chief, died this morning at 5 o'clock, aged 78. (Nov 18, 1907,Hawera & Normanby Star,4)

Te Whiti-ism¶

n.

COWAN In Taranaki the adherents of Te Whiti-ism - quite a different brand of old-time religion from the Ringatu - have their monthly meetings for prayer and exhortation at Manu-korihi, on the Waitara. (1930,Maori, The,66)

RICHARDS Rev. Croasdaile Bowen came in '76 but was unable to do much as Te Whiti-ism had such a grip of the Islanders. (1952,Chatham Islands,121)

Buck, going to Te Aute from a boyhood in Taranaki, where the missions had given way to Pai Marire and Te Whitism, was pleasantly surprised at the strength of Anglicanism among the East Coast Maoris. (1986,Na To Hoa Aroha,1/14)

I do not know whether you heard the story about a Nelson woman beseeching Mr. Mackay to give up the pakehas and go and live at Parihaka, for Te Whiti had told his people that all the Europeans would be destroyed, and she begged her old friend to embrace Te Whiti-ism while there was yet time. (May 10, 1879,Taranaki Herald,2)

There is a likeness of the late Wi Parata, M.H.R., of Waikanae, a man who did much for Te Whitism, one of Waharepouri in the act of handing over to the New Zealand Company the land about Port Nicholson. (Nov 22, 1907,Star, The,1)

If instead of year after year fostering those Parihaka meetings the Government had boldly pushed on the coast road by an armed force if necessary, Te Whitiism would have been a thing of the past; but so long as the Government ask for permission to make a road through confiscated land, what can be expected from irrational and hostile natives but a distinct refusal and bouncable threats. (Jun 13, 1879,Taranaki Herald,2)

I cannot forget when Te Whitiism was rampant, and those who understood the native character best were in doubt from day to day what the result might be, you came forward like one man - not only you here but all throughout the district which I have the honor to command - for the purpose of preparing for the worst. (Feb 28, 1881,Taranaki Herald,2)

Te Whiti-ite¶

n. [aka Te Whitiite]

RICHARDS The Rev. P. Anderson also baptised several white children and one Maori child. All the other Maori families were Te Whiti-ites. (1952,Chatham Islands,124)

They seem to be anxiously expecting the return of Rangi Paunanga, the head man of the Te Whitiites, but he refused to return as long as one man remains in gaol. (Jun 8, 1881,Nelson Evening Mail,2)

She was a kindly old lady and very hospitable, but a strong Te Whitiite. (Jul 9, 1881,Wanganui Herald,2)

"It reads as though during the past twenty-four years only 150 Te Whiti-ites have returned to the Church, whereas the number would be nearer 1500, and as though only one church had been built during that time ..." (May 9, 1905,Wanganui Herald,5)

He was a chief of considerable importance and a staunch Te Whiti-ite, having consistently refused to accept any rent. (Dec 16, 1893,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

Te Whitism¶

n. (See Te Whiti-ism)

Defendant used to preach to the people, and he believed that she had endeavored to get the people to abstain from drink and the children and women from smoking; did not know if she used to try and get people away from Te Whitism. (Sep 23, 1910,Hawera & Normanby Star,6)

The Christian religion recently found a strong defender in a North Island Maori, who had been converted from Te Whitism. (Apr 19, 1899,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

te-farre¶

n. (See whare)

te-matau kauri¶

n. (See tumatakuru)

tea¶

n. a full meal, dinner

My girlfriend almost did get presented with `a plate' (empty), when she asked me to meet some folks at her place for dinner - whoops, sorry tea. (1989,Chosen Place,22)

Papa has brought home a gentleman, Colonel Lorrimer, and we are to wait tea for them... You say you have not had tea yet. Ask Grace to wait ten minutes. (Jan 16, 1890,Otago Witness,42)

"Such a splendid walk!" said the two young men. "And such a nice, early tea, "said Grace ironically, "for I am sure Mabel has lit the fire and put the kettle on. " (Jan 16, 1890,Otago Witness,42)

TEA¶

abbr. Tasman Empire Airways [ORIGIN: acronym] (See TEAL)

A likely alternative for T.E.A. is to take over nearby yacht buildings as temporary passenger handling accommodation. (Jul 29, 1950,Dominion,8)

tea billy¶

n.

BELL (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,7) [NOTES: ... his swag generally contained some [eatables] that, with the help of the ever-present tea-billy which he carried, could supply a meal if necessary.]

COWAN [In the year 1873] they observed that the tea-billy was upturned on the fire, things were in general disorder, and Sullivan and Jones were missing. (1922,NZ Wars, The,2/515,1983 ed.)

tea break¶

n. (political allusion) (See cup of tea,cuppa)

1988 Dominion 26 Aug. 8 We are invited by Mr Lange, the chief architect of our adversity, to pause and take tea... A tea break is not going to solve anything. (Aug 26, 1988,Dominion,8)

Apparently the job has been done and it is simply a matter of lying back, waiting for the good times to roll again and taking the tea break of a lifetime. (Sep 22, 1993,Evening Post,2)

[Hdg] Time for 'tea break' in claims process - historian. It is time for the Government to stop for a cup of tea in the Maori claims settlement process, according to eminent historian Alan Ward. (May 12, 1999,Dominion,7)

Just as in 1988, when Prime Minister Lange announced a "tea break", the mood is "put the kettle on, mum". (Mar 24, 1996,Sunday Star Times,C2)

The Government's failure to press ahead with economic reforms had turned a "tea break" into an extravagant long lunch that was threatening the economy while favouring the rich. (Jul 27, 1997,Sunday Star Times,D4)

When David Lange made his remark in 1988 about the country needing to stop for a "teabreak" from the task of economic reform, he probably had no idea that his metaphor would enter the national vocabulary. (Aug 1, 1997,Independent (Auckland),11)

In calling a tea-break in order to defend Labour's social goals, Mr Lange effectively delivered government into the hands of the "natural enemy". (Feb 26, 1995,Sunday Star Times,C2)

tea fight¶

n. [cf. bunfight]

I have passed without serious injury through a terrific tea fight at Mr Woodward's ... (Aug 12, 1866,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/121) [NOTES: (H.R. Richmond)]

SEDDON "Tea fights" were church events of great interest to growing boys. The womenfolk of the congregation vied with each other in producing appetising arrays of home-made cakes. These were displayed with the best family china and linens on tables in a hall and were consumed with copious cups of tea by a paying public. (1968,Seddons, The,32)

tea plant¶

n. = tea-tree (cf. New Zealand tea = manuka Leptospermum scoparium )

HAWKESWORTH (1769,Voyages) [NOTES: 1769 Hawkesworth Voyages, Cook etc (And)]

COOK (And) (1773,Voyage Towards the South Pole,1779 ed.)

of Cooper: `... began to make Beer from a Tree of a Rosinish quality intermixt with the Tea Plant [fn] ... Tea plant Manuka L. scoparium Ibid. 2/138 The Tea Plant is a shruby tree which grows on dry soil near the shores, it bears a small leafe of which this [...] is the natural size, small white flowers and small [cones] which contain the seeds ... . [It is also] a substitute for tea, this we found out last voyage ... . (1773,Cook's Journals,2/114 [fn],1961 ed.)

BELL The Tea plant we found in plenty and mix'd it with the Spruce in Brewing. (Nov 1791,Journal of Voyage in HMS 'Chatham',50)

NICHOLAS On the hills we saw some of the myrtle species, but the tea-plant, so common in Otaheite, and said to grow here, [233] and from which the natives of that island extract a spirituous liquor, we could not meet with it in the progress of our excursion. (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/232)

There are many shrubs with myrtle-leaves. The tea-plant, kaikatoa [a2-acute], covers the plains, ... Ibid. 2/394 The Kaikatoa, [a2,a3-acute] (Philadelphus Australis,) a polyanthus, called the tea plant from its leaves possessing the same myrtiform character. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/293)

BARNICOAT ... tea plant. (1842,Journal,46)

BURTON Captain Cook, who had dubbed it [manuka] teaplant', wroteThe leaves were used by many of us as tea, which has a very agreeable bitter taste and flavour when they are recent ... ` (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,18)

We were glad to land and breathe in the first little bay which presented itself in the beautiful beach which surrounds the lower end of the lake; to squat upon a patch of green sward - not grass, but the Maori tea-plant; and to solace ourselves with scraps from the "shrunk shanks" of the larder. (Dec 13, 1867,Otago Daily Times,4)

tea shrub¶

n. manuka, tea-tree

... finding that the decoction of Spruce alone made the Beer to [sic] astringent we mixed with it an equal quantity of the Tea plant. ... we first made a strong decoction of the leaves of small branches of the Spruce tree & [sic] Tea shrub. (May 11, 1773,Cook's Journals,2/37)

... finding that the decoction of Spruce alone made the Beer to [sic] astringent we mixed with it an equal quantity of the Tea plant. ... we first made a strong decoction of the leaves of small branches of the Spruce tree & [sic] Tea shrub. (May 11, 1773,Cook's Journals,2/37)

COLENSO ... close growing Tee shrubs and briars. (1841,Journal,1/119)

tea-boy¶

n. [1989 Nov 7 W.P. Jeffries MP 9.45pm ... tea-boy ...]

tea-broom¶

n. manuka, (tea-tree) [see also tea plant, tea shrub]

DOMETT Manuka [a1 acute] ... The settlers often call it `tea-broom'. (1872,Ranolf and Amohia,505 [notes])

DOMETT Ma'nuka .... O. Myrtaceae; G. Leptospermum; S. or L. ericoides. A large shrub or small tree; leaves used as tea in Tasmania and Australia, where the plant is equally abundant.' In the poem it is called indiscriminately manuka, broom, broom-like myrtle, or leptosperm. The settlers often call ittea-broom.' (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/303)

MORRIS Tea-broom, n. a New Zealand name for the Tea-tree (q.v.). [Domett 1872] (1898,Austral English,463)

We were glad to land and breathe in the first little bay which presented itself in the beautiful beach which surrounds the lower end of the lake; to squat upon a patch of green sward - not grass, but the Maori tea-plant; and to solace ourselves with scraps from the "shrunk shanks" of the larder. (Dec 13, 1867,Otago Daily Times,4)

In the poem it is called indiscriminately manuka, broom, broom-like myrtle, or leptosperm. The settlers often call it "tea-broom." (Jul 18, 2011,Evening Post,19)

tea-can¶

n.

HALL-JONES Boiling our flesh or fowl in our tea-can (called a billy) ... (1971,Mr Surveyor Thomson,60) [NOTES: 1850s in 1971 Hall-Jones Mr Surveyor Thomson 60]

tea-leaf¶

n. thief; to thieve, general English slang recorded in NZ from at least the 1970s (G. McEwen, Auckland; and HNZD

NEWBOLD Ralphie used to tealeaf anything that wasn't tied down. Ibid. 180 A tealeaf is just a cunt in my eyes . . . You're a peter thief and you're a dog. Ibid. 255 THIEF (n) and (v) Thief, steal. (1982,Big Huey, The,148)

a tea-leaf confesses (Mar 22, 1982,Salient,15)

According to the Old Bill, three tea leafs went into the Willis Street shop on Tuesday about lunchtime, and while one kept the manager busy, the other two lifted four big ones from the till. ... Three people robbed Arthur Daley's Lockup of $400 on Tuesday. (Nov 15, 1986,Dominion)

tea-oh¶

exclam. tea's ready

McLINTOCK The back country runs have quite a vocabulary of their own ... terms like cow paddock and horse paddock and tea-oh and township which, like most of these terms, took on their special use in Australia. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/679) [NOTES: Wall NZ Speech]

I had not quite finished when the cook called out 'Tea-oh!' (Dec 20, 1928,Evening Post,8)

tea-pot¶

n. billy [[Swainson does not use billy]]

CHAPMAN Of course in these [bush] whares there are degrees of comfort and accommodation. In one tea is boiled in the kettle and drunk out of a pannikin: in another the tea is made in a tin teapot and drunk out of crockery. (Nov 24, 1874,Letters to His Father, 1843-1851,140) [NOTES: 1847 Nov 24 H.S. Chapman Letters to His Father [TS, ATB] in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 140]

SWAINSON A knife, fork, spoon, pannikin, tin plate, and tea-pot, form a sufficient yet not extravagant equipment [for the bush traveller]. (1853,Auckland,125)

tea-shower¶

n.

FRAME ... parcels from the handwork sale, tablerunners and tea-showers in lazy-daisy and chain and shadow stitch. (1958,Owls Do Cry,24,1958 ed.)

tea-tree¶

n. [nb tea-tree scrub, tea-tree bush, tea-tree brush are listed separately]

adj.

I saw the man in question take a tea-tree broom and place it against the full bags of sawdust. (May 4, 1867,Daily Southern Cross,5)

BARLOW Procuring a tea-tree stake about five feet long, he ... laid down a plan of attack. (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,91)

RICHARDS The earthen floor [of the nikau whare] would be kept clean with a tea tree broom. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,44)

A little old hut / With a hard clay floor, / A tea-tree broom just by the door. (Apr 11, 1944,Daily Southern Cross,10)

OWEN & PERKINS Before there was a ready supply of electricity the demand was for tea-tree firewood, and so we built up a constant trade. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,132)

New Zealand palings, 5-feet, 11s. to 12s.; 6-feet, 14s.; tea-tree rails, 42s. per 100 ... (Jun 26, 1869,Daily Southern Cross,3)

1 n. (Rural) a scrubby bush, manuka (Leptospernum spp), often used to add flavour to billy tea. [nb see also ti-tree, incl fig: in the tea-tree] (See ti-tree)

KIRK An infusion of the leaves is often used by bushmen as a substitute for tea: in all probability it owes its common name 'tea-tree' to its having been used for this purpose by early voyagers. (1889,Forest Flora,136)

The forests contain a mixture of trees of all kinds, from the giant akuri to scrubby tea-tree or manuka (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,2)

JOHNSTONE-SMITH Ti-tree was plentiful but tawa had to be snigged home from quite a distance. (1975,Battles, Buggies and Babies,42)

LOUGHNAN tea-tree: manuka (Leptospernum spp). Some people will slip a sprig of the leaves in whilst boiling up the tea billy as it gives a pleasantly piquant flavour. [ti-tree] (1981,Loughnan Glossary,84)

Puriri Posts, house blocks and firewood (puriri, tea-tree, matai and tarariri). (Sep 1907,Wairoa Bell & Northern Advertiser,[13])

Its Sputnik-like extremities become caught in a pink teatree. (Jul 2000,NZ Geographic,47/35)

The plant would be sure to take possession in a short time of land where fern and tea-tree grows [sic] (Mar 30, 1897,Bruce Herald,6)

The tea-tree country around Silverdale has been whiter than usual this season, and all the meadow flowers are earlier in bloom, writes a correspondent to the "New Zealand Herald." (Dec 4, 1922,Evening Post,6)

Despite her efforts to restrain him, he went into the tea-tree, from which she heard a shot. (Jun 6, 1944,Evening Post,6)

It comes out on a country covered with scrubby tea-tree, with a poor soil of sand and pumicestone. (May 10, 1873,Auckland Weekly News,20)

No hot water unless you go out an' cut a heap o' tea-tree. (Jun 18, 2000,NZ Catholic,7)

He saw a man's head in the tea-tree. (Jan 8, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,19)

You've got to get those stones really hot, so we burn tea-tree or other hard woods. (Jul 2004,AA Directions,Spring/28)

tea-tree brush¶

n.

MARKHAM The appearance [of the Kicaitore,kahikatoa]] is like what in Van diemans land is called Tea Tree Brush and it has a pretty Flower. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),33,1963 ed.)

Some of our party have been engaged in a swamp nearly to their middles, cutting tea-tree brush and rushes for roofing, and all have been busily occupied. (Sep 21, 1867,Daily Southern Cross,3)

tea-tree bush¶

n. manuka, tea-tree

FINLAYSON She slipped behind some tea-tree bushes and changed into the clean frock.. to be ready to go with Ripi to Rotorua in the service-car. (1938,Brown Man's Burden,58)

tea tree bush - man|nook [manuka] (1835,Boultbee Journal,110,1986 ed.) [NOTES: also 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 283]

Silk drove his second low through the fence into a small tea-tree bush on the near side of the road. (Apr 5, 1934,Evening Post,6)

A leather belt had been knotted round a tea-tree bush and one end was round the neck of the dead man. (Jan 18, 1945,Evening Post,4)

TENDERS WANTED, TO Clear from 20 to 40 acres of fern and teatree bush on Thos. Craig's farm, Wairoa river. (Sep 27, 1859,Daily Southern Cross,2)

The land is as good as any in the block, having natural grass, flax, fern, teatree bush, and a few kauri trees. (Oct 6, 1864,Daily Southern Cross,2)

In the middle of the terrace were the remains of a ti-tree bush, which was standing where a small patch of soil was still uncovered. (Jun 19, 1886,Evening Post,1)

The contractor for repairs to the baths is now about to commence work at the enclosure, the delay having been caused by the great difficulty in obtaining stakes of sufficient length and diameter for the job, the titree bush at Katikati being now about worked out of stuff of the sort required. (Dec 1, 1893,Bay of Plenty Times,4)

tea-tree country¶

1 n. (Rural) land that grows scrub and other forms of secondary growth.

The land I would apply it to is fairly new fern and tea-tree country, but has been in grass for a few years ... (Apr 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,323)

tea-tree jack¶

n. stick insect

SATCHELL [note] `Animated straws'. Sometimes the Straw or Teatree Straw Insect, usually the New Zealand Stick Insect or (formerly) Walking Stick Insect also known as the Teatree Jack, Acanthodemus horridus of Hudson (1892). Thin, segmented, attenuated fine legs; capable of camouflage by colour change. Satchell refers to this at the end of the paragraph. (1902,Land of the Lost,215) [NOTES: 1971 Smithyman in 1902 Satchell Land of the Lost 215]

GEE I launched ...pink and blue [paper] ships manned by spiders, caterpillars, beetles and small ti-tree jacks. [Auckland] (1972,In My Father's Den,16)

tea-tree scrub¶

n. [incl ti-tree scrub]

HENDERSON We'd dragged our way through the short hakea and tea-tree scrub covering the long flat. (1965,North & South,155)

BAINES Bush fashion. [page heading] ... He [the Northland sawmiller] wore what is called a blue shirt', that is, a sailor's shirt of serge, fitting very closely, and a pair of moleskin trousers, very much torn ... from walking through harsh fern andtea-tree' scrub, ... and a wideawake hat ... (1874,Edward Crewe,39)

Towards the latter river, which had no water in its bed, but chains of lagoons parallel to its banks, the creeks were lined by a dense tea-tree scrub, half a mild or more broad. (Jul 18, 1846,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,79)

On Friday, however, she was happily discovered in a ti-tree scrub near Mr. Bruchall's Remuera, safe, though doubtless in a state of exhaustion. (Jan 27, 1857,Daily Southern Cross,3)

There are at the present time some sixty prisoners in residence there, and the work of clearing the high tea-tree scrub, preparing the foundations for the central buildings, cultivating the cleared area, and making concrete blocks for the buildings yet to be erected, is proceeding apace. (Jun 8, 1914,Evening Post,2)

These deep bays are filled with fern and dwarfed ti-tree scrub. (Oct 5, 1925,Evening Post,9)

HOW many Aucklanders can remember the day that the first horse-drawn tram careered proudly down Hobson Street or the time when the now populous suburb of Grey Lynn was a desolate waste of ti-tree scrub? (Sep 18, 1930,NZ Truth,4)

Tea-tree scrub had in many places replaced the glorious bush of days gone by. (Jan 13, 1944,Evening Post,7)

For instance, there are six or seven acres near the Botanical Gardens without any means of access, except through titree scrub and gorse, although a road is surveyed, which would give a capital frontage to each of the sections. (Apr 22, 1890,Evening Post,4)

Each in turn led her about for a distance through the teatree scrub, and then admitted that "it was'nt [sic] the place at all." (Dec 29, 1904,Evening Post,6)

The town of Invercargill is well laid out ... When I was in it before - 16 years ago - the roads had on them tea tree scrub, and in some places wide planks, instead of stones, to prevent the traffic being bogged in the mud, and its footpaths were made of battens nailed across, and evidence of the old state of things still remain [sic] in some of the streets. (Aug 26, 1880,Timaru Herald,2)

tea-tree straw insect¶

n. stick insect, tea-tree jack

SATCHELL [note] `Animated straws'. Sometimes the Straw or Teatree Straw Insect, usually the New Zealand Stick Insect or (formerly) Walking Stick Insect also known as the Teatree Jack, Acanthodemus horridus of Hudson (1892). Thin, segmented, attenuated fine legs; capable of camouflage by colour change. Satchell refers to this at the end of the paragraph. (1902,Land of the Lost,215) [NOTES: 1971 Smithyman in 1902 Satchell Land of the Lost 215]

TEAC¶

abbr. Tertiary Education Advisory Commission

"Our advice to TEAC was we applaud any measures taken to encourage cooperative research in this country, especially between universities and CRIs, because as we are a small country excellence doesn't come out of one centre but every one." (Mar 20, 2002,NZ Education Review,2)

teacher aid¶

n.

I get a bit from music, and I work as a teacher aid part-time. Teacher-aiding is Scott's first brush with the world of work. (Jul 26, 2000,Capital Times,6)

teacher-only day¶

n. the first day of (esp. the first) term when only teachers (no children) attend school to prepare for the beginning of the tem [ca1987 p.c. L. Bauer: in Britain called in some places anoccasional day''.]

Teachers College¶

n. formerly (Teachers) Training College, and still colloquially referred to as Training College: a training institution for school-teachers; now COLLEGE OF EDUCATION [HNZD (1979) 1133: 'formerly called Training College - a training institution for teachers.']

SHADBOLT ... Ruia would go to Teachers' Training College at Auckland. (1959,New Zealanders, The,21,1986 ed.) [NOTES: (The Woman's Story)]

TURNER A New Zealand [trainee] teacher at a Teacher's College usually called Training college without specification, goes on section... (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,158)

teachers college NZ college for training school teachers. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,788) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

teak¶

n. in early New Zealand use, trees with teak-like wood, especially puriri and rata [usu. native, New Zealand teak; 1867 HNP, 1868 PPO (Native teak), 1919 W. Best (Otaki) Vernac. (Andersen, 7 entries)]

There are many reasons, says the author, influencing the choice of a name .. It may refer to its similarity to some other familiar plant: New Zealand oak, New Zealand ash, New Zealand teak. (Jul 27, 1926,Evening Post,6)

POLACK (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers)

HAY The Puriri (Vitex littoralis) is sometimes called teak', orironwood'. ... The timber is hard, heavy, very durable, very hard to work, and of a greenish colour. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/190)

MORRIS Teak, n. The original Teak is an East Indian timber-tree, Tectina grandis, but the name has been trasferred to other trees in different parts of the world, from a similarity in the hardness of their wood. ... In New Zealand, it is Vitex littoralis; Maori name, Puriri (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,463)

PYKE Rata (native teak or `ironwood' of the colonists). (1868,Province of Otago in NZ, The,34)

PYKE Metrosideros lucida native teak (1868,Province of Otago in NZ, The) [NOTES: (And)]

POLACK Metrosideros lucida native teak (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers) [NOTES: And)]

n. [black teal]

2 n. an old name for puriri [[1919 July 29] Ver.(WB). = Vernacular names used by settlers supplied by W.Best, Otaki (And) Vitex lucens New Zealand teak]

ANGAS33 The New Zealand teak (Vitex littoralis) grows near the sea, and produces a fine durable wood, which takes a fine polish, and is of great use in ship-building. (1866,Polynesia)

HOCHSTETTER Vitex lucens New Zealand teak (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter)) [NOTES: (And) (list of trees from Taylor 1848)]

Vitex lucens New Zealand teak (1871,TrNZI,3)

The Puriri, or New Zealand Oak, or Teak, (Vitex littoralis,) is a large tree of irregular growth. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/43) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

Vitex lucens New Zealand teak ..[15] [Puriri] has been appropriately styled the New Zealand teak:it is ... closely related to the Asiatic teak, and affords a timber of great density and durability, closely resembling lignum vitae in general appearance. (1875,Durability NZ Timbers) [NOTES: (And)]

[Native name] Puriri .. [Settlers' name] New Zealand teak .. [Family] Verbenaceae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

KIRK Vitex lucens New Zealand teak (1889,Forest Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

2 n.

2 n.

Vitex lucens puriri (1869,TrNZI,1) [NOTES: (And)]

The Black Teal are usually associated in small flocks ... (1872,TrNZI,4/208) [NOTES: (Travers NZ Birds)]

teakettle broth¶

n.

BURTON A `dish' known [during the Slump] as teakettle broth was sometimes a last resort, consisting simply of stale bread cut into cubes, sprinkled with salt and pepper and covered with boiling water. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,29)

teal¶

n.

A shipment of black ducks by the Cuzco are bringing 1s 9d each; teal, 10d; rabbits, 1s to 1s 2d, although a few of the latter are only realising 9d. (Apr 21, 1894,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

A point in natural history was raised at the Dunedin City Police, when Mr A. C. Hanlon, a well-known solicitor, demanded proof positive as to whether a teal was a wild duck, which he did not admit. (Sep 19, 1908,Thames Star,1)

HEAPHY The Paradise and common duck, teal, widgeon, water-hen, and diver [check cit punct] are all found in great numbers on the rivers ... (1842,Narrative of a Residence in Various Parts of NZ,47)

WAKEFIELD Teal, very like our English ones, are also common on the rivers and lakes. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,164)

POWER ... flocks find abundant pasture where, within the settler's memory, there was food only for bittern and teal. (1849,Sketches in NZ,203)

SWAINSON Pigeons, ducks, teal, and other water-fowl, abound; ... (1853,Auckland,120)

DRURY BIRDS MET WITH IN PELORUS ... Ducks of several kinds - Parera of the natives. Teal. Cormorants - several kinds .. (1855,Sailing Directions,66)

`My friend' .../ You like hapuku drying;/ Kapai the smelt, the duck, the eel,/ And shark when putrifying./ (Jul 1866,Canterbury Rhymes,85) [NOTES: 1860 July in 1866 Canterbury Rhymes 85 (The Maori's Choice)]

BUTLER Our teal is, if not the same as the English teal, so like it, that the difference is not noticeable. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,ix/137)

Grey ducks, Paradise ducks, (which are rather a species of geese) teal, and widgeon frequent the streams. ... Blue mountain-duck is found in the more elevated regions. (1868,Province of Otago in NZ, The,31)

BARLOW [At Kaipara] ... birds of various kinds, including duck, teal, shags eel-hawks [77], and flocks of godwit and red-shanked plover, added further life to the scene. (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,76)

... the light-eyed Teal slunk silently from view; or ... the little Grebe with rosy breast, dived and sported with restless activity; close by a group of sober Grey Ducks; whilst the watchful Paradise Drake basked on the sunny bank above ... Ibid. 2/72 ANAS CHLOROTIS, Gray. Puteke. Teal. (1870,TrNZI,2/47) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)[should be under BROWN TEAL???]]

WHITWORTH At the mouth of the river you might fill your boat with ... the blue, grey and paradise ducks, teal, ... and other birds ... (1879,Spangles and Sawdust,25)

HAY The species we have identified in the Kaipara and Hokianga are - the Putangi, or paradise-duck' (<i>Casarca variegata</i>); the grey duck, or Parera (<i>Anas superciliosa</i>); the brown duck, an allied species or variety of the last; the Papanga, orteal,' or `widgeon' (Fuligula N.Z.), and some other varieties that may be imported birds, or crosses, or other native species. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/225)

A few paradise ducks, usually in pairs, grey ducks and teal, and black swans, were seen on the tarns at Tarndale, and Lakes Guyon and Tennyson. (1884,TrNZI,17/355) [NOTES: (Park)]

I noticed the following:- Pigeon, tui, korimako, kaka, ruru, piwakawaka, toutouwai, kingfisher, duck and teal in the lakes, and pukeko in the swamp, and various sea birds. (1884,TrNZI,17/419) [NOTES: (Gold-Smith)]

BEATTIE On and around the [Central Otago] streams there were teal, grey duck, and the blue mountain duck, but the last-named was scarce. `I saw stilts, the black-fellows ... wading about ...' (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,120)

BEATTIE A moulting bird is called a mounu [sic: ?maunu], and at this season great numbers of paradise and grey ducks and teal were taken. (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,14)

Brown Teal Anas aucklandica (GRAY, 1844) ... OTHER NAMES: Pateke, brown duck, teal duck. ...DISTRIBUTION Brown teal: Great Barrier Island and Northland. Rare and isolated elsewhere. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,146)

The lake was covered with swarms of duck and teal, so tame that they allowed me to approach within a yard of them, without being in the least disturbed. (Sep 16, 1842,New Zealand Colonist & Port Nicholson Advertiser,4)

TEAL¶

abbr. (historical) Tasman Empire Airways Limited [ORIGIN: acronym] (See see also TEA)

[Ansett] put the cat among the pigeons when he offered to buy Teal (the international fore-runner of Air New Zealand) for GBP2 million. (Dec 6, 2000,Evening Post,24)

As the TEAL Lockheed Electra bringing the group from Australia taxied to a halt, the screaming nearly drowned out the noise from the plane's turbo-prop engines. (Jun 12, 2004,Dominion Post,E1)

Don.. also spent eight years at Teal (now Air NZ). (Dec 18, 1992,Evening Post,1)

That jaunt by flying-boat also introduced me to the way TEAL, now Air New Zealand, pampers its customers. (Nov 6, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

When Tasman Empire Airways Limited (TEAL) became Air New Zealand in 1965, Roundhill came up with the koru, which was reduced to a stylised form by his studio team. (Apr 16, 2004,Dominion Post,B12)

During the year 1950-1951, Tasman Empire Airways Ltd., the main operator out of New Zealand carried only 220 tons of freight ... However, TEAL carried almost the same tonnage of mail! (Oct 1952,NZ Geographer,157) [NOTES: (Bishop)]

CAMERON New Zealand's ties with Fiji have been strengthened by air services (such as TEAL's Coral Route) ... (1965,New Zealand (various authors/titles),34)

We represent that airlines of the world... TEAL Tasman Empire Airlines Limited at the D.I.C. on the Quay. (Jul 10, 1950,Dominion,3)

Finally, a deal was struck to form Tasman Empire Airways Ltd (soon known as Teal), with ownership divided between the New Zealand Government, Qantas, Britain's Imperial Airways and local company Union Airways. The first Teal flight took off five days later. (Apr 29, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

A quarter of a century later, TEAL became Air New Zealand and brought overseas visitors to this country in wide-bodied jet aircraft. (Nov 2003,AA Directions,No. 58/59)

[Heading] Evans Bay base delays declared fault of TEAL (May 25, 1950,Southern Cross (Wgton),7)

The only major airline operating flying-boats today is TEAL. (Apr 28, 1952,Evening Post,8)

Captain Tredrea joined TEAL in 1946. (Apr 3, 1952,Evening Post,6)

KEITH Things were much more elegant aboard TEAL, New Zealand's first international airline which it owned jointly with BOAC and QANTAS. (1991,Lovely Day Tomorrow, A,52)

tealeafing¶

n. stealing [ODE has tea leaf = thief (rhyming slang)]

Another seriously regarded offence is tealeafing (stealing from another inmate while in prison). (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

NEWBOLD At Paremoremo, some tealeafing used to occur . . . . (1982,Big Huey, The,178)

team¶

n. sc of sheep-dogs

Team: Each shepherd's dogs. He may have anything from two to eight. Usually in large teams only three are much use. The rest are for sale or being broken in. The distinction between team and pack (rabbit pack q.v.) was general in Canterbury until a few years ago [from 1933]; but several North Canterbury correspondents have told me that many of the younger shepherds now speak of their sheepdogs as a pack. (1933,Press, The) [NOTES: Acland]

NEWTON [gloss.] A shepherd refers to his dogs as his team. An ideal high-country team would be one heading dog, two handy dogs, and two huntaways. Or alternatively, two heading dogs, one handy dog and two huntaways. Ibid. 23 I loosened my `team' of two dogs. (1947,Wayleggo)

NEWTON Team: A shepherd refers to his dogs as his team. An ideal high country team would be one heading dog, two handy dogs and two huntaways. Or alternatively, two heading dogs, one handy dog and two huntaways. (1966,Boss's Story, The,190)

WANTED, Situation, by experienced shepherd, aged 25, with good team of dogs, just arrived from Blenheim. (Nov 8, 1902,Evening Post,1)

The same competitor also won the president's prize of GBP2 2s for the best team of dogs, Mr Miles' prize rug for most points for two dogs, Mr Bain's prize stockwhip for the noisiest huntaway, and Mr Young's prize silver teapot for most points in the second contest. (Apr 4, 1896,Timaru Herald,3)

1 n. (Rural) [farming in general] a group of dogs owned by a single owner, or working in a group e.g. a rabbiting team of dogs, a mustering team etc.

LILICO The home shepherd invariably uses only one dog on his rounds, but his colonial brother-in-trade always has a 'team' or 'pack.' (1919,Breeding and Training of Sheep Dogs,22)

LOUGHNAN team: in a mustering gang, each man has a team of dogs - never, never a 'pack' of them. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,84)

Shepherd General: Must be motivated, a good stockperson, reliable and have a good team of dogs. (Feb 9, 2002,Dominion,31)

Team New Zealand¶

n. NZ America's Cup yachting team

[Hdg] Sock it to them Team NZ... The "socks" were all sent up to Team New Zealand's headquarters on Friday, as the yachties counted down for the first race against Italy's Prada challengers. (Feb 22, 2000,Independent Herald (Wellington),2)

[Hdg] Team NZ 'not left in the lurch'. Russell Coutts, the hero of New Zealand's two successful America's Cup yachting campaigns, sees considerable irony in the possibility of him competing in the 2003 regatta against Team New Zealand and his protege, Dean Barker. (May 23, 2000,Dominion,30)

team policing¶

n.

This was the era of "team policing", when the appearance of a task force in a pub was the signal to drink up, or get stuck in. (Mar 25, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

teamster¶

n. [1933 Acland]

TURNER New Zealand coaching days contributed the teamster named from his team of horses. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,157)

teapoteer¶

n. one of the party faithful who man the teapots, cake stalls; a backroom party worker

New Zealand First has fallen foul of its teapoteers on three different fronts. (Sep 21, 1996,Sunday Star Times,A12)

tear¶

n. sc of kauri gum

The greater part of the kauri-gum ... is found in a fossil condition, a very small portion being the produce of living trees, although ocasionally it occurs in recent masses or `tears' of several pounds weight, at the junction of a large branch with the stem. (1881,TrNZI,13/138)

tear hell out of¶

phr. to tear to pieces (fig.)

GASKELL It just tore hell out of me. (1947,Big Game,39)

tear into¶

v. to attack vigorously (cf. RIP)

SMYTH Three notes a man if we win out'.Aw, make it five an' we'll tear into the job'. (1929,Girl from Mason Creek, The,131) [NOTES: EDD 8. work hard or strenuously; do anything with great speed or energy. Sc Ir and Eng. dialects; nf OED]

v.

SARGESON You could still hear them tearing into each other. (1946,That Summer,93) [NOTES: P: B1942: Austr: 20C]

tear off¶

2 v.

BAXTER Do you know the story about the bloke that was tearing one off with his cobber's wife? ... [37] This bloke ... went round to his cobber's place to tear one off. (1985,Horse,36) [NOTES: c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Name and the Game) 36]

Tear one off at a picnic [heading of advt] its the drink that hits the spot on the spot ... because Fresh-Up Apple juice & Apple and Orange juice now come in a 12-ounce can with a tear-tab top! (Oct 27, 1971,Otago Daily Times,14) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

LELAND tear off a tab - **tear off a scab: is to OPEN a tear top CAN OF BEER. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,102)

tear tussocks¶

phr. (Rural) [mustering] to be in a rage with one's dog.

LOUGHNAN tear tussocks: to be in, or fly into, a rage over a dog's performance. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,84)

tear up for arsepaper¶

phr. (informal) severely scold, reprimand; demolish in argument [in the 1947 cit. used humorously to express surprise; a var. of well, I'll be blowed, etc.]

PARTRIDGE Tear up for arse-paper. To reprimand severely: New Zealand soldiers': in the G.W. (B. and P.) (1937,Dictionary of Slang,869)

DAVIN Livingstone. I believe', said Frank.Well, I'll be torn up for arsepaper', said Pat Murphy. (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,300)

tearoomography¶

n. reports on tearooms [word invented by Steve Braunias]

I need more tips, more tearoomographies. (Jul 17, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

teaser¶

n. a steer kept on a bull-farm to stimulate the bulls into ejaculation to collect semen for artificial insemination; an animal which cannot get a female pregnant, used to test which females are on heat: either an entire male animal prevented by various means, such as vasectomy, tieing on an apron, etc., or a female treated with male sex hormone to make her act like a male

Male that cannot get a female pregnant. An entire male is made into a teaser by: Vasectomising ...Penis deviation ... Treating a female with male hormone to sexually activate her and make her act like a male ...Tie an apron on an entire male which prevents his penis entering the female when he mounts ... . (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,13)

1 n. (Rural) a vasectomised ram or bull used to stimulate and/or detect oestrus in ewes or cows.

DU FAUR It may thus be advisable, where teasers are used, to put out two-thirds of the rams immediately, and to add the remainder when needed. (1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,40)

The teaser used for the first five days would be fitted with a harness containing oranger marker ink. (Aug 1970,NZ Dairy Exporter,17)

.. it has been found that, providing all teasers were efficient, submission rates in the pen system would at least equal single-sire paddock-mating rates. (Jan 1977,NZ Journal of Agriculture,25)

2 n.

The presence of a "teaser" stallion in a nearby paddock didn't help... (Sep 5, 2003,Dominion Post RaceForm,20)

Once the ewes are on heat a marked teaser ram is put out and then the ewes are artificially inseminated. (Sep 27, 2002,Dominion Post,C11)

teatime¶

n. evening meal [aka tea-time]

He was outvoted, and compelled to quit Cambridge about an hour before tea-time. (Feb 12, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

I saw him no more till tea-time, and he again told me his ribs were broke, and he could not get up, and that Frank Macdonald had done it. (Jan 24, 1857,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

MIDDLETON It was nearly teatime when I remembered his letter. He sat down to read it while I fried bacon and eggs for our meal. (1959,Stone, The,65) [NOTES: (The Stone)]

We're supposed to believe he has emerged from a dark teatime of the soul since his wife's death... (Feb 26, 2004,Dominion Post,B11)

'Hondai Lanka' Tea is playing an important part in many households - it is giving tea-time satisfaction! (Oct 28, 1909,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,1691)

In one case the work was finished by tea-time, whereas in the other no appreciable progress had been made. (Jun 1, 1921,Ohinemuri Gazette,4)

To English ears the notion of serving coffee at tea-time sounds a little incongruous. (Jul 23, 1936,Evening Post,19)

Another pilotless plane fell at teatime among people returning from their Sunday afternoon walk. (Jun 19, 1944,Evening Post,6)

At teatime I had bread and butter and tea, if I chose to take it. (Mar 24, 1865,Daily Southern Cross,6)

Teatime finds him fagged out, poor dear, but he eats with much gusto, then retires to his well-worn chimney corner and dozes his evening away. (Aug 13, 1872,Daily Southern Cross,3)

teatspray¶

1 v. (Rural) to spray the teats of dairy cows prior to, and/or following, milking.

Teatspray all cows after every milking over the complete lactation. (Oct 1999,NZ Dairy Exporter,51)

TEC¶

abbr. Tertiary Education Commission

[The] new chief of the embattled Tertiary Education Commission had barely had time to get her feet under the desk when the State Services Commission issued its scathing review of the education sector last year... It went on to say the TEC was unable to recognise poor courses... (Feb 1, 2006,Dominion Post,B7)

(Mar 31, 2003,Salient,No. 5/18)

Tech¶

n. in NZ usually an abbreviation of TECHnical College, TECHnical High School at secondary level, rather than of PolyTECHnic at tertiary, though by 1980 at least, TECH in Wellington was used for the Wellington Polytechnic.

DAVIN (1970,Not Here, Not Now,156)

techite¶

n. a person from a Tech

(1947,Miscellany,9/33) [NOTES: ... we passed several techites going to football.]

Technical School Institute¶

n. also called a Polytechnic or Community College, a tertiary educational institution which provides continuing education to meet the needs of commerce, industry and the social services as well as the community at large.

technicolour yawn¶

n.

Just a small update on 'helicopter heave'; my brother recently spoke to a member of the Massey University Students' Assn, and he confirmed that the term is still in use (at Massey anyway). It is particularly associated with the "chunder-mile," a rather ,messy capping event... "Technicolour yawn" is used for an instance of vomiting, as is "liquid laugh', I believe. (Aug 24, 1998,Letter,00)

GIFFORD About an hour from home he leaps to the slidin' window [of the bus] and goes [does???] a technicolour yawn that MGM would have been proud to produce. (1976,Loosehead Len's Bumper Thump Book,31)

TUCKER ... Jerry suddenly lurched to the side of the vessel and produced what is now commonly referred to as `the technicolour yawn'. (1978,Thoroughbreds Are My Life,21)

LELAND technicolour yawn: To empty the contents of one's stomach through the oral orifice; often done as a response to an excess of alcohol in the system. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,102)

McGILL technicolour yawn vomit. ANZ. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,112)

New Zealanders have more words for chundering, hurling, producing technicolour yawns and making a long-distance phone call on the great white telephone than the Inuit have for snow. (Feb 10, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

technofencing¶

n.

Contract fencers have put in 100ha of technofencing over the last six months and about 120ha of the farm have been drilled with new annual ryegrasses. (Jul 12, 2005,Country-Wide,28)

technosystem¶

n. [Wier or Weir in first citation?]

Pasture covers in the technosystem typically climbed to 3500kg DM/ha last year, but Livingston says as the system intensifies this year "the longest feed they will go into will be just over 3000kg DM/ha". ... About 150 units of N/ha were applied to the technosystem this season in five applications, however the input of the last 30kg N/ha in January was "under question" because pasture response was limited. (Jul 2005,Country-Wide,29)

. . . he split the 20-30ha-sized paddocks into 6-8ha, installed the Technosystem of intensive bull finishing devised by Bulls farmer Harry Wier, planted 13ha of pines on his rough country and began introducing the Rangitikei farmer Roger Marshall's Kelso composite sheep breed to the Romney flock that came with the farm. (May 13, 2004,Dominion Post,C7)

He started running a technosystem eight years ago, gradually increasing the size of the system to the stage where it covered about 80ha of easier contour last year. (Jul 2005,Country-Wide,28)

techo¶

n. technician

In the cafeteria, however, all we encountered were techos letting out their belts, belching, wiping their mouths with the backs of their hands, picking their teeth and declaring innocently that to the best of their knowledge no food had been provided. (Oct 26, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

Tecomanthe¶

n. a vine

[Hdg] Tecomanthe speciosa - a relic. Although popular in people's gardens, Tecomanthe speciosa is listed as "critically threatened". (Jul 2004,Conservation Action,20)

tecomaria¶

n.

tecomaria [s] Tecomaria capensis (Thunb.) Spach. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,78)

Ted¶

n. a German

It is the arrogance of the American labelling other peoples gooks' andwops': the New Zealand soldier had his Wogs' andIties' and Teds', at home there are theChinks' and Ikes' andDallies' and even the Horis'. <i>(Sep 1952,Landfall,23/220</i>) [NOTES: (PearsonFretful Sleepers')]

SLATTER These Welshmen are a stubborn lot, just like the Teds in the Gothic Line, ... (1970,On the Ball,136)

Tucker now we had realised that the Italian name for Germans was Tedeschi, so of course we had nicknamed them The Teds'. Our nickname had absolutely no reference to Tedeschi at all, but merely was a shortening ofshitheads'. We derived great pleasure from looking at one another and saying, Well, the Teds have cleared off,' orThe Teds have done this' or whatever had happened. (1978,Thoroughbreds Are My Life,26)

tedder¶

n.

Neither ted or tedder are recognised and the sweep has vanished into the mists of haymaking history. (Mar 28, 1979,Otago Daily Times,21) [NOTES: (G. Griffiths)]

The new-cut grass lies there in rows / To brown it off beneath the sun / Just waiting for the tedder's teeth... (Jun 2003,NZ Memories,No. 42/35)

Teddy Woodbine¶

n. Edward, Prince of Wales, later Edward VIII (cf. WOODBINE)

PARTRIDGE There is Church Parade tomorrow and Teddy Woodbine with all the heads of the Army is going to review the troops. (1935,Slang Today,287) [NOTES: 1935 A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287]

PARTRIDGE Woodbine, Teddy. Edward, Prince of Wales Australian and N.Z. soldiers': GW. B. & P. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,963)

In connection with the visit of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales to New York last November, the New York World issued as a supplement on November 30 an autographed photo-gravure of "Teddy Woodbine," as the prince was familiarly styled in France, and a copy has been forwarded to THE EXPRESS Office. (Feb 11, 1920,Marlborough Express,4)

teddy-cart¶

n.

MACLEOD The vehicle was probably "the teddy-cart", a tank on a brake by means of which water was carted from the Heathcote River. (1964,Fighting Man, The,46)

teddywood¶

n. Ixerbis brexioides, tawari [1926 B.C. Aston (vernacular) (Andersen) Ixerbia brexioides [a1927] Ver.(A). = Vernacular names supplied by B.C. Aston (And)]

LAING & BLACKWELL North Island from Whangaroa to Hawke's Bay (1940,Plants of NZ,193)

teddywood Ixerbia brexioides Ver. (A). (1927,TrNZI,57/962)

tee¶

n. a fence-post [ca1951 R. Gilberd (Okaihau) [?definition] 2. Swinging T' </i>- a foot with a length of wire attached which is either stapled to the post above the ground or twisted onto the bottom wire. 3. <i>Anchored T' - similar to a `swinging T', but no post is used. The anchor wire is twisted around each wire in turn, holding them at correct elevation. It is used where posts have to be packed to the fence-line, e.g. in the Gisborne district.]

tee scum¶

n. in disc golf, the highest scorer on the previous tee

While I spent most of the times as "tee scum" (the highest scorer on the previous tee and therefore the last player to throw) I found the game enjoyable... (Jan 14, 2004,Capital Times,17)

tee-tote¶

n. a teetotaller [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

... You see, my family have become tee-totes. Father's joined the A.A. So the reception was dry, ... Father's an alki-anonymous you know. ...' (1974,Islands,7/5) [NOTES: Henderson (The Last News ...)]

teegoomme¶

n. tikumu

PARKINSON At one particular place we met with a substance that appeared like a kid's skin ...; and were afterwards informed, by the natives, that it was gathered from some plant called Teegoomme: one of them had a garment made of it, which looked like their rug cloaks. (Jan 15, 1770,Journal,115)

Several large bundles of the tomentum stripped from the back of the large alpine Celmisia (tikumu). [fn] 1773 edn Parkinson Journal of a Voyage to the South Seas 115 `At one particular place ... we met with a substance that appeared like a kid's skin, but it had so weak a texture that we ... were afterwards informed by the natives that it was gathered from some plant called teegomme. (1897,TrNZI,29/175)

teehokee¶

n. (See titoki)

teeth arms¶

n.

HUGHES For me there was no question that I had to be in one of the teeth arms - artillery, infantry, armour or engineers. (1999,Shooting from the Lip,40)

teetotum¶

n.

GERYGONE ASSIMILIS, Buller. Piripiri. Warbler, Teetotum. (1870,TrNZI,2/58) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

  1. Gerygone flaviventris, Gray. Grey Warbler, Teetotum, Piripiri. -The warbler is a true pensile nest-builder ... (1884,NZ Journal of Science,284) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

Grey Warbler Gerygone igata (QUOY & GAIMARD, 1830) ... OTHER NAMES: Riroriro, teetotum. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,278)

TEFRom¶

n. a breed of sheep: Texel, East Friesian, Romney [also tefrom]

About 200 Southland tefrom embryos were exported to Mr Croser's Adelaide property and his ewes are expected to start lambing later this month. (Aug 23, 2005,Wairarapa Midweek,24)

3 breeders have standardised a breed which they have named TEFRom ( Romney, Texel, East Friesian). The breeders Messrs R Welch, R Campbell & D Daniell have more than 1,000 ewes and are SIL recorded. (Jan 13, 2004,Internet - see Notes,0) [NOTES: http://www.nzsheep.co.nz/news.htm (accessed 04/01/2006)]

TEG¶

abbr. Terrorist Emergency Group

The Terrorist Emergencuy Group (TEG), a joint ministerial-officials group chaired by Miss Clark, was originally activated about 10.30am... As well the TEG has received reports of explosions in Palmerston North and of a car bomb exploding in Christchurch. (May 2, 2001,Evening Post,2)

tehori¶

n. (See taiore)

TEI¶

abbr. Technical Educational Institute

[Hdg] TEIs hold breath on course cutting. (May 29, 2002,NZ Education Review,2)

teina¶

n. a younger brother or sister; a junior (compare TUAKANA). [ORIGIN: Maori]

Buck To sum up briefly, a male is tuakana to all his younger brothers and teina to all his older brothers. ... If there are any daughters in the family, they follow the same principle, being tuakana to all their younger sisters and teina to their older sisters. (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,340)

teka¶

n. a fib, a lie; tito [ca1950 V. O'Sullivan (Ahipara, Northland) to tell tekas, etc.]

You teka! she [a Maori grandmother] giggled. Who'd want to have you! (1984,Some Other Country,162) [NOTES: 1972 Ihimaera `Game of Cards' in 1984 Some Other Country 162]

tekapo¶

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] a New Zealand-bred cultivar of cocksfoot (orchard grass, Dactylis glomerata).

Tekapo - Densely tillered, prostrate cultivar suitable for hard grazing and dry environments. (1995,Grasslands Range of Forage and Conservation Plants,20)

tekateka¶

n. [empty headword] (See tekoteko)

tekoteko¶

n. carved figure on the gable of a house; figurehead of a canoe [ORIGIN: Maori, Ryan 256]

IHIMAERA & LONG Behind glass panes / the tekoteko stares helplessly (1982,Into the World of Light,197)

Where the barge-boards meet is a carved face, surrounded with feathers, and surmounted with a small figure called a tekoteko. (1876,TrNZI,8/175) [NOTES: (Stack Maori House)]

The tekoteko on the roof above is Takenga, one of the descendants of Tama te Kapua (1895,TrNZI,27/674)

They were often ... inlaid with pawa-shell (Haliotis), and finished off with a tekoteko (grotesque wooden figure) set up at the apex of the roof. (1903,TrNZI,35/22)

TREGEAR A carved face (koruru) was placed at the junction of the barge-boards, and above this was an image (tekoteko) which, especially on state occasions, was decked with feathers and ornaments. (1904,Maori Race, The,273)

REISCHEK From the hut itself I took the long middle post made of totara, on which was a very beautiful tekateka, or carved figure, representing the face of Chief Tirorau fully tattooed. (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,65,1933 ed.)

... - her eyes like paua-eyes of the gable-tekoteko. (1930,NZ Short Stories,32) [NOTES: J.C.Andersen]

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,2/121)

tekoteko, grotesque carved human figure standing on the gable of a Maori house, above the koruru covering the join of the barge-boards at the gable. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

BUCK A carved head(koruru) was placed over the vertical join of the two barge-boards forming the gable apex. ... Sometimes a complete human figure (tekoteko) was used instead of a koruru type ... (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,129)

Beneath the carven counterparts of their ancestors and the fierce teko teko on guard high above ... the Maoris lament on their mats. (Aug 1953,Here & Now,21)

ASHTON-WARNER `I've designed a banner for the school. Look! Here's the Maori tekoteko, here a book to indicate learning. [fn.]Maori figurehead on meeting house. (1958,Spinster,127)

TAYLOR In the only Maori I knew/ I called/ Tihei Mauriora./ Above me the tekoteko raged./ He ripped his tongue from his mouth/ and threw it at my feet./ (1979,Eyes of the Ruru,15)

At Papawai Marae, near Greytown, the tall, red tekoteko - the carved figures that represent ancestors - mostly face inward. ... The tekoteko represent Papawai's position as a place of peace and harmony, and a new era. (Oct 2005,Air New Zealand inflight magazine,88) [NOTES: -]

He goes all round the posts, and other parts of the house searching for it, and at last walks outside to consult the small wooden image (tekoteko) placed at the end of the ridge-pole in the front of the house. (Jun 22, 1921,Ohinemuri Gazette,2)

The tekoteko, the figure on top of the meeting-house, represents Tuterangiwhiuiti, who was a descendant of Porourangi and a great warrior. (Dec 1965,Te Ao Hou,53: 49)

The prices for the more modern, or more recently acquired, articles included .. tekoteko, GBP5. (May 24, 1912,Evening Post,4)

The mahi figure on the doorway represents Pikiao, the ancestor of the Ngatipikias tribe, and the small figure, or tekoteko, that surmounts the top is called "Te Takinga," the son of Pikiao. (Dec 19, 1889,Otago Witness,17)

Maori material culture, the patterns and forms of tekoteko, taniko and tukutuku, is a tempting source of raw material for artists. (Dec 14, 2005,NZ Herald,B4)

To be honest the carvings I saw would not set Rotorua alight, but they are not for sale and the teko teko made by brothers Clinton and Jay Rei should soon grace the Patea High School. (Mar 14, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

tele-con¶

n. a telephone cold-call [Renee]

RENeE How's your day been? asks a strange voice. I might have known it. A Tele-Con. (1998,Yin & Tonic,7)

tele-conner¶

n. a cold-call telephone operator [Renee]

RENeE After a brief startled moment, the Tele-Conner acceded to this request and sped into round two, which was - you guessed it - a repeat of round one, with the addition of an ill-disguised tremor of anxiety. (1998,Yin & Tonic,9)

telegraph pole¶

n. a pole supporting telegraph or electric power lines or wires [Jim writes: This is defined in Chambers and Macquarie in the literal sense of a pole supporting telegraph wires. There is not entry in Collins. NSOD refers to "telegraph or telephone wires". In NZ the term was widely used informally also in relation to electric power lines (=power pole) (I cannot remember ever having seen telegraph lines in the strict sense). Does this loose use persist?]

CONLY Multi-storey commercial buildings at Napier and Hastings view with telegraph poles in swaying to the extremes. (1980,Shock of '31, The,3)

telegraph time¶

n.

WATT In May, 1877, a clock was placed in the eastern window of the telegraph office ... Hence, `telegraph time', another name by which standard time was known. (1971,Centenary of Invercargill,156)

telescope fish¶

n. Mendosoma lineatum

AYLING TELESCOPE FISH Mendosoma lineatum ... This species gets its name from the extensible mouth which can be protruded forward and downward to form a long tube. ... They are found from Cook Strait southwards ... (1982,Collins Guide,248,1984 ed.)

[species name] telescope fish .. [scientific name] Mendosoma lineatum .. [other name(s)] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL [species name] telescope fish .. [scientific name] Mendosoma lineatum .. [other name(s)] (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,106)

telescoping¶

n. tucking the legs of frozen lambs inside their carcass

BELICH ... 'telescoping' - tucking the legs of frozen lambs inside their carcass and so saving 15 per cent of shipping space. (2001,Paradise Reforged,228)

teletangi¶

n. a video-filmed tangi/funeral distributed by webcam and cellphone. [ORIGIN: blend]

Because our family is scattered worldwide and some of our young people are computer literate, we used the internet to share it [a funeral in 2007] online via webcams and cellphones. This teletangi was the first to be done by the Maori but I think it will become crucial to keeping families connected in death and life. (Oct 13, 2007,New Scientist,52) [NOTES: from article 'A Maori Farewell' by Paratene Ngata]

Telethon¶

n. a 24-hour TV charity fund-raising event; a television programme to raise money for charity, where viewers telephone the comperes to pledge donations over many hours or days [The first Telethon in NZ was held in 1979 but this date needs checking.]

It was winter, Telthon was happening in a cold showgrounds shed with equipment gleaned from obsolescent and surplus stock. There was a public who had heard of Telethon but had never seen one. (Jul 10, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

telethon n. U.S. a lengthy television programme to raise charity funds, etc. [C20: < TELE- + MARATHON] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1203) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 791; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 495]]

tell-pie-tit¶

n. used occasionally for the more usual but general English, tell-tale-tit (your tongue shall be split,/And every little puppydog shall have a little bit)

HYDE Tell-pie-tit, his tongue will be split. (1938,Godwits Fly, The,117)

telltale¶

n. an instrument for measuring roof movement in a mine

At intervals, devices called telltales, resembling a pair of small fluorescent clock faces, had been installed. A telltale measures movement in the roof - telling miners what's happening in the seam above their heads. (Jul 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 68/43)

temperance ship¶

n.

LANG [The two American whalers] are both temperance ships, but I know well from past experience that they are by this time full of native women for the worst of purposes. (1839,New Zealand in 1839,8)

temporary constable¶

n.

[caption] THE UNREAL McCOY: Nick Udy (left) in the new polo shirt for temporary constables, and Constable Sione Tangi in the standard police uniform. (May 31, 2006,NZ Herald,A4)

tempured¶

adj. tempura-battered

Despite a chronically over-cooked sludge of bok choi, the pork-stuffed chicken breast was succulent and good, its accompanying "tempured" (i.e. tempura-battered) coconut rice rolls standing uprioght on the plate.... (Jul 22, 2004,Dominion Post,D4)

Temuka stone¶

n.

FRAME Where were the cladders with their load of Temuka stone that was not genuine stone but layers of imitation wood painted the colour of stone? (1988,Carpathians, The,147)

Ten Guitars¶

n. the "unofficial National anthem", originally written and performed by Engelbert Humperdinck.

The notion that Kiwi soldiers abroad can readily win the hearts and minds of the locals - a few smiles for the kids and a rendition of "Ten Guitars" down at the market is usually believed to do the trick - is about to be put to a serious test. (Jul 5, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

The evening began and ended with a singalong - "10 Guitars", what else? (May 24, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),64)
