What happened to the good old "enjoy yourself and bugger the culture and the deeper meaning" theory? The black singlet, the meat pie and the knees-up to Ten Guitars at the local pub seem to have lost their place to a troop of line-dancing Peruvian whistlers. (Mar 12, 2002,Evening Post,25)

ten skin bowling¶

phr. beating up skinheads

ten-acre block¶

n. (Rural) a hobby farm, or a semi-rural lifestyle property where emphasis may be on lifestyle rather than land production. [In some local body areas, a ten acre block represented the minimum area for optimal small-property production.]

Get yourself a 10-acre block and it can kill you. (Dec 9, 1976,NZ Farmer,53)

FIRTH There was an initial rush to buy 10 acre blocks 20 years ago. (1988,Farmers are Bananas,151)

YEREX At one time we talked about '10-acre blocks,' mainkly because that was the minimum size for farm subdivision. (1992,New Zealand Off the Beaten Track,64)

Small farms, or hobby farms or life-style blocks, used to be referred to as 10-acre blocks because county councils decided that farm land should not be divided into anything less than that size. (1992,New Zealand Off the Beaten Track,106)

'Ten acre blocks' can easily become productive units in a way that they never could be with cattle or sheep! (Sep 10, 1996,NZ Emu Farming Association Journal) [NOTES: Promo]

ten-acre blocker¶

n. a lifestyler on a ten-acre block

I was giving some classes to ten-acre blockers. (Jul 29, 2004,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Lunchtime News]

1 n. (Rural) a hobby farmer.

MEADOWS This book would not be complete without reference to the hobby farmer or owner of a small block of land. Known in New Zealand as 'ten-acre blockers' because many small blocks are of that size, they range from retired farmers who can't quite let go through to rural-dwelling company executives.. (1996,NZ Guide to Cattle Breeds,47)

ten-acre blockie¶

n. (Rural) a hobby farmer, or one running a farmlet on approx. ten acres. (See lifestyle farmer)

These are not just the 10-acre blockies or lifestyle farmers who don't understand or don't care about the economics of calf-rearing... (Apr 6, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,19)

ten-eighty¶

n. sodium fluoroacetate, a poison used to kill noxious animals (See 1080)

ten-gallon hat¶

n.

LYON The diggers brought into general use [in the 19th century] the soft felt of various shapes, the larger of which were termed the ten-gallon' oreight horse' hats. (1952,Faring South,98)

ten-minute gate¶

1 n. (Rural) a Taranaki gate, composed of fencing wire and battens.

FISK Taranaki Gates: Otherwise known as ten-minute gates because they take only ten minutes to make but supposedly just as long to open and close. (1996,Practical Smallfarming,19)

ten-pound Pom¶

n. an assisted-immigrant who paid [pounds]10 only towards cost of passage, and was bonded to Government directed work for a set period [also 10-pound Pom]

"I was enchanted by it all," he says, and took up the offer of becoming a "GBP10 pom". (Oct 4, 2001,Dominion,11)

Her parents sailed to New Zealand in 1962 as newly wed "GBP10 Poms", determined on a better life for themselves and children-to-be. (Jul 7, 2007,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

For years whenever we talked about Captain Cook with anyone I could never understand how we were called GBP10 Poms. One man said it's a misnomer to call us GBP10 Poms because at the time if you applied to Australia, it cost GBP10 and to Canada it was GBP10 - he said that's why he was in New Zealand, as he didn't have GBP10. (Jan 22, 2003,Dominion Post,A6)

His parents were among the wave of 10-pound Poms who came to New Zealand in search of a better life, when Jones was two. (Jun 14, 2008,Dominion Post Indulgence,18)

A job in a shoe factory, National Service, and then Bland comes to New Zealand, as a 20-year-old, another GBP10 Pom. (Aug 14, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

tena koe¶

n. a Maori [nonce?]

NEWNHAM I couldn't quite fathom out though why our teacher always called us "You Maori tena koes." (1989,1840-1990. A Long White Cloud?,68)

v. [aka tenakoe]

She "tenakoed" the hero of Khartoum with a vivacity that must have reminded him of some of his interviews with those most interesting folk, the Soudan Dervishes, and he smilingly "tenakoed" in return. (Mar 24, 1910,Wanganui Chronicle,2)

exclam.

exclam. a common form of Maori greeting (to one person) various early spg the [a[a]] has given rise to the usual anglicisation [te|naakwe; to greet with tena koe , sometimes used as a greeting by Pakeha, becoming (with KIA ORA) more frequent from c1975-1980 after about 50-60 years of infrequent use. [Compare tena koutou katoa. [Maori tena[e,a-macron] koe]]

SCRYMGEOUR Jim gave the salutation "Tenaqua". "Tenaqua Ehoa". (1960,Memories of Maoriland,176)

TAYLOR Two natives put their heads in at the tent-door, and tena koe'd the Bishop. .sk 2;B. in English contexts, espec (?) North Island (1959,Early Travellers,110) [NOTES: 1855 Aug 15 Abraham Walk from Auckland to Taranaki in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 110]

MORRIS A Maori salutation used in the North Island of New Zealand. (1898,Austral English)

PARTRIDGE Tena Koe? How do you do?: coll., North Island of New Zealand: late C. 19-20. Ex Maori (lit., `that is you'). Morris. Cf. taihoa, q.v. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,871)

McNAB Now that our political leaders are less lavish with Maori greetings, spoken and cabled, tenakoe' andkia ora' are less assured of a long life. (Apr 2, 1938,Press, The,18) [NOTES: NZ Slang]

BAKER ...tena koe, a salutation... (1941,NZ Slang,56)

TURNER (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,169)

HEAPHY ... canoes ... which meet you ... with the everlasting greeting of Naumai', ortena-koit-ou', welcome' orhail to you', and exchange, as they pass, news up and down the river. (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),94)

"Tena koe. Tena koe. Te Prince," exclaimed an elderly Maori dame, as she bore down upon the distinguished visitor, with hand outstretched and beaming countenance. (May 11, 1920,Poverty Bay Herald,4)

"Tenakoe," said Princess Elizabeth to Lieutenant A. T. Bennett, Rotorua (son of Bishop Bennet), and Lieutenant H. Wiremu, of Kaitaia. (Jun 21, 1945,Evening Post,8)

Saying Taraqua. [?tanaqua] (1842,Letters from Settlers,48,1843 ed.) [NOTES: (W. Ferguson)]

LEE & KENDALL T|ena ra ko koe; Be thou healthy! or Good morning (day, or night) to thee! (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,211)

how do you do? - ta'nna ra'kkoo ko'ee [tena ra ko koe?] (1835,Boultbee Journal,112,1986 ed.)

MAY `Tenera coqui emera' the native salute. (1838,Journal of a Voyage to NZ,212)

MATHEW They flocked out ... to welcome us, with their usual salutation of Tanerakakoi' orHow do you do', ... (Feb 16, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Feb 16 F.Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 48]

Saying Taraqua. [?tanaqua] (1842,Letters from Settlers,48,1843 ed.) [NOTES: (W. Ferguson)]

BARNICOAT We were eveywhere saluted with the usual Tenago or Howdyedo. (1842,Journal,66)

WEEKES [A maori] came towards me with extended hand and a friendly `Tenaqui'. (1842,Journal,IV/4)

POWER In the interior of the Pa the Wahines[e-acute], or matrons, are busy weaving flax-mats, cleaning potatoes or fish, or engaged in the superintendence of a Maori oven, or a huge gipsy-looking cauldron, called a go-ashore', and can only afford to greet the visitor with a whiningtena koe pakeha', sighing as though they were very much to be pitied. (1849,Sketches in NZ,160)

TANCRED The salutation Tina-koe', which being pronounced rapidly has the sound of a single wordtinaque'. (1856,Natural History of Canterbury,32)

ASKEW On passing their [sc. Maoris'] tents, I was saluted with `taner, ake-kouie,' (good [343] morning) by the men. (1857,Voyage to Australia & NZ,342)

THATCHER Ropata's whare soon they spied,/ Tenakoe!' the deputation cried,/Haeremai, Pakeha!' Ropata replied,/ When they got to the Ohinemuri. (1869,Wit and Humour: Local Songs...,33) [NOTES: The Ohinemuri Deputation]

ASKEW I was saluted with: `taner, ake-ouie'. Ibid. [?...] 342 ... taner, ake-ouie. (1857,Voyage to Australia & NZ,342)

THATCHER We often used to visit them, and instead of looking black / At these Rangiriri rebels, we'd pat them on the back, / Shook hands, and said tena koe[e-dieresis], and pointed to the shore, (1869,Maori Captives in Local Songs,16)

CAMPBELL But inasmuch as we only knew Maori enough to the extent of being able to say, Tena koe?</i>' (How do you do?'), and as that terminated our conversational powers in their vernacular, nothing then was left us but to stare at each other. (1881,Poenamo,3/4/162)

MORRIS a Maori salutation used in North Island of New Zealand. Lit. That is you,' and meaningHow do you do?' Tena and Tera both mean that'</i>; but <i>tena</i> implies the idea of nearness,that near you,' tera the idea of distance, `that (or there) away younder.' Hence, while Tena koe is a welcome, Tera koe would be an insult. (1898,Austral English,466)

ALEXANDER & CURRIE Tenakoe: a word of greeting. (1906,Treasury of NZ Verse,289)

MANSFIELD they meet a Maori again - barefooted and strong -she shouted Te nakohi? - (1907,Urewera Notebook,70,1978 Gordon ed.)

tena koe interj. good-morning! howdo you do! [Maori] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,12)

HYDE From a shack doorway Old Kahu ... gave him `Tena koe'. She wore a man's plug hat, and had had children by so many whites that they all looked alike to her, big kids. (1938,Godwits Fly, The,142)

HYDE Her voice said Tena koe', and he answeredTena koe', dropping down to squat beside the mattress. Ibid. 192 Some [Maoris] called `Tena koe', but the beasts were more curious about strangers. (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,133)

(1944,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),408)

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,1/79)

SOLJAK New Zealand colloquialisms which are of Maori origin include; ... tena koe: good day to you (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),117)

te[e]na[a]koe, tenakorua, tenakoutou, greeting to one, two, or more. Really two words in all three - Tena koe! (That you! or There you are! Fancy!) I have heard it Tenaaqui)! (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

tenakoe Maori greeting. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

Tena koe A Maori greeting which means how do you do?', literallythere you are'. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),408)

HI;LIARD (1960,Maori Girl,92)

tena koe (phr.) Maori greeting, meaning `How do you do?'. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),626)

BRAITHWAITE TENA KOE Good morning! (Singular.) (1967,Evil Day,382)

tena koe ... (Phr.) Maori greeting meaning There you are and implying How do you do? (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

BAXTER .. at the church I murmured,Tena koe',/ To the oldest [Maori] woman/ and she replied,Tena koe'- (1979,Collected Poems,460,1969 ed.)

LELAND tena koe: pronounced tena[acute]qway means ALOHA or hello and goodbye. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,102)

BAXTER tena koe greeting (1982,Selected Poems,189)

tena koe int. Maori greeting (to one person). (Other inflected forms for two or more people.) [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,792) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 495]]

OTAGONIAN The Squire replied by the word "Tenakui". (1867,Rambles with a Philosopher,63)

"Tena koe" and other polite compliments were exchanged, and inquiries instituted as to the whereabouts of a gentleman who - for the sake of the narrative - will be called Honi. (Oct 7, 1872,Daily Southern Cross,3)

HOCHSTETTER The old folks sitting at the door hailed us with their cordial "Tenakoe." (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),250)

'Allo, kia ora, bon jour, tena koe. Would you like puha on your baguette? (Jul 19, 2002,Capital Times,13)

"Tena-koe, Miss Elaine," said Rewa politely. (Dec 14, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,17)

"Tenakoe," said Princess Elizabeth to Lieutenant A.T. Bennett of Rotorua. (Jul 2, 1945,NZEF Times,IV/210 : 1)

Tenakoe, Sister Province, 'Neath Otira's snowy crest A hundred thousand welcomes I extend you to the West. (Aug 29, 1918,Hawke's Bay Herald,6)

tena korua¶

n. greeting to two persons [ORIGIN: Maori] (See cf. tena koe,tena koutou)

te[e]na[a]koe, tenakorua, tenakoutou, greeting to one, two, or more. Really two words in all three - Tena koe! (That you! or There you are! Fancy!) I have heard it Tenaaqui)! (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

tena koutou (katoa)¶

exclam.

BAKER 'Tena koutou,' he said. The barely comprehensible formal greeting sounded more like 'tinna goat.' (2000,Kokopu Dreams,118)

".. We saluted each other with friendly "tena koutou," exchanged tobacco for some of the finest wood-pigeons - a capital dish for our dinner, and passed on." (Jun 17, 1870,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

"You have just surprised me - this is the first real haka I have seen for many years," and said again, "Kapai, kapai. Tena koutou." (Jun 22, 1887,Bay of Plenty Times,4)

The Maoris salute us from their pahs, "Tena Koutou!" to which we reply, "Karangamai!" (Jan 8, 1898,Poverty Bay Herald,4)

Every here and there a small kainga would be passed and "Tena koutou!" would cause hills and woods to resound again and again with friendly greeting. (Dec 28, 1901,Evening Post,1)

"Tena Koe" (salutation to you); if two persons "Tena Korua" (salutations to you two); if there are more than two he says "Tena Koutou" (salutation to you all). (Dec 24, 1917,Thames Star,2)

MANING I stepped into the circle formed by my new friends, and had just commenced a tena koutou, when a breeze of wind came ... (1863,Old New Zealand,(II)58)

te[e]na[a]koe, tenakorua, tenakoutou, greeting to one, two, or more. Really two words in all three - Tena koe! (That you! or There you are! Fancy!) I have heard it Tenaaqui)! (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

BRATHWAITE TENA KOUTOU Good morning! (To several people.) (1967,Evil Day,382)

She spoke of the loyalty of the people, and of their services to the Empire on the battlefields of Gallipoli and France, and finished with the greeting, "Tena koutou. Kia ora koutou katoa." (Dec 23, 1926,Evening Post,18)

SCOTT We had so far met.. one man who took no notice whatever of us except to say "Jenokoi" (good day to one person) and if we had been three or four he would have said "Jenokuru". (1897,How I Stole 10,000 Sheep,38)

FRAME These days you even say tena koutou or haere mai without saying Hairy My and looking nervous. (1988,Carpathians, The,30)

tenakoe-ing¶

n.

WEEKES .. half a dozen lean dogs ... commenced a yelping chorus which they kept up lustily during the period of teneako-ing [a-grave], handshaking, etc. (1842,Journal) [NOTES: also 1841 Weekes Progress of the Colony in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 92 .]

tench¶

n.

POLACK Many other fish are equally numerous, answering to our hakes, tench,.. and dog-fish. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/322)

POLACK Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, .. cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202 fn)

tender¶

adj. wool with a tensile weakness

FERNANDEZ How's this hogget wool going, Bill?'First class wool, just first class but it's tender - fleece after fleece. It's heartbreaking.' ... He plucked a specimen of the fine wool from the tender bin ... and gave a sharp tug. The wool parted along a line of weakness in its growth. (1973,Tussock Fever,5)

McDONALD Tender Wool - Wool that will not resist reasonable strain without breaking. (1915,NZ Sheepfarming,88)

FERNANDEZ How's this hogget wool going, Bill?'First class wool, just first class but it's tender - fleece after fleece. It's heartbreaking.' ... He plucked a specimen of the fine wool from the tender bin ... and gave a sharp tug. The wool parted along a line of weakness in its growth. (1973,Tussock Fever,5)

Tender:Wool with a tensile weakness.A less severe form of break. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,60)

This wool is long stapled tender wool, unfit for combing, but might be improved, and the kemp and scurf eradicated. (Oct 12, 1861,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

One grave error our farmers make is pursuing the practice of crossing beyond the first remove from the merino, the result being a coarse, kempy, tender wool, by no means a favourite with the wool buyers. (Nov 16, 1878,Otago Witness,6)

In trueness exists eveness and freedom from waste, for if the fibre is irregular in bulk an even cloth cannot be produced, and, if very tender, the fabric would fall to pieces in the process of manufacture. (Nov 15, 1884,Otago Witness,7)

A good deal of the wool has been strong and bright, but a considerable percentage of tender fleeces was found in a number of flocks which had been well fed throughout the year, and some people are unable to explain the cause. (Feb 3, 1909,Otago Witness,8)

tender box¶

n. an animal casket

One of her holistic therapy students has designed animal caskets, called "tender boxes".. along with special body bags for the burial of larger animals. (Jun 2004,North & South,25)

tenni¶

n. tennis [1951 16+ M 26 Marlborough C. 20 TENNI (TENNIS)]

tennikoit¶

n. a game of catching and returning quoits across a tennis net or taut wire at waist height [Jim writes This word (and the game it signifies, although one can guess its nature, are new to me. It is not in any dictionary I have seen... Possibly proprietary, possibly of brief currency (cftaipo as the name of a game from about the same period, possibly distinctive NZE. DEH notes : I know this from St Pat's Silverstream where it was played in the quadrangle on areas marked out as in tennis with doubles and singles lines; it is probably still played there today.]

EDMONDS [Caption] We played tennikoit on our small front lawn. (1989,Hot October,52)

tens¶

n. 10-acre allotments in Dunedin

Heeding Captain William Cargill's advice to "settle on the tens", they took up the suburban 10-acre allotments along the harbour or in areas such as North East Valley, Wakari and Andersons Bay. (Apr 1998,North & South,78)

n. a ball-bouncing game

SUTTON-SMITH Ball-bouncing games have come into their own on the asphalt playgrounds of modern schools and are played in many schools throughout the country. There is no evidence of such games before 1900, but a number of instances between 1900 and 1920 are recorded. The games were known as Fives, Tens, Sevens, and Walls and have been recorded more often since under the names O'Leary or Sevens. Before 1920 there is only one report of the game being played with a rhyme, and this was a rhyme more often used in skipping. (1981,History of Children's Play,273)

tent¶

n. part of the paraphenalia of backyard abortion

A `tent', if used, would cause a miscarriage within twenty-four hours, but it was absurd to say that one used in January would take effect in May. (Jul 13, 1907,NZ Truth,108/5/5)

She did not know what a seaweed pencil' was, nor what atent' was. She had informed no girl that she had used a crochet needle for a certain purpose, and she had, as a matter of fact, never used the needle. (Sep 28, 1907,NZ Truth,119/4/7)

tent camp¶

1 n. (Rural) a temporary musterering camp composed of tents and tent flies.

MCCASKILL With no accommodation on those distant blocks, a tent camp is needed for two or three nights, a useful experience for a young stockman. (1969,Molesworth,194)

A party of four (Pyne, Ward, Fitzgerald and a DSIR assistant) worked on the 2 m thick sea ice from tent camps, using specially designed ice auger, winch and corer. (Feb 1981,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,51,11 ed.)

tent fly¶

n. (See fly)

tentage¶

n.

CRUMP He'd read it in silence, then go on [check] to sort out some tentage which Trevor and I would take for the new camp at the head of the river. (1960,Good Keen Man, A,15)

tenth¶

n. [usually tenths]

As it was a test suit by which their right to all the other sections was to be determined, their claim to the 'tenths' has passed away. (1877,NZ Parliamentary Debates,517)

The matter is still further complicated by the stipulation attached to the various trusts, such as the Kemp Trust, and the Native tenths, from which some of the medical officers are paid. (May 16, 1913,Poverty Bay Herald,8)

Attempts to place a contemporary value on the nearly four million acres Ngai Tahu should have owned had the Crown set aside the promised "tenth" of all land sold is extraordinarily difficult. (Nov 1993,North & South,60)

The Whakarewa Grant was part of what was called the tenth', a term coined by the New Zealand Company for land it reserved for Maori people. The principle of the tenths was conveyed in the instructions from the New Zealand Company in 1839 to its principal agent, Colonel William Wakefield, before he set out for New Zealand. Inevery purchase of land from the natives ... a proportion of the territory ceded will be reserved by the Company and held in trust by them for the future benefit of the chief families of the tribe ... You will explain that after English immigration and settlement a tenth of the land will be far more valuable than the whole was before'. ... To Alexander MacKay, commissioner of Native Lands, writing in 1872, the tenthsguarded the natives that common failing of all Aboriginal races, want of foresight, and it secured them from the dangers to which colonisation exposed them'. In short, land was a better asset for the Maoris than cash. In Nelson, the `tenth' comprised a total of 15,000 acres of land, involving a mix of urban and rural land in Nelson, Motueka, and Golden Bay. Most of that land remains in Maori ownership and today is managed by an incorporation. The Whakarewa land - the most valuable area of the tenth - has however been subverted from the control of the ... (Jul 1986,New Outlook,28)

[Colonel William Wakefield] set about negotiating the purchase of some 160,000 acres and in Septmeber 1839 a deed of purpose, written in English, was signed by 16 local chiefs. It provided that one tenth of the land purchased would be reserved for the Maori owners of the Land... No proper explanation was given to Maori of the 'tenths' reserve scheme, nor were they made aware that the deed of purchase made no provision for the retention by Maori of their pa, cultivations, and burial grounds. (Jun 2003,Wel-com (Wellington),13)

They claim that they are descended from one of the chiefs who sold the land around Port Nicholson to Col. Wakefield in the early days of settlement, and that they are entitled to their share of what are known as the Wellington tenths. (Sep 6, 1899,Evening Post,5)

Fortunately for some of the Maoris of the Porirua and Hutt districts they are in receipt of small yearly sums from the proceeds of their interests in the Nelson and Wellington "tenths" and the rents of small pieces of land. (Nov 2, 1906,Evening Post,6)

Of the 110,000 acres so measured one tenth part is to be reserved for the use or benefit of the aborigines, according to the original plan of sale proposed by the New Zealand company; and the lands for the aborigines shall be selected by lot, as provided for by the same plan of sale. (Dec 10, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,1)

[The Maori reserves] comprise, for example, the Wellington, Nelson, and Motueka "tenths", being a tenth part of the land reserved for the Maoris by the New Zealand Company. (1955,NZ Parliamentary Debates,307/2947)

tenting¶

n.

Tenting Amongst the Lyell Mountains. [title] (Dec 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,163)

tenure review¶

n. (Rural) an exchange of some Crown-leased land for conservation purposes, for freehold title to the remainder of a leased property.

It's called "tenure review", an unremarkable term for a remarkable transformation now taking place in our legendary South Island high country. In exchange for giving up the scenic and uneconomic parts of their land for a massive conservation estate, pastoral lease holders get freehold title to the rest of their property. [18] Currently, the main way of achieving it [sc. taking land for the conservation estate]is known as tenure review; a huge land swap inside the pastoral leases that make up 20 percent of the South Island and 10 percent of New Zealand. (Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

When Jim Morris of Ben Avon Station entered tenure review, he did it with an open mind, prepared to move with the times and embrace the consequences. (Jun 2007,Conservation Action,17)

High-country farmers are quietly opting for tenure review because many are likely to become wealthy from what is [7] one of the best real estate deals in New Zealand in the last 50 years... I suspect that history will judge tenure review as not such a great idea for farmning or the public... What should have happened is a careful review of the pastoral lease system to maintain this unique form of land tenure, with adjustments to assist farmers to diversify and to protect uneconomic land. (Jul 26, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

Relph After six years about two-thirds of the 300 pastoral leases in the South Island have passed through or are undergoing tenure review. (2007,From Tussocks to Tourists,144)

Tenure review is a voluntary process for owners of high-country leases who may trade off areas of high conservation value to the conservation estate in return for freeholding the rest of their farms. (Oct 9, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

tepo¶

n. (See taipo)

terakihi¶

n. (See tarakihi)

terapo¶

n.

The natives said it was a bone of the terapo, a very large bird which lived at the top of Hikurangi, and that they made their largest fish-hooks from its bones. (Apr 27, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,16)

Terawhiti pie¶

n. Pie made with chops cooked in camp oven including onions and potatoes and topped with Cape Gooseberries.

After the bush was cleared, Cape Gooseberries, distributed by birds, sprang up everywhere giving rise to a recipe for "Terawhiti Pie", in Betty's Old Curiosity Recipe Book, with chops in a camp oven, onions and potatoes, topped off with Cape Gooseberries; but the cattle later ate them out. (Jun 1987,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,76/45)

teredo¶

n.

KIRK ON THE NEW ZEALAND TEREDO, OR SHIP-WORM. ... Only one species, Teredo antarctica, Hutton, has at present been described as a native of New Zealand. (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,25)

teretere¶

n. brown gecko

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,61) [NOTES: [used in purely maori descr. context so omit]]

terminal sire¶

1 n. (Rural) a ram whose progeny are destined only for slaughter.

We have used a terminal sire before and it worked very well. (May 4, 1993,NZ Farmer,4)

MEADOWS Terminal sire: a ram whose progeny are destined only for slaughter. (1997,Sheep Breeds of New Zealand,90)

The 2 th and aged ewes had the service of terminal sires, and the MA ewes to the Romney in the month of February. (Jun 19, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,22)

When used with a terminal sire from one of the meat breeds such as a South Suffolk or Dorset Down, this type of ewe will produce lambs of around 16-17 kg carcase weight at 12-16 weeks. (2001,Lifestyle Farmer,Aug/Sept 43)

We were changing our sommercial ewe flock to terminal sire. We used various breeds and liked the Suffolk. (May 31, 2002,Dominion,31)

termination rate¶

n. the fee a mobile phone company charges other carriers to end calls on their networks

The Commerce Commission will investigate whether mobile phone call termination rates - the fees a mobile phone company charge other carriers to end calls on their networks - should be regulated. (Apr 30, 2004,Dominion Post,C3)

terms¶

n. have/run sheep on terms [see Acland quotation below (cf thirds; even terms) [check index at ON]

Letters to Godley (J. Hamilton, Christchurch) Russell is giving up his sheep on terms at the Upper Station. (1855,Canterbury Papers,2/250)

FITTON I may here explain the ... custom of placing out capital under the care of an experienced manager, to be invested in sheep, or occasionally in cattle also. This is a well-known arrangement in the colonies, under the name of `keeping stock on terms', and is very general, and ... the most advisable [230] plan for persons who cannot conveniently reside on a station of their own at a distance from a town (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),229)

FITTON I may here explain the ... custom of placing out capital under the care of an experienced manager, to be invested in sheep, or occasionally in cattle also. This is a well-known arrangement in the colonies, under the name of `keeping stock on terms', and is very general, and ... the most advisable [230] plan for persons who cannot conveniently reside on a station of their own at a distance from a town (1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),229)

BUTLER Everyone suggests different investments. One says buy sheep and put them out on terms. I will explain to you what this means. I can buy a thousand ewes ..., these I should place in charge of a squatter whose run is not fully stocked ... This person would take my sheep for either three, ... or more years, ... and would allow me yearly 2s. 6d. per head in lieu of wool. This would give me 2s. 6d. as the yearly interest on 25s. Besides this he would allow me 40 per cent. per annum of increase, ...; moreover, the increase would return me 2s. 6d. per head wool money as soon a they became sheep. At the end of the term, my sheep would be returned to me as per agreement, ... sheep of the same age as [any who have died] would have been will be returned in their place. (Oct 2, 1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,4/36)

[My sheep] are on for one year less 40% less 3% deaths, 2/6 wool money. ... Sheep on terms are not what they used to be ... (Mar 25, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,170,1950 ed.)

DUNCAN [In 1862] Mr Switzer bought some few hundred sheep ... which were `running on terms' with Mr Rees. (1888,Wakatipians,64)

Sheep on terms. A favourite investment in the fifties and sixties. A man bought ewes and handed them over to a runholder whose run was understocked and who had not money to buy sheep. The runholder allowed the owner of the ewes 2s 6d a head a year for their wool and marked 40 per cent. of lambs for the owner as well; or they shared the increase equally. When the ewe lambs became old enough they were bred from as well, so that by the end of the time arranged (anything from three to seven years) the owner had a much larger mob to sell than he had started with. The practice was so much in vogue that in 1863 C.M. Ollivier published a pamphlet computing the interest and profit of s. o. t. at the various lengths of time. The last of such agreements at Horsley Down ran out in 1870 (H. D. letter book) and these are the latest I have found any record of. `I must confess to be fairly puzzled to know what to do with the money you have sent me. Everyone suggests different investments. One says buy sheep put them out on terms.' --[Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 37, where there is a good description of the business too long to quote. (Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

Sheep on terms. A favourite investment in the fifties and sixties. A man bought ewes and handed them over to a runholder whose run was understocked and who had not money to buy sheep. The runholder allowed the owner of the ewes 2s 6d a head a year for their wool and marked 40 per cent. of lambs for the owner as well; or they shared the increase equally. When the ewe lambs became old enough they were bred from as well, so that by the end of the time arranged (anything from three to seven years) the owner had a much larger mob to sell than he had started with. The practice was so much in vogue that in 1863 C.M. Ollivier published a pamphlet computing the interest and profit of s. o. t. at the various lengths of time. The last of such agreements at Horsley Down ran out in 1870 (H. D. letter book) and these are the latest I have found any record of. `I must confess to be fairly puzzled to know what to do with the money you have sent me. Everyone suggests different investments. One says buy sheep put them out on terms.' --[Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 37, where there is a good description of the business too long to quote. (Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

RICHARDS Jim ... evidently must have had some money for he owned sheep which Ritchie kept for him `on terms', that is Ritchie fed and looked after Jim's sheep, keeping half the wool and the [?check] natural increase in return [ca1860s-1870s]. (1952,Chatham Islands,146)

McLEOD Sheep grazed on behalf of another owner under the terms of an agreement by which profits are shared. (1972,Mountain World,310)

n. [the requirement of attendance and satisfactory completion of set work as a pre-requisite to sitting final degree examinations; usu in phr 'keep terms' or 'fail terms'; transferred from 'term' as division of academic year.]

A student must pass the examination and then sign the college declaration before he can keep terms in any subjects. (Feb 22, 1928,Evening Post,8)

The donors require candidates to keep terms in one subject only - music, - but the regulations require that terms should be kept in three subjects. (Nov 29, 1889,North Otago Times,2)

It was resolved that the Board of Examiners in medicine in the first and second professional examinations be instructed that they may, if they see fit, recommend any rejected candidate for admission to a special examination in April, provided that the examiners in the subjects in which he has failed agree to such recommendation, all candidates rejected in the third professional examination to keep terms for one year before they can be re-admitted for examination. (Mar 3, 1893,Evening Post,4)

The professorial Board wrote suggesting certain changes in the regulations as to the keeping of terms. (Dec 19, 1901,Evening Post,2)

The decision of the university authorities that students for the degree of Bachelor of Commerce must keep terms in accountancy subjects at a university college was criticised at the annual meeting of the New Zealand Society of Accountants. (Mar 1, 1941,Evening Post,7)

terms sheep¶

1 n. (Rural) sheep that are grazed on specific terms or on thirds.

BALFOUR Usually, the grazier took one-half of the annual wool clip of the 'terms' sheep and one-third of the total increase at the end of the period. (1885,Balfour Diaries,75)

tern¶

n. a seabird related to the gull, having a slender body, long wings, and graceful flight. [check white-fronted, black-fronted, Antarctic, caspian; sea-swallow, tara, kahawai-bird]

FORSTER Saw common Albatrosses, ... & some affirmed to have seen Eggbirds or Terns. [ed. fn] Not specifically identifiable but perhaps the White-fronted Tern Sterna striata (Gmelin, 1789). Ibid. 2/289 Capt Furneaux dined with us & I described a new Owl & a new Tern, the former of which was drawn by George. [ed. fn] Sterna antarctica of Descr. Anim., p.107. Now the Black-fronted Tern Chlidonias hybrida albostriatus (Gray, 1845). (Mar 25, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/237)

FORSTER We saw ... [in s. Indian Ocean] a single tern (sterna) or as the seamen call it an egg-bird, which had a forked tail. (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/113)

POLACK Blue herons, auks, sand larks , sand plovers, terns, ...; as also black divers, rails of various kinds and variegated colours. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/306)

ADAMS Among these may be noticed the albatross, the molimawk, the Cape pigeon, and several varieties of tern and petrel. The Cape pigeon, which is a beautifully marked black and white bird about the size of a wood pigeon, will follow the vessel to the end of the voyage. (1853,Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A,8)

NATUSCH Family STERNIDAE (terns). The graceful white-fronted tern (Sterna striata, ... ) is seen in all New Zealand bays ... The somewhat stumpier black-fronted tern (Chlidonias hybrida albostriatus, ... ) is common on South Island shingle flats ... The large Caspian tern (Hydroprogne caspia, ... ) is a large tern that includes New Zealand ... in its world-wide breeding range ... The rarest tern breeding in New Zealand is the fairy tern (Sterna nereis,) reported from Lake Ellesmere in 1944, and breeding also, sparingly, in Northland and a few other places. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,267)

The graceful terns are some of the most welcome visitors to the Brothers. (May 14, 1910,Evening Post,13)

The bird you describe as skimming the water was probably a kind of tern or sea swallow. (Nov 3, 1892,Otago Witness,24)

ternlet¶

n.

210. Procelsterna cerulea albivitta Bonaparte, 1856 Grey ternlet Subtropical Pacific, including Kermadec, Norfolk and Lord Howe Islands; has also bred in the Bay of Plenty ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,56,1980 ed.)

Grey Ternlet Procelsterna cerulea (BENNETT, 1840) ... The grey ternlet breeds in loose colonies on the coasts of Pacific islands. ... OTHER NAMES: Grey noddy, blue-grey noddy, little blue petrel, blue billy. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,235)

terrace¶

v.

A few yards further on, a party were `terracing'. (Oct 27, 1867,Trip to the Thames Gold-fields,27,1978 ed.)

Homann and party, terracing in the main creek, Mahakipawa, obtained 11ozs for four days' work, this week. (Sep 29, 1888,Marlborough Express,2)

With regard to alluvial diggings, a few I hear are doing fairly well "terracing" on the Lower Wilson, getting some rough "shotty" gold. (Jun 28, 1894,Otago Witness,16)

n. a horizontal shelf on the side of a hill, or sloping ground [cf. terrace bottom, terrace workings]

FORSTER The Scenery of the country was bold & worthy of the Pencil of a Salvator Rosa, all the Sides of hills were steep, rocky, & on all the little slopes & small terrasses or Settlements covered with fine shrubs, of various kinds; we saw here a great many Palmtrees, [ed. fn Cordyline sp.] of the same kind as had been found on April Ye 24th. (Apr 27, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/267)

[The Rangitata Valley bottom] consisted of a large swamp from which arose terrace after terrace up the mountains. ... The country is, as it were, crumpled up in an extraordinary manner, so that it is full of small ponds in lagoons - sometimes dry - sometimes merely swampy - now as full of water as they could be. (Jun 1860,Forest Creek MS,36,1960 ed.)

BUTLER I had to cross the Waimakiriri just after a fresh, ... and I assure you I did not like it. I crossed it first on the plains, where it flows between two very high terraces ... of which the most northern must be ... 300 feet high. Ibid. vii/96 The terraces, which are so abundant all over the back country, and which rise, one behind another, to the number, it may be, of twenty or thirty, with the most unpicturesque regularity (on my run there are fully twenty), are supposed to be elevated sea-beaches. They are to be seen even as high as four or five thousand feet above the level of the sea, and I doubt not that a geologist might find traces of them higher still. (Mar 1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,v/62)

These old lake beds [in the upper Clutha] are composed of loose drift ... and are generally known by the name of `terraces', although that phrase is more particularly applicable to the remarkable elevations of the Maruherikia and Upper Clutha valleys, which closely resemble military earthworks with glacis-like slopes and surprisingly uniform surfaces. ...[18] ...Terrace workings are in many places proving highly remunerative (1863,AJHR,D/6/16) [NOTES: Pyke Goldfields Report]

WALKER (Central Otago) The hill was formed of terraces or steps about 1 or 2 ft high, ... (Jan 19, 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker))

BARKER We drove for some miles till we came to the edge of one of the high terraces common to New Zealand scenery: ... (1865,Station Life in NZ,27,1870 ed.)

LINDSAY Throughout the Province are to be found numerous remains of former extensive lakes, estuaries, and rivers in the form of flats' andterraces' of clay, loam, grass, or sand ... (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,31)

EVANS These questions have reference to gulley workings mainly as I am aware the miner cannot cut a Race on those Runs to work the terraces with ... (1962,Waikaka Saga,18) [NOTES: 1870 Nov 30 in 1962 Evans Waikaka Saga 18]

MONEY We saw it in their claim (which was on a terrace some fifty feet above the creek) the morning after its discovery. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,97)

PYKE The scene opens on a rolling plain, flanked by rocky spurs' of the ever-present mountains; a plain of unequal surface, broken byterraces', and watercourses, and of varying width - irregular. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,3/iii/81,1889,1974 ed.)

CAIRD The words terrace' andflat', so often used, rather aptly describe the general nature of the country. A flat means a plain, but it is a rare thing to gallop along a flat for more than a mile without coming across a terrace, which terrace may be only six feet high, or it may be a hundred ... [and] is certain to be as regular as if it formed part of some ornamental ground. (1874,NZ Sheepfarming,26)

KENNEDY One of the men waded up to his knees and shoved off the boat to the edge of the `terrace', where it was caught by the rush of the deeper stream [fording the Waitaki river]. (1877,Colonial Travel,192)

PYKE It is on these Terraces (many of which are of considerable extent), ...that our gold miners pursue their avocations ... (1881,White Hood and Blue Cap,4)

RIVER TERRACES [title] ...One of the most remarkable features in the scenery of the South Island ... is the series of river terraces which flank the broad shingle-filled vallies [sic] on either side. (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,511) [NOTES: (Hutton)]

MITCHELL I afterwards heard that a party of men drove a tunnel into the terrace ..., and got a pile out of it. (1889,Rhyme or Reason,19)

PRINCE The Falls were soon arrived at, and standing ... upon a little terrace of cutty grass, a full ... view was obtained. (1889,Diary of a Trip,11)

[West Coast] terrace flats ... covered with Red and Black Pine ... . (1892,Letter) [NOTES: 1892 letter to Strauchan in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 175]

DOBSON A number of gold-diggers were working in the neighbourhood, some on the beaches and some on the adjoining terraces. (1930,Reminiscences,141)

LEVY On steep hillsides stock will tend to track and contour the land, and the ultimate surface formation of well-stocked country will be a series of broad or narrow terraces with steep slopes between them upon which stock seldom tread. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,254,1970 ed.)

PEARSON (1963,Coal Flat,156)

DAVIN (1970,Not Here, Not Now,19)

Besides, river workings being subject to damage from floods, are much more precarious ventures than terrace workings; and the Kawarau can flood at times, and does so pretty often. (Nov 26, 1887,Otago Daily Times,6)

Braemar is situated upon a flat green terrace between the town and the Tasman river bed. (Jan 13, 1898,Otago Witness,25)

This pah is pleasantly situate [sic] on the terrace of the cliff, where the hills rise more gradually from its edge. (May 9, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

I walked along these cliffs this evening before sundown, and was charmed at the sight of our pretty town lying snugly in lovely dells and on the slopes of natural terraces, beyond which in the South towered the mountain and the Kaitake Ranges, while Paritutu stood sentinel in the West. (Feb 6, 1907,Taranaki Herald,3)

PFAFF I sunk a shaft on the Larrikin's Terrace there, but it proved a duffer. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,56)

On a terrace below the Karitane Home, there is a small but well-equipped laboratory. (1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),II(22) : 12)

DAVIN "We were having a wonderful party up in Royal Terrace." (1970,Not Here, Not Now,30)

PEARSON They stopped.. where they could look.. across Coal Creek to the terrace where the dredge gouged and scraped with weird screams. They breathed a sense of expansion from the open space over the flat terrace across the Creek. (1963,Coal Flat,156)

terrace bottom¶

n. [Cf. bottom n]

South of Hokitika, there are no marine deposits on higher levels beyond the existing run of the beaches; the `terrace bottom' (i.e. gravel ^ash) abuts on the lagoons. (1906,Mining Handbook,124)

".. The tunnel is just on the border line, and Mr Morgan is of the opinion that the tunnel is leaving the terrace bottom and coming into wash." (Nov 13, 1883,Grey River Argus,2)

The underlying brown terrace bottom, which is now within 18 inches of the black laths, is more like soft sandstone than the usual gravel conglomerate. (Apr 4, 1916,Grey River Argus,4)

Cumming's claim, adjoining the latter company, is worked by three shifts, night and day, and maintains a very high reputation among those contributing our golden harvest. It is one which has a long time yet in store ere the necessity will arise to sink for the fifth or terrace bottom. (Feb 20, 1871,West Coast Times,2)

Nature of country sunk through between second and third bottoms, fine gravel with terrace bottom, watery drift and sandy clay, coarse light gravel, and admixture of clay and gravel. (Dec 7, 1899,Otago Witness,19)

They intend sinking for the terrace bottom, which they expect to reach at about 200 feet. (Aug 13, 1867,West Coast Times,4)

terrace of houses¶

phr. trousers [ORIGIN: rhyming slang]

I decked myself out in a box of fruit, with knife creased terrace of houses, polished up the mary lous, locked up the shovel and headed for the racetrack. terrace of houses....trousers (May 21, 1963,NZ Truth,19)

terrace working¶

n. [goldmining, usually plural, occasionally terrace-working]

With this invention [sc. Smith's jet pump] we applied to Warden Beetham for a special claim of one mile in length of the Shotover, but as we would not divulge our modus operandi in compliance with the Mining Act, the application for our special claim fell through; when we determined to rest on our oars until our terrace workings were played out. (Jul 20, 1899,Otago Witness,22)

Besides, river workings being subject to damage from floods, are much more precarious ventures than terrace workings; and the Kawarau can flood at times, and does so pretty often. (Nov 26, 1887,Otago Daily Times,6)

It was resolved .. that alluvial gold-mining was on a different footing from any other branch of industry, and to ensure the success of the schemes for high terrace workings, water-power for pumping purposes should be granted free in all cases affecting alluvial undertakings. (Jul 28, 1909,Bay of Plenty Times,3)

At the last sitting of the Warden's Court, applications were granted for 400 acres of a prospecting area, in addition to the scope of ground already held in the immediate locality of the Seddon's Terrace workings. (Mar 19, 1920,Grey River Argus,2)

terracette¶

n. [cf bench]

Terracette and miniature scarps are to be seen on many slopes throughout Hawke's Bay ... (1946,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,27/158)

terraki¶

n. (See tarakihi)

Terralink¶

n. New name of map-making section of Lands & Survey

Oh, all right, it's Terralink, as in map-making. But it certainly rattled the dags of its board when its practically irreplaceable core specialists demanded the right to take part in a buyout. (May 27, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

terrier¶

n. a member of the Territorial Army (cf. Terry)

... and to try and prevent the anti-militarists from doing anything foolish concerning same, I dare to give a little advice: Join theTerriors,' preach your doctrines, educate, agitate, demonstrate, surely any cause deserves a little sacrifice. (Sep 15, 1911,Maoriland Worker,28/17/2)

A jockey named Geo. Jas. Lee, charged before a Feilding Court with being a defaulting `terrier,' produced a doctor's certificate showing he had been undergoing medical attention. (Jan 18, 1913,NZ Truth,395/1/6)

terrior¶

n. (See terrier)

Territorial¶

n.

INGRAM Those of us who had received training as Territorials were asked to-day whether we would care for stripes. (Jan 9, 1917,Anzac Diary,10,1987 ed.)

McLINTOCK The Defence Act of 1909 created The Territorial Force; ... (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/384)

LELAND Territorials: The army RESERVES, weekend warriors, not to mention a fortnight in January. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,102)

PUGSLEY The organisation had been outlined by Field Marshal Lord Kitchener on a visit to New Zealand in 1910. All New Zealanders from the ages of 14 to 30 years were liable for part-time military training. Boys from 14 to 18 years served in the senior cadets, and young men from 18 to 25 years served as Territorial soldiers with the regionally affiliated regiments and battalions - hence the name `Territorial'. Service in the reserve was a requirement from the age of 25 to 30, but legislation allowed for this service to be extended up to the age of 55 years in the case of a national emergency. The same legislation allowed the Territorial Force to be mobilised by proclamation for service in New Zealand, and Section 26 (1) of the 1909 Defence Act made provision for members of the Territorial Force to volunteer for special service outside New Zealand. (1984,Gallipoli: the New Zealand Story,38)

Territorial Customary Right¶

n. (See TCR)

A2 But there was concern at how a finding in the High Court of a Territorial Customary Right (TCR) would be given effect, and Government MPs were looking at ways to give the courts some guidelines. (Nov 5, 2004,Dominion Post)

terroirism¶

n.

If terroirism was established here, the result would be rich, engaged regional communities producing food and drink that commanded high prices on international markets, providing handsome returns for farmers for taking care of their land. (Apr 2, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),37)

terror¶

n. used for anything surprisingly distinctive or outstanding, either good or bad; a great one for, usu. humorous [thus different in sense or application from P8: something large or forbidding of its kind; something allegedly difficult to handle: contrast Holy Terror or Terror]

Owing to the inclemency of the weather - the preceding night being "a terror" for wind and rain, when the wind blew as "'twad blawn its last," and the rain fell in torrents, and Friday being also a cold and stormy day (the dark clouds began to disperse and there was a gleam of sunshine about 4 o'clock) - the attendance was not so large as was anticipated. (Nov 29, 1878,Clutha Leader,6)

The son of our next-door neighbour is of an inquisitive turn of mind (writes "Marcia"), and, as his father, says, it "a terror for finding out things," Mr. M_____ tries to get even with the small questioning son sometimes, but doesn't always manage it. (Jun 8, 1910,Colonist (Nelson),1)

14 Billy is one of those players who get right into the thick of it, and is a terror for work. (Sep 9, 1922,Evening Post,14)

There was a young farmer of Kent, / Such a terror for using strong scent / That he sprayed himself over / With otto de clover, / And bees chased him wherever he went. (Jul 14, 1937,Evening Post,10)

KERSHAW .. the roads were terrors, the lake was a terror, some of the women were terrors .. Terror is a New Zealand adjective. Shilling knives are advertised as `perfect terrors'. You can't go far wrong if you call a thing a terror. (1886,Colonial Facts and Fictions,266)

DAVIN Your uncle was a terror for the drink after you went away. (1947,For the Rest of Our Lives,24)

COMMENT: `I'm a terror for my veges'. (1961,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: programme about Christmas foods]

[The plough] would quite often overturn. Having done so, it was a terror of a thing to get upright again. (Oct 30, 1963,Weekly News,[farming page])

Terry¶

n. a member of the Territorial Army (cf. terrier)

Trouble for the Terries. (Jun 30, 1941,2NZEF Times,1/1)

SLATTER He could have gone on to Otago if he'd pushed it but he went into the terries and then overseas when he was twenty-one. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,134)

SLATTER Talking of tin hats, said Captain Southam. Remember old Bluey when we were in the Terries. (1968,Pagan Game, The,86)

McGILL Terries, the Territorial Army; ref. Partridge and Gordon Slatter; c. 1930. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,112)

One feature of New Zealand speech that is often commented on by visitors is our inordinate fondness for abbreviations which end in ie' ory'. ... [11] ... Military types often belong to the Terries. (Jan 1989,Pacific Way,10) [NOTES: (Sharp New Zildish)]

test¶

n. milk test

CONDON Of the quality of milk being received, the test stands high. (1992,Hurleyville,109) [NOTES: Quoted from 1901]

tester¶

n. a herd-tester

tester: a person who visits farms and tests milk for butter fat content; e.g., `The tester's at Jack's farm tonight.' (1981,NZ Police National Headquarters) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

n. (Rural) a herd-tester.

After much too long a break the tester comes back into the shed during the next week or two. (Apr 11, 1960,NZ Dairy Exporter,43)

1 n. (Science) a cow, when its milk is being tested for butterfat or milk solid content.

The preference for the Jersey is largely due to the fact that the co-operative companies have adopted the system of paying for milk on the butter-fat content, and the Jersey being a high tester appears to return a better profit to the owner than any other breed. (Jul 5, 1923,Hawera Star,3)

To improve your average test you would require to either cull your low-testers which is not always advisable, and replace with high testing animals. (Dec 20, 1928,NZ Dairy Exporter,30)

testing station¶

n.

testing station NZ establishment where motor vehicles are tested for roadworthiness. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,794)

tete¶

n. Aythya novae seelandiae

TAYLOR We shot some [several???] Tetes, but could not hit them, because they dived so frequently. . . [fn]Generic name for small ducks of the kind commomly called Teal. The only one of these that dives readily is the Black Teal or Scaup (Aythya novae seelandiae) (1959,Early Travellers,354) [NOTES: 1858 [Jan 7???] S.P. Smith Journey from Taranaki in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 354]

2 n.

FALLA et al. GREY TEAL Anas gibberifrons Maori name: Tete. ... Like the Grey Duck has pale throat, but noticeably smaller ... (1966,Birds of New Zealand,88)

Grey Teal Anas gibberifrons gracilis BULLER, 1869 ... OTHER NAME: Tete. ... Native to Australia, New Guinea and New Caledonia. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,145)

2 n.

HUTTON 100. RHYNCHASPIS VARIEGATA. Gould. Shoveller. Tete (1871,Birds of New Zealand,37)

BULLER SPATULA {RHYNCAPSIS} VARIEGATA. (NEW-ZEALAND SHOVELLER.) ... Native name. Tete, {Pateke,} Putaitai, Kuriwhengi, {Kuruwhengu, Papaungungu,} Kahoho, and Wetawetangu; `Spoon-bill Duck' of the colonists. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,252,{1888 2nd edn 2/269} ed.)

4 n.

Querquedula gibberifrons. - Tete, Little Teal. Both Islands; Australia, New Caledonia, Indian Archipelago. (1886,TrNZI,18/117) [NOTES: (Martin)]

tete-whero¶

n. brown teal

BULLER ANAS CHLOROTIS. (BROWN DUCK.) ... Native names.- Tarawhatu, Patete, {Tete,} and Tete-whero. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,248,1888 2nd edn 2/257 ed.)

teteaweka¶

n.

Tete-a-waka .. Olearia angustifolia .. Timber small and of little use (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,15)

CHEESEMAN O[learia] angustifolia, Hook.f. ... SOUTH ISLAND ... near Bluff Hill ... STEWART ISLAND: sea-coast south of Paterson's Inlet ... Titi-a-weka. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,281)

CHEESEMAN O[learia] angustifolia, Hook.f. ... SOUTH ISLAND ... near Bluff Hill ... STEWART ISLAND: sea-coast south of Paterson's Inlet ... Titi-a-weka. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,281)

COCKAYNE A close relation of O[learia] operina, the teteawaka (O. angustifolia) ... (1910,NZ Plants,76)

HOWARD Along the coastal fringes [of Stewart Island] it consists of a characteristic scrub known locally as `Mutton-bird scrub', the principal constituents ... being Puheretaiko (Senecio Rotundifolius), Tete-a-weka (Olearia Angustifolia) and Daisy Tree (Olearia Colensoi). (1940,Rakiura,xvii)

SANSOM In the house, big fire of dead tete-a-weka wood going. Two witch's pots (small edition of a whaler's try-pot) and a camp oven swinging above the fire. Titis sizzling in their own kato fat (fat from insides). Piro fat, the fine fat from the intestines, is more precious. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,154) [NOTES: 1952 Apr 20 in 1982 Sansom In the Grip of an Island 154]

MARTIN The TETE-A-WEKA of Bluff and Stewart Island [Olearia angustifolia] and (O. operina) of the west coast sounds are similer plants. (1961,Flora Mt Cook,200,1929 ed.)

McLINTOCK Teteaweka, Olearia angustifolia [title] ... O. angustifolia is a very attractive plant with purple flowers and comes from coastal areas along Foveaux Strait. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,1/440)

MOORE & IRWIN OLEARIA CHATHAMICA, keketerehe. A few species of Olearia have purple disc florets -O. angustifolia, the teteaweka of southern Southland and Stewart Island, and, in the Chathams, ... O. chathamica on drier ridges. (1978,Oxford Book of Contemporary NZ Poetry,130)

WILSON On one visit we were thrilled to find a Titiaweka in flower. It had a large daisylike flower, the centre of which is ringed with clusters of tiny yellow flowers. (1979,Titi Heritage,83)

SANSOM Herekopare and Woman's Island are the only two beneficiary muttonbird islands. All the rest are Crown lands. ... I know ... that the fierce nettle also grows on Herekopare. Other lovely ... plants are there too - the Stewart Island yellow senecio, teteaweka of course, ... Cook's health-giving scurvy grass, soft native tatahi grass and punui, the giant-leafed umbrella-like araliad. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,69)

WILSON Olearia oporina TEETEEAWEKA ...Shrub or small tree ... Common, windswept coastal scrub and shrubland ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,98)

The teteaweka - muttonbird scrub - is in flower; white petals, waxy, serrated leaves, purple-black buds. (Mar 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 56/105)

tetepango¶

n.

BULLER FULIGULA NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (NEW-ZEALAND SCAUP.) ... Native names. Papango, Tetepango, Matapouri, Titiporangi, and Raipo; Black Teal' andWidgeon' of the Colonists. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,259,1888 2nd edn 2/273 ed.)

tether-my-cow¶

n. humorous alteration of Taramakau (river)

BUTLER We have seen the water flowing down the Teramakau (or `Tether-my-cow', as the Europeans call it). (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,67,1915 ed.)

tetra brik¶

n. a cardboard carton for milk etc.; cf. tetra pack

[He] claims that milk will keep for up to a week in an unopened tetra brik... (Jun 28, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

Teurian¶

adj. Geol. classification

The lower Teurian age for the vertebrate/lingual horizon makes this locality the most important in New Zealand for providing a record of Lower Paleocene elasmobranchs. (Jul 1981,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,53/37)

The Cretaceous-Tertiary boundary in New Zealand is generally placed at the boundary between the Teurian and Haumurian Stages (Hornibrook 1962). (Nov 1978,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,46/13)

tewhatawhata¶

n.

The Maori was armed with a tewhatawhata, a wooden weapon shaped like a battleaxe, with a long handle, and a plume of hawk's leathers just below the blade. (Nov 1937,NZ Railways Magazine,19)

tewhatewha¶

n. a long axe-like Maori weapon, usually of wood and having both blade and sharpened handle. [ORIGIN: Maori]

The carved weapons of the Maori on which he lavished so much of his artistic skill are well represented in stone and bone mere, taiaha, and tewhatewha. (Oct 16, 1925,Evening Post,9)

Boys were taught at a very tender age the use of weapons when they indulged in mock battles in which reeds and flax stems were used in practising movements they would later use in earnest when the taiaha and tewhatewha were in their hands. (Apr 1958,Te Ao Hou,22: 45)

The tewhatewha, or paiaka, was used in somewhat similar fashion to the taiaha. (1894,TrNZI,26/441)

tewhatewha, a weapon with a terminal broad semi-crescent of one side, the other end sharpened for thrusting, the lower side of the crescent pierced with a hole for attachment of a small tuft of feathers, such as pigeon-feathers, the weapon being largely used in oratory. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

SHORTLAND ... the taiaha, a kind of two-handed sword made of the hardest wood of the country; and the tewhatewha, a wooden battle-axe, having a sharp-pointed handle to enable it also to answer the purpose of a spear. (1856,Traditions & Superstitions,244)

TREGEAR Another weapon of authority or direction was the battle-axe (tewha-tewha or paiaka) made of bone or hard wood. (1904,Maori Race, The,312)

BAUCKE (1928,Where the White Man Treads,57, 137)

REISCHEK Others carried wooden lances or long, hatchet-like weapons called tewhatewha. (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,152,1933 ed.)

The energy of the paddling - the rhythm of it! The time-giver stood on the thwarts, a feather-tufted tewha tewha in his extended hand; ... the time-giver sang his song ... (1930,NZ Short Stories,30) [NOTES: J.C.Anderson]

BUCK (1944,Coming of the Maori, The,2/274)

The Constabulary at work in the vicinity of the Gate Pah unearthed a perfect handsome tewhatewha of whalebone, solid, with blade eight inches long. (Jun 10, 1876,Evening Post,2)

A Tewhatewha or paiaka, a wooden P-shaped weapon, with hawk-feathers tied below the blade, looks innocent now under the glass, but it figured grimly only in a treacherous murder in the time of William IV., 1832. (Feb 18, 1911,Evening Post,9)

The eight natives who had returned from the Front then stepped forward with their arms, seven flint muskets and one tewhatewha. (Apr 2, 1864,Daily Southern Cross,3)

text dump¶

n. ending a relationship by text message

She is alarmed by stories of boyfriends breaking up with their girlfriends by text message and vice-versa (a phenomenon one girl labels "the text dump"). (Dec 28, 2004,Sunday Star Times,A11)

textual intercourse¶

n. communication by texting

thanks¶

exclam. for please' orthank(ing) you in anticipation' in usu. shopping contexts as, e.g. shop-person to customer, when a finalisation of a transaction is anticipated: That will be $1.99 thanks.' [1987 Dec p.c. Professor G.E. Hughes (Wellington)Noticed over the years, and reminded again recently, that this seems a NZ usage or idiom as distinct from British usage.']

thar¶

n.

This dramatic recovery of native plants... results from a huge reduction in the populations of introduced feral deer, chamois (European antelope) and, in some places, of Himalayan thar (mountain goat). (Nov 2002,Forest & Bird,306/2)

that would be¶

phr. = that is (hinting for polite agreement with the speaker)

BALLANTYNE I dare say he was pissed and confused.'That would be the strong of it, `said Sid. (1978,Talkback Man,193)

McGILL Nah,' said Fred.... Now that'd be maize over there. Not for Watties. More for meal. ...' (1985,G'day Country,68)

that'll be the day¶

phr. expressing doubt, disapproval, etc., of a statement or request; used ironically for something most unlikely to happen. [also that will be the day; (cf. 1867 Lady Barker Station Life (1874) 113 [a cockie speaks] Ah but it'll be a far day first [before I'll believe that].) ca1935 at least e.g.I thought you were at church.' That'll be the day.'That'll be the day when you see me there.']

"That will be der ruddy tag," said the bloke. (Jan 10, 1944,NZEF Times,III/133 : 7)

"That'll be the day," chorused half a dozen Kiwis. (Dec 18, 1944,NZEF Times,IV/182 : 5)

"THE DAY THE BOOKIES WEPT" .. That WILL be the Day! Under that'll be the day (Feb 7, 1940,Evening Post,2)

BAKER That'll be the day! used as a cant phrase expressing mild doubt... (1941,NZ Slang,50)

PARTRIDGE That'll be the day! `Expressing mild doubt following some boast or claim,' B., 1941: New Zealand: C. 20. See also day, that'll be the. (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1199)

HARVEY I asked some Wellington people if they'd like a shine, and all they said was, You've got a bloody nerve,' orThat'll be the day,' or something mean like that. (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,35)

TURNER That'll be the day, a way of expressing a strong disinclination to do something, was unknown to visiting Americans during the war, one of whom thought it expressed gay anticipation and answered `That'll be the day' when asked to visit a New Zealand family. The expression was worked to death and in its dying agonies produced some contortions as That'll be the frosty Friday etc. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,177)

McGILL That'll be the day c/p expressing doubt or incredulity; NZ since 1930s, widespread elsewhere; also, that'll be the bloody day, boy! (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,112)

MARSH He's a beaut. Wait till I get him. That'll be the day. (1943,Colour Scheme,101)

MARSH If I've bungled', Alleyn muttered,I've .. bungled in a big way.' .. Bailey astonished everyone by saying .. That'll be the day.'Don't talk Australian', Mr Fox chided. (1951,Opening Night,248)

HENDERSON Onward. "That'll be the Day," we say. "The Day" is getting closer. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,239)

"That'll be the day!" she snorted. (Aug 14, 1947,NZ Woman's Weekly: The First 60 Years,17)

That will be the Day... Tokyo will get worse punishment that London ever got. "That will be the day." (Sep 7, 1942,NZEF Times,II/62 : 8)

that'll be the frosty Friday¶

phr.

HENDERSON In a Quartermaster's store? That will be the Frosty Friday. (1945,Gunner Inglorious,131)

TURNER That'll be the day, a way of expressing a strong disinclination to do something, was unknown to visiting Americans during the war, one of whom thought it expressed gay anticipation and answered `That'll be the day' when asked to visit a New Zealand family. The expression was worked to death and in its dying agonies produced some contortions as That'll be the frosty Friday etc. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,177)

McGILL that'll be the frosty Friday/frozen fortnight Kiwi variants of `that'll be the day', which Partridge thinks derives from WWI officer usage. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,112)

that'll be the sunny afternoon¶

phr. that'll be the day [ca1949 (Dunedin) fide R. Mason That'll be the Saturday afternoon; or That'll be the sunny Sunday afternoon]

There are [from 2NZEF], of course, the eternal variations on the old theme which nearly wrecked New Zealand's slang two or three years ago - That'll be the day,'That'll be the sunny afternoon', and so on. (Jan 28, 1944,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20) [NOTES: L R Hobbs]

SLATTER That'll be the Sunday afternoon,' says Spandau Craig ...You're only saying that. ... What have you been up to in these parts? Lashing out on your eight and a bender?' (1970,On the Ball,137)

that's right¶

phr. as an affirmation or agreement cf she's right; easy

Happily, there is not at present any decided New Zealand accent, but certain very objectionable expressions are current, and by no means only in the sermo plebei. I have heard this, or variants of it, quite frequently:- First decently dressed youth: Well, how's things?' Second decently dressed youth:Oh, jest like this, yer know.' First d.d.y.: `That's right!' (Jan 10, 1910,Triad, The,4)

that's the shot¶

exclam. an expression of agreement or approbation [AND 1953]

that's the stuff¶

phr. Assent or support or agreement.

How are you Phil? Quite all right. That's the stuff. (Sep 5, 1998,Radio Pacific,00)

thatched¶

adj. (of wool)

Add to that their superb mothering ability and a type of thatched wool that keeps out the wet and you have the perfect Taihape sheep, Mr Rowe says. (Jun 20, 2003,Dominion Post,C5)

thatching¶

n. a kind of wool

The oval lock, or thatching, keeps out water and means the lambs survive storms at lambing and flystrike in summer. (Jun 20, 2003,Dominion Post,C5)

THC¶

abbr. Tourist Hotel Corporation

After the wars years, [the Chateau] reopened to the public under the control of the government-owned Tourist Hotel Corporation (THC), which also developed ski facilities up the hill. (Oct 8, 2001,Evening Post,20)

theatre¶

n. cinema, pictures (check picture theatre [Jim writes: NSOD tags this as now chiefly NAmer Austral. and NZ. Not in DNZE. Though perhaps now less common, the word is still often used in NZ in this sense at an informal level.]

TURNER (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The)

theatre ... 8. Austral. & N.Z. the usual word for cinema. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1213) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 796; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 498]]

FRAME There are two theatres opposite each other, the Regent and the Miami. (1960,Owls Do Cry,82)

n.
