there's an old boot for every sock¶

phr. -

LELAND there's an old boot for every sock: a phrase bearing reassurance for all those seeking spouse or paramour. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,103)

thermal area¶

n.

The bridge will be specially carved in Maori designs to provide a unique entrance to the thermal area. (Oct 7, 1933,Evening Post,8)

The discovery of a new thermal area four and a half miles from Rotorua, on the Taupo highway at Waiotapu, was made by engineers engaged on the new Waikiti Valley road from Waiotapu to Ngakuru, states a Rotorua correspondent. (Mar 15, 1940,Evening Post,6)

STAFFORD The first "tourist".. in Rotorua... was John Bidwill, the great naturalist, who.. apart from examining the Rotorua thermal areas, acquired some notoriety by.. transgressing this tapu place. (1977,Romantic Past of Rotorua,9)

After all, argued Mr. Fox, a good many holes had been bored in the thermal areas of the North Island. (Sep 7, 1955,Evening Post,10)

thermal district¶

n.

Owing, it is believed, to the increase of railway fares, there were fewer visitors to the thermal district during the recent holidays than during the previous Christmas and New Year Season. (Jan 20, 1918,Evening Post,6)

But if we are to reap the full benefit from the opening up of communication between Auckland and the Lakes via [sic] Waikato, we must have a speedier means of communication with the Thermal Districts than now exists, and hence this action of our Auckland neighbours should stimulate the people of Tauranga not to let the proposal to construct a railway, via Te Puke, meet the fate that has attended so many promising schemes launched before the public of Tauranga. (Oct 31, 1881,Bay of Plenty Times,2)

Much has been written and more has been said concerning the wonders and miraculous healing properties of the SPRINGS AT WAIRAKIE AND ROTORUA, But by far the most wonderful of all the Hot Springs in the Thermal district are the BATHING PUIAS OF TOKAANU. (Jan 2, 1890,Wanganui Herald,3)

thermal spring¶

n. [usually plural]

Here, again, the chief attraction of the thermal springs which issue close to the margin of the lake. (Apr 6, 1844,Daily Southern Cross,4)

To the north of this line, the volcanic action appears to have entirely ceased, if we except certain thermal springs which rise in several localities in New Ulster, and which although not situated in volcanic districts, indicate that a channel of communication has been opened with the interior of the earth, at some former period of local convulsion. (May 28, 1852,Daily Southern Cross,2)

Areas where decomposition and siliceous infiltration have affected the rocks will be recognised by ferruginous springs and by the occurrence of large blocks of the quartz cement, which though non-auriferous in itself yet indicates the former agency of thermal springs. (Oct 31, 1867,Wellington Independent,41)

Amongst the manifold blessings bountiful Nature has bestowed upon New Zealand, to which hitherto very little or no attention has been paid, none deserve our consideration more than the thermal springs situated towards the central parts of both islands. (May 11, 1870,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

A Bill to provide for the settlement of the thermal springs districts of the Colony was brought in by the Hon F. WHITAKER, and read a first time. (Aug 27, 1881,Star, The,4)

CONFERENCE ON THERMAL SPRINGS. (Sep 21, 1898,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

Bath Houses at Pipiriki Thermal Springs now open. (Dec 21, 1907,Wanganui Herald,1)

It repeals the Thermal Springs Act of 1908, which was designed to reserve districts containing thermal springs, and makes other provision in its place. (Feb 3, 1911,Evening Post,3)

There are several thermal springs, of which the temperature is variable, ranging from 105 to 124 degrees in the hottest parts. (Jul 31, 1926,Evening Post,15)

THERMAL Springs and Pools; Ketetahi Blowholes. (Mar 18, 1938,Evening Post,1)

Thermal Spring's Level Drops. (Jul 20, 1900,Evening Post,4) [NOTES: Year is incorrect]

thermal wonderland¶

n.

STAFFORD All of this fuelled the desire of a multitude to travel into what was now being described as "The Thermal Wonderland." (1977,Romantic Past of Rotorua,10)

From Auckland, tourists would typically head for the thermal wonderland of the central North Island. (Nov 2003,AA Directions,No. 58/55)

A LECTURE will be given in St. THOMAS'S SCHOOLROOM .. Subject: "Our Thermal Wonderland." (Jul 3, 1908,Evening Post,8)

She decided to go to Waiotapu, a witch's brew of blasting steam, bubbling pools, heaving mud and giddy smells, a storm of the senses in a Thermal Wonderland. (Apr 5, 1993,Evening Post,13)

thermette¶

n. [brand name, cf. Benghazi burner]

BRIDGES & DOWNS The original Thermette was first sold in 1931 in a blue, green and orange tin, or in tinned copper if you had a few extra bob. (2000,No 8 Wire: The Best of Kiwi Ingenuity,33)

[Hoarding on advertising car in photo] THERMETTE 12 cups of tea in 5 minutes. To the farmer, camper, picnicker & motorist "The more wind the quicker it boils". (Jun 10, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34) [NOTES: 1930-1940 vintage]

The Thermette, that old water-boiler-in-an-instant without which no New Zealand picnic was once complete is undergoing something of a revival. Thermette buyers.. are mostly middle-aged... For a while the Thermette also sold in Australia as "The Great New Aussie Billie" so named, says Mr Tull heavily, "because the Australians invented everything. (Jan 14, 1999,Dominion,9)

I'm not sure whether my useless, but quirky, thing will qualify. It is a thermette. For those who do not know what this is, it is one of the finest inventions to come out of New Zealand. An ingenious means of boiling water. (Oct 6, 2001,Dominion Weekend Magazine,4)

Stevens agreed with Orsman in most respects, except that he said Hart got his first patent for the Thermette on October 29. 1930, and the later one was an extension... Both sources agreed that Kiwi soldiers nicknamed it the Benghazi boiler (after a coastal town in Libya), and that every desert unit had one as standard equipment (Sep 18, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

Many a miserable night in the bush as been made more bearable by John Hart's wonderful Thermette. The idea was simple - a jug with a chimney up the middle of it and a built-in fireplace underneath (Nov 30, 1999,Evening Post,27)

[Advt.] Complete your Camping-Boating Holdiday by a Thermette. 12 cups of tea or coffee in five minutes with a genuine Thermette. (Dec 1964,Sea Spray,14)

The Quick-boiling Picnic Kettle "THERMETTE". (Dec 4, 1930,NZ Truth,22)

BACON Thermette-An ingenious portable water-heater-fireplace, consisting of a short metal chimney surrounded by a water jacket. Extremely popular on picnic excursions, they will burn anything combustible, and provide a considerable quantity of boiling water in a very short time. (1963,In the Sticks,184)

ARMFELT But first Ray had to set up the thermette - a sort of tall cylindrical kettle, with a hollow up the middle in which Ray stuffed some paper and kindling for a fire. The fire was lit and the water in the walls around it boiled in next to no time. `She's a New Zealand invention, the thermette: the servicemen brought it back from the war'. (1971,Catching Up,59)

thermette: a genuine NZ word for a Benghazi, or a camp volcano (1981,Rangiora High School 1884-1984) [NOTES: Goldie Brown Collection]

Other families had "Thermettes", which I coveted as they involved lighting a real fire. (Nov 5, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),67)

How can we ever forget the rabbits and rabbiters, the thermette for the outdoor cuppa, home-made soap, felling trees with a cross-cut saw, splitting the logs with a maul, wedges and blasting gun? (Feb 2004,NZ Memories,No.46/46)

Harco Sales..was granted an extension of a patent issued on October 29, 1930, in the name of John Ashley Hart, in respect of an invention for 'means of heating water and cooking operations' called 'Thermette'. (Jun 10, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34) [NOTES: 1930 original use of word]

We had to stoke up this water-boiling contraption with small sticks and dry twigs. We stuffed them down a funnel on top of some crumpled newspaper. A strike of the match and, by the time dad had pulled off his waders, the water was boiling for mother to make a cup of tea... It was a Thermette. (Jun 10, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34)

I am glad to leave them, sprinkling water / Over the embers that heated the Thermette (Sep 1967,Landfall,21(3) No. 83 / 257)

In the meantime, no one can tell me if it's permissible to plonk a tartan car rug down on the front lawn of Huka Lodge, light up the Thermette, and tuck in to a good feed of curried egg sandwiches. (May 6, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

[Advt] For a stop on the road, there's little to beat the efficiency of the "Thermette." This wonderful little kettle burns twigs, paper, rubbish, etc., creating its own forced draught. (Sep 4, 1952,Evening Post,14)

I learned to stay downwind of the aromatic manuka-fuelled thermette to avoid the sandflies. (Sep 1998,North & South,34)

Some old soldiers rang in. They had used the same device during the desert campaign in World War II. But it hadn't been called a Thermette. They knew it as a Benghazi Boiler or chip heater. (Jun 10, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34)

thespo¶

n. an actor, a thespian

Musos and thespos like nothing better than to bask in the warm glow of each other's fame. (Apr 8, 2001,Sunday Star Times,F4)

they must have captured a sugar boat¶

phr.

PARTRIDGE captured a sugar-boat!, they (occas. we) must have. A cp explaining the issue of a liberal ration of sugar: NZders': in GW. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,127)

they're off, Mr Cutts¶

phr.

McLINTOCK In 1875 G.G.Stead (1841-1908), the famous race-horse owner, bought a half-share in Redwood's racing stud. Under the partnership agreement Stead managed the business side while the training was put in the hands of E. Cutts. The horses were raced in the name of one or other of the partners. This arrangement, which proved immensely successful, lasted into the 1890s and was terminated when Stead bought out Redwood's share of the stud. During his lifetime Henry Redwood was known as `the Father of the New Zealand Turf.' (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/58)

SCRYMGEOUR One student [of Canterbury Agricultural College], ... the son of a sporting and well-known racing baronet of North Canterbury, would take Jim into the stables at `Cutts' to see the horses in training; ... (1960,Memories of Maoriland,60)

They're off, Mr Cutts!' At least, they will be about three o'clock today (Saturday), and in less than four minutes afterwards, you will all know whether you have lost your money or not. (Nov 4, 1911,NZ Truth,332/6/4)

BENNETT Horse-racing, another popular pastime (including trotting races, or the trots) provides two colloquialisms which need explanation. The exclamation `They're off, Mr Cutts!', announcing that any contest or affair has begun, contains the name of a one-time popular starter at the Auckland races. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,90)

McLINTOCK Examples of slang and colloquial expressions of local origin are ... they're off Mr Cutts, for `the performance is about to start',... (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/680) [NOTES: Wall NZ Speech]

BAKER ...they're off Mr Cutts!, meaning things have started!' and ornow we're getting down to business!' (1941,NZ Slang,50)

PARTRIDGE They're off, Mr Cutts. is a C. 20 New Zealand shape (B., 1941) cf:- [monkey] (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1200)

McGILL they're off, Mr Cutts! the race has begun; Partridge identifies as a variant of they're off', said the monkey', usually indicating start of a horse race, hence as something that has come loose; often with addition:when he looked into the lawnmower and carelessly lost his testicles.' This addition may explain Mr Cutts. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,112)

"They're off, Mr Cutts!" Heaven only knows where the expression originated, but elderly Ted Cutts, Clifford's trainer, who is the person mentioned, was at Trentham, with his white hair trailing in the breeze. (Jan 25, 1908,NZ Truth,1)

THEY'RE OFF, MR CUTTS!! What's that left? Kennaquhair? No, that's Kennaquhair out in front, with Poitrel! (May 4, 1921,Ashburton Guardian,1)

they're off...¶

phr. they're off, as the monkey said when he got his balls caught in the chaff-cutter (lawnmower) [ca1935 Havelock (chaffcutter) ca1955 Upper Hutt (lawnmower)]

thick-leaved lancewood¶

n. Pseudopanax crassifolium

LAING & BLACKWELL lancewood, thick-leaved lancewood, Pseudopanax crassifolium, (1906,Plants of NZ)

thickeners¶

n.

McARA Thickeners: The vacuum thickeners were canvas-covered frames which allowed the water to be drawn off by reduced pressure inside the frames, thus thickening the pulp and requiring less cyanide to treat it. They worked in a similar manner to the vacuum filter-baskets. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),334)

thickhead¶

n.

GRAHAM Thickhead Cetonurus crassiceps (Gunther) (1955,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,403) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 403]

PAUL et al. thickhead 877 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

thieve out¶

v. to sneak out

MANSFIELD Isabel and Lottie, who liked visitors, went upstairs to change their pinafores. But Kezia thieved out at the back. Nobody was about; she began to swing on the big white gates ... . (1922,Stories,503,1984 Alpers ed.)

thigh-chain¶

1 n. (Rural) a chain used to secure a cow in a cow-bail for milking purposes.

The bails are fitted with thigh-chains. (Oct 20, 1926,NZ Journal of Agriculture,239)

thin `un¶

n.

British nicknames that have been current at some time in New Zealand's history include the following. A Sovereign was variously known as a jingle box, and a thick un,</i> while the half sovereign was obviously a <i>half-thickun, or sometimes a thin `un (Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,15)

thin as a hen's face¶

phr. very thin

`Blimey! Who's that joker? I'll bet he's cold - he's as thin as a hen's face. Looks as tough as a goat's knee tho'. (1945,Sixes & Sevens,16)

thin as the back of a chair¶

adj. very thin

MASTERS ... the sheep were half wild Merino wethers, as thin as the back of a chair, and as fast and scattery as a sou-westerly gale. (1960,Back-Country Tales,25)

thin client¶

n. hospital jargon for computer terminals connected to a central server.

"Thin clients", it was explained, were computer terminals connected to a central server. (Feb 21, 2002,Dominion,3)

thin-barked totara¶

n. (Environment) Podocarpus hallii

Podocarpus hallii thin-barked totara (1908,AJHR) [NOTES: (And) Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of the Tongariro National Park]

COCKAYNE Podocarpus hallii thin-barked totara (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The) [NOTES: (And)]

WILSON Podocarpus hallii HALL'S TOOTARA ... Thin-bark tootara (1982,Stewart Island Plants,52)

HOWARD In the northern and eastern portions of the Island, the predominant trees are Rimu ... accompanied by Miro (Podocarpus Ferrugineus), thin-barked Totara (Podocarpus hallii ) and southern Rata (Metrosideros Lucida). (1940,Rakiura,xviii)

Masses of grass tree, mountain totara, thin-barked totara, mountain celery pine, senecias, and others form a mass and tangle about fix feet high, under which one must crawl, or over the top of which one must walk; it is impossible to get through any other way. (Apr 1, 1929,Evening Post,8)

thing out¶

v.

The girlfriend was bringing him back to Gisborne because he had thinged out for four days, he wasn't sleeping, he had overdosed himself. (May 27, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

thingo¶

n. an obsessional notion; a `thing' (as in have a thing about something/somebody)

SLATTER I've just about had this cobber thingo, said Erik Johansen. Cobbers are cobbers when it suits them. (1968,Pagan Game, The,150)

things are lively on the Western Front¶

phr.

Things are Lively on the Western Front. - Previously a popular paper phrase. Used to be true, too. Now they give us baths and ointment. (1918,New Zealand At the Front,32)

Think Big¶

n. - [attrib. uses (also l.c.)]

It was he who saddled New Zealand with a think-big philosophy, which was really, I suppose, an antipodean example of a cargo cult gone mad. (1986,NZ Parliamentary Debates,471/2270)

Bill Birch appears to have been landed with much of the blame for the debacle over New Zealand Steel and other "Think Big" projects which have not performed up to expectations. (Feb 15, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),31)

MOORE On 29 September 1986, Cabinet invited me to prepare a report on the previous Government's decision-making on the Think Big projects. (1987,Hard Labour,92) [NOTES: 1986 Dec 16 in Moore Hard Labour (1987) 92]

The re-financing of the think-big debt has created ... (Feb 12, 1987,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Morning Report National Radio Richard Shallcrass, Treasury Financial Director]

WILKINSON The think big' policy is being mobilised here too. Too large a hospital means difficulties in communications, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 197 The reception given to National'sThink Big' policy had not been favourable....[fn] Significantly, it was later changed to `Think Growth'. (1981,NZ Way, The,138)

Birch has carried on. And on. There was Think Big with its billions of dollars of debt...Ibid. 31 There were six Think Big projects pushed through by Bill Birch as Minister of Energy and National Development in the lead-up to the 1981 election. .. In 1988 the Treasury calculated that the country was then $1.3 billion poorer because of Think Big projects, which accounted for 20 percent of all public debt. (Dec 12, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

His most enduring legacy.. was the massive debt burden created by his extravagant national superannuation scheme.. later exacerbated by the Think Big projects. (Aug 5, 1992,Evening Post,6)

Little changed behind the Think Big facade. (Aug 9, 1992,Dominion Sunday Times,9)

The Think Big projects came out of a national energy surplus that developed in the mid 1970s. (Sep 17, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

I believe a story we ran forced the Muldoon government to back off polluting a mussel reef on the Taranaki coast with waste from a think big plant. (2009,Mana,87/68)

1983 will go down in history as the year the Think Big projects literally started to take shape on the New Zealand skyline. (Apr 9, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

It was not so much an argument as a monologue - and discussed, like all "think big" disasters before it, as though the alternatives were this or nothing. (Nov 26, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

No to mention Muldoon's Thing Big / Lose Big programmes. (1997,Mana,Autumn : 72)

He wants the Council to start following a "Green City" programme aimed at reducing urban unemployment, and over-expenditure on "think big" style projects. (Oct 5, 1992,Salient,9)

When the Government sold the country its think-big strategy, it sold more than an economic game-plan - it put in motion forces which will have a profound impact on New Zealand. (Mar 13, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

n. an economic growth strategy developed by the National Government in the early 1980s to promote industrial development from natural resources such as natural gas and oil.

If our energy consumption has gone up by over 80% since Bill Birch visited Think Big on us, then aren't we in a bit of trouble? But of course I'm forgetting what Think Big was all about. (Nov 22, 2000,Capital Times,16)

But 'think big'.. was a sensible way of dealing with borrowing. (Oct 21, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

Is it the member for Franklin, the person who brought us "think big"; is it the member for Rotorua, son of "think big"; is it the member for Waitotara?... Ibid. The Prime Minister may achieve a $5.8 billion debt - as he called it - as a consequence of "think big" and several magnificant projects developed by our former government. (1986,NZ Parliamentary Debates,471/2272)

There has been unusual - and healthy - criticism of Mr Quigley's forced resignation and of the apparent stifling of debate about "think big". (Jul 10, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10)

Think Big now seems quite a noble thing in retrospect. (May 10, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

There is no doubt that Think Big was a flawed means of establishing a gas industry infrastructure but establish one it did. (May 2000,North & South,71)

Such will never be the fate of any biographer of Sir Robert Muldoon, the former prime minister of this country who invented Think Big, a best-forgotten big adventure with taxpayers' money. (Sep 1, 2011,Dominion Post,B4)

Birch has carried on. And on. There was Think Big with its billions of dollars of debt...Ibid. 31 There were six Think Big projects pushed through by Bill Birch as Minister of Energy and National Development in the lead-up to the 1981 election. .. In 1988 the Treasury calculated that the country was then $1.3 billion poorer because of Think Big projects, which accounted for 20 percent of all public debt. (Dec 12, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

Ian Wedde's 1975 "Pathway to the Sea" was so insightful about development and the environment, I asked him if he revised it in the light of "Think Big." (Jun 5, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),54)

Think Big was the tonne weight that broke the camel's back. (Aug 31, 2004,Dominion Post,B4)

Instead, we went for financial mysticism with even more disastrous consequences than "think big". (Aug 4, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

This is in contrast to the heady days from 1977 on when the [rural] sector had its own version of Think Big. (Sep 27, 1992,Dominion Sunday Times,18)

think no small beans of¶

phr. think highly of

All loyal Wanganuites think no small beans of the local fire brigade, and they have the same opinion of themselves. (Aug 4, 1906,NZ Truth,59/3/6)

think one is Christmas¶

phr. to have a high (sometimes undeserved) opinion of oneself [ca1938 at least, in Havelock: used by older women. She thinks she's Christmas in her new hat. 1922 Heard then in Pukekoke from one who came from the Hutt Valley. Was quite a new expression to us then and I do not recollect hearing it in Auckland.]

R. MASON Think oneself Christmas: (Jun 7, 1952,Letter)

JANE GODFREY We always used this expression of thinking someone or something else Christmas: `She thinks it's just Christmas' - meaning someone was especially delighted with something. There was no derogatory sense to it. (1985,Personal Communication)

think the sun shines out of one's arse¶

phr. [->1984 16 F E37 Pakuranga Coll. 17 HE THINKS THE SUN SHINES OUT OF HIS ARSE [M2] [describing a boaster] -->1984 17 M E99 Pakuranga Coll. 17 SUN SHINES OUT OF HIS ARSE]

HULME `O him, he'll be okay at the Tainuis. Marama and Wherahiko think the sun shines outa his arse excuse me. He's the white haired boy round there, literally. (1983,Bone People, The,116)

thinnie¶

n. (informal) one who is thin

Fatties, thinnies, oldies and youngsters have, literally, been walking themselves fit and healthy in the ground breaking Walk 2 Health Challenge. (Nov 29, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,1)

Third Echelon¶

n.

SINCLAIR & HARREX The troops left home in three 'Echelons'... The third turned up in Egypt in a new uniform and were referred to by 'grim digs' (old Kiwi hands) as 'the regimental boys'. (1978,Looking Back,215)

SANDYS The Government tried to decide whether to allow the Third Echelon to depart, or retain it in New Zealand against the growing Japanese threat. (1982,Love and War,185) [NOTES: 1989 edition]

third rail¶

n. (political use)

Over at National Party Central they have developed a code for those, ahem, awkward issues. They call them "third rail policies"... National's "third rail" is not a new policy alternative but a warning to its own politicians. The third rail on a railway track is the live one, the dangerous one. Touch its political equivalent and you risk a nasty electoral shock from the voting public... The politics of the third rail are simple: avoid, downplay or defuse issues for which the majority of the public has no stomach, even if the party and its MPs think they are desirable. (May 13, 2004,Dominion Post,C2)

Parallel to the economic message, Dr Brash is likely to continue softening some of the remaining "third rail" issues that national's strategists believe cost it votes at the September election. (Feb 13, 2006,Dominion Post,B7)

thirds¶

n. [local government; cf 'on thirds' rural]

No eligible tender for the work in Rising Sun Valley having been received, it was resolved that the work stand over, and that the Board should meet on next meeting day at 5.30 p.m. to go to Rising Sun Valley, to see to the work to be done there in forming and improving the road on Rabbit-hill by day-work, not to exceed GBP4 on thirds, Mr Bockman to direct the work. (Mar 1, 1893,Nelson Evening Mail,2)

A meeting representing the local bodies in the Ashley County, interested in the recovery of thirds of purchase money received by Government for Midland Railway lands, was held at Rangiora and it was decided to prepare a petition to Parliament. (Jul 9, 1902,West Coast Times,2)

The Kaiteke County Council, at its month[l]y meeting to-day agreed to invest GBP3000 of "hypothecated thirds" in the war loan. (Sep 3, 1917,Grey River Argus,3)

thirteen list¶

n.

[glossary] Thirteen List: Army Medical list showing personnel stricken by palsy, out the monk, or otherwise sick and ailing. (1946,Johnny Enzed in Italy)

thirty days¶

n. a card hand [[?3 x 10s]]

MIDDLETON Although he laid down three Jacks to the Aussie's thirty days, Johnson still looked white. (1964,Walk on the Beach,91) [NOTES: (Greaser's Story)]

thirty degrees below freezo¶

phr. very cold

HOLLOWAY The temperature of Reefton during the last two days, has been truly Siberian, or as it is locally expressed `Thirty degrees below Freezo'. (Jun 18, 1874,Journal of a Visit,117)

Thirty-Niner¶

n. Army veteran who enlisted in 1939;(often capital) one who volunteered for the First Echelon at the outbreak of World War II in 1939. often pl a soldier who volunteered for war service in 1939; a First Echelon man [cf. FOUR-FIGURE MAN, GRIM DIG)]

I asked the thirtyniner for his counsel on the subject and he replied... "You just pick it up, kickin' around... From the moment.. a thirty-niner guard told a myopic boatman to "stanna, stanna, asib, STANNA", I was filled with a desire to learn Arabic. (Aug 9, 1943,NZEF Times,III/111 : 2)

With the exception of the `thirty-niners' and other pioneers, most members of the 2NZEF left New Zealand with a reasonably fitting battledress. (1946,Johnny Enzed in the Middle East,3)

ST BRUNO Frank Bruno left New Zealand as a machine-gunner with the `Thirty-Niners' (First Echelon) of the N.Z. Division. (1959,Hellbuster, The,[back dust-jacket])

First Echelon reunion, Dunedin, Labour Weekend `Thirty-Niners' and their wives who intend travelling to Dunedin ... (Apr 18, 1964,Evening Post,1)

The forgotten legion, the thirty-niners, the four-figure man ...all sound like mysterious titles. [an article on First Echelon] (Sep 18, 1982,Evening Post,12)

That's not a Wog, son. That's a Thirty-Niner! (1945,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),3(11) : 22)

That's not a Wog, son - that's a Thirty-Niner, my oath. (Oct 19, 1942,NZEF Times,II/69 : 12)

this side¶

phr. sc. of the Tasman; New Zealand (a response to THE OTHER SIDE, Australia)

BEATTIE Australian aborigine words which were new to this side. In 1851 a number of Australian squatters' came over and took up runholding in Canterbury, but, generally speaking, their advent was some years later in Otago. ... They brought over a number of Australian aborigine words that were new to this side, and which were used a certain amount, usually in a joking manner as far as I know. I have heard some of them fairly frequently used by theold hands,' sometimes oracularly and sometimes as a semi-humorous quotation. When I was a boy I heard sheep called jumbucks,' an Australian aborigine term for them, but with the decease of ex-Australian stockmen the word has gone out of use now. Another term brought over from Australia wasmaimai,' for a rough shelter from the weather. It was said to be a name for a blackfellow's camp, which I have always seen spelt miamia,' and which is calledgunyah' or `wurley,' etc., by some tribes. We now apply the name to shooting shelters. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,10)

thistle¶

v. to remove thistles

Little wife walked all the afternoon thistleing and gardened till dark. (Jan 6, 1890,Chudleigh Diary,370,1950 ed.)

v. euphemism for scouting for or shooting Maoris

Went up to Harry's, at 7 expecting to go thistling (indeed No I had marched off) ...[sic] Before long we got the order to march for Bell Block, the Col. & troops following. (Jan 19, 1864,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/83,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

n.

The Gundagai thistle, as it is called in New Zealand (Carduus pycnocephalus, Jacq.), flourishes on newly-disturbed soil ... (1895,TrNZI,28/23)

2 n.

HILGENDORF SAFFRON THISTLE (Carthamus lanatus). This is a sparingly-branched annual up to 2 feet tall. The leaves with spiny segments, flowers yellow. Found locally in both islands. ... This is an aggressive weed in the wheat lands of Victoria and South Australia. (1967,Weeds of New Zealand,nf 1926 ed.)

2 n.

HILGENDORF CREEPING SOUR THISTLE [SOWTHISTLE] (Sonchus arvensis), is called also perennial [sow]thistle. It is found in cultivated fields near Auckland, in the Manawatu, in Canterbury, and in Southland. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,210,1967 ed.)

perennial sow thistle [s] Sonchus arvensis L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,57)

2 n.

HILGENDORF MILK THISTLE (Silybum marianum), sometimes called St. Mary's thistle, variegated or spotted thistle, and, near Akaroa, French thistle ... . It is abundant in scattered localities in both islands, sometimes forming dense masses. It is an annual or biennial, grows up to 6 ft. in height, and has large leaves without wings. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,192,1967 ed.)

2 n. spear thistle

Z W WELLS Went to Mangorei cutting in Scotch thistles. (Nov 9, 1861,Diary,23)

WALLACE (1890,Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ,310)

HILGENDORF SCOTCH [1967 SPEAR] THISTLE (Cirsium [vulgare syn. C. lanceolatum), is also called Spear [Scotch] thistle. This exceedingly common weed is a biennial. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,186,1967 ed.) [NOTES: [1926 headword Scotch thistle; 1967, Spear;]]

LEVY Weeds that are neglected by all classes of stock ... Scotch thistle, Californian thistle, winged thistle, variegated thistle, and the like are all weeds which, when properly established, are unpalatable to stock. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,302,1970 ed.)

Scotch thistle [=] cardoon: cotton thistle [s] ... Scotch thistle [s] Cirsium vulgare (Savi) Ten. Ibid. 78 thistle, Scotch [=] cotton thistle [s] ... 78 thistle, Scotch [s] Cirsium vulgare (Savi) Ten. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,68)

Scotch thistles are not allowed to grow as on the majority of the farms in the district. (Jul 12, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,13)

2 n.

There are two varieties of the thistle which are very stubborn to eradicate.. They have been called respectively the American and the Californian thistle, a distinction which has been unfairly given to the Union and to the particular state whose name is used. Both plants are natives of Britain (Feb 20, 1890,Otago Witness,7)

2 n.

POLACK Speedwell, sow, and melon thistles (coetus), virgin's bower, vanilloe, or willow, euphorbia, cudweed, crane's-bill, junchous rushes in all the swamps ... (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/295)

2 n.

thistle, slender winged [s] Carduus pycnocephalus L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,78)

2 n. puwha, rough sowthistle

JOHNSON On making New Zealand, Cook was pleased to find wild celery growing in profusion as well as `scurvy grass' of the cress family and the native sowthistle, puwha. (1968,Turn of the Tide, The,74)

HILGENDORF PRICKLY SOUR THISTLE [SOWTHISTLE] (Sonchus asper) is also called rough sour thistle [sowthistle,] and also by its Maori name of Puwha. This is very similar to the former [S.oleraceus, sowthistle] in all respects, except that the margins of the leaves are much more prickly, ... This form seems scarcely as common as the former, though it was found in New Zealand when Cook arrived here. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,210,1967 ed.)

prickly sow thistle [s] Sonchus asper (L.) Hill (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,61)

TAYLOR PRICKLY SOW THISTLE (Sonchus asper) Annual, like sow thistle, growing in similar places and almost as common. It grows a little taller than sow thistle and has leaves more prickly with a saw-tooth edge. (1980,Weeds of Crops,90)

HILGENDORF PRICKLY SOUR THISTLE [SOWTHISTLE] (Sonchus asper) is also called rough sour thistle [sowthistle,] and also by its Maori name of Puwha. This is very similar to the former [S.oleraceus, sowthistle] in all respects, except that the margins of the leaves are much more prickly, ... This form seems scarcely as common as the former, though it was found in New Zealand when Cook arrived here. (1967,Weeds of New Zealand,210,1967 ed.)

It is abundant in scattered localities in both islands, sometimes forming dense masses. It is an annual or biennial, grows up to 6 ft. in height, and has large leaves without wings. thistle grubber¶

1 n. (Rural) a farm worker set to dig up noxious thistles.

CANDY The skilled thistle grubber strikes but once .. the sagacious thistle grubber leaves no trace of his passing. (1988,Every Living thing,79)

thistle money¶

1 n. (Rural) [1800s] a development entitlement payment available to bush settlers.

H R RICHMOND I write to know whether you wish any claim made in respect of your clearing at Hurworth. You would probably be allowed, thistle money at 30/- per acre and rent at 20/- per acre per annum or perhaps less ... (1863,Letter,33) [NOTES: Letter in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers II]

thistle-peeper¶

1 n. (Rural) an eye dog or heading dog.

Heading dog - thistle-peeper. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

It was time to take the maggot taxis up to the marrowbone country with the shandygaff, fly-flicker, powder puff, thistle-peeper, the wool classer and the gravel-scraper. (Nov 22, 2002,Dominion Post,C6)

thistle-sick¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of grazing land] overcome by thistles.

GUTHRIE-SMITH The top spit is in fact clover-sick, as much more rapidly it previously had become thistle-sick. (1921,Tutira,311)

thistling¶

n.

From this somewhat premature return of the southern natives, it will be seen that the thistling which had just been actively began [sic] must be suspended for a while, as it will no longer be safe for any but large parties to go about the bush: indeed they express a hope of catching the Bushrangers unawares, and murdering them all. (Nov 28, 1863,Taranaki Herald,2)

thistling mattock¶

n.

Thistling Mattocks, and Handles. (Dec 7, 1867,Taranaki Herald,2)

thongs¶

n. a pair of simple sandals (usually made of rubber) with two straps joined and fitted between two toes. Also called jandals

[Wardells Liftout Advertisement] CANDY STRIPED THONGS - ALL SIZES (Dec 6, 1982,Evening Post)

thong ... NZ & Austral. (in pl.) light backless sandal with thongs between the big toe and the small toe. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,799) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. THONG 1219, FLIP-FLOP 426; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 500]]

thorn apple¶

n.

thorn apple, [s] Datura stramonium L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds)

TAYLOR THORNAPPLE (Datura stramonium) ... This cosmopolitan plant is common in the North Island, Nelson and Marlborough ... (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,147)

thorn apple, purple [s] Datura stramonium L. var. tatula Torr. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,78)

thorn-tail(ed) stingray¶

n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] stingray, thorntail(ed) 336 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

thornfish¶

n.

Bovichthys variegatus (Richardson). Thornfish (horny). (1938,TrRSNZ,68/414) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

GRAHAM THORNFISH or HORNY Bovichtus variegatus roseopictus Hutton This beautifully marked and coloured fish is sometimes called Horny by boys. Both the common names are derived from the sharp spines which puncture the flesh of one's hands when taking the Thornfish from a net. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,299)

DOOGUE & MORELAND THORNFISH ... Other names: Bovichtus variegatus. (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,266)

NATUSCH The thornfish, Bovichtus variegatus, is a rock-pool fish, up to ten inches long, of Stewart Island and the islands further south. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,224)

WILSON THORNFISH A distinguished-looking, but poor-eating, fish the scaleless Thornfish inhabits our inshore, rocky coasts in cooler waters from about the central North Island southwards. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,260)

AYLING THORNFISH (Horny, dragonet) Bovichtus variegatus (Bovichthys variegatus) ... The thornfish is a small, cylindrical fish with scaleless body ... There is a distinctive strong spine directed upward and backward on each gill cover behind the eyes. ... Thornfish are common in tidepools ... from the Wellington area southwards ... (1982,Collins Guide,274,1984 ed.)

PAUL Thornfish Bovichthys variegatus Family Bovichthyidae (thornfishes). Sometimes called horny, or dragonet (which is the name of a similar but unrelated fish). Also occurs off south-east Australia. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,117 ed.)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] thornfish 1861-4 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

thorough brace¶

n.

The coach used at the time was a type known as a "Thorough Brace," which meant that instead of steel springs the coach was suspended on several thicknesses of buffalo leather, which ran from the front under the body to the back of the coach. These coaches were in common use throughout Australia and New Zealand in the early days of mail coaches. Leather suspension was used because steel springs would not stand up to the rough roads. (1965,Otakeho District & School 80th Jubilee 1884-1964,18)

thoroughbreeding¶

n. (Rural) the breeding of thoroughbred stock, usually horses for the racing industry.

GORDON Just a 20-minute drive north from Christchurch, the stud's well out of the more highly publicised mainstream of 'thorough-breeding,' the Waikato. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,160)

thousand, the¶

n. the thousand town-acres sold by the NZ Company to first settlers [??in Wellington and/or Nelson only]

JOLLIE My choice [of land] is unfortunately beyond `the thousand' and consequently desparate [?sic] bad. (1842,Letter) [NOTES: 1842 E. Jollie in 1843 Letters from Settlers [p?]]

thousand-jacket¶

n. [aka thousandjacket, thousand jacket]

Most New Zealanders know the Thousand-Jacket or Lacewood Tree. (Dec 20, 1910,Wanganui Chronicle,6)

Thoú.sand-jacḱ.et (thoú.zand-j&abreve.ḱ.&ebreve.t), n. (Bot.) The ribbonwood of New Zealand. See RIBBONWOOD, in the Dictionary. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

A most ingeniously-made and tastefully-decorated hat made from the bark of the thousandjacket tree by Miss Walker, a girl of thirteen, was a centre of attraction to all the lady visitors, and the exhibitor, who was present, must have been quite delighted to hear the praises lavished on her work. (Nov 21, 1881,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

thousand-leaved fern¶

n. Hypolepis millefolium [see cit. at mountain kiokio]

thousand-leaves¶

n. Hypolepis millefolium

POTTS Hypolepis millefolium (1882,Out in the Open) [NOTES: (And)]

Hypolepis millefolium thousand-leaves (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: (And)]

thrash¶

v. to overwork (anything mechanical, espec. an engine or vehicle) excessively; to work or drive at an excessive pace hence, to overwork or overexploit soil, country, a trapping block, a fishery, etc.; to take more than a sustained yield espec. as a ppl aj thrashed, `overexploited; ruined, done in (mechanically)' [ca1938 Havelock That car's been pretty well thrashed after only three thousand miles if the rings are gone.]

CRUMP I found that deer don't hang about in the open once you start thrashing [sc. overshooting] a place, and it became necessary to go farther and farther along the range. (1960,Good Keen Man, A,24)

LAWSON We raced her past the Brothers,/And thrashed her through the Straits,/And where the wild rip smothers ... (1903,Red West Road,17)

2 v. to move cattle by use of stockwhip

[The cattle] were in two mobs ... We commenced thrashing them about 8 a.m. and by 7 p.m. had verilly thrashed them over some 20 miles. I never [125] thrashed cattle so much before. (Mar 15, 1864,Chudleigh Diary,124,1950 ed.)

Wilkinson & James thrashing. (Jul 21, 1866,Puketoi Station Diary)

thrashing-floor¶

n.

SHORTLAND Mr. Hughes had a very comfortable weatherboarded house, and a large barn with a thrashing-floor: ... (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,128)

thrashing-machine¶

n.

WAKEFIELD If you can afford it, by all means take a Thrashing-machine, adapted for horse-power, but so arranged that either wind or water power may be easily applied to it, in case of need. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,448)

thray¶

n. a threepenny bit

BENNETT In New Zealand slang a penny is a brown, a threepenny piece is a thray (cf. English tray), a sixpence a sax, presumably from Scottish saxpence. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,91)

HARGREAVES Threepence [:] thray (1972,From Beads to Banknotes,151)

thread fern¶

n.

Climbing ferns are much less dominant in New Zealand bush than in tropical rainforest, but mokimoki (Microsorum scandens), Rumohra adiantiformis and thread fern (Blechnum filiforme) are common throughout, while jointed fern (Arthropteris tenella) and mangemange (Lygopodium articulatum) are characteristic of the warmer northern forest. The thread fern is an unusual plant, beginning life on the ground where it scrambles around until it finds a trunk to climb. (2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/76)

three As¶

n. Amateur Athletic Association

I am bitterly disappointed the three As have taken this attitude. Here you have a young go-ahead promoter and he is squashed. (Oct 24, 1974,Dominion,30)

three corner(s)¶

n. a flatfish

WAITE Sand Flounder New Zealand Flounder, Patiki, Three corner, Tinplate Rhombosolea plebeia (1911,Records of the Canterbury Museum,1/197)

GRAHAM NEW ZEALAND SAND-FLOUNDER (PATIKI) Rhombosolea plebeia (Richardson) ... The common Sand-flounder is known from one end of New Zealand to the other, sometimes by other names in different localities. In Auckland it is known as the Dab.../ Some refer to it as Tinplate or Three Corner; the latter name is derived from its fancied trangular shape but why Tinplate I am at a loss to know. To other than fishermen and those intimately connected with the fishing industry it is just a Flounder. Some say it is Tinplate because when cooked it fills a plate. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,191)

SORENSON FLOUNDER (four species) (a) Scientific name: (i) Rhombosolea plebeia (ii) Rhombosolea retiaria (iii) Rhombosolea tapirina (iv) Rhombosolea leporina. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southern waters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,24)

[species name] sand flounder .. [scientific name] Rhombosolea plebeia .. [other name(s)] dab, diamond back, square, tin-plate, three corners (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

15 Clark has fallen foul of what might be called the three Hughies. Humour, humility and hubris. (May 4, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener))

One of these is the Three Kings Kaikomako (Pennantia baylisana). (May 7, 2005,Dominion Post,E13)

Three Kings kawakawa¶

n. Macropiper melchior [ORIGIN: Maori]

A lush tropical look can be achieved by planting it in a forest-free, shelted spot with other species such as the Three Kings Island cabbage tree (Cordyline kaspar), puka (Mertya sinclairii) and Three Kings kawakawa (Macropiper melchior). (Nov 6, 2004,Dominion Post,E13)

Eadie also has her eye on the Three Kings kawakawa (Macropiper melchior). (Sep 16, 2001,Sunday Star Times,D8)

WODZICKI [Turbott found in 1948 on Great Island, Three Kings] no seedlings of any other trees:...wharangi (Melicope terrata), ...mangeao (Litsaea calicaris) Three Kings' milk-tree (Paratrophis smithii) ...twapou [check] (Sideroxyloncostatum) (1950,Introduced Mammals of NZ,162)

Three Kings skink¶

n. (Environment) a very large and strongly built skink confined to the Three Kings Islands; difficult to sight. [Oligosoma fallai, aka Falla's skink]

For a while there, I was worried two of New Zealand's iconic beers were going to join the black mudfish, gold-striped gecko and Three Kings skink on the endangered species list. (Jun 29, 2004,Independent Herald (Wellington),12)

three o'clock¶

n. centaury

HILGENDORF CENTAURY ([Centaurium umbellatum]), also called three o'clock and red centaury, is common is [sic] grass lands throughout the islands. It is an annual, hairless, up to 18 inches high, with square erect green stems much branched at the top. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,134,1967 ed.)

MacDONALD My father had heard [c1840s] something of an Australian stockyard 8 feet high. He had also heard of an Australian three rail fence. (1910,Reminiscences,8)

three-finger¶

MARTIN Next we have the FIVE-FINGER, the THREE-FINGER, the HAUMAKAROA, and the RAUKAWA, all species of Nothopanax ... the three-finger or MOUNTAIN IVY-TREE has as a rule three sessile leaflets. (1961,Flora NZ,183)

WILSON 2.? Pseudopanax sp. aff. colensoi FIVEFINGER ... Threefinger ... Orihou ... Shrub or small, rounded tree. Leaves ...with 3-7 unstalked `fingers' (mostly 5). (1982,Stewart Island Plants,82)

three-quarter bred¶

n. [Harry says sheep but term applies also to cattle]

For SALE, about FIFTY head of very superior young STEERS and HEIFERS, nearly all of which were hand-reared, and are half or three-quarter bred Durhams. (Nov 11, 1854,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2) [NOTES: cattle]

50 three-quarter bred Ram Lambs, descended on the male side from imported Prize Ram. (Nov 1, 1864,Hawke's Bay Herald,5)

The average clips for the various breeds of sheep are approximately as follow: Merino, from 4lb. to 7lb.; quarter-breds, about 6 1/2lb.; half-breds, 7 1/2lb.; three-quarter breds, 8 1/2lb. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,122)

The average clips for the various breeds of sheep are approximately as follow : Merino, from 4lb. to 7lb.; quarter-breds, about 6-1/2lb.; half-breds, 7-1/2lb.; three-quarter-breds, 8-1/2lb.; ... (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,92)

In the South Island particularly, there is a further breakup of cross-breds' intothree-quarter-bred,' this term being applied to the progeny of any long-woolled ram with half-bred' ewes, or by matinghalf-bred' rams with any long-woolled ewe. (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,415)

I have sold three-quarter bred South Down, two-tooth wethers, to the butcher, after shearing, which weighed 80lbs, and have also killed them that weight. (Dec 2, 1871,Otago Witness,9)

Three-quarter bred wool also eased on previous rates to the extent of a halfpenny per lb. (Dec 8, 1920,Grey River Argus,3)

The closing prices for three-quarter bred, in grease, was within from 1d to 1d of superior quality. (Jul 1, 1885,Tuapeka Times,4)

Mr. P. Hende, of South Westland, got 14d per lb. for his eight bales of wool (halfbreds), whilst Mr. P. Butola, - of Poerua, got 13?d for ten bales (three-quarter breds). (Feb 15, 1915,Grey River Argus,5)

345 two-tooth Wethers, threequarter-bred. (Jul 3, 1907,Otago Witness,41)

three-titter¶

CASEY Arh, some of them cows you were keeping on there just weren't earning their keep - three-titters and two-titters and some hardly turning out a cupful of milk - I gave them the bullet smartly. (1963,As Short a Spring,159)

"'Well, Mr. Howard,' I says, 'there's just two reasons why I want to sell her. One is, she cut one of her tits - cut it on a barbed fence. You can see the scab there now. Of course, if it cut clear through she'll be a three-titter.' ..." (Jul 25, 1903,Evening Post,9)

three-up¶

n. a gambling game with three coins: three heads or three tails must fall for the tosser to win (cf. TWO-UP, ODD MAN OUT) [The citation is Aust cited in AND: omit]

THATCHER The pleasures found in history, Some fools will prate about; / 'Tis insignificant, compared / With three up' orodd man out.' (1875,NZ Songster,No.5/62) [NOTES: The Leary Boy]

NEAVE At `Hillside' ... there were few fences, and any, were sod walls with gorse planted on top with a three-wire and a barb. (1980,Land of Munros, The,91)

threepenny¶

n. a blenny (See threefin blenny,triplefin)

Tripterygion tripenne (Forster). Threepenny. (1938,TrRSNZ,68/416) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

GRAHAM Threepenny Gilloblennius tripennis (Bloch and Schn.) (Syn. Tripterygion forsteri Cuv and Val, T. decemigitatus Clarke, and Blennius tripinnis Richardson) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,411) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 411]

GRAHAM Threepenny Gilloblennius tripennis (Bloch and Schn.) (Syn. Tripterygion forsteri Cuv and Val, T. decemigitatus Clarke, and Blennius tripinnis Richardson) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,411) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 411]

GRAHAM THREEPENNY Gilloblennius tripennis(Bloch and Schneider) THREEPENNY is a small fish and a close relative to the well known Cockabully but is less abundant though often taken for the latter fish. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,326)

MORELAND THREEPENNY [Gilloblennius tripennis] ... Threepenny is the only name in use.-- (1967,Marine Fishes,18)

NATUSCH Gilloblennius tripennis... is exceptional [among cockabully] in being evenly coloured. Its popular name - threepenny' - looks like a broken-down version oftripennis', i.e. three-winged, a reference to the dorsal fin. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,229)

WILSON The Blenny goes by several other names too. In his various forms he is the Cockabully, Threepenny, Twister, and Topknot. All are slightly different in looks but come under the collective name of Blenny for easy grouping. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,28)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] threepenny [TS] 1919, 1976, 1988 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

threepenny bit¶

n. a willowherb

RICHARDS The coinleaf or threepenny bit [Epilobimun sp.: a willowherb] has dull green fleshy round leaves and forms a valuable food for sheep on account of the creeping root system and its rapid growth. (1952,Chatham Exiles,35)

threepenny piece¶

(thripenny) n. (historical) a pre-decimal silver coin worth three pence

We stirred the mixtures for luck and slotted threepenny pieces into the pudding. (Dec 2001,NZ Memories,No. 27/44)

thresher¶

n. a shark

Collins reckons you get threshers occasionally as far south as Kaikoura. (Mar 25, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

thresher shark¶

n. also called mango ripi, a shark noted for the large upper fluke on its tail (See also sea-fox)

In Account of the Alopias Vulpes, Thresher, or Fox Shark; by G. WILLIAMS, Esq. .. On examination, the fish proved to be a male Alopias Vulpes, or Thresher, known also by the names, Fox Shark, Sea Fox, and Sea Ape. (Jun 8, 1870,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

Further interesting contributions have been made by Mr. Petherick to the Newtown Museum. These include a very large specimen of the boa constrictor, nearly 30ft long, in addition to the previous specimen (23ft long), a fine puma, almost as large as a lion, and a thresher shark, over 12ft long. (Aug 27, 1907,Evening Post,7)

Fig. 9. - Thresher-shark, Alopias vulpinus. ... (Phillipps) Synonyms: Squalus vulpinus; Alopias vulpes; Alopecias vulpes. The thresher, or sea-fox (Alopias vulpinus. ), was included by Hutton ... (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/265) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

SANSOM Wonderful days those were, when we might be amongst the dolphins (cow-fish we called them) or a school of pilot whales (black fish to us), or to see a single thresher shark whacking the water with a tail as long as its body. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,78)

HUTTON 126. ALOPECIAS VULPES. Gml. Thresher. (1872,Fishes,78)

SHERRIN Alopecias vulpes .. Thresher. (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,115)

Alopias vulpes, Gmelin. The thresher; an occasional visitor. (1906,TrNZI,38/552) [NOTES: (Thomson, Otago)]

PHILLIPPS Alopias vulpinus.(Bonnaterre). THRESHER-SHARK. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,8)

SPEIGHT The thresher shark is related to these swift mackerel sharks,... (1927,Natural History of Canterbury,193) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 193]

Alopias vulpinus. : Thresher. (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,71)

Alopias vulpinus. (Bonnaterre). Thresher shark. (1938,TrRSNZ,68/401) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

POWELL THRESHER SHARK (Alopias caudatus), Mango ripi of the Maoris, is very easily recognised by the extremely large upper fluke of the tail... (1947,Native Animals of NZ,61)

GRAHAM Thresher Shark Alopias caudatus Phillipps (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,397) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 397]

GRAHAM THRESHER SHARK (MANGO-RIPI) Alopias caudatus Phillipps (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,75)

DOOGUE & MORELAND THRESHER SHARK ... Other names: Alopias vulpinus; thrasher shark; mango-ripi (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,182)

McL Thresher shark .. .. mango ripi .. .. Alopias vulpinus. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

PAUL Thresher shark Alopias vulpinus The commonest of several species in this family (Alopiidae), widespread through almost all tropical to cool temperate seas. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,27)

thresher shark .. [scientific name] Alopias vulpinus. .. [other name(s)] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

thresher shark NZ & Austral. kind of shark with long upper fluke to its tail. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] SHARKS, THRESHER 174-80 shark, thrasher 179 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

On approaching close the commotion was found to be a big whale over 30 feet long fighting with a great thresher shark. (Oct 14, 1891,West Coast Times,2)

On approaching close the commotion was found to be a big whale over 30 feet long fighting with a great thresher shark. (Oct 14, 1891,West Coast Times,2)

They were pursued by the thresher sharks mentioned in our columns a day or two ago. (Nov 26, 1919,Ohinemuri Gazette,2)

thrift¶

1 n. (Rural) [livestock] well-being or growth.

STEVENS As autumn merges into winter there is usually an improvement in the general thrift of the hoggets. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,31)

STEVENS Rotational grazing on hill country pasture has a detrimental eefect on lamb weight, lambing percentage, wool weight and general thrift. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,61)

thriftiness¶

1 n. (Rural) the healthy condition of stock.

thrifting¶

n. ??

Not only is thrifting a cheap alternative for students and bohos alike, it has the advantage that all your shopping needs can be met in one place. (Jul 26, 2005,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),The College Supplement, p4) [NOTES: source appears incorrect TD]

thriftless¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of stock] showing poor health or growth.

GASCOIGNE Without it the feed grows rank, the sheep graze in patches, there is poverty in plenty and the lambs soon look thriftless. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,60)

thrifty¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of stock] healthy or growing.

The black-polled Aberdeen Angus cattle are, as the name implies, of Scottish descent and like good Scots, are thrifty beasts. (Oct 13, 1934,Hawke's Bay Herald,5)

STEVENS While this is true for healthy, thrifty lambs, where lambs have had a set-back or are unthrifty, there is some advantage in postponing the docking day. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,57)

STEVENS The surprising feature of the operation is the small effect it has on the progress of healthy, thrifty lambs. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,58)

In the United States, The Pretender played in tandem with Profiler on the same network to form part of a thrillogy. (Jan 31, 1997,Evening Post,12)

Throaties¶

Throaties is a New Zealand icon. We have relied on it for years to relieve our sore throats, and Kiwis young and old have always loved the taste. (May 2003,Family Health Diary (Auckland),18)

He drives the sort of car I can neither understand nor condone, a low-slung throatmobile, with a boombox in the back that can shatter paving slabs. (Nov 20, 2002,Dominion Post,B6)

The electro-dub duo missed out on the final cut but they still delivered a wobbly-bottomed throbathon that held the attention better than most. (Oct 1, 2005,Time Out,11)

through the arch¶

phr.

MARSHALL Creamy was even better with the aluminium ones [sc. knuckle bones]. Cutting cabbages, camels, swatting flies, clicks, little jingles, through the arch, goliath, horses in the stable; Creamy mastered them all. (1982,Master of Big Jingles,55)

throughs¶

n.

SUTTON-SMITH Action terms related to the movements of the marbles are, Throughs and No Throughs... . (1953,Unorganized Games,175)

SUTTON-SMITH Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles... Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears,.. throughs. (1972,Folkgames of Children,175)

throw¶

v. of humans, to give birth to vicariously (here transf.) (cp. drop)

FULLARTON Bob? Didn't you hear? He threw twins pretty smartly to dodge the draft. (1944,Troop Target,24)

n.

FAULT.- A fissure, accompanied by a displacement of the strata, same as a slide, heave, hitch, throw, and trouble. (1868,Thames Miner's Guide, The,54)

McARA When the round of holes was fired each was detonated in sequence from the front and all the broken rock was heaped up at the opposite end of the shaft, this being the `throw' of the holes. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi,179)

v. in main sense of cast

MACNICOL George had to be shown how to pick up a fleece and how to / throw it. (1965,Skippers Road,93)

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR Bill hadn't learned to pick up and throw a fleece, and he felt the anger of a fleeco was directed at him for not getting stuck in when the shearer cried, `Wool away!' ... Fleecos hated this; it made the fleece difficult to throw. The aim was to stand by as the shearer made his last blow, gather the fleece into a compact armful, and throw it like a tablecloth on the wooltable, weather side up. (1981,Sunrise,46)

v. to fell, cut through, or knock down [(cf. DROP, KNOCK DOWN)]

The pines should be thrown last because then they do not cover up the other stuff until it is dry. (Nov 10, 1854,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/158) [NOTES: H.A. Atkinson]

HURSTHOUSE ... the trees are thrown with the x [sic] cut saw and American axe. (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/331)

WELCH ... trees thrown with a cross-cut saw and American axe. (1863,NZ Guide,22)

THOMSON They could fell a tree in real bushwhackers' style, and could judge best how to `throw' the tree too. (1905,Bush Boys of NZ,138)

v. to put on; perform etc (See wobbly; sickie; hollywood)

1 v. (Rural) [land] to produce feed for stock.

This farm 'throws a lot of feed before Christmas,' he says. (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,84)

2 v. to throw an animal to the ground

ROBERTS At Macfarlane's the men saddled fresh horses and rode in some cattle which we had a great bother to yard, ... The yard was divided into three - ... but as there was no crush pen, or drafting race, we had to head rope those requiring brands, and ... legroped and threw them ...[chk] (Dec 18, 1856,Diary) [NOTES: 1856 Dec 18 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 43]

3 v. of a crop, to reap [[see DROP (a tree) for quot]]

throw a mental¶

phr. have a mad fit, become enraged [1984 17 F E53 Pakuranga Coll. 5 THROWS A MENTAL]

Faith Oxenbridge Bea was down for the university break at the time and threw a mental. 'What do you mean, Brian?' Bea said dangerously. (2007,Six Pack 2, The,19)

throw an ep¶

phr. put on a demonstration of temper, annoyance, pique, etc. (resembling an epileptic fit); cf bersy. [ca1945-46 Air Training Corps (D. Close Letter May, 1951)]

throw down¶

v. to fell a structure

(Jul 22, 1911,NZ Truth,317/6/3) [NOTES: He gave instructions to Alexander Davey, head labourer, to take 4 [and-a-half] inches out of the bottom of the wall, and to leave three or four bricks, or `pins' to support the wall, which was the usual method of throwing down a structure of this kind.]

throw into¶

v. sc to put runs or blocks into a goldfield

EVANS ... as these runs are likely to be wanted for settlement, I should not recommend their being thrown into a gold field till after they have been thrown into Hundreds when the Waste Lands Board could refuse to sell any portion ... considered highly auriferous. (1962,Waikaka Saga,16)

throw off at¶

v. to deride; to tease

(1953,Short Stories (various authors)) [NOTES: 1950 Landfall in 1953 Short Stories]

throw open¶

v. sc. a block of land, for settlement

BELL If I had a couple of hundred acres of good bush land, and a wife like that girl down there would make, I wouldn't call the Queen my aunt; and, by Jove! I mean to have a buck at some of those sections in the Whakatangi Block that'll be thrown open shortly, ... (1899,In the Lee of the Hokonuis,84)

SINCLAIR The system of free selection' enabled a would-becockatoo' to choose land in localities `thrown open' to selectors (under certain conditions regarding residence, improvement, and area) and to buy the freehold. (1959,History of New Zealand,155)

The circumstamces under which they occupied the land had been explained at a former meeting, and it was resolved to remain satisfied with what had been done until the natives could be induced to throw open the Upper Thames. (Oct 19, 1867,Daily Southern Cross,4)

All the pettifogging attempts that have been made to prevent land being thrown open sink into insignificance - collapse like a punctured balloon - when pierced and confronted by plain facts. (Apr 29, 1874,Tuapeka Times,3)

Mr. W. W. M'Cardle drew attention to the very large number of persons who had attended the late sale, eager to obtain selections, but who, owing to the limited amount of land thrown open, had failed in their endeavours to secure holdings. (Aug 29, 1889,Evening Post,2)

The Lands Department will throw open about 59,000 acres of first and second class land in the Bay of Plenty districts. (Jan 31, 1903,West Coast Times,3)

Altogether, such a course would throw open about five thousand acres for settlement. (Jul 23, 1912,Evening Post,3)

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN, that on Monday, June 6, 1842, the township of Wanganui and Country Sections in that district will be thrown open for selection at the Resident Surveyor's Office at Wanganui, at 11 A.M. precisely, and close at 4 P.M.; one half the choices will be made on the first day, and the remainder on the second or following day. (May 4, 1842,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2)

1 v. (Rural) to offer or make free land for selection or balloting.

WARD We have thought and deemed it proper to throw open all the country ... (1858,BLANK ENTRY,45) [NOTES: in Reeves (1883) Canterbury Rhymes]

It is rumored - but we can't vouch for the accuracy of it - that as soon as road lines are cut through the bush country the land will be thrown open for free selection as was done in Canterbury ... (Oct 6, 1880,Hawera Star,2)

The surveyors are pushing on with the survey of the Waimarino block up the Wanganui River, part of which will shortly be open for application. (Nov 1891,NZ Farmer,471)

This is a sample of a large portion of the land shortly to be thrown open by the Crown ... (Jun 1898,NZ Farmer,197)

BELL By Jove! I mean to have a buck at some of those sections in the Whakatangi Block that'll be thrown open shortly. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,84)

In one case, where a section was thrown open by the Government to be ballotted, there were over two hundred applicants. (Mar 1907,NZ Farmer,214)

With the idea of giving information to those acquiring land, there will be published in this column full particulars of all Crown, public, and native lands thrown open for settlement. (1908,Weekly News,47)

It is interesting to watch the development of an estate such as Starborough or Flaxbourne, which has been purchased by the government and thrown open to settlers. (May 1909,NZ Farmer,394)

GUTHRIE-SMITH Following its destruction, through man's agency by fore and stock, a huge area of virgin soil was, to use a New Zealand political term, 'thrown open' to selection. (1921,Tutira,236)

SINCLAIR The system of 'free selection' enabled a would-be 'cockatoo' to choose land in localities 'thrown open' to selectors (under certain conditions regarding residence, improvement and area) and to buy the freehold. (1959,History of New Zealand,115)

throw over¶

n. [light cloth thrown over food to keep off flies etcetera aka (Waikato) tea shower.]

Dainty milk jug covers were in use during the summer as were the delicate "throw overs" made from sheer material and decorated with either fine embroidery or painted motifs. (Aug 19, 2006,Nelson Mail,18)

These plate throw overs are lightweight nylon edged with different cotton fabrics. Ideal for covering food at barbeques and the like. (2010,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.felt.co.nz/listing/28150/Plate-Throw-Over]

throw the toys¶

phr. react vigorously

"I probably threw the toys a wee bit, because I just felt it was unfair. (Feb 3, 2002,Sunday Star Times,B16)

throw-down¶

n. (Sport) an artificial cricket pitch? [no Google evidence found TD May06]

[heading] Styris backs throw downs policy. ..Marshall confessed last summer to relying solely on throw-downs, largely because he had no faith in the practice wickets around the country. (Dec 6, 2005,Dominion Post,C14)

throw-up¶

n. [graffiti term]

Graffitti Speak... Throw-up : Single coloured piece with outline. Usually takes about three or four minutes to create. (Nov 30, 2000,Evening Post,19)

Leaving the ranks of bored adolescents getting quick thrills from quick tags (toys, as the amateurs are called), she has gone on to the more esteemed throwup or bomb (a tag in fat letters with the outline coloured in), then the dub (a throwup with an outer line and bubbles), and finally the piece, short for masterpiece (a dub with filled in letters and a painted background). (Jan 20, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),51)

throwaway¶

n.

McGILL The guy across from me had a blanket over him and his blue Addidases [check spg???] poking out in the aisle. He drained an L & P, flicked through a throwaway, killed his light. (1985,G'day Country,50)

throwdown¶

n. a small banger or modified firework set off by throwing onto a hard surface - [sold pre-Guy Fawkes in NZ in 1940 (DEH), also figurative (see 1907)]

TURNER (1896,Little Larrikin,321)

"A cold throwdown," says I to myself, and then I turns to him, "I guess she didn't get your wire - she ain't there.' (Aug 3, 1907,Poverty Bay Herald,1)

"I was not doing it for mischief," said a youth named James Owen, at Lower Hutt to-day, when charged before Mr. E. Page, S.M., with letting off "throwdowns" in the King George Theatre during a picture performance. (Jan 14, 1920,Evening Post,6)

He had stopped at a shop and bought them, a penn'orth of throwdowns. (Dec 23, 1914,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

BALLANTYNE All along Stout Road kids were exploding throwdowns on the footpaths, making women and girls squeak. (1948,Cunninghams, The,67,1976 ed.)

GUTHRIE ... it was a fireworks thing, called a `throw-down' (1935,Little Country, The,114)

thrower-in¶

1 n. (Rural) the worker at a swim or pot sheep dip responsible for encouraging sheep into the dip.

GASCOIGNE Our working system involved Manu in the role of thrower-in and John in the rear keeping the pens filled with new victims. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,35)

thrower-on¶

n.

MORRIESON It was obvious that men were still on the job from the carts loaded with skins that had to be hauled to the `thrower on' at one end of the paint table. The trimmers who lined the table, even the foreman who supervised the spraying of the skins, were gone. (1976,Pallet on the Floor,95)

throwover¶

n. a cover

WOOLLASTON They grew like a pretty throwover, all embroidered, that you put over the food to keep flies off when afternoon tea is waiting for visitors. (1980,Sage Tea,10) [NOTES: [?c1915]]

The bridegroom's gift to the bride was a beautiful set of "throwovers." (Jun 7, 1911,Marlborough Express,8)

APPLIQUE ORGANDIE THROWOVERS. Finest quality Organdie in exquisite applique designs, all ready for working. Hemstitched, as sketched. (Nov 6, 1933,Evening Post,3)

Hand-painted Organdie Throwover Sets, 36 x 36. (Sep 12, 1940,Evening Post,16)

thrum¶

n. short for thrummer an old informal word for a threepenny piece

Following are other local money-names...3d. thrum, half-tiz, tray or tray-piece... (Jan 14, 1899,Sydney Bulletin,(Red Page)) [NOTES: Letter from Loafer, Tauranga) [Bill Pearson]]

... a large number of casuals have dropped in [to the pub] to spend a thrum ... . (Sep 30, 1905,NZ Truth,15/1/6)

A tray-bit, or trey, thrum, or half-tiz are recorded for the threepence. (Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,15)

DEVANNY The breathless agony of wondering whether the knife would strike a "thrum", a sixpence or, joy unreasonable, perhaps a shilling. (1928,Dawn Beloved,28)

There was ten bob in pennies.. four bob in thrums. (Mar 19, 1904,NZ Observer,16)

"Got a duff?"... "Oh, yes. I made two, filled ours with thrums and sent one to mother." (Apr 2, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,71)

About 300 names given to good money and coin in slang and Engish by NEMO, Reefton, (Concluded) .. teviss, thrums, time, thrummers ... (Mar 17, 1888,Grey River Argus,2)

thrumbo¶

n. elaboration of thrum [ca1920 Blenheim (G. O'Connor)]

thrummer¶

n.

He pointed out that the railway trains between Auckland and Onehunga ran empty, because in place of paying a sixpenny fare, as demanded by an intelligent Department, people could make the same journey by tram for a modest "thrummer" and thus award themselves a fifty per cent. bonus towards meeting the callous cut. (Jul 15, 1922,NZ Truth,5)

I'm single, and jingle / A thrummer and a brown, / Assessors and guessers / Of tax have done me down. (Feb 12, 1937,Evening Post,8)

WHITWORTH Mother ... what about a thrummer? (1950,Otago Interval,52) [NOTES: ca1950 [?1890s]]

About 300 names given to good money and coin in slang and Engish by NEMO, Reefton, (Concluded) .. teviss, thrums, time, thrummers ... (Mar 17, 1888,Grey River Argus,2)

Pound notes, gold coins, half-crowns, "colonial Roberts," "tanners," "thrummers," and "browns" rattled into the boxes, and the beaming faces of the collectors were a sight to see. (Jul 2, 1904,Wanganui Herald,5)

The humble "thrummer" is a big item on a shilling and two bob a day stunt. (May 24, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/44 : 183)

He was up about Waimate working fairly night and day, / He'd forked in eighty bushels wheat - that wasn't no child's play - / He'd wallabied right into town to save his blooming fare, / and now if he'd a thrummer left he says he wouldn't care. (Apr 29, 1897,Otago Witness,47)

thrush¶

n. any of a family of songbirds, often brown; Turnagara capensis, piopio (See also piopio,shrike thrush)

FORSTER We landed & ... shot a Thrush [[ed. fn] Turdus ochrotarsus of Descr. Anim.,Ibid. 2/269 The male & female of a small Thrush [[ed. fn] Turdus minutus of Descr. Anim. p.83; ... Now the Yellow-breasted Tit ...] was shot, which we hitherto had taken for a variety of the small yellow legged Thrush, commonly called Robin by our Ship's-crew; ... (Mar 27, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/240)

FORSTER ... Pohebirds, Fantails, Thrushes, Mocking birds, Yellowheads & various other birds inhabit these impenetrable Forests. [ed. fn ... the `thrushes' are the Yellow-breasted Tit and South Island Robin] (May 13, 1773,Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The,2/278)

FORSTER ... the birds seemed to retire from it to a little distance, where the shrill notes of thrushes, the graver pipe of wattle-birds, and the enchanting melody of various creepers resounded on all sides ... (1777,Voyage Round the World,1/148)

BUTLER The wren and the tomtit and the thrush all are represented quite as nearly or even more so than the robin save that the tomtit is black headed with a yellow breast. (1860,Forest Creek MS,44,1960 ed.)

HAAST Another ... belonging to the family Turdidae, is the piopio (Turnagra crassirostris), the thrush of the settlers. (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,140)

BUTLER We have a thrush, but it is rather rare. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,ix/137)

HUTTON 36. KEROPIA TANAGRA. Schleg. Thrush. Pio-pio. Tumagra Hectori. BULLER (1871,Birds of New Zealand,14 ed.)

HILL I do not know to what to attribute the scarcity of small birds, ...such as crows, saddlebacks, thrushes, tuis, canaries, wrens, riflebeaks, fantails and many others. (1987,Richard Henry of Resolution Island,88) [NOTES: 1897 Apr 5 E.H. Wilmot Exploration and Topographical Survey in Fiord Country in 1987 Hill Richard Henry of Resolution Island 88]

MORRIS This common English bird-name is applied in Australia and New Zealand to four different genera of birds, ... (5) Turnagra (the New Zealand Thrushes), viz. - T. hectori, Buller, North Island Thrush. ... T. crassirostris, Gmel., South Island Thrush. (1898,Austral English,468)

It is interesting to note that the Piopio, or Native Thrush (Turnagra crassirostris), and the Long-tailed Cuckoo ... are somewhat [similar] in appearance. (1904,TrNZI,36/124)

2 n.

HUTTON 40. COLLURICINCLA CONCINNA. N.S. Shrike Thrush. (1875,Birds of New Zealand,15)

2 n.

T. hectori. - Piopio, Northern Thrush. Southern part of North Island. (1886,TrNZI,18/112) [NOTES: (Martin)]

2 n. [pipit, snow thrush; one cit]

PICKERING Of the other birds the pipit or snow thrush, with its polite bobbing and repetitious call note, is usually the most evident. (1988,Hills, The,51)

2 n.

Fernbird Bowdleria punctata (QUOY & GAIMARD, 1830) ... North Island Fernbird B.p. vealeae KEMP, 1912. South Island Fernbird B.p. punctata (QUOY & GAIMARD, 1830) ... Codfish Island Fernbird B.p. wilsoni STEAD, 1936. Stewart Island fernbird B.p. stewartiana OLIVER, 1930. Snares fernbird B.p. caudata (BULLER, 1894). EXTINCT Chatham Island Fernbird B.p. rufescens (BULLER, 1869). OTHER NAMES: Swamp thrush, grass bird, matata. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,274)

2 n.

HUTTON 35. KEROPIA CRASSIROSTRIS. Gml. Thick-billed Thrush.Turnagra crassirostris. GRAY. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,13)

thugger¶

n.

Even now, as a minister more influential than any save Clark and Cullen, Mallard has a reputation as parliamentary thugger that still dogs him. (May 19, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

thumb bird¶

n. a rifleman

GUTHRIE-SMITH From two localities [Nelson province] came the silvery `tic -tic' of a squad of Thumb Birds - Rifleman - the males most desparate [check spg???] fellows for all their littleness ... . (1936,NZ Naturalist,62)

Firstly, where did she get the name "Thumb Bird"? It is the first time I have ever heard it, though the tiny little wrens [sic] or rifleman is little larger than one's thumb, and the name is expressive. (Jul 25, 1906,Otago Witness,80)

thumbie¶

n. cf Tom Thumb bird for bush wren

SUTHERLAND ... we came to think that the novelty of having calico under their feet was chief attraction to the `thumbies' - a local name given to New Zealand's smallest bird, more correctly called Acanthisitta Chloris. ... That was the cue for thumbie bedlam to break loose. (1953,Golden Bush, The,109,1963 ed.)

FALLA et al. RIFLEMAN Acanthisitta chloris Other names: Titipounamu, Thumbie (Nelson). (1966,Birds of Australia,191)

thumper¶

n. rammer, for compacting earth around post (See rammer,post rammer)

"There were no post hole borers or thumpers... so we just used a spade." (Apr 12, 2003,Hawke's Bay Today,C1)

thunder and lightning¶

phr.

KEENE Sunday night's tea [early 20c] was always `thunder and lightning', in other words, treacle and Devonshire cream. (1967,Tang of The Bush,108)

thunder jug¶

n.

His [Turner's in Turner 1966] BANG BOX on p. 117 reminds me of the THUNDER JUG, but perhaps yours will be a genteel list with no crockery under the beds. (Jul 29, 1966,Letter) [NOTES: I. DAVEY (WHANGAREI)]

thunder-dirt¶

n. fairies' closet [nb. unconscious pun between the Maori and English name] -

MORRIS Thunder-dirt, n. In New Zealand, a gelatinous covering of a fungus (Ileodictyon cibarium) formerly eaten by the Maoris. (1898,Austral English,469)

thunderpants¶

n.

Visit the home place of Thunderpants, the best underwear in the Pacific, possibly the universe. Thunderpants aren't your usual glamorous bits of tissue that pass for women's underwear. They are made of cotton and designed to a broad-of-bum brief that delivers satisfaction, as promised by their rather earthly advertising: 'They don't ride up your bum'. (Nov 2003,AA Directions,No. 58/42)

Thunderpants are go... Founded in 1995 by Josie Bidwill and Victoria McKenzie.. the Martinborough-made underwear line was born out of frustration and a need for comfortable but stylish knickers...Where did the Thunderpants label spring from? It was the name given to underwear at the boarding school Josie attended... (Jun 19, 2003,Dominion Post,C1)

Other than designs for new-born to 12 year olds, the shop also stocks gifts, thunder pants and is looking at adding women's jewellery. (Nov 2003,Experience : Ngaio, Khandallah, Crofton Downs,12)

thunderplump¶

n.

DELUGED [heading] I am beginning to think that I must be the only ignoramus in Dunedin who has never heard of a thunderplump. Everyone else has known the word since childhood and, as a Buccleugh Street reader neatly put it, I was fairly deluged with thunderplumps yesterday. Other readers wanted to explain that plumps' were to be found in many dictionaries, but I was aware of that anyway. Most of the people who knew of thunderplump claimed a Scottish origin for it, but it still took me quite a time to locate it in my range of dictionaries. Finally I ran it to earth in a seven-volume Century, published back in 1891, which gave it asA short violent downpour of rain in connection with a thunder-storm (Rare),' and produced a 19th century quotation. Perhaps we didn't hear it much in Invercargill in my younger days because thunderplumps are pretty uncommon there; but a colleague who came from Winton certainly knew of it; and it was even noised abroad by the Canterbury English. ... (Nov 18, 1977,Otago Daily Times) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

thunderweed¶

n. marijuana

He and other extras would sneak away between takes and smoke joints filled with "thunderweed" at the top of a tower on the set... "New Zealand has some of the strongest grass in the world. Thunderweed blows your mind away." (Dec 21, 2001,Evening Post,1)

thyme¶

n. . [citations both 'wild thyme']
