The soil is consequently dry, and apparently barren enough; but the herbage which it affords is that which peculiarly suits the sheep, and the cocksfoot grass, and the clover (trifolium pretense), and the common thyme, and the wild thyme, and the lavender (lavandula spica), grow amid the flint, affording a pasture nutritive, without one dangerous aqueous property, and of luxuriance that would scarcely be deemed possible. (Dec 21, 1844,Daily Southern Cross,2)

WELD ... several veronicas of great beauty, wild thyme, dwarf yew, Alpine rose (consanthenum), white violet, a ribes, several heaths, gentianella, harebell, a lily, and several varieties of ranunculus. (Jan 1851,Letter) [NOTES: 1851 Jan Weld Letter in 1851 Feb 21 NZGG 34]

n. ?Samolus spp.

HOOKER Thyme, wild of Otago. Samolus littoralis. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

2 n.

creeping thyme [s] Thymus serpyllum L. Ibid. 79 thyme, creeping [s] Thymus vulgaris L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,17)

Shall I ever, shall I never, / At the sunset chime, / Know the bless revealed / By that seaside field / Of rich wild thyme? (Mar 11, 1908,Otago Witness,90)

2 n. Pimelea laevigata [citation: native thyme]

GUTHRIE-SMITH Other species like native Thyme (Pimelea laevigata) and the alien Horehound (Marrubium vulgare) selected small holdings about the camps. (1926,Tutira,169) [NOTES: [also 1921 get p. no]]

2 n.

thyme, water [s] Thymus serpyllum L. Ibid. 84 water thyme [=] Canadian pondweed [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,79)

2 n.

thyme, wild [=] Canadian pondweed [s] Ibid. 87 wild thyme [s] Thymus vulgaris L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,79)

TAYLOR WILD THYME (Thymus vulgaris) ... is a European plant of characteristic smell and taste, and is used for flavouring. It is best known for its dense growth on some hillsides in Central Otago. (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,173)

ti¶

n. cabbage tree [ORIGIN: Maori, The form ti-tree often leads to confusion with TEA-TREE (=MANUKA) and possibly underlies the spellings ti-tree, titri for tea-tree . (But see TI-SHRUB for distinction from MANUKA] (See also ti palm)

The name "cabbage" tree seems to have been applied to the ti because the leaf buds provided for the early settlers a substance that could be cooked and eaten in the place of green vegetables. (1945,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),III/1 : 13)

BRUNNER (19 January 1847) Collected a quantity of the roots of the ti, or cabbage tree, which we placed in a humu or native oven, for the night. (Jan 19, 1847,Diary) [NOTES: quoted in 1982 Burton Two Hundred Years of NZ Food 19]

Ti (t&emacr.), n. [Polynesian.] (Bot.) A liliaceous tree of the genus Cordyline, common in the Polynesian islands and in New Zealand; especially Cordyline ti; - called also titi, ti-tree, and ti-tri. The genus Cordyline comprises twelve species, distributed in the West Indies, the Malay Archipelago, the Pacific Islands, and Brazil. Four species are found in Australia, and six in New Zealand. The name ti is usually confined to C. ti. C. indivisa and C. australis are more commonly called cabbage tree. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

KEENE ti: cabbage tree; grows to height of about 30 ft. (1963,O Te Raki,195)

LEE & KENDALL T|i, s. The root called Tee, which when baked is very sweet; (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,212)

MARKHAM Hattay [crossed out by Markham] or Ettay [heti] is a Tea tree, quite different to the Tea tree bush, a sort of myrtle; as Parr a Fort and Hipparr [he pa] a Fort in Cooke, / is put down The Hip or Hit, is only the Article. Tay, it is useless, it only grows eight to twelve feet and the bark rough, and does not change. It seems very often Solitary. Away from every other Tree. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),33,1963 ed.)

POLACK ... the guardian ... pointed to a small bunch of human hair made fast to a ti, or cabbage palm-tree, denoting the strictness of the tapu. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/67)

This last [Mauku] the root of a shrub called by the Mauries T is of extraordinary sweetness when dressed ... . (Apr 1842,Journal of Ensign Best,344,1966 ed.)

DIEFFENBACH We ... turned ... over the downs and hillocks of the coast, which were covered with fern and flax, overshadowed here and there by a picturesque ti (Dracaena australis). Ibid. 2/387 Ti - sweet root of the dragon-tree (1843,Travels in NZ,1/142)

SHORTLAND This evening, Huruhuru made me a pair of sandals, such as are in common use among these natives. They are called paraerae', and are made either with the leaves of the flax-[210]plant, or of theti' (cordyline Australis). ... Mine were a pair with double soles, called `torua', ... (Jan 13, 1844,Southern Districts of NZ,209,1851 ed.)

TUCKETT At the first view of this plain [Molyneux], ... I observed a continued line of dry land, indicated by the number of Te trees, and the frequent succession of pine groves. (May 7, 1844,Diary) [NOTES: 1844 May 7 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 217]

WAKEFIELD ... cabbage-tree, called ti by the natives. (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/58)

TAYLOR The ti (Cordyline australis or Dracaena australis) is found in great abundance. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,435)

SMITH [We found] what was to us quite a new kind of tree, called nei nei. It is something like a diminutive ti. (Jan 8, 1858,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1858 Jan 8 Smith Notes of a Journey in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 355]

Turned out by waeroas about 4 a.m. ... Eat kumara, ti & kuharu. [fn.] The root of the ti - rather like licorice root. (Dec 20, 1860,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/67,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

HOOKER Ti, Col[enso]. Cordyline australis and indivisa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Ti. Cordyline australis, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/50) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Ti. Cordyline australis, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/50) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Of our shrubs and smaller timber trees, several are of strikingly beautiful growth ... (e.g.) the Houhere, Hoheria populnea; ..the Ti, Cordyline australis;.. and, on the sea-coast, ... the Karo, Pittosporum crassifolium; and the truly evergreen Ngaio, Myoporum laetum ... Ibid. Besides which the following roots and plants were often eaten, viz., the roots (cooked) of the Panahi (Calystegia sepium); of the Maikaika (Arthropodium cirrhatum); ... the roots of the little sugary Ti-koraha (Cordyline stricta), of the large Ti, or Cabbage Tree' (<i>C. australis</i>), and of the large Fern, Para, (<i>Marattia salicina</i>). <i>Ibid.</i> 32 The young inner blanched leaves and heart of the Ti, orCabbage-tree' (Cordyline australis), and of the Nikau, or New Zealand Palm, (Areca sapida), were eaten both raw and cooked. Ibid. 36 ... the roots of the Tikoraha (Cordyline stricta), were tied separately for baking ... for their Kao, or prepared sweet potatoes, they used the leaves of the Parataniwha (Elatostemma rugosum); ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/5) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

Tikapu. Cordyline indivisa, Kunth. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/50) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

CHEESEMAN C[ordyline] australis, Hook.f. ... Ti; Ti-kauka; Ti-rakau; Palm-lily. ... Universally known to New Zealand residents by the inappropriate name of `cabbage-tree'. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,706)

BAUCKE Ti (tee): The Cabbage-tree. (1908,Shingle-Short,185)

COWAN The Kapenga tableland ..., a gully-seamed broken plateau, is covered with a thick growth of manuka and monoao shrubs, tutu and fern, with many ti or cabbage trees ... (1922,NZ Wars, The,2/399,1983 ed.)

ti[i], a tree (Cordyline spp.), cabbage-tree, palm-lily, the various species being in Maori denoted by the adding of a descriptive suffix: .br;ti[i]-kouka, C. australis (kouka the chief of several suffixes for this species. ti[i]-kapu, C. indivisa. ti[i]-rauriki, C. pumilo (also ti[i]-koraka). ti[i]-ngahere, C. Banksii. ti[i]-parae, C. stricta. ti[i] is the only term in common use, and it has been wonderfully maltreated. see manuka. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

ti: cabbage tree (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

A Pacific Island and New Zealand (Maori) name for the palm, ti `cabbage-tree'. (See cabbage-tree.) (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),413)

HULME ... and a greasy little fellow with buck teeth and hair styled like ti was still the rocking fifties, beside him. (1983,Bone People, The,304)

BURTON [Title] Ti (cabbage tree) There are a number of species of cabbage tree (Cordyline) in New Zealand, all of which provide a vegetable in the form of white inner trunk or heart and the fleshy tap-root. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,7)

ti n. NZ cabbage-tree; any of several trees related to the cabbage-tree. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,803) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

. - This is the broad-leaved, deep green Ti, with red veins, a single head, and long elegant flowers. It is found plentifully on the West Coast, and merits a place in every collection. Maori, Ti-kapu. (May 28, 1902,Otago Witness,10)

ANGAS The tropical-looking dragon-trees (dracaena), called ti by the natives, and the karaka-tree, grow up the steep sides of the hills ... (1847,Savage Life,1/240)

At 3 p.m. Charlie arrived with potatoes and ti from the pah. Ibid.72 ti-root as food He [Tarawata's father] went off with all our enakis and ti and my stick - but I pursued him and recovered the latter. (Mar 31, 1849,Torlesse Papers,71,1958 ed.)

At first the old hands predicted that when cleared of fern, ti and bush it would blow away. (Feb 7, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/76)

Frequent groves of Ti (C. australis) (1851,Canterbury Papers,31)

SHORTLAND TI, in North Island commonly called Whanake (cordyline ti),;a liliaceous plant, resembling in appearance the Xanthorrhaea, or grass-tree of Australia. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,314)

MACKIE ... the Cordyline australis called the `ti' ... has the appearance of a narrow leaved yucca ... (Feb 3, 1853,Traveller under Concern,76,1973 ed.)

EARP ... the sides of the [Wellington] hills ... are almost tropical in their character, from the abundance of the ti, or dragon trees, with which they are covered. (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),92)

HOOKER Cordyline australis, Endl. ... Nat. name, Ti',<i> Cunn. </i> ... [Cordyline] Natives of the Tropical islands and South Temperate zone; ... The celebrated Ti of the South Sea Islands (whence the New Zealand nameTi' for C. australis) belongs to this genus ... (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 257)

2/126 Cordyline Pumilio Tirauriki (1870,TrNZI) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

HAY The Ti, or `cabbage-tree palm' (Cordyline Australis), grows as high as fifty feet. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/192)

DOMETT Asphodel (Ti) ..... O. Liliaceae; G. Neodaphne; S. C. Australis. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,2/336)

MORRIS Ti, N. the name of various species of trees of the genus Cordyline, N.O. Liliaceae. It exists in the Pacific Islands as C. Ti, and in New Zealand the species are C. australis and C. indivisa. Is is called in New Zealand the Cabbage-tree (q.v.), and the heart used to be eaten by the settlers. The word is Polynesian. In Hawaiian, the form is Ki; in Maori, Ti. Compare Kanaka (q.v.) and Tangata. By confusion, Tea, in Tea-tree (q.v.), is frequently spelt Ti, and Tea-tree is sometimes spelt Ti-tri (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,469)

BAUCKE For in their season he could supplement his dry fare with berries and nuts, with the tender bulbous shoots of the tii (cabbage tree), at heart white and delicate, baked in a haangi; the tender leaves of the nikau - that part between the last ring and where the leaf stems separate, below which there is a huge bulge, clasped firmly, clasp on clasp, with the grip of steel bands. (1905,Where the White Man Treads,16)

CHEESEMAN C[ordyline] australis, Hook.f. ... Ti; Ti-kauka; Ti-rakau; Palm-lily. ... Universally known to New Zealand residents by the inappropriate name of `cabbage-tree'. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,706)

There were also plenty of sugar ti (draecana terminalis), the true ti of Polynesia. (Sep 8, 1917,NZ Truth,8)

n. obs. elliptical form of ti-tree = tea-tree, manuka

POLACK The ti is a useful close grained wood, well adapted for handspikes. It grows to forty feet with crooked branches. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),2/397)

n. a finger game among Maoris

YATE (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),113) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

ti kapu¶

n. [aka tekapu, te-kapu]

HOOKER Cordyline indivisa, Kunth. ... Nat. name, `Tikapu', Col. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 258)

HOOKER Tikapu, Col[enso]. Cordyline indivisa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

  • This is the broad-leaved, deep green Ti, with red veins, a single head, and long elegant flowers. It is found plentifully on the West Coast, and merits a place in every collection. Maori, Ti-kapu. (May 28, 1902,Otago Witness,10)

"Ti-tree," on the other hand, is the cabbage tree, of which there are several species, such as ti-mataku-tai (or toii), ti-kapu, ti-rapo, ti kupenga, &c. (Jan 29, 1887,Wanganui Chronicle,2)

Rangiora bloom is over, but ake-piro, ake-rautangi, ti-kapu, harakeke, and manuka are in full flower. (Dec 3, 1895,Wanganui Chronicle,2)

ti kauka¶

n. cabbage tree [cf. ti kouka]

Kawakawa (pepper tree) leaves for aching joints, bruises and eczema, ti kauka (cabbage tree) leaves for cuts, sores and abrasions, pohutukawa bark for toothache and harakeke (flax) for wounds and skin ulcers are just a few of the huge number of native plants that were used by Maori and early European settlers for treatment of ailments. (Aug 13, 2003,Capital Times,14)

Ti Kauka of Whanake is the familiar Cabbage tree (Cordyline australis. (Oct 2000,Growing Today,40)

ti koraha¶

n.

HOOKER Tikoraha, Col[enso]. Cordyline stricta. ...Tikoraha, Geolog. Surv. Cordyline pumilio. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

ti kouka¶

n. cabbage tree [ORIGIN: Maori]

LAING & BLACKWELL Cordyline australis. (Ti-kouka. The Cabbage-Tree or Palm Lily). (1907,Plant Life in Maoriland,93,1940 p. 95 ed.)

FULLER Ti-kouka and whanake are varieties of the ti .. (1978,Maori Food and Cookery,6)

ADCOCK ti-kouka commonly `cabbage tree', Cordyline australis, with distinctive long narrow leaves growing in tufts (1982,Contemporary NZ Poetry,143)

The landscape of rainswept, ragged pasture, remnant stands of natives and brave, lonely ti kouka standing against the rising southerly aren't much like the rich land around Stratford, where I grew up. (Jun 15, 2000,City Voice,14)

HUTT One of the early infamous nineteenth-century Southland illegal stills was run by Owen McShane, who converted the sugary pulp of cabbage tree roots (ti kouka) into a concoction similar to brandy or rum... Missionary and Maori alike made beer from ti kouka. (1999,Maori & Alcohol,14) [NOTES: see also Eldred-Grigg "Pleasures of the Flesh...", p. 73; Riley, Maori Healing & Herbal, p. 18]

Niwa climate scientist Darren King said the second flowering of ti kouka was likely to reflect greater variability of recent regional temperatures. (Mar 23, 2006,Dominion Post,A3)

ti kupenga¶

n. [ORIGIN: Maori]

HOOKER Tikupenga, Lindsay. Cordyline stricta. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

ti mi¶

n. ?tainui Pomaderris apetala

PAULIN Among the trees Mr. Traill pointed out [on Stewart Island], was what he called a Ti Mi' tree, and which he said was only found growing in one place in New Zealand, that being Mokai, on the west coast of the North Island. He stated that the Maori tradition about it was this - that the first Maoris who visited New Zealand came in a large canoe built ofTi Mi' wood, and they landed at Mokaia, where there is a good harbour. canoe got broken up, and some of the planks took root and grew.' Paulin WWC, pp. 33-4. [Andersen notes:] The canoe referred to was the Tainui', and the tree is said to be the karaka or kopi. White Ancient History Maori (1890), vol. 4, p. 38. Ti Mi is probably intended for tainui: this tree is said to have sprung from the skids of theTainui' canoe. Cheeseman Manual NZ Flora (1906), p. 100. (1889,Wild West Coast) [NOTES: (And)]

ti ngahere¶

n. Cordyline banksii [ORIGIN: Maori, aka ti-ngahere, ti ngaherehere]

HOOKER Tingahere, Geolog. Surv. Cordyline stricta. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

HAY The Tingahere, or `lancewood' (Cordyline stricta), is another species of the same family. It is of very singular appearance, its head resembling a tuft of copper-coloured hair. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/192)

CHEESEMAN C[ordyline] Banksii, Hook.f. ... Ti-ngahere. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,706)

C. Banksii (Ti-ngahere): A smaller and more graceful species than C. Australis. (Mar 5, 1917,Ohinemuri Gazette,4)

Ti ngaherehere, Cordyline banksii. - A much smaller plant than the [ti]. (1874,TrNZI,6/56)

ti parae¶

n.

HOOKER Tiparae, Geolog. Surv. Cordyline Banksii. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

ti pore¶

n. Cordyline terminalis, a cabbage tree [ORIGIN: Maori]

MANSFIELD - walking breast high through the manuka - Lily of the valley - the ti pore we approach Galatea. (1907,Urewera Notebook,48,1978 Gordon ed.)

CHEESEMAN C[ordyline] terminalis, Kunth. ... KERMADEC ISLANDS: ... NORTH ISLAND: Formerly cultivated by the Maoris in the Bay of Islands ..., now nearly extinct. Ti-pore. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,705)

ti rauriki¶

n. Cordyline pumilio (as ti koraha) [ORIGIN: Maori]

HOOKER Tirauriki, Geolog. Surv. Cordyline pumilio. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

CHEESEMAN C[ordyline] pumilio, Hook.f. ... NORTH ISLAND: ... Ti-rauriki. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,708)

ti tawhiti¶

n.

HOOKER Titawhiti, Geolog. Surv. Cordyline sp. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Among the varieties of Cordyline grown by Maoris was one, variously known as ti tawhiti, ti kowhiti and ti para by tribes of the Taranaki, Wanganui and east coast regions respectively... The lack of a documented history, the unusual dwarf suckering habit, and the observation that it had never been recorded to flower suggested to us that Cordyline 'Thomas Kirk' could be the forgotten ti tawhiti... Ibid. 49 The name ti tawhiti is translated as "the ti from a distant place" or alternatively "the ti from Tahiti". (Jan 1992,NZ Gardener,48)

ti toi¶

n. toi, ti kapu, Cordyline indivisa

COWAN There are mountain palms or titoi (cordyline indivisa), and mamaku fern-trees ... (1926,Travel in NZ,148,(Vol II South Island) 148 ed.)

ti-bush¶

n. manuka

We walked afterwards around the farm ... saw the young men cutting Ti-bush, and carting it to the sea to be shipped for Auckland. (1886,Oceana,280 (Ch.XVIII))

ti-palm¶

n. ti, cabbage tree Cordyline australis [incl tipalm, also ti palm] (See also ti,ti-ti palm)

SEWELL The Chapman's house is about half a mile from the River bank, with nothing to mark it but a perfect grove of those Ti-palms. (Mar 12, 1856,Journal,210) [NOTES: in McIntyre (1980) Sewell Journal 1953-1856]

POLACK The provisions consisted of about three thousand baskets of potatoes, kumeras, ... steamed kernels of the karaka [a's-acute] maori, tarro [a-acute], ...: the baked roots of the Ti palm, &c. graced the festal scene. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/229)

POLACK A long lane was formed on an extensive level plain, fifty feet in width, by two high walls, formed by perhaps upwards of ten thousand baskets of potatoes, kumeras, Indian corn (Holcus indicus), tarro (arum), water melons, turnips preserved, (kou) steamed kernels of the native fruit, (karaka[as-acute]) baked roots of the ti palm tree, (korou) a quantity of dried cod, eels and other fish, also of shell-fish, bundles of fern-root, onions, peaches, grapes, &c. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/91)

SELWYN Walked over a beautiful grass plain [south Canterbury] ... after twelve miles covered with the Ti palm; ... (Jan 18, 1844,Journal) [NOTES: 1844 Jan 18 Selwyn Journal in 1851 NZ Part III (Church in the Colonies VIII) 14]

WAKEFIELD ... the indigenous flax-plant and ... the Cabbage-tree or Ti-palm. [fn] Dracaena Australis. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,45)

Country undeviating grass and ti-palm. (Mar 4, 1849,Torlesse Papers,64,1958 ed.)

The appearance of Ti palms on the Canterbury plains is very remarkable. They rise amidst the short rich grass with their thick stalks and graceful crest; often when one looks up suddenly from the ground, startling with their likeness to men. One of our wags remarked of these plants, that they looked like men as trees walking'. A less observant youth having lost his way a few nights ago, in the neighbourhood of the capital, was cheered in the loneliness of the prairie, by the appearance of a man approaching. He took off his hat, (not having yet forgotten the courteous address of the old country,) and accosted the stranger,I beg your pardon, sir, but can you tell me which is the way to Christchurch.' It was a Ti palm. (Apr 12, 1851,Lyttelton Times,5)

ALFRED C BARKER Letter about the New Canterbury Cordyline australis Settlement (And) (Jun 18, 1851,Letter)

SEWELL The regular line of enclosures ceases, and it is all open wild land, an unbroken flat - dotted about with Ti palms (a tall ungainly tree like plant with a cross head like a ragged Aloe). . (1853,Journal,1/423,1980 ed.)

(Jan 1856,Edinburgh New Philosophical Journal) [NOTES: Tancred Notes on the Natural History of ... Canterbury (And)]

BUTLER The distinctive marks which characterise it as not English are the occasional Ti palms, which have a very tropical appearance, and the luxuriance [34] of the Phormium tenax. Ibid. ix/132 The cabbage-tree or ti palm is not a true palm, though it looks like one. It has not the least resemblance to a cabbage. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,iii/33-34)

BARKER Ti-ti palms are dotted here and there. (1866,Station Days in Maoriland,52,1874 ed.)

... the constantly recurring bush fires have cleared off the stately Ti palms (so fragrant in early spring); ... (1870,TrNZI,2/49) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

The banks [Thames-Piako] are bare with the exception of small patches of kahikatea and ti palm ... (Jun 23, 1890,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/558,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

A small grove of ti-palms or cabbage-tree. (Dec 22, 1892,Otago Witness,7) [NOTES: (Morris)]

Ti-palm; Ti-tree.- Cabbage-tree (q.v.). ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Dec 23, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

Cabbage trees ... which in the old days grew singly or in groups on many parts of the [Canterbury] plains, and up to 1500 feet on the hills. Earliest settlers called [them] ti-tree, ti-palm from [their] Maori name. (1933,Press, The) [NOTES: Acland]

TURNER (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,166)

Alas! He's gone, / Shattered by death's blow / As broken lies my tall ti-palm, / Shattered by the whirlwind / On the cliffside of Opoura. (Aug 13, 1910,Evening Post,10)

Then the ti-palm (cabbage tree), which comes into full bearing only at intervals of three or four years, occasionally supplies the bird with an abundant feast. (Jul 2, 1927,Evening Post,17)

McIntyre (ed.) The Naya is as good as the laurel and not unlike it. Plenty of Tree ferns and Tipalms. (1980,Journal of Henry Sewell,I/328) [NOTES: from Journal of HS 1853-7]

By an antique sundial, so old that though all then known parts of the world were mapped on it, so that the sun at mid-day should tell the time everywhere, Australasia is not marked, stands a New Zealand Ti-palm, the shadows of its leaves now falling aslant that deluded time-piece! (Apr 1, 1903,NZ Illustrated Magazine,21)

ti-root¶

n.

McNEISH In the library he found a Kauffman he had lent hung over a notice advising that the smoking of ti-root and other rank mosses was to be encouraged. (1970,Mackenzie,22)

ti-shrub¶

n. =ti(tree), cabbage-tree, cabbage : contrast manuka

WAKEFIELD An unmixed growth [462] of stunted manuka is a bad sign, a quantity of ti-shrubs, commonly called the cabbage-tree, a very good one [sc. of the quality of soils]. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,461)

ti-ti palm¶

n. ti, cabbage tree [ti-palm, see] (See also ti)

DRURY TREES [MET WITH IN PELORUS]. Ti - Ti palm or Ti bush, common everywhere. Supplejacks - Karea of natives, ... (1855,Sailing Alone,67)

HARPER The inner substance of the Ti-ti palm, which is long and fibrous, contains a good deal of sugar, ... (Oct 1, 1863,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,75,1914 ed.)

BARKER Nothing seems [25] so wonderful to me as the utter treelessness of the vast Canterbury plains; occasionally you pass a few Ti-ti palms (ordinarily called cabbage-trees), or a large prickly bush which goes by the name of `wild Irishman,' but for miles and miles you see nothing but ... undulating downs of yellow tussocks, the tall native grass. Ibid. 52 Ti-ti palms dotted here and there. (1865,Station Life in NZ,24,1870 ed.)

ti-tree¶

n. ti, cabbage tree [one cit only]

[A] coarse sieve, made of the long ...mid-ribs obtained from the linear leaves of the tii-tree (Cordyline australis). (1881,TrNZI,13/26)

v. ti-tree oneself, be ti-treed, to be in a shelter (that is, to take to the scrub)

PARTRIDGE [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... ti-tree oneself, to take shelter from artillery, the ti-tree being very common in N.Z., where during the Maori War, the natives had an exasperating habit of retreating to `the bush', wooded country; (1935,Slang Today,286) [NOTES: 1935 Mitchell and Strong in Partridge Slang Today 286]

PARTRIDGE Ti-tree oneself; be ti-treed. To take shelter from artillery fire: New Zealand soldiers': in G.W. Ex Maori custom of retreating to the bush at time of the Maori War. See preceding entry. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,881)

[Slang of the N.Z.E.F.] ... `to be ti-treed' meant to be in shelter. (Apr 2, 1938,Press, The,18) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

1 n. (Rural) tea-tree or manuka. [titree, ti tree; includes attibutive use and 'in the ti-tree']

His Inspectorship noted a ti-tree whiskered individual during his inspection. (Apr 27, 1912,NZ Free Lance,15)

The girl did her evening work gathering ti-tree kindling for the morning porridge. (Oct 20, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

IRELAND [A memory] that has never left me is of Mac out on a far hillside of the nextdoor farm, slashing ti-tree. (1998,Under the Bridge & Over the Moon,107)

[Colin Meads] talks about being a 21-year-old "fresh off the ti-tree", being selected for the All Blacks in 1957. (Dec 12, 1999,Sunday Star Times,B7)

TINNE My horse ... pitched heavily ... sending me [5] head first among the manuka or ti-tree scrub ... I had to stop at an `accommodation house' (or way-side inn) to sponge him down. (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,4)

".. We goes round that ti-tree bush on the bend of the road, and back again " (Sep 28, 1901,New Zealand Free Lance,12)

The one great difficulty is the drying process. A good deal of latitude is allowed in this respect, and one may choose from the million and one ti-tree bushes on the hillside, or rig a line with the assistance of two upright sticks, in the vicinity of the tent. (Aug 6, 1918,Wanganui Chronicle,3)

At the time the family arrived at Auckland the only habitation of any description was a raupo store depot on the beach, situated on the site of the present Shortland Street Post Office, the rest of the district being covered by dense ti-tree bush. (Aug 2, 1924,Evening Post,6)

The Sergeant of Police said the prisoner was a perfect nuisance to the inhabitants, and had no home that he was aware of, excepting a shanty stuck up in the ti-tree. (Jun 9, 1866,Wellington Independent,5) [NOTES: Harry's tea-tree 4b, as in 'the sticks']

Ti-tree thicket on a hot summer day. (Nov 4, 1935,Evening Post,8)

Very heavy rain was encountered during the search, which ended with the men being discovered huddled on cement bags under thick ti-tree. (Sep 5, 1944,Evening Post,7)

Tí.-treé. (t&emacr.́.tr&emacr.), n. (Bot.) (a) The ti or titi. See TI. (b) An erroneous spelling of TEA TREE. See under TEA. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

JOHNSTONE-SMITH Ti-tree was plentiful but tawa had to be snigged home from quite a distance. (1975,Battles, Buggies and Babies,42)

PRICE required for Clearing Half-acre Broom and Ti-tree. (Sep 7, 1929,Evening Post,3)

FOR SALE, Ti-tree Stakes, Tomato and bean, approx. 8doz. (Sep 21, 1940,Evening Post)

The present writer was asked.. to go and see the hot water away in the ti-tree somewhere. (Mar 5, 1904,NZ Observer,4)

Auckland people are glad to get stumpy little bagfuls of ti-tree at half a crown a bag. (Aug 23, 1913,NZ Observer,3)

A considerable number of settlers and others visited the ground on Saturday to see the trial of Mr Henry Reynolds' new Triumph ti-tree cutter. (Jan 24, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

"The Soul of the Ti-Tree", by Edwinia C. Geach. (Feb 10, 1910,Triad, The,XVII(2) ; 35)

FIREWOOD. - Cut and Uncut Titree. CHARCOAL. - Best Titree. (May 8, 1897,Observer (Auckland),20)

Orders for Matai or Totara posts, Ti-tree Rails, Shingles, and Kaikatea [sic] Building Timber, executed. (Apr 1, 1873,Waikato Times,1)

Over an hour was spent by the Fire Brigade this morning in beating out flames which were licking up the grass and titree on the Rhodes estate at Wadestown at a great rate. (Feb 11, 1915,Evening Post,8)

It's a titipounamu, and you often find him in the ti-tree scrub... It is the rifleman, very shy, and a friend of the scrub-cutter. (Feb 5, 1995,NZ Tablet,7)

Perchance he's raced tho' the ti-tree bush. (Oct 30, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/5 : 109)

FIREWOOD.- Cut and Uncut Titree. CHARCOAL.- Best Titree. (Nov 16, 1901,Observer (Auckland),26)

Only a small cartel of particularly hardy plants could survive - titree, gorse, umbrella fern and small red carnivorous sundews are major components (Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,112)

ti-tree sawyer¶

n. (a weta)

The so-called mosquito was a "Weita" or "Ti-tree Sawyer" which is found at times in this district and is very common in Auckland and other provinces. It is called a scorpion by some~settlers, and is considered to be poisonous. (Dec 23, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

tiaki¶

n. a bird, the saddleback

YATE Tiaki, or Purourou - This elegant bird is about the size of the sky-lark; and its plumage ... is of glossy black; ... (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),56)

POLACK Among the birds that distinguished themselves in this woodland concert, were the tui, or mocking-bird, the korimaku [a-acute], kohapiroa, and tiaki [a-acute]. The little restless piwakawaka [a2,a4-acute], a kind of thrush, who is incessantly hopping from twig to twig, put forth its single note. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/108)

MORRIS Tiaki (spelt also Tieke), Maori name for the Saddle-back or Jack-bird (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,469)

tiake, tiaki n. Maori name for the saddle-back or jack-bird [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

tiake, tiaki ... n. Maori name for saddle-back or jack-bird [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

n. a tree

POLACK Among the many valuable trees ... the following are best known. The kouri, totarra [a1-acute], puriri, rata [a's-acute], pohutokawa, rohito, kahikatea [a's, e-acute], kaikatoa [a2-acute], towai, rimu, maidi, torairi, tanikaha [a2,a3-acute], kowai, rewarewa, maioi, tipou, touwa, kawaka [a's-acute], miro, koikoi, hinou, tiaki, akki pirou, angi angi, patu [a-acute], koihiu, &c., and various akkas' [a2-acute], or liands. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/286)

tiaki-aki¶

n.

RICHARDS L[arus] novae hollandiae ... Red-billed Gull, Jacky. TIAKI-AKI. (1952,Chatham Exiles,83)

tiariraka¶

n.

Man is like unto the smallest of the Maori birds, the name of which is the tiariraka (fantail fly-catcher), and its song is, tit! tit! (Jun 28, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,4)

Sydney Taiwhanga is a great humbug - or, as the Ngapuhi term him, atiariraka (the fantail flycatcher). (Jul 5, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,15)

tiaweke¶

n.

The nearest approach they could make to [Wakefield] was Era Weke, and some wag immediately suggested "Tiaweke," the name of a small bird which is very common in the woods, and known for its chattering propensities. (1845,Chambers Edinburgh Journal,4(84) : 85)

tick tack¶

n.

SUTTON-SMITH One common prank was Knick Knock. In this game, children knocked on someone's door, then ran away, but it could be played more elaborately: In Tick Tack we stuck a pin into the middle sash of a window; a button was suspended from this on a piece of cotton. Then a long length of cotton was attached to the smaller piece and led away to the gate. The cotton was pulled every now and then and the button tapped against the window. It was nighttime, and folks would pull up the blind and peer out. Some more adventurous spirits would come out and investigate and would maybe get entangled with the cotton. Then the culprit would run away to some other house. (1900; Moeraki) (1981,History of Children's Play,90)

tick tick¶

exclam.

WATT A warning like the English schoolboys' cave!'. From J. M. Barrie's <i>Peter Pan</i> where Hook was always warned of the approach of the crocodile because of the ticks of the alarm clock it had swallowed. If a master approaches, the boys warn the rest withtick tick!'. Also used in the expression `to go tick' - that is, to go on watch for masters and prefects while the rest get into mischief. (1951,Letter) [NOTES: 1951 Dilworth School (McWatt letter)]

ticker¶

n. spirit

There was more ticker shown by these Lions than you'd find in a Swiss clock factory and they deserve a healthy reception at their next home game. (Oct 1, 2001,Evening Post,28)

MARRINER I can't condone your actions, but I'd be the first to admit that you've got plenty a ticker. (2001,Stonedogs,328)

A night to find out just how much ticker this All Black team has, whether the extraordinary commitment shown in Dunedin against England was a oneoff or a sign of things to come. (Jul 18, 2004,Sunday Star Times,B3)

They [Warriors] used to be the sort of team that once you put a few points on them you could score 50 or so. But not now. They've found a bit of ticker. (Apr 9, 2001,Evening Post,25)

Caroline's day begins by feeling her pulse rate... Georgina usually passes on the ticker test. (Nov 11, 2001,Sunday Star Times,B18)

This season is a great opportunity to show people I do have a little bit of ticker. (Nov 28, 2003,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,3)

tickerless¶

adj. lacking heart

I fear we have now gone from a team full of Deans; gutsy but talentless Cantabs to a bunch of highly skilled, but tickerless Aucklanders. (Dec 21, 2003,Sunday Star Times,B12)

ticket¶

n. Union membership card

HAMILTON Bluey had lost his seaman's ticket over his jail blues, and I don't suppose he'll ever get it back. (1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,127)

He was told that Campbell and Liggett had said that if he was not going to pay the levy they [the Union] were going to have his `ticket' and they would have him down the road. That meant they were going to deprive him of his right to work. (Dec 7, 1983,Press, The,4)

n. a traffic offence notice; a traffic offence summons, espec. in get a ticket (cf. Bluey, sticker) [Also `ticket' used on English TV show Dec 1984 for parking ticket. 30/3/85 1985 People's Court : US he got a ticket [for riding a moped]]

His client had sold his motor-cycle two days after the incident which gained him a ticket ... . (Feb 27, 1953,Evening Post,6)

[A] number [of motorists] were detected by traffic officers and collected `tickets'. (Sep 1957,Evening Post)

Story of cricketer Cawdrey driving up a one-way street while listening to cricket test, being stopped by policeman. `Colin Cawdrey got a ticking off rather than a ticket.' (Nov 30, 1984,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 2YA Wellington Morning Report]

Otahuhu District Court thought that the department would sort out the computer snafu fairly quickly, so it took no further steps towards processing Mr lange's speeding ticket, or any of the other snarled-up cases. (Apr 23, 1988,Dominion,2)

[Hdg] Unruly drivers clock up one millon tickets. Close to one million traffic tickets were issued to unruly Kiwi drivers last year... "The minister has said in the past if people don't like receiving tickets, then the message is simple: don't speed,"... (Nov 9, 2003,Sunday Star Times,A3)

ticket boy¶

n.

Just by the slaughterhouse office was a place called the Ticket Room, and not surprisingly perhaps, the boys who worked there were called Ticket Boys. (Jan 24, 1981,Evening Post,7) [NOTES: [Clem Goddard on the Gear Meat Co.]]

COLIN GORDON The carcases are washed and wiped by a wiper, then a stringer, generally a boy, puts strings on the front legs and necks, and they go over to the clock which counts them. The carcases then go to the pusher-up who pushes them along to the scales to be weighed and graded. A stamper stamps the carcases and a ticket-boy puts a grade ticket on them out at the scales after the grader has graded them for weight and size. (May 17, 1951,Personal Communication)

The employees in question embrace such departments of the industry as:- Floormen, boners, cooling chamber hands, general labourers, meat classers, weigh clerks, temporary clerks, trimmers, ticket boys, gut men and gut runners, pressers, vat hands, dryers, crushers, and baggers, etc. (Feb 9, 1912,Evening Post,8)

WOODHOUSE Past the meat-inspector and ticket boy / In a line that never fails / Goes your dear wee lamb to the cooling room/ From the grader and his scales./ (1967,Farm & Station Verse,188) [NOTES: From Stronach 1949]

ticket girl¶

n.

FRAME They walked into the vestibule and over to the box where the ticket-girl waited. (1951,Lagoon, The,109) [NOTES: 1961 edition; also 1951 Frame Lagoon 114 -->[check OED [S]]]

ticket room¶

n. [1951 Foxton Freezing Works (C. Gordon)]

Just by the slaughterhouse office was a place called the Ticket Room, and not surprisingly perhaps, the boys who worked there were called Ticket Boys. (Jan 24, 1981,Evening Post,7) [NOTES: [Clem Goddard on the Gear Meat Co.]]

ticket-of-leave man¶

n. [1933 Acland (1930/183)]

George Butler ... charged with being ... a ticket-of-leave man illegally at large. ... by a recent Act escaped ticket-of-leave men could be dealt with at once [without need of communicating with Australian authorities]. (Apr 18, 1868,Marlborough Express,5)

ticky¶

2 n. South African, threepence, a threepenny bit NB Iris W. was born in South Africa (p.c. J.E.P.Thomson

HYDE Elize 'ud rather have a tikky,' said Bob ... South African children saytikky' for threpenny-bit, and Corby branded them as outlanders by sticking to `tikky' even now. (1938,Godwits Fly, The,7,1970 ed.)

HYDE Then Elf always had money in his pocket. They supposed this was because he was an American citizen, and the moral lesson of that estate is that you have money when nobody else canscare up even a tikky (1938,Wednesday's Children,138)

tiddling¶

adj. G.J.Griffiths notes: trivial, ineffectual; probably a manufactured word, and possibly personal to the columnist, manufactured from piddling' andtiddler' -

When it is noticed how thousands of dollars of Golden Kiwi funds are so often frittered away in tiddling grants to all and sundry for every minor parish project one can imagine, I cannot help feeling that someone up there in the seats of the mighty in Wellington needs a decent shake-up. (Sep 18, 1971,Evening Star,8) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

tide¶

n. often used in NZ colloquial (espec. in children's) for the sea' as in English dialectwithout reference to ebb or flow', espec. in localities where low tide leaves mudflats, sandbanks etc. exposed [ca1935 Havelock Where the same mudflat tidal conditions applied.]

MICALFE In Whangaroa, Maunganui, in Northland, one always speaks of going for a swim in the tide. These places are silted up with mudflats: one cannot swim etc. when the tide is out, so tide' andsea' are identified. (1951,Personal Communication)

SARGESON ... and a great Christmas tree in flower reached out far enough to colour the tide. (1977,Never Enough!,11)

tide-rip¶

n. (See rip)

tide-waiter¶

n. a ship waiting for the tide

ROCHFORT It was now sunset, so we went aboard. The tide-waiter had come off, and the captain, afraid of his men running away, had put this functionary on guard; he was marching up and down the quarter-deck with the captain's double-barrelled gun on his shoulder, which he ... was swearing to shoot, ... and without the slightest compunction, [15] any man trying to leave the ship. (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,14)

... and landed in Nelson away back in 1842-. ... Her father was for a time engaged in Nelson as tide waiter, but subsequently removed to the Wairau. (Sep 9, 1911,NZ Truth,324/4/7)

tie off¶

v.

CRUMP Then for three weeks they dug post- and strainer-holes, ran out wires,.... strained up, tied off, tacked up and hung battens. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,126)

tie the knot¶

phr. to become a swagger; to be on the swag

AGNEW During the four years I was to tie the knot I became known as simply The Kid. ... It was an unspoken rule never to question a fellow-swagger about his past ... . Ibid. 68 He's a miserable bastard who claims we're [sc swaggers] lazy buggers who'd rather tie the knot than work. (1974,Loner, The,66) [NOTES: [check knot but leave at tie]]

tie up¶

v. usually in get tied up, to get married, `hitched' [ca1985 Jan 16 Wellington They had been living together for some time and had decided to get properly tied up when she was pregnant.]

The newly-married couple were tied-up in Auckland (1882,Brighter Britain,171)

tie-back¶

n. tie-wire

(See tie-wire) (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,30)

tie-down¶

1 n. (Rural) a deadman anchor [used to secure fenceposts.]

MOWAT Joe & I went round the fence round Middle Hills & put in a few tie-downs. (Oct 9, 1908,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

MCLEOD He dug holes for posts and learned how stays and 'tie-downs' were used. (1954,On the Hill,22)

DU FAUR The use of chains for tie-downs, where footed posts are normally used, has become popular and effective. (1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,193)

Then it was a matter of setting to to make the Taranaki gates as we discussed. Have completed three gates and dug in nine tie-downs but still more will be needed. (Jun 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture,32)

Clearing sale .. Insul timber posts and tie-downs, Waratah standards.. (Nov 10, 1993,Napier Daily Telegraph,21)

Tie-downs: (See dead man). Wire that ties the dead man to the post. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,30)

CRUMP By letting go a tie-down just along the fence he manages to get the fence wires done up in the same twists they were in before. He loses a bit of tension on the tie-down but no one's going to notice that. (1989,Bullock Creek,92)

tie-up¶

n. [from taiepa, see]

As a guide, so far, we should say that the common post and rail fences usually erected are "substantial" in the meaning of the ordinance, and that they ought to be held so till decayed. Even a maori [sic] "tie-up" might at first be substantial, but of course it would soon cease to be so. (Mar 4, 1848,Evening Post,3)

Every unfortunate canine which made its appearance within the marae was promptly collared and removed to the "tie-up." (Feb 24, 1910,Hawera & Normanby Star,8)

A favourite dodge of the Maoris was to put a "tie-up" or Maori fence across the roads being formed. (Nov 9, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,39)

tie-up fence¶

n. (See also taiepa)

NESFIELD A large Hau Hau flag-staff stood in an enclosure, ... and twenty or thirty whares with their usual `tie-up' fences around them formed the outside Pah. (1881,Chequered Career,43)

tie-wire¶

n. a piece of wire used to fasten two objects together; tie-back [Jim writes: In NZPOD but not DNZE or any other dictionary available to me]

Tie-wire: Wire that ties the dead man to the post (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,30)

tieke¶

n. the saddleback, Philesturnus carunculatus,

In 1869, saddleback, or tieke, were described as "very common" on Little Barrier, but by 1882 they had all but disappeared. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/17)

The saddleback, or tieke, a mid-sized bird with a distinctive orange "saddle" on it's back and an orange-red "wattle" at the base of its beak, became extinct on the mainland around 100 years ago but yesterday arrived at its new home on Motuihe Island in the inner Hauraki Gulf. (Aug 12, 2005,NZ Herald,A7)

DIEFFENBACH 33. Creadion carunculatus. G.R.Gray, ... Tieke of the natives of Tasman Bay. Quoy and Gaim Tiaka or Purourou of the natives. Yate. Tira-oua-ke [e-acute] of the natives. Less. Tierawaki, Cook's Straits. Dieffenbach. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/192) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/192]

Creadion carunculatus. Tieke. Saddle-back. Not uncommon. (1869,TrNZI,1/160) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

HUTTON 45. CREADION CARUNCULATUS. Gml. Saddle-back. Tieke. C. Cinereus. BULLER. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,17)

BULLER CREADION CARUNCULATUS. (THE SADDLE-BACK.) ... Native names. Tieke, Tiraweke, {Tirauweke,} and Purourou. [151] It is naturally a noisy bird, and when excited or alarmed becomes very clamorous, hurrying through the woods with cries of `tiaki-rere', quickly repeated. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,150, 151) [NOTES: {1888 2nd edn 1/18}]

  1. Creadion carunculatus, Gml. Saddle-back, Jackbird, Tieke. (Mar 1885,NZ Journal of Science,377) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

Creadion carunculatus. - Tieke, Saddle-back. Both Islands. Flight feeble. (1886,TrNZI,18/112) [NOTES: (Martin)]

BULLER CREADION CINEREUS. (JACK-BIRD.) ... Native name.- Tieke. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/19)

BULLER ... to say nothing of Korimako and Pitoitoi ..., we never saw or heard the notes of either the Piopio, the Tieke, or the Hihi, all of which birds were at one time more numerous even than the Huia. The Zosterops was everywhere abundant, also the Grey Warbler and Rifleman, and ... we found the Tomtit comparatively plentiful; the Parakeet chased its mate through the tree-tops with sharp cries of `twenty-eight'; ... and among the tangle of the underwood the ever-present Flycatcher displayed its pretty fan-like tail. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/14)

MORRIS Tieke, n Same as Tiaki (q.v.). (1889,Austral English,469)

REISCHEK I shot a tieke, and was pleased to notice that this starling had increased in numbers since my earlier visit in 1880. (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,107,1933 ed.)

tieke, a bird (Creadion carunculatus), saddleback, now a rare bird: its saddle is the mark of the hot hand of Maui. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

saddleback forest bird. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

FALLA et al. SADDLEBACK Philesturnus carunculatus Maori name; Tieke (1966,Birds of New Zealand,233)

  1. a. Philesturnus carunculatus rufusater (Lesson, 1828) North Island Saddleback [(Tieke)] (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,72,1980 ed.)

Saddleback Philesturnus carunculatus (GMELIN, 1789) ... North Island Saddleback P.c. rufusater (LESSON, 1828). South Island Saddleback P.c. carunculatus (GMELIN, 1789). ... OTHER NAME: Tieke. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,302)

tier¶

n. ? a coating of clay or earth on a ? sod or wattle and daub house; ? or tie-beam

Fine weather, Chapman shepherding Wedders, put tier on house &c [24] no tier got on house clay wet [Mar 31] put last tier and wall plates on house. [Apr 2] clayed walls of house put on tie beams [3] finished claying & put on ridge pole & rafters of house. [Apr 4] nailed wattles on roof [Apr 5] commenced thatching house. [Apr 12] put in clay in eaves and put tier on gable and chimney, [14] put tier on gable and chimney & tier of small stove, (Mar 19, 1860,Puketoi Station Diary) [NOTES: [Hocken TS]]

tier-pole¶

1 n. (Rural) a rack of parallel bars upon which curing-sticks rest in the curing of tobacco.

They [curing-sticks] usually carry from eight to ten plants, and are hung in the shed by resting the ends of the sticks on tier-poles. These are strong squared timber, 2in by 4in., lying horizontally, and held in position by bolting them to uprights .. If the distance between curing-sticks on the tier-poles is reckoned at 8 in., it is now possible to work out the accommodation required for curing the crop. (Nov 21, 1927,NZ Journal of Agriculture,340)

The stick is placed on tier poles, which run like parallel bars in the curing-shed. (Jan 21, 1929,NZ Journal of Agriculture,59)

tierawaki¶

n. (See tiraueke)

tiffin¶

n.

McGILL tiffin midmorning cuppa and snack, late C19; from Anglo-Indian word for a light lunch. [Partridge] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,113)

tig¶

n. a fit of temper. a tantrum

MARSH [girl speaks] I can't see why you're getting into such a tig over it. (1943,Colour Scheme,217)

n. the children's game of tag. (from TIG v) [[see Sutton-Smith]]

4 Steeple-chasing, cricket, ... were varied by a game known as tig', ortwos and threes', rounders, &c., in some of which the ladies assisted. (Nov 7, 1868,Marlborough Express)

v. to touch, to tag (espec. in the game of TIG or tag.) [ca1935 Havelock children e.g. Tigged you last. cf. also Tiggy-tiggy-touchwood, a children's game.]

2 v. (occas.) to filch [ca1935 e.g. He tigged an apple from my lunch-tin.]

tiger¶

n. an energetic person, a `tiger for work'; a fast, vigorous tramper

With the following dawn two tigers stood by for a quick trip back to Maruia Springs while each pack was [40] searched and emptied. (Sep 1958,Tararua,39)

`What about Screamin George? Real bloody tiger. Make two of Donovan.' (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,205)

SLATTER Doesn't know if he's punched, bored, or countersunk - A tiger for punishment - (1968,Pagan Game, The,162)

tiger: A shearer who works very hard. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/28) [NOTES: Wallace Shearing Glossary]

Aycliffe made his third start on the day and ran well into fourth place - a tiger for work. (Nov 4, 1922,NZ Truth,7)

A veritable tiger for work was Rufus Kiser. (Jan 13, 1931,Evening Post,11)

This man is, I learn, a perfect tiger at work, most strong, most reliable, and no doubt, when times improve, will rapidly grow independent, after all realising the dreams which gladdened the sweet hours of his voyage to these shores. (Nov 6, 1885,NZ Tablet,19)

Premier Seddon is a tiger for work. (Jan 23, 1897,Observer (Auckland),4)

  • That F.G. Bolton's enthusiasm to have the Hutt Park vested in the Wellington City is approved by all the athletic bodies. And isn't F.G.B. a tiger for work? (May 16, 1908,New Zealand Free Lance,22)

The men have enlisted to fight and are tigers for work. (Nov 7, 1914,Evening Post,5)

3 n. a shark

RUHEN tiger shark He was so old a tiger that his stripes had faded, and his colour was a even as a porbeagle's. (1964,Lively Ghosts,38)

tiger country¶

n. [figurative, far off the local area, esp in sport]

DAVIES Come down to Wellington if you feel that your batteries need to be recharged. I think it's going to be tiger country up there for a permanent union official, but we trust you to do your best. (1984,Bread and Roses,177)

Duncan's was the longer ball, but it kicked off the fairway into the "tiger country" to the left. (Nov 11, 1932,Evening Post,11)

Goss, after a pulled drive, hooked his second at "Alma" away into the tiger country. (Oct 6, 1923,NZ Truth,9)

1 n. (Rural) wild, isolated and steep country [usually scrub-covered and difficult to access and traverse.]

At the moment the Department [of Lands] is confined to buying areas that can be divided into multiple units. This restricts them to the real 'tiger' country. (Dec 10, 1964,NZ Dairy Exporter,13)

Much of the land is 'tiger' country, in gullies and gulches, wide riverbeds and faces leading sharply to broken tops. (May 11, 1968,Napier Daily Telegraph,5)

It's tiger country all right. David has 15,380 acres in a longish block without even a track to his far boundary. (Jul 8, 1971,NZ Farmer,32)

The Thomas family had farmed happily and well enough on their 760 ha. home block of medium to tiger country for the first 20 years or so. (May 13, 1982,NZ Farmer,14)

HOLDEN This was the type of steep, grey-walled stuff that on the West Coast they refer to with some pride as 'tiger country.' (1991,Fall Muster,22)

Rightly or wrongly, some would call the 520 ha Okoki Valley property farmed by Graeme and Marise Northcott 'Tiger Country.' [big tiger country ] (Nov 18, 1999,NZ Farmer,19)

LETHBRIDGE It had been pretty hard `tiger' country in the first place, but when the land had been cleared ... the subsequent pasture was good enough ... to run a dairy herd. (1971,Sunrise on the Hills,126)

NEWTON This road . . . winds its way through the harsh `tiger' country which typifies much of that [Marlborough Sounds] locality. (1973,Big Country,32,1977 ed.)

Surveyors and geologists use the term tiger country' ...for the areas of low manuka scrub mixed with second growth native trees in the Rotorua-Taupo district (replacing forest destroyed by erruptions). Geologists say it is country only a tiger could get through, but I have suggested it may derive from the Siberian <i>taiga'. (1980,NZ Geochemical Group Newsletter,No. 57/12)

They come from a mostly fatherless family settling on the Pori Hill's legendary `tiger country', (May 9, 1987,Dominion,11)

tiger lily¶

n. (introduced)

lily, tiger [s] Lilium tigrinum L. Ibid. 79 tiger lily [s] Lillium tigrinum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,44)

tiger shark¶

n. [aka tiger-shark]

A fisherman at Paraparaumu made a haul of twenty-five sharks on one line which had 450 hooks baited for schnapper. None were [sic] less than six feet, and one was a tiger shark nearly 18 feet long which bit a piece out of the boat and made a great fight before it was killed. (Dec 16, 1897,Taranaki Herald,2)

While fishing for crayfish at Castlepoint the other day, Mr Southey hauled up a large tiger shark in a crayfish net. (Aug 9, 1900,Otago Witness,44)

ANGAS ... an annual fishery for the tiger-shark is carried on by the natives in Hauraki Gulf, at a certain season of the year. (1847,Savage Life,1/295)

ANGAS The tooth of the tiger-shark, drilled, and the end covered with red wax, is also an esteemed ornament as an ear-drop. (1866,Polynesia,157)

HUTTON 124. LAMNA GLAUCA. Mull. and Henle. Tiger Shark. Mako. (1872,Fishes,77)

Lamna glauca .. Tiger shark. Ibid. 117 to 119 TIGER SHARK (Lamna glauca). ... In New South Wales it is called the blue pointer, and, as Mr. Hill tells us, is `not only a very powerful, but perhaps the most bold of any of the large sharks visiting our shores. ... Ibid.118 Although there is some doubt on the subject, Lamna glauca is considered to be the mako of the Maoris, which is mainly found in the neighbourhood of Mayor Island. ... Mango, it should be remembered, seems [119] almost a generic name for shark in the North, as there is the mango-taniwha, a large variety; the mango-pare, the hammerheaded shark; the mango-reremai, the common dog-fish; the mango-pekepeke, and the mango-aruroa. (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,115)

MORRIS Tiger S.- Scymnus sp. (Maori name, Mako). (1898,Austral English,412)

WILLIAMS Ngutukao, ... lamna cornubica, tiger-shark. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,275)

Galeocerdo arcticus, Mull & Henle. Tiger Shark (1927,TrNZI,59/Plate 9) [NOTES: (Griffin)]

Galeocerda articus: Tiger shark, shovel nose. (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,71)

BEST Toiki (tiger-shark) (1929,Fishing Methods,49)

BEATTIE Mako or Mango - the tiger-shark. (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,61)

GRAHAM Tiger Shark Galeocerdo cuvier (Lesueur) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,397) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 397]

DOOGUE & MORELAND TIGER SHARK ... Other names: Galeocerdo cuvieri; leopard shark, toiki (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,179)

McLINTOCK Tiger shark .. .. toiki .. .. Galeocerdo cuvier (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

PAUL Tiger shark Galeocerdo cuvier A large shark of all tropical and some warm temperate oceans and coastal waters ... The common name refers to the striped pattern, but this is faint in adults... (1966,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,26)

[species name] tiger shark .. [scientific name] Galeocerdo cuvieri .. [other name(s)] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] shark, tiger 154-6, 245-9, 262 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

An immense tiger shark 15 feet long was captured a few days ago at the same place; the girth of its carcase was as great as that of a horse. (Jun 20, 1872,Wellington Independent,2)

tiger shell¶

n. a marine mollusc

POWELL TIGER SHELL (Maurea tigris). Grows to 3 inches in diameter and is at once recognised by its delicately tapered spire and conspicuous pattern of zig-zag reddish-brown radiating bands. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,25)

WILLIAMS Maurea. Maurea tigris, a univalve mollusc, the tiger shell. (1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,197)

McLINTOCK Tiger shell .. .. matangongore, maurea .. .. Maurea tigris (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

Pink Cameo and Tiger Shell and Enamels set in finest gold. (Jul 11, 1882,Star, The,2)

Numerous tiger shells, one of New Zealand's prettiest, nestle between the sponges and anemones. (Nov 1, 2003,Dominion Post,E9)

tiger weed¶

n. Bidens tripartitus [ca1953 R. Mason citing H.H. Allan: local to Foxton area]

tiger weed [=] beggars' ticks: cobblers' pegs [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,79)

tiger-skin¶

n.

He don't like to see others toiling,/ And he proves he's a tiger-skin',/ When he drinks with a bloke and chats him/Why don't you join up and dig in?' (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,69)

Tigers¶

n. Christchurch gang name

There used to be much more of the push element around Christchurch than there is now, and it frequently occurred that pushes [ie youths belonging to these groups] like the Tigers,' theDiehards,' the `Scalpers,' and the [rest of citation???] (Feb 3, 1912,NZ Truth,345/7/3)

tigerwood¶

n.

(Dec 1958,NZ Timber Journal,73)

tigger¶

n.

KEENE Because most of us were too small to be of any use in team games, we played hide-and-seek, `tigger', marbles or whipped tops. (1982,Myrtle and Sophia,6) [NOTES: [c1877]]

tiggy¶

n. a game out of school [1984 16 F E5 Pakuranga Coll. 21 TIGGIE -->1953 14 M A5 Thames DHS 21 TIGGY [2] -->1984 16 F E7 Pakuranga Coll. 21 TIGGY]

In the afternoon we were playing "tiggy" around the flower beds in front of the house, when a naughty bee from the hives came and sat on my head, and it did not forget to sting me before it went away. (Oct 12, 1904,Otago Witness,74)

tiggy touchwood¶

n. [see OED, English use from 1845; aka tiggy tiggy touchwood, tiggy-tiggy touchwood]

CONDON Other games played by the whole school from time to time included rounders, bedlam, tick-tack, tiggy tiggy touchwood, hide and seek, hares and hounds and cock fights - a form of piggy back (1992,Hurleyville,25)

HEINZ Some of the simple games played by the [West Coast] children were rounders, shinty, duckstone, tiggy touchwood, kiss in the ring, ... cockfighting, marbles, fly the garter and leapfrog. (1974,Bright Fine Gold,38) [NOTES: [c1870s] 1953 Patrick Magee (aged 86) Growing Up at the Diggings in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 38]

Here they, to the number of 250, were soon engaged in sport, and the games of "I-spy eye" and "tiggy touchwood" were indulged in with the gusto only to be felt in the early part of one's teens. (May 5, 1866,Wellington Independent,5)

BOARD AND MINISTER PLAY AT TIGGY-TIGGY TOUCHWOOD. (Dec 30, 1926,NZ Truth,1)

I was at a Sunday night concert given by the Derwent Infantry Band recently, and one of the items was Mozart's "Gloria," rendered in what I think fine style, and as the last note died away there was but one solitary attempt at applause, and that was drowned by the shouts of the "dear" children (who are always prominent at our open-air concerts nowadays), playing "Tiggy touchwood," or some other Sabbath pastime, which must be in great favour with the police, for they never seem to interfere, although to the person who goes to hear the music such amusements are rather annoying. (Dec 11, 1907,Otago Witness,74)

tight¶

n. ?two-up: prob. merely a play on having little or no money -

There is a tight' in the affairs of man [sic], which taken at the floods leads on to therising' - if you haven't 5s. to ante-up. (Jan 18, 1908,NZ Truth,135/1/3)

adj. of country, difficult to work [1898 [see index and discards]]

adj. close

GOLDSMITH At this time, when the Government needed to keep things 'tight' - to use the dominant rugby metaphor of the Bolger administration - Banks threw a series of wild passes. (1997,John Banks : A Biography,194)

1 adj. (Rural) [of pasture feed] in short supply.

.. the other 35-40 cows reared Holstein-Friesian bull calves while feed was tight in spring ... (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,84)

Agribusiness consultant Ivan Lines said while feed was a bit tight, most dairy framers would be in a much better situation compared with this time last year. (Aug 6, 2002,Southland Times,3)

tight as...¶

phr. very mean (espec. with money), often further elaborated by adding `and that's watertight'; very drunk; (in various expressions of comparison with TIGHT in the senses: (1) close-fisted (P: mostly US: 1828; so WF); and (2) drunk (where NZ English would perhaps prefer FULL AS)) [ca1948 Wellington (Douglas Gray) cf. P: tight as a drum, tick, etc., which are also frequent in NZ.]

HILL;IARD Yet in spite of it all he was as tight as a bull's arse going uphill in the fly season. (1969,Green River,38)

McGILL tight as a duck's arse, also bull's/gnat's/fish's mean with money; often carrying the response: and that's water tight. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,113)

tight bush¶

1 n. (Rural) a bush forest close with undergrowth and heavily wooded.

HOLDEN In 'tight' bush, Richard reckoned the calibre and ultra-short barrel was an ideal combination. (1996,Great Hunting Yarns,185)

tight chains¶

phr. horses working

As a teamster, Pop was required (when working the team) to have 'tight chains' from 8am until 5.30pm. That means that the harness chains had to be tight (horses working), and prior to 8am the horses had to be caught, fed, prepared - and after 5.30pm the opposite applied, so I am not sure just how long his day was. (Feb 2004,NZ Memories,No. 46/41)

tight five¶

n. the nucleus of a rugby union scrum, the three front-row forwards and two locks.

New Zealand's tight five forwards have been given the big ask by coach Laurie Mains in the lead-up to Saturday's thirds rugby test. (Jul 1, 1993,Evening Post,32)

We've put a bit of work into getting the tight five together. (Jul 1, 1993,Evening Post,32)

The tight five! As far as I was concerned they were the loose five. (Sep 5, 1999,Sunday Star Times,C1)

Everything clicked, especially in the tight five where we set up the platform. (Jun 8, 1992,Dominion,13)

In the Wairarapa we have our 'tight five'. Our caterer goes everywhere we go. (Feb 14, 2001,Capital Times,14)

The scrum was stronger than the World Cuppers' and should stay intact in the tight five. (Jul 6, 1992,Evening Post,28)

He was very happy with the tight five. (Jul 6, 1992,2ZB,Morning Talkback)

The All Black tight five was the guilty party. (Jul 23, 1992,Evening Post,27)

Our tight five laid the platform and that made it easier for the rest of us. (Aug 6, 1992,Dominion,36)

Knight The most obvious of these was the need to bolster the forwards' tight five. (1991,They Led the All Blacks,130)

Simply, the tight five, who had slept through the Toulouse test, awoke and that fuelled the loose trio and gave the backs the forward velocity. (Nov 20, 1995,Evening Post,26)

2 n. (transferred use, political context)

That assurance does not preclude a breakway from NZ First by Mr Henare and the other members of what he yesterday called the "tight five" - the five Maori electorate MPs. (Jul 15, 1998,Dominion,1)

He no doubt realised that splitting from the party which took his so-called "tight five" into Parliament would be counterproductive, for them and for Maori. (Jul 15, 1998,Evening Post,10)

Mr Kirton said criticism of Mr Peters from the so-called "tight five" of Maori MPs - Mr Henare, Tutekawa Wyllie, Tukoroirangi Morgan, Rana Waitai and Tuariki Delamere - was understandable, but he doubted they would form a breakaway Maori party - at least not yet.Ibid. He disagreed with Mr Henare's notion of the Maori MPs being a "tight five", because although there were strong areas of common interest, there were areas where the MPs disagreed. (Jul 16, 1998,Evening Post,2)

The reluctance of the "tight five" to leave a mainstream party is much to be applauded.Ibid. The tight five have something going for them in the Maori constituencies. (Jul 16, 1998,Evening Post,4)

Mr Delamere was responding to New Zealand First sources who questioned his position in the so called "tight five" of Maori MPs, seen to be backing the deposed Mr Henare. (Jul 18, 1998,Evening Post,1)

Each of the infamous "tight five" - Maori Affairs Minister Tau Henare, Tukuroirangi Morgan, Tu Wyllie, Rana Waitai and Tuariki John Delamere - was last night despatched to political oblivion. (Nov 28, 1999,Sunday Star Times,A3)

That group included a noisy and ambitious group of Maori MPs, labelled "the tight five" and known by their trademark Dirty Dog sunglasses, any one of which probably fancied himself the next leader. (May 21, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

Maori voters were not impressed by the antics of the "tight five", especially the suglasses-flashing Mr Henare, who returned to Parliament as a National list MP on Saturday, and Tukuroirangi Morgan, notorious for his expensive wardrobe. (Sep 19, 2005,Dominion Post,A7)

To win Tauranga, [Peters] needed to shed the Maori "tight five", and take his core troops.. into opposition. (Aug 29, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

This year, more than a tight five of New Zealand-born artists are continuing to exceed our national rugby team's performance around the world. (Sep 26, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

The audit was instigated after Mr Tamihere sided with the "tight five" of disaffected members against the rest of the board... (Nov 2, 2004,Dominion Post,B7)

tight stocking¶

n. (Rural) [pasture management] running of heavy numbers of stock in one area.

NEWTON A firm believer in tight stocking, he has the welfare of his country at heart. (1975,Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,53)

tight-arse¶

adj. uptight

O'SULLIVAN ... Skull worked with the Hories / who were O.K. so long as their tight-arse worries / over land rights and such didn't throw them in flurries / (1982,Rose Ballroom, The,28)

n. a close-fisted, stingy person; a tight-wad also aj tight-arsed [ca1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream ca1946 Victoria University]

MARSHALL You know how they choose acountants,' I said.The tightest arses in the firm,' said Sully. (1984,Day Hemingway Died, The,143) [NOTES: (Sully's Country)]

tighten up¶

v. [of pastoralism] to restrict feed to stock

We never tighten up the hoggets and they get as much feed as we can give them ... (Oct 2004,Country-Wide,26/3,10 ed.)

tightie¶

n. a rugby tight forward

The tighties are replaced by the loose forwards while other players arrive for the 11am practice and take turns in physio Glen Muirhead's adjoining room. (Mar 9, 2001,Evening Post,21)

And when the ABs have the pill, some hard yards up fat man's track must be gained at scrum time the acid must go on a front row put together by band aids, and the tighties must do their job to clear out and retain the breakdown ball. (Jul 30, 2000,Sunday Star Times,B3)

tihe¶

n.

BULLER POGNORNIS CINCTA (STITCH-BIRD.) ... Native names. Ihi [omitted 1888], Hihi, Tihe, Kotihe, Kotihewera, {Tiora, and Tiheora}; male and female are someties distinguished as Hihi-paka and Hihi-matakiore or Tihe-kiore. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,98,{1888 2nd edn 1/101} ed.)

tihore¶

n. (Rural) a variety of farmed native flax, Phormium tenax. [ORIGIN: Maori, aka tihori]

The native gave pride of place to 'Tihore', a strong grower, running up to twelve feet in height and liking a moist soil. (Aug 22, 1903,Farmers' Union Advocate,1)

WAKEFIELD The species of <i>Phormium tenax</i> thus cultivated is the tihore, literally theskinning' flax. This name describes the ease with which it submits to the scraping process.' (1845,Adventure in NZ,2/286)

LINDSAY Purchas and Minnis [????] of Auckland [use the fibre] of that variety or species [of flax] known to the natives [79] as Tihori,' orTihore,' - all other forms yield a coarser fibre. (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,78)

MORRIS Maori name for a species of New Zealand flax. Name used specially in the North Island for the best variety of Phormium (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,470)

tihore n. New Zealand flax. [Maori] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,12)

But above all, samples of flax, the peculiar produce of the colony, - which we yet hope will shortly become one of its staple exports, as soon as the difficulties of preparing it in a cheap and expeditious manner are surmounted, - should be sent carefully prepared, particularly samples of the Tihori, and best kinds of flax. (Jun 22, 1850,New Zealander, The,3) [NOTES: Reprinted from the Wellington Spectator 4 May]

With the best kinds (tihore), they simply tore out the fibre, rubbed it together in their hands to open the bundles, and removed the small quantity of tissue that remained by scraping it with their nails. (Dec 2, 1889,Hawke's Bay Herald,6)

The noble bush that once yielded tawhari, tihori, kahikatia berries, nikau and fern root, is going down to be replaced with smiling paddocks of English grasses. (May 27, 1919,Thames Star,3)

CORRESPONDENCE. NEW ZEALAND FLAX. .. First and foremost is the Tihori. This is the stoutest and best kind. It is known from the others by the extra substance of its leaf, and by a red tinge on the edges. This is the sort the natives select for cultivation, as it is the easiest to clean. (Sep 14, 1844,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,109)

The Secretary stated that the subject had engaged his attention, and, during a recent visit to the Waikato, he had procured plants of the true Tihore, the Wairarekei, and other forms, which would be planted in the garden and labelled, as suggested. (May 4, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,5)

tika¶

n. right, correct [`among the neighbours was one that a Maori would have classed as not tika'. [Maori]]

From lookouts on the hills the ti trees sign / that everything is tika, everything couth; / that the circus is coming, that it will soon be gone. (Mar 16, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),59)

LEE & KENDALL T|ika, a. Straight, even. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,213)

DIEFFENBACH Tika - just, straight, even (1843,Travels in NZ,2/387)

TAYLOR He replied they had thought over my words and yielded to them because they were tika (straight). (Jun 12, 1846,Journal,4/40)

SHORTLAND Only get him to assent that your proposition is `tika' or straight, and you will soon obtain his consent to it. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,135)

MANING The whole proceeding was objectionable in every respect, and tika (correct). Ibid. 178.. Maoris seldom act against the law, and always try to be able to say what they do is `correct' - (tika). (1863,Old New Zealand,4/73)

[On the attack on the Ngati Paoa at Whakatiwai.] The object of this attack was to balance an utu' account. ... [sic] Ngati Paoa say this account had been previously squared, and the killings which happened at this attack were murders. The other side deny this and say that the balance was against them previously, but the deaths of the three men who fell wound up the account and the whole proceeding wastika'(correct). (1966,Journal of Ensign Best,421) [NOTES: 1879 J.D. Fenton Important Judgments Delivered in the Compensation Court and Native Land Court, pp. 75-80 in 1966 Best Journal (ed. Taylor) 421]

TREGEAR A High Chief's conduct had to be `straight' (tika) and justified by their ideas as to the behaviour of a great noble; ... (1904,Maori Race, The,33)

HOCKEN A High Chief's conduct had to be `straight' (tika) and justified by their ideas as to the behaviour of a great noble; ... (1906,Old New Zealand,xi) [NOTES: 1906 Hocken Biographical Sketch to ONZ xi]

GUTHRIE-SMITH ... the writer can see that he himself was in part responsible for what had occurred, that his conduct had not been tika, not been correct. (1926,Tutira,388) [NOTES: see also p. 53]

COMBS It was on the other hand tika'. ...[fn] Maori forcorrect'. (1939,Harrowed Toad) [NOTES: [ref. to Auckland country schoolchildren]]

LYON Notable among the neighbours was one that even a Maori would have classed as not tika or correct. (1952,Faring South,118)

CAMPBELL All that he did was tika, strictly correct,/ and would have raised grim smiles/ of approbation/ (1963,Sanctuary of Spirits) [NOTES: `Tamihana Te Rauparaha']

HILLIARD When your cousin dies you do not continue at your workbench, you attend the funeral rites: that is tika, that is the proper use of time, ... (1969,Green River,32)

HILLIARD Tika, she had said. That was their [sc/ Maoris'] word to justify doing what you like. Behaving according to character, she had said. Doing what you feel the urge to do. If that's the way you are, you do it. (1978,Glory and the Dream, The,191)

HULME 151. Tika = right, appropriate, correct (1983,Bone People, The,466)

"It's a tika [authentic] to be a two ticker", is the Maori Party's mantra. (May 8, 2005,Sunday Star Times,A10)

HULME It's the right size, tika size, fitting his hand. (1983,Bone People, The,151)

The natives shouted a lively chorus, interspersed with cries of "tena! tena!" or "pull away," from the steersmen, and of "ki a tika," or "keep her straight," from the others. (May 16, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

tikanga¶

n. (Maori) culture [ORIGIN: Maori] (See tikanga Maori)

They're people who have come from a very strong tikanga basis, they have been engaged with Maori people in quite a significantly different way. (Jul 23, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C14)

It is debatable whether the amount he waggles his tongue and wiggles is hips is strictly within the bounds of Maori tikanga. (Oct 17, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

I don't have a tikanga Nazi attitude. (Dec 24, 2000,Sunday Star Times,D6)

Do you know anything about tikanga? Yes, I do. You don't wear it around your neck. (Jul 2004,TV2) [NOTES: ? Shortland Street; alternatively Facelift on TV1]

The greatest reception the Governor has had from natives, the most loyal reverence for the Queen's name and `mana', the most intelligent acquaintance with the English tikanga [fn. Policy.], ... are to be found in the Ngapuhi ... (Mar 21, 1858,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/367,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (F.D. Bell)]

HOWE . This term refers to the customs, rules, habits and accepted ways of behaving in each tribal area, and as such may differ from marae to marae. Even within marae. one cannot know all the tikianga' of that tribe, since aspects of life may only be known by specialists. To find out the tikianga of each marae, one should ask connected tangata whenua or knowledgeable people of the right way to enter and speak and act on that marae. To breaknga tikanga' is to invite (polite) scorn and this means a lowering of mana'. Tikanga - seekawa'. (1985,Towards Taha Maori,23)

John Clarke is a highly respected professional who enjoys wide support from the Maori community and who has a great depth of knowledge of tikanga (things) Maori. (Dec 24, 1988,Dominion,7)

In their rough and ready way of reasoning, the two judgments were paradoxical; no amount of logic could reconcile the two contradictory tikanga. (Feb 2, 1877,Star, The,3)

Postgraduate qualifications are essential, and knowledge of te reo Maori me ona tikanga are preferred. (Nov 19, 2005,Dominion Post,H20)

KAITA RONGORUA Personal Assistant .. Key qualities for the position are: *Knowledge of teo reo Maori me ona tikanga ... (Nov 11, 2006,Dominion Post,H10)

They hadn't had much tikanga and te reo passed on to them, but these sorts of rituals were the most important for them to learn... (2003,Huia 5: Contemp. Maori Fiction,85)

...tikanga is not tapu. Tikanga is actually the customary usage or behaviours of Maori people, which, if they are to be respected, must be widely known and acknowledged. (Nov 13, 2002,Dominion Post,B9)

But a short time ago, a serious altercation arose between the Natives of Orangituapeka and Waimate, three days to the southward of this place: the inhabitants of the former Pa declaring, that they had adopted the bishop's tikanga, and refusing to allow their Missionary, the Rev. J. Skevington (who resides within two miles of the place) to visit them; at the same time using very contemptuous language towards the Natives of Waimate. (Jun 22, 1844,Daily Southern Cross,3)

Basic, simple things - swearing, attitude, personal respect, respect for our audience, respect for our listeners. These are tikanga issues. (May 25, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

Potatau sent a letter to the various tribes this morning, saying that he had not sanctioned the "tikanga reti," viz., - leasing runs to Europeans. (Jun 5, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,2)

tikanga Maori¶

phr. [ORIGIN: Maori]

The problem was, suggested Te Paa, that most of us are absolutely unwilling to challenge what we now glibly define - in the case of the 'parliamentary worriors', it has been defined for us - as 'tikanga Maori' (Maori agenda). (Mar 22, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

He ... had a `strong loyalty to tikanga maori' (Maori custom) and was more willing to accept whatever outcome a marae sitting might come up with. (May 6, 1989,Evening Post,1)

Mr Peters was not steeped in tikanga Maori but had taken with him a group of Maori who were, knowing that "cultural facets" would emerge on the trip. (Jun 12, 2006,Dominion Post,A1?)

You will need to learn more about tikanga Maori before you criticise what you do not understand. (Oct 31, 2005,Dominion Post,B6)

The perpetrators against whom he advises action are ever seeking the lost fount of "Whakairo" from which the "Tupuna" drew their knowledge, and if "Te Ramanui" has "Tikanga Maori" at heart and knows how to correct the gross misconceptions of would-be Maori carvers and designers, then let him come out on to the "Marae" and let his "great light" ("Te Remanui") so shine before all men that we may see his good works in the making and so profit thereby. (Sep 21, 1933,Evening Post,12)

Giving Wellington's cafe patrons a taste of tikanga Maori is among the goals of one of the Capital's newest coffee houses. (May 25, 2000,Contact (Wgtn),1)

Maori and Management along with the Maori and Administration programmes are designed to equip students with bi-lingual and bi-cultural management and administration skills for both tikanga Maori and tikanga Pakeha organisations. (Mar 15, 2006,Wairarapa News,13)

(4) Te Ture Whenua Maori Act / The Maori Land Act 1993 "Tikanga Maori" means Maori customary values and practices. Ibid. 35 Each person appointed under subsection (1)(b) of this section shall possess knowledge and experience of tikanga Maori. (1993,NZ Statutes,7)

I believe that tikanga Maori - or culture - will also evolve. (1993,NZ Parliamentary Debates,533/13741)

But tikanga Maori is still at the core of what Mai FM is all about. (May 25, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),30)

Two outstanding features for me were that the Kaupapa Atawhai waka is now fully launched - a sign of the department's commitment to tikanga Maori and its strength for the greater good of conservation. (Mar 1993,What's Up Doc,12 : 1)

tikanga Moriori/Maori¶

phr. knowledge of Moriori and Maori culture
