Experience of tikanga Moriori/Maori and te reo helpful. (Oct 1, 2005,Dominion Post,H17)

tikanga National¶

phr. National Party protocol

But as with many matters of pressing concern, no one is exactly sure just what Tikanga National would prescribe. (Jan 27, 2004,Dominion Post,B4)

tikati¶

n.

PHILLIPPS Jordanidia solandri (Cuv. & Val.). HAKE or SOUTHERN KINGFISH; TIKATI. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,48,1971 ed.)

GRAHAM SOUTHERN KINGFISH or HAKE (TIKATI) Rexea solandri (Cuv. and Val.) .../ This fish is known as Hake in Auckland. In New South Wales it is often caught by trawlers in one hundred and fifty fathoms and is known as King Barracouta. It is a favoured food fish. In Tasmania it is referred to as Tasmanian Kingfish. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,315,2nd ed.)

DOOGUE & MORELAND SOUTHERN KINGFISH ... Other names: Jordanidia solandri; kingfish, hake, barraconda; king barracouta, Tasmanian kingfish (Australia); tikati (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,280)

WILSON [The Southern Kingfish is] Called Hake in southern fish shops but bears no resemblance to the traditional English Hake which is far less oily. Tasmanian kingfish, barraconda and `tikati' (Maori) are other names. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,201)

Frost-fish. ... This is the para of most New Zealand Natives, and the tikati of Taranaki. (1932,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,13/232) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

Tikati, the fish that precedes the frost fish, are [sic] now fairly plentiful on the Otaki beach, and on Sunday several fine specimens were found. (May 2, 1913,Poverty Bay Herald)

2 n.

tike¶

n. [aka tyke] (See tyke)

The Marist Old Boys' teams, often called "The Tikes" on account of the grim determination they exhibited in all their games, were called together by Brother Virgilius (now of Wellington) in May, 1905, when the Auckland Secondary Schools Old Boys' Unions played matches for a banner donated by Messrs Smith and Caughey. (Jul 20, 1912,NZ Truth,3)

Tiki¶

[In Maori myth Tiki is the first man]

And in New Zealand Tiki was the creator of man. (May 10, 1851,Lyttelton Times,6)

HOW THE CHILDREN OF TIKI MIGRATED FROM THE HIDDEN LAND OF TANE. (Jun 18, 1896,Otago Witness,46)

tiki¶

v. elliptical for tiki-tour (See tiki tour n,tiki-tour v)

I loved watching travel.co hosts Petra Bagust and Dean Cornish tiki-ing about the world. (Dec 29, 2002,Sunday Star Times,D11) [NOTES: [Jo McCarroll]]

n. short for tiki tour n. q.v.; an exploratory look or visit (often as a tiki around a place)

(in the context of a story about some female university students tidying up the backyard of their flat, 20-year-old Greta File is quoted as saying: "We'll all attack it at once, and get it all done. The lawns, a couple of car-loads to the tip and a wee tiki around a garden centre to find some plants we like." (Aug 30, 2007,Star, The,3) [NOTES: citation sent in by Brent Southgate]

n. the fish, tarakihi

SORENSON TARAKIHI (a) Scientific name: Cheilodactylus macropterus. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Tarakihi. (c) Other common names: Tiki (Kaikoura); Porae (Cheilodactylus douglasi) is normally lumped with Tarakihi and is known as Morwong in Australia and also as Sea Bream. (d) Principal localities where taken: [all except far south] (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,47)

tarakihi .. [scientific name] Nemadactylus macropterus .. [other name(s)] morwong, ocean bream, teraki, tiki (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

n. . [ORIGIN: initialism, a flat carving, often in greenstone, of a grotesque figure representing the first man; short for heitiki. In English contexts used where possibly heitiki more correct, and now (at least in Australian English) for `a lucky charm worn from the neck' [get reference].]

... they had brought many Articles of Trade such as Ahoos, green Images called Tigis, Stone Adzes etc (Feb 24, 1777,Cook's Journals,3/1001) [NOTES: 1777 Feb 24 Samwell Account in Cook Journals (1967) 3/1001]

TAYLOR Their Tikis or green jade ornaments are becoming so scarce that I could not procure one without paying an exorbitant price, they are only made in the South Island where the stone is found ... (Apr 28, 1839,Journal,2/120)

ANGAS ... she was dressed in the European fashion, ... but retained the mako, or shark's teeth, in her ears, and wore suspended round her neck the tikii, or household god of green jade, which passes as an heir-loom amongst families. Ibid. 1/308 We can trace in the carvings of the New Zealanders - in their huge tikis or wakapokokos, and in their ornamental houses - a strong analogy to the architectural ornaments of the Mexicans. (1847,Savage Life,1/267)

MORRIS (1898,Austral English) [NOTES: [see Heitiki]]

LYSNAR The eyes of the tiki were filled with rings cut from the parva [sic], or mother-of-pearl, but recently this has been quite superseded by the charm of red sealing-wax. (1924,New Zealand (various authors/titles),62)

... they filled an old canoe with treasures from the pa ... greenstone implements, tikis and carvings, etc., burying it somewhere in the neighbourhood. (1930,NZ Memories,115)

BUCK (1946,Coming of the Maori, The,449-453)

tiki, flat carved greenstone image worn on a cord round the neck, particularly by women: a charm for fertility, being a rough representation of the human embryo. The name in full is heitiki, hei signifying anything worn round the neck; and the tiki being the chief object so worn the hei has been dropped. The tiki is highly valued, and genuine ones can rarely be obtained; fakes are plentiful. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/150) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

tiki: grotesque fiqure of greenstone, etc., used as neck ornament. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

I would include among New Zealand English words: tiki: special NZ carving of small ornament. It represented to the Maoris the unborn child and so good luck (May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class)

A small Maori ornament of greenstone representing a human figure and worn round the neck on a string. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),413)

SLATTER A small Maori ornament of greenstone representing a human figure and worn round the neck on a string. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,224)

tiki n -s [Maori & Marquesan] 1 usu cap : an embodiment of the male principle in Polynesian mythology often depicted as the first man or the superhuman creator of mankind 2 a : a Polynesian wood or stone image set up as a temporary abode or embodiment of a god or other supernatural power but not worshiped [sic] as an idol b : a Maori image representing an ancestor that is usu. either large and of wood or small, often in the form of a pendant, and of greenstone Auckland (New Zealand) Star) - compare hei-tiki (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2393)

No one has claimed a rare pre-European tiki found in the luggage hold of a plane, two years ago, and given to the Museum of New Zealand, Te Papa, for safekeeping. (Apr 19, 2000,Dominion,14)

KEENE heitiki (or tiki): a greenstone ornament worn suspended from the neck. (1963,O Te Raki,190)

tiki n. Maori name for the Creator, thence taken to represent an ancestor; wooden images made by Maoris to represent their ancestor; miniature greenstone neck ornaments [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

tiki ... n. as proper name, Tiki, mythological figure held in some stories as first man; greenstone ornament said to be based on shape of human embryo and once worn as fertility charm. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

JENKIN On another occasion she found a beautiful greenstone tiki, whakakai (ear pendants), and a greenstone mere. (1970,NZ Mysteries,101)

tiki n. a Maori greenstone neck ornament in the form of a foetus. [ Maori heitiki figure worn round neck] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1225) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 804; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 502]]

POLACK Around the neck, similar kinds of ornaments are worn, but the principal favourite is the Tiki. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,II : 178)

Wooden Tikis, some of immense size, usually represented the ancestors. (1889,Catalogue NZ Exhibition,81)

PHILLIPPS The body is U shaped, humanised below after the manner of a Maori tiki. (1955,Maori Carving Illustrated,12)

The beautiful and valuable greenstone from which the Maoris fashion all their..tikis. (1921,Outward Bound,46)

His Excellency (the President) with his usual kindly urbanity contributed largely to the enjoyment of the occasion by sending a great number of his rarest curiosities of Native art and manufacture, amongst which we may notice the large Tiki, presented to him by Honi Heke, and the large carved box presented to him by Rangihaeata (Oct 6, 1852,New Zealander, The,2) [NOTES: Reprinted from the Wellington Spectator 18 August]

Where possible this [greenstone] would be of sufficient size to produce not only a mere for the chief, but also a tiki for his wife. This latter, which was worn exclusively by women - was fashioned after the form of a human foetus. (Dec 1956,Te Ao Hou,17: 51)

At the dinner after the match on Saturday night his Excellency the Governor, on behalf of the New Zealand Rugby Union, presented each member of the British team with a greenstone tiki. (Aug 17, 1904,Otago Witness,59)

n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of perennial brome grass (Bromus inermis). [ORIGIN: Maori]

Tiki - winter-dormant and summer-active. Establishes best in warm spring conditions. (1995,Grasslands Range of Forage and Conservation Plants,24)

3 n. [blonde child (?)]

ANGAS Their hair is remarkably black ... Children having flaxen hair, are called `tikis', and [144] are much admired. (1866,Polynesia,143)

tiki tour¶

n. originally a tour of [part of] New Zealand; now more generally for a look around, a search [Recently heard applied to a document at meeting where a lengthy document was tabled "Could you give us a tiki tour around this".]

His latest exhibition Tiki Tour is a roundabout journey through Taupo. (Jun 12, 2002,Capital Times,15)

We have done a quick tiki tour of this small site before finally settling in the main area of the dining room, which is still quite petite. (May 9, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),16)

Jeff took a tiki tour of Upper Hutt .. and discovered many a hidden treasure. (Dec 2000,Capital Holiday Guide,4)

[Hdg] Tiki tour of the feelgood fiasco (Apr 18, 1999,Sunday Star Times,A8)

The spores were then.. photographed, developed and stuck on to the glass panes. Visitors are invited to gaze at the topography of "living" air laid over the landscape. It's not the sort of tiki tour most tourists would take, although there are some familiar places... (Dec 1, 2002,Sunday Star Times,F2)

Simon Doull's one-day "tiki tour" in the last year looks destined to end today when New Zealand meets Australia in the fifth one-day cricket international at McLean Park in Napier. (Mar 1, 2000,Dominion,48)

If it can get [their clients] to Feilding and take them on a tiki tour, they're hooked: "The Americans and the Aussies when they come over here, they're more comfortable in a rural setting." (Oct 19, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),27)

You'll not hear any bad language on this show, unless you count Jim's excruciating wordplay: "Tiki tour? This is a tuk-tuk tour!"... I'd like to have seen and heard a lot more of Mike's work, since they'd gone to all the trouble of a tuk-tuk tiki tour to his studio. (Jun 29, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),78)

McGILL tiki-tour unlicensed driving; eg `When I was 12 I had an old BSA Bantam motorbike hidden on the farm, and used to tiki-tour all round the back of Cambridge.' New Zealand Herald, 22 February 1989 .. tiki-tour a look or nosy around. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,101)

Concerned Timberlands would only take me on their "tiki-tour", as Brooker calls it, they show me sites where recent "experimental felling" has occurred. (Apr 2000,North & South,84)

This Saturday it will also become a performance space for a 15-minute tiki tour of the history of world art... (Feb 15, 2002,Dominion,18)

We were responding to a lot of calls received by the communications centre reporting a mystery glow in the hills behind us .. so off we went for a little tiki tour. (Apr 2, 2001,Evening Post,3)

These encounters begin a concatenation of events which culminate, after a chaotic Tiki tour around England, in the birth of a baby. (Jul 15, 2000,Dominion,27)

There's, likewise, a wee tiki tour of the Med in the skordalia, ratatouille and tapenade which dress the lamb flanks. (Aug 2, 2003,Independent Herald (Wellington),F7)

"There's been a few people around. Some of them just were going for rides, doing a bit of a tiki tour," she said. (Dec 26, 2002,Dominion Post,A3)

I went outside and played basketball with the house owner's kids for a while because the bus had gone on some tiki tour round the suburbs to find a place to turn around. (Aug 5, 2001,Sunday Star Times,B1)

HUGHES Later that day, I was due to pick up an Australian lieutenant colonel from the airport and was then to host him on a tiki-tour around the South Island for a week while he 'inspected his men'. (1999,Shooting from the Lip,107)

[heading] Tiki-touring tutus. The Royal New Zealand Ballet's much-loved tiki-touring institution is on the road. (Jan 10, 2005,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.nzballet.org.nz/news-media-releases.html?news_item_id=34 Accessed 24/03/06]

Since the [Dairy] board's annual meeting last month, he and board chairman Graham Fraser have been on a tiki tour of dairying regions to tell farmers how the board's performing. (Oct 26, 2000,Evening Post,4)

A tiki tour around the best - and worst - of Canterbury's burgeoning farm forestry plantings. (Jun 1996,Growing Today,1)

tiki-tehetehe¶

n.

BURTON Many types of fungus were eaten by the Maori. These were known by various names such as hawai, wairuru, tiki-tehetehe, maiheru, tawaka (a species of Agaricus) and hakeka (Himeola). (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,8)

tiki-tour¶

v. go on a tour (often tiki-tour around); tour (a place)

Thus begins a lengthy literary road trip, as Ritz tiki-tours around England. (Sep 25, 1999,Dominion,20)

He had no debilitating illness and was still tiki-touring around the country - much to the dread of some of the parishes he audited. (Oct 2001,Wel-com (Wellington),18)

In the first episode of MO' Show.. hosts Mark Williams and Otis Frizzell tiki-tour around LA, shooting guns, looking at cars, daring each other to eat jalapeno peppers and visiting a porn film. (Sep 1, 2002,Sunday Star Times,F7)

Changes to navigation rules in the Marlborough Sounds are being rushed through after a cruise liner "tiki-toured" the area without the harbourmaster's knowledge and unnerved at least one boatie. .."This pilot was tiki-touring around the bays as if he was in a 40-foot launch on one of the busiest days of the year". (Jan 13, 2006,Dominion Post,A6)

tikihemi¶

n.

TAYLOR ...the tikihemi corresponds with our trout; in shape and appearance it is much like an eel, hence it is named the eel-trout;... (1855,Te Ika a Maui,499)

Vernacular Name.- Powell [TrNZI 2/84] was the first to point out that two fish were referred to as smelt' in north Canterbury. These were <i>Galaxias attenuatus </i>and <i>Retropinna retropinna</i>. At present Canterbury residents refer to<i> R. retropinna</i> assilvery,' on account of the silver line running along the side of the half-grown fish. Maoris refer to this silvery' astikihemi,' and to the adult as `paraki.' (1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/291) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

PHILLIPPS In some other localities these young [smelt, Retropinna] are called tuarenga. The half-grown fish is termed tikihemi and the adult paraki. Certain races of fish have a broad silvery band running along the side; hence the term `silvery.' It is to be regretted that in Canterbury the term smelt is still used to apply to the minnow, Galaxias attenuatus. (1940,Fishes NZ,54)

tikkitak¶

n. white-fronted tern, Sterna striata

FALLA et al. WHITE-FRONTED TERN Sterna striata Other names: Sea-swallow, Kahawai Bird, Tara, Blackcap, Grenadier, Swallowtail, Noddy (Chathams), Tikkitak (Stewart Is.) (1966,Birds of New Zealand,164)

tiko¶

n. shit, excrement [ORIGIN: Maori, cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 259.]

"You are the most ugliest, nastiest piece of tiko around ..." (Oct 18, 2006,Wairarapa News,24)

tikumu¶

n. (Rural) a Celmisia spp cotton plant [used by early rural travellers to make leggings for protection against matagouri and Spaniard spikes.] [ORIGIN: Maori]

KERR All these travellers found the going hard, the rough tussock and fern and matagouri and spaniard tearing their clothing and spiking their legs in spite of leggings made of the stripped leaves of tikumu, the cotton plant. (1976,From the Beginning: chronicles of a county,44)

HOOKER Tikumu, Col[enso]. Celmisia coriacea. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Sometimes the snow-white downy fibres from the under side of the leaves of the Kowharawhara, and the Kahakaha, (Astelia Cunninghamii, and Solandri,) and the thin transparent epidermis from the leaves of the mountain Tikumu (Celmisia coriacea), were also used ... to ornament ... the head. (1869,TrNZI,1/iii/37) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

Tikumu, or Cotton plant Celmisia Coriacea, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/44) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

BEATTIE Tikumu, the mountain celmisia, is also mentioned [in the c1880 lists]. The white fibrous down was scraped from its under side and manufactured in taupa (leggings). (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,65) [NOTES: c1880 South Island Maori Lists `Wahi Mahika Kai' in 1945 Beattie Maori Place-names of Canterbury 65]

tikumu, an alpine plant (Celmisia spectabilis, C. coriaceae). (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

BROOKER et al. Celmisia coriacea (Forst.f.) Hook.f. and allied spp. Common names: Cotton plant, horse daisy Maori name: Tikumu ... [W.Lauder Lindsay 1861 applied `cotton plant' to the more familiar sp. of Celmisia] (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,41)

Reverting to the right-hand lower corner there is a plaque representing miners at work, surrounded by New Zealand mountain lilies (ranunculus lyalii), tikumu (mountain daisies), celmisia longifolia (Dec 10, 1889,Otago Daily Times,6)

It is owing to the thick coating of woolly hairs found on the flower-stalks and under the leaves that the name "cotton plant" is given to it. By the Maoris it was named Tikumu, which it is thought that they gave to all large-flowered celmisias. (Jul 1, 1908,Otago Witness,82)

Passing round a spur in the gully I came on a large patch of ground completely covered with the tikumu (Celmisia coriacea). (Mar 13, 1875,Otago Witness,7)

tile-drain¶

1 v. (Rural) to drain low-lying land with field tiles.

TAIT The flat to easy rolling country has been extensively plug-drained and tile-drained. [verb ] (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,96)

tilefish¶

n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] TILEFISH 1333 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography,1333)

tilly¶

n. a swag

After 8 hours with Tilly up, our destination loomed up at last. (Feb 24, 1906,NZ Truth,36/5/1)

tilt¶

n. the canopy of a covered wagon

MASTERS I took my primitive dray, now made like a large basket, with bows and a tilt over it. (1871,Autobiography,45)

BEATTIE In 1867 there were many wagons on the road bearing huge freights from Dunedin to the diggings, but Thomson still adhered to his faithful dray with its tilt over it, and drawn by three horses, one shafter and two leaders. (1956,Pioneer Recollections,2) [NOTES: 1947-1948 Beattie Pioneer Recollections (1956) 2]

HENDERSON [Caption to picture of 4-wheeled wagon covered by canvas cover on rounded hoops, and 6-horse team, c1900] A `schooner'. ... This is a typical colonial type schooner. Note the five-inch wide iron tyres, and the storm lantern swinging under the hooded canopy, or tilt, as it was called. (1961,Friends in Chains,[facing 161])

HENDERSON TILT: Thickly oiled canvas forming hooped cover on four-wheeled vehicles. (1961,Friends in Chains,189) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 189]

tilter¶

n. (Rural) a harvesting machine. (See also back delivery)

STUDHOLME It took a lot of men to work the old back-delivery machines or 'tilters' which looked rather like grass-mowers. (1940,Te Waimate,174)

EVANS Following the scythe as a means of cutting oats and wheat, and preceding the reaper and binder, the tilter filled in the gap as a reaping machine. It consisted of a set of fingers and a knife similar to a modern mower or harvester. (1975,Silver Tussock, The,133)

EVANS The crops were cut with a tilter .. As a schoolboy Benjamin Evans drove the tilter for his father. (1975,Silver Tussock, The,229)

MARTIN The 'tilter' - also known as the back-delivery because it dropped the sheaves from the back of a ilting hinged platform - was drawn by two horses and was first used in the early 1860s. (1990,Forgotten Worker, The,123)

STUDHOLME When cutting crop with the old tilters (back deliveries) ... [161] The old back-delivery [harvesting] machines or `tilters', which looked rather like grass-mowers. (1940,Te Waimate,157)

IMPLEMENTS, ETC. .. McCormick Clover Tilter, McCormick Hayrack (May 8, 1920,Ashburton Guardian,8)

WANTED. - A good TILTER, for a Reaping Machine. (Jan 25, 1870,North Otago Times,3)

Reid and Gray's Tilter. (Oct 11, 1875,Timaru Herald,2)

TENDERS WANTED for TYING, STOOKING and STACKING 233 Acres of Wheat and Oats, near the Cave. To be cut with two Tilters. Tilters, Horses, Drays, and two Stackers found. (Jan 23, 1884,Timaru Herald,1)

McCormick mowing machine, rake and tilter. (Jan 15, 1908,Hawera & Normanby Star,8)

Disc and chain harrows, s.f. plow, mower and tilter, hayrake, milk cart, 2 cattle dogs. (Jul 23, 1910,Hawera & Normanby Star,8)

Our land is hilly, and before we bought the Buckeye we had only tilters in use. (Nov 13, 1890,Otago Witness,14)

Timarooster¶

n. an occas humorous nickname for a person from Timaru, a TIMARUVIAN [1951 Nov (R. Mason) `Heard in train; used by Taranaki person, and not heard used in Timaru itself.']

Timaru Blacksmith, the¶

phr. world heavyweight boxing champion (1897-1899), Bob Fitzsimmons

"I assume that March 17 will henceforth be a public holiday throughout New Zealand, not to honour a saint, but to keep alive the day when Bob Fitzsimmons, the Timaru Blacklsmith, became champion pugilist of the world." (Mar 15, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),59)

Timarusian¶

n.

A thirsty Timarusian, fined for entering a pub on Sunday, that he hadn't had a drink, and had only been in the place 30 seconds. (Oct 20, 1906,NZ Truth,70/1/3)

Timaruvian¶

n. one born, or residing in, Timaru

The brigade, however, seemed to have some inspiration or other which its own brains and tongues did not supply, but as their "distinguished organ," to quote Mr Williams' sarcastic phrase, seldom meets the eye of any but a Timaruvian, their dogged obstinacy in retrogade policy was perplexing to the public. (Jun 18, 1875,Timaru Herald,4)

Timaruvians (Oct 28, 1905,NZ Truth,19/6/3)

MITCHELL To be a Timaruvian means as much as to be a New Zealander. (1972,Half-Gallon Quarter-Acre Pavlova Paradise, The,34)

LAWRY (No Lawry and no Timaruvian can tell me who won that contest, so it could ... not have been the Timaru Garrison Band!) [itals sic] (1980,Good Luck & Lavender,50)

The Timaruvians are not timorous. (Sep 20, 1924,NZ Truth,14)

Thousands of New Zealanders, like the Timaruvian, now pin their faith to this sterling remedy. (Nov 15, 1930,Evening Post,26)

We have just as ardent a desire to see a cable laid between Australia and New Zealand as any Timaruvian breathing, and shall hail with delight the day on which the work is begun (which day we believe is not far distant), but we certainly do object in the strongest manner possible to the way in which the railway is spoken of. (Feb 23, 1875,Colonist (Nelson),3)

MCKAY Loud are the shouts that the far echoes fill, / As the brave Timaruvians answer "We will! " (1889,Spirit of Rangatira,32)

We've quite a number of Timaruvians here. (Oct 16, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/4 : 83)

Timaruvians rise and bite like trout. (Nov 15, 1916,Century of Sail,I/6 : 134)

The song "Good Night to Thee" has a special interest to Timaru people, in the fact that it was written for Miss Stirling in Melbourne by a Timaruvian, Mr H. J. Bilton, son of Mr Bilton, the well known musician here. (Jan 10, 1894,Timaru Herald,3)

Timaru, he had been told, was the most boring place in New Zealand. Who told him that? "A Christchurch girl working in London as a nanny." No doubt a few Timaruvians will want to have a word with that nanny. (Nov 20, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

timata¶

n. starting time [ORIGIN: Maori]

AGM on Sunday, Nov 20, 2005 For all trustees, whanau members Timata 11am (Nov 18, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,45)

timber¶

n. pieces of woody stem or hard stalk in cut cigarette tobacco (CC Ransom: also tealeaves found in tea) [ca1935 Havelock ca1951 Wellington]

n. deer antlers

These antlers had four points and were well developed, carrying good solid timber. (May 10, 1921,Quick March,13)

SUTHERLAND The top tines were badly finished and without much symmetry. The timber was light in weight for all its size pointing to an abnormal amount of pith at the heart and the stag was past his best by several years and going back. (1953,Golden Bush, The,171,1963 ed.)

HOLDEN He avoided stepping in the cast antler of a red stag, but noted from habit the number of the points - five well-shaped ones, good timber, a decent length. (1984,Razorback,13)

timber drive¶

n. (See drive)

BAINES (1874,Edward Crewe)

timber line¶

n. the highest limit of (timber-)tree growth (cf. bush-, snow-, etc. line) [aka timber-line; ca1900 at least ca1952 Busdriver, Routeburn, Otago `The timber-line as you North Islanders call it - the snow-line as we call it down here.']

ODELL Probably the best camping site is on the edge of the timber line, for the bush stops abruptly to give place to tussock and snow grass. (1935,Handbook Arthur Pass National Park,23)

MOORE & IRWIN NOTHOFAGUS MENZIESII, silver beech. A hardy tree, growing from sea level to timber line and often forming pure forests, especially in Nelson and Southland. ...Some stems become malformed through infestations of mistletoe, Elytranthe colensoi, and it is the only known host for our three species of Cyttaria, strawberry fungi which cause large galls. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,80)

Mr. D. R. Hoggard, president of the Wellington branch of the Forestry League, said that in the Wellington Conservation Region, which took in practically half of the North Island, the percentage of the total area occupied by permanent State forests was only 5.4, and of that over half was above the timber line. (Mar 19, 1924,Evening Post,6)

Although thar and chamois kept to the country above the timber line, rarely, if ever, descending into the bush, they were just as much of a menace as the deer, because erosion started on the heights when the vegetation was removed could start a train of erosion extending far down. (Sep 11, 1945,Evening Post,6)

This is an enormous area of mountains which rear their summits about 2000 feet above the timber line. (Aug 10, 1895,Evening Post,4)

The timber line in Otago is fixed at 3200ft above sea level, and it is here where the shelter hut is now building. (Mar 1, 1900,Otago Witness,63)

Most of the way up, until the timber line, young birches, veronicas, and ferns afforded very good handhold. (Feb 25, 1887,Otago Witness,15)

timber rearing¶

n. [(mining)]

McARA Timber rearing: Usually a wall at the end of a stope partitioning off the ladderway and consisting of 5 ft slabs nailed vertically to stulls wedged between the walls. Also used to make the central `box' in a three-compartment rise. Sometimes cribbing was used instead of building a rearing. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),335)

timber station¶

n. (obsolete)

SELWYN Capt. Lewington's Timber Station. (1843,Journal,22)

(1846,McLean Papers,3/227)

WANTED, a PARTNER, to take an active interest in an established Timber Station. (May 2, 1862,Daily Southern Cross,1)

SAWMILL and Timber Station in WANGAROA HARBOUR, convenient for ALL PORTS, with 17ft water at wharf. (Feb 9, 1875,Daily Southern Cross,2)

Sawmill and Export Timber Station: Manganui. (Mar 19, 1885,Hawera & Normanby Star,4)

The Auckland Knights of Labor having represented to the Kauri Timber Company that their men have to work different hours in different localities, have to submit to the truck system, and to a charge of commission on pay cheques, with other grievances, the directors expressed great surprise and authorised the deputation to wire to all timber stations that the men were absolutely free to purchase stores wherever they pleased. (Jul 19, 1890,Wanganui Herald,2)

He had been to every timber station in the province, and could hit off to a nicety the leading features in the character of every contractor or boss between Tairua and Mangonui. (Dec 1, 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,177)

timber-bush¶

n.

As regards the timber-bushes and the forest of the North Island generally, the case ... is hopeless. (1893,TrNZI,25/439)

timber-drag¶

n.

The Colonist's attention should be directed to the following articles, with which he must provide himself according to his means and his intentions. For clearing and cultivating timbered land:- ... Waggons, bullock-drays, and timber-drags. ... (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,447)

timber-getter¶

n. [also timber-getting]

timber-jack¶

n. [aka timber jack]

On country too steep for bullocks the bushmen themselves moved the logs with tools called 'timber jacks' that they cranked by hand. (Apr 2003,NZ Memories,No. 41/50)

BAINES The principal tools required [by the kauri bushman] were Yankee axes, cross-cut saws, and timber (not screw) jacks. Ibid. 173 (Northland) Timer jacks [are] better than scew -jacks ... The timber-jacks consist of a toothed spear, two pinions, a cogged wheel, all of wrought iron, and properly arranged in a strong piece of wood. A double handle puts in motion the gear, and the spear can be ground out about two feet with power, one man being able to lift at the handle a ton easily. (1874,Edward Crewe,171)

Flotation is the method most commonly used in the kauri districts ... After the trunks are cut into lengths a `rolling-road' is formed to the nearest creek. All the scrub is closely cut down for a width of from twenty-five to thirty feet ... to obtain an approximately even surface, inclined towards the creek. The logs are forced along this road by timber-jacks, which the bushmen use with remarkable skill, and are impelled with a rapidity which is simply astonishing to persons unused to the process. If the creek contains plenty of water the logs float to the nearest booms without further trouble ... (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,131) [NOTES: (T. Kirk)]

KIRK The [kauri] logs are propelled along these roads by `timber-jacks' until they reach the water. (1889,Forest Flora,150)

BARL;OW ... timber jack. (1889,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,112)

BODELL This man had taken my 2 timber Jacks and cooking Utensils from the Mill ... (1890,Soldier's View of Empire, A,211,1982 ed.)

HENDERSON TIMBER JACK: See Screwjack. (1961,Friends in Chains,189) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 189]

MALFROY [caption] TIMBER-JACK MADE IN NEW ZEALAND ... This is a ... well-tried-out jack which is extensively used in logging operations from North Cape to the Bluff (1923,Small Sawmills,21)

MOORE The bushmen that did this work were a tough capable lot - a race apart - whom no difficulty could deter, and who performed amazing feats with a few quite primitive tools. These were axes, maul, and wedges, crosscut saws, mattocks for earth work, pinching bars or crowbars, and the versatile New Zealand-made timber jack. These jacks weighed about 80 pounds and by geared cogs multiplied the man power applied to the revolving handles so that the `spear' with its two chisel points, when applied to a log, could exert a lifting pressure of 5 tons. (1969,From Forest to Farm,38)

We may also mention that Mr. Masefield has on hand a quantity of saw-mill machinery, timber-jacks, &c. (Mar 24, 1869,Daily Southern Cross,4)

Re the timber-jack: To the best of my knowledge this wonderful instrument of the bushman is solely a New Zealand tool made in the sixties of the last century by that well-known firm of engineers, A. and G. Price, Ltd., of Thames, and later still by Messrs. Judd Bros., also of Thames, for the use of the sawmillers in the Coromandel and North Auckland kauri forests. (Aug 14, 1941,Evening Post,8)

Receiving no reply to their knocks, they forced open four doors with a timber-jack before gaining entrance to the lower part of the building. (Sep 20, 1933,Evening Post,11)

Everything in the shape of staging planks, chains and ropes, crowbars, timber jacks, and other gear is thrown overboard and there is considerable delay and expense in replacing these work tools. (Mar 25, 1914,Grey River Argus,5)

HAWKE & SCOTT First timber jacks were used [sc. for stumping] and later a Trewella stumping machine which had a thirteen ton pull on it (1985,Early Farm Machinery in NZ,129)

Two ploughs, 2 drays, 1 spring dray .. 4 tons chaff, road scoop, timber jack .. also household furniture of every description too numerous to particularise. (May 26, 1908,Grey River Argus,3)

Everything in the shape of staging planks, chains and ropes, crowbars, timber jacks, and other gear is thrown overboard and there is considerable delay and expense in replacing these work tools. (Mar 25, 1914,Grey River Argus,5)

timber-jacking¶

n.

Booreedy Jack was a specimen of the old-time bushman ... kauri-cutting, timber-jacking, pit-sawing, rafting and mill-work, etc. - ... [178] ... he acquired the soubriquet of `Booreedy' (settlers' name for puriri), which stuck to him ... (Dec 1904,NZ Illustrated Magazine,177)

timber-licence¶

n.

timber-wheel¶

n.

In portions of the Taranaki District, where milling timber is somewhat sparse, timber-wheels are commonly used; ... (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,332) [NOTES: (T. Kirk)]

timber-worker¶

n. [get cits from Awards]

timber-worrier¶

n.

Frederick William Tapling, a youthful Linwood carpenter, was prepared last week to take the leap into eternity with a nice-looking girl of his acquaintance ... Tapling is a dark-complexioned timber-worrier of highly-strung disposition, ... (Apr 9, 1910,NZ Truth,250/5/3)

timberbelt¶

1 n. (Rural) a long and narrow plantation of trees grown for both timber and shelter.

WHITE & HODGSON Timberbelt is a term coined in New Zealand to describe a belt of trees designed to emphasise the production of timber; they may also have some sheltering function. Utilisation of timberbelts is not yet widespread but they are increasingly evident in regions where they are being promoted (eg Wairarapa and Canterbury.) (1999,NZ Pasture and Crop Science,275)

WHITE & HODGSON Shelter belts and timberbelts should be removed before they become over-mature. (1999,NZ Pasture and Crop Science,276)

timberman¶

n.

PEARSON TIMBER-MAN n-->1963 Pearson Coal Flat 28 There was soon a crowd of miners, truckers and timber-men. (1963,Coal Flat,28)

McARA Timberman: A man specially skilled in the repair and installation of mine timbers. (1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),335)

The Star's Otira correspondent telegraphs that Frank Brosnan, a timber man, employed in the tunnel at Otira, was killed this morning. (Jun 1, 1910,Evening Post,8)

All the underground men received an advance of 2/- a day; timbermen, blacksmiths, engine drivers 2/-; surface and battery employees 1/6. (Feb 19, 1920,Grey River Argus,4)

Two shifts of men are employed, besides the timberman, and the tunnel, which is 6ft high in the clear, is being securely timbered as it advances. (Sep 23, 1889,Evening Post,2)

The Contractors will Provide dynamite, fuse, candles, and caps. They will also be required to assist the timberman in putting in all sets. (Feb 8, 1894,Otago Witness,25)

At the time of the accident Love was timberman, and Elie was watching the supports. (Feb 26, 1907,Evening Post,2)

time-giver¶

n.

ANDERSON The energy of the paddling - the rhythm of it! The time-giver stood on the thwarts, a feather-tufted tewha tewha in his extended hand; ... the time-giver sang his song ... (1930,NZ Short Stories,30)

time-poverty¶

n.

Lazy as snakes and pleading time-poverty, our virtuous intentions come to nought but a daily stroll to the letter box or pulling a few weeds on the way to the car. (Feb 2005,North & South,116)

Timms trap¶

n. (Rural) [orig. trade name] a box trap used to catch and kill possums, ferrets, rats, and other vermin.

Have you got a problem with opssums? The Timms trap is the easiest and most effective solution. (Apr 1996,Growing Today,16)

After requests from residents it has spread into other areas in the Hutt Valley, including Parkway, where local residents are provided with Timms traps for catching and killing the animals. (Jul 5, 2001,Contact (Wgtn),1)

timori¶

n. a decoy bird

TREGEAR The parrot (kaka ...) was taken in one way ... by the noosed perch (tutu[us-macrons]) but with the assistance of a decoy bird (timori) a tame kaka. (1904,Maori Race, The,174)

timothy block¶

1 n. (Rural) a large land area that is pastured with timothy grass.

NEWTON The timothy block in particular illustrated the over-abundance of summer country on Mangaohane ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,142)

timothy tree¶

n. a `tree' made from the stems and heads of timothy grass

BROWN I wonder do country kiddies still bunch Timothy heads to form tops like a miniature pine tree; still wind the furry heads round the stem of the trunk', adding branches according to the none too plentiful supply, as a rule, to be gleaned. ... The littleTimothy Tree' being hidden ... . (1933,Farmer's Wife, The,117)

timuka¶

n.

(Jun 28, 1851,Lyttelton Times,7) [NOTES: There are two plants, the karo (prickly thorn) and taramea (spear grass), which are well worthy of their names, but are almost exclusively confined to the hilly regions. There generally grows near these a plant called the timuka, from the leaf of which the natives make mats and leggings, which are impervious to the sharp points of the former.]

tin¶

n. luckiness [1984 16 F E21 Pakuranga Coll. 32 TIN [F3 M2] -->1984 14 F E123 Wgton Girls C. 32 TIN [3]] (See cf. tinny adj)

n. sc loaf (cf double tin, raised tin, split tin)

BYCROFT LTD Double or Raised Tin (1934,Bread Baking in NZ)

n. tinned iron

tin ... 5. N.Z. & Austral. galvanized iron: a tin roof. ... 8. N.Z. a receptacle for home-baked biscuits, etc. (esp. in to fill her tins to bake a supply of biscuits, etc.) (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1227) [NOTES: [nf. 1986 NZPOD; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 503]]

The man ... / Grates words at his companion in the train / In tones like rain on tin; (1964,Book of New Zealand, A (J.C. Reid),319) [NOTES: Louis Johnson `Suburban Train']

tin billy¶

n. (See cf. billy-tin)

BAINES [in quots: colloc. tin] The tin billy' had been slung over a roaring fire, and the tea made; I was using the pannikin - ... while my companion drank his tea from out thebilly's' lid ... (1874,Edward Crewe,142)

DOBSON Boiling was done in light tin billies. (1930,Reminiscences,156)

WILY & MAUNSELL He made long and wearisome journeys ... into the heart of the Urewera country, taking a bag of biscuits, tin billy and tea; ... (1938,Robert Maunsell,179)

HILLIARD Netta bought a shiny tin billy without any clear idea of what she would do with it. (1960,Maori Girl,221)

tin can¶

adj. . [ref to tin-canning; tin can army, tin can party. aka tincan, tin-can]

WEBB He ... recalled how he had himself described a man as `a stingy blackguard' who only offered the tin-can party ... twenty-five shillings to be spent in beer. (1925,Miss Peters' Special,62)

And is it true that W.G. is going to bring home a mistress for the little cottage, and that L.M. is quite delighted with her costume of grey, also that the officers and men of tin-can army are ordered out in honour of the happy pair? (Aug 19, 1893,Observer (Auckland),21)

not milk made, just testing (1900,'Milkmade' Cook Book,5) [NOTES: Year is incorrect]

There will be a job for the tin-can army in the good time coming. (Sep 9, 1893,NZ Observer,22)

tin canoe¶

n.

GEE So I talked about Charlie: the playground fight, the orchard raiding, the tin canoes. (1972,In My Father's Den,130)

tin cat¶

n. (tinned) fish (See tin dog)

tin cow¶

1 n. (Rural) [mustering and shepherding] canned milk.

LOUGHNAN tin cow: canned milk, usually condensed. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,85)

tin dish¶

n.

The only tools we took with us were, a spade, tin dish, and pannikin. We tried a number of places along the bed of the creek, sinking in each from two to four feet; out of the whole we washed not more that six buckets full, ... (Jun 29, 1861,Otago Witness,5)

We bought a little flour, and borrowed a tin dish from one of the stations in the Manuherikia Valley, and panned out forty ounces [of gold] in about a week. [of gold inserted by JM -OK???] (Aug 23, 1862,Otago Witness,7)

Took a spade and tin dish with us to look for gold, made a pit 6ft. deep and 4 by 3 keenly gossen. (May 29, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,40,1950 ed.)

HODDER ... a group of women were round the pool washing the `tailings' in tin dishes. (1862,Memories of NZ Life,166)

BARRINGTON ... I saw the swag, and picked it up with the loss of two tin dishes, one long-handled shovel ... (Dec 22, 1863,Diary of a West Coast Prospecting Party,393)

In one day they obtained 2oz. of rough gold with a shovel and tin-dish, and immediately reported the circumstance to the Warden at Dunstan. (1887,Handbook NZ Mines,8) [NOTES: 1863 V. Pyke's Report in 1887 Handbook NZ Mines 8]

A new rush has taken place over the saddle, six or eight miles from the township, which is turning out well, an ounce being washed out there in a day with a tin dish. (Mar 14, 1865,Lyttelton Times) [NOTES: 1865 Mar 14 Lyttelton Times in 1966 Turner English Language 151]

PYKE Borrowing a pan (Anglice : tin-dish) from some neighbourly miners, he progressed up the Gorge trying prospects' in many places, and at length he was satisfied topeg out'. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,1/iv/17,(1889,1974) ed.)

PFAFF ... some few of them had done a little desultory gold getting with shovel and tin dish ... one of whom ... had in his possession in 1862 a fine sample of coarse gold obtained ... up the Kapiti Creek ... (1914,Diggers' Story, The,94)

BEATTIE The shops supplied ... mostly diggers, and all I saw of their goods were tin dishes and diggers' tools hanging outside. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,166)

HISLOP ... all we got for our trouble with the tin dish were a few colours and black sand, which is always an indication that you are in gold-bearing wash. Ibid. 115 So there [in a grave] the good old chap lies besides the remains of his unknown miner of the 1865 tin dish and cradle days. (1943,Pure Gold,69)

BUTLER We did not wash any of the gravel, for we had no tin dish, neither did we know how to wash. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,iv/56) [NOTES: 1860 Mar 24 in 1863 Butler First Year iv/56]

A tailor named McKenzie got 43 ounces in one day, worth GBP3 17s 6d per ounce, with a tin dish on a bar in the Slate River. (Sep 17, 1906,Ohinemuri Gazette,2)

In 1862 two miners suffering terrible hardships made their famous gold discovery in the Molyneux River below the junction of the Kawarau and Clutha Rivers, where the town of Cromwell now stands, and after several months of scratching around the crevices and river-bed beaches with pick, shovel, tin dish and cradle, returned to Dunedin with 87lb. weight of gold; these two men were Messrs. Hartly and Riley. (Jun 9, 1927,NZ Truth,14)

I washed an ounce and a-half of alluvial gold from a tin dish of dirt, 40 miles farther south than where I sank the first shaft, but on a continuation of the same leading range. (Dec 22, 1871,North Otago Times,4)

Mr Evenden of Te Aroha has invented a machine for saving fine gold based upon the principal [sic] of the miners' tin dish. (Mar 28, 1889,Grey River Argus,2)

tin dog¶

n. a motor toboggan

In recent years the "tin dog" or motor toboggan has become the main mode of transport [sc. in the Antarctic]. (Feb 1992,North & South,23)

n. [stones in tin to rattle behind herd of sheep in absence of a dog]

BARRY DOYLE "... when we got home from school we would get a tin dog and drive the sheep to wherever dad said." What is a "tin dog" I asked. "Motorists, he replied carried petrol in 4 gallon cans in the boot of their car and when they were empty they would throw them in the ditch by the roadside. We would find one, put a fistful of gravel in it and drive the sheep. They were called 'tin dogs'". (Jun 25, 2003,Personal Communication) [NOTES: original from Ewan McGregor of Hawkes Bay ewan-mac@xtra.co.nz]

1 n. (Rural) a rattle made of tin lids and wire [ used to move sheep when a dog is not available or appropriate.]

PETER tin dog: rattle made of tin lids. (2000,Peter Glossary,5)

tin dog - a rattle made of tin lids and wire, used to drive sheep. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

tin down¶

v. (Rural) to can (meat)

The Patea works are tinning down more beef than mutton of late. (May 7, 1885,Hawera Star,2)

tin hare¶

n. nickname for a railcar

Passenger services to Masterton, with the new route, eventually used new articulated railcars whereas those over the old route had used smaller railcars, nicknamed "tin hares". (Feb 23, 2002,Evening Post,28)

LEITCH The Wairarapa cars.. were designed to negotiate the Rimutaka Incline under their own power... Of special lightweight construction, these forty-nine-seaters, which sooner earned the affectionate name of the 'tin hares', proved to be fast and reliable machines. (1972,Railways of NZ,194)

Tin Hat¶

n.

Tin Hat.' -Thicknut' asks: Can anyone tell me why the Heads' are calledTinhats'? Are they any relation to the beings known in mythology as tin gods'? [The termsTin Hat' and Brass Hat' were current years before the war began, especiallyTin Hat.' Probably the expression had its origin in the metallic headgear worn by some of the military units in pre-war days. There is no evidence (at least no etymological evidence) that tin-hat' is a corruption oftin-head,' as one cynic has suggested.] (Nov 1, 1918,Quick March,15)

tin loaf¶

n. a square 2lb loaf, baked in a covered tin

MANSFIELD Digression no 2 - I had to leave this letter - go into the kitchen & cut myself an entire round of bread and bloater paste - tin loaf - (Jun 19, 1908,Letters,1/50,1984 ed.)

tin mill¶

1 n. (Rural) a small tractor-led metal threshing mill [widely used on individual farms and requiring seven or eight men to operate.]

LOUGHNAN tin mill: see combine. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,85)

GORDON His main source of income, the cocksfoot seed, is harvested in the old way, in sheaves, with a binder and an old tin mill. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,1)

GORDON The direct descendant of the tin mill is the combine harvester, or header, of today, the only real difference between the two being that the mill lacks an engine, cutter bar and self-motivation. Jim's got four tin mills but uses only two, one on each farm. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,10)

OGILVIE Next to the header harvester, the tin' mill did the mill [sc. threshing] men most disservice. This smaller style of mill came in with the tractor by which it was drawn and driven. Thetin' mill only needed seven or eight men to operate it, and its output was no more than half that of the big' mill. But within a short time these small mills became so popular that many farmers bought their own and could thresh their grain exactly when it suited them and their crops. Thetin' mill and the `Sunshine' header thus put an effective end to the era of the mill men [in South Canterbury]. (1971,Moonshine County,158)

NEAVE Then the tin mill and tractor came in, ... and [threshing] work was reduced to a few days only. (1980,Land of Munros, The,90)

The tin mill is smaller, slower but more portable [sc. than the threshing mill]. (1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),2(7) : 10)

tin rattle¶

1 n. (Rural) a rattle made of tin lids [used to move sheep when a dog is not available or appropriate.]

MILLS ET AL It is not unusual to see the tin rattles strung at strategic points along the crush pen with individual cords running from these to within easy reach of the drafting gates. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,76)

MILLS ET AL A makeshift tin rattle is good but only if expertly used. (1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,80)

tin roof¶

n.

The red tin roofs topping the weather board walls, the one straight street running between, and the few shops, did not seem to have acquired either roots or character. (May 26, 1955,Dominion,9)

tin rush¶

n.

HOWARD Such is the tale of the beginnings of the [Stewart Island] tin rush', pieced together from the reminiscences of variouseighty-niners', who ... were not members of the original party of discoverers. (1940,Rakiura,296)

Tin Shack¶

n.

HENDERSON Hilary and I took her away in the afternoon to inspect the Tin Shack, the unlovely corrugated iron cube, which served her as a school for four years. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,106)

tin shed¶

n.

"Look... it's a tin shed. We're not glitzy, but we don't try to hide our uniqueness." (Nov 2001,AA Directions,Summer 50 : 15)

After sun-down seven pilgrims reached the tin shed that marked the end of their journey. (Jan 12, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,28)

Tin Shed¶

n.

The 'old tin shed,' as the building is irreverently called by the students, was thronged with people throughout the evening, who passed through from room to room, inspecting the assaying plant and all the interesting geological and mining exhibits for which the school is noted. (Jun 5, 1901,Otago Witness,54)

OTAGO SCHOOL OF MINES. .. In 1891 a separate building was erected, the material being supplied from the exhibition of 1889-90. At the same time the staff was increased, separate lecturers on metallurgy and geology being appointed. .. This, Mr Given explained, was a very brief and crude history of the Otago institution, or, as it was familiarly called, "The Tin Shed." (Dec 26, 1906,Otago Witness,26)

At any rate, the absolute banality of a common "tin shed" does not hinder the students of the Otago School of Mines from feeling and expressing this sentiment. (Jul 8, 1908,Otago Witness,29)

n. nickname for the Wellington Fever Hospital at Newtown

HYDE When they [the Newtown slum family] took the scarlet fever in a batch, and were sent off in the ambulance to be isolated at the Tin Shed - the fever hospital - Augusta sent them custards ... (1938,Godwits Fly, The,26,1970 ed.)

Her first charge was the building frankly known as "the tin shed," in which diptheria [sic] patients were housed. (Oct 11, 1928,NZ Truth,6)

In 1939 a 50-bed "emergency" ward was erected, displacing a block of wards, known as the "tin shed," which had previously catered for infectious disease cases. (Dec 10, 1940,Evening Post,8)

The isolation ward, termed the "tin shed," was a properly-constructed and lined ward. (Aug 6, 1915,Evening Post,8)

Tin Town¶

n. part of Brockenhurst (NZ No 1) Hospital in England in WWI

Sister Anderson, of No. 1 N.Z. General Hospital (Tin Town), on Wednesday, 13th, took up the duties of matron here, and is well liked. Ibid. 66 Brockenhurst Hospital is divided into four sections - headquarters, a collection of huts usually known as "Tin Town," and two large hotels and a hall converted. Balmer Lawn and Morant sections I visited that afternoon. (Sep 29, 1916,NZEF Chronicles,60)

In January 1916, eighty-seven years ago, the tented and galvanised iron hospital complex, known locally as 'Tin Town' was taken over by No. 1 New Zealand General Hospital. Over 21,000 New Zealand casualties were treated there, including the 93 who died. (Apr 2004,NZ Memories,No. 47/16)

tin worm¶

n. rust

They [sc. British cars]were invariably slow, handled like corners didn't exist, dribbled oil, were prone to tin worm, required constant maintenance and would likely kill, you if you crashed into something. (Aug 4, 2001,Evening Post,27)

tin-arse¶

n. a lucky person [1984 16-17 M E90 Pakuranga Coll. 32 TIN(-)ARSE [luckiness] [M13 F4]]

BEATON KATE: Good ol' Ginny [for escaping the consequences]! SANDY: Yeah! KATE: Tin arse! Ibid. Glossary 110 lucky; a lucky person (used ironically). (1984,Outside In,20)

McGILL tin arse lucky person; also tinbum; eg `First time he's ever swung a golf club and he scores a hole in one. What a tin arse!' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,113)

tin-arsed¶

adj. (informal) 1. (non-derogatory, with perhaps often edge of jealousy, or of jealous non-acceptance) lucky. 2. (derogatory)= tinpot, tinny, cheap in appearance or structure [ca1940 Havelock You don't call that tin-arsed thing a fort, do you?]

tin-bum¶

n. (informal) a lucky person (occas. tin-arse, adj. tin-arsed) cf. tinny

BAXTER Song of Tinbum Kelly (1979,Collected Poems,137,1954 ed.)

SLATTER The luckiest player that ever pulled on a jersey, said Old Bert. He's been a bit of a tin-bum. Not like me. I'm always shit out of luck. Ibid. 164 Full as the family poe [sic] - The trouble with the game today - The biggest tin-bum. (1968,Pagan Game, The,158)

ANDERSON One of our calls was on a chap who had recently had a good win in the Art Union, and Dan took the opportunity to congratulate him. The result had appeared in the Invercargill paper and the nom-de-plume published was Tinburn'. Dan of course wanted to know what prompted him to use such a curious nom-de-plume, and the proud winner said that he hadn't used that nom-de-plume at all.Well what did you use?' asked Dan [57] `Tinbum.' Obviously the press in those days was a little more prudish than it is today. (1975,Men of the Milford Road,56)

It's a bizarre and miraculous thing to happen. It's a real tin-bum thing [sc. on winning Lotto]. (Nov 22, 1992,Sunday Times (NZ),1)

tin-can¶

v. tin-kettle [aka tin can, tincan]

FRAME We tin-canned them and threw rice at them and they gave us a cream bun that was only half cream. (1960,Owls Do Cry,84)

DAVIN At that moment the very devil of a noise started up outside, as if a thousand mongrel dogs with two thousand tin cans tied to their tails had been suddenly let loose on a corrugated-iron roof. What on earth is that?' I gave a jump that nearly sent Norah sprawling.They must be tin-canning us.' And what, I'd like to know, is tin-canning?'Oh, it's a thing they always do round here when a newly married couple comes home.' (1959,No Remittance,96) [NOTES: [Southland]]

FRAME Florrie married. We tin-canned her and her new husband and had a feast of fizzy drinks and cakes,... (1982,To the Is-Land,81,1984 ed.)

D E HURLEY Reporting a conversation with Maori woman from Northland who mentioned that over the Christmas/New Year 1989-1990 she and others had gone `tincanning' on Christmas and New Year Eve, meaning going as a group to people's places for drinks etc. making anoise outside until the householder let them in. (Jan 25, 1990,Personal Communication)

`My sister married a farmer who lives at Alford Forest [Canterbury] ... and, when she and her husband arrived back from their honeymoon, they were tin-canned.' (Dec 1987,Letter) [NOTES: 1987 Dec Letter from Christchurch [re Alford Forest] in RussellJ. Stone folder (ATB MS)]

My mother was born and lived in Invercargill up to 1915, and has told me of the custom there to go `tin-canning' newly-weds. (Feb 12, 1988,Letter) [NOTES: 1988 Feb 12 Letter from Napier in Russell J. Stone folder (ATB MS)]

SCOTT The chaps are coming up tonight. Tin-canning. (1953,Breakfast at Six,19)

F.H. has been married, tin-canned, &c., I hear, and is looking better than ever. (Oct 27, 1888,Observer (Auckland),20)

Little boys "tincan" the happy pair. (Jun 15, 1918,Wairarapa Daily Times,4)

At the Thames Police Court last Monday, four youths were fined L1 each and costs for tincanning a wedding party. (Feb 5, 1891,Poverty Bay Herald,3)

Speaking to a new chum the other day he said he was surprised at people tin-canning newly-married couples. (Jun 22, 1906,Hawera & Normanby Star,8)

n. [tin-canning/tin-kettling aka tin can, tincan] (See tin-canning/tin-kettling)

It is rumoured that several couples are going to run in double harness soon, so get your tin-cans ready, boys. (Nov 22, 1890,NZ Observer,17)

Is it a case of get your tin cans ready, boys? (Aug 20, 1904,NZ Observer,22)

Our frolicsome boys won't be short of tincans at the next rejoicing if they will only pay a visit to the swamp. (Aug 21, 1880,Bay of Plenty Times,3)

tin-can band¶

n.

"It was quite a usual thing to parade the streets with waving banners, and a tin-can band, and make the night hideous with noise. .." (Aug 4, 1906,Evening Post,14)

tin-can mail¶

phr.

Niua-foou is the island famed for its tin-can mail'. The monthly bills are sealed in a kerosine tin and thrown into the water, a swimmer from the shore picking up thebag'. (Aug 10, 1921,Quick March,13)

tin-canner¶

n. tin-kettler [aka tin canner, tincanner]

WEBB I suppose I'll have to part at least two quid of the money I've saved ... for the tin-canners. Ibid. 64 I forgot to warn you. It's the tin-canners, the first lot - youngsters you know.' He dashed out ... and was greeted by shrieks, cheers, and a deafening banging on benzine and kerosine tins. After a brief parley ... the giggling boys departed, and the bridegroom returned to explain to his wife that `It was just a custom - you know. They always do it in this part of the country. The men will be here a bit later, and I'll have to give them something to go and drink our health. (1925,Miss Peters' Special,62)

KEENE Now he was on hand early to ensure that the tin canners did not over-step the mark in decorum. (1967,Tang of The Bush,55)

That foolish practice of "tin-canning" the bride and bridegroom was indulged in at Whangarei the other evening, and so terrific was the din, that now there is talk of "tin-canners" being asked to explain themselves at the S.M.'s Court. (Nov 9, 1912,NZ Truth,1)

Why wouldn't E.W. join the tin-canners? (Aug 13, 1904,NZ Observer,21)

Of course the inevitable 'tincanners' were in force, and made night hideous for a few minutes. (Aug 29, 1891,Observer (Auckland),16)

A.B. to Miss W. and E.N at the Kowhai to R.B. - so I hear - tin canners, get ready ... (Jun 18, 1887,Observer (Auckland),18)

JH and FS have taken the decisive step at last. Congratulations. Don't forget the cake and the tin-canners. (Feb 7, 1903,Observer (Auckland),21)

tin-canning¶

adj. [attrib. use: tin-canning parties]

WEBB He ... had taken his full share in the New Year's Eve pranks and mischief in which colonial youth delights, as well as being a promoter of most of the tin-canning parties when anyone got married. (1925,Miss Peters' Special,62)

n. = tin-kettling [aka tincanning, tin canning]

This was called "tin-canning" or "tin-kettling," and newly married couples were those who suffered. (Mar 25, 1943,NZ Farmers' Weekly,16)

tin-canning NZ serenading of newly-married couple by beating cans. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,806) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

McGILL tin canning a greeting, often of newly-weds, by tin can bashing, often now for sport or rock music performers; originally and still occasionally aka tin kettling. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,113)

`I was growing up in Central Southland in the 1920ies when tincanning was very common.' (Feb 10, 1988,Letter) [NOTES: 1988 Feb 10 Letter from Wellington in Russell J. Stone folder (ATB MS)]

KEENE In the evening [of our wedding day: ca1898] we prepared for visitors. The number who came to the tin canning was the measure of a couple's popularity. The usual plan was for the guests to approach silently, wait until all were gathered, then to smite their tins with might and main, making a din which could be heard for miles. (1967,Tang of The Bush,55)

Eight young men were convicted of disturbing an inhabitant [of Hamilton] and fined 5s. and costs each. The magistrate gave them a lecture on the absurdity of the barbarous custom of tin-canning. (Sep 5, 1891,Waikato Times) [NOTES: [1891 Sep 5 Waikato Times] in 1964 Norris Settlers in Depression 197]

They say they are going to give me an awful tincanning when I get married. Hope you won't mind, Dora.' (Feb 11, 1911,NZ Truth,294/5/1)

... if I have a dance at someone's tincanning. (Nov 13, 1953,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

DAVIN You knew this would happen?' I said to her when she came to bed.Of course. There was bound to be a tin-canning. We'd hardly be married without it. Don't they have them everywhere?' `No, indeed they don't.' (1959,No Remittance,96)

They say they are going to give me an awful tincanning when I get married. Hope you won't mind, Dora.' (Nov 13, 1953,NZ Truth,294/5/1)

... if I have a dance at someone's tincanning. (Nov 13, 1953,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

DAVIN You knew this would happen?' I said to her when she came to bed.Of course. There was bound to be a tin-canning. We'd hardly be married without it. Don't they have them everywhere?' `No, indeed they don't.' (1954,No Remittance,96)

HOWE ... I suppose our [children's wedding] celebrations [c1880] were rather childish. ... We called them `tin-canning'. We [117] usually started rather late because by then the guests were fairly drunk and their reactions more amusing. Our drums were empty kerosene tins beaten with copper-sticks and the din could be heard for miles. ... Tradition decreed that red-hot pennies be thrown to us when the tin-canning started. (1964,Stamper Battery,116)

The usual amount of tin-canning was gone through by the smaller fry, who for their endeavours at instrumentality were rewarded with good things ad infinitum. (Aug 13, 1881,Observer (Auckland),548)

In re-examination, Miss Lowen said she had been to a "tin-canning" at Ashburton while on holiday after the return of a honeymoon couple, but that was the only function she attended. (Jun 26, 1902,NZ Truth,5)

[Caption] "Tin Canning". Bride and groom surprised. (Dec 20, 1944,Franklin Times,2)

The OM would like to know if JH gave the boys some wine and cake after the tin-canning last week ... (Aug 23, 1902,Observer (Auckland),22)

tin-ear¶

n.

PARTRIDGE An (habitual) eavesdropper: Australian: since ca. 1918. Baker, 1942. (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,725)

tin-filler¶

n. A plain biscuit or easily made cake,etc, of which a ready supply might easily and cheaply be kept [in airtight tins]

Anzac biscuits are a standard tin-filler. (Aug 17, 1999,Radio NZ / National Radio,Morning Report) [NOTES: Alison Gofton & Alison Host during a promotiion of Anzac Biscuits as the Millenium Biscuit.]

tin-kettle¶

v. [cf tin-can]

WOOD Presently we heard an awful uproar in the ball-room. Oh! Glory,' said Bridget,they're tin-kettling them [the newly-weds]; come on,' and she seized an empty kerosine tin and was off. ... There stood Ned and Maggie in the centre, while round marched the rest of the people armed with kerosine tins, billies half filled with stones, and tin dishes, shouting, yelling, and singing ... (1875,Waiting for the Mail,110)

BATHGATE I was wakened by the din caused by a lot of the diggers tin-kettling the newly-married pair. (1881,Waitaruna,234)

BRADSHAW ... the members of the school committee hostile to our popular and excellent teacher were hooted and tin-kettled to their houses. (1888,New Zealand Of Today,323)

ANDERSON One night, when I had been on the station [newly-married] about a month, Ron ... announced, `We'll be having visitors tomorrow night. They're coming for miles around to tin-kettle us. (1981,Both Sides of the River,103)

It falls to the lot of very few couples to be tin-kettled after they have been married for a period of two and a half years, but this was the distinction which befell a Rakaia pair (writes a correspondent). The husband had just returned from the front after being absent for practically the whole of his married life. (Feb 7, 1919,Poverty Bay Herald,3)

The larrikins are indanger of losing their time-honored privilege of tin-kettling newly-married couples. (Oct 29, 1894,Hawera & Normanby Star,4)

They had "tin-kettled" in front of the residence of a newly-wedded couple. (Nov 16, 1908,Taranaki Herald,4)

tin-kettler¶

n.

A Tin-kettling Episode: The detestable practice of tin-kettling a newly-married couple [with kerosine tins] doesn't seem to die out like other barbarities in this country; it is a relic of by-gone days. ... The origin of the custom has never been authoritatively determined and whether it is an English or purely Colonial custom ... doesn't appear to be known. However, the tin-kettlers expect the happy bridegroom to stop the din by handing them cakes and ale. ... It is only the idiotic low-class class of people who would go banging tin-cans opposite a man's house after dark ... . (Sep 23, 1905,NZ Truth,14/8/3)

MARKS But it was to the uninvited guests [to the wedding] that we boys paid most attention - the tin-kettlers. (1934,Memories (Mainly Merry),18)

I was married in Greymouth in 1937 ... a crowd of children and young adults arrived, armed with noisemakers ... But, six months ago, here in Rotorua, my young neighbour remarried and I was surprised and delighted to see and hear the `tin-kettlers' arrive when the young couple returned from their honeymoon. (Feb 13, 1988,Letter) [NOTES: 1988 Feb 13 Letter from Rotorua in Russell J. Stone folder (ATB MS)]

`The local farmers put their heads together and planned a tin-kettling party. In the hands of people were carried an assortment of pots and kettles, wooden and metal spoons, kerosene tins containing stones as a rattle, old-fashioned car horns ... The tin-kettling was not complete until the house was circled by the tin-kettlers.' (Feb 8, 1988,Letter) [NOTES: 1988 Feb 8 Letter from Christchurch [re Alford Forest] in Russell J. Stone folder (ATB MS)]

The "tin-kettlers" are made up by the male friends of those just married, amounting sometimes, if the bridegroom is popular, to fifty persons, the "tin-kettles" used being generally kerosene tins, which are beaten with sticks, sometimes small stones are put in the tin, and the thing is shaken, drums are beaten, pipes played, and everything done which can tend to make a noise. (Jun 26, 1876,North Otago Times,2)

At a recent wedding, the next-door neighbours of the bridal party provided cakes for the tin-kettlers. (Apr 23, 1904,NZ Observer,7)

The tin-kettlers reckoned with their host, but not the bull. (Oct 22, 1904,NZ Observer,17)

The Missing Link having asserted that it was the muddy roads kept the tin-kettlers from visiting T.B., the latter would be anxious to get an answer to the following question ... (Jul 21, 1883,Observer (Auckland),4)

The guardians of the law at the place just named came down on a large force of "tin-kettlers" who were worrying a new-married couple, and secured no less than nineteen of the offenders, who were each fined ten shillings and costs by the magistrate. (Mar 30, 1892,Tuapeka Times,2)

I'm a stout tin-kettler / For the small, but honest settler. (Jan 1, 1910,NZ Truth,1)

tin-kettling¶

n. (formerly) a custom whereby a newly-wed couple are welcomed to their marriage home by noisy banging of kerosene (etc.) tins until they provide the tin-kettlers with refreshments. [also called tin-canning]

This was called "tin-canning" or "tin-kettling," and newly married couples were those who suffered. (Mar 25, 1943,NZ Farmers' Weekly,16)

A Tin-kettling Episode: The detestable practice of tin-kettling a newly-married couple [with kerosine tins] doesn't seem to die out like other barbarities in this country; it is a relic of by-gone days. ... The origin of the custom has never been authoritatively determined and whether it is an English or purely Colonial custom ... doesn't appear to be known. However, the tin-kettlers expect the happy bridegroom to stop the din by handing them cakes and ale. ... It is only the idiotic low-class class of people who would go banging tin-cans opposite a man's house after dark ... (Sep 23, 1905,NZ Truth,14/8/3)

R. MASON `Term must date back 60 years at least judging by the people who are familiar with it as an old expression. A custom (in country districts mostly) of visiting a newly settled-in just married couple in the evening and banging tins and making other noise, etc., outside their house. (1905,Personal Communication)

(Aug 1952,Straight Furrow,11 (10)/54)

SUTHERLAND After it [sc. the house] had weathered two traditional `tin kettlings' we knew we had nothing to fear. (1956,Green Kiwi,204,1960 ed.)

MARSHALL Used to be real live-wires when we were first married,' said Mrs Foden philosophically.Never missed a tin-kettling or first-footing; euchre evenings, sales, duck shoots, dances, send-offs, fires. We always went. ...' (1979,Supper Waltz Wilson,47)

HUNT [On the Chatham Islands] another thing they've dropped now is tin-kettling after a wedding ... thirty or forty of you, all with kerosine tins, you'd make a hell of a din. Then you'd all be called in for drink and tucker. (1981,Speaking a Silence,30)

Mr Buck says he wants to put the record straight `as one who in 1935 was present when Keith Holyoake and his new bride arrrived back in Riwaka from their honeymoon to a traditional "tin-kettling"'. (Dec 24, 1983,Dominion,2)

tin-kettling NZ = tin-canning. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,806)

`The local farmers put their heads together and planned a tin-kettling party. In the hands of people were carried an assortment of pots and kettles, wooden and metal spoons, kerosene tins containing stones as a rattle, old-fashioned car horns ... The tin-kettling was not complete until the house was circled by the tin-kettlers.' (Feb 8, 1988,Letter) [NOTES: 1988 Feb 8 Letter from Christchurch [re Alford Forest] in Russell J. Stone folder (ATB MS)]

I was present at both the tin-kettling and the presentation [to the new bride of a chamber-pot filled with salt and tied about with a wideish ribbon ... with a large bow tied in it ... with the advice that if they used up all of the salt in the chamber-pot they would have Good Luck.] which probably took place between 1925 and 1930. (Feb 10, 1988,Letter) [NOTES: 1988 Feb 10 Letter from Nelson in Russell J. Stone folder (ATB MS)]

I remember ... being carried to my first `tin-kettling' [at Cobden c1930]. (Feb 12, 1988,Letter) [NOTES: 1988 Feb 12 Letter from West Coast in Russell J. Stone folder (ATB MS)]

HUNT Another thing they've dropped now is the tin-kettling after a wedding... One bloke might say "How about tin-kettling so and so?" (1981,Speaking a Silence,30)

The practice of tin-kettling and levying blackmail on people after a wedding was of frequent occurrence, expecially in St Alban's District. ... serenaded a newly wedded happy couple with a tintinnabulation of tin kettles (Nov 13, 1874,Otago Guardian,2) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

The Inspector of Police referred to the common practice of tin-kettling at weddings. (Jun 6, 1868,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

The return of Mr and Mrs Niven from their Honeymoon on Wednesday was taken advantage of a party from here to attend at Cloverleigh, and perform the rites of the ceremony of tin-kettling, without which no marriage in New Zealand is complete. (Mar 26, 1912,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,5)

That invigorating and intellectual sport, the tin-kettling of newly-married couples, has been carried on with such tremendous vim lately that several of the kerosine-tin brigade had faced the magistrate. (Oct 22, 1904,NZ Observer,17)

The practice of "tinkettling" seems to be carried to extremes in the Wairarapa, judging from the following letter to the Masterton Star:- "A respectable party, as you are aware, has lately joined the bonds of matrimony, and retired to their private residence, some little distance from the town , to spend their honeymoon ..." (Jan 4, 1882,Evening Post,2)

To the individual unused to attending such functions, the time-honoured custom of "tin-kettling" a newly-married couple is something dreadful, and must be avoided at all costs. (May 5, 1917,Wairarapa Daily Times,4)

Amongst the local news will be found reports in the Magistrate's Court of the Arahura dog case and the Woodstock tinkettling case. (Oct 1, 1891,West Coast Times,2)

n. TIN-KETTLE, TIN-PAN [kettle ?= cauldro, boiler, billy] OED(S tin-kettle: to serenade roughly or opprobriously ... by beating a tin-kettle, [1898 sc an inn-keeper who had beaten his wife; 1900 Lawson diggers for newlyweds; OEDS 1881 Bathgate] also, to (cause swarming bees) to settle [1900 H. Lawson]; also tin pan 1885 English Dialect Dictionary Tin 1 (7) tin-kettle to punish a notorious offender by means of rough music', i.e., the beating of tin kettles, etc. Hmp; also (10) <i>Tin-pan</i> s.Not. -->SHIVAREE/CHARIVARI cf OED(S<i> charivari </i>the tin-kettling of incongruous marriages. W3 [=Third Webst. Int]<i>Brit</i>. a mock serenade; esp.<i> shivaree </i> cf. Mencken Amer. Lang. Supp 1/232-3 <i>shivaree </i>... a rowdy serenade of a newly-married couple ...' for a list of US (near-)synonyms and discussion W3 shivaree [f F charivari] A noisy mock serenade to a newly married couple who are expected to furnish refreshments to silence the serenaders. [Had to make new entry to alter verbal noun to noun and was unable to copy in full discussion above (see dataset for remainder) TD]

tin-kettling party¶

n.

MARKS There were about fifty boys in the tin-kettling party; ... (1934,Memories (Mainly Merry),18)

tin-opener wife¶

phr. often elaborated with AND FRYING-PAN, of one who (it is believed) cannot or will not cook `decent' food for her family [ca1935 Havelock]

tin-tippy¶

n. [[New Plymouth schoolboys', early 1920's: a tin canoe made of bent corrugated iron fastened at both ends and made watertight with tar.]]

GLOVER We discovered that once a tin-tippy was capsized or rammed it was difficult to get it up again. (1981,Hot Water Sailor,29,1962 ed.)

tina¶

n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of rape, a forage crop. [ORIGIN: Maori]

Tina swede - The only swede resistant to both club root and dry rot. (1995,Grasslands Range of Forage and Conservation Plants,72)

tinana¶

n.

IHIMAERA What I'm trying to say ... is that the conflict was not only over the land, the tinana, but also over the spirit, the wairua. (1986,Matriarch, The,69)

tine harrows¶

n.

EVANS Up to the late 70's tine harrows were popular for preparing land for sowing, but during the 1870's the first Disc Harrows were imported from America. (1956,History of Farm Implements,12)

One of my earliest impressions of dairyfarming was the sight of a farmer, complete with sou'-wester oilskin and gumboots, following two horses and a set of tyne harrows around a hillside in the pouring rain on a Saturday afternoon. (Sep 30, 1959,NZ Dairy Exporter,31) [NOTES: (nb: date provided to database was 31/9/1959)]

tinhorn gambler¶

n.

PARTRIDGE Tinhorn gambler. A petty gambler: Canadian since ca. 1912, Australian since ca. 1920, New Zealand since ca. 1922. Adopted from U.S.A.: (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1203)

tinker grass¶

n. (See grass)

tinker up¶

v.

Kaikora calved ... [17] Wintry weather, tried to bail up Kaikora but failed. tinkered up hut Mr Newton still there. (Mar 16, 1859,Puketoi Station Diary)

tinker-tailor¶

n. tinker grass

FRAME The cutty grass and the tinkertailor were brushing against her black stockings (1963,Reservoir, The,139) [NOTES: 1966 edition]

tinned¶

adj. preferred in NZ to CANNED until about WW2; thence canned (can) became more common in collocations as tinned (canned) food, etc. sc canned (Davin an old-fashioned writer) see also can, canned [ca1935 Havelock general store tinned peaches, salmon, etc. usual; canned seldom or never heard]

The Western Packing and Canning Company during 1899 slaughtered 43,000 sheep, averaging 54lb. each; 1,000 cattle, averaging 550lb.; with an output of 9,000 cases of tinned meats, and 640 casks of tallow. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,10)

MULGAN There liners and tramp steamers ... tied up at wooden wharves, pouring in machinery ...whisky and tinned salmon ... (1934,Spur of Morning,44)

THOMSON We decided to pack enough tinned stores and go ... up the valley a considerable distance. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,128)

WINKS ... seldom purchased by Americans in New Zealand, are: clothing, shoes, tinned (we call them `canned') goods, ... (1954,These New Zealanders,68,1956 ed.)

AITKEN Midday passed in this way; we made a meal of bread, tinned Maconochie rations and pork-and-beans, which for attack fare ... was wonderful to have. (1963,Gallipoli to the Somme,160)

DAVIN So Jack scratched round in the kitchen and before long I [120] had my entrenching tools into a fine binder of bully fritters and fried tinned potatoes, ... (1975,Breathing Spaces,119)

Tinned rabbits were fetching more per pound than either tinned or frozen mutton. (Jun 12, 1890,Otago Witness,7)

tinned cow¶

n. tinned condensed milk (cf.tin cat, tin dog; armoured cow)

THORNTON Have some tinned cow?' He ... explained thattinned cow' was a "bushism' for condensed milk. (1916,Wowser, The,90)

tinned dog¶

n. bully beef or other tinned meat [aka tin dog]

FOSTON The living ... consisted chiefly in some camps [for labourers on the Main Trunk construction] ... of tin dog' (meat) ortin cat' (fish). (1921,At The Front,116)

He [soldier on Gallipoli] loathed plum-and-apple jam, tinned dog and granite-like biscuit ... (Apr 25, 1918,Quick March,3)

Water was always scarce, and food consisted of unappetizing "tinned dog." (Nov 12, 1930,Evening Post,10)

Tinned dog, methinks I smell it now, and after having a few British beers to wash the dog down we were rushing along at the rate of 15 miles per hour, arriving at Beverly at 5 am, where we had a good wash in brackish water. (Feb 19, 1895,Grey River Argus,2)

And there is no need to eat 'tinned dog,' as on some of the West Australian gold fields. (Sep 29, 1911,Grey River Argus,7)

The dishes bore South African names, but no "damper" or "tinned dog" outraged the palates of these wealthy diners, for the menu was Parisian, and the food was washed down with champagne at GBP1 a bottle, hock at 30s a bottle, and port at 25s, the dinner concluding with costly cigars and fifty-year-old brandy at 3s the liqueur glass. (Apr 25, 1906,Wanganui Herald,4)

n. canned meat [aka tinned dog]

tinned soldier¶

n. a tankman, tankie

BRUNO Gunboat Nelson, a tinned soldier of the Tank Brigade. (1944,Desert Daze,24)

tinnie shop¶

n. (informal) (See tinny house)

[He] said he knew a tinnie shop - a house where cannabis is sold in tinfoil packages - in Newtown. (Feb 3, 2001,Dominion,11)

tinny¶

1 adj. (informal) lucky [1953 18 M A40 Thames DHS 1 TINNY -->1960 16C F B5 Wellington Girls C. 32 TINNY 1984 16-17 F E10 Pakuranga Coll. 32 TINNY [lucky] [M6 F3] -->1984 14 F E125 Wgton Girls C. 32 TINNY -->1984 14 F E127 Wgton Girls C. 32 TINNY [5] ca1935 Havelock `Tinny eh?' was a common remark among children after someone had made a good or lucky shot at marbles.]

HENDERSON Flukes? Destiny? Fate? Or just : How Tinny Can You Be? (1990,So They Began,82)

Soon there'll be something worse than reading about some tinny person who's just won Lotto. (Apr 3, 1988,Sunday News,11)
