McGILL tinny lucky, possibly by association with English tinny', rich; egThe bail just hit his racket abd dobbed over the net. How tinny can you get!' NZA. -not very impressive; from tin being regarded as as inferior metal to iron or steel; eg `I tell you that horse is tinny, it'll never amount to anything.' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,113)

Clark rejects Shipley's view that Labour was tinny to inherit a growing economy. (Mar 18, 2000,Evening Post,7)

STEWART The truck's in the ditch. We were tinny, though. I no sooner got little Joe out ... but a bloke in an Oakland van came along, brought us right in here. (1981,Hot & Copper Sky,49)

BEATON DI: So, what about you? GINNY: Nothin' ... DI: How come? GINNY: They're tryin' to keep it quiet ... DI: You're a tinny bitch. Ibid. 110 TINNY (adj) lucky (1984,Outside In,43)

tinny NZ & Austral. sl. lucky. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,806) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 1228, sense 5]]

tinny NZ & Austral. sl. lucky. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,806) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 1228, sense 5]]

KEINZLY `I won two houseys. Ten quid. ... Every Friday night regular as Sunday for two years and this is the first time I've got it. And got it straight again after. Tinny, eh?' (1960,Tangahano,151)

PARTRIDGE [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... tinny, lucky; (1935,Slang Today,286)

PARTRIDGE When I said `Hooray' he called me back and gave me a few francs; I reckon I was very tinny. (1935,Slang Today,287)

PARTRIDGE Tinny. 2. ? hence, lucky: Australia and New Zealand: C. 20. Occ. tin-arsed. Cf protected. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,888)

SLATTER No slouch when it comes to a bit of knuckle - The tinniest player that ever wore the jersey - (1968,Pagan Game, The,164)

Only 100 people a day get to walk along the 2000-year-old cemetery which is the third level under the basilica so we were fairly tinny. (Dec 14, 2003,NZ Catholic,8)

There's nothing tinny about two former Wellingtonians behind the consortium that bought Ford's alloy wheel plant in Manukau this week. (Jun 27, 2001,Evening Post,21)

Remarks are heard on the "tinny" luck of otherwise of the players while the "stiffs" bemoan their luck. (Jun 7, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/45 : 205)

2 adj. (informal) unsubstantial, jerry-built, badly-made (though often, superficially, appearing well-made) (cf. Tin Lizzie, tinpot) [ca1935 e.g. a tinny piece of work, of a job badly done]

The shaving cabinets you buy always seem a bit tinny to me. (Apr 12, 1951,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 1951 Apr 12 2YA Wellington Women's Session]

tinny house/tinnie house¶

n. (informal) retail outlet for tinnies [Chris Fowlie (6/10/1999) says these are usually rented by gangs (so they can't be seized under the Proceeds of Crimes Act), are run by teen-agers (they can't be arrested) and are often open for business 24 hours a day with sales often taking place through a hole in a wall or window - the equivalent of the US "crack house".]

A truly fishy "tinny house" has been busted in Foxton. It is alleged that for about three years a man has been selling black-market flounder from his house in an operation the Fisheries Ministry likened to a tinny house. (Jun 27, 2003,Dominion Post,A1)

[headline] Tinny house man ordered to sell car (Apr 28, 2006,Dominion Post,A6)

[Hdg] Tinny house worker jailed (Sep 29, 2001,Dominion,11)

There are not a lot of tinny houses. The involvement of people here would be as growers and brokers. (Jan 23, 1999,Dominion,19)

An 18-year-old found helping to run a tinnie house in Newtown was given a suspended jail term by a Wellington District Court judge yesterday. (May 29, 1999,Evening Post,22)

The use of rented properties as "tinny houses" - drug outlets - has increased since the confiscations started. (Jun 6, 1999,Sunday Star Times,A12)

It means that if I go to a "tinny house" that is a gang residence and I buy my drugs there, and I am attacked by someone unlawfully on those premises, a much greater penalty will apply to the person whom commits that offence. (1999,Weekly Hansard,77 : 17615)

Another man is expected to face similar charges while a number of other people have been charged with possessing cannabis, allegedly bought from a "tinnie house". (Nov 10, 1998,Evening Post,3)

Armed undercover officer raided tinny houses in the suburbs of Manurewa and Otara and then posed as drug dealers peddling tinnies - foils of cannabis. Tinny houses are set up specifically to sell cannabis to the public. (Apr 17, 1999,Dominion,3)

How the thugs' merry peals of laughter must have echoed through the tinny houses and cell blocks. (Dec 16, 1999,Dominion,10)

The traditional gang-run tinnie house is now the tinnie and speed house. (Feb 14, 2001,Capital Times,6)

The traditional gang-run tinnie house is now the tinnie and speed house. (Apr 2001,Elements,9 : 1)

She went looking for a tinnie house, got caught up in the scene. (Oct 9, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),93)

They know old people who frequent tinnie houses to access the illegal drug they say assists with everything from epilepsy, muscle spasms, stress, insomnia, headaches, occupational overuse syndrome pain, anxiety, anorexia, cancer, depression, alcohol withdrawal, violent temper control and HIV and Aids-related symptoms. (Jun 20, 2004,Sunday Star Times,A6)

A certain amount of P is distributed by the gangs who manufacture it through the well-established, nation-wide tinny-house network. (Apr 5, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

A Waitara pre-school worker denied she was at a tinnie house when cannabis bullets were sold to an undercover cop last year, the New Plymouth District Court heard yesterday... Every adult at the address knew it was a tinnie house, Pue said. (Jun 15, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,3)

Justice Ellis called [him] the shopkeeper of a long-time tinnie house operation in Newtown. (Aug 12, 2000,Evening Post,21)

If we destroy the power of the illegal market by allowing adults to grow their own, there won't be the number of unscrupulous tinny houses for college kids to buy from. When you go to a tinny house, nobody asks you for ID. (Jul 8, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

tinny/tinnie¶

n. (informal) a small package of cannabis wrapped in tinfoil as sold by drug-vendors. [Worik Stanton (worik@noggon.com)writes that his wife commented "we called them tinnies in Palmerston [North] but when I got to Auckland I found they were called foils."]

McFarlane handed over eight tinnies, which he had concealed down his trousers. A ninth was behind his ear. He had been asked to help out with sales and "what was in it for him was one tinny". (Sep 29, 2001,Dominion,11)

[Hdg] Tinnie salesman gets year in jail. The salesman at a Newtown tinnie house caught with 52 cannabis tinnies behind the architrave of a door was jailed for one year. (Aug 13, 1999,Evening Post,14)

Tinnies of cannabis - about enough of the drug for three cigarettes, wrapped in foil, are sold at such houses. (Nov 10, 1998,Evening Post,3)

Armed undercover officer raided tinny houses in the suburbs of Manurewa and Otara and then posed as drug dealers peddling tinnies - foils of cannabis. Tinny houses are set up specifically to sell cannabis to the public. (Apr 17, 1999,Dominion,3)

A tinny is usually 1-2g of cannabis wrapped in tinfoil. (Jan 28, 2000,Evening Post,9)

The judge said the possession of 18 cannabis "tinnies" for sale was too serious a crime for home detention to be considered. (Apr 20, 2000,Dominion,7)

Owen Marshall I remember a spring day smoking tinnies among the marram dunes at New Brighton when he was shat on twice by seagulls... (2005,Watch of Gryphons,282) [NOTES: Also in Listener 3.4.2004, p.46]

...the mental picture of besuited Rotarians proffering tinnies on street corners had me distracted for a moment. (Mar 29, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),67)

Until two years ago the minimum amount a week was five tinnys. One tinny equals a gram of three joints for $20. (Jul 27, 2000,Contact (Wgtn),7)

n. (informal) a can of beer

"Would you like a beer before you go? I've got some tinnies in the fridge," said my London friend. (Aug 6, 2003,Capital Times,19)

JP II and JT I would be doing a damned sight more good it they told the tinnie-and-telly brigade to "return to their paternal vocation". (Aug 8, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C9)

When they come back, I'm gonna have to take them to a camp, run a barbecue, have a few tinnies, talk about where we stand as men, what we're supposed to do ... and when those French come back next time, by God they'll be surprised. (Nov 17, 1999,Evening Post,26)

A couple of weekends before Norm had invited some of his mates up to his Brooklyn home to watch a couple of videos, have a few tinnies and generally catch ahead of the new season. (Oct 21, 2001,Sunday Star Times,C1)

In "Sione-rella", Mr Pepelo demands to know how his "loser sons" manage to track him down yet again as he watches daytime TV sucking on a tinny in their own lounge. (Nov 7, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C4)

Hunters in the Orongorongo Ranges near Wellington down tinnies in the huts at nights and talk darkly of the real reason so much 1080 is dropped. (May 19, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C1)

Myself, who repaired to the relative sanctuary of a darkened laundry with a tinny and a transistor radio. (Aug 17, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),67)

After partying late into the night, they take off back home leaving a litter of tinnies and food scraps to be cleaned up by decent trampers who have just had their backcountry experience ruined. (Oct 2000,NZ Wilderness,8)

If patriotism is the last refuge of the scoundrel, at least he can have a few tinnies with his mates and sing along to such great ditties as "The Silver Cap Says It All" and "My Kind of Country, My Kind of Beer." (Feb 5, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),63)

n. (informal) a small metal boat [Used also Aust.]

More than 30 years ago Parkercraft introduced the first aluminium dinghy to New Zealand boaties. The ubiquitous "tinnies" have since come of age. (Sep 4, 1993,Evening Post,38)

Just before lunch.. there is a moment of drama on an aluminium dinghy, lovingly called a "tinnie" or "frying pan" by its owner, local fisherman Pete Pethybridge. (Jul 5, 1999,Evening Post,16)

There was one man in a little tinnie in the middle of the Tasman being pulled around by a marlin. (Mar 10, 2004,Otago Daily Times,6)

He fished with a brother in a small "tinny" for a few years, but bought his first boat about seven years ago. (Jan 21, 2002,Evening Post,15)

The aluminium dinghy makes slow headway against the tidal flow... We beach the "tinnie" on the mudflats of Motuotu Island and make our way through the mangoves taking hold along the shoreline. (May 2002,NZ Geographic,57/84)

Kai moana is our heritage and, now that we have wine and supermarkets, we also have mussel farms and savvie, so that you don't even have to own a 12-foot tinnie to indulge. (Oct 30, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),57)

The boat, a very basic three metre "tinnie" gets hitched on the back of the wagon, rods strapped in the hull. (Mar 2003,North & South,38)

Quietly paddling the Devonport-Takapuna coastline this summer I was nearly run over by an otherwise sane-looking Dad in a tinny pulling his child on an inflatable "biscuit". Only trouble was he was driving fast forward while facing backwards, waving at his child. (Mar 2004,North & South,8)

Instead, here, you can get out in a little tinnie in the inner harbour and you're set. (Feb 22, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),4)

Another popular occupation was building 'tinnies'. Canoes made from old corrugated iron, pointed to a bow at one end and with a wooden stern nailed in at the other... Before the days of television and 'spacies' this was one of the ways Devonport kids amused themselves, scooting in their trusty tinnies in among Ngataringa Bay's scrubby mangroves. (Sep 1991,Metro,30)

New Zealanders are big on fishing: flinging a line off a wharf, from the rocks or over the side of a tinny is a 'regular pastime' for over 400,000 kiwis. (Jul 2004,AA Directions,Spring/21)

Whether you have a tinny that barely beats the tide, or a monster which makes your accountant weep, you need a place to either park it or ramp it. (Aug 26, 2005,Dominion Post,B9)

tino pai¶

phr. very good [ORIGIN: Maori]

Tino pai story writer (Oct 20, 2005,Wellingtonian,News 5) [NOTES: headline]

tino rangatiratanga¶

n. (Politics) full (Maori) sovereignty or self-determination. [ORIGIN: Maori, from the Maori text of the Treaty of Waitangi (tino indicating a superlative degree, RANGATIRATANGA)]

I guess a lot of Kiwis associate the words tino rangatiratanga with protest, aggression and conflict. (Jun 4, 2004,Dominion Post,B4)

It is very seductive to say to aggrieved Maori that we must form a political party and go our own way and scream tino rangatiratanga, but, frankly, it isn't a goer. (Oct 21, 2003,Dominion Post,B4)

"I was a chain-smoker many years ago. I saw what it was doing for Maori health, for my whanau, so I said `that's it'. Hurrah for tino rangatiratanga." (Apr 20, 2000,Evening Post,2)

Maori themselves have to put tino rangatiratanga into personal practice and do it for themselves. (Feb 26, 2004,Dominion Post,B5)

Tino rangatiratanga (chieftainship over land, villages and property was retained by Maori tribal leaders. (Mar 29, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

You can still enjoy our tikanga [customs], you can still have all the drama from the marae, your wives can still practise tino rangatiratanga [being the boss] every day ... (Sep 8, 2004,Dominion Post,C5)

Patricia Grace We need politicisation and decolonisation if we're going to claim tino rangatiratanga, otherwise nothing's gunna change, gunna keep on being bad statistics... (2001,Dogside Story,146)

.. we are proud to bear the tino rangatiratanga flag ... (Jul 19, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,2)

In the Otararua hapu offices on McLean St, below the tino rangatiratanga flags, he explained his comment. (May 20, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

tino reka tenei kai¶

phr. the food was delicious [ORIGIN: Maori, code switching not NZE]

More of an event than a meal out .. plus tino reka tenei kai (the food was delicious). (Aug 2005,Capital Times,17-23 Aug / 20)

tino tika¶

phr. quite correct

It's all tino tika, quite correct. (Dec 1912,NZ Free Lance,Xmas Annual : 35)

tinplate¶

n. sand flounder

Sand Flounder New Zealand Flounder, Patiki, Three corner, Tinplate Rhombosolea plebeia. (1911,Records of the Canterbury Museum,1/197) [NOTES: Waite]

GRAHAM NEW ZEALAND SAND-FLOUNDER (PATIKI) Rhombosolea plebeia (Richardson) ... The common Sand-flounder is known from one end of New Zealand to the other, sometimes by other names in different localities. In Auckland it is known as the Dab.../ Some refer to it as Tinplate or Three Corner; the latter name is derived from its fancied trangular shape but why Tinplate I am at a loss to know. To other than fishermen and those intimately connected with the fishing industry it is just a Flounder. Some say it is Tinplate because when cooked it fills a plate. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,191,2nd edn ed.)

DOOGUE & MORELAND SAND FLOUNDER ... Other names: Rhombosolea plebeia; diamond, tinplate, dab, square; patiki (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,216)

MORELAND SAND FLOUNDER [Rhombosolea plebeia] ... Other names are dab, diamond, tinplate, and square. The Maori name patiki, originally generic, is now loosely used for most flounders. (1967,Marine Fishes,32)

SORENSON FLOUNDER (four species) (a) Scientific name: (i) Rhombosolea plebeia (ii) Rhombosolea retiaria (iii) Rhombosolea tapirina (iv) Rhombosolea leporina. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southern waters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,24)

WILSON FLOUNDER SAND ... Other names are dab', tinplate, square flounder. The Maori namepatiki' is used for all flounder except the sole which is the `patiki rori'. Ibid. 200 TINPLATE see Flounder, sand (1981,Fisherman's Bible,71)

sand flounder .. [scientific name] Rhombosolea plebeia .. [other name(s)] dab, diamond back, square, tin-plate, three corners (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

tinplate flounder¶

n. = sand flounder

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] flounder, tinplate 2284 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

tinpot¶

adj. (informal) small, insignificant [not exclusively a New Zealand term: OED from 1838]

SLATTER I'm a cosmopolitan now. I don't stick up for any tin-pot place any more. Ibid. 167 I've never been in the tin-pot place. Never heard of it. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,75)

McGill He told Rogers the newspaperman wanted to know if he was interested in a story on a gold strike in some tinpot dump up the coast... (1995,Gold in the Creek,163)

He added that he and the Transvaal representatives were strongly opposed to wretched tin pot navies, and hoped that in future the British naval programme would be discussed in the Colonial Parliament beforehand. (Oct 30, 1909,Wanganui Herald,5)

If they would join one or other, and exercise their vote and influence, I think the desired result would be obtained - that is one respectable association instead of two tinpot affairs, as all the best stock in the Waikato would not make one good show. (Jan 22, 1874,Waikato Times,2)

Does he think to impose upon Rororua by his tinpot philanthropy? (May 7, 1887,Observer (Auckland),10)

As to tin pot Napier, he's nothing. (Jul 8, 1899,Observer (Auckland),17)

Its [sic] a shame that four tinpot mines should be able to disturb the coal industry of N.Z. (Jul 3, 1920,Grey River Argus,3)

It would, he said, be "fatal for New Zealand with only one million of population to start to tinker with a tinpot local navy." (Oct 4, 1912,Evening Post,6)

WATSON Erin Carter born in March 1932, brought up on his father's farm in Northland, near a tin pot village where there's only the store with the red benzine bowsers in front of it. (1986,Address to a King,59)

tins¶

n. cake tins

Everyone kept their cake tins full, and visitors would be offered at least a cup of tea and buttered date loaf on arrival. (Jul 17, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56)

There is morning and afteroon tea as well as three meals a day, and the biscuit tins are always full. (Mar 13, 2004,Dominion Post,E12)

HENDERSON I don ' t know how she coped. I never knew of her ever having been caught with empty cake tins.... (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,79)

These were the staple of her everyday cooking - the delicacies always to be found in the "tins" when we came home from school. (Jan 12, 1993,Dominion,6)

KEITH 'Keeping the tins full' was a housewifely virtue for which school girls were trained at an early age. (1991,Lovely Day Tomorrow, A,42)

DAISH Not long ago it would have been embarrassing, if not shameful, to be caught with your tins empty. (1989,Good Food,94)

Tiny¶

n. familiar NZ Divisional nickname of General Freyberg

HAYDON We all thought the world of `Tiny'. He called us his boys. (1941,NZ Soldiers in England,17)

SINGLETON-GATES To the men who have followed him battle through two desperate wars he is "Tiny", as he was in New Zealand forty-nine years ago. (1968,General Lord Freyberg,9)

tio¶

n. rock-oyster

Whilst it was being prepared I strayed along the beach knocking off rock oysters (native name tio). (1940,Establishment of New Plymouth Settlement,119) [NOTES: c1846 Weekes My Island in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 119]

2 n.

BEATTIE Notable omissions from this list [of food sources compiled by Maori hands c1880] are the kareko (edible sea-weed), tio-kohatu (rock oysters), tio-pati (oysters), and various kinds of shellfish. (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,62)

tiora¶

n.

BULLER POGNORNIS CINCTA (STITCH-BIRD.) ... Native names. Hihi, Tihe, Kotihe, Kotihewera, Tiora, and Tiheora; male and female are someties distinguished as Hihi-paka and Hihi-matakiore or Tihe-kiore. Ibid. 103fn [Stitch-birds] utter that peculiar whistle from which the natives have named them Tiora. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/101)

REISCHEK In another place I have already given an account of my search after one of the rarest of New Zealand birds, the ti-ora (Pogonornis cincta). (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,227,1933 ed.)

Tip¶

n. chiefly pl., (the) Tips, Tipperary boys; Irish rowdies; larrikins

THATCHER To rescue him this rowdie Tip unto his mates he hollered ... . (1862,Canterbury Songster,19)

GOLDIE Some of these distant and retired mountain gorges are often the scene of many a wild encounter between the Tipperary or Tips as they are generally termed and the Galway Boys. (Feb 28, 1863,Diary) [NOTES: 1863 Feb 28 J. Goldie Third Diary in 1947 Beattie Pioneers Explore Otago 149]

MONEY En passant, no class of men ... are less generally known and appreciated than the digger. In saying this, I do not for one moment refer to those curses of a gold-field, the low Irish `tips,' for a more cowardly, ruffianly, or brutal character I have never met with than that lively specimen from the green isle, who seems to flourish with rank luxuriance in the neighbourhood of gold. He is the man who will, as long as he has a mob of his mates to back him, smash up a store, jump a claim, rob a church, ... with equal zest. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,73)

PYKE In those days the diggings were infested by gangs of rowdies, who (whether rightly or wrongly I know not) were designated by the generic name of `Tips'. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,Bk I ch v 19)

tip¶

n. a tipping pen q.v.

NEWTON The tip, a small pen capable of holding ten or twelve sheep, was situated a foot or so above and partly overhanging the dip. Constructed on a large axle ... with the aid of a lever it could be tipped and the sheep sent slithering into the dip below. (1949,High Country Days,102)

n. a rubbish dump; THE TIP, the usual term for a town or city rubbish dump (most NZ dumps are worked on a tip and fill (often the Bradford tip) system) [ca1900 at least take one's rubbish to the tip is a common expression.]

Any increase in tip fees is usually followed by an increase in illegal dumping. (Sep 9, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

LELAND tip: (A) The tip is the GARBAGE DUMP. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,104)

n.

NEWTON Unshorn hoggets, having more `tip' to their wool, are particularly prone to entanglement;... (1966,Boss's Story, The,29)

v. (Rural) to turn sheep on their backs for inspection or shearing. (See ram-tipping)

The rams have been tipped, the dog whistles blown, and the caps have long since flown from the tops of giant brown bottles of beer. A bunch of hard-case southern sheilas battling it out for the title of the southern man's Perfect Woman - tipping rams, digging in fence posts, reversing farm bikes and trailers of hay. The 10 finalists followed up on the Sunday with a repeat of those events as well as tipping a ram into the shearing position ... (Nov 2, 2002,Dominion Post,F12)

tip dip¶

1 n. (Rural) a platform sheep dip or plunge dip in which sheep are plunged from above into the dipping fluid.

NEWTON This has been fairly good going for a tip dip. (1949,High Country,102)

tip down¶

v. rain heavily

I surreptitiously unbuttoned my trouser's fly and released a gentle, uncontrolled flow of urine on to the gabardine overcoat of the unsuspecting Scots College boy sitting in front of me. Try doing that at Westpac Stadium, even when it is tipping down. (May 22, 2004,Dominion Post,E6)

tip grazer¶

1 n. (Rural) a farm animal that grazes the top of pasture.

Because angoras are tip grazers, they need at least 10 cm of grass in an ideal situation. (2002,Lifestyle Farmer,June/July 25)

tip it¶

n. a guessing game

[In the Lyttelton Gaol]"Tip it' is something after the style of eggs in the bush. You have one button and some two or three fellows play another two or three. One side guesses which hand of the others contains the button. If they don't guess right it scores one against them. If they do, they take the button and the others guess. (1895,Diary of Jonathan Roberts,32)

tip tap¶

n.

SUTTON-SMITH J.A.Lee in his Children of the Poor (1939) mentions the game of knocking on doors. It was known also as Tip Tap (1885; Waikouaiti). Another widely known trick was Jingle the Penny: `We tied a string to a penny with a hole in it, then hid behind a hedge or on top of a verandah. As a person stooped to pick it up, we would whisk it away' (1895; Ngakawau). (1981,History of Children's Play,90)

tip-cat¶

n. 1930-35 West Coast children's game (R. B. McLuskie) A piece of wood with squared sides numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, but tapering to bevelled points at each end, is struck on the bevelled end with a batten so that it spins and lands with one numbered side uppermost. From that number a sequence of ? tasks is given.

Tommy Packer was playing tip cat on the pavement, and he hit the cat with his stick, and tipped it, all muddy, straight into the masher's face. (Jun 13, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

STEWART Tip-cat's out and hoops are in.' (1983,Springtime in Taranaki,101) [NOTES: 1991 edition]

tip-dray¶

v. (See dray)

tip-head¶

n.

MITCHELL I got over the hill to Port Lyttleton, and got a job keeping a tip-head on some reclamation work that was going on there. (1889,Rhymes and Rambles,19)

Waggons are met at what is known as the tiphead. (1901,NZ Illustrated Magazine,4/612)

In the Tokatea area the vein is well exposed in the bed of the Whakaroa Creek, just below the `tip-head' of the Harbour View low-level. (1907,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No 4 (N.S.)/120)

tipa¶

n.

BURTON Definitely a luxury is the queen scallop or tipa of the Maori. ... Scallops occur throughout New Zealand in muddy and sandy flats, the main beds occurring in Tasman Bay and the Marlborough Sounds. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,61)

tipani¶

n.

CAMPBELL She wore a tipani flower in her right ear. (1989,Frigate Bird,42)

tipare¶

n. a headband [ORIGIN: Maori]

MITCALFE And then ... a whole set of newly-made tipare from Te Hapua. (1985,Hey Hey Hey,155)

It's a look he seldom varies, except when he looses his hair, puts on tipare (headband), piupiu (flax skirt) and tatua (ceremonial sash) to lead Manutake in haka. (Dec 2004,North & South,64)

Grace Another idea was to get some of the young girls to dress in piupiu, bodice and tipare and be available to have photographs taken with tourists. (2001,Dogside Story,252)

tipau¶

n.

LEE & KENDALL T|ipau, s. A shrub so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,213)

POLACK Many other trees abounded in Pamaki [a's-acute], such as the kaikatea [a2-acute], towai, rewa-rewa, totara [a's-acute], puriri, rata [a's-acute], kahika [a2-acute], tipow, tanikaha [a2-acute], rimu, and various kinds of akkas, all of which will be found described in the Appendix (Note 7). Ibid. 2/399 The Tepau is a similar wood to Towai. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/109)

WILLIAMS The Tipau, although not remarkable yet a stately tree. [Glossary 120 ... Suttonia australis or the larger S. salicina]. (1844,NZ Journal,106,1956 ed.)

HOOKER Suttonia australis, A.Rich. ... Nat. names, Mapau',Sipau', and Matipo', Middle Island, <i> Lyall.</i>Tipau', north of the Thames river, and `Mapua', south of that river, Colenso. ... A small leafy tree, very closely resembling Pittosporum undulatum in appearance. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 172)

HOOKER Tipau, Col[enso]. Myrsine Urvillei and salicina. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Black Mapau, or Tipau (Pittosporum Colensoi). A shrub tree, very ornamental in contrast with the last [White Mapau], the whole tree very dark coloured... Black Mapau, Tipau (Pittosporum tenuifolium). Ibid. 39 Tipau. Pittosporum tenuifolium, Banks and Sol. Ibid. 46 Tipau. Myrsine Urvillei, A. D.C. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/33) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Of our shrubs and smaller timber trees, several are of strikingly beautiful growth ... (e.g.) the Houhere, Hoheria populnea ...; the Horopito Drimys axillaris.. the Tipau, Myrsine Urvillei and M. salicina.. and, on the sea-coast, ... the Karo, Pittosporum crassifolium and the truly evergreen Ngaio, Myoporum laetum ... Ibid. 1/III/48 The Tipau, or Mapau, (Myrsine australis,) is a small leafy tree ... more plentiful at the north. (Myrsine salicina.) (1869,TrNZI,1/III/5) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

KIRK MAPAU.- (Myrsine australis.) (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,20)

[Native name] Tipau .. [Settlers' name] Tipau .. [Family] Myrsineae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,122) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 122]

CHEESEMAN M[yrsine] Urvillei, D.C. ... Mapau; Tipau (1906,Manual NZ Flora,432)

The following is a list of the Auckland contributions towards the Vienna Exhibition .. tepau, myrsine salicina ... (Jan 23, 1873,Daily Southern Cross,2)

tipi¶

n.

TREGEAR `Ducks and drakes' (tipi) were made [57] by throwing flat stones so as to skip along the surface of the water. (1904,Maori Poetry,56)

tipo¶

n. (See taipo)

tiporu¶

n. (Rural) a variety of farmed native flax, Phormium tenax. [ORIGIN: Maori]

Tiporu was used plaited into plates. It grows 16' high, has very fine fibre. Specimens of this may be seen at Motuiti. (Aug 22, 1903,Farmers' Union Advocate,1)

tipper¶

n.

Before preference to unionists was passed the pay [for coal workers in the Wellington Branch of the Waterside Workers' Federation] was per hour for shovellers 1s 6d and for top hands (i.e. winchmen, bullrope-men, trimmers, and tippers), is 3d. (Jun 9, 1911,Maoriland Worker,14/12/3)

Tipperary kisses¶

n.

McCREDIE TIPPERARY KISSES ... eggs ... butter, sugar, flour and cornflour ... baking powder, essence ... Drop on cold tray; bake ,,, Press together with raspberry jam. (1915,Bungalow Recipe Book, The)

Tipperary riot¶

n.

It was a good sale. Lots of fellows got drunk and we had a regular Tiperairy riot. They stuck to the rule where ever you see a head, hit it. (Oct 16, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,62)

tippet¶

n. part of a fishing line left behind when it snags

Tippet: What you leave behind when you snag. Also known as a leader or trace, it's the fine nylon between the hook and the line proper. (Nov 28, 2004,Sunday Star Times: Escape,12)

tipping pen¶

n. (Rural) a pen holding six to eight sheep with a floor than can be tipped, spilling the sheep into a pot dip. [also tip]

STEVENS The sloping surface which gives a slide in from the side of a bath, the tipping pen in which the floor moves from the horizontal to a steep angle, and the turntable pen, all have the common purpose of getting the sheep into the bath with a minimum of effort and with little risk of injury to the sheep. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,86)

tippy¶

adj. wool with a very pointed tip to the staple

1 adj. (Rural) [of fleece-wool staple] the projection of thick fibres beyond the fine ones at the tip end.

Evenness of fleece is always to be preferred to a fleece which is particularly good on one part of the carcase and weak on another part. Avoid "tippy" wool as much as possible. (Sep 15, 1913,NZ Journal of Agriculture,238)

DU FAUR The hoggets with short-stapled, hairy, very "tippy" fleeces or with poor quality wool, or undesirable wool count, can be marked for culling. (1966,Sheep Farming for Profit,151)

The end of the staples should be blunt (not tippy). (Dec 1976,NZ Journal of Agriculture,20)

MAF Tippy: Wool with a very pointed tip to the staple. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,60)

SQUIRE Tippy - the pointed projection of thicker fibres above the thinner fibres at the tip end of this type of wool staple. Sometimes medullated, weathered, and/or harsh handle. (1991,A to Z Glossary of Wool Terms,39)

In a study of `tippy' or unlevel dyeing of loose wool ... he found that ... samples from the back ... of the sheep dye unlevel ... (1938,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,20/250B)

Wool with a very pointed tip to the staple. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,60)

Tippy: Wool with an extra amount of grease at the tip. (Feb 23, 1920,Ashburton Guardian,2)

tips¶

n.

SUTTON-SMITH Here are some [marble] terms from Taranaki around 1880-1890: firsts, lay-up, stakes, tips, sticking-taw, nothings, anythings, fade-it, knuckledown stiff, dubs, finking [sic, ?funking], sips, spanning, placing; and from Dunedin School in 1949: knee high, manyies, tracks, screws, nuts, sleets, kills, forces, dig, dubs, cheats. (1981,History of Children's Play,269)

tipsy cake¶

n. equivalent to present-day trifle without fruit

MURDOCH TIPSY CAKE ... wine over a ... sponge ... sweet almonds, stick them all over the cake; ... ratifias [sic]. Pour ... custard ... brandy (1887,Dainties ... How to Please Our Lords and Masters,63)

TIPSY CAKE Soak the cake in brandy ... almonds ... all over ... Pour the custard over and garnish with whipped cream. (1910,Colonial Everyday Cookery,205)

TIPSY CAKE ... sponge cake ... sherry ... brandy ... sweet almonds ... rich custard ... Make a small hole in the centre of the cake and pour in and over the cake, sherry and brandy ... Place whipped cream over cake before almonds if desired. (1924,Help the Babies Cookery Book,80)

TIPSY CAKE ... Savoy cake in slices ... glass dish ... white wine ... rum over ... served with custard; ... blanched almonds or glace cherries and whipped cream. (1932,St Andrew's Cookery Book,138)

tipua¶

n.

tipua: goblin. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

BAUCKE ... directly [the Maori] enters the domain of witchcraft, tipau' (ghouls),patupaiarahe' (fairy demons), dreams, or tohunga imbecilities, he becomes a fear-haunted, helpless perverter of truth! (1905,Where the White Man Treads,63)

tipuna¶

n. ancestor, grandparent [ORIGIN: Maori, [Ma. tipuna Ancestor, grandparent.] cf. P.M. Ryan Dict. Modern Maori (1995) 261.] (See tupuna)

There were songs for aunties and uncles, tipuna and mokopuna all over the island. (Jul 17, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),64)

HULME Tipuna = grandfather/mother (1983,Bone People, The,469 [p] 383)

HOWE Tipuna (Tupuna) - are the ancestors and/or the grandparents, and as such the retainers of the language, and the holders of knowledge. Fortunate is the Maori who has had the chance to learn from the experience of their tipuna. (1985,Towards Taha Maori,23)

Only his tipuna' had had the gift of communication, and now he was dead, while Danny'skuia' thought of nothing but Pakeha mores. (Dec 1986,Landfall,160/492) [NOTES: (Smither)]

How will we stand united and with mana, as our tipuna did? (Jul 26, 2005,Wairarapa Midweek,32)

He ushers me into his lounge, where the walls are heavy with portraits of his tipuna. (Mar 8, 2003,Dominion Post,F12)

.. each hole sports a carved pou that embodies a tipuna of the local tohunga who carved them. (Oct 9, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

tipuna rights¶

n. ancestral rights

...our kaumatua were very clear that we draw a distinction between customary rights as defined at common law (which naturally have some affinity with private property rights) and what we call "tipuna rights", which are substantially and substantively different. (Oct 14, 2003,Dominion Post,B4)

tipuna whare¶

n. ancestors' house? [ORIGIN: Maori]

The final stages of the Tangihanga have now begun. The men carry Wiki's mother and put her onto the front of the tipuna whare, Tane-Nui-A-Rangi. (May 23, 2006,NZ Herald,E7,The College Herald ed.)

tira-oua-ke¶

n. (See tiraueke)

tirairaka¶

n. fantail

BULLER RHIPIDURA FLABILLIFERA. (PIED -FANTAIL.) ... Native names. Piwaiwaka, Tiwai-waka, Piwakawaka, Tirairaka, Pirairaka and Tiwakawaka and Pitakataka. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/69)

tirakara¶

n. fantail

YATE Piwakawaka, or Tirakaraka - This restless little bird is continually on the wing, or hopping from twig to twig. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),57)

LUSH I have already [?seen]there in numbers the Tui, the Tirakara and the Kingfisher. I have also seen a fine Owl. (Jun 23, 1857,Auckland Journals,189,1971 ed.)

tirakau¶

n. [[check if this is correct???]]

CHEESEMAN C[ordyline] australis, Hook.f. ... Ti; Ti-kauka; Ti-rakau; Palm-lily. ... Universally known to New Zealand residents by the inappropriate name of `cabbage-tree'. Maori ti raakau (1906,Manual NZ Flora,706)

tirango¶

n.

Names - The general name is upokororo ("head full of brains"), derived from the fatness which characterizes it. The small ones are also called rehe, and the large size tirango. (1926,TrNZI,58/638) [NOTES: (Buck)]

tiraueke¶

n.

DIEFFENBACH 33. Creadion carunculatus. G.R.Gray, ...Tieke of the natives of Tasman Bay. Quoy and Gaim. Tiaka or Purourou of the natives. Yate. Tira-oua-ke [e-acute] of the natives. Less. Tierawaki, Cook's Straits. Dieffenbach. ibid 192 - 35. ... Mr Polack also mentions a lark-like bird, of a black colour, under the native name of Purourou, which I do not think belongs to this genus. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/292) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/192]

DIEFFENBACH Another bird, the tierawaki (Jeterus rufisater, Less.), is very common. It is as large as a blackbird, of a jet-black plumage, with red-brown coverlets of the wings and tail. It has two small orange-coloured appendages at the base of the beak. This bird is seen on the lower branches of trees, is very lively, and has a loud penetrating note. It always screams when anything attracts its attention - huei, huei, tierawak, tierawak. It feeds principally on fleshy berries, but also on coleopterous insects. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/147)

BULLER CREADION CARUNCULATUS. (THE SADDLE-BACK.) ... Native names. Tieke, Tiraweke, {Tirauweke,} and Purourou. [151] It is naturally a noisy bird, and when excited or alarmed becomes very clamorous, hurrying through the woods with cries of `tiaki-rere', quickly repeated. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,150,{1888 2nd edn 1/18} ed.)

tireeraka¶

n.

Birds seen occasionally [on Three Kings were] kingfishers - kotaretare (Halcyon sanctus); moreporks - koko (Ninox novae-zealandiae); fantails - tireeraka (Rhipidura flabellifera); ... (1930,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,11/154) [NOTES: Fraser]

Tiri¶

n. New Zealand's first pirate radio ship

The actuallest actuality of all is probably the live commentary by a DJ on board the pirate radio ship Tiri, as it ran aground in 1868. (Apr 22, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

Pictures of the Tiri, the boat Hauraki originally broadcast from, clutter the corners along with a Tiri life preserver placed strategically on the wall. (Jul 1, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),63)

tiritea¶

n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of wheat. [ORIGIN: Maori]

Tiritea was bred from the same parental combination that gave rise to Rongotea. Tiritea resembles its sister line, Rongotea, in height and maturity. Tiritea grains are compared with Takahe. (May 1982,NZ Journal of Agriculture,23)

Tiriti¶

n. Treaty (of Waitangi) [ORIGIN: Maori]

Mr Chapman also raised the interesting question of whether or not the tiriti was abrogated by the 1845-72 Anglo-Maori wars. If these wars were a case of foreign invasion, then the members of those tribes which resisted did lose the rights conferred by the tiriti. (Aug 9, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),11)

There is, however, nothing in either the Tiriti or in the English translation to suggest that Maori agreed to the hyper-colonisation that occurred during the next 60 years and which saw the settler population jump from around 2000 in 1840 to 1,000,000 in 1900. (Jan 31, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

tishy¶

n.

WOODHOUSE A customary test [for wet wool] was to rub a cigarette tishy along the wool next to the skin. (1972,Blue Cliffs,226)

tissue¶

n. a cigarette paper

Might just as well settle down to rolling your own. Better go and see if the parole-jumper in Number 8 has got any tissues left. (Jan 1952,Here & Now,2/4:32)

TURNER A tissue is a cigarette paper. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,164)

tit¶

n. teat [ca1935 Havelock children's rhyme Johnny come milk the bull,/Only one tit to pull:/Pulled the wrong tit/Got covered in shit,/O Johnny come milk the bull.] (See also pussy's tit)

BROWN [The cockies] labour at the `tits'. (1900,Lay of Bantry Bay,32,1917 ed.)

n. ngirungiru [one general use]

It was ideal country [Nelson] for birds, Bush Canaries, Tits (Myiomoira macrocephala), Fantails (Rhipidura fuliginosa), Grey Warblers ... . (1936,NZ Naturalist,54)

n. almost a polite taboo word in NZ with assoc of breast see also TOMTIT 1. simplex [no cits] -

... to hear the little Grass-bird utter its unchanging note u-tick, u-tick, as rising on feeble wings that just sustained it to the sheltering grass ... beneath the ... flax bush, whence perhaps the Tit (Petroica) darted to the ground ... Ibid. 2/60 PETROICA TOITOI, Less. and Garn. Tit. (1870,TrNZI,2/47) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

The tit (Myiomoira), the fantail (Rhipidura), the wax-eye (Zosterops), ... also appear to be in no danger of extinction ... (1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/328)

2 n.

Tit Petroica macrocephala (GMELIN, 1789) .. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,284)

2 n.

2 n.

tit-proud¶

adj.

This is no question to obsess his heart/ ... a tit-proud blonde to tickle up desire. (May 1956,Numbers,1/12/16) [NOTES: (Packer)]

tit/titty¶

n. of a car, engine, etc., acceleration: herbs, juice, power [ca1940 Blenheim (Jack Columbus) `Give her a bit more tit (titty)' means accelerate]

titaha¶

n.

(1966,Short Stories (various authors),239) [NOTES: [Check~sense]]

titahi¶

n.

WILSON After the cross sticks were tied to the uprights, the frame was thatched with titahi grass roots and all beginning at the bottom and working up to the hole in the roof. (1979,Titi Heritage,86)

titerack¶

n.

White-capped Noddy ... OTHER NAMES: Black noddy, lesser noddy, titerack. ... In New Zealand breeds at the Kermadec Islands ... (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,234)

titi¶

n. [attrib. uses (and one compound)]

In 1982, zoologists John Warham and Graham Wilson estimated that there were 3,287,000 titi burrows on the Snares. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/65)

IHIMAERA & LONG I am as fat-rich as a titi-chick, ready for the far ocean flight. (1982,Into the World of Light,261)

HULME & MORRISON Winter is for me (and a large number of Maori, and not a few Pakeha) titi time. (1989,Homeplaces,13)

LAWLOR When titi time's at hand / There come from far and near / The Maori folk (1935,Confessions of a Journalist,113)

n. muttonbird [ORIGIN: Maori]

During summer months the sky at dusk is flecked with uncountable numbers of titi returning to their nests from sea. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/65)

mutton bird - tee' tee' [titi] (1826,Boultbee Journal,113,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 113; see also 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 285 (|= macron precedes)]

DIEFFENBACH 67. Pelecanoides urinatrix, Cuv. Procellaria ... Forst. Teetee of the natives of Queen Charlotte's Sound. Forst. 70. Procellaria Cookii. ... [200] Titi of the natives. Dieffenbach. (1842,Travels in NZ,2/199) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/199,200]

HURSTHOUSE The young Titi (mutton-bird), a species of puffin, is caught by the Southern natives in great quantities ... (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/121)

THOMSON The young Titi (mutton-bird), a species of puffin, is caught by the Southern natives in great quantities ... (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/28)

CLARKE ... I have not yet been able to make much progress in negotiating, on behalf of the Government, with the Natives for the purchase of Stewart's Island, on account of the absence of many of the Natives interested, who are engaged catching titi (mutton birds), nor shall I be able to do much till they return. (Mar 30, 1864,Letter) [NOTES: 1864 Mar 30 N.T.Clarke in 1979 Wilson Titi Heritage 136]

Pelecanoides urinatrix. Titi. Very numerous. (1869,TrNZI,1/161) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

HUTTON 124. HALADROMA URINATRIX. Gml. Diving Petrel. Titi. Pelecanoides urinatrix. GRAY. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,45)

BULLER PUFFINUS BREVICAUDUS {TENUIROSTRIS}. BRANDT'S {BONAPARTE'S} SHEARWATER. ... Native name{s}.- Titi {Hakoakoa, and Hakuakua}. Ibid. 317{1888 2nd edn 2/232} PUFFINUS TRISTIS {GRISEUS}. (SOMBRE SHEARWATER.) ...Native names.- Titi, Hakoakoa, and Totorore: `Mutton-bird' of the colonists. ... when hovering overhead at night [Titi] utter a frequent call-note, like tee-tee-tee, from which the Maori name is derived. [Check that some of this may be 1888 edn only.] (1873,Birds of New Zealand,315,{1888 2nd edn 2/230} ed.)

In that great battle, the two birds, the tiitii (Haladroma urinatrix = petrel), and the taiko, were made prisoners by the river-birds ... [fn] Of this bird, the Taiko, I have formerly heard, particularly at the northern parts of the North Island, but have never seen one. (1879,TrNZI,11/103) [NOTES: (Colenso)]

BULLER Native name.- Titi. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/217)

FALLA et al. SOOTY SHEARWATER Puffinus griseus Other names: Muttonbird, Titi. Ibid. 52 COOK'S PETREL Pterodroma cooki Maori name: Titi (1966,Birds of New Zealand,42)

Titi n. New Zealand sea-bird, the diving-petrel [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

titi ... n. N.Z. sea-bird, the diving-petrel [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

44. Pterodroma [cookii cookii] (Gray, 1843) Cook's petrel (Titi) Ibid. 27 61. Puffinus griseus (Gmelin, 1789) Sooty Shearwater (Titi) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,24,1980 ed.)

JENKIN There is a Maori saying that when the hakuwai calls, all the titi (muttonbirds) come to the mouth of their burrows and listen. (1970,NZ Mysteries,157)

SANSOM Their next venture, after the muttonbird season was over, ws to run ketes of birds, the titis, up to the Otago heads ... (1970,Stewart Islanders,158)

LOCKLEY Taiko' is the name for any large muttonbird, once abundant on all mountain ranges from the Waitakeres to the Rimutakas of the North Island. In thegood old days', each Maori village had it own taiko colony, which was visited in the autumn to collect the fat `titi' (young birds). (1980,House Above the Sea,188)

BURTON On the southern coasts and in the Bay of Plenty, the greatest delicacy was the muttonbird or sooty shearwater, a type of seabird known to the Maori as titi. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,9)

Mottled Petrel Pterodroma inexpectata (FORSTER, 1844) ... OTHER NAMES: Scaled petrel, Peale's petrel, rainbird, korure, titi. Ibid. 80 Cook's Petrel Pterodroma cookii GRAY, 1843) ... OTHER NAME: Titi. ... [81] Many years ago, adult and young Cook's petrels were taken for food by Maoris. Ibid. 96 Sooty Shearwater Puffinus griseus (GMELIN, 1789) ... [97] OTHER NAMES: Titi, New Zealand muttonbird. ... Of all the various petrels serving as `muttonbirds' in New Zealand this is the most important. Ibid. 99 Hutton's Shearwater Puffinus huttoni MATHEWS, 1912 ... OTHER NAMES: Titi, pakaha, muttonbird. ... Hutton's shearwater breeds only on the South Island. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,76)

titi n. NZ = MUTTON-BIRD. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,807)

HULME & MORRISON It would also be an unhappy thing to cook titi in a hangi. (1989,Homeplaces,13)

DIEFFENBACH Its [the Mangorake's, Taranaki] banks are steep, and from one of them Tangutu dug out a titi: this bird, a Procellaria, or mutton-bird as it is commonly called, has many peculiarities. Ibid. 2/387 Titi - the mutton bird (1843,Travels in NZ,1/148)

SELWYN Eels were still the principal food of the people; but they had imported considerble numbers of titi, or mutton-bird, from the rocks about Stewart's Island. (Jan 10, 1844,Journal) [NOTES: 1844 Jan 10 Selwyn Journal in 1851 NZ Part III (Church in the Colonies VIII) 10]

WAKEFIELD The jibbering of a night-bird (called the titi-porangi) (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/330)

TAYL;OR [by Mongurewa river] In the evening there was quite a deafening noise from vast numbers of birds flying about; I found on enquiry it was the titi which is remarkable as being both a sea bird and a night bird as well ... (Dec 1, 1846,Journal,4/145)

WAKEFIELD There is also a sort of Puffin or pelicanoides, commonly called the mutton-bird, which the natives take in large quantities by lighting fires on the seaward face of the hills near the coast, into which these birds, called titi by the natives, fly, and are killed. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,165)

The petrels - there are nine kinds, and we have names of our own for them, the black burrower, the mutton-bird, the white burrower, the short-billed ti-ti, the long-billed ti-ti, the little storm petrel, and three others that we had no names for - abound on the island.' (Nov 14, 1891,Australasian, The,963, col. I) [NOTES: (`A Lady in the Kermadecs'):]

The petrels - there are nine kinds, and we have names of our own for them, the black burrower, the mutton-bird, the white burrower, the short-billed ti-ti, the long-billed ti-ti, the little storm petrel, and three others that we had no names for - abound on the island.' (Nov 14, 1891,Australasian, The,963, col. I) [NOTES: (`A Lady in the Kermadecs'):]

COLENSO A peculiar sea-bird, called by the natives tiitii, which often flies irregularly at night, making a noise resembling `tee-tee-tee', rapidly uttered (whence its name), is sometimes taken in this neighbourhood in large numbers. [fn] ... a Petrel ... not identifiable by call only: prob. a mottled petrel (Pterodroma inexpecta). (1894,Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ) [NOTES: 1894 Colenso Excursion in Northern Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 23]

MORRIS Ti-ti, n, Maori name for the sea-bird Pelecanoides urinatrix, Gmel., the Diving-petrel. Spelt also tee-tee. (1898,Austral English,471)

Tí.ti (t&emacr.́.t&emacr.), n. 1. (Zoo.l.) The mutton bird (Nectris (?) brevicaudus), so called from its note. 2. (Bot.) See TI. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

SHAND The young of many sea birds ... were used as food [on the Chathams], such as Kuaka (plover), young gulls (Ngoiro), shags (Kuau) ... Ho[o]po (the albatross), Hakoakoa (mutton bird), Taiko[macron] (a smaller-sized mutton bird of slatey blue colour), Titi[i's macron] (a still smaller size) ... (1911,Moriori People of the Chatham Islands, The,6)

The tuatara lives in the same burrows as are used by the oii, the titi and the toanui. All three of the petrels are included in the term mutton-birds. (Sep 11, 1922,Quick March,15)

COWAN Many of the offshore islands [of Stewart Island] are the breeding-places of the petrel called the mutton-bird (titi or taiko), ... (1926,Travel in NZ,(Vol II South Island) 167)

HOWARD These are the names used by the southern Maori; in the North Id. Kuaka, Parara and Titi are applied to other birds. Kuaka: Pelicanoides Urinatrix, or Diving Petrel. Black Bill. Wing 4.7 inches. Titi Wainui: Prion Turtur or Dove Petrel. Parara: Prion vittatus, or Broad-billed Petrel. Bill very wide. Wing, 9.5 inches. Titi: Puffinus Griseus or Mutton-Bird. Sooty brown. Bill horn colour. Wing, 12 inches. (1940,Rakiura,205)

BAILEY & ROTH I am a gay muttonbirder,/ ... I'm an expert at catching the titi. (1967,Shanties,136) [NOTES: [c1940] 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 136]

ZIMMERMAN We sat down at last, and then it was told me that the titi is a traditional Maori dish, a bird that is known among the Pakeha as mutton bird, because of the richness of its flesh. (1946,Where the People Sing,68)

ZIMMERMAN We sat down at last, and then it was told me that the titi is a traditional Maori dish, a bird that is known among the Pakeha as mutton bird, because of the richness of its flesh. (1946,Where the People Sing,68)

ti[i]ti[i], a sea-bird (Puffinus griseus and other spp.), mutton-bird; appear in great numbers and nest in peaty holes on cliffs on unfrequented shores, when great numbers of the young are taken and preserved in their own fat. The tuatara lizard often occupies the same burrow; but the terms of partnership are not known. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

POWELL MUTTON BIRD (Puffinus griseus), Titi or Oi of the Maoris, was and still is in the South an important item in the diet of the Maori people. (1946,Native Animals of NZ,79)

SANSOM In the house, big fire of dead tete-a-weka wood going. Two witch's pots (small edition of a whaler's try-pot) and a camp oven swinging above the fire. Titis sizzling in their own kato fat (fat from insides). Piro fat, the fine fat from the intestines, is more precious. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,154) [NOTES: 1952 Apr 20 in 1982 Sansom In the Grip of an Island 154]

SHORTLAND The "titi" or mutton bird, as it is termed by the whalers, is.. a species of puffin. Ibid. 314 TITI, a sort of puffin, called by the whalers mutton-bird. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,225)

GORDON Since the spread of rats all over the country the Titi (mutton Bird) has ceased to breed on the summits of inland cliffs and on the rocky bluffs of Lake Taupo to which it regularly resorted of old. (1938,Children of Tane,39)

The titi (mutton bird) seeks the land, and flies direct to the one bright object of its desire. (Apr 5, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,16)

The taking of Titi seems to the white man like one big picnic for the Maoris. (Mar 1937,NZ Privy Council Cases,23)

WILSON Where have all the Titi gone? (1979,Titi Heritage,[8])

DIEFFENBACH P. urinatrix Teetee... Procellaria Titi. Ibid. 200 Titi. (1842,Travels in NZ,II/199) [NOTES: Article by Gray]

EDWARDS The tables themselves are loaded: hangi food, kaimoana, trout, tuna, titi, puha, karengo. (1992,Marist Messenger,21)

As well as the titi, or muttonbirds (sooty shearwaters).. Whenua Hou is home to a variety of petrels, prions and penguins. (Sep 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 59/60)

n. variant of ti (cabbage tree) [ORIGIN: Maori]

MONRO The part of the [Canterbury] plain which we crossed ... is uniformly covered with grass ..., mixed with toi-toi and flax in the moister parts, and, in some places, thickly dotted over with the ti-ti. (1844,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 236. Also in 1898 Hocken Contributions 236, 245]

Looking up it [Molyneux River] we could trace its course through the large extent of alluvial land, by the thick fringe of ti-ti trees upon its banks, ... producing a most picturesque effect. (1844,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 249]

Soft young shoots of the titi or cabbage tree are a taste that one acquires. (Mar 1964,Te Ao Hou,46: 6)

titi islands¶

n. muttonbird islands [sometimes Titi Islands]

HOWARD ... the Titi Islands following:- Horomamae, Wharepuaitaka, Kaihuka, ... (1940,Rakiura,394) [NOTES: 1864 June 29 Deed of Sale [of Rakiura] in 1940 Howard Rakiura 394]

He used to attend the Titi Island meetings, which have always been the cause of bitter whanau quarrelling. (Oct 1998,Mana,No. 24: 68)

BEATTIE TITI ISLANDS. [heading] ... `... I was about the only old person on the titi islands this year, and do not know whether I will go again.' (1944,Maori Place-Names of Otago,83)

There is no difficulty as far as the Chatham Islands or Stewart Island are concerned, although the Census date usually coincides with the mutton-birding season, with the result that a "count" has to be made on the Titi Islands near Stewart Island. (Oct 1, 1935,Evening Post,10)

.. with a large settled population, the bottom of the Straight along the coast from Port Pegasus to Rugged Point, and Ruapuke to the Titi Islands, off Patterson's Inlet, will be found to be lined with this popular mollusc. (Jul 13, 1872,Otago Witness,8)

Most people understand in a general sort of way that the privileges in connection with the mutton bird islands, the Titi Islands, adjoining Stewart Island, are preserved solely for the benefit of the Maori people. (Jan 19, 1910,Grey River Argus,4)

titi-a-weka¶

n. (See teteaweka)

titi-wainui¶

n. Pachyptila turtur, southern fairy prion, a sea bird [also titi wainui]

GUTHRIE-SMITH We also got four kinds of Petrel in their burrows,- the Mutton Bird, Parara, Titi Wainui, and the Kuaka. (1914,Mutton Birds & Other Birds,16)

HOWARD These are the names used by the southern Maori; in the North Id. Kuaka, Parara and Titi are applied to other birds. Kuaka: Pelicanoides Urinatrix, or Diving Petrel. Black Bill. Wing 4.7 inches. Titi Wainui: Prion Turtur or Dove Petrel. Parara: Prion vittatus, or Broad-billed Petrel. Bill very wide. Wing, 9.5 inches. Titi: Puffinus Griseus or Mutton-bird. Sooty brown. Bill horn colour. Wing, 12 inches. (1940,Rakiura,205)

POWELL FAIRY PRION (Pachyptila turtur), Titi Wainui of the Maoris, is the small dove grey petrel which skims the surface of the sea in its energetic quest for food. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,79)

FALLA et al. FAIRY PRION Pachyptila turtur Maori name: Titiwainui (Stewart Island). (1966,Birds of Australia,40)

NATUSCH There are six species of prions ... of which the likeliest to be seen is the dainty fairy-prion or titi-wainui (P[achyptila] turtur . . ., (1967,Animals of NZ, The,257)

51. Pachyptila turtur (Kuhl, 1820) Fairy Prion (Titi Wainui) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,25,1980 ed.)

SANSOM With [the titi] were scatterings of the smaller titi-wainui, the Fairy Prions, and a sprinkling of kuaka, the Southern Diving Petrels, which ducked and rose on the outskirts. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,91)

Fairy Prion Pachyptila turtur (KUHL, 1820) ... OTHER NAMES: Titi-wainui, narrow-billed prion. ... Fairy prions patrol the seas in large, loose flocks. ... Fairy prions are one of New Zealand's most abundant petrels ... (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,87)

It is known by the vernacular name of fairy dove-petrel and to the Maori as titi-wainui. (Sep 6, 1030,Evening Post,17)

titiko¶

n. a univalve shellfish

KAIMOANA: Maoris gather a kitful of titiko (a univalve shellfish) from the tidal flats, a traditional right reaffirmed by recent court judgement. (Sep 7, 1986,Sunday Star (Auckland),A8)

titimako¶

n. Williams 425 Ti[i]ti[i]mako ... Anthornis melanura, bell-bird.:

BUL.LER ANTHORNIS MELANURA. (BELL-BIRD.) ... Native names. Mako, Makomako, Komako, Kokomako, Korimako, Kohimako, Kokorimako, Titimako, and Kopara. Of the above names, Korimako is most generally used by northern and Makomako by southern tribes. The Ngatiawas call this bird Rearea; and the natives of the Bay of Plenty distinguish the male and female as Kokorohimako and Titapu. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,91,{1888 2nd edn 1/85} ed.)

titiporangi¶

n.

BULLER FULIGULA NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (NEW-ZEALAND SCAUP.) ... Native names. Papango, Tetepango, Matapouri, Titiporangi, and Raipo; Black Teal' andWidgeon' of the Colonists. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,259,{1888 2nd edn 2/273} ed.)

titipounamu¶

n. rifleman (bird)

titipounamu: rifleman, forest bird. Acanthisitta chloris, bush-wren, rifleman (Williams 425) (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

FALLA et al. RIFLEMAN Acanthisitta chloris Other names: Titipounamu, Thumbie (Nelson). (1966,Birds of New Zealand,191)

239.b. Acanthisitta chloris chloris (Sparrman, 1787) South Island Rifleman (Titipounamu) (1966,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,63,1980 ed.)

Rifleman Acanthisitta chloris (SPARRMAN, 1787) ... South Island Rifleman A.c. chloris (SPARRMAN, 1787) North Island Rifleman A.c. granti MATHEWS & IREDALE, 1913. ... OTHER NAME: Titipounamu. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,264)

DIEFFENBACH 13. Acanthisitta longpipes. G.R.Gray, ... E[acute] tectee te pomou of the natives of Dusky Bay. Forst. [tectee ?misprint for teetee (1843,Travels in NZ,2/188) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/188]

HUTTON 18. ACANTHISITTA CHLORIS. Sparrm. Creeper. Titipounamu (1871,Birds of New Zealand,8)

BULLER ACANTHISITTA CHLORIS {ACANTHIDOSITTA CHLORIS}. (RIFLEMAN.) ... Native names. Titipounamu, {Kikimutu,} Kikirimutu, Pihipihi, Piripiri, Tokepiripiri, and Moutuutu. [(1873) 113] The Rifleman is the smallest of our New-Zealand birds; ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,112,{1888 2nd edn 1/113, 114} ed.)

  1. Acanthisitta chloris, Sparrm. Wren, Titipounamu, Pi-wau-wau. - Often builds in a small hole in a tree. I know one old konini which is resorted to yearly ... (Nov 1884,NZ Journal of Science,282) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

MORRIS Titipounamu, n. (spelt also Tititipunamu), n. Maori name for the bird Acanthidositta chloris, Sparm., the Rifleman (q.v.). It has many other Maori names. (1898,Austral English,471)

POWELL RIFLEMAN (Acanthisitta chloris). This is a wren and our smallest bird, being only three inches in total length. There are two forms, typical chloris from the South Island and A. chloris granti, the North Island rifleman....The Maori name is Titi-pounamu. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,86)

It's a titipounamu, and you often find him in the ti-tree scrub... It is the rifleman, very shy, and a friend of the scrub-cutter. (Feb 5, 1995,NZ Tablet,7)

titipuke¶

n. muttonbirds buried underground or deep-frozen with their guts still in them -->ca1974 Chatham Islands (Alf Martin)

titirangi¶

n. (Environment) the indigenous flowering plant, Hebe speciosa

Napuka ( Hebe speciosa ), also known as the titirangi shows off its bottle-brush flowers all year round. (Dec 2006,Growing Today,30)

HOOKER Titirangi (Middle Island), Lyall. Veronica speciosa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768 ed.)

titirangi, a plant (Veronica speciosa), one of a very numerous family. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

titiwai¶

n. the glow-worm, Archnocampa luminosa

The titiwai (stars in wet places) of Waitomo, which means water entering a shaft, have been celebrated since 1887, when they were first explored by local Maori chief Tane Tinorau. The insects feed ravenously as larvae, then briefly emerge as adult fungus gnats to mate, lay eggs and die within three days. (Dec 9, 2003,BLANK ENTRY,A11)

title¶

n. an abbreviation of certificate of title, a copy of the entry in the land titles register recording the identity and ownership of a piece of land and any legal encumbrances on it. [Jim Cameron writes : The English equivalent in relation to registered land there is land certificate. The term title deeds is sledom used in NZ. The attached clippings illustrate an aspect of its general use e.g. on separate titles, titles pending.]

Some New Zealand land law terms are uncommon or unknown in England. (Conversely the term title deeds is not much used here either by lawyers or laymen. Instead we talk of the title or certificate of title, in the concrete sense of a document which is a copy of the registry entry in the Land Transfer Office. (Jan 1999,NZWords,1)

title deeds¶

n.

The land transfer system contrasted with the older deeds system, introduced in 1841 as a reformed version of traditional English real property law whereby rights to ownership depended on the existence and validity of a chain of documents. The term title deeds derives from this. (Jan 1999,NZWords,2)

title unit¶

n.

The plan was to divide it into two title units and sell it. (Sep 12, 2000,Evening Post,13)

titmouse¶

2 n. [great-headed titmouse]

POLACK The nirungiru (Parus macrocephalus), or great-headed titmouse, is very common in the country. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/298)

tito¶

n. a fib, a lie. [ORIGIN: Maori, ca1900 King Country (J. Morison) ca1935 Havelock in pron. [|ti:tou]]

WAKEFIELD [The natives] were sure we were telling them tito, `lies'. (1845,Adventure in NZ,2/43)

POWER It is a pity [the Maories] do not extend the same condemnation to lying, which is an almost universal failing, and is considered no disgrace whatsoever ... [146] The consequence is, that the natives are generally distrustful and incredulous; and toe' andteto', lie and liar, are the words most frequently heard in their conversation, and which they apply to one another and to white men of all ranks without the least hesitation or compunction. (Dec 13, 1847,Sketches in NZ,145)

DOMETT `A tito this - a fib, I know; (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/190)

2 n. [ca1935 Havelock]

GUTHRIE ... most natives thought nothing of it, looking upon it as a joke if, finding them out in one, you called them `tito' or liar. (1930,NZ Memories,82)

titoki¶

n. a forest tree Alectryon excelsum and its timber; also formerly called New Zealand ash. [[?d] Ed. Fairburn Maharatanga 30 Titoki (this tree sometimes called New Zealand `Ash")]

When I saw the stone smash into the glasshouse, images of Sir Robert hiding behind the titoki tree like a miscreant rabbit dodging Elmer Fudd, and groans resounding from the dogged but hapless sharpshooter, leapt up and barked. (Mar 22, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

DIEFFENBACH The hair is often greased with ... an oil pressed from the seeds of the titoki (Aledron [sic] excelsum, belonging to the Sapindaceae). (1843,Travels in NZ,2/54)

(Jul 29, 1844,Report of Select Committee on NZ) [NOTES: 1844 July 29 House of Commons Report of Select Committee on NZ (And)]

WILLIAMS Amongst the most remarkable Trees is the Teehokee [Titoki] whose berry is of a dark black substance.... (1844,NZ Journal,99)

HOOKER Alectryon excelsum, DC. ... Nat. name, Titoki' andTitongi' of southern parts of North Island. Colenso. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 38)

HOOKER Titoki, Col[enso]. Alectryon excelsum. Titongi, Col[enso]. Alectryon excelsum. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

The Titoki (Alectryon excelsum), the Akeake (Dodonaea viscosa), the Ngaio (Myoporum laetum), and above all the Rewa Rewa (Knightia excelsa), yield woods, out of which some very beautiful pieces of furniture have been made. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/14) [NOTES: (Monro)]

... the curious red fruit of the Titoki, or Titongi, (Alectryon excelsum); the fruit of the Tutu-papa (Coriaria thymifolia);... and of the Kareao, or Pirita, (Rhipogonum parviflorum). (1869,TrNZI,1/III/31) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

Alectryon excelsum Titoki (1870,TrNZI,2/122) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

DOMETT The youth, with hands beneath his head,/ Against a great titoki's base (1872,Ranolf and Amohia,253) [NOTES: (Morris)]

DOMETT Alectryon (Titoki) .....O. Coriariae; G Alectryon; S. A. excelsum. A fine large forest tree. Ibid. 2/40 Against a great titoki's [o-acute] base,/ (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/302)

HECTOR Alectryon excelsum, DC. Titoki.--A beautiful tree with large panicles of reddish flowers trunk 15-20 feet high, and 12-20 inches in diameter. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,131)

[Native name] Titoki .. [Settlers' name] Titoki .. [Family] Sapindaceae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

FEATON ALECTRYON EXCELSUM (D.C.) ... The TITOKI' orTITONGI'. Ths very beautiful and valuable tree is indigenous to both Islands, but is most plentiful in the ... North Island.Ibid. 178 Titoki [Maori name] .. Titoki [Settlers' name] .. Alectryon excelsum .. Tree Titongi [Maori name] .. Titoki [Settlers' name] .. Alectryon excelsum .. Tree (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,97)

KIRK It is sometimes termed the New Zealand Ash', doubtless on account of its resembling that tree in the shape of its foliage and in the toughness of its wood, but it is most generally known as thetitoki'. (1889,Forest Flora,183)

Titoki .. Alectryon excelsum .. Timber strong and very tough; ... bark suitable for tanning (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,15)

MORRIS Titoki, n. Maori name for the New Zealand tree, Alectryon excelsum, De C., N.O. Sapindaceae. Also called New Zealand Oak and New Zealand Ash. See Alectryon. (1898,Austral English,471)

Tí.to-ki (t&emacr.́.t&omacr.-ke.; colloq. t&emacr.-t&omacr.́.ke.), n. [Maori.] (Bot.) A New Zealand sapindaceous tree (Alectryon excelsum); - called also New Zealand ash. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

... titoki or native ash [fn Alectryon excelsum.], and the totara pine [fn Podocarpus totara.] jostle one another in the dense dry bush. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,184)

CHEESEMAN A[lectryon] excelsum, Gaertn. ... Titoki. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,103)

LAING & BLACKWELL Alectryon excelsum [(The Titoki)] ... This tree is sometimes called The New Zealand Ash, and its timber is largely used. Maori name, Titoki. perversion of sense of a genuine Maori word. (1907,Plants of NZ,225,1940 p. 239 ed.)

ANGAS Oil is employed in beautifying the hair: ... expressed from the seeds of a tree called titoki, ... (1847,Savage Life,1/326)

WAKEFIELD 12. Titoki, (name not known.) This tree is also mentioned here, because it bears in great abundance berries from the inner kernel of which the natives extract a very fine oil, samples of which have been pronounced in England as peculiarly suited to the purposes of the watch-maker. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,143)

EARP The tetoki berry is a fruit resembling a raspberry, but somewhat lighter; .. (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),130) [NOTES: 1853 Allom letter in 1853 Earp NZ 130]

titoki, a tree (Alectryon excelsum), scarlet fruit with shiny black seed at tip, whence the tree (or fruit) is called crayfish-eyes: they fruit yields a scent used with the oil with which chiefs anoint themselves, apparently plentifully once every three years or so, whence the proverb applied to an upstart: "Chief of the titoki year," since anyone can use the scent that year. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

LARGE TREE, NEW ZEALAND ASH. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

Titoki is the New Zealand ash.'I always thought it was something else.' [laughter] [see 2. below] (Nov 6, 1952,2ZB) [NOTES: ca1952 Nov 6 2ZB `Taylor's Quiz']

A small, handsome New Zealand tree. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),415)

Titoki n. New Zealand tree, kind of ash or oak [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

titoko ... n. N.Z. tree, kind of ash or oak; [Maori] mixed drink, usually lemonade or raspberry essence, and beer. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

titoki n. red-flowering NZ tree yielding a tough timber. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,807) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

WAKEFIELD The berry of the titoki tree might be turned to account. The natives extract a very fine oil from it. (1845,Adventure in NZ,2/317)

Upon the hill behind the house is the grove of titoki Alectryon excelsus, the trees from which the garden takes its name. (Apr 1998,North & South,94)

HIGGINS in LE PROU We ate bull-a-bulls flour, fuchsia, red pines, tetoke. (1989,Waters Back,17) [NOTES: Citation from 1842]

Titoki, better known as New Zealand ash, has poisonous fruit. (Feb 3, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),25)

HUNT We ate lots of nikau too, and lawyer berries - they were like raspberries - and miro and titoki berries. (1981,Speaking a Silence,29)

HEAPHY There are many natural productions of the country ... One of these is the oil of the Pitoku berry, which is of very fine quality, and much used by the natives in anointing their hair. It is a sweet and pleasantly-tasting oil ... The berry is small, of a brown colour, and very unctuous, with but little taste as a fruit. The tree is wild in every part of New Zealand. (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),43)

A surprise find was that the fruit of Syzygium maire or swamp maire had more than 18 times the level of antioxidants while the berries of Alectron excelsis or titoki contained more than 12 times the level. (Feb 28, 2006,Dominion Post,A3)

BOTANICAL DRAWINGS, COLORED. XII. - The Titoki and the Taua in fruit. (May 28, 1853,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,2)

In places where they can be established the native karaka is a fine tree, also the koe-koe and titoki - in fact, so are many others. (Apr 20, 1912,Evening Post,12)

n. (Rural) a shandy or beer and raspberry. [ORIGIN: Maori]

HUNT Then very often you'd get a Maori ask for a 'titoki' at the pub and that was a stout with a drop of raspberry in it. No one understands what you're talking about if you ask for a titoki in a pub today. (1981,Speaking a Silence,29)

MCGILL titoki: a beer/lemonade/raspberry shandy(gaff) from its similarity to titoki berry juice. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,113)

2 n. a beer; a shandy [cf. matai beer cf also used for ?stout and raspberry (?red with a black head, or vice versa)] (See cf. matai beer)

... this reminiscence reminds me, too, of the variety of bush berries which we children would eat [in Carterton in the 1860s] - the white pine berries, the runi-runi, and ti-toke, these last very much resembling a raspberry, with a black seed on the head of it. (Feb 10, 1921,Quick March,13)

PARTRIDGE Ti-toki. A mixed drink of beer, lemonade and raspberry: New Zealanders': C. 20. Ex Maori. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,881)

BAKER ... when we call a shandygaff titoki we are giving an authentic native word a meaning it has never had before. (1941,NZ Slang,56)

PARTRIDGE Titoki. A shandygaff: New Zealand: C. 20. B., 1941. (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1204)

Titoki is the New Zealand ash.'I always thought it was something else.' [laughter] (Nov 2, 1952,2ZB) [NOTES: ca1952 Nov 6 2ZB `Taylor's Quiz']

titoko ... n. N.Z. tree, kind of ash or oak; [Maori] mixed drink, usually lemonade or raspberry essence, and beer. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

HUNT Very often you'd get a Maori ask for a `titoki' at the pub and that was a stout with a drop of raspberry in it. (1981,Speaking a Silence,29)

McGILL titoki a beer/lemonade/raspberry shandy (gaff), from its similarity to titoki berry juice. [Acland] (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,113) [NOTES: [cf OED]]

titoki berry¶

n.

Around December-January, you might also spot titoki berries on the track. A fleshy scarlet [sic] fruit holds a glossy black seed in a woody capsule. (Jan 5, 2005,Dominion Post,C2)

titoki fruit borer¶

n.

MOORE & IRWIN The growing seed is often destroyed by the titoki fruit borer, a caterpillar that feeds only on this species. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,92)

titongi¶

n. (See titoki)

titri¶

n. Olearia lineata

WRIGHT TITRI. - The name given in Otago for Olearia lineata. Not to be confused with tea-tree (manuka) or ti-tree (cabbage-tree palm). (1945,Station Ballads,63) [NOTES: [check 1897]]

tits on toast¶

phr.

HUNT We'd make dumplings, too, fried up in the camp oven. Buggers afloat we called them [c1916] ... And what did we call the poached eggs? A pair of bastards on a raft, and we'd have tits on toast - belly pickled pork on toast. I still use those old names; everyone laughs at me. (1985,I'm Ninety-five,29) [NOTES: (Bill Henderson)]

titted¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of cows] having teats.

To identify cows which are treated or three titted paint them on the legs with red tailpaint, stays on a lot longer than spray markers. (Feb 10, 2002,RD1.com,Farm Management)

titter¶

n. a young woman, a girl [some NZ specificity, via whalers; in OED from 1819]

BAKER (1941,NZ Slang,11)

(1953,Landfall,7/3/179)

The man who knows when he is well off is the bloke who has spliced a wealthy titter. (Sep 9, 1911,NZ Truth,5)

Who were those two young titters in white, who do not reside many miles from the police station in Manakau Road, who were playing up such pranks in the moonlight, outside Whitaker's paddock last Sunday evening? (Apr 4, 1891,Observer (Auckland),18)

It was my lot to be seated with two titters in front and a seat full behind. (Nov 15, 1890,NZ Observer,9)

tittie-bottle¶

n. a baby's feeding bottle

FINLAYSON Feed'em with a tittie-bottle. (1948,Tidal Creek,49)

tittlebat¶

n.

The lady [Clara Butt] came to New Zealand, and I followed my invariable plan, and told the truth about her. What the TRIAD had to say (while Mr Tacon and the other tittlebats squealed) went forth. (Jan 10, 1910,Triad, The,3)

tituriwhatu-pukunui¶

n. [red breasted plover] (See also tuturiwhatu-pukunui)

CHARADRIUS OBSCURUS, Gml. Tituriwhatu-pukunui. Red-breasted Plover. (1870,TrNZI,2/68) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

tiutiukata¶

n. [ORIGIN: Maori]

BULLER TURNAGRA HECTORI. (NORTH ISLAND THRUSH.) ... Native names. Piopio, {Koropio,} Korohea, and Tiutiukata. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,135,{1888 2nd edn 1/26} ed.)

tivaevae¶

n. [Samoan word now entering NZ vobulary]

I made a tivaevae for my son Johann. All the people who loved him would stitch a little bit of their love and affection into the quilt. (Apr 29, 2004,Dominion Post,D2)

The most beautiful present, a rare and precious gift indeed, was a red and white tivaevae with a pineapple patttern, which now graces the bed in our spare room in un-tropical Auckland. (Nov 2, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

tiver¶

n. potato [NOTE: In view of the meanings and varieties in spelling above, it is not improbable that the word represents the name of one Stivers, who is said to have visited the Bay of Islands before Cook. [See] Lee and Kendall's Grammar p. 107] (See also taewa,tawai)

MARSDEN [The old chief] told us he had seen three generations and was in the middle life when the first ship came to New Zealand. The captain's name was Stivers. [fn] Sta[?]ivers, hence another name for the potato, taewa, since he apparently supplied some seed.] (Oct 20, 1819,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,208,1932 ed.)

[The chief] expresses grief that his `tivers', potatoes, are all gone. (1841,NZ Journal,2/32/92) [NOTES: (John Pierce)]

[The natives] boiled some tea and tivers (potatoes). (1843,NZ Journal) [NOTES: (W. Ferguson) 1842 (1843) Letters from Settlers 46]

SAM. STEPHENS [A Maori says] iti-iti bit of ground to grow the tawai (potatoes) and the leeks. (1843,Letters & Journals,113)

tivots¶

n. new kids [1951 14-16 M 59 Wellington H.S. 25 TIVERPS [?=twerps] -->1951 14-16 M 59 Wellington H.S. 25 TIVOTS]

tiwai-waka¶

n. (See tiwakawaka)

tiwaikawaka¶

n. (See tiwakawaka)

tiwakawaka¶

n. Rhipidura spp., fantail [includes tiwaikawaka, tiwai waka, tiwai-waka; cf similar words with initial p]

LEE & KENDALL T|i waka waka; A bird so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,214)

POLACK They had simply decorated their hair ... with the pretty yellow flower of the towai, which hung in heavy clusters from that tree on the banks of the stream ... From their ears were appended the dried feathered skin of the towakawaka-bird [sic : a's-acute; ?error for tiwakawaka], whose body, when living, is scarcely larger than a walnut. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/113)

RHIPIDURA FULIGINOSA, Sparrm. Tiwaikawaka. Black Fan-tail. The Black Fan-tail Flycatcher breeds under conditions so very similar to those of the preceding species, that one description will serve for both. (1870,TrNZI,2/63) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

BULLER RHIPIDURA FLABILLIFERA. (PIED -FANTAIL.) ... Native names. Piwaiwaka, Tiwai-waka, Piwakawaka, {Tirairaka, Pirairaka} and Tiwakawaka {and Pitakataka}. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,143,{1888 2nd edn 1/69} ed.)

HAY The Waka-waka (Rhipidura flabellifera) is the robin of our Brighter Britain. It is a fantail, or flycatcher. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/226) [NOTES: [check spg waka-waka]]

Rhipidura flabellifera, Gml. Pied Fantail, Pied Flycatcher, Ti-waka-waka [36] Rhipidura fuliginosa, Sparrm. Black Fantail, Black Flycatcher, Ti-waka-waka. (Mar 1885,NZ Journal of Science,35) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]
