55/159 ti[i]wakawaka, a bird, the black fantail, see pi[i]wakawaka. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

HILLIARD A fantail flickered across the glade, tiwakawaka, tiwakawaka. (1965,Power of Joy,179)

And what said Kupe of you,/O small bird of grace?/He said: "The Tiwai Waka/Kept flitting past my face!" (Jul 11, 1936,Evening Post,8)

tiz¶

n.

to have/throw a tiz: to show anger (1980,Lynfield College, Auckland) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

tizzie¶

n. a sixpenny piece (??occas. a shilling) (the 1873, 1984 cits reveal a play on TANNER and TIZZY, both contemp. colloq. for 6d) [also tizzy]

DILKE [The Hokitika newsboy put a newspaper] into my hand. How much?' I askedAy-a tizzy.' Understanding this more familiar term, I gave him a shilling. [Is Dilke merely advertising his generosity] (1868,Greater Britain,1/332) [NOTES: [see snapper]]

That 'ere eye is aweeping to think that there ain't a tizzy in the [?] to vet the other. (1869,Punch or the Auckland Charivari,140)

We are now in the thick of the cross examinatn. by Sheehan of the chiefest of the apostles - Tizzey the Tanner (ko Tanera). ... We have not found anything that can be called a rat; nor even got the scent very strong. But I must not report upon Heret[aunga]. (Apr 6, 1873,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/347) [NOTES: (C.W.Richmond, Napier)]

Following are other local money-names...6d. - tizzie, sprat or tanner... (Jan 14, 1899,Sydney Bulletin,(Red Page)) [NOTES: (Letter from Loafer, Tauranga) [Bill Pearson]]

WALL A sixpence was a `tizzy', a term not yet quite extinct. (1958,Queen's English, The,97)

TURNER The word tray and its variants for threepence' and zack fprsixpence' are said to be common Australianisms but are not known to me in New Zealand. Tizzie, perhaps from tester, is said to have been current in New Zealand, but again I do not know it. On the other hand, a word which Baker says is not current in New Zealand is one I have long known, razoo. ... The word razoo refers to no particular amount of money but is used in the negative I haven't got a razoo', or, more often,I haven't got a brass razoo'. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,133)

HARGREAVES Sixpence [:] tanner, sprat, tizzy, bender, snapper (1972,From Beads to Banknotes,151)

The sixpence attracted many slang terms - tizzy, tanner, sprat, bender, and a kick.. (Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,15)

BOYD The chief lessee and purchaser was Thomas Tanner, sometimes called Tizzy the Tanner or Tommy Tickles, and by Maori, Ko Tanera. Born in 1830, the son of a Wiltshire landed proprietor, Tanner studied medicine but disliked it. In 1850 he emigrated with his young wife, Julia, ... (1984,City of the Plains,6)

Why, it is only half as bad as the tithe pig; and instead of a tizzy, they might as easily have demanded the whole hog. (For the information of those not acquainted with pure English, I may remark , that a tizzy means a sixpence; a hog, or bob, a shilling." [sic] (Dec 1, 1860,Otago Witness,5)

tizzy up¶

v. (informal) make (a person or thing) more attractive or showy; (without object) smarten up, dress up. [often as tizzied up adjective]

McGILL tizzy up dress up for an outing; probably derived from titivate'; egWell, ladies, are you going to go and tizzy up before we leave?' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,113)

McGill And, if Ron was interested, he had rescued all those old tin cigarette and petrol and soap signs from the tip, if he wanted to tizzy up his store frontage. (1995,Gold in the Creek,249)

TLA¶

abbr. three-letter acronym

...longtime Internet users especially will sprinkle written debates with TLAs (three letter acronyms - yes, they can have more than three letters). (Oct 5, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

to-and-from¶

n. a Pom [ca1978 G. McEwen Auckland and HNZD1. rhyming slang]

(Dec 12, 1984,TV2) [NOTES: The Sullivans (Aust TV soap opera)]

toa¶

n. warrior

A remark of Manuka's was rather good - Maori chiefs (leaders) were toas & went out at the head of their men, Pakeha chiefs stayed in Town and ate biscuit. [fn.] Their notion of luxury. (Dec 25, 1860,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/671,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

Tuninia was a celebrated toa ... and made use of the expression as a boastful and defiant speech addressed to some opponents. (Jun 12, 1881,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/486,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C. Wilson)]

MANING Toa - A warrior of pree[dieresis]minant[sic] courage; a hero. (1863,Old New Zealand,239)

(1953,Short Stories (various authors),19) [NOTES: 1901 Grace Tale of D.R. in 1953 Short Stories 19]

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,3/362)

COWAN Of great stature and in his prime a toa or warrior of exceptional strength and activity, he was now grown old ... (1940,Sir Donald Maclean,15)

toa, bravery; a tried warrior (possibly after the tree of that name in Polynesia). (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

toa: warrior (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

toa: warrior (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

ST BRUNO In a far corner, the few Maoris watched the pakehas making a cruel game of one of their own whiteskins. And was this the toa who had stood up to ... [100] `Bully' Krausen with his bare hands? (1952,Hellbuster, The,99)

But the Daedalus [in 17??] succeeded in taking two Maoris on board, a warrior and a tohunga [to teach flax-dressing] - rather unfortunate choices when it is considered that flax-dresssing was neither toa nor tohunga work but wahine work. (1971,NZ Heritage,1/277)

After 20 strokes, though, we had learned to loathe him and his metronomic chant as surely as we found ourselves marvelling at those toa of old, who travelled hundreds of kilometres in this way, and still had the energy to fight. (Jun 22, 2004,Dominion Post,A11)

The toa or warrior was ranked at the top level of the occupational level. (Sep 21, 2003,NZ Catholic,16)

n. champion marble

McGILL toa champion marble; from Maori for a warrior. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,102)

toadflax¶

n. a British garden plant run wild in New Zealand., linaria, yellow toad flax, also called yellow linaria

COCKAYNE But ... the toadflax, ... and the foxglove, to mention only a few British plants, are now wild in various places. (1910,NZ Plants,135)

HILGENDORF TOAD FLAX (Linaria [vulgaris]), often called linaria, and sometimes yellow toad flax, is frequent on roadsides and waste land in both islands. It is [perennial] with trailing stems up to 30 inches long. ... Four other linarias, all called toad flax, and all with spurred flowers, are found in a few localities. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,157,1967 ed.)

toadflax [s] Linaria vulgaris Mill. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,79)

TAYLOR TOADFLAX (Linaria vulgaris) ... This plant is native to Eurasia and an important weed of arable crops in Canada and Europe. (1980,Weeds of Crops,106)

toado¶

n. globefish

WILSON [GLOBE-FISH] ... Other names include Toado, Balloon-fish, Mouse-fish, (N.Z.) Rabbit-fish and Stink-fish (U.S.); and Publican-fish (Aust). Gives off an offensive odour when handled. Ibid. 261 TOADO: see Globefish or Pufferfish (1981,Fisherman's Bible,115)

MORELAND GLOBEFISH [Spheroides jaculiferus] ... Puffer, toado, common toado, are alternative names sometimes heard here. (1967,Marine Fishes,24)

2 n. globefish

DOOGUE & MORELAND GLOBEFISH ... Other names: Spheroides richei; puffer, common toado, sand toado. (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,296)

2 n. globefish

DOOGUE & MORELAND GLOBEFISH ... Other names: Spheroides richei; puffer, common toado, sand toado. (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,296)

2 n. globefish

PAUL STARRY TOADO Arothron firmamentum ... The starry toado is a large puffer ... with a regular pattern of close-set bright blue oval spots ... (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,147)

DOOGUE & MORELAND GLOBEFISH ... Other names: Spheroides richei; puffer, common toado, sand toado. (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,296)

AYLING STARRY TOADO Arothron firmamentum ... The starry toado is a large puffer ... with a regular pattern of close-set bright blue oval spots ... (1982,Collins Guide,147 or 318 (check))

2 n. a fish

Other fish to be seen, especially in the clear oceanic water off Hauturu's north-eastern faces and stacks, are clown toado, schools of spotted demoiselles, butterfly perch, maomao, trevally, kahawai and large kingfish. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/20)

AYLING CLOWN TOAO (Sharpnosed pufferfish) Canthigaster callisternus ...The clown toado is a small puffer ... (1982,Collins Guide,316,1984 ed.)

PAUL Clown toado Canthigaster callisternus Alternatively sharpnosed pufferfish. Present off south-east Australia, regularly seen around north-eastern New Zealand. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,147)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] toado, clown 2356 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

Jones mentions vivid semi-tropical fish that the polytechnic students regularly come across - clown toado, combfish, rainbow fish, Lord Howe coral fish, mado and coral shrimps. (Jun 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 52/75)

The tuatara lives in the same burrows as are used by the oii, the titi and the toanui. All three of the petrels are included in the term (Sep 11, 1922,Quick March,15)

toast rack¶

1 n. (Rural) a very thin, bony cow.

They [store cattle] can range from big, fat animals ready to kill, 'forward stores' that will be ready in a few weeks if feed is good, to walking toast racks. (2002,Lifestyle Farmer,April/May 22)

Who could forget Rob Muldoon calling a general election while obviously toasted, with Sue Wood looking for a big rock to hide under? (Feb 24, 2000,Dominion,8)

toastie pie¶

n. a type of toasted sandwich

Toastie-Pies... Next came the heating of the toastie-pie iron, the forerunner to electric jiffy makers, without burning the wooden handle. (Oct 20, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

Every week, Fly Buys books about 1500 flights with Air New Zealand and gives away 500 toastie pie machines. (Apr 28, 2004,Dominion Post,C4)

And so to the assembly of the mussel, onion and cheese toastie-pies. (Oct 20, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

McGILL Then I'd bring more books home, have a cheese toastie pie for supper. (1989,Kiwi Baby Boomers,139)

You could get anything from a toastie-pie maker to a turntable - secondhand of course. (1997,Mana,Autumn : 68)

toatoa¶

n. an endemic shrub-like bush. [Haloragis erecta a perennial shrubby bush aka Toatoa, fire weed, shrubby haloragis, not to be confused with the three toatoa pine species.]

HOOKER Toa-toa, D'Urville. Haloragis alata. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Haloragis alata Toa toa (1870,TrNZI,2/122) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

FEATON Toatoa [Maori name] .. Toatoa [Settlers' name] .. Haloragis alata .. Herb (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,178)

Tó.a-tó.a (t&omacr.́.a.-t&omacr.́.a; colloq. t&omacr.́.a-t&omacr.́.&adot.), n. [Maori.] (Bot.) A New Zealand coniferous tree (Phyllocladus glauca). Another species of (P. alpina) is called celery-topped pine. See Illust. under PINE. [Local, N. Z.] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

HILGENDORF TOA TOA (Haloragis alata [erecta]. This is a native to which no English name has become attached, though it is abundant in lowland country from Auckland to Stewart Island. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,129,1967 ed.)

RICHARDS Haloragis ... erecta ... It was used as greens by the Maoris. ... TOA-TOA (greens). (1952,Chatham Islands,129)

toatoa [=] shrubby haloragis [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,79)

WILSON Haloragis erecta TOATOA ... Perennial bushy herb with 4-angled stems, tough near the base. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,144)

HOOKER Haloragis alata, Jacq. ... Nat. name, `Toa-Toa', D'Urville. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 62)

Such are the principal conifers of New Zealand, and those which the largest dimensions; but there are others, although humble specimens enough, which are utilised for various purposes, and amongst these we must cite the toatoa (podocarpus asplenifolius, Taylor), which may be said to take the place of the cedar ... (May 25, 1865,Daily Southern Cross,5)

n. indigenous pine distinctive for large leathery leaves. [Phyllocladus toatoa, formerly P. glaucus: the 'celery' pine which grows in lower habitats than P.alpinus, the mountain toatoa.]

LAING & BLACKWELL Phyllocladus glauca (the toa-toa) is found chiefly in Northern Auckland, and was considered by Hooker to be the `most charming of all the New Zealand pines.' (1940,Plants of NZ,81)

toatoa n -s [Maori]: a New Zealand celery-topped pine (Phyllocladus glaucus) having striking whorled branches and often cultivated for ornament (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2402)

toatoa n. small New Zealand tree with bright red wood, much prized for walking sticks. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

toatoa ... n. small N.Z. tree with bright red wood, prized for walking sticks. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

toa-toa n. small NZ tree related to celery-topped pine. [M] -->OED (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,808) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

[Brown dye] is obtained from a shrub or small tree named toatoa which is said to be rather scarce. (1845,NZ Journal,V/140/119)

MORRIS Toatoa, n. Maori name of New Zealand tree, Phyllocladus glauca, Carr., N.O. Coniferae. The Mountain Toatoa is P. alpinus, Hook. (1898,Austral English,472)

n. Phyllocladus spp. (cf. also mountain toatoa)

n. an indigenous pine, the mountain toatoa. [aka toa toa; Phyllocladus alpinus aka mountain toatoa; as one of NZ's three Phyllocladus genera it is sometimes referred to as celery pine, but c.f. celery pine Phyllocladus trichomanoides. See also toatoa Phyllocladus toatoa.]

MONRO I may mention also another dye with which I saw flax stained of a rich reddish brown colour at Molyneux. It is obtained from a shrub or small tree named toa-toa, which is said to be rather scarce. (1844,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 249]

WAKEFIELD (1845,Adventures by Sea and Land,1/120)

TAY;OR ... I noticed the Toa toa the Kaikatea the totara and another Taupo pine not only growing as stunted trees but actually as creepers running many yards along the ground ... (Nov 11, 1845,Journal,3/167)

LAING & BLACKWELL Phyllocladus alpinus (The Mountain Celery Pine or Alpine Toa-toa). (1940,Plants of NZ,79)

Toa toa (Phyllocladus alpinus). Celery leaved Pine. A small tree, common on the central mountains, ... Ibid. 1/III/49 Toatoa. Phylloclades alpinus, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/32) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

From 1000 feet upwards ... in addition to the common kinds [of Pine],the Toa-toa or Celery Pine Phyllocladus alpinus) becomes abundant. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/4) [NOTES: (Hector)]

As also Toa Toa, a small Alpine pine, giving heavy and durable wood, have both a very useful appearance. (Dec 24, 1872,Star, The,2) [NOTES: Syntax correct as written.]

McDONNELL toa toa [a-acutes] (1834,Extracts From a Journal)

McDONNELL A great variety of hard-wood grows at New Zealand, admirably adapted for the timbering of any sized ships; among them is the boride[e-acute], rattar[as-acute], taraide[ase-acute], mai[a-acute], totara[a1-acute], koi katoa[a2-acute], toa[a-acute] toa[a-acute], tani raha[as-acute], to wai[a-acute], reiva[a-acute] reiva[a-acute], tana[as-acute], and many (1834,Extracts From a Journal,19,1979 ed.)

WAKEFIELD [Morris attributes this to P. glauca] The toa-toa, a small tree which is much prized by the natives for walking-sticks, and only grows, they say, in the neighbourhood of Tonga Riro. The stick underneath the bark is of a bright red colour, which takes a fine polish. [cf. 1940 Laing and Blackwell Plants of NZ 79ff] Ibid. 1/457 ... long poles made of manuka, toa toa or other hard wood. (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/120)

TAYLOR The principal trees on these [central N.I.] plains are the Tawa or beech and the toatoa, a pine, ... (Jul 10, 1846,Journal,4/81)

HOOKER Phyllocladus trichomanoides, Don. ... Nat. names, Tanekaha' north of the Thames, andToa Toa' south of that river, Col. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 235)

HOOKER Toa-toa, Col[enso]. Phyllocladus trichomanoides. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

(Colenso Botany North Isd) (1869,TrNZI,1/III/34) [NOTES: The channelled stems of the Neinei (Dracophyllum latifolium), and the ... saplings of Toatoa, or Tanekaha (Phyllocladus trichomanoides), made valued walking-sticks.]

[Native name] Toatoa .. [Settlers' name] Toatoa .. [Family] Coniferae [Native name] Toatoa .. [Settlers' name] Mountain toatoa .. [Family] Coniferae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,122) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 122]

CHEESEMAN P[hyllocladus] trichomanoides, D.Don. ... Tanekaha; Toatoa; Celery-leaved Pine. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,658)

(1944,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn))

toatoa, a tree (Phyllocladus Trichomanoides). (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/150) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

toatoa: The Maori name of a New Zealand tree also known as the "celery-pine.' (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),415)

2 n.

In support are large, rough-leaved tree daisies (Olearia lacunosa), deciduous mountain ribbonwoods (Hoheria lyalli), mountain toatoa, inaka (D. longifolium) and mountain cedar (Libocedrus bidwillii). (Mar 13, 2004,Dominion Post,E17)

Tobacco Country¶

n. area on Chatham Islands

SKINNER The first part of the track from Waitangi to Owenga lies through well-grassed, hilly country ... a region which the settlers have given the name `Tobacco Country'. (1923,Morioris of the Chatham Islands, The,12)

RICHARDS Whatever the cause, the further and more steeply you rise, the deeper and wetter the bogs become ..., till they reach the foot of the Tobacco Country as the tableland block is locally called (1952,Chatham Islands)

.. but there is also a large area of comparatively worthless land - in what is known as the "tobacco country," for instance - so-called, because once bought of the Natives for so much tobacco, though the purchasers never took possession, or, if they did, never made any use of their purchase. (Jan 24, 1902,Star, The,4)

ALL THAT LEASEHOLD PROPERTY Known as the "TOBACCO COUNTRY," And estimated to contain 20,000 Acres, more or less, Held at a rental of GBP40 per annum, lease of which expires 12th June 1897. (Jun 20, 1889,Otago Witness,19)

We had three glorious days pig-shooting in the "Tobacco Country," a wild waste of bog and bush land lying across the south of the island [sc. in the Chathams] so called because it was bought by a speculative white in the early days from the Maori conquerors for a box or barrel of tobacco. (Dec 28, 1920,Otago Witness,55)

tobacco plant¶

n. Linotea Hectori [possibly from the fancied resemblance of the leaves to those of the tobacco plant] (See mullein)

Linotea Hectori' better known through the [West Coast, Nelson] district as thetobacco plant'. (1902,NZ Illustrated Magazine,8/100)

79 tobacco plant [=] woolly mullein: woolly nightshade [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds)

As there is a probability that your correspondent is confusing a comparatively harmless plant called "malin," or tobacco plant, with foxglove, and that old residents here have never known of ragwort in the district, I consider it would be advisable, in fairness to the reputation which the district has for scarcity of noxious weeds, to obtain the opinion of the Inspector of Noxious Weeds on the matter and publish his reply in your paper. (Oct 13, 1913,Marlborough Express,4)

tobacco pouch¶

n.

MOORE & IRWIN THAXTEROGASTER PORPHYREA, violet tobacco pouch. ... Like the red tobacco pouch, this was once placed in Secotium; ... (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,12)

tobacco pouch fungus¶

n. a fungus Weraroa virescens , also known as the pale blue pouch fungus.

MOORE & IRWIN WERAROA (CLAVOGASTER) ERYTHROCEPHALA, red tobacco pouch. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,12)

[photo captions] (1) Honey mushroom (2) Red tobacco pouch fungus (3) Violet tobacco pouch fungi ... (5) Basket ... fungus. (1983,Land of the Mist,64)

The blue fungus seen in quantity on Ed and Juliet's 28 June Mt Climie trip was Weraroa virescens , also known as the pale blue pouch fungus or tobacco pouch fungus. (Aug 2008,South Wairarapa Tramping Club bulletin,3)

... a wilderness of giant solanum (which children called `the tobacco tree"), fern and teatree, grass in patches ... . (1948,Landfall) [NOTES: Frank Sargeson review of Tidal Creek (reference to Auckland's North Shore) [check]]

tobacco water¶

1 n. (Rural) [sp.use] a nicotine effusion for dipping sheep against scab mites.

MANNERING Of all the work I tackled the most disagreeable was dressing a sheep with tobacco-water for scab. (1852,Journal,123) [NOTES: in Cresswell (1951) Canterbury Tales]

WELD Every sheep should be thoroughly examined before he is passed to the dippers .. besides the dipping in tobacco water. (1860,Hints to Intending Sheep-Farmers in New Zealand,26)

Sheep have to be dipped three months before they quit Nelson and inspected and re-dipped (in tobacco-water and sulphur) on their entry into this province. (1860,BLANK ENTRY,43) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

This was followed with a decoction of strong tobacco water. (Apr 1, 1920,NZ Farmer,450)

tobacco weed¶

n. woolly nightshade

DAVIS .. a billygoat. Doing a great job on the danthonia, tobacco weed, thistles and blackberry. (1964,Watersiders,39)

tobacco weed [=] woolly mullein: woolly nightshade [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,79)

An open area at t he top of this covenant (left) had previously been planted but was struggling against kikuyu, Chinese and tree privet, elaeagnus, and tobacco weed. (Nov 2005,Open Space,7)

toby¶

n.

Kokopu had been found in stormwater drains, toby holes, and hidden under leaves on moist ground. (May 7, 2001,Evening Post,18)

n. a raddle stick

PROF. DARCY WALKER He did not hear it till c1955 when he came to Wellington cf Macquarie: toby = stick used by owner to raddle badly-shorn sheep with. (Nov 8, 1983,Personal Communication)

raddled: This word means robbed' in the sense of being deprived of one's proper payment. It is an extension ofraddling', carried out by unscrupulous farmers before the Shearers' Union looked after shearers' interests. Any sheep considered unsatisfactorily shorn was marked with red or blue raddle and such a sheep would not be counted in the shearer's tally. The raddle stick was also called a `Toby'. This must not be confused with [27] marking a sheep for other purposes, such as identification of certain sheep for easy selection later. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3.26) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

n. A stop-cock or valve in a water- or gas-main, gen. in a roadway at which the supply may be turned off, also applied to the covering, lid or box protecting it [Frequently toby box or toby-box; ca1954 Upper Hutt (Val Kiddie)(This was the first time I had heard the word used: I had always called it the `stopcock'. HWO) ; 1955 occas. seen (but not recorded) in the Evening Post --->ca1960 Karori, Wellington]

STANDARDS INSTITUTE (1956,Glossary of Building Terminology)

Where necessary, street-front tobies [water stopcocks] would be turned off and sealed to prevent firms turning the water back on. (Apr 12, 1999,Dominion,7)

Wellington City Council worker Chris Cashen was inspecting a flooded toby in Miramar a few days ago when he saw objects wriggling in the water. (Jan 29, 2001,Evening Post,16)

I must correct you as to the origin of 'toby'. It's not Irish for road. It is Gaelic for 'spring'. My ancestors built the navigation canals in the UK. That's why they were called 'navvies' and they took the word toby with them. I'm fluent in the Gaelic, so trust me! (Feb 14, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),48)

I also recommend that all the toby-boxes should be cast in a small block of concrete, as I find that a good many of them get shifted from their positions. (May 2, 1901,Hawera & Normanby Star,4)

She objected to the toby box on the bounday [sic], but he could not touch it. (Jun 25, 1915,Poverty Bay Herald,5)

All he did afterwards was to fix a new ball tap, do some minor repairs, and supply a toby-box of the value of 4s 6d. (May 2, 1930,Evening Post,15)

Toby - surface box generally set flush with paving or other surface to cover the stop-cock or control valve of a water or gas supply. (1979,NZ Standards Council Glossary Building Term.,119)

Toby - Surface box generally set flush with paving or other surface to cover the stop-cock or control valve of a water or gas supply. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,119)

LELAND toby: (A) the MASTER WATER VALVE for a building ordinarily located under a metal cover in the sidewalk outside. Who was Toby anyway? `Turn off (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,104)

A temporary worker had been engaged to detect unauthorised connections to council tobies (mains taps), and he had found the connections were mostly a normal hose connection to the toby. (Apr 28, 1982,Evening Post,15)

Large quantities of water have leaked from a toby in St Francis Grove, Lower Hutt, in the past few days, and the Lower Hutt City Council has done nothing to stop it, an angry woman resident says. (Apr 18, 1985,Evening Post,32) [NOTES: ? here a fire-hydrant valve?]

toby n. water stopcock on section boundary (1985,Collins Compact Dictionary,504) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD]]

MARSHALL I'll change the washer on that tap ... Go out and turn off the toby, will you dear. (1985,Nest of Cuckoos,107)

JAMES M DERMODY, WARKWORTH My parents, and I as a four-year-old, came out from Ireland in 1921. My father became involved in a new water-supply scheme for Blenheim. In the later 1920s the `toby-box' was an item of daily reference: my father had a small supply in his shed at home. They were a cast-iron cylinder of about four inches diameter and not much greater length. (Nov 6, 1989,Personal Communication)

What is the origin of the "toby". the tap that turns off water at the street frontage of a house?... I am prepared to wager that it is derived from "toby", which was the gypsy-tinker slang term for "street. There is an early link between tinkers and plumbers, both being experts with the soldering-iron, and I think the plumbers took over "toby" from the tinkers. Consequently, when they turned water off "at the toby" they were turning it off at the street. (Jun 11, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),56) [NOTES: Ian Gordon]

tochee¶

n. [empty headword] (See toki)

tod¶

v.

E. Murtagh was offered the ride on Ribstone Pippin in the Great Northern Hurdles, but he was unable to accept it, as he had been engaged to `tod' a couple of prads at Otaki. (Jun 3, 1911,NZ Truth,310/2/5)

todarodes¶

n.

[species name] todarodes .. [scientific name] Todarodes .. [other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

todea¶

n. a fern [usually Todea superba but also Todea barbara etc; incl attrib - todea fern.]

Though ferns are not absolutely [83] peculiar, ... - from the great arborescent species ..., the lovely todea (Leptopteris superba), down to the exquisite little Hymenophyllum - a most characteristic feature of the forest scenery. (1883,High Alps of NZ,82)

WHITE The Gleichenias [51] are a very distinct kind, with their ladder-like fronds set in umbrella shape. Hymenophyllums, or filmy Ferns, are very curious. Adiantums, or Maiden-hairs, are in infinite variety. The Todeas are very beautiful, especially Todea superba, which is commonly called Prince of Wales' Feather. (1905,My NZ Garden,50)

POTTS (And) Todea barbara hard todea (1882,Out in the Open)

Some time ago specimens of Todea superba, commonly known as the Crape fern, grew in these grounds, but were removed (May 29, 1920,Evening Post,7)

It was composed of plants representing the various Dominions and Colonies - maple leaf for Canada hibiscus for British West Indies, and todea fern for New Zealand. (Jan 20, 1939,Evening Post,18)

The ferns, which attain the size of trees, are the splendid long-fronded mamaku with its black trunk, the mauku and tuakura, and the smaller ones are the wheki, the maru, and the tainwhaniwha [sic], the heruheru (todeamedia), and that queen of the New Zealand fern tribe, the tete or todea superba, commonly known as the "Prince of Wales' Feather." (Jun 4, 1910,Evening Post,10)

Among the various articles to be sent from this Province to the Exhibition at Otago is a splendid collection of Ferns by Mr. R. H. Huntley, Wellington, consisting of five groups in large frames with glass, each forming a distinct landscape picture. They are classified in the following order .. No.3. Nephrolepsis, Polypodium, Pymatodes, Dictymea, Arthropteris, Grammitis, Gymnogramma, Northolaena, Stenchlaena, Lygodium, Schizaea, Leptopteris, and Todea. (Dec 14, 1864,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,3)

The trees growing here were, for the most part, cedars, intermixed with pines, and amongst the ferns the beautiful Todea Superba was very plentiful. (Mar 30, 1872,Otago Witness,10)

Apart from the advantage of attracting tourists it will be found a pleasant resort for families and parties desiring to spend a few days during the summer months where they can procure the pure air to be obtained on the mountain, and see the grand views in some of the gorges where grows the mountain cypress, the lovely crape ferns, (todea superba), the toi, and other plants not to be seen elsewhere. (Feb 19, 1890,Taranaki Herald,3)

2 n. Todea barbara

toe¶

n. (informal) (of rugby players, racehorses, etc.) speed [ca1957 Upper Hutt]

(Oct 8, 1963,NZ Truth) [NOTES: [on racing page, check]]

The most serviceable back for Wellington was Page, who was appearing for the first time in big football here. Possessing plenty of toe and being quick off the mark, he frequently found himself away from his supports. Fast as Bert Cooke is, he never appeared able to keep near Page. (Aug 28, 1930,NZ Truth,12)

toe into¶

v. to venture into

"I think I'm good at teaching and good at writing but I'm not a professional fundraiser. It's been very interesting to toe into that world, but I'll be very pleased to go back." (Dec 30, 2005,NZ Farmers' Weekly,1)

toe it¶

v. to run away, escape

NEWBOLD TOE-IT (v) Run away, escape. (1982,Big Huey, The,255)

toe-biter¶

n. Dobson fly larva, Archichauliodes sp, black creeper [aka toebiter]

insect larva Order 4 (alder-flies) is represented in New Zealand by only a single species Archicauliodes dubitatus, an insect of large size, whose fat, succulent larva is found under rocks in streams, and forms excellent food for trout. This larva is called the black creper,' or sometimes thetoe-biter'. (Jan 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,3/273) [NOTES: (Tillyard)]

NATUSCH The Dobson fly ... is a speckled orange-winged insect which flits weakly over streams at dusk. The larva (known as the black creeper or toe-biter). . . hides under stones in the creek bed by day, coming out for a night's career with its powerful jaws ready to seize and devour whatever comes its way; (1967,Animals of NZ, The,151)

She made a sudden dip and scooped up a creature she identified as the nymph of a dobsonfly. "It's known as the 'toe-biter,'" she said, "on account of its large jaws and habit of nipping bare feet." (Nov 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 50/51)

It is perfectly true that the big bags early in the season are obtained principally by the aid of the "toe-biter," which "hangs out" under stones near the water's edge; but matters adjust themselves later, for the "toe-biters" develop into a fly or something, and they are no longer found in any number. (Nov 2, 1901,Nelson Evening Mail,2)

toe-kiwi¶

n.

The tufts of the toe-kiwi - the `cutting-grass' of the bushmen - which are a feature of the kauri bush, are set in a blaze; and as the flames flare up ... the masses of the puwharawhara (Asteliads) which encumber the branches are ignited ... (1897,TrNZI,29/493) [NOTES: (Walsh)]

toe-rag¶

n. a handkerchief (cf. SWEAT-RAG) (cf. as a British slang term of abuse: e.g. Eastenders `You're lying toe-rag': and cf. [ca1935 Havelock children]

WAINWRIGHT A germ called Frampton gets himself stiffened in Cawdale Rise. A miserable little tow-rag who happens to have been at Saville's party last night.') (1973,High-Class Kill,194)

HISLOP Out came my toe rag, as we called our handkerchiefs [in the 1880s in Central Otago], and up went my other hand. (1943,Pure Gold,78)

toe-ragger¶

n.

MORRIS Toe-ragger, n. In the bush a term of abuse; though curiously in one or two parts of New South Wales the word toey,' which is derived from it, is a term of praise, aswell.' The word has been explained as of convict origin, that the rags were used to soothe the galling of fetters; but the explanation is not satisfactory, for the part galled by the irons would not be the toe, but the ankle. A writer in `Truth' has cleared up the word (see quotation). It is of Maori origin. Away from Maoriland "toe-rigger' had no meaning, and a false meaning and origin were given by the change of vowel. (1898,Austral English,472)

The bushie's favorite term of opprobriuma toe-ragger' is also probably from the Maori. Amongst whom the nastiest term of contempt was that of tau rika rika, or slave. The old whalers on the Maoriland coast in their anger called each other toe-riggers, and to-day the word in the form of toe-ragger has spread through-out the whole of the South Seas.' (Jan 12, 1896,Truth (Sydney))

toe-ragger n. a term of abuse. [corrupt. fr. Maori tau rika rika, a slave] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,12)

PARTRIDGE Toe-ragger, rigger. A term of opprobrium: Australia and New Zealand resp., as in Truth (the Sydney one), Jan. 12, 1896, `"A toe-ragger' is Maori... The nastiest term of contempt was tua rika rika, or slave. The old whalers on the Maoriland coast in their anger called each other toe-riggers, and to-day the word in the form toe-ragger has spead throughout the whole of the South Seas.' Morris. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,893)

McNAB Slang words of Maori origin were once common, but most of them are dead and dying [including] "toe-ragger,' a curse (taurekareka); ... (Apr 2, 1938,Press, The,18)

BAKER Another old whaling term - this time a pejorative - is toe-rigger, which is the original of the still-current slang expression in Australia, toe-ragger. Here is what the Sydney Truth, January 12, 1896 had to say on the subject: "The bushie's favourite term of opprobrium, a toe-ragger, is...probably from the Maori, amongst whom the nastiest term of contempt was that of tau rika rika, or slave. The old whalers on the Maoriland coast in their anger called each other toe-riggers and to-day the word in the form of toe-ragger has spread throughout the whole of the South Seas.' Morris also declares: `It is of Maori origin. Away from Maoriland toe-rigger had no meaning, and a false meaning and origin were given by the change of vowel.' (1941,NZ Slang,14)

toe-ragger n. term of contempt for a person down and out [from tramps who tied rags round their feet to prevent blistering]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

TURNER The toeragger was not much wealthier [as a swagger] than the battler. His name is from the rags he wore in lieu of socks. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,144)

toe-ragger n. whalers' slang for a person to be despised. Also toe-rigger [From Maori taurekareka, slave]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

toe-stall¶

n. [in the phrase "toe-stalls to clipper-stalls" from footbag]

Expect to see toe-stalls to clipper-stalls (catch the sac on the toe, then flick it to rest on the inside of the opposite foot behind your leg). (Jan 10, 2001,Capital Times,9)

toeball¶

n. a form of football [1951 16+ M 26 Marlborough C. 20 TOE BALL]

This paper is not run solely in the interests of toeball,... (Mar 14, 1908,NZ Truth,143/3/4)

toebiter¶

n. a fish [dubious defn]

SORENSON MONKFISH (a) Scientific name: (i) Geniagnus monopterygius (ii) Kathetostoma giganteum. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (both) Whitefish. (c) Other common names: (both) Monkfish, Monks, Stargazer, Flathead (also applied at times to export gurnard); Churchills, Toebiters, Bulldogs, Spotted Stargazer, Maori Chief (Dunedin); Muddies. (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Cook Strait, Nelson, Banks Peninsula, Bluff-Stewart Island. ... Monkfish is a general term for species of the Families Uranoscopidae and Leptoscopidiae. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,37)

[species name] stargazer .. [scientific name] Kathetostoma giganteum .. [other name(s)] monkfish, boofs, bulldogs, churchills, flathead monk, giant stargazer, monks, muddies, spotted stargazer, toebiters, whitefish, sandcod (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

toeing¶

n. (Rural) footrotting or inspecting of sheep's feet.

STAPLES He was really a shearer but often stayed on to help with the toeing. When we first arrived, there were three extra men helping with the toeing. (1964,Cooks and Shepherds Come Away,22)

STAPLES April brought the end of the hay baling at last but the toeing still dragged on for the shepherds. (1964,Cooks and Shepherds Come Away,42)

MACINTOSH I read a book about sheep on a half way to high country farm and was puzzled throughout by the many references to 'toeing.' This 'toeing' seemed to be an ever recurring job to do with footrot. (1974,Never a Dull Moment,114)

toenail¶

n. shellfish Waltonia inconspicua

NATUSCH Probably the best known [species are] the small, smooth Waltonia (formerly Terebratella) inconspicua ... which is scarlet or pink or white. Some people call them toenails. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,65)

2 n.

SANSOM At low tide this is a good place [on Stewart Island] to find the pretty toenail shells, the small pink and red brachiopods which are cast up on the firm white sand of Bathing Beach. (1970,Stewart Islanders,146)

toetoe¶

n. tussock grass

n.

n. a tall showy plumed reed similar in appearance to the South American pampas grass. [Maori] Arundo spp., esp. A. conspicua (kakao), a pampas grass; cuttygrass [English spellings (and to some extent, pron.) vary around two modes, usually, but not always, reduplicated, and with or without an h. (1) toetoe, tohetohe, tohe (2) toi-toi, to"ito"i [dieresis-o], tohi-tohi, towi-towi, towy-towy; and (?from pron [t it i]) tortor (1842) totitoti (1937) is a mistake or misprint. English pron [|toui:toui:], [|touwi:touwi:], [t it I] The form is occasionally found unreduplicated, espec in combination with -grass (cf. tui-grass, probably an analogous Canterbury hearing influenced by tui: cf.poe, pui) plurals usu. with -s]

The only buildings were the New Zealand Company's store;.. a whare of toetoes, occupied by Lethbridge, the surveyor, and another occupied by Peter Crow in the bush... (1948,Port Chalmers,16)

Native toetoes can be recognised by their white, waxy leaf-sheaths plus the veins or tramlines on the leaves between the midribs and the leaf margins. (Aug 27, 1999,Dominion,14)

1/III/34 ... the outer thatch [was] Toetoe, (Cyperus ustulatus), or Rautahi (Carex ternaria,) or Ririwaka (Scirpus maritimus), or of two kinds of Wiwi, or Rushes (Juncus maritimus, and effusus); ... (1869,TrNZI) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

WILLIAMS (grass) ... the huts were always well constructed ..., the thatch of toe-toe being securely fastened ... with the wire-like stems of the ake or metrosideros scandens. The interior was lined with reeds of the toe-toe, [88] kakapo or arundo conspicua. (1876,East Coast Historical Records,87)

DOMETT Toe-toe ..... (See Sword-grass) The term toe!' alluding to the light large flower of this grass is used metaphorically precisely as we use the wordchaff.' ... Sword-grass (Toe-toe) [es-dieresis] .... O. Gramineae; G. Arundo; S. A. conspicua. "The largest New Zealand grass; confined to these islands; culms three to eight (ten) feet high; used for thatch and lining houses with reed-work. Flowers very like those of Panama grass.' (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/303)

BAUGHAN Toe-toe (toy-toy): A tall plumed grass, very much like the Pampas. (1908,Shingle-Short,191)

ACLAND I am told [toetoe] is the correct spelling, not toi toi which is more usual. (1933,Press, The)

toetoe: large grass with white and yellow plumes. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

toe-toe: The Maori name of a very large New Zealand grass something like the `pampas' grass grown in gardens. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),415)

HILLIARD (1960,Maori Girl,215) [NOTES: [see raupo]]

(1966,Short Stories (various authors),311) [NOTES: 1963 Shadbolt in 1966 Short Stories]

MIDDLETON It seemed impossible that this ... estuary, with its toe toe and flax-covered banks, was only half-an-hour's fast drive from the city. (1964,Walk on the Beach,47) [NOTES: (Day by Itself)]

McLINTOCK Toetoe (plume grass) .. .. toetoe, toetoekakaho .. .. Arundo conspicua (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

toetoe [s] Cortaderia fulvida (Buchan.) Zotov Cortaderia richardii (Endl.) Zotov Cortaderia toetoe Zotov (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,79)

BROOKER et al. Cyperus ustulatus A. Rich. Common name: Cutty grass Maori names: Toetoe, upokotangata ... The name `toetoe' was applied to various graases and sedges. ... Cheeseman's name for it was Mariscus ustulatus (A. Rich.) Cheesem. Ibid.58 Cortaderia fulvida (Buchan.) Zotov Cortaderia splendens Connor and allied species Maori names: Toetoe, kakaho ...The second has been known as Arundo kakaho Steud., A. conspicua Forst.f., and Cortaderia toetoe Zotov. (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,49)

WILSON Cortaderia richardii TOETOE ... Native to: S[outh and] St[ewart Islands]. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,372)

Clumps of dead toetoe and marram, grass seem to have been resting places for them [sc. gulls]. (Jul 12, 2003,Dominion Post,F9)

All along the miles of the straight stretch of road from Waitakaruru to the Pipiroa ferry are to be seen hedges of toetoe, mostly marking boundaries or the margins of Government drains. (Apr 27, 1929,Evening Post,11)

I stuck a toetoe branch down the back of my neck. (Apr 3, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

It is not quite clear how pampas came originally to the Piako Swamp - invading the domain of the indigenous toetoe and flax - but probably pampas just wandered there, for it is classed, among other exotics, as garden escape. (Dec 14, 1932,Evening Post,18)

...nothing else was familiar: the mountains of dark steaming bush, the huge braided river, the clumps of flax and toetoe, the stark promontories of rock, amd all around the house boggy pasture and wet and rotting trees. (May 7, 1994,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

35/22 The roof was .. covered with raupo - sometimes with an inner sheeting of totara-bark - while an upper layer of toetoe-grass, secured by ropes of mangemange .. preserved the raupo from wet. (1903,TrNZI)

LEE & KENDALL To|e to|e; A long rushy grass so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,215)

WILLIAMS They cut a few sticks, ... tie them together with a flax plant, and thus form the frame of their shed, and cover it with toetoe, a kind of long grass, four to five feet long ... . (Jan 4, 1832,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,212,1961 ed.)

POLACK The most disgusting insects in nature exist among the spear-grass, called toi toi, of the swamps and plains; it is called the kikararu [a's-acute]. Its odour is disgustingly offensive, and it is often found in rush or other dwelling-houses. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/320)

MACKIE This day's journey was over a level grassy plain diversified with patches of flax and toetoe. (Mar 17, 1853,Traveller under Concern,88,1973 ed.)

SHORTLAND It happened that as Tuhuihuia was going one day to gather a species of grass, called toetoe, to thatch his hut, ... (1856,Traditions & Superstitions,18)

... from the consecrated grove, flax and toetoe have been gathered; ... (Aug 15, 1857,Lyttelton Times,3)

HOOKER Toe-toe. Arundo conspicua. ... Toe-toe, Col[enso]. Cyperus ustulatus. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

WILY & MAUNSELL the rays of the rising sun first struck the glistening leaves of the flax, toetoe, raupo and karamu shrubs in the swamps adjoining the river ... (1938,Robert Maunsell,139) [NOTES: 1935 J.W.Stack More Maoriland Adventures in Wily and Maunsell Robert Maunsell (1938) 139]

BEATTIE They dwelt in whares [11] (huts) built in the traditional shape of an inverted V, roofed with grass, and lined inside with the reeds of the toetoe or New Zealand pampas grass. The orthodox Maori name for these reeds is pukakaho, but the white men called them `bukaka'. (1839,First White Boy Born in Otago,10)

COWAN And along the river bank the kakaho, the toetoe or pampas grass, once waved its plumes abundantly; ... (1940,Sir Donald Maclean,146)

ANDERSEN Earp spells the word tohitohi, and even to the present day it is spelt toi toi as often as the correct toe toe. (1942,Maori Place Names,277)

toetoe, giant ornamental grass (Arundo conspicua), the flower-culms used for reed-work between the carved slabs of house-walls, cross-laced in a variety of patterns with narrow strips of flax [147] or pingao, white and black or bright orange (the tukutuku-work): very often mis-spelt toitoi or toi toi, or tohi tohi. Though the name toetoe is by the Pakeha confined to Arundo, by the Maori it is applied to various species of rush and grass with a qualifying suffix: Arundo is toetoe-kakaho, the latter word referring to the valued culms. Some people object to the reed tukutuku-work as being flimsy and perishable: in reality it is as durable as galvanized-iron and far more handome and artistic: the interior of a good Maori house is a thing of beauty. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

Coastal shrub species such as flax, toetoe, hebe and manuka were planted. (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 7)

Whatipu is a wilderness of slick sands, a soft, broad headland laced on one side by toetoe (swamp grass) and on the other, by foaming sea. (Jul 2006,Air New Zealand inflight magazine,33)

MORELAND Beautiful clumps of the giant flax, formium tenax [sic], or the tall pampas-like toe-toe grass [sc. Leptospermum scoparium (sic), footnote confused with Arundo conspicua] with its drooping plumes, lined the shore. (1911,Through South Westland,144)

There is a good cart road up to this pa, but it traverses country covered with flax, toetoe, and light bush. (May 25, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,4)

DREAVER The land turned out to be a waste of raupo and toetoe by the Tokomaru Stream. (1984,Horowhenua County and its People,146)

Toetoe (Cortaderia) is excellent for the holiday home, but avoid pampas grass, which is a pest plant... (Jan 24, 2004,Dominion Post,E14)

Wooden buildings, mostly built after the Maori style, are rapidly taking the place of the old houses of toetoe and raupo. (Dec 30, 1898,Timaru Herald,3)

The hall was neatly decorated with the foliage of toetoe, nikau, keikei, and other native plants. (May 5, 1874,Daily Southern Cross,3)

Here, however, we doubt if there is even one so enamoured of the beauties and luxuries of those good old times when poles and bundles of toetoe were deemed a comfort, and if to these were superadded a few baskets of tiwa's and a spare rib of native pork to grace the festive board; language was too poor wherewith to express our delight. (Jan 21, 1843,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,183)

Of the above-mentioned plants, only a few can be recommended as likely to resist the local gales - viz., koromiko, rewarewa, manuka, karamu, taupata, akeraho, akepiro, houhou, kaikaia, tikapu (?), the tawhais, tawhera, toetoe, and, in damp and fairly sheltered and shaded places, the ferns - ponga, mamaku, tuakura, korokio, piupiu, rarauhe, Pteris tremula. (Aug 29, 1912,Evening Post,8)

2 n. (Environment) [ORIGIN: Maori]

toetoe-upoko-tangata¶

n. (See cf. Maorihead)

CHEESEMAN M[ariscus] ustulatus, C.B.Clarke, ... [767] Abundant in lowland districts throughout. ... Toetoe-upoko-tangata; Toetoe-whatu-manu. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,766)

toetoewhatumanu¶

n. =toetoewhatumu q.v.

The displacement of the ... coarse sedge known as toe-toe-whatumanu (Cyperus ustulatus, A. Rich.), ... by European grasses ... is so striking ... (1895,TrNZI,28/18)

toetoewhatumu¶

n.

Toetoewhatumu. Cyperus ustulatus, A. Rich. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/50) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

toey¶

adj. bad-tempered, aggressive

He agreed he became "toey" at times when his payments stopped because ACC said it had not received his medical certificates. (Nov 24, 2002,Sunday Star Times,A13)

Party members are a bit toey about getting rid of the monarchy. (Apr 14, 1996,Sunday Star Times,A7)

Maureen was getting all toey as all Brian wanted to do was stay and drink more grog. (2001,Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success,45)

Anyway, since I'bve been crook, it's a fact that I've been getting all ratty and toey ... (Jun 11, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

He's [sc. a stalker] been sending letters and is getting really toey. This guy is quite serious about what he's doing. (Oct 21, 2001,Sunday Star Times,C3)

Understandably, US exporters get toey competing against their own cheaper goods, in essence, arguing that they face too much competition. (Nov 20, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5)

NEWTON This was our third child so I wasn't as `toey' as John had been .... (1966,Boss's Story, The,86)

NEWTON Unfortunately, [the dog] had one fault - his temperament. He got toey on the trial ground and Bain had difficulty in holding him. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,86)

West Coasters sometimes get toey. In fact they probably coined the phrase. But the toey-ist people in the South Island at present are the voters of Otago Central. (Oct 30, 1972,Dominion,4/3)

NEWBOLD By about the third day cooped up in that little box I began feeling really toey ... .Ibid..</I< 255 TOEY (v) Agitated, excited, ill-at-ease. It has been suggested that this derives from the racecourse, where a horse that is nervous and fidgetty at the starting gate is said to be toey. (1982,Big Huey, The,145)

NEWTON All this made me a bit toey to get out but the doctor wasn't having any. (1966,Boss's Story, The,102)

[Hdg] Tow operators toey over confiscated cars. (Jan 17, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,1)

[Hdg] Getting toey. Environment Waikato is considering selling millions of dollars worth of overseas shares in the face of faltering investment returns. (Sep 22, 2001,Evening Post,15)

2 adj. of race-horses, rugby footballers, sports, fast, ready to move

Don't let them down. You've got to be toey and eager to get after them; tough but not dirty. (Jul 4, 1983,National Business Review,32)

A toey field which included Olympic Games aspirant Richard Lockart lined up for the men's 100 metres breaststroke final. (Mar 19, 1988,Dominion,38)

McGILL toey anxious, randy, ready, excitable; originally of a keen sprinter in horse racing; eg `Am I toey tonight! I must score or I'll go apeshit.' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,114)

He's a stronger horse now and is not as toey as he used to be. (Sep 26, 2003,Dominion Post RaceForm,20)

toff¶

n. person of stature or integrity

NEWBOLD TOFF (n) Person of stature or integrity. (1982,Big Huey, The,255)

toghee¶

n. [empty headword] (See toki)

togho-togho¶

n. (See tokotoko)

togs¶

n. (See togs)

n. bathing, swimming costume [aka bathing togs, swimming togs; ca1932 GT Diary (Dannevirke) ...togs always meant bathing togs.]

GUTHRIE ... We tore down to a quiet beach, stripped off our clothes, and plunged in ... We didn't bother about togs. (1935,Little Country, The,216,1937 ed.)

HYDE ... `Roll your stockings in your bloomers and hide them under the seat [of the dressing-shed]. A girl last week lost simply everything, and had to go home in her togs.' (1938,Godwits Fly, The,117,1970 ed.)

BENNETT togs, used of bathing suits rather than of clothes in general; hippies, bathing trunks. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,92)

BALLANTYNE Inside his pants Gibert's togs chafed his skin, and he was impatient for the water to swish about his body. (1948,Cunninghams, The,203,1976 ed.)

WILSON You want to see her in swimming togs. (1956,Sweet White Wine,92)

WILSON You want to see her in swimming togs. (1956,Sweet White Wine,92)

SLATTER Who would care that I had swum at Waikiki? Not from the Royal Hawaiian but changing into togs in a public lavatory. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,38)

HARVEY Old Pimply Face was starting to take off her bathing togs.Ibid. 67 67 He had his togs underneath. `You start cheering and I'll do the swimming.' (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,64)

JEFFREY I didn't bring any t-togs,' I said. `I have no intention of swimming. I detest fresh water. ...' (1964,Mairangi,147)

HASCOMBE As for the children, they soon adjust to change. They soon learn for instance that togs' are bathing clothes, thatskite' means to show off ... (1969,Down and Almost Under,42)

FRAME Our bathing suits, rolled in their towels (there was a special way of parceling up your `togs")., were forever wet,... (1979,Living in the Maniatoto,42)

LELAND togs Not all kinds of clothing, but only one kind. Bathing togs, or a bathing suit. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,104)

togs (1981,Auckland Secondary Teachers College) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

GILDERDALE togs Bathing costume. In T.T. Garland's Old Joe (1937) used first as old togs', meaningold clothes' in English sense, but later in the same book as `bathing togs'. (1982,Sea Change,242)

OLIVER He always had a large old suitcase with him; when it was opened it revealed little more than togs and a towel, ... (1983,James K. Baxter,31)

McCAULEY On the hottest days she takes her togs when she goes to the shop or the phone booth. (1986,Then Again,57)

tog sl. 1 n. (usu. in pl.) garment, esp. (NZ & Austral.) swimming costume. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,808) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 1231; cf. 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 505]]

[Hdg] Don't throw out your togs yet.... But don't throw out the togs in despair - summer is (still) on its way. (Jan 6, 2000,Dominion,1)

Tarts' Swimming Togs, the Trouble. (Feb 4, 1911,NZ Truth,4)

HENDERSON Boys of all sizes swirled and yelled and grinned, some dressed in swimming togs or footie jerseys. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,147)

When I was a kid I kept a pair of togs under my pillow in case of the Big One. (May 8, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

Most of the children didn't even have togs. (Apr 1992,Charivari (Auckland),3)

He'd arrive each summer with togs - we'd say, what the hell are they for? - and soft feet! (Jul 29, 2003,Dominion Post,B5)

COLE Or was it at the creek where you used to swim without togs? (1949,It Was So Late,11)

ANDERSON The first thing Mum does when we arrive at the cottage, before she sweeps up mouse droppings or once a dead one, or unpacks anything, is to open all the windows wide, then take off her corsets quick as anything, put on her togs and head for the sea. (1999,Long Hot Summer,18)

Waikato had a decidedly male-in-male- togs-looking woman in their goal. (May 3, 1993,Salient,15)

At least one of the teachers.. should be in their swimming togs and stay with the children. (Jan 28, 1928,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,33)

Sam was in bathing togs, and all ready should occasion occur to go overboard. (Nov 11, 1908,Evening Post,16)

HYDE So I put on my swimming-togs, and went down to the creek. (1937,Wednesday's Children,49) [NOTES: 1989 edition]

Bring my bathing togs, Mum? (Feb 16, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,62)

... Mum's bag ... was bulging with bathing togs and things to change (1987,In Fifteen Minutes,162) [NOTES: 1944 Texidor in 1987 In Fifteen Minutes 162]

It was with great reluctance that wet togs are donned on a raw and rainy morning. (1934,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,III/45)

We haunted the Marton baths.. lining up long before opening time with our bundles of togs and towel. (Apr 1992,North & South,40)

Two New Zealanders walk by, like schoolboys on their way home, swinging their bathing togs in their hands. (May 25, 1942,NZEF Times,I/48 : 4)

n. sports clothing

SLATTER ... he knew very well what [the coach] would say when his boys were changed out of their cadet uniforms into their football togs ready to practice. Ibid. 119 ... boys hanging up their clothes on the pegs and pulling on their practice togs. (1968,Pagan Game, The,88)

GLOVER Once you have your togs on/ There is no chance of any escape/ From life's or love's or rugby's battle./ (1971,Diary to a Woman,1)

McGILL togs swimming trunks for [sic] football gear; contracting English meaning of any clothes. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,114)

Time to see about FOOTBALL TOGS With the Season not far ahead, all intending Players should get in touch with us right away. (Apr 2, 1921,NZ Truth,7)

The girls were dressed in black football togs, even to the shorts. (Jul 30, 1932,Evening Post,13)

In his football togs Todd is 14st 12lb, and Gillespie is 13st 11lb. (Sep 21, 1940,Evening Post,15)

Cricketing togs galore on Saturday; they got a proper christening ... (Dec 8, 1888,Observer (Auckland),17)

P L is quite a masher with his tennis togs on ... (Mar 5, 1898,Observer (Auckland),26)

Q is for Quinlan, most charitable Paddy, / In striped football "togs," begad he's a laddie. (Dec 3, 1904,Observer (Auckland),12)

2 n.

4 n. clothes generally [universal use - archive]

TOGS. - Clothes - in war sometimes unrecognisable as such. (1917,New Zealand At the Front,xiv)

On her return home she took off her Sunday "bests" and donned her milking "togs." (Jul 23, 1927,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,44)

This "capping" occasion was Sir James Hector's first appearance before an Otago audience in his Chancellor's togs. Wonderful togs they are - gorgeous to a quite unspeakable degree. (Sep 4, 1890,Otago Witness,24)

tohe¶

n. (See toetoe)

tohemunga¶

n.

EDWARDS Kuku and tohemanga or toheroa are also very nice cooked this way. (1992,Mihipeka,39)

toheroa¶

n. [also attrib]

toheroa n, pl toheroa or toheroas [Maori] : a large marine bivalve mollusk (Amphidesma ventricosum) of New Zealand used extensively for food (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2404)

KEENE toheroa: shellfish from which the famous toheroa soup is made. (1963,O Te Raki,195)

McLINTOCK Toheroa .. .. toheroa .. .. Amphidesma ventricosum (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

toheroa n. a New Zealand edible mollusc [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),169)

TURNER (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,169)

20 toheroa ... n. New Zealand edible mollusc [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins))

toheroa n. a large edible bivalve mollusc of New Zealand with a distinctive flavour. [< Maori] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1231) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 808; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 505]]

[species name] toheroa .. [scientific name] Paphies ventricosa .. [other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Toheroa Paphies ventricosa ... A species unique to New Zealand. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,161)

We were sure that the toheroa inspector would arrest her and put her in jail. (Apr 1998,North & South,31)

Bubbles in the wet sand tease anyone who remembers toheroa soup or fritters - but, if you see toheroa, don't touch. This succulent fish is protected by law now to allow regeneration. (Nov 1999,AA Directions,30)

The only canning company, at present operating in a small way.., packed a very limited number because of the number of small toheroa in the beds. (1955,AJHR,H.-15/46)

Toheroa diggers were present at west coast beaches, North Island, in large numbers during the weekend for the reopening of the season. (Dec 4, 1945,Evening Post,8)

POLACK On the north bank were placed, among the bushes, three raouis, or carved monuments, painted with red earth. These had been erected here to prevent native travellers or strangers from grubbing in the sand for a favourite large cockle, called toi-roa, which are steamed and dried by the natives, and taken as portable food for a journey. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/71)

TINNE ... she sent us a basket of tairoas, a large white shellfish from the coast, which is considered a delicacy .. (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,66)

STALLWORTHY Sufficient ... was done ... to show that the toheroa could be successfully tinned ... (1916,Early Northern Wairoa,59)

REISCHEK Along the coast I came to the dunes, and here I piched camp and roasted some tohiroa. This is a huge shellfish, which in these parts lives in colonies under the sand. (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,68,1933 ed.)

HYDE The toheroa taste has spread among members of the Royal Family. (1934,Journalese,124)

THE TOHEROA (Amphidesma ventricosum). (1934,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,15/396)

BASHAM SCALLOPED TOHEROAS ... Mince toheroas with onion. Mix in ... breadcrumbs. Stir in 1 beaten egg, pepper and salt. Put a spoonful in each cleaned toheroa shell and ... piece of butter on top. Bake ... (1939,Aunt Daisy's Cookery Book,29)

BEAGLEHOLE From the sea, the principal foods obtained are the toheroa shellfish (local [Otaki] variety, tohemanga) and flounders. (1946,Some Modern Maoris,99)

toheroa: edible shellfish. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

The Maori name of an edible shellfish found on New Zealand beaches, a great delicacy. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),415)

The Maori name of an edible shellfish found on New Zealand beaches, a great delicacy. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),415)

It is said that like caviare and olives the Toheroa is an acquired taste. (Jun 1936,NZ Railways Magazine,54)

Toheroa fritters for breakfast are scrumptious. (Mar 9, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,95)

EDWARDS Kuku and tohemanga or toheroa are also very nice cooked this way. (1992,Mihipeka,39)

Sale for one month only and strictly for cash. A few quotations .. Toheroas, 6d tin ... (May 14, 1906,Wanganui Herald,7)

v. to gather toheroa

McLEOD The four of them had been toheroa-ing, hunting the large, slithery-tongued shell-fish delicacy with wooden spades, and a sack. (1967,Dorinda,64)

toheroa bed¶

n.

Evidence of a recognition among the public of the need to conserve the toheroa beds on the Ninety-mile and North Kaipara beaches.. is noted in the annual report of the Marine Department. (Aug 2, 1940,Taranaki Herald,4)

toheroa fritter¶

n.

BLACKMORE TOHEROA FRITTERS AND BACON ... Egg ... Butter ... Milk and Water ... Flour ... Salt and Pepper ... Toheroas or other shell-fish ... Baking Powder ... Fry in spoonfuls in smoking hot fat. (1928,Cooking of NZ Fish,34)

TOHEROA FRITTERS ... toheroas ... egg-white ... butter ... warm water ... flour ... pepper and salt ... cook tablespoonful in smoking fat ... garnish with lemon. (1936,Recipe Book [St Mary's],21)

toheroa soup¶

n.

WILSON ... we could look over half the restaurant and watch the waitresses ... hurrying between the tables with wooden trays filled with plates of sausages-and-mash, baked beans on toast, or toheroa soup. (1956,Sweet White Wine,54)

Our familiar emblem is a rare bird - the kiwi. ... Almost a rare as the kiwi is the toheroa soup we talk about but seldom sip. (Oct 24, 1959,Dominion,14)

THOMAS None of us dreamed that the day was coming when toheroa soup and toheroa fritters would be featured on menus at home and abroad; that they would be popularly recognised as being the most distinctive of our national delicacies ... (1970,Way Up North,61)

DRYLAND Toheroa soup?' The waitress laughed outright. In 1957 this most blessed of shellfish had not yet proved its ability to survive.You won't get no Toheroa soup. Hasn'y been any for years. But there's Kontiki.' (1973,Multiple Texture, A,38)

LELAND Toheroa soup is canned and sold overseas, but the only place you can get it in New Zealand is in the larger tourist hotels. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,104)

BURTON It is in the area of soups that we find New Zealand's greatest contribution to international cuisine - the legendary toheroa soup. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,40)

LATHAM The lisle stockings were a ghastly greenish-khaki colour that the girls called `toheroa soup'. (1986,WAAC Story, The,20)

OVENDEN I'll bet the entire Trentham yearling stock sale to a tin of Toheroa soup that the money from Rialto is the key. (1986,O.E.,198)

TOHEROA SOUP ... toheroas ... stodk ... onion ... celery ... milk ... cornflour ... curry powder ... seasoning ... cream ... lemon juice ... (1936,Recipe Book [St Mary's],13)

TOHEROA SOUP ... toheroas ... milk ... onions ... simmer gently for 2 hours. (1938,'Milkmade' Cook Book,5)

HENDERSON ... tinned fruits purchased with our own money, and a great can of toheroa soup (bought at the New Zealand Club, Cairo) to be quaffed in triumph at Benghazi on Christmas Day. (1945,Gunner Inglorious,18,1974 ed.)

Each year during the season she produced great bowlfuls of marvellous toheroa soup, richly green, spiked with a touch of cayenne, a little mace. (Sep 1999,Cuisine,No. 76 :)

Toheroa soup is just a memory for most of us now and whitebait fritters for Sunday breakfast an almost unheard-of luxury. (Mar 2, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

Toheroa soup is such a delicacy (says the Lyttelton Times) that is deserves more fame than it enjoys in New Zealand, where the curious burrowing shellfish from which it is made flourishes in beaches from Dargaville to the Bluff. (Aug 18, 1916,Evening Post,6)

She recalled her visit to New Zealand in 1920, and said her memories included toheroa soup and blue cod. (Dec 24, 1942,Evening Post,4)

We came upon a notice I could not resist photographing - "The famous New Zealand toheroa (oyster) soup." (Jan 5, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,18)

"Toheroa soup!" sighed Lisbeth blissfully over the menu, "and not out of a tin, either." (Mar 9, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,95)

A fine menu, including toheroa soup, was quietly settled behind the varying depths of waistcoat, and the King was duly toasted. (Oct 29, 1907,Observer (Auckland),16)

toheroa stakes¶

n.

THOMAS But my friends in the far north tell tales of parties going to the beach to fish, and spending their time engrossed in a game known as the Toheroa Stakes. The game is based on the shellfish's remarkable ability to bury itself and disappear in the solid sand of the wet beach. ... The game is, or was, played by drawing a circle on the beach. Each player selects a toheroa. The bets are made. On the word go each toheroa is placed on its side within the circle. The first to disappear is the winner. (1970,Way Up North,100)

tohetohe¶

n. toetoe [toetoe aka tohitohi, tohi tohi, tohi, tohetohe, tohi grass; see toetoe] (See toetoe)

ANGAS Close to Pipitea is a whare karakia, or chapel,belonging to the Christian natives, which is built of raupo and tohi-tohi grass, according to the native fashion. Ibid. 1/289 The New Zealand flax grows in every direction ... and the tohi tohi, a species of long rush-like sedge, is abundant on the margin of the water, and in marshy and damp situations. (1847,Savage Life,1/235)

WAKEFIELD The indigenous grasses are not numerous in their varieties, or remarkable, with the exception of the tohe-tohe, [at 240 toitoi] a reed whose leaves are sometimes four feet in length, and its cane-coloured seed-stems six feet in height. (1848,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),148)

6 This is a rich tract of land: some of it dry, and clothed with luxuriant grass; other portions of it more or less swampy, with a vegetation of flax, tohe-tohe, (a long riband-grass with graceful feathery seed-tufts,) ... (Jan 18, 1851,Lyttelton Times)

EARP About 200,000 acres consist of open land covered with grass, anise, fern, flax, and tohitohi. Arundo conspicua tohe-tohe (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),113)

BARKER The banks of the ... Avon ... are thickly fringed with weeping willows, interspersed with ... clumps of tohi, which is exactly like the Pampas grass you know so well in English shrubberies. (1866,Station Life in NZ,47,1870 ed.)

Then ... amongst the ... tohe tohe reeds, and saw-edged grass, a pair of Harriers had built their rough, flat-topped home or ... alarmed the pyebald Redbill, that circles round ... screeching its clamorous note; or we might watch the pied Stilt with long pink legs ... making for the rush-fringed lagoon ... (1870,TrNZI,2/47) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

TINNE There was some difficulty in picking one's way ... through the tall raupo (rush) and tohi-grass; ... (1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,28)

ANSON ... all the open ground surrounding the settlement [at Piraki] ... being covered with tussac-grass, raupo, or tohitohi (N.Z. pampas-grass). (1911,Piraki Log,155)

The valley is covered with a high crop of fern [,] flax, tohi tohi, tutu, and other shrubs. (May 16, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

n.

POTTS (1882,Out in the Open) [NOTES: (And)]

tohi-palm¶

n. Cordyline indivisa (See toi-palm)

tohitohi¶

n. [?any connection with TOI n2]

TAYLOR Tohitohi, a small fresh-water fish, about two inches long. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,414)

tohora¶

n. the southern right whale [ORIGIN: Maori]

COLLINS Eto-ho-ro-ha[macron], A whale. (1804,English Colony in NSW,561)

LEE & KENDALL Toh|ora, s. A sperm-whale. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,215)

POLACK Among the leviathans, who sport in shoals around these shores, the para paraua [a's-acute], or sperm-whale (Physeter macrocephalus); the tohora, or right-whale (Balaena bysticoetus); the mungu nui, or black physeter; the sun-fish (Diodonmola); fin-back (Balaena physalis); the musculus, or large-lipped whale; ... (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/323)

POLACK Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called para[as-acute] paraua[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, mungu nui (black physeter); right whale, tohora (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis)... (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/202fn)

DIEFFENBACH Tohora, or Right Whale. - Polack , N.Z. i. 323; ii.401. Balaena Antipodum, Gray. N.S.t1. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/183) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/183]

TAYLOR (1855,Te Ika a Maui,136)

`Looking at it as it lay extended, it resembled a very large whale (nui tohora).' (1878,TrNZI,11/90)

HECTOR `In the open sea, and to the south, the most prized whale next to the sperm is the black whale, or tohora (Eubalaena Australis), which is like the right whale of the North Sea, but with baleen of less value.' (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,21)

MORRIS Tohora, n, Maori name for a whale. [1855, 1878, 1883] (1898,Austral English,473)

REID Tohora, n, Maori name for a whale. [1855, 1878, 1883] (1961,New Zealand (various authors/titles),97) [NOTES: 1930 Cowan Tales of the M. Coast in 1961 Reid NZ 97]

RICHARDS Balaena australis ... [94] Southern Right Whale. TOHORA. (1952,Chatham Islands,93)

KEENE tohora or tohoraha: whale. (1963,O Te Raki,195)

tohora n. Maori name for the whale. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

tohora ... n. Maori name for whale. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

Orca the Killer and his mate, in their patrol of the seas, never went far from a certain bay, where a whaling station was; and the sea they searched for food was in the track that is followed by Tohora, the Right Whale of the Southern Seas, in his journeyings north. (Jan 21, 1911,Marlborough Express,6)

tohu¶

n.

HULME You chew absently ... and bring your other hand down to fiddle ... with that rattler, tohu, cloak pin, long dagger of pounamu you wear by the silver cross round your neck ... (1986,Te Kaihau,10)

tohunga¶

n. a (Maori) priest or gifted or learned person; a teacher, faith-healer, doctor, or wise man (often in English contexts, `medicine man') [ORIGIN: Maori] (See also priest,wizard)

COLLINS ?explanation Etang-a-te[acute]da Eti-ket-ti-ca, means a principal chief, or a man in very great authority. ... Etanga-roa, or E-ta-hon-ga, is a priest; whose authority in many cases is equal, and in some superior to the Etiketica. (1804,English Colony in NSW,344)

The tohangha (tohunga) Rakoo (Rakau) paid great attention to Mr. Hall; ... (Sep 6, 1814,Marsden's Lieutenants,59,1934 ed.) [NOTES: 1814 Sep 6 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 59]

The tohunga or medicine-man who revealed these secrets thus concluded his narrative. (1905,TrNZI,37/95)

BAUCKE attrib ... directly [the Maori] enters the domain of witchcraft, tipau' (ghouls),patupaiarahe' (fairy demons), dreams, or tohunga imbecilities, he becomes a fear-haunted, helpless perverter of truth! Ibid. 130 When the next measle, or other epidemics, come along, you send for that hideous monstrosity, your tohunga, who knows no more of treatment than that shag in the river there, who brings his stinking lotions and baths, his idiotic prescriptions, ... until the sufferer dies, and then stalks away to do murder elsewhere. Ibid. 262 In my recent outback explorations I have met with scenes which horrified ... and brought home to me ... the imperative necessity ... that it be a criminal offence, punishable with hard labour imprisonment, to practise tohungaism, boast of tohungaistic reputation, apply to a tohunga for illegal operations, and learning the incantations, ... (1905,Where the White Man Treads,14, 63)

Preamble WHEREAS designing persons, commonly known as tohungas, practise on the superstition and credulity of the Maori people by pretending to possess supernatural powers in the treatment and cure of disease, the foretelling of future events, and otherwise, and thereby induce the Maoris to neglect their proper occupations and gather into meetings where their substance is consumed and their minds unsettled, to the injury of themselves and to the evil example of the Maori people generally: ...[check if cap initial req for tohungas???] (1907,NZ Statutes,No. 13) [NOTES: 1907, No. 13 Title An Act to suppress Tohungas (24th September, 1907)]

The other party applied to a 'tohunga, or seer, for information. (Dec 7, 1872,Auckland Weekly News,5)

Ethnic statistics are fleshed out, the Tohunga Suppression Act is revisited and Maori genesis is show to be a way of healing the fragmentation of modern life. (Nov 28, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),40)

Ihimaera Something like the story you wrote about the wily Maori tohunga who puts a spell on a red-headed Irish woman? (2007,Ask the Posts,7)

We shall probably next hear of a tohunga applying to the Supreme Court for a writ of mandamus to some Maori Council. (Sep 3, 1904,NZ Observer,3)

Yes, it is better to be a tohunga than a seller of sly grog (Oct 1, 1904,NZ Observer,23)

The Maori Tohunga is a kind of bush Baptist who dips the community in a creek for every kind of ill. A girl named Kake was immersed up Hukerenui way, and died shortly after from inflammation of the lungs. A charge of murder occasionally would discourage Tohungaism. (Mar 7, 1908,NZ Truth,142/1/4)

It is not many years since a tohunga in the North Island materially reduced the Maori population by applying the same treatment to every patient I brought to him. ...Naturally, the cemetery began to assume a busy appearance, and the practice of his profession by the tohunga was cut short by a charge of manslaughter. (Jan 1913,NZ Truth,397/5/6)

When a party goes out eel-fishing at night, the old man of the band, the kaumatua or tohunga, divests himself of his clothes and goes first to the river-bank. (May 10, 1920,Quick March,38)

HENDERSON T.W. Ratana was a direct descendent of a tohunga and although he opposed tohungaism ... . (1972,Ratana,48) [NOTES: 1925 July 23 United Press in 1963 Henderson Ratana (1972) 48]

tohunga n. a priest; a prophet; a wise man. [Maori] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,12)

FINLAYSON (1938,Brown Man's Burden,42)

FINLAYSON All this became a bit of a nuisance for Tupara, the local tohunga, that old cure-all and fortune-teller. (1944,Brown Man's Burden,14,1973 ed.)

tohunga , expert: hence, tohunga-karakia, priest; tohunga-moko, tattooing expert; tohunga-whakairo, carving-expert; tohunga-makutu, devil-doctor. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/147) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

BEAGLEHOLE tohunga an expert in folk medicine or magic Ibid. 236 These [Otaki Maori] people tend to make a distinction along these lines between the semi-respectable curing-tohunga and the completely unrespectable sorcerer-tohunga. (1946,Some Modern Maoris,xxii)

PRIEST. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

The Maori name for the priest, prophet or `medicine-man' of the tribe. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),415)

The Maori name for the priest, prophet or `medicine-man' of the tribe. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),415)

SINCLAIR The ministers of religion were the tohunga, who were usually chiefs, though they did not form a hereditary or distinct caste. Ibid. 302 [Maori glossary] tohunga Wizard; priest; skilled person. (1959,History of New Zealand,22)

KEENE tohunga: priest, expert (1963,O Te Raki,195)

tohunga n. Maori name for wise man, magician. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

BRATHWAITE (1967,Evil Day,382)

tohunga ... n. Maori word for wise man, magician [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

FINLAYSON tohunga: traditionally an expert, learned man or priest; in recent time a faith-healer. (1973,Brown Man's Burden,142)

LELAND Tohunga: Maori WITCHDOCTOR, priest, wise man, scholar, etc. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,104)

tohunga n. N.Z. a Maori priest, the repository of traditional lore. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1231) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 808; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 505]]

TOHUNGA Priest. Mr Manihera held one of the most prestigious positions in Maoridom as tohunga (high priest of knowledge) in the Mataatua canoe tribes (Jul 6, 1983,Dominion,4)

The young Maori who stole the sacred pouwhenua from outside the Tauranga Town Hall on Friday night is risking ostracism and death, says respected Maori leader Sir Graham Latimer. Sir Graham has issued a special plea to the young man to return the pouwhenua (a sacred post) and to consult a tohunga (Maori spiritual advisor). (Sep 20, 1987,Sunday News,1)

Educated Maoris favour the new order, and impute the national decay [in health] to modern tohungas, who are but imposters; ... (Jul 1910,Kai Tiaki,103)

The taiaha Barney wields in the challenge has been ritually blessed by tohunga Oho Brown. (Jun 4, 1983,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

EDWARDS The tohunga is a very wairua person, trained.. to know what sort of bush plants to look for, and how to give it to a person. (1992,Mihipeka,56)

MANING Kawiti, who is himself a tohunga, throws a rakau for his own path. (1973,Old New Zealand,255) [NOTES: Original edition 1863]

I have met with scares which.. brought home to me.. that it be a criminal offence, punishable with hard-labour imprisonment, to practice tohungaism, boast of a tohungaistic reputation, apply to a tohunga for illegal operations, and learning the incantations, for the latter is the tap root of the upas tree. (Feb 11, 1905,NZ Herald,Suppl. 1)

A CENTENARIAN TOHUNGA FOUND ALIVE AT WAIROA. (Jun 15, 1886,Waikato Times,2)
