A "tomo", for the benefit of novices and overseas readers, is from the Maori language, a generic term for any sort of pot-hole or sink-hole. (Mar 1953,NZ Speleological Bulletin,I/5 : 10)

I look back on the Tomo Thyme expeditions as times of really good fun. (Sep 1992,NZ Speleological Bulletin,IX/163 : 80)

The drainage of this limestone dip-slope area is mostly underground by means of sink-holes or tomos,' which are so common as to give the nameTomo Country' to the district. (1946,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.41 (NS) 20) [NOTES: (Marwick, `The Geology of the Te Kuiti Subdivision') see also p. 37]

Te Kuiti, April 14 (P.A.) - A slip into a tomo (A water-worn hole) over 100 feet deep resulted in the death yesterday of ... of Oparue, Te Kuiti. ... A search resulted in the finding today of his rifle on the tomo edge ... (Apr 14, 1952,Evening Post) [NOTES: Apr 14 (?15 or 20th?)]

(1952,Arena,31/3)

(1953,Short Stories (various authors),188) [NOTES: 1953 Middleton in 1966 Short Stories 188]

MASON tomos with [Limestone hole] in brackets as explanation. Some way further north many tomos noted (1954,Personal Communication,2)

MIDDLETON `Coming to look for tomos?' he used to sing out ... (1959,Stone, The,32) [NOTES: (The Stone)]

(1959,Tararua,xiii/47)

PARK (1961,Hole in the Hill,76)

CASEY He wouldn't have had a show if the horse hadn't swerved off the road and gone straight through the crust of a small tomo, a volcanic cavity in the ground, and wasn't able to clamber out again. (1963,As Short a Spring,72)

WATSON ... a lot of new things came into our life when we were at Taupo. ... And there weren't any fears in our life then, either; except for tomos that might be there covered with bracken and you wouldn't see them and you might fall in ... (1965,Stand in the Rain,122)

See him [sc. a shepherd] drag a gully full of tomos and patches of scrub and guarantee ... you wouldn't find one straggler. (1966,NZ Short Stories,127,1976 ed.) [NOTES: (Middleton `Saving the Breed')]

NEWTON A characteristic of this limestone country [near Te Kuiti] are its caves and underground tunnels or holes - `tomos'. One of the Puketi tomos has been measured to run for two miles.... (1972,Wake of The Axe,155)

S H WILSON Completely enclosed cavity found in volcanic ash or pumice beds, sometimes filled with steam or gas. (Sep 14, 1980,Letter)

HOLDEN He seemed to think that the dog was stuck down a tomo (deep chute-like hole) somewhere [Waione-Galaxy area of Rotorua.] (1982,Wild Pig,168)

tomo n. NZ depression or hole in limestone terrain. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,809) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

The plateau is covered with a splendid growth of grass, and would form an excellent cattle run but for the deep funnel-shaped holes which everywhere abound. The Natives call them "tomo." (Jul 8, 1859,Auckland Provincial Gazette,VIII (14) : 94)

HOCHSTETTER The limestone formation.. forms a plateau.. remarkable for subterraneous water-courses, caves and deep funnel-shaped holes, called by the natives Tomo. [Fn] Tomo signifies crumbling, sinking down, and is therefore very appropriate (1867,New Zealand (Polack),340)

A fortnight later she turned a flip into a tomo - (a miniature cave) - the King Country is riddled with them. (Feb 26, 1927,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,39)

PARK Occasionally the ground fell in, creating an oubliette of raw earth out of which rose frightening plinks and gurgles and squishing sighs. These pits were called tomo, an abstruse word used sometimes of caves, such as the celebrated Waitomo Caves. (1992,Fence Around the Cuckoo,14)

The underlying caves are mainly horizontal, often with steep entrance shafts known as tomos (wai means water, tomo a hole in the ground). (Apr 1997,NZ Geographic,No. 34/43)

n. betrothal

HUTT At a 'tomo' (betrothal) ceremony, "Ratu's father then spoke... [later] the tomo proceedings had merged into that of the beer party." (1991,Maori & Alcohol,79) [NOTES: See Hohepa A Maori Community in Northland 1970, pp. 99-100]

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] a sink-hole or under-runner, down which sheep and cows can be trapped and left to die

MOWAT This afternoon filling in tomos and burning on front face. (Aug 18, 1936,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

MIDDLETON See him drag a gully full of tomos and patches of scrub and guarantee if you went over it all on foot afterwards you wouldn't find one straggler. (1953,Short Stories (various authors),26)

NEWTON One of the Puketiti tomos has been measured to run for two miles, and some of them are a death trap for stock. (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,155)

LOUGHNAN tomo: name adopted from the Maori for an underrunner. 'we'll have to fence that tomo.' (1981,Loughnan Glossary,85)

tomo group¶

n.

There are now quite a number of Tomo Groups in New Zealand. In what places do they practise their rather chilly sport? (Jul 1972,Affairs,23)

Tomorrow's Manukau - Manukau Apopo¶

phr. Manukau City Council's long term strategic plan

John's valuable insight into community issues and his work on the community consultation for Council's long term strategic plan, Tomorrow's Manukau - Manukau Apopo, will be of lasting benefit to all of Manukau's residents. (Dec 6, 2005,NZ Herald,C8)

Tomorrow's Schools¶

phr.

The Tomorrow's Schools policy provided an innovative and sound model of educational administration which achieved a consensus among parents and teachers. However, education policy in the last 18 months has substantially departed from Tomorrow's Schools as market-oriented policies have been introduced. (May 11, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

The Education Ministry had been deliberately allowed to become a spectator of school failure in the 10 years since the introduction of the Tomorrow's Schools model... The original scheme of Tomorrow's Schools did not anticipate that the Ministry of Education would become a spectator. Ibid. 11 The Tomorrow's Schools reforms saw the abolition of the Department of Education and thousands of elected parents taking over the governing of their local schools... "It's important to bear in mind what Tomorrow's Schools was and what it wasn't." (Sep 29, 1999,Dominion,8)

Northern suburbs educators are looking back on 10 years of Tomorrow's Schools with a mixture of opinions... "The co-operative ideals of Tomorrow's Schools have been betrayed by the very agencies that are supposed to serve schools." (Oct 12, 1999,Independent Herald (Wellington),11)

The Education Act 1989 brought in Tomorrow's Schools and radically overhauled an education administration system that had changed little in concept for over a century. (Nov 5, 1999,NZ Education Review,14)

Is Tomorrow's Schools communication between school and community, the democratic process in action, or a fruitless round of meetings to put ideals on paper? (Dec 4, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),131)

Rees-Thomas dislikes the notion, central to Tomorrow's Schools, of open-slather competition between state schools. (May 20, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34)

The whole thing began, really, with Tomorrow's Schools ... teaching had always been about teachers sharing resources and working co-operatively, and suddenly it became individual schools working on their own. (Jul 6, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

Under the Tomorrow's Schools system, each school gets a block grant, from which they have to pay for everything from chalk and school books to toilet taxes. (Oct 14, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

The Tomorrow's Schools reforms introduced in 1988 gave every school its own governing body and the school structures in existence in October 1989 are the ones that are still in place today. (Jun 12, 2006,NZ Herald,A11)

tomtit¶

n. (Environment) a small bird found in both the native bush and exotic forest, also called miromiro or ngirungiru; occas. used for esp Petroica toitoi, pied tit, white-breasted tit (tomtit preferred for euphemistic reasons to TIT simplex) (See tit)

The wren and the tomtit and the thrush all are represented quite as nearly or even more so than the robin save that the tomtit is black headed with a yellow breast. (Jun 1860,Forest Creek MS,44,1960 ed.)

PETROICA MACROCEPHALA, Gml. Ngirungiru. Piro piro. Tomtit. (1870,TrNZI,2/59) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

MYIOMOIRA TOITOI, Reich. Pied Tit. This familiar little bird, the `Tomtit' of the Colonists, is far less plentiful than it formerly was ... (1878,TrNZI,10/203) [NOTES: (Buller)]

SUTHERLAND The robins, riflemen and tomtits tamed very soon, the robins being an easy first in this respect. (1953,Golden Bush, The,108,1963 ed.)

EVANS Bush robins, parakeets, tomtits, grey warblers, riflemen, pigeons and the bush hawk are still to be seen. (1962,Waikaka Saga,129)

FALLA et al. TOMTIT Petroica macrocephala Other names: Miromiro (North Island), Ngirungiru (South Island), Wheedler, Butcher-bird (Taranaki). (1966,Birds of New Zealand,200)

McLINTOCK Tomtit .. miromiro (North Island), ngiru-ngiru (South Island) .. Petroica macrocephala ... (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

NATUSCH There are five races of tomtits (Petroica macrocephala): the pied tit (toitoi) of the North Island and outlying islands; the yellow-breasted (macrocephala) from the South Island, Stewart Island and neighbouring islands; the Snares black (dannefaerdi); and the Auckland Islander (marrineri). (1967,Animals of NZ, The,279)

JOHNSON .. their way still led through bush-land, and .. tiny birds began to appear: perky tomtits in immaculate suits of black and white .. grey warblers trilling their lilting arias. (1968,Turn Back the Clock,69)

HUNT No, my father didn't mind us shanghaiing thrushes and that, but he always said don't touch the natives. We did, though - pigeons and tomtits and tuis. (1985,I'm Ninety-five,261) [NOTES: (Wattie, Stewart I.)]

tomtit n. tit; small NZ bird, esp. miromiro. [TOM, TIT] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,810) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

BULLER .. to say nothing of Korimako and Pitoitoi .. we never saw or heard the notes of either the Piopio, the Tieke, or the Hihi, all of which birds were at one time more numerous even than the Huia. The Zosterops was everywhere abundant, also the Grey Warbler and Rifleman, and .. we found the Tomtit comparatively plentiful; the Parakeet chased its mate through the tree-tops with sharp cries of `twenty-eight'; .. and among the tangle of the underwood the ever-present Flycatcher displayed its pretty fan-like tail. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/14)

MORRIS Tomtit, n. name applied in New Zealand to two New Zealand birds of the genus Myiomoira, the species being M. toitoi, Garnot, in North Island; M. macrocephala, Gmel., in South Island. [1888 Buller] (1898,Austral English,475)

Toḿ.tit́. (t&obreve.ḿ.t&ibreve.t́. or t~oḿ.t&ibreve.t́.), n. (Zoo.l.) [Add.] (c) Either of two species of miro. See MIRO. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

I have paid special attention to the nests of three birds- the Native Canary (Orthonyx ochrocephala), the Robin (Myiomoira albifrons), and the Tomtit (Myiomoira macropcephala). Sir Walter Buller says .. that the Blue Crow (Glaucopis cinerea) lays a single egg, and .. leaves the care of the chick to the to the Popokatea, or Canary (Orthonyx albicilla). (1904,TrNZI,36/119)

WILLIAMS Homiromiro .. = miromiro, n. Petroeca toitoi, tomtit. [so 1957/58] (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,68)

Born under another state of things, it [Governor Grey's Appeal Bill] slumbered for a term of years, and has been only now woke up, to find itself old, without having really ever lived - emerging from its roosting hole like an owl into daylight, perplexed and dismayed by the strange company in which it finds itself, buffeted, like that venerable bird, by every tomtit that comes across it. (Apr 21, 1857,Daily Southern Cross,3)

Numbers of native birds such as tomtits, white heads, grey warblers and fantails are expected to increase in the Otaki catchment of the Tararua Forest Park ... (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 11)

n. shit [rhyming slang]

HILLIARD And what of Kruschen?'To help him towards his daily tom-tit, and for the same reason, ...' (1976,Send Somebody Nice,17)

MANTELL `First time I saw him nearly had tomtits. Thought he'd fall for certain.' (1978,Murder in Fancydress,123)

ton¶

2 n. a hundred sheep

ton: A hundred sheep and the first target for a learner. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/28) [NOTES: Wallace Shearing Glossary]

tonga¶

n. goods [variant of Maori taonga]

STALLWORTHY [The spars cut by Maori spar-contractors c1850] were paid for in tonga (that is, in goods). The tonga consisted of axes, tobacco, pipes, clothing, blankets, etc. (1916,Early Northern Wairoa,27)

n. [Williams nf: is this a nominalisation of 436 Tonga (i) South wind. > cold > protection????; or is it an anglicisation of TAONGA (see TAONGA)]

CAMPBELL This [shawl] was [69] his tonga' or rug, which had been hidden when he departed the previous night ... <i>Ibid</i> 1/123 They generally wear thetonga', or blanket, and fold it round them, ... (1864,Martin Tobin,1/68)

Tonga granite¶

n. [aka Tonga Bay granite - NZ source, not Tongan]

[Advt] This Tonga granite, so-called from its abiding place at Tonga Bay, between Motueka and Takaka.. is an asset of considerable value to the Dominion. (Dec 1912,NZ Free Lance,Xmas Annual : 29)

1905 Nelson Evening Mail 19 September. 2 The first cut granite blocks from the Tonga Granite Company's Quarry are now lying on the Government wharf for shipment to Wellington and Dunedin, and they look very handsome in their wooden cases. (Sep 19, 1905,Nelson Evening Mail,2)

There is much activity at present at the Tonga Island quarry (says the Nelson Mail), owing to the acceptance of the contract for building the new Public Trust Office at Wellington of Tonga granite. (May 18, 1907,Evening Post,9)

Tongan Adidas¶

n. sandals

Tongan Adidas: jandals (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: Goldie Brown Collection]

Tongaporutuan¶

adj. rock classification

On the 27th the party travelled north, examining Tongaporutuan conglomerate in cliffs at Urenui, proceeding then to Awakino Valley where fossil bearing Triassic and Jurassic strata were examined, and, later, mid-tertiary limestone. (Nov 1959,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,7/3)

Larsen, C.V. Grain Size as a Possible Controlling Environmental Factor in a Lower Tongaporutuan Section at Palliser Bay. (Jun 1974,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,37/17)

tongs¶

n. handshears

handshears: These are the tool of the blade shearer and usually called blades'. Also known assheep shears', shears',tongs', swords',b-bows', bows',daggers', and `Jingling Johnnies'. Ibid. 3/29 tongs: Hand shears. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/25) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

Tongs.-Nickname for blade shears. (Jan 27, 1934,Press, The,15)

BAKER We find shears called jingling johnnies and tongs... (1941,NZ Slang,39)

MILLS For the benefit of the non-farming reader, blade shearing is done by twin-bladed sheep shears [41] (called `tongs') ... (1960,Sheep-O,40)

NEWTON A top blade-man in his day . . . He's past using a pair of tongs now but I noticed he's still got a dog tied up in his backyard. (1973,Big Country,20)

I can handle a pair of tongs. (Oct 29, 1984,TV1) [NOTES: 1984 Oct 29 Country GP TV1]

n.

(Dec 1958,NZ Timber Journal,73/1)

1 n. (Rural) [shearing] hand or blade shears.

Tongs.- Nickname for blade shears. (Jan 27, 1934,Press, The (Acland Glossary),15)

BAKER We find shears called jingling johnnies and tongs. (1941,NZ Slang,39)

Ex-Pupils Budget March 1. 11 Our muscles protested at the effort , and the old tongs felt even colder than the sneakers had done ... (1946)

NEWTON A top blade-man in his day, he claims that his 164 ewes, at Molesworth, is the blade record for that shed. He's past using a pair of tongs now. (1973,Big Country of the South Island,20)

GORDON They used - and still do in parts of the high country - shears, exactly the same as those a down on his knees edge trimmer uses. But slightly adapted and much sharper and liable to be called "Tongs" or "Jingling Johnies." (1983,Other Side of Farming, The,2)

tongue¶

n. (Rural) [sheepdogs] a useful bark.

NEWTON .. when our forty odd dogs came screaming round a bend in the road, flat out and full tongue ... (1964,Straggle Muster,24)

SHARPE They'll give tongue, too, when they get excited ... (1966,Fiordland Muster,96)

Tongue and Meat Club¶

phr. Wellington Tramping AND Mountaineering Club [ca1952 R. Mason A contemptuous nickname for this club which assumed the all-inclusive provincial title though only the fourth or fifth oldest in Wellington. Now (1952) used by W.T.M.C. members themselves. At a meeting of the Wellington Association of Mountain Clubs a member of the W.T.M.C. can be a `Tongue and Meat'.]

Tongue and Meat Club, that name bestowed on the Wellington Tramping and Mountaineering Club by the scarcely sympathetic members of fellow clubs when it first adopted its present name, has become so established that a W.T.M.C member may now introduce himself by saying `I'm a Tongue and Meat'. (Sep 1958,Tararua,30)

tongue-bashing¶

n. occas. variant of tongue-lashing [ca1945 Wellington]

tongue-murder¶

v.

Tongue-murdering' appears to be a new term applied to slandering a man, orputting his pot on' with intent to do him harm. At least it is a new term to this writer ... [and] was used during the hearing of an assault case at Lyttelton. ... using some kerbstone language with much emphasis ... `You've tongue-murdered me ... (Nov 11, 1905,NZ Truth,21/5/8)

tongue-thrashing¶

n. a tongue-lashing

VAILE I roared and gave him a real good tongue-thrashing. (1939,Pioneering the Pumice,54)

tongueing¶

n. a tongue-lashing

THOMSON [My father] would give me a rare old `tongueing' and perhaps a "tanning'. (1905,Bush Boys of NZ,59)

tonguer¶

n.

BAKER The now obsolete term tonguer was also in use in the early 1830's, and very likely before it although I have discovered no written records of it prior to 1836. A tonguer was a native or white living in New Zealand who assisted a whaling crew to cut up whales and who also acted in the capacity of an interpreter. These men earned their name not from the act of interpreting, but from the fact that they were given the whale's carcase and tongue to dispose of as they wished. (1941,NZ Slang,13)

CAPT JOY ... it was told to me by our toungers [sic, at Cloudy Bay] that the cost [of a shore-hut] was trifling. ... I left them [sc Maoris] Came [sic] on board and despatched the boat the other side for a linguist our tounger. (The Ships all employ Tonguers [sic] and it is a general custom I have acceded on the same terms as others) On his arrival we opened the Subject but they [sc Maoris] were ashamed and finally settled that they would build the house. ... I must not omit here Some mention of what are called tonguers. they [sic] are here 2 and 3 white people who have a boat and some natives on a ship arriving they repair on board to solicit the Job for the ship The terms are that they occasionally furnish a crew to help tow whales they furnish a boats crew to help cut the whale in and do any talking for the captain whose ignorance of the language requires their aid in any matters with the natives. When the whale is cut in they are entitled to the carcass and the tongue which in plentiful Whaling is always left on the carcass and they contrive to get for [sic] 6 to 8 barrels of oil from each carcass but they are in general Blackguards and no dependence can be put in them - Runaways from Ships Mostly. [McNab's ed. fn] The Americans had ... to rely to a great extent upon Maori labour and to be indebted to the services of interpreters. These men were locally [?Cloudy Bay] called tonguers'. ... InThe Piraki Log' [1911] the word tonguer' is suggested as a corruption of the Maoritonga'. This is quite wrong. The tonguer was a man who interpreted and assisted in cutting up and who was paid with the tongue of the whale.[choose between this and following citation???] (Apr 28, 1835,Log of Mary Mitchell) [NOTES: 1836 Apr 28 Capt. Joy Log of Mary Mitchell in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 435, 436]

CAPT JOY The Principal Chief (Te Rauparaha) is absent on one of his marauding traverses like the Ancient bands (of) Pirates and his authority delegated to 3 chiefs 1 on the western shore the other 2 here ... I despatched the boat the other side for a linguist or tonguer ... I must not omit here Some[sic] mention of what are called touguers. They are here 2 or 3 white people who have a boat [40] and some natives. On a ship arriving they repair on board to solicit the Job for the ship. The terms are that they occasionally furnish a crew to help tow whales, they furnish a boats crew to help cut the whale in and do any talking for the Captain whose ignorance of the language requires their aid in any matters with the natives. When the whale is cut in they are entitled to the carcass & the tongue which in plentiful Whaling is always left on the carcass and they contrive to get from 6 to 8 barrels of oil from each carcass but they are in general Blackguards and no dependence can be put in them - Runaways from Ships Mostly. (Apr 28, 1836,Log of Mary Mitchell,39)

[He] found it to be James Robinson, the Tonguer from Wongooloa [ed Anson note Glossary 166: The word is obviously a corruption of the Maori tonga' meaningfrom the South', or `Southerner'; ... ] (Apr 10, 1839,Piraki Log,82)

JOHNSON After the ships had cut off the blubber ... the carcase was towed on shore by a crew of men, who call themselves `tonguers'. These men take off what little blubber the ship's crew have passed over, and also take out the tongue and try it all out. (1840,Plain Truths,60)

DIEFFENBACH The tongue was of a white or ash colour, blackish towards the root. This organ gave several barrels of oil, and is a monopoly of the tonguer,' orcutter-in.' The latter operation is performed in Te-awa-iti near the shores, where by means of a windlass the whale is raised to the surface of the water under a scaffold called the shears.' <i>Ibid.</i> 1/109 To this quantity must be added the tonguer's oil, so called from the man whocuts-in the whale,' for which he is allowed the oil of the tongue, of the heart, and of the intestines, for his own benefit. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/51)

WAKEFIELD The ["tonguer"]takes his name from having an exclusive right to the oil obtained from the tongue and other interior parts of the whale in payment for his duty of `cutting in', or dissecting the whale. (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/323)

McNAB The Americans had ... to rely to a greater extent on Maori labour, and to be indebted to the services of interpreters. These men were locally [at Cloudy Bay] called tonguers'. <i>Ibid.</i> 322 The Robinsons, so their names were given to the Doctor [Thiercelin in January 1840 at Akaroa], acted ascarcassiers', as the French called them, collecting stray floating whales, or the intestines of whales ... blown into the Bay, and melting them down to produce an inferior [323] class of oil which they sold to the whalers. Among the English-speaking whalers these men were called `tonguers'. (1913,Old Whaling Days,194) [NOTES: [see also 1836 citations???]]

BAKER The now-obs word tonguer was also in use in the early 1830's... These men earned their name not from the ... interpreting, but from the fact that they were given whale's carcass and tonguer to dispose of as they wished,' B., 1945: New Zealand and whalers': C. 19. (1941,NZ Slang,13)

PARTRIDGE Tonguer. `A native or white living in New Zealand who assisted a whaling crew to cut up whales and who also acted ... [as] an interpreter. (1949,Dictionary of Slang Addenda,1205)

tonguer n. interpreter in whaling gang, given whale's tongue and carcase to dispose of. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

2 n. the worker who takes out the tongue and weasands [ca1951 May 17 Feilding freezing Works p.c. Colin Gordon Tonguer: one who cuts out tongue and who also `pulls the weasands'. [wiz ndz]]

tonguer's oil¶

n. an inferior whale oil

WRIGHT Also you must be more particular in keeping your dark or tonguers oil separate and branded as such, as I have been obliged to allow a deduction of [pounds]3 per tun ... (Nov 20, 1838,Letter) [NOTES: 1838 Nov 20 Wright Letter in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 232]

tonguing¶

n. perming hair in electrically heated rollers [misspelling of tonging? TD (check E-G)]

McGILL tonguing perming hair in electrically heated rollers; ref. Stevan Eldred-Grigg's Oracles and Miracles. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,114)

tonic¶

n.

SYDER & HODGETTS To drink alcoholic liquor in consecutive sessions, as over a weekend. .in 4;`No, he's stopped going to the pub, no more of those session he used to have - on the tonic for the weekend.' (1974,Australian & NZ English [TS],819)

tonk¶

n. [ca1941 esp among schoolboys: St Patrick's College, Silverstream; 1951 14 M 10 Wellington H.S. 1 TONK]

n. a penis [ca1938 Havelock schoolboys']

n.

The cook got my goat when he started doing the same thing. He was a tonk all right, just a real old auntie. (1943,Penguin New Writing,17/83)

SARGESON He was a tonk all right, just a real old auntie. (1946,That Summer,84)

SARGESON tonk: homosexual. (1964,Collected Stories,304)

tonky¶

n. fashionable

BENNETT Tonky suggests superior social standing or `tone'. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,89)

McGILL tonky fashionable; possible blend of toney' andswanky'; eg `My, my, doesn't she look tonky.' c. 1935. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,114)

tono¶

n. demand; application [ORIGIN: Maori]

The southerners were always in trouble with their tono because Pat spent maybe 40 of his 80 years in Te Arawa. (1995,Mana,No. 10 : 11)

tony¶

adj. having `tone', stylish; stuck up

Cowardly coves like Percy are much too tony to attack well-dressed bounders ... a tony performance. (Jun 24, 1905,NZ Truth,1/4)

He admitted that he was still living with `that' woman who said to be a housemaid at a very toney city hotel. (Aug 25, 1906,NZ Truth,62/6/2)

DEVANNY You have got some toney friends. (1928,Dawn Beloved,148)

BAUME She was most frightfully exclusive and tony. (1933,Half Caste,173)

PARTRIDGE Tony; loosely, toney. Adj., stylish, `swell'; high-toned: coll., orig. (- 1886), U.S. >, in 1890's, Australian and New Zealand. H. Lawson, 1901. (O.E.D.) Ex high tone, or possibly ex ob. ton-ish, tonish (itself ex ton, fashion). (1937,Dictionary of Slang,897)

too right¶

exclam. (informal) yes indeed! certainly! [Very common expression as far back as 1940s]

In short, it was tremendous fun, and too right I went back unsteadily for more. (Oct 14, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

"How do you plead, guilty or not guilty?" enquired the clerk. "Not guilty, too right I do," responded Florrie. (Nov 2, 1918,NZ Truth,2)

right ... NZ & Austral. ... too right exclamation of assent or approval. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,657) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

"Threatened me? Too right he has ..." (May 13, 1926,NZ Truth,9)

WINKS Too right' especially common in North Auckland, andgoody-oh' are two fascinating phrases [for Americans]. (1954,These New Zealanders,54,1956 ed.)

SLATTER He's a beaut. Too right he is. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,146)

JOSEPH I'm terribly sorry, Stan ....'She's right, Mr Keogh,' said the boy with a grin. We'll do it this time, eh?'Too right we will.' (1962,Pound of Saffron, A,152)

(1966,Short Stories (various authors),163) [NOTES: 1963 Ballantyne in 1966 Short Stories 163]

(slang phrase) n. mild ejaculation of approval or approbation. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

too right! (Sl. phr.) mild ejaculation of approval or approbation. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

HULME Bloody oath, Mat what good luck!' ...Shout you eh?' Too right you can. Double whisky.' <i>(1984,Some Other Country,182</i>) [NOTES: 1976 HulmeHooks and Feelers' in 1984 Some Other Country 182]

LELAND too right: `That's too right mate'. That's a correct statement (opinion), and furthermore I AGREE WHOLEHEARTEDLY with my friend. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,105)

MARSH I suppose so. Oh yes. Too right it was.' ...Are you thinking of Maria?' `Too bloody right I am, mate.' (1980,Photo-Finish,201)

SHERWOOD He can be tiresome, I imagine.'Too right he can, and I'm exhausted.' (1985,Botanist at Bay,49)

CRUMP Missus Wayne's a bit of a beaut, isn't she. She's a hard case all right. (1961,Hang on a Minute, Mate,159)

SCANLAN Too right I could'.You're not allowed to say too right.' (1934,Winds of Heaven)

MARSH What is it they say in this country? Too right. Too right I would darling. Ibid. 94 I'll have something to say to young Packer about that. Too right, I will ... (1937,Vintage Murder,34)

BENNETT The expressions too true',too right', in which too has its old intensive value, are in common use. (1943,English as it is spoken in NZ,90)

Too right - certainly, sure. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,39)

SOLJAK Following are examples of colloquialisms common to New Zealand and Australian English, with their English or American equivalent ... too right: certainly (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),115)

I would include among New Zealand English words: too right (May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class)

"Oh I don't know," objected Irene. "We get on very well without one here, don't we, Belinda?" "Too right," assented Belinda promptly (1933,Guardians of Tony, The,p19)

toodle about¶

v. to potter about, to fill in time (?tootle and toddle) [ca1945 Wellington (`to waste time')]

PHILLIPS Sunday: ... caught no eels - all toodling about - prayers ... (Sep 21, 1856,Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point,51)

tooey¶

n. (See tui)

tooky¶

n. a fuck (also as a v) possibly an echoic euphemism (cf NOOKY) as it does not appear to have a Maori base: rarely heard since the 1930s [ca1935 Havelock]

tookytook¶

n. an anglicised form of kotukutuku, the native fuschia tree (cf matagouri from tumatakuru) [ca1935 Havelock] (See kotukutuku)

MORRIS Tookytook, n. a corruption of Kotukutuku (q.v.), a Maori name equivalent to Konini, the fruit of the Fuchsia-tree (q.v.). ' (1898,Austral English,475)

TURNER The konini or native fuchsia is called kotukutuku in Maori, and has been called tookytook in English. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,168)

Tooḱ.y-tooḱ. (t&obreve.&obreve.ḱ.&ibreve.-t&obreve.oḱ.), n. [Corruption of Maori kotukutuku.] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International)

tool¶

n. a fool, a simpleton; a poor unlikeable fellow (?rhyming slang on fool, or dool; or a semantic development like `prick')

DAVIN (1970,Not Here, Not Now,107)

His international man of mystery is a tool. (Jul 4, 2001,Capital Times,6)

tool off¶

v. in the sense `to depart' is not obsolescent in NZ

GASKELL I think I'll tool off. (1947,Big Game,41)

Tooley Street¶

n.

We have the three tailors of Tooley Street with us still. (May 4, 1912,NZ Free Lance,8)

Who are we to think we make Tooley Street toe the mark? (Nov 10, 1926,NZ Observer,2)

She has been.. working in the famous Tooley Street. (Aug 18, 1938,NZ Observer,16)

The officers report that the best houses in Tooley Street have.. co-operated with them... Let me say at once that we have received nothing but co-operation, so far, from the Tooley Street people. (1936,NZ Parliamentary Debates,244/682)

Our officers in London have been asked to work with Tooley Street for the purposes of implementing the new policy. (1936,NZ Parliamentary Debates,244/682)

From the worried gentlemen in Tooley Street to the humblest cow-spanker, we all look to the cow. (Dec 18, 1926,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,35)

No knight ever learned more from a fall in the lists than New Zealand learned from many years of hard effort to share equally with Denmark in the popularity of the British butter consumer; and it is almost certainly a fact that both New Zealand and Denmark, and also the consumer, profited by the daily contest at the Round Table of non-romantic Tooley Street. (May 11, 1944,Evening Post,4)

Cold stores, capable of storing two thousand tons of butter and cheese, are being erected in Tooley Street. (May 21, 1894,Wanganui Herald,2)

[Caption] Tooley Street Control... The Prime Minister stated.. that.. the butter market in London was controlled by a committee of Tooley Street merchants who met daily and fixed a price. (Aug 24, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,23)

Captain FitzRoy said that he had never admitted that the Government had acted on any such principle as the one described; and that he requested that gentlemen would not attribute sentiments to him which were not his; and that he did not concur in the opinion expressed of the position of Maories [sic] and the settlers, although it might be the real opinion of some few persons who thought they represented the public, just as "the three tailors in Tooley Street" imagined that they were the people of England. (Nov 16, 1844,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,1)

Four merchants of Liverpool have rivalled the fame of "the three tailors of Tooley street" by addressing a letter to the Emperor of the French, enquiring if he intended to invade England. (Feb 21, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,3)

A Nominee Council, worse than a Tooley street oligarchy, aping a House of Lords in New Zealand! (Nov 30, 1852,Daily Southern Cross,3)

Hursthouse The Free Kirk of Scotland, were it twice as numerous and twice as "emigrationary" as it is, could no more colonise and fructify the noble province of Otago, than the "three Tailors of Tooley Street" could represent the people of England. (1857,New Zealand, or Zealandia,I: 251)

Mr Singleton, the Government cheese expert, states that "he found in Tooley Street, London, that merchants, sore over their losses of last year, are disinclined to contract for a whole season's butter supply, but prefer to purchase in London as consignments arrive ..." (Oct 21, 1907,Bay of Plenty Times,4)

toot¶

n. (See tutu)

FOR SALE, about 50 superior bred heifers most of them heavy in calf, and having been some time in the Colony, not liable to suffer from the effects of the Toot. (Jul 2, 1842,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,1)

W.D. MURISON We passed through the bush and came to an extensive flat with fern, flax and toot growing higher than your head. (Jan 19, 1856,Letter) [NOTES: Quoted in Francom, Margaret: An Otago Letter in Kiwi 40(3): 44.]

Toot (t&omacr.&omacr.t), n. (Bot.) See TUTU. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

One of them had been on hard drugs and started to get withdrawl pains and ranted and screamed all night like a cow that had eaten toot. (2001,Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success,228)

n. an idle or worthless person; a simpleton, fool 1888-1894; a worthless (or silly) person; also used in address: `You bloody toot! [ca1935 Havelock schoolchildren e.g. Ya toot! Don't be a silly toot.] (See cf. also tutter)

n. anus, bum [ca1935 Havelock e.g. I'll kick you up the toot. I'll root your toot. I've got a sore toot.]

tooted¶

adj. tutued [ca1949 Marlborough `tooted' used of circus elephants, affected by eating tutu.]

This recalls the fact that a tooted' sheep often displays no very obvious symptoms until it isworked'. (1909,TrNZI,41/305)

Two [cattle] beasts got slightly tooted coming over the horse range. (May 19, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,88,1950 ed.)

BATHGATE Mr Steel, the manager, told us that sheep were often tooted ... These were at once bled, and so far recovered that they would eat and often fatten, but they lost their gregarious instinct, and became what they called hermits. The hermits were kept in a special paddock, and supplied the station mutton. (1925,Random Recollections,20)

BEATTIE ... one or two [cattle] drowned at Molyneux and two tooted' at Teschemaker's ... <i>Ibid.</i> 152 I have had little experience of sheep beingtooted' [tutu-ed] [sic] or of scab. (1939,First White Boy Born in Otago,140)

BAKER Stock which ate tutu were said to be tooted... (1941,NZ Slang,27)

BEATTIE `Tooted' animals could be relieved and saved if bled in time, ... (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,29)

BEATTIE ... of a `tooted' (tutu poisoned) family who ate the berrries and then suffered a recovery; ... (1947,Pioneer Recollections,37,1956 ed.)

TOMLINSON After camping the night there, we had to cross Kerr's Hill which was covered with tutu, a poisonous plant for sheep, and the curse of drovers. ... Odd sheep started to get `tooted' and instead of pushing on the men started bleeding the sheep. This was done by cutting a vein under the eye. It was supposed to help the sheep, although I never thought it did any good. (1968,Remembered Trails,19)

McNEISH Tutu?' Polson inquired.We opened is stomik an there was the weed lying like clover.' `Tooted. I'm sorry, Droo.' (1970,Mackenzie,129)

tooth-leaved beech¶

n. Nothofagus fusca [[So Kirk, Botany Thames Goldfields TrNZI 1869 90]] (See beech)

The tooth-leaved beech (Fagus fusca) occurs in considerable quantity at the sea level ... (1879,TrNZI,11/445) [NOTES: (Kirk Hauraki Gulf)]

[Notho]fagus fusca,Hook. f. ... Tooth-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Auckland and in part of Otago and Southland. Black or Bull Birch of Lake Wakatipu. Red Birch of Wellington, Nelson, and in part of Otago and Southland. It is not so easy to see why any difficulty should have occurred in the identification of this fine timber-tree apart from the misleading tendency of the common names generally applied. The thin yet firm texture of the leaf, the prominent veins, the sharply-toothed margins, are characters that can only be confused with those afforded by a careless observer. Yet merely owing to the use of common names based upon colour, and applied or rather misapplied to the leaves, bark, or wood at the fancy of the bushman, no species has been more misunderstood. Ibid. 302 All the men engaged at the sawmills [of West Oxford] had heard of `tooth-leaved beech,' but only one or two of them had seen it growing, and no one had seen it converted. TOOTH-LEAVED B. F. fusca, Hook f. All these, however, are commonly called Birches. (1885,TrNZI,17/300) [NOTES: (Kirk, NZ Beeches),]

KIRK With the view of obviating the confusion caused by the misuse of the common names hitherto applied to the New Zealand beeches, I would suggest the adoption of new names based on the obvious characteristics of their foliage:- For Fagus fusca, tooth-leaved beech; for Fagus solandri, entire-leaved beech; and for Fagus menziesii, round-leaved beech. (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,17)

The utmost confusion prevails among the common names of the birches. There are scarcely two districts, a few miles apart, in which the same name is applied to the same tree, and a similar result may be obtained by consulting two bushmen in the same bush. With a view to obviating this difficulty Mr Kirk suggests the adoption of new names based of the obvious characteristics of foliage [e.g.] for Fagus fuscatooth-leaved beech'; for Fagus solandri `entire-leaved beech' etc. [This is unsuitable as foliage varies] I would suggest the retention of the common Otago names Fagus fusca - Red birch ; F. solandri - Black-heart birch ; F Menziesii - Silver birch. (1876,TrNZI,64/) [NOTES: (Blair),]

(1880,TrNZI,12/) [NOTES: (And)]

KIRK (1889,Forest Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

Beech ... In New Zealand, there are six species of true beeches, which according to Kirk are as follows - ... (1908,AJHR) [NOTES: Cockayne: Report on a Botanical Survey of the Tongariro National Park (And)]

tooth-leaved birch¶

n. Nothofagus fusca

[Native name] Tawhai-raunui .. [Settlers' name] Tooth-leaved birch .. [Family] Cupuliferae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,121) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 121]

toothed lancewood¶

n. Pseudopanax ferox, aka savage lancewood

LAING & BLACKWELL lancewood, toothed. (1906,Plants of NZ)

[Native name] Horoeka .. [Settlers' name] Toothed lancewood .. [Family] Araliaceae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,122)

Lancewood, toothed .. Pseudopanax ferox .. Wood very elastic and strong, suitable for cabinet making and walking sticks Pseudopanax ferox (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers)

The chameleon nature of the ferocious-looking toothed lancewood (Pseudopanax ferox) fascinates him for the same reason. As a juvenile, this unusual tree resembles an anorexic stick insect with thin, leathery leaves drooping pitifully from a single puny stem. (Sep 15, 2002,Sunday Star Times,D9)

The spindly, prehistoric-looking toothed lancewood Pseudopanax ferox is always a talking point. It undergoes a radical transformation as an adolescent, shedding its stiff, jagged, juvenile leaves to become a fairly ordinary dark green tree. (Oct 31, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),47)

toothfish¶

n. a desirable but ugly Antarctic fish

The Government is to seek international agreement for up to three New Zealand ships to catch endangered toothfish in the Ross Sea near Antarctica this summer. (Jul 19, 2000,Dominion,2)

There's big money in toothfish... In posh restaurants they know ir as Chilean sea bass. To the Japanese, it is mero. (Aug 7, 2000,Dominion,8)

Toothfish has quite a unique flavour. Orange roughy is more opaque and white with a fleshy feel. This is a way lot more firmer. It's damn ugly to look at too. (Aug 13, 2003,Dominion Post,A7)

2 n.

Ross Sea toothfish are a separate species from the Patagonian variety. "The research we've gathered suggests this Antarctic variety grows faster than the Patagonian. They seem to mature in five to seven years and probably live from 30 to 409 years." (Aug 7, 2000,Dominion,8)

2 n.

It's sweet and delicate on the palate, and heavy on the wallet, but scarce supplies of Antarctic toothfish are now available in Wellington. (Aug 13, 2003,Dominion Post,A7)

toothpaste tube principle¶

phr.

Certainly it is not difficult to find places where the simple law of superposition appears to be no longer obeyed, and other places where the rock architect appears to have made an over-enthusiastic use of the tooth-paste tube principle in moving rocks. (Dec 3, 1960,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,9/7)

TOP¶

1 abbr. (Rural) Traits other than Production [a dairy breeding score of 17 criteria or traits.]

The information that can be gleaned from TOP, if the time is taken to use it, is of immense value. (May 31, 2002,Dominion,27)

The inspection of cattle and the official scoring by Jersey New Zealand through the Traits Other than Production (TOP) system is another service offered. Animals are scored for 17 traits on a 1 to 9 basis, which gets entered on the LIC database. (May 31, 2002,Dominion,29)

top¶

n. the deck (of a ship) or wharf (distinct from the hold `down below')

... a top job. Ibid. 104 You might get a job `on top'. (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book,65)

n. (Rural) a best quality farm-produced animal.

MOWAT Brought sheep in, picked out the tops, then drafted up some odds and ends. (Feb 26, 1931,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

MOWAT Stan, June and I to the yards & drafted off 60 wethers, the tops of the mob which I hope to fatten. (Jan 31, 1941,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

NEWTON With both the steer calves and the wether lambs, the tail-enders plus a few of the tops are sold at weaning time and the balance are held over. (1972,In the Wake of the Axe,156)

Jersey diary heifers - Tops, BW 112. (May 4, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,29)

n.

MACDONALD A top' is a ball of sorted, scoured, and combed wool. As the sovereign is the recognised standard monetary coin so istop' the recognised basis of manufactured wool dealings. (1920,Australian & NZ Sheep Farming,145)

n.

ANDERSON They led me along a tunnel (level, as they called it), which ran at right-angles from the main drive. At the coal-face two men were working up a ladder ... They're blowing out tops,' Charlie explained.Lumps of coal hanging from the ceiling are a danger to men working below'. (1981,Both Sides of the River,45)

n. the head, esp. in phrs off one's top [ca1938]

n. high point, ridge of mountain on musterer's beat (See tops)

HARPER [Is he] sleeping out top. (1937,Windy Island,22)

NEWTON Brownie was to do the top and the head shepherd was to be `under the top'. (1949,High Country Days)

McLEOD Get up on a high top with a musterer and he will gaze out across the far ranges and ask you what this peak is... (1951,High Country,44)

v. sc. a saw

BAUCKE And while I topped', andset,' and filed [the old saw], the mother looked from them to me ... (1905,Where the White Man Treads,178)

1 n. (Rural) a highest paddock or mountain pasture [grazing sheep in the summer, and from where the top-man takes his mustering beat.]

EVANS .. cannot give a full account until the tops have been mustered for shearing. (Nov 25, 1867,Letter,242) [NOTES: in Vance (1965) High Endeavour]

Fixed up crossing onto rocky staircase .. rode home up Stuart's paddock mustering the sheep up to the tops. (Apr 24, 1889,Tutira Station Diary)

THOMSON Higher up the valley they [sandflies] weren't so bad, and out on the open tops they ceased to exist ... (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,169)

NEWTON .. we managed to get out on to a top from which was a good view of much of the country. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,222)

PORTER .. the slow drive back to the safe country, where the sheep spent the months of winter, here we had to watch them carefully because if left alone the stupid beasts would try to return to the tops. (1970,Under the Nor'West Arch,33)

LOUGHNAN tops: the high country. Hence the phrase - for working or grazing - 'on the tops.' (1981,Loughnan Glossary,86)

WRIGHT .. the typical 'back country' sheep run, where the sheep were let loose across the tops, grazing on fern regrowth. (1985,Farming in the Mohaka State Forest,4)

GORDON You still miss it, nothing like it - getting up on those tops at daylight. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,179)

BARNES Originally Ian used the chopper to actually muster the sheep off the tops down to 1,200 metres ready for the men to take them home. [open tops] (1987,Country Calendar (TVNZ),116)

1 v. (Rural) [mustering] to reach a vantage point on the top of a hill or ridge.

NEWTON Before I topped the ridge on my way out the next morning ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,196)

top (on)¶

v. to inform on

Detective Denis O'Rourke said Spence denied knowledge of the alleged rapes, and said he would `do time rather than top on his mates'. (Oct 9, 1973,NZ Truth,51)

And he claimed that he was told that he would be looking down the end of a 12 gauge' if hetopped' about the alleged rape of his girl-friend. (Jan 24, 1973,NZ Truth,3)

JUSTIN One morning three of us were sitting behind some boxes having smoko. One said, `One thing about our [prison] librarian friend, he's improved. He doesn't top any on us all so everyone can hear.' (1973,Prisoner,33)

MACKENZIE top, to to inform on someone. To hang (1980,While We Have Prisons,99)

DAVIS `That flaming tally-clerk must have topped me, I heard Gaint groan, ... (1964,Watersiders,31)

top and tail¶

v. to sleep (or fit) head to foot (e.g., of children in a bed, of people in a bunk or small tent) (cf HEADS AND TAILS) [ca1952 R. Mason citing N. T. Moar used of trampers on a hut mattress]

top beat¶

1 n. (Rural) a highest altitude mustering area in a muster.

STRONACH The man on the top beat, in all but exceptional circumstances, keeps a little in front [in a sidling operation]. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,23)

PASCOE & WOODALL Usually one man and his dogs will climb well above the sheep to what is known as the 'top beat.' (1958,NZ Sheep Station,22)

LOUGHNAN top beat: though it comes from musterers' parlance the expression is not used by them alone. It is the 'plum' job of a day though it ensures the longest climb. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,85)

HALL It's lonely working the top beat on a muster. The next shepherd may be a kilometre away and you've got to think ahead as you move along, to ensure you keep in line with the others and cover the country. (1987,Shepherd's Year, A,52)

CHARLES There's no place I'd rather be,/ Than the top beat/ With a snow-line boundary./ (1981,Black Billy Tea,35)

top beat man¶

1 n. (Rural) a musterer who works in a mustering team at highest altitude. (See high beat man; top man)

MOMATIUK & EASTCOTT The top beat man will go for the ridge, others for their assigned positions further down the slope. (1980,High Country,69)

top hand¶

n.

OWEN & PERKINS Like most bushmen, his axe-work was a mighty necessary part of his makeup (and Old Dad was a top hand'). If he wasn't a good man on the end of a saw - some blokes werejockeys', they rode it - well, he wouldn't last long in the bush as far as his work was concerned ... (1986,Speaking a Silence,62) [NOTES: (Bob Edwards, bushman)]

top lip¶

n.

BOWEN The present-day Romney, with wool to the toe and even on the `top lip' is much different from the clear open-pointed Romney of fifty years ago. (1955,Wool Away!,9)

top man¶

n. attrib use of TOP n1, of the highest level of a musterer's beat; or phs as a collocation TOP MAN, the musterer working the higher (or highest) beat (See also top beat man)

HARPER ... the top man (1937,Windy Island,232)

BLAKISTON Starting at dawn, we climbed up the Clayton side of the range, leaving men at intervals to muster along the side, and the top man waited while others went through the saddle to muster the southern side. (1952,My Yesteryears,18) [NOTES: [f. c1869]]

n. (Rural) a musterer in a mustering team who has the beat at highest altitude. (See top beat man; high beat man)

NEWTON Although their instructions were to 'just scratch the bottoms' it was inevitable that the top man would have some long hard 'heads' catching sheep up in the basins. (1949,High Country Days,70)

STRONACH On the third spur I stopped to await the top man. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,53)

NEWTON The top man in this case was following a narrow ridge straight into a cold southerly. (1964,Straggle Muster,105)

It was probably another quarter of an hour or so before the topman showed ... (Mar 23, 1967,NZ Farmer,35)

MCLEOD If there is any extra work at the end of the day such as killing a sheep or driving the mob on round the hill, the bottom man gets the job, not the top man. (1970,Many a Glorious Morning,92)

KERR Breakfast is timed so the top man - the one with the highest beat - can reach his starting position by daybreak. (2000,High Times in the High Country,44)

KERR The top man moves off with others slightly behind to stop sheep breaking back behind them. (2000,High Times in the High Country,45)

2 n. (See top)

Before preference to unionists was passed the pay [for coal workers in the Wellington Branch of the Waterside Workers' Federation] was per hour for shovellers 1s 6d and for top hands (i.e. winchmen, bullrope-men, trimmers, and tippers), is 3d. .. A gang of men consists of eight - four shovellers - and four top men - with an aggregate of 11s per hour, before preference. (Jun 9, 1911,Maoriland Worker,14/12/3)

top milk¶

n. the creamy top of a bottle of milk; aka top of the milk [ca1950 Wellington 1980 p.c. Ross Clark (Auckland)]

(Oct 1949,Here & Now,10/3)

LELAND top of the milk: As most Kiwis don't like their milk homogenized, a thick layer of CREAM accumulates at the top of your milk bottle. Many private recipes call not for cream, but top of the milk. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,105)

top off¶

v. to inform against

He wasn't exactly a topper, but you couldn't trust him not to top you off if the occasion was right, ... (Nov 1953,Here & Now,44) [NOTES: (Hamilton)]

NEWBOLD TOP OFF (v) Inform against. Australian, since about 1920. (1982,Big Huey, The,255)

1 phr. (Rural) to finish the condition of stock.

PERRY In the South Island large areas of rape and soft turnips, and a certain quantity of kale and other fodder crops are grown to top off the lambs. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,70)

Such an area could be used later in the season for topping off cattle or sheep which are intended for the meat-works. (Oct 20, 1926,NZ Journal of Agriculture,231)

During 1923 a mob of forward store lambs on account of Messrs. Dailey and Manchester was drafted into two lots of 150 each and topped off on lucerne and rape respectively. (Dec 20, 1928,NZ Journal of Agriculture,387)

Rape is used to top off other drafts and ewe lambs are weaned on to the best pasture. (Oct 22, 1953,NZ Farmer,4)

NEWTON In common with Lagoon Hill the 2-tooth wethers are shorn and sent to one of their fattening farms to be topped off ... (1969,Big Country of the North Island,43)

top rail¶

n. sc of a POST-AND-RAIL fence [AND 1898] check Chudleigh

top shelf¶

n.

On the top shelf behind the bar were 16 or 18 bottles, also labelled as cordials. (Dec 22, 1876,Clutha Leader,5)

SLATTER So we did our drinking in the town. Hard stuff from the top shelf in the hotels ... (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,14)

JOHNSTON `Moody bugger when he's had a session on the top shelf,' Jamie put to Pop. (1981,Fish Factory,32)

... drink off the top shelf ... (Nov 7, 1989,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: John Banks MP 9.05pm]

The bottles on the top shelf were filled with water. I had been told so previously. It was called old tom. I don't think there was more than a gallon of spirits in the bar altogether. (Dec 4, 1866,Daily Southern Cross,5)

After doing this the robber reached to the top shelf, and took down a bottle of Usher's whiskey, which he put under his coat and then he walked out of the bar by the way he came in, passing me in the passage. (Feb 13, 1893,Taranaki Herald,2)

top shifting/great shifting¶

1 phr. (Rural) [of sale stock] that will thrive on being well fed.

Annual draft of top shifting high country calves .. top shifting hill country lambs ... (Mar 23, 2002,Hawke's Bay Today,29)

Great shifting herd. The auctioneers will recommend their great shifting ability. (May 4, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,29)

Top Table¶

n. a drug alliance

Fuelled by the lurid fantasies of crime reporters, the methamphetamine trade has become an "unholy alliance" between rival gangs who have banded together to form the "Top Table". (Apr 6, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

top the rise¶

phr. to be on the decline (because of age), to be `over the hill'

EADDY Even at the time I was shipmate with him he had `topped the rise', and was, in our opinion, an old fellow. (1933,Hull Down,24)

top the sale¶

1 phr. (Rural) to gain the highest price for livestock or wool at an auction.

WATERS McConochie Brothers brought in good sheep and often topped the sale. (1976,Mostly a Farmer,105)

DOMINY The bales 'topped the sale' and the farmer and I spent the afternoon examining each of the fine wool samples in the buyers' shed for a comparison. (2001,Calling the Station Home,191)

top work¶

n.

165/2 (Feb 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture)

ACLAND (1951,Early Canterbury Runs,199)

top-hamper¶

n. [aka top hamper, tophamper]

When examining the plan for a county bridge submitted to him during the course of a deputation this afternoon, the Minister of Public Works (the Hon. J. G. Coates) remarked that it seemed to have a good deal of "top-hamper" about it. (Dec 17, 1923,Evening Post,6)

Heavy scaffolding is being erected round the Town Hall in preparation for the removal of parapets and other unnecessary top-hamper. (Jul 31, 1934,Evening Post,7)

Recently I bought some carrots from my greengrocer. I was indignant to find that they had been weighed with great bunches of tops, which added somewhat to their weight, particularly as they had gone to seed. When I asked that the carrots should be weighed without this top-hamper, I was told that they had been bought from the Internal Marketing Department in that condition so they were obliged to sell them with the tops on to avoid loss to themselves. (Sep 29, 1945,Evening Post,4)

McCASKILL ... superphosphate was hand-sown on top of areas where good cocksfoot and clover had been established by serial [?aerial] sowing ... but with the first heavy frosts in March and April, the top-hamper was killed and there was no extra feed remaining for the winter. (1969,Molesworth,210)

Top-knot¶

1 n. a small marine fish of the family Tripterrygiidae [topknot, top knot]

Such [scaling] is minutely the case in the comber, Serranus cabrilla .. conspicuously in the top-knot, Rhombus hirtus, where the border of the scale is turned outward (Mar 28, 1868,Otago Daily Times,4)

top-uddered¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of dairy cows or ewes] with well-formed udders.

Livestock for Sale - Top uddered young Jsy Herd ... (Oct 6, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,41)

topdress¶

v.

Tar in the boiler, being used by men topdressing part of the new ferry wharf decking, apparently became overheated. (Apr 2, 1954,Press, The,10)

You know what they say about country folk. If they're not top-dressing, they're cross-dressing. (Apr 22, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45)

topdresser¶

n. (Rural) a portable topdressing machine carried on a tractor, truck or trailer [known as a 'blower'].

The season for farm clearing sales began auspiciously in Taranaki last week .. A top-dresser brought GBP49. (Jun 13, 1946,NZ Farmer,20)

MACNICOL & TROTTER Then with new modern machinery and topdressing all the farmers were able to buy topdressers, first the small ones with the manure put in and spun out on the grass behind the tractors. Then came the Munro topdressers which were fitted on to the back of a trailer ... [top-dresser] (1987,I, Duncan from Skippers,98)

TURNER ... a topdresser< is an implement for spreading fertilizer. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,141)

1 n. (Rural) a pilot of a topdressing plane or a topdressing plane.

WHEELER Within a week we should have the aerial topdressers in with super and fresh grass seed. (1973,Historic Sheep Stations of NZ,59)

topdressing¶

n. (Rural) a fertiliser used for topdressing.

ASPINALL Forty or fifty tons of top-dressing are brought in by truck, then loaded on to a plane and spread from the air. (1976,High Country Sheep Station,21)

n. (Rural) the applying of fertiliser to farm land.

Another method of effecting economy in topdressing is by the use of the grass harrow in the regular spreading of animal excreta. (Jul 15, 1940,NZ Journal of Agriculture,11)

On fat lamb farms topdressing now will improve the feed position and ensure that ewes are better fed before and during lambing. (Apr 1956,NZ Journal of Agriculture,349)

GORDON Burning, oversowing and topdressing, followed by severe grazing, has worked on a few blocks. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,179)

n. the fertilising of land with superphosphate, etc., in farming spread from machines or aeroplanes. -->see also TARANAKI TOPDRESSING the application of fertiliser to the surface of the soil (cf also AERIAL TOPDRESSING)

A top-dressing plane flies round us. (Feb 1989,North & South,45)

Advt.] V.O.B. Basic Slag is cheaper this year. The value of Slag Top-Dressing need not be stressed. (Dec 18, 1926,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,10)

`Topdressing' in England is used only of nitrogenous manures and on a growing crop. In New Zealand a much wider use. [The restricted meaning given by Walker would seem to be that of the OED vb and vbl sb.] (Jul 24, 1953,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 1953 July 24 Professor T.W. Walker, Lincoln Agricultural College :talk on 2YA Wellington (8.00 pm)]

TURNER (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The)

The first commercial topdressing flight, made ... in May 1949, pointed the way to a new industry ... (Nov 24, 1979,Listener (New Zealand Listener),365/4) [NOTES: (Duncan Campbell)]

[Country Calendar's] special on topdressing pilots was highly therapeutic. (Feb 8, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),64)

2 n.

The claims of the National Party are similar to an offence in the fruit industry which is termed `top-dressing'. This consists of deceiving a buyer by placing high-quality fruit on the top layer of the case and inferior quality fruit underneath it. (Mar 31, 1954,Standard, The,2)

TULLET I want the top-dressing pilot.'They're both top-dressing pilots.' (1964,Red Abbott,9)

tope¶

n. (See also shark,school shark)

HUTTON 130. GALEUS CANIS. L. Tope. (1872,Fishes,81)

SENIOR [Maoris] have a sweet tooth for sharks, especially the smooth-hound dog-fish and tope (1880,Travel & Trout,298)

SHERRIN Galeus canis .. Tope. Ibid.. 116 TOPE (Galeus canis). ... It is the `school-shark' of the Sydney fishermen. (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,115)

MORRIS Tope, N. an Australasian Shark, Galeus australis, Macl. It differs somewhat from Galeus canis, the Tope of Britain. Called also the School-Shark, in Australia. (1898,Austral English,475)

MORRIS Tope, N. an Australasian Shark, Galeus australis, Macl. It differs somewhat from Galeus canis, the Tope of Britain. Called also the School-Shark, in Australia. (1898,Austral English,475)

Galeus australis Macleay. The tope is common along the east coast of Otago. (1913,TrNZI,45/235) [NOTES: (Thomson, Otago)]

SPEIGHT The Tope (Galeorhinus australis) is a medium sized shark,... but neither it nor the ten foot whaler (Carcharinus brachyurus) seem to be dangerous. (1927,Natural History of Canterbury,192) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 192]

  1. Galeorhinus australis Macleay. Tope. Maori: Mangoreremai (1929,TrNZI,61/130)

~ n. a kind of shark. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,12)

POWELL SCHOOL SHARK or TOPE (Notogaleus australis). This is very similar in shape to the Dog-fish, ... but it ... is much larger. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,61)

GRAHAM TOPE OR SCHOOL SHARK Notogaleus rhinophanes (Peron) The origin of the vernacular name Tope is not certain, but local fishermen who followed this occupation in Britain, said this name is a corruption of `top' in allusion to its well-known habit of following the lines to the top of the water and then snatching off Whiting or other hooked fish in full view of the helpless fisherman. Other New Zealand common names are Southern Tope and School Shark. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,63)

MORELAND SCHOOLSHARK [Galaeorhinus australis] ... Sand shark and tope are alternative names (1967,Marine Fishes,12)

SOR SHARK, SCHOOL (a) Scientific name: Galeorhinus australis (principally). (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Flake Fillets. (c) Other common names: B.B., Big Boys; Soupfin; Grey Boys; Tope or Topi. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,42)

WILSON SCHOOLFISH The flesh, like that of the gummies, is quite edible and regularly marketed, usually as Lemonfish. The Schoolshark is usually dark-grey-green above and white below. Known also as Tope and Sand shark they are the only fish who close their eyes when they sleep. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,224)

Mrs Heather Morgan, of New Plymouth, caught a 21.77kg tope on an 8kg line in Northland's Parengarenga Harbour in January last year. (Jul 11, 1986,Evening Post,12)

[species name] school shark .. [scientific name] Galeorhinus australis .. [other name(s)] tope, big boys, greyboys, flake, grey shark, soupfin, sandshark (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL School shark Galeorhinus australis ... Other names include tope and grey shark. Also occurs around southern Australia, and is similar to the Californian soupfin shark. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,29)

It must be remembered that this bird, having for its habitat the tops of alpine ranges, is seen by few others than shepherds ... (1895,TrNZI,27/.278) [NOTES: ?transitional use]

Several tope sharks were hooked on his line. (Mar 9, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

Some anglers have been catching good sized ling and tope sharks out at Nicholson's Trench. (Sep 16, 1992,Evening Post,42)

2 n.

The southern tope, or school shark, Galeorhinus australis, is one of the small so-called dogfish commonly taken by trawlers around New Zealand. (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,6/259) [NOTES: (Phillipps)]

PHILLIPPS Galeorhinus australis Macleay. SOUTHERN TOPE or SCHOOL SHARK. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,7,1971 ed.)

Galeorhinus australis Macleay. Southern tope. (1938,TrNZI,68/400) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

tope shark¶

n. (See tope)

  1. Galeorhinus australis Macleay. Tope.Mangoreremai (1929,TrNZI,61/139)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] shark, tope 201-4, 208-9, 218, 234 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

topi¶

n. (See tope)

topitopi¶

n.

HOOKER Topitopi, Mantell. Alectryon excelsum. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

topknot¶

n. a bump near spout-hole of a whale

DIEFFENBACH The whalers can distinguish ... a bull from a cow; - the elevation near the spout-hole(s), called the top-knot, being much higher in the bulls, and this part is always above the water; (1843,Travels in NZ,1/54)

n.

1 n. (Rural) the kempy wool growing on a sheep's head that may cause wool-blindness. [top knot, top-knot]

The odd bits, such as the 'top knot,' cheeks, and little odds and ends of broken wool, should be packed separately, but the filthy wool should be thrown out. (Aug 1887,NZ Farmer,229)

Top-knot, consisting of very light kempy tender wool, often having a bluish tinge. (1919,Wool in NZ,20)

Pick out stained wool, face pieces, leggings and top-knots. (Oct 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,313)

BOWEN The wool on the forehead known as the top-knot is the wool that hangs down over the eye, blinding the sheep. (1955,Wool Away!,64)

BLACK & DYSON If possible keep top knots out of all specialty carpet wool. (1978,Carpetmakers: Specialty Carpet Wool breeds of NZ,15)

FISK If you have a bigger mob or are pooling wool with neighbours then you can divide the bellies and pieces into crutchings (from the back end) bellies, leg pieces and topknots (the short hairy pieces from the top of the head and cheeks.) (1996,Practical Smallfarming,84)

WOOLPRO Topknot: short, fuzzy, and usually kempy wool growing on the poll of a sheep (top of head.) [top-knot, top knot] (2001,A to Z Glossary of Wool Terms,38)

The points are: Large head, on a strong neck, well covered with wool, and having a top-knot (Oct 9, 1906,Nelson Evening Mail,1)

PERRY A top-knot of true wool, not down, should cover the forehead [of the Leicester]. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,37)

SMITH He ... removes the top-knot - a small cap of fuzzy oily wool which grows on the top of the sheep's head. (1927,Sheep & Wool Industry,77)

Pick over the lambs' wool. Pick out stained wool, face pieces, leggings, and top-knots, as these wools make the buyer suspicious ... (Oct 16, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,313)

Top knot: The wool grown on the top of the head. (Feb 26, 1965,NZ Journal of Agriculture,15) [NOTES: (H.A.L. Laing)]

166 What's 2nd Pcs H?'Grade 2, pieces - that's skirtings - hogget wool.' And Bls E?'That's belly wool. E grade bellies.' Lox?'Oh, that's floor sweepings.' What about Lbs Wigs?'Lamb top-knots - off the head.' (1973,Tussock Fever,FERNANDEZ)

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR .. inside the hind legs, off with the topknot, lean the sheep over to the left,. . (1981,Sunrise,45)

Topknot: Wool shorn from the top of a sheep's head. Ibid. Wigging: Shearing wool from the head of sheep. Normally carried out at crutching. The trade term for this wool is eye clips. Also known as topknots or wigs. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,60)

topknot ... NZ & Austral. wool shorn from top of sheep's head. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,811) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

Sheep of the following description may be safely rejected .. 2. Sheep that strip at the points, and lose the belly-wool, having a clean head without top-knot. (May 3, 1871,Taranaki Herald,3)

The head should have a good topknot, the face wool meeting under the eyes, and ending abruptly, yellow down, not white hairs on the nose: ears small, and covered with down or wool; wool to the toes is desirable. (Jan 28, 1882,Otago Witness,7)

topknot/topnot¶

n.

AYLING TOPKNOT Notoclinus fenestratus ... It also has a distinctive high first dorsal fin set well forward toward the head that prompted the name topknot. (1982,Collins Guide,283,1984 ed.)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] topknot, topnot 1926, 1932, 1984, 870 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

Notoclinus fenestratus (Forster). Topnot. (1938,TrNZI,68/416) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

GRAHAM Topnot Notoclinus fenestratus (Bloch and Schn.) (Syn. Tripterygion compressum Hutton) ... Topnot Zeablennius laticlavius (Griffen) ... Topnot Sticharium venustum (Griffen) ... Topnot Cynophidium punctatum Regan (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,4111) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 411]

GRAHAM TOPNOT Notoclinus fenestratus (Bloch and Schneider) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,335)

MORELAND TOPNOT [Notoclinus fenestratus ] ... No other names are in common use. (1967,Marine Fishes,18)

WILSON The Blenny goes by several other names too. In his various forms he is the Cockabully, Threepenny, Twister, and Topknot. All are slightly different in looks but come under the collective name of Blenny for easy grouping. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,28)

topknotting¶

n. (Rural) the cutting of headwool from sheep. (See eye-wigging; eye-clipping)

Crutching rates are 10/- per 100 plus an extra 2/- per 100 for topknotting or eyewigging, plus 15 per cent. (May 24, 1951,NZ Farmer,26)

topmaker¶

n.

BREMNER Topmaker manufacturer who straightens and thins wool into a continuous, untwisted, thumb-thick sliver, ready for the spinning machine. (1985,Woolscours of NZ,10)

topmaking¶

n.

(Nov 5, 1969,NZ News,5/5)

1 adj. (Rural) [of fleece wool] suitable for worsted processing.

Crossbred descriptions were mainly light conditioned good average topmaking wools, though a proportion lacked full length ... Good average topmaking, however, compared the bulk of the offering. (Nov 6, 1963,Straight Furrow,5)

Prices for poor topmaking sorts and fairly faulty lines of oddments were very erratic. (Jan 8, 1964,Straight Furrow,5)

topper¶

n. informer

GLOSSARY OF TECHNICAL TERMS: A boobhead is a prisoner; a screw is a warder; a topper is a toady or an informer. The Act or the Collar - The Habitual Criminals Act, under which persons declared habitual criminals can have their sentences increased by the Prisons Board for offences against prison discipline during their incarceration. (Nov 1950,Here & Now,14) [NOTES: (Ian Hamilton `NZd's Last Flogging')]

HAMILTON Some screw had been earwigging, I like to think, though there were quite a few toppers and crawlers at the [detention] camp. Ibid.53 Toppers are what used to be called copper's narks in England and there's always about thirty per cent of them in jails. (1953,Till Human Voices Wake Us,22)

Truck drivers were `staff men' and nearly all toppers and crawlers. (Nov 1953,Here & Now) [NOTES: (Hamilton) [Prison]]

WATSON ... Detective Crome came round. He wanted a statement about Jerry. ... `I'm not a topper,' he said after Detective Crome had gone. (1965,Stand in the Rain,109)

JUSTIN `Yeah! Here's my slot. Twenty-two. Come on in. ...' So, a slot was a cell. A topper was a kind of pimp. I was learning. (1973,Prisoner,23)

To Sergeant A. Carter, prosecuting, the witness alleged gang members had accused her friend of being a `topper'. (Dec 24, 1973,NZ Truth,3)

AGNEW I learned later that a topper was at the dance. He betrayed my presence to the Whataroa constable. (1974,Loner, The,176)

The Prisoner's Code: I can't crawl to screws (cops, prison officers, etc), snyone who does is a Nark',topper', or has Hands on his stomach' orBrown Ankles' or is `Pushing a third' remission. (Jul 12, 1976,Salient,6)

MacKENZIE Prisoners who did converse [with officers] were accused of sucking up' to officers, and were held in contempt by their fellows. They were known asbrown noses', toppers' orcanaries'. (1980,While We Have Prisons,16)

NEWBOLD TOPPER (n) Informer. (1982,Big Huey, The,255)

The phone rang twenty times a day, with accusations of topper, pakeha topper ... (1987,Metro Fiction,10) [NOTES: (Keogh, Chiaoscuro)]

topping¶

n. informing (See cf. top (on),top off v)

The complainant's fiance said `topping' was a term the gang used to describe reporting a matter to the police. (Dec 24, 1973,NZ Truth,3)

topping and tailing¶

1 phr. (Rural) ear-marking, castrating and tailing of lambs.

A & P Conference iv topping and tailing were best done on grass or in temporary yards and low, swampy ground was best avoided. (Aug 1900,NZ Farmer,Supplement)

topping off¶

n. (Rural) the finishing or fattening of farm stock for sale or exhibition. [1956 citation is of the verb to top off]

TAIT Crops of swedes are grown for feeding out in winter and for 'topping off' the stock. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,88)

TAIT Farms & Stations of NZ II All wether lambs are fattened, a crop of turnips being grown for topping off. (1958)

tops¶

n. usually pl with def art THE TOPS, the top of a ridge; a peak; (collectively) the tops of hills, ridges, or mountains, the highest country (usually above the bushline) occas. in phrs ON TOP (cp BOTTOMS) cf also TOP MAN - [used regularly in weather forecasts]

(1958,Tararua,12/29)

McLEOD Faintly he heard Mac on the top above him yelling and barking his dogs. (1959,Tall Tussock,22)

CRUMP (1961,Good Keen Man, A,22)

SLATTER On the sheep station they called me Cloudburst ... I was on the tops while you were still on the titty. (1968,Pagan Game, The,174)

The Forest Service has placed huts at short intervals along the tops, ... marked tracks ... (1971,VUWTC'71,7)

FERNANDEZ I'll push them [sc sheep] off right there, towards the tops. (1973,Tussock Fever,44)

DENNIS Beyond Top Hut the track is benched for maybe 20 minutes before large poles take over to mark the easy, well-worn path across the tops. (1981,Paparoas Guide,65)

DENNIS Beyond Top Hut the track is benched for maybe 20 minutes before large poles take over to mark the easy, well-worn path across the tops. (1981,Paparoas Guide,65)

WHEELER But treacherous bogs ... abound in the flat tops, and roadmaking would be difficult. (1982,Historic Sheep Stations of NZ,5)

The agreement freeholds the tops of the Hector Mountains on the lake side of the range... Under their agreement, the Taylors can graze the tops on their property only with a limited number of a specified kind of sheep for the first three months of each year. (Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

We gaze towards the tawny peaks - the areas thart are likely to go to DoC through tenure review. Bridget Mead declares that her daughter has the right to muster along those tops, as she has done - it's a part of her heritage. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/41)

The ridge walk had become impassable and they had to bush-bash through the leatherwood on the tops. (Jan 9, 1994,Sunday Times (NZ),19)

At the end of the second day, I'm bluffed on the tops and have to set up a fly-camp surrounded by an arena of windthrow-covered ridges, cliffs and waterfalls... Compared with the tops on which I had been stranded, the podocarp-clothed Waiau River provides easy travelling and a relative abundance of bush-foods... (Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

It must be remembered that this bird, having for its habitat the tops of alpine ranges, is seen by few others than shepherds ... (1895,TrNZI,27/278) [NOTES: ?transitional use]

I went out to the tops: in a small basin under the top, .... facing a rocky country that we called `skay', there was a mob of sheep snowed in ... (1907,TrNZI,39/73)

Most of the ridges are rounded on the tops, and many of them are covered with extensive peat bogs, dotted over with numerous lagoons. (1915,TrNZI,47/121)

ACLAND ... there was a wedge-shaped block of ninety thousand acres of high tops, mostly bush-bound, in the middle ... (1946,Early Canterbury Runs,210)

PICKERING Cloud on the tops always keeps trampers on their toes. Navigation becomes important and the likelihood of some whacking directional error increases sharply. (1988,Hills, The,48)

PICKERING Basic tops travel involves little more than following a track out of the bushline and onto the crest of a tussock ridge, ... Even more challenging than this is camping on the tops, perhaps by a pretty tarn with a long-range view over the mountains and a brilliant sunset. ... (1988,Hills, The,46)

[Caption] Tops camp at head of Karangarua Valley, South Westland. (1988,Hills, The)

It is a fine sight you see the river flowing down between mountains 3 and 4000 ft., the [70] lofty back ranges looking blue and the tops covered with snow. (Dec 13, 1862,Chudleigh Diary,69,1950 ed.)

Abner and I took the top of the range and had a great run after the sheep. There were eight fellows spread about the face of the range below us but we did not make a very clean muster notwithstanding. (Oct 24, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,202,1950 ed.)

BARKER We lost very few sheep; [217] they were all up at the tops of the high hills, their favourite summer pasture. (1868,Station Life in NZ,216)

ROBERTS We were so late in the season we could not tackle the high tops, but had to dodge a ray-trace [check] across the depression abreast the Ramsay Glacier. (1893,Letter) [NOTES: 1893 Roberts letter to A.P. Harper in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 28]

... the tops, however, often carry tussock and other herbage, affording admirable pasture for sheep in summer; but stock have to be removed from April to October, during which period this country is generally covered with snow. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,31)

I went out to the tops. (1907,TrNZI,39.73) [NOTES: (Benham)]

... I only managed to botanize the sea-face and the tops ... (1907,TrNZI,39/382) [NOTES: (Townson)]

Dawn finds the leader [of the musterers] on the tops, six thousand feet up, the wet wind in his face and his shirt ringing wet with sweat. (Apr 10, 1917,Triad, The,66)

GUTHRIE-SMITH On the right below the high top called Pou-nui-a-Hine is another small cave beneath a limestone projection, in ancient times the home of a kumi. Ibid. 170 The burn' of 1902 ... was not what is technically known as aclean' fire. ... this fire left unburnt ridge-caps, the tops, sometimes even the upper slopes. (1921,Tutira,65)

Tops.- Often called high tops. (1) High summer country. (C.) (2) In North Canterbury, country above the bush. (C.) (Dec 23, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

On the tops he could keep pace with men young enough to be his sons. (1945,NZ Geographer,29) [NOTES: 1945 Pascoe Canterbury High Country in NZ Geographer 29]

NEWTON ... shingle tops ... Mount White's beckoning tops. [check] (1947,Wayleggo,33 et passim)

Next morning we had to be up early to reach the tops before the merinos broke camp and started back for the country off which they had been mustered. Ibid. 31 Merino ewes always camp just below the highest top on what they regard as their own piece of country, ... (1952,My Yesteryears,18) [NOTES: [f. c1869]]

28 The end came when, coming down off the tops with a fair-sized load of skins, the frame wedged in some stout branches of scrub. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,THOMSON)

THOMSON On the high open tops shooting was also at reasonably close range. (1952,Deer Shooter,44)

DUFF If sheep there sometimes grew fat it would be as deer occasionally grow fat on the tops and basins above our beech forests; ... (Mar 19, 1951,Shepherd's Calendar,26,1961 ed.)

...set out under tall mahoe and fuchsia, till the track breaks out of the bush on to scrubby tops beaten flat by the wind. (Jan 9, 2004,Dominion Post)

Beyond here the track ascends the open tops of Judd Ridge, which can be very exposed to the elements. (2008,NZ Geographic,94/30)

Another area sought for wilderness designation is the 'Paparoa tops', along the rugged ridges inland from Paparoa National Park. (May 2002,Forest & Bird,No. 304/4)
