Generations of high-country run-holders, for example, speak of the tops, the tussock and the tarns with something akin to awe, as do the Tuhoe, the people of the mist, of their land. (Aug 13, 2003,Dominion Post,B8)

There are some groves of fine timber on the sides of the valley; the hills which bound it are high, but on their tops lies a table land only partially wooded. (May 16, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

Little two-seater Robinsons, which some of the cockies have, were ferrying snow rakers up to the tops. (Oct 1992,North & South,17)

MACLEAN Diederich and Scanlon followed the usual route to the tops. (1994,Tararua : the Story of a Mountain Range,144)

The map showed that the far side of the valley would soon have farmland in behind the bushed tops. (Nov 17, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C9)

They knew which way each gate opened, how to saddle up, whether it was a stray sheep on the Tops or that plant thing. (Nov 26, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

topside run¶

1 n. (Rural) an approach or position of a dog, while working sheep on a hill.

LOUGHNAN topside run: the more usual, and opposite of, bottomside run. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,86)

NEWTON Top-side run: This refers to a run where the dog works above or on the top side of the sheep. The reverse to bottom-side work. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,169)

topside work¶

1 n. (Rural) [high or hill country mustering] the driving of sheep downhill from above.

The 'Lake' country is mainly open shingle and it's mostly 'topside' work - slewing sheep downhill. (Apr 11, 1968,NZ Farmer,45)

topuni¶

n. a mat [ORIGIN: Maori]

In his hand [Pomare] usually carries a short cloak of dog-skin, called topuni, shupuni, or patutu. (1852,U.S. Exploring Expedition,1/303) [NOTES: 1840 Mar in 1852 Wilkes U.S. Exploring Expedition 1/303]

ANGAS These two distinguished chiefs sat to me ... wearing the topuni, or war-mat of dog's skin. Ibid. 156 The topuni,' or war mat, belongs exclusively to the man, and is only possessed by chiefs ... Thetopuni' consists of a large flax cloak, into which is fastened, with every thread, a portion of dog's hair, assorted into various colours, having the exact appearance of a beautiful fur. (1847,Savage Life,1/297)

ANGAS The topuni,' or war mat, belongs exclusively to the man, and is only possessed by chiefs ... Thetopuni' consists of a large flax cloak, into which is fastened, with every thread, a portion of dog's hair, assorted into various colours, having the exact appearance of a beautiful fur. (1866,Polynesia,156)

There is a splendid show of greenstone .. genuine topuni or fighting gown made out of the skin and hair of dog tails; and a host of other things, a careful examination of which would be a liberal education in the achievements of the natives. (May 25, 1893,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

topuni reserve¶

n.

Also included were statutory acknowledgements of [nohoanga] (traditional camping sites), topuni sites (significant sites)and place names. (Sep 2000,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://knowledge-basket.co.nz/waitangi/temanu/celebrate.html]

It was the announcement of the creation of nohoanga (exclusive riverside campsites facilitating access to customary fishing sites) and topuni reserves (the granting of additional status to areas of special significance) within the Ngai Tahu settlement that resulted in Mr Graham's recent comments that there were some different laws for Maori and pakeha. (Jun 15, 1997,Sunday Star Times,C1)

tor¶

n. a marble (See also taw)

Tor - the one you used for all shooting - a marble never to be given away (1987,Alfredton,75) [NOTES: Quote from c1935]

KEINZLY Gus had prayed every prayer he could think of that Knocker would do it so that he could give back to Knocker the seven marbles he had won from him by cheating. ... That afternoon he did a boy's sums for seven allys and a tor. (1960,Tangahano,10)

tora¶

adj. (See toro)

torairi¶

n. (See taraire)

toraro¶

n.

2 n.

They included 345 pingao, 600 spinifex and 350 Muehlenbeckia astonii (shrubby toraro) planted as part of a dune restoration project at Castlepoint. (Oct 2003,Footnotes,No. 20/7)

torch¶

v. to seek out and take fish (esp. flounders and eels, by spear), or muttonbirds, by dazzling them with torchlight [ca1935 Havelock, for flatfish The torchlight provided by strong torches, car-battery lamps, or flaxstick and tow, dipped in tar or oil and fired]

JENKINS A writer in the Southland Times in the early part of the century stated that he had heard the hakuwai on 10 May 1913. He and his companions were on one of the hills of Poutama Island, torching, when they heard an unusual sound. (1970,NZ Mysteries,157)

POWER [The flounders are a splendid fish, the finest of their tribe; spearing them by torchlight is an excellent sport.] (1849,Sketches in NZ,77)

torchie¶

n. sc. in eel-fishing

(Apr 6, 1966,Weekly Herald,32)

torching¶

n. catching fish, or muttonbirds, by dazzling them with torchlight [ca1935 Havelock e.g. Go torching on the mudflats.] (See cf. spotlighting)

BAILEY & ROTH We catch all our birds in the torching,/ And after the cleaning we're scorching;/ (1967,Shanties,136)

DEMPSEY It is during this period that mutton-birders go out at night, `torching', catching the young birds which are often found at the entrance to their burrows. (1964,Little World of Stewart island,60)

... the hunting system [for muttonbirds] known as `torching' which takes place right at the end of the season ... (Mar 5, 1966,Dominion,6)

JENKINS This would account for the fact that it is heard only at torching time, after most of the adult birds have left the island, and when muttonbirders search out the young birds by torchlight. (1970,NZ Mysteries,156)

WILSON Ever since the beginning, to take' meant journeying to the islands and living there for the season and using hands or any device to catch the birds. ... totake' also includes an attempt to take'. During the torching season the birds run down the paths to the sea at night. Paths are used as boundaries by the [56] supervisors and in some cases the dividing line is the middle of the path. If one pursues a bird and grabs it over the other edge of the path one can be prosecuted, even although the bird came from the pursuer's manu. <i>Ibid.</i> 68 Thetorching' season became known as such because the birders used flaming torches thick enough to be held aloft comfortably grasped in the hand. They were about three feet long and well soaked in muttonbird fat, before being set alight and were made from dry tree branches. Piles of these torches' were prepared and set aside awaiting [69] the start of thetorching' and each family had their torch bearers. In most cases this duty was carried out by the children. Gradually this primitive method of `lighting the way' gave place to the European kerosene lantern and when supplies of kerosene were exhausted a lighted candle was sometimes used inside the glass globe of the lantern. (1979,Titi Heritage,55)

SANSOM First part of the work over except for scrapings. Coming up to torching time. Birds excellent in quality and quantity. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,153)

About April 20 the birds start coming out of their burrows and torching begins. (Oct 14, 1953,NZ Observer,16)

The 'torching' season become known as such because the birders, used flaming torches thick enough to be held aloft comfortably grasped in the hand. (1979,Titi Heritage,68)

torea¶

n. the oystercatcher, Haematopus spp. or red-bill

LEE & KENDALL Tor|ea; A bird with a long red bill. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,216)

DIEFFENBACH 51. Haemotopus picatus, Vigors's King's ... Scarcely different from this species, and very common in New Zealand. Toria of the natives. Dieffenbach. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/196) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/196]

TAYLOR [Word list] Torea a sea bird (1843,Journal,52)

HAAST We continued our route along this beach, ... endeavouring in the meantime to shoot some toreas (redbills), in order to add a little to our [51] small stock of provisions. (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,50)

HAAST ... the most numerous bird along the coast is the torea (Hematopus picatus). (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,140)

WEKEY Among gulls, albatrosses, and other sea birds ..., the toria, or oyster eater, and the korora, also living on a species of shell-fish, called pipi, is met with on the sea shore. (1862,Otago As It Is,66)

Haematopus unicolor. Torea. Red-bill. East Coast. (1869,TrNZI,1/160) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

HAEMATOPUS LONGIROSTRIS, Vieil. Torea. Oyster-catcher, Red-bill. (1870,TrNZI,2/69) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

HUTTON 68. HAEMATOPUS LONGIROSTRIS. Vieill. Pied Oyster-catcher. Red-bill. Torea. 69. HAEMATOPUS UNICOLOR. Forst. Black Oyster-catcher. Red-bill. Torea. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,26)

BULLER HAEMOTOPUS LONGIROSTRIS. (PIED OYSTER-CATCHER.) ... Native name.- Torea. ... This fine species ... is generally dispersed round the southern coast of Australia ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,273,1888 2nd edn 2/16 ed.)

HAY The Torea, or oyster-catcher (Haematopus longirostris) is one of the sea-coast birds, and is often to be seen about our tidal rivers. It is a black bird. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/225)

Haematopus longirostris, Vieill. Pied Oyster-catcher, Red-bill, Torea. iBID. 67 Haematopus unicolor, Forst. Black Oyster-catcher, Black Red-bill, Torea. - Breeds out on `the plains' in riverbeds ... (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,510) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

MORRIS Maori name for all the New Zealand species of the Oyster-catchers (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,475)

TREGEAR The large sea-gull (karoro: Larus dominicanus) and another gull, the Oyster-catcher (torea: Haemotopus sp.), were domesticated, but merely as pets ... (1904,Maori Race, The,180)

BEATTIE An island further up the river is known as Torea (redbill) because these birds nest there. (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,18)

to[o]rea, a shore-bird (Haematopus ostralegus), oyster-catcher. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

torea: oystercatcher, bird. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

RICHARDS Haematopus ... longirostris ... The bill is shorter and stouter than the New Zealand type, ... Oyster Catchers are found in New Zealand, Australia and the Moluccas west of New Guinea. Oyster Catcher. Torea. (1952,Chatham Islands,79)

FALLA et al. SOUTH ISLAND PIED OYSTERCATCHER Haemotopus finschi Other names: Redbill, Torea. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,118)

torea n. Maori name for the New Zealand oyster-catchers [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

There's so much outdoors,.. the Ahuriri River atrtracting dotterels, plovers, terns, oystercatchers, pied stilts, paradise ducks. (Jan 6, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

torea ... n. Maori name for N.Z. oyster-catchers [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

142. Haematopus ostralegus finschi Martens, 1897 South Island Pied Oystercatcher (Torea) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,43,1980 ed.)

LOCKLEY There is also the plain, all-black torea (known as the variable oystercatcher') locally [Hauraki Gulf] calledmussel-picker,' a solitary bird which haunts the rocky shore where mussels grow. (1980,House Above the Sea,180)

FALLA et al. South Island Pied Oystercatcher Haematopus ostralegus finschi MARTENS,1897 ... OTHER NAMES: Torea, redbill. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,174)

Along the uncovered mudflats may be seen the torea or oyster catcher (haematopus longirostris), a bird of pied plumage. (Nov 5, 1887,Auckland Weekly News)

2 n.

BULLER HIMANTOPUS LEUCOCEPHALUS. (WHITE-HEADED STILT.) ... Native name.- Tutumata {and Tuturipourewa}; Torea (of Arawa tribe). ...The White-headed Stilt, which appears to be also widely distributed over ... Australia, is a comparatively common bird in the middle and southern portions of New Zealand; ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,203,{1888 2nd edn 2/21} ed.)

2 n.

Shot 9-1/2 couple of ducks besides 2 torias and 2 quail. (Oct 25, 1849,Torlesse Papers,110,1958 ed.)

SMITH On the sand at the mouth of one of [the branches of the upper Waikato at Taupo] were an immense number of ducks, toreas, and some pretty white birds. [ed. fn] This name is applied to both the Oystercatcher ... and the Pied Stilt (Himantopus leucocephalus). The latter is more likely to be seen about these lakes, and is known today in the area as Torea. (Jan 21, 1858,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1858 Jan 21 Smith Notes of a Journey in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 368]

FALLA et al. PIED STILT Himantopus leucocephalus Other names: Stilt, Barker, Poaka, White-headed Stilt, Daddy Long-legs, Torea (Rotorua), Pip (Kaipara). (1966,Birds of New Zealand,147)

3 n.

BULLER HAEMOTOPUS UNICOLOR. (BLACK OYSTER-CATCHER.) ... Native name.- Torea-pango. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,225,1888 2nd edn 2/18 ed.)

3 n.

BULLER HIMANTOPUS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (BLACK STILT.) ... Native names.- Kaki and Tuarahia; Torea-pango (of Arawa tribe). (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/24)

3 n.

Variable Oystercatcher Haematopus unicolor FORSTER, 1844 ... OTHER NAMES: Torea-pango, redbill. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,175)

torehe¶

n. a light-coloured eel [ORIGIN: Maori, also a fishing net or basket (Williams sense 1):see Macalister for cit.]

Split lengths also make elastic spreaders for the torehe trap (1926,TrNZI,58/599) [NOTES: (Buck)]

torete¶

n. a parakeet

BULLER PLATYCERCUS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (RED-FRONTED PARRAKEET.) ... Native names. Kakariki, Kakawariki, Powhaitere, Porere, and Torete ...[59] The Red-fronted Parrakeet is very generally dispersed over the whole country - but is more plentiful in the southern portion of the North Island than in the far north, where the yellow-fronted species predominates. Ibid. 62 PLATYCERCUS AURICEPS. (YELLOW-FRONTED PARRAKEET.) ... [follows preceding cit.] (1873,Birds of New Zealand,58,1888 2nd edn 1/137, 142 ed.)

toretore¶

n.

HEAPHY We ... lived upon ... toretore or sea anemonies [sic], making the latter into what we termed a `soup', flavoured with salt water and the wild parsley which grows among the rocks of that coast. (1846,Notes of an Expedition to Kawatiri and Araura) [NOTES: 1846 Heaphy Expedition to Kawatiri in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 244]

Tori tori, and ko toretore, are sea anemone. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,415)

tori line¶

n.

...New Zealand's challenge in Hawaii is to convince other countries to use techniques such as: setting hooks at night to reduce bird numbers;.. flying streamers (tori lines) astern to distract birds; firing cannons to scare birds; avoiding areas where birds are known to congregate. (Nov 23, 2002,Dominion Post,F12)

Marine investigations have shown that tori lines (bird-scaring devices) dramatically reduce the by-catch of sea-birds. (Aug 24, 1997,Sunday Star Times,A6)

toria¶

n. early variant of torea (stilt)

66 BIRDS MET WITH IN PELORUS ... Oysterpickers - two kinds, called Toria by the natives... BIRDS MET WITH IN PELORUS ... Stilts - two kinds, called Toria by natives. Flycatchers and Fantails. (1855,Sailing Directions)

Torlesse¶

adj. . [Geol. classification]

As far as I know, there is no adequate definition of the upper limit of the Torlesse. There is a default Definition:the Torlesse is the rocks of the accretionary complex below a line, commonly a discordant contact, that are more deformed, less fossiliferous and generally more geologiacally intractable than those above. (Mar 1998,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,115/53)

The name "Torlesse" was introduced by Haast (1865) for the "greywackes" of Canterbury, based on the Torlesse Range in the foothills of the Southern Alps. (Jul 1998,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,116/21)

In contrast to the Torlesse Group the Haast Schist is represented with considerable structural detail, mainly derived from Grindley (1963). (Nov 1968,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,Vol 26) [NOTES: No page numbers in Newsletter 26]

The revival of Haast's term "Torlesse", proposed informally by Brian Mason and formally by Suggate (1961), has been found convenient and practicable for mapping purposes. (May 1971,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,30/9)

The great bulk of Canterbury greywacke remains Torlesse undifferentiated: Perhaps Wilson's units defined in S62 may be shown to have wider application. (Jun 1974,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,37/31) [NOTES: [That capital on 'perhaps' is as written.]]

toro¶

n. Myrsine salicina

Of the nine Myrsine native to New Zealand, toro is one of the lesser known. (Aug 12, 2006,Dominion Post Indulgence,19)

The leaves of toro (Myrsine salicina, mamangi (Coprosoma arborea) amd makomako (wineberry) have a rich pink undersurface, yet these species thrive in sunny, exposed positions at the forest margins. (Nov 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 60/61)

n. Persoonia, a member of the Proteaceae, [Auck/N Auck to 38 lat]

DIEFFENBACH Of the Proteaceae, the Tora (Persoonia tora)[toru] and Rewa-rewa (Knightia excelsa) are the only known species. (1843,Travels in NZ)

WILLIAMS [=? Suttonia; ? Persoonia] The Toro, this tree grows naturally into a perfect oval, and the leafs [sic] at the extremity of each branch are pink, the others quite green and printed. It seldom grows larger than 40 feet and its flower has a pleasing and odoriferous smell. [glossary 120 ... Suttonia salicina. The reference to flower odour suggests Persoonia toru, also sometimes known as toro]. (1844,NZ Journal,105,1956 ed.)

HOOKER Persoonia toro, A.Cunn. ... HAB. Northern Island. Woods, from Auckland northward, ... Nat. name, `Toro', Col. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 219)

HOOKER Toro, Col[enso]. Persoonia Toro. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

1/iii/5 Of our shrubs and smaller timber trees, several are of strikingly beautiful growth ... the Toro, Persoonia Toro;... the Karo, Pittosporum crassifolium; and the truly evergreen Ngaio, Myoporum laetum ... (1869,TrNZI) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

2/90 The slopes of the hills are usually covered with a dense forest ... the forms being ... Toro (Persoonia Toro, A Cunn.) ... and immense tussocks of an undescribed Astelia, and cutting grasses (Gahnia lacera, Stend., G. arenaria, Hook. f.) ... and Mange-mange (Lygodium articulatum, Swartz.), ... render all progress tedious ... (1870,TrNZI) [NOTES: (Kirk)]

KIRK TORO.- (Persoonia toro.) A small tree, 20 to 30 feet high, confined to the Province of Auckland. (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,23)

KIRK [Native name] Toro .. [Settlers' name] Toro .. [Family] Proteaceae (1886,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,122)

LAING & BLACKWELL Persoonia toru (The Toru or Toro). A small tree. (1907,Plants of NZ,148,1940, p. 153 ed.)

LEVY The development of the kauri to dominance was preceded by scrub and low-forest phases, the chief species being mingimingi, Gaultheria, manoao, kumarahou, tauhinu, Lycopodium, umbrella fern, manuka, kanuka, tree ferns, tanekaha, toro, and rewarewa. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,3,1970 ed.)

BRASCH He had collected too a number of North Island trees and shrubs, at that time rareties in Dunedin, ...-a kauri, a whau, a puriri, a toro, a tawa and others. (1980,Indirections,53)

n.

CHEESEMAN P[ersoonia] Toru, A.Cunn. ... North Cape to Rotorua and East Cape. ... Toru; Toro. ... The specific name was given as Toru' in Cunningham's original description ... and according to Mr Colenso this is the proper spelling of the Maori name. It was, however, changed toTora' ..., and was again altered to `Toro' by Sir J.D. Hooker. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,605)

LAING & BLACKWELL Persoonia toru (The Toru or Toro). A small tree. (1907,Plants of NZ,148,1940, p. 153 ed.)

LEVY ... such species as lancewood, karamu, toro, ramarama, koromiko, kanono, kohuhu, kawakawa, hangehange, rangiora, five finger, patete, toru, tree daisies, broadleaf, kamahi, mahoe, tarata, karo, lacebark, wineberry, fuchsia, kowhai, with tree ferns, weki, and mamuku. Toetoe, phormium, cabbage tree, with swamp coprosma and hupiro may figure as a developmental phase on wet soils. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,87,1970 ed.)

... such species as lancewood, karamu, toro, ramarama, koromiko, kanono, kohuhu, kawakawa, hangehange, rangiora, five finger, patete, toru, tree daisies, broadleaf, kamahi, mahoe, tarata, karo, lacebark, wineberry, fuchsia, kowhai, with tree ferns, weki, and mamuku. Toetoe, phormium, cabbage tree, with swamp coprosma and hupiro may figure as a developmental phase on wet soils. (Dec 1958,NZ Timber Journal,73/1)

MARTIN 4. Toru (Persoonia toru) leaves 4-8 in., narrow, ... (1961,Flora NZ,164 ed.)

MOORE & IRWIN PERSOONIA (TORONIA) TORU. Toru is common in the north and extends to the Volcanic Plateau where it can be seen ... on Rainbow Mountain. ... `The name is derived from the epithet toru, of Maori origin, and the ending -onia to suggest the affinity with Persoonia'. (Johnson and Briggs 1975). (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,22)

2 n. Myrsine MYRSINACEAE [to n.SI 42 lat.]

KIRK MAPAU.- (Myrsine australis.) (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,20)

CRAWFORD [Myrsine] [Near Wellington] red, black, white birch - hinau, kahikatea, rimu, miro, toro, rata, tawa. (1880,Travels in NZ,185)

CHEESEMAN M[yrsine] salicina, Heward[?????] A small tree 15-30 ft. high ... [432] Toro. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,431)

LAING & BLACKWELL [Suttonia salicina (The Toro)]. A small tree, sometimes 40 ft. in height ... Maori name, Toro. ([1907] Rapanea salicina) (1907,Plants of NZ,332,1940[353] ed.)

MAR 6. Toro (Suttonia salicina) leaves 3-7 in., obtuse, shiny; ... (1961,Flora NZ,163)

MOORE & IRWIN MYRCINE SALICINA, toro. A small, narrow-headed tree of forest margins and second growth in the North Island and warmer parts of the South Island. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,116)

DENNIS Most prominent among the broadleaf species here [in Westland] are toro (Myrsine salicina), Westland quintinia (Q. acutifolia) ... stinkwood (C. foetidissima) ... and pate (Schefflera digitata) with hutu Ascarina [158] lucida) ... (1981,Paparoas Guide,157)

TORO/ Myrsine salicina/Tree reaching 10m. (1982,Field Guide to Common NZ Trees & Shrubs,26)

DAWSON Other species which tend to be more wide ranging are mahoe (Melicytus ramiflorus), pigeonwood (Hedycarya arborea), toro (Myrsine salicina) ... (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,102)

3 n.

(Dec 1958,NZ Timber Journal,73/1)

toroa¶

n. the albatross. [Maori]

They spent their time in fishing, shooting, and planting for the settlers and in catching the Toroa, a bird which they prized for its flesh. (Feb 1, 1933,NZ Tablet,15)

LEE & KENDALL Tor|oa, s. An albatross. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,217)

DIEFFENBACH 72. Diomedea exulans, Linn., Lath. ... `Not immediately near the shores ... but in the New Zealand seas, exist several kinds of albatrosses, which the natives call Toroa.' - Dieffenbach. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/200) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/200]

TAYLOR [Word list] Toro[?a] a sea bird a large bird hakokoa do (Aug 1843,Journal,52)

THOMSON Six species of the Procellaridae are found on the sea-coasts. The Titi, or mutton bird, and the Toroa, or albatross, are the most celebrated birds of this family. (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/28)

Diomedea exulans. Toroa. Albatross. (1869,TrNZI,1/161) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

HUTTON 118. DIOMEDEA EXULANS. L. Albatross. Torea.[sic: error for Toroa] (1871,Birds of New Zealand,43)

BULLER DIOMEDEA EXULANS. (WANDERING ALBATROSS.) ... Native name.- Toroa. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,289)

DIOMEDEA MELANOPHRYS. (BLACK-EYEBROWED ALBATROSS.) ... Native name.- Toroa. ... This species of Albatross is far more common in our seas than Diomedea exulans, ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,292,1888 2nd edn 2/198 ed.)

BAUCKE (1928,Where the White Man Treads,61)

55/159 toroa, a sea-bird (Diomedea exulans), albatross: tuft of down much valued as an ear-ornament. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

toroa: albatross (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

BUCK Feathers of the albatross (toroa), long-tailed cuckoo (koekoea), and heron (kotuku) were also valued. (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,284)

RICHARDS Diomedes ... regia ... [88] Royal Albatross. TOROA. (1952,Chatham Islands,87)

KEENE toroa: albatross. (1963,O Te Raki,195)

toroa n. the wandering albatross [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

toroa ... n. the wandering albatross [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

18. a. Diomedea exulans exulans Linnaeus, 1758 Wandering Albatross (Toroa) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,18,1970 ed.)

Wandering Albatross Diomedea exulansLINNAEUS, 1758 ... OTHER NAMES: Wanderer, toroa. Ibid. 60 Royal Albatross Diomedea epomophora LESSON, 1825. ... OTHER NAME: Toroa. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,58)

2 n.

HULME It was the kind of bird Kerewin called a mollymawk, and Joe, toroa. (1983,Bone People, The,247)

New Zealand Black-browed Mollymawk D[iomedea] m[elanophrys] impavida MATHEWS, 1912. OTHER NAME: Toroa (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,61)

toroa-haoika¶

n. Australian gannet

BULLER SULA {DYSPORUS} SERRATOR. (AUSTRALIAN GANNET.) ... Native names.- Takapu, Takupu, and Toroa-haoika. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/177)

toroa-pango¶

n. sooty albatross

BULLER DIOMEDEA FULIGINOSA. (SOOTY ALBATROSS.) ... Native name.- Toroa-pango. ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,296,1888 2nd edn 2/205 ed.)

toroa-ruru¶

n. the nelly

RICHARDS Ossifraga ... or Macronectes ... giganteus ... If a birder comes near the nest the old birds move away a little and the young ones squirt a horrible smelling oil out of their mouths for a distance of 8 ft. Nellies are filthy birds that range the whole of the Southern Hemisphere and deserve their name of stinkpot. Nelly, Stinkpot. TOROA-RURU. (1952,Chatham Islands,86)

toroheke¶

n.

CHEESEMAN P[imelea] arenaria, A.Cunn. ... Aute-taranga; Toroheke. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,612)

toroi¶

n.

Nick will now be selling toroi, a mixture of muscles and puha, by the pottle. (Sep 12, 1998,Dominion,17)

toromiro¶

n.

HOOKER Toromiro. Podocarpus ferruginea. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

toropapa¶

n. one of several native shrub species distinguished by highly fragrant flowers and crimson berries

LAING & BLACKWELL Alseuosmia macrophylla (The Large-leaved Alseuosmia). A shrub, 4 ft.- 10 ft. in height. ... Maori name, Toropapa. ... Alseuosmia quercifolia (The Oak-leaved Alseuosmia) ... Maori name, Toropapa. (1940,Plants of NZ,428)

LAING & BLACKWELL ALSEUOSMIA MACROPHYLLA. Toropapa ... is common in the northern half of the North Island, less so at its southern limit about Nelson. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,428)

SALE The Maoris call it toropapa, and the botanists alseuosmia - perfume of the grove. (1982,Four Seasons,33)

The alseuosmia macrophylla, the sweet-scented toropapa, or bush daphne, to give it yet a third name, is also very early this year, as it has been out for at least a week on the top of the Waitakeres. (Sep 3, 1930,Evening Post,10)

Toropapa was discovered by Europeans when Alan Cunningham found it growing in Hokianga in 1826. ... Toropapa can be found growing in the Wild Garden and the Banks Entrance Garden at Otari-Wilton's Bush. (Oct 14, 2006,Dominion Post,17)

tororaro¶

n.

The shrubby tororaro (Muehlenbeckia astonii) is found only on Wairarapa and Wellington-Cook Strait coasts and inland in Marlborough and Canterbury. (Sep 24, 1998,Evening Post,1)

They include Carex cirrhosa (a sedge which was growing at the edge of a boat ramp at Lake Wairarapa), the Castlepoint daisy, not found anywhere else in the world, and shrubby tororaro or Meuhlenbeckia astonii, a coastal shrub ranked as nationally vulnerable. (May 2004,Footnotes,No. 21/7)

At the far end of a flat triangular peninsula, you'll find an exclosure plot built by the Conservation Department to protect the last few shrubby tororaro in the area. (Dec 30, 2003,Dominion Post,C2)

Muehlenbeckia astonii, the shrubby tororaro, suffered habitat disturbance, unseasonal chills, roading, quarrying, fire, and predation everything from horses, goats and possums to rabbits and invertebrates. Today there are just 44 wild plants in DOC's Wellington conservancy, and its conservation status is "highest priority threatened species". (Sep 1, 2001,Dominion,10)

Among the species being grown in the new reserves are Muehlenbackia astonii (shrubby tororaro), Euphorbia glauca (shore spurge, thought to have been extinct in the Wellington region for 20 years, then rediscovered in 1996/96 on a rocky stack off Kapiti Island), Discaria tomentosa (a species of anchor plant, one of Wellington's - and the North Island's - rarest plants), Hebe speciosa (showy hebe) and Tetragonia tetragonioides (New Zealand spinach). (Jan 2004,NZ Geographic,No. 67/11)

torore¶

n. = torori

TAYLOR That [tobacco] which they grow universally obtains the name of Torore which signifies intoxicating. (Apr 28, 1851,Journal,7/198)

TAYLOR (fn) This song has a great deal of meaning : the being bereft of pipe refers to the very heavy duty which had been put on tobacco, to make the native, who was the chief consumer, pay as much as possible; but this over-grasping defeated itself. The native, unable to purchase tobacco to the extent he formerly did, began to grow it himself, and from instructions he has contrived to pick up, he now manufactures it; this he calls torore; some of it is so well made that there are great smokers who will give equal weight of our best tobacco for it. (1868,Past and Present of NZ,134)

A stranger - a white man - passes through and stops to give his horse a feed; at once some twenty or thirty people turn out; and squat down in all dignity, wrapping their blankets around them like so many Roman consuls, smoke their vile burning torore (why they prefer that to our Cavendish at 8s. the lb. I can't understand), and take notes of every gesture. (Jan 19, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,3)

torori¶

n.

Torori - Tobacco of Maori manufacture; smokes like Boer tobacco but has an odour peculiarly its own. (May 16, 1917,Chronicles NZEF,II/18 : 126)

Maori youths under fifteen are not to smoke tobacco, 'torori' (the powerful native-grown 'baccy).. on pain of fine. (Jun 15, 1912,NZ Free Lance,9)

My native acquaintance also took advantage of the spell, for ... she inquired if I objected to the smell of torori' (native tobacco); ...My torori; I cured it; take some, try it.' I shuddered. I remembered one day when the tobacco hunger pinched me sore - torori or suffer; ... (1905,Where the White Man Treads,144)

BAUCKE (1928,Where the White Man Treads,31)

torori n. Maori tobacco, prepared from plants cultivated over generations from seed obtained from early settlers and seamen. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

FINLAYSON torori: home-grown tobacco (1973,Brown Man's Burden,142) [NOTES: (1938 p.42 get cit]]

PARK It had.. an interior atmosphere thick with the woeful fumes of torori, the black native pigtail tobacco. (1992,Fence Around the Cuckoo,37)

torotoro¶

n. ?a cloak ?a climber

HYDE Soak the lithe toro-toro,and best yarn/ Was not so strong for tying up stockades,/ (1937,Selected Poems,37,1984 ed.)

T|oro t|oro; ... the root of a shrub so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,217)

MARKHAM In tying the Rafters to the Ridge Pole, and in making their Parrs, the same Creeper is used, but I forget its name Toro Toro [torotoro [inserted by E.M. later]]. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),35,1963 ed.)

YATE The minor fence [of a pa] ... formed of large poles and stakes tightly knotted or woven together with torotoro, the fibrous roots of a plant which abounds in the woods; ... (1835,New Zealanders at Gallipoli,122)

MANING .. I was in the thick of it, and worked all day lashing the fence; the fence being of course not nailed, but lashed with toro-toro, a kind of tough creeping plant, like a small rope, which was very strong and well adapted for the purpose. (1863,Old New Zealand,(iii) 41)

HOOKER Torotoro, Lindsay. Metrosideros scandens. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

BAINES ... stout pieces of timber were securely fastened horizontally, by a good lashing of `Toro-Toro' vine ... (1874,Edward Crewe,85)

BULLER The spot fixed upon was ... under the shadow of a ... tawhero (Weinmannia racemosa), sheltered all round by close-growing porokaiwiria, torotoro, and other shrubby trees ... (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/12)

FEATON Torotoro [Maori name] .. Myrtle [Settlers' name] .. Metrosideros scandens ..Climber (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,178)

HYDE (1952,Houses by the Sea,63)

One hundred and sixty Kauri spars, raised perpendicularly, form the frame-work of this singular pile, several of them are squared, and five of them from 90 to 100 feet high, to which smaller spars of from 10 to 15 feet are again added, bound firmly together by the strong vine Torotoro, making the total height of the turret in the centre from 115 to 120 feet, from which other 8 turrets, ranging from 70 to 80 feet, run the length of the erection. (Sep 4, 1849,Daily Southern Cross,2)

torpedo¶

n. a shark (See ray)

Narcobatus fairchildi (Hutton). SOUTHERN NUMBFISH, OR WHAI REPO. ... The species is also called torpedo' orelectric ray.' Hutton states that the Natives (presumably of Napier) call it whai-ngenge. (1930,Selected Poems,11/198) [NOTES: Phillipps]

n. a torpedo-shaped bottle

All that was whole were [sic] unembossed Mace and Dixon torpedoes and plain ginger beers. (May 1980,NZ Antique Bottle Collector,4(3)/19)

I have been hearing a lot about the Hamilton patent controversy, lately, namely Walter Hamilton patented the torpedo (or egg shape bottle). I believe I have indisputable proof that he did not. (1980,NZ Antique Bottle Collector,5(1)/9)

[Caption] Early Australian impressed ginger beers and Schweppes torpedo from the Avon (Feb 1978,NZ Antique Bottle Collector,No. 2(2)/11)

NEAME Now we were into the top class bottles, torpedos, Maughans patents or aerated water bottles and two bluish-green Townsends both in one camp. Ibid. 37 ...we found a lot of Torpedos and also a few Australian Torpedos. (1985,Gold, Coins, Greenstone, & Bottles,29)

torpedo fish¶

n.

MANNERING I was told [during a visit to Te Anau in December 1923] that poachers had been taking them [Alantic Salmon Salmo salar] for some years previous to our visit and that local people called them `Torpedo fish', as distinct from trout. (1943,Eighty Years,206)

torpedo pass¶

n.

SLATTER ... Wilkinson ... suddenly flings a torpedo pass right out to his backs ... (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,84)

torpedo-juice¶

n. a mixture of beer and anti-freeze; (any (home-brewed) strong liquor [ca1943 (Ken Griffiths); in common use postwar (DEH)]

He and 13 others.. drank a mixture of beer and glycol, an anti-freeze liquid. The resultant brew is generally known as torpedo-juice. (Aug 20, 1947,NZ Observer,12)

Torrens title¶

n.

I feel I should correct [Easton's] throwaway comment on "outrageous overcharging" by government for transfers under the Land Transfer Act, commonly referred to as the Torrens Title system... However, the Torrens Title system as originally established in 1871 was from the outset intended to be self-funding and not a cost on government. (Mar 19, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),115)

torrentfish¶

n. Cheimarrichthys fosteri

McDOWALL A very distinctive and unusual looking fish occasionally caught by whitebaiters is the torrentfish Cheimarrichthys fosteri... [23] Adult torrentfish are found in similar habitats to the bluegilled bully - swift gravelly rapids, from sea level to 50 or more kilometres inland. (1984,NZ Whitebait Book, The,23)

"Rare species such as giant, banded and short-jawed kokopu have been found or relocated in streams and rivers on Council land, as well as koaro, red-finned bullies and torrentfish." (Jun 2002,Elements,17/3)

n. Cheimarrichthys fosteri [aka torrent fish; also shark-bully, [Maori Name] papanoko.]

Cheimarrichthys fosteri , Haast (1929,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,11/166) [NOTES: (Phillips)]

Cheimarrichthys fosteri : [European Name] Torrent-fish or shark-bully [Maori Name] Papanoko. (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,73)

McLINTOCK TORRENT FISH .. .. papanoko .. .. Cheimarrichthys fosteri (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

NATUSCH Family CHEIMARRICHTHYIDAE. The torrent fish, Cheimarrichthys fosteri... spends part of its life in salt or brackish water, and part in rapids of lower stretches of shingly rivers. (1967,Animals of NZ, The,222)

DENNIS The curious-looking torrentfish (Cheimarrichthys fosteri) also comes out of the sea in spring. (1981,Paparoas Guide,189)

The torrentfish is found in very swiftly flowing, tumbling rapids and so is not likely to be seen ... The blue-gilled bully may share its habitat, and both species have sea-living juveniles. (1983,Land of the Mist,73)

[caption] Under water: Native fish found in the region's [Wellington] rivers and streams are, clockwise from top left, inanga, redfin bully, torrent fish, banded kokopu, giant kokopu and kaoro. (May 7, 2005,Dominion Post,A21)

SPEIGHT The Stargazers or `Catfishes' are related to the Rock Cod and the Torrent fish of the rivers;... (1927,Natural History of Canterbury)

Being so rare, it has not received a popular name, and I cannot therefore do better than chisten [sic] it 'Torrent fish.' (Jan 22, 1908,Grey River Argus,1)

toru¶

n. variant of toro (See toro)

Some interesting botanical associations - such as toru, kauri and tanekaha - occur in the 85 hectares of coastal modified primary and secondary forest at Taupiri Bay. ... Toronia toru, the only endemic species of the Toronia genus, has fragrant flowers, leaves that can be red-tinged, and corky spots on the bark. (Nov 2005,Open Space,5)

torua¶

n.

SHORTLAND This evening, Huruhuru made me a pair of sandals, such as are in common use among these natives. They are called paraerae', and are made either with the leaves of the flax-[210]plant, or of theti' (cordyline Australis). ... Mine were a pair with double soles, called `torua', ... (Jan 13, 1844,Southern Districts of NZ,209)

toss a reverse lunch¶

phr. to vomit [toss also as noun]

He claimed incident in Eastern Moon had arisen when local person had `tossed a reverse lunch' of prawns, sweetcorn, and tomato skins over his person ... (1979,Loosehead Len's Gluepot Greats in $1,154)

toss in¶

v. to throw in esp. toss it in, to admit defeat

THOMSON And though a few had stuck it out, gradually gaining experience and learning to love the life, others had decided out of hand that deer shooting was not for them and had tossed it in. Ibid. 22 In fact, over the years one could find men from practically every occupation tossing in what are generally considered `good' jobs, and spending the rest of their working lives in the mountains. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,21)

DAVIN (1956,Sullen Bell,128)

toss one's lollies¶

phr. to vomit [also chuck or lose one's lollies; cf. ODE toss one's cookies N.Amer.]

They were seen ... tossing back Tequila Slammers and then heard together in the pissoir on their knees tossing their lollies long and loud. (Mar 1986,Metro,27)

Blah! The Ferret's about to toss her lollies. (Jul 1987,Metro,22)

McGill lolly any sweets, short for lollipop. NZA. - chuck or lose your lollies to spew. - do one's lolly lose one's temper. NZA (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,70)

toss the coin¶

phr.

Gilbert said that he had plenty of money as he played pool, toss the coin and won quinellas at the races. He refused to point the finger' at where Mr Maddox got the dope.... this has spoilt a good day. I have been raging all day. I punched him over because he tried to punch me over, and put me in my place. He reckoned he was a Liverpudlian seaman who had been here for 20 years, a big toughie,' Gilbert had told him. (Dec 7, 1984,Press, The,4)

toss the tiger¶

phr. an elaboration of toss (up) to vomit f. striped appearance of vomit: cf Techicolour yawn [ca1960 Auckland (Vincent O'Sullivan)]

toss up¶

v. to vomit: a variant of the general English throw up (cf TOSS THE TIGER) [ca1935 at least]

toss-about¶

n.

`Euclid Junior' writes: I notice that diagrams, graphs, charts, etc., are now much used to explain things. After a toss-about among Government departments, I tried to think of a suitable diagram for the Official Mind. (Sep 2, 1918,Quick March,11)

tossel¶

n. a (child's) penis [or tassel [ca1935 (but possibly from ca1900) Havelock Jane Morison]

tossing¶

n.

THATCHER Algebra is all my eye, / For mathematics do not sigh, / But at tossing learn to be quite fly. / And you'll be a leary boy. (1875,NZ Songster,No. 5/62) [NOTES: The Leary Boy]

tot¶

n. (informal) totara [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

McGILL Jack Wilson of Orepuki had his first job with the sawmill at Port Craig. He remembers the twenty-four-metre-high derrick used to winch the timber on a pulley out to the ships. In his day about 130 men cut rimu, tot (his word for totara) and birch on the beach. (1980,Ghost Towns of NZ,195)

totalisator¶

n.

From the birdcage, the people would walk to the totalisator. (Nov 18, 1935,Christchurch Star-Sun,3)

BRIDGES & DOWNS The invention of the automatic totalisator is as much a New Zealand one as it is Australian. (2000,No 8 Wire: The Best of Kiwi Ingenuity,54)

In fan tan palaces 10 per cent goes to the house. Seems almost as respectable as the totalisators, doesn't it? (May 25, 1912,NZ Free Lance,30)

PHILLIPS By the late 1870s a monster in the form of the totalisator (primitive as it was at that stage) raised its head to leer in the direction of the bookies. The warning became louder in 1879 when the Wellingtonc orrespondent of the Lyttelton Times telegraphed:'... that it is proposed to amend the Lotteries Act so as to legalise the totalisator"... In 1880 a Mr Ekberg patented an elementary type of totalisator which was first used at the Canterbury Jockey Club in that year. (2000,First Past the Post,89) [NOTES: Miriam Redwood "I lay the Field" in <Proud Silk 1979]

[WICKHAM] Another social pest that might very well be handed on to the local option tribunal, is the Totalizator. (1897,Casual Ramblings,80)

There are suggestions that there were some early primitive totalisator machines in operation in Auckland and Australia, but the credit for the first mechanized totalisator in the world goes to a Mr. Ekberg of Christchurch who invented and patented a mechanical totalisator in 1880. ... It was first used in Riccarton by [47] the Canterbury Jockey Club. ... Public opposition continued to flourish and in 1896 a Bill to abolish the totalisator was narrowly defeated. (Jun 2005,NZ Memories,No 54, p. 46)

D'AVIGDOR Nine-tenths of the betting is done through the Totalisater, ... (1888,Antipodean Notes,114)

BARLOW A sort of betting machine called the `Totalisator' has indeed been legalised by the New Zealand Government; but may only be used at race meetings where prizes of thirty pounds or upwards are given. (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,98)

WILSON The `totalizator' provides for many the excitement that may sometimes be lacking in the race; but the dividends dispensed therefrom never seem to be adequate ... (1894,In the Land of the Tui,43)

The Totalisator, at the late Sydney meeting, seems to have taken greatly with the public. (May 24, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,19)

Every village has its race course, its grandstand, and its totalisator. (Jan 1, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7)

An electric machine has a tremendous advantage over the old manual totalisator. (Aug 23, 1939,Taranaki Herald,3)

Totalisator Agency Board¶

n. the government sponsored betting agency (See also TAB)

This was soon followed by the establishment of private bookmakers, known as 'bookies' who were to remain on the New Zealand scene, albeit illegally, until the Totalisator Agency Board was established in 1950. (Jun 2005,NZ Memories,No. 54, p. 46)

JOURNET Your betting shop will have a notice in its window announcing that it is a Branch of the Totalisator Agency Board. (1954,Take My Tip,69)

BOOTH Stop off at the TAB., will you, Jim.' ...the converted shop which now carried the big signTotalistor Angency Board', the open sesame for off-course betting. (1964,Footsteps in the Sea,64)

McLINTOCK A Totalisator Agency Board was then set up under a Gaming Amendment Act (15 December 1949) to operate the scheme, ... (1966,Encyclopedia Britannica,3/22)

TURNER [spg -z-] The introduction of off-course betting in 1949 brought the doubles totalizator and the TAB (`there shall be a board [175] to be known as the Totalizator Agency Board' - Gaming Amendment Act, 1949). (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,174)

Totalizator Agency Board NZ official board, with local offices, for off-course betting on horses. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,813) [NOTES: [.nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.] [spg with -z- ]]

totalla¶

n. (See totara)

totalled¶

adj. drunk

Getting "pissed", "off your face". Trashed", "boozed" or "totalled" is still seen as a rite of passage, and no alteration of the legal drinking age seems to be changing that. (Jun 3, 2000,Dominion,19)

totara¶

n. (Environment) a fish

TAYLOR Of the Fam. Plectognathi there are three species: Tetraodon Hamiltoni, the Monacanthus parika, and the Diadona globulas. Kopuawai, Koputaratara, Papati and Totara, all these are descriptive names, implying that it is covered with sharp spines, and is inflated; this singular fish is frequently cast up on the shore, and sometimes of a large size. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,625)

n. = patotara

HOOKER Totara,Lindsay. Cyathodes oxycedrus. ... 768 Totara, Col[enso]. Leucopogon Frazeri. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

CHEESEMAN L[eucopogon] Fraseri, A.Cunn. ... A small shrubby plant 2-6 in. high, ... branching from the base; ... [415] Totara. ... The drupe is juicy, sweetish, and edible. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,414)

n. (Environment) Podocarpus totara, a forest tree and its timber, mahogany(-pine); a large native forest tree prized for its timber. [ORIGIN: Maori]

N.Z. Rail is the totara in the rain forest of inter-island communication. (Jun 1987,Landfall,162/208) [NOTES: (Coker)]

I am not sending my totara tree [sketch] this time because I want to make another foreground. (Jun 18, 1884,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/522) [NOTES: (Dorothy K. Richmond)]

WAKEFIELD The totara is one of the finest trees in the forest. (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/221)

  1. Totara, (Podocarpus totara.) This tree grows to a large size, especially in the Hutt, Porirua, and Karori districts. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,141)

BRADEY totarer (1849,Papers)

FOR SALE, a few 2-inch Totara COUNTER TOPS, 2 feet wide. (Feb 1, 1851,Lyttelton Times,4)

The timber in [the groves] is chiefly Kaikatea, (white pine), Mahi, (black pine), Remu, (red pine), Pokaka, Kowai, and Totara .. That in the other forest [ie. not Harewood or Alford] is principally tawai, (black birch), the best timber for boat and ship building, but sometimes unsound ... (Jun 28, 1851,Lyttelton Times,6)

Totaras, white and black pines, koas etc (1851,Otago Journal,8/126,1852 ed.)

EARP Of the [Wairarapa] plain, about 100,000 acres is covered with fine timber, chiefly totara, matai, hiora, kahikatea, manuka &c., all highly valuable for .. cabinet work and carpentry. (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),113)

Podocarpus totara, Cunn. .. Nat. name, `Totara', Cunn. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 233)

BARKER There are traces all over the hills of vast forests having once existed; chiefly of totara, a sort of red pine ... (1866,Station Life in NZ,95,1870 ed.)

HOOKER Totara, Col[enso]. Podocarpus totara. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Totara (Podocarpus Totara), a most valuable timber tree, being very durable and easily worked. Ibid. 32 Totara (Podocarpus nivalis). A mountain shrub resembling Totara, of no economic value. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/31) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Podocarpus Totara Totara (1870,TrNZI,2/122) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

PRENTICE Black, white and red pines, totara .. (1870,Tale of NZ,33) [NOTES: (Otago)]

DOMETT Totara [a1 acute] .. O. Coniferae; G. Podocarpus; S P. totara. The Swamp-totara, P. dacrydiodes, grows up to 150 feet in height. P. totara, from which canoes are made,' to a less height.Bark used for roofing.' (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/302)

English Name Native name Botanical Name Totara Totara .. (1889,Catalogue, Canterbury Court Exhibition,35)

Totara .. Podocarpus totara .. Timber of a reddish colour, soft, easily worked, and of great durability ... (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,15)

DOUGLAS .. Red and Black pine, Rata and Totara .. the Cedars and Totaras .. young Totara, however large they may be [in Westland]. (1892,Letter) [NOTES: 1892 Douglas letter to Strauchan in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 175]

HARPER There is also the rata tree, the prince of firewoods .. miki-miki, kamahi, or so-called red-birch, white and black birches (which are really beeches), the mountain broom, ribbon wood, broad leaf, totara, and many others .. and always available in the Ranges [sc. Alps]. (1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,35)

MORRIS Totara, n. Maori name for a lofty-spreading New Zealand tree, Podpcarpus totara, A. Cunn., N.O. Coniferae. In Maori, the accent falls on the first syllable; but in English use it is often placed on the second, and from Mr. Polack's spelling it must have been so as early as 1840. Called also Mahogany-pine. There are several other species, e.g. P. vivalis, Hook, the Mountain Totara; called also Mahogany Pine. (1898,Austral English,475) [NOTES: see Mahogany, and Pine. [1832 on various cits]]

BAUGHAN Totara: A native timber. Ibid. 54 Kauri and Totara, Rimu, and Matai and Maire,/ Red-as-blood Rata, and bright-as-blood Pohutukawa,/ Manuka dark-ey'd, Convolvulus star-ey'd - / The glittering of you that morning! (1908,Shingle-Short,12) [NOTES: [fn2 attached to the italicised names] 2. Kauri, etc. (Kow-ree, To[acute]-ta-ra, Ree[e acute]-moo, Mah[a acute]-ti, Mi-reh, Rah[a acute]-tah, Po-hoo-too-kah[a acute]-wah, Mah[a acute]-noo-kah): New Zealand Bush trees.]

~ n. a large coniferous tree giving valuable timber; the timber of the tree [Maori]. (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,12)

The chief indigenous trees of commercial value are: Kauri (Agathis Australis) .. totara (Podocarpus totara and Podocarpus Hallii), Miro (Podocarpus ferrugineus) .. northern and southern rata (Metrosideros robusta and Metrosideros lucida). (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,578)

AYSON Totara posts were put in at intervals, leaving spaces for doors and windows according to the plan ... (1937,Thomas,64)

totara, a most valued timber-tree (Podocarpus totara), so useful to the Maori that he considered it the ariki of all trees; the best timber for canoes, house-timbers, slabs for carving, manuka and like heavy woods being used for weapons - taiaha, tewhatewha, etc. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/147) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

totara: tall timber tree. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

SARGESON (gloss.) totara: a New Zealand tree. (1949,I Saw in My Dream,273,1974 ed.)

DUFF In addition the boys have cut down rimu, totara, matai, and pinus growing on the property and built a 4-stand woolshed without help from outside. (Dec 22, 1954,Shepherd's Calendar,202,1961 ed.)

The Maori name of a large timber tree, much used by the Maoris for canoes, housebuilding, etc. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),417)

totara n -s [Maori] : a tall tree (Podocarpus totara) of New Zealand having hard reddish wood used for furniture and construction (as of bridges and wharves) and being the country's most valuable timber tree next to the kauri. (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2415)

McLINTOCK Totara .. totara .. Podocarpus totara (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

totara n. lofty New Zealand tree, a red pine [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

totara ... n. lofty N.Z. tree with fine and easily worked reddish wood [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

totara [s] Podocarpus totara G. Benn. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,79)

The Duke of Edinburgh Chest of 8 Drawers, centre drawer richly panelled with totara burr and rewarewa - - GBP6 10s. (Apr 8, 1882,Bay of Plenty Times,3)

The principal samples sent by the company were a figured rimu door with mottled puriri panels, and a series of veneers of the following timbers:- Mottled and plain rimu, totara burr, mottled and wavy kauri, honeysuckle, pohutukawa, maungaeo, silver pine, and towai. (Feb 27, 1905,Evening Post,4)

Successional planting of such species as totara and miro is so labour intensive. (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 1)

The totara piles without sheathing were, he added, all sound. (Dec 24, 1884,Evening Post,4)

The organ front is of a very chaste design, the uprights being of rimu, the cross rails kauri, the open fret-work in this being backed by totara burr, and further relieved by totara mouldings; the desk is of rimu, and the whole being polished up shows up the beautiful contrast of the woods to perfection. (Sep 29, 1896,Evening Post,5)

NICHOLAS A species of pine, called by the natives totarra, excited our astonishment, from the bulk and height to which it grew. (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/329)

LEE & KENDALL T|otara, s. A species of pine ... (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,217)

McCRAE Here we found the trees .. of that kind called by the natives Demo and Totara. The former resembles the pine and the latter has a leaf like the yew tree ... (1820,Journal,20,1928 ed.)

.. the wood with which they make a light - cow|atti and to'talla [kauati and totara] (1826,Boultbee Journal,1986,109 ed.)

LAMBERT (1832,Genus Pinus,2/190) [NOTES: 1832. G. Bennett, in Lambert's `Genus Pinus,' vol. ii. p. 190: [Mor]]

McDONNELL A great variety of hard-wood grows at New Zealand, admirably adapted for the timbering of any sized ships; among them is the boride[e-acute], rattar[as-acute], taraide[ase-acute], mai[a-acute], totara[a1-acute], koi katoa[a2-acute], toa[a-acute] toa[a-acute], tani raha[as-acute], to wai[a-acute], reiva[a-acute] reiva[a-acute], tana[as-acute], and many others. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,19,1979 ed.)

McDONNELL Tota[acute]ra (1834,Extracts From a Journal)

totara n. a tall coniferous forest tree of New Zealand with durable wood. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1237) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 813; COM 506]]

1/III/32 .. the small berries of the Makomako (.us; Aristotelia racemosa), [and] of the heath-like Totara (Leucopogon Fraseri) .. were eagerly sought after .. by [incomplete citation?] (1869,TrNZI) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

YATE Totara (Taxus) - This tree .. is about twenty feet in circumference, and from fifty to sixty feet high in the trunk. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),39)

POLACK There is scarcely a more splendid sight to behold than a New Zealand forest. In the one we now entered, we did not perceive any kouri, or yellow pine-trees; but the totara [a's-acute], or red pine, grew in vast abundance .. The rito, and innumerable other palm-trees, were in great quantity. Ibid. 1/286 .. tota[acute]rra Ibid. 2/391 Totara [a's-acute] (taxus australis) g. coniferae .. is known as red pine. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/105)

POLACK .. the most superior [canoes] are to be found at Wairoa, (Hawkes' Bay) the tribes at that place employ the totarra or red pine, the kouri or white pine being rarely found beyond the Thames (Horake[a-e-acute]). (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/227)

I was informed that about 15 miles from Petoni, there is an extensive forest of toteroa, which timber ranks next in value to kauri. (Oct 10, 1840,GBPP,1841 (No.311) 120) [NOTES: 1840 Oct 10 Shortland to Hobson in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 120]

HODGSKIN Tatatarra [sic], another tree, growing between 60 and 70 feet in high [sic] ... (1841,Narrative of Eight Months Sojourn in NZ, A,27)

.. forests of totorra. (1841,NZ Journal,2/28/47)

totarra (1841,NZ Journal,2/29/51) [NOTES: (Dieffenbach)]

BRIGHT to-ta-ra (1841,Handbook for Emigrants,54)

Totara is one native that, along with manuka and tauhinu, can establish itself into pasture even under moderate grazing pressure. (Oct 2000,Growing Today,69)

TOTARA, MATAI, AND RIMU - SUPPLIED AT CURRENT RATES WHOLESALE AND RETAIL. (Apr 6, 1907,New Zealand Free Lance,15)

BIDWILL It was an open forest of Totara [fn Podocarpus totara] and strongly resembled the pine-woods of Canada. (1841,Rambles in NZ,72,1952 ed.)

HEAPHY The red pines are the Totara, Towa, Mahi, and Rata, all of which are close-grained, and moderately hard. (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),42)

TUCKETT The prevailing species of tree are remo, totara, and tall manuka, all indicative of an inferior soil. (May 24, 1844,Diary) [NOTES: 1844 May 24 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 223]

Podocarpus totara spg TOTARRO (Jul 29, 1844,Report of Select Committee on NZ) [NOTES: (And)]

[tatare] Bark of Tatare [Totara] Tree .. Ibid. 105 [tohara] The Tohara [totara] is handsome, with small sharp leafs [sic] of a dark, green color ... (1844,NZ Journal,49,195t6 ed.)

adj.

The roof was thatched with raupo and strips of totara bark called "flags." (1988,Tales of Pioneer Women,205) [NOTES: Writing of 1940]

DOMETT One lone totara-tree that grew/ Beneath the hill-side. Ibid., 1/157 Made .../ Fast to a single lightsome yew,/ One lone totara-tree [a1-acute] that grew/ Beneath the hillside rising high .../ (1872,Ranolf and Amohia,107)

25 Totara slab. Ibid. 20 269 Totara knot slab. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,16)

When they got to a fence overlooking a deep gully, prisoner and Sergeant Moore dismounted, and the former said: `You see that totara tree and a fern. The body is there.' (Jun 3, 1911,NZ Truth,310/5/2)

HUNT It appeared as a small inverted totara canoe. (1951,Confessions,38)

They used the totara stakes of the stockyards to construct the frame of the house and stripped iron from the slip-torn houses of the wealthy suburbs for the roof. (Jan 21, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),25)

Amongst the articles on view were .. [a] chess table of kauri, with kauri and cedar top, border of Queensland oak and totara burr. (Dec 4, 1920,Poverty Bay Herald,4)

YATE It lays seven purely white eggs, in a compact nest, in the lower branches of the Totara-tree. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),56)

WAKEFIELD ... the natives have a legend that [the Manawatu] was formed by an Atua, or `Evil Spirit', who was in the form of a large Totara-tree ... (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,118)

[Chemist and Druggist's advertisement] N.B. A few Scantling and well-seasoned Totara Boards. (Feb 15, 1851,Lyttelton Times,1)

GOLDER Upon Te Aro Tot'ra Line (1854,Pigeon's Parliament) [NOTES: [get more context and page no]]

ANDERSON Eight feet tall and totara proud, he steps forwards, speaks for a few minutes in Maori, then switches to English. (1999,Long Hot Summer,107)

There was a long bridge on the main road,.. the piles of which, totara rickers, had rotted away. (Sep 13, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,7)

FORDYCE & MACLEHN In 1890 Mariano built wharves at Paremata and Mansa Island from totara posts washed down from floods in the Manawatu and Rangitikei. (2000,Bay, The : A History of Community at Titahi Bay,31)

totara bark¶

n.

TUCKETT already incorporated into ordinary text huts made of totara bark ... (May 2, 1844,Diary) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)1844 May 2 Tuckett's Diary in Hocken Contributions 214]

SMITH Most of the houses are built of slabs of totara bark which is taken from the tree in sheets, often 20 feet long by 10 broad, ... (Jan 14, 1858,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1858 Jan 14 Smith Notes of a Journey in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 362]

[At the abandoned Maori camp was] a pannikin of native manufacture made of totara bark ...[sic] (Feb 12, 1864,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/87,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

... we may divide colonial architecture into periods or ages. First, the wattle-and-dab period, with its contemporaneous, but more advanced, varieties of fern tree and totara bark (1876,TrNZI,8/166) [NOTES: (Blair Building Materials Otago)]

COWAN The camp ... contained thirty thatched houses roofed with totara-bark. (1922,NZ Wars, The,2/282,1983 ed.)

The roof was ... covered with raupo - sometimes with an inner sheeting of totara-bark - while an upper layer of toetoe-grass, secured by ropes of mangemange ..., preserved the raupo from wet. ->1940 Howard Rakiura 208 The tightly packed [kelp bags of mutton-birds] are then cased in longitudinal strips of totara bark and placed in flax bags, the whole being laced with fibre or twine. (1903,TrNZI,35/22)

SMITH It was still raining fast ..., but we continued on till two, [385] when we halted, and commenced building a totara bark hut. (Feb 16, 1858,Notes of a Journey) [NOTES: 1858 Feb 16 Smith Notes of a Journey in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 384-385]

The scene, he writes, is one of those bush hamlets you may see in some of the less-frequented parts of the Urewera Country, a kainga of three or four houses of the olden type, roofed with totara bark; a camp nearly surrounded by forest ranges. (Oct 10, 1931,Evening Post,19)

The bag is protected with strips of totara bark lashed around it, and the mutton-birds are then ready to be sent to market, to be consumed by those who like this dainty. (May 11, 1910,Evening Post,4)

The best house here was built of reeds, wattled together and bound with flax, roofed and lined with totara bark and coarse grass. (Oct 11, 1842,New Zealand Colonist & Port Nicholson Advertiser,4)

Totara bark, it may be explained to the uninitiated, can be pulled from the trees in great sheets, and makes a capital roof when properly laid. (Apr 26, 1888,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

No raupo thatch is seen here, but the whares are roofed instead with totara bark. (Mar 16, 1899,Poverty Bay Herald,4)

totara berry¶

n.

Totara berries, glowing like tiny orange beacons in the morning mist, send a succulent signal to passing birds that breakfast is served. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,82)

totara birch¶

n. ?=hard beech, Nothofagus fusca [ca1935 Marlborough like TOTARA, resistant to decay in the ground, and wood of a reddish colour: used especially for fence-posts] (See totara birch)

totara knot¶

n.

I finished a candlestick for Mrs Cox I have been making out of two totara notts. (Mar 23, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,169,1950 ed.)

The centre [of the table] is a beautifully figured totara knot with a border of tetoki, the whole being highly polished. (Mar 20, 1869,Wellington Independent,4)

The top of the desk is of heart of kauri, beautifully polished, and is inlaid with the guide trefoil in totara knot and kahikatea. (Dec 21, 1926,Evening Post,13)

It took the form of an old brass helmet badge, which had been recovered in the course of excavations at Wanganui, mounted on a handsome piece of polished totara knot, and carrying a suitable inscription. (Nov 6, 1930,Evening Post,5)

.. large honeysuckle and totara knot chest (Aug 29, 1944,Evening Post,3)

We hope Mr Berger will repeat the experiment: we imagine totara knot would soon become a more general favourite even than walnut for piano cases. (Sep 15, 1873,Evening Post,2)

The whole will be enclosed in a casket made of indigenous woods, mounted on carved legs, with a top of totara knot, on which the Duke's arms will be carved. (Jun 5, 1901,Evening Post,5)

After an exciting contest, prizes were presented as follows .. Gentlemen - First, Mr. J. Davis (pipe made from totara knot) ... (Aug 29, 1918,Grey River Argus,3)

The Wellington specimens before alluded to as exhibited by Mr Vogel were kowai, honey-suckle, totara and knot, aki rotangi, rimu knot, black macri, and aki aki. (Jan 3, 1863,Otago Witness,6)

In addition, five other valuable Presents will be distributed, viz. .. Totara Knot Looking-glass[,] Totara Knot Book-shelf. (Oct 17, 1884,Evening Post,3)

totara pine¶

n.

HAAST Along the rather wet track appeared, besides the Totara pine, white pines (Kahikatea, Podocarpus dacrydioides), and black pines (Rimu or Dacrydium cupressinum), which ... towered high above the other forest foliage; although here and there black beeches (Fagus fusca), 100 feet high ... were also to be seen. (1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,81)

Broadleaf [fn Griselinia littoralis.], five-fingered Jack [fn Panax arboreum.], ..and the totara pine [fn Podocarpus totara.] jostle one another in the dense dry bush. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,184)

BASTINGS, LEARY, AND CO, on Jerry street Wharf - Red, black, and totara pine. (Jun 28, 1884,Otago Daily Times,2)

totara post/batten¶

1 n. (Rural) a fencepost or batten made from the hard native timber totara.

.. with good fences of totara posts and wire, 4 pig-proof paddocks ... (Aug 13, 1908,Weekly News,2)

In the long run, totara posts are cheaper. (Apr 1, 1944,NZ Dairy Exporter,02)

Sheep farm: Good sheep-proof fences, ring-fenced with concrete and totara posts. (Sep 29, 1961,NZ Farmer,69)

I strung a couple of extra snarly 3 in barbs atop the new 8-wire boundary line and stayed the barbs up fairly liberally with totara battens. (Aug 1972,NZ Farmer,10)

In the mid 90s he started collecting old totara fenceposts. (Jun 16, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),35)

Clearing sale: deer strainers ... deer gates; quantity totara posts. (Jun 22, 2002,Hawke's Bay Today,22)

totara sponge¶

n. (recipe)

BASHAM TOTARA SPONGE ... eggs ... beat yolks ... with ... sugar ... whites to a stiff froth and add to yolks ... and beat ... Sift ... flour ... cream of tartar ... soda ... fold into mixture and add grated rind of 1 orange ... orange juice ... Bake ... (1939,Aunt Daisy's Cookery Book,155)

totara-kiri-kotukutuku¶

n. fuchsia barked totara

Most frequently the kauri will be found mixed with rimu, kahikatea, tanekaha, miro, totara, totara-kiri-kotukutuku, northern rata, puriri, . (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,116)

totaratara¶

n.

TAYLOR [Word list] totaratara a small shrub like a heath (Aug 1843,Journal,51)

Totarol¶

n. a natural preservative made from totara

[He] has been working for six years to develop and patent Totarol, a natural anti-bacterial and preservative made from totara wood. (Aug 5, 2004,Dominion Post,C1)

totarra¶

n. (See see totara)

tote¶

n. a shrub (=? toke)

SAUNDERS Fighting above Anzac Cove in late April 1915 would be similar to fighting today on the gorse and scrub-covered slopes around Wellington Harbour and the Hutt. It was very thick and stood about 5ft high and was of a laurel leaf type very likeTote' that is found in New Zealand.' It was such scrub that the Anzacs laid in their coffin trenches. (Apr 27, 1915,Diary) [NOTES: 1915 Apr 27 Saunders Diary in 1984 Pugsley Gallipoli 160]

n. (informal) totalisator [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

BRIDGES & DOWNS Is it fair to call the automatic tote a New Zealand invention? (2000,No 8 Wire: The Best of Kiwi Ingenuity,56)

McCALLUM This side-of-the-mouth coot says for me to touch the pants first, so I say, `O.K. Five beers please'. Ibid. 75 There is all sorts of plonk, and the little joker tells me to touch my kick [to shout] ... I think all the others have death adders in their pockets, 'cause not one of them touches his tweeds. (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,23)

(1952,Here & Now,2(4) : 3) [NOTES: Not found]

[WICKHAM] Confronted with a plebiscite the exit of the 'tote' would be a hurried one., (1897,Casual Ramblings,80)

That skinny little bloke standing next to me down by the tote said there was nothing in it. (Dec 21, 1914,Public Service Journal,17)

11/1/1 If it were not for the `tote' ... (Sep 2, 1905,NZ Truth)

What you've got to do is to keep up agin the tote and when I signal, bung in and get the div. quick,' a youth was explaining to hiscobber'. (Jan 10, 1916,Triad, The,43)

(1952,Here & Now,2/4/3)

the tote: each way (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

The tote, says Grant, accurately reflected the amount of discretionary spending money in the wider economy. (Aug 12, 2001,Sunday Star Times,C2)

tote betting¶

n.

Three `tote-betting' cases ... (Jan 1899,Evening Post,4)

... procuring the offence of `tote-betting'. (May 1, 1899,Evening Post,6)

tote odds¶

n.

Prior to that date a very considerable amount of 'tote odds' betting had been done away from racecourses. (Jan 3, 1914,Great Days in NZ Mountaineering,3)

[Hdg] Laying "Tote" Odds... So said Mr. Poynton S.M.. when urged to increase by one day the sentence passed.. for having laid totalisator odds. (Feb 19, 1924,Otago Witness,66)

tote ticket¶

n.

He had in his possession a large number of tickets known as "tote tickets," in packets of 50 ready for distribution to agents. To the person holding the ticket of which the last three figures corresponded to the last three figures of the totalisator turnover at a certain race-meeting a prize was paid. (Aug 2, 1943,NZEF Times,III/110 : 3)

BELL Why, even your wives ... wouldn't sit out two [racing] events if they couldn't invest in a tote ticket or a half-crown sweep. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,118)

MILLER Fivers and singles in every conceivable pocket, tucked in with undecipherable notes, tote tickets, everything you could think of. (1967,Ink on My Fingers,106)

totera¶

n.

HOOKER Totera, Cunn. Fuchsia procumbens. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

tothersider¶

n. an Australian, an Australian immigrant (See also the other side,othersider)

In those early years the whaling vessels often brought doubtful characters from Australia, most of them ticket-of-leave men or ex-convicts, commonly called T'othersiders', orVan Demonians', etc. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,33)

T'Othersiders are still calling Maoriland legislation `experimental'. (Sep 9, 1905,NZ Truth,12/1/4)

toti¶

n.

DOOGUE & MORELAND BASS ... Other names: Polyprion moeone; bass-groper; moeone, toti (Maori). (1966,Sea Anglers' Guide,226)

totitoti¶

n. (See toetoe)

totoa¶

n.

HECTOR Phyllocladus alpinus, Hook. Totoa.[check = toatoa] --A small ornamental and densely-branched tree sometimes 2 feet in diameter. Bark used for dyeing and making tar. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,125)

totoara¶

n. the robin

HAAST Amongst the small inhabitants ... is the Totoara, the New Zealand robin, which is the first to welcome the explorer in the wilderness, and which remains steadily near the camp. (1861,Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson,140)

PETROICA ALBIFRONS, Gml. Totoara. Robin. (1870,TrNZI,2/60) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

BULLER MIRO LONGPIPES {MIRO AUSTRALIS}. (NORTH ISLAND ROBIN.) ... Native names. Pitoitoi, Toutou, Toutouwai, and Totoara. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,121,{1888 2nd edn 1/33} ed.)

BULLER MIRO ALBIFRONS. (SOUTH-ISLAND ROBIN.) ... Native names. Pitoitoi, Toutou, Toutouwai,and Totoara. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,122,1888 2nd edn 1/36 ed.)

  1. Petroeca albifrons, Gml. Robin, Toto-ara. - This delightful warbler is decreasing in numbers very rapidly ... (Nov 1884,NZ Journal of Science,287) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts) [spg toto-ara]]

totoeka¶

n. Streaked variety of greenstone.: spg also totoweka

JOSEPH The jade, the pounamu ... It's a beautiful stone ... Look,' he said, holding up a long hooked ear-drop of pearly translucence,that's tau tau and the stone is called inanga. And this, the pekapeka - they say the shape comes from the bat. This is for the ear, too - the mako, like a shark's tooth ... And these,' - he ran his fingers along a row of ... nephrite adzes - toki. See this one' - he held the heavy red-mottled adze in his palm -that's the red kind, totoweka, woodhen's blood. The deep green, that's kawakawa.' (1962,Pound of Saffron, A,113)

totokipio¶

n. the dabchick

BULLER PODICEPS RUFIPECTUS. (NEW-ZEALAND DABCHICK.) ... Native names.- Weweia, Totokipio {, Taihoropi (Hokianga), and Taratimoho (Waikato)}. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,350,1888 2nd edn 2/280 ed.)

BEATTIE Totokepio is the little diver' of the settler to distinguish it from thebig diver' (the crested grebe). The Canterbury compiler spells it as given, but in Southland the name is Totokipio, and if taken in sections To-toki-pio it is easy to pronounce. The kamana or crested grebe is not mentioned. (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,64) [NOTES: c1880 South Island Maori Lists `Wahi Mahika Kai' in 1945 Beattie Maori Place-names of Canterbury 64]

Podiceps rufipectus. - Totokipio, Dabchick. Both Islands. (1886,TrNZI,18/113) [NOTES: (Martin)]

PODICEPS RUFIPECTUS, Gray. Totokipio. Dab-chick, Little Grebe. (1870,TrNZI,2/73) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

HUTTON 105. PODICEPS RUFIPECTUS. Gray. Dab-chick. Totokipio. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,39)

totore¶

n. [Maori tobacco aka totori, torore, torori] (See torore)

The Maori tobacco, totori, as it is called, though it looks very well when not cured too green, is rank, hot, and pungent. (Jan 18, 1884,Timaru Herald,2)

totoreka¶

n.

LEE & KENDALL T|oto r|eka; A shell-fish so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,217)

totorore¶

n.

BULLER PUFFINUS TRISTIS {GRISEUS}. (SOMBRE SHEARWATER.) ...Native names.- Titi, Hakoakoa, and Totorore: `Mutton-bird' of the colonists. ... when hovering overhead at night [Titi] utter a frequent call-note, like tee-tee-tee, from which the Maori name is derived. [Check that some of this may be 1888 edn only.] (1873,Birds of New Zealand,317,{1888 2nd edn 2/232} ed.)

18/95 Observations on Puffinus assimilis (Gould), Totorore, their habits and Habitats. (1886,TrNZI) [NOTES: (Reischek)]

2 n.

2/209PRION TURTUR. (DOVE PETREL.) ... Native name{s}.- Whiroia and Totorore. (1888,Birds of New Zealand)

totorowhiti¶

n.

CHEESEMAN D[racophyllum] strictum, Hook.f. ... A much-branched shrub; ... Totorowhiti. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,421)

totorra¶

n. (See totara)

totorungu¶

n. a fresh-water fish

TAYLOR The Maori bearers ... had sufficient energy to fish, catching nearly a hundred totorunga, the only New Zealand fresh water fish with scales ... (Jan 19, 1841,Diary) [NOTES: [1841 Jan 19 R.Taylor Diary] in 1966 Mead Richard Taylor 24]

totowai¶

n. (See toutouwai)

totoweka¶

n. (See totoeka)

touch¶

2 n.

McGILL touch somebody's turn to buy a round of drinks; eg `Hey, Sid, isn't it your touch?' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,114)

touch noses¶

phr. to hongi

NICHOLAS Duaterra immediately recognised [the chief], and ... behaved to him with particular respect, touching noses with him, the usual mode of salutation in this part of the world, when any honour is to be paid, and which he did not do with the other chief. The latter he contemptuously described as an ittee ittee rungateeda, or a chief possessing very little power. (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/91)

ALEX McCRAE On taking leave of these boys I touched noses with them. (1820,Journal,12)

HOWARD We were received by them all sitting and after the salutation of touching noses, they eagerly enquired for what purpose we had come. (1940,Rakiura,345) [NOTES: 1823 June 1 Capt.J.R.Kent Mermaid log in 1940 Howard Rakiura 345]

An old man named Oree Pahbah ... saluted us, by touching noses (the New Zealand custom). (1827,Boultbee Journal) [NOTES: 1827 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 185]

An old man named OOree Pahbah came to us as we were walking up to the village, who saluted us by touching noses (the New Zealand custom). (1835,Boultbee Journal,68,1986 ed.) [NOTES: c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 68]

TAYLOR We had a very cordial reception, and as the chief was an old acquaintance of Mr W. they touched noses together, ... (Apr 6, 1839,Journal,2/87) [NOTES: [TS:ATB]]

DIEFFENBACH When they meet one another, or a European, after the first salutation, by touching noses, they do not remain standing upright, but squat down on their heels; ... (1843,Travels in NZ,2/109)

T.S.GRACE Where?' (his back being towards me), and immediately jumping up he hongied (touched noses [?Ed.]) with me, and saluted me asthe face of Te Heuheu.' (Aug 1877,Journal) [NOTES: 1877 Aug T.S.Grace Journal in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 264]

SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR Bill wondered uneasily how he would manage to keep working with Dumby [a Maori] ... But when Bill went back to the shed Dumby touched noses with him. (1981,Sunrise on Hikurangi,47)

Monkhouse ... however he at last ventured forward, they saluted by touching noses. (Oct 6, 1769,Journal) [NOTES: 1769 Oct 6 W.B. Monkhouse Journal in Cook Journals (1955) 1/567]

touch of the stepmother's breath¶

phr. a catchphrase said to indicate a nip in the air, a cold day [ca1964 Alistair Campbell Heard it in Wellington]

touch of the tarbrush¶

phr. (offensive) Maori ancestry [also dash or lick of the tarbrush]

FINLAYSON ` ... They're such nice people. Usually so quiet. ... You'd never dream there was a touch of the tar-brush.' (1949,Brown Man's Burden,80,1973 ed.)

DAVIN (1970,Not Here, Not Now,340)

O'SULLIVAN Suspect there might be a touch of the tarbrush there - just a smidgin, mind - ... (1985,Shuriken,27)

ROSIER-JONES Emma stiffens at the word hori', but surely he's not referring to . . .[sic]Emma has got Dally in in her y'know, Fred,' the manager says. `Coulda fooled me. Looks like the old tar-brush t'me.' (1985,Cast Two Shadows,129)

She told him that after Mr Beresford died ... his face turned black and [18] his stomach too. `Maybe it was the tar-brush coming out,' said Zip. (Mar 1986,Landfall,157/17)

Other [White Club] members feel perfectly free to talk to me about bongas',a touch of the tar brush', the jungle coming out in him' andbloody Maoris'. (Apr 3, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,8)

MEIKLE I can remember only a few Maori children at school and a few who were overtly half-castes' or who hada touch of the tarbrush' - labels commonly applied. (1988,Through the Looking Glass,128)

GUTHRIE .. their progeny, whose brown skins betrayed a touch of the tar-brush ... (1935,Little Country, The,390,1937 ed.)

MEIKLE in GIFKIN I can remember only a few Maori children at school and a few who were overtly 'half-castes' or who had 'a touch of the tarbrush' - labels commonly applied. (1988,Through the Looking Glass,128)

This dame, who was something more than a brunette, - in fact, her friends were wont to say that she had a touch of the tar-brush, - had long smarted under a sense of Mrs Chutney's pretensions to superiority, and she determined to assert herself. (Aug 17, 1883,Bruce Herald,5)

'So, Annie, where is it you're from in New Zealand. You've a lick of the tar brush like me eh?' (2007,Huia 7: Contemp. Maori Fiction,63)

There are varying evidences of "the dash of the tarbrush" in Wellington. One sees a female glorification of Mongol ancestry[,] a negress with most of the coarseness eliminated, or an idealised Maori with most of the ancient characteristics blown away by the Wellington winds and metropolitan smartness. (Jan 26, 1907,New Zealand Free Lance,12)

touch one's foblocker¶

phr. to reach for or spend one's money; pay out (cf. touch one's kick etc.) [ca1951 Wellington (Foblocker, ? a portmanteau coinage from fob @n small (money-) pocket in the waistband of trousers' (OED n2) and lockera secure cupboard (for valuables etc.))]

touch one's kick¶

phr. to pay money

McGILL touch your kick a modest loan, a `kick' being old word for sixpence; common request by Pedlar Thomas quoted NZ Oral History Unit Martinborough study. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,114)

NEWTON (Glossary) Touch the kick: To pay out money - put your hand in your pocket. (1971,Ten Thousand Dogs,169)

touch up¶

v. to remind, to hurry up
