Messrs Littlejohn and Sons are the parties you should make reference to, as I sub-lease from them that portion of the building, but not the clock so you had better touch them up about it. (Jun 20, 1908,NZ Truth,157/4/7)

toucher¶

n.

BEATTIE 10. Why,' said he to me,Old Toucher,/ You don't really meant to say,/ ... NOTES ... Verse 10: Toucher was a borrower, (1947,Pioneer Recollections,55,1956 ed.)

touchie¶

n. (informal) a touch judge

Make friends with the touchies. ... And the touchies will love being on telly so much. (Nov 25, 2005,NZ Herald,D11)

touchstone¶

n.

TOUCHSTONE.- A black silicious stone used for testing the quality of gold. (1868,Thames Miner's Guide, The,56)

tough¶

adj. of wool

BOWEN Early in the season, especially if sheep have had hard treatment before shearing, some sheep become really `tough', and the wool seems glued to the skin. (1955,Wool Away!,47)

tough ask¶

phr. (informal) [esp. sport, used globally, esp. Austral.] (See big ask,hard ask)

She's a tough ask, selecting a national soccer team. (Jan 29, 2006,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),B4)

tough bickies/tough bikkies¶

phr. in sense of `tough luck (on)'; a variant or euphemism of tough titty/ies [-] (See cf. stiff bickies)

The Budget used to be a time for mixed sweets - presents for some, tough bikkies for others. (Jul 25, 1983,National Business Review,6)

...the staff have evolved a sensible self-protective psychology; they simply don't care. If individuals are treated unfairly, tough biccies. (Nov 30, 2002,Dominion Post,B5)

ELDRED-GRIGG Tough biccies on me, I suppose, she said. (1977,Of Ivory Accents,42)

Mr Browlee said it was tough bickies, he had been given the floor and was therefore entiltled to be on his feet, and Dr Cullen wasn't. (Apr 7, 2005,Dominion Post,A2)

tough cheese¶

phr. a var. of British slang hard cheese, ?with tough titty, hard luck.

tough cheese: hard lines (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

tough rag¶

phr.

Tartan must be a `tough rag' after eighteen months' spell, including stud duty and dry-docking for repairs owing to an argument with a station fence, to account for the Randwick Plate in such a decisive manner. (Nov 2, 1907,NZ Truth,124/2/6)

tough spin¶

phr.

SARGESON tough: difficult, demanding: a tough spin, the going was tough, tough to work for. (1964,Collected Stories,304)

toughie¶

2 n. a difficult sheep

I have seen a real `toughy' go from No.1 pen right down the catching pens to the bottom, as shearers threw it over the rails when no one was looking. (1955,Wool Away!,48)

toughie-sticker¶

n. a false tattoo

He's covered in tattoos and has an intimidating look about him, but he has the ruggedness to back it up. They're not just toughie-stickers, the joker has the minerals. (Jul 15, 2005,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,16)

toumatou¶

n.

Discaria Toumatou Toumatou (1870,TrNZI,2/122) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

FEATON DISCARIA TOUMATOU (Raoul.) ... The TOUMATOU'.- ... The plant is very generally known throughout the Colony asThe Wild Irishman'. In the Middle Island, more particularly towards Otago, it is called `Native Thorn'. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,93) [NOTES: ?an error on the Featons' part]

n.

HOOKER Discaria australis, Hook. ... Nat. name, `Toumatou', Raoul. (1853,Flora NZ,47)

toumatu gowrie¶

n. tumatakuru, matagouri

These include euphorbia glauca, pseudopanax ferox (toothed lancewood), toumatu (matagouri), muehlenbackia astonii, pimelia aridula (sand daphne) and coprosma. (Jul 6, 2000,Evening Post,15)

The so-called roads were generally bridle tracks through the ordinary tussock and toumatu gowrie. (Nov 2, 1920,Otago Witness,54)

I used to have to fix tumatu kuru scrub over the thatch of my.. small oat stacks to keep the pukeko from stripping them. (Nov 2, 1920,Otago Witness,54)

tourist¶

1 n. (Rural) a person who has opinions but shows ignorance about farming.

MAF is encouraging farmers to watch their image after complaints from townies and tourists over cattle being held in muddy sacrifice paddocks. (Aug 1, 1996,NZ Farmer,4)

A person who knows nothing about farming: a tourist. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

Tourist Bureau¶

n. the Government Tourist Bureau

SLATTER So I went straight to the Tourist Bureau and was lucky enough to get a berth. [omit as encyclopedic: certainly much earlier] (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,16)

touristified¶

adj.

Cr Allen says passengers could be carried in converted stock carriages like those that took lambs to the slaughter at the old Gear meatworks. An alternative would be "touristified" refrigerated trucks like those that carried carcasses to the wharves. (Mar 9, 2001,Evening Post,18)

Tourists¶

n. usu. with def art., a nickname for the first contingent, NZEF (cf. WAR BABIES)

M & N ROSS The men from the Antipodes have brought with them a humour and a slang of their own. Their definition of the various batches of volunteers that have come out to fight is worth quoting. The first contingent became known as The Tourists'. They were out to see a bit of the world. Incidentally they would do any fighting that came along. And they did it. Then cameThe Dinkums' - the true fighting men as they called themselves. (1916,Light and Shade)

Tournament¶

n. an inter-universities' sports tournament

(1912,Auckland Capping Book,14) [NOTES: [see cit WOODEN SPOON]]

There was a Tournament held in a Southern town:/ We sent our annual team to as usual to win renown,/ They kissed their mothers .../ And left by the Main Trunk Train. (Jun 6, 1912,Auckland Univ. Coll.Students Assn Souv. Progr.,46)

SEDDON The newcomer was Te Rangitiroa [sic], Dr.Peter Buck, my friend of University Tournament days; ... (1968,Seddons, The,188)

tout suiter¶

n. (WW1 ?nonce)

MILLER These guns are known to be long range naval guns of high velocity. The boys call the shells `tout suiters' because they come with such a rush. (Nov 27, 1917,Camps, Tramps and Trenches,184)

toutou¶

n.

BULLER MIRO LONGPIPES {MIRO AUSTRALIS}. (NORTH ISLAND ROBIN.) ... Native names. Pitoitoi, Toutou, Toutouwai, and Totoara. Ibid. 122 {1888 2nd edn 1/36} MIRO ALBIFRONS. (SOUTH-ISLAND ROBIN.) ... Native names. Pitoitoi, Toutou, Toutouwai,and Totoara. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,121,{1888 2nd edn 1/33} ed.)

HAY The Toutou (Miro longipes) is a small grey and white bird, which some people have said is called the New Zealand robin. It is to be seen in the bush now and then, and seems tame, but we prefer to call another species our robin. (1882,Brighter Britain,2/224)

toutouwai¶

n. the NZ robin [ORIGIN: Maori, aka totowai] (See bush robin)

Above and to every side are riroriro (grey warbler), korimako (bellbird), tui, titipounamu (rifleman), miromiro (tomtit), kakariki (red-crowned parakeet), toutouwai (New Zealand robin) and even a pair of exquisite hihi, or stitchbird. (Jan 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 55/16)

LEE & KENDALL T|ou t|ou wai; A bird so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,17)

Toutouwai - This bird is nearly the size of the sparrow; ... its feathers are dark, tinged whit white about the breast and tail, ... (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),56)

POLACK The toutouwai is also of the swallow species. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/301)

WILLIAMS The Toutouwai is a smaller slate coloured bird, has a shrill whistling note and is particularly fond of gazing (if I may so express it) at strangers, and if encouraged by a whistle will follow the person for some distance. [Glossary 120 North Island Robin ...] (1844,NZ Journal,113,1956 ed.)

Petroica longipes. Totowai. Robin. Common. (1869,TrNZI,1/160) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

The Popokatea (Mohoua albicilla) is represented by another species (M. ochrocephala) differing in colour but so closely allied to it that the natives apply the same name to both; the Toutouwai (Petroica longipes) ... is represented by (Petroica albifrons) ... (1869,TrNZI,1/111/5)

The Popokatea (Mohoua albicilla) is represented by another species (M. ochrocephala) differing in colour but so closely allied to it that the natives apply the same name to both; the Toutouwai (Petroica longipes) ... is represented by (Petroica albifrons) ... (1869,TrNZI,1/111/5) [NOTES: (Buller Ornithology)]

HUTTON 31. PETROICA ALBIFRONS. Gml. Wood Robin. Totowai. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,12)

BULLER This bird is the subject of an article - the Pitoitoi or Toutouwai of the natives and the `Robin' of ther colonists. Ibid. 121 MIRO LONGPIPES {MIRO AUSTRALIS}. (NORTH ISLAND ROBIN.) ... Native names. Pitoitoi, Toutou, Toutouwai, and Totoara. Ibid. 122 MIRO ALBIFRONS. (SOUTH-ISLAND ROBIN.) ... Native names. Pitoitoi, Toutou, Toutouwai,and Totoara. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,120,1888 2nd edn 1/33, 34, 36 ed.)

I noticed the following:- Pigeon, tui, korimako, kaka, ruru, piwakawaka, toutouwai, kingfisher, duck and teal in the lakes, and pukeko in the swamp, and various sea birds. (1884,TrNZI,17/419) [NOTES: (Gold-Smith)]

toutouwai, a bird (Miro longipes), the North Island form; the South Island form (Miro australis) bears the same name, the two forms differing only in the coloration of the breast and abdomen, which are white in the former, and in the latter the abdomen yellowish-white tinged with lemon-yellow on the breast. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

toutouwai: New Zealand Robin. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

FALLA et al. TOMTIT Petroica australis Maori name: Toutouwai. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,202)

258.a. Petroica australis longipes (Lesson, 1828) North Island Robin (Toutouwai) Ibid. 68 258.b. Petroica australis australis (Sparrman, 1788) South Island Robin (Toutouwai) (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,68,1980 ed.)

Robin Petroica australis (SPARRMAN, 1788) ... North Island Robin P.a. longpipes (LESSON, 1828). South Island Robin P.a. australis (SPARRMAN, 1788). Stewart Island Robin P.a. rakiura FLEMING, 1950. OTHER NAMES: Bush robin, toutouwai. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,282)

This morning the robin or totowai (Jan 1986,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: 1986 January Birdcall over National Radio [announcer]]

R ICHARDS Miro Traversi ... Found now only on Little Mangere Island ... Black Wood Robin. TOU-TOU-WAI, MIRO. (1952,Chatham Islands,71)

A fine specimen of the blue-wattled crow (kokako), hopping from bough to bough, was observed at close quarters for five minutes, and two other rarely seen birds, the North Island robin (toutouwai, male and female), and the saddleback (tieke) were also seen. (Jan 15, 1932,Evening Post,5)

[caption] Left: North Island robin, toutouwai Petroica australis longipes with food in beak. (Jul 2009,Open Space,32)

tow truck¶

n. a truck designed to tow broken-down or damaged or illegally-parked vehicles [Jim writes: BritE = breakdown van. Not recorded in DNZE but cf towie - "tow-truck driver or operator". Not in NSOD. Collins tags it as US and Canadian. Tow truck is standard NZE.]

tow truckie¶

n. [also towie]

The tow truckies say it's common for car owners to storm into the yard exploding with unrepeatable criticism of the qualities of the towies in particular, and life, the universe and everything in general. (Apr 7, 1983,Dominion,7)

towai¶

n. a tall spreading forest tree of the North Island, related to the kamahi. [Maori towai[o-macron]]. also called tawhero; Weinmannia racemosa, kamahi (in the n. North Island W. sylvicola, tawhero) [TOWAI( or TAWHERO) W. silvicola up to 15m. n.NI to 38 lat.; W. racemosa kamahi takes over from about 37 lat. southwards (from Manukau south) and is the `red birch' of Westland]

Tó.wa-i (t&omacr.́.wa.&ibreve. or t&omacr.́.-w&imacr.), n. [Maori.] (Bot.) A New Zealand saxifragaceous tree (Weinmannia racemosa); - called also birch. [Local, N. Z.] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

NICHOLAS ... towha,another species of pine, not so large as the totara, small, narrow leaf, smooth bark, berry.[check that this is towai] Ibid. Nicholas NZ 2/245 The trees which the natives chiefly make subservient to their purposes, are [besides the pines cowrie, totarra, towha and zarida mentioned above] ... the henow, from which they extract a black dye, the towha, a tree resembling the sycamore, the river river, the grain of whose wood is similar to that of the beech, a species of cork-tree, called by these people vow, a large tree named eckoha, and another named kycata, a tall and beautiful tree, ... Ibid. 1/330 The towha, another species of pine, though not so large as the totarra, grew here [Waimate, Northland] at the same time to a considerable size, and the forest abounded with it. This tree has likewise a small and narrow leaf, but its bark is thin and quite smooth; it bears a berry which is eaten by the natives. (1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/329)

LEE & KENDALL T|owai; A shrub so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,217)

McDONNELL A great variety of hard-wood grows at New Zealand, admirably adapted for the timbering of any sized ships; among them is the boride[e-acute], rattar[as-acute], taraide[ase-acute], mai[a-acute], totara[a1-acute], koi katoa[a2-acute], toa[a-acute] toa[a-acute], tani raha[as-acute], to wai[a-acute], reiva[a-acute] reiva[a-acute], tana[as-acute], and many others. (1835,Extracts From a Journal,19,1979 ed.)

YATE Towai - a tree of the Podocarpus species, with a dark-brown bark, and a leaf similar to, and about the size of, the moss-rose. (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),46)

POLACK Many other trees abounded in Pamaki [a's-acute], such as the kaikatea [a2-acute], towai, rewa-rewa, totara [a's-acute], puriri, rata [a's-acute], kahika [a2-acute], tipow, tanikaha [a2-acute], rimu, and various kinds of akkas, all of which will be found described in the Appendix (Note 7). Ibid. 2/396 The Towai, (a podocarpus,) is but a small tree compared with those preceding. Its wood ... has a handsome deep red colour when polished. It grows to the heighth [sic] of twenty-five feet, and then is richly furnished with virent leaves. The wood is heavy and but little used hitherto. (1838,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/109)

WILLIAMS The towai is not remarkable for a tree, makes fair fencing. [Glossary 120 ... Weinmannia sylvicolaM]. (1844,NZ Journal,106,1956 ed.)

The bark of the Towai, Weinmannia silvicola, does not appear to have been collected for tanning purposes ... (1869,TrNZI,1/145) [NOTES: (T. Kirk)]

The Towai, and Tawhero, (Weinmannia sylvicola, and W. racemosa,) are small trees ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/46) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

BAINES ... on either side [of the harbour] much of the land was covered with a growth of manuka (tea-tree), rewa-rewa, towai, karaka, and other smaller kinds of timber ... (1874,Edward Crewe,144)

KIRK The towai (W. silvicola), a closely allied tree, which is abundant in the north, ... would probably prove more durable [than tawhero]. (1875,Durability NZ Timbers,20)

FEATON WEINMANNIA SILVICOLA (Banks & Sol.) ... The `TOWAI'.- ... The wood is similar in quality to its ally W. racemosa, but is denser, and of finer grain; ... [136] This tree is sometimes called Tawhero, or Kamai, and is not unusually confounded with W. racemosa, the Tawhero or Kamai proper. In the same manner the tawhero is confused with this species by the uninitiated. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,135)

DAWSON In towai (Weinmannia silvicola) the trend is from one to five pairs of leaflets ... (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,38)

It prefers stream banks and forest clearings and can often be found rubbing shoulders with a close relative called towai (Weinmannia silvicola) in a region south from Kaitaia to Whangarei. (Oct 1, 2005,Dominion Post,E13)

"The towai, or kamahi (Weinmannia racemosa), furnishes a splendid bark that is valuable for tanning cordage, fishing nets, &c., and when mixed with equal proportions of rimu (red pine) bark it is also valuable for tanning leather, and will ultimately be a great source of wealth to the colony ..." (Jul 30, 1896,Otago Witness,5)

The bark used for tanning.. is not the bark of tawa.. but it is the bark of the towai - a tree that grows to the height of about twenty feet, and is somewhat scarce in most of the timbered districts. (Feb 24, 1883,Auckland Weekly News,22)

n. (See toetoe)

2 n.

DIEFFENBACH From the high tawai-trees [[fn] Leiospermum racemosum.] a graceful moss hung down in long festoons. Ibid. 2/389 Towai - a timber tree (1843,Travels in NZ,1/146)

HOOKER Towai, Col[enso]. Weinmannia racemosa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Towai, or Karmai (Weinmannia racemosa). A beautiful large tree, especially when in flower. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/37) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Towai. Weinmannia racemosa, Forst. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/41) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

HECTOR Weinmannia racemosa, Forst. Towhai, Kamahi.--A large tree; trunk 2-4 feet in diameter, and 50 feet high. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,132)

MORRIS Maori name for New Zealand tree, Weinmannia racemosa, Forst., N.O. Saxifrageae. i.q. Kamahi in south of South Island, and Tawhero in North Island (Wellington). (1898,Austral English,476)

CHEESEMAN W[einmannia] racemosa, Linn. ... Towai; Kamahi. Very closely allied to W. Sylvicola [Tawhero]. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,139)

(Dec 1958,NZ Timber Journal,73/2)

McLINTOCK Towai .. .. towai .. .. Weinmannia (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

towai n. New Zealand tree, the bark of which is used for tanning. Called also tawhero and kamahi [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

towai ... n. N.Z. tree, the bark of which is used for tanning. Called also tawhero and kamahi [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

towai n. large NZ timber tree related to kamahi. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,814) [NOTES: [.nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

3 n. Paratrophis milk tree

HOOKER The Milk-tree' of the Nelson and Wellington colonists is described by Mr. Bidwill and Dr. Sinclair as producing a milk which is used with tea, and is equally suitable for the purpose with that of the cow; it is also drunk as it flows from the tree, and is good and sweet, but has a vegetable after-taste. - A large tree, 60 feet high, ... often extremely like <i>Carpodetus Serratus.</i> ... Nat. nameTowai', Raoul. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 224)

HOOKER Towai, Raoul. Epicarpurus microphylla. [=Paratrophis] (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Epicarpurus microphyllus Towai (1870,TrNZI,2/122) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

4 n. [1890 cit. S.I. confusion with Westland and Christchurch name of red birch for kamahi wood and ornamental foliage]

WAKEFIELD ... towai ... It is used for ship building and is called by Englishmen `black birch'. [check towai, ??tawhai] (1845,Adventure in NZ,2/95)

WILSON [Canterbury] [Near Castle Hill] there is but one patch of forest, the dull, sad green of the Towai (black birch). [fn] Weinmannia racemosa. (1894,In the Land of the Tui,78 ed.) [NOTES: 1890 Feb 28 in 1894 Wilson Land of the Tui 78]

4 n.

HOOKER Towai, Hector. Cordyline indivisa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

4 n. [cf 43 Towa berries; description of wood fits W. racemosa and not TAWA; but does kamahi have oil-bearing berries]

HEAPHY The red pines are the Totara, Towa, Mahi, and Rata, all of which are close-grained, and moderately hard. They are used principally for interior work, in house-building, and for furniture-making. They are all of a red colour, and when oiled and polished are very ornamental. ... All these red firs make good spars for ships, and are frequently used by vessels visiting the settlements. The Towa spars are considered the best for this purpose. The fore-yard of the Tory, a 400 ton ship, was made from a green towa spar obtained in Queen Charlotte's Sound, which stood many severe tests without sustaining any injury. ... The only fault of this wood is its weight, but in that respect it is less objectionable than the teak which is used for the masts of all Indian-built vessels. [43] ... The Towa and the Kraka berries also yield an useful oil, but not in such quantity as that first mentioned. (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),42)

4 n.

POLACK They had simply decorated their hair ... with the pretty yellow flower of the towai, which hung in heavy clusters from that tree on the banks of the stream ... From their ears were appended the dried feathered skin of the towakawaka-bird [sic : a's-acute; ?error for tiwakawaka], whose body, when living, is scarcely larger than a walnut. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/113)

POLACK The ladies had decorated their glossy ringlets with oil, and inserted the pretty flowers of the kaikatoa[a2-acute] and towai in their beautiful tresses, which hung down on their backs in profusion. (1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/82)

4 n.

towel up¶

v. [ca1941 St Patrick's College, Silverstream [mistaken meaning at the time] I got towelled up proper in the boxing finals.]

towelling¶

n. (informal) a beating

I reckon we could give the Aussies a bloody good towelling - it's on the cards judging by the World Cup form shown so far. (Nov 14, 2003,Dominion Post Sport & RaceForm,8)

towelling hat¶

n.

Dad would put on an orange towelling hat. When he wore it, we knew that summer had really begun. (Jan 3, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),19)

towha¶

n. (See towai)

towie¶

n.

Not only do towies witness death and mayhem; many speak of having to watch their own backs and are aware of other tow truck drivers who have been badly injured or killed... The era of the cowboy towie - cruising the roads in hotted up V8s, chasing and pouncing on a crash to hook, and fighting off other towies - has passed. (Feb 6, 1999,Evening Post,12)

If the general confusion worsens, and anarchy prevails, he said that towies would simply `sit back and let Rafferty's Rules take over'. (Feb 28, 1983,Salient,3)

The tow truckies say it's common for car owners to storm into the yard exploding with unrepeatable criticism of the qualities of the towies in particular, and life, the universe and everything in general. (Apr 7, 1983,Dominion,7)

There is a great deal of yahooing and complaining; obscenities fall as thickly as the rain and echo from truck to truck as the towies climb into their cabs and roar away. (May 19, 1984,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

The towies cart away the pieces of the cars and the ambulances the pieces of the people. (Sep 1986,Metro,70)

Lastly, a huge thank you to police and St John Ambulance, our 'towie' and the wonderful service at Whakatane Hospital. (Oct 5, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,2)

Bruce Hopkins who, as the bewildered policeman in last year's I'll Make You Happy succeeded in making gormlessnesss endearing, does it again with Rhys the towie. (Mar 25, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),40)

The problem is not the towies, it's the motorists who keep them in a job. (Mar 6, 2002,Evening Post,10)

[Hdg] SH1: A towie's perspective. (Aug 2, 2000,Evening Post,4)

Towies work day and night in all weathers, cleaning up after motorway accidents, towing illegal parkers, pulling cars out of ditches and rivers, and patrolling the clearways to keep rush hour traffic flowing. (Sep 18, 2000,Evening Post,TV Week : 5)

There is also a cop.., doctors.., a towie.. and a neighbourhood curmudgeon. (Jul 21, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

Just occasionally someone representing an unpopular cause or group, like.. the chairman of the towies federation will spend an hour putting their case and answering to the public directly. (Feb 1993,Metro,62)

The towies say they are the ones being penalised, (Jan 17, 2000,Taranaki Daily News,1)

Money hungry towies .. I called their number and I was told they had my car and that it would cost me $180 to retrieve it! (Aug 8, 2007,Capital Times,4)

towitowi¶

n. toetoe [sometimes towai, towai grass] (See toetoe)

n. toetoe [towi towi, toti toti, towai, towai grass]

HEAPHY (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),92) [NOTES: [towai grass: see TOE GRASS]]

Islands now began to appear, generally covered with flax and towi towi, a species of reed with long drooping leaves. (v) ?erroneous forms, misprints, mistransliterations (1847,Oamaru Mail)

Islands now began to appear, generally covered with flax and towi towi, a species of reed with long drooping leaves. (v) ?erroneous forms, misprints, mistransliterations (1959,Early Travellers,128) [NOTES: 1847 Johnson Notes for Journal in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 128]

MOORE You can get the longest stalk of Toti Toti [sic] and strip the feathers off. (1937,Reminiscences)

We now ascended the vale, whose bed was well-furnished with several varieties of grass, and clumps of towi-towi, and would form a good cattle-run. (Nov 13, 1847,New Zealander, The,3)

towmotor¶

n.

SLATTER ... yellow fork-lift trucks, towmotors they call them, with sides striated from squeezing up the narrow alleys, racing about ... pushing and lifting and squeezing the cargo into position and puffing hot fumes from their exhausts. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,22)

town¶

n. (obsolete) a Maori village

HOVELL ``At 10 a.m. sent a party of men on shore to destroy the town and the canoes. At noon the people returned with two pigs, having destroyed the principal part of the town and canoes with fire. At 2 p.m. the people went on shore again and set fire to the remainder part of the town, canoes, huts, and all their food, and returned with one large pig and two small ones. (Aug 31, 1815,Personal Communication) [NOTES: 1815 Aug 31 Captain Hovell quoted in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 89]

MARSDEN The next day (24th) we landed the horses and cattle, and fixed upon a place for the present residence of the settlers, and began to clear away the rubbish and prepare for erecting the houses for their reception on a piece of ground adjoining to the native town pitched upon by Duaterra and the chiefs of the place. (1814,Letters & Journals of Samuel Marsden,91,1932 ed.)

town acre¶

n. an allotment of land in a prospective town to a New Zealand Company settler. [AND 1838]; the acre-section of town land allocated by the NZ Company for every twenty acres of uncleared `suburban' land purchased [see also town section] (See cf. country acre)

Each "land purchaser" was entitled to a "town" acre, a 50-acre section of "suburban" land, and a 150-acre "rural" section. (1940,Tales of Pioneer Women,143) [NOTES: Pagination from 1988 edition]

`These doubly-selected lands will be divided into 1100 sections, each section comprising one town-acre, and 100 country-acres. 110 sections will be reserved by the Company, ... (1852,GBPP,1852, xxv (570) /19) [NOTES: 1839 June 1 Terms of Sale of the New Zealand Land Company; Great Britain, Parliamentary Papers, 1852, xxxv. 570, p.18 in 1971 Speeches and Documents. 19]

1/154 (et pass.) Extremely well fitted for a system of jobbing in town acres. (1840,NZ Journal)

The 27th had been the day appointed for the holders of land [in Wellington] under the Company to choose their Town Acres and during the previous week the Plan had been exhibited, ... (Jul 27, 1840,Journal of Ensign Best,231,1966 ed.)

We are going to select the town acres. (1840,Letter,52) [NOTES: 1840 Revans to Chapman (MS) 52]

I will buy for you a town acre. (1841,NZ Journal,2/32/94)

WOOD ... we were accompanied by two gentlemen ... who had not hitherto seen some town acres belonging to absentees, for which they were agents. (1843,Twelve Months in Wellington,10)

PO ... we find [the New Zealand Company] planting rival settlements one after the other ..., without reference to the wants or wishes of the colonists, but with the goood commercial purpose of getting the highest possible price for the land, by the sale of those delusive baits, `town-acres'. (1848,Sketches in NZ,198,1849 ed.)

POWER ... we find [the New Zealand Company] planting rival settlements one after the other ..., without reference to the wants or wishes of the colonists, but with the goood commercial purpose of getting the highest possible price for the land, by the sale of those delusive baits, `town-acres'. (1848,Sketches in NZ,198,1849 ed.)

WAKEFIELD cf Town-section [In Wellington] ... transfers [have] been effected ..., in quantities varying from ten or twelve sections to the smallest subdivision of a valuable town acre. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,175)

DILLON Of this, one town acre [in Nelson] has a house and garden rented by Major Richmond ... (Dec 29, 1850,Dillon Letters,141,1954 ed.)

(Canterbury) The immediate choosing of the town acre sections has been a most important and useful measure.' Section has remained the normal New Zealand word for a city building plot and tutu, usually pronounced and sometimes spelttoot', is a poisonous shrub. (Jan 11, 1851,Lyttelton Times) [NOTES: 1851 Jan 11 Lyttelton Times in 1966 Turner 165]

SEWELL He is jealous of Clifford and the Squatters - is addicted to Landscrip, Town Acres and Rural Sections, and therefore I can see evidently has a leaning in favor [sic] of cheap land. ... (1853,Journal,1/188,1980 ed.)

NORRIS Because most of his men [of the Number 1 Company of the Fourth Waikato Militia Regiment] received their town acre grants in what is now the suburb of Whitiora, that locality was once called Number One . (1964,Settlers in Depression,6)

Messrs. J. H. Bethune & Co., land and estate agents, report that, acting in conjunction with Mr. Thomas Ward, they have negotiated the sale by private contract of the splendid freehold property, containing two acres, one rood, one perch (town acre No. 449, and parts of town acres Nos. 448 and 447) owned by the late Captain Chas. Sharp. (Apr 16, 1898,Evening Post,5)

AUCTION SALE. 3 TOWN ACRES. (Jan 30, 1924,Evening Post,12)

TARANAKI STREET, WELLINGTON. Town Acres 243 and 244. (Jun 25, 1935,Evening Post,16)

Each order represented one town acre and a hundred acres of country lands which they were to select on arrival, and this selection became the first important business of the new colony. (Jan 5, 1940,Evening Post,9)

Francis Joseph Wardell's land grants of a Town Acre in Cambridge and 200 acres of swamp in Whangamarino were useless as, when the war ended, there was a recession with no money or jobs. (2009,NZ Memories,77/15)

With respect to the town acres, however, it seems indispensable that the whole should be surveyed and mapped before any choice is allowed, and that the allotment of the whole should place at one time. (Aug 21, 1839,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

There is a conveniently arranged Six-roomed Dwelling House on Town Acre No. 498, in excellent state of repair, with Outhouses, Garden, &c, &c. (Apr 13, 1867,Evening Post,3)

ELIGIBLE CORNER BUILDING SITE, having a frontage to Adelaide-road of 33ft 8in, and a frontage to Alfred-street of 90ft 10in, containing an area of 11.20 perches, being part Town Acre No. 741. (Mar 5, 1906,Evening Post,10)

The following is a complete list of the properties disposed of by Messrs. J. H. Bethune and Co., at their sale yesterday .. lot 3, three town acres, Nos. 360, 361, and 362, Austin-street, GBP2400, Mr. J. M. Taylor ... (Jun 6, 1878,Evening Post,2)

FREEHOLD TOWN ACRE No. 29 on the plan of the City, and fronting EPUNI-STREET, Polhill's Gully. (Sep 17, 1883,Evening Post,3)

town acre man¶

1 n. (Rural) a person who owned land in town under the town acre system and did not farm his allotted rural land seriously.

HASTIE One particular settler owned a lot of horses and had very little land to support them. He called this gentleman one of the 'loafing society' and the 'town acre man'. (1864,BLANK ENTRY,5) [NOTES: in Hastie (1986) Hastie History]

town allotment¶

n.

On the expiration of three years ..., each settler ... will be entitled to a Crown Grant of the town allotment, and farm section allotted to him, .. (1864,NZ Gazette) [NOTES: c1863-64 NZ Gazette in 1879 Featon Waikato War 52 (15).]

PIAKO SECTIONS, TOWN ALLOTMENTS. (May 27, 1914,Thames Star,4)

Call and inspect our list of other farms. Houses and town allotments. (Mar 15, 1920,Ohinemuri Gazette,3)

Mr. G. will explain his views more fully in a subsequent advertisement; meantime he will be happy to receive offers either to lease or sell him a town allotment. (May 9, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2)

TO LET OR SELL, TWO TOWN ALLOTMENTS, situated in Princes Street, and one ALLOTMENT on the Road leading to the Half-Way Bush. (Oct 18, 1851,Otago Witness,1)

FOR SALE, WAITARA, 6 TOWN ALLOTMENTS, Nos. 1 to 6, Block 8, on the east of the river, opposite the anchorage. (Mar 8, 1871,Taranaki Herald,1)

In the Town of New Plymouth, containing together 4 acres and 1 rood (more or less) being Town Allotment marked N, and Town Allotments Nos. 840, 1329, 1330, 1331, 1332, 1333, 1334, 1335, with Dwelling-house and Outbuildings thereon. (Mar 17, 1881,Taranaki Herald,3)

town belt¶

n. OED : N.Z., a belt of public land reserved chiefly for recreational purposes in or round a town; a belt of reserve land around or in a town or city, vested in the town authority and reserved for public, scenic or recreational purposes; also THE BELT

This is a victory for conservation and the Friends of the Town Belt, who have lobbied hard to protect the town belt. (Dec 7, 2000,City Voice,12)

BATHGATE This town-belt, as it is called, is pretty much in a state of nature. (1874,Colonial Experiences,23)

PYKE Does she live near the Town Belt?'Yes.' `Why, then, ... My people live within cooee - quite near to her.' (1881,White Hood and Blue Cap,59)

Our common Tutu (Coriaria ruscifolia) is familiar to everyone who rambles on our Town Belt. (Mar 1881,NZ Journal of Science,371)

DAVIDSON The native bush which covers a large portion of the [Dunedin] `town belt' is in itself a heritage to be highly prized, ... (1889,Stories of NZ Life,61)

BATHGATE ... the Town Belt (1890,Picturesque Dunedin,16)

The whole is admirably set off by Hagley Park (400 acres in extent), the Domain and Botanical Gardens (79 acres), Lancaster Park, the Town Belts, and other public and private gardens and plantations. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,55)

COCKAYNE The Town Belt of Dunedin consists of a remnant of such a forest; ... (1910,NZ Plants,47)

HYDE The best houses [in Dunedin] stood up on the hills, set back in the dark native green of the Town Belt; ... (1938,Nor the Years Condemn,40)

VOM HAAST On May 13 [1867], the City Council received a report from a committee on planting, recommending planting the Belts in the following manner. A footpath, 10 ft. wide on each side of the Belt, two roadways running parallel to the footpaths, each half a chain in width, leaving 46 ft. clear in the middle of the Belt, to be planted with trees, so as to allow a 10 ft. grass-walk down the centre of each block between the intersecting streets. Each block was to be planted with one variety of tree. (1948,Julius Von Haast,490)

DAVIN Ellen's house was up on Maori Hill and every night I took her out I used to see her safely home, ... and come down through the Town Belt ... (1959,No Remittance,84)

BAXTER Lying awake on a bench in the town belt,/ Alone,. . . (1979,Collected Poems,256) [NOTES: (1961-62)]

ARMFELT The [Dunedin] house was large ..., and the situation - just above the Town Belt - beautiful. (1971,Catching Up,243)

... he was off this high summer evening along the road that led to the Town Belt - that was to say a back-to-nature acre or so with a name that derived from many decades previously, when the city fathers as they used to be called had wisely decided that not every square foot of the territory they administered should be privately owned, either to be lived on or for commercial purposes. (1987,Islands,7/92) [NOTES: 1974 Sargeson (Brixton) in Islands 7/92]

SARGESON ... he was off this high summer evening along the road that led to the Town belt. (1976,Sunset Village,30)

WAKEFIELD [Karori] district begins immediately outside the boundary of the Town-belt, ... (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,97)

We afterwards went on to the Town Belt and Riccarton. (Jan 3, 1851,Journal of Edward Ward,98,1951 ed.)

SEWELL What, cut up the Town Belt which we had engaged and were legally bound to keep open? (1853,Journal,1/256,1980 ed.)

Extension to house Cook Island nest [heading] A hall is to be extended on Wellington's town belt land so a Cook Islands language nest can be established. (Oct 7, 1988,Dominion,6)

Took a house for the Pattissons. South town belt. ... 9th. Returned to Ch.Ch. cf OEDS Green Belt [Belt sup. n1 5a] An officially designated belt of open coutryside in which all development is severely restricted, usually enclosing a built-up area and designed to check its further growth. 1932-1961 (Sep 8, 1877,Chudleigh Diary,262,1950 ed.)

[Hdg] Town belt saved by house. Part of Wellington's town belt - where some Wellington Hospital buildings stand on reserve land - are now safe, following a decision of parliament this week... "This ia a victory for conservation and the Friends of the Town Belt, who have lobbied hard to protect the town belt,"... (Dec 7, 2000,City Voice,12)

The Town Belt was originally 1500 acres in extent. It is now only about 1100 acres (430 hectares). But this is land that was supposed to be "reserved for the enjoyment of the public and not to be built upon"... A need arose, an itch had to be scratched, and the Town Belt was the best/cheapest/least politically-damaging option available. (Jan 7, 2001,Capital Times,2)

The Town Belt is so fundamental to our vision of Wellington and our feelings for it that there is a tendency for us to take it for granted. (Jan 24, 2001,Capital Times,2)

Two blocks on the North town belt fenced with wire, trenched, and planted; and the whole of the plantations on the East and North town belts kept in order. (Dec 14, 1869,Star, The,2)

A recommendation by the reserves committee that a request that a proposed children's play area on the Town Belt at Owen Street be leased for the formation of bowling greens be not approved, but that the applicants be offered a nearby area at present used by garden plot holders, was referred back to the committee by the City Council last night at the request of the chairman of the committee, Councillor R. L. Macalister. (Jun 14, 1945,Evening Post,9)

Most Wellingtonians would be surprised at the history of the city's Town Belt, but the mystery will be unravelled at an exhibition opening at the Museum of Wellington City and Sea tomorrow... The original Town Belt Deed of 1873, which transferred the Town Belt in trust to the people of Wellington from the Provincial Government and is still an active document, will be on display. (Jun 25, 2001,Evening Post,12)

"It is indeed desirable that the whole of the town inland should be separated from the country sections by a broad belt of land which you will declare that the Company intends to be public property on the condition that no buildings ever be built on it." New Zealand Company Secretary John Ward to Surveyor General William Mein Smith, August 1839. And so the idea of Wellington's fantastic Town Belt was born... The 425 ha Town Belt, including the beloved Botanic Garden - is indeed public property - and it's admniistered by the City Council on behalf of Wellingtonians. (Aug 2001,Absolutely Positively Wellington,1)

[The Crown] acquired 1,500 acres of the Wellington town belt as well as Somes and Ward Island. (Jun 2003,Wel-com (Wellington),13)

2 Allotments of Town Acre No. 776, adjoining Sellars' Dairy, commanding a run of the Town Belt. (May 12, 1843,New Zealand Colonist & Port Nicholson Advertiser,2)

A comprehensive view of Wallace Street, (Town Belt area), in the vicinity of which three women were attacked by a manaic [sic] during previous assaults. (May 2, 1929,NZ Truth,7)

[Hdg] 'Town Belt' land ours - Capital Coast Health. Capital Coast health has conceded that exclusive real estate it plans to sell in Kelburn was originally part of the Town Belt but says it is now the legal owner... He said the Government took ownership of the land when it assumed control of the New Zealand Company's assets, and the properties were not part of that finally vested to Wellington City Council as Town Belt in the 1870s. (May 2, 2001,Dominion,16)

ISBISTER - May 22, at Fulham, South Town belt, the wife of J. J. Isbister, of a daughter. (May 25, 1893,Star, The,2)

DEATH. GLEESON. - On July 16th, at her residence Town Belt, LOUISE, beloved wife of Charles Gleeson, Native of Okarito. (Jul 17, 1915,Grey River Argus,4)

The proposed tramway was intended to be constructed on portions of the Town Belt which were vested in the corporation. (Sep 16, 1924,Otago Witness,60)

town bike¶

n. the local (small-town) prostitute; one who is free with sexual favours (sc. everybody has a ride) [ca1938]

GEE I was having my first real affair with a girl of fifteen called Melva Butter. Charlie said she was the town bike (he was sour at missing his turn) but she had her own sort of morality: ... she took on only one boy at a time. (1972,In My Father's Den,55)

LELAND town bike: This is teenage slang for the most ridden members of their female compatriots. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,105)

MARSHALL ... Neddy's girlfriend in Te Tarehi wasn't worth it. He said he'd met someone who knew her: she was flat-chested and the town bike. (1982,Master of Big Jingles,112)

Ellen was the town bike. (Apr 1992,Charivari (Auckland),30)

town bike of politics¶

phr. (Politics) Peter Dunne of the United Future Party, who is willing to join with any party under MMP.

Dunne is the town bike of politics. He's available to anyone who will have him ... (Sep 19, 2008,Dominion Post,B5) [NOTES: Bob Jones column]

town board¶

n.

THATCHER And the booth they visited for prog,/ And sometimes took a nip of grog;/ There was Grieve, one of your famed Town Board,/ McIvor too his orders roared/ (1864,Invercargill Minstrel,6) [NOTES: (The Caledonian Gathering)]

SARGESON He worked for the town board and in the dry weather he'd have to drive about the streets on the water-cart. The butcher would say no, it was the fair dinkum truth. (1977,Listener Short Stories,20,1945 ed.) [NOTES: 1945 Sargeson in 1977 Listener Short Stories 20]

GEE I was having my first real affair with a girl of fifteen called Melva Butter. Charlie said she was the town bike (he was sour at missing his turn) but she had her own sort of morality: ... she took on only one boy at a time. (1972,In My Father's Den,55)

It was decided at the meeting of the Johnsonville Town Board last evening to ask the Wellington City Council whether it would consider the amalgamation of Johnsonville with the city, and on what basis. (Jun 15, 1937,Evening Post,5)

Manaia and Opunake Town Boards wrote regarding the reduction of publicans' licenses. (Jul 22, 1909,Hawera & Normanby Star,6)

NOTICE is hereby given that the Balance-Sheet for the year ending 31st March, 1915, is now open to inspection at the Town Board Offices, Upper Hutt. (Jun 8, 1915,Evening Post,10)

The Council met on the 3rd inst., when the following Bills were read a first time:- Excess of Expenditure Bill - Dunedin Town Town Board Bill - Immigration Appropriation Debentures Bill - Dunedin Roads and Streets Bill. (Jan 6, 1855,Otago Witness,3)

The demand for a new school for Cobden is being endorsed by the Cobden Town Board. (Dec 24, 1920,Grey River Argus,4)

TOWN BOARD OF NEW PLYMOUTH ENDOWMENT ORDINANCE, 1871. (Mar 4, 1871,Taranaki Herald,6)

A letter was received from the Clark to the Gore Town Board, stating that Mr Driver, M.H.R., was about to introduce a bill into Parliament to amend the Town Districts Bill. (Jul 1, 1882,Otago Witness,21)

From the chairman Stratford Town Board inviting co-operation in obtaining similar powers for Town Boards as exists for Road Boards in the matter of bank overdrafts. - Approved. (Aug 14, 1896,Timaru Herald,3)

town day¶

n. the day that farmers travel to town for supplies, usually on a stock sale day.

TURNER [In winter] a farmer does not have to be mindful of cow-time or milking time on town day (or sale day, equivalent to English `market day'). In winter, one or two house cows might be milked by hand. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,150)

town district¶

n. [variously a specific classification with ref to local government or more general description. Note Town Districts Bill &/or Town District bill, early 1900's, but term used before that.]

Not a great deal of change has occurred in the population of Springs and Ellesmere counties and the Leeston and Southbridge town districts during the 10 years since the 1926 census. (Apr 21, 1936,Ellesmere Guardian,4)

Leeston town district: 609; last census 566; increase 43. (Oct 23, 1945,Ellesmere Guardian,3)

town house¶

n. one of a group of similar houses especially but not essentially in the central part of town (gen. Engl. sense a house in town) [cf British use and Canterbury use eg of Runholder Charles H.Greenstreet He had a town house in the corner of Mays[???] Rd. Papanui.]

MIDDLETON Mr Silva [the owner] went back to his town house and ... there were only Charlie and his wife and I on the station. (1959,Stone, The,50) [NOTES: (The Stone)]

ELDRED-GRIGG So a moving van was eventually sent from ... Dick's townhouse ... (1977,Of Ivory Accents,8)

MANTELL She's moved into one of those town houses next door. (1980,Murder or Three, A,79)

BAUER ... in New Zealand a town house is a semi-detached house with a very small garden, and not just any house in a town - this can be contrasted with the traditional British English sense of town house with its implications of secondary residence. (1983,English Word-formation,58)

... the things just below [the crane] look good too: the toy-town city, with its shops and vehicles, the flash townhouses by the beach, and especially the big ... hotel right next door. (Jan 1987,Metro,126)

LOWER HUTT: Central. $165,000. 3 br townhouse to be built of low maint materials on sunny section. (Jan 7, 1987,Evening Post,20)

Town house is in, and uneasily acceptable as a residence in town esp. of person with house in the country' althoughin the country' could be better phrased; but house in (esp. terraced) group in town' is not apt, and increasingly the style for this type of dwelling is <i>townhouse.</i> That is,My town house is a townhouse', correctly distinguishes, on the page, and will be distinguished in speech; tow stresses for the one, and one stress (TOWNhouse) for the other. There is as well a question of nuance to be noticed. A townhouse is emphatically upmarket from a home unit. (1987,Te Reo,30/132) [NOTES: Smithyman Review NZPOD]

*Modern 3 bedroomed Townhouse in Papakowhai, available from the beginning of October - short or long term. (Sep 16, 1988,Victoria Univ. Weekly Staff Circular,902/5)

L. Bauer noted in April in UK town-house being used in a sense similar to the usual NZ sense of compact executive homes on very small sections (1988,Personal Communication)

This in the context of a Metro piece that reverently treats his own decision to replace the family home with a block of townhouses as a shining example of the new entrepreneurial spirit. (Jun 5, 1993,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

town lot¶

n. (historical)

The memorial [from Mr.Sinclair, Wellington] states that certain town lots ... had been advertised for sale by auction, but that several allotments, comprising some of the most valuable lands in the township, ... had been reserved from such sale ...; that these sections were to be paid for at the average price of half the town sections ... (Sep 10, 1841,GBPP,(No.569) 130) [NOTES: 1841 Sep 10 Villiers and Lefevre : Colonial Land and Emigration Office in GBPP 1842 (No.569) 130]

CAMPBELL It was at a very early stage of the existence of the embryo capital, when we were all squatters, and the survey lines of the town were only half cut, and when we were all helping each other to do nothing until the first sale of town lots should come off, ... (1881,Poenamo,Bk4/12/342)

That, with the foregoing exceptions, no lands be reserved as sites of towns, and that in all cases in which such reserves may have been already made, the lands comprised in them shall be sold by auction to the highest bigger, should any portion of them have been disposed of as town allotments, but, if none have been so disposed of, shall cease to be reserved as town lots, and shall be open to sale at the general uniform price. (May 1, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

Sale of Paeroa town lots at Paeroa. (Aug 27, 1909,Ohinemuri Gazette,2)

Auction sale of town lots at Paeroa. (Nov 5, 1913,Ohinemuri Gazette,2)

WANTED, a Conveyancer to convey town lot at Waikanae. (Oct 10, 1928,Evening Post,1)

Until the town lots were surveyed, he lived on an island in the harbour, Brown's Island, and kept pigs there in readiness for selling to the townspeople once the town site was decided upon. (May 14, 1935,Evening Post,3)

Thirteen town lots, four suburban, and two country, were purchased, in some instances, at an higher than the upset price. (Jan 26, 1850,New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian,2)

Saturday's sale brought forward 70 entries, principally made up of dealers' and town lots. (May 1, 1890,Otago Witness,18)

Te Ngakau has been going round the Waikato townships examining what allotments belong to the Government, in view of Sir G. Grey's proposals to give town lots to the Kingites. (Jun 14, 1878,North Otago Times,2)

"No town lots have been offered on Doubtless Bay; no town or village lots have been offered at GBP2 per acre in that vicinity, nor have any town lots whatever been sold for GBP2 an acre continuous to any town lot bringing GBP30 an acre." (Jun 24, 1863,Daily Southern Cross,4)

town Maori¶

n.

BROWNING `Blay stuck-up bish, blay pakeha ... Her'n that other one, o' there. Blay town Maori things she's good, eh?' (1976,Watch Your Language,28)

town milk¶

n. [milk produced or delivered in town, cf town milk produced in the country for 'town supply'.]

In New Zealand about 85 per cent. of all town milk sold in urban areas is pasteurised. ... Too much 'billy' milk is still sold. (Oct 16, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,306)

Town milk supply is.. a question of Quotas. (Aug 1959,NZ Dairy Exporter,41)

[Hdg] Price-Determining Formula for Town Milk (Sep 1959,NZ Dairy Exporter,19)

WANTED, a Man capable of conducting a Town Milk Business. (Jul 2, 1878,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

Our Borough Council is in favour of Government inspection of the sources of the town milk supply. (Apr 13, 1899,Taranaki Herald,2)

Ideal place for retired farmer, contractor, carrier or small town milk run. (Jun 20, 1922,Otautau Standard,4)

The country milk is a richer and more creamy fluid than the town milk, and we may fairly estimate that town buyers get for their shilling the equivalent of fourpennyworth of country milk. (Sep 6, 1906,Poverty Bay Herald,1)

This shows that town milk is much stronger on the water, and has far less butter and milk sugar than that given by a country cow. (Mar 16, 1881,North Otago Times,2)

n. (Rural) (in attrib. use) [of farms, farmers and herds] providing milk all year round for town consumption. [aka townmilk, town-milk]

The majority of town milk suppliers do not breed their own replacements, but rely on buying close-up cows at dispersal sales. (Oct 9, 1952,NZ Farmer,22)

As might be expected, there's a very ready demand in the Christchurch town milk herds for the Macartney culls. (Mar 1, 1955,NZ Dairy Exporter,6)

Townmilk farmers on the plain generally consider it's easier to produce milk in winter than it is in summer in our climate. (Jan 1977,NZ Dairy Exporter,2)

The town-milk industry is composed of three fairly clearly defined sections, production, treatment, and distribution, all of which seek to serve the interests of the housewife. (Oct 16, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,303)

This would bring the average price paid to cheese suppliers for the 1934-35 season to 10.6953d per lb butter-fat, excluding town milk sales. (Jan 23, 1936,Evening Post,14)

A request for an increase in the price of milk for the 1945-46 season was placed before the Minister of Marketing (Mr. Roberts) and the Minister of Health (Mr. Nordmeyer) by a deputation from the Town Milk Producers' Federation. (Jun 11, 1945,Evening Post,6)

Assets. - Freehold and leasehold premises and plant GBP11,501 16s 9d, additions to buildings GBP178 2s 6d, additions to plant GBP195 6s 3d, paid on Newstead property GBP169 1s 11d, town milk supply, capital (GBP642 7s 9d, less depreciation GBP30) GBP612 7s 9d, stocks on hand GBP389 4s 1d .. total GBP16,843 13s. (Apr 15, 1915,Poverty Bay Herald,7)

town quarter-acre¶

n.

WAKEFIELD [Terms of Purchase of Land in the Settlement of Otago' agreed on by theOtago Association' and the Company] 16 In exchange for each sum of 120l. 10s. ... each Purchaser to receive ... three separate Land-Orders, namely, for the Town quarter-acre, the ten acres of Suburban Land, and the fifty acres of Rural Land, respectively. These lands to be severally selected according to priority of choice, to be determined by Ballot. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,317)

Town Ranger¶

n.

Letter from Mr. Baker Polhill, soliciting the appointment of Town Ranger of Public Reserves ... (Oct 18, 1842,New Zealand Colonist & Port Nicholson Advertiser,2)

town reserve¶

n. land set aside as the site of a town [1839[??=NZ paper town]]]

SEWELL A large space has been set apart as what is called a Town Reserve near Lyttelton. (1853,Journal,1/139,1980 ed.)

In 1900, after a long search, the Council obtained statutory authority to acquire a site of six acres in Salamanca road, part of a town reserve made available by arrangement with the City Council and the Board of Governors of Wellington College. (Apr 9, 1924,Evening Post,9)

For summer bedding in the gardens and town reserves 63,000 plants have been tended in the last year, and for the spring beds which, in November, will have run their span, there were 5000 tulips, 3000 hyacinths, 5000 ranunculi, and 5000 anemones. (Sep 11, 1940,Evening Post,7)

SUGGESTIONS FOR RESOURCES EQUAL TO DEFICIT FROM LOSS OF SUBSIDY.- 1st. The Government to compensate us for loss of subsidy by granting the licenses as annexed: Public houses L150; liquor, L100; .. 2nd. To relieve the Corporation of their debt incurred under the impression that the subsidy would be continued. This, with the Crown Grants for Oamaru Town Reserves, would enable the Coproration to contunue such works and improvements as were needed. (Feb 23, 1872,North Otago Times,2)

The Town Council asked the Minister of Justice to authorise prison labor to be employed free of charge to carry out certain municipal works, and in this way compensate the Corporation for loss sustained through the Railway Department having taken one of the town reserves, the effect of which had been to render the public baths useless. (Sep 21, 1888,Marlborough Express,2)

Without in any way disparaging Victoria Park, it cannot for a moment be contended that that park will ever be anything like so popular as the town reserve, which, from its proximity to town and natural advantages, must ever claim pride of position. (Jun 2, 1896,Wanganui Herald,2)

The City Council have decided to erect a building immediately, on a town reserve, which could be used as a hospital in the event of the plague visiting the city. (Apr 19, 1900,Timaru Herald,3)

TREE-PLANTING ON TOWN RESERVES. (Apr 25, 1914,Evening Post,9)

Only a small portion of this road requires to be made, and that is chiefly before the country sections are reached. The first part that must be made practicable is within the town, and is the termination of the Tinakori-road; the other part passes through the town reserve. (Oct 13, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2)

ALL persons occupying Town Land under Business Licenses are reminded that the land included within the Town Reserve of Hokitika will shortly be withdrawn from the goldfields, and the sections either sold to the present occupiers, or put up to public auction. (Feb 15, 1866,West Coast Times,4)

town section¶

n. (historical) a section of land (often an acre) within a planned town [See also town acre; rural section]

GIFKIN The name 'the Quarter Acres' for an area of town sections allotted to Pakeha after the battles of Gate Pa and Te Ranga (1864) was commonly used. (1988,Through the Looking Glass,130) [NOTES: Article by Meikle]

In June 1839, the New Zealand Land Company, issued proposals for the sale of nine-tenths of a township of 110,000 acres, in lots of 101 acres, each comprising 100 acres of country land and one town section. (Sep 24, 1840,GBPP,1841 (No.311) 123) [NOTES: 1840 Sep 24 Port Nicholson Deputies to Gipps in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 123]

By the Government advertisement for the sale of town lands at Auckland, it was stated that sections ... would be exposed to sale by auction, but we have since learned that several allotments, comprising some of the most valuable lands in the township, have been reserved from such sale ...; and that these sections are to be paid for, not according to the price ... of the less valuable lots in their vicinity ... but at the average price of half the town sections ... (Feb 10, 1841,GBPP,1842 (No.569) 131) [NOTES: 1841 Feb 10 D.Sinclair and others, Wellington to Sir George Gipps in GBPP 1842 (No.569) 131]

The memorial [from Mr.Sinclair, Wellington] states that certain town lots ... had been advertised for sale by auction, but that several allotments, comprising some of the most valuable lands in the township, ... had been reserved from such sale ...; that these sections were to be paid for at the average price of half the town sections ... (Sep 10, 1841,GBPP,1842 (No.569) 130) [NOTES: 1841 Sep 10 Villiers and Lefevre : Colonial Land and Emigration Office in GBPP 1842 (No.569) 130]

We have had a selection of town sections of land, by the different proprietors and there agents, and they are now being leased - I mean the sections of absentee proprietors, and such others as have them to dispose of - and this at high remuneration. The town section measures a quarter of an acre, and costs in London 10s; ... (May 2, 1848,Letters from Otago,10,1978 ed.)

WAKEFIELD [spg town-section] cf Town-acre One Town-section [one acre] was attached to each rural section [100 acres]. Ibid. 284 Two hundred and fifty Town-sections [at New Plymouth], with their orders of choice ..., each with a Rural section of 50 acres attached ... (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,175)

SEWELL He wants to take some of the Church Lands at Kaiapoi, a rural section and a Town Section. (1853,Journal,1/336,1980 ed.)

HOCKEN The 21st of April [1848] was fixed for the formal selection of their own town sections by the land purchasers, ... Mr.David Garrick ... was the first private individual to select in Dunedin, and ... he chose what is now probably the most valuable site - that quarter acre upon which now stands the Bank of New Zealand ... Upon this he erected his frame house brought out on the John Wicliffe, ... (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,99)

The immediate choosing of a town acre section has been a most important and useful measure. (Jan 11, 1851,Lyttelton Times,5)

APPLICATION having been made to me for the issue of a New Certificate of Title in the name of OWEN BECKWITH SNELLING, of Kaukapakapa, Farmer, for 9 acres and 3 roods, more or less, being Town Section 101 and Suburban Sections 23 and 26 .. I hereby give notice that I will issue the New Certificate of Title as requested after fourteen days from the date of the "Gazette" containing this notice. (May 1, 1930,Evening Post,3)

ALL THAT piece of land situated in the City of Wellington containing Ten and Two-Tenths Perches (10.2P.) being the same a little more of less being part of Town Section 967 (Dec 19, 1945,Evening Post,3)

The following town sections were sold by Mr Osborne, on behalf of the Government, at the Waste Lands Office on Wednesday. (Apr 3, 1874,Southland Times,2)

The long looked for sale of the Paeroa town sections took place in the Criterion Theatre yesterday. (Dec 4, 1908,Ohinemuri Gazette,2)

TO BUILDERS, WHARFINGERS, AND OTHER CAPITALISTS PROCEEDING TO NEW ZEALAND. TO BE SOLD or LET on Building Leases a Town and Country Section, being the second in the order of choice in the first British settlement in New Zealand. (Aug 21, 1839,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,1)

Any one having a town section of land (an early choice) to dispose of, will meet with a purchaser, by applying to F. Bradey, on the Beach. (Apr 18, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2)

There was not much demand for Manaia town sections, but suburban were keenly competed for, and brought a good deal more than the upset price. (Feb 26, 1881,North Otago Times,2)

Messrs Friedlander Bros. and D. Thomas sold to-day by auction 29 sections of Cameron's Springfield estate, a town section realising GBP20 per acre. (Apr 23, 1902,Otago Witness,19)

MORRISON, SCLANDERS, AND CO. have for SALE - Part TOWN SECTIONS 437, 439, and 442, with frontage to Hardy-street, Collingwood-street, Selwyn-place, Morrison-street, and Hope-street. (Sep 28, 1867,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,1)

This demand for big rents is based on the mad speculation which has been allowed to go on in town sections, always forcing the prices up and consequently the rents. (Nov 27, 1918,Grey River Argus,2)

THE undermentioned Town Sections will be sold by auction, at the Land Office, Invercargill, at noon, on Monday, the 31st day of July current. (Jul 22, 1876,Otago Witness,12)

TENDERS FOR PURCHASE OF HOTEL AND TOWN SECTIONS. (Nov 29, 1920,Grey River Argus,1)

town supplier¶

1 n. (Rural) a farmer who provides milk all-year-round for local consumption.

While the farming methods do not differ greatly from those adopted on an ordinary dairy farm, the town supplier is confronted with special problems incidental to an all-the-year-round supply of milk. (Aug 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,157)

town supply¶

1 n. (Rural) the provision of fresh whole milk by farms to local milk treatment stations [requiring a proportion of autumn-calvers for milking to continue in the winter months] or the farm that provides such milk. [aka town-supply]

But between the prices given at a bush creamery and for milk sold for town supply there is a wide margin. (Jul 1899,NZ Farmer,238)

Handy suburban farm. Milking for town supply. (Nov 1, 1920,Hawera Star,03)

This..is the opinion of a well-known farmer who has had over 20 years' experience in catering for town supply on his farm at Albany about 10 miles north of Auckland. (Aug 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,155)

That town supply has in the main proved profitable over a period of years is well demonstrated by the fact that in addition to providing a good living for the occupier ... (Aug 15, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,159)

A herringbone milking shed without walls and with a round - or partly round - yard has been built at Te Kuiti by Mr John Ormsby for his town supply herd. (Sep 4, 1961,NZ Farmer,4)

... Mr Steve Algie, a town supply dairyman on the low-lying Taieri Plain, has provided a partly-covered loafing yard to keep his milkers off the pastures ... (Sep 28, 1961,NZ Farmer,46)

A 90-acre town supply dairy farm with 35 cows ... [town supply herd, town supply farm, town supply farmer] (Aug 2002,Growing Today,7)

FALLA et al. A single bird spent the cold winter of 1963, ... near Christchurch alternating between two herds of Friesian-Holsteins `on town supply'. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,79)

A producer stated that long before butter rationing came into force producers were regarding the town supply with disfavour, and the latest restriction, on cream selling was the last straw. (Nov 15, 1943,Evening Post,3)

The milk was sold to a retailer for the town supply. (Mar 29, 1926,Evening Post,10)

Such things may have taken place before inspection of our town supply; but for such an insinuation to be levelled at our milk vendors I consider is unjust and uncalled for. (Apr 29, 1905,Wanganui Herald,2)

town-supply¶

adj. (of a farm) devoted to the production of milk for town drinking as opposed to butter and cheese production [town supply] (See town milk)

[caption] Tanker collecting milk from a town-supply farm at Te Awamutu... (1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,93) [NOTES: A town-supply farmer undertakes to supply a fixed quota of milk all year round.]

[Recolonisation] turned New Zealand into "a town-supply district of London" while "London became the cultural capital of New Zealand." (Dec 8, 2001,Dominion Weekend Magazine,12)

towner¶

n. a rare and obs variant of townie

... the `towners' piled up a score of 13 points. (Jun 2, 1906,NZ Truth,50/2/8)

towneyite¶

n.

HUNT Or when we were playing around having a fight down the back, someone would say, `Go away, nigger.' ... Then there'd be a fight. Same thing when the towneyites - the kids from up Kaikoura - came down here. (1985,I'm Ninety-five,98 ed.) [NOTES: (Marama, Kaikoura)]

townie¶

n. a person bred to the town and ignorant of or awkward in country ways

Dr. Pigeon and his young wife are not fitted for this island. ... She is a little towny, wee bit thing, quite lost in the country. (Sep 15, 1904,Chudleigh Diary,424,1950 ed.)

these poor Towneys. (Jul 5, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,252)

Townie.- (1) Two men from the same part of England speak of each other as `a to t. of mine'. (C.) (2) I have heard people from town derided as townies but perhaps it is a schoolboy word. (Dec 23, 1933,Press, The,15) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

Should the wife be a confirmed townie' the sheepman must get work nearer the fleshpots. [cp ibid. 29 Mosttown fellers' he would pity as being too smart.] (1945,High Country,28) [NOTES: 1945 Pascoe High Country in NZ Geographer 28]

FINLAYSON A towny travels for the good of his health. (1948,Tidal Creek,3)

SINCLAIR In the eyes of many a farmer the `townies' were mostly parasites who, sheltering behind the tariffs, lived by selling him dear and inferior goods. (1959,History of New Zealand,200)

McNAUGHTON Lucas [the head shepherd] thought of him as a townie. (1970,Tat,96)

SARGESON When I took a sitting shot [at a pigeon] ... Miles said he didn't believe there was anyone except a townie who could be so dirty ... [sic] (1973,Once Is Enough,64)

OGONOWSKA-COATES Townie. Person from town (1987,Boards, Blades & Barebellies,98)

VIRTUE The other blokes at school were always slinging off at him because he was a dunce and a townie and a holy roller. (1987,Redemption of Elsdon Bird, The,45,1988 ed.)

We came in as townies, and had never even seen a possum. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/89)

IRELAND Country children wore proper boots all the time, summer and winter, whereas townies - at least in the Auckland of my childhood - made it a point of honour to go barefoot, even on the roughly metalled streets of Takapuna, and our feet were always covered in stone bruises to prove it. Ibid. 90 'That's what I think of bloody townies.' 'Why?' I asked. 'Cos they don't bloody smoke,' he said. (1998,Under the Bridge & Over the Moon,87)

It is mostly townies like us who have fuelled New Zealand's smallfarming revolution. (Jan 2000,NZ Geographic,No. 45/40)

A hopeless townie like me wouldn't last five minutes in Te Kuata's rugged world. (Nov 21, 1998,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45)

It's easy to bag the creative townies behind the funny ads when they are just reflecting an image, Mr Ryan says. (Feb 25, 2000,Dominion,16)

Being a good townie I must have missed something (Jul 19, 2000,Evening Post,4)

Native trees and other features of interest on the track are numbered in black paint, and the leaflet gives you enough information at least to impress a visiting townie. (Apr 28, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),40)

Mr Kidd says the ignorance of some townies amazes him. (Sep 9, 2004,Dominion Post,C7)

Brought up a townie, his dream was always to be a sheep and beef farmer and he had to teach himself basic skills, at one stage single-handedly building a house with only a book on carpentry as his guide. (Jul 1, 2004,Dominion Post,C6)

FARRELL At their first encounter Peg and Jack and Kath had decided that their cousin was a sook, a townie and a sook. (1992,Skinny Louie Book,24)

n. (Rural) [used elsewhere but widely and often derisively in NZ] a person inexperienced and/or incompetent in rural matters.

It is essential that many preconceived ideas about the idyllic existence of 'townies' or conversely 'farmers' must be scrapped ... (Jan 1, 1941,NZ Dairy Exporter,13)

MARRIOTT But when a townie is suddenly transplanted from the city to a real backblocks farm, in the middle of the worst slump in history as I was, there are likely to ensue all kinds of episodes, hair-raising as well as hilarious. (1981,Life in the Gorge,9)

ROBERTS & TURNER When a 'townie' comes to the high country the pranksters are ready and waiting to conduct proper initiations. (1983,NZ High Country Four Seasons,17)

CARR He was not really a farmer, just a townie gone bush, and did not fully understand the time-lag involved in making little pigs. (1986,Diary of a Pig Hunter,129)

HARRISON Cups fell off everywhere as the townies tried frantically to put cups on teats with unaccustomed fingers. (1986,She's a Fair Cow,20)

BARNES She used to cope with what a townie could only imagine in her worst dreams - feeding station staff with provisions coming in only twice a year. (1987,Country Calendar (TVNZ),20)

BENNETT Unfortunately the orchard was across the paddock where the sows were kept and June and Joyce being 'townies' were scared of being in the same paddock as the sows. (1990,Bryans, The: At Home on the Farm,27)

Uncontrolled, thousands of romantic townies would canker the nation's farming backbone. (May 12, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

Paul van Beers, competing in the fencing heats at Mystery Creek, was a townie the first time he picked up a strainer and went fencing more than 20 years ago. (Jun 15, 2001,Dominion,14)

1 adj. (Rural) [of an animal or person] inadequate or inexperienced in rural matters. (See townie dog)

STACEY I could have shown my new townie friends how to skin a rabbit or an eel, clean a fish or work a dog ... (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,34)

BLAKE There was a delightful array of typical townie-type dogs waiting in the pound .. one look was enough to convince me that no self-respecting possum hunter would risk his reputation being seen dead with any one of them. (1999,Trappers, Dogs 'n' Deer,41)

BLAKE The SF90 bush was such that these townie shooters, completely unfamiliar with their surroundings, were always getting themselves lost. (1999,Trappers, Dogs 'n' Deer,235)

KERR Let's clear up a townie misunderstanding. Sheep will eat tussock, but only in dire circumstances .. A young townie relative would learn to pick up, starting on the morrow. (2000,High Times in the High Country,83)

townie dog¶

1 n. (Rural) a dog that is not capable of long hours of hill or hunting work.

STACEY I must admit it gave me a certain amount of satisfaction to see the townie dogs go howling home, snapping at their fat backs where the whips [drovers' stock whips] cut in. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,43)

BLAKE Corletts were running a few dry cows on the flats, and Roy being a townie dog had more than likely never seen a cattle beast before. (1999,Trappers, Dogs 'n' Deer,70)

townified¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of a person or community] with few rural characteristics or allegiances.

NATUSCH Invercargill became townified (1976,On The Edge of the Bush: Women in Early Southland,65)

Towns' skink¶

n. (Environment) an endangered skink species resident only on Mokohinau, Hen and Chicken, and the Great and Little Barrier island groups. [Oligosoma townsi aka pre 2009 Cyclodina townsi aka mokohinau skink]

New lizards found off the Northland coast include... the Mokohinau skink.. from the Mokohinau islands and Hen and Chickens Islands in Hauraki Gulf. (May 2002,Forest & Bird,No. 304/18)

township¶

n. a paper town

The memorial [from Mr.Sinclair, Wellington] states that certain town lots ... had been advertised for sale by auction, but that several allotments, comprising some of the most valuable lands in the township, ... had been reserved from such sale ...; that these sections were to be paid for at the average price of half the town sections ... (Sep 10, 1841,GBPP,(No.569) 130) [NOTES: 1841 Sep 10 Villiers and Lefevre : Colonial Land and Emigration Office in GBPP 1842]

A township can, I apprehend, have no meaning other than a continuous block of land; ... (Oct 6, 1840,GBPP,(No.311) 122) [NOTES: 1840 Oct 6 Gipps to Lord John Russell in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 122]

Shares to the amount of 100,000l, to be paid up almost immediately, have been suscribed for; and, what is still more remarkable, the sum of 100,000l. was paid within five weeks, for as many acres of land, in a township the site of which is not yet determined. (Aug 21, 1839,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,4)

The survey of Kawhia township is completed. (Mar 5, 1883,Grey River Argus,2)

ALTHOUGH over two years have passed since the Premier visited Pipiriki and took over a site for a township from Kemp and Topia Turoa, which was to be surveyed and disposed of as soon as possible by the Government as trustees for the native owners, not one single allotment has been dealt with. (Jun 2, 1897,Wanganui Herald,2)

2 n. a small town,a village; occasionally in early NZ usage (or of British planners' usage) the paper or planned site for a town; but quckly developing the sense village, small town, and becoming the usual word in NZ for what in Britain (and in the usage of many early writers) would be called a village or hamlet (cp VILLAGE) [ca1960 the Main Highway signs in diminishing progression of size include: City, Borough, Township, Settlement, Settled or Populated Area, Beware Stock [check AAand/or MWD]] (See native township,Maori township)

COLLINS (1802,Account of the English Colony in NSW, An,2/7)

In June 1839, the New Zealand Land Company, issued proposals for the sale of nine-tenths of a township of 110,000 acres, in lots of 101 acres, each comprising 100 acres of country land and one town section. (Sep 24, 1840,GBPP,(No.311) 123) [NOTES: 1840 Sep 24 Port Nicholson Deputies to Gipps in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 123]

CAPT SMITH Port Ashley ... is quite unfit for settlement ... as there [330] is no fit place for a Township. (Nov 1842,Report) [NOTES: 1842 Nov Capt. Smith's report in 1848 Wakefield Handbook for NZ 329-330]

HEAPHY ... while the additional circumstance of Auckland possessing a tolerable harbour, would also have always caused its pre-eminence over the adjoining township [at Thames]. (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),21)

MAJORIBANKS It is fortunate that it [the Hutt] was abandoned as a township, as the water on one occasion, rose three or four feet in several of the huts, ... (1845,Travels in NZ,62)

SHORTLAND This is now the site of a township, called Dunedin, founded by a Scotch company. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,174)

... Ordinance to abate the Dog nuisance, the boundaries of the township of Akaroa in the Middle Island of New Zealand, shall be hereafter known as follows:- ... (Nov 19, 1852,NZ Government Gazette,V/28/169) [NOTES: [compare VILLAGE used about the same date in NZGG] 1852 Nov 19 NZGG (Governor Grey's Proclamation) V/28/169]

SEWELL The notion of the new Township spreads like wild-fire. Ibid. 1/130 The general opinion is that the contiguity of this native Pah is no objection to the new Township. (Feb 4, 1853,Journal,1/126,1980 ed.)

JOHN GROVES ... we are in the centre from Wellington to a township called Ahuriri. For all travellers ... are often obliged to sleep under the flaxbush. (Nov 17, 1855,Letter) [NOTES: 1855 Nov 17 John Groves in 1971 Manson I Take up My Pen 31]

PAUL Malvern Hills, where Mr. Cass thinks there is a site suited for a township. (1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,72)

WILLIS GANN & CO The sites of new towns and townships [are] rising or filling up in the Colony. (1864,Handbook of New Zealand,37)

WILLIS GANN & CO The sites of new towns and townships [are] rising or filling up in the Colony. (1864,Handbook of New Zealand,37)

BURGESS While we were at the township [in Otago, c1862 March], one of our acquaintances came to me and told me there was a man in a disreputable shanty, that had plenty of money and would I come and put him up? Now the Wetherstone diggings were very quiet, so that I objected to men being put up and let go to alarm the place - for I anticipated robbing this banker sooner or later, and that would do me. (1866,Confessions,76,1983 ed.)

McLEAN (F. Robinson) Mr Duncan's [property] comes between me and the Township. (1866,Papers,26/137)

MONEY About this time, though almost a new chum' myself, I was much amused by a trio who arrived in the township and put up opposite myshanty'. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,17)

BATHGATE We reached the township of Maori Point ... consisting of ... a few `frame tents' ... (1874,Colonial Experiences,134)

BATHGATE The village, or township as they call it in this part of the world, has an unpronounceable Maori[?] name. (1881,Waitaruna,181)

(1895,NZ Reader,97) [NOTES: 1882 in 1895 NZ Reader 97]

PAYTON Every little township has its public park (so called). (1888,Round about NZ,15)

WILLIAMS & REEVES ... cities and Townships (colonial for towns) (1889,Colonial Couplets,23)

CHAMIER I have to go to the village - I beg its pardon, the township. (1891,Philosopher Dick,548)

WILSON ... township (1894,In the Land of the Tui,42)

ARTHUR Townships are the smaller colonial towns, and vary in size from the dimension of a moderate English village to about a fifth-rate English country town. (1894,Kangaroo and Kauri,89)

MORRIS a village, a possible future town. In the United States, the word has a definite meaning - a district, subordinate to a country, the inhabitants having power to regulate their local affairs; in Australia, the word has no such definite meaning. It may be large or small, and sometimes consists of little more than the post-office, the public-house, and the general store or shop. (1898,Austral English,476)

Towń.ship (touń.sh&ibreve.p), n. [Add.] 4. In Australia, a small town; a village. Also, the space surveyed for the site of a town. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

BELL Townships are formed here and there as settlement proceeds; - at first a store and post office, a cottage or a blacksmith's shop perhaps; then a hotel, another store, and again another hotel. Ibid. 20 Sanguine in their anticipations, and bountifully provident for the wants of posterity, the promoters of these bush townships - whether it were the Government, private companies or individuals, or a supplementing of the former by the latter - made the boundaries of them wide enough for all possible future requirements, and gave ample scope for prospective development. This was very commendable and necessary in some instances, but where a township, as sometimes happened, did not go off' at the sale, or if it did go off, was never subsequently embellished with a building of any kind, the effect had something of the ludicrous about it - for while settlement went on around thetownship,' and the land was cleared and occupied, the `town' itself remained a solid block of standing bush, and the absentee owners of its acre or quarter-acre sections were only reminded of their possessions by the persistent recurrence of the notices to pay rates (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,3)

BAYLY ... a so-called `township'. (1905,NZ Courtship, A,8)
