HULL Generally speaking, a township [in North Auckland] consists of a `pub', a store, half-a-dozen scattered homesteads, and about thirty-nine million Maori bugs. The Maori bug is about half an inch by an inch, but his influence extends over about half an acre. (1907,College Songs,46)

MANSFIELD He had ridden over to the township with four of the boys to help hunt down the young fellow who'd murdered Mr Williamson. ... Willie Cox said they found him in the barn, shot bang through the head, the young English `johnny' who'd been on the station learning farming - (1913,Stories,134,1984 ed.)

MANDER The bay was now a township. It had its own post office, its little public school, its town hall, its football field. (1920,Story of a NZ River, The,198,1960 ed.)

ACLAND (1933,Early Canterbury Runs,100)

I would include among New Zealand English words: township (May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class)

MACFARLANE During our short history villages have come and gone, have flourished and then decayed, and some once again flourished. There is a story behind all these happenings. These many widely-scattered urban oases in the rural desert have been known for all their short lives as townships'. A very ugly name coming down to us from the old digging days. Village' or justtown' are now gaining ground over the ugly old name, and rightly so. You could scarcely talk of beautifying a township, but could get quite enthusiastic over improving a village. (1954,Te Raka,19)

DAVIN There'd been a few more drinks with Ron Strachan, who ... was in the township for his annual booze-up. (1956,Sullen Bell,84)

A small town. - (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),418)

MIDDLETON (Not for a Seagull) I remember I was jiving with a girl ... who worked in a milkbar in the township. (1964,Walk on the Beach,161)

McLINTOCK The back country runs have quite a vocabulary of their own ... terms like cow paddock and horse paddock and tea-oh and township which, like most of these terms, took on their special use in Australia. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/679) [NOTES: Wall NZ Speech]

township n in Australia any small town, village or settlement. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

township n . in Australia, any small town, village, or settlement. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

ARMFELT Down to Elgin: sprawling, squat, bungaloid: not even large enough to be a township': just the all tar-sealedmain drag', quite wide, with crooked telegraph posts on both sides. (1971,Catching Up,20)

township n. small town or settlement. (NZ & Austral.) ... NZ & Austral. hist. tract of surveyed land, site for a town (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,814) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 1239]]

SEWELL The fact is that when the Gladstone scheme was abandoned, Simeon and I agreed that the opportunity should not be lost of realising a Township Scheme upon the same site for the benefit of the Church. (Feb 4, 1853,Journal,1/424,1980 ed.)

He never omits to call at the township post office which usually comprises the tuckershop as well ... At the way-back township of Mataroa ... (Jan 6, 1906,NZ Truth,29/8/4)

Clarke's is not a township; it is simplv a roadside hotel. (Jan 30, 1890,Otago Witness,13)

The subscriptions will be confined, in a great measure, to the permanent endowment of the church, by the purchase of one or more sections of land in the principal township of the colony, to the erection of the necessary buildings, including a house for the clergyman, and to the providing for him a suitable outfit. (Aug 21, 1839,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,7)

FOR SALE, Several quarter-acre sections in the Government Township, Timaru, and A few sections in Rhodes' Township. (Jun 11, 1864,Timaru Herald,1)

EARP [quoting Land Regulations] All reserves for townships or agricultural establishments shall have reserves marked off of one-twentieth of all bush-land within the limit of such block, or if there be no bush within such block, then a sufficient reserve of bush-land outside the block, ... shall be made. (1858,Handbook Wellington,13)

THOMSON ... the Counties act [passed in 1856], a precursor of the counties, hundreds, and townships of Old England; ... (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,2/242)

WILLOX ... different districts, townships and settlements. (1860,Handbook of New Zealand,52) [NOTES: [quoting Land Regulation terms]]

[The runanga] will bear the same relation to other political machinery ... as the township in the United States of America bears to the county and state organization, and ministers suggest the name of township as the most suitable English term for the community that will be represented by a single runanga. It will correspond with the division of hundreds proposed by his Excellency. [Grey's annotation] I should have preferred the term hundred'. It is already in use here. The natives will make a strange word out oftownship'. (Nov 1, 1861,Memorandum of Ministers) [NOTES: 1861 Nov 1 Memorandum by Ministers on Governor Grey's Proposed Institutions for the Native Race in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents 112e]

It [the new bridge] will cross the Waipa at Whatiwhatihoe, and literally joins together the European and Maori townships, bringing Finch's hotel in a line with the native township, a facility which, judging by last night's proceedings, will be largely taken advantage of. (May 1, 1882,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

Manutuke, a Maori township about fifteen miles from Gisborne, suffered a heavy loss within the past few days in the deaths of two tribal leaders, the second occurring under unusual circumstances. (Apr 12, 1932,Evening Post,10)

The land in the neighbourhood of Korarika was rapidly advancing in value. Our correspondent states, that on the 24th ultimo, 40 acres situated at a little more than a mile from that township, were sold in nine separate lots, for in all GBP241; and on the very present day, the buyer of one of these these [sic] lots realised a premium of 70 per cent by his purchase. (Jun 6, 1840,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,4)

The farmers and citizens in the township grew anxious. (Sep 28, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,62)

towser¶

n.

A better-hearted old towser never cracked a stock-whip. (1900,Auckland Weekly News,17)

toxa¶

n. ? a rabbit poison {ref. early 20C)

SCRYMGEOUR Phosphorised oats, toxa, pollard baits, strychnine and jam combined, gradually laid down the `bunny' population ... (1960,Memories of Maoriland,39)

toxic treasure¶

n.

However, he accepted that complaints could become "toxic treasure" - having a negative effect on both patient and doctor. (Jul 24, 2004,Dominion Post,A17)

Toxinz¶

n. a database of chemicals, pharmaceuticals, hazardous creatures and plants.

The "Toxinz" database, developed by the National Poisons Centre, had previously been available to poisons and emergency medical experts only .. It could be accessed at www.toxinz.com. (Jul 15, 2005,NZ Herald,A9)

toy¶

n. an inexperienced or inexpert tagger (of graffiti)

Graffiti Speak... Toy: Inexperienced or incompetent writer. (Nov 30, 2000,Evening Post,19)

Leaving the ranks of bored adolescents getting quick thrills from quick tags (toys, as the amateurs are called), she has gone on to the more esteemed throwup or bomb (a tag in fat letters with the outline coloured in), then the dub (a throwup with an outer line and bubbles), and finally the piece, short for masterpiece (a dub with filled in letters and a painted background). (Jan 20, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),51)

toy soldier¶

n. territorial soldier

He's in the territorials, a toy soldier ... but they're a very small percentage of our customers. (Aug 12, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

trace high¶

phr. = kilt verb q.v.

Trace high.-See kilt. (Jan 27, 1934,Press, The,15)

trace-element Maori¶

phr. [offensive?]

There were 1500 trespassers, led by trace-element Maoris but including some real ones. (Apr 9, 1995,Sunday Star Times,C3)

track¶

v. to smuggle contraband into and out of prison

NEWBOLD TRACK (v) Smuggle contraband in and out of prison. Possibly a corruption of TRUCK, Standard English for dubious trafficking in goods, since the early 16th century. (1982,Big Huey, The,255)

n. in NZ since 1839 (as elswhere), a rough path or way usually, originally, trodden clear; a rough unsurfaced road [also bush track TRACK is the general use in NZ among outdoors people (trampers, etc); also for regular paths trodden by animals, e.g. sheep tracks, goat tracks; trail is occasionally used, ?esp. of deer cf also MAORI TRACK [AND seems to suggest a much wider spec. use in Aust.]] (See also bush track)

ACLAND Track.- Pack t., etc. Originally an unformed, unfenced way, but Leach's T., Shand's T., etc., perpetuate the name. The county councils will probably alter these in time. The Bealey T. (to Hororata) is oftener than not called the Bealey road. `We came upon a very bad track-- that is the name by which all roads are called, and they don't deserve a better.'--S.L., p.76. (Dec 23, 1933,Press, The,15)

ODELL They will no doubt be ultimately opened up by the formation of tracks and the erection of huts, and will then allow of the fullest exploitation of the winter sports attractions of the Park. Ibid. 25 On tracks which are little used, for instance the Upper Edwards Bush Track, much assistance could be given to subsequent parties if travellers were to renew the blaze marks so that the `blazes' attracted the attention from a distance of those unfamiliar with the district. (1935,Handbook Arthur Pass National Park,20)

In the bush or in the open do you tramp on a track, a trail, or a path? Not on a path one may be sure, seldom if ever on a trail, almost always on a track, like a proper New Zealander... Track is undoubtedly the established word in New Zealand. It is the only one occurring on maps or applied to named routes, such as Hongi's track, the Milford track, the Pahiatua Bush Track Road. ..[25] It is interesting to compare the use of track and trail in The Tramper. Through the first volumes track is always used when referring to an actual track, and trail occurs rarely and then only in the expression blazed trail or more or less figuratively - to fare forth on the trail'. In 1935 there is the first definite use of <i>trail</i> as a synonym for <i>track</i> in a reference to theHandbook of Arthur's Pass National Park'. It is significant that it occurs in reference to Arthur's Pass for trail seems to have come into use in Canterbury in this sense before it reached Wellington. It occurs once or twice in the first volume of the Canterbury Mountaineer, and there is the B.B. Trail in the Arthur's Pass Hand book of 1935. From 1939 till 1940 in The Tramper, trail is used moderately frequently for an actual track, e.g. an old Maori trail',a miner's trail', but only by the one writer, a Wellington member of the Canterbury Mountaineering Club. Trail shows no sign of ousting track. (Sep 1958,Tararua,24) [NOTES: Ruth Mason `Track and Trail']

DENNIS Beyond Top Hut the track is benched for maybe 20 minutes before large poles take over to mark the easy, well-worn path across the tops. (1981,Paparoas Guide,65)

ROCHFORT We did not stay long at Whanganui, and returning made a slight diversion from the usual track to visit Otaki, which is considered the finest native town in the country. (1853,Adventures of a Surveyor,27)

BARKER ... first it was necessary to build on a flat (as the valleys here are called), not too far off the main track, on account of having to make the road to it ourselves; ... and a good creek, or brook, which would not go dry in the summer, close at hand. (1866,Station Life in NZ,63,1870 ed.)

BARKER After we had passed our own boundary fence we came upon a very bad track - this is the name by which all the roads are called, and they do not deserve a better. (1866,Station Life in NZ,76,1874 ed.)

We started ... for the track through the Bush to Lake Brunner. You must not mistake the word `track' to mean a road, for we had to scramble and crawl ... for seven miles. (Jan 20, 1890,Letter) [NOTES: 1890 Jan 20 in 1894 Wilson Land of the Tui 50]

"I don't think that is always the case here and until that is fully sorted out and the tracks brought up to standard, we'll obviously struggle." (Dec 22, 2002,Sunday Star Times)

Soon after parting from our guide the path became clear enough, at first passing through a grove of tawa; when at fault, a few broken branches shewed us the track again. (Mar 13, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2)

I have had this track repaired of slips, and broken cu[l]verts, and cleared it throughout of underbush and fern, as it was entirely grown over, but is now in good order. (Sep 15, 1888,West Coast Times,2)

The damage principally complained of is that done by the gale of April 13th last. Although the timber was not cut off the track, tracks were cleared around the trees and horses and cattle could be taken through. (Sep 7, 1895,Grey River Argus,4)

Mr Dale to move, "That this Council allow the Kanieri Road Board to collect all rates in the district, for the purpose of keeping in repair all tracks, dray roads, bridges, and culverts constructed by the Board, and such other works as the Board thinks fit; and that James Webster be appointed rate collector by this Council for the district." (Apr 9, 1878,West Coast Times,2)

The track from Milford to Glade House is sound and in good order and makes excellent walking, while the accomodation is entirely satisfactory, so that any compaints from tourists are not likely to be heard again. (Feb 3, 1909,Bush Advocate,5)

n. (See (contrast trail)

In recent years there seems to have been a tendency to use both track and trail and to differentiate between them. A trail seems to be something narrow and perhaps rather hard to follow - a way marked only by blazes or worn by animals, usually deer. A track seems to be something broader, cut or formed by man. ... A well-known older Club member made this distinction when, on hearing him speak of a deer trail, I asked him what he thought to be the difference between track and trail. I remarked that I thought it a very recent distinction, one not occurring in the Club until about 1957. He disagreed, believing it to be one he had always known. Yet, on looking through The Tramper, I could not find deer trail used until 1944, but deer track occurs from the first number in 1928 onwards, and he himself had used it in 1940. It remains to be seen whether this distinction will become established. In the meantime deer track still seems to be used far more than deer trail. (Sep 1958,Tararua,25) [NOTES: 1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' in Tararua 25]

We followed deer tracks zigzagging up through snow totara and Dracophyllum, then plugged up through soft snow to Brodrick Pass (5,308ft.), taking nearly two hours from camp. (Sep 1958,Tararua,49)

BACON There's a whacking great suspension bridge across the river, but get to the other side and there's nothing but a few pig tracks through the scrub. (1963,In the Sticks,62)

n. a man-made and maintained trail

DEMPSEY ... most mornings found Dad and Arthur out with slashers, opening up tracks ... (1964,Little World of Stewart island,47)

TURNER (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,29)

KNOX Beside the track the last of the flax bushes ... clapped encouragement. (1987,After Z-Hour,232)

DOC contractors cleared vegetation and remarked sections of track along 16 km of track in the western Tararuas. (May 2004,Footnotes,No. 21/2)

v. to pull (up-stream) by rope [pull = row]

[We] took oars and a rope to the boat. ... After more hard work we succeeded in tracking her two miles up stream. Tracking is pulling by a rope fastened to the bows. (Dec 29, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,209,1950 ed.)

BATHGATE `We'd best put him in the boat ... and track it up as far as the hotel.' ... Taking one of the oars, and placing the one end against the boat's prow, ... so as to keep the boat out from the bank, the boatman took the rope over his own shoulder, and began to slowly drag the boat up the stream. (1881,Waitaruna,253)

2 v. to follow land contours

LEVY On steep hillsides stock will tend to track and contour the land, and the ultimate surface formation of well-stocked country will be a series of broad or narrow terraces with steep slopes between them upon which stock seldom tread. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,254,1970 ed.)

track-and-bowl¶

adj. ??

Back during the 1870s, this was kakapo country and from my sub-standard camp I can easily visualise where the main track-and-bowl systems of this large parrot (now extinct in the area) would have been located. (Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

track-and-trace¶

v.

Mainfreight has meanwhile improved the ability of customers to track-and-trace their goods over the Web, while they are in warehouses and in transit. (Apr 7, 2003,Dominion Post,C6)

track-cutter¶

n. [track cutter, trackcutter]

BROWN G. Snow, who had been ... a track-cutter on the Mangles, undertook ... to cut the track from Walkers to the Grey. (1976,Difficult Country,48)

HOLDEN A shot distance below them he came to a gametrail so pronounced and so well defined that a party of Forest Service trackcutters, using grubber, slasher and spade, might have fashioned it out of a steep hillface. (1976,Razorback,76)

Even then he returned to make sure we were leaving, and finally departed in a glorious gallop which was the envy of four track-cutters toiling up the ridge to Hector. (Jan 4, 1932,Evening Post,3)

As regards Big Bay, the presence of a surveyor and track-cutters will enable the place to be fairly prospected for the first time. (Oct 1, 1886,Otago Daily Times,4)

The Okarita paper says:- Several of the track cutters have arrived in town during the week, having completed their contracts, or done so at least as far as their instructions serve. (Sep 3, 1867,Grey River Argus,2)

About 4 p.m. the track cutters reached a SWIFT RIVER coming in on the left, rushing down a steep rocky face, then over a rough bed. (Apr 9, 1896,Otago Witness,51)

As we are given to understand that Dr Bell's field work is to be commenced on the Coast, he should be proceeded by poineers in the way of track cutters. (Mar 27, 1905,Grey River Argus,2)

track-cutting¶

n. [track cutting]

PRINCE The writer started from Quinten McKinnon's (track cutting) camp, now called Trackton ... (1889,Diary of a Trip,5)

MAY Besides coal surveys and track-cutting on the West Coast, the Nelson Provincial Government endeavoured to shorten the inland route from the capital to the middle valley of the Buller, (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,75,1962 ed.)

The deepest parts of the forest have not yet been pierced by the track-maker, though this work will probably be undertaken in the near future. (Feb 7, 1914,Evening Post,10)

The subsidy of 30s granted in such cases by the Unemployment Board will be increased to 35s a week while the men are engaged in track cutting. (Jun 2, 1933,Evening Post,9)

Tentative selection of homestead sites has been made and road and track cutting has been mapped out. (Jan 17, 1945,Evening Post,7)

This man piloted the surveyors and track-makers of Gippsland through the ranges, and marked out the way for them to follow through country that could not have been faced without the assistance of great skill and courage. (Jul 23, 1902,Otago Witness,37)

As I now had done all I promised and was anxious to get home as soon as I could, and there being three days track cutting to do on the way back, and also there being chances of rain, I thought by coming down the river and getting the steamer about the 15th or 16th, I would be as soon home as going overland, especially as I had to come to Nelson. (Oct 23, 1863,Colonist (Nelson),3)

Farther north, in the Levin hinterland, track-cutting has recently been instituted on a moderately extensive scale, and the present article deals briefly with the progress to date. (Dec 5, 1929,Evening Post,17)

Mining affairs in the district are by no means of discouraging nature, and if more attention was paid by the Government to that indispensable desideratum of track cutting, to allow miners to penetrate into the interior, so from them alone must fresh discoveries emanate - no new ground having for some time been opened - everything would be more prosperous. (Aug 20, 1870,Grey River Argus,4)

However, he felt confident, and when he found that track cutting had to be done he took the party up the hill. (Apr 5, 1918,Poverty Bay Herald,7)

Of what use is it for men, who will dare almost anything for the gold, to rush about the country and find payble ground if the Government is not also prepared to venture a few pounds in track cutting? (Oct 31, 1863,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

WANTED - Man for track cutting, wages 8s per day. (Dec 10, 1904,Bush Advocate,1)

The first 18 days were spent in track cutting and prospecting in a north-eastern direction from Port's hut. (Mar 12, 1896,Otago Witness,17)

n. (See New Zealand Railways Corporation)

trackies¶

n. tracksuit styled trousers [also used: UK, Aust]

Jennifer Ludlam donned slippers, trackies and a broad New Zild accent to play the white-trash Connie, in Potiki's Memory of Stone. (Jan 3, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),63)

Victoria University students Natasha, 22 (commerce), and Nicola, 21 (tourism), turned up last week wearing the wrong clothes - trackies - so they are back this week in shorts - and heels - for their first lesson. (Aug 13, 2005,Press, The,13)

Levina, a vision in brown singlet and matching trackies, tell us she's 27. (Jan 4, 2006,Dominion Post,A6)

tracking¶

n. track or the railing from which curtains or drapes are suspended [Jim writes: In relation to curtains or drapes there is no entry for these words in any dictionary I have seen., Track may be covered, though imprecisely, under one of the general definitions but tracking is not. Both words are in standard use in NZ. They seem likely to be international English but may be worth checking out.]

n. [(whaling)]

[We] took oars and a rope to the boat. ... After more hard work we succeeded in tracking her two miles up stream. Tracking is pulling by a rope fastened to the bows. (Dec 29, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,209,1950 ed.)

PRESHAW Up to here I went in a whale boat, which was partly pulled, partly poled, and the rest of the distance dragged up by the crew - they up to their waists in water, with a rope over their shoulders. This was termed `tracking'. (1888,Banking Under Difficulties,133) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

n.

LEVY In areas where much timber remained unburnt, tracking of the burn was necessary to enable stock to graze all parts of it freely, because the ability of stock to graze and tread the burn largely determined whether the succession was to grass or back to forest. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,246,1970 ed.)

trackmaker¶

n. [track maker, trackmaker]

Then in April 1864 a note was brought by a track-maker and left at the store for Moffat ... (1976,Difficult Country,34)

HENDERSON Roy Mytton, trackmaker, musterer, Mount Arthur and Cobb Valley, Motueka, August 1979. Ibid. 117 On trackmaking over the hills and far away, with precious few witnesses, with payment being made by the distance covered, usually so much per chain, the sceptical are inclined to remark: `If there's only the trackmaker and the overseer there, just the two of them present on the job, ...' Ibid. 122 The rare perspiring trackmaker and the flitting packman were Chaffey's passing neighbours, who'd drop in and leave stores and mail from time to time. (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,7)

This man piloted the surveyors and track-makers of Gippsland through the ranges, and marked out the way for them to follow through country that could not have been faced without the assistance of great skill and courage. (Jul 23, 1902,Otago Witness,37)

The deepest parts of the forest have not yet been pierced by the track-maker, though this work will probably be undertaken in the near future. (Feb 7, 1914,Evening Post,10)

.. and Satruday night was spent in the tents of the surveyors and track-makers a little above the Orongorongo bed. (Oct 25, 1921,Evening Post,7)

Besides the amateur effort, quite a good story could be told of the work of the professional track-maker and hut-builder associated with the club. (May 10, 1930,Evening Post,8)

Another jolly evening, the Abbot's stew was consumed to the last drop, the track makers, three in number, had joined the party before tea and they took part in the enjoyments of the evening. (Apr 27, 1907,Taranaki Herald,3)

trackmaking¶

n. [track making, track-making]

HENDERSON When fifteen-year-old Les Waghorn, up in the mountains on trackmaking, called in with the mail, she always gave him a little packet, ... Ibid. 117 On trackmaking over the hills and far away, with precious few witnesses, with payment being made by the distance covered, usually so much per chain, the sceptical are inclined to remark: `If there's only the trackmaker and the overseer there, just the two of them present on the job, ...' (1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,28)

Local committees in Greytown and Otaki have struggled valiantly with the work of track-making and hut-building, but the burden of maintenance and extension of this accommodation requires assistance from Wellington. (Jul 8, 1919,Evening Post,6)

In reporting to the executive on the progress of the track-making work on the Otaki side, the two members spoke in glowing terms of the excellent work done by the track-making party. (Feb 11, 1921,Evening Post,8)

Excellent work, says Mr. F. W. Vosseler, who has just returned from a trip into the country at the back of the Ohau River, has been done in track-making by the Palmerston North Tramping Club. (Dec 27, 1932,Evening Post,8)

Another in the Tararuas was well advanced when war forced the suspension of track-making. (Dec 28, 1944,Evening Post,6)

The Board must recollect that the summer is passing away and the time is flying when branch road and track making could be done cheaper and more efficiently than in the rainy season and short days. (Nov 26, 1874,Grey River Argus,2)

The most of the river claims at the top end are worked out, and the parties are setting in to the terraces on the banks, some of them are doing fairly well, but the body of wash is small, and will run out very soon, and unless the Government assist the miners in track making, to open up the country further ahead, there will not be much encouragement for men to come here, or for those that are here to stay. (Dec 6, 1892,Bruce Herald,2)

Track making is here understood to mean clearing off the timber only - no formation. (Mar 6, 1880,Otago Witness,8)

Aware, however, of the known procrastination and apathy of the Government in all matters relating to the real advancement of Westland, but particularly in track-making, they shake their heads doubtingly, and fear that the Waimea district will fare no better than the rest. (Aug 27, 1866,West Coast Times,2)

There is a lot of road work and track making going on, in fact more than at any period since the days of Clark and Ryan. (Jan 27, 1903,West Coast Times,3)

tracks¶

n.

SUTTON-SMITH Action terms related to the movements of the marbles are, Throughs and No Throughs, Tracks and Clears, Stops and Rolls, Lay-Up, Manyies, Kiss, Ons, Gees, Haystacks, Stays, Spiders Can't Cross a River etc. Action Terms related to taking an opponent's marbles are Fires, Double-Hits and Forces. (1953,Unorganized Games,2/769)

SUTTON-SMITH Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. (1972,Folkgames of Children,175)

SUTTON-SMITH Here are some [marble] terms from Taranaki around 1880-1890: firsts, lay-up, stakes, tips, sticking-taw, nothings, anythings, fade-it, knuckledown stiff, dubs, finking [sic, ?funking], sips, spanning, placing; and from Dunedin School in 1949: knee high, manyies, tracks, screws, nuts, sleets, kills, forces, dig, dubs, cheats. (1981,History of Children's Play,269)

tracky dacks¶

n. (informal) tracksuit trousers [cf. trackies]

..wearing supportive stretchy fabrics such as nylon-lycra blends on your body during exercise will give you significantly greater leg-power than you'll get in your sloppy old tracky dacks. (Jul 4, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),31)

tract and treacle¶

phr. (See (cf. sugar and flour (blanket) policy)

HURSTHOUSE A mere bit of [Gore-Browne's] old Tract and Treacle' Policy [towards the Maoris]. <i>Ibid.</i> 53 He [George Grey] is a Governor who in his former reign in New Zealand was an administrator of thatTract and Treacle' Policy toward the Maori sketched at page 34. (1865,England's NZ War,52)

traction engine¶

n.

The `Canterbury Press' notices the arrival in the Province of the first traction engine ... intended to travel with a threshing machine (Apr 22, 1867,Otago Daily Times,5) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

tractor country¶

1 n. (Rural) land that is too steep for a truck, but can be accessed by a tractor with steel wheels or tracks.

.. it must be understood that this land, though it was treated as tractor country, and all pastures were sown and cultivated seed-beds following preliminary cropping ... (Nov 5, 1953,NZ Farmer,4)

It is mainly wheel tractor country. (Sep 27, 1962,NZ Farmer,4)

Only eight to 10 acres are too steep to be called tractor country. (Apr 1968,NZ Journal of Agriculture,40)

Contour can be described as rolling to steep. Mostly crawler tractor country. (Sep 27, 1973,NZ Farmer,139)

Almost all the farm's grassed area is tractor country. [crawler tractor country; wheel tractor country] (Feb 1993,NZ Dairy Exporter,85)

tractor tray¶

1 n. (Rural) a platform fitted to the back of a tractor on which to transport stock or implements. (See back tray)

For sale - .. 200 Corriedale cryptorchid lambs; tractor tray and crate. (Nov 10, 2000,Press, The,39)

tractor tube¶

n. an inner tube from a tractor tyre, usually used for flotation

HARGREAVES Not many of us had boats. I used to use tractor tubes for many years. (1998,On the Next Tide,99)

tractor-spinner¶

n. (Rural) a revolving fertiliser distributor, used on a tractor. (See spinner)

TAIT Topdressing was done by hand until after World War II, when contractors' trucks were used until a tractor-spinner was introduced in 1955. (1958,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol II,468)

tractor-spread¶

1 v. (Rural) [ topdressing] to spread fertiliser or spray chemicals with tractor equipment.

This winter he tractor-spread five tonne of urea on the 67ha of new grass, and 10 tonne of DAP Sustain on 50ha of flats. (Oct 3, 2002,Taranaki Daily News,18)

trade¶

adj. (Rural) [of sale stock ] sold for local butchery.

Trade and lighter hoggets sold well. (Nov 4, 1999,NZ Farmer,25)

There was a good yarding of useful lambs which started on a strong note with good trade lambs selling up to $2.60/kg carcase weight. (Nov 25, 1999,NZ Farmer,29)

n. trade goods

BURNS The only plan that he [the Maori chief] advised was for me to get a large war canoe, and take the best part of my trade along with me, and proceed to Poverty Bay, ... (1844,NZ Chief,7)

WILLIAM HALL If I had a little trade to pay [124] the natives with, .. (Jan 12, 1816,Letter) [NOTES: 1816 Jan 12 William Hall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 123-124]

trade, the¶

n. the liquor trade

In the past, the licensing laws had been framed on representations made by the two extreme parties - the prohibitionists and the "trade". (Oct 5, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,22)

1 n. (Rural) [stock sales] the local butchery.

TAIT The wether lambs are fattened for the trade. (1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,100)

TradeMe¶

n. (trademark) an online trading site [TradeMe is usually printed with the capital 'TM' in superscript.]

The taxman is tracking top traders on TradeMe as the website's success turns it into a valuable law enforcement tool. ... [D6] With such a large audience at the fingertips of anyone with a home computer, it is no surprise that thousands see TradeMe as a way to leave their day jobs and become online traders. ... [D7] Now, a new generation of entrepreneurs is using TradeMe as a platform from which to start retail businesses, keeping down costs by working from home and tapping into the website's 1.2 million members. (Oct 30, 2005,Sunday Star Times,A2)

Newseditor Keith Ng listed a "liberated" copy of the controversial edition of Salient on trademe.co.nz to raise money for VUWSA ... Mr Edgeler though disappointed by Smith's listings says he will not complain to trademe on behalf of Salient. (Oct 20, 2005,Wellingtonian,6)

Trades Council¶

n. a regional organisation which serves as the collective voice of the trade union movement in its region.

tradesman¶

n. in NZ applied to a skilled worker, a craftsman, not a shopkeeper

tradie¶

n. tradesman [Also Australian]

In his defence Mr Williamson was speaking to building industry awards crowd and could possibly have expected the tradies to at least handle and enjoy a bit of rough humour. (Sep 10, 2010,Waikato Times,6)

The Competition encompasses all facets of a Tradies job; from carpentry to brick laying, painting to plumbing - even ute handling and excavation equipment skills will be tested. (Feb 15, 2007,Scoop)

The last mob who came through just after February 22 said they'd send the tradies round pronto to tear it down and we never saw hide nor hear [sic] of them. (Jul 25, 2011,Dominion Post,B5)

traditional¶

n.

This was my last traditional against Stream, and it was good to beat them. (Jun 14, 2001,Evening Post,1)

traffic cop¶

n. (informal) a traffic officer [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

This was the beginning of a fraught relationship between Kiwi drivers - especially the more macho males - and 'traffic cops', which was to continue for many decades. (Jun 2003,AA Directions,43)

traffic inspector¶

n. traffic officer [1947 Smith in 1961 Reid 151]

traffic john¶

n. traffic cop

HARVEY We waited until the traffic bloke with the white hands gave us the okay and then crossed with all the other people. ... we stopped and waited to see if this traffic john got squashed between the trams when two of them passed each other. (1964,Any Old Dollars Mister?,24)

traffic officer¶

n. [1944 Scott in 1961 Reid 142]

trail¶

n. (See (contrast track)

BEST ... bush trails [alo uses anent, hapless',wend his way' etc] (1906,TrNZI,38/159)

(Mikonui) ... a foot-track, which branching off near Frew Creek from the Whitcombe Pass trail, leads to Frew Saddle ... (1908,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.6 (N.S.) 21) [NOTES: 1908 Morgan NZ Geol. Survey Bull. No.6 (N.S.) 21]

HYDE There was a dark trail, ... and a stream came with edgings of fine malachite ferns, ... Purple berries lay fallen, rich as damsons but not as big, and good only for the fantails ... (1938,Godwits Fly, The,126,1970 ed.)

In the bush or in the open do you tramp on a track, trail, or a path? Not on a path one may be sure, seldom if ever on a trail, almost always on a track, like a proper New Zealander. ... I well remember the shock of astonishment when in 1937 I first saw trail used in New Zealand. The word was on a rough signpost pointing out the beginning of White's Track at Piha. I am afraid I thought somewhat scornfully, Hm, some townie who has never been out of the city or set foot off a pavement has got all his ideas of New Zealand outdoor life from reading books about North America.'...[25] It is interesting to compare the use of <i>track</i> and <i>trail</i> in <i>The Tramper</i>. Through the first volumes <i>track</i> is always used when referring to an actual track, and <i>trail </i>occurs rarely and then only in the expression <i>blazed trail</i> or more or less figuratively -to fare forth on the trail'. In 1935 there is the first definite use of trail as a synonym for track in a reference to the Handbook of Arthur's Pass National Park'. It is significant that it occurs in reference to Arhtur's Pass for trail seems to have come into use in Canterbury in this sense before it reached Wellington. It occurs once or twice in the first volume of the <i>Canterbury Mountaineer</i>, and there is the <i>B.B. Trail</i> in the Arthur's Pass Hand book of 1935. From 1939 till 1940 in <i>The Tramper, trail</i> is used moderately frequently for an actual track, e.g.an old Maori trail', a miner's trail', but only by the one writer, a Wellington member of the Canterbury Mountaineering Club. <i>Trail</i> shows no sign of ousting <i>track. </i> <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,24</i>) [NOTES: 1958 Sep Ruth MasonTrack and Trail' in Tararua 24]

In recent years there seems to have been a tendency to use both track and trail and to differentiate between them. A trail seems to be something narrow and perhaps rather hard to follow - a way marked only by blazes or worn by animals, usually deer. A track seems to be something broader, cut or formed by man. ... A well-known older Club member made this distinction when, on hearing him speak of a deer trail, I asked him what he thought to be the difference between track and trail. I remarked that I thought it a very recent distinction, one not occurring in the Club until about 1957. He disagreed, believing it to be one he had always known. Yet, on looking through The Tramper, I could not find deer trail used until 1944, but deer track occurs from the first number in 1928 onwards, and he himself had used it in 1940. It remains to be seen whether this distinction will become established. In the meantime deer track still seems to be used far more than deer trail. (Sep 1958,Tararua,25) [NOTES: 1958 Sep Ruth Mason `Track and Trail' (deer shooters')]

From the top we had seen many deer trails on the other bank, but there were none on our side, so we fought our way down the bank ... (Sep 1958,Tararua,35)

(1959,Tararua,xiii/50)

TURNER (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,29, 161)

There's never a trail like the home trail, / At the end of a toilsome day. (May 7, 1919,Poverty Bay Herald,7)

n. ?a trace

The pioneer prospectors had discovered `trails of gold' in the creeks on the western side of the valley ... (1912,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,(NS)No.15/8) [NOTES: (Bell and Fraser, Waihi-Tairua)]

n. ?the `innards' of a small bird

MEREDITH They [Maoris] cook a pigeon by covering it with plastic clay, ... When cooked, they crack the clay, which retains all the feathers - and the gravy. The `trail' shrinks into a small ball, and is easily removed. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,37,1935 ed.) [NOTES: c1872 in c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935) 37]

trail a pike¶

phr. to enlist, to join up [in SOED5, labelled 'arch.' (serve as a soldier)]

BRUNO The more soldierly and less crusading characters of us rude ... private soldiers who stampeded to trail a pike early in the show for seven-and-six ... per diem. -->1944 Bruno Desert Daze 16 Plum answered promptly to trail a pike for Democracy. (1944,Desert Daze,(foreword))

trailer queen¶

n.

"They are for people who really care about cars and beautiful engineering so you don't get people saying "Look at that prat in the Porsche," he says. "It's pretty well-known in my patch, but whenever I take it anywhere else in the country people stop to talk about it, particularly because it's not a trailer queen." (Jan 4, 2002,Dominion,12)

trailer-sailer¶

n.

In real life, a town like that would be full of racist senior citizens, violent ferals living out their Mad Max fantasies and other assorted white trash. (Sep 4, 1999,Dominion,18)

BURCHFIELD trailer-sailer Chiefly N.Z. & Austral. Also without hyphen. [f. TRAILER sb. 6b + SAILER 2b.] A sailing vessel, usu. one up to 8 metres in length, that can be carried on a motor-vehicle trailer. Usu. with a centreboard or retractable keel. (1988,Lexicographical & Linguistic Studies,196)

Dust off your dinghy and un-trailor that sailor. (Jan 10, 2001,Capital Times,3)

(heading) Equipment for a 21-foot trailer-sailer. (Jan 1973,Motor-Boating & Sailing,170/1)

The resurgence of this class and the Idle Along in other centres points up the lack of a viable family centreboard boat other than a trailer sailer for fresher conditions. (Dec 1976,Sea Spray,66/1)

The retractable centreplate allows the trailer-sailer to float in extremely shallow water. (1977,Australian Sailing,47/3)

Trailer sailers .. must be capable of going to sea, at least in semi-protected waters, and must be capable of being towed behind a family car. (1981,Guinness Guide to Sailing,viii. 86)

After mucking about in a variety of small boats, including trailer-sailers on the Swan River. (Jan 31, 1984,Sydney Bulletin,35/1)

[Advt] "Trailer Sailer" Centreboard Yacht... Trail it! Sail it! Power it! (May 1963,Sea Spray,84)

[Hdg] Trailer-Sailer Sloop (Oct 1962,Sea Spray,41)

[Advt] TrailerSailers (Plywood)... Trailer Sailer - 21' x 7'11". Four Bunks. Centreboard or Fixed Keel. ... People interested in forming a New Zealand Trailer Sailer Association write direct to Secretary, .. Takapuna North. (Dec 1964,Sea Spray,116)

Trailer Sailer Association... The inaugural meeting.. got off to a good start with an informal talk by Richard Hartley, designer of the Trailer Sailers. (Aug 1965,Sea Spray,00) [NOTES: Check page number]

Trailer Sailer Association... To create interest in our newly formed association, the committee decided to display a 16ft. Trailer Sailer.. at the Auckland Show... When the Australians built the first fleet of Trailer Sailer 16s a new era was born and now the class has spread back across the Tasman to the man who designed it... Designer Richard Hartley, Auckland, New Zealand. (Dec 1965,Sea Spray,112)

All the attributes of a small keeler are crammed into a Dick-Hartley designed trailer sailer. Ibid 83 He is reasonably handy to Tauranga Harbour and.. Lake Karapiro where the Cambridge Yacht Club sponsors the Waikato Division of the Trailer sailer Association. (Sep 1970,NZ Boating World,82)

n.

Once he and Cliff shot 100 black swans - a whole trailerload - on the wing. (Apr 1998,North & South,125)

Training College¶

n. the former name of a College of Education

SARGESON (1967,Hangover,28)

SARGESON (1967,Hangover,28)

PHILLIP So she had no one to turn to for comfort except her training coll friend Alison Mulvihill, ... (1984,South Pacific Street,91)

TEXIDOR Everyone goes to varsity or to Training College. (1987,In Fifteen Minutes,204) [NOTES: a1964 Texidor in 1987 In Fifteen Minutes 204]

AMOS WILBY 1869 - occupation, driving tram from Marsden to Paeroa with passengers and luggage, in conjunction with the Greymouth train. (1869,Diary) [NOTES: 1869 Diary in 1914 Pfaff The Diggers' Story 116]

I believe that it would be risky to open the Training College again next year. (Jul 23, 1934,Napier Daily Telegraph,6)

HENDERSON The Depression closed the training colleges for four years. (1983,Down from Marble Mountain,108)

She continued reading and went north to training college. (Nov 26, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),58)

training farm¶

n. (Rural) a state-run farm where cadets attend a residential course on practical and theoretical aspects of farming. (See repatriation farm)

Cadets or students on training-farms should have an occasional lesson in blacksmithing (including horse-shoeing), joinery, and harness-mending. (Feb 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,91)

The Director [of Repatriation] .. soon after the passing of the Repatriation Act in 1918, set out, with the assistance of the Department of Agriculture, to establish a training-farm at Tauherenikau, in the Wairarapa district, where returned soldiers suffering from chest trouble could be trained in poultry-keeping, bee-keeping, horticulture and general light farming so as to enable them to take up small holdings of their own under the Discharged Soldiers Settlement Act. The accompanying photographs afford a very good idea of the training-farm. (Apr 20, 1922,NZ Journal of Agriculture,237)

training run¶

n. (in rugby union during training) practice in running with and handling the ball : going for a run [1986 L.Bauer. (Not general use by harriers, x-country people, or the use of running to get fit; not roadwork)]

(Sports News) The Kiwi League team will have two training runs in Sydney today. (Jul 17, 1986,Radio NZ / National Radio)

tram¶

n. a bush-tram

(1952,NZ Forest Glossary)

WILSON Frank ... went to the mill and, selecting the best boards, loaded them onto the tram trucks. (1955,Land of My Children,28)

OWEN & PERKINS In some cases steam engines were employed [to get logs out of bush], or locomotives running on a bush railway, or `tram'. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,161) [NOTES: (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country)]

v.

REED It had been the intention of the k[auri] T[imber] C[ompany] to tram the Kauri in from No Gum Camp ... (1953,Story of the Kauri, The,259)

It must be gratifying to the shareholders to know we have commenced to prepare ore for the crusher - tramming vein stuff on the floors at the rate of 50 wagons per day. (Jan 25, 1867,Daily Southern Cross,4)

The drives, too are seldom straight, but wind about without any object, which is a great hindrance both in tramming out the stuff, and in ventilating the mine. (Aug 9, 1869,Daily Southern Cross,6)

The quartz has to be trammed from the mine to the machine site, and when once in the trucks a little further to run would be no great object; and I believe the same length of tram would be required to bring in the wood as to take the stone to the water. (Dec 10, 1870,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

n. a bush-tram

BOWMAN The Tram, Deborah Bay: From the tram-line used for bringing timber from the saw-mill to the beach, and for carriage of goods to and from the "Taipo" powder factory. (1948,Port Chalmers,222)

He will be able to fetch the logs right in to the mill by means of a tram without using the junkers at all. (Mar 17, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

OWEN & PERKINS Bullocks weren't the only method.. used to get the logs out. In some cases steam engines were employed, or locomotives running on a bush railway, or 'tram'. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,161)

MAHONEY Bush trams varied greatly in length and life expectancy. The longest log haul was 31 km on the Matahina tramway... Most bush trams in New Zealand were laid to a gauge of 3'0" (914 mm) or to the 3'6" (1067 mm) used by the NZR system. (1998,Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The,17)

VIRTUE The tram stopped in the middle of the bridge. (1987,Redemption of Elsdon Bird, The,3) [NOTES: 1988 edition]

n. street car

Tram - street car, trolley car. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,39)

Tram - street car, trolley car. (1944,US War Dept. Short Guide to NZ,39)

BAXTER I came to Training College...It was possible at that time to take two Varsity subjects a year. (1979,Collected Poems,xxiii) [NOTES: (1961 The Spike 61-64) in 1979 Baxter Collected Poems xxiii]

tram truck¶

n.

.. 4 tram trucks complete (Dec 1, 1920,Thames Star,1)

Tram Trucks, from 3rd May to 25th June .. GBP40 13s. 3d. (Jul 20, 1855,Daily Southern Cross,6)

With this object in view, we took possession of a large vacant shed situated at the shore end of the jetty, where we found an old tram truck and some pieces of timber out of which we readily improvised a table. (Mar 27, 1880,Tuapeka Times,5)

3 sets tram trucks ... (May 18, 1909,Bush Advocate,8)

FOR SALE, one Team of six Working Bullocks, broken in, four below five years of age, with yokes and chains; GBP6 a head; also, one Tram Truck, with wide wheels, and various Tools; cheap. (Jul 27, 1891,Evening Post,3)

To-day, all kinds of contrivances for carrying goods are in vogue; hand-barrows, tram trucks, and all the lame, halt, and blind conveyances that can be raked up from every hold and corner in the town are pressed into the service. (Oct 2, 1872,Evening Post,2)

PATENTS .. J. Cannell, tram truck safety catch ... (Mar 16, 1910,Poverty Bay Herald,7)

n.

WILLIAMS To gain entry into the hall proper, ... you'll have to slip the doorkeeper (dressed for the part in a white coat and old tram-bag around his neck) four dollars, (1979,Skin Deep,6)

TAYLOR The tram barn was just a couple of hundred yards along the road [in Auckland.] (1978,Twilight Hour)

tram-car¶

n. bush tram

WILSON We had grand weather for our return journey from Greymouth, and began it ... by a drive ... through the Bush in a tram-car that went on wooden lines. (1894,In the Land of the Tui,234) [NOTES: 1891 Sep 28 in 1894 Wilson Land of the Tui 234]

A villainous attempt was made yesterday morning to throw the Kanieri tram car off the rails, and a serious accident would probably have ensued had not Mr Smith, the manager, providentially walked down the line ahead of the carriage, and removed three large stones that some scoundrel had placed upon the rails. (Nov 20, 1867,West Coast Times,2)

At an inquest on the child killed by the tram car, medical evidence showed that the skull was fractured, which caused death by pressure of blood on the brain. (Mar 24, 1881,West Coast Times,2)

Unfortunately the party was put to some extra fatigue and inconvenience by an accident happening to the fine saloon tram car that was to convey them up and down the valley. (Jan 21, 1870,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

tram-cart¶

n. (See cf. jinker,cat,etc)

These logs are then rolled on to a kind of sleigh or tram-cart by the help of screw-jacks, and conveyed by horses to the mill. (1891,TrNZI,23/488)

At the inquest touching the death of Miss Muriel A B Taylor, killed by being run over by a Kaikorai cable tram cart as she was going to work, the evidence showed that several passengers saw her walking parallel to the line, and then attempting to cross[.] (Nov 30, 1903,Grey River Argus,3)

tram-laying¶

n. laying a bush tramway

HENDERSON ... the guv'nor offered them a good tram-laying job at the Waitahu mill ... (1961,Friends in Chains,71)

It is there where everything new and astounding in the way of road-making or tram-laying first astonishes the vulgar - there where all the absurdest of engineering tricks are practised at the expense of a beneficent Government and patient population. (May 21, 1873,Wellington Independent,2)

Men for breaking down, snigging, tram-laying and slabbying are being advertised for. (Feb 5, 1916,Grey River Argus,5)

10 Good Navvies for tram-laying (Feb 29, 1936,Evening Post,1)

There is every probability of tram laying being started about February to connect Mr Rathbone's mill with the bush at Makotuku. (Dec 9, 1890,Bush Advocate,2)

The Kotuku Sawmill Co advertise that they want at once three men used to tram laying. (Jan 18, 1901,Grey River Argus,2)

tram-road¶

n.

HEAPHY ... the formation of roads of any considerable lengths would not be immediately requisite [in the Chathams]: a few short tram-roads formed spells of tramping we duly arrived at our Transport's late lines ... (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),131)

spg tram road] Persons desirous of constructing Tram Roads, or forming Reservoirs or Dams on the gold field, for the purpose of washing gold, must make application to the Commissioner for permission so to do: ... (1852,Coromandel Gold Field. Provisional Regulations...) [NOTES: 1852 Coromandel Gold Field. Provisional Regulations in 1853 Swainson Auckland 162]

EARP (Quoting Gold Diggers' Provisional Regulations 1852) Persons desirous of constructing tram-roads, or forming reservoirs or dams on the goldfield, ... (1853,New Zealand (various authors/titles),252)

What is wanted is a good main road as direct as possible between Greymouth and Maori Gully, and so on to Brunner lake, and as we have said before a tramroad would probably be as easily made as it would certainly be the most economical and efficient. (Apr 2, 1867,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

That your memorialists believe that the Awaroa river might easily be rendered an excellent means of transit, and that a canal or tramroad might at a comparatively small expense be constructed from some point on that river to the Waiuku creek, by means whereof the communication between the town of Auckland and the before named Waikato district might be rendered complete. (Jun 17, 1853,Daily Southern Cross,3)

"This Council is also of the opinion that it will greatly facilitate and encourage the more speedy settlement of large areas of valuable bush country and be of high value to the operations of defence, if the intermediate portions of the aforesaid main line are opened up as soon as possible by means of a light tramroad, preparatory to the formation of the permanent way ..." (Jun 23, 1871,Evening Post,2)

tram-shed¶

n.

VIRTUE of felled timber, in the forest districts, ... (1987,Redemption of Elsdon Bird, The,5,1988 ed.)

tramline¶

n. [also tram lines, tram-lines; NB OED entries 1886, 1895, 1896, 1905 . . . NZ term if ref to bush / mining tramlines]

.. with the Mine fully established, and available at a small cost, for steam purposes, in the Manukau, the time cannot be far distant when a tramline or railroad will be laid down from Onehunga to Auckland, when the success of the Mine will exceed the most sanguine expectations of those who initiated the enterprise. (Feb 17, 1860,Daily Southern Cross,2)

The trees are felled and cross-cut into suitable lengths for conversion, the logs being conveyed to the mill by flotation, by tramline, or ... by oxen or horses. .. [332] Tram-lines are less common in the kauri district than in the southern parts of the colony. (1894,NZ Official Yearbook,331) [NOTES: (T. Kirk)]

MALFROY When setting out to put in a tram-line be careful to select ... an easy hauling grade ... (1923,Small Sawmills,15)

SMYTH They continued up the tram-line. (1930,Wooden Rails,35)

SARGESON And this, of course, was where their sawmill had been. And as they started along the track that had once carried the tramline for bringing out logs, Mr Anderson said ... You'd never have recognised this place if you'd seen it all covered with bush, Dave, he said. (1949,I Saw in My Dream,116,1974 ed.)

WILSON He led the way along the mill tramline - wooden rails laid on sleepers and ballasted with red sawdust. The bush had been hacked and smashed to build the trolly-line. Ibid. 28 Every settler chose the nearest site to the [mill] tram-line. In fact the tram-line was the road, ... ... along the tram-line came ... five loads of first-class timber drawn by three horses harnessed tandemwise. Men from the mill sat on the loads. (1955,Land of My Children,23)

DAVIN Only we had to keep to the middle of the road because it was built on an old bush tramline ... (1959,No Remittance,74)

SANSOM Barely half a mile from the tram head on a good track one met up with the head of the Maori Beach tramline, a favourite `walk-way' for visitors then. (1982,In the Grip of an Island,31)

Fletcher's sawmill was saved, but GBP100 worth of tramline was burnt. (Jan 31, 1911,Evening Post,7)

A TIMBER TRAMLINE IN THE POURAKINO BUSH. (May 6, 1903,Otago Witness,39)

MAHONEY The tramline often ran right through the middle of the tiny community. (1998,Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The,58)

HOLLAND As tramlines were built to extract the timber, the bush gradually receded around Palmerston North. (1982,History of the Manawatu River,14)

Their strengths are away from the area of bulldozing, grunting forwards marching up and down the tramlines. (Apr 16, 1999,Evening Post,28)

After lunch and a look through the mill, we set out to walk up the tramline. (Nov 9, 1920,Otago Witness,57)

At a meeting of the directors of the Champion Copper Company yesterday it was resolved to order at once from Fraser and Chalmers, of Chicago, a thirty-ton Water Jacket Smelter, and also to lay a tramline from the mine to the smelting site. (Sep 6, 1884,Wanganui Herald,2)

Of course these feed lines may be overdone, and money recklessly wasted in carrying out the idea ad absurdum, but a mistake cannot be made when a tramline is projected through a rich agricultural and mineral bearing country. (Jul 26, 1871,Timaru Herald,2)

GBP250 - ST ALBANS, near Tramline, 4 Rooms, quarter, fruit trees, lets 9s. (May 17, 1902,Star, The,5)

A portion of smashed houses, part of a boat branded "Auckland No. 3" and part branded "Auckland," also bedsteads, chairs, part of a tramline and wood work, also a portion of a wharf, have been found on the beach about two miles east of Mount Maunganui, at the entrance to Tauranga Harbour. (Sep 25, 1914,Evening Post,8)

trammer¶

n.

The linked trucks are taken by a small electric trammer, called a "mule" to the main shaft. (1944,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),2(8) : 19)

trammie¶

2 n. an industrial tram employee [Jim writes : DNZE records this as an obsolete term for the operator of a bush tramway.It is also used in relation to tramways carrying flax, as in the Shannon district.]

DREAVER The trammies took the loads of flax bundles on horse-drawn trucks to the weighbridge where each man's tally was credited. (1984,Horowhenua County and its People,147)

HENDERSON The trammie was at the skids with his tandem-yoked horses ready to load the logs on the tram. (1967,Return to Open Country,236)

trammie/trammy¶

n. a city tram employee; a tram-driver or tram-conductor

Generally, the Trammy' had been much misunderstood. ... [345/5/5] Many there were who refused to believe that theTrammies' would do such a thing, [i.e. stop work] but it was perceptible that as two o'clock drew nigh, the conductors and the motormen meant it, and the street cars were gradually deserted. (Feb 3, 1912,NZ Truth,345/5/4)

Then he slathers up the `trammies'/ As the conductor goes through. (1926,Transport Workers' Song Book)

Two trammies ... waiting with ticket-boxes under their arms. (1947,Landfall,3/162) [NOTES: J. Reece Cole]

I would include among New Zealand English words: trammie: tram conductor (May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class)

trammie n. tram-driver or conductor. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

TURNER Established diminutives are ... possie (position or place), ... jelly (gelignite), trammie (tramway worker), ... and shrewdie (a shrewd person). (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,118)

trammie ... n. tram-driver or conductor. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

ANDERSON Little did that trammie realise that I had just reached the point where one more Ding-ding would have precipitated a tribal war in Conon Street, Invercargill. (1975,Milford Road,131)

In fact, the [Christchurch] trammies, justly wild, made up their minds to strike. (Apr 7, 1906,NZ Truth,42/5/3)

[Hdg] A Trammie's Reminiscences. In July 1942 I joined the trams. (Aug 2003,NZ Memories,No. 43/45)

A Wellington trammie played an exciting game of "tag" with an electric trolley guide rope in Kent Tce yesterday afternoon while other trams piled up behind. (Jun 18, 1949,Southern Cross (Wgton),2)

When He opens wide the portals / And you're stepping softly through. / Will you ask the lord to guide you / To those trammies once you knew. (Oct 2003,NZ Memories,39)

Trammies¶

n. [Tramway Players rugby team]

Further donations in connection with the relief workers' Christmas tree are as follows .. "Kilbirnie trammies," GBP1 (Dec 21, 1931,Evening Post,11)

University "B" were too good for the Trammies, scoring 17 to 5. (Jun 23, 1927,NZ Truth,12)

Now, the Trammies ask, how could they possibly rebut evidence they were not allowed to hear? (Jul 24, 1930,NZ Truth,16)

tramming¶

n. [mining context, OED 1983, not clear that this is a New Zealandism.]

It is purposed shortly to make use of this connection for trucking purposes, thus avoiding the present low level tramming through the mine of drainage water. (Jan 10, 1916,Grey River Argus,8)

TENDERS are invited for Cutting, Logging, and Tramming, for the Cheltenham Sawmill for the ensuing twelve months. (Jan 3, 1888,Feilding Star,4)

The Geldenhuis was the first deep level worked, and the stopes that caved in were worked some years back, and the levels were used more for tramming than anything else. (May 21, 1906,Thames Star,1)

tramming carriage¶

n.

He was killed whilst removing the log from the tramming carriage, the log rolling on him, and crushing his neck and face. (Nov 21, 1863,Daily Southern Cross,4)

tramp¶

n. trip or tramping trip is NZ trampers' common usage, where British usage might prefer `walking expedition; hike' (OED 1859) for something similar

WALKER on the tramp I have a better chance of getting these things than Bill as I am nearly always on the tramp and he is in the store always. (Apr 5, 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker)) [NOTES: (Central Otago)]

WILSON [? walking trip] A good breakfast, and off we start on our tramp. ... On the hill side sometimes as high as 1000 feet up, we see numerous races or flumes as they are called used by diggers to take water to sluice the gold out of the stuff the gold is found in. (Jan 30, 1873,Diary) [NOTES: 1873 Jan 30 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 158]

COWAN Led by Julian with his slash-hook ... - bushmanlike figure enough was `Wirihana' for he ... travelled bare-legged in Maori fashion all that week's tramp - (1916,Bush Explorers,9)

REISCHEK During our tramp he told me much about his people and the Maori wars. (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,156,1933 ed.)

Words that concern walking and moving about might be expected to be of interest to a tramper. First there is the word tramp itself. Though the Club in 1919 was the first in New Zealand and probably the first in the world to take the name of tramping club, and by its usage and activities has played a considerable part in establishing the term, the meaning we give to tramp was not of New Zealand origin, for it was used colloquially in England as early as 1908 for to go on foot, to go on a walking expedition'. The nature of the country into which the expeditions are made may often be very different from that [29] where the term originated, but the essential idea is the same. ... <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,28</i>) [NOTES: 1958 Sep Ruth MasonTrack and Trail' in Tararua 28-29]

SCRYMGEOUR He was passionately fond of long tramps with his breach [sic] loader in search of sport, and ... he and Willam Steuart soon became fast friends. They tramped the creeks and over the ridges, carrying back their game, ... (1960,Memories of Maoriland,10)

(Aug 3, 1966,Weekly News,7/4)

We were a small railway party and had completed the tramp of nine miles through the bush to a mountain hut. (1926,NZ Railways Magazine,1(6) : 9)

We were rested sufficiently to commence the last portion of our tramp the following morning. (1929,NZ Railways Magazine,4(7) : 45)

There is absolutely no need to make yourself a hideous spectacle merely because you are going for a tramp. (1929,NZ Railways Magazine,4(8) : 53)

... it is very hard work humping your blankets and tucker. ...[sic] On the tramp along the Buller ... you must reckon on being wet through half your time. (May 12, 1864,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/111,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond, Nelson)]

MACLEAN But at first [women] were excluded from the more adventurous expeditions that appeared on the club schedule the following year headed 'Reasonably Strenuous Tramps - Gentlemen Only.' (1994,Tararua : the Story of a Mountain Range,129)

n. a trampoline [ORIGIN: abbreviation]

PROFESSOR S JOHNSTON A notice outside a Mangere motel: `Children's Tramp' (Jun 1987,Personal Communication)

v. to travel on foot in unroaded country usually for recreation and esp. as a member of a TRAMPING CLUB; to hike; to bush-walk

The thought of again tramping that thirteen miles with heavy packs was not pleasing. (1929,NZ Railways Magazine,4(7) : 43)

WAKEFIELD ... some strange pakehas would come and take the land while I was tramping about.) (Mar 27, 1840,Diary,1839 ed.)

... encumbered only with a blanket ... they have tramped from diggings to diggings, from rush to rush - free and unfettered. (1866,NZ & Australian Songster,9,1970 ed.)

I'll have to tramp it [sc the distance].] (1900,NZ Illustrated Magazine,2/591)

SCRYMGEOUR He was passionately fond of long tramps with his breach [sic] loader in search of sport, and ... he and Willam Steuart soon became fast friends. They tramped the creeks and over the ridges, carrying back their game, ... (1960,Memories of Maoriland,10) [NOTES: transitional' usage]

GILKISON Along the road you can `hike', but over the winding trails and trackless hills you can really tramp. (1940,Peaks, Packs & Mountain Tracks,80)

GILKISON Along the road you can `hike', but over the winding trails and trackless hills you can really tramp. (1940,Peaks, Packs & Mountain Tracks,80)

I would include among New Zealand English words: to tramp: to hike or walk (May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class)

MANTELL Tramping gear instead of business clothes. ... Had a tramping pack ready just in case. ... He was always going off on tramping trips, seems like.'He didn't tramp all the way back to Wellington!' (1980,Murder or Three, A,155)

McGILL Peter was tramping Te Anau, having tramped Britain and Borneo. ... I asked if he had met a gaunt tramper called Maurice walking round the mountains. (1985,G'day Country,170)

A Man tramped into the Pines. (Jun 19, 1914,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,8) [NOTES: capital for pine is correct - caption.]

MACLEAN I have tramped and climbed in the Southern Alps for over forty years, and yet the Tararua retains its magic for me. (1994,Tararua : the Story of a Mountain Range,29)

v. (informal) go fast

ca1938 Havelock e.g. His new car can really tramp. In the half mile he was tramping along well ahead of the rest and eventually won by a big margin. (May 23, 1969,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12/1)

It was a souped-up Ford. They were tramping, in anybody's language. (May 23, 1969,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

2 n. a tramping route

The [Hutt Valley] Tramping Club - always seeking new `tramps' - made an official trip there. (1936,Hills and Valleys,2/4)

tramp a press¶

phr.

BOWEN In loading fleeces tramp them in layers of five, one fleece in each corner, one in the middle. ... In tramping a press, concentrate on the sides and not the middle, ... (1955,Wool Away!,95)

tramp it¶

v.

PRESHAW Had to `tramp it' to Arahura (1988,Banking Under Difficulties,120) [NOTES: 1865 Feb 13 diary in Preshaw Banking under Difficulties (1888)120]

BELL But it's time we were trampin' it again, to see if we can win some place o' shelter for the nicht, be it hut or ha'. Ibid. 11 Fower days we ha'e been trampin' it,' he said, ...There's naethin' gies a man an appetite like trampin' it alang sic tracks as ye hae in these pairts; an' it's an ower lang fast since the morn.' (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,8)

he couldn't get a billet, tho' he tramped it up and down (1903,King Bill's Philosophy,23)

THOMPSON (1909,Ballads about Business,63)

tramp metal¶

n.

... Uranium is soluble, even more so than copper, which is commonly known as `tramp metal', and consequently uranium salts have the ability to move through rocks provided they are porous. (1957,NZ Geog. Society Rec.,24/15)

... uranium is what the old miners used to call `tramp metal' ... What they meant was that it reacts readily with the weak acids in the ground water and the salts of uranium resulting from this reaction are very soluble moving through the space in porous rocks, or the cracks in denser rocks for miles from where they originated. (Sep 10, 1958,Weekly News,4)

tramper¶

n. one who travels on foot over rough country for recreation; a hiker; a bush-walker

ODELL ... the track to Aicken through the bush was not cut originally to assist trampers and mountaineers, but was made for the purpose of providing a way for a pipe line used during the constructional work on the tunnel. Ibid. 59 The place is a strategic base for mountaineers who wish to conquer the peaks at the head of the Waimakariri, and for trampers on the `Three Pass Trip' (see Harman Pass) it makes a convenient resting place. (1935,Handbook Arthur Pass National Park,27)

... the track to Aicken through the bush was not cut originally to assist trampers and mountaineers, but was made for the purpose of providing a way for a pipe line used during the constructional work on the tunnel. Ibid. 59 The place is a strategic base for mountaineers who wish to conquer the peaks at the head of the Waimakariri, and for trampers on the `Three Pass Trip' (see Harman Pass) it makes a convenient resting place. (1935,Handbook Arthur Pass National Park,27)

COWAN ??a tramp; one on the tramp or swag Sometimes Maraekakaho [station] entertained ... twenty-two swaggers in a night. Most trampers looking for a job ... were bound for the patriarchal Maclean estate. (1940,Sir Donald Maclean,145)

STRONACH The homestead was full of people : two parties of deerstalkers, one party of trampers - the word `hiker' had not then arrived - and a gentleman of the road. (1953,Musterer on Molesworth,55)

The term tramper likewise has an English origin, as one who tramps or travels on foot, a pedestrian', but it may specifically, and less respectably, be a tramp or vagrant. <i>(Sep 1958,Tararua,29</i>) [NOTES: 1958 Sep Ruth MasonTrack and Trail' in Tararua 29]

CRUMP (1960,Good Keen Man, A,60,. 70)

PASCOE ... today fit trampers can journey from the pass to the farmland in Koiterangi in two days ... (1960,Over the Whitcombe Pass,14)

SARGESON (1965,Memoirs of a Peon,33)

MEAD [title page] (1966,Richard Taylor) [NOTES: 1966 Richard Taylor - Missionary Tramper by A.D.Mead/ A.H. & A.W.Reed-]

TURNER Tramping and tramper were used colloquially in England as early as 1908 but the word seems not to have been used in the title of a tramping club until 1919 when it was used in New Zealand. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,160)

(Jul 24, 1967,NZ Woman's Weekly,8/2)

SARGESON I had on my shoulders my few items of clothing ... all packed into a sugar bag transformed by a loop of light rope into that handy pack for trampers which the Maoris called pikau. (1977,More Than Enough,25)

HASCOMBE It has been our job to wait anxiously by the telephone for news of trampers and mountaineers. (1969,Down and Almost Under,159)

ALLAN And a wharf where trampers were gathering attracted by the Titan's hooter. (1981,See Our Island,49)

tramper n. N.Z. a person who tramps, or walks long distances, in the bush. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1243) [NOTES: [cf. 1986 NZPOD 817; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 509]]

SANSOM Trampers who walk the four-mile bush track from Halfmoon Bay ...come out on the open green patch ... (1982,In the Grip of an Island,31)

PICKERING Who were the first trampers? The first person who carried a swag and did it for pleasure and not for its own sake? What about the Maori? Did they go tramping as such or were they out for food, or greenstone, or other Maori? And what about the gold-digger and the musterer? Surely their trades came first and if they enjoyed the walk it was likely that it was because they'd found some good pasture or a `bit of the colour'. (1988,Hills, The,5)

I'm not the girl you'd find at a nightclub at 4am, but I'm not a tramper either. I could never go camping with this hair cut. (Feb 6, 2000,Sunday Star Times,D2)

[Hdg] Wellington Trampers Explore the Virgin Forest... The journey proper was commenced from Napier, from which town the trampers were conveyed to Wairoa. (1929,NZ Railways Magazine,4(7) : 42)

Here are a few suggestions for the wardrobe of the girl tramper. (1929,NZ Railways Magazine,4980 ; 53)

WANTED to Buy, Down Sleeping Bag, suitable for tramper. (Nov 24, 1945,Evening Post,4)

[Hdg] Tramper hut advice... Trampers are being advised to take tents this Easter in case back country huts are overcrowded. (Apr 17, 2003,Dominion Post,A3)

McNAUGHTON Tired tramps and trampers fare / sadly along the endless roads (1986,Countless Signs,130) [NOTES: From Basil Dowling (1949): Canterbury]

MACLEAN With more time, more money and easier travel, trampers and mountaineers visited the mountains in both islands in large numbers for the first time. (1994,Tararua : the Story of a Mountain Range,17)

There is no need for anxiety for the tramper or deer-stalker so long as parties are always aranged, and there is no reason whatever why this healthful form of excercise should become less popular. (Jun 1, 1909,Nelson Evening Mail,2)

The Defence Department has for Sale, Sleeping Bags (for week-end trampers), Ground Sheets, Straps ... (Jan 13, 1923,NZ Truth,6)

trampers' hut¶

n.

DUFF It is true that this is primarily a trampers' hut, but trampers don't usually carry periodicals in their swags. ... But here the two journals are now, and I wish I knew how often they are read by the other users of this shelter - rabbiters, deer-cullers, roadmen, storm-bound swaggers, and so on. (Mar 19, 1951,Shepherd's Calendar,25,1961 ed.)

TRAMPERS' HUTS COLLECTION OF DATA. (May 21, 1934,Evening Post,15)

TRAMPERS' HUTS NEW SCHEME IN HAND. (Mar 9, 1940,Evening Post,15)

FRAME Now there's the trig station, there's the trampers' hut; perhaps a hermit lives up there among the wild pigs. (1988,Carpathians, The,64)

tramping¶

adj.

It's a tramping metaphor. One group say they want to go this way, the other wants to go that way, and another says, 'We really ought to stick together.' (Dec 20, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

MARKS This was brought home to me very bitterly once in a tramping expedition. (1934,Memories (Mainly Merry),192)

MANTELL Tramping gear instead of business clothes. ... Had a tramping pack ready just in case. ... He was always going off on tramping trips, seems like.'He didn't tramp all the way back to Wellington!' (1980,Murder or Three, A,155)

TRAMPING TRAGEDY. (Jun 20, 1928,Evening Post,15)

n. hiking

TURNER ... tramping (called bushwalking in Australia). (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,160)

McDERMOTT There are simply sensational hikes in NZ of every description. New Zealanders say `tramping'. (1976,How to Get Lost & Found in NZ,15)

LELAND tramping: HIKING, what's that. In New Zealand ... everyone goes tramping. Ask your Kiwi acquaintances if they own tramping boots and sleeping bags. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,105)

tramping n. N.Z. 1. the leisure activity of walking in the bush. 2. (as modifier): tramping boots. (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1243) [NOTES: [cf. 1986 NZPOD 817; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 509]]

McGILL Best country in the world.'Eh?' `For tramping. Beautiful walks and always a hut (1985,G'day Country,170)

STEPHENS in MILLER Sometimes at night the rain came down in torrents, and their tents, quite ragged with rottenness, let in the cold air and wet most piteously. In the daytime they struggled through thickets of high fern, manuka and toitoi, and waded through icy flax swamps which caused them to suffer from swollen legs, rheumatism and colds. 'We surveyors as Pioneers,' wrote Samuel Stephens,'have a great deal of this tramping, and most tiring work it is.' (1958,Early Victorian NZ,63) [NOTES: 1974 edition. Original quote from Stephens' Letters 1/1/1843]

(1958,Tararua,xii)

As one who has tramped a good deal in New Zealand usually along fairly well-beaten tracks, I have noted with pleasure the active interest which is being taken in tramping just now, not only in New Zealand but also in Britain and other countries. (May 19, 1933,Evening Post,6)

Owen Marshall Tramping's always come easy to me, with pack or without. (2009,Living As A Moon,27)

EASTER TRAMPING. (Mar 29, 1934,Evening Post,10)

Autumn Days for Tramping. (May 18, 1940,Evening Post,15)

But our leader roused us before dawn to set off again, and that put me off serious tramping for quite some years. (May 22, 2004,Dominion Post,E16)

MACLEAN I had begun tramping, a decade earlier, in the Orongorongo Valley. (1994,Tararua : the Story of a Mountain Range,8)

tramping boots¶

n.

[Advt] TRAMPING BOOTS All the Best Boots by the following makers:- Trojan - Sargoods - King Leo - OBRIEN . (Dec 1952,Tararua Tramper,7)

McGILL The chap next to me leaned over. Great value, these drivers. Aussie drivers are never like that.' He was a Pom. Smoked lens glasses, bush shirt, shorts, tramping boots.You mean they don't crack funnies?' `Menace is the word. ...' (1985,G'day Country,169)

TRAMPING BOOTS, in box Calf, Welted, .. 20/-, 22/6, 25/-. (Apr 8, 1912,Colonist, The,4)
