Youths', Boys' and Girls' strong and best wear boots; also Tennis and Boating Shoes, Cricket and Tramping Boots, etc. (Dec 8, 1906,Nelson Evening Mail,1)

Tramping Club¶

n. an organisation whose members engage in back-country expeditions on foot. [incl attrib; see Hills and Valleys; letter D.Close]

McLINTOCK (1959,Descriptive Atlas,74)

TURNER Tramping and tramper were used colloquially in England as early as 1908 but the word seems not to have been used in the title of a tramping club until 1919 when it was used in New Zealand. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,160)

This is the story of the Victoria University tramping club's first fifty years. (1971,VUWTC'71,5)

SUTTON-SMITH By 1900 these [bucking a rider off one's back] games had faded out of regular school playground play. But out of school, we can assume that these games were still played occasionally. For example, a version of Buck Buck ... under the name Jumbucks is played today by one of New Zealand's tramping clubs (hiking clubs) in its haunts near the snowline. It is said that the hobnailed boots of the players contribute strongly to the hazards of the game. (1972,Folkgames of Children,194)

PICKERING The first tramping club was formed in 1919 and many more followed in the twenties. A hardy lot they must have been. Heavy leather boots studded with hobnails or clinkers on the soles, `kidney-crusher' or A-frame packs, and canvas or cotton tents ... (1988,Hills, The,6)

OWEN I finally had enough sense to join the Tramping Club which was greatly despised by the rest of the University. (1998,Snapshots of the Century,24)

GUTHRIE After the band came the Tem Boy Scouts ... and the members of the Tem Tramping Club, and the members of the Tem branch of the Ancient Order of Buffaloes. (1935,Little Country, The,319,1937 ed.)

ODELL In February, 1927, a party of Tramping Club members went up to Camp Corner, .. (1935,Handbook Arthur Pass National Park,59)

River crossing is an important skill for tramping club members - it used to be the most popular way of trampers dying. (Jan 2, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),12)

DUTY OF TRAMPING CLUBS. (Jun 16, 1926,Evening Post,9)

GREIG The public meeting held on July 3, 1919, well attended by leading citizens, resulted in the foundation of the Tararua Tramping Club. (1946,Tararua Story,13)

McLINTOCK The Tararua Tramping Club, which was founded in 1919, is the largest [tramping club]. With the Tararua Ranges so readily accessible from Wellington it was in fact the first home of tramp ing. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,II/597)

The Tararua Tramping Club held its adjourned meeting last week when a draft constitution and set of rules were submitted and adopted. (Aug 5, 1919,Evening Post,10) [NOTES: Couldn't find similar report in Dominion. Both reports of the first meeting call it simply the Tararua Club and do not use the word "tramping" in the report. I think this is probably the genuine first occurrence of the combination in print.]

tramping gear¶

n.

MANTELL Tramping gear instead of business clothes. ... Had a tramping pack ready just in case. ... He was always going off on tramping trips, seems like.'He didn't tramp all the way back to Wellington!' (1980,Murder or Three, A,155)

tramping hut¶

n. a back-country shelter for members of tramping clubs and others

Tramping huts and bivvies are dotted around the back country of New Zealand like nowhere else on earth... Many huts are a legacy of the early pioneering days of exploration and endeavour in the rugged and unforgiving high country. (Nov 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 54/88)

trampoline¶

n.

WHITWORTH I was down there with Old Ashmore's lot, doing the trampoline, and so on; but things was very quizby. Everything went crooked somehow, and the gorger had a hawful cramp in his kick. Well, ramp was the word, and vamose we did, the lot on us; some here, some there. I was reg'lar beached, and I tell you when a cove 'as to spout his smish it's about time to look out. However, I got a job at a livery stable, but although that kep' me in grub, and I slep' in a spare stall, the billet was very multy, and I kep' on the kivvy for something better. [fn] 1. [trampoline] Vaulter. 2. [quizby] Bad. 3. [crooked] Wrong. 4. [cramp in his kick] Emptiness in his pockets. 5. [ramp] Clear out. 6. [vamose] Go. 7. [beached] Hard up. 8. [smish] Shirt. 9. [multy] No good. 10. [kivvy] Look out (qui vive.) (1879,Spangles and Sawdust,5)

tramway¶

n. (See also tram)

A poll is about to be taken for a loan of GBP30,000 to construct a tramway between Gisborne and the Patutahi quarry, and as it has been shewn in the orignal [sic] prospectus of the 11th March last that the financial success of the proposed tramway depends on the ratification of a tentative agreement entered into by the late members of the Borough Council ... (May 18, 1909,Poverty Bay Herald,5)

HINGSTON [Hokitika] has a wooden road also, in the shape of a tramway, ... on which cars go to the diggings fourteen miles away. (1879,Australian Abroad, The,293)

BARLOW The country north of Auckland ... seldom admits of a tramway being laid down to carry the logs on. (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,112)

The one is the erection ... of a steam saw-mill; the other, the formation of a tramway leading from the forest ... to the mill. (1891,TrNZI,23/487)

In the south, rough tramways are laid down in the bush, and the logs hauled on low carriages to the mills by horse- or bullock-teams. here the great round baulks of timber are broken down' being cut lengthwise (by saws moving up and down vertically) intoflitches', which are passed over to the circular-saws to be ripped into boards and scantling. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,158) [NOTES: (sawmillers')]

But before this [treefelling] has been done rolling-roads have been formed, or tramways laid, involving the vast destruction of arboreal growth ... (1895,TrNZI,28/16)

... an old tramway-track runs through a saddle in the coast range ... (1898,TrNZI,30/536)

HENDERSON TRAMWAY: Bush wooden rails on which log trucks, originally pulled by horses, travel. (1961,Friends in Chains,189) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 189]

They first `blaze' or mark a course from the fallen tree to the nearest stream or tramway. (1901,NZ Illustrated Magazine,5/374)

JEWELL Tram [way]: A light railway built for the transportation of logs and/or sawn timber. (1948,Accounting in the Timber Industry,128)

McLINTOCK The term `tramway' could be applied in New Zealand from 1860 onwards to lines constructed to carry timber from bush to sawmill. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/444)

BENNETT The previous night he and two others had been driving a tramway downhill taking out the coal and timbering up as they went. (1980,Canterbury Tale, A,128)

BEARDSLEY Well, no, sir. It's an aerial tramway. (1984,Blackball 08,159) [NOTES: (coalminers')]

The logs were transported to the mill in the case of the Waitanui by a wooden-railed tramway; in the case of the Tamaki they were `driven.' (1913,NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin,No.16 (NS) 19) [NOTES: (Henderson and Bartrum, Aroha and Hauraki)]

A section of a wooden rail line buried between a landslip since 1938 has been uncovered during efforts to restore a historic log hauler tramway near Otaki Forks. (May 2004,Footnotes,No. 21/14)

Cr. Phillips.. moved that any saw mill proprietor be allowed to lay a tram way along the public road, and in reference to junkers, he moved that the use of them be allowed. (Feb 16, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

A tramway could be made, but it would have to be carried about ten miles, and it would not pay to convey the timber by that means. (May 3, 1873,Auckland Weekly News,11)

HOCHSTETTER First, a broad clearing leads from the interior of the forest, generally straight down the steep mountain slopes, and forms a kind of a road along which the logs are rolled, down to the head of a regular tramway. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter),147)

The centralization of New Zealand traffic at Manakau [sic] would afford a reasonable prospect for the introduction of steam to Sydney. It would reduce the voyage one-third, and few persons would either adventure by sailing vessels through Cook's Strait or round the North Cape; whilst the produce of our own East Coast, would easily find its way to Onehunga, by the tramway which would assuredly traverse our Epsom downs. (Jan 24, 1849,New Zealander, The,3)

To complete the advantages derivable from steam communication upon the Waikato and Manukau, a tramway (preferable perhaps for the present to a canal) at the Awaroa portage would be requisite. (Apr 17, 1855,Daily Southern Cross,2)

The tramway on which the logs are taken into the mill comes down some steep hills. (Aug 5, 1924,Otago Witness,15)

n.

My first lot came from the Nihotupu water pipeline tramway in the Waitakeres. (Jun 2001,NZ Memories,No. 30/49)

tramway bridge¶

n.

[The Percy Burn Viaduct] was hailed as the tallest tramway bridge in the Dominion when it was opened in 1925. (Jul 11, 1999,Sunday Star Times,A9)

Trans¶

n. the Transactions of the Royal Society of New Zealand (earlier, New Zealand Institute) abbrev. in DNZE to TrRS and TrNZI [ORIGIN: abbreviation, ca1945 at least (R. Mason, and others) A common abbreviation used by a good many, but certainly not all, who have occasion to use this series.]

trans-Tasman¶

adj. a) travelling or extending across the Tasman Sea: trans-Tasman travel'. b) held or holding between New Zealand and Australia:a trans-Tasman pact'. [trans Tasman, transtasman]

Fishguard is a recent case in point, and perhaps when it is a question of saving a few hours in the trans-Tasman run, and improving the connection between Australia and New Zealand, Point Elizabeth will have its day. (Sep 10, 1910,Grey River Argus,2)

(Oct 15, 1963,NZ Truth)

LELAND trans-Tasman: The body of water separating New Zealand and Australia is called the Tasman Sea. ... [106] beware of thinking of Australia and New Zealand as one lump. (1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,105)

trans-Tasman a. (of yacht race etc.) traversing the Tasman Sea; (of series of sporting contests etc.) held in both Australia and NZ (Auckland won the Trans-Tasman Cup from Sydney). (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,819) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

Transtasman rationalisation Union Shipping has joined forces with the New Zealand Line and the Australian National Line in a rationalisation of transtasman shipping. (Sep 8, 1987,Evening Post,40)

INWARD MAILS DUE WELLINGTON. BY AIR. Australia, by trans-Tasman service: Every Monday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. (Dec 6, 1945,Evening Post,12)

A theatrical fiend of mine predicted one day this week that the Maori League players who went across to Australia some weeks ago have proved to be mighty poor advance agents for the Maori Rugby men who travelled trans-Tasman last week. (Jun 24, 1922,NZ Truth,8)

trans-Tassie¶

adj. (informal) trans-Tasman; Australian

Thankfully I never had to deal with plagues of bed bugs unlike our trans-tassie cobbers [Australians], whose sleep-clobber is, it seems, infested with them. (Feb 10, 2006,NZ Herald,A18)

transactor¶

n. ? a person involved in share transactions [Google search of "transactor shares" Mar 2006: all hits From NZ]

Satara has an unusual hybrid share structure - investor shares for outside owners and "transactor" shares for cooperative members. (Sep 29, 2004,Dominion Post,C3)

cardwatch..assesses all the cards in New Zealand from one to five stars based on whether you are a "transactor" or a "debtor". (Dec 20, 2005,Dominion Post,A6)

transfer charge service¶

phr.

Transfer Charge Service. There are now a number of alternatives to the Transfer Charge service which offer the same benefits but are cheaper and easier for customers to use, such as Telecom Calling Card or our Home 0800 service. (Mar 1999,In Touch (Wellington),[1])

Transit¶

n. the State Roading Authority [Ellipsis of Transiit New Zealand.]

Transit is reopening a road through Plimmerton that had been closed during peak-hour traffic to stop motorists using it as a "rat run". (Apr 10, 2004,Dominion Post,A10)

transit camp¶

n. initially a camp for the temporary accommodation of troops; later used for immigrants and refugees

REID Transit Camp: a camp erected for the accommodation of passing troops (1944,Turning Point, The,22)

... in an interim period we had to be rehoused in that abomination called a transit camp at western Springs. (May 1987,Metro,134)

Transmission Gully¶

n. a proposed inland roadway to provide an alternative route from near Wellington to McKays Crossing

Transmission Gully is a proposed 27km-long, four-lane highway linking Linden (20kmn north of Wellington) to McKays Crossing. (Mar 13, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),23)

The Plan looks at improvements along the entire corridor from Ngauranga to Peka Peka, not just the Central Section where Transmission Gully is an alternative to the Coastal Route. The current cost estimate for Transmission Gully is $1.09 billion compared to the current cost estimate of $730 milllion for the Coastal Route. (Oct 2005,Greater Wellington Regional Council,00,Western Corridor Transportation Study ed.)

transmitterised¶

adj. equipped with a transmitter

All kakapo are now 'transmitterised and microchipped'. (May 2003,Forest & Bird,No. 308/5)

transnational immigration¶

n. where migrants simultaneously carry on lives in two or more countries

Bartley came to the conclusion that what we are seeing is transnational immigration where migrants simultaneously carry on lives in two or more countries. (Jul 17, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

transport tray¶

1 n. (Rural) a freight deck affixed to a truck, trailer or tractor.

Farm clearing sale: chain saws .. transport tray, ute crate. (Jun 22, 2002,Hawke's Bay Today,22)

transport truck¶

1 n. (Rural) a commercial transport truck used in rural areas for carting wool, fertiliser or implements.

STAPLES Every Friday evening he dressed up and was away to the gate to be picked up by a transport truck on its way back from the back country stations. (1964,Cooks and Shepherds Come Away,20)

HUNT .. the buyers would look for a drover instead of a transport truck. (1981,Speaking a Silence,60)

SALISBURY 34 I caught up with an East Coast transport truck which was being driven by a Maori chap I got to know. (1994)

Transpower¶

n.

[Treasury] says that while there is a strong case for owning monopolies such as Transpower, which operates the national power grid, and Airways, which handles air traffic control, there is a moderate or weak case for owning others. (Jul 20, 2003,Sunday Star Times,A2)

TranzAlpine¶

n. a passenger train between Christchurch and Greymouth

And there it was again, when I recently swanned in as a daytripper on the TranzAlpine train from Christchurch, which drops you off by the river, near the Railway Hotel. (Oct 21, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

The Tranzalpine train which passes through this surfeit of beauty is a bit of a bone-shaker despite being rated among the six top journeys in the world. (Aug 30, 1999,Evening Post,12)

It's not quite the Orient Express but the Tranzalpine is up-market by New Zealand Railway standards... Seemingly existing in a time all of its own, the Tranzalpine clickety-clacks through the rapidly yuppifying Moana.. above Lake Brunner. (Feb 1989,North & South,18)

Twice a day the Trans Alpine train passes through the world. (Jun 2001,NZ Geographic,52/36)

TranzAlpine Express¶

n.

CHAPMAN & HURST At the end of 1987 a new concept in long distance passenger trains came with the upgrading of the Christchurch-Greymouth Express which was renamed the 'Tranz-Alpine Express' (1990,Radio NZ Sporting Annual,64)

My visit to Greymouth was the second I had made in a fortnight; the first was by the Tranz Alpine Express to visit the Coast in between rugby tests... (Aug 2004,Photographer's Mail, The,13 (8)/8)

The Tranz Alpine Express gathered speed and the click-clack of the wheels, the gentle swaying and the warm sun on my face had me thinking ... Railways invested $150,000 in the Christchurch-Greymouth train and renamed it the Tranz Alpine. (Nov 12, 1990,Listener (New Zealand Listener),89)

Cheaper projects such as the new Tranz-Alpine Express - Christchurch to Greymouth and back, daily - courageously ignore the fact that New Zealand has the population of one medium-sized city spread over a landscape larger than Great Britain... From Springfield the Tranz-Alpine Express jistifies its name, all but hovering over the upper Waimakariri River as it climbs into a magical world of high mountains spectacularly snow-clad in winter, spectacularly barren in summer. (Feb 13, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

trap¶

n. a four-wheeled, horse-drawn carriage [OED from 1807]

HOOD Cabmen or drivers of `traps' as they term their hideous street vehicles in Wellington. (1875,Chowbokiana,9)

PARTRIDGE Trap. 3. A smallish, sprung carriage; in Britain, esp. an gig, but in Australia and New Zealand a four-wheeled carriage; from ca. 1805: coll. , by 1900, S.E. Perhaps ex rattle trap. (1937,Dictionary of Slang,906)

n. a policeman, a cop [Also Aust. AND from 1812. (esp. in pl, THE TRAPS -->very frequent in early Truth 1905 to c1914: e.g. 1905 Aug 12 Truth 8/1/6; and see esp. the citation 1905 of JOHN DUNN]

tha The traps I twigged, all got up very nobby,/ By Mr Weldon their commanding bobby./ And Sergeant Chapman, too, I noticed there,/ Togged up just like a trooper I declare;/ (1864,Invercargill Minstrel,3) [NOTES: (The Sessions)]

THATCHER Mine [police] are regular traps,/ None of your blue shirt identities./ (1865,Otago Songster,19)

I'm a Dunedin peeler,/ .../ Trap, trap, trap, trap! they calls me trap,/ But that I never mind. (1875,NZ Songster,3/62) [NOTES: Trap, Trap]

(Some of the Traps collar him, and walk him off to the chokie.) (Aug 5, 1843,Daily Southern Cross,3)

Apparently Black pulled a doublecross on McRae, and when the traps came through - 'traps' being what the police were called at the time - Black did nothing about it. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,65)

n. trap rock [OED from 1813, seems universal, no obvious NZ difference]

TUCKETT On the summits of the [Otago] hills the surface is almost covered with large blocks of stone (a species of trap rock); ... (Apr 24, 1844,Diary) [NOTES: 1844 Apr 24 and 25 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 211]

SWAINSON The bed of the Kapanga, in which the gold was found, consists of rocks of quartz, trap, and a bluish granite containing iron pyrites... In the detritus on the sides of the mountains, and in the beds of the stream, quartz occurs in detached blocks of various sizes, mixed with fragments of slate, granite and trap; but regular dykes of quartz are not generally met with, although they are reported to exist. (1853,Auckland,91)

n. trapdoor to the cells; or fig.

[Headline] Kathleen Mavourneen Stakes [sub] Sheehan a Sure Starter ... Sheehan did not exhibit any intention of worrying, and when sentenced to twelve months and labelled as an habitual criminal, which at his age (63) means life, he passed down the trap feeling apparently relieved. (Jun 4, 1910,NZ Truth,258/7/5)

2 n. [running trap - plumbing and other uses, OED from 1880, doubt any NZ specificity]

Trap, running- U-shaped trap with inlet and outlest at the same level. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120)

2 n. [petrol trap; not in OED]

Trap, petrol- Trap installed in the drainage system to prevent ingress of petrol into the drainage system and fitted with vent pipes to carry off the petrol vapour (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120)

2 n. [oil trap OED 1863 re coal oil, 1927 re machinery]

Trap, oil- Trap to prevent oil entering the drainage system. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120)

2 n. [trap-screw; ubiquitous on google but no OED mention]

Trap-screw- Screwed plug giving access to a trap for cleaning purposes. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120)

2 n. [anti-siphonage trap; 1989 Charles Ransom notes: Trap, antisiphonage - Not found elsewhere in this form, but Webster II has antisiphon as an adjective designating such a trap.]

Trap, anti-siphonage (resealing trap)- Trap designed to prevent siphonage unsealing the trap. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120)

2 n. [deep seal trap - plumbing not sealing!]

Trap, deep seal- Trap having a water seal of 75 mm or more. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120)

2 n. [interceptor trap]

Trap, interceptor- Trap situated on a drain at some point between a sewer and the lowest inlet to the drain to prevent the passage of air or gases from the sewer to the drain. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120)

2 n. [neutralizing / neutralising trap]

Trap, neutralizing- Trap containing crushed limestone or caustic alkali to neutralize acid waste. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120)

2 n. [offal trap]

Trap, offal- Trap for preventing waste matter or refuse entering the drainage system. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120)

trapdoor spiders¶

n. (a recipe)

TRAP-DOOR SPIDERS ... cylinders of stale bread ... Scoop out a hollow ... Fry ... meat minced fine and seasoned. Fill the cases ... and place a poached egg as a lid on each. (1908,Souvenir of All Nations Fair,24)

trash girl¶

n.

She was scathing of the "trash girls". "They're not really lesbian, not even bisexual, they just do it because they get trashed and think it's cool". And, she said, the boys encourage it so they can watch these girls getting it on. (Jan 28, 2001,Sunday Star Times,D2)

travel¶

v. (transitive use)

[Stock Act 1893-1898] Travelling Diseased Stock. - No diseased stock can be travelled without a permit from the Inspector. (1902,Settlements of NZ Coy,222)

travel per Harry Pannell¶

1 phr. (Rural) [mustering] to walk. (See walking country)

NEWTON It was all walking country and no hacks were taken there, the musterers travelling either per 'Harry Pannel' (walking) or riding on the pack dray. (1947,Wayleggo,35)

NEWTON All hands, including the shearers, travelled in and out per 'Harry Pannel' (walked) ... (1978,Five Hundred Horses,29)

NEWTON ... in my mustering days we had to travel per `Harry Pannell' (boots) / and it was a two-day walk from the homestead to the Ada. (1973,Big Country,112,1977 ed.)

travel rug¶

n.

ELDRED-GRIGG 'Travel rug,' I said to Mum, reading from the list. 'What's a travel rug?' (1995,Mum,188)

traveller¶

n. ? a shackle or other device to travel along a rope so that one might haul oneself along in a boat from one end to the other

38 Irons - .. 8/- ea. ... 14 Lances - .. 8/- ea. ... 1 Cutting Spade - .. 8/- ... 2 Boat Spades - .. .16. 4 Boat axes - .. 4/- ea. ... 5 Boat Knives - .. 2/- ea. ... 3 Pughs - .. .9. ... 2 Blubber Knives - ... 8. ... 1 [Boat] Traveller - .. .4. (1837,Piraki Log,49,(ed. Anson 1911) ed.)

KITTO ... the men in the boat will want to come on board by means of [the side line]. A traveller may be used if there is one on hand; if not, the horn of the boat will do. Ibid [16] The traveller or runner dropped to the bottom [when the line broke] and anchored the boat ... (1900,Practical Dredgeman's Manual,13)

traveller's joy¶

n. Clematis spp. other than C. vitalba [1938 Godwits Fly HYDE Page 39 Edition 1970 Quote ... on scrubby bushes grew the pale-starred clematis, traveller's joy.(which species?)]

HOOKER Clematis indivisa, Willd. ... Nat. name, `Puawhananga'. ... It is the most common species, and far handsomer than its English congener the Traveller's Joy. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 6)

HOOKER Traveller's-joy. Clematis hexasepala. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768 ed.)

Clematis indivisa Traveller's joy (1870,TrNZI,2/123) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

Clematis indivisa traveller's joy (1885,TrNZI,17) [NOTES: And]

FEATON CLEMATIS HEXASEPALA (D.C.) In some parts it is known as the `Traveller's Joy', a name probably due to its appearance in early spring, as a harbinger of brighter weather and sunnier skies. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,3) [NOTES: (Andersen)]

clematis, wild [=] traveller's joy [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,14)

travelling certificate¶

1 n. (Rural) a certificate required before a farmer could drove his sheep [ contingent upon a clean certificate for scab being produced.]

Sheep farmers must produce clean certificates for all sheep offered at my yards, as it is necessary for copies to be taken before a travelling certificate is issued. (Feb 10, 1882,Hawera & Normanby Star,02)

travelling labour¶

n.

BAKER These were the real swagmen, the men...described with euphemistic accuracy as travelling labour and travelling labourers. (1941,NZ Slang,41)

trawl squid¶

n.

Significant numbers [of seals] drown in nets in the West Coast hoki fishery, in the trawl squid fishery west of the Snare Islands and in the southern blue whiting fishery around the Bounty Islands. (Apr 19, 2000,Dominion,12)

tray¶

n. a plumber's term

Tray- 1. Metal or plastics tray with a waste outlet placed under storage tank or a hot water cylinder to obviate damage from overflow. 2. Flashing placed under the sill of a window or upper dor to prevent soakage of water to the wall beneath. (1979,SANZ Glossary Building Terminology,120)

tray-bit¶

n.

Following are other local money-names...3d. - thrum, half-tiz, tray (Jan 14, 1899,Sydney Bulletin,(Red Page)) [NOTES: (Letter from Loafer, Tauranga) [Bill Pearson]]

I upend them to collect the tray bits. (Mar 17, 1937,Tomorrow,3/310) [NOTES: (Sargeson)]

(Dec 23, 1944,2NZEF Times,18) [NOTES: [get cit]]

SARGESON It was only a tray-bit I dropped. (1946,That Summer,71)

PARTRIDGE `threepenny piece': Australian and S. African low s., rather than c.: late C. 19-20. See trey. (1949,Dictionary of the Underworld,741,1961 ed.)

TURNER The word tray and its variants for threepence' and<i> zack</i> forsixpence' are said to be common Australianisms but are not known to me in New Zealand. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,133)

tray, trabit n.(slang). a threepenny piece. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

A tray-bit, or trey, thrum, or half-tiz are recorded for the threepence. (Oct 1977,NZ Numismatic Journal,15)

tray-trapper¶

n. a derogatory (?early Truth) coinage, now obs, to describe evangelising street-preachers and collectors (esp. Salvation Army), and the qualities asociated with them

Prurient Parsonical Parasites. A Trinity of Tarnished Tray-trappers ... smug snuffle-busters. (Sep 23, 1905,NZ Truth,14/8/6)

A tray-trapper of the Methodist variety named Flanagan, who is travelling in these parts for the good of his health and his pockets, struck Temuka the other day, and paid a tribute to the behavior [sic] and morals of New Zealand. (Feb 8, 1908,NZ Truth,138/1/7)

tray-trapping¶

adj. ??

... a tray-trapping institution. [sc a church] (Sep 2, 1905,NZ Truth,11/1/6)

tread¶

v. to tread (eels) out from mud [ca1935 Havelock children -]

treadin¶

1 n. (Rural) a narrow graduated metal fencepost used in temporary fencing, similar to a standard or waratah.

.. 2 station saddles, elastrators, Gallagher tredin standards ... (Nov 10, 1993,Napier Daily Telegraph,21)

There are a number of treadins or temporary posts available. Treadins should be spaced at 10-12m. (2000,Lifestyle Farmer,Autumn 66)

Use pigtails for cattle and treadins for sheep. (2000,Gallagher Power Fence Manual,29)

He has designed a new hotwire tread-in with the pigstail curl at the top extended into a simple handle. [tredin; tread-in] (2002,Lifestyle Farmer,Aug/Sept 11)

treadly¶

n. treadly: a bicycle [1981 Rangiora High School (Goldie Brown Collection)]

n.

But it now appears that the number of shares held by the trust is excessive and some 213 million of them are to be treated in the next annual report as so-called "treasury stock" - that is, effectively cancelled. (Jul 25, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),41)

Treasury troika¶

phr. a trio of financial politicians (Roger Douglas, Richard Prebble, David Caygill) in the Lange-led fourth Labour government

Surrounded by able ministers such as deputy Geoffrey Palmer and the "Treasury troika" of Roger Douglas, Richard Prebble and David Caygill, Mr Lange impressed the public and the business community with his steely performance under crisis, but much more was to come. (Aug 15, 2005,Dominion Post,A2)

treatment injury¶

n. medical misadventure

..the ACC Minister has announced that she will be introducing legislation to put medical misadventure (in future to be known as "treatment injury") on a new footing. (Apr 17, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),38)

treatment station¶

n. short for milk treatment station

SANDYS On the street below a milk van rattled past on its way from the Treatment Station to its delivery round in the suburbs. (1982,Love and War,3)

Treaty¶

adj. [pertaining to the Treaty of Waitangi]

Lambert The wealth of its carving ... will compare favourably with those of the Waitangi meeting-house, contemplated to memorialize the recent Treaty centenary celebrations. (1936,Pioneering Reminiscences of Old Wairoa,138)

Winston has won the ballot, something of a coup so close to an election, though his version does little more than delete the offensive phrase "treaty principles" from 27 acts. (Feb 20, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C2)

He then laid into "the elements within our leadership" who, he says, are prepared to sell Treaty rights for cash - "mixing the kai with the tapu", as he put it, "having their hands in the hangi". (Jan 14, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),34)

The imposition of the so-called "Treaty process" upon New Zealanders, by an unholy alliance of left-wing social engineers and Maori activists, was actually a covert declaration of war against the better part of all things European in this country. (Aug 2, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9)

Pakeha' is a word that seems to be bugging many New Zealanders. Perhaps this is the reason why the Royal Commission on Social Policy in its booklet dealing with the Treaty of Waitangi uses the wordTauiwi' instead of Pakeha'. For example a section of the booklet is headedPartnership between Maori and Tauiwi'. Tauiwi, according to the booklet's glossary, means later settlers from another country'. A Dictionary of the Maori Language ... givesstrange tribe, foreign race' as the meaning of Tauiwi. As a New Zealander born and bred in this country I was disturbed at the unceremonious use of a word which seems to make me some sort of foreigner in my own land. ... On phoning the commission's office I was informed that despite considerable unease over the use of Tauiwi in the treaty booklet staff were told that it had to be used. I was also informed that the use of Tauiwi instead of Pakeha had been discontinued (Jun 6, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,11)

Sir Paul Reeves refers to Aotearoa as a Treaty driven' society. ... To use the phrasetreaty driven' is to raise questions about who drives, who rides, ... (Mar 1988,Human Rights Commission Focus) [NOTES: (H. Kaa)]

She sees the Treaty process as a disincentive, however, because it has created an expectation in some quarters that really big benefits are on the way... The Treaty process has reinforced the iwi model, perhaps because iwi are nice, neat compartmentable boxes into which you can put things, such as apologies and reparations, whereas urban Maori are a comparatively ill-defined lot. (Mar 22, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

n. (with def. art.) the Treaty of Waitangi [also Tiriti also attrib. uses below] (See also Tiriti)

MATHEW Accordingly, [we] sailed down to the place of Rendezvous where the ceremony of signing the Treaty (as it was called) was soon performed, ... (Mar 4, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Mar 4 F.Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 70]

STACK I beg to apologize for the very soiled state of the treaty, but the native habits are so filthy it could hardly be avoided. (May 23, 1840,Letter) [NOTES: 1840 May 23 James Stack to Willoughby Shortland, Acting Col.Secretary in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 104]

HOBSON The treaty which forms the base of all my proceedings was signed at Waitangi on the 6th February 1840, by 52 chiefs, 26 of whom were of the confederation, and formed a majority of those who signed the Declaration of Independence. This [=?, or copy of treaty] instrument I consider to be de facto the treaty, and all signatures that are subsequently obtained are merely testimonials of adherence to the original document. (Apr 25, 1840,Letter) [NOTES: 1840 Apr 25 Hobson to Bunbury in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 17]

Observe what the Treaty was that was framed under those instructions to Captain Hobson: ... [quoting Hobson] When I had finished reading the Treaty, I invited the chiefs to ask explanations on any points they did not comprehend, and to make any observations or remarks on it they pleased. (Jul 1845,House of Commons: Parliamentary Debates (UK),Vol. LXXXI col. 947) [NOTES: 1845 July Sir Robert Peel in House of Commons: Parliamentary Debates (G.B.) Vol. LXXXI col. 947 in 1949 Rutherford ed. Select Documents4 14A page 7]

We are having this function next anniversary of the signing of the Treaty to [87] acknowledge the Bledisloe gift. (Jun 11, 1933,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/86) [NOTES: (Ngata)]

SHERWOOD `Don't let the pakehas brainwash you. ... All the time we're here I feel guilty because I'm not up north campaigning against the Treaty.' (1985,Botanist at Bay,49)

TAYLOR the rough copy of the treaty was sent to me to get copied.... I sat up late copying the treaty on parchment and I kept the original draft for my pains. (Feb 5, 1840,Journal,2/189)

... it will be found of interest to give in regular order the printing that was done after the treaty was signed: - Feb. 17 Captain Hobson, R.N.: Compositing and printing 200 copies of treaty, foolscap folio, [pounds]1 10s. 6d.; 41/2 quires of foolscap paper for above, at 2s., 9s. [from Colenso `The Signing ...'] (Feb 17, 1840,Report) [NOTES: 1840 Feb 17 in 1901 TrNZI 33/423 (Hill Printing)]

On the morning of the 14th ... two tribes ... requested that their names might be withdrawn from the treaty (1841,GBPP,(No.311) 11) [NOTES: 1840 Feb 17 Hobson Report in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 11]

T is for Treaty; unusually confused term, used both to describe the founding document of a nation and as a codename for a runaway gravy train. (Jul 27, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

But his trick is to have found a formulation of words that gives people permission to feel uncomfortable about immigration and the Treaty, without feeling guilty. (Jul 22, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

Among the chiefs present was the son of Te Heu Heu, that fine barbarian who was the last of the old heathen warriors, who could neither be coerced or persuaded to sign the Treaty. (Mar 17, 1908,Feilding Star,4)

However, even this is being questioned, as we see the Treaty being used in ways that were not intended. Using the Treaty to get out of paying dog registration fees on the grounds that they are a taonga, and claiming preferential health treatment are two examples. (Feb 17, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

I think National's equivalents are the action and courage around Treaty issues. (Aug 4, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

Treaty fatigue¶

n. state of being fed up with Treaty discussions

(May 25, 2004,Radio NZ / National Radio) [NOTES: Nine to Noon]

Treaty gravy train¶

n.

NZ First , which has made attacks on the "Treaty Gravy Train" one of its key election planks, wants claims lodged within five years, and aims to have them settled in 10 years. (Aug 4, 2005,Dominion Post,A1)

The negative publicity about the treaty gravy train and the foreshore also fuelled it. (Dec 2004,North & South,72)

A Maori is condemning the treaty gravy train, or "Treaty gravy supertanker" as Winston called it in a particularly hyperbolic moment. (Jul 20, 2002,Weekend Herald,A23)

Treaty industry¶

n.

They did not foresee that one day Pakeha would set up a Treaty industry. (Dec 17, 2000,Sunday Star Times,C6)

ACT was bounding away on its cynical promises to end the "treaty industry" and lock up criminals for even longer terms than National has imposed this past nine years. (Dec 1999,North & South,170)

This widening gap between the lives of claimants and those farming the Treaty industry is a recipe for social disaster... Sooner rather than later ministers will be forced to take a grip of the Treaty industry or it will grip them. (May 1, 2002,Dominion,10)

"This change has been brought about by the Treaty industry that the Government has fostered and funded through the Waitangi Tribunal, the Crown Forestry Rental Trust and the Fisheries Commission." (Feb 8, 2003,Dominion Post,A15)

The treay industry is awash with cash. (Feb 6, 2002,Dominion,12)

[The government] has also vetoed the Treaty industry's attempt to have listed under the definition of "historic heritage" councils have to preserve in approving developments, non-definable terms such as "cultural landscapes", "ancestral landscapes" and "spiritual resources". (May 25, 2003,Sunday Star Times,C2)

During the 1990s, the Treaty industry continued to breathe strange reasoning into that slender 1840 document, which, like the 1985 act, had been hastily cobbled together. (May 27, 2003,Dominion Post,B4)

For our sins, and because of our craven readiness to go along with the excesses of the Treaty industry, we have to tolerate offering jobs to Maori-only candidates. (Jun 16, 2002,Sunday Star Times,C12)

Treaty of Waitangi¶

n.

Chatham Island Morioris have joined the chorus of discontent at the Government's selection of the Treaty of Waitangi Fisheries Commission. (Jun 1, 1993,Dominion,10)

Though by no means faultless, the measure [1846 Constitution Act] seems calculated to be a fair opening to the true history of our great Southern Colony, after the preliminary chapters of tragi-comic blundering. It sweeps away the whole system of official machinery and self-impeding sophistry established by Lord Stanley - all the Treaty of Waitangi' nonsense, and all the past Downing-Street plans for hindering the settlement of the islands.' Henceforward, echoed the Colonial Gazette,the humbug treaty of Waitangi' would be `very properly laid on the shelf'. (Jan 2, 1847,Wellington Spectator) [NOTES: 1847 Jan 2 Wellington Spectator in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 149]

A Parliamentary committee was thwarted only by the early election from sparking a radical and long-awaited overhaul of the Treaty of Waitangi industry. (Jun 21, 2002,Dominion,2)

Race relations in New Zealand will never be harmonious while we have the Treaty of Waitangi industry promoting racial discrimination. (Oct 29, 1992,Evening Post,6)

Treaty of Waitangi Fisheries Commission¶

n.

Chatham Island Morioris have joined the chorus of discontent at the Government's selection of the Treaty of Waitangi Fisheries Commission. (Jun 1, 1993,Dominion,10)

Treaty settlement¶

n.

The treaty settlements, says Maanu Paul, are "a recipe for disaster." (Sep 26, 1999,Sunday Star Times,C6)

[Hdg] Treaty settlements cost Crown $500m. Settling historical Treaty of Waitangi claims had cost the Crown more than half a million dollars... It was not possible to estimate the total cost to the Crown of settlements of all historical claims. (Jul 6, 2000,Dominion,2)

There is sharply pointed satire, for instance, of iwi mismanagement, welfare scams and the scramble for Treaty-settlement payouts. (Mar 15, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),52)

However, the increase was after a deferred part of the tribe's 1998 treaty settlement, allowing Ngai Tahu to purchase up to $250 million worth of Crown land. (Oct 25, 2001,Dominion,21)

[Richard Prebble's] firm assertion that the notion of a time limit on Treaty settlements was "an idea whose time had come" was one of the few things said that night that no one could argue with. (Aug 10, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),78)

Officially, the fiscal envelope - that sought to place a billion-dollar cap on Treaty settlements - is dead. (Feb 8, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),28)

Treaty trout¶

n. (humorous, for trout illegally taken)

FINLAYSON The sport turned out to be spearing trout. ... Seeing Henry's wonderment, Moses gave him a sly dig in the ribs. These the treaty trout,' he grinned.Waitangi, you know, the Maori own all the fish for ever. God bless the Queen!' (1938,Brown Man's Burden,22,1973 ed.)

FINLAYSON `treaty trout'. A reference to the widely-held belief in a clause of the Treaty of Waitangi, signed in 1840 between Governor Hobson and some of the Maori chiefs, which ostensibly guarantees to Maoris the right to hunt and fish for as long as they wish in the country of which they gave sovereignty to Queen Victoria, the queen Moses blesses. Recent historical research shows that the supposed clause is not present in the Maori text that was signed, though it occurs in some of the variant English versions. ... In any case Maoris have not been exempt from laws restricting fishing and hunting. (1973,Brown Man's Burden,136 [note 11 to p.22])

Treaty-mongering¶

n.

What her government is paying for..[is] all the bans and taxes and wowserism against mostly blameless people like smokers, dog owners, sherry drinkers and amateur home-builders; the indiscriminate Treaty-mongering... (Jul 2, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21)

Treaty-ness¶

n.

Those who favour the "partnership" version over the "one people" version of Treaty-ness will now be hyper-motivated and out in force. (Apr 3, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

treatyism¶

n. an excessive reliance on, or application of, the principles of the Treaty of Waitangi.

Beyond treaty-ism, this [discrimination towards Maori in public health] is the next level of deep research. (Jul 15, 2007,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),A9)

It is seen that Justice Elias is an admitted judicial activist, a supporter of treatyism, a de fact race separatist... Despite all this, Justice Elias is recruited as Chief Justice in the apparent expectation she will help Parliament ablate, if not suppress, public opposition to treatyism... Even Albert Einstein, brilliant in one orbit, was a dunce in another, as Justice Elias seems over treatyism. (Apr 16, 1999,Evening Post,6)

In his eyes, Dr Prasad committed the unpardonable sin of challenging the all-pervasive advance of Treatyism, with its implications of preferential treatment for Maori. (Nov 7, 2000,Evening Post,4)

treatyitis¶

n. .

Haden loves this stuff - it fits his off-the-shelf views on Maori activism, Treatyitis and the PC plague. (May 1, 2005,Sunday Star Times,C11)

treatyology¶

n.

Perhaps realising this topic could be seen as disloyal, English revised and delivered a 2002 speech on the :"Treatyology" of relations instead... (Oct 29, 2005,Listener (New Zealand Listener),24)

English's Robert Chapman lecture last night, which Upton was originally asked to deliver, focussed on what he calls "treatyology" and the challenge of ethnic diversity, which he illustrated by reference to his "Samoan-Italian-Pakeha" son's school class in which there are only three obviously "European" names. ... English's "treatyology" is "public doctrine and public policy that ... asserts that the Treaty of Waitangi underpins a contemporary constitutional partnership between Maori and the Crown or its agents and that this partnership will continue to develop towards a bifurcated state". (Oct 4, 2005,NZ Herald,A13)

"Labour can fiddle all they like, but treatyology and low expectations are rife in the education sector ..." (Dec 17, 2004,Dominion Post,A2)

tree avalanche¶

n.

I find that the drowned trees had probably come from what the Fiordlanders call a tree avalanche. Because Fiordland was so thoroughly gouged by glaciers, there is virtually no topsoil on the steeper valley sides. Even the fully-grown forest has only the precarious hold of a woven skin of roots that stretch over rock. This net has a weak grip and if one section tears free it can peel the forest from the cliff-faces in great strips. The fall of just one tree can trigger a tree avalanche. (Jan 1992,NZ Geographic,92)

tree block¶

1 n. (Rural) an area of land used for forestry investment.

This land faces the north, is good clean and safe and runs mainly sheep with some cattle. Could make an ideal tree block for an investment. (Jan 22, 2001,Taranaki Daily News,7)

tree creeper¶

2 n. (Environment) brown creeper

WILLIAMS pipipi, ... 3. Finschia novae-zealandiae, tree-creeper; a bird. = toitoi. (1917,Dictionary of the Maori Language,328)

tree-creeper, a gregarious bird (Finschia novaeseelandiae), tree-creeper: the flock sings a long song in time and in unison. (Jun 1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/156) [NOTES: (J.C.Andersen)]

tree cropper¶

1 n. (Rural) a farm forester.

Our main objective as Tree Croppers is to initiate and develop new land uses. (Jul 1983,Growing Today,41)

The Tree Cropper 24 Winter 21 For many, a 'tree cropper' stands surrounded by his/her well-spaced, carefully pruned, espaliered, framed or stand-alone orchard or forest .. Among the most blessed are those individuals who are it seems descended from generations of far-sighted tree-croppers ... (2000)

tree daisy¶

2 n. Olearia fragrantissima

Cockayne Plant Covering Kennedy's Bush (Canterbury) (1915,AJHR,C-6)

tree fern¶

n. a large fern having a trunk-like stem with fronds at the top. See also ponga, mamaku, wheki (See also fern tree)

DIEFFENBACH High tree-ferns [fn Cyathea medullaris and dealbatawith the cabbage-palm [fn Areca sapida], strike the eye as the most beautiful forms of New Zealand vegetation. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/27)

MANSON The allotments were made to consist of 100 acres each, and these are what we call `sections'. ... Papa has taken a great deal of pains with it, indeed I think he has too much taste for a Colonist, for he cannot bear to see the beautiful trees and tree-ferns cut down. (1971,I Take Up My Pen,25) [NOTES: 1843 Mary Swainson in 1971 Manson I Take Up My Pen 25]

ANGAS Amongst the most remarkable of these are the lofty tree-ferns of New Zealand, the Cyathea dealbata, which attains a height of forty fee, the Cyathea medullaris, the Dicksonia squamosa, and the Mahrattia elegans. (1866,Polynesia,47) [NOTES: [? f 1860 Bennett Gatherings of a Naturalist]]

Some people speak and write of them as tree ferns' ... this is of course loose and misleading. There are fern-trees on my section up to fifty feet in height, and at least one of them - the wheki variety, is a hard-bitten fellow ... The unobservant are apt to lump all fern-trees together, as pongas, or, in the vernacular,bungers'. (Mar 10, 1920,Quick March,38)

WAKEFIELD Everywhere are to be seen Tree-ferns, (Cyathea medullaris and dealbata) some of them with stems forty to sixty feet high, ... (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,144)

... in many places the undergrowth consisted of young tree [84]ferns and cabbage plants. many of the ferns attain a great height but the palms more rarely, probably for their being cut down at a certain age for the sake of the heart of the young stem which is very good to eat either raw or cooked, being something between the heart of a cabbage and a cocoanut. (Apr 3, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/83) [NOTES: (H.R. Richmond)]

Tree Fern ..... O. Filices; G. Cyathaea; S. C. dealbata or Silverfern and C. medullaris. Ibid. 2/37 The stately tree-fern leaned aside/ (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,2/336)

HOCHSTETTER ... it is again ferns ... that meet the eye, magnificent Tree ferns, their trunks as if coated with scales, and with neatly shaped crowns (Dicksonia and Cyathea). (1867,New Zealand (various authors/titles),133)

... and an undergrowth which comprises many species of ferns, including tree ferns [fn .Dicksonia squarrosa.]. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,186)

I have [a kakariki nest] made entirely of feathers, moss and the downy scales of tree ferns (Dicksonia); ... (Jul 1885,NZ Journal of Science,480) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

Tree Fern. Cyathea dealbata, Swartz ... Tree Fern. Cyathea medullaris, Swartz ... Tree Fern. Cyathea Smithii, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/51) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

While botanising in the high and dry woods near Matamau, I came upon a fine tree fern (Cyathea dealbata). (Aug 27, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,34)

n.

SHEPHERD The Tree Fern is a very striking object in the woods, it grows from 20 to 40 feet in hight [sic] and from four to eight inches in diameter in its stem, which is of a spongy brittle nature. (1826,Journal) [NOTES: 1826 Shepherd Journal in 1940 Howard Rakiura 356]

SARAH MATHEW ... lofty trees ..., the graceful tree-fern and a sort of tufted reed-like grass tree of very bright vivid green; the ground covered in many places by a most delicate carpet of a peculiarly beautiful creeping fern. (Apr 7, 1840,Journal) [NOTES: 1840 Apr 7 Sarah Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 106]

Another small portion lying along the banks of fresh water creeks, covered with evergreens and tree ferns, affords a rich, pliable clay, ... (1843,Report of Auckland Agricultural Society) [NOTES: 1843 First Report of the Committee of the Auckland Agricultural Society in 1853 Swainson Auckland 21]

ANGAS ... there is an undergrowth ... composed of the nikau palm (areca sapida), and the beautiful tree-fern, which ... has been aptly styled the king of ferns. (1847,Savage Life,1/245)

ARNOLD Then there is the cabbage-tree and the beautiful tree-fern. (Apr 26, 1848,Letters) [NOTES: 1848 Apr 26 Arnold Letters (1966) 41]

[see cit BUSH attrib] (Apr 25, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/79)

J.C. PATTESON I wish you could see the tree-ferns ... (Jul 12, 1855,Letter) [NOTES: 1855 July 12 J.C. Patteson in 1874 Yonge Life of John Coleridge Patteson 2/217]

HOOKER The traveller ... on arriving in New Zealand, finds himself surrounded by a vegetation that is almost wholly new to him; with little that is at first sight striking except the Tree-fern and Cordyline of the northern parts, and nothing familiar, except possibly the Mangrove; ... (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants xxvii)

... a bush-hand, living the life of a hermit in his little whare of tree-fern stems, up in the Waio river-bed. (1871,TrNZI,5/182) [NOTES: (Potts)]

The nikau, or southern palm, is plentiful all through the district, and is everywhere accompanied by noble tree-ferns and palm-lilies. (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,116)

tree-fern large fern with upright woody stem (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,821) [NOTES: [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 1249; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 12]]

POTTS We now pass under the Tree-ferns; the tribe Cyathea is nobly represented by some fine species ... (1882,Out in the Open,55)

Prince The Beech Hut is built of slabs with a tree-fern roof, and contains eight sleeping berths ... (1889,Diary of a Trip,10)

n. Cyathea medullaris, mamaku

LOGAN (And) Cyathea medullaris black tree fern (1875,Ferns of NZ)

POTTS (And) Cyathea medullaris black tree-fern (1882,Out in the Open)

FIELD (And) (1890,Ferns of NZ)

CHEESEMAN C[yathea] medullaris, Swartz ... Trunk 20-50 ft. high ... Korau; Mamaku; Black Tree-fern. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,948)

TURNER (And.) (1909,AJHR,C-11) [NOTES: Botanical Examination Higher Waimarino]

COCKAYNE (And) [see also 1919] (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story)

(And) (1916,NZ Association of Nurserymen, Trade Register)

(And) (Jul 29, 1919,Vernacular Names) [NOTES: Vernacular names used by settlers supplied by W. Best, Otaki]

DOBBIE (And) (1921,NZ Ferns)

COCKAYNE (And) Cyathea medullaris black tree-fern (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The)

(And) Cyathea medullaris black tree fern (1925,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue)

ANDERSON The great uncoiling fronts [of the mamuku] are thickly clothed with dark brown scales ... It is these scales which gave the name black tree-fern in contradistinction to the name silver tree-fern given to the ponga (Cyathea dealbata) with its silvery-undersided fronds. (1942,Maori Place Names,273)

McLINTOCK Black treefern .. mamaku Cyathea medullaris (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

black tree fern [=] mamaku [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,5)

CROOKES ... we can be sure that the beauty-loving soul of the ancient Maori delighted whole-heartedly in these lovely inhabitants of the New Zealand bush. However, his interest in the different tree ferns was certainly not purely aesthetic. Take, for instance, the mamaku, or `black tree fern' (Cyathea medullaris). This is one of the largest and most handsome of all our tree ferns. It can be distinguished by the black stalks of the fronds and the leaf scars that form a definite pattern all round the slender black stem. (1926,Plant Life in Maoriland,10)

tree fuchsia¶

n. Fuchsia excorticata, kotukutuku (See fuchsia)

HEAPHY The Tree Fuchsia (Fuchsia excorticata) is generally about thirty feet in height, and not unlike the weeping willow in general appearance. (1842,Narrative of a Residence in Various Parts of NZ,45)

SEWELL The tree fuchsia not in flower, we are too for the summer and too soon for Autumnal flowers. (1853,Journal of Henry Sewell,I-149)

LAING & BLACKWELL [311] Fuchsia excorticata (The Tree Fuchsia) ... Maori name Kotukutuku or Kohutuhutu, and of the fruit, Konini. (1907,Plants of NZ,294,1940 ed.)

(Dec 1958,NZ Timber Journal,73/2)

tree fuchsia [s] Fuchsia excorticata (Forst.) L.f. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,80)

COCKAYNE (And) (1910,NZ Plants & Their Story,also 2nd ed. 1919 ed.)

ko[o]hutuhutu, an irregularly-growing tree (Fuchsia excorticata), tree-fuchsia: more commonly ko[o]tukutuku, but ko[o]hutuhutu adopted to avoid possible confusion with ko[o]tuku, white-heron. Very often called konini, but konini is the berry of kohutuhutu, edible if rather insipid. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/152) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

BURTON Other berries popular as delicacies were the fleshy, white, pineapple-shaped bracts and berries of the kiekie (Freycinetia banksii), the ripe, black berries of the makomako or wineberry (Aristotelia serrata) and the small, sweet berries (known as konini) of the kotukutuku or tree fuchsia (Fuchsia excorticata). (1980,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,7)

WILSON Fuchsia excorticata TREE FUCHSIA ... Kootukutuku (1982,Stewart Island Plants,70)

DAWSON The flowers of the tree fuchsia (Fuchsia excortica) are mostly produced towards the ends of woody branches... (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,35)

Our native tree fuchsia reputedly bears the tastiest fruit, being likened to blueberries or gooseberries. (Jan 12, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),47)

CHAPPLE A wide variety of plants and trees crowded the track as I made my way up to Harpers Pass. Mountain holly, the Mount Cook lily, tree fuchsia, the turpentine shrub, mountain pine. (2002,Te Araroa: the New Zealand Trail,191)

tree grass¶

n. ? tussock; ? toetoe

TUCKETT Beyond the bush land, that which is called grass land chiefly produces a very cutting wiry species, very similar to that which in swamps we call tree grass, but without the stem or trunk on which the former is elevated above the water surface; these plumes of grass on this dry land in burning diffuse a fragrant and aromatic odour, ... (May 13, 1844,Diary) [NOTES: 1844 May 13 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 220]

TUCKETT ... the prevailing species of trees are remo [rimu], totara, and tall manuka, all indicative of inferior soil.... The bush-like woods on the east side are of white birch, likewise no recommendation of the soil, but the chief objection to the district is, that the prairie soil affords scarcely any food for cattle ... it grows only the wiry tree grass [tussock] ... and Phormium tenax [flax], no aniseed, perennial groundsel, or milk thistle, and very little couch grass. ? Carex secta (Niggerhead) ... [Andersen notes:] Tuckett saw a grass, a very cutting wiry species, very similar to that which in swamps we call tree grass, but without the stem or trunk on whic h the former is elevated above the water surface; these plumes of grass on this dry land in burning diffuse a fragrant and aromatic odour, but as food for cattle they are valueless.' HCE, p. 220. - Dr. D. Munro called this the grass-tree, speaking ofgrass-tree swamps.' HCE, p. 245. (Aug 16, 1844,Diary) [NOTES: 1844 Aug 16 Tuckett's Diary in 1898 Hocken contributions 223-224]

tree gum¶

n.

BARLOW Tree gum is not so valuable as ordinary gum found in the ground ... (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,154)

MALCOLM Commercially this "tree gum" was not as valuable as that found on the ground. (1982,Where it all Began,27)

tree jack¶

n. a device for conveying large logs to a creek or skid road. [Jim writes: Hist? Not in DNZE or NSOD.]

tree line¶

n. (See cf timber-line)

MARK & ADAMS In many parts of New Zealand the lower limit of the alpine zone, marked by the tree line, is a conspicuous feature of the mountain landscape. (1973,NZ Alpine Plants,10,1979 ed.)

Among the large silver and red beech trees of the tundra regions are clearings which contain many plant species also found above the tree line on Mt Manuoha. (1983,Land of the Mist,66)

DAWSON Internationally, the treeline is generally taken to be the lower limit of alpine vegetation. (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,163)

tree lucerne¶

n. Chamaecytisus palmensis. A small quick-growing tree, native to the Canary islands but naturalised in NZ. [Jim writes: Both tree lucerne and tagasaste are recorded in Macquarie 1981 (there classified as Ch. prolifer) but not in any other dictionary I have seen. It is interesting that there is no reference to this tree in Guthrie-Smith's Tutira. Its naturalisation at least in Hawke's Bay is thus likely to be later than 1939.] (See tagasaste)

A search party was formed, gumboots scuffing the gravel of the driveway, past the ute and the well, past the Californian lilacs and the tree lucernes, until we came to a clearing, and there was the gum tree on its side. (Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

On these south slopes, you can see the native plants popping up through the gorse and tree lucerne. (Jan 5, 2006,Dominion Post,C2)

Three-quarters deciduous, one-quarter evergreen with lots of tree lucerne stuffed in the gaps as minders. (Jun 30, 2002,NZ Catholic,17)

lucerne, tree [s] Cytisus proliferus L. Ibid. 80 tree lucerne [s] Cytisus proliferus L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,45)

W3 Mainly Aust (1933 Aust) =TAGASTE, a shrub (Cytisus proliferus) of the Canary Islands that yields cattle fodder. (Sep 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,208/1)

tree lupin¶

n. Lupinus arboreus

lupin, tree [s] Lupinus arboreus . Sims Ibid. 80 tree lupin [s] Lupinus arboreus . Sims [not the Tree lupin . in small tree form] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,45)

Leguminosae Lupinus arboreus . tree lupin (1975,Tane,21/8) [NOTES: Wright Vegetation Mt Maungatawhiri]

TAYLOR TREE LUPIN ( Lupinus arboreus) Perennial with spreading branches, some from the base, growing into a moderately dense bush up to 2.5m but commonly 1 - 1.5m tall. ... In early summer light-yellow flowers ... This Californian plant occurs throughout new Zealand. ... (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,149)

n. Lupinus arboreus

CROWE The common mame is really an exaggeration since tree lupin rarely grows to more than shoulder height, yet the name is helpful in distinguishing this plant from the non-woody perennial lupins, such as Russell lupin. (1995,Which Coastal Plant?,6)

tree manuka¶

n. Leptospermum ericoides, bush manuka, kanuka [[1919 July 29] Ver.(WB). = Vernacular names used by settlers supplied by W.Best, Otaki (And) Leptospermum scoparium tree manuka]

Leptospermum ericoides tree manuka (1907,AJHR) [NOTES: Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of Kapiti Island (And)]

COCKAYNE The tree-manuka (Leptospermum ericoides), with its multitude of white or pinkish flowers, ... (1910,NZ Plants,37)

Leptospermum ericoides tree-manuka (1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology) [NOTES: (And).]

Towards the head of the North-east Valley a considerable quantity of tree-manuka (Leptospermum ericoides) grew; ... (1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/280) [NOTES: (Bathgate, Otago)]

The association of tree-manuka (Leptospermum) ... is a feature of the vegetation ... (1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/202)

HUDSON Tree manuka (L. ericoides) (1934,NZ Beetles,18)

LAING & BLACKWELL Leptospermum ericoides (The Tree Manuka) ... Maori name Manuka-rauriki, but now very often called the kanuka. Both islands. (1940,Plants of NZ,289)

KENWAY ... the timber we had - tree manuka - ... (1947,Quondam Quaker,41)

ma[a]nuka, a shrub (Leptospermum scoparium), commonly called tea-tree, because Cook's people used the fresh young leaves infused for tea; but very often mis-spelt ti-tree - ti being something totally different, the cabbage tree (Cordyline). The tree-manuka is kanuka, with smaller leaves and smaller flowers than the scrub-manuka, and it is the kanuka that is usually sold for firewood. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/144) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

BROOKER et al. Leptospermum scoparium J.R.& G.Forst. Common names: Tea tree, red manuka Maori names: Manuka, kahikatoa Leptospermum ericoides A.Rich. Common names: Tree manuka, white manuka Maori name: Kanuka (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,71)

n.

medick, tree [s] Medicago arborea L. Ibid. 80 tree medick [s] Medicago arborea L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,48)

COCKAYNE (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

tree Nazi¶

Now I'm not a native tree Nazi when it comes to pines. (Jul 15, 2005,NZ Herald,A2)

tree pull¶

1 n. (Rural) a removal of orchard trees.

Option for orchardists: Free tree pull. J.M. Bostock Ltd is offering a free tree pull in addition to a good land lease rate... Agnew Horticulture Ltd Free tree pull on fixed term lease. (May 19, 2001,Hawke's Bay Today,26)

tree tomato¶

n.

Tree Tomato Pie. - Skin the tomatoes by pouring boiling water over them. (Jul 27, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,59)

n. [These were thought to be first mentioned in NZ in the 1891-92 Seed Catalogue of D Hays and Sons, Nurserymen of Parnell, but see quote 1887 Auckland Weekly] (See also tamarillo)

It appears that from Kew, during the last three years, hundreds of packets of seed of the tree tomato have been distributed to various people in the colonies, very favourable accounts having been received of the introduction of the fruit into Southern India, Ceylon and other places. (May 21, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,28)

The tree tomato likes a rich, well-drained soil. (1921,Brett's Gardening Guide,201) [NOTES: 2nd edition]

Tree tomatoes sold at 3s 6d to 6s per case. (Mar 30, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,46)

On February 1, 1967, the name tamarillo officially replaced tree tomato. (Feb 1967,Orchardist NZ,23)

The tamarillo or tree tomato, Cyphomandra betacea Sendt.. is a native of Brazil and Peru. (Jun 1970,Orchardist NZ,149)

GEE For household use we had plum,lemon, grapefruit, peach and nectarine trees and a small grove of tree tomatoes (tamarillos today). (1972,In My Father's Den,83)

BURTON The origin of the old name [sc. of tamarillo], tree tomato, is fairly obvious since it does indeed look like an elongated tomato growing on a tree, but although the tomato and tamarillo belong to the same family, the Solonacaea, there is no similarity between the flavours. (1985,Delectable Fruits Cookery,146)

Tree-tomato (Cyphomandra betacea) . This plant is a native of tropical America, but has been introduced into Jamaica, India, and other countries, including the Australasian Colonies .A quantity of fruit was this summer sold by Wellington fruiterers under the name of "Queensland tomato," and quite took the fancy of buyers. (1894,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture,II/79)

COCKAYNE (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

COCKAYNE (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story) [NOTES: (And)]

Tree Tomato Chutney. Put 2 dozen tree tomatoes in boiling water to remove skins. ... (1936,Cookery Book of NZ Women's Institutes,168)

Other fruits [grown at Kerikeri], of which there are fairly extensive plantings, are Chinese gooseberries and tree tomatoes. (1948,Our Own Country,10) [NOTES: 1948 Our Own Country (from Korero, AEWS magazine) 10]

(May 8, 1959,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22/3)

(1962,Short Stories (various authors),359) [NOTES: 1962 Duckworth in 1966 Short Stories 359]

TURNER Among cultivated plants, silver beet, tree tomato and Chinese gooseberry seem to be commoner in New Zealand than in other English-speaking countries. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,172)

The currency of tree tomato (p. 263) might also owe something to New Zealand, where the tree is well known and has always been called tree tomato (until in 1967 the growers decided to change the name to tamarillo, thought to be a better name for publicity). (1968,Anglia,86/359) [NOTES: G.W.Turner review Pitcairnese Language in Anglia 86/359]

GEE For household use we had (...) a small grove of tree tomatoes (tamarillos today). (1972,In My Father's Den,83)

BURTON Supplies of tropical fruits were curtailed because of the Japanese threats to the sea lanes, and tamarillo (or tree tomato as they were then known) growing began in earnest. [WWII] Ibid. 141 New Zealanders always used to know the tamarillo by the rather uninspired name of tree tomato', but after the fruit became a big export business in the 1960s, the growers decided to change the name to the far more appealingtamarillo', in 1967. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,31)

tree-tomato tamarillo. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,821) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 512]]

Although it sounds Spanish, the name 'tamarillo' is another New Zealand invention. The former name 'tree tomato', was considered inappropriate for use overseas where people buying the fruits for the first time might expect them to taste like tomatoes. In 1967, orchardist Bill Thomson took the Maori word 'tama' added 'tillo' (taken from tomatillo, a complete unrelated Mexican fruit) and then (just to make the sound more mellifluous) he replaced 't' with an 'r'. Thus, 'tamarillo' was born. (Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,58)

CRICHTON Tree Tomato. - The plant known under this name is Solanum betaceum (Cyphomandra betacea), a tall evergreen shrub or small tree, which sometimes attains a height of twenty feet. It is indigenous to Central America. (1893,Australasian Fruit Culturalist, The,II/423)

MESSRS GREEN AND CO., having received instructions, will sell by Public Auction at their Yards 5000 TREES. Consisting of .. Pears, Guavas, Tree Tomatoes ... (Aug 1, 1900,Marlborough Express,3)

The tree tomato is much better known commercially than the egg-plant, but this is probably owing to more having been put upon the market. (Dec 31, 1918,Poverty Bay Herald,8)

tree tutu¶

n.

There are three descriptions of Tutu - the Tree Tutu, the Dwarf Tutu, and the Tutu proper, the latter of which is the most common, and the most dangerous to man. (Mar 8, 1862,Otago Witness,7)

The tree tutu (Coraria ruscifolia) is in some places from 20 to 30 feet high; and although the plants are numerous, each has its independent root. (Feb 8, 1873,Otago Witness,3)

tree weta¶

n. Hemideina ricta

Horace the Hemideina ricta (the Banks Peninsula tree weta) has been a good ambassador for his species, having spent some of February at Lincoln University as part of a study into these rare and endangered species. (Jul 2004,Conservation Action,21)

n.

Dr Gibbs.. visited Somes-Matiu Island during the weekend to check on the progress of the tree weta and the giant weta... Dr Gibbs has kept tabs on female tree weta, building tree boxes for them to nest and then gluing numbers to their skin, allowing him to check on their movements, diet and breeding. (May 5, 2004,Dominion Post,A10)

Many large flightless ground beetles and tree weta became extinct on Quail Island, probably due to vegetation loss and predation by rats, mice and hedgehogs. (Nov 2002,Forest & Bird,306/42)

The domestic arrangements of the Wellington tree weta are fascinating. (Oct 14, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),71)

Tree weta are tough and aggressive, one of our few groups of larger insects which seem able to hold their own against introduced predators. (Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/65)

n.

GILLESPIE ... in places the so-called Maori bug (Platyzosteria novaeseelandiae), and the tree weta (Hemideina megacephala), as well as species of stick insects. (1958,South Canterbury,10,1970 ed.)

McLINTOCK Weta, tree .. .. putangatanga .. .. Hemideina magacephala (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

2 n. Hemideina crassicornis

The Wellington tree weta, (Hemideina crassicornis..) which is found from Mt Ruapehu to Marlborough and Haast, is the most aggressive of the three species of tree weta. (Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/65)

tree-cricket¶

n. weta also forest-cricket [tree cricket]

BULLER Rahui informed us that this [manuka grove] was a favourite resort of the Huia when feeding on the weta or tree-cricket (Deinacrida thoracica). (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/12)

BULLER Rahui informed us that this [manuka grove] was a favourite resort of the Huia when feeding on the weta or tree-cricket (Deinacrida thoracica). Ibid. 1/195 Judge Munro informs me that ... he found in [a morepork's] stomach a specimen of the weta-punga, or tree-cricket (Deinacrida heteracantha), with a body as large as a magnum-bonum plum; ... (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/12)

On a new Species of Deinacrida or Forest-cricket from Nelson. [title] ... I have the pleasure of exhibiting ... a perfectly new species of ... orthopterous insects known as Wetas or Tree-crickets. (1895,TrNZI,28/323) [NOTES: (Buller)]

The nest of the tree cricket is very interesting; the eggs are laid in the pith of raspberry stalks and grape shoots, and as the mother must bore through the tough stem, lay the egg and then close the opening with fluids from her mouth, the amount of work performed by her is incredible. (Apr 18, 1902,Bruce Herald,2)

tree-daisy¶

n. Olearia operina (See also daisy-tree)

COCKAYNE (1919,NZ Plants & Their Story)

LEVY ... such species as lancewood, karamu, toro, ramarama, koromiko, kanono, kohuhu, kawakawa, hangehange, rangiora, five finger, patete, toru, tree daisies, broadleaf, kamahi, mahoe, tarata, karo, lacebark, wineberry, fuchsia, kowhai, with tree ferns, weki, and mamuku. Toetoe, phormium, cabbage tree, with swamp coprosma and hupiro may figure as a developmental phase on wet soils. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,87,1970 ed.)

[In New Zealand there are] daisies growing on trees. Flowers of the tree-daisy (Olearia operina) look like those of the common meadow plant, but wave in giant bunches sometimes as high as twenty feet above the ground. (Apr 1952,National Geographic Magazine,419)

McLINTOCK Tree Daisy see OLEARIA; (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

DAWSON Accompanying species may be the two common larger-leaved coprosmas both known as karamu: C. robusta and C. lucida, the bubbly-leaved ramarama (Lophomyrtus bullata), wharangi (Melicope ternata), the `tree daisies' heketara (Olearia rani) and the familiar large-leaved rangiora (Brachyglottis repanda). (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,103)

HAWES He crashed down towards the river through the wild Irishman, mingimingi, manuka and tree-daisy - leaving behind him a mixed fragrance of rotten egg from smashed stinkwood and roses from bruised mutton-bird scrub.tree-daisy. (2000,Dream of Nikau Jam, The,20)

n. Olearia cheesemanii

There are many tree daisies, both coastal and alpine, but the best known is Olearia cheesemanii, the streamside tree daisy, which is the most abundantly flowered of the lot and deserves to be grown more often as a spring flowering shrub. (Apr 27, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,9)

n. Olearia albida

... I am distracted by another native daisy nearby that has been flowering for the past few weeks. This is the coastal bush tree daisy, Olearia albida, an autumn-flowering member of a large tribe of showy white-flowered native shrubs and trees. (Apr 27, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,9)

n. [general, unspecified]

At the edge of one pengiun colony I visited in December 2002, a single Auckland Island shag had built a large tussock nest under some stunted tree daisies. (Mar 2003,NZ Geographic,62/77)

I have two tree daisies smothered in bunches of white flowers, which all too soon, I'm afraid, will start looking dingy while they go to seed. (Apr 27, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,9)

SHRUBS .. Pink Tree Daisy, Yellow Tree Daisy, Ngaios, 6d. each. (Sep 25, 1930,Evening Post,15)

WANTED Known - Plants for present planting .. Tree Daisies, double and single, white 6d each, sulphur yellow 1s each ... (Oct 1, 1900,Evening Post,1)

The latest plant novelties are here staged, one of them being a very pretty white tree daisy, which resembles a chrysanthemum. (Jan 8, 1913,Evening Post,8)

As a result, the couple are to covenant their stand of Olearia hectori, a deciduous tree daisy, which Sir Peter calls "quite a little treasure trove." (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/92)

tree-doze¶

1 v. (Rural) to knock down a tree with a bulldozer.

FERRIS Live trees were 'treedozed.' The large trees were more easy to treedoze and clear than the medium size timber. (1940,Cavalcade of Farming 1840-1940,71)

tree-flax¶

n. kahakaha, Astelia solandri

Kahakaha, Astelia solandri.- The tree-flax of the settlers; abundant on lofty trees and rocks throughout the Colony. (1874,TrNZI,6/55)

tree-frog¶

n.

HULME A windless peace-filled night, the only sound that liquid continuous chirruping of tree-frogs. (1986,Te Kaihau,39)

tree-gummer¶

n. one who climbs kauri trees to collect ?pieces of GUM lodged in trunks and branches (or ? to collect bled gum) (cf TREE-BLED)

BARLOW [note to a photograph] A Group of Tree-gummers under Kauri. (1888,Kaipara and Waitemata Echo,149)

tree-sitting¶

n.

We started taking people into the forest, providing analysis and intellectual arguments to other organisations like Native Forest Action which was becoming active in terms of tree-sitting. (Apr 2000,North & South,87)

tree-toot¶

n.

The name `tutu' is applied to three distinct species of the ... natural order Coriariae: Coriaria ruscifolia, L. (C. sarmentosa, Forst., C. arborea and C. tutu, Lindsay, tutu, pohou, and tupakihi of the Maori), is commonly known as the tree-toot ... (1901,TrNZI,33/347)

treedozer¶

1 n. (Rural) a bulldozer specifically used to knock down trees and push root, trunk and branches into a stack.

FERRIS The roughing out work was done with either a bulldozer or a treedozer. The treedozer had the advantage of leaving a windrow on either side of the blade as it passes through the ground surface in the roughing out operation. (1940,Cavalcade of Farming 1840-1940,70)

FERRIS When the treedozer was used for 'roughing out,' windrows were left throughout the paddock containing stumps, bush, debris and some soil. (1949,Cavalcade of Farming 1840-1940,71)

The dozer pushes everything - sawn trees and those it overturns itself, plus all the undergrowth - into windrows. [dozer] (Mar 9, 1967,NZ Farmer,8)

trefoil¶

n. [?should TREFOIL go to GRASS; or a separate CLOVER (as TUSSOCK) entry: prob. most to be omitted as gen English]

trefoil [=] black medick: clustered clover: haresfoot refoil: hop trefoil: lesser suckling clover: oxalis: striated clover: suckling clover [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,80)

2 n. stone clover, pussy tail

HILGENDORF HARESFOOT TREFOIL (Trifolium arvense), also occasionally called stone clover and pussy tail, is a weed of light dry gravelly soils and roadsides over both islands. It is an annual with greyish, downy, very inconspicuous leaves, ... and the hairy flower heads, feeling something like a hare's foot, are very characteristic. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,108)

haresfoot trefoil [s] Trifolium arvense L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,36)

trefoil, haresfoot [s] Trifolium arvense L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,80)

2 n.

trefoil, English [=] black medick [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,80)

2 n.

HUTTON & HECTOR The Arara of the Maoris, or the Trevally or Cavalli of the fishermen. (1872,Fishes,110)

hairy birdsfoot trefoil [=] lotus hispidus [s] Ibid. 80 trefoil, hairy birdsfoot [=] lotus hispidus [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,35)

2 n.

hop trefoil [s] Trifolium campestre Schreb.Ibid. 80 trefoil, hop [s] Trifolium campestre Schreb (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,38)

2 n.

trefoil, lesser [=] lesser suckling clover [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,80)

2 n. suckling clover

HILGENDORF SUCKLING CLOVER (Trifolium dubium) was formerly named T. minus. Alternative common names are yellow suckling clover and little trefoil. it is common in pastures throughout all the sown grass lands and even where no sowing has taken place. Its seeds pass unharmed through sheep, and are therefore scattered wherever sheep can travel. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,105,1967 ed.)

2 n.

COCKAYNE But the ... the bird's-foot trefoil, ... and the foxglove, to mention only a few British plants, are now wild in various places. (1910,NZ Plants,135)

PERRY Birdsfoot trefoil. - Under this heading can be considered Lotus major, Lotus corniculatus, Lotus hispidus, and Lotus augustissumus. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,105)

birdsfoot trefoil, [=] [lotus sp(p) [s]] ... birdsfoot trefoil, hairy [=] lotus hispidus [s] Ibid. 80 trefoil, birdsfoot [=] [lotus spp. [s] ] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,5)

Trekka¶

n. New Zealand's only locally designed and mass-produced motor vehicle

"I took a Trekka down to the phonebox - I ran out of petrol - to send a telegram on behalf of the Mt Eden Committee."... The Trekka became known as "the poor man's Land Rover", and many an unfortunate motorist made the mistake of treating their Trekka as if it were a Land Rover, and came to grief when attempting to tackle rough terrain... Even so, the maker found it necessary to suggest to new Trekka owners that "if the engine fails to start ... a push start may be sufficient." (Dec 31, 2001,Dominion,8)

Making the boxy Trekka the centre of New Zealand's contribution to the 2003 Venice Biennale bemused New Zealanders, as well as those who visited. ... The Trekka is an extinct fossil that led nowhere, not even to a kiwi or tuatara, which if clunky, have at least survived millions of years. (Nov 13, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

You are right, Brian Easton, the Trekka was but a fleeting moment in our manufacturing history ... but the Trekka existed. (Nov 20, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),8)

Four "arts ambassadors" from public galleries will spend six weeks working as attendants at the New Zealand exhibition, This is the Trekka, at the 50th Venice Biennale of Art. (May 27, 2003,Dominion Post,A10)

Yes, yes, that ruffled bikini looks fetching, and you've got to love those surfboards, but the star of the picture is the Trekka - a forgotten New Zealand design classic... It's a brilliant story, New Zealand's only locally designed and mass-produced motor vehicle, the Trekka, was the brainchild of Noel Turner, a millionaire who supported Labour. The first Trekka rolled off his assembly line in Otahuhu ion 1966. It came in two colours... It had a four cylinder engine, and took 11 gallons in the tank... Turner's formula was a Skoda mechanical kit, bought at basement prices from Czechoslovakia, bolted to a simple boxy body. (Apr 7, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),65)
