EDMOND knocked himself unconscious (Jesus leans over him -/ slides out the fat, tuatua wallet -/ `For the poor' - he smiles). (Jun 1986,Landfall,158/191)

tuatua .. [scientific name] Paphies subtriangulata .. [other name(s)] -- (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

tuatua n. edible NZ mollusc (tuatua pancakes). [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,828) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

PAUL Tuatua Paphies subtriangulata and P. donacina ... There are two New Zealand species commonly known as tuatua (sometimes less accurately as pipi). In general, P. subtriangulata occurs around the North Island and P. donacina around the South Island and southern North Island ... (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,160)

And mid-40, dreadlockless and with clothes as cool as a scorched tua tua... (Jan 7, 1993,Evening Post,6)

Tuatua Fritters (makes 35 cocktail serves, or six entree or lunch serves)Find a beach near you which has tutaua, check for low tide and take some friends collecting. Alternatively, your fish supplier should be able to procure tuatua meat, possibly already chopped. (Aug 23, 2003,Dominion Post,F5)

"We've been doing it for 12 years. We think we've just about got it right." I do like a good tuatua fritter but, no, the other bloke at my table, snaffled that. I had the scallops. (Aug 17, 2005,NZ Herald - Viva,17)

tuawhenua¶

n.

He is a frightful sufferer from the Maori disease known as tuwhenua, a kind of leprosy. (May 31, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,16)

tub¶

n.

BEARDSLEY As you dug your way in the rails followed, enabling the truckers to push empty tubs right up to where you were working. (1984,Blackball 08,128)

tub-oarsman¶

n. [tub oarsman]

.. the whale is sounding, and the line is running through the 'chocks' or groove in the head of the boat, with the rapidity of lightning, and as it passes round the loggerhead it ignites from theheat produced by friction, but the tub-oarsman is continually dashing water upon it in the line tub. (Aug 15, 1862,Daily Southern Cross,4)

WAKEFIELD The common men have nothing to do but ply their oars according to orders, except one, called the tub-oarsman who sits next to the tub containing the whale-line, and has to see that no entanglement takes place. (1845,Adventure in NZ,1/318)

tubbo¶

n. a tubby person

If you think I'm going down to the gymn [sic] at Parliament, forget it. I'm not going to sit there next to some opposition member looking like a bloody tubbo. (Jun 30, 2001,Dominion Weekend Magazine,2)

tube¶

n.

tube: can of beer to crack a tube: to open a can of beer (1980,Lynfield College, Auckland) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

tube mill¶

n.

BLYTH Tube Mill: Used for fine grinding of ore after it has been rough crushed by stamp mill or other crusher. Usually about 20 feet long and 4 or 5 feet diameter lined with manganese steel or rubber. (1935,Gold Mining Year Book,11)

tube park¶

n.

Two years ago 20% of snowmaking equipment over there [sc. the States] was sold to tube parks. (Jul 23, 2000,Sunday Star Times,C11)

tube rescue¶

n. a swimming rescue using an inflated tube

If we were going to do a tube rescue we would strip down to the boardies. (Jan 2001,Sunday Star Times,D4)

If we were going to do a tube rescue we would strip down to the boardies. (Jan 14, 2001,Sunday Star Times,D4)

tube-wrapped¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of hay and silage] enclosed in a single long plastic tube.

Tube-wrapped silage is also easier to feed out. (Oct 22, 1998,NZ Farmer,17)

tubed, get¶

v.

tubed: modern word for the abandonment of anything; e.g., `I failed my units and got tubed.' (1981,NZ Police National Headquarters) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

tuber sword fern¶

n.

The tuber sword-fern (Nephrolepis cordifolia) produces small potato-like tubers on its roots that will grown out into new plants. (Jan 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 49/69)

TUC¶

abbr. Trade Union Council

A rival organisaton was set up and named the Trade Union Council (TUC). (Feb 17, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),32)

tuck in¶

v. (Rural) [sheepdogs] to keep a tidy periphery of a mob of sheep.

WHYTE It is usually unnecessary for a dog to come round too far tucking in the corners when he has only three sheep to deal with - although with a larger flock of wild sheep on a steep hillside turning in the corners becomes an urgent necessity. A full tucking-in turn is necessary. (1927,Sheep-Dog, The,52)

tucker¶

n. (Rural) stock feed. (See milking tucker; dog tucker; hard tucker)

The cows have exhibited an unfailing ability to consume every whisp of tucker they're offered, and then make it clear they's like more. (Sep 11, 1961,NZ Dairy Exporter,73)

He likes the black. It's a small cow which is ideal on the hill, requiring minimum tucker for maintenance. (Sep 10, 1970,NZ Farmer,35)

At this stage the lamb is still getting most of its tucker from Mum so is not dirtying pastures. (Jun 11, 1981,NZ Farmer,39)

Much of the rest of the district finishes the winter with plenty of tucker both in the paddocks and in the barns. (Aug 23, 1984,NZ Farmer,74)

Canterbury beekeepers now have their own bee tucker orchard for growing willows. We have someone somewhere working on growing carobs .. which could provide winter tucker in our drought areas. (Aug 1985,Growing Today,46)

HALL Haylage is better, more succulent tucker, too. (1987,Shepherd's Year, A,106)

"We're constantly moving sheep," Hamish says, "trying to bank up tucker ahead of them all the time." (Dec 14, 1988,NZ Farmer,19)

It's not the sort of tucker to fatten lambs on, but somehow it does seem to clean them up. (Nov 2000,Growing Today,65)

HOLDEN Out on the flat, big hairy ears shot up and some horses whinnied. Tucker! Again Piers whistled, and horses streamed by him ... (2001,Riding Country,79)

1 v. (Rural) [station staff] to eat.

NEWTON .. the cowboy was tuckering at the cookshop on his own. (1964,Straggle Muster,87)

NEWTON When they were out at camp the cowboy tuckered at the house. (1966,Boss's Story, The,25)

NEWTON As it happened he wanted a cowboy and against his better judgment he gave me the job - $2 a week, sleep in the whare with the men, tucker with the married couple. (1978,Five Hundred Horses,7)

In reply to His Worship defendant said he did not know who his brother Willie was "tuckering" with at the time referred to, but it was not with him. (Oct 5, 1889,Te Aroha News,2)

The bosses like them[,] they tucker themselves and they put the men to sleep in any sort of a stable or pig stye. (Jan 19, 1912,Maoriland Worker,14)

Wanted to know - whether young B. is tuckering himself now, as he is so often seen at the baker's shop. (May 4, 1889,Observer (Auckland),17)

NEWTON When they were out at camp the cowboy tuckered at the house. Ibid. 130 They tuckered at the cookshop and while they were there the boys lived like kings. (1966,Boss's Story, The,25)

1 n. (Rural) food for farm or station personnel [now in more general use.]

In such cases they have to wade up nearly to their chins in some parts in snow water, so as to evade their being "jammed["], probably for a week, without a "tucker." (Oct 17, 1857,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

The foreign tucker went down a treat at the postwar smoko, with members "wiping the platter clean". (Nov 1, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

MONEY .. The blankets did duty as a carpet bag, holding ... and tucker, the latter comprising almost anything within the provinces of food. (1871,Knocking About in NZ,23)

.. there have been hundreds of men travelling about the country in search of work, who, as the saying is, are not worth their 'tucker.' (Feb 21, 1880,Otago Witness,5)

WILLIAMS Only a pound a week and tucker ... (1899,Colonial Couplets,28)

After tucker the men sat round the eating-house discussing the phenomenon. (May 1, 1945,NZ Dairy Exporter,86)

NEWTON There were no huts out on the tops and they carried everything they required on their backs - tent, bedding and tucker. (1975,Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,71)

The cafe was opened last year for those who like some tucker with their tipple. (Sep 24, 1999,Taranaki Daily News,Farming Today Supplement 23)

... it might make people sick at the thought but it's great bloke tucker. (Dec 9, 2001,Sunday Star Times,D6)

Native tucker: Chef Charles Royal has developed a wide range of native New Zealand ingredients. Now we can try horopito pepper in the form of a rub or horopito and piripiri sauce. (Jan 2002,Cuisine,70)

IRELAND During this time he worked for his tucker on a bullock team, as a goad-boy. (1998,Under the Bridge & Over the Moon,26)

RICHMOND It is very hard work humping your blankets and tucker. (May 12, 1864,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,II : 111) [NOTES: 1960 edition]

FORBES A peer's son who is earning his 'tucker' as a station cook in New Zealand. (Oct 1883,Contemporary Review,606)

KOEBEL If they had obtained no wages for the first six months or so, they would have obtained their 'tucker' free. (1911,Maoriland Bush,275)

SHADBOLT Later Ned got the tucker cooking. It was stew and spud, like most nights. (1972,Strangers and Journeys,43)

One week might be right enough, but if they would only "butt in and get out into the farmers' country" they were bound to get enough work to live, if it was only grubbing gorse, but they would not do that while they got tucker for nothing. (Aug 3, 1926,Evening Post,6)

People would turn up on the steamer with no money and no idea. He'd kit them out with gear and tucker on the condition they'd sell the gum to him. (Apr 1991,NZ Geographic,22)

DAVIES There would be no hope of "tucker" - a bad look-out, as we were down to the last "split pea". (1884,Poems & Other Literary Remains,262)

I can state that our "tucker" is of the best, both in quality and quantity. (Sep 29, 1916,Chronicles NZEF,I/3 : 60)

As for "tucker" being dear, it is all false. (May 3, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,19)

We halted to refresh ourselves from the supply of 'tucker' in our swags. (Feb 12, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

PASCOE They were short of tucker as birds were scarce, and were glad to reach a roadman's camp at the Haast, where they fed like kings for four days. (1958,Great Days in NZ Mountaineering,146)

2 v. to provide food for

NEWTON One of his peculiarities was that he never liked to dine in the cookhouse; he always preferred to tucker himself and in true Maori fashion he practically lived off the land. (1969,Big Country of the North Island,63)

The men unloading the cargo ex the Tyser steamer Marere at No.16, Jervois-quay wharf, are being accomodated and "tuckered" on that vessel. (Nov 17, 1913,Evening Post,8)

All hands are "tuckered" on the premises, a much better system than "so much and tucker yourself," the odds in favour being glaringly apparent at dinner-time, when the cooking of " spuds,'' etc., eating thereof, and travelling to and fro have to be accomplished by a bachelor in the short space of one hour. (Jan 6, 1892,Tuapeka Times,3)

The men "tucker" themselves, in pairs .. "Tuckering" small parties is necessarily extravagant, particularly where men are unskilled in culinary arts. (Aug 14, 1908,Bay of Plenty Times,4)

CARR All shearing work in New Zealand ... is so much and found. In ... some sheds, the Maoris tucker themselves. (1913,Country Work,15)

To quote the words of a visitor whom I overheard make the remark, "They couldn't have been better tuckered." (Apr 11, 1879,Clutha Leader,6)

All hands are "tuckered" on the premises, a much better system than "so much and tucker yourself," the odds in favour being glaringly apparent at dinner-time, when the cooking of " spuds,'' etc., eating thereof, and travelling to and fro have to be accomplished by a bachelor in the short space of one hour. (Jan 6, 1892,Tuapeka Times,3)

The men "tucker" themselves, in pairs .. "Tuckering" small parties is necessarily extravagant, particularly where men are unskilled in culinary arts. (Aug 14, 1908,Bay of Plenty Times,4)

Ample provision appeared to be made for "tuckering" the passengers. (Apr 3, 1879,Grey River Argus,2)

She claimed GBP10 for damages and 17s 6d a day each for tuckering and boarding the team. (Jun 10, 1922,NZ Truth,5)

tucker allowance¶

1 n. (Rural) an amount of meat each musterer is permitted for his team of dogs.

HOLDEN Each man was allowed a maximum of five dogs; they received a tucker allowance of one-quarter of a sheep every second day. (1993,Station Country I,51)

tucker bag¶

n. a container for food, especially as carried by a swagger, outdoor worker, etc. (See also tucker box)

ELKINGTON Each swagman carries his "billy" (a tin can for boiling tea) and a "tucker-bag," in which he keeps his lunch. (1906,Adrift in NZ,127)

That night, either by accident or design, Jim left his tucker bag on the job when he went back to camp. Next morning the tucker bag was still there but the half-loaf of bread and the remains of a roast pigeon it contained had gone. (Sep 1962,Te Ao Hou,40: 18)

BELL The squatter may growl at the prices of wool,/ And the farmer complain of the weather./ But though money be tight, and though times may be dull,/ It's little we [sundowners] care if our tucker-bag's full -/ Ibid. 51 [spg tucker-bag] It was midday when he roused himself, opened his tucker-bag, and made a fair meal of what he found there. He did not boil his billy, ... but contented himself with a drink from a small stream that ran in a gully near by. (1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,15)

AYTON Cooking meat and vegetables. Making new tucker bag. Destroyed one tom kitten. (Apr 18, 1900,Diary,27,1982 ed.)

MOWAT So the packman, W, Sansom, dealt out a pound to each man to carry in his tucker bag. (1907,Diary) [NOTES: c1907-1914 Mowat diary in 1969 McCaskill Molesworth 103]

ACLAND (1933,Press, The)

SARGESON Right at the top they stopped to eat their lunch. ... But before sitting down Mr Anderson took off the tucker-bag he had carried on his back - and there were sandwiches, wholemeal scones, slices of cold mutton, bananas and fancy cakes. (1949,I Saw in My Dream,119,1974 ed. Rhodes ed.)

NEWTON Bundling the bird up in his tucker bag he finished his beat ... and gave it to the [packie].... (1952,High Country Journey,180)

HOGAN There's tucker in the tucker bag/ The world is good to me./ (1962,Billy-Can Ballads,12)

tucker bag n. bag for carrying food. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

JOHNSTON A tucker bag with a bottle of oatmeal water was soon prepared and the two set off. (1968,Turn of the Tide, The,69)

tucker bag n. bag for carrying food. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

TOMLINSON I had a good horse, saddle and bridle, and also a ... tucker bag and tea billy as I headed for Tarndale [station]. (1968,Remembered Trails,37)

McCASKILL The quart billy clipped on to the shoulder strap of the tucker bag ... (1969,Molesworth,101)

AGNEW I handed [the swagger] a couple of thick-sliced mutton sandwiches from the tucker bag and we munched away in silence, aware of the tumbling of a nearby brook, . (1974,Loner, The,103)

SUTHERLAND ... Ewan [a schoolboy] got the sandwiches from the tuckerbag. (1978,Elver, The,64)

CHARLES There is a black billy pot by my camp fire,/ Tucker bag and blankets beside./ (1981,Black Billy Tea,51)

RICHARDS [To our British teacher] a paddock was now a field, our tucker or crib bags (made out of sugar bags) became satchels or lunch bags and our oilskin coats became macs. We preferred to retain our bush language. Ibid. 61 First we [bushmen] would put our `tucker bag' in a dry place, then sharpen our axes. (1986,Off the Sheep's Back,38)

The fire would not burn, and the four sat round a few smouldering embers waiting for the billy to boil. At length the water bubbled, and a rush was made for the tucker bag. (May 29, 1877,Bruce Herald,5)

On Monday they get up at five o'clock, when it is dark: and when they had been mustered on July 6, Eastwood asked to be allowed to go to his cell for his tucker bag, which he had forgotten. (Jul 14, 1885,Star, The,3)

The bag is a calico bag, commonly called by diggers a tucker bag. (May 6, 1865,Otago Witness,18)

Another way was for the men below working in collusion with the trucker, to put the specimens in a "tucker" bag put in the bottom of a truck loaded with mullock. (Apr 23, 1910,Evening Post,10)

tucker bell¶

n. a dinner bell; a bell rung to summon hands to meals

NEWTON He waited for the tucker bell at a nearby station. (1947,Wayleggo,103)

tucker bill¶

n. a food bill; a grocery bill (urban use of the word is often humorous rather than slangy) [ca1960 Wellington The tucker bill's twenty pounds this month.]

... their own tucker-bill. (1905,NZ Truth,13/4/5)

tucker box¶

n. the box holding musterers' tucker when camped away from the homestead

n. (Rural) a musterer's food box.

NEWTON They were also to collect the tucker box and billy from the cookshop, and have the billy swinging when the mob was yarded. (1949,High Country Days,19)

NEWTON the 'rousie' had the billy boiling so .. they collected the tucker box and sought a prominence, where they could get a full view of the flat. (1949,High Country Days,22)

MCLEOD Early next morning he left the station, riding a big, black horse called Nigger and leading a packhorse with a big tucker box hung on each side and Willie's swag across the top. (1954,On the Hill,26)

I then saw him on the top of the waggon, when he was in the act of taking the tarpaulin off the top of the tucker box. (Oct 15, 1874,Clutha Leader,5)

This sensitively constructed, family story evokes dry, Central Otago rabbiting, but with a tucker box - a loaf of bread, cheese, hardboiled eggs, a leg of cold mutton, apples and a fruit cake - of an amplitude outside the scope of present-day poor families. (Feb 15, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),46)

The carrier inevitably produced the proverbial tucker box. (Jan 30, 1890,Otago Witness,13)

A fire is lit in an oil drum, the billy is dipped over the side of the boat and filled, the `tucker box' is produced and its contents spread, ... and luncheon is served. (Mar 5, 1891,Otago Witness,28) [NOTES: 1891 Mar 5 Otago Witness 28 in 1987 Hill Richard Henry of Resolution Island 88]

(1933,Press, The) [NOTES: Acland]

NEWTON They were also to collect tucker-box and billy from the cook-shop. (1949,High Country Days,19)

SCRYMGEOUR Tucker boxes from home were a source of gratification and each had many pals when these well-filled parcels arrived, and were safely put away in their respective lockers. (1960,Memories of Maoriland,35) [NOTES: (boarding school)]

tucker box n. tin or wooden box for carrying food. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

tucker box n tin or wooden box for carrying food. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

HAMILTON In the [mustering] hut were two bunks, a tucker box, an old frying pan, various billies and a teapot. (1969,Wild Irishman,107)

LETHBRIDGE Ivan [the cook] had his `tucker boxes' packed, the horses loaded with all our gear,... (1971,Sunrise on the Hills,42)

CHARLES Once in the tucker-box he had him a ball,/ And ate all the grub ... (1981,Black Billy Tea,26)

HARTLEY Sometimes we came across one [swagger] boiling his billy in a roadman's clearing ... and eating cold meat and bread from his tucker box (1987,Swagger on Our Doorstep,113)

".. Men once again got some welcome variety into their 'tucker boxes.'" (Aug 10, 1943,Evening Post,4)

(N.B. - Always take a dog when you go camping out; it helps to discourage the rats a little. They are inquisitive little critters, and have a great fancy for the tucker box.) (Dec 23, 1887,Otago Witness,20)

tucker boy¶

1 n. (Rural) a young male worker who takes food and drinks to rural workers. (See billy boy)

EVANS Once when I was nine, and had just arrived in the shearing shed with the men's morning tea, Bobbie Rhodes of Bluecliffs Station called in and he said 'Are you the tucker boy?' A girl aged nine, I never forgot the insult. (1975,Silver Tussock, The,87)

tucker claim¶

n.

SUTHERLAND The Jeweller's Shop' supported its owner generously and allowed him leisure and relaxation which his hard work entitled him to and exciting week-ends in the city that notucker' claim would have given him. (1953,Golden Bush, The,97,1963 ed.)

HEINZ CLAIMSWorthless claims or ground were called schicers or duffers. Those yielding up to [pounds]3 per week per man were known as tucker' claims; up to [pounds]8 per week were known aswages' claims; above [pounds]8 were known as pilers'; the richest of all were known asHome-ward-bounders.' (1974,Bright Fine Gold)

.. and many claims, which would command a special report in the mining intelligence of the local papers in those districts, are abandoned or talked of as mere "tucker" claims in the Tokitika or Grey districts. (Jan 2, 1866,Colonist (Nelson),3)

Circumstances of this kind go to prove that the industrious prospector is sure of finding something worth his trouble, and at all events has a much better chance of a rise than the steady worker in a mere tucker claim. (Sep 4, 1869,Tuapeka Times,2)

To my question to one party relative to the payable nature of the ground or otherwise, I received the following impromptu reply, "Not much good, only tucker claim, very poor," &c., &c. (Feb 4, 1887,Otago Witness,22)

One or two claims in the gully contunue to pay the shareholders fair wages, while others are what the diggers call "tucker" claims. (May 22, 1873,Tuapeka Times,5)

At the Wilson there are three or four payable alluvial claims on the terraces, while others are only tucker claims, the more so as water has been scarce for the last two months. (Feb 21, 1895,Otago Witness,17)

tucker diggings¶

n.

After a few remarks about the West Coast being worked out, except as a tucker diggings, and about the good a new rush would do, the visitor goes on his way, and Bill resigns himself without a sigh to the prospect of being the sole inhabitant of the gully for the nest twelvemonths. (Jan 17, 1887,Star, The,1)

MAY The field', wrote a Waimea digger,is what is usually termed `tucker' diggings ... there is gold everywhere, but it has been scattered with a sparing hand.' (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,107,1962 ed.)

Provisions are very dear, and men have to swag them over five miles, through a bad track, all crags and hills - and the returns from mining in the Bullock Creek, and the gullies of it are so small as to give it (the Haast) the name of a tucker diggings. (Dec 4, 1873,Grey River Argus,2)

Even at the best of times the gullies were only tucker diggings, and for every ton of alluvial there were ten tons of stones to be shifted. (Jul 15, 1903,Otago Witness,86)

Let the Invercargill Times publish as a stern indisputable fact - th[a]t the present Switzer's is barely a tucker diggings. (Sep 11, 1863,Otago Witness,5)

tucker fucker¶

n. an army cook [ca1963 Oct 4 G.L. Gabites (Wellington) Heard `tucker-fucker' from a Wellington Taxidriver.]

McGILL tucker fucker army cook. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,115)

tucker ground¶

n. OED: 6. [f. TUCK n.1 6 or v.1 10.] The daily supply of food of a gold-digger or station-hand; rations, meals; also, food generally, victuals: = TUCK n.1 6b. to earn or make one's tucker, to earn merely enough to pay for one's keep. Austral. and N.Z. slang.

n. auriferous ground on which merely bare tucker can be made (cf wages ground; payable) [aka tucker-ground]

Tucker Flat..has been looked upon as containing worse than 'tucker' ground. (1870,AJHR,40 : 4)

Tucker Flat ... has been looked upon as containing worse than `tucker' ground. (1870,AJHR,D40/4) [NOTES: (Report Goldfields)]

[In c1865] the diggings were only considered `tucker-ground'. (1887,Handbook NZ Mines,125)

PFAFF [The Scandinavian field] was called in those days `Flash Tucker Ground,' and paid about [pounds]20 per week. (1914,Diggers' Story, The,80)

HEINZ (1947,Bright Fine Gold,200)

HEINZ Tucker ground: Poor ground, just rich enough to allow the miner to buy the necessities of life. (1952,Prospecting for Gold,56)

MAY It was a matter of nice judgement. The digger recognized four classes of payable ground: tucker ground' kept him in food with nothing to spare; awages claim' gave him a pound or two above living expenses; a riser' was a rich claim; and apiler' or homeward bounder' the richest of all. Probably most of thepilers' were beach-claims, where the leads were shallow and rich, the outlay small and provisions cheap because of easy access. (1967,West Coast Gold Rushes,244,1962 ed.)

The whole country has been prospected ... and ascertained to afford only very ordinary `tucker ground'. (1865,Evening Post,1/46/2)

The whole country has been prospected for months, if not years, and ascertained to afford only very ordinary "tucker-ground." (Mar 27, 1865,Otago Daily Times,4)

This is abundantly proved by the testimonials which have been received from time to time, which in some instances afford striking evidence of the changes wrought in the productiveness of the soil by the application of the latest thing in plough, drill, or harrow, causing areas that were formerly, in digger parlance, only "flash tucker" ground, to yield a harvest equal to the most fertile. (Jan 20, 1892,Southland Times,3)

tucker house¶

n. a hotel considered from the point of view of its table

HISLOP [Stanley's Hotel at Macraes Flat, Central Otago] was one of the best tucker houses on the road, and with bacon and eggs for breakfast, the hungry C.T. who was usually found stopping there would have a full ashet to help himself from, placed before him. (1943,Pure Gold,16)

tucker money¶

n.

WHEELER He looked over the half-completed sketch, ... then asked, What's the dough like?' Sensing competition, I had the presence of mind to assure him thatIf you're lucky you just about make tucker money.' (1973,Historic Sheep Stations NI,98)

tucker stand¶

n. a food depot

EASTWOOD Sometime prior to 1880, a horse track ran from the Grey River up Ford Creek and over Hughes Hill, to a "tucker stand" or food depot at Coal Creek. (1982,Brief History of Gold Mining, A,56)

tucker trip¶

n.

Basically, I was working for food and a bunk - they're what we call 'tucker trips' so I'm real keen to get some big fish now the bluefin season is on. (May 15, 2004,Dominion Post,C4)

tucker-cart¶

n. A conveyance carrying food for an outdoor working group.

(1900,Auckland Weekly News,Xmas No. / 17)

tucker-time¶

n.

BEATTIE Another pioneer said ... [that] a meal was often alluded to as tucker-time', and there would sound forth what the hungry men regarded as the welcome call oftucker's ready', or perhaps `the billy's boiling', or some cry of similar import. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,12)

FARRELL They're back in a minute, creepy creepy, tails tucked to bony bellies waiting for tucker-time. (1992,Skinny Louie Book,270)

[Caption] Tucker-time; Specials at Dinner at Mount Cook Barracks, Wellington. (Aug 13, 1908,Auckland Weekly News,53)

tuckered out¶

adj. exhausted [Jim writes: NSOD tags this as NAmer, Collins as chiefly US & Canadian. In NZPOD and used in NZ for many years.]

Just spent two hours chainsawing wood so I'm real tuckered out." (Mar 15, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),51)

IHIMAERA Yeah, you wait till I'm too tuckered out before you attack ay. (1974,Whanau,130)

The wind had dropped, so it took till Tuesday afternoon to row with those heavy seas to a sheltered bay off the cape, intenting to settle in for the night "all being pretty well tuckered out." (Feb 2001,NZ Memories,35)

tuckering¶

n. the provision of food (See tucker n. & v)

Then another practical difficulty is the extravagance of the cost of "tuckering." (Aug 18, 1908,Hawera & Normanby Star,4)

I have often before now referred to the system of threshing in this district, and especially regarding the paying and "tuckering" of the men, as it is called. (Apr 23, 1891,Otago Witness,17)

tuckerless¶

adj. without food

HARPER We were left almost `tuckerless' on Christmas day. (1946,Memories of Mountains,162)

From her previous state the day before, jobless, moneyless, referenceless, tuckerless - any other - less you like to make things look dar-r-r-k and gloomy - it was quite a step to her present state of affluence; any ordinary girl might be pardoned for indulging in a little weep at her prospects, but not Connie. (Aug 6, 1921,NZ Truth,2)

There was nothing for it - no returning, and the ark was tuckerless, - so into this dug-out Maori canoe we were - 20 all told - constrained to enter, bag and baggage. (Dec 21, 1904,Otago Witness,90)

tuere¶

n. hagfish, blind eel

Cleaning the fish in the shore water for the tuere, the blind eel, to smell and come nosing in. (Jan 10, 2000,Evening Post,9)

Mr. E.R. Waite.. gives tuere as their [sc. blind eels'] Maori name, but Mr. Sutherland was told that kapo is the proper Maori name. (Mar 9, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

Tuere to the Maoris, hagfish to the [English].. and plain blind eels to you and me. (Aug 1962,Sea Spray,79)

TAYLOR Fam. Cyclostomi has the Tuere. (Heptatrema domberyii,) found in Dusky Bay, and also in Cook's Straits, it is about two feet long, has several small feelers attached to the head, and a broad flat tail, the color [sic] is dark brown, and the body of uniform thickness; it is known as the mud eel and is remarkable for its power of emitting slime to such an extent as completely to envelop it. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,627)

PHILLIPPS Heptatretus cirrhatus (Bloch and Schneider). HAGFISH; TUERE. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,6,1971 ed.)

GRAHAM Heptatretus cirrhatus (Bloch and Schneider). Hagfish (slime-eel, hag, slimy, borer). Tuere. (1938,TrRSNZ,68/399)

BEATTIE The above list of fish to be caught along the Canterbury coast has some notable omissions, as hoka (red cod) ... Others omitted are the tarakihi, or terakihi, the moki, the komutumutu (trevalli), the puhaiwhakarua (red-jacket), koiro (conger eel), tuere (blind eel), whai (skate), and the koekohe [sic] (trumpeter). (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,62)

GRAHAM HAGFISH (TUERE) Eptatretus cirrhatus (Bloch and Schneider) The Hagfish, or Blind-eel as the fishermen call it, is one of the most unpleasant-looking creatures of the sea. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,51)

DOOGUE & MORELAND HAGFISH ... Other names: Heptatretus cirrhatus ; blind eel; tuere, napia (Maori) (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,297)

MORELAND HAGFISH [Eptatretus cirrhatus] ... Hagfish and blind eel are widely used alternative names, while the Maori tuere and napia are still in use. (1967,Marine Fishes,30)

WILLIAMS Tuere, Tuare, n. 1. Heptatretus cirrhatus, blind eel. (1971,Dictionary of the Maori Language,448)

GRADY Some of the whalers at Fishing Bay, especially the Maoris, enjoyed sea foods and found turi (blind eels or hagfish) a particular delicacy after they had been properly treated. (1982,Perano Whalers,111)

EDWARDS Blind eels like tuere and piharau - very unusual taste. (1992,Mihipeka,39)

Tuesday blues¶

n.

The main drawbacks [to Ecstasy] are the come downs or "Tuesday blues" and he says the drug is only unsafe if you don't know what you are taking. (Apr 5, 2003,Dominion Post,F1)

tuft-grass¶

n. (See grass,tuft-grass)

McGILL tug to masturbate. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,115)

tufted penguin¶

n. [variously Eudyptes antipodum, Eudyptes crestatus / Eudyptes crestatus filholi, uncertain taxonomy; a rockhopper penguin]

This is the list of eggs Dr Fulton wants to order to make a complete collection for the museum ... Rock Hopper, Tufted Penguin ... (Sep 20, 1905,Otago Witness,88)

Somewhat similar in general appearance save that the crest consists of elongated drooping feathers is the Tufted Penguin, which never breeds on the mainland but frequents the Snares, Antipodes, Auckland, Campbell, and Macquarrie [sic] Islands, and is even found within the Antarctic Circle, as is recorded by Scott, Shackleton, and Mawson. (Apr 14, 1920,Grey River Argus,5)

tug chain¶

n.

HENDERSON TUG CHAIN: Short stout chain used on horse working in shafts. (1961,Friends in Chains,189) [NOTES: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 189]

tug merchant¶

n.

O'SULLIVAN Talk about jellies on springs ... Bloody tug merchant (1985,Shuriken,28)

tuhituhi¶

n. writing [ORIGIN: Maori]

In the course you will learn korero (speaking), whakarongo (listening), tuhituhi (writing), panui (presentation), and language structure in a safe and comfortable whanau environment. (Dec 2, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,10)

Tuhoe¶

n. Maori of the Urewera

Urewera Country is the high, forested and remote region of the North Island, extending from the eastern edge of the Whakatane district in the eastern Bay of Plenty down into Hawke's Bay and including Lake Waikaremoana... It was the home of the Nga Potiki, or Tuhoe people, also known as 'The Children of the Mist'. (2000,Bateman New Zealand Encyclopedia,656)

We have a really distinctive Tuhoe monotone. (Jun 1998,Mana,35)

The Urewera are the home of the Tuhoe tribe, the people of the mist. (Nov 19, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

[The Urewera] is home to the Tuhoe, "the children of the mist", of all the Maori tribes the least touched by Eueopean influences. (May 18, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

Tuhoe n. large Maori tribe found in the Urewera country inland from the Bay of Plenty, sometimes called the Children of the Mist. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,829) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

By walking the original Maori war trails, we have found a wilderness of waterways, mountains, centuries-old trees, rare forest birds, ancient Tuhoe pa and also the long-hidden battlesites of the protagonists... [30] Ngati Kahungunu, with some attached Pakeha soldiers and civilian scouts, at last accomplished what no previous government force had: overrunning and defeating the lake-dwelling Tuhoe tribes in a number of waterborne operations... (Oct 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),29)

The world is full of mist and rain again. You'd expect mist - the Tuhoe, the Children of the Mist, are descended from a cloud maiden - but we could do without the rain. (Oct 11, 2003,Dominion Post,E15)

Tuhoeland¶

n. a name given by Elsdon Best to the Urewera and other neighbouring areas of ancestral Tuhoe lands

BEST The bush which still covers the greater part of Tuhoeland is what an European bushman would term light bush'. A sawmiller would not describe it as atimber bush'. There is a good patch of timber at Te Whaiti, but elsewhere the timber trees ... are scattered, or in small clumps. (1925,Tuhoe: The Children of the Mist,9)

FIRTH He [a Tuhoe elder] knew the old Native names of every tree, shrub, plant, or fern in the forests of Tuhoeland. (1929,Primitive Economics of NZ Maori,43)

LAMBERT But while it may not be possible to claim for Tuhoeland a monopoly of fairy-folk, it is true that nowhere in Maoriland are there such varieties of legends ... (1936,Pioneering Reminiscences of Old Wairoa,58)

'Twas then the bloodstained garments of the slaughtered twain were found, / And the darkling woods of Tuhoeland rang to the trumpet's sound. (May 22, 1909,Star, The,2)

"Tuhoe Land" was an article dealing with personal reminiscences in the Uriwera [sic] Country. (Sep 1, 1896,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

A dangerous cliff has for many years formed a bug-bear to travellers who have essayed the overland journey through Tuhoeland, but a track has been opened up which will enable this obstacle to be safely negotiated. (Feb 10, 1914,Poverty Bay Herald,9)

tuhua¶

n. obsidian

Parts of the shore are composed entirely of jet black obsidian, or "volcanic glass," termed by the Maoris Tuhua. (Feb 16, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,14)

Tuhuan¶

adj. Geol. Classification

Adams also completed a new, tentatively Tuhuan, Rb-Sr isochron for certain Dusky Sound granites. (Oct 1982,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,58/57)

Janet Gabites and Chris Adams (INS) presented up-to-date compilations of K-Ar and Rb-Sr age data for the late Tuhuan (U. Devonian-Carboniferous) phase. (Nov 1978,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,46/35)

tuhuhi¶

n. a tree

McKILLOP The tanekaha tree yields a black or brown dye, and the tuhuhi a blue-black dye from the wood and bark, as does the mako; the whakou also yields a handsome blue. (1849,Reminiscences,162)

tui¶

n. a glossy black native honeyeater with a tuft of white feathers at its throat, an excellent mimic. Prosthemadra novaeseelandiae [ORIGIN: Maori, aka New Zealand blackbird, koko, mocking-bird, parson-bird, poe] (See parson-bird)

Tui work their way round the suburbs drawing nectar from seasonal flowers such as pohutukawa and flax (and, yes, introduced trees such as eucalypts and Indian coral). (May 2002,Forest & Bird,26)

Bird enthusiasts are in for a treat with a good chance of seeing .. tui, bellbirds and kaka in the regenerating forests ... (Nov 2006,Footnotes,26 / 7)

SINCLAIR [Maori glossary] tui Bird (Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae) (1959,History of New Zealand,302)

tui n -s [Maori] : a predominantly glossy black New Zealand honey eater (Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae) with white markings on throat, neck, and wings that is a notable mimic and often kept as a cage bird - called also parson bird (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2461)

FALLA et al. TUI Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae Other name: Parson Bird. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,221)

McLINTOCK The vocabulary of New Zealand English has been influenced by .. the adoption of Maori words and phrases .. Examples of the native words now in general use are the names of birds, fish, plants, and trees: kea, tui, hapuku, tarakihi, koromiko, raupo, and kauri, hapuku. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/679) [NOTES: Wall NZ Speech]

HAYNES The bird has received the appellation of the `parson bird' (the Maori name of Tui is perhaps more generally used). (1865,Ramble in the NZ Bush, A,13)

Prosthemadera Novae Zelandiae. Tui. Very abundant. (1869,TrNZI,1/160) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

PROSTHEMADERA NOVAE ZELANDIAE, Gml. Tui. Parson-bird .. in the eyes of the omnivorous settler, it possesses the higher merit of furnishing an article of food, and no weak sentimental feeling saves it from the camp-oven. (1870,TrNZI,2/55) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

BULLER 11. PROSTHEMADERA NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. Gray. Parson Bird. Tui. (1871,Birds of New Zealand,5)

BULLER PROSTHEMADRA NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (TUI OR PARSON-BIRD.) .. Native names. Tui and Koko; the young bird distinguished as Pi-tui or Pikari. (1873,Birds of New Zealand,87,1888 2nd edn 1/94 ed.)

CAMPBELL No sign of human life that morning; the shrill cry of the curlew on the beach and the full rich carol of the tui or parson-bird from the brushwood skirting the shore fell faintly upon the ear. (1881,Poenamo,2/5/99)

DOMETT (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/305)

HOWARD [Stewart Island birds include] the fern-bird (Bowdleria fulva), the bell-bird (Anthornis melanura), South Island Robin (Miro Albifrons), Tui (Prosthemadera novae zealandiae), 'Tui,' Parson-bird or Poe-bird of Capt. Cook Melliphagidae; Prosthemadera Novae Zealandiae. (1940,Rakiura,323)

tui n. small New Zealand bird, with remarkable imitative powers; the mockingbird, or parson-bird. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

tui .. n. small N.Z. bird, with remarkable imitative powers; mocking-bird, parson-bird. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

266.a. Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae novaeseelandiae (Gmelin, 1788) Tui (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,70,1980 ed.)

tui n. a New Zealand songbird with white feathers at the throat. Also called: parson bird. [< Maori] (1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,1260) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 829; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 516]]

Tui Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae (GMELIN, 788) .. Chatham Island Tui P.n. chathamensis HARTET, 1928 .. OTHER NAME: Parson bird. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,291)

WHITWORTH The tui-tui in his coat of metallic black ... (1875,Cobb's Box,1875,5 ed.)

  1. Prosthemadera Novae Zealandiae, Gml. Parson-bird, Poe-bird, Tui, Koko. - Often builds under the shelter of Rubus twines, which many of us have learnt to fear or respect as bush-lawyer .. More than once I have found it near the top of a matipo (Myrsine) ... (Nov 1884,NZ Journal of Science,276) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

I noticed the following:- Pigeon, tui, korimako, kaka, ruru, piwakawaka, toutouwai, kingfisher, duck and teal in the lakes, and pukeko in the swamp, and various sea birds. (1884,TrNZI,17/419) [NOTES: (Gold-Smith)]

He has had a rough time of it surveying a block on the ranges up the Wai-o-hine in the Wairarapa [sic] .. Once [sic] .. they had nothing to eat but a tui and a more-pork .. They were stewing the two birds when a kuku-pa (bush pigeon) flew up and perched .. Bob shot it .. This is not exactly what the Britishers call `sport' - but there is more of nature about it than 30 gents in pink and tops .. waiting for a wretched little fox who, when he is killed, is not equal for culinary purposes to a more-pork. Once coming up the Waikato in 1851 your Uncle James got a pot-shot at a lot of parera (grey duck) ... (Mar 22, 1894,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,2/597,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (C.W. Richmond)]

MORRIS Maori name for the New Zealand bird, Prosthemadera novae-zelandiae, Gray; called the Parson-bird (q.v.), and earlier the Poe (q.v.). Another name is the koko, and the young bird is distinguished as Pi-tui, or Pikari. It is also called the Mocking-bird. (1898,Austral English,481)

WHITE The Tui, or `Parson Bird,' as he is irreverently called, because he has a tuft of white feathers on his throat which are supposed to resemble a clergyman's bands, is shining black and metallic blue. (1905,My NZ Garden,70)

MANSFIELD - ferns, tuis and we saw the sheep sheds - smell and sound - 12 Maoris - Ibid. 51 Here we drive in and ask for a paddock [sic no stop] Past the shearing shed - past the homestead to a beautiful place with a little patch of bush - tuis - magpies - cattle ... (1907,Urewera Notebook,40) [NOTES: 1978 Gordon]

TUI. - New Zealand bird with sweet song. (1917,New Zealand At the Front,xiv)

MANSFIELD And then at the first beam of sun the birds began. Big cheeky birds, starlings and mynahs, whistled on the lawns, the little birds, the goldfinches and linnets and fantails flicked from bough to bough. A lovely kingfisher perched on the paddock fence preening his rich beauty, and a tui sang his three notes and laughed and sang them again. (1920,Stories,233,1984 Alpers ed.)

Prominently ... is to be observed ... the tuii ... (1883,TrNZI,15/317) [NOTES: (Colenso)]

PROSTHEMADERA NOVAE-ZEALANDIAE, Gml. - Tui. (1886,TrNZI,18/125) [NOTES: (Hamilton)]

Prosthemadera novae-zealandiae. - Tui. Both Islands; also, Auckland and Chatham Islands. (1886,TrNZI,18/112) [NOTES: (Martin)]

So with the New Zealand birds: the Mocker, the Tui, the warbler, the Tomtit, the Robin, the Brown Creeper, the Canary, the White-eye .. are all known to feed the Cuckoo bantlings ... (1904,TrNZI,36/116)

Tú.i (tú.&emacr.), n. [Maori.] (Zoo.l.) The parson bird. See under PARSON, in the Dictionary. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2033)

(Black Stewart Island) The following is a list of the birds shot .. Hieracidea Novae Zealandiae, the sparrow hawk; Prosthemadera Novae Zealandiae, tui or parson bird. (1872,Appendix Proc. Otago Prov. Council,39)

(Duppa) ... ptui, or mocking bird. (1840,NZ Journal,1/1/221)

HODGSKIN .. the most harmonious is the toi or tue, to which we gave the nickname of parson, from its being a beautiful glossy black, and having a small patch of snow-white feathers on the neck .. Some call this the mocking-bird, as it imitates the voice of almost every other bird ... (1841,Narrative of Eight Months Sojourn in NZ, A,28)

DIEFFENBACH 6. Prosthemadera Novae Seelandiae. Strickl. .. Poe, or Toi of the natives of Queen Charlotte's Sound. Forst. Toni of the natives. Less. Tui of the natives. Dieffenbach. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/187)

SELWYN The natives added to our store by catching a parrot, five Tuis, and a Weka (a species of rail), living themselves upon fern root ... (Nov 15, 1843,Journal) [NOTES: 1843 Nov 15 Selwyn Journal in 1845 NZ Part II (Church in the Colonies VII) 49]

DIEFFENBACH Tuis or mocking-birds. (1841,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/45)

DIEFFENBACH After leaving the village we crossed to another bay, E-Taua. This bay also is spacious and pleasant. Kingfishers, oystercatchers, tuis [fn Anthochoera concinnata, Vig. and Horsfield.], and cormorants [fn Pelecanus pica, Forst.], enlivened the trees on its shores, and many birds were singing in the forest. Ibid. 1/118 .. the warbling of the tui [fn1 Anthochaera concinnata, Vig. and Horsf.], whose note resembles that of our thrush or blackbird ... (1843,Travels in NZ,1/59)

[spg toe] Henry went in the bush: shot two Birds and two toes. (Feb 27, 1844,Piraki Log,150,ed. Anson 1911 ed.)

Rail and pukeka were caught by snares set in their sphagnum moss runs .. Tui and mako (bell birds) were killed by the birder hutching beneath a cone of fern fronds ... (1928,BP Bishop Memoirs,Vol. IX No. 5 /362) [NOTES: 1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 362]

GUTHRIE The lapping of the sea mingled with the bell notes of the moko moko and tui and .. that of the burning bush wood in the boiling of the `billy'. Ibid. 89 The liquid notes of tuis and moko-mokos rang out in unison, and kaw-kaws and [90] parakeets made splashes of colour as the sun caught their iridescent wings. (1930,NZ Memories,70)

Tui.- The old name Parson bird had gone out of general use before 1880. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (Dec 30, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

You have done some mad things Where the glad tui sings His song, but you were always wild ... (Jul 25, 1919,Hawke's Bay Herald,7)

The Tui, or parson-bird, preaches extempore from the bush. (Nov 10, 1888,Observer (Auckland),4)

The tuis at this period of the year appear to be out of voice - their notes being of a very bass and guttural description. (Oct 26, 1910,Hawera & Normanby Star,8)

No bullocky ever loved a tui, for the simple reason that these birds are great imitators, and they would often lead these bullockies astray. The bullocky would follow what he thought was the sound of one of his bells, and instead, find a tui up a tree. (1986,Speaking for Ourselves,161)

MORELAND The tuis were going mad with delight; cheerful birds dressed in sober black, with two white feathers at the throat, earning them the name of the 'parson-bird'. (1911,Through South Westland,00)

There is a definite pecking order among the birds, with the larger tui holding the "top gun" position, followed by bellbird and then hihi, which are the social underdogs of the trio. (Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/89)

WADMAN Only the tui, oblivious in the honey-flower, blows a crystal bubble into the air and anchors it with a rusty chain. (1947,Yearbook of Arts in NZ,3/148)

LEE & KENDALL T|ui, s. A bird so called. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,218)

CRUISE [The dawn chorus ceased] and with the exception of the tooi, and some other birds whose songs are almost uninterrupted, the woods are comparatively silent for the remainder of the day. (1823,Journal,196,1957 ed.)

EARLE Tooee or New Zealand Blackbird. (1832,Narrative of a Residence in Various Parts of NZ,174)

MARKHAM .. and also the Toi [tui] bird or Parson .. With two bands under the Chin of white Feathers .. called Parson birds. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),34,1963 ed.)

McDONNELL [spg zooe] The Pigeon and Zooe are perhaps the handsomest - the former is really a magnificent bird - almost as large as a barn-door fowl, and equally invites the attention of the Ornothologist [sic] and the epicurean - the latter has two feathery [35] wattles pendent from its ear, and some few of its notes are not unlike those of the wattle bird of Van Diemen's Land. (1834,Extracts From a Journal,34,1979 ed.)

YATE Tui - This remarkable bird, from the versatility of its talents for imitation, has, by some, been called `the Mocking Bird'; and, from its pecu-[53] liar plumage, has by others been denominated the Parson Bird'. (1835,Some Account of NZ,52)

POLACK Among the birds that distinguished themselves in this woodland concert, were the tui, or mocking-bird, the korimaku [a-acute], kohapiroa, and tiaki [a-acute]. The little restless piwakawaka [a2,a4-acute], a kind of thrush, who is incessantly hopping from twig to twig, put forth its single note. Ibid. 1/296 The tui, or mocking-bird, is best known to the stranger in the country. The natives vend these birds, in wicker cages, to their transient visitors : it is called tui, from the resemblance of its note to that sound. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/108)

TAYLOR The Tui bird's note is very sweet it reminds me of a German clock. (Apr 13, 1839,Journal,2/100)

MAY The Tui is a curious greenish black bird with a little ruff of feathers under his chin like a clergymans [sic] bands. (1840,Journal of Ensign Best,222,1966 ed.)

MAY Just as I had shot the 2nd Toughie (or Toey Toey as it is also spelt) spied a Barque beating in. (Oct 1840,Journal of Ensign Best,248,1966 ed.)

WAKEFIELD Tui or mocking-bird. (1845,Advance NZ,1/80)

ANGAS The graceful tui, or parson-bird (Prosthemadera Novae Selandicae) sported amongst the yellow blossoms of the kowai ... (1847,Savage Life,2/29)

The tui, or parson-bird, or mocking-bird, as it is indifferently called ... (1851,Canterbury Papers,11/310)

GODLEY Across the path .. comes the bush, full of birds singing all day, tuis and bell-birds and New Zealand robins ... (Sep 8, 1851,Letters from Canterbury, NZ) [NOTES: 1851 Sep 8 C. Godley ?Letters from Canterbury in 1947 Reed Story of Canterbury 100]

MACKIE The only native bird we find commonly kept in cages is the `tue', Parson bird. (Apr 4, 1853,Traveller under Concern,96,1973 ed.)

BUTLER The tui or parson-bird is a starling, and has a small tuft of white cravat-like feathers growing from its throat. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,9/137)

BARKER Then we crept softly up .. to have a good look at the Tui, or Parson-bird, most respectable and clerical-looking in its glossy black suit, .. and white wattles of very slender feathers .. curled coquettishly at each side of his throat, exactly like bands. (1866,Station Life in NZ,93,1870 ed.)

tui, a bird (Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae), the most characteristic of the smaller Maori birds, kept by the Maori as a pet and by them taught to speak, it being an excellent mimic, and so by the settlers called the mocking-bird, shortened to mockie, and called parson-bird because of the two white curled tufts of feathers at its throat. Then, [check parson-bird inclusion - not in Journ Polyn Soc ref???] because some folk thought mockie was short for makomako, a name of the bell-bird (korimako) in some parts, some thought it was the korimako which was the mimic, and hence both birds have been called the mocking-birds. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/147) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

tui: singing forest bird. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

HENDERSON I thought I had had enough excitement .. but Ratapu persuaded me to go on with my tui-catching. The hawk had scared the tuis away for a time ... (1948,Taina,138)

The Maori name of a handsome New Zealand bird. (Pronounce .us too-ee See parson-bird.) (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),424)

Tui¶

n. a brand of beer, originally produced at Mangatainoka [ORIGIN: Maori, propr.]

Mr Young says: "Pass the Ecstasy/latte/chardonnay/Tui". (Jun 21, 2002,Evening Post)

Tui has been brewing on its present site since 1889 when Henry Wagstaff began brewing "quality brews to beer drinkers around the colony"... "It's this bottle of Tui," said the visitor. "It's cloudy". (Sep 27, 1999,Manawatu Evening Standard,Suppl. 4)

You score a try under the Tui goalpost every Saturday and when you're old enough you can stand at the Tui bar and drink. (Feb 29, 2004,Dominion Post,A9)

"It's not cool to go around the corner and find a six-pack of used Tuis," he said. (Oct 31, 2003,Dominion Post,A1)

"A handle of Tui's, please, I gasped, and by Christ it tasted superb sitting there beneath an electric fan, my face already cooled down after splashing myself with cold water in the bathroom basin. (Mar 18, 2000,Dominion,94)

The truth is, I was down at the pub with everyone else on Saturday, shaking my head in disbelief and looking for some solace in the bottom of a Tui handle after we were robbed of the Bledisloe. (Aug 14, 2000,Salient,No. 17 : 42)

Norman Dowling produced a large bottle of liquid "Tui." (1938,Canterbury Mountaineer, The,VII/57)

And even when we do all sit together, differences in gender rhetoric keep us talking past each other like a lineup of bill boards for Tui beer. (Oct 11, 2003,Dominion Post,B4)

n. a woman soldier in WWII [[check whether refers to NZWWSA, or NZWRAC, or NZWAAC] ?sc member of the NZWRAC: NZ Woman's Royal Army Corps]]

This incident occurred before the NZWWSA in the Middle East became known as WAAC's.] (1946,Johnny Enzed in the Middle East,14)

... Lady Freyberg was mother' to the New Zealand girls, a special relationship she maintains, Miss Neeley said. It was her idea, she said, to settle onTuis' as a nickname for the women. `The New Zealand men were always known as Kiwis, so they wanted a slang term for us'. (Oct 24, 1972,Press, The,6/3)

hend ... Lady Freyberg's personal maid ... was a `Tui' in the war. (1978,Soldier Country)

LATHAM On October 29th the unit was welcomed at Tewfik by Brigadier Falconer and Mrs B.C.Freyberg (who christened them the Tuis'. Was the reasoning that the General had his Kiwis so the girls naturally became the Tuis?) <i>Ibid.</i> 37 [caption] <i>First draft of 30 WWSA (calledTuis') on steps of Parliament House, September 1941. (Hats! - also note WWSA badges on lapel.) (1986,WAAC Story, The,21)

"Tuis" is the name by which the girls are likely to become known. (Oct 20, 1941,Top of the Bill,I/17 : 17)

[Hdg] A "Tui" Wedding... On Friday, June 19, a very quiet wedding took place between Corporal Joyce Gilmour, N.Z.W.W.S.A... and Lieutenant Kenneth Webb, R.N. (Jun 29, 1942,NZEF Times,II/53 : 5)

n. a member of a WWI NZ pierrot party; "The Tuis", the concert party

WOLFE Another bunch of theatrical New Zealanders who sometimes swelled the ranks of the Kiwis were the Tuis, whose costume was ornithologically correct with white frothy ruffles and pompoms. (1991,Kiwi,34)

DOWNES The concert party was enlarged by members of the small free-lance entertainment troupe of the 4th Brigade, the Tuis. (1979,Top of the Bill,54)

The existing pierrot troupes The Kiwis',Tuis' and others have reached a high standard of excellence. (Aug 2, 1918,NZEF Chronicles,10)

A few evenings ago we were treated to a very meritorious and musical entertainment by "The Tuis" Pierrots (mobile). (Jul 5, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/47 : 248)

The existing pierrot troupes, "The Kiwis", "Tuis" and others, have reached such a high standard of excellence that it makes it doubly hard for a new troupe to create an impression. (Aug 2, 1918,Chronicles NZEF,IV/49 : 10)

tui fever¶

n.

They call it tui fever, the time around now when tui feast on the late autumn nectars of the bush... Tui released into the sanctuary are already being attributed to the rise in sightings of this native in the Capital's backyards. (Jun 5, 2003,Contact (Wgtn),7)

tui grass¶

n. toetoe grass [(misrep. of toe (toi))]

CAIRD Tui grass ... a very graceful plant, closely resembling a grass that is grown in the gardens, called, I think, Spanish grass. (1874,NZ Sheepfarming,30)

DAVIDSON ... a cluster of tui-grass. (1889,Stories of NZ Life,55)

WALKER ... silver plumes of `tui' grass. (1902,Zealandia's Guerdon,80)

Tui moment¶

n. a realisation of disbelief, expressed by 'Yeah right'. [From Tui beer advertising, the 'Yeah right' series]

Over here at Computerworld, we had a major Tui moment on reading that, and I got stuck into the figures. (Feb 24, 2006,Computerworld Friday Fryup,1)

Author: adrian woodliffe Date: 05-07-04 18:08 mmm not sure guys BUT this sounds like a "tui" moment: YEAH RIGHT!!! (2005,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.homebizbuzz.co.nz/forum/read.php?f=14&i=54&t=52 *Accessed 1/3/6]

tui-catching¶

n.

HENDERSON I thought I had had enough excitement ...; but Ratapu persuaded me to go on with my tui-catching. The hawk had scared the tuis away for a time ... (1948,Taina,138)

tukauki¶

n. a plant, Libertia ixioides

tu[u]ka[a]uki, a plant (Libertia Ixioides), handsome smallish flower with three round white petals and pale-yellow centre: at its best it forms a semi-globe of white blossom in most unlikely-seeming places. [brackets in name/hyphen in semi-globe???] (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/159) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

WILSON Libertia ixioides MIKOIKOI ... Native iris ... Tuukaauki (1982,Stewart Island Plants,296)

tuke¶

n. a form of bird snare

BULLER The Maoris are accustomed to snare [Bell-birds] by means of a tuke [illustrated: 1873 edition has tuki] baited with the crimson flowers of the etrosideros. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,1/89)

tuki-tuki¶

n. a pestle

REISCHEK Within lay two rotted and carved coffins, and close by were cases of death-offerings, wooden clubs, stone axes, tuki-tuki, etc. (1930,Yesterdays in Maoriland,65,1933 ed.)

Tukidale¶

1 n. (Rural) a New Zealand-bred sheep, bred specifically for carpet wool production. [ORIGIN: blend, toponymic origin: Tukituki, Hawke's Bay]

BLACK & DYSON The Tukidale descended from a hairy Romney ram lamb ("Dreamy") adopted as a pet in 1966 by Mr M V Coop of Tuki Tuki, east of Havelock North. (1978,Carpetmakers: Specialty Carpet Wool breeds of NZ,7)

BLACK & DYSON The fleece weight of the Cheviot and Down breeds does not match that of the Drysdales. Tukidales, Carpetmasters, and coarse Perendales. (1978,Carpetmakers: Specialty Carpet Wool breeds of NZ,12)

WARMAN It [the Drysdale] grew into something called 'a carpet on the hoof' and its success has inspired the development of two similar breeds - the intriguingly named Tukidales and Carpetmasters. (1991,What Sheep is that?,28)

WONZ Tukidales and Carpetmasters, other strains developed since Drysdales, have similar genes and wool characteristics. (1994,NZ Sheep and Their Wool,19)

The Tukidale breed originated in the early 1970's [sic] when mutation in a Romney flock produced a very coarse coated ram which passed on the characteristics to his progeny. (1993,Wool Technology and Sheep Breeding,383)

tukirunga¶

n. a tree fern

HOOKER Tukirunga, Col[enso]. Dicksonia antarctica. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),78)

tukituki¶

v. to kill

... tukky-tuk [from E tek-ke [acute]] (1798,Account of English Colony in NSW)

GRACE ... what the law would do if he tukituki'd a white man. (1901,Tales of a Dying Race,16)

[A Maori woman speaks] Make me 'trong again. T'en I show you Pakeha what I do. I tukituki everyone. (1911,Triad, The,18/6/38)

tukorehu¶

n.

HOOKER Tukarehu, Lindsay. Plantago sp. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

tuku land¶

n. land gifted in accordance with customary Maori lore

Kennedy Bay is famous in the Maori world for being one of the few remaining examples of land gifted in accordance with customary Maori lore - tuku land. (Jul 1998,NZ Geographic,No. 39/39)

Tukugate¶

n.

Will Mr Sturt be asked to stand aside while the Serious Fraud Office investigates complaints into the Tukugate scandal? (Mar 13, 1997,Dominion,2)

Isn't it a fact that Tukugate could result in the collapse of this Government and a general election? (Mar 14, 1997,Dominion,2)

Parliamentary insiders report that one of the "old school" they effect to despise.. had to be called in to prevent a macho boilover in the inner circle during Tukugate discussions. (Mar 22, 1997,Listener (New Zealand Listener),7)

He has said these phrases so often now during Tukugate that it begs for the parroting. (May 3, 1997,Dominion,25)

[Hdg] Tukugate sets the Govt morally adrift... With a failure to resolve Tukugate when it first came up earlier this year, the crisis has grown sticker, deeper and more unmanageable in the repetition. (May 4, 1997,Sunday Star Times,C2)

This breaks the unofficial rule, that the Opposition leader's gaze should never fall lower than the third-ranked minister unless the pickings are rich - such as Tukugate or the Tourism Board. (Sep 4, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),13)

"It follows on from Tukugate and the attempted annihilation of a Maori MP..." (Mar 15, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

tukura¶

n. (Rural) a variety of farmed native flax, Phormium tenax. [ORIGIN: Maori]

The Tukura which used to grow on the Motoa Estate was much sought after by the Maori. (Aug 22, 1903,Farmers' Union Advocate,1)

tukus¶

n. underpants [From MP Tukuroirangi Morgan whose expenditure claims on the Maori TV station included very expensive underpants]

He shows them his "Tuku" undies, silk boxer shorts emblazoned with cannabis leaves. (Nov 5, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

Wellington meanswear retailer reports the best line (to date) from a shopper: "I need a pair of tuks. Large." (Feb 22, 1997,Evening Post,64)

I keep telling myself not to panic, not to get my tukus in a knot over the catastrophe. (Feb 21, 1997,Independent (Auckland),13)

Having followed the shenanigans of Tuku Morgan, I thought I'd write to you with the suggestion that from now on men's underwear should simply be called "tukus". (Mar 10, 1997,Dominion,10)

We have a new word in the language. On Wednesday I heard some Lower Hutt schoolboys discussing the birthday of one of their number. When he was asked what sort of presents he'd got, the birthday boy recited a list, and about half-way through he said, "and I got some new tukus"... I look forward to the next edition of the Oxford New Zealand Dictionary, for the inevitable entry:tuku n. pl (Colloq.) 1. underpants, worn by males, usu. decorative. [abbrev. of Tukuroirangi, Maori]. 2. v. intr. (sl). 1. offer to sell an interview on a matter of importance when a Member of Parliament. (Jun 7, 1997,Dominion,20)

tukutuku¶

n. the ornamental lattice-work panels in the walls of a Maori house. [Maori]

ALEXANDER Seeing that poupou and tukutuku are the traditional means of decorating, I have taken it that both must be employed. (1951,Story of Te Aute, The,205)

Tukutuku panels adorned the walls and kowhai covered the exposed beams overhead. (2000,Kokopu Dreams,64)

HULME 266 Tukutuku/poupou = forms of wall decoration (1983,Bone People, The,467)

tukutuku n. ornamental lattice-work of toi-toi reeds interlaced with flax etc., used as wall panelling in Maori whares. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,829) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

The gate across the road into the Nga Hau e Wha Christchurch National marae is chained and double- padlocked. Behind the palisade fence the weeds are knee high. The whare nui is boarded up ... None of its carvings and tukutuku are in place and the carvings are still tapu. The whare wananga beside it, meant to house the kohanga reo, lies uncompleted, torn building paper flapping. (Mar 5, 1988,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

TREGEAR The panels of this lattice-work (tukutuku) had elaborate patterns, and the horizontal laths were gaily painted. (1904,Maori Race, The,272)

It is nearly time now to devote some attention at the school to tukutuku. The idea is to reintroduce the kakaho reeds at the back, instead of milled laths. (Jun 11, 1933,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/88) [NOTES: (Ngata)]

The arts and crafts section comprised tukutuku, ... plaiting (rourou [fn A small basket used for cooked food.], rough kits and floor mats), taniko work and making poi balls. (Mar 28, 1936,Na To Hoa Aroha,3/212) [NOTES: (Ngata)]

tukutuku, ornamental lattice-work of toetoe-reeds (kakaho) cross-laced in various patterns with narrow strips of flax and pingao: a panel of tukutuku was placed between every pair of poupou on the whare walls. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/160) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

ZIMMERMAN Between the beams, the wall was covered with lattice panels, which Weno told me were tuku-tuku work - geometric figures of white on a dark background, like very coarse cross-stitch. (1946,Where the People Sing,30)

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,2/321-322, 2/127-128)

187 The tuhu tuhu or kowhaiwhai (coloured scroll work) and the tukutuku (decorative reed panels) are admirable examples of Maori art ... (Aug 15, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture)

(Nov 20, 1958,Listener (New Zealand Listener),825/2)

tukutuku n -s [Maori] : decorative Maori latticework usu. of flax or kiekie stems and in the form of panels that are used esp. between the carved posts of communal buildings (as a meetinghouse) (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2461)

MANTELL It [sc. a banner] was about two foot square ... An edging of tukutuku the pattern enclosed trade symbols of motorcycles ... (1980,Murder and Chips,66)

I became inspired then to write a play where, as the tukutuku panel purapurawhetu (a basic star design) is being woven, its story unfolds around the weaver. (Mar 6, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),37)

The interior of the house has some very pretty panel lattice work, the tukutuku of the Maori house-builder. (Nov 6, 1911,Evening Post,9)

Robinson's ambiguous "The What is and the What is not" plays with the binary codes of computer technology, suggesting the tukutuku of a whare, as well as the flash-card patterning of British artist Bridget Riley. (Jun 21, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),50)

n.

n. a curse, particularly one directed towards a notable person. [ORIGIN: Maori]

.. and it is not uncommon to hear a chief complain that he has been shot at, when on explanation it appears that he has only been thus shot in effigy. This form of insult is called a "tapatapa," or "tukutuku." (Mar 31, 1852,New Zealander, The,2)

Other peculiar uses of names were the tapatapa and tukutuku . To tapa anything was to give the name of a person to it, the effect of which was to put it, figuratively, into the keeping of the person named, after which any other person taking a liberty with it would be regarded as an insult to the person whose name had been so used. (1892,Proceedings RSNZ,25/397)

Taylor Another way of obtaining revenge, was by cursing. To call any object by the name of a chief, and then strike or insult it, was regarded as a curse; this was tapatapa, or tukutuku. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,94)

2 adj.

JC always intended that the mezzanine wall should be furnished with tukutuku panels, but Emma hasn't got around to doing that just yet. (May 10, 2003,Dominion Post,F14)

BAXTER ... an old church/ Where the tukutuku work/ Plaited by women's fingers, has split and dried,/ Ibid. 400 And I knew for the first time the meaning of/ The yellow woven tukutuku panels,/ (1979,Collected Poems,374,1966 ed.)

tukutuku-work¶

n. [tukutuku work]

Arundo is toetoe-kakaho, the latter word referring to the valued culms. Some people object to the reed tukutuku-work as being flimsy and perishable: in reality it is as durable as galvanized-iron and far more handome and artistic: the interior of a good Maori house is a thing of beauty. (Sep 9, 1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/146) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

BUCK (1949,Coming of the Maori, The,3/381, 397)

BAXTER ... an old church/ Where the tukutuku work/ Plaited by women's fingers, has split and dried,/ Ibid. 400 And I knew for the first time the meaning of/ The yellow woven tukutuku panels,/ (1979,Collected Poems,374,1966 ed.)

And lastly, the tukutuku work which fills in the spaces between the carved pillars around the walls of the house is brought only two-thirds of the way up instead of up to the cornice. (Jun 2, 1924,Evening Post,8)

tukuwhenua¶

n. inherited land [ORIGIN: Maori]

We've got Maori selling tukuwhenua now, inherited land from the grandparents, now . . . . (Sep 6, 2005,NZ Herald,A13)

tumatagowry¶

n. [empty headword, no cits] (See tumatakuru)

tumataguru¶

n. [empty headword, no cits] (See tumatakuru)

tumatakahuki¶

n. tukutuku pattern [ORIGIN: Maori, (from kiwianatown.co.nz) Tukutuku are intricately woven panels often found lining the walls of the Wharenui (meeting house). These panels express ideas from Maori mythology, philosophy and history. The patterns displayed here are : Tumatakahuki (pattern either side) double/triple binding which ensures strength. Poutama (steps) has religious and educational connotations relating to levels of attainment. Roimata Toroa (albatross tears) denoting misadventure particularly to crops. Purapura Whetu (myriad of stars) relates to population and the peopling of a region.]

Vertical lines reference tumatakahuki, a procedure which binds the horizontal tukutuku rods in place - an analogy for the kind of frameworks required to maintain the Maori collective. (Nov 23, 2005,NZ Herald,B5)

tumatakuru¶

n. Discaria toumatou, matagouri (q.v. for anglicisations), =(wild) Irishman, a thorny shrub

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] a prickly native shrub Discaria toumatou [commonly corrupted from the Maori tumatakuru to matagouri.] [tumatagora, tumatikura, tomatagaru, toumatakuru, tomatagorra, tumatagowry] (See matagouri)

THOMSON Much of the country bears fine grass but is overrun with a shrub called tomatagaru by the natives or Wild Irishman by the colonists. (1857,BLANK ENTRY,9) [NOTES: in Hamilton (1952) History of Northern Southland]

BATHGATE .. one may there travel for days in succession without ever seeing anything larger than a bush of tumatakuru (discaria toumatou) a straggling prickling, almost leafless shrub, attaining sometimes a height of ten to fourteen feet, known to the colonists as 'wild Irishman.' (1874,Colonial Experiences,70)

There's even pressure to propagate the frightful thorny tumatakuru, or matagouri, a pest in anyone's language. (Aug 15, 2004,Sunday Star Times,C3)

SELWYN Slow walk over the plain from the Tumatakuru Bush which made the men feel their way very cautiously. (Jan 1844,Journal,70)

SHORTLAND They [sc. sandals] no doubt owed their invention to the necessity of protecting the feet from ... the sharp prickles of the small shrub `tumatakuru' (discaria toumatou, Raoul), which is very common on the plains, ... (Jan 13, 1844,Southern Districts of NZ,210) [NOTES: 1844 Jan 13 in 1851 Shortland Southern Districts of NZ 210]

TAYLOR We passed over a grassy plain filled with the Tumatikura, the taramea, and a beautiful flower ... a variety of herb centaury ... (Mar 13, 1845,Journal,3/93)

HALL-JONES The country ... is much overrun with a scrub called Tomataguru [H.-J. matagouri] by the natives, or `wild Irishman' by the colonists ... (1971,Mr Surveyor Thomson,59) [NOTES: 1850s in 1971 Hall-Jones Mr Surveyor Thomson 59 (Griffiths Collection)]

SHORTLAND TUMATAKURU .us (discaria toumatou, Raoul),;a dwarf thorn, common in the plains of the Middle Island. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,314)

ROBERTS Writing of the Waimea Plain in 1856: - The ground was well grassed, but the speargrass was too plentiful. The pasturage was very good. There was a good deal of scrub in the bends of the Mataura known aswire plant' (Olearia virgata). There were also manuka and koromiko. Maori-heads, a kind of grass tree about three feet high, abounded in the swamps, and in some we saw toitoi grass and raupo. We did not pass any cabbage trees to-day ... we proceeded slowly through tomatakuru scrub, speargrass, Spaniard, snowgrass, and other native grasses ... we camped in a bend with good feed at the Elbow and a swamp on one side. Maori cabbage abounded ...' (1856,Diary) [NOTES: 1856 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 18]

HECTOR Discaria toumatou, Raoul. Tumatakuru, Wild Irishman.--A bush or small tree with spreading branches; if properly trained would form a handsome hedge that would be stronger than whitehorn. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,131)

PYKE As the only trees' to be found on the Tuapeka goldfields were Te-matau Kauri (better known asWild Irishmen') and Tutu bushes, of not very exuberant growth, the law in this respect went ahead of the facts. (1887,History of the Early Gold Discoveries in Otago,61,1962 ed.)

DUNCAN A shovelful of earth from under a tomatagorra bush ... (1888,Wakatipians,82)

MORRIS Tumata-kuru, n. Maori name for plant better known as Wild Irishman (q.v.), Discaria toumatou, Raoul. `A thorny plant, very difficult to handle.' (Vincent Pyke.) Tumatagowry, or Matagory (q.v.), is the Southern corruption of contractors, labourers, and others. (1898,Austral English,482)

Tú.má.tu-kú.ru (tú.ma.́.tu-kú.ru), n. [Maori.] [Written also tomatakuru.] (Bot.) A New Zealand tree (Discaria toumatou) of the order Rhamneae; - called also matagory and wild Irishman. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2033)

I remember, in 1867, visiting a runholder who had a small lawn of English grass ... which ... was covered with toumatukuru bushes, which had been collected from the run. (1898,TrNZI,30/268) [NOTES: (Bathgate)]

ROBERTS ... tumatakuru, a small thorny scrub, one of the few deciduous plants of New Zealand, which Europeans nick-named Wild Irishman', ... speargrass, orSpaniard', as the stronger variety was called, ... (1906,Diary) [NOTES: 1906 W.H.S.Roberts in 1914 History of North Otago (1978) 4]

CHE D[iscaria] Toumatou, Raoul. ... Tumatukuru. ... Can only be distinguished from the Australian and Tasmanian D. australis by the absence of petals. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,101)

LAING & BLACKWELL Discaria toumatou (The Wild Irishman). ... Maori name Tumatakuru. (1907,Plants of NZ,239,1940, p. 252 ed.)

SPINY BUSH, WILD IRISHMAN. (1847,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

SPINY BUSH, WILD IRISHMAN. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

RICHARDS spg: in error Discaria ... Toumatu [sic] ... Wild Irishman. MATAGOWRI, TUMATA-KURI [sic] ... (1952,Chatham Islands,54)

tumatakuru also tumatukuru n -s [Maori tumatakuru] : a New Zealand shrub or tree (Discaria toumatou) of the family Rhamnaceae having stout sharp spines used by the Maoris for tattooing - called also Irishman, matagory, wild Irishman (1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,2461)

MEAD ... crossing first a grassy plain filled with tumatikuru ..., taramea, ... and a pretty cream-coloured star flower, ... (1966,Richard Taylor,69)

[TUMATA KURU (SIC)] tumatakuru n. New Zealand spiny shrub, with durable wood, called also Wild Irishman (q.v.). (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

In our shaded valleys are the beautiful tree ferns, on the dry plains the tussock and tumatakuru. (Jul 15, 1933,Evening Post,17)

PARK Between the long deltas of screes the thickets of tumatagora grew, a shrub as grey as old bones. (1957,One-a-pecker, Two-a-pecker,45)

ROBERTS There was a good deal of tomataguru on the ridges. (1890,History of Oamaru & North Otago,13)

July 12 and 13 - Mr. M., Tom, and J.F. pulling down Goi on Roughridge'; July 17 - Went for firewood and brought home a load of Korokio'; `August 2 - Snow. Tom and J.F. collecting Tomatagora up the Gully'; ... (1860,Puketoi Station Diary) [NOTES: 1860 Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 91]

Drays loaded with tomatagora and flour started for Moa Cottage. (Mar 5, 1861,Puketoi Station Diary) [NOTES: [Hocken TS]]

HOOKER Tumatakuru, Col[enso]. Discaria Toumatou. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

TAYLOR In the Middle Island ... a great proportion of the land ... is one grand plain of shingle scarcely covered with soil, and only supporting grass ... much inferior to that of the North Island, filled also with spiny bushes of the Tumatakura, and that singular family of plants, the Acifolia Taramea, commonly called Spaniards; ... (1868,Past and Present of NZ,202)

The plains are covered with grasses, the roots of which are gathered into tufts or tussocks, intermixed with the Bayonet grass or `Wild Spaniard' (Aciphylla Colensoi), Toumatakuru (Discaria Toumatou), and a great variety of the New Zealand brooms (Carmichaelia), ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/5) [NOTES: (Hector)]

The spines of the Tumatakuru, or New Zealand Thorn, (Discaria Toumatou,) were sometime [sic] used for tattooing ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/37) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

PYKE NOTE. - As I have no desire to mystify readers unacquainted with New Zealand flora, I append a brief description of the shrubs mentioned:- Kowhai - A papilonaceous flowering tree, of the acacia tribe. [17] Bush-lawyer - Native name, Tataramoa - A disagreeable bramble, very tenacious of grasp. Koromiko - A white flowering Veronica. Tutu - A berry-bearing, glossy-leaved plant, deadly to man and to all animals - except goats. Tumata-kuru - Better known as `Wild Irishman' - a thorny plant, very difficult to handle. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,1/iii/16-17,(1889,1974) ed.)

PYKE Amid these the native flax flourishes ..., and even the cantankerous Tumatukuru attains considerable magnitude. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,3/iii/81,(1889,1974) ed.)

tumatakuru. See matagouri. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

tumatakuru n. NZ = MATAGOURI, the thorns of which were used by the Maoris in tatooing. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,829) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

Tumatauenga¶

n. (also as Tu elliptical) the Maori god of war. [ORIGIN: Maori]

Ihimaera 'I bring you three boys under the tapu of Tumatauenga, the God of War. Fight for the honour of your tribe!' (2000,Uncle's Story, The,42)

tumatikuru¶

n. (See tumatakuru)

tumble-weed¶

n. the dried flower-heads of Scirpus frondosus, pingao or nassella tussock [tumble weed, tumbleweed; definition not exclusive, some general use for seed heads that tumble along the ground in the wind.]

Thus, a horse with caution, and a faculty for seeing everything he passes, having been startled by a piece of paper, or a tumble weed being blown under him or against his legs, may never get over shying at these particular objects. (Aug 1, 1885,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

HILGENDORF & CALDER Nassella Tussock's ... seed heads break off when mature and are blown along the ground by strong winds. It is sometimes referred to as `tumble-weed' on this account. (1918,Pasture Plants & Pastures of NZ,48)

ANDERSEN The globular, spiked flower-head [of the pingao] drops when the seed is mature and trundles along the beach in the wind ... The Pakeha name of such spherical flower-heads is tumble-weed'. [Marginal pencil note on this copy:spinifex'.] (1942,Maori Place Names,274)

pingao, sea-shore plant (Scirpus frondosus), tumble-weed, after the stiff-spined globular seed-heads: the leaves, drying a bright-orange much used for plaiting ornamental girdles and for tukutuku[spg/hyphen???] (lattice-work) lacing in wall-panels of whares. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/155) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

n. the dried heads of nassella tussock

tumbler¶

n. a kind of shell or mortar bomb [?or merely a shell that `tumbles' end over end in flight]

PILLING Jerry opened out on Jock's Joy with his minnies, rum jars, tumblers etc. - another bombardment! (Feb 1, 1917,Anzac Memory,121,1933 ed.)

n. the end of the dredge ladder round which the belt holding the buckets revolves, or changes direction

KITTO Before letting down the ladder you should examine the bottom tumbler and hangers to see they [sic] are all right. Ibid. 20 GETTING BUCKETS ON THE BOTTOM TUMBLER. (1900,Practical Dredgeman's Manual,16)

tumbler sweep¶

n.

HAWKE & SCOTT The tumbler sweep consisted of a number of teeth, perhaps up to a dozen, according to whether it was a one horse or a two horse sweep...
