It had two curved handles and often a board to sweep the hay off when the handles were released by the driver who walked [behind. When] the handles were released the sweep turned over completely and just carried on for the next load. (1985,Early Farm Machinery in NZ,89)

tumbler-rake¶

n.

SINCLAIR & HARREX The tumbler-rake.,.raked the cut hay until it had caught up a good quantity. Then the rake was raised to leave the hay in what was called a windrow. (1978,Looking Back,92)

tumbleweed amaranth¶

n.

tumbleweed amaranth [s] Amaranthus albus L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,80)

tumblewheel¶

1 n. (Rural) a hubbed wheel on six legs for feeding out and maintaining electric fence wire at the appropriate height. (invented 1980s by Taranaki farmer, Sandy Chesswas.).

RENNIE This 'tumble wheel' system, designed to make moving the wire easy, was invented by a Taranaki hill country farmer. (1988,NZ Agriculture,21)

Each Tumblewheel can be easily assembled or dismantled for storage. (1996,Gallagher Power Fence Manual,34)

It is easy to 'walk' the tumblewheel up a paddock. It [a tumblewheel] looks like something from outer space, with six legs being attached to a central core through which the tape runs. If you are just having to control cattle, the single wire tumblewheel system is ideal. [tumble wheel] (2000,Lifestyle Farmer,Autumn 66)

tumblewheel fence¶

1 n. (Rural) a type of electric fence where wire is supported on a spiked metal or plastic wheel structure, enabling easy movement.

To erest a tumblewheel fence, run out the Polywire across the pasture and tension, preferably with a reel at each end. (1996,Gallagher Power Fence Manual,34)

tumeke¶

adj. (informal) awesome, cool [ORIGIN: Maori, The English version of the word 'Tumeke' would be 'Choice' or 'Awesome' so if you would like a choice web name presence then you need this www.Tumeke.com (from TradeMe)]

Tumeke! We've got one signed copy of Akon's CD - 'Trouble' for you to win. (2005,Te Mana Taiohi,16,Summer ed.)

They say that the best moves are hard to learn but look tumeke. (2002,Te Mana Taiohi,4,Summer ed.)

Everything about Taiohi is just tu meke!!! (2003,Te Mana Taiohi,7,Autumn ed.)

A lot of emotions were visible and the ahua among us was tumeke. (Oct 2006,Pu Kaea,4)

And we profile Turanga Merito .. in Australia's biggest theatre production, The Lion King - tumeke! (2005,Te Mana Taiohi,1,Autumn ed.)

(heading) Tumeke Tuis! (2008,Mana,85/78)

tumingi¶

n.

HOOKER Leucopogon fasciculatus, A.Rich. ... Nat. name, `Tumingi', Middle Island, Lyall. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 164)

HOOKER Tumingi, Middle Island, Lyall. Leucopogon fasciculatus. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

tumuaki¶

n. chairperson; head; CEO [ORIGIN: Maori, *1984 VUW Used in Accountancy Dept for `Chairperson' [? for Professor Whata Winiata]]

Te Runanga O Ngati Ruanui Annual General Meeting [agenda item] Tumuaki Report (Oct 26, 2005,NZ Herald,D6)

The Tumuaki role is the most senior Maori Health position in the provider arm. (Feb 26, 2006,Sunday Star Times,D13)

[advertisement] Chief Executive/Tumuaki Te Whare Wananga o Awanuiarangi - Whakatane Tertiary Education Sector - Leadership Role (Mar 11, 2006,Dominion Post,H6)

I am also informed by the gentleman I formerly alluded to, and who has indeed great experience in what is called "native affairs," that members of parliament, Tumuaki; or, as my friend the old settler says, the word translates "top knots," have, by established usage, the right to kill anyone they are able, on any pretence or none, as they choose, and that this old custom from immemorial usage has all the force of law, and that it would be both impolitic and dangerous to interfere with it ... (Jun 27, 1862,Daily Southern Cross,4)

tuna¶

n. tunny

SORENSON ALBACORE (see also Tuna) (a) Scientific name: Thunnus alaunga. (b) Suggested commercial name: Albacore. (c) Other common names: Tuna, Tunny, long-finned albacore. (d) Principal localities where taken: Bay of Plenty, East Cape to Gisborne, North Taranaki Bight. Ibid. 49 TUNA (3 species excluding Albacore) (a) Scientific name: (i) Katsuwonus pelamis (ii) Thunnus maccoyi (iii) Thunnus albacares. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Skipjack Tuna (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna (iii) Yellowfin Tuna. (c) Other common names: (i) Skipjack; Striped Bonito (ii) Bluefin Tuna; Southern Bluefin; Southern Tuna (iii) Yellowfin All sometimes referred to as Tunny. (d) Principal localities where taken: (i) A summewr visitor to New Zealand ... (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna is a large species of temperate Australasian seas and migrates south to Foveaux Strait in summer months. (iii) A widely distributed tropical species which ranges into northern waters ... in summer months. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,9)

MORELAND STRIPED BONITO [Katsuwonus pelamis] ... Striped tunny or tuna, skipjack, bonito, and sometimes skipper, are alternative names in use. (1967,Marine Fishes,52)

266 TUNAS ... Tuna were generally known as `tunny' until the discovery of a potentially big export market to America, where tuna is rated a luxury fish. The name as then changed to conform with that used in America. Since then Southern Bluefin tuna, Yellowfin tuna and Striped, or Skipjack, tuna have been developed into important export fishes. In New Zealand the Albacore has become an important commercial fish. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,WILSON)

[species name] tuna .. [scientific name] -- [other name(s)] unspecified - see albacore, skipjack, southern bluefin, yellowfin, bigeye, frigate, slender and butterfly tuna. (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] tuna, tunny 2048-2113 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

n. Anguilla spp.; a freshwater eel, aka silverbelly [ORIGIN: Maori]

Nor is the wily "tuna" beaten when merely stunned. (Dec 26, 1928,NZ Free Lance,42)

LEE & KENDALL T|una; An eel. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,219)

large eels - too'na [tuna] (1826,Boultbee Journal,113,1986 ed.) [NOTES: see also 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 285]

TAYLOR Eight Tunas or eels. (1840,Journal,2/2/288)

Stopped at Tommy's' [a Maori]. Kikied thetiners' and the fish. Slept on a Maori mat, wrapped in a blanket: 4 in a bed-place - heads and tails. (Aug 15, 1842,Piraki Log,143,(ed. Anson 1911 ed.) [NOTES: [Note Anson p166 gives tunas: but perhaps tivers `potatoes']]

TAYLOR [Otaki] my boys are feasting on a large tuna they caught as they came along. ... They have found a native eel basket which they have set, ... [Oct 3] ... they went to the hinaki and found it almost full they took about 2 doz. (Oct 2, 1844,Journal,3/26)

We were 6 in party, ourselves, young Stark & 3 Maoris with `pikau' burdens. ... After tiring of [singing] they set off with burning brand & tomahawk to catch crawfish & tuna, the eels of the country, in a little brook near our encampment. [spg tomahawk/tomehawk???] (Mar 25, 1851,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/79,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (J.C. Richmond)]

TAYLOR New Zealand has no large fresh-water fish. The only exception is the tuna, or eel; there are many varieties of it, and almost all the other fresh-water fish partake more or less of a similar character. The number of names given to this fish, and the careful way they have noticed every little difference between one and another, clearly shows the great value the natives put upon it. Ibid. 498 The principal ones are the tuna, eel, the pipiharau, lamprey, the kokopu, and inanga ... (1855,Te Ika a Maui,413)

BEATTIE Tuna - the generic name for eels, of which the Maoris classify several varieties. (1945,Maori Place-Names of Canterbury,62) [NOTES: c1880 South Island Maori Lists `Wahi Mahika Kai' in 1945 Beattie Maori Place-names of Canterbury 62]

HAY In the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga). (1882,Brighter Britain,2/151)

Mabel and I called on Wi Te Tahuhu ... and saw some 2000 tuna drying. ... I think there will be quite 20,000 eels in all for Te Whiti. Piripiri and Pene took a large contract from me fencing. They gave their word as Te Whiti men but would not sign an agreement. (Feb 12, 1885,Chudleigh Diary,332,1950 ed.)

The following is a list of the fishes which are chiefly met with in the market: hapuku, kahawai, red-snapper, snapper, tarakihi, moki, trumpeter, frostfish ... gurnard, mullet, sea-mullet, ... flounder or patiki, ... grayling, smelt, kokopu, sardine, sprat, eel (tuna), black-eel, conger-eel [168], and silver-eel. (1892,NZ Official Handbook,167)

PARK Old grandfather eel, old king tuna, you are dead meat now! (1951,Witch's Thorn, The,138)

We are following in a long line. Like a tuna winding its way back up river from the sea, looking for a nice spot in a creek. (2007,Huia 7: Contemp. Maori Fiction,69)

MORRIS Tuna. See Eel. (1898,Austral English,482)

ANGUILLA AUSTRALIS Richardson. Common Eel; Tuna. ... Distribution: South Island and southern portion of North Island. (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/119) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

PHILLIPPS Anguilla aucklandii Richardson. EEL; TUNA. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,17,1971 ed.)

Anguilla australis: [European Name] Short-finned eel [Maori Name] Tuna. (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,73)

Anguilla aucklandii Richardson. Long-finned eel. Tuna. (1938,TrRSNZ,68/403) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

tuna, a fish (Anguilla sp.), eel, of which there are only two species in Newzealand, though there are about 110 supposed varieties named by the Maori, and even Pakehas think there are several varieties going by size, shape, and colour, but these variations are due to age and sex. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/147) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

POWELL SHORT-FINNED EEL (Anguilla australis schmidtii). These are the common freshwater eels called Tuna by the Maoris. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,64)

GRAHAM NEW ZEALAND EELS Long-finned Eel (Tuna): Anguilla dieffenbachii Gray, Short-finned Eel (Tuna Heke): Anguilla australis schmidtii Phillipps. Ibid. 125 The Short-finned Eel varies from dark brown to very light brown on the back, with silvery sides and belly, and is known as the Silvery-eel or Silver-belly. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,123)

The Maori name for an eel. (Pronounce .us too|-na). (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),434)

KEENE tuna: eel. (1963,O Te Raki,195)

MORELAND LONGFINNED EEL [Anguilla dieffenbachi] ... Mud-eel and black eel are alternative names, while a variety of Maori names are in use. Tuna is widely used. (1967,Marine Fishes,30)

BURTON New Zealand eels, known to the Maori as tuna, are esteemed for their succulence and keeping qualities by the many countries which import them. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,71)

tuna n. NZ freshwater eel. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,829) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

EDWARDS The tables themselves are loaded: hangi food, kaimoana, trout, tuna, titi, puha, karengo. (1992,Mihipeka,21)

tuna heke¶

n. a migrating eel [ORIGIN: Maori, aka tuna hao]

They found good populations of longfin eels (tuna), freshwater crayfish (koura), and - most surpassingly - torrentfish (papanoko), whose closest relative is the marine blue cod. (Jun 2005,National Centre for Aquatic Biodiversity,No. 12/2) [NOTES: National Centre for Aquatic Biodiversity and Biosecurity Update]

When the migrating eels (tuna heke) come down in the March floods,... (1926,TrNZI,58/639) [NOTES: (Buck)]

PHILLIPPS Anguilla australis Richardson. SHORT-FINNED EEL; TUNA HEKE. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,17,1971 ed.)

GRAHAM NEW ZEALAND EELS Long-finned Eel (Tuna): Anguilla dieffenbachii Gray, Short-finned Eel (Tuna Heke): Anguilla australis schmidtii Phillipps. Ibid. 125 The Short-finned Eel varies from dark brown to very light brown on the back, with silvery sides and belly, and is known as the Silvery-eel or Silver-belly. (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,123)

tuna kuwharuwharu¶

n. long fin eel [ORIGIN: Maori, aka long fin eel, longfin eel, long finned eel.]

Today the eel population in the Wairarapa is under stress and none more so than the largest species - the majestic Tuna Kuwharuwharu. Tuna Kuwharuwharu are one of New Zealand's most ancient inhabitatns but have decreased in number so rapidly that they are now nearing endangered status. So it's extremely special to see a large number of female tuna kuwharuwharu being fed at Pukaha Mount Bruce which occurs daily at 1.30pm. (Feb 2011,Wairarapa News,supplement: pukaha Mount Bruce p. 8)

Joseph Potangaroa Tuna kuwharuwharu are one of New Zealand's most ancient inhabitants but have decreased in number so rapidly that it is now nearing endangered status. (Feb 2010,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: http://www.rangitane.iwi.nz/education/attachments/169_tuna_vweb.pdf]

Tunbridge fern¶

n.

Concerning the almost cosmopolitan Tunbridge fern, far more common here than in England ... (1882,Out in the Open,60)

tunchie¶

n. [ca1935 Alistair Campbell (Dunedin) probably a corruption of turnip: also there was a `Tunchie Goat' in an early reading-book]

tundra¶

n.

[caption] The silted lake bed north of Lake Waikareiti is known as `the tundra'. (1983,Land of the Mist,66)

tune-up¶

n. a reprimand [Used both as verb and noun : Give somebody a tune up; to tune somebody up]

I won't say anything more than that the PM gave me a tune up about it. (Apr 27, 1999,Radio NZ / National Radio,Kim Hill Show) [NOTES: Hon. Tau Henare in interview with Kim Hill, about his public refusal to pay back money overpaid to him by WINZ equivalent]

Tau Henare's sudden paradigm shift, occasioned by the "tune-up" administered from the prime minister, should not convince anyone of a change in his basic beliefs. (Apr 30, 1999,Dominion,8)

tuniwa¶

n. (See taniwha)

tunnel gully¶

1 n. (Rural) a tomo or under-runner.

An area eroded by tunnel gullies. The same area after the tunnel gullies had been erased [cp] (Oct 15, 1962,NZ Journal of Agriculture,301)

LAFFAN Tunnel-gully erosion has been observed in may localities in New Zealand ... [tunnel-gully] (1973,Soils and Tunnel-gully Erosion,1)

tunnel-grunter¶

n. potato

Other classically-crafted words for potatoes brought to light by my painstaking research are murphies, Irish apricots, bog-oranges and tunnel-grunters. (Nov 3, 1999,Evening Post,23)

tunnel-gullied¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of land and soils[ containing tomos or under-runners.

LAFFAN To compare the tunnel-gullied soils of the Wither Hills ... (1973,Soils and Tunnel-gully Erosion,4)

LAFFAN Indications are that active downcutting has and still is occurring in the severely tunnel-gullied areas. (1973,Soils and Tunnel-gully Erosion,87)

tunnel-gullying¶

1 n. (Rural) the forming of tomos or under-runners.

LAFFAN It was thought that such a comparison .. would help explain the susceptibility of some soils to tunnel-gullying and also the actual process of tunnel formation. (1973,Soils and Tunnel-gully Erosion,5)

LAFFAN In both soil landscapes tunnel-gullying is less severe on concave footslopes ... (1973,Soils and Tunnel-gully Erosion,84)

tunny¶

n. (See tuna)

SPEIGHT The only true mackerels recorded from Canterbury are the Pacific Bonito (Sarda chiliensis) and the large-scaled Tunny (Gasterochisma melampus) which may reach a length of 6 feet; but a related family includes the well-known Barracouta (Thyrsites atun), the King Barracouta, Jordanidia solandrii (often known locally as Kingfish, but not to be confused with the North Island Kingfish which is a form or Yellowtail) and the elongated, silvery-hued frost fish (Lepidopus caudatus) whose curious stranding habits can hardly yet be said to be satisfactorily explained. (1927,Natural History of Canterbury,199) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 199]

PHILLIPPS Sarda chilensis (Cuv. & Val.). TUNNY. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,45,1971 ed.)

Sarda chilensis: Tunny. (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,72)

Gasterochisma melampus Richardson. Tunny (sporting tunny). (1938,TrRSNZ,68/414) [NOTES: Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour]

SORENSON ALBACORE (see also Tuna) (a) Scientific name: Thunnus alaunga. (b) Suggested commercial name: Albacore. (c) Other common names: Tuna, Tunny, long-finned albacore. (d) Principal localities where taken: Bay of Plenty, East Cape to Gisborne, North Taranaki Bight. Ibid. 49 TUNA (3 species excluding Albacore) (a) Scientific name: (i) Katsuwonus pelamis (ii) Thunnus maccoyi (iii) Thunnus albacares. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Skipjack Tuna (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna (iii) Yellowfin Tuna. (c) Other common names: (i) Skipjack; Striped Bonito (ii) Bluefin Tuna; Southern Bluefin; Southern Tuna (iii) Yellowfin All sometimes referred to as Tunny. (d) Principal localities where taken: (i) A summer visitor to New Zealand ... (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna is a large species of temperate Australasian seas and migrates south to Foveaux Strait in summer months. (iii) A widely distributed tropical species which ranges into northern waters ... in summer months. (1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,9)

WILSON TUNAS ... Tuna were generally known as `tunny' until the discovery of a potentially big export market to America, where tuna is rated a luxury fish. The name as then changed to conform with that used in America. Since then Southern Bluefin tuna, Yellowfin tuna and Striped, or Skipjack, tuna have been developed into important export fishes. In New Zealand the Albacore has become an important commercial fish. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,266)

[species name] albacore .. [scientific name] Thunnus alalunga .. [other name(s)] tuna albacore, longfinned tuna, tunny (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

[index to common names 283-293] tuna, tunny 2048-2113 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

HUTTON 33. PELAMYS CHILENSIS. C. and V.? Tunny. (1872,Fishes,22)

GREY The boatmen told of small tunny taken off Cape Brett. (1926,Angler's Eldorado,27)

2 n.

Gasterochisma melampus Richardson. The `butterfly-fish', as it is called when young, has been taken in Otago Harbour, and is now known to be the young of the scaled tunny, described as Lepidothynnus huttoni Gunther. (1913,TrRSNZ,45/230) [NOTES: (Thomson, Otago)]

GRAHAM BUTTERFLY-FISH or SCALED TUNNY Gasterochisma melampusRichardson (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,301)

PARROTT Butterfly-fish Gasterochisma melampus Scaled Tunny (1957,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,169)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] tunny, scaled 2053, 2067 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

[index to common names 283-293] tunny, scaleless 2102 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

McLINTOCK Tuna, tunny, southern bluefin.. .. Thunnus maccoyi .. .. (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

DOOGUE & MORELAND SOUTHERN TUNA ... Other names: Thunnus maccoyi; southern bluefin tunny or tuna. (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,269)

MORELAND SOUTHERN TUNA [Thunnus maccoyi] ... Southern bluefin tunny is an alternative name. (However, while our species is related to the famous bluefin tuna it has yellow finlets.) (1967,Marine Fishes,50)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] tuna or tunny, southern 2100-1 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

LEE & KENDALL Tu p|akii; A fruit-tree resembling the alder. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,219)

2 n.

PAUL et al. bluefin tuna or tunny, southern 2100-1 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] tuna or tunny, northern 2065 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

DOOGUE & MORELAND STRIPED BONITO ... Other names: Katsuwonus pelamis; striped tunny or tuna, skipjack, bonito, and sometimes, skipper. (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,268)

MORELAND STRIPED BONITO [Katsuwonus pelamis] ... Striped tunny or tuna, skipjack, bonito, and sometimes skipper, are alternative names in use. (1967,Marine Fishes,52)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] tuna or tunny, striped 2062, 2064 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

MORELAND YELLOWFIN TUNA [Thunnus albacares] ... Yellowfin tunny and albacore are other names. (1967,Marine Fishes,50)

DOOGUE & MORELAND YELLOWFIN TUNA or ALBACORE ... Other names: Neothunnus macropterus; yellowfin tunny or albacore. (1966,Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ,270)

[index to common names 283-293] tuna or tunny, yellowfin(ned) 2069-71, 2095-7 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] tuna or tunny, slender 2048 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

2 n.

GRAHAM Gasterochisma melampus Richardson. Tunny (sporting tunny). (1938,TrRSNZ,68/414)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] tunny, sporting 2053 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

tunutunu¶

n.

BURTON For preparing small meals in a fowlers' camp or fishermen's bivouac, the open hearth was used and the fish or birds might be grilled on sticks leaning over the glowing embers. Grilling was known as tunutunu or rorerore. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,1)

tuokura¶

n. the fern Dicksonia lanata

At two metres, Dicksonia lanata, or Tuokura, is the baby of the Dicksonias. It has a slim, sometimes prostrate trunk, which can be branched, and the fronds are markedly lighter yellow-green compared with other tree ferns. (Nov 30, 2002,Dominion Post,F15)

tuoro¶

n.

TAYLOR The largest eels are called rauhine; they were originally fed and regarded as inferior gods. There is an eel found in marshy ground called a tuoro, which is said to have a large head, and to attack men. (1855,Te Ika a Maui,414)

tup crutch¶

v. (Rural) carry out a pre-tupping shearing of ewes' rear ends. (See bullseye,buttonhole,ring-crutch)

March and April : ewes tup crutched, rams out, lambs drenched. (Oct 2002,Wairarapa Times-Age,Supp. 11)

tupak grass¶

n. (See grass)

HOOKER Tupak Grass of Otago. Carex apressa. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

tupakahi¶

n.

The masses of tupakihi, the clematis,.. the groups of puriri, and clumps of nikau, composed a sylvan landscape of great beauty. (Dec 3, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

tupake¶

n. (See tupakihi)

tupaki¶

n. (See tupakihi)

tupakihi¶

n. [wine from the plant] (See also tupakihi (juice): see tupakihi wine,tutu wine)

Otene & his people came down to see us, bringing large stores of tupakihi which I quaffed with pleasure*, also mango ... Rogan fastidious about smell sent them to a distance to eat it. [fn.] The old women whose peculiar duty it is to squeeze the tupakihi berries never wash their hands by any chance. The only approach to it is in squeezing the tupakihi juice ... (Dec 30, 1860,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/673,1960 ed.) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

Went on to Kapoai ... had dinner - well supplied with pipis but alas no tupakihi ... saw another noteworthy sight ...[sic] a young karoro just out of the nest, running along in a curious human way all by himself. (Jan 21, 1861,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,1/680) [NOTES: (A.S. Atkinson)]

n. tutu [ORIGIN: Maori]

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] a native plant, tutu of the Coriaria spp. [plant]

In some districts, where tupakihi familiarly called 'toot' is plentiful, the young growth of this poisonous plant springing up after a burn may account for some deaths. (Aug 1888,NZ Farmer,296)

In January the berries of the kotukutuku, poroporo, kaiwiria, puriri, mangaio, and tupakihi, constitute its ordinary bill of fare. (Jul 2, 1927,Evening Post,17)

MORRIS Tupakihi, n. i.q. Tutu (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,482)

spg tupaki ... the plants around were ... makomako ..., tupaki Coriaria ruscifolia), and pukapuka. (1898,TrNZI,30/146)

The name `tutu' is applied to three distinct species of the ... natural order Coriariae: Coriaria ruscifolia, L. (C. sarmentosa, Forst., C. arborea and C. tutu, Lindsay, tutu, pohou, and tupakihi of the Maori), is commonly known as the tree-toot ... (1901,TrNZI,33/347)

TREGEAR In case ... of poisoning by having swallowed the seeds of the tutu or tupakihi plant (Coriaria ruscifolia) the smoke remedy was resorted to ... (1904,Maori Race, The,18)

CHEESEMAN [Coriaria ruscifolia, Linn.] Tutu; Tupakihi. ... The poisonous principle appears to be a glucoside, to which the name `tutin' has been applied. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,106)

LAING & BLACKWELL Coriaria sarmentosa (The Shrubby Tutu) ... Maori name: Tupakihi or Tutu (usually pronounced Toot). (1907,Plants of NZ,226,1940, p. 239 ed.)

WILLIAMS The land was now overgrown with firn [sic] and tupakihi bushes. (Oct 31, 1833,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,339,1961 ed.)

YATE ... (the fruit of the Kohutuhutu, Fuchsia excorticata) ... the juice of the Tupakihi (Coriaria sarmentosa), a berry similar in taste to that of the elder, whose leaves, branches and seed, are highly poisonous; ... (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),111)

WAKEFIELD & WARD Tutu or Tuparki ... (1837,British Colonies,324)

POLACK On emerging from Pamaki [a's-acute], we ascended another plain of some miles in circumference, covered with fern and bush, above which the tupakihi [a-acute], or native elder-berry, occasionally shewed its bending stem, yielding to the weight of the fruit, which hung in purple clusters. ... The natives, on perceiving me make use of this berry, warned me not to swallow any of the seeds, as the doing so would make me ourangi, drunk, or mad. Ibid. 2/134 The flexible tu pahihi [prob ?typo see 288] (elder berry) with its pensile clusters of ripe fruit ... Ibid. 1/288 The korai, koutu utu, miro, and putuhutu, are wild forest fruits, prized only by the elder natives. The tu pakihi (Coriaria sarmentosa), or elder-berry, is a very pleasing fruit. (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/110)

MATTHEW Tupakihi, (Coriaria) a shrub indicating the richest soil. (1840,Reports and Essays,12)

WADE The Tupakihi ... produces ... berries, the expressed unfermented juice of which is called tutu. (1841,Journey in NZ,57)

MAUNSELL tutu is the tupakihi of the Ngapuhi. (1842,Grammar of the NZ Language)

COWAN Its carved slopes and ... are softened with fern and flax and tupakihi bushes. (1935,Hero Stories of NZ,163)

... tupake that bane of New Zealand may be found here. (Apr 16, 1842,Journal of Ensign Best,351,1966 ed.)

HEAPHY From the Tupaki berry the natives make a wine, which in taste is exactly similar to that of the elder. (1842,Narrative of a Residence in Various Parts of NZ,45)

`About one-half of the district ... is covered with fern and various shrubs, chiefly the Tupaki, ... (1843,Report of Auckland Agricultural Society,20)

DIEFFENBACH 'They sometimes press out the juice from the drupes of the tupakihi (Coriaria sarmentosa), which is called tutu, and which they drink unfermented. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/50)

SHORTLAND This was the season when the fruit of the tutu' ortupakihi', as it is called in the North Island, was ripe. Ibid. Jan 9 in 1851 Shortland Southern Districts of NZ 195-196 These plains are called pakihi,' a word used in the North Island to signify dried up. So thattupakihi,' the name by which the tutu' is there known, appears to be a contraction oftutupakihi,' or tutu' of the [196] plains, which are well calledpakihi,' being for the most part arid. ((8/0/1851),Southern Districts of NZ,191) [NOTES: 1844 Jan 8 in 1851 Shortland Southern Districts of NZ 191]

WILLIAMS The Tupakihi Tree [Tutu], troublesome, yet [a] useful one, abounds all are the Island, ... (1844,NZ Journal,107,1956 ed.)

WAKEFIELD [fn] tupakihi, called tutu in the south [i.e. in the Wellington district]. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The)

HOOKER Coriaria ruscifolia, Linn. ... Nat. name, Tupa-kihi', <i>Colenso</i>.Tutu' and `Puhou' of Southern Island, Lyall. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 45)

HOOKER Tupa-kihi, Col[enso]. Coriaria ruscifolia. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

LINDSAY The too-well-known Toot' of the Otago farmer; theWine-berry shrub' of the early settlers of the Bay of Islands, (according to Dr. Bennett [Wanderings in Australia'] and theTreasury of Botany'); the Tutu,'Tupakihi,' and Puhou' of the North Island Maoris; theTaweku' of the Waikatos; the Tupake' [a-macron, e-acute] of Coromandel district; theTua-tutu' of Otago, (Hooker). ... [`Tutu'] appears also to be a generic or general [term] ... (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,85)

Tupakihi. Coriaria ruscifolia, Linn. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/40) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

CAMPBELL ... we walked along the native footpath, [105] the high fern and tupakihi proclaiming the richness of the soil. (1881,Poenamo,Bk2/6/104-5)

DOMETT [tupaki = berry] ... Then a store/ Of jellies ... pressed/ ... [from]/ Rich clusters of tupaki, luscious sweet;/ Ibid. 1/302 [tupaki] Tutu or Tupaki ..... O. Coriariae; G. Coriaria; S. C. ruscifolia. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/184)

HECTOR Coriaria rusifolia, Linn. Tupakihi, Tree Tutu.--A perennial shrub 10-18 fee t high; trunk 6-8 inches in diameter. The seeds and leaves contain a poisonous alkaloid. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,131)

FEATON Tupkakihi [Maori name] .. Tutu [Settlers' name] .. Coriaria ruscifolia ..Shrub (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,178)

CATTLE POISONING BY TUPAKIHI. .. Tupakihi does not generally affect them unless they either drink after eating, or it rains, or in close damp weather, or they eat much of it on an empty belly. (Nov 4, 1874,Daily Southern Cross,3)

Coriaria Ruscifolia. Or as it is generally called, Tutu or Tupakihi, affects cattle as well as sheep, and is even much more dangerous to them. (Apr 3, 1890,Otago Witness,39)

These tracks twist in and out all over this lonely country, through the high fern and the glossy green tupakihi with its black clusters of elderberry-like fruit, and the thickets of manuka that in springtime are showered with delicate white blossom till they look as if a snowfall had powdered the face of the country, and diffuse an aromatic fragrance that is the most insistent of the grateful odours of the bush. (Jul 9, 1910,Evening Post,10)

tupakihi wine¶

n. = tutu wine

VON TEMPSKY Roberts and myself bathed in the river, made Tupake wine, ... [fn](NOTE) A blue berry with poisonous seeds - whose juice however is wholesome, and delicious in flavour. (1864,Memoranda,75)

tupapaku¶

n. a corpse [ORIGIN: Maori]

Ihimaera ed. He looked so thin and pallid, his cheeks gaunt and sunken... I tried hard not to think of tupapaku - dead bodies - when I looked at him. (2007,Get on the Waka,112) [NOTES: (Kingi McKinnon)]

They were determined to take his tupapaku back home with them. (1955,Mana,No. 10 : 11)

tupara¶

n. a double-barrelled gun [ORIGIN: Maori]

BELICH Men with tupara were ordered to reserve their second barrel. (1986,NZ Wars, The,169)

MORRIS Maori corruption of `two-barrel.' Compare the aboriginal word Whilpra (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,482)

BAUCKE He cleaned his `tupara' (double-barrelled gun), but never a word to me! (1905,Where the White Man Treads,152)

Led by a chainman ... with his slasher, and Wirihana with his tupara - a bushmanlike figure was the Boss, for he cannily packed his trousers in his swag and travelled bare-legged, Maori fashion ... (Apr 10, 1920,Quick March,13)

COWAN He ... only surrendered ... when his last home-made cartridge for his tupara had gone. (1940,Sir Donald Maclean,117)

The Maori word for a gun in the early days in New Zealand - `two-barrel'. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),434)

KEENE *tupara: double-barrelled gun. (1963,O Te Raki,195)

BRATHWAITE TUPARA Double-barrelled shotgun. Tupara is Maori pronunciation of two-barrel. (1967,Evil Day,382)

BELICH tupara double-barrelled gun (1986,NZ Wars, The,337)

PAYTON The birds naturally prefer districts where they are not likely to be molested by the pakeha and his tupara. (1888,Round about NZ,315)

WOOD My only hope is in a handy way (to give them [sc. Maori] their due) which they have with a tupara. (1959,From New Plymouth to New Plymouth,98) [NOTES: Quoted from CARRINGTON 1843]

Bates.. demanded that the people should recover his valuable tupera (doublebarrel) from the thief. (Nov 1937,NZ Railways Magazine,18)

He was an unborn participant in the siege of Orakau, his mother.. fighting in the earthworks alongside her husband, beating off the pakeha line regiments and colonial riflemen with rifle and tupara. (Sep 7, 1938,Auckland Weekly News,94)

MARKHAM On arriving I was requested to fire my two Purra [tupara] as the Natives call a double barreled Gun, in honour of the (Mattie Noue) [mate nui] dead. (1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),42,1963 ed.)

WAKEFIELD (1845,Adventure in NZ,2/109)

MANING Those Ngatiwaki are getting too many muskets - ... they have got besides two tupara. Ibid. 236 Tupara - A double gun; an article, in the old times, valued by the natives above all other earthly riches. (1863,Old New Zealand,(i) 14)

CAMPBELL Little wonder that Waipeha declared pigeons we should have', but a little hitch did crop up nevertheless, for all the <i>tuperas</i>, double-barrel guns [fn: Maori pronunciation of two-barrelled] were at Mangare, and there was only one oldbrown-bess' forthcoming, and a few ball cartridges! (1881,Poenamo,Bk2/7/115)

She shuddered when telling of the old tales of Maori rumours that floated down the Hutt of great war parties, with tupara, tomahawk and mere creeping stealthily to murder the newly arrived in their sleep... (Aug 2001,NZ Memories,No. 31/47) [NOTES: 10 September 1915 in NZ Memories No. 31/47]

It was a tupara (double barrel). (Oct 18, 1873,Otago Witness,5)

tupara-gun¶

n.

LANCASTER In fact, what with the land-trouble and too many tupara-guns, Queen Victoria's Maori nurslings were having the time of their lives; ... (1938,Promenade,124)

tupare¶

n. leatherwood

The tupare and turpentine scrub topping the low cliffs have been wind-sculpted into mushroom shapes. (Jan 4, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),17)

DEMPSEY The familiar mutton-bird scrub, tupare, covers much of the ground and there is a handsome relative, also called tupare, which grows only on a few of the islands in [48] Foveaux Strait and on the Snares. (1964,Little World of Stewart island,47)

WEBSTER The Maori call this shrub tupare, and for Tuhoe its significance is that it [193] grows on the sacred mountain. The leaves were much prized as pare or head wreaths ... the main route winds among boulders ... to disappear into thickets of taupare.[sic] (1979,Rua,192)

WILSON Olearia colensoi LEATHERWOOD ... Tuupare ...Stiffly branching shrub or small tree. Leaves leathery ... (1982,Stewart Island Plants,98)

Here, a small zone of sub-alpine scrub includes tupari and pink pine. (1983,Land of the Mist,65)

HOOKER Tupari, <Hector. Olearia operina and O. Lyallii. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

The principal are, Tupari (Olearia operina). <.I>Ibid. 43 Tupari. Olearia operina, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/35) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

[The Snares are] almost entirely covered with scrub and trees of stunted growth, the Tupari, Akeake, and Kokomuka. Of M'Quarrie cabbage there is abundance, and of fine growth, some of the leaves measuring two feet in diameter.Patches clear of scrub are clothed with Lutaki tussock. (1870,TrNZI,2/176) [NOTES: (Hector Outlying Islands)]

The traveller who visits Stewart Island in December or January will have his attention arrested by the blaze of crimson presented by the rata (Metrosideros lucida), often flecked with the pale racemes of the kamahi (Weinmannia racemosa), the deep green leaves of the puheretaiko and the tupari (Senecio rotundifolius and Olearia colensoi), and the grass-like leaves of the inaka (Drachophyllum longifolium), all of which form a fringe of greater or less breadth at the water's edge, and (except the puheretaiko) often expand into large masses ascending to the crests of the hills. (1884,TrNZI,17/216) [NOTES: (Kirk)]

CHEESEMAN O[learia] Colensoi, Hook.f. ... [mainly on mountains] STEWART ISLAND: Abundant from sea-level ... Tupari. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,282)

MARTIN The TUPARI (O[learia] colensoi) is an allied plant forming extensive areas of subalpine and coastal scrub ... . (1961,Flora NZ,208,1929 ed.)

tupari¶

n. (See tupare)

Tupari (Blechnum procerum) is usually quite as abundant as Paesia (1943,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,23/119B)

tuparki¶

n. (See tupakihi)

tupeia¶

n.

LAING & BLACKWELL The staminate flowers of Tupeia [Tupeia spp.] [itself] are found in panicles, in which the individual blossoms are not only more numerous, but larger in size than those on the pistillate panicles. (1907,Plants of NZ,145,1940 ed.)

tupeia [s] Tupeia antarctica (Forst.f.) Cham. & Schl. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,80)

tupeka¶

n. tobacco

WILLIAMS ... gave Waharoa the box ... and a pound of tupeka from Titore. (Mar 11, 1835,Early Journals of Henry Williams, The,421,1961 ed.)

tupenu¶

n. a wrap-around long skirt similar to a lava-lava, worn by Tongan men on formal occasions [ORIGIN: Tongan]

They break all the "fobby" stereotypes of what Pacific people in this country are supposed to be like. They don't wear mumus or tupenu to their ankles. (2005,Internet - see Notes,1) [NOTES: www.victoria.ac.nz/modernletters/bnzp/2005/mila-note]

tupoupou¶

n. a porpoise

... the most important [Chatham Island] edible sea-birds: AS WRITTEN AS PRONOUNCED ENGLISH hopo ho[macron]p' albatross hakoakoa ha[macron]ko[macron]k' mutton bird taiko tchai[macron]k' pied shear water tupoupou tchu[macron]poup' pied blue billie reoreo ro[macron]ro[macron] Mother Carys chicken turiwati tchu[macron]riwat' dottrel [sic] kuaka ku[macron]k' snipe (1928,BP Bishop Memoirs,Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 358) [NOTES: 1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 358]

n. a bird, the pied blue billy [only as porpoise/dolphin in Williams, Ryan (TD)]

tupping block¶

n.

NEWTON The 5,000 ewes were all out on their tupping blocks. (1966,Boot, The,47)

tupping country¶

1 n. (Rural) land that is suitable for use in mating ewes and rams.

NEWTON The Riverdale flats, opposite Grasmere, include some extensive areas of swamp and sweet, healthy, matagouri flats and although they lie on the shady side of the river, are wonderful lambing and tupping country. (1952,High Country Journey,138)

tupping crayon¶

1 n. (Rural) a chalk or raddle used to indicate the occurrence of tupping in sheep.

WOOLPRO Glossary of Wool Terms 4 Brand - wool on the sheep's back, marked with a temporary colouring agent eg tupping crayon or raddle. (2001)

tupping paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a paddock where rams are released to join ewes for the tupping season.

GASCOIGNE Granted that it had been possible to plan a good range of tupping paddocks, the smaller the ewe mobs and consequently the fewer the rams needed in each paddock, the better for at least the important first three weeks of mating. (1965,From the Top of a Hill,49)

tupping weight¶

1 n. (Rural) a weight of ewes at the time of conception.

MACMILLAN The tupping weight of ewes affects their lambing percentage. Ewes weighing 45 kg liveweight at tupping may drop 80% lambs whereas if they weigh 60 kg at tupping they should drop 120% or more. (1980,Land Development in the Chatham Islands,13)

tuppler¶

n. a large metal wheel which revolves and feeds coal into a chute

Emptying the boxes is the `tuppler', a large metal wheel which revolves and feeds the coal into a chute. (1971,NAC Airline Review,58/21)

tupuku¶

n. butterfish

The hiwihiwi (Chironemus fergussoni), tupuku, ngutere, tangahangaha, and koeaea (Coridodax pullus Forster) (butterfish), are amongst those caught (1926,TrNZI,58/646) [NOTES: (Buck)]

tupuna¶

n. a grandparent, ancestor [ORIGIN: Maori, -] (See also tipuna)

He thought he'd offended the tupuna, that they were coming back to get him. (Aug 14, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),33)

Rita will be buried with her tupunas at Waimahana Bay Cemetery, Northland (Dec 13, 2005,NZ Herald,C7)

Third, our tupuna never envisaged the Treaty ending on a particular date and we have no right to abandon their dream in such a cavalier fashion. (Sep 15, 2005,NZ Herald,A18)

Any person identified who descends from Tupuna from either Ngati Koata, Ngati Rarua, Ngati Tama and Te Atiawa who were living in the northern South Island between 1820 and 1840 are invited to attend. (Oct 1, 2005,Dominion Post,C13)

At this they exclaimed in greater wonder and admiration, for the Maoris are staunch ancestor worshippers, and if a man's "tupuna" (as they call ancestors) have not been gentle folk, he is secretly despised by the Natives of New Zealand. (Sep 28, 1929,Evening Post,24)

This 'tapu' was imposed in consequence of the European traveller of the name of Bidwill having gone to the top without permission, which had caused great vexation, as the mountain it held in traditional veneration, and is much dreaded by the Natives, being, as they tell you, the 'backbone of their tupuna,' or great ancestor, and having a white head, like their present chieftain. (Feb 15, 1932,Evening Post,3)

English New Zeland South-sea Islands ... ... ... Grand Father Toubouna Toubouna ... ... ... [Number] 2 Rua Rua. (Mar 31, 1770,Cook's Journals,1/287,1955 ed.)

WAKEFIELD I asked his permission to ascend Tonga Riro ... But he steadily refused, saying,I would do anything else to show you my love and friendship, but you must not ascend my tepuna, or ancestor.'' (1845,Adventure in NZ,2/113)

TAYLOR Our guide pointed out a singular shaped stone ... [and] informed me [it] was one of their Tupuna. (May 28, 1849,Journal,6/103)

TAYLOR On a small island in this lake (Rotoiti) there is a fine turkey cock who is called by the name of a tupuna. When anyone goes past the spot and calls out to him he answers. I think he is viewed as an object of reverence. (Mar 13, 1851,Journal,7/78)

TAYLOR `Tupuna, to stand, to spring; an ancestor; hence Tu-pu, to grow.' (1855,Te Ika a Maui,202)

BUDDLE [Ngaruawahia] has been surveyed ... and a large Town laid out in one acre allotments, ... the streets being named after Maori tupunas (ancestors) and living chiefs. (1860,Maori King Movement,15)

MANING `One evening a smart, handsome lad came to tell me his tupuna was dying ... The tribe were ke poto or assembled to the last man about the dying chief.' Ibid. 214 ... a smart handsome lad, of about twelve years of age, came to tell me that his tupuna was dying, ... and had sent for me to see him before he died. (1863,Old New Zealand,196)

... the genealogical stick by which `King Tawhiao' traces back his ancestry to the earliest of tupunas ... (Jan 1884,NZ Journal of Science,58)

MORRIS Maori word, meaning ancestor, progenitor, male or female. Often used in the Land Courts in the question: `Who are your tupuna?' (1898,Austral English,482)

tupuna n. an ancestor; a progenitor, male or female. [Maori] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,12)

ANCESTOR. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

tupuna n. Maori word for ancestor, progenitor [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

tupuna n.. Maori word for ancestor, progenitor [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

Often people are whakama about gout or they blame themselves or their tupuna for it. (2009,Mana,87/43)

This stream is called Rangoriri, after an old native tupuna, who fell in and was scalded to death. (Mar 19, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,8)

It was while he was working at the radio station that Mr Flavell discovered he needed to practise what he preached, and began using his tupuna (ancestral) name -- Te Ururoa... "We are encouraging people to reclaim their tupuna names for the next generation... (Sep 26, 2005,NZ Herald,A6) [NOTES: -]

Each of the representatives of the human figure bears the name of some tupuna, or ancestor, and the whole is actually a carved history. (Apr 6, 1844,Daily Southern Cross,4)

tupuru¶

n. sandals

Herries Beattie describes a different method: "This tussock was placed in the paraerae (sandal) and the foot inserted. Then the tussock was brought up the leg and tied above the ankle. This protection was called puru and the sandals were then known as tupuru." Patiti was also regarded as "a fine thing to put in the paraerae to keep the feet warm and if one was wading it was warmer with patiti around the feet than without it." (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/40)

tuputupu¶

n. a mangrove

POLACK Manawa and Tuputupu, two varieties of the well-known mangrove, cover the mud banks of the rivers and creeks of the country in which they flourish. (1983,New Zealand (Polack),2/398)

turangawaewae¶

n. the ability, conferred by belonging to a home-turf, to stand on one's own two feet; a strong homeland-based identity. [Maori turanga[u-macron] a standing + waewae foot]

Why do they do it? Because Springer gave them a place to be, their very own turangawaewae (spiritual home). (Jun 1, 1999,Dominion,11)

I remember being taken to Ruapuke, our turangawaewae, for the first time with my parents. (Oct 1998,Mana,No. 24: 68)

HULME & MORRISON It is my turangawaewae-ngakau, the standing-place of my heart. (1989,Homeplaces,64)

The possum and I were not going to pass the night in the same room... This was his turangawaewae, the place where he stood. (Nov 2002,NZ Geographic,No. 60/72)

For the French, and almost all European winegrowers for that matter, wine is about the land, about a piece of dirt that is turangawaewae. And you can no more separate the land from the wine than you can call a Greek a Turk, or vice versa, which is why Europe is riddled with those convoluted wine regulations that read like a dialogue for a frustrated Homer Simpson - DO, DOG, AoC, VDQS, QmP, QbA! What all these mean is turangawaewae, the place that wine calls home, and there is only one. (Aug 21, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

Kalik, the final book in Jack Lasenby's "Travellers Quartet", is a satisfying end to the story of Ish and his quest for turangawaewae. ((9/0/2002),Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

Kalik, the final book in Jack Lasenby's "Travellers Quartet", is a satisfying end to the story of Ish and his quest for turangawaewae. (Mar 9, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),62)

Happy because he's bought some land in Rotorua, his turangawaewae after 20 years in Devonport. (Sep 19, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),21)

"You gotta honour your Pommie whakapapa, for sure, but home isn't [England], eh. Your turangawaewae is in the Pacific, where there's sand and kauri and gorse. That's where your family is, eh. Your real whanau. You can't change that, the sand's already on your feet." (Aug 7, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),42)

The site - the Observatory Reserve at Kelburn - is highly significant: it is a taonga, a turangawaewae, to be treasured and preserved - none but a fool or a knave would willingly surrender it! (Nov 1993,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,102/66)

I feel like a Wellington girl. I jokingly call it my turangawaewae - my spiritual home. (Mar 15, 2003,Dominion Post TV Week,3)

HILLIARD These acres were his [a Maori farmer's] [13] turangawaewae; the only heirloom of consequence his family ever had - (1969,Green River,12)

(Feb 17, 1982,Dominion,9) [NOTES: see Incorporations]

Although economic factors have helped to scatter the Maori people from their homelands, the majority of them see themselves as belonging to a tribe whose turangawaewae (place for the feet to stand) and whose ahi-ka (burning fire) are located at specific regions. (1984,Te Maori,31)

HOWE Turangawaewae - this term refers to the ability to stand on one's own two feet because one belongs (see papakainga) to a piece of land which reflects one's history - one's identity. It combines therefore, the feeling of belonging and the idea of the place itself. If one loses one's papakainga, one has no turangawaewae. (1985,Towards Taha Maori,23)

I put my $16,000 into a 36-perch piece of land behind Hekerua Bay ... It is my turangawaewae and I'll pass it on to my successors. (May 1987,Metro,70) [NOTES: Roger `Auckland Life']

Maclean Each group [i.e. tramping club] had its own turangawaewae in the hills and its own chiefly figures. (1994,Tararua Story,167) [NOTES: check quote]

turawera¶

n. a plant

HOOKER Turawera, Col[enso]. Pteris tremula. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

turbot¶

n. a fish

HECTOR Occasionally a large flat fish, said to resemble the Patiki, has been brought to market and sold as Turbot, but, from native information, it is probable that several distinct species yet remain to be discovered by the Pakeha fishermen. (1872,Edible Fishes,177)

HECTOR Occasionally a large flat fish, said to resemble the Patiki, has been brought to market and sold as Turbot, but, from native information, it is probable that several distinct species yet remain to be discovered by the Pakeha fishermen. (1872,Edible Fishes,177)

Turbot - a fish not uncommon in the Dunedin market, where it goes by the name oflemon-sole.'' (1876,TrNZI,8/215)

SHERRIN TURBOT (Ammotretis Guntheri). ... [28] In the Transactions of the New Zealand Institute vol. viii., p.215, Captain Hutton writes thus of the Ammotretis rostratus: A fish not uncommon in the Dunedin market, where it goes by the name oflemon sole,' agrees so well with Dr. Gunther's description of A. rostratus, from Tasmania, that I have no hesitation in considering it that species.' (1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,26)

MORRIS The name is given to a New Zealand fish, called also Lemon-Sole (q.v.) or Yellow-belly (q.v.), Ammotretis guntheri. (1898,Austral English,482)

[Flatfish submitted for opinion included] (1.) The flounder, or patiki, wrongly named plaice,' about one-tenth adult size. (2) The turbot sole, wrongly [559] namedbrill,' about one-fortieth its adult size: ... (3.) The lemon sole, wrongly named `flounder,' ... (4.) The New Zealand sole ... (1901,TrNZI,33/558)

Brill - Turbot - Ammotretis guntheri. (1911,Records of the Canterbury Museum,1/197) [NOTES: Waite]

Referring to the liberation of turbot, ... (1919,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,2/279) [NOTES: (Thomson)]

AMMOTRETIS NUDIPINNIS Waite. Turbot. A rare fish in each of the four chief towns. I have been informed that it is more common around Invercargill and Stewart Island. ... Distribution: South Island coasts; examples have been taken as far north as Whangarei. (Jun 1921,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,4/122) [NOTES: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes]

SPEIGHT These two are the Turbot (Colistium nudipinnis) with broadly blotched upper surface, and the Brill (C. guntheri) (Pl. II. fig. 30) which is marked with spots forming lines along the body. (1927,Natural History of Canterbury,202) [NOTES: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 202]

PHILLIPPS Colistium nudipinnis Waite. TURBOT. (1927,Bibliography of NZ Fishes,27,1971 ed.)

"Waiter," he called, "fetch me a nice piece of boiled turbot." (May 27, 1939,Evening Post,20)

Colistium (Ammotretis) nudipinnis: Turbot. (1936,Handbook for New Zealand, The,72)

Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour (1938,TrRSNZ,68/407)

POWELL Thirteen species of flat-fishes are known from New Zealand waters, including a large Turbot, Colistium nudipinnis, which is comparatively rare, and the Megrim, Caulopsetta scapha, which is not popular as a food fish as it is usually very thin. (1947,Native Animals of NZ,67)

GRAHAM Turbot Colistium nudipinnis(Waite) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,404) [NOTES: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 404]

WILSON FLATFISH ... Inhabitants of sandy or muddy, shallow flats the flatfish are also occasionally taken in deep water. This is specially so of the fairly rare Turbot which grows to a considerable size and inhabits the deeper, southern waters. (1981,Fisherman's Bible,71)

BURTON These much sought-after but relatively rare flatfish [flounder and sole] are generally found on sandy bottoms of shallow inshore areas. There are eight commercial species in New Zealand : the sand flounder, yellowbelly flounder, greenback flounder, black flounder, lemon sole, common sole, brill and turbot. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,73)

AYLING TURBOT Colistium nudipinnis ... The turbot is the largest of the New Zealand flounders and individuals over 80cm in length have been recorded ... (1982,Collins Guide,311,1984 ed.)

Closely related to the brill is the turbot, the largest New Zealand flatfish. It has a reddish-brown back with darker brown splotches and is found mainly on the west coasts of both the North and South Islands, although only about 20 tonnes is trawled annually... If it is any consolation, the turbot of northern waters is a slightly different species to ours, having its eyes on the other side of the head. (Dec 8, 1982,Evening Post,37)

[species name] turbot .. [scientific name] Colistium nudipinnis.. [other name(s)] (Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters)

PAUL Turbot Colistium nudipinnis Restricted to New Zealand. (1986,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,145)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] turbot 2240-2, 2253, 2292-3, 2309 (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

ON sale by the undersigned:- Salmon trouts, Fresh haddocks entire, Boiled turbot ... (Sep 25, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,1)

TO ARRIVE, Per Wellington, Coromandel, and Roman Empire .. Turbot, Sardines, 1/4's and 1/2's ... (Jan 27, 1882,Wanganui Chronicle,1)

Fresh Salmon, Herrings [sic], Mackerel, Haddock, Skate, Trout, Turbot, Mockturtle, Hotch-potch, packed in tins, which would be found to make most acceptable dishes at the Diggings. (Apr 18, 1857,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

FECUNDITY OF FISH. - The Trout, weighing 1lb., carries 1,000 eggs .. the turbot, weighing 8lbs., contains 385,200 ... (Mar 16, 1865,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,3)

2 n. [New Zealand turbot]

New Zealand turbot, he believes, is not quite as good as its European counterpart (which sells for astronomical prices), since our version is thinner and more like an oversized flounder. (Feb 28, 2004,Dominion Post,E6)

Ammotretis nudipinnis Waite. (Ammotretis rostratus Hutton.) This fine fish is named `New Zealand turbot' by Waite ... (1913,TrNZI,45/232) [NOTES: (Thomson, Otago)]

GRAHAM NEW ZEALAND TURBOT Colistium nudipinnis (Waite) (1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,188)

PAUL et al. [index to common names 283-293] (1987,Fishes: A Bibliography)

turd¶

n. third-former, a new kid [this is the most common name for new kids in various spgs TIRDS, terds, etc, or third-formers in the responses to quest. -->1984 17 M E109Pakuranga Coll. 25 TURDS - 3RD FORMERS]

turd: third former (Feb 1981,Avondale College Slang Words in Use) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

turd-burglar¶

n. a male homosexual

O'SULLIVAN JACKO: Worse if it was the Air Force mind. Pack of turd-burglars, that outfit. (1985,Shuriken,21)

McGILL turd burglar male homosexual. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,115)

turehu¶

n.

The surviving Turehu became mountain dwellers, and the last known traces proved them to be mere phantoms with human voices. (Sep 1, 1900,NZ Illustrated Magazine,911)

Tom.. says turehu can be found in these parts. "Turehu?" I say. "Goblins", he whispers. (Aug 9, 1997,Evening Post,14)

When the mist comes low on our maunga [mountain] it means the Turehu and Patupaiarehu, spiritual beings, have come to teach us our whakapapa and the practice of the taiaha. (Sep 27, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),44)

They were here from at least 3000BC, an enlightened and peaceable peo0ple who built cities and temples and tended the land before being wiped out by the incoming Maori - though their memory remains in tales of the Turehu (fair-skinned people) and patupaiarehe (bush fairies). (Apr 8, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

They were here from at least 3000BC, an enlightened and peaceable people who built cities and temples and tended the land before being wiped out by the incoming Maori - though their memory remains in tales of the Turehu (fair-skinned people) and patupaiarehe (bush fairies). (Apr 8, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),26)

Fairies or forest elves are known as "heketoro" and "turehu." (Oct 25, 1933,Evening Post,16)

If there should be any claims they should be by turehu, the white-skinned people who were the original pre-Maori inhabitants of New Zealand, the white tangata whenua who lived here at least 500 years or more before Maori ever arrived. (Jun 16, 2003,Dominion Post,B4)

Intelligent Maoris.. believe.. that on its upper slopes there lived a race of little red men, Turehu, parties of whom went down at night to fish in some of the bays near Port Jackson. (Jun 15, 1922,Auckland Weekly News,15)

In those good old times the interior was occupied, they say, by Turehu or Patupaiarehe, a race short in stature and of fair skin. (1889,TrNZI,21/32)

turehu: fairy people. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.)

KEENE turehu: fairy-folk. (1963,O Te Raki,195)

HILLIARD ... Then the fairy won't forget to come.'The turehu won't take to sugar,' ... It's not turehu,' ...It's patupaiareke where we come from. And they take to sugar....' (1978,Glory and the Dream, The,116)

GILDERDALE turehu fairy, ghost (1982,Sea Change,242)

Sometimes Maori women have Turehu lovers whom they meet in the bush unknown to their people. (Dec 20, 1894,Otago Witness,6)

The dread of Patupaiarehe (or Turehu, as they were sometimes called) no doubt hindered the natives from ascending the mountain, but it was surprising that the natural indomitable curiosity of some colonists did not urge them to the summit. (Sep 1, 1888,Te Aroha News,3)

turepo¶

n. Paratrophis banksii, milk-tree

Portion of a batten for a whare, Kaho, made of Turepo, Hoheria populnea ribbon wood. (Sep 22, 1874,Star, The,2)

HECTOR Occasionally a large flat fish, said to resemble the Patiki, has been brought to market and sold as Turbot, but, from native information, it is probable that several distinct species yet remain to be discovered by the Pakeha fishermen. (1872,Edible Fishes,177) [NOTES: moved to turbot headword - wrongly in turepo]

[Native name] Turepo .. [Settlers' name] Milk-tree .. [Family] Articeae (1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,122) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 122]

... the turepo' of the Maoris and themilk-tree' of the settlers. (1897,TrNZI,29/498)

MEREDITH ... we lived on the tender bleached ends of cabbage tree leaves, and the inner bark of the turipa tree, which is sweet and not unpalatable but not very satisfying. (1898,Reminiscences and Experiences,21)

CHEESEMAN P[aratrophis] heterophylla, Bl.Mus. ... NORTH ISLAND: ... Turepo; Milk-tree. ... Abounding in milky sap, which is said to be palatable. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,632)

In Paratrophis Banksii there is an example of a large-leaf form of the turepo, ot milkwood' of the bushman. ... Growing in close proximity ... is <i>Sideroxylon costatum,</i> known to the Bay of Plenty Natives asorewa', but given theless euphonious name of `tawaapu' by writers on the New Zealand flora. (1924,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,7/186) [NOTES: (Sladden)]

... a small tree ... about 15 feet high, with smooth cineraceous bark, solitary crimson fruit ... On cutting its bark, a profusion of thick, viscid milky juice gushed out. [fn] Presumably Paratrophis heterophylla, Turepo, milk-tree. (1959,Early Travellers,37)

FULLER THE MILK-TREE (TUREPO) The turepo (Paratrophis microphylla) trunk will slowly exude a creamy sap if it is cut or bruised. The sap was used as a substitute for milk by early colonists. (1978,Maori Food and Cookery,84)

BURTON Those pioneers who were without dairy cattle made a kind of `milk' from the creamy sap of the turepo or milk tree (Paratrophis microphylla). (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,20)

TUREPO (Milk Tree)/ Paratrophis microphylla / Tree reaching 12m. Bark whitish grey with noticeable breathing pores. (1982,Field Guide to Common NZ Trees & Shrubs,14)

For example, there have been no podocarps, rimu or matai or smaller species such as the intriguing Streblus heterophyllus, or Turepo, known to European settlers as the milk tree, because of the sweet milky sap they used in their tea. (Aug 10, 2002,Dominion Post,F14)

turf¶

v. throw out or away; discard

SLATTER He'd just got a letter from his girl friend. She was marrying a Marine. So you boys elected him to the Turf Club. Another good boy turfed by a girl back here. (1959,Gun in My Hand, A,100)

to turf (something) out: to throw it away (1980,Lynfield College, Auckland) [NOTES: (Goldie Brown Collection)]

I'll take all the rubbish ...and .... I'll follow the old bitch back and turf it all over her floor (Jun 1982,Landfall,142, 145)

turiwata¶

turiwati/turiwhati¶

n. (See tuturiwhatu)

Vol. IX No. 5 p. 358 ... the most important [Chatham Island] edible sea-birds: AS WRITTEN AS PRONOUNCED ENGLISH hopo ho[macron]p' albatross hakoakoa ha[macron]ko[macron]k' mutton bird taiko tchai[macron]k' pied shear water tupoupou tchu[macron]poup' pied blue billie reoreo ro[macron]ro[macron] Mother Carys chicken turiwati tchu[macron]riwat' dottrel [sic] kuaka ku[macron]k' snipe (1928,BP Bishop Memoirs) [NOTES: >1928 Baucke Manuscript in Skinner and Baucke The Morioris (Bishop Museum Memoirs Vol. IX No. 5 pp. 343-382) 358]

RICHARDS Thinornis ... novae zealandiae ... The shore plover is found on the Chathams and has no near relative left in New Zealand. ... Shore Plover. PURIWATA, KUKURUATU. (1952,Chatham Islands,79)

Turkey¶

n. a Turkish soldier

BAILEY & ROTH Old Abdul under cover was as cunning as a rat;/ As yet we'd done no shootin' - saw nothin' to shoot at,/ Till a Turkey popped his head up; that head he ne'er withdrew,/ For a rifle pinged... (1967,Shanties,115) [NOTES: [ca1915-1918] in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 115]

turkey¶

n.

Button-pushers, or `turkeys' as they are known in CB jargon, hold down the buttons on their CB sets and play music or use abusive language. Their actions prevent other CB operators from using the frequency. (Jul 20, 1987,Evening Post,2)

n. (Rural) a fine whetstone used by blade shearers.

LOUGHNAN turkey: a fine whet-stone used by blade shearers, so named from the country whence it used to be imported. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,87)

turkey drive¶

1 n. (Rural) an annual muster of wild turkeys before Christmas.

KEENE The exciting time came with the turkey drives each year, just before the December steamer arrived. (1978,Mimiwhangata Station,39)

turkey off¶

v. to depart quickly, decamp

PARTRIDGE Well, I was so stiff I nearly turkeyed off from the line, but I decided to wait. (1935,Slang Today,287) [NOTES: 1935 A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge Slang Today 287]

PARTRIDGE Turkey off. To decamp: New Zealanders': C. 20. (1935,Dictionary of Slang,917)

RAWLINSON Everyone thought he'd just turkeyed off. (1938,Music in the Listening Place,15)

18 % `to turkey off' (to depart). (Apr 2, 1938,Press, The) [NOTES: McNab NZ Slang]

McGILL turkey off absent without leave; WWI. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,115)

The cold of recent nights/Has led me to believe/That winter, ere it turkeys off,/Has something up its sleeve (1900,Star, The) [NOTES: Year is incorrect.]

turkeys in gumboots¶

phr. a reference to a celebrated TV spoof Country Calendar item

It was a big week for the turkeys-in-gumboots school of local television drama. (Aug 4, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),77)

Turkish delight¶

n. shellfire

PILLING We passed the French batteries serving out `Turkish delight' ... (May 6, 1915,Anzac Memory,37,1933 ed.)

turn¶

n. [AND: fuss]

He takes girls off the streets and lives on them.'I never go past without her giving me a turn about something or other,' the witness explained to the Bench. Once Mrs. Blood had said something particularly atrocious about him,... (May 9, 1908,NZ Truth,151/6/1)

n. [re sheep dog behaviour]

Turn.- When a dog heads or slews sheep, shepherds speak of his having done a good (etc) t. (C.) (Dec 30, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

1 v. (Rural) [sheepdogs] to slew sheep.

LOUGHNAN turn: a dog turns his sheep when he slews them. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,87)

turn a seven¶

phr. to turn a somersault

In the Hack Hurdles, Kimberley, of whom something was expected, turned a seven at the first hurdle Charlie Lett fortunately escaping without serious injury. (May 23, 1890,Wanganui Herald,2)

At the first hurdle in the straight Commonwealth came a cropper, and at the second Katerina turned a seven. (May 12, 1905,Taranaki Herald,3)

While working last week Prince Child turned a seven and his rider took away a pain in the shoulder just to remember the incident. (Nov 19, 1921,NZ Truth,7)

No sooner had the competitors been dispatched on their long journey than Sir Donald and Hurakia set out to force the pace, while the supporters of Awahou had the mortification of seeing their fancy turn a seven at the second obstacle. (Aug 18, 1915,Hawera & Normanby Star,2)

BEATTIE Even the best horsemen were not proof against their horses putting a foot in a grass-hidden hole and `turning a seven'. (1947,Early Runholding in Otago,157)

turn custardy¶

phr. variant of turn to custard q.v.

It's when National tries to get clever that things turn custardy. (Oct 14, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

turn dog on¶

phr. to inform on f. dog `informer' 1848

It was a very contemptible thing, added the beak for Machray to `turn dog' on his mates. (Apr 4, 1908,NZ Truth,146/5/3)

Certainly it made Green see red, and turn dog on his old pal, Joe Winter, who had a much warmer time of it than his name would suggest. (May 22, 1909,NZ Truth,205/7/2)

Amongst other witnesses were George Muldon and his wife. The latter said that ... Shears was saying her husband had beaten him (Shears) for 18[pounds], and he would make it warm for Muldon if he went into the witness-box. ... In addition to inflaming the woman's mind, Constable Maher magnanimously offered to see what he could do to secure the husband work as compensation for loss of employment through turning `dog' on Shears. (Mar 11, 1911,NZ Truth,298/7/1)

2 phr. to turn sour on

Latest political small talk is that Masterton's member, A.W. Hogg, the ill-fated ex-Minister, is turning dog on it. Next election will, it is said, see him wooing an Auckland electorate in the interests of Labor [sic]. (Mar 5, 1910,NZ Truth,245/1/8)

MUNDY ... Fred struggled along not doing so well, complaining that he had no help, and that the rest of the family had turned dog on him. (1953,Days That Are No More,25)

MORRIESON The bottle of `the red' he had tossed off in such high spirits had turned dog on him. He was on the verge of nausea. . (1974,Predicament,207,1981 ed.)

turn in¶

v. to give up esp. turn it in, give up a job

HYDE Timothy ... began to scribble. Birkett called, Hey, what're you making, Sonny Boy?'Writing to my girl.' `Christ. Fancy turning in a smoke for a bint. What's her name?' (1938,Godwits Fly, The,129,1970 ed.)

SARGESON turning it in: giving up the job. (1964,Collected Stories,304) [NOTES: 1964 Pearson Glossary to 1964 Sargeson Collected Stories 1935-1963 304]

v. (Rural) to add stock to another group e.g. rams to ewes.

PERRY The ewes should be dagged and the tails trimmed before turning the rams in. (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,73)

v. (Rural) to add stock to a paddock or yard.

Customarily, broken-mouthed ewes are turned in to eat off the tops and the roots are then harrowed out in breaks (May 20, 1933,NZ Journal of Agriculture,300)

CONNELL & HAFIELD When the paddock has been fed off, dry stock are turned in, or the mower used, to clean up any roughage. (1961,Agriculture,305)

turn it on¶

phr. to provide liquor at a party etc.

The leader of the ruffians, when interviewed by "The Week's" Special Inquisitor, said that the whole trouble was due to shock, caused by the local hotel-keeper "turning it on." (Sep 5, 1930,Star, The,5)

AFTER "turning it on" for his men, Frederick Williamson, a well-known Christchurch builder, stayed in town for tea, and later had a few more spots, with the result that when he set out in his car he was in that state in which his driving was a danger both to himself and to other users of the road. (Jul 31, 1930,NZ Truth,6)

McGILL turn it on give a party or buy drinks; eg `What do you say we turn it on for the boys tonight?' NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,115)

turn it up¶

v. to offer or allow sexual intercourse

Gee I was not seeking anything impossible, just more than 'leg over', something more than 'turning it up'. (2009,Access Road,54)

McGILL turn it up make oneself, usually a female, available for sex; eg `Hey, Mort, reckon that sheila over there'd turn it up?' (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,115)

She said he tried to rape her behind the hedge and then in her flat. He said she told him she sometimes `turns it up' and he thought she was an easy mark. (Oct 16, 1973,NZ Truth,18)

turn Nagasaki¶

phr. become nasty

McGILL turn Nagasaki become nasty as when atom bomb struck Nagasaki; eg `No need to turn Nagasaki on me, mate. I'm on your side.' Underworld. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,115)

turn off¶

1 v. (Rural) to produce stock [usually for sale].

NEWTON In Hugh Ensor's time the station shore over 20,000 and turned off some fine lines of sheep. (1952,High Country Journey,87)

turn on¶

v. (Rural) to move stock on to a crop or paddock.

Would you please let me know if pigs turned on lucerne will require any other food, and if so, what kind and how much? (Oct 20, 1926,NZ Journal of Agriculture,287)

turn rusty¶

phr.

Should he be foolish enough to do so, and gets [sic] the sack for doing it, he will get scant sympathy from his mates, but, should he on the other hand turn rusty and refuse to come up to expectations, they will say (to put it in polite language) that his mother and father were never united in the holy bonds of matrimony. (Jan 7, 1911,NZ Truth,289/4/6)

turn sheep over¶

phr. (Rural) to tip sheep on to their tails [ for inspection of udders or scrotum or to trim their hooves.]

GORDON Turned them all over on the board here [in the shearing shed, with hoof clippers] Of the 2,000 ewes we had, 1700 were infected the first time we turned them over. (1987,People, Places & Paddocks,125)

turn tail¶

phr. (Rural) [sheepdogs] to 'spin' or back off and turn around when confronted by sheep. (See spinning)

HARTLEY Any pup that is inclined to turn tail will be sure to give up the practice provided that the trainer does not choose turns that are too difficult at first. (1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,4)

A dog that under pressure from sheep and backs off a little and turns right around, is said to turn tail. Turning tail shows first a lack of confidence in a young dog, and in an older animal, a lack of strength. If a youngster is let away with it, 'turning tail' will just become a habit. (1984,NZ Journal of Agriculture,Jan/Feb 13)

turn to custard¶

phr. turn out badly, go pear-shaped

"You can't take you [sic] eye off the ball for a minute. If you do it will turn to custard on you," he said. (Feb 22, 2000,Evening Post,28)

British Prime Minister Tony Blair's best-laid plans for the re-establishment of the London mayoralty are turning to custard, thanks to veteran leftie Ken Livingstone. (Mar 13, 2000,Dominion,5) [NOTES: This is the preamble to an article from AAP. It is not clear whether it came with the original article or was attached in NZ.]

HUGHES Expecting final confirmation of her releases from the clutches of the ordnance corps, she was stunned to see it all turn to custard. (1999,Shooting from the Lip,147)

New Zealand had a shot at victory yesterday... However, it all turned to custard inside the hour. (Mar 28, 2000,Evening Post,40)

The 1970s. The decade when it all started to turn to custard. Britain decided its trading future lay with Europe, meaning New Zealand had to wean itself off the reassuring teat of the Mother Country and the economy reeled under the impact of Arab-instigated oil price shocks. (Nov 30, 1999,Evening Post,Looking Back : 3)

Retrace your steps before darkness falls and everything turns to custard - or arm yourself with a fancy torch. (Aug 1996,Hot Rides,No. 8)

Last year, New Zealand First's Tuariki John Delamere objected to her, a woman, being allowed to sit in the front row - although you'll notice he shuts his mouth now that his coalition leader, for whom he'll depend for a job if NZ First turns to custard, is a woman. (Feb 13, 1998,Russell Brown's Hard News)

The bottom line is that if the savings are worthwhile then have a go, and if it all turns to custard afterwards then go back to your local camera shop, let them laugh at you and say we told you so for a few minutes and then get it fixed. (1997,Photo & Video International (NZ),Easter)

Noel Bigwood is the man who gets involved when things turn to custard. (Dec 29, 2005,Horowhenua-Kapiti Chronicle,1)

Human nature being what it is, says Alison Laurie, senior lecturer at Victoria University's Women's Studies faculty, when it [sc. a relationship] all turns to custard "most people want to get the goodies for themselves." (Feb 8, 2000,Evening Post,10)

Rather than run the risk to our egos of continually electing political teams that give us a five minute thrill but impoverish us in the process, why not appoint an expert to oversee them and then if it turns to custard we can blame him. (Jul 19, 2003,Dominion Post,C2)

Best references to custard:... "It all turned to custard" - just about everyone interviewed on a local news show. (Jan 2, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),69)

Even positive(ish) measures, such as building new prisons, turn to custard. (May 15, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),15)

"Rigoletto has hate. Envy. Love. Revenge. Passion. Jealousy... I think it's a wonderfully profound piece of music." And what's more, says this fan. Just hearing it turns her to custard. (Feb 19, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),63)

I vote. You get elected. You (plural) govern. They (junior coalition partner) muscle in and govern, too. We wait for it to turn to custard. It custardises. (Dec 18, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14)

You or I could go over and try to transplant the Team New Zealand ethic into a Swiss team led by one powerful individual and the whole thing might turn to custard. (Mar 25, 2000,Sunday Star Times,A5)

After the Force deal turned to custard, Wood hinted other deal-makers were waiting in the wings. (May 21, 2000,Sunday Star Times,E3)

Although my brain has turned to custard and it's a rare occasion I'm able to complete a task or sentence in one attempt, it's these skills that allow me to know exactly how smart my kids really are. (Jul 5, 2000,Contact (Wgtn),9)

I wait with much interest to see the form and substance of underneath the froth that the Dairy Board is trying to get us to drink. Right now it all looks like it could turn to custard rather than be the top of a good cappuccino . (1999,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.pandaspot.co.nz]

With that freedom, of course, comes responsibility, above all, responsibility for your actions, and not demanding that someone else take care of you should everything turn to custard. (2000,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.freeradical.co.nz]

To make the most of the new law, parties will need to consider these issues when entering into contracts, and select from the menu of available rules. A little foresight may be amply repaid should commerce later turn to custard. (Aug 7, 1997,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.chapmantripp.co.nz]

If the situation calms down, and air service to/from Fiji continues, we will proceed to Savusavu. If it continues to turn to custard in Fiji, we will divert to the Vava'u Group in Tonga and hang out there and play wait and see with Fiji. Don't feel bad for us, as Vava'u is not too bad of a place to "wait and see." (May 30, 2000,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: Dave & Jaja Martin www.setsail.com]

When things started to turn to custard in the second half, a strong leader would have gathered his troops together to demand a monopoly of possession. Just like Buck Shelford would have done. (Aug 25, 1999,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.scrum.com/super12/]

Lionel can't please both son and wife-to-be. Frank decides the clinic's fate. Caroline's suspicions turn to custard (Jan 1999,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.shortlandst.com/current-jan1999]

27-01-99 On nights (1st years start nights after 6 weeks) you're it!!! (Including O&G/Paeds). Great experience but things can turn to custard. (Jan 27, 1999,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: www.nzrda.org.nz/newsletter]

Last year, New Zealand First's John Delamere objected to her, a woman, being allowed to sit in the front row - although you'll notice he shuts his mouth now that his coalition leader, for whom he'll depend for a job if NZ First turns to custard, is a woman. (Feb 13, 1998,Internet - see Notes) [NOTES: Russell Brown's "Hard News" at www.nz.com/NZ/News/Hard News]

Tuck in : we're talking chilled Grand Marnier sabayon in a chocolate cup with seasonal fruit... The colours were a play of light and shadow, and I liked the way the sabayon turned to custard. (Aug 21, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),94)

turn under¶

1 v. (Rural) to cultivate vegetation-covered land.

Using his Ferguson to the utmost he managed to turn the gorse under and apply lime and phosphate. (Jun 10, 1958,NZ Dairy Exporter,4)

turn up¶

v. lay off, stop (it), to give up, to give away

Pug Bob Turner has announced that he has turned up the game, and accordingly the match with Bob Byrant [sic] in Sydney is off. (Nov 3, 1907,NZ Truth,128/3/1)

PARTRIDGE [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... turn it up! give over; (1935,Slang Today,286)

PARTRIDGE Hey, turn it up and stop all those gloomy forecasts or you will find that I can go very hostile, and it's time we all took a tumble to ourselves and discussed something pleasant, say a little party. (1935,Slang Today,287)

turned on, be¶

v. to smoke marijuana

Two of the youths suggested that they be turned on' - smoke marijuana. ... Whitehead went to Patterson's home to rejoin the boys and girls, but requests to again beturned on' were refused, he said. (Jul 16, 1963,NZ Truth,38)

turner¶

n. (Rural) a sheep or cattle dog that is not eager to work.

Turner - A 'Sunday passenger' or a 'tripehound' who does nothing but turn good tucker into something far less desirable. (1984,NZ Journal of Agriculture,Jan/Feb 13)

MCGILL turner: a dog. Why? Because he turns good food into sh--. (1989,Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The,104)

SWAN Any dog, of any description, may be a cat cruncher, a general turner,....a dog may be a scrapper. (1995,Chasin' Bacon,82)

GORDON Another of that ilk [lazy dog] would be the 'turner' which simply turns good food into something far less desirable. (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,87)

1 n. (Rural) a member of a harvesting-mill team who sets sheaves to be fed into the mill.

ANGUS Each mill employed ten or thirteen men, three breaking down the stack, then a 'turner' who set the sheaves the right way for the 'feeder,' the man who had the skilled task of cutting the binding and letting the sheaves slide down his arm into the mill at an even rate. (1981,Aspiring Settlers,49)

LOUGHNAN turner: he deposits each sheaf to the hand of the bandcutter, or the stacker - who very often works on hands and knees anyway. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,87)

KERSE The usual gang for stack threshing [c1900] was 12 men.
