The boss kept steam up and attended to the mill adjustments and lubrication, three men worked in the bag hole, the bag-rammer, the bag-sower, and the bag-carrier; two men were on top of the mill, a band cutter and a man to turn the sheaves to the band cutter: two men were on the stack forking to the turner', and then there was the chaffy, two men on the straw stack, a builder and a strawwalloper' and last of all, the water joey. Threshing out of the stock required an even larger gang, usually about three more men. (1984,Knapdale Run, The,148)

turning tail¶

n. (Rural) the spinning or veering of a sheepdog when confronted by a sheep.

HARTLEY Turning tail: This is the fault of a dog not turning in towards his sheep head-on. Instead he turns outwards from them ... (1949,Shepherd's Dogs, The,72)

Turning tail shows first a lack of confidence in a young dog, and in an older animal, a lack of strength. If a youngster is let away with it, 'turning tail' will just become a habit. (1984,NZ Journal of Agriculture,Jan/Feb 13)

n. of a sheepdog, turning away from the sheep in a complete circle; failing to `face up' to the sheep all the time (See turn tail)

Turning tail: Fault in a dog whereby it turns away from the sheep in a complete circle. It fails to `face up' to the sheep all the time. (1982,MAF Agricultural Glossary,25)

turnip¶

1 v. (Rural) to turn lambs or sheep on to a paddock of turnips for fattening.

When it is necessary to turnip the sheep, the most economic method is to fence the turnips off into breaks, or small paddocks ... (1919,Livestock in New Zealand,44)

MCCASKILL .. necessary to get the ewe lambs down to the lowest country and turnip them for the winter. (1969,Molesworth,112)

NEWTON Alan recalls the trainload of 5,000 - 61 trucks - arriving at Ealing to be 'turnipped' on their place. (1975,Sixty Thousand on the Hoof,35)

PERRY The hoggets should be wintered ... - if they can be fed on turnips ... so much the better. If they are turniped, then the shepherd must watch them carefully when they are once more put back on the tussocks, for they will usually fret for a time, ... (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,93)

Above cattle have been turnipped since June. (Sep 26, 1919,Bay of Plenty Times,1)

NEWTON .. they turniped their hoggets .. Furthermore, the paddocking and turniping of sheep inclined to make them more difficult to muster. (1949,High Country Days,182)

Store Cattle. - The business doing is small, and prices remain about the same as last week's quotations, only a few small lots changing hands for turnipping purposes at up to GBP5. (Jun 10, 1887,Bruce Herald,2)

turnip break¶

1 n. (Rural) a section of a crop of turnips.

STACEY Some of the boys, who had been shifting a turnip break further across the flat, had seen the dray flying through the snow. (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,123)

turnip fly¶

n. [transferred use]

There are twenty-eight native species belonging to the genus Odontria, but all observers agree that the principal grass grub is Odontria zealandica. In the larval stage this is known as grass grub,'white grub,' or curl grub,' and the adult stage is known asgrass grub beetle,' brown beetle.' orturnip fly.' (1943,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,23/306A)

Turnip-fly (Odontria zealandica): What is commonly referred to as `turnip-fly' is in reality the adult beetle Odontria zealandica, the common grass-grub beetle. (1943,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,24/129A)

The turnip fly, haltica nemorum, is a colcopterous insect, having four wings, two shorter than the others; and is one of the most destructive species, as they feed on plants, when the insects are in their larvae, and in their perfect state also. (Jun 18, 1864,Daily Southern Cross,5)

The Hessian fly is reported to be doing damage in some parts of the Geraldine district, and the turnip fly is also in evidence. (Jan 14, 1913,Evening Post,3)

Turnips also have come away well, and though the turnip fly is keeping them back in places the larger part of the crops are doing well. (Jan 6, 1925,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,1)

Every farmer knows the necessity for rapid growth in the early stages of the turnip plant, which is so subject to the "turnip fly" and other pests. (Oct 20, 1909,Otago Witness,8)

turnip topper¶

1 n. (Rural) a weaned lamb that requires priming before slaughter.

Small store lambs, or turnip toppers, are in demand, making $25 to $33 ... (Jun 15, 1994,NZ Farmer,51)

turnip weed¶

n.

turnip weed [s] Rapistrum rugosum (L.) All. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,81)

turnip-scuffler¶

n.

HARPER Before the days of turnip-scufflers seven or eight Chinese thinned and weeded the sweedes [sspg???] and turnips. (1975,Eight Daughters,26)

turnipping¶

n. [grazing of stock on turnips]

NEWTON .. they turniped their hoggets .. Furthermore, the paddocking and turniping of sheep inclined to make them more difficult to muster. (1949,High Country Days,182)

To add GBP12 10s a week to the cost of 500 sheep is no light matter, but owners who pay it consider they are lucky to find "turnipping" within reasonable access, since in some paddocks the roots are not worth eating. (Sep 24, 1935,Evening Post,14)

Forward cattle, suitable for turnipping, sold well. (Sep 2, 1896,North Otago Times,2)

The demand for store wethers in good condition for turnipping is very keen. (Apr 23, 1902,Otago Witness,44)

turnout¶

n. mode of transport, such as a bike or side-car; as recorded in Frank S. Anthony's Me and Gus.

Turnout.- Horse complete with saddle and bridle, and often including breastplate and crupper. In great use among station hands, especially when dealing or swapping. (C.) (Dec 30, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

I have the best turn-out in town now with my rubber tyres and newly-painted cart. (May 20, 1924,Otago Witness,24)

n. a `show' (esp. a party), esp. in collocation A GOOD TURN-OUT [-->ca1949 Wellington She was a good turn-out last night. Plenty of beer.]

McGILL She was a good turn-out last night. Plenty of beer. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,115)

turnsies and fairsies¶

phr.

Throw in the dairy cooperative philosophy of "turnsies and fairsies" and you have a sludgy mix that doesn't rise when the commercial heat goes on. [Andrea Fox] (Mar 25, 2000,Dominion,13)

turnstone¶

n.

HUTTON 67. STREPSILAS INTERPRES. L. Turnstone (1871,Birds of New Zealand,26)

  1. Strepsilas interpres, L. Turnstone. - This cosmopolitan wader was, I believe, first observed between Ellesmere and Ninety-mile beach, Nov. 1870. (1885,NZ Journal of Science,511) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

Strepsilas interpres (Turnstone) Occurs among the rough beds of boulders on the Ahuna River, but never at any time numerous. (1889,TrNZI,21/220)

The turnstone (Arenaria interpres) also breeds in the Northern Hemisphere ... (1901,TrNZI,233/255)

FALLA et al. TURNSTONE Arenaria interpres (1966,Birds of New Zealand,138)

171. Arenaria interpres (Linnaeus, 1758) Turnstone Breeding holarctic region, migrating to southern hemisphere, including New Zealand ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,49,1980 ed.)

Turnstone Arenaria interpres (LINNAEUS, 1758) (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,201)

turnstyle shed¶

1 n. (Rural) a rounded design of milking shed.

The partnership milks 450 Jersey-Friesian cross cows through a 60-bail turnstyle shed built four years ago. Six years ago they milked about 240 cows through a 22-bail turnstyle shed. (Mar 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture,42)

Farm buildings include a 50-bail turnstile milking shed ... [turnstile] (Nov 5, 2002,Dominion Post,C3)

There have been moves towards new turnstyle sheds in the Bay of Plenty... During the tour the group inspected 16-bail, 22-bail and 28-bail turnstyles. (May 1972,NZ Dairy Exporter,13)

turntable pen¶

1 n. (Rural) a raced and rounded pen that allows sheep to be easily manoeuvred into a pot dip.

STEVENS The sloping surface which gives a slide in from the side of a bath, the tipping pen in which the floor moves from the horizontal to a steep angle, and the turntable pen, all have the common purpose of getting the sheep into the bath with a minimum of effort and with little risk of injury to the sheep. (1958,Sheep. Part 1, Sheep husbandry,86)

turoa¶

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] a New Zealand-bred cultivar of red clover (Trifolium pratense).

LEVY For primary forest burn: Turoa or Hamua red clover. (1970,Grasslands of NZ,183)

Turoa - late-flowering, summer-active, diploid cultivar derived from the old Montgomery red clover. (1995,Grasslands Range of Forage and Conservation Plants,6)

turp¶

v. to put turpentine on the arsehole anus of esp. a dog or cat as a presumed salutary punishment, or as a warning to stay off one's property [ca1940 Havelock]

turpentine¶

n. various shrubs or trees with aromatic leaves or resin (See tarata)

Turpentine - Pittosporum eugenioides. This is the largest of the mapau family; it sometimes attains a height of 40 feet, with a diameter of 24 inches. The bark is thin, and of a light colour; the leaves are silvery green, and the flowers pale yellow... The bark exudes a thick gum, and the juice of the leaves, which is somewhat similar, was formerly used by the Maoris as a perfume, but I fear it is too resinous for European tastes. (1877,TrNZI,9 : 143)

Turpentine (tarata) .. Pittosporum eugenioides .. Timber white and elastic; ... (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,15)

KEENE Hina hina abounded [near Owaka, Otago], also turpentine with its light foliage and sweetly scented flowers of palest green. (1967,Tang of The Bush,34)

P. eugenioides turpentine (1877,TrNZI,9)

It [Mentha australis]is called `turpentine' by the settlers. (1882,TrNZI,14/383) [NOTES: (Kirk)]

50 Tarata (turpentine) slab. Ibid. 22 334 Turpentine slab. (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,16)

turpentine bush¶

n.

MOORE & IRWIN DRACOPHYLLUM FILIFOLIUM is one of the group of grass trees' or needle-leaved species with few-flowered racemes ..., known generally asinanga' in the north, inaka' in the south, andturpentine bush' to those who use the twigs to make a quick fire. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,114)

turpentine plant¶

n.

COWAN The flowering koromiko (veronica) and the turpentine plant - the latter invaluable to the camper-out because it burns well even when green - are two of the most plentiful shrubs. (1926,Travel in NZ,2/66)

turpentine scrub¶

n.

Such scrub occurs more or less on all the high mountains; but on the drier ones - such as those of Central Otago, East Nelson, Marlborough, or the eastern portions of the Southern Alps - not forming a distinct belt, but only patches in places. Its tendency to burn is well exemplified by the local name `turpentine scrub'. (1899,TrNZI,31/400) [NOTES: (Cockayne)]

SUTHERLAND The verdure was eighteen inches high all over it broken here and there by rock outcrops and turpentine scrub. (1953,Golden Bush, The,167,1963 ed.)

DENNIS It is frequently made difficult by thick patches of hardy leatherwood and turpentine scrub (Dracophyllum longifolium and D. uniflorum) although respite is provided by ... the flowering of mountain heath. (1981,Paparoas Guide,164)

WILSON Dracophyllum longifolium INAKA ... Turpentine scrub ...Erect shrub or small tree. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,80)

turpentine shrub¶

n.

COCKAYNE Dracophyllum uniflorum turpentine-shrub (1924,Cultivation of NZ Plants, The)

turpentine shrub [s] Dracophyllum uniflorum Hook.f. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,81)

MARK & ADAMS Dracophyllum uniflorumHook. f. TURRPENTINE SHRUB MATIPO, KARO (1973,NZ Alpine Plants,114)

turpentine tree¶

n. tarata [[1919 July 29] Ver.(WB). = Vernacular names used by settlers supplied by W.Best, Otaki (And) Pittosporum eugenioides turpentine tree]

HEAPHY The turpentine tree is likewise very common in the neighbourhood of Port Nicholson. A considerable quantity of the gum which I obtained by tapping the trees, was very strong in flavour, and beautifully transparent. The cultivation and tending of this tree [44] might be easily learned by the natives, and the produce would, probably, prove of great importance. (1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),43)

KIRK Pittosporum eugenioides turpentine tree (1889,Forest Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

MATTHEWS Pittosporum eugenioides turpentine tree (1890,Descriptive & Priced List) [NOTES: (And)]

MORRIS Turpentine-Tree, n. The name is applied to many trees in Australia yielding a resin, but especially to the tree called Tallow-Wood (q.v.). . . . In New Zealand, it is also applied to the Tarata. See Mapau. (1898,Austral English,484)

NAIRN & SON Pittosporum eugenioides turpentine tree (1912,Catalogue (Nairn & Son)) [NOTES: (And)]

turpentine tree n. name for many trees yielding a resin, especially the tallow wood (q.v.). (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),21)

Pittosporum tenuifolium is the `turpentine tree' of the Otago settlers, who plant it for hedges, as it bears clipping freely. (1972,TrNZI,4/262) [NOTES: (Kirk NZ Pittosporads)]

2 n. karo

FEATON Karo [Maori name] .. Turpentine tree [Settlers' name] .. Pittosporum crassifolium .. Tree (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,177)

P. crassifolium, =KARO (1872,TrNZI,4) [NOTES: (?mainly East Coast, North Island)]

FEATON PITTOSPORUM CRASSIFOLIUM (Banks & Sol.) ... The KARO'.- This species is common on the coastline throughout the Northern Island ... In common with some of the other Pittosporads, it is known to the settlers as one of theTurpentine' trees; which are probably so called on account of the gluten, in which the seeds in the capsule are immersed, emitting a peculiar odour, when expressed. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,34)

turpentine wood¶

n.

Upon the western bank of the valley there are extensive patches - thousands of acres of it in all - of the turpentine wood, which, should it ever catch fire by any means, would make a conflagration such as petroleum only could excel. (Feb 9, 1893,Otago Witness,46)

Tent space and firewood were some what scarce [here in the Ruahine range] but dry turpentine wood or grass tree (Dracophyllum filifolium) provided the welcome cuppa ... (Sep 1958,Tararua,13)

We are able to supply at Lowest Prices all Hardwoods, including Ironbark, Tallow Wood, Turpentine Wood, Blackbutt, etc., etc. (Apr 4, 1914,Poverty Bay Herald,12)

The turpentine wood was recommended as the best for resisting the teredo. (Jan 28, 1905,Taranaki Herald,4)

Recently, while at Sydney, my attention was drawn to the so-called "turpentine" wood as a material for the construction of wharves, and other works exposed to the action of sea-water and the attacks of marine animals, which it is said to resist better than any other description of timber known in the colony. (Jan 9, 1871,Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle,2)

Mr. Philips's amendment was agreed to, and the Secretary was instructed to get a log of the jarrah, one of the turpentine wood, &c., for the purpose of experimenting with to test their resistance to the worm here. (Jan 10, 1872,Daily Southern Cross,3)

turps¶

n. (informal) booze, alcohol [ca1945 Weir House University Hostel (Wellington)] (See on the turps)

Bolger observed grimly that his chief whip's political career was about to end. "You can't blame it on the turps," he added, "Neither of those two drink." (Apr 22, 1995,Listener (New Zealand Listener),18)

I've even given up the turps. (Oct 15, 2003,TV2) [NOTES: Shortland Street]

Not so for a Victoria prez. who managed only one jug before a violent reaction between the turps and his course of antibiotics caused it to abruptly reverse its direction. (Jun 3, 1986,Campus News,14)

McGILL turps any alcohol; on the turps on a drinking bout. NZA. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,116)

Hammer thrower Bronwyn Eagles couldn't wait to hit the turps after winning a silver medal at the City of Manchester Stadium. (Jul 28, 2002,Sunday Star Times,B3)

HUGHES We got stuck into the turps on the Friday night before the wedding and held Morgan's stag night in the bar. (1999,Shooting from the Lip,213)

LACEY I went out there with.. enough turps to start a Reimers Ave rival to Charlie Passmore's.Ibid. 9 I've got more turps inside me than the drip tray at the Pot. (1976,Loosehead Len's Bumper Thump Book,7)

turpsed up¶

adj. (informal) drunk

There is no way that they will want you to drive them if you're turpsed up. (Oct 5, 1998,Dominion,10)

turtle¶

n. a girl or woman (as a sexual object) [ca 1968 Wellington explained as: `put her on her back and she's fucked (useless)']

2 n.

In decreasing order of frequency the other turtles seen in New Zealand are the green, loggerhead, hawksbill and olive ridley - all bony-shelled species that reach around 0.8-1 metres in length when fully grown. (Nov 2002,Forest & Bird,306/14)

turtleback¶

n.

LEITCH Later examples [sc. of birdcage car] built towards the turn of the century featured a round or 'turtleback' roof (elliptical in British parlance) in place of the elevated or clerestory type. (1972,Radio NZ Sporting Annual,198)

turtledove¶

adv. in love

There are many examples of rhyming slang in use at Paparua:.. turtledove for 'in love' (turtledoves are a traditional symbol of fidelity). (Oct 1999,NZWords,2(2) : 2)

turuhuhu¶

n.

Hand specimen, turuhuhu (mingimingi). (1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,1636)

turukio¶

n.

Huts were made from.. a fern called turukio. (Oct 14, 1953,NZ Observer,16)

turutu¶

n. a plant with sedge-like leaves, small flowers and large blue berries. [ORIGIN: Maori, dianella intrmedia; [Maori turutu[u1-macron]]]

An endeavour is made below to place these New Zealand native plants in the relative order of their importance, an arrangement which, in the main, is considered justified .. (11) Dianella intermedia, turutu (Oct 10, 1934,Evening Post,15)

HOOKER Turutu, Lindsay. Dianella intermedia. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

CHEESEMAN D[ianella] intermedia, Endl. ... Turutu. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,715)

tu[u]rutu, a plant (Dianella intermedia), sedge-like blades and very small flowers followed by surprisingly large beautiful blue berries which fall at once if picked. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/160) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

turutu [s] Dianella intermedia Endl. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,81)

MOORE & IRWIN DIANELLA NIGRA. Turutu, blueberry, inkberry, or whistles thrives in lowland scrub, on clay banks, and along bush tracks. ... The reddish leaf-base leaves a yellow scar when broken ...; often it is folded into a tube so that skilful blowing can force air out in an ear-splitting whistle. Shining berries, ranging from palest grey to almost purple, or clean blue and white like old china, ripen in great numbers but they drop at a touch; ... (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,182)

Of native shrubs, I noticed howhi, kowhai, ngutu-kaka, koromiko, and manuka, as well as the pretty turutu (dianella intrmedia) and cocksfoot grass, hawkweed, sowthistle, and wild geranium. (Jul 18, 1895,Wanganui Chronicle,2)

2 n. Lyall. Libertia ixioides.

HOOKER Libertia isioides, Spr. ... Nat. name, `Turutu', Lyall. (1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 252)

HOOKER Turutu, Lyall. Libertia ixioides. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Turutu. Libertia ixioides, Spreng. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/49) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

Libertia ixioides Turutu (1870,TrNZI,2/126) [NOTES: (Armstrong Botany Canterbury)]

TUS¶

abbr. a brand of hand shears

T.U.S.: The brand of hand shears that shearers prefer. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/29) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

tusked weta¶

n.

Among other things, he fed kakapo on Maud Island, spent a fortnight alone on the tuatara sanctuary of Stephens Island, searched for tusked weta on the Alderman Islands, felled pine trees in Abel Tasman National Park, and monitored possum browse in Kahurangi National Park! (Mar 2002,Thin Green Line, The,18)

Scientists from the School of Biological Sciences.. have already investigated the rare tusked giant weta from one of the Mercury islands, used miniature radio transmitters to track giant weta in the wellington region, and discovered a new species in the southern alps. (Nov 3, 1993,NewsVUW (Wellington),2(17):11)

tusker¶

n. a wild pig; a large wild boar [[check OED(S)]]

OVERTON Some dogs become very cunning, and will not approach too near an old "tusker," but will just stand off and bark. (1949,Fifty Years Sheep Farming,99)

SEVERINSEN Got a really big tusker all lined up for Bill here. ... The dogs have had him bailed three times now. (1970,Hunt the Far Mountain,33)

HOLDEN Sometimes a photograph would accompany the piece, showing a serious hunter, his broadly grinning dogs, and an expressionless tusker lying at their feet. (1984,Razorback,11)

Tell Them I've Gone Pig-Hunting.. is a catalogue of shot, stabbed, clubbed tuskers described with blokey energy, plus endearingly purple prose for "Nature's orchestra." (Oct 26, 1996,Listener (New Zealand Listener),49)

1 n. (Rural) [used elsewhere but sp. in NZ pighunting] a wild boar. [bush pig, Irish merino, Captain Cooker DB also cross-refs to scoofler but no entry] (See bush pig,Irish merino,Captain Cooker)

.. from that point to the top of the mountain saddle was famous pig country, and many a good hunt for tuskers and their progeny was held there ... (1910,Tapanui Station,43)

MCLEOD They found a large and angry tusker, and bailing him up with the dogs, they made him angrier still. (1951,NZ High Country,45)

KEENE The boars were treated with great respect. When bailed up in a corner by dogs, a big tusker would attack men, horses and dogs ... (1978,Mimiwhangata Station,60)

NGAWHIKA With three ripped dogs and a 231 pound tusker to get out of a forest that was closed to hunting and heavily patrolled, the fun wasn't over for us yet. (1996,Tell Them I've Gone Pighunting,108)

tussac¶

n. (See tussock)

A new species of grass, called tussac, the blades of which grew seven feet high, had also been discovered, which it was intended to bring over to this country for cultivation. (Dec 6, 1843,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,3)

tussock¶

v. to grub tussock or coarse herbage

PRESTON Four tramps arrived on 4 June and were put to 'tussocking' at 5s an acre. (Jun 1871,Diary,7) [NOTES: moved to tussocking noun]

Few - especially runholders and others having a practical interest in those and similar improvements, and desiring to participate in the same - but must have felt that a great desideratum in Southland was the possession of some means by which the immense benefits above referred to might be rendered possible to be shared in by others without the large outlay hitherto entailed by the necessary expenses of tussocking, ploughing, &c., required previous to sowing the English grass; which expense on a large estate, was quite possible to those possessing the extensive capital which the company in question does, but just as likely to be a serious consideration to private individuals. (Oct 3, 1867,Southland Times,2)

The Chairman presented a petition from Hugh McFetridge and others, Gladfield, requesting that certain roads be tussocked and graded immediately so as to enable them to have a more ready means of ingress and egress. (May 15, 1896,Southland Times,4)

Tenders for tussocking certain streets were opened, when that of Mr J. McBride was accepted. (Nov 8, 1884,Southland Times,3)

Tussocking Three Chain road at 4d per chain, tussocking Copeland's road at 3d per chain, J. R. Cole (Aug 8, 1891,Ashburton Guardian,3)

It was resolved to call tenders for tussocking the South Road, and a new race crossing on Gardiner's Road was ordered to be better graded and the boulders taken off. (Oct 4, 1912,Ashburton Guardian,7)

MURRAY [The intending farmer] will do well to `tussac' a few acres; - that is chip off with an adze the flax and coarse grass growing on the land. (1866,Description Province Southland,28)

280 chains of road had been metalled at a cost of GBP238 16s 7d, and 1420 chains had been tussocked at a cost of GBP101 19s 8d. (May 6, 1905,Ashburton Guardian,3)

It was also resolved that Mr Watson be authorised to have a length of Christie's Road tussocked. (Oct 8, 1917,Ashburton Guardian,3)

The clerk then read the correspondence, among which was a letter from Mr Joseph Hatch, in reference to the necessity of the Corporation tussocking block 17, as the long rank grass was apt to get ignited by sparks from the railway engine; and while there was a probability of the grass taking fire the houses in the locality could not be considered safe. (Jan 16, 1874,Southland Times,2)

adj. tussock-covered

TOMLINSON The lambs stopped about halfway down the spur on a big tussock face, ... (1968,Remembered Trails,40)

n. (collective) grassland of native tussock grasses. frequent early spg also tussac; also tussuck [also nassella tussock, snowgrass includes 'the tussock', off the tussock,and 'in the tussock'; G.J.Griffiths notes: originally it meant a tuft',bunch', hillock' and only later came in NZ to be transferred to the kind of vegetation that grows in that fashion; here shown Tuckett did not havetussock' to use] (See also nassella tussock,snowgrass)

Les White was a champion leg-puller of us children running wild and free in the tussock. (Dec 27, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),6)

Fat lambs made 11s 3d to 11s 11d, others 9s to 10s 9d, do off the tussock 7s 4d to 8s 6d (Mar 2, 1900,Star, The,1)

.. 29s 3d for fat wethers off the tussock (Mar 14, 1916,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,5)

No doubt plenty will be heard, at the inevitable inquiry, about mountaineering control, guiding qualifications, party discipline, food, clothes, protected matches, and the wisdom or otherwise of sticking to the tussock instead of diving deep into the jungle; but these things may stand over. (Sep 4, 1931,Evening Post,6)

(Jun 1844,Nelson Examiner) [NOTES: 1844 Jul Tuckett in Nelson Examiner in Hocken Contributions 234 (Griffiths Collection)]

The presence of either of these `tussocks' [Danthonia flavescens, D. crassiuscula] is evidence of relative dryness. (1915,TrNZI,47/127)

Michael King [Samuel Butler] would be remembered for, among other things, playing Bach in his sod hut homestead among the tussock and the sheep. (2003,Penguin History of New Zealand,173)

On Tuesday afternoon, says the Ashburton Mail, what appeared to be smoke was noted apparently rising from the tussock near Springburn. (Aug 4, 1899,Marlborough Express,4)

The natural grasses are always found to grow in bunches known by the name of tussocks and these tussocks vary in colour and dimensions with the quality of the soil and the nature of climate. (1856,Report) [NOTES: c1856 J.T. Thomson Report quoted in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 19]

BUTLER We kept one [horse] on the tether - tethered to a tussock of grass by a peculiar kind of New Zealand knot - and let the others loose; ... (Jun 1860,Forest Creek MS,48)

BUTLER How shall I describe everything - the little townlet, ... the scattered wooden boxes of houses, with ragged roods of scrubby ground between them - tussocks of brown grass - the huge wide-leaved flax ... the healthy clear-complexioned men, shaggy-bearded, rowdy-hatted, and independent ... - the stores, supplying all heterogeneous commodities - Ibid. 29 It is volcanic, brown, and dry; ... and then a stiff, wiry, uncompromising-looking tussock of the very hardest grass; then perhaps a flax bush, or, as we should have said, a flax plant; ... (Jan 27, 1860,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,3/28)

BARKER Some of the houses are built of `cob,' especially those erected in the very early days, when sawn timber was rare and valuable: this material is simply wet clay [50] with chopped tussocks stamped in. (1866,Station Life in NZ,49)

The plains are covered with grasses, the roots of which are gathered into tufts or tussocks, intermixed with the Bayonet grass or `Wild Spaniard' (Aciphylla Colensoi), Toumatakuru (Discaria Toumatou), and a great variety of the New Zealand brooms (Carmichaelia), ... (1869,TrNZI,1/iii/5) [NOTES: (Hector)]

PYKE The American ... pulled out a lump of unmistakeable `honey dew', transferred a goodly-sized plug to his left cheek, chewed away at it ..., aimed a well-directed shot at an unoffending tussac ... (1873,Wild Will Enderby,1/i/9,(1889,1974) ed.)

HART Armed with tussocks, having a fairly good quantity of earth attached, the ... warriors [sc. boys] would open fire on the enemy. (1886,Stray Leaves,31)

HISLOP Some of the lads made their bricks in what they called a pug ring, formed by driving the horses round in a circle as with the old-time chaffcutter, but Cecil made his on what they called a straight. A strip of ground about 30 yards long by four or five wide was scooped free of top soil, which was dumped on the garden nearby. It was then ploughed about ten inches deep, or according to the number of bricks required, and very well watered, which was usually done with a shovel from a tank on a sledge for even distribution, and left to soak all night. A good layer of chopped-up tussocks was then evenly spread over the top. After more watering a six-horse team was driven up and down the strip until the pug was well mixed. (1943,Pure Gold,116) [NOTES: [c1910, Otago]]

BEATTIE There were no bridges and no proper roads but there were sheep tracks through the tussocks. (1947,Pioneer Recollections,18,1956 ed.) [NOTES: [pl = tussock bush]]

BLAKISTON .. , I went off for some distance and sat with my dogs in the tussocks, where the sheep could not see me. (1952,My Yesteryears,28) [NOTES: [f. c1869] [pl use] .]

MASTERS They each get behind a tussock and hang on by their teeth, and when the storm gets going good and proper they gradually get swept away until that's all that's left of them. (1959,Tales of the Mails,69) [NOTES: [pre-1900]]

Sheep grazed among the tussocks. (1962,Landfall Country,164) [NOTES: Courage `An Evening for a Fish']

Stiffer soils.. such as those which produce the large coarse tussock popularly called snow grass, are not good producers of the clovers. (Oct 30, 1890,Otago Witness,17)

Surounded by jaw-dropping vistas of tawny tussock, glowing tarns and cloud-wreathed peaks, he gets down on his knees to examine a myriad of plants no bigger than a fingernail. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/92)

n. Astelia banksii (aka fragrans); tree tussock

DAWSON Neomyrtus pedunculata may be prominent in the subcanopy and large tussocks of Astelia fragrans may be abundant on the forest floor. (1988,Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks,120)

2 n. any grass which grows in clumps (`tussocks') rather than as a mat, esp. Poa and Arundo spp., and esp. in the high country [pl. often tussocks]

Tussock.- Up-country people only recognise the small blue t. (Poa colensoi) and the common yellow, usually called white t. (Poa caespitosa ) but sometimes brown . and sometimes yellow or silver. On the other hand, some men call the blue one silver (rare). White t. includes at least two varieties, a poa and a fescue (Festuca [novae-zealandiae]). The poa is a sign of good country and the fescue is not; but five shepherds out of six can't tell them part. The dreariness of the brown tussock plains seems to have been the first thing that struck every newcomer to Canterbury. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) `In the country far distant from town, my boy,/ All desolate, drear and alone,/ Some people exist among tussocks and sheep;/ And Brittan looks after his own.' --C.RH., p. 4(2) (Dec 30, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

MURRAY Short and succulent grass is found to be growing in greater or less profusion between the tufts of coarser and more conspicuous `tussac'. (1866,Description Province Southland,8)

BARKER (1869,Station Life in NZ,1874)

PYKE ... tussac' orsnow grass' ... (1873,Wild Will Enderby,1)

PERRY The hoggets should be wintered ... - if they can be fed on turnips ... so much the better. If they are turniped, then the shepherd must watch them carefully when they are once more put back on the tussocks, for they will usually fret for a time, ... (1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,93)

LEVY Tussock - Tufted, harsh grasses that characterise the montane belt. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,363,1970 ed.)

tussock A clump of grass. A grass that grows in clumps in many of the drier parts of New Zealand, especially in the South Island. The parts where it grows are called tussock country. (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),426)

MARTIN The tussocks referred to are the SNOW TUSSOCK. Danthonia flavescens the RED TUSSOCK (D rigida), and in smaller amount (D.cunninhamii); and the low tussocks' are chiefly the SILVER TUSSOCK (<i>Poa caespitosa</i>) and the FESCUE TUSSOCK (<i>Festuca novae-zelandiae</i>) or more rarely Poa colensoi, the BLUE TUSSOCK. The nametussock' is applied to those tufted grasses which hold water in the decaying leaves at the base. Tall tussock is dominant in subalpine regions and low tussock in montane and lowland country, though in Southland the red tussock reaches sea level and dominates much of the landscape. (1961,Flora NZ,129)

TURNER The term tussock grass has been formed from the English word tussock a clump' (of grass) for a kind of grass which grew in clumps. The name ... was soon shortened to <i>tussock</i>, not merely a reversal of the initial process, since it is quite possible to talk ofa clump of tussock' in New Zealand. (1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,52)

McLINTOCK Tussock .. .. wi .. .. Poa caespitosa (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

3 n. the `sward' of tussock(s) which can be eaten, as ??distinct from b. the general TUSSOCK-GRASSLAND, the geographical phenomenon itself [?? can this distinction be carried by the evidence??]

HOCKEN [tussac] The town sadly need improvement too; ... swamp and tussac demanded cat-like agility in traversing many a street. (1898,Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand,160)

Poa caespitosa (1909,AJHR,C-11) [NOTES: Botanical Examination of the Higher Waimarino District]

STUDHOLME The land towards the hills was covered with tussock and scrub - white tussock chiefly, but with some blue. (1940,Te Waimate,84)

tussock n. native grass which once covered much open country in N.Z.; hence v. tussock tether, tie horse to a clump of tussock and tussocker n. tramp or sundowner. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),21)

MARK & ADAMS Some of the smaller tussock (Poa colensoi), alpine fescue tussock (Festuca matthewsii) and bristle tussock (Notodanthonia asetifolia), have become aggressive in this way. Bristle tussock now now dominates in parts of Marlborough and North Canterbury while the other two are more important in inland areas of South Canterbury and Otago. (1973,NZ Alpine Plants,22)

tussock basin¶

1 n. (Rural) a high-altitude depression, where stock graze tussock.

FARMER The three of us carried on and camped that night in a beautiful tussock basin right back in the headwaters. (1994,Best Job Ever, The,223)

tussock bench¶

1 n. (Rural) a high mountain or hill terrace, covered in tussock.

AXBEY It was a fairly typical head basin, with a small lake and tussock benches dropping away to secondary growth ... (1991,Along the Track: a collection of NZ hunting yarns,43)

tussock block¶

n. a large tussock grazing area of a high country station.

Some runholders maintain that, providing a tussock block sunny and free from snow is available, it is better to send to the plains two-tooths and older ewes, which have a better resistance to parasites, and keep the hoggets on the sunny blocks of the run. (Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,103)

HALL Wethers at Glencoe station being driven back to their tussock blocks after shearing. (1987,Shepherd's Year, A,24)

tussock burn¶

1 n. (Rural) an annual burning of coarse tussock to allow for fresh growth.

Even the stack fires or the tussock or scrub burns which must have consumed millions of night flying beetles and moths had become unfashionable ... (Oct 15, 1962,NZ Journal of Agriculture,294)

tussock bush¶

n.

MASTERS As they were going up the Blowhard, Chum noticed sheep skulls, with very few other bones nearby, behind almost every tussock bush. (1959,Tales of the Mails,69) [NOTES: [pre-1900]]

tussock country¶

n. (Rural) land where tufted tussock grasses grow [principally in S.I. high country].

On poor tussock country..the use of danthonia invariably increases the carrying-capacity. (Mar 20, 1918,NZ Journal of Agriculture,135)

The maintenance or improvement of Otago's large area of unploughable tussock country has for many years been the subject of much consideration and endeavour by farmers and others interested. (Sep 16, 1940,NZ Journal of Agriculture,183)

WHEELER The station consists basically of tussock country sweeping down from the crest of the Garvie mountains. (1971,Historic Sheep Stations SI II,16)

ROBERTS & TURNER .. it was difficulty enough by daylight covering this tussock country ... (1983,NZ High Country Four Seasons,26)

RICHARDS George Stuart had added another large station Mangaohone to his contract sheds, and as it adjoined Otupae he now had three sheds in the high rugged tussock country. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,51)

The original sheep, landed prior to the arrival of the Maria, and before any attempt had been made to improve the country, suffered severely, the low "tussock" country of Southland affording but scant natural feed for sheep, more especially for those newly imported of a long-woolled breed, and unacclimatised. (Aug 31, 1867,Hawke's Bay Herald,2)

Throughout these districts the increase of lambs this year will be considerably below the average. .. This unfortunate state of affairs arises from two causes. The first is due to the wholesale system carried on of burning the tussock country. (Dec 10, 1874,Clutha Leader,5)

The above comprises a first-class block of tussock country, well surface sown; fences all in good repair and water in every block. (Nov 23, 1945,Ellesmere Guardian,1)

Widely dispersed throughout the tussock country recently visited by the author were small patches of ground ... upon which no tussocks were growing. (1941,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,22/22A)

Owen Marshall 'This was originally all tussock country, some of it up to the knees of men on horseback.' (2007,Drybread,265)

MASTERS Beneath me, stretching back into the legend haunted ranges of the Urewera country, was a tussock clothed valley with patches of scrub and bush dotted along the silvery stream that wended its way through it. (1960,Back-Country Tales,185)

We turned down past a swampy flat surrounded by dreary, monotonous, barren tussock country. (Jan 22, 1924,Otago Witness,69)

Tussock country. Agricultural and pastoral land. (Mar 11, 1899,Mataura Ensign,4)

It is an interesting and creditable publication, and that it meets a want is shown by the letters written by farmers who ask for advice upon such subjects as the burning of tussock country, how to treat and combat the grass grub, and also by the correspondence written by farmers concerning their experiments in growing various grasses for stock food. (Sep 15, 1910,Ashburton Guardian,4)

tussock field¶

n.

Below Ivory Lake Hut, after weaving through some bluffs, I reach the tussock fields of the Waitaha, a remote West Coast valley. (Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/36)

tussock grass¶

n.

A conspicuous feature of the New Zealand landscape from summer to autumn, the flowers and seed heads of native tussock grasses wave like creamy-white pennants in the breeze. (Aug 27, 1999,Dominion,14)

TUWHARE standing sentinel to your bleak / loneliness the tussock grass (1977,No Ordinary Sun,23)

Tussock grasses belong to three groups; [39] the tall snow tussocks (Chionochloa) and the short tussocks (Festuca and Poa). (May 2003,Forest & Bird,No. 308/38)

Tussock grasses are a taonga to Ngai Tahu and in the past had many uses apart from material for leggings. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/40)

The island is clothed with a dense green mantle of vegetation formed of high tussock grass and the Kerguelen cabbage. (Jul 12, 1924,Hawera & Normanby Star,15)

They also used the ashes of burnt `tussac' grass, and a lotion prepared by boiling the leaves of the plant kopakopa (Plantago major), or from the bruised leaves of the kopata (Pelargonium australe). (1905,TrNZI,37/67)

Poa anceps, Forst. - This is the common tussock-grass of the Plains and Port Hills. (1872,TrNZI,4/303) [NOTES: (Report on Grasses)]

Tussock grasses - of which New Zealand has some two dozen species - are the dominant vegetation in the first hundred metres above the treeline, often forming great sweeping fields a metre or more deep in rustling strands. (Sep 2001,NZ Geographic,No. 53/39)

I find that tussock grass almost covers the face of the country. (Sep 25, 1890,Otago Witness,34)

A very remarkable circumstance occurred in connection with a piece of ground on Mr Tuckey's property covered by the natural tussock grass. (May 30, 1883,Tuapeka Times,3)

EXPORTS. Per S.S. Stormbird - 12 packages, A.E. Kitchen: 1 ton tussock grass, U.S.S. Company ... (Aug 10, 1891,Wanganui Herald,2)

One remarkable thing about Macquarrie [sic] Island, at which the Discovery called on her voyage to New Zealand, was the fact that it was covered with a thick mantle of tussock grass, standing from five to six feet high in places. (Dec 4, 1901,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

adj.

Below, a close-up of a young bull sea elephant enjoying the luxury of a soft tussock grass bed on the same island. (Jun 2, 1930,Evening Post,7)

tussock grassland¶

n.

Most of New Zealand's tussock grasslands are found in the South Island high country. (May 2003,Forest & Bird,No. 308/ 39)

All the tussock grasslands that you now see below the tree-line are fire affected... (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/32)

The tussock grassland is a study almost entirely apart from the ordinary sown grasslands of New Zealand. (Jun 15, 1927,Evening Post,19)

Secondly, it is intended to produce artificially the various types of primitive vegetation in New Zealand, such as kauri forest, southern beech forest, tall and low tussock grassland, and subalpine scrubs of different kinds. (Mar 10, 1932,Evening Post,10)

234 So let the steppes remain in U.S.S.R., the pusstas in Hungary, the veld in South Africa, the prairies in North America, the pampas in South America. Let New Zealand stick to its tussock grassland, colloquially known as `the tussock'. (1946,NZ Alpine Plants,1945 ed.) [NOTES: (Allan)]

The high-country tussock grassland of Marlborough has ben occupied for pastoral purposes for almost 100 years. (Oct 16, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,293)

LEVY The tussock grasslands, originally some 14,000,000 acres, mainly in the South Island, have pioneered the clothing of new country, and older country too dry for forest. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,95,1970 ed.)

McLINTOCK Tussock (bunch grass) grasslands, generally with species of Poa and Festuca dominant. (1959,Descriptive Atlas,24)

The quickest and best method, moreover, had been arrived at of converting the native tussock grass land into permanent artificial pasture, carrying three times as many stock as the tussock carried before; and also of securing a rotation of crops. (Jan 29, 1890,Timaru Herald,4)

tussock grubber¶

1 n. (Rural) a person employed to dig out noxious nassella tussock [S.I.]

8 I worked for the North Canterbury Nassella Tussock Board in Cheviot as a tussock grubber in the late 1970s ... (Mar 2002,NZ Wilderness,08)

tussock grubbing¶

n. the removal by digging of tussock

The Clerk was instructed to have some repairs done to roads at Dromore, and to pay a small amount for tussock grubbing on a street in the Dronmore township. (Dec 23, 1910,Ashburton Guardian,4)

tussock gully¶

1 n. (Rural) a narrow high-altitude valley with sides of tussock cover.

FARMER The red letter morning found us walking up a tussock gully 16 kilometres out of Rotorua towards Taupo. (1994,Best Job Ever, The,18)

tussock gut¶

1 n. (Rural) a narrow tussock-lined chute, common in S.I. high country.

AXBEY .. they carried on up the valley, staying concealed in the bush edge, until suddenly in a tussock gut, they almost stumbled on two roa ... (1991,Along the Road,144)

tussock hogget¶

1 n. (Rural) a young sheep grazed on tussock blocks with little attention.

The tussock hogget is healthy and apparently not infected with parasites to any extent. (Feb 20, 1937,NZ Journal of Agriculture,103)

tussock jumper¶

n.

McGILL tussock jumper station hand. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,116)

1 n. (Rural) a musterer.

THOMSON Well, what good is it [religion] to the hard-boiled rock hopper or tussock jumper? (1964,Deer Shooting Days,85)

Even the hardiest, most-seasoned tussock-jumper is reduced to 'tenderfoot' status by the end of the day. (Apr 28, 1966,NZ Farmer,37)

STACEY tussock jumper: a term usually referring to a musterer on the eastern uplands of the South Island where silver tussock grows ... (1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,164)

tussock jumper: Musterer. (1989,NZ English Newsletter,3/29) [NOTES: (Wallace Shearing Glossary)]

tussock knot¶

n.

BUTLER We kept one [horse] on the tether - tethered to a tussock of grass by a peculiar kind of New Zealand knot - and let the others loose; ... (1860,Forest Creek MS,48,1960 ed.)

<iTussock knot.-The knot by which the leaves of a t. are doubled over so that it will hold a tether rope or dogchain safely. (Jan 27, 1934,Press, The,15)

BAKER ...just as have tussock tether or tie, to tie a horse to a clump of tussock in such country, and tussock knot, the method of tying to prevent the horse breaking away. (1941,NZ Slang,41)

tussock lamb¶

n.

Lister's lambs were about as good a quality of tussock lambs as he had seen. (Sep 9, 1924,Otago Witness,15)

tussock land¶

n.

1 n. (Rural) [high country] pastoral country on which native tussock grows. [tussock-land, tussockland]

ROSS .. that saw the lordly squatter once king of tussock land. (1889,BLANK ENTRY,64) [NOTES: in Woodhouse (1950) NZ Farm & Station Verse]

FERRIS .. with the deterioration of the tussock land especially, the Merino has proved his thriftiness. (1940,Cavalcade of Farming 1840-1940,49)

The successful management of a sheep run calls for .. an appreciation of the carrying capacity of tussock land to 'do' sheep well without either overstocking or understocking. (Oct 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,347)

RICKARD In any study of farming in early New Zealand the men who operated the big sheep runs of the tussock lands must occupy a prominent .. place. (1967,Strangers in the Wilderness,52)

KERR .. some of its own aims are well-planted breaks to assist pasture growth, to prevent wind erosion on tussock land, and to hold gullies against soil erosion. [tussockland] (1976,From the Beginning: chronicles of a county,321)

Year by year, as I go my rounds along dusty roads and over bare brown plains, I see the face of nature changing more and more ; pleasant homesteads dotted here and there, and trees and fences shutting out the view, and well-tilled fields, and well-stocked pastures, and the busy hum of industry arises from places that but yesterday were silent as the grave, and the merry laughter of little children as they wend their way to school and the shout of the ploughman as he labours in the newly-broken tussock land or builds his modest dwelling on the soil that is his own at last. (Oct 31, 1870,Star, The,3)

Run. No. 1. 1325 acres 21 years lease at a yearly rental of GBP130 Miss Eliza Thompsom [sic] only one of the runs was applied for and that by the members of one family who must have thought there was something to be made out of hill-side tussock land at 2/4 acre rent. (Dec 7, 1895,Oxford Observer,3)

BATEMAN The tussock land abounds in the Middle Island, although the richest land was originally what are termed `flax swamps'. (1881,Colonist, The,186)

VINCENT It was wonderful in this bleak, hilly country, generally called `tussock land', to see what changes of colour ... there were. (1885,40,000 Miles,217)

Professor Worley also makes a great outcry as to the huts facing due north, which, he contends, will give only a view of the tussock land, and not of the mountain. (Feb 7, 1928,Evening Post,10)

A Romance of New Zealand and the Commonwealth. By Arthur H. Adams. (Mar 21, 1936,Evening Post,28)

There were thousands of hares in the tussock lands of the South Island, said Mr. Parry, and they took a heavy toll of pastures, crops, and the bark of fruit and other trees. (Aug 7, 1945,Evening Post,6)

RICKARD In any study of farming in early New Zealand the men who operated the big sheep runs of the tussock lands must occupy a prominent - perhaps too prominent - place. (1967,Strangers in the Wilderness,52)

WHEELER George drove us up into the foothills, which open out into unexpectedly wide rolling tussocklands, with good stands of native bush in the gullies. (1982,Historic Sheep Stations of NZ,5)

STUDHOLME There was no bush on this wide expanse of tussockland. (1985,Coldstream,xi)

A farmer who grew a fine crop of wheat on the new tussock land at Otiake, and who had already disposed of 2000 sacks at a satisfactory price, was offered and declined 3s 5d (f.o.b.) for the remaining 1000 sacks. (Nov 1, 1905,Otago Witness,36)

Investigation of tussock land, South Island GBP500. (Nov 19, 1918,Grey River Argus,3)

tussock line¶

n. (See cf. grassline)

... after a few hundred steep feet of the Dorset Ridge had been covered, an indifferent blaze was picked up which led through bush and scrub to the tussock line at the end of Dorset Ridge, ... (Sep 1958,Tararua,69)

1 n. (Rural) the level or altitude at which most tussock will grow in place of other vegetation.

LOUGHNAN vegetable sheep: native plants Raoulia eximia or R mamillaris, which will grow in a dense mass from about 300 metres below the tussock line up to 1000-1200 metres above that. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,88)

PICKERING .. the manuka takes over the ranges up to the tussock line. (1988,Hills, The,21)

tussock madness¶

1 n. (Rural) abnormal behaviour [said to be induced by loneliness.]

RICHARDS Like me, he had the tussock madness. (1989,Pioneer's Life, A,74)

tussock paddock¶

1 n. (Rural) a large grazing area containing tussock grasses.

.. enormous boulders to be climbed, and tussock paddocks riddled with rabbit-holes ... (1894,In the Land of the Tui,284)

Each night they were driven off to a second tussock-paddock of 300 acres with no clovers or grass undergrowth. (May 20, 1930,NZ Journal of Agriculture,299)

tussock park¶

1 n. (Rural) a high country conservation area growing tussock grasses and other plants.

Tussock park opened. The 22,000-hectare (55,000-acre) park covers the Big Ben and Torlesse ranges and has a range of flora and fauna, including tussocks, beech forests and unusual plants adapted to unstable screes and rock ridges, such as the vegetable sheep and South Island edelweiss. (Nov 2, 2001,Dominion,2)

tussock run¶

1 n. (Rural) a high country grazing property.

Wanted to buy: tussock runs. (Aug 10, 1972,NZ Farmer,128)

tussock station¶

1 n. (Rural) a high country pastoral property growing native tussock.

BARDSLEY Molly worked as shepherd, drover and harvester on the tussock station running 10,000 half-Merino sheep. (2000,Land Girls, The,159)

tussock tether/tussock tie¶

v.

BAKER ...just as have tussock tether or tie, to tie a horse to a clump of tussock in such country, and tussock knot, the method of tying to prevent the horse breaking away. (1941,NZ Slang,41)

tussock track¶

n.

BLAKISTON John Grigg told me that on one trip he and Meikle saw a peculiar object, not far from the tussock track between Ashburton and Rakaia. (1952,My Yesteryears,14) [NOTES: [f. c1869]]

tussock unit¶

1 n. (Rural) a high country pastoral property.

For Sale: North Canterbury cattle and sheep tussock unit.. (Aug 10, 1972,NZ Farmer,128)

tussock-burner¶

n.

If the original tussock-burners could revisit this area they would be terribly shocked to see the change. (Oct 7, 1924,Otago Witness,31)

tussock-clad¶

adj.

1 adj. (Rural) [of land] clothed with tussock. [tussock clad]

LOUGHNAN [shute] A narrow, newly eroded and steep-sided gut cutting through the tussock-clad hillside. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,72)

GORDON In mid-afternoon sun, the detail on the tussock-clad hills is lost - it's just a warm blur of tan and gold, sheep and dog country (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,222)

It is about 30 years ago since the present member for Wakanui first set foot upon the shores of New Zealand, but it was not on the yellow level tussock-clad plain where he has since made his home. (Jul 28, 1884,Star, The,2)

What a contrast it is to turn from the tussock-clad, weed-producing vacant sections of the Government to the Lower Wairuna settlement. (Jan 28, 1903,Otago Witness,31)

A number of the "Pilgrims" are said to have wept when, from the top of the Port Hills, they caught their first sight of the dreary tussock-clad country; but they and their descendants have since had ample cause for rejoicing. (Dec 16, 1911,Ashburton Guardian,6)

Sixty years ago and more, study Methodist pioneers wended their way across the swamp or tussock-clad plains in search of land on which to settle and make homes for themselves and their families. (Aug 6, 1929,Ellesmere Guardian,3)

The usual mist was encountered along the tops, but frequently it lifted temporarily and the sun shone through to disclose beautiful vistas of bush and tussock-clad valleys looking charming in lovely shades of green and brown, and occasional glimpses of the more distant plains of the Manawatu and the Wairarapa. (Oct 26, 1934,Evening Post,15)

Charadrius bicinctus, Jard. and Selb. Dottrel [sc]. - One of the earlier breeders, whether on the tussock-clad plains or on river-bed spits and flats; ... (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,62) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

LAING & BLACKWELL The edges of streams on the tussock-clad plains are often fringed with flax and bulrush, whilst, in the water itself, stand numbers of blackened stumps about two feet high, bearing on their summits drooping brushes of long, coarse, green, or tawny threads. These are termed by the colonists, nigger-heads. (1940,Plants of NZ,5) [NOTES: [check 1907]]

LEVY The original tussock-clad country of the lower levels in the South Island has either been turned under by the plough or so burnt and grazed by sheep and rabbits as to be changed almost beyond recognition. (1951,Grasslands of NZ,272,1970 ed.)

The hills now began to get further apart, and the valley to open out; paradise ducks were to be seen and heard, cattle began to show themselves in the river-beds and upon the tussock clad terraces. (Apr 16, 1892,Oxford Observer,3)

tussock-clothed¶

adj.

MASTERS Beneath me, stretching back into the legend haunted ranges of the Urewera country, was a tussock clothed valley with patches of scrub and bush dotted along the silvery stream that wended its way through it. (1960,Back-Country Tales,185)

tussock-covered¶

adj. [tussock covered]

We were not more than a score of people all told, and we lived in an out-of-the-way, half-forgotten little gully walled in by steep tussock-covered spurs, with the creek from which the township took its name running through, and the Mataura river flowing past the opening. (Jul 15, 1882,Wanganui Herald,1)

Mr. Friedlander has seen tussock-covered areas replaced by the present well-equipped borough, and he would find it difficult, were he to take stock of the borough's assets, to note one worth mentioning which he did not assist to secure for the public welfare. (Nov 15, 1919,Ashburton Guardian,4)

By the passing away, at the age of 72 years, of Mr James Cochrane, Riverside, one more link has been removed from the chain of worthy pioneers who settled in the Ashburton district and converted the land from its rough native tussock-covered condition into some of the best wheat and other grain-growing land in the Southern Hemisphere. (May 10, 1921,Ashburton Guardian,4)

The camp site is at the mouth of a long narrow valley where it debouches from between low hills on to a vast expanse of rolling tussock-covered country. (Aug 17, 1940,Evening Post,20)

THOMPSON Sendin' all the sheep a-pantin' to the shady-sided slopes/ Of the tussock-covered foothills, ... (1909,Ballads about Business,46)

(2) The typical, originally tussock-covered plains land, the soils of which vary from light and stony, as at Burnham, to heavy silts as at Ashburton; ... (1936,Agricultural Organization in NZ,77)

TOMLINSON Long tussock-covered spurs about a mile long, reached to the top on both sides. (1968,Remembered Trails,40)

When the Lark is flushed from her nest on the wide expanse of the tussock-covered plains, ... what rare instinct ... enables her to find her nest ... (1870,TrNZI,2/45) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

... I well remember the extraordinary clouds of moths of all kinds which rose from the ground as one walked either through the tussock-covered areas or through fields of cultivated grass. (1903,TrNZI,35/8)

Most of the good land on Waikakahi was cropped, and the then owner of the station, Hon John McLean, must have made a stack of money out of letting the tussock covered sheep walk. (May 31, 1899,Hawera & Normanby Star,4)

tussock-dwelling¶

adj.

As we returned across the plateau to our camp we disturbed some tussock-dwelling birds, probably pipits. (Sep 1958,Tararua,13)

tussock-former¶

1 n. (Rural) a plant that provides a basis from which tussock can seed and grow.

Such species in the main are cocksfoot and crested dogstail, both of which are more or less tussock-formers. (Sep 20, 1916,NZ Journal of Agriculture,200)

tussock-jumping¶

n. (Rural) mustering.

LOUGHNAN tussock-jumping: mustering. Like the phrase chasing mutton, this is used in a general rather than a particular sense. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,87)

tussock-spine¶

n.

BARKER ... the frost sparkled on every broad flax-blade or slender tussock-spine. (1873,Station Amusements in NZ,68)

tussock-swamp¶

n.

LINDSAY Hence, next to bush and swamp-land proper (on alluvial clays), Flax-land is regarded as the most desirable for agricultural purposes. Flax-swamps' are frequently as common asTussock-swamps,' though their soil is far from being so wet or watery. Like the Tussock-swamps,' they are frequently verytussocky' - causing walking thereon to be extremely ... fatiguing. (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,80)

tussock-tether¶

1 v. (Rural) [high country mustering] to tether one's horse to a tussock clump.

WALKER We'll ride to the end of that spur, 'tussock-tether' our horses on the plain and walk up till we get to the good pig gullies. (1902,Zealandia's Guerdon,30)

BAKER ...just as have tussock tether or tie, to tie a horse to a clump of tussock in such country, and tussock knot, the method of tying to prevent the horse breaking away. (1941,NZ Slang,41)

tussock n. native grass which once covered much open country in N.Z.; hence v. tussock tether, tie horse to a clump of tussock and tussocker n. tramp or sundowner. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),21)

tussockdom¶

1 n. (Rural) large pastoral tracts of native grassland.

HOBHOUSE He is now a shepherd king with no moderate slice of tussockdom under his charge. (Nov 1860,Hobhouse Letters and Papers)

KENNINGTON .. the lords of the tussockdom. (1978,Awatere: a district and its people,40)

tussocked¶

1 adj. (Rural) [of high country] covered with predominantly native tussock.

BETHELL Bronze tussocked terraces before precipitous Great purple alps ... (1936,Time and Place : poems,27)

The zig-zag hunt is on a magnificent tussocked face that you just keep looking up and up and up. (Jul 15, 1986,NZ Journal of Agriculture,60)

GORDON .. early enthusiasts found the flat-bottomed gullies, steep slopes and tussocked faces necessary to test man, dog, and quite often, the sheep. (1998,Three Sheep and a Dog,28)

LEE There was a tussocked hill I examined every morning about sunrise. (1934,Children of the Poor,173,1949 ed.)

Old Himi had a great deal to tell, gesticulating and pointing vehemently at times across the bay, where a tall wooded peak shot a dark blue silhouette upward against the sky, contrasting strongly with the yellow tone of the tussocked hills in the foreground. (Feb 9, 1889,Observer (Auckland),7)

He has ceased to haunt the backblocks, o'er the tussocked hills to roan [sic], / And life's sunset finds him camping in the Old Men's Home. (Nov 8, 1916,Ashburton Guardian,6)

On Tuesday, July 17, near the crude shack which for the past thirty years had been his home in the bleak desolation of tussocked hill-side and rugged creek-bed, he was brutally done to death by gunshot. (Sep 13, 1928,NZ Truth,8)

The tussocked plain and virgin bush are a thing of the past. (Feb 8, 1896,Southland Times,3)

The private line trends away from Milton through grren pastures, and, opening up tussocked slopes, winds its way between them to the Tokomariro River, just beyond which lies the township (as yet in embryo) of Waronui. (Sep 30, 1908,Otago Witness,12)

tussocker¶

n. a sundowner

PYKE Now, a sundowner', ortussocker', for the terms are synonymous - is a pastoral loafer; one who loiters about till dusk, and then makes for the nearest station or hut, to beg for shelter and food. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,3(10)105)

MORRIS Tussocker, n.a New Zealand name for a Sundowner (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,485)

PYKE Now, asun-downer, or 'tussocker' for the terms are synonymous - is a pastoral loafer; one who loiters about till dusk, and then makes for the nearest station or hut, to beg for shelter and food.' (1889,Wild Will Enderby)

BAKER Tussocker is a New Zealand equivalent for the Australian sundowner mentioned above. (1941,NZ Slang,41)

SOLJAK New Zealanders have coined or adapted many expressions to meet local requirements, as illustrated by the following: ... tussocker: hobo (1946,New Zealand (various authors/titles),118)

tussocker n.New Zealand a sundowner (q.v.). (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

tussock n. native grass which once covered much open country in N.Z.; hence v. tussock tether, tie horse to a clump of tussock and tussocker n. tramp or sundowner. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),21)

McGILL tussocker shearer or casual labourer arriving at dusk to avoid work but not the tucker; from his tussock grass hide; `sundowner' in Australia. (1988,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,116)

There is one thing, however, that I am not quite pleased with - that is, that the Building Committee should have been entirely chosen from among the big wigs of the district, as I should have liked to see them joined by a few of my own class - that is, tussockers, ditchers, or other decent and respectable farm labourers. (Jul 28, 1869,Bruce Herald,5)

tussocking¶

n.

If he were to stick to his trade, tussocking, he would be doing more good to people generally and himself in particular than writing such stuff. (Apr 5, 1871,Bruce Herald,7)

Contract 110. - Formation &c., near Mr McCloskie's, and Tussocking Craig's Road. (Oct 4, 1887,Mataura Ensign,5)

PRESTON Four tramps arrived on 4 june and were put to 'tussocking' at 5s an acre. (Jun 1871,Diary,7)

WATT (caption) Early view of the south portion of the town ... The tussocks are noticeable. Their removal from street lines and sections provided work for contractors, who charged so much an acre for what was known as tussocking. Ibid. 64 ... among them tussacing' - the removal of tussocks from streets and town reserves. It was some time before the town clerk came round to the spelling,tussock' ... On February 26, 1874, the council called tenders for tussocking (so spelt) the remainder of the untussocked streets south of the Puni.--> (1971,Centenary of Invercargill,8f)

adj.

Other tussocking works were left in the hands of the Clerk to let. (Oct 7, 1905,Ashburton Guardian,4)

.. I have been daily, weather and personal inclination (drouthiness?) permitting, prosecuting my ditching and tussocking contract, so far as necessary to keep hunger and thirst from the door of my rough out-of-the-world sod hut. (Jun 2, 1869,Bruce Herald,6)

tussocky¶

n. a swagger

European swaggers were sometimes known as "tussockies" because of their habit of tying the leaves of two tussocks together to form a simple shelter to sleep beneath. (Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/40)

adj.

1 adj. (Rural) [of land, country, pasture, property etc] clothed with native tussocks. [includes sense of being tussock-like]

COURAGE The greenish-brown tussocky hills all dewy and glistening in a glow of sunlight. (1896,Lights and Shadows of Colonial Life,13)

WRIGHT Over the tussocky flat and down (1898,Station Ballads,14)

Tapanui Station as a tussocky run went by the board and Brooksdale Estate came into being. (1910,Tapanui Station,16)

BEATTIE On the tussocky sides of the gullies the pleasant-tasting snowberries grew. (1956,Pioneer Recollections,IV 5)

BECKETT On those tussocky valleys and tussocky hills where the wild wind rides ... (1978,Mountains of Erewhon, The,71)

HALL At Glenrock there's a broken wall of bluffs up from the farm, with guts separating knobs, and behind that a tussocky plateau I've only been told about. (1987,Shepherd's Year, A,40)

KERR North Island boys wouldn't have any idea of big open tussocky alluvial flats ... (2000,High Times in the High Country,172)

It is due to a microbe that may be present in mouldy hay or in rank tussocky grass, or in a rank growth of oats that has decayed foliage at the bottom. (Aug 2, 1933,see notes,6) [NOTES: Rodney & Otamatea Times, Waitemata & Kaipara Gazette]

MEREDITH The hills around Port Lyttelton are bold ridges covered with ferns and tussocky grass. (1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,16,1935 ed.)

This species [of grass] is somewhat tussocky in habit (1876,TrNZI,9/497) [NOTES: Kirk]

LINDSAY Hence, next to bush and swamp-land proper (on alluvial clays), Flax-land is regarded as the most desirable for agricultural purposes. Flax-swamps' are frequently as common asTussock-swamps,' though their soil is far from being so wet or watery. Like the Tussock-swamps,' they are frequently verytussocky' - causing walking thereon to be extremely ... fatiguing. (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,80)

... we came across four wild dogs baiting a sow ... in a dry tussocky lagoon. (1878,TrNZI,10/323)

THOMPSON On those tussocky valleys and tussocky hills/ (1909,Ballads about Business,84)

... the lonely little settlement of the Maori sheep-farming hapu was more than two thousand feet above the sea, squatting on the tussocky banks of a cold clear stream that came ... down from ... Tongariro. (Jan 10, 1920,Quick March,13)

HISLOP After an early cup of tea ... I went back to bed ... leaving them ... to mount their `neddies' for a long day's mustering in those lovely tussocky hills and gullies. (1943,Pure Gold,57)

BEATTIE On the tussocky sides of gullies the pleasant-tasting snowberries grew in profusion, while a berry known as the wind-berry grew on a little plant similar to the snowberries and both kinds were eaten and enjoyed. (1947,Pioneer Recollections,5,1965 ed.)

THOMSON This heavy bush-clad country was a completely new experience for me, as most of my previous shooting had been done on more open tussocky country. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,42)

SARGESON (1969,Joy of the Worm,33)

MARSH The air up here [in the Southern Alps] was wonderfully fresh and smelt [33] aromatically of manuka scrub patching warm tussocky earth. (1980,Photo-Finish,32)

The black tussocky sand was as dragging as syrup; ... (Dec 28, 1986,Sunday Star (Auckland),B1)

Further along the line the country is chiefly unimproved alternate heavy flats, portions of which are swampy and peaty, and rolling tussocky downs, under which lie large tracks [sic] of limestone deposits and coal-bearing country. (Nov 30, 1899,Otago Witness,13)

The chairman read the audited balance sheet and also report, which stated that during the year the ordinary work of maintenance had absorbed the sum of GBP1500, which is represented by 11,054 cubic yards of shingle placed on the roads, 900 chains of the grading roads, and 284 chains of tussocky roads. (May 10, 1910,Ashburton Guardian,4)

Having procurred information as to the road to Mr Boyd's home station, we started forward, with a vast tussocky plain spread out before us as far as the eye could reach. (Oct 16, 1880,Otago Witness,17)

2 adj. having patches or plants of tussock-grass; ?infested with tussock

tussocky country¶

1 n. (Rural) [high country] pastoral land that is covered in tussock.

STUDHOLME Whilst riding after cattle over tussocky country one was always likely to come a cropper. (1940,Te Waimate,136)

THOMSON Most of my previous shooting had been done on more open tussocky country. (1952,Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker,42)

BRITTAIN Before shelter belts were planted the wind tore unchecked over the tussocky country. (2000,Lake Coleridge,49)

tussuck¶

n. (See tussock)

tutae¶

n. dung; excrement (lit. and fig.); a defecation [ORIGIN: Maori]

dung - too'tai [tutae] (1835,Boultbee Journal,111,1986 ed.)

In my next reincarnation I'm coming back as a full blooded maori [check], that'll scare the tutai out of all those pakeha statiticians. (Apr 3, 1974,Salient,13) [NOTES: [check spg]]

Black tutai ... It was left by Archy, the scrubcutter. (Oct 1981,Climate,32/34) [NOTES: 1981 Harry Goodwin `Omahu Station' in Oct/Nov Climate 32/34]

[Maori girl speaks] `Howzat you fullas?' but the girls were already conferring and Charlotte was enraged. ... she was going to throw that Macky in the tutae for sure. (1985,Women's Work,223) [NOTES: (Grace Kepa)]

Ihimaera Ah well, tutae happens. (2007,Ask the Posts,8)

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] dags [ from the Maori for excrement.]

dags: tutae. (2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB))

tutae happens¶

phr. Maori version of 'shit happens'

'Ah well', tutae happens. (2007,Best New Zealand Fiction, Vol 4, The,77) [NOTES: 'I've Been Thinking About You Sister', Witi Ihimaera, 2007]

tutae kehua / tutae whetu¶

n. basket fungus [ORIGIN: Maori]

CLATHRUS CIBARIUS, THE BIRD-CAGE FUNGUS'. ... This fungus, known variously asbasket fungus,'lattice fungus,',Devil's purse,' tutae whetu,'tutae kehua,' belongs to the Phallaceae, a family included in the Basidiomycetes. It is found commonly throughout New Zealand during the late autumn and early spring. [Distribution.- Australia; Chile; ... New Zealand] (Dec 1922,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,5/247) [NOTES: (Cunningham)]

tutae koau¶

n. native celery (Apium prostratum) [ORIGIN: Maori]

Here in New Zealand we also hae a native celery, tukaekoau or Apium prostratum (Dec 24, 2004,Dominion Post,C9)

I'll be looking out for native celery when I next go walking along the coast. This creeping plant, tutae koau (Apium prostratum) is found throughout the country, accoding to Andrew Crowe, the author of A Field Guide to the Native Edible Plants of New Zealand... (May 29, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),41)

tutaekuri¶

n. a variety of Maori potato (See urenika)

These [Maori potatoes] differ from the common spud in colour and texture: some varieties, like 'Urenika' (also known as 'Tutaekuri'), have purple flesh that retains its colour when cooked, while others have black or pink skins and creamy flesh. (Feb 1, 2004,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),15)

Tutaekuri: Known as urenika in the north, this looks like a cross between a yam and a potato... Popular with chefs for their bright colour. (Sep 7, 2003,Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine),13)

tute¶

n. (See tutu)

n.

HOOKER Tute, a wild, Hector. Olearia operina. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768) [NOTES: ?=??mistaken entry]

Holders already suffer terribly from cattle being compelled to eat tute, a most poisonous shrub, and from which they die almost immediately after having filled themselves with it (Nov 1, 1843,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2)

tute bush¶

n. tutu

.. but I should recommend the principal settlement to be placed about 10 miles inland, on the banks of the river communicating with the port, being near the centre of a fine alluvial valley, apparently surrounded with hills of moderate elevation, containing probably about 200,000 acres of grass land, mostly clear of fern, and, with the exception of some tute bushes, all ready to put the plough into, without any preparatory expense in clearing. (Apr 24, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2)

.. but I should recommend the principal settlement to be placed about 10 miles inland, on the banks of the river communicating with the port, being near the centre of a fine alluvial valley, apparently surrounded with hills of moderate elevation, containing probably about 200,000 acres of grass land, mostly clear of fern, and, with the exception of some tute bushes, all ready to put the plough into, without any preparatory expense in clearing. (Apr 24, 1841,New Zealand Gazette & Wellington Spectator,2)

tuted¶

adj. poisoned by "tutu" (See tutued)

Any variety of creature, from a maggot to an elephant, can be (and has been) "tuted," and Dr Malcom's experiments were made upon rabbits by the painless method, sometimes employed with recalcitrant suffragettes, of feeding the poison through a stomach tube. (Oct 14, 1913,Otautau Standard & Wallace County Chronicle,7)

HUNT With tuted cows on farms they have a sort of a frame thing (1981,Speaking a Silence,67)

They, however, eat and fattened well, and these tuted sheep, or "hermits" as they were called, were kept in a separate paddock, whence the supply of station mutton was drawn. (Jun 17, 1908,Otago Witness,17)

BUTLER In spite of your most frantic endeavours, you will be very liable to get some sheep tuted. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,102)

adj. variant of tutued

BUTLER As, then, my bullocks could not get tuted on being turned out empty, I yarded them. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,7/98) [NOTES: 1860 in 1863 Butler First Year vii/98]

A Tuted sheep stood erect and had full use of its extremities. (1869,TrNZI,2/401) [NOTES: (Dr Monro)]

T.C.KIERNAN Two bullocks dead at Troutbecks. One `tuted', the other bogged. (Jan 8, 1879,Diary) [NOTES: 1879 Jan 8 8T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie-Smith Tutira 123]

If [stock] were allowed to feed or rest there soon after landing, probably half of them would be tuted' and lost. <i>Ibid.</i> 181, 183 We also find ... the celebrated tutu, whose poisonous properties have proved so destructive to stock in all parts of New Zealand that the wordtuted' - [183] i.e., poisoned by eating tutu - has become a necessary part of our vocabulary. (1900,Canterbury Old & New,120)

tutin¶

n.

CONNOR Hodges and White.. succeeded in isolating tutin from toxic honey... The fate of tutin in the body was investigated by Ford.. who concluded that the toxin became localised in the brain and spinal chord in a detoxified state. (1977,Poisonous Plants of NZ, The,57)

There is a considerable literature on Coriaria or tutu, and the scientific results of the study of the active principle tutin (C17 H20 O7), which was first isolated in the chemical laboratory of the Department of Agriculture in 1900. (Oct 10, 1934,Evening Post,15)

The first substantial advance in the investigation of the chemical properties of tutu was made in 1900, when Easterfield and Aston succeeded in isolating a crystalline glucoside, to which they gave the name `tutin'. (1909,TrNZI,41/294)

tutsan¶

n.

FEATON HYPERICUM GRAMINEUM (Forst.) ... The leaves of some of the British species were formerly applied to fresh wounds, which they were supposed to heal; hence the plant was called in French Toutesaine - corrupted into Tutsan, its common English name. (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,50)

HILGENDORF TUTSAN (Hypericum and rosaemum), is a similar [to St. John's wort] but the less common weed. It is widely spread usually near the bush edge in both islands.] ... Tutsan is a corruption of Fr. Toutsaine- meaning heal-all. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,125,1967 ed.)

tutsan [s] Hypericum androsaemum L. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,81)

TAYLOR TUTSAN (Hypericum andro saemum) Shrubby perennial. . ., native to Eurasia. ... Tutsan is common in some places in the North Island and the Marlborough sounds. (1981,Weeds of Roadsides,155)

tutt-tuttery¶

n.

By all means faff about with a select committee inquiry, and join in the tutt-tuttery. (Oct 5, 2002,Listener (New Zealand Listener),16)

tutter¶

n. an abusive tem of address, or an obscene word for female genitals (cf. titoa) [ca1935 Havelock children ?imitated from Maori children]

tutu¶

n. a little look around, maybe even a poke around a room; used in the phrase "have a little tutu".

No, it was a 37-year-old, self taught mum of four - who learned her computer skills by "having a tutu". (May 2005,Kokiri Paetae,1)

adj. [tutu plant, tutu leaves, tutu tree, etc]

Numbers of trout are to be seen lying dead in many of the streams and rivers throughout the Masterton district. This is owing to the trout devouring the numerous green beetles which have been poisoned with the green tutu leaves which overhang the water in many parts. (Jan 12, 1895,Thames Star,3)

The writer had no pen or ink or pencil, but contrived to write with a pointed stick dipped in some reddish mixture, supposed to have been made from the tutu plant. (Feb 9, 1911,Thames Star,2)

There is still a large field for investigation in regard to the anomalous action of tutu plant on stock in the field, and why at times it may be consumed as a regular part of the diet and at other times may act as a powerful and immediate poison; possibly there may be a very simply explanation for this. (Oct 10, 1934,Evening Post,15)

The Native Reserve there is Hau-tutu (to chop up tutu tree). (Sep 26, 1903,Marlborough Express,6)

We were preparing roosts in the highest tutu trees when the rain ceased and the stormwaters quickly subsided. (Jan 4, 1929,Evening Post,13)

n. an owl

...swarms of fantails tease the cats, fat kereru perform nail-biting high-wire acts and tutu hoot through the night. (Jul 10, 2004,Dominion Post,E12)

n. a large shrub whose pulpy black berries contain poisonous seeds, and whose leaves can poison stock. [Maori]

"Tutu'" is easily destroyed by fire. (Jul 29, 1943,NZ Farmers' Weekly,34)

OVERTON He again baled up in some tutu on the other side of the stream and was then finished off with the spear... (1949,Fifty Years Sheep Farming,22)

The name `tutu' is applied to three distinct species of the ... natural order Coriariae: Coriaria ruscifolia, L. (C. sarmentosa, Forst., C. arborea and C. tutu, Lindsay, tutu, pohou, and tupakihi of the Maori), is commonly known as the tree-toot ... (1901,TrNZI,33/347)

One [sc. of the cattle] had died from eating tutu, a poisonous herb. (Apr 12, 1873,Auckland Weekly News,11)

HOCHSTETTER139 There are no poisonous plants with the solitary exception of the Toot plant. (Fn) The Toot-plant, Tutu or Tupakihi of the Maoris.. is a small bush. (1867,New Zealand (Hochstetter))

HENDERSON Barley grass and toot to the horizon. (1998,From Top to Bottom : Reinga to Bluff,117)

ANTHONY Five-finger, tu-tu, koromiko and gig hung in tangled profusion all along the river-bank... (1936,Follow the Call,107)

WOOD The fern is fired; if it burns well, all the thick and matted dead stuff at the bottom.. will be consumed, leaving only the shrivelled 'Tutu'; and the cane-like fern stalks.. should be cut at once, either with a strong hook, or, better still, with a short scythe, and the 'Tutu' slashed down with a bill-hook. (1978,From New Plymouth to New Plymouth,138) [NOTES: Quotation from HURSTHOUSE 1849]

MORELAND Leaving the horses tied below, we began a toilsome ascent through a belt of tutu - a stout herb growing as high as our shoulders... [Note.] Coriaria ruscifolia. (1911,Through South Westland,174)
