ROBERTS The ridges clothed with the snow-grass tussock, the gullies growing fern and tutu. (1890,History of Oamaru & North Otago,25) [NOTES: quote from 1856]

This has been a day of sorrow.. one of our best cows died of tut and curiosity (Sep 30, 1926,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,40) [NOTES: check spelling - "tut" or "tutu"?]

For short periods, under certain adverse conditions, bees may produce poisonous honey derived from tutu, a highly toxic native plant. (Feb 28, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),43)

1 n. (Rural) [Ma.] a small shrubby native tree of Coriaria spp., poisonous to stock.

SEWELL The sheep were all down with the tutu. (Jan 25, 1856,Sewell Journal 1853-1857,212) [NOTES: in McIntyre (1980) Sewell Journal 1853-1856]

DEANS Letter 30 in Deans (1964) Pioneers on Port Cooper Plains 100 .. we all helped him, raking and gathering tutu roots, which grew very strong there, the berries being very poisonous to people, horses, sheep and cattle. When dry the roots made capital firewood ... (1857)

Tutu is a plant which dies away in winter. (1860,BLANK ENTRY,82) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

Perhaps some of your experienced well-informed country readers would inform me as to the best plan for dealing with cattle that have got 'staggers' from eating tutu or tupakihi. (Nov 9, 1867,Weekly News,12)

KENNEDY .. native trees in great numbers, and the poisonous 'toot' plant, a small shrub terribly destructive to sheep and cattle. (1876,Colonial Travel,170)

The uncultivated land was surface sown, and the grass has grown for over twenty years .. High fern, flax and tutu covered the ground ... (May 12, 1888,Egmont Star,6)

Fern and tutu hills were selected for pastoral activities. (Mar 15, 1947,NZ Journal of Agriculture,244)

On many farms tutu has now been completely eradicated. (Feb 24, 1966,NZ Farmer,29)

FISK Coriara arborea (tree tutu). [toot] (1996,Practical Smallfarming,209)

The south-west wind blew as hard on them as on us, but they had no shelter for the cattle which would find the beds of creeks and rivers, where grew the deadly native poison plant tutu. (Oct 26, 1945,Ellesmere Guardian,5)

Stock were also affected by eating tutu. (May 14, 1943,Ellesmere Guardian,5)

A farmer is credited with saying that he has seen cattle eat tutu, and suffer no ill effects from it, whilst others he had observed eating it very shortly developed symptoms of poisoning. (May 6, 1911,Marlborough Express,5)

Children Poisoned With Tutu. (Aug 13, 1885,Evening Post,2)

2 n.

COCKAYNE Report on the Dune-areas of NZ (1911,AJHR,C-13)

TUCKETT ... the prevailing growth [at Taieri mouth] is flax, fern, toot, and grass. (May 4, 1844,Diary,215) [NOTES: 1844 May 4 and 5 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 215]

[The bull] runs a risk from a plant called the `toot', which is greedily fed on. (1848,Otago Journal,3/41) [NOTES: (Rev. J. Burns)]

... flax, toots etc. (1850,Otago Journal,6/107)

RICHARDSON [North Island] ... flax, fern and toot. (1854,Summer's Excursion,114)

LINDSAY The too-well-known Toot' of the Otago farmer; theWine-berry shrub' of the early settlers of the Bay of Islands, (according to Dr. Bennett [Wanderings in Australia'] and theTreasury of Botany'); the Tutu,'Tupakihi,' and Puhou' of the North Island Maoris; theTaweku' of the Waikatos; the Tupake' [a-macron, e-acute] of Coromandel district; theTua-tutu' of Otago, (Hooker). ... [`Tutu'] appears also to be a generic or general [term] ... (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,85)

I find the opinion that there are three kinds' oftoot' unanimous among the more observant settlers alike of Otago and Auckland. (1870,TrNZI,174) [NOTES: (Lindsay)]

His hearty salutation in its faultiness proved to be about on a par with rummy rum',triddy', and toot'. The last word reminds me of a man near by who was even judged to be somewhat vain of his Maori accent and pronunciation. With one word indeed he was very particular, he could not bring himself to use that manifest corruptiontoot'. With him it was ever `tutu'. He had to make rather a boggle or dodge of it when he used the colonial made verb formed on his favourite Maori noun. (1891,NZ Country Journal,201) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts, Morris)]

MORRIS Toot, n. the anglicised spelling of the Maori word Tutu (q.v.). (1898,Austral English,475)

BAUGHAN Tute, correctly tutu (toot): A poisonous native shrub. (1908,Shingle-Short,14)

toot n. a shrub or small tree with astringent bark, the berries of which can be made into wine but the seeds are poisonous.-toot'ed a. poisoned by toot. [Maori tutu] (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,12)

Tutu (-->toot, -->tute .. .. tupakihi, tutu .. .. Coriaria (1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/705-712)

toot n. slang for tutu (q.v.). (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),20)

McGILL There was a shrub like a peach tree, with red flowers. Doug called it `tute'. (1985,G'day Country,150)

toot var. of TUTU. (1960,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,811) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 506]]

2 n. esp. C. sarmentosa, C. aborea [(cf tupakihi; and cf 1841 citation for reference to the juice of the plant)]

TUTU, Coriaria arborea, is one of seven Coriaria species endemic to New Zealand. (Apr 30, 2005,Dominion Post,E13)

LEE & KENDALL T|utu, s. Fruit from the Tu p|akii. (1820,Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ,220)

... his face and hands were stained with the juice of Etootoo, a berry which when squeezed, affords a nutritious beverage; ... It being Summer time, we had abundance of the Etootoo to drink. This is a berry that grows in clusters like currants, on a plant about three feet high, in colour they are like the elder-berry; they are full of seeds, which are of a pernicious nature. (1835,Boultbee Journal,68,1986 ed.)

He [a Maori] was a stout tall fellow ... & his face and hands were stained with the juice of Etootoo, a berry which when squeezed, affords a nutritious beverage, .... (1827,Boultbee Journal) [NOTES: 1827 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 185]

WAKEFIELD the berry ... tutu or tuparki ... (1837,British Colonization of NZ,324)

DIEFFENBACH Near the beach appear shrublike veronicas [fn Veronica ligustrifolia.], myrtles [fn Myrtus bullata.], fuchsias, solanum [fn Solanum laciniatum.], the karaka tree [fn Corynocarpus laevigata.], tutu [fn Coriaria sarmentosa.], and flax [fn Phormium tenax.]. (1843,Travels in NZ,1/26)

Its current is rapid ... enclosing islands covered with a jungle of tu-tu and toi-toi. (Jul 20, 1844,Nelson Examiner) [NOTES: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 236]

SHORTLAND This was the season when the fruit of the tutu' ortupakihi', as it is called in the North Island, was ripe. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,191) [NOTES: 1844 Jan 8 in 1851 Shortland Southern Districts of NZ 191]

WAKEFIELD Rested at Okiwi; one ewe died through eating Tutu. (1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,25) [NOTES: 1848 Wakefield Handbook for NZ 124 [1845 August] 25.]

  • saw a cow (dead of tutu). (Dec 29, 1850,Torlesse Papers,178,1958 ed.)

... three [cows] have died, Mr. Brittan's by falling over a cliff, Mr. Fitzgerald's and Mr. Phillips's by eating tutu. ... To beasts just out of a ship, the tutu, of which there is abundance here, is certainly fatal. (Jan 11, 1851,Lyttelton Times,5)

I ... was occupied two hours in searching amongst the tutu and fern for the boundary posts of the section required; ... (Jun 14, 1851,Lyttelton Times,6)

... generally about ten per cent [of imported stock] die ... partly from the `tutu,' a poisonous plant which the stock eat greedily, and which has an effect on them not unlike Strychnine. ... After about a month this plant ceases to effect them and they thrive upon it. (Jul 1, 1851,Lyttelton Times,6)

MORRIS Tutu, or Toot, n. Maori name for a shrub or small tree, Coriaria ruscifolia, Linn., or C. sarmentosa, Forst., of New Zealand, widely distributed. It bears greenish flowers, and shiny pulpy black berries. From these the Maoris make a wine resembling light claret, taking care to strain out and not to crush the seeds, which are poisonous, with an action similar to that of strychnine. It goes also by the name of Wineberry-bush, and the Maori name is Anglicised into Toot. In Maori, the final u is swallowed rather than pronounced. In English names derived from the Maori, a vowel after a mute letter is not sounded. It is called in the North Island Tupakihi. In Maori, the verb tutu means to be hit, wounded, or vehemently wild, and the name of the plant thus seems to be connected with the effects produced by its poison. To `eat your toot': used as a slang phrase; to become acclimatised, to settle down into colonial ways. (1898,Austral English,485)

Tú.tu (tú.tu; colloq. t&omacr.&omacr.t), n. [Maori.] [Written also toot.] (Bot.) A New Zealand shrub (Coriarai ruscifolia) of the order Coriariae, extremely poisonous to cattle. [Local, N. Z.] (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2033)

The name `tutu' is applied to three distinct species of the ... natural order Coriariae: Coriaria ruscifolia, L. (C. sarmentosa, Forst., C. arborea and C. tutu, Lindsay, tutu, pohou, and tupakihi of the Maori), is commonly known as the tree-toot ... (1901,TrNZI,33/347)

TREGEAR In case ... of poisoning by having swallowed the seeds of the tutu or tupakihi plant (Coriaria ruscifolia) the smoke remedy was resorted to ... (1904,Maori Race, The,18)

tutu: small tree with poisonous berries. (1947,Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.,176)

SARGESON (gloss.) tutu: often called `toot' by Europeans, native shrub poisonous to cattle. (1949,I Saw in My Dream,273,1974 ed. Rhodes ed.)

tutu Prounced by Europeans as toot'. A New Zealand plant bearing shiny black berries from which the Maoris made a kind of wine. The plant is poisonous to stock; animals affected by it are said to betooted'. (Pronounce .us too|-too|). (1958,Whitcombe's Modern Junior Dictionary (8th edn),426)

HILLIARD (1960,Maori Girl) [NOTES: see cit taupata]

tutu n. small New Zealand shrub, with poisonous seeds, the pulpy black berries being used by the Maoris to make wine [Maori]. (1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),627)

BRATHWAITE TUTU A poisonous shrub. Coriaria sarmentosa. (1967,Evil Day,382)

tutu ... n. small N.Z. shrub, with poisonous seeds, the pulpy black berries being used by Maoris to make wine [Maori]. (1968,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins),21)

tutu [s] Coriaria sarmentosa Forst.f. (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,81)

BROOKER et al. Coriaria arborea Linds. Common name: Toot Maori names: Tutu, tupakihi, puhou ... The New Zealand species of Coriaria were revised by Oliver and the name C. arborea Lindsay was applied to the common large-leaved shrub formerly regarded as identical with the South American C. ruscifolia L. (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,45)

BURTON A more flavoursome delicacy was prepared by soaking the [fernroot] cakes in the juice of tutu (Coriaria) petals. (1982,Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery,5)

tutu n. NZ shrub with black berries that contain poisonous seeds. [M] (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,832) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 517]]

CHEESEMAN [Coriaria ruscifolia, Linn.] Tutu; Tupakihi. ... The poisonous principle appears to be a glucoside, to which the name `tutin' has been applied. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,106)

HILGENDORF TUTU (Coriaria ruscifolia [spp.]), usually corrupted into `toot,' is a native of New Zealand, abundant in the open country throughout. It usually grows 2 or 3 feet high ... Tutu is one of the best known poisonous plants in this country, the poison occurring in the young shoots and seeds. (1926,Weeds of New Zealand,120,1967 ed.)

tutu n. see TOOT (1929,Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.,12)

GUTHRIE The natives were very fond of a plant called tutu, ... (1930,NZ Memories,115)

Pronounced toot'.Various species of Coriaria. A poisonous plant. There are three sizes and the smaller (like a fern) is the most dangerous. The past participle of the verb meaning to be poisoned by t., is spelt either tooted or tuted. (Dec 30, 1933,Press, The,13) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

tutu, a small tree (Coriaria Ruscifolia); its young leaf-shoots are poisonous to stock, especially when hungry; the seeds and stalks poisonous to man. C. Thymofolia is tutu-heuheu and tutu-papa. (1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/147) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

SHORTLAND TUTU .us (coriaria sarmentosa),;a shrub with long feeble branches, its fruit growing in racemes or clusters. (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,314)

ALLOM There is a great variety of native grasses [in the Wairarapa]; ... mixed with other kinds of vegetation, such as the coarse grasses, fern, tohi-tohi, porcupine grass, flax, tutu, manuka, and others. [? itals indicate native names]. (1853,Letter) [NOTES: 1853 Allom letter in 1853 Earp NZ 119]

Coriaria sarmentosa tutu (Jan 1856,Edinburgh New Philosophical Journal) [NOTES: (And)1856 Tancred Notes on the Natural History of ... Canterbury (Edinburgh New Philos. Journal (NS) Jan 1856)]

HURSTHOUSE (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles)) [NOTES: 1857. R.Wilkin, in a letter printed by C. Hursthouse, `New Zealand,' p. 372: [+other cits incl. tree tutu]]

BUTLER The tutu not having yet begun to spring I yarded my bullocks at Main's. (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,vii/97) [NOTES: 1860 in 1863 Butler First Year vii/97]

BUTLER Tutu (pronounced toot) is a plant which abounds upon the plains for some miles near the river-beds; ... (1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,ix/131)

HOOKER Tutu, Col[enso]. Coriaria ruscifolia. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

HOCHSTETTER The toot-plant, tutu or tupakihi of the Maoris ... is a small bush, one of the most common and widely distributed shrubs of the islands. It produces a sort of `hoven' or narcotic effect on sheep and cattle, when too greedily eaten. It bears a fruit, which is produced in clusters, not unlike a bunch of currants, with the seed external, of a purple colour. The poisonous portion of the plant to man are the seeds and seed-stalks, while their dark purple pulp is utterly innocuous and edible. The natives express from the berries an agreeable violet juice (carefully avoiding the seed), called native wine. (1867,New Zealand (various authors/titles),139) [NOTES: (Morris)]

(Coriaria ruscifolia, var). The plant known as Tutu, on the pasture lands of Otago, is a strong robust shrub 3-6 feet high, dying down to the ground every year. Ibid. 40 Tutu. Coriaria ruscifolia, Linn. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/34) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

PYKE NOTE. - As I have no desire to mystify readers unacquainted with New Zealand flora, I append a brief description of the shrubs mentioned:-.. Tutu - A berry-bearing, glossy-leaved plant, deadly to man and to all animals - except goats. Tumata-kuru - Better known as `Wild Irishman' - a thorny plant, very difficult to handle. (1873,Wild Will Enderby,1/iii/16,1889,1974 ed.)

DOMETT Tutu or Tupaki ..... O. Coriariae; G. Coriaria; S. C. ruscifolia. (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/302)

FEATON CORIARIA RUSCIFOLIA (Linn.) ... The `TUTU', or TUPAKIHI'.- Ibid. 178 Taweku [Maori name] .. Tutu [Settlers' name] .. Coriaria ruscifolia ..Shrub ... Tutu [Maori name] .. Tutu [Settlers' name] .. Coriaria ruscifolia .. Shrub Tupkakihi [Maori name] .. Tutu [Settlers' name] .. Coriaria ruscifolia ..Shrub (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,103)

2 n.

DIEFFENBACH Tutu - a wine made from the berries of the tupakihi (1843,Travels in NZ,2/390)

WADE The Tupakihi ... produces ... berries, the expressed unfermented juice of which is called tutu. (1841,Journey in NZ,57)

2 n.

A combination of cooked karengo and tutu juice was fermented and used as a laxative by pre-contact Maori - though I wouldn't recommend the potion to amateur herbalists, who might find their self-healing process turns into a suicide mission, given that every other part of the tutu berry, apart from its juice, is deadly poisonous. (Oct 12, 2002,Dominion Post,F7)

Perhaps the most infamous of all native plants is the tutu family. Steams, leaves and seeds of these shrubs and small trees are extremely poisonous and paralysis and death may occur if eaten. It has small green flowers, purplish-black fruit enclosed by enlarged petals, and the new shoots from the base look like overgrown asparagus. (Feb 3, 1992,Listener (New Zealand Listener),25)

CONNOR Tutu beer and tutu pie made with fruits including the seeds caused death or serious illnesses in Europeans early in New Zealand history. (1977,Poisonous Plants of NZ, The,52)

TAYLOR Simonin gathered a handkerchief full of tutu berries, beat them up, squeezed them, and got a pint of wine, which was first-rate drink. (1959,Early Travellers,402) [NOTES: Quote from Journal of A.J. Barrington, March 16, 1864]

TAYLOR Simonin gathered a handkerchief full of tutu berries, beat them up, squeezed them, and got a pint of wine, which was first-rate drink. (1959,Early Travellers,402) [NOTES: Quote from Journal of A.J. Barrington, March 16, 1864]

HENDERSON Many cows ate the dark green leaves of tutu bush and died. (1967,Return to Open Country,77)

3 n. Coriaria sarmentosa

(1909,AJHR,C-12) [NOTES: 1909 Cockayne Botanical Survey Stewart Island in AJHR C-12 (And)]

(1911,AJHR,C-13) [NOTES: 1911 Cockayne Report on Dune-areas in AJHR C-13 (And)]

3 n.

HURSTHOUSE Grass land, consists of coarse grasses, intermixed with scrubby fern, flax, dwarf tutu, toe-toe, and ti tree. (1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/330)

3 n. Coriaria angustissima

FEATON (1889,Art Album NZ Flora) [NOTES: (And)]

3 n. Coriaria thymifolia

THOMSON (1859,Story of New Zealand, The) [NOTES: (And)]

Alpine Tutu (Coriaria angustissima). A very distinct species, found only in Sub-alpine localities, ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/34) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

3 n.

FEATON The Ground Tutu, C. thymifolia, of the Middle Island, is, however, said to be highly poisonous to horses. Ibid. 105 CORIARIA THYMIFOLIA (Humb.) ... In Otago it is commonly known as the Small Ground Tutu, and is said to be highly poisonous to horses. Ibid. 178 Tutupapa [Maori name] .. Ground Tutu [Settlers' name] .. Coriaria thymifolia .. Herb (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,104)

ground tutu [=] small-leaved tutu [s] ... Ibid. 81 tutu, ground [=] small-leaved tutu [s] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,35)

THOMSON Coriaria angustissima ground tutu (1859,Story of New Zealand, The) [NOTES: (And)]

3 n. Coriaria thymifolia spg ? TUTE

Thyme-leaved Tutu (Coriaria thymifolia). The varieties of this are so numerous that it is difficult to determine the size of the species; ... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/34) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

COCKAYNE (1909,AJHR) [NOTES: Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island (And)]

(1911,AJHR,C-13) [NOTES: Report on the Dune-areas of NZ (And)]

3 n.

tutu, small-leaved [s] [5 Coriaria spp.] (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,81)

3 n. Coriaria thymifolia

(1885,NZ Country Journal) [NOTES: (And)1885 NZ Country Journal (Canterbury A & P Ass.) Vol I 1877-XXII 1898]

3 n.

WODZICKI On the tops they feed on Hebe sp., mountain tutu (Coriaria sp) and snowgrass (Danthonia sp.). (1950,Introduced Mammals of NZ,223)

MARK & ADAMS Coriaria plumosa W.R.B Oliver. MOUNTAIN TUTU (1973,NZ Alpine Plants,70,1979 ed.)

3 n. [Contrast tutu-tree]

LINDSAY C[oriaria] arborea, (C. ruscifolia, Auct. pr. p.) The Tree Tutu;' which Dr. Hector asserts is quite distinct from the commonHerbaceous Tutu,' or `Tutu' proper. ... Tree Toot also occurs in the forests of the Te Anau and Manipori Lakes. (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,84)

Tree Tutu (Coriaria ruscifolia). A small shrub-tree, with a trunk 6-8 inches diameter, growing often solitary in the bush. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/34)

HECTOR Coriaria rusifolia, Linn. Tupakihi, Tree Tutu.--A perennial shrub 10-18 feet high; trunk 6-8 inches in diameter. The seeds and leaves contain a poisonous alkaloid. (1883,Handbook of New Zealand,131)

LAING & BLACKWELL The other New Zealand species [ofCoriaria are C. lurida, C. angustissima, and C. arborea, the tree tutu. There are many hybrids. (1940,Plants of NZ,241)

MARTIN [On] the forest margin the TREE TUTU (toot) (Coriaria arborea) is a common small tree ... . (1961,Flora NZ,183,1929 ed.)

tree tutu [s] Coriaria arborea Lindsay Ibid. 81 tutu, tree [s] Coriaria arborea Lindsay (1969,Standard Common Names for Weeds,80)

MOORE & IRWIN CORIARIA ARBOREA. Tree tutu is found throughout [New Zealand]. (1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,64)

WILSON Coriaria arborea TREE TUTU ... Shrub with stout, arching, perennial branches. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,112)

3 n.

LEVY ... shrubs common in the tussock zone: matagouri, native brooms, dwarf koromikos, monoao, sarmentose tutu, the grasslike spiky-leaved Spaniard, the harsh patotara, golden cottonwood, cushion-like pimeleas, and the low, matted, carpet-like growth of the scabweeds are characteristic of the low tussock country, ... (1951,Grasslands of NZ,35,1970 ed.)

3 n.

LAING & BLACKWELL Coriaria sarmentosa (The Shrubby Tutu) ... Maori name Tupakihi or Tutu (usually pronounced Toot). (1940,Plants of NZ,239)

3 n.

WILSON Coriaria plumosa FEATHERY TUTU ...Summer-green prostrate to ascending shoots in colonies. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,112)

5 n. having tutu endemic esp. tutu (toot) plant

Tutu bush ... and other shrubs. (1843,Letters from Settlers) [NOTES: (H.S.Tiffen) 1842]

ED. WARD ... saw his cow lying dying of `toot' poison. (Jan 6, 1851,Journal,101,1951 ed.)

THOMSON From the poisonous Tutu berries (Coriaria sarmentosa) a grateful and not intoxicating drink was expressed ... (1859,Story of New Zealand, The,1/19,1974 ed.)

HOCHSTETTER The toot-plant, tutu or tupakikihi [?check] of the Maoris ... (1867,New Zealand (various authors/titles),139)

LINDSAY By reason of its including the too-familiar and fatal `Toot' plant, [Coriaria] is ... of no secondary importance to the New Zealand colonist. (1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,83)

Coriaria sarmentosa spg TOOT PLANT (1868,Province of Otago in NZ, The) [NOTES: (And)]

Coriaria sarmentosa spg TOOT PLANT (1908,Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture) [NOTES: (And)]

78 I mention this cure because I have actually seen it done when droving cattle through tutu-areas. (Jan 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture)

LETHBRIDGE One died as a small boy - eating `toot' berries on his way home from school. (1971,Sunrise on the Hills,140)

WOODHOUSE Haul out the toot roots and everything near ye;/ Grub away, tug away, toil till you're weary,/ (1950,Farm & Station Verse,4) [NOTES: [1852-1860 Barr] in 1950 Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse 4]

tutu around¶

v.

I'm stuck here like a beached whale and he's off tutuing around sight-seeing! (Jul 10, 2004,Listener (New Zealand Listener),81)

tutu bed¶

1 n. (Rural) a grove of poisonous Coriaria or tutu.

SEWELL It seems that the spot where the sheep were placed was just upon the borders of a tutu bed ... (Jan 25, 1856,Sewell Journal 1853-1857,213) [NOTES: in McIntyre (1980)]

tutu beer¶

n.

Tutu beer and tutu pies made from the edible berries - but accidentally including seeds or other parts of the plant - have caused death and serious illness to people. (Feb 26, 1985,Dominion,3)

tutu berry¶

n. [tutu-berry]

The infant son of Samuel Rogers, Te Awamutu, has been poisoned by eating tutu berries. (Sep 30, 1882,Taranaki Herald,2)

Recently United States Consular reports contained the formulae for making ink from tutu berries. (Mar 12, 1918,Thames Star,2)

.. Mr. Freeman recalled to mind that one man died through eating a pudding he had made for himself containing tutu berries. (Apr 30, 1924,Evening Post,9)

Three young Maori children were poisoned on Sunday afternoon through eating tutu berries, states a Thames correspondent. (Sep 7, 1938,Evening Post,5)

In another case two young men partook of some tutu-berries, about 4 p.m. (1909,TrNZI,41/290)

tutu grove¶

1 n. (Rural) a closely-growing group of poisonous Coriaria or tutu shrubs.

GUTHRIE-SMITH Certainly there was no grass in it, but the tutu-groves sprouting again from their burnt stools were open. (1921,Tutira,167)

tutu land¶

1 n. (Rural) country upon which the poisonous Coriaria or tutu grows [ thought to be a sign of fertility.]

PAUL The tutu land will yield very good crops. (1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,96)

PAUL If the soil is good, such as strong flax and grass, or tutu land, two or three successive crops of wheat may be taken ... (1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,98)

tutu poison¶

n.

TUTU POISON .. At the Otago Institute, Dr. Malcolm detailed the results of experiments with the toxic properties of the tutu which should be of immediate interest in a sheep-growing country. (Jan 6, 1914,Marlborough Express,4)

tutu poisoning¶

n.

n. (Rural) sickness and possible death of farm stock from the eating of tutu. [1907 citation: toot-poisoning]

CRESSWELL There were no tracks - just hard punching all the way, with a fair number of sheep dying from tutu poisoning. (1949,Early NZ Families,5)

ASPINALL Since increasing the cattle numbers and top-dressed areas, the station has lost more cattle through tutu poisoning. (1993,Farming Under Aspiring,160)

PULLEN After that we had trouble with tutu poisoning. (1996,On the Road Again,29)

T. Venn on Tutu poisoning case ... 283. (Jan 2, 1862,Hawke's Bay Herald,3)

Antidote for Tutu poisoning. (Apr 18, 1892,West Coast Times,4)

LAING & BLACKWELL Thus Dr. Lauder Lindsay states in the British Medical Review (July 1865): `He seemed a fortunate farmer or runholder who had not lost more than 25 per cent. of his stock from toot-poisoning, whilst in some instances, the losses were so high as 75 per cent.' (1907,Plants of NZ,228,1940, p. 241 ed.) [NOTES: 1865 in 1907 [1940] Laing and Blackwell Plants of NZ 228 [241]]

Birds are said to be unaffected by the seeds, but ... domestic fowls have been poisoned by eating the berries, the symptoms being typical of tutu-poisoning. (1901,TrNZI,33/346)

Treatment of a beast suffering from tutu poisoning by pulling its tongue as far as possible out of the mouth towards the ear would be of very little avail. (Jan 15, 1912,NZ Journal of Agriculture,78)

AYSON The danger of tutu poisoning and the pleuro scare made constant observation of the cattle necessary, but all went well in this corner of the south. (1937,Thomas,115)

Do any readers know a remedy for tutu poisoning? (Sep 13, 1926,NZ Dairy Produce Exporter,40)

Mr. C. H. Mills, of Havelock, formerly a resident of Wellington, states in a letter to a local paper that his brother, Mr. T. H. Mills, has found kerosene a complete antidote for tutu poisoning in cattle. (Jun 2, 1881,Evening Post,2)

tutu pudding¶

n.

Tutu Pudding [page] 61. (Jul 15, 1897,Otago Witness,33)

Isaac Hill seized the bucket and ran towards the river, but he tumbled over and began to imitate Goulter so exactly that we all were reminded of the tutu pudding. (May 5, 1928,Evening Post,8)

It was very evident and very fortunate that we had not put on our best clothes for that Sunday's work, and it was highly probable that none of us would ever eat any more tutu pudding. (Jul 30, 1897,Timaru Herald,4)

tutu soil¶

1 n. (Rural) a high-fertility soil that supports Coriaria or tutu.

PAUL Tutu soil is the most expensive to break up ... (1857,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,97)

tutu wine¶

n.

To experiment upon the flax is inexpensive and easy to accomplish, and some of our brewers who desire to make themselves famous might try both that and the manufacture of tutu wine. (Jul 8, 1870,Daily Southern Cross,4)

HAY With the advent of 'waipiro' it no longer became necessary to make tu-tu wine. (1915,Reminiscences of Earliest Canterbury,19)

Indeed, in the very early days the tutu was known as the wine-berry shrub. This wine, however, has not always proved to be above suspicion. Canon Stack ... relates that ... after partaking of some tutu-wine he was seized with alarming symptoms. (1909,TrNZI,41/292)

HUTT A Canterbury Pakeha settler in the 1840s recorded that gourds were made into wine containers for fermenting, but "with the advent of 'waipiro' it no longer became necessary to make tu-tu wine". (1999,Maori & Alcohol,14)

The men thought it would be the wiser to give me a deep draught of tutu wine that would lull me to eternal sleep, but the women pleaded hard that I might be allowed to live amongst them, and the King, full of mercy, gave me his support. (Sep 24, 1887,Tuapeka Times,5)

tutu-grown¶

adj.

COWAN We turned off ... where a track opened up in a tutu-grown valley between two mighty green hills (1916,Bush Explorers,4)

tutu-papa¶

n.

HOOKER Tutupapa, Col[enso]. Coriaria thymifolia. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

...the fruit of the Tutu-papa (Coriaria thymifolia)... (1869,TrNZI,1/III/31) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

n. (Rural) a type of tutu, Coriaria plumosa. [ORIGIN: Maori]

CROWE The Maori, however, commonly consumed the juice of the petals of these two plants and according to Colenso, another small-leaved one called tutu-papa, in a variety of ways. Tutu-papa is Coriaria plumosa according to Beever. (1990,Native Edible Plants of NZ,63)

tutu-poison¶

n.

TVNZ abbr. Television New Zealand. (1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,832) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]

`On the Toot-poison of New Zealand,' by W. Lauder Lindsay ... Report of the British Association's thirty-second meeting, Cambridge, 1862. (1901,TrNZI,33/354)

tutu-tree¶

n. [contrast tree-tutu (no entry for this TD)] (See tutu)

DOMETT So men compared him to the tutu-tree,/ (1883,Ranolf and Amohia,1/152)

HILLIARD And there's the lights on the leaves of the taupata, and on the tutu trees over the creek where the cows can't get at them. (1960,Maori Girl,215)

Some were cases of cattle living constantly on the open run, but from some cause or other were penned at night, and let out in the morning to the run with empty stomachs, and having found a 'Tutu' tree they never left it until all the shoots were consumed, and in consequence in a short time delirium would be almost certain to follow, and then death, unless discovered by the owners and well dosed and bled, in which case, unless too far gone, they might be saved. (Dec 27, 1859,Daily Southern Cross,3)

There are plenty of tutu trees in Cambridge. (Nov 1, 1865,Daily Southern Cross,6)

At this point the rata begins to grow, although it is not seen to much advantage until further up the lake, and here also the tutu tree begins to attain considerable dimensions. (Mar 30, 1870,Star, The,2)

A seven-year-old boy of Mr Steven Liddle, of Kaiti, was poisoned on Saturday by eating the young shoots of the tutu tree. (Nov 30, 1896,Poverty Bay Herald,2)

tutua¶

n. a worthless person, a nobody [ORIGIN: Maori]

MANING But then certainly, the pakeha was a tuatua, a nobody, a fellow not worth a spike nail; (1863,Old New Zealand,(ii) 19) [NOTES: [check spg]]

SINCLAIR Within each tribe the population was further divided into slaves, who were mostly prisoners of war, tutua or commoners, and the numerous class of chiefs, rangatira. At the head of the tribe there was a paramount chief, the ariki. Ibid. 302 [Maori glossary] tutua Low-born (person) (1959,History of New Zealand,20)

Rangihaeta insisted that only the lives of the principal Europeans could compensate as sufficient utu for the loss of his wife. 'We are sure to be killed for this some day,' he told Te Rauparaha. 'The white people will take utu, let us then have some better blood than that of these tutua (common people).' (Sep 1960,Te Ao Hou,32: 8-9)

To steal a man's clothes was the act of a "tutua," a no-account fellow, but to steal his wife was the act of a chief. (Mar 23, 1912,NZ Free Lance,4)

From Hemi te tutua. 'Hemi te tutua' is Jim the nobody. (Jun 1981,Landfall,6(4) No. 31-32 : 115)

tutued¶

adj. of stock, poisoned by eating tutu

adj. (Rural) [of a grazing animal] affected by eating tutu. [including tooted, tuted and tutu'd]

KENNARD On the trip we lost two bullocks drowned when crossing the Clutha and two died at Teschmaker's through getting 'tooted' ... (1859,Journal,41) [NOTES: in Hamilton (1952) History of Northern Southland]

As, then, my bullocks could not get tuted on being turned out empty, I yarded them. (1860,BLANK ENTRY,83) [NOTES: in BUTLER First Year (1863)]

BATHGATE Those [animals] feeding amongst it .. are apt to be affected by it, or be, as the phrase is, 'tutued.' (1974,Colonial Experiences,211)

Two bullocks dead at Troutbecks'. One "tuted" the other bogged. (Jan 8, 1879,Tutira Station Diary)

HALL If they [sheep] were allowed to feed or rest there soon after landing, probably half of them would be 'tuted' and lost. (1900,BLANK ENTRY,120) [NOTES: in Canterbury Old and New]

HALL We also find here and there patches of the celebrate tutu, whose poisonous properties have proved so destructive to stock in all parts of New Zealand that the word 'tuted' ie poisoned by eating tutu - has become a necessary part of our vocabulary. (1900,BLANK ENTRY,181) [NOTES: in Canterbury Old and New]

MOWAT Got a few [sheep] tutued coming through Aotea but did not lose any. (Feb 24, 1909,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

MOWAT Had a bit of trouble with the sheep that we tutued yesterday. (Feb 25, 1909,Alexander Mowat Diaries)

STEVENS Laurie & Person Bros. looked around the fences & whilst away came across a tutued steer. (Jul 1, 1914,Stevens Diary)

ACLAND It came on to rain so Walker moved the sheep down the hill to shelter and got 70 of them tooted. (1946,Early Canterbury Runs,92)

CRAWFORD .. a driver with a 'tuted' mob had many cares on his shoulders. (1949,Sheep and Sheepmen of Canterbury,31)

HUNT With tuted cows on farms, they have a sort of a frame thing to put them in ... [tooted; tuted] (1981,Speaking a Silence,67)

[Hdg] Tutued Sheep (Jun 15, 1916,Lake County Press,5)

It appears that a station manager in going his rounds.. found a good fat bullock tutued. of which he could not save the life. (Apr 10, 1890,Otago Witness,20)

TREATMENT OF TUTU'D CATTLE. (Jun 28, 1875,Clutha Leader,3)

Toot́.ed (t&omacr.&omacr.t́.&ebreve.d), a. Poisoned by tutu; - said of ú.tued cattle. [Local, N. Z.] [SP] Bleeding and a dose of ammonia were usually tried on tutued animals. Ibid. . 2033 Tutú.ed (t&omacr.&omacr.ed), a. See TOOTED. (1898,Merriam-Webster Third International,2032)

BATHGATE [Sheep] feeding amongst [tutu], on being dogged or driven, are apt to be affected by it, or be, as the phrase is, `tutued'. (1874,Colonial Experiences,211)

GUTHRIE To animals this shrub [tutu] was deadly poisonous, especially to cattle, and my grandfather had many `tutu-ted'. (1930,NZ Memories,115)

STEWART [1879 Kati Kati] Our cow, a recent purchase, was found next day staggering about, wheeling round and round in a most alarming fashion. Luckily, a half-caste passing by saw her, and said, Your cow is 'tutu'd'; give me a sharp knife,' and promptly bled her by cutting her ears, when she fell down exhausted, but did not die, as many of our cows did from time to time later on, when having eaten too greedily of a poisonous native planttutu.' (1908,My Simple Life in NZ,27)

MORRIS Tooted quasi past participle from Toot. The cattle are tooted, sc. poisoned by the Toot. [1863, 1891 Potts] (1898,Austral English,475)

MORRIS Tooted quasi past participle from Toot. The cattle are tooted, sc. poisoned by the Toot. [1863, 1891 Potts] (1898,Austral English,475)

tutuheuheu¶

n.

HOOKER Tutuheuheu, Mantell. Coriaria thymifolia. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

Tutuheuheu. Coriaria angustissima, Hook. f. (1869,TrNZI,1/III/40) [NOTES: (Buchanan Botany Otago)]

tutukiwi¶

n. Pterostylis, an orchid

And here and there we came at other times on the curious green elfs-hood or tutukiwi, a ground-orchid; or the difficult to see grey spotted huperei, another ground-orchid, a gastrodia. (Mar 20, 1934,Evening Post,3)

LAING & BLACKWELL Pterostylis Banksii (Banks' Pterostylis) ... Maori name, Tutu Kiwi. (1940,Plants of NZ,129)

RICHARDS PTEROSTYLIS ... Banksii. ... The hood is upright at the bottom and then curves forward, the upper sepal often forming a long tail. ... [24] Elf's Hood. TUTU-KIWI. (1952,Chatham Islands,23)

MARTIN Much the largest and commonest [helmet orchid] is the tutukiwi (P[terostylis] bankii), ... . (1961,Flora NZ,309)

WILSON Pterostylis GREENHOOD ORCHIDS ... Tutukiwi ... Greenhood are familiar Australasian orchids, but the individual species are not yet fully understood. (1982,Stewart Island Plants,290)

One of my favourites, now in flower at Otari Wilton's Bush, is the greenhood orchid, tutukiwi (Pterostylis banksii)... It stands erect (tutu- stand erect; tutukiwi - standing kiwi) up to 30 centimetres tall, has four to six narrow leaves and a magnificent green, hood-like flower up to five centimetres high. (Nov 20, 2004,Dominion Post,E13)

n. the sub-antarctic or Snares Island snipe, Gallinago huegelii

FALLA et al. SUB-ANTARCTIC SNIPE Coenocorypha aucklandica Maori name: Tutukiwi. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,139)

tutumako¶

n. the herb, Euphrasia cuneata

BROOKER et al. Euphrasia cuneata Forst.f. Common name: New Zealand Eyebright Maori name:Tutumako ... An erect herb usually found on the mountains between East Cape and Marlborough. (1981,NZ Medicinal Plants,90)

tutumata¶

n. a stilt

DIEFFENBACH Fam. SCOLOPACIDAE 54 Himantopus Novae Zealandiae. Gould, Proc. Zool. Soc., 1841; Birds of Austr., ... Tutumata of the natives of Port Nicholson. Dieffenbach. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/196) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/196-197]

BULLER HIMANTOPUS LEUCOCEPHALUS. (WHITE-HEADED STILT.) ... Native name.- Tutumata {and Tuturipourewa}; Torea (of Arawa tribe). ...The White-headed Stilt, which appears to be also widely distributed over ... Australia, is a comparatively common bird in the middle and southern portions of New Zealand; ... (1873,Birds of New Zealand,1888 2nd edn 2/21)

tutunawai¶

n. a plant

HOOKER Tutu-nawai, Col[enso]. Polygonum prostratum. (1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),768)

CHEESEMAN [Polygonum serrulatum, Lag. Gen.] Abundant along the sides of rivers or in lowland swamps ... Tutunawai. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,590)

tuturipourewa¶

n. white-headed stilt

BULLER HIMANTOPUS LEUCOCEPHALUS. (WHITE-HEADED STILT.) ... Native name.- Tutumata and Tuturipourewa; Torea (of Arawa tribe). ...The White-headed Stilt, which appears to be also widely distributed over ... Australia, is a comparatively common bird in the middle and southern portions of New Zealand; ... (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/21)

tuturiwata¶

n. (See tuturiwhatu)

tuturiwatu¶

n. (See tuturiwhatu)

DIEFFENBACH Mr. Polack refers to the following names of Riroriro, Piripiri, Toutouwai, Tututuriwatu, as species of "swallows". (1842,Travels in NZ,186) [NOTES: Quote from Gray]

YATE Tuturiwatu - This is a small delicate bird, not much larger than the thrush, with short black legs; and a pigeon-beak, with the nostrils very far down and widely extended. (1835,Account of NZ, An,65)

n. . [a sea-swallow? the main application is to a plover or dotterel or dotterel-like sea bird]

POLACK Tuturi watu [a-acute] (hirundo) is a swallow, of a small size; ... (1838,New Zealand (Polack),1/298)

n. red breasted plover

HUTTON 63. CHARADRIUS OBSCURUS. Gml. Red-breasted Plover. Tuturiwata (1871,Birds of New Zealand,24)

CHARADRIUS OBSCURUS, Gml. Tituriwhatu-pukunui. Red-breasted Plover. (1870,TrNZI,2/68) [NOTES: (Potts Birds)]

  1. Charadrius obscurus, Gml. Dusky, Red-breasted, or Mountain Plover, Big Dottrel [si], Tuturiwatu, Paturiwhata, Tituriwhatu-pukunui. - This excellent gamebird formerly bred on the Canterbury Plains ...; since farms and settlements have occupied the waste lands of the plains, for the most part it has retired to the mountains of the back country. (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,506) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

tuturiwhata¶

n. NZ dotterel

The New Zealand dotterel (charadrius obscurus), or tuturiwhata.. has similar black and white legs. (Nov 5, 1887,Auckland Weekly News,7)

tuturiwhatu¶

n.

DIEFFENBACH 47. Charadrius xanthocheilus. Wagl. Tuturiwhatu of the natives. Miss Stone. Takahikaki[check?] of the natives. Yate. Tuturuata of the natives of Cook's Straits. Dieffenbach. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/195) [NOTES: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/195]

n. banded dotterel; red-breasted plover, pohowera [aka tuturiwatu]

YATE Tuturiwatu - This is a small delicate bird, not much larger than the thrush; ... (1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),65)

COLENSO (1844,Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ) [NOTES: see KUAKA (?kuaha)]

Charadrius obscurus. Tuturiwata. East Coast. Common. (1869,TrNZI,1/160) [NOTES: (Hutton Birds Great Barrier)]

FEATON Tutupapa [Maori name] .. Ground Tutu [Settlers' name] .. Coriaria thymifolia .. Herb (1889,Art Album NZ Flora,178)

CHEESEMAN C[oriaria] thymifolia ... Tutupapa. (1906,Manual NZ Flora,106)

HUTTON 63. CHARADRIUS OBSCURUS. Gml. Red-breasted Plover. Tuturiwata (1871,Birds of New Zealand,24)

  1. Charadrius obscurus, Gml. Dusky, Red-breasted, or Mountain Plover, Big Dottrel [sic], Tuturiwatu, Paturiwhata, Tituriwhatu-pukunui. - This excellent gamebird formerly bred on the Canterbury Plains ...; since farms and settlements have occupied the waste lands of the plains, for the most part it has retired to the mountains of the back country. (1885,NZ Journal of Science,506) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

BULLER CHARADRIUS OBSCURUS. (NEW-ZEALAND DOTTREL.) ... Native names.- Tuturiwhati and Tuturiwhatu. Ibid. 2/3 CHARADRIUS BICINCTUS. (BANDED DOTTREL.) ... Native names.- Tuturiwhata, Tuturiwhatu, and Pohowera. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/1)

POWELL BANDED DOTTREL (Charadrius bicinctus), or Tuturuwhatu is a characteristic little bird of the sand dunes, river beds and tussock clad plains.... It is widespread in New Zealand and occurs also in Tasmania and Australia.... (1947,Native Animals of NZ,81)

FALLA et al. BANDED DOTTEREL Charadrius bicinctus Other names: Double-banded Dotterel, Mountain Plover, Tuturiwhatu, Pohowera. (1966,Birds of New Zealand,122)

6 [-->150.b. Charadrius bicinctus exilis Falla, 1978 Auckland Island Banded Dotterel] (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,1980 ed.) [NOTES: 1970 Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ [1980] 45]

[-->150.b. Charadrius bicinctus exilis Falla, 1978 Auckland Island Banded Dotterel] (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,6,1980 ed.) [NOTES: 1970 Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ [1980] 45]

Banded Dotterel Charadrius bicinctus JARDINE & SELBY, 1827 ... OTHER NAMES: Pohowera, tuturiwhatu, double-banded plover. Ibid. 182 New Zealand Dotterel Charadrius obscurus (GMELIN, 1789) ... [183] OTHER NAMES: Tuturiwhatu pukunui, paturiwhata, red-breasted dotterel. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,180)

tuturiwhatu-pukunui¶

n. [New Zealand dotterel]

  1. Charadrius obscurus, Gml. Dusky, Red-breasted, or Mountain Plover, Big Dottrel [sic], Tuturiwatu, Paturiwhata, Tuturiwhatu-pukunui. [chk spg] - This excellent gamebird formerly bred on the Canterbury Plains ...; since farms and settlements have occupied the waste lands of the plains, for the most part it has retired to the mountains of the back country. (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science,506) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

tuturu¶

n.

One may be staunch, or tuturu, to protect the kaupapa, but what point is there if the underlying idea is outdated ... (Dec 14, 2004,Dominion Post,B5)

tuturuatu¶

n. = tuturiwhatu

New Zealand Shore Plover Thinornis novaeseelandiae (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAME: Tuturuatu. ... DISTRIBUTION South East Island in the Chathams. (1985,Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds,188)

DIEFFENBACH 48. Charadrius obscurus. Gmel ... Charadrius glaveola. Forst. ... Tuturiwatu of the natives. Yate. 49. Hiaticula Novae Seelandiae. - Charadrius torquatulus. Forst. ... Charadrius Novae See-[196]landiae. Gmel. ... Doodooroo -attoo of the natives of Queen Charlotte's Sound. Forst. (1843,Travels in NZ,2/195)

NO. C.65. - THIORNIS NOVAE-ZEALANDIAE, Gray. Masked Plover. Tuturuatu. In the summer months this gay-looking Plover affects sandy beaches of the sea-shore. (1874,TrNZI,6/150) [NOTES: (Potts)]

  1. Thinornis Novae-zealandiae, Gml. Masked Plover, Sand Plover, Shore Plover, Tuturautu.[?tuturuatu check] pretty plover is ... seen in the southern part of this island fossicking about the sandy shores at the mouths of rivers. (Sep 1885,NZ Journal of Science) [NOTES: (T.H. Potts)]

BULLER THINORNIS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (NEW-ZEALAND SAND-PLOVER.) ... Native names.- Kohutapu and Tuturuatu. (1888,Birds of New Zealand,2/11) [NOTES: [1873 edn 214 called the NZ sand-plover]]

FALLA et al. SHORE PLOVER Thinornis novaseelandiae Maori name: Tuturuatu. ... Now apparently confined to South-east Island in the Chathams, where in 1937 the population was estimated at about 70 pairs ... (1966,Birds of New Zealand,127)

155. Thinornis novaeseelandiae (Gmelin, 1789) New Zealand Shore Plover (Tuturuatu) ... now restricted to Chatham Islands ... (1970,Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ,46,1980 ed.)

tuturuwhatu¶

n. (See tuturiwhatu)

tuwhana¶

n. a pole used in fording rivers

SHORTLAND TUWHANA, a pole used in fording rivers. (Vide p. 241.) (1851,Southern Districts of NZ,315)

tuwhenua¶

n.

The disease known to the Taupo and East Coast tribes as "ngere-ngere," to the Ngapuhi and Northern tribes as "puhipuhi" and to the Wanganui and Western tribes as "tuwhenua," is one and the same disease, and is true leprosy. (Jul 31, 1890,Otago Witness,19)

TVNZ¶

abbr. Television New Zealand

twacking¶

n. violence by prison staff against inmates

Violence used against inmates by staff at Napier's Mangaroa Prison was common practice, according to a sociology lecturer... Staff concerned about the practice - called 'twacking' by inmates and staff - had told him of it about the middle of last year. (Mar 30, 1993,Dominion,1)

twang¶

n.

There is a perverse tendency to expect an accent because of his name [Lijvsebic], but the New Zealand twang is there if all-but educated out. (1999,Sport,22)

MARSHALL Although he was ex-Hutt High, he now had an Oxford accent. He said his antipodean twang undermined his credibility with his patients. (1985,Nest of Cuckoos,24)

HERZ The disregard of the external evidences of culture, is shown in the speech of the people. Sad to relate, one far too often hears the younger generation talk with a twang that horrifies the ear of anyone used to good English ... A mother will request her daughter Kyte</i>' to ask the <i>lydy' whether she will tyke'</i> another piece of </i>cyke'. The vowels and diphthongs are so drawn and twisted that it is often difficult to recognise the King's English. ... This twang is worse in Australia than in New Zealand but is gaining ground here and ought to be strenuously eradicated by school-teachers, for it really does not sound nice, and robs sweet girlish lips of all their poetry. (1912,New Zealand (various authors/titles),352)

REES She spoke without the faintest twang' which Creed had grown accustomed to expect, in a greater or lesser degree, amongst the back-block girls of New Zealand. ... [29] Billy [a back-country farm-boy] always saiddidjer' [did you], and ... as no one had ever taught him ... that well-known and useful little formula `How now, brown cow!' in order to correct his colonial twang and get his vowel sounds rounded correctly, ... (1924,Heather of the South,17, 29)

A physical difference which is accentuating itself rapidly is to be found in what is known as the "Colonial twang," in speech. (Jun 30, 1893,Star, The,2)

tweaker¶

n. a heavy methamphetamine user

American law enforcement authorities consider the heavy methamphetamine users or 'tweakers' a real threat to the lives of officers. (Jun 2002,Lucid,No. 9 : 15)

tweedmen¶

n.

I would like to point out that the Monarchist League of New Zealand is not comprised of "tweedmen, beardies and blue-rinsers", as he suggests. (Jun 9, 2001,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10)

tweeds¶

n. men's (sports) trousers [ca1935 at least He got his working tweeds caught in the fence. I'll warm your tweeds for you.' said to a boy,I'll give you a thrashing'.) ca1946 University students' `Down with the tweeds.']

INGRAM What a motley looking mob we were! ... Some wearing `bun' hats, some straws and others felts. Some in navy serge suits, some in grey tweeds, some even in knickerbockers ... (Jan 4, 1917,Anzac Day,9,1987 ed.)

Some drongo's beer spills on your tweeds/ As you're drinking, as you're drinking in the pubs./ (1951,Moa on Lambton Quay,21) [NOTES: (James Ryan)]

REV.R.W.CONNELLY As for clothing, I suggest as New Zealandisms: ... suit-coat (jacket), singlet (sometimes used in England but more commonly called Vest) tweeds and strides. (Nov 26, 1957,Letter)

McCALLUM (1963,Half-Gallon Jar,75) [NOTES: [see touch one's kick]]

tweeler¶

n.

The ability of a youth to handle a plough cropped up... Mr Fleming was a "tweeler" of no mean order. (Aug 1, 1917,Northern Advocate,2)

tweensitter¶

n.

Later.. the babysitter arrives. "You mean," says Sarah, who is quite possibly a genius, "our tweensitter." (Sep 2, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),22)

tweeny¶

adj. tiny

Well, what's going on their tweeny minds? (Sep 2, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),20)

twelve apostles¶

n. (Rural) the twelve-man team operating a threshing mill

LOUGHNAN twelve apostles: the team of twelve needed to operate a threshing mill. (1981,Loughnan Glossary,87)

Twelve Apostles¶

n. see 1908 citation

The recent calls to the Legislative Council are giving rise to speculation as to whether the "Twelve Apostles" called in 1892 are likely to be re-appointed should the present Government be in office in October next. (Jun 24, 1898,Nelson Evening Mail,3)

The death of the Hon. Feldwick removes another of the "twelve apostles," by which name the dozen members of the Legislative Council first appointed under the seven years system in 1892 were known. (Aug 8, 1908,Wanganui Herald,5)

1 n. (Rural, historical) twelve holders of large valuable Maori land holdings in Hawke's Bay, subject of a special commission in 1873

CW RICHMOND There were no small farmers. The Twelve Apostles hold the agricultural lands. (Dec 11, 1879,Letter,471) [NOTES: in Scholefield (1960) Richmond-Atkinson Papers II]

.. a block of the fattest land in the colony - was parcelled out amongst a syndicate of twelve gentlemen, notoriously known as the twelve apostles. (Oct 8, 1887,Weekly News,8)

'You've seen, my lad,' he pronounced, 'country that for years past has been an out-station of the Kereru run - land owned by the 'Twelve Apostles.' (Jul 8, 1953,Free Lance,33)

REED The names of twelve owners of these properties were so much in the news at the time that they came to be known as 'The Twelve Apostles.' (1958,Story of Hawke's Bay, The,171)

CAMPBELL Thomas Tanner, who acted as chief negotiator for the purchasers (locally known as the Twelve Apostles) began with an extra-legal lease before the block went before the Native Land Court. (1972,Evolution of Hawke's Bay Landed Society,54)

ROLLESTON The notoriety of the defendants gave rise to their being called, variously the Twelve Apostles (actually, only seven were involved in the ownership of twelve shares) or the Forty Thieves. (1980,Master, The,96)

BOYD A rival of The Hawke's Bay Herald, The Times had increased its circulation prodigiously by publishing articles headed Acts of the Apostles and Apostolic Creed. Though there were 7 leases and 12 shares, not 12 apostles, the name stuck. (1984,City of the Plains,12) [NOTES: Thomas Tanner and partners leased the Hastings Block in 1867 and purchased it in 1870, thus avoiding laws against purchasing land from the Maoris - the book is in the Beaglehole Collection]

They were retained, for GBP300 to do all that the Heretaunga people required - I mean the "twelve apostles." (1877,NZ Parliamentary Debates,XXV/316)

I wish to illustrate what I mean by referring to the purchase of land in the Hawke's Bay District by the gentlemen who are known as "the Twelve Apostles."...Owing to the action taken by those "Apostles." the land has been largely increased in value. (Sep 21, 1885,Wairarapa Daily,2)

The Napier Telegraph has treated the Twelve Apostles of Hawke's Bay to some healthy reading for once. (Nov 15, 1890,NZ Observer,1)

Re railway gold passes, it is said ex-members have lost their [sic]; if so, call in all that are left and issue leather ones - the same as has been supplied to the twelve apostles and Sir R. Stout. (Aug 14, 1893,Hawera & Normanby Star,4)

He (Tiwai) overtook them in the ranges on their way to the Twelve Apostles, who are, I believe, somewhere inland. They are going for the purpose of consulting the Twelve and other Hau Hau tribes to commence hostilities in this quarter. (May 3, 1867,Evening Post,2)

Had a conscientious person been there to value the land he would have assessed it as L180 an acre. This was a property among the Hawke's Bay twelve apostles' acquisitions. (Feb 21, 1905,Wanganui Herald,2)

SHERWOOD It was a Hastings lawyer did the fixing, to keep it out of the papers. He acts for a lot of those awesome Hawkes Bay families who came over with the Twelve Apostles. [fn] A nickname for the Founding Fathers of the town of of Hastings. (1985,Botanist at Bay,129)

There is a Tory Party - or, in other words, what they call the land-grabbers, or "Twelve Apostles" in Hawke's Bay. (1895,NZ Parliamentary Debates,84/182)

twelve o'clock hold¶

n. sc. at the end of the LONG PULL

McNAUGHTON When your dog gets the sheephome', he must bring them right into the circle, on the far side if possible, and hold them perfectly still - yourself, the sheep, and the dog all in line: the sheep looking at the dog and the dog looking at the sheep, although the dog doesn't have to be in the ring. This is called the `twelve o'clock hold'. (1970,Tat,119)

twelver¶

n. a twelve-year sentence

That settled her hash, as she had no defence; her misrepresentations were altogether too strong, but as she is an old offender, having such a long list of convictions against her, it is doubtful if the `twelver' she is now doing will have the slightest effect in ... reforming her. (Nov 17, 1906,NZ Truth,74/5/6)

twentieths¶

n. bills

"They reminded us to pay our 20ths [bills] and do our debt collection and that sort of thing." (May 3, 2003,Dominion Post,F2)

twenty¶

n. a 20-cent piece

MITCALFE All else was forgotten as they stood playing the machines ... on and on for Billy, who played steadily, lending Winston all his spare twenties until it was time to go home. ... How many [free games] you got?'Countless. Untold!' said that hardened space hero ... (1985,Hey Hey Hey,103)

n.

HUNT One day I took in a camp oven and a twenty-five of flour on my back. (1981,Speaking a Silence,103)

Our twenty-five pounders are giving them hell. (Dec 28, 1942,NZEF Times,II/79 : 5)

Twigs and Tweeters¶

phr. The NZ Royal Forest & Bird Society

He has been director of Forest and Bird - or Twigs and Tweeters, as its deriders call it - since 1989. (Sep 1, 1996,Sunday Star Times,C5)

twigs, get¶
